text: To the Editor:

headline: In China, Political Outsiders Turn to Microblog Campaigns
text: BEIJING — For at least some candidates seeking parliamentary seats in local Chinese elections this year, the winning formula is the very antithesis of what works in the United States.

headline: Homeless Families
text: To the Editor:

headline: Failed Solar Company’s Auction Draws Bargain Hunters
text: FREMONT, Calif. — To some people, the bankruptcy of the solar-module maker Solyndra shows the folly of government trying to pick winners in technology markets. To others, the furor over its $535 million federal loan guarantee represents an attack on the solar industry and the Obama administration’s clean energy policies.

headline: Time Warner Trims Its Excesses
text: The sprawling taupe-colored offices of Jeffrey L. Bewkes, Time Warner’s chairman and chief executive, overlook Central Park from the 11th floor of one of Manhattan’s most plum pieces of commercial real estate. Mr. Bewkes cannot wait to move out.

headline: Unnecessary Horn Honking
text: To the Editor:

headline: Picturing 7 Billion
text: Update | View the visual time capsule here.

headline: Yanks Keep Sabathia, Giving Ace Extra Year
text: The Yankees avoided a potential pitching calamity Monday when their ace, C. C. Sabathia, agreed to a contract extension just hours before the deadline for him to opt out of his current deal and become a free agent.

headline: A Dictionary Updated, and a Campaign to Spread the Word
text: TRYING to sell a $60 print dictionary in 2011 is like trying to sell a silent movie.

headline: Florida: Prison Privatization Plan Is Scrapped
text: A plan by the State of Florida to transfer 29 of its prisons to private management is dead, at least for now. Gov. Rick Scott has decided not to appeal last month’s court decision that called the plan unconstitutional. The judge said in the ruling that Florida lawmakers had erred in tucking the measure into a budget bill to get it passed. The judge said the privatization plan — a “substantive” policy change — merited its own debate and should have been presented as a stand-alone bill.

headline: Congress Questions the I.R.S. About Delays in Its Oversight of Nonprofit Hospitals
text: In August, the Illinois Department of Revenue moved to revoke the property tax exemptions enjoyed by three major nonprofit hospitals after a court ruling determined that a fourth hospital in the state did not provide enough charity care to justify the tax benefit.

headline: South Carolina: U.S. Challenges Immigration Law
text: The federal government filed suit against South Carolina on Monday to block a recently passed state law that would require the police to check the immigration status of every person they detain. The Justice Department argued in the suit that South Carolina’s law, which takes effect on Jan. 1, undermines federal authority on immigration. The department has filed similar challenges to immigration laws in Alabama and Arizona. “Pushing undocumented immigrants out of one state and into another is not a solution to our immigration challenges,” Tony West, assistant attorney general, said in a news conference. A spokesman for Gov. Nikki Haley said the state would continue with plans to implement the law.

headline: Postcard From L.S.U.: Geaux? Just Go With It
text: BATON ROUGE, La. — Louisiana is famous for its Cajun French influences, its gumbo, crawfish étoufée and Mardi Gras. It is famous for laissez les bon temps rouler, as the saying goes, or letting the good times roll.

headline: Domestic Oil Drilling
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Quality of Homework
text: To the Editor:

headline: Court Lets Nashville Protesters Stay
text: A federal judge on Monday ruled in support of dozens of protesters in Nashville who were arrested over the weekend.

headline: By Deadline, 7 Bids in Science School Contest
text: New York City officials have been dreaming for months about a new graduate school bearing a prestigious brand name like Cornell or Stanford. But what about Amity University?

headline: Central Park Cleanup Has Sunday Deadline for Marathon
text: The weekend snowstorm that upended the plans of many trick-or-treaters is also messing with another autumn ritual: the running of the New York City Marathon on Sunday.

headline: Dissenting, or Seeking Shelter? Homeless Stake a Claim at Protests
text: LOS ANGELES — Robert Gaffney, who came here from Oklahoma 10 years ago, settled on a scrap of burlap the other day on a grassy hill outside City Hall, surveying the tents and crowd that make up Occupy Los Angeles. For many of his neighbors at City Hall Park, this is a center of protest and political grievance. For Mr. Gaffney, it is the latest piece of land that he calls home.

headline: For Pakistan, Deep Ties to Militant Network May Trump U.S. Pressure
text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and other senior administration officials visited Pakistan in October to demand that Pakistan’s spy agency either deliver the Haqqani network, a virulent part of the insurgency fighting American forces in Afghanistan, to the negotiating table or help fight them in their stronghold in Pakistan’s rugged tribal areas.

headline: Israel and the Apartheid Slander
text: THE Palestinian Authority’s request for full United Nations membership has put hope for any two-state solution under increasing pressure. The need for reconciliation between Israelis and Palestinians has never been greater. So it is important to separate legitimate criticism of Israel from assaults that aim to isolate, demonize and delegitimize it.

headline: City Hall Admits Mishandling Technology Projects
text: The Bloomberg administration acknowledged on Monday that it had mismanaged its major information-technology projects, vowing to revamp its oversight of them.

headline: President Is ‘Tobacco Free,’ and ‘Fit at 50,’ Doctor Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Forget the rumors that he has been sneaking cigarettes; President Obama is “tobacco free,” the president’s doctor said in reporting the results of the president’s second physical since he took office.

headline: Libya Names an Engineer as Premier
text: TRIPOLI, Libya —Libya’s provisional leaders named an engineer as its new prime minister Monday, taking the first step toward assembling a new transitional government after the killing of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and the formal end to the uprising that ended his nearly 42 years in power.

headline: Iraq Arrests More in Wake of Tip About Coup
text: BAGHDAD — The government of Iraq continued to respond vigorously on Monday to a tip from the new interim leaders in Libya that former members of Saddam Hussein’s military and Baath Party were plotting a coup — so much so that critics are now saying that the information has become a pretext for arresting its political opponents.

headline: Documents Reveal Reactions to Disputed A.T.F. Investigations in Arizona
text: WASHINGTON — The head of the Justice Department’s criminal division, Lanny A. Breuer, was told in April 2010 that Arizona-based agents of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives had allowed a gun trafficking ring to buy hundreds of weapons and send them to Mexico as part of an investigative tactic, according to newly disclosed documents.

headline: MF Global Bankruptcy Rattles Wall St. Firms
text: The markets were haunted this Halloween by the ghosts of the past financial crisis.

headline: Tales From the Supercommittee
text: There are only three weeks left for the Congressional supercommittee to come up with a plan to reduce the federal deficit by at least $1.2 trillion, and there is no sign that the panel is anywhere close to reaching an agreement. Only one side, in fact, seems to be trying — the Democrats — and it is being far too accommodating, given the fierce obstructionism of the other side, the Republicans.

headline: Postcard From Alabama: The Choice: Memories Or Cash
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Students surely choose to attend the University of Alabama for a variety of reasons: its academic reputation, a diverse student body, an accomplished faculty.

headline: My Life Report
text: Last week my colleague David Brooks made a request I couldn’t refuse. He asked people over 70 to “write a brief report on your life so far, an evaluation of what you did well, of what you did not do well and what you learned along the way.” Well, here I am, reporting in.

headline: In Stare-Down With Protesters, Governor Blinked
text: ALBANY

headline: Mets’ Roster May Get Makeover, Too
text: On a day when the Mets officially announced that they would make significant changes to the dimensions at Citi Field, Sandy Alderson, the team’s general manager, offered some measured insight into what the team that will play there next year may look like.

headline: Uncle Mo Upstages Havre de Grace as Favorite in Breeders’ Classic
text: The Breeders’ Cup Classic usually shines a light on the horse of moment while the race run two before it, the Juvenile, tries to identify the colt whose name will be on everyone’s lips at the Kentucky Derby on the first Saturday of May. Those lines may have been blurred Monday at the post-position draw of the Breeders’ Cup when Uncle Mo was made the 5-2 morning-line favorite in the $5 million Classic.

headline: The Ticket-Fixing Scandal
text: The arrest of 16 New York City police officers in the Bronx last week, 11 of them for fixing tickets, was bad enough. What added to the outrage was the thuggish behavior of a crowd of off-duty police officers who went to the courthouse to support their accused colleagues. Some chanted “Down with the D.A.!” in reference to Robert Johnson, the Bronx district attorney whose office is prosecuting these cases. Others mocked welfare recipients who were lined up at a benefits office near the courthouse.

headline: Punishing Poverty
text: Being poor and needing public assistance is not a crime. Yet some states and cities, including New York City, are gratuitously inflicting punitive measures on people who seek government help.

headline: Egyptians Rally for Blogger Jailed by Military
text: Egyptian activists marched in Cairo on Monday night to demand the release of an imprisoned blogger and an end to military trials for civilians. Supporters of the blogger, Alaa Abd El Fattah, chanted slogans demanding his freedom as they rallied outside his cell.

headline: A Storm Out of Season
text: It sounds like the pitch for a Tim Burton movie: White Halloween. But Saturday night and Sunday morning were more frightful than amusing. The astonishing snowstorm that swept across the region left millions without power. Everywhere from West Virginia to New Hampshire, the landscape was a chaos of downed limbs, felled trees and snapped utility lines. Monday began in many places without school and electricity; in some, it looked as though even Halloween might be put on hold until the cleanup was further along.

headline: It’s Lonely Without the Goldman Net
text: He was from Goldman Sachs.

headline: After a Kidnapping, Hackers Take On a Ruthless Mexican Crime Syndicate
text: MEXICO CITY — The hackers’ message, delivered via YouTube by a man wearing a red tie and a Guy Fawkes mask, was as bold and risky as anything produced by the Zetas, Mexico’s most ruthless crime syndicate. But this time, the Zetas were the target.

headline: Congressional Voting Records Show Few With Perfect Attendance
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Don Young of Alaska likes to get around his home state, and he does not let his voting schedule get in the way. One Tuesday in July when his fellow House Republicans voted for their signature budget measure, known as Cut, Cap and Balance, Mr. Young was the only one among them to miss the vote, for a charity fishing trip in Whittier.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Capitals, Off to Hot Start, Know That’s Not the Goal
text: WASHINGTON — For the past week, visitors to the Madame Tussauds here have lined up to have their pictures taken with a newly unveiled gap-toothed wax figure wearing a gaudy red hockey sweater. No matter that the real Alex Ovechkin plays three blocks away at Verizon Center. In the nation’s capital, there is no bigger sports celebrity than Ovechkin.

headline: Cain Confronts Claim From ’90s of Sexual Harassment
text: Herman Cain, a surprise leader in the Republican race for the presidency, acknowledged Monday that he was accused of sexual harassment while chief of the National Restaurant Association in the 1990s, but he denied wrongdoing in an episode that has consumed his rising candidacy.

headline: ‘The Napoleon of the American Republic’
text: Around 4 a.m. on Nov. 2, 1861, a party of officers and the newly appointed general in chief of the Union armies rode through the rain-slicked streets of Washington toward the B&O train station. Their mission: To see off the nation’s longest-serving general, who was boarding a train for New York and retirement. For over half a century, Winfield Scott had fought for the United States, commanding troops during the War of 1812, the Mexican War, the Black Hawk War, the Second Seminole War and the current War of Rebellion.

headline: Portraying the Face of Job Growth
text: The presidential campaign of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas started broadcasting its second television ad on Monday in Iowa.

headline: Corzine Crashes Like It’s 2008
text: When Goldman Sachs went public on May 4, 1999, Jon Corzine, who was then the firm’s chief executive, held a stake that was suddenly valued at $305 million. So, perhaps, it’s uncharitable to complain about the piddling $12 million severance he was poised to gain if he had managed to sell his current firm, MF Global Holdings, over the weekend.

headline: High Fatality Rate Found for Low-Cost Buses
text: The low-cost bus industry, which has revolutionized transportation for students and other budget-conscious travelers, has racked up an alarmingly high number of fatal accidents and safety violations over the last few years, and regulators are having a hard time enforcing federal safety standards, according to a government study released on Monday.

headline: After a Bye, the Jets Are Eager to Pick Up Where They Left Off
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Calvin Pace, a Jets outside linebacker, apparently likes playing football a lot more than watching football. He spent Sunday flying to New Jersey after six blissful days off, paying little attention to how the axis of the football world tilted back the Jets’ way.

headline: Trial Opens in Court-Martial of Soldier Tied to Afghan Killings
text: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash. — The soldier accused of leading an Army unit that killed three unarmed civilians in Afghanistan last year believed he was engaging in legitimate combat at the time and has been made a scapegoat by others accused of the crimes, his lawyer said Monday.

headline: The Wrong Inequality
text: We live in a polarizing society, so perhaps it’s inevitable that our experience of inequality should be polarized, too.

headline: Giants Gaining Lots of Ground, but Not the Way They Expected
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — There can be little debate about what has been the biggest surprise this season for the Giants. After all, even Victor Cruz would not have imagined that he would be showcasing his salsa dance in the end zone as often as he has over the Giants’ first seven games.

headline: Activists Denounce Film Deal in China
text: BEIJING — The Hollywood producers of a slapstick comedy that began shooting last week in a city in China’s eastern Shandong Province describe their feature about a young man facing a birthday, “21 and Over,” as an “epic misadventure of debauchery and mayhem.”

headline: Fresh Scars on the Body Politic
text: Oh, to have been in that room in Juba, the capital of South Sudan, on Oct. 16. That’s when the leadership of the world’s newest country met with Xanana Gusmão, the prime minister of East Timor, the first new country of the 21st century [1]. Surely, Mr. Gusmão must have lectured on the nitty gritty of starting up a brand new country. And undoubtedly, talk must have turned to borders: how to demarcate, secure and police them. (Yes, such are the daydreams of borderspotters like myself.)

headline: Tuesday: Forum Cheer
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I know I’ve mentioned this before, but if you haven’t seen the documentary Wordplay, for which this blog is named, you should definitely give it a whirl. It’s a very interesting peek into the world of crossword construction and competitive solving. Some of the people whose bylines you see in The New York Times crossword make an appearance in the film.

headline: O, That Rowdy Passage From Celibate to Celebrate
text: The grassy green rectangle that occupies most of the stage is considerably smaller than a football field. But it is the setting for a dangerous sport, the kind that sends its players hurtling to the ground with cranium-rattling impact. The game is love. And though it may at first feel like a mild diversion, as contact sports go, it soon becomes clear that no one is leaving the field without injuries.

headline: Hay Shortage Compounds Woe in Drought-Stricken Texas
text: TERRELL, Tex. — Dozens of ranchers waited for hours for the donations, in a line of pickup trucks that stretched for a mile in this rain-starved region east of Dallas.

headline: Marathon Weather Has Been Taken to Extremes
text: Had last weekend’s snap of winter weather struck a week later, it would have created a gigantic mess for the New York City Marathon, which would have had a hard time proceeding through a Central Park littered with hundreds of downed trees. Fortunately, the forecast calls for a much more normal early-November day this Sunday, when the marathon is to be run. If the forecast holds true, it will be 58 degrees and sunny.

headline: Report on Low-Cost Bus Safety Is Released
text: The National Transportation Safety Board released its Executive Report on Curbside Motorcoach Safety on Monday, after six months of research.

headline: Report Says New York Fed Didn’t Cut Deals on A.I.G.
text: WASHINGTON — The findings of a federal investigation released Monday raised new questions about the Federal Reserve Bank of New York’s handling of the 2008 bailout of American International Group.

headline: Race, Religion and Same-Sex Marriage
text: Without drawing much attention to it yet, one of the leading groups promoting same-sex marriage has taken an interesting tack, one that implicitly acknowledges the complicated relationship between gay Americans and another minority group not firmly on their side.

headline: An Exceptional Change in Zambia, and via the Ballot Box, Too
text: LUSAKA, Zambia — Guy Scott stood the other day in the middle of the Zambian National Assembly, where a stuffed lion and a stuffed leopard lounged on the floor, and trumpeted, “This country is the envy of Africa!”

headline: Tom McNeeley, Challenger to Patterson, Is Dead at 74
text: Tom McNeeley, a knockout artist who challenged Floyd Patterson for the heavyweight championship in 1961, losing an action-packed four-round bout that featured at least nine knockdowns — it depends how you count — died on Oct. 25 in Weymouth, Mass. He was 74.

headline: Second Look Needed on Pay
text: Eugene Isenberg, the chairman and chief executive of Nabors Industries, is pocketing $100 million just to give up one of his two titles. That seems absurd. But the board of Nabors, a $5.3 billion oil drilling company, was hamstrung by an old contract. Even so, the stock of Nabors has underperformed for a decade.

headline: Intentions at Heart of Arms-Trafficking Case
text: At the time of his arrest in 2008, Viktor Bout was either an illegal arms dealer intent on selling 100 tons of explosives, grenade launchers and other weapons to terrorists — or an innocent and broke businessman in a scheme to sell a pair of old airplanes. At least, those are the two portraits of the 44-year-old Russian that have been offered in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: City to Pay $70 Million in Medicaid Suit
text: New York City will pay the federal government $70 million to settle a lawsuit that accused the city of overbilling Medicaid by improperly approving home care for frail and elderly clients, both parties said on Monday.

headline: Special Parking Rules
text: On Tuesday, because of All Saints’ Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations in New York City will be suspended. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Rangers Shake Their Malaise With a Thrashing of the Sharks
text: The Rangers awoke from their long slumber Monday night, putting together their strongest effort of the season in a 5-2 rout of the San Jose Sharks.

headline: Liberia: Presidential Candidate May Still Boycott Runoff Vote
text: The presidential candidate Winston Tubman said Monday that he could still withdraw from next week’s runoff elections even after his demand for the resignation of the head of elections was met. “When it happened, we felt that we had made a gain but we didn’t think that was all,” Mr. Tubman said by phone. “We need to make some administrative arrangements to allow us to observe the process more closely.” His party, the Congress for Democratic Change, had said it would boycott the elections after claiming the first round of voting was fraudulent. Mr. Tubman came in second, but President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf did not win the majority needed to avoid a runoff.

headline: In Haiti, a Step Toward the Rule of Law
text: A trial of police officers implicated in a prison massacre is a seminal event for Haiti’s troubled criminal justice system.

headline: Raucous Trial Is a Test of Haiti’s Legal System
text: LES CAYES, Haiti — It is a legal spectacle unlike anything Haiti has seen: the government trying 13 of its own police officers — including high-ranking prison officials and riot squad members — on charges of murder, attempted murder or other crimes stemming from a prison massacre here last year.

headline: Media Distrust May Shield Cain From the Right’s Critiques
text: Do political scandals sting less than they used to?

headline: Mayor's Award for a Special School That Embraces the Arts
text: When the Mayor's Awards for Art and Culture are given out, the principal of a special education school will be recognized alongside luminaries including Mikhail Baryshnikov, the musician Jimmy Heath, the artist and architect Maya Lin and Stephen Sondheim.

headline: Joyce Clifford, Who Pushed for ‘Primary Nursing’ Approach, Dies at 76
text: Joyce C. Clifford, a nurse who advocated a partnership of equals between doctors and nurses in the treatment of patients, and whose ideas were adopted in some of the nation’s best hospitals because they reduced medical errors and improved survival rates, died on Oct. 21 in Boston. She was 76.

headline: China’s Copycat Culture
text: This is the first post in Latitude. Read more about the blog »

headline: Union President Fisher Assures N.B.A.’s Players That He Will Stay the Course
text: In the face of collapsed negotiations, canceled games and unsourced reports of fractures in his union, Derek Fisher moved to reassure N.B.A. players on Monday with a letter that reaffirmed his loyalty to them and his commitment to “the best deal possible.”

headline: Dodge Grand Caravan, Chrysler Town and Country and VW Routan Earn Top Rollover Marks from I.I.H.S.
text: On Tuesday, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety released test results relating to the roof strength of five minivans. This was the first time the models were subjected to rollover tests, the primary dynamic tool for measuring roof strength, by the institute, which is financed by the insurance industry.

headline: A Thanksgiving Feast, No Turkeys Allowed
text: Are you ready to reimagine Thanksgiving without the turkey?

headline: Corrections: November 1
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Well’s Vegetarian Thanksgiving 2011
text: Are you ready to reimagine Thanksgiving without the turkey? All month, we present delicious no-meat recipes for your holiday table from some of your favorite chefs and cookbook authors.

headline: Word of the Day | evocative
text: evocative •\i-ˈvä-kə-tiv\• adjective

headline: Rangers Expect a Spark, but Not Too Much, From Avery’s Return
text: Sean Avery will receive a hero’s welcome from the majority of the Madison Square Garden crowd when he makes his expected return to the Rangers’ lineup Thursday. There will be a detectable buzz in the arena and jump in the Rangers’ step, and for good reason. The feisty shift disturber has an undeniably charismatic presence, whether anyone likes it or not.

headline: Seeking a Billionaire’s Halloween Treats
text: Amid the slightly frenzied atmosphere of Halloween on the Upper East Side, three fathers and their sons walked west on East 79th Street with purpose.

headline: NYT Front Page for 11/01/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 11/01/2011

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
text: The political storm created by the 2G spectrum scam continues to dominate headlines, as a joint parliamentary committee meeting devoted to the issue Monday witnessed a fiery exchange (Hindustan Times). Opposition members accused the government of concealing relevant information and, in particular, of having rewritten a word in the internal note of March 25 from the finance ministry to the prime minister’s office. That document appeared to blame the previous finance minister, P Chidambaram, for failing to prevent the scam. According to a two-page letter from the current finance minister, Pranab Mukherjee, to the prime minister, Manmohan Singh, the note was drafted after detailed consultations with the prime minister’s office and the cabinet secretariat, and issued at the behest of the prime minister’s office. (Times of India).

headline: South Korea Sentences U.S. Soldier to 10 Years
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean court sentenced an American Army private to 10 years in prison on Tuesday for raping an 18-year-old South Korean woman, the most severe such ruling in almost 20 years.

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 1, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: The Ra.One Marketing Mania
text: Shah Rukh Khan’s manic marketing campaign for his new film “Ra.One” culminated with a whirlwind tour of the globe. The Hindi-film star, who acted in and co-produced the superhero movie, traveled first to Dubai, then went on to London before landing in Toronto. His 1,000-watt charisma appeared to suffer no jet lag. No wonder Cameron Bailey, co-director of the Toronto International Film Festival, which hosted Mr. Khan and his movie “Ra.One,” declared on Twitter that Mr. Khan is the hardest-working man in show business.

headline: Nov. 1, 1952 | First Hydrogen Bomb Test
text: On Nov. 1, 1952, the United States conducted its first nuclear test of a fusion device, or “hydrogen bomb,” at Eniwetok in the Marshall Islands. News of the event surfaced more than two weeks later, when The New York Times reported : “The Atomic Energy Commission announced tonight ‘satisfactory’ experiments in hydrogen weapon research … In a three-paragraph announcement, the Commission did not go so far as to state that a full-scale hydrogen bomb had been detonated, but it did say ‘experiments contributing’ to hydrogen bomb research had been completed.”The origins of the hydrogen bomb date to the early 1940s, when the Italian-born physicist Enrico Fermi suggested to the Hungarian-born Edward Teller that a weapon based on nuclear fission was possible. Dr. Teller, a member of the Manhattan Project assigned to build the atomic bomb for the Allies, advocated for a hydrogen “super bomb” instead.

headline: Haiti: The Police on Trial
text: A public theater in Les Cayes, Haiti, has been transformed into a courtroom as over a dozen police and prison officials stand trial in connection with a prison massacre last year.

headline: Taken by Storm
text: WHO died as a result of a freakish October snowstorm that hit the Northeast on Saturday?

headline: Champions League Tuesday Preview: Reruns in New Theaters
text: The Champions League group stage makes the turn for home with what are essentially second-leg games from Matchday 3. Several of the favorites that won at home that day — Chelsea, Bayer Leverkusen, A.C. Milan, Barcelona — will be looking to repeat the feat on the road and lock up places in the knockout stages. Several others will just be looking to make their lives easier, and maybe separate themselves from the pack in their groups.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 1, 2011
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, “Wall St. Protest Isn’t Like Ours, Tea Party Says.”

headline: Greek Revolt on Bailout Vote May Oust Prime Minister
text: ATHENS — The government of Prime Minister George Papandreou teetered on the verge of collapse on Tuesday, threatening Greece’s adherence to the terms of a new deal with its foreign lenders and plunging Europe into a fresh bout of financial turmoil.

headline: Does Pop Culture Deserve Serious Study?
text: Last week, an academic conference was held where scholars discussed the reality television show “Jersey Shore.” Are shows, movies and other elements of popular culture just as worthy of serious study as novels and art films? Would you like to take an academic course focusing on reality TV or mainstream movies?

headline: Bengals’ Dalton and Green Making Rare Rookie Magic
text: With two minutes left in the first half, the Bengals led the Seahawks, 10-3, on Sunday. Cincinnati called a play-action pass, but the pocket collapsed on the rookie quarterback Andy Dalton as he began to execute the fake handoff. With multiple Seahawks players crashing toward him, Dalton stepped up and fired a bomb into the end zone. At the same time, the rookie receiver A.J. Green had gained a step on Seattle safety Earl Thomas. As Green reached the end zone, Dalton’s pass hit him perfectly in stride for a 46-yard touchdown. It was the fifth touchdown reception for Green this season, and the fourth time he’s connected with Dalton for a score (Bruce Gradkowski was responsible for Green’s first touchdown catch as a pro).  If Green and Dalton can connect six more times over the next nine weeks, they will become the first pair of rookie teammates to combine for 10 passing touchdowns.

headline: New Prague Gallery Offers Contemporary Works
text: There’s a new stop in Prague for contemporary art – Vernon Depot (U Pruhonu 22) has opened in the industrial-chic Prague 7 neighborhood of Holesovice. Part of the Vernon family of galleries, Vernon Depot will show works by the gallery’s artists as well as a rotating schedule of exhibitions.

headline: The Early Word: Scrutiny
text: In Today’s TimesHerman Cain rejected as false the past complaints of sexual harassment that have surfaced against him but conflicting statements about how much he knew about the cases have prompted greater scrutiny of the Republican presidential candidate, Michael D. Shear and Jeff Zeleny report.

headline: A Close Look at the Perry Tax Plan
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the coming book “The Benefit and the Burden.”

headline: Study: Few Hospitals Qualify for Digital Funds
text: Though hospitals are eligible for billions of dollars in federal stimulus money to bring their facilities into the digital age to save money and improve the quality of health care, just one in 10 is ready to meet government standards to qualify for the funds, a new analysis shows.

headline: Microrevolutions Off Tahrir Square
text: CAIRO — It has been nearly three months since the last really big, unmanageable crowd converged on Tahrir Square and threatened to stay until its demands were met. On the eve of Ramadan, in early August, the Egyptian military smacked and clubbed that group — a broad but woefully inarticulate coalition opposing the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces’ hold on power — out of the square. And much to the protesters’ horror, the majority of Egyptians seemed fairly satisfied with the pushback, preferring a return to order even if it came with a military policeman’s truncheon.

headline: Credit Suisse Plans More Job Cuts Even as Profit Rises 12%
text: 6:28 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Start-Up Tries to Eliminate ‘Food Deserts’
text: Last year, M.B.A. students at the Bainbridge Graduate Institute in Seattle began hunting for a business-based solution to the problem of “food deserts” — low-income neighborhoods lacking access to healthful, affordable food. (More than 23 million Americans live in such places, according to the Department of Agriculture, which maps them here.)

headline: After Years of Clearing Boards, Charles Oakley Takes to Buffing Cars
text: On a recent sunny afternoon, unaware drivers who pulled into the car wash on Central Park Avenue in Yonkers might have thought they had seen an apparition when they saw a 6-foot-9 man in a black T-shirt and jeans vacuuming and wiping down cars.

headline: Syria Says It’s Accepted Plan to End Crackdown
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria said Tuesday that it had reached agreement with an Arab League delegation on a road map to end more than seven months of bloodshed and start a dialogue between the opposition and the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Check Your Receipt: It May Be Tainted
text: Over eight billion pounds of bisphenol-A, a chemical compound used in making plastic products and the linings of tin cans, are produced annually worldwide. Known as BPA, the substance turns up in human tissues, too.

headline: G4S Pulls Bid for Rival Security Firm ISS
text: LONDON — G4S, the world’s largest provider of security services, has abandoned its roughly $8.2 billion bid for a rival, ISS of Denmark, after G4S shareholders balked at the takeover plan.

headline: Artists File Lawsuits, Seeking Royalties
text: When the taxi baron Robert Scull sold part of his art collection in a 1973 auction that helped inaugurate today’s money-soused contemporary-art market, several artists watched the proceedings from a standing-room-only section in the back. There, Robert Rauschenberg saw his 1958 painting “Thaw,” originally sold to Scull for $900, bring down the gavel at $85,000. At the end of the Sotheby Parke Bernet sale in New York, Rauschenberg shoved Scull and yelled that he didn’t work so hard “just for you to make that profit.”

headline: Pixar’s John Lasseter Answers Your Questions
text: Pixar Animation Studios hasn’t made a big deal of turning 25 this year. But it can celebrate several achievements, including its perfect 12-hit record at the box office, capped this year by “Cars 2,” which is being released on DVD on Tuesday. It hasn’t been an easy year, though: There was the passing of Steven P. Jobs, who helped build Pixar Animation Studios and who was crucial to the company’s success, and unusual for a Pixar film, “Cars 2″ met with mixed critical reaction. Still at this quarter-century milestone, John Lasseter, the studio’s chief creative officer, agreed to answer selected reader questions. Here are his responses, submitted by e-mail.

headline: In Flood, Thai Leaders Choose Between Bad and Worse Options
text: BANGKOK — In the rush to defend Bangkok from monsoon floodwaters on Tuesday, Thai officials were faced with the choice of saving men or machines.

Corzine, a former New Jersey governor and United States senator, several people briefed on the matter said on Monday.

headline: Eurodämmerung
text: Things are falling apart in Europe; the center is not holding. Papandreou is going to hold a referendum; the vote will be no. Italian 10-years at 6.29 at pixel time; that’s a level at which the cost of rolling over the existing debt will force a default, even though Italy has a primary surplus. And with everyone simultaneously pushing for fiscal austerity, a recession seems almost certain, aggravating all of the continent’s problems.

headline: Goldikova in Position to Add to Her Record in the Mile
text: At last year’s Breeders’ Cup, somewhat obscured by the blazing mare Zenyatta, Goldikova made history by winning her third Breeders’ Cup Mile. This week Goldikova is at Churchill Downs preparing to take home an unprecedented fourth victory in the Mile.

headline: BB&T to Buy Assets From BankAtlantic
text: BB&T agreed on Tuesday to buy the bulk of BankAtlantic in a move to expand BB&T’s footprint in the Southeast.

headline: Architect Named for American Revolution Museum in Philadelphia
text: The architect Robert A.M. Stern has been selected to design the American Revolution Center museum just steps from Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell in Philadelphia’s historic area, the center announced Tuesday.

headline: Groupon Amends Its Prospectus, Again
text: Another day, another amended Groupon prospectus — this one only days before the company prices its initial public offering.

headline: The Power of Myth, Kid-Lit Version
text: Of the many gifts Rick Riordan has bequeathed to the world of children’s literature, the one most fervently embraced by teachers and librarians may well be the interest in mythology he has awakened in children. Other authors have been following his lead, with two excellent new nonfiction books for middle graders, “Gifts From the Gods,” by Lise Lunge-Larsen, and “Treasury of Greek Mythology,” by Donna Jo Napoli, out now. Classics majors, linguists and otherwise literary-minded parents will greatly appreciate these books — as will their actual intended audience of young readers.

headline: Graduates Versus Oligarchs
text: Dean Baker raises an important point here: it’s really awfully late in the game to be saying that the important inequality issue is college graduates versus non-graduates. It’s not clear that this was ever true, and it certainly hasn’t been true for a while.

headline: China Seeks $2.4 Million in Taxes From Dissident
text: BEIJING — Ai Weiwei, the dissident artist whose detention earlier this year stirred an international outcry, has been given two weeks to pay $2.4 million in back taxes and penalties, he said Tuesday.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Salon: Some help for those trying to resist the temptation of leftover Halloween swag: a sobering morning-after trek through the unsavory history of candy. Snake oil, slavery, exploitation of immigrants: it all helped build that little fun-size bomb you’re craving. — Patrick Farrell

headline: Cellphones: Why Not Use Them to Teach?
text: Two advocates for bringing the latest digital devices into the classroom say educators who are taking simple steps and putting the proper building blocks in place are experiencing great success in encouraging students to use their mobile devices as powerful learning tools.

headline: Dorothy Rodham, Mother of Hillary Clinton, Dies at 92
text: 10:43 a.m. | Updated  The family of Secretary of State Hillary Clinton put out a statement Tuesday saying that Dorothy Rodham died shortly after midnight in Washington.

headline: Q&A: Holiday Vacation for a Family of Four
text: We’re a family of four with two 7-year-olds. We live in Washington, D.C., and New York City and are looking for an active family vacation within driving distance of either for four or five nights during the week between Christmas and New Year’s. I’ve looked at Mohonk Mountain House and at Wintergreen Resort. Any great ideas? We don’t necessarily need a big resort type of place, but rustic alone won’t work; we need some activities.

headline: JPMorgan Shuffles Its Capital Markets Leadership
text: JPMorgan Chase has reorganized the management of its capital markets operations, naming separate global leadership teams to oversee both equity and debt capital markets, the firm announced in an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook on Tuesday.

headline: Advice on Whittling Your Admissions Essay
text: Mr. Gelb is the author of “Conquering the College Admissions Essay in 10 Steps.”

headline: F.T.C: No App to Cure Acne
text: Apparently, there isn’t an app for everything.

headline: Japanese Official Drinks Water From Fukushima Reactor Buildings
text: After insisting for weeks that water collected from reactor buildings at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant posed no threat to human health once it was decontaminated, a Japanese government official poured himself a glass of the liquid and drank it on live television on Monday.

headline: Auto Sales Reach an 8-Month High, Helped by Stable Gas Prices
text: DETROIT — Consumers took advantage of stable gas prices and bought more trucks and sport utility vehicles, which helped push up the sales of new automobiles in the United States to an eight-month high in October.

headline: It’s Never Too Early to Start Handicapping
text: The fields have been drawn for both days of this year’s Breeders’ Cup. With the benefit of post positions and morning-line odds, it’s time to get down to the business of handicapping racing’s greatest day(s). Some initial thoughts:

headline: The Elephant in the Room
text: The connection between population growth and environmental degradation seems clear enough – the more people there are, the more greenhouse gases are emitted and the more resources are consumed. But as I report in Tuesday’s Times, the population issue has been conspicuously absent from the public discourse on global warming in the United States.

headline: Detective Is Found Guilty of Planting Drugs
text: The New York Police Department, already saddled with corruption scandals, saw its image further tainted on Tuesday with the conviction of a detective for planting drugs on a woman and her boyfriend.

headline: Romney and Cain Pass on Iowa G.O.P. Dinner
text: On the campaign trail, Mitt Romney likes to quote Ronald Reagan, quipping that liberals aren’t ignorant — it’s just that what they know is wrong.

headline: Before Kim and Kris, There Was Ethel and Ernest
text: It was a storybook celebrity marriage that captured a public’s imagination, and then suddenly it was over before they even had a chance to complete their wedding registry. No, not Kim Kardashian and Kris Humphries, who devastated the American populace when Mrs. filed for divorce from Mr. on Monday; we’re talking about a couple whose all-too-brief union makes the 72 days of Kardashian-Humphries nuptial bliss seem as old as the cosmos itself. That would be Ernest Borgnine and Ethel Merman, who separated after five weeks of marriage in 1964.

headline: Shearling Breaks Out
text: DESIGNERS have not been content to confine their use of shearling this season to linings and trim; it’s all over their accessories. Viktor & Rolf’s high-heel platform booties are completely covered — best for a non-snow day. Among the bags, a Céline mini-luggage model, a Marni tote and a Miu Miu with a braided top handle are carpeted in the curly stuff. We like this Jerome Dreyfuss shearling one, with black or burgundy leather. Carrying it is like throwing your favorite shearling-lined leather jacket over your arm. But the pockets are deeper.

headline: Prayer for Relief to Miss Breeders’ Cup Classic
text: The West Virginia Derby champion Prayer for Relief is out for Saturday’s $5 million Breeders’ Cup Classic at Churchill Downs after failing to board a flight from Southern California early Tuesday morning along with other contenders trained by Bob Baffert.

headline: It Takes a Village
text: You’ll have to find your own spot at the folding metal table that Deirdre Foley-Mendelssohn and Peter Stella use when entertaining at their apartment on Christopher Street. Neither believes in seating charts, opting instead to let guests fend for themselves among the mismatched plates, found silverware and batik napkins from Indonesia. Stella, 29, a medical and M.B.A. graduate student, grew up in the neighborhood, and the couple takes full advantage of their local farmers’ market and the many West Village specialty stores. “Super-simple ingredients make everything better,” says the 28-year-old Foley-Mendelssohn, a senior editor at The Paris Review, who carries provisions in a wicker basket on her vintage Schwinn bike. “Peter’s more of a traditionalist when it comes to cooking, inclined to think that a pasta with too many ingredients is actually a salad.” Go to slide show >>

headline: Dorothy Rodham, Mother and Mentor of Hillary Clinton, Is Dead at 92
text: Dorothy Rodham, who overcame years of struggle to become a powerful influence on the life and career of her daughter, Hillary Rodham Clinton, the first lady, senator from New York, presidential candidate and now secretary of state, died on Tuesday in Washington. She was 92.

headline: Civility on the Brink
text: Scholars of Southern culture see manners on the decline, eroded by modern life and its complexities.

headline: A Last Bastion of Civility, the South, Sees Manners Decline
text: ATLANTA — One August night, two men walked into a popular restaurant attached to this city’s fanciest shopping mall. They sat at the bar, ordered drinks and pondered the menu. Two women stood behind them.

headline: CME Investigating MF Global
text: The investigation into hundreds of millions of dollars in missing money at MF Global has widened, as the CME Group confirmed on Tuesday that the brokerage firm failed to keep customer money separate from company money.

text: Time to strap on your green visor and sharpen your red pencil.

headline: For N.F.L. Quarterbacks, Days, and Plays, to Forget
text: Today, we welcome San Diego quarterback Philip Rivers to the sports dartboard. Step right up, Mr. Rivers. Yes, you’ve been here before. Tim Tebow will happily give up the seat for you, although, Mr. Tebow, you didn’t actually seem to mind your time there. You seem dart-proof, which comes in handy when you’re Tim Tebow. We hear the Broncos are starting you again Sunday, so we’ll see you again on Monday.

headline: Company Ordered to Stop Selling Uninspected Poultry to Retailers
text: A Queens slaughterhouse that had been selling thousands of pounds of uninspected poultry to local supermarkets has been enjoined from the practice by a court-approved decree announced Tuesday by federal prosecutors.

headline: Since 1990s, U.S. Students’ Math Has Sharpened, but Reading Lags
text: Elementary and middle school students have improved greatly in math, but their reading skills have stagnated over the last two decades, federal officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Say Hello to … Snowliage!
text: The record-breaking late-October snowstorm, which buried some northern New England towns in snow (up to 31 inches) and snapped trees like twigs, may be the final blow to an already lackluster foliage season.

headline: London Cathedral Stops Legal Action Against Protesters
text: LONDON — St. Paul’s Cathedral has suspended legal action to evict hundreds of anti-capitalist protesters camped outside its doors, according to a statement on Tuesday.

headline: Herman Cain and the ‘Liberal Media’
text: I’ve always been impressed, well alarmed really, at how quickly the right wing jumps on an issue almost in unison. This week, it was the news that Herman Cain, one of the contenders for the Republican presidential nomination, was accused of sexual harassment when he was running the National Restaurant Association.

headline: On National Test, New York Declines in Math
text: UPDATED: Average math scores for New York fourth graders fell by three points on the National Assessment of Educational Progress, also known as the Nation's Report Card. New York was the only state in the country in which the scores declined. State officials and others reacted to the news.

headline: Success Academy Charter Battle, Take Two
text: Eva S. Moskowitz is deep into another battle, this time in Brooklyn where she is trying to start one of her Success Academy charter schools in Cobble Hill. Some of the people at Public School 261 Philip Livingston in Brooklyn are planning an event in protest.

headline: Repost: European Inflation Targets
text: One problem with blogging is that at any given time many of your readers don’t know about ground you’ve already covered. I’ve tried to remedy that in part with my list of macroeconomics posts over to the right — before commenting on my macro analysis, you might want to read them. Still, it sometimes helps to repost an earlier argument.

headline: Cashman, With His Own New Deal, Sets Pitching as Yankees’ Priority
text: In a matter of hours, the Yankees resolved their two biggest off-season issues. They announced Tuesday morning that General Manager Brian Cashman had signed a three-year contract extension, less than a day after they agreed with C. C. Sabathia on a contract extension that will keep him in pinstripes at least through 2016.

headline: $10 Million Gift for Study of White House History
text: WASHINGTON – More than a million visitors traipse through the White House each year, hoping for a glimpse of its occupants, yet there is no central place for the study of the building itself. Now the nonprofit White House Historical Association has received a $10 million gift toward a long-held goal of converting its historic headquarters – including a carriage house that contains a rare example of urban slave quarters – into a National Center for White House History.

headline: For Bird Lovers, a Race to the Finish
text: When people think about birds in games these days, they are usually of the angry variety. But a different kind of game is unfolding on the Web, with 34 pecking and chirping species just daring users to catch them.

headline: Readers Respond: Not-So-Super Committee
text: Today’s lead editorial takes the deficit-reduction supercommittee to task, scolding the Republicans for their continued fierce obstructionism, and the Democrats for being too accommodating. The editorial board argues that the Democrats’ proposed cuts to domestic spending and social-insurance programs are “so large as to be imprudent.”

headline: Ex-Treasurer Pleads Guilty to Embezzling From Brooklyn PTA
text: Providence Hogan, the former PTA treasurer at Public School 29 in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty to three counts of grand larceny in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Tuesday and handed over a check for $50,000, while agreeing to pay back the remainder of the money she embezzled — $32,392.91 — over two years.

headline: Investors Check Out ‘Honeymoon in Vegas’ Workshop
text: A long-gestating musical adaptation of the 1992 movie “Honeymoon in Vegas,” which is perhaps best remembered for its skydiving team of Flying Elvises, was staged in a private workshop last week for theater investors with an eye toward a future production in New York or regionally, according to one of its producers.

text: Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

text: Rachel Donadio on the Greek government's potential collapse, and Graham Bowley on the market reaction to worries that last week's debt deal may be a casualty.

headline: Pfizer Reports Higher Profits and Share Buyback Plan
text: Pfizer, the world’s largest drug company, surprised Wall Street in a good way Tuesday with higher-than-expected quarterly sales and an aggressive plan to respond to looming generic competition to Lipitor, the top-selling drug in the world.

headline: Cain’s Wife in Talks to Make Television Appearance
text: As Herman Cain continues to face intense questioning about sex harassment allegations, some have wondered whether his wife, Gloria, will come forward to make a statement of support.

headline: What We Learn (or Don’t) From Test Scores
text: I was devastated by Michael Winerip’s article on how the No Child Left Behind Act has affected the creative teaching at a New Hampshire middle school. It used to be that eighth graders at Oyster River Middle School chose semester-long “genre” projects in English class. They’d pick “a subject area like mysteries, read masters like Agatha Christie, study the writer’s craftsmanship (‘Explain how the author foreshadows doom’), then draft their own.” In science class they would spend two weeks building a real underwater vessel; in social studies they re-enacted the Boston Massacre.
