headline: Bergen, Lansbury and Larroquette Join Cast of Gore Vidal’s ‘Best Man’
text: Candice Bergen, Angela Lansbury, John Larroquette and Michael McKean will join James Earl Jones in the Broadway revival of “Gore Vidal’s ‘The Best Man,’ ” scheduled to open in early April, the producers announced on Tuesday.

headline: In Cheating Verdict, a Milestone for Cricket’s New Era
text: LONDON — After a trial that many saw as a turning point for the game of cricket, a jury found two former members of Pakistan’s national team guilty Tuesday of conspiracy to cheat in a contest with England last summer at Lord’s, the London ground that is regarded as the spiritual home of the game.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 1
text: A look at the day in sports from the Senior Olympics in Florida to Champions League play in Russia.

headline: Pandora Extends Its Reach to Businesses
text: In six years, the Internet radio service Pandora has made its way to more than 100 million personal computers, cars and home entertainment systems. Now, in an effort to find new sources of income, it also is coming to shopping malls, doctor’s offices and restaurants.

headline: Art World Watches Closely as Auction Season Starts
text: As the fall auction season kicks off on Tuesday night in New York, the art world will be watching closely to see how the turmoil in the world’s financial markets affects the bidding. This week, all eyes will be on the sales of Impressionist and modern art at Christie’s (Tuesday night) and Sotheby’s (Wednesday), where hundreds of millions of dollars’ worth of work by masters like Degas and Picasso, Giacometti and Magritte will be up for sale. As has happened in the past, collectors may feel safer investing in a painting or sculpture than in the stock market, making for a buoyant round of auctions. Or, as has also occurred, nerves and outright fear could lead to stagnant sales and flat prices. Stay tuned.

headline: After the Series, Appreciating Tony La Russa One Last Time
text: He wasn’t the most popular manager in the game. Matter of fact, maybe he was the least popular.

headline: Avery, Demoted Agitator, Is Poised to Rejoin Rangers
text: Sean Avery’s career with the Rangers, thought to be finished not long ago, has resumed.

headline: On Our Radar: Smog Dispute in Beijing
text: With smog blanketing Beijing, residents take issue with the Chinese government’s estimates of air pollution, citing different readings from the American Embassy. The government acknowledges the concerns and says it uses a different metric to measure the pollution. [CNN]

headline: Flatter Than Ever?
text: A conversation about globalization between Thomas L. Friedman and Nandan M. Nilekani, hosted by India Ink.

headline: Clip: ‘The Other F Word’
text: In this clip from the documentary ”The Other F Word,” Fatt Mike, the lead singer of NOFX, tends to his second job, that of parenting his daughter.

headline: New Leader Says U.S. Base in Kyrgyzstan Will Be Shut
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan — In one of his first statements as Kyrgyzstan’s new president, Almazbek Atambayev said Tuesday that he would seek to close an important American military base when its lease runs out in 2014, reviving a threat dropped by past leaders after the United States agreed to increased payments.

headline: The Sugar Stimulus
text: Before Halloween, the National Confectioners Association estimated that Americans spent more than $2.2 billion on candy — a new record. That works out to approximately $7.36 per person. Confectioners produced some 35 million pounds of candy corn for the season, or 27 syrup-cones for each and every one of us.

headline: City Finds Possible Cause of Fire at Harlem Sewage Plant
text: The four-alarm fire that shut down a Harlem sewage treatment plant in July, sending hundreds of millions of gallons of wastewater into New York City’s waterways, was probably caused by a single, improperly tightened nut, according to a report the city’s Department of Environmental Protection released on Tuesday.

headline: COPO Camaro: A Quarter-Miler With an Insider’s Pedigree
text: LAS VEGAS — Chevrolet is bringing back the quarter pounder.

headline: Book Report: Who Speaks for the Climate?
text: Robert J. Brulle, a sociologist at Drexel University, has for years been been a valuable guide for me to the large, and largely under-appreciated, body of behavioral research illuminating why it’s so hard to gain traction on the super wicked problem of human-driven climate change.

headline: Fraud and Loopholes Deliver Small-Business Contracts to Big Firms
text: It’s been a busy season for combating fraud in government contracts for small business, for prosecutors enforcing the law as well as the legislators trying to improve it. But for both, it appears to be an uphill battle.

headline: Hating Incumbency and Incumbents Too
text: WASHINGTON — One of the immutable laws of American politics has been that while voters typically loathe Congress, they tend to tolerate their own lawmaker. Now, with ratings for that institution in the root cellar and approval of individual lawmakers heading there, members of Congress and analysts are beginning to wonder if that law could be repealed next year.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Renewable Energy
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. National Team Data Dive: Ratings, Stats and Opinions
text: Want to get a quick sense of how Albert Pujols performed in game 3 of the World Series? No problem. Simply find a box score and in a matter of seconds you can see that Pujols went 5 for 6 with three homers, four runs scored and six R.B.I. He batted third and played first base, and oh, by the way, he was 1 for 1 with runners in scoring position and drove in three two-out runs.

headline: Is the Web Amplifying Consumers’ Voices?
text: First, Netflix dropped its plan to make customers have separate accounts for mail order and online movies. Now, Bank of America has reversed plans to charge a $5 monthly fee for some customers who use their debit cards to make purchases. Both decisions came after the original plans were sharply criticized by their customers.

headline: Grand Marnier Soufflé
text: Adapted from Adam Gopnik

headline: Adam Gopnik on the Days of Great French Dining
text: “YOU feel transported,” Adam Gopnik said, moments after easing into a red banquette at La Grenouille, the Gallic grande dame on East 52nd Street that made its debut a few weeks after the Cuban missile crisis. “This is a reminder of why there were great French restaurants, once upon a time.”

headline: Middle School Angst Gets Its Hour
text: This American Life, the popular radio show, takes a look at middle school life. The host, Ira Glass, interviews a 14-year old named Annie, who gave the producers the idea to do a program about these difficult years.  "The drama every day can be frustrating," Annie said. "No matter who you are or what you do you can made fun of for it." Hear stories from around the country, from students and experts.

headline: Newspaper Circulation Figures Show Some Digital Growth
text: Some of the nation’s largest newspapers are recording gains in digital circulation as print circulation continues to weaken, a trend that is helping to ease what has become a relentless overall decline in recent years.

headline: Reactor in Japan Restarts, a First Since the Tsunami
text: TOKYO — A nuclear reactor in western Japan began starting back up on Tuesday after a month’s hiatus, the first reactor in the country closed for any reason to win approval from a local government to resume operations since the Fukushima nuclear disaster.

headline: As Miles Add Up, So Do the Unforgettable Moments
text: By nature, a marathon promotes melodrama. Weary minds make bad decisions. Overused muscles malfunction. Logistical challenges create unexpected mishaps. A zoned-in runner misreads the course and stumbles in midstride or falls. The latter happened to Bill Rodgers in the 1980 New York City Marathon when he fell over Dick Beardsley, who had tripped in a pothole, and finished fifth. Rodgers had won New York the four previous years.

headline: For Trailing Candidates, Encouraging Words in Iowa
text: PELLA, Iowa — Mitt Romney wasn’t there. Nor was Herman Cain. But for the five Republican presidential candidates who did appear, Terry E. Branstad, the Republican governor of Iowa, offered encouraging words, as they all gathered on Tuesday at a National Association of Manufacturers forum.

headline: MoMA Plans New Antony and the Johnsons Work to Take Flight at Radio City
text: The Museum of Modern Art is not getting into the concert promotion business just yet, but its latest commission has, at least on paper, the components and the pedigree of a pop-music spectacle.

headline: 20111101_ARNAL_CHOCO
text: Arnal Choco

headline: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company in Seattle
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the 17th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from Seattle.

headline: First Came the Egg | Nora Kogan’s Ode to Fabergé
text: Nora Kogan, the Brooklyn jewelry designer behind St. Kilda, is known for costume pieces like the Surrealist-inspired Man Ray lip cuffs that are favored by fashion insiders like the blogger Garance Doré. She’s now designing higher-end baubles under her own name. The first Nora Kogan collection, Anastasia, is inspired by a Fabergé egg that, according to family lore, her Russian grandfather acquired during World War II in exchange for a box of chocolates. The egg disappeared — presumably into the pockets of a Soviet customs official — when the family immigrated to Australia in the 1970s, but Kogan retains clear memories of it. “It opened up into three sections, and in the center was a hand-painted icon,” recalls Kogan, who riffs on Fabergé’s legendary craftsmanship and stylized nature motifs in pieces like these diamond drop earrings and ring. “Designing this collection has been therapeutic for me as I’m still often haunted by this loss.”

headline: Another View: Can Groupon’s I.P.O. Be Saved?
text: Anthony H. Catanach Jr. is an associate accounting professor at the Villanova School of Business and a Cary M. Maguire fellow at the American College. J. Edward Ketz is an associate accounting professor at the Smeal College of Business at Pennsylvania State University.

headline: Survey Finds Chain Stores Spreading More Slowly
text: New York City may have reached its Dunkin’ point.

headline: No Debate: It’s Lincoln and Douglass
text: For decades, the New-York Historical Society has struggled against the architecture of its own building, which conveys — in its cold grandeur — an institution that is insular, impenetrable and inscrutable.

headline: PTA Treasurer Admits Guilt and Will Pay Back What She Stole
text: The treasurer of an elementary school PTA in  Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty to theft charges and agreed to pay back all the money she embezzled. She started by handing over  a check for $50,000, and promised to pay off the remaining $32,392.91 over two years.

headline: Winter Squash With Anchovies, Capers, Olives and Ricotta Salata
text: Adapted from a recipe in Clifford A. Wright’s book “Mediterranean Vegetables,” this is another Italian recipe for winter squash (or pumpkin, to Italians), this time from the southern region of Apulia. It’s a delicious contrast of sweet and savory. Serve it as a side dish, toss it with pasta or use it as a topping for squash blini. The seasoning is provided by the anchovies, capers and cheese, a salty contrast to the sweet squash (the recipe is not for you if you cannot eat salt).

headline: 10 Ways to Teach About Election Day
text: Any election – whether off-year, midterm or presidential and whether local, state or federal – presents opportunities for learning about civics and how government actually works as well as the importance of active citizenship.

headline: Simple Provençal Winter Squash Gratin
text: I’ve offered a few winter squash gratin recipes over the years, but none as simple as this one. There’s little more than squash here, seasoned with lots of garlic and fresh herbs. Dicing all the squash takes time, but then the work is just about done. If you want to use a food processor, you can, but you can’t get even pieces that way. The recipe is based on one of my favorite recipes in Richard Olney’s book “Simple French Food.”

headline: Will Greece Destroy the Euro Zone?
text: The collapse of the Papandreou government may undo European efforts to restructure debt and hold the union together.

headline: Inside MF Global’s Bankruptcy Hearing
text: 5:54 p.m. |Update

headline: In Egypt, Tourism Remains in a Tailspin
text: More than eight months after President Hosni Mubarak was toppled, the euphoria of Egypt’s political spring has surrendered to a season of discontent.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nepal and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Nepal, Afghanistan, Libya and Russia.

headline: Sentence of the Week, Pathos and Petulance Edition
text: Here are our candidates:

headline: Visiting Artists | Lauren Luloff
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Shaken Baby Syndrome
text: The Republican presidential candidates Newt Gingrich and Rick Santorum say the Ninth Circuit appeals court, based in San Francisco, should be abolished because they often disagree with its rulings. Apparently the appellate court has some detractors on the Supreme Court, too.

headline: McCaskill’s Campaign Prep: Lose 50 Pounds
text: Most politicians hate loss, but not when it applies to their waistline.

headline: Tokyo String Quartet Losing Two Members
text: Two members of the Tokyo String Quartet, including its founding violist, will retire from the group at the end of next season, in June 2013, the ensemble said in a statement from its public relations firm on Tuesday. The violist, Kazuhide Isomura, 65, helped start the quartet in 1969. Also leaving is the second violinist, Kikuei Ikeda, 64, who joined in 1974.

headline: Cashew Apples, VW Bugs and Waterfalls in Pirenópolis, Brazil
text: Sometimes in little towns in far-off lands, you do things you wouldn’t do at home, like hanging on the back half of a motorbike as it jolts over unpaved country roads. In Pirenópolis, Brazil, a cute, cobblestoned colonial town 85 miles west of Brasília, moto-taxis are the public transportation system and the main way, if you’re not part of a tour group, to get to the waterfalls that dot the surrounding hills. You get a helmet of your own and, if you’re lucky, a driver named Wesley, who for one great Tuesday morning in early September also served as my de facto tour guide. We hiked on hilly trails and dived into waterfalls, and Wesley dashed into the brush to pluck juicy, tannin-packed cashew apples for us to snack on.

headline: Coach Inc. Agrees to Occupy Third of Hudson Yards Tower
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday that Coach Inc. would buy over 600,000 square feet in the first tower of the Hudson Yards site — in a major step forward for the long-gestating development project.

headline: ‘Charles Addams’s New York’
text: Images from an exhibit at the Museum of the City of New York.

headline: A Few Drinks a Week Raises Breast Cancer Risk
text: Some women who drink to their health may want to reconsider. A new study shows that women who routinely have even small amounts of alcohol, as few as three drinks a week, have an elevated risk of breast cancer.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nepal and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Nepal, Afghanistan, Libya and Yemen.

headline: Tigers Ponder Future, Which Will Not Include Ordonez or Guillen
text: Falling just short of the World Series, the Tigers now face an off-season of decisions, and while General Manager Dave Dombrowski is not considering a Yankees-style shopping spree, he does have some moves to try to make an already good team better. The Tigers lost the American League Championship Series to Texas in six games after a strong season that produced the team’s first A.L. Central title since 1987.

headline: In San Diego, Mulling the Second Life of an E.V. Battery
text: There is no denying how cost-intensive battery packs are for manufacturers of electric vehicles. A possible strategy for defraying those costs would involve giving them a second, stationary life as backup power for the electrical grid.

headline: Obstacles Hinder Formation of Afghan Security Force, Report Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai’s plan to disband private security companies that protect billions of dollars worth of aid projects and replace them with government forces is fraught with problems and unlikely to meet the president’s March deadline to complete the transition, according to a six-month assessment of the program.

headline: More Seats for Lower Manhattan, But Not Right Away
text: Nearly 200 seats will be added to an elementary school planned for Lower Manhattan, city Education Department officials announced on Tuesday, but that additional space in a neighborhood that sorely needs it will not become available until 2015.

headline: Union Claims Nearly a Million Students Hit by Budget Cuts
text: City teachers are reporting more crowded classrooms, fewer textbooks and even a lack of furniture in a survey of union representatives across the five boroughs. The union released the results of an email survey to its representatives across the system, and said class sizes are more crowded than at any time since the 1970s.

headline: Civil War Diarist’s Photo Collection to Go on View in South Carolina
text: Mary Boykin Chesnut’s diary offers a first-person view of the Civil War from the upper reaches of Southern society. She details what it was like to sit atop a house in Charleston, S.C., and watch the shelling of Fort Sumter, and, later, what it was like in Chester, S.C., to receive news of Robert E. Lee’s surrender at Appomattox, with “the Elite of the Confederacy — going and coming — and when night comes … more beds are made on the floor of the landing place. …The whole house is a bivouac.’’

headline: My Three Favorite New Yorker Cartoons
text: This week, a redesign of the Conde Nast Web site went live, including a change in the Cartoon Bank, which sells prints of old New Yorker cartoons and is one of my favorite places to visit. To mark the occasion, here are my three favorite New Yorker cartoons. By “favorite” in this exercise, I mean the three that shaped my image of what a New Yorker cartoon is. It may be nothing like your image of the quintessential New Yorker cartoon, but my tastes have always been simple, like the fictional New Yorker editor on “Seinfeld” whose justification for running a certain abstruse cartoon was: “I like the kitty.”

headline: Coming Into a Crowded World
text: Lynsey Addario photographs a maternity ward in Delhi, India as the world population reaches seven billion.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 46
text: Snow and cold are on everyone’s minds, but downtown, there are other issues, too.

headline: Few Treats for Networks on Halloween
text: Nielsen families must also be avid trick-or-treaters if the broadcast ratings from Halloween are any indication. Many network shows fell to season, or in some cases, series lows, on Monday night.

headline: A 556-Horsepower Chevelle With Earnhardt Touches Introduces G.M.’s Crate Performance Packages
text: LAS VEGAS — The Nascar driver Dale Earnhardt Jr. was on hand at the Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show this week to introduce a 1970 Chevelle SS with a 2011 twist:  the first installation of a new powertrain system, called Connect and Cruise, being offered by Chevrolet Performance.

headline: Michael Bloomberg, Ignoramus
text: Via David Dayen, the favored candidate of those who believe we need a smart centrist to solve our nation’s problems reveals himself to be completely ignorant about the causes of our economic crisis, someone who just swallows right-wing propaganda whole:

headline: How Cain’s Story Has Changed
text: As soon as the sexual harassment allegations against Herman Cain surfaced on Sunday night, the candidate himself started talking. And with each interview, his story shifted.

headline: Report Hashes Out Battle Plan Against Military Suicides
text: With military suicides remaining at a stubbornly high level in recent years, there has been no shortage of calls to action. But this week the Center for a New American Security, an influential military policy group in Washington, offered some specific recommendations for what the armed services, Department of Veterans Affairs and Congress could do to bring the rate down.

headline: Olympus Scandal Reveals How Little Japan Has Changed
text: If there were any doubt remaining, the scandal surrounding the Olympus Corporation of Japan has proved Michael Crichton wrong. What does the late Mr. Crichton, the author of “Jurassic Park” among other books, have to do with this, you may be asking?

headline: Rainbow Brights
text: When the designer Bibhu Mohapatra visited Rachel Dooley’s studio in search of a birthday gift for a friend just months after they’d both been inducted into the CFDA Fashion Incubator, he found the Gemma Redux jewelry designer only too happy to make a swap. “Necklace for a coat — sweet deal for me!” Dooley says of the exchange. Soon thereafter the two friends started plotting a joint venture — the first to emerge from the CFDA’s incubator program. Their 10-piece offering, which made its debut at Mohapatra’s spring presentation during New York Fashion Week, includes bangles with an iridescent finish that Dooley describes as “totally trippy.” The geode ring and pendant, which are cast in brass and then glossed in super-saturated prismatic hues, pair especially well with Mohapatra’s orange harem pants; the long brushed bronze earrings look best with the designer’s floor-skimming gowns. “Those bar earrings just accentuate the collection’s linear silhouettes,” Mohapatra explains. “They add just enough shine.”

headline: How About Affirming That the Seas Are Still Shining?
text: From time to time someone in Congress floats the idea of a constitutional amendment to outlaw flag burning, which the Supreme Court has ruled is protected by the First Amendment. And from time to time, the editorial page reminds readers that such proposals are nothing more than pandering – by politicians on the right trying to please their base, or by politicians on the left hoping to look less, well, left. Flag-burning, as we wrote in 2005, “hasn’t been in fashion since college students used slide rules in math class and went to pay phones at the student union to call their friends. Even then, it was a rarity that certainly never put the nation’s security in peril.”

headline: Socializing for a Cause
text: The publicity firm founded by two New Yorkers who are no strangers to high society specializes in gathering their friends for charitable fund-raising events.

headline: The World of Hunger Has a New Language
text: THE terms food desert and food insecurity are part of the new language of hunger.

headline: H.P. Builds Servers With Cellphone Chips
text: Hewlett-Packard announced on Tuesday a new design for some of the world’s largest computer centers and says it could reduce power consumption in some cases by 90 percent.

headline: Scene City: Heidi Klum’s Halloween Party
text: A Gremlin, Black Swans, Zoolander and a couple of simians party at the PH-D Rooftop Lounge.

headline: In Doling Out Economic Incentives, Bloomberg Looks Outside Manhattan
text: Updated 6:47 p.m. | Under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, New York City has continued to give tax breaks and other financial incentives to businesses, but he has spread them more widely around the city than his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, according to a study released on Tuesday by the city’s Independent Budget Office.

headline: Project Halloween
text: SOMEWHERE amid modeling for Victoria’s Secret, producing a reality TV franchise and designing clothing lines, Heidi Klum became known as the Queen of Halloween. In years past, she transformed herself with over-the-top costumes like Lady Godiva, the Hindu goddess Kali and a robotic superhero.

headline: An Appetite for Discussion
text: You may have noticed that we have become, as a nation, kind of obsessed with eating. Obsessed in the same way that many of us used to be obsessed with listening to music.

headline: Food Delivered, Fresh and Free
text: A nonprofit agency delivers fresh meat, produce and other healthful foods to hungry people in an area near Boston with no supermarkets.

headline: Carriage Horse That Died Was Sickly, A.S.P.C.A. Reports
text: A carriage horse that collapsed and died on the job last week was “not a healthy horse” and suffered from stomach ulcers, among other things, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said.

headline: Peanut Butter Plus
text: Abbott Laboratories is helping Haitians build a self-sustaining enterprise making a nutritional supplement.

headline: A Peek at Punk Paternity as Rockers Raise Families
text: Dedicated to proving that punk rockers can not only procreate but also follow through with the aftercare, “The Other F Word” invites a cross-section of aging bad boys to dish on the demands of fatherhood.

headline: Setting a Clubfoot Straight
text: Dr.Ignacio Ponseti’s decades-old method of correcting clubfoot works in up to 98 percent of cases, and can be taught to nondoctors, making it a treatment that can be readily transferred anywhere.

headline: The Upside of Gifts Made Directly From I.R.A.’s
text: AN important tax break for retired people expired last year, then was renewed but too late for most eligible people to take advantage of it. Now the provision, which allows people who are 70 1/2 or older to make charitable donations of up to $100,000 directly from their I.R.A.’s, is available through Dec. 31.

headline: In the Company of Animals, Healing for Humans
text: SOPHIE is a goat whose taste in books leans toward popular best sellers, says Solana Mejia-Schnaufer, who reads aloud to her several times a week. “I know she likes ‘The Hunger Games’ because she didn’t try to eat it. That wasn’t true of ‘Animal Liberation.’ ”

headline: Marriage May End; Wedding Went On
text: When the news leaked at midday on Monday that one of the biggest stars on E!, Kim Kardashian, was divorcing her husband after a mere two months, the channel had a quick decision to make. Keep on its schedule the daily repeats of “Kim’s Fairytale Wedding,” a four-hour extravaganza that it reportedly paid millions of dollars to televise? Or yank the repeats now that reality had so rudely intruded?

headline: Tax Rules Allow an Array of Givers to Be More Generous
text: IF you, like most charitably inclined people, wish you could afford to give more, the good news is that you probably can, simply by taking advantage of the tax code’s provisions that effectively make Uncle Sam your partner in giving.

headline: Speaking Up to Honor the Quiet Work of Librarians
text: IN a city where philanthropy has to rise to more than a $1 million to grab headlines, a gift of $2,000 may not seem all that noteworthy. But every year for the last 23 years, such a gift has made a great difference to two librarians in the New York Public Library who are selected by their colleagues to receive a $2,000 prize from the Bertha Franklin Feder Award program.

headline: A Horoscope That Prompts a Long Journey
text: There are times when “Five Star Day” lulls you into thinking you’re watching a pretty sophisticated movie. The writer and director, Danny Buday, shows flashes of subtlety and makes the occasional unexpected choice. But a drippy ending erases all the hopes you’ve built up and forces you to conclude that this wasn’t such a well-thought-out film after all.

headline: Sirius XM Profit Grows, but Subscription Growth Fails to Meet Expectations
text: Profit at Sirius XM Radio grew by more than 50 percent in the third quarter, and its subscription numbers hit a high of 21.3 million, the company reported on Tuesday. But analysts were disappointed by Sirius’s subscription growth rate, and the stock fell 3.35 percent for the day, to $1.73.

headline: In Afterword, Ravitch Brings Things Up to Date
text: In the afterward of the paperback version of her book, "The Death and Life of the Great American School System," Diane Ravitch continues her crusade against the school reform movement, reacting to the events, people and ideas of the last year and a half. Read some excerpts.

headline: Rosy Nostalgia and Sharp Reality Entwine in a Potent Jig
text: The narrator of “Dancing at Lughnasa” drifts back to his most vivid recollection of late summer 1936 when, he says, “In that memory atmosphere is more real than incident and everything is simultaneously actual and illusory.”

headline: Reviewing Saxon & Parole
text: Back when I was on the restaurant beat full time, I used to know all the best places in New York to get a hamburger. Now I have to rely on other authorities to get my burger information.

headline: Conjuring the Past, Feeding the Present
text: BRAD FARMERIE, the executive chef at the new NoHo restaurant Saxon & Parole, is nothing if not versatile. When his restaurant Double Crown, a culinary fantasy of British imperialism in Asia, closed this summer, Mr. Farmerie and his partners, AvroKO Hospitality Group, quickly created an entirely different mood, aura and menu in the same space, as if they were stagehands changing sets between acts at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Honk-Honks and Melodies: Two Sides of the Atlantic Meet
text: On certain nights in the tiny town of Dingle, Ireland, residents can hear the strains of music coming from an ancient church, with musicians from around the world having made the long journey to the westernmost edge of the country. And on other nights — the local fishermen will swear by this — you can hear the distant sounds of Manhattan traffic leaping across the Atlantic into the mists just off the coast.

headline: Two Shores Meet in the Village
text: “Other Voices,” an Irish television program, took up residence at Le Poisson Rouge last week.

headline: Occupy Protesters Focus on Iowa Caucuses
text: A group called Occupy Iowa is urging like-minded protesters from across the country to descend on the Iowa headquarters of the presidential candidates the week before the caucuses, which will be held Jan. 3.

headline: Empty Times Square Is Fantasy; The Stranger Stuff Is Science
text: You might want to think twice, if you cherish your notions of reality, before accepting a ride from Brian Greene.

headline: Two Vendors at Metropolitan Museum Are Carted Away by Police
text: In the continuing battles over who gets to sell hot dogs in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the city cracked down on Tuesday on two military veterans who have each operated pushcarts in front of the museum despite city orders to stop.

headline: A Busy Soloist, Working at Collaboration
text: Some soloists spend their lives shuttling around the world, trotting out standard works for the umpteenth time. Others often refresh their repertory and always seem to have some innovative project under way.

headline: French Pastries Find a Home in SoHo
text: Dominique Ansel, below, who was the pastry chef at Daniel for six years and worked at Fauchon in Paris before that, opens his own pastry shop and cafe Wednesday. Besides croissants, macarons and éclairs, he is baking a few specialties that are not everyday indulgences in New York. Among them is a tall fluted cake, the gâteau battu, which comes from Mr. Ansel’s native Picardy, north of Paris, and is halfway between brioche and poundcake but lighter than either one. He sells the whole cake or slices, excellent with soft butter and jam. He is also baking kouign-amann, a flaky, crispy little Breton pastry, which a few American chefs are starting to feature on their menus. His take on the Paris-Brest, a filled ring of cream puff pastry, is called Paris-New York (above) and has caramel, peanuts and chocolate. His menu also includes savory items like sandwiches, quiches, soups and salads. The narrow space with an open kitchen has a few seats and a marble counter, an all-weather greenhouse for seating in the back and a garden.

headline: Obama Goes Local in Round of Interviews
text: With his re-election campaign now in full swing, President Obama has been visiting swing states and attending fund-raisers almost every week. Unfortunately, this week he’s obligated to travel to a place with no electoral votes: Cannes, France, for the Group of 20 economic summit.

headline: U.S. Judge Bars a Suit for Victims of Madoff
text: For the second time this year, a federal judge has barred a court-appointed bankruptcy trustee from seeking billions in damages from big banks and other third parties to help compensate victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s giant Ponzi scheme.

headline: Euphoria Turns to Discontent as Egypt’s Revolution Stalls
text: GIZA, Egypt — Lurching around the Great Pyramids on a camel was part of the trip-of-a-lifetime experience that Farag Abu Ghaneima once touted dozens of times a day, but he recently sold three of his five camels to the butcher.

headline: Lens: Turning Point — Lazar
text: Lens: Turning Point — Lazar

headline: Cain Accuser Wants to Tell Story, Lawyer Says
text: The lawyer for one of the two women who accused Herman Cain of sexual harassment said Tuesday that she wanted to come forward but was bound by a confidentiality agreement with the National Restaurant Association.

headline: Some Chase Accounts See Delay in Credit for Deposits
text: Because of a delay in the electronic batch posting of transactions on Monday night, some Chase bank accounts were not credited with deposits as they should have been, a bank spokesman said.

headline: The Legend on the N.B.A. Logo, Running Scared
text: Like almost everyone who attended West Virginia University in the late 1950s, my father has a Jerry West story. West was, and is, West Virginia’s greatest sports legend. His fame was never larger there than in 1959, the year he led the Mountaineers to within one point of a national basketball championship. National championships — or positive recognition of any kind, really — didn’t come that often to West Virginia.

headline: The Thanksgiving Help Line Is Open
text: Although Sam Sifton won’t be manning the Help Line this year, the Dining staff is ready to take your questions on Thanksgiving cooking, drinking, entertaining, or any other holiday hurdles. Tweet us at @nytimesdining using the hashtag #ThanksgivingQs, or post a question below. They’ll be answered in the coming weeks.

headline: Postcard From L.S.U.: When a Stadium Was a Dorm
text: BATON ROUGE, La. — In 1931, the administration of Louisiana State University was at odds with Huey Long, the state’s governor.

headline: Top Spanish Ham, Now Found in the United States
text: The top Spanish ham comes from purebred black-footed Ibérico pigs that feed on wild acorns. Now, it is available in the United States. The brand with the most cachet is 5 Jotas, in business for more than 100 years. It took four years to get final approval from federal agencies. At present, the front-leg ham, called the paleta, above, is available. The hind legs, which take longer to cure, will be available in a few months. Slices of 5 Jotas are silky and rosy, with no sign of drying, and a flavor that’s irresistibly nutty-sweet, with succulent fat. Dehesa, another, less expensive brand — which says its hams are also from purebred Ibérico pigs, and are raised by members of Covap, a cooperative — will reach American stores in about two weeks. A preview sample of the Dehesa paleta was somewhat deeper in color than the 5 Jotas, but was also nut-sweet, satin-textured and mellow.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: In Egypt, Tourism Remains in a Tailspin
text: Tourism, a buttress of the Egyptian economy, continues to suffer more than eight months after the fall of President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Exploring Bartok’s Legacy With Plenty of Energy
text: Master is a term applied too loosely in classical music. To declare someone a master makes it sound as if an artist had reached some benchmark of skill and insight, and every performance said master gave would automatically be masterly. In fact great musicians work constantly and continually challenge themselves.

headline: Butter-Blanched Mustard Greens With Mustard Oil
text: Adapted from “Home Cooking With Jean-Georges” (Clarkson Potter, 2011)

headline: Frisée Salad with Bloomed Mustard Seed and Mustard Oil
text: Adapted from Laurence Edelman, Left Bank, Manhattan

headline: American Chefs Discover Mustard Oil
text: LAURENCE EDELMAN is not a chef who looks often to Asia for culinary inspiration.

headline: Occupy Oakland Regroups, Calling for a Strike
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — A week after police in riot gear rousted and then tear-gassed Occupy Oakland protesters, supporters of the movement have rebuilt their encampment in front of City Hall and are calling for a general strike on Wednesday that will include an attempt to shut down the nation’s fifth-busiest shipping port.

headline: Britain, Watching Europe, Seeks to Preserve Influence
text: LONDON — Even as Britain hopes for an end to the debt crisis plaguing the euro zone, it also fears an outcome that may threaten its influence in the European Union and London’s role as a financial center.

headline: Putting Zuckerberg’s Millions to Work for Schools
text: NEWARK

headline: For Injured Veterans, Healing in Service to Others
text: WHILE working with refugees and landmine survivors in Rwanda, Bosnia and Cambodia in the 1990s, a Rhodes scholar named Eric Greitens had an epiphany about teenagers in traumatic circumstances: the ones who fared best were the ones who helped others.

headline: Dance Devotee Stays in Motion
text: GIVEN that she is 77 years old and has been on the board of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater for 17 years, 11 as chairwoman, Joan H. Weill clearly does not need to serve any longer. She could simply be enjoying time with her husband, Sanford I. Weill, who recently retired as the head of Citigroup. They could be relaxing at their home in California’s wine country or spending more time with their four grandchildren.

headline: Philanthropist Takes Hands-On Approach to Giving
text: WHEN Leon Levine, the founder of Family Dollar Stores, a chain of neighborhood discount retail stores based outside Charlotte, N.C., was running his company, he took what he called a “hands-on approach.”

headline: Volunteering Rises on the Résumé
text: LYNN DOWLING BRUNO had never heard of the Wren’s Nest, a nonprofit organization that preserves the home of the writer Joel Chandler Harris. Ms. Bruno, 49, lives in Northern California. Wren’s Nest is in Atlanta. But when the opportunity arose to do volunteer work for the nonprofit this year, helping it raise its Internet profile, she jumped at it.

headline: Donors Weigh the Ideals of Meaningful Giving
text: FOR 11 nights last month, several dozen homeless people slept on plastic sheeting and soiled blankets outside the gleaming new $500 million headquarters of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in Seattle. Their objective was a $30,000 grant to help reopen shelters that had been closed by cuts in government funds.

headline: Somalia’s Agony Tests Limits of Aid
text: BENADIR HOSPITAL is a chunky block of a building in downtown Mogadishu, built in the 1970s by the Chinese. It has cracked windows, ceiling fans that don’t turn and long, ghostly hallways that stink of human excrement and diesel fuel — all that the nurses have to wash the floors. Each morning, legions of starving people trudge in, the victims of Somalia’s spreading famine. Many have journeyed from hundreds of miles away. They spent every last dollar and every last calorie to make it here, and when they arrive, they simply collapse on the floor. Benadir’s few doctors and nurses are all volunteers and all exhausted, and many wear tattered, bloodied smocks. The minute I walked in, I had a bad feeling I would find what I was looking for.

headline: Finding Inspiration in a Doctor’s Legacy
text: MY morning sprint through the pages of this newspaper typically goes like this: the front page, the corrections, the sports section (during baseball season) and the obituaries.

headline: Making Nutrition a Sustainable Business in Haiti
text: PHARMACEUTICAL companies around the globe are donating billions of dollars in free drugs to third world countries grappling with poverty and disease.

headline: A Mobile Oasis in a ‘Food Desert’
text: BY 8:30 on a chilly late October morning, a crowd of almost 200 has formed outside the Germantown Neighborhood Center in Quincy, Mass.

headline: German Anger Over Israeli Settlements Could Cost Israel a Submarine
text: In response to the Palestinian Authority’s successful bid for membership in Unesco, Israel decided to take a number of punitive steps on Tuesday, including the accelerated construction of 2,000 new homes for Israelis in East Jerusalem and the West Bank.

headline: It’s an Event for Charity, but Certainly, It’s a Party
text: IT’S just past noon on a Tuesday in late October, and Christine Mortimer Biddle is sequestered on a tuffet in a pastel pink powder room at the Metropolitan Club on the Upper East Side, her Hermès bag by her feet and a laptop on her knees.

headline: Putin Honors a Journalist Badly Beaten After Exposés
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin has bestowed an annual state prize on a muckraking journalist who was beaten nearly to death after investigating official corruption in Khimki, a Moscow suburb. The case of the journalist, Mikhail Beketov, has become a symbol Russia’s culture of impunity.

headline: Airy Macarons That Rise Above the Rest
text: THE macaron is the anti-cupcake.

headline: IHome Takes on Sonos
text: Amended 11/2/2011 to clarify iW1’s feature set.

headline: Special Election in Iowa Will, G.O.P. Hopes, Cement Grip on Power
text: By any standard, the midterm election had been a landslide for Iowa Republicans. Last November, the party won back the governorship, gained a majority in the General Assembly and nearly took the Senate, leaving a perilous 26-to-24 edge there as the Democrats’ sole claim to power.

headline: The Brother-Sister Bond
text: I wept as I read Mona Simpson’s eulogy for her brother, Steve Jobs, in The Times on Monday, and not just because the Willy Wonka of technology was taken from us too young. What really struck home with me was the rare public declaration by a sister of love for her brother.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Here’s to a Beer Room

headline: Benefits
text: Upstate Farmers

headline: Whispers of Return to Drachma Grow Louder in Greek Crisis
text: The political upheaval in Athens has suddenly made the once unspeakable — Greek debt default — a distinct possibility.

headline: Soul-Searching at Nomura
text: Western banks in Japan often complain that Nomura’s long-term dominance means they cannot get a look in. It turns out that works both ways. Tough markets have hit Nomura’s operations in the United States and Europe harder than most, driving the Japanese investment bank to a $589 million loss in the latest quarter. With far bigger rivals also set on shrinking, it is hard to see how Nomura’s global ambitions will survive.

headline: A Likely Favorite’s Long-Shot Story
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Charles Dickey walked into the Breeders’ Cup office at 9:05 on Monday morning and entered his best horse in the race of a lifetime at Churchill Downs.

headline: Driven to Cast Charms Against Drug Lords’ Darker Forces
text: CATEMACO, Mexico — In the dimly lighted back room of a modest house in this tourist city now largely devoid of tourists, Luis Tomás Marthen Torres, a warlock with 50 years of experience, closes his eyes and chants as he briskly rubs a stark white egg over the arms, chest and neck of a worried customer.

headline: In God We Trust, With the House’s Help
text: WASHINGTON — Citing a crisis of national identity and mass confusion among Americans about their nation’s motto, the House on Tuesday voted on a resolution “reaffirming ‘In God We Trust’ as the official motto of the United States.”

headline: Know Your Cuts
text: A new wave of butcher shops offers cuts of meat rarely seen at supermarkets.

headline: No More Doubts: Smith Is 49ers’ Leader
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Some players make their team during minicamp. In June, San Francisco 49ers quarterback Alex Smith used minicamp to make his team his.

headline: The Lost Art of Buying From a Butcher
text: PATRICK MARTINS summed it up in a single slab: pork belly. “That’s the cut that people ask for the most,” he said. “Evidently they can’t find it in their supermarkets.”

headline: Israel Plans to Speed Up Settlement Growth
text: JERUSALEM — Israel said on Tuesday that it would accelerate the construction of 2,000 housing units in contested areas of East Jerusalem and in two West Bank settlements. The announcement came a day after the Palestinians won full membership in Unesco in the face of staunch Israeli and American opposition.

headline: A Political Battle Over the Courts’ Power
text: To the Editor:

headline: Arriving at the Finish Line, Days Before the Race
text: For a moment, it was as though Fred Lebow, the founding father of the New York City Marathon, were back, moving steadily along the route in Central Park where more than 45,000 runners will plow through the final leg of the race this Sunday.

headline: Helping Madoff’s Victims
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kids and Fast Food
text: To the Editor:

headline: School Lunch Proposals Set Off a Dispute
text: WASHINGTON — The government has some thoughts on how to make the federally financed school lunch program more nutritious: A quarter-cup of tomato paste on pizza will no longer be considered a vegetable. Cut back on potatoes and add more fresh peaches, apples, spinach and broccoli. And hold the salt.

headline: Veterans’ Mental Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Catching a Wave, and Measuring It
text: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — James Gosling wants to network the world’s oceans.

headline: Local Food: No Elitist Plot
text: I’m not a jingoist, but I’d prefer that more of my food came from America. It’d be even better, really, if most of it came from within a few hundred miles of where we live. We’d be more secure and better served, and our land would be better used. And I’d feel prouder, as if we had a food culture rather than a food fetish.

headline: Talking Trash, Just to Be Heard
text: Long ago, when N.F.L. pregame shows lasted 30 minutes and sports arguments were more common in barrooms than on cable television, former players did not cause many ripples from the broadcast booth.

headline: New York Sea Levels
text: To the Editor:

headline: State Department Defends Contractor Chosen for Pipeline Study
text: The State Department defended its decision to award a sensitive environmental impact study on the Keystone XL pipeline to a company that had previous ties to TransCanada, the company seeking a permit for the 1,700-mile project, which would run from the tar sands of Alberta to the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Postcard From Alabama: Days Away, but So Close They Can Taste It
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — By Tuesday, Alabama football fans had already arrived in anticipation of Saturday’s game against top-ranked Louisiana State.

headline: Despite Losses, Investors Stick With Paulson
text: John A. Paulson, the billionaire hedge fund manager who made his fortune betting against subprime mortgages, has been fodder for Wall Street gossip as rivals wondered whether investors would bolt after suffering staggering losses this year.

headline: LG Brings Ad Capability to Internet-Connected TV
text: A LEADING marketer of consumer electronics is adding an advertising capability to its Internet-connected televisions through an agreement with a video advertising technology company. And a charter sponsor has already been signed to join them.

headline: Bloomberg and Koch Deeply Split Over Blame on Fiscal Ills
text: For Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, a pragmatic alumnus of Wall Street, arguing over who is to blame for the nation’s financial crisis is a waste of time.

headline: California: Jackson’s Doctor Won’t Testify
text: Michael Jackson’s personal doctor told a Superior Court judge Tuesday that he would not testify in his involuntary manslaughter trial in which he is accused of giving Jackson a fatal dose of a powerful anesthetic. The Los Angeles County district attorney’s office said closing arguments in the trial of Dr. Conrad Murray would begin Thursday. Defense lawyers say Jackson gave himself the fatal dose of propofol, a powerful anesthetic usually used under medical supervision in a hospital, not in a private home, on June 25, 2009.

headline: How to Prop Up the Euro
text: Here’s the critical takeaway from last week’s European rescue plan: Nothing in it addresses the endemic economic weaknesses that nearly propelled the euro zone into a meltdown.

headline: How to Feed the Hungry, Faster
text: On Friday, I wrote about how people in Dhobley, Somalia, are getting emergency food despite a guerrilla war that is keeping out aid workers ― and food.  Instead of trucking in sacks of food, World Concern and its partner, the African Rescue Committee, distribute  vouchers that people in Dhobley use to buy what they need from local merchants.

headline: City Reports More Suspensions, but Serious Crimes Declined
text: New figures on crime and suspensions in the city's schools show suspensions are up while serious episodes have declined. They also show that most suspensions, 87 percent, were given to black and Hispanic students. A third of all suspensions were given to special education students.

headline: In Libya, Fighting May Outlast the Revolution
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Many of the local militia leaders who helped topple Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi are abandoning a pledge to give up their weapons and now say they intend to preserve their autonomy and influence political decisions as “guardians of the revolution.”

headline: Mr. Corzine’s Big Bet
text: Why did Jon S. Corzine make the risky bets that have now plunged MF Global Holdings into bankruptcy court? We don’t know, but the likely explanations are disturbing.

headline: In the Oval Office, a Passage to Freedom
text: Washington, Nov. 1, 2011

headline: Cain Accuser Got a Year’s Salary in Severance Pay
text: WASHINGTON — The National Restaurant Association gave $35,000 — a year’s salary — in severance pay to a female staff member in the late 1990s after an encounter with Herman Cain, its chief executive at the time, made her uncomfortable working there, three people with direct knowledge of the payment said on Tuesday.

headline: Under ‘Color of Federal Law’
text: The Supreme Court ruled three decades ago in Carlson v. Green that a federal prisoner could sue for money damages from prison employees who abused his constitutional rights. On Tuesday, in Minneci v. Pollard, the court heard the government and others contend that a prisoner held in a facility operated by a private contractor cannot bring this kind of action.

headline: Arms Flying Into Somalia for Militants, Kenya Says
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The Kenyan government said Tuesday that aircraft were delivering weapons to Islamist insurgents in southern Somalia, widening the international nature of a war that has already engulfed several African nations.

headline: Vital Drugs in Short Supply
text: President Obama has issued an executive order that takes reasonable, if modest, steps to ease disruptions in the supply of certain important drugs. Congress could address the problem even more aggressively by passing legislation that has been languishing for months.

headline: Federal Inquiry of MF Global Escalates
text: Federal officials are escalating an investigation into MF Global, the bankrupt brokerage firm run by Jon S. Corzine, as the search continues for roughly $600 million in missing customer money.

headline: The Widening Gyre
text: Once in a great while, a beachcomber in Hawaii or the Pacific Northwest will find treasure: a lustrous sphere of translucent green glass, sometimes as big as a basketball. It is a Japanese fishing float, which had worked loose from a rope net and circled the Pacific Ocean for years before wind and current finally nudged it to shore.

headline: Drug Terms Reduced, Freeing Prisoners
text: There are some big meals on the way for Darryl Flood.

headline: Wednesday: Elegantly Dressed Bloke
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — It always gives me a little thrill (O.K., it’s more of a big thrill) when people I get to know as solvers make the big leap into crossword construction and eventually get published here in The New York Times. Seeing your name in the byline is different from anything else you can experience. Why, I remember back in the day when I had my first puzzle published, blah blah blah fame, glory and untold riches yada yada yada it’s really not about you, Deb. Stay focused on the story.

headline: Teenage Motherhood Is Serious, Especially With Baby Bling at Play
text: The three young women chirping away like baby birds in a feathered nest in the opening scene of “Milk Like Sugar,” a provocative new play by Kirsten Greenidge that opened on Tuesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, don’t seem to have much of anything special on their minds. With blinged-out cellphones clutched permanently in elaborately manicured hands, they are killing time in a tattoo parlor, exchanging texts with boys, arguing over whose phone is the coolest (“Slider phones are kaput”), and what’s the best kind of ink to be getting: a rose or a ladybug?

headline: Austerity Faces Test as Greeks Question Their Ties to Euro
text: PARIS — The crisis of the euro zone has finally hit the potholed road of real politics, with the Greeks now openly questioning whether their commitment to Europe and its single currency still matters more to them than control over their own future and economic well-being.

headline: Cain Not Able
text: WASHINGTON

headline: For Whistle-Blower in Medicaid Suit, Finding Guidance in Parents and Capra
text: It has not always been a wonderful life for Dr. Gabriel Ethan Feldman. He has been bankrupt, unemployed and penniless. He has been forced to move back to his mother’s house. At this very moment, he lives in a 275-square-foot rent-stabilized studio apartment in a frumpy building on the Upper West Side.

headline: Co-op Ends Fight With City Over Its East Side Backyard
text: An exclusive East Side co-op has released its ownership claim on a 10,000-square-foot patch of its elevated backyard overlooking the East River, ending a decade-long boundary dispute with the city.

headline: A Long List of Suckers
text: Agra, India

headline: Dismal Tale of Arrest for Tiniest of Crimes
text: The arresting officer came by the cell, Samantha Zucker said, to make snide remarks about finding her with a friend in Riverside Park after its 1 a.m. closing.

headline: United They Stand, Huge Fine Aside
text: Micky Arison employs two of the N.B.A.’s most electrifying talents. They came two wins short of the championship last June. Their arena is packed every night. Arison’s wildly profitable franchise, the Miami Heat, is worth an estimated $425 million.

headline: A Silver Lining to America’s Waning Influence
text: WASHINGTON — President Hu Jintao of China will arrive in Cannes, France, this week pondering a plea from Europe for tens of billions of dollars to help the continent get out of its debt crisis. And President Obama will arrive with a smile, some hearty handshakes, and his own plea: that Greece get its act together and that Europe fix its economic ills, which he has called one of the biggest drags on the United States’ own ailing economy.

headline: Corruption Trial Opens for Lawmaker From Brooklyn Political Family
text: An assemblyman from one of Brooklyn’s most prominent political families struck a secret deal to use his influence in Albany on behalf of a hospital chief executive in return for a sham consulting job that paid him about $175,000, a federal prosecutor said Tuesday.

headline: Stone-Washed Blue Jeans (Minus the Washed)
text: SAN FRANCISCO   —  From the cotton field in rural India to the local rag bin, a typical pair of blue jeans consumes 919 gallons of water during its life cycle, Levi Strauss & Company says, or enough to fill about 15 spa-size bathtubs. That includes the water that goes into irrigating the cotton crop, stitching the jeans together and washing them scores of times at home.

headline: The Pawlenty Surge Was Never Coming
text: With several Republican candidates struggling in the nomination race and no Chris Christie or Mitch Daniels to save them, those underwhelmed by the current field have instead turned their attention toward the one who already dropped out: Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota.

headline: Deficit Panel Is Warned That It Must Not Fail and Is Urged to Compromise
text: WASHINGTON — A co-chairman of President Obama’s fiscal commission told members of a powerful Congressional panel on deficit reduction Tuesday that he feared they would fail, and he said the consequences of such failure could be calamitous.

headline: Long Dodgers Ordeal May Soon Be Over
text: The battle over the Los Angeles Dodgers spanned the entire baseball season.

headline: In Corzine Comeback, Big Risks and Steep Fall
text: When Jon S. Corzine joined MF Global last year it seemed like a strange choice — the firm had none of the glamour, let alone the profits or footprint of Goldman Sachs, the bank he ran during the 1990s.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Russia Stays Transfixed by a Switch at Birth
text: MOSCOW — For several weeks, Russian television has followed the story of two 12-year-olds in the Siberian city of Kopeysk: pale, light-eyed Anya, who is being raised by a Tajik man according to the precepts of Islam; and black-haired Irina, the beloved daughter of an ethnically Russian blond woman.

headline: K.K.R. in Talks With Samson Investment
text: After a string of smaller deals in the oil patch over the last two years, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is gearing up for a potential blockbuster takeover.

headline: Citi Field Fits In With History of Ballpark Changes
text: When the Mets alter the playing dimensions at Citi Field — installing new outfield fences closer to home plate — the changes will symbolize an admission that the club, after enduring three seasons of grief and long flyouts, had erred in its original design.

headline: When Each Bad Storm Means More Dark Days
text: First came the heavy snow in February that crushed the hangar and destroyed the vintage Piper J-5A airplane he housed in Dutchess County, N.Y. Then came the tornado in June that ripped out an ancient oak tree in his backyard in Roxbury, Conn. When Tropical Storm Irene blew through in August, another huge oak fell — this time on his house, blasting a hole through a back bedroom. In each case, electricity was lost.

headline: Challenges Facing Leaders in the European Debt Crisis
text: Leaders of European countries face new challenges in the debt crisis.

headline: Afghanistan and Pakistan Agree on Joint Inquiry Into Envoy’s Murder
text: ISTANBUL — Afghan and Pakistani leaders agreed on Tuesday to conduct a joint investigation into the assassination in September of the leader of Afghanistan’s peace process.

headline: As Polls Slip, Perry Gets First Bounty of ‘Super PAC’ Ads
text: A new “super PAC” co-founded by Gov. Rick Perry’s onetime chief of staff has begun running campaign ads in Iowa and South Carolina, marking the first advertising by a major super PAC in the Republican presidential primary and serving as a reminder of the Texas governor’s formidable financial resources despite his recent slide in the polls.

headline: Spurring Growth on Boston’s Waterfront
text: BOSTON — When Vertex Pharmaceuticals agreed this year to move into an as-yet-unbuilt waterfront office complex, it made history as the city’s largest commercial lease at 1.1 million square feet, with a rent of $72.5 million a year. But more important for the city over all, the huge deal has spurred growth and eased the way for financing other projects.

headline: To Survive, Medical Companies in New Jersey Are Building New Hospitals
text: HOPEWELL, N.J. — The dazzling new hospital that will open here on Sunday looks more like a five-star resort than a medical center. It may also be the best hope for survival of its corporate parent, Capital Health, a nonprofit company that operates three health care facilities in New Jersey.

headline: Turkey: Activists Ordered Held
text: An Istanbul court on Tuesday ordered the detention of more than 20 pro-Kurdish political activists, including a prominent political science professor and a leading human rights activist, on terrorism-related charges. The move was criticized by a pro-Kurdish political party and hundreds of intellectuals who issued a joint statement calling the arrests “a heavy blow against the efforts to achieve real democracy within equality, peace, social justice, as well as academic and political freedoms.” The suspects denied that they were members of the outlawed Kurdistan Workers’ Party, or P.K.K. The arrests come as a major military offensive in pursuit of Kurdish militants based in Iraq continues. The government has been debating constitutional changes to help the Kurds.

headline: The Big East Is on the Verge of Adding New Members
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Big East, in a effort to pull the conference back from the brink, moved to extend invitations to several universities after a unanimous vote by the league presidents at their annual meeting Tuesday.

headline: 4 Georgia Men Arrested in Terror Plot
text: Four Georgia men who were part of a fringe militia group were arrested on Tuesday in what the Justice Department described as a plot to use guns, bombs and the toxin ricin to kill federal and state officials and spread terror.

headline: Britain: Tabloid Records Published
text: British lawmakers published internal documents from Rupert Murdoch’s now-defunct tabloid The News of the World on Tuesday, raising further questions over the extent to which the phone hacking scandal there was covered up. The documents, unearthed during Parliamentary investigations into allegations the tabloid illegally intercepted the voice mails of thousands of newsworthy figures, include e-mails between senior executives at the British arm of Mr. Murdoch’s global media empire and their lawyers.

headline: Credit Where It's Due
text: Ben Roethlisberger's off-the-field behavior has tarnished his on-the-field success, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: Colombia: Spy Agency Dissolved
text: President Juan Manuel Santos dissolved the country’s main intelligence agency, the sprawling Administrative Department of Security, or DAS, after a series of scandals that severely damaged the agency’s credibility. DAS illegally spied on human rights activists, judges and political leaders, and its former spymaster, Jorge Noguera, was recently convicted of collaborating with paramilitary assassination squads in the murder of a prominent scholar. Mr. Santos, above, in an executive order issued late Monday, said about 3,000 DAS employees would migrate to the attorney general’s office, while the Interior Ministry, National Police and Foreign Ministry would absorb almost 2,000 other employees. A new intelligence agency is to be created.

headline: Iran: Finance Chief Survives Vote
text: Iran’s finance minister survived a vote in Parliament on Tuesday to remove him from office over the country’s banking scandal, the state-run Islamic Republic News Agency reported. More than two dozen lawmakers had submitted a motion to impeach the minister, Shamseddin Hosseini, an ally of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad who oversaw country’s economy during the time Iranian authorities have said a record $2.6 billion banking fraud occurred. Mr. Ahmadinejad’s conservative critics have tried to link his close associates to the alleged fraud. It was unclear what affect the vote would have on Parliament’s request to summon Mr. Ahmadinejad himself for questioning.

headline: A Fateful Stop for Candy for a Helper to So Many
text: There have never been enough causes for Marion Salmon Hedges, but always enough time.

headline: Video: Credit Where It’s Due
text: Ben Roethlisberger’s off-the-field behavior has tarnished his on-the-field success, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: Markets Rebound but Remain on Edge
text: Stocks pushed higher Wednesday as investors weathered continued uncertainty over the sovereign debt crisis in Europe and a lowered growth forecast for the United States.

headline: Florida: Miami Beach Mayor Wins Another Term
text: Matti Herrera Bower was re-elected Miami Beach mayor Tuesday, winning a final term before she retires in two years. Ms. Bower, 72, a former dental assistant and longtime Miami Beach commissioner, was first elected mayor in 2007. She faced three challengers, including Steve Berke, a comedian who ran on a pro-marijuana, pro-casino, pro-economic development platform. Ms. Bower, who had the support of police officers and firefighters, won nearly 60 percent of the vote. Mr. Berke was second, with 23 percent of the vote.

headline: Plane Lands in Poland Without Landing Gear
text: An LOT Polish Airlines flight slid into a Warsaw airport on its belly on Tuesday, sparks flying and smoke hissing, crash landing onto the runway without the aid of its landing gear, which refused to drop.

headline: Gilbert Cates, Producer of Oscar Shows, Dies at 77
text: LOS ANGELES — Gilbert Cates, a director and producer who shaped Hollywood’s labor relations through the Directors Guild of America and its glamour scene through a record 14 Oscar telecasts, died here on Monday. He was 77.

headline: Degas Ballerina Among the Works Unsold at Christie’s
text: Against a backdrop of reeling financial markets and nervous collectors, paintings and sculptures by Degas and Picasso, Matisse and Giacometti went unsold at Christie’s on Tuesday night.

headline: Tom Keith, Creator of Radio Soundscapes, Dies at 64
text: For more than 30 years Tom Keith conjured animals, gunshots, screeching tires, even a man falling into piranha-infested waters, for a live national audience that reached nearly four million, using only his vocal cords and an array of props.

headline: Curbing Holiday Weight Gain With Exercise
text: The next few months, filled with holiday feasting, represent a dire threat to most people’s waistlines. Even those of us who normally eat a wholesome diet can find ourselves gorging on fatty, high-calorie foods and gaining the annual Christmas inner tube. But several new studies promote a simple and effective response: Run or walk from the buffet. Even if you’ve already overindulged, the studies suggest, exercise can lessen or reverse the unwelcome consequences.

headline: Arizona Governor and Senate Oust Redistricting Leader
text: PHOENIX — Arizona’s Senate on Tuesday night ousted the chairwoman of the citizens’ commission charged with redrawing political boundaries, igniting a fierce legal battle over whether the state’s Republican leaders were interfering in a redistricting process that voters sought to insulate from politics.

headline: Word of the Day | wallow
text: wallow •\ˈwä-(ˌ)lo\• verb and noun

headline: Dorothy Rodham Dies at 92
text: Dorothy Rodham was a powerful influence on the life and career of her daughter, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Bloggingheads: Herman Cain’s Blackness
text: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate race and Herman Cain.

headline: Beryl Davis, British Singer With Big Bands, Dies at 87
text: Beryl Davis, a British singer who was beloved in England for carrying on with her cabaret performances during the bombing of London in World War II, and who later performed with Frank Sinatra and the big bands of Benny Goodman and Glenn Miller, died on Friday in Los Angeles. She was 87.

headline: Fisher Fights Back Against Reports
text: A day after defending his honor in a letter to N.B.A. players, the union president Derek Fisher issued another statement Tuesday, this time denouncing news reports that accused him of betraying the union’s trust.

headline: Leaders Reflect on Highs and Lows
text: Michael R. Bloomberg, Edward I. Koch and David N. Dinkins spoke Tuesday at a breakfast event in Midtown Manhattan. Here are some highlights:

headline: NYT Front Page for 11/02/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 11/02/2011

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
text: Pakistani cricketers Salman Butt and Mohammad Asif were found guilty Tuesday of taking bribes to fix part of a match against England during the Lord’s Test last August. A third cricketer, Mohammad Amir has already pleaded guilty but this was not reported earlier since he was only at 18 at the time (The Hindu). Mr. Butt and Mr. Asif face up to seven years in jail or large fines. The case followed a sting operation by the now defunct News of the World newspaper (The Indian Express).

headline: God Plans, Man Laughs
text: LONDON — God walked into the nave in high heels and dictated tweets to an angel. Ruth and Naomi held hands and kissed. A voice spoke from a tomb. Men and women challenged Him and weren’t struck down. There were trysts in chapels; a man was imprisoned beside the cloisters; somewhere a Bearded Lady was breaking a Strongman’s heart. This was Westminster Abbey on Oct. 21, when it played host to a 12-hour performance of Sixty-Six Books, a collection of monologues, songs, and short plays commissioned by the Bush Theatre for the 400th anniversary of the King James Bible.

headline: Agreeing to Sell, McCourt Gives Dodgers Fans Hope
text: First, Frank McCourt tried to buy his hometown Boston Red Sox. Then he sought the Anaheim Angels. Finally, in late 2003, McCourt, a land developer, triumphed: he and his wife, Jamie, bought the Los Angeles Dodgers for $430 million.

headline: Hyper-Connected: Video from the India Ink Launch Party
text: At an Oct. 31 event, guests and speakers talked about change transforming the United States and India.

headline: Corrections: November 2
text: NATIONAL

headline: Nov. 2, 1976 | Carter Defeats Ford in Presidential Election
text: On Nov. 2, 1976, Jimmy Carter defeated the Republican incumbent Gerald R. Ford, becoming the first United States president from the Deep South since the Civil War.

headline: Archbishop of Canterbury Urges Debate of Tax on Bankers
text: LONDON — A day after St. Paul’s Cathedral suspended legal action to evict hundreds of anti-capitalist protesters camped outside its doors, the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, the archbishop of Canterbury and the spiritual leader of the world’s Anglicans, was quoted on Wednesday as expressing sympathy for their cause.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 2, 2011
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the Economix blog post, “Kardashianomics.”

headline: Satirical Magazine Is Firebombed in Paris
text: PARIS — The office of a French satirical magazine here was badly damaged by a firebomb early on Wednesday, the publisher said, after it published a spoof issue “guest edited” by the Prophet Muhammad to salute the victory of an Islamist party in Tunisian elections. The publication also said hackers had disrupted its Web site.

headline: Behind the Scenes With Scorsese
text: Photographs from Martin Scorsese’s first movie in 3-D, “Hugo.”

headline: Martin Scorsese’s Magical ‘Hugo’
text: Last year, Martin Scorsese began working on a film version of “The Invention of Hugo Cabret,” a graphic novel by Brian Selznick about a 12-year-old orphan named Hugo who lives inside the walls of a 1930s Paris train station. Hugo (Asa Butterfield) oils and maintains the station clocks while guarding a magnificent secret: a broken-down automaton and a notebook, left by his father (Jude Law), with incomplete instructions on how to bring it to life. An encounter with a bitter toy salesman and his goddaughter (Chloë Moretz) leads Hugo into the world of the real-life magician and grandfather of science-fiction film-making, Georges Méliès (Ben Kingsley). Scorsese talks about updating Méliès’s celluoid fantasies a century later — and in 3-D.

headline: Looking for Gold in a Distant Jungle
text: RIO DE JANEIRO – Squeezed between the Pacific Ocean and the Andes, covered by thick, forbidding jungle and drenched by so much rain that it’s among the wettest places on Earth, the Colombian region of Chocó was described by the anthropologist Michael Taussig as “one of the most remote regions of the world.”

headline: Champions League Wednesday Preview: Real Madrid Looks to Keep Rolling
text: Real Madrid will try to join Barcelona in the Round of 16 of the Champions League, because heaven forbid one of the Spanish rivals be able to claim something the other cannot. (A.C. Milan also advanced to the knockout stage on Tuesday, and Benfica and Bayern Munich can go through with the right results on Wednesday.)

headline: Celebrating the 7 Billionth
text: This edition of 6 Q’s About the News draws from a variety of recent Times articles and features about world population. Each question links to the place in which an answer for it can be found.

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 2, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: British Court Says WikiLeaks Founder Can Be Extradited for Questioning
text: LONDON — A British court ruled Wednesday that Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, can be extradited to Sweden for questioning over allegations of sexual abuse made against him by two women there last year. He will seek a final appeal at Britain’s highest court, according to a person close to him.

headline: Do You Have Good Manners?
text: An article laments the decline of civility in the southern United States, a region where manners were once considered an important cultural marker. How would you define “good manners”? Do you agree with those who say that civility in general is declining everywhere? Do you think you have good manners yourself?

headline: Numbers Aside, India’s Newborns Face Challenges
text: Usha Kumar’s wails sounded like the cries of a wounded animal, guttural and wrenching, her screams seeping through the corridor of Kasturba Hospital in Delhi, until, finally, mercifully, Ms. Kumar pushed out her baby boy.

headline: New Video Attacks Romney
text: Priorities USA Action, the pro-Obama super PAC, is marking the start of the yearlong countdown to Election Day 2012 by releasing a video entirely devoted to attacking former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts, painting him as a cold-hearted businessman disconnected from the pain of ordinary Americans.

headline: How Unemployment Benefits Became Twice as Generous
text: 12:48 p.m. | Updated  to revise reference to standard benefit period.

headline: Tavares’s Contract Extension: How the Deal Got Done
text: Slap Shot contributor Christopher Botta recently interviewed Pat Brisson, of the Creative Artists Agency, on his offseason negotiations with the New York Islanders on a six-year contract extension for John Tavares. Here’s their conversation:

headline: Paris Exhibit Showcases Unusual Medium: Wool
text: Glance quickly at some of the items on display at La Maison du Danemark and you might think you just saw a gun, a pair of high heels, a set of dice. Look closer, though, and you’ll see that the works are made of an unlikely material: everything is wool.

headline: Week 8 Film Review: Giants’ Offense Lacks Balance
text: A closer look at three games from Week 8, with the benefit of film review:Giants O vs. Dolphins D

headline: The Early Word: Pressure
text: Today’s Times

headline: Chief of Lloyds Banking Group Takes Medical Leave
text: 5:39 p.m. | Updated

headline: Greek Premier Pledges Vote in December on Debt Deal
text: CANNES, France — Prime Minister George A. Papandreou of Greece emerged from a meeting with Europe’s leaders here on Wednesday pledging to hold a referendum on a new European debt deal on Dec. 4 or 5.

headline: With $600 Million Building, John Jay College Gains a Whole Campus
text: For nearly 50 years, the John Jay College of Criminal Justice has made do with secondhand space, scattered through an odd variety of buildings, with nothing like a campus to unite its 15,000 students. Its visual identity has been that of an old high school — a distinguished old high school, to be sure, but an old high school all the same.

headline: Mounting Woes Prompt Sony to Predict Another Annual Loss
text: TOKYO — A strong yen, flooding in Thailand and tepid sales in the United States and Europe all conspired to knock Sony to a net loss for the latest quarter, putting the company on course for a fourth unprofitable year in a row.

headline: Comcast Posts 4.7% Profit, With Mixed Results From NBCUniversal Acquisition

headline: Now Playing | ‘Parallax,’ the New Album by Atlas Sound
text: Inscrutable? Cryptic? Finding the right word to describe Bradford Cox is not easy. The Atlanta-based musician, lead singer of the popular indie rock band Deerhunter and mastermind behind the more esoteric solo project Atlas Sound, is tall and lanky and moves with a long, excited gait thanks to a genetic condition of the connective tissue called Marfan Syndrome. He’s gone through wild periods of provocation involving onstage cross-dressing and fake blood. He’s written song lyrics inspired by subversive Dennis Cooper novels. Spending time with him is a roller coaster ride that sweeps those around him up through various random-seeming whims and high-strung emotions. Despite all of this, or more likely because of all this, he is prolific with at least eleven albums and EPs to his name since 2005. His latest album, “Parallax,” released under his solo moniker, further proves Cox’s lo-fi genius, showcasing his deftness at weaving multilayered lyrics through harmonizing electronic tones and across undulating beats to create catchy but complex pop songs. It’s worth noting that the album’s title refers to the optical effect wherein our perceptions of various objects’ relative positions depend on our distance from them — if you drive down a highway, the tree line whizzes past while faraway objects like the sun barely move at all. It’s one of those facts in nature that seems intuitive and yet, upon examination, gets quite confusing quite fast. The same can be said of Cox’s songs. Here we present an exclusive stream of the complete “Parallax” album (out next week, Nov. 8, from 4AD), along with a few words from Cox explaining the meaning of and inspiration behind four of his favorite songs — explanations he offers in his own signature fashion, without making any distinction between the technical, musical, literary or lyrical aspects of his work.

headline: Fossil Teeth Put Humans in Europe Earlier Than Thought
