headline: A Look at the Films in DOC NYC
text: DOC NYC, a film festival that rounds up some of the year’s most notable documentaries, returns to two Manhattan locations, the IFC Center and the Skirball Center at New York University. The festival, which runs through Nov. 10, features an array of documentaries, from possible Oscar contenders to works covering well-known figures. Above is a look at a selection of films from the schedule. Tickets and showtimes can be found at the festival’s Web site.

headline: In Every Note, the Pangs of the Heart
text: Every emotion is larger than life in the songs of Evanescence, the band that performed at Terminal 5 on Tuesday night with its first studio album since 2006, “Evanescence” (Wind-up), which reached No. 1 on the Billboard chart for a week. The death of a loved one, the breakup of a romance or a crisis of self-doubt all send Amy Lee’s voice aloft, to wail with unbridled drama while her band thrashes and roars. “I’m everything you can’t control/Somewhere beyond the pain there must be a way to believe,” she sang as the set opened with “What You Want,” the new album’s first single.

headline: Guilty Verdict for Russian in Arms Trial
text: Viktor Bout, a former Soviet Air Force officer who became known as the “Merchant of Death” for running what American officials have described as an international arms-trafficking network, was found guilty on Wednesday of conspiring to sell antiaircraft missiles and other weapons to men he believed were Colombian terrorists intent on killing Americans.

headline: A Reward for Bird-Friendly Buildings

headline: An Insider Intro to Performa 11
text: If insider repartee about the art world served up by two accomplished British actors is your idea of a good time, then Performa 11 got off to a brisk start on Tuesday night. The fourth incarnation of the visual art performance biennial founded in 2005 by the art historian-impresario RoseLee Goldberg opened at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts at New York University (one of scores of venues) with the American premiere of “Happy Days in the Art World,” a short three-act play by the Scandinavian performance-art duo Michael Elmgreen and Ingar Dragset, directed by Toby Frow. (It is among several works commissioned for Performa and will be performed again on Thursday night.)

text: Thanks to Mitt Romney, we know that corporations are people. But should that also mean that a big business gets to file lawsuits anonymously under the name of “Company Doe”?

headline: Diagnosis Cancer: Creating Fact Sheets About Screening, Prevention and Treatment
text: Overview | In this lesson, students consider their knowledge about and associations with cancer. After reading up on new recommendations to limit cancer screenings, they develop patient fact sheets about cancer, focusing on treatments and screening techniques.

headline: Purging Cells in Mice Is Found to Combat Aging Ills
text: In a potentially fundamental advance, researchers have opened up a novel approach to combating the effects of aging with the discovery that a special category of cells, known as senescent cells, are bad actors that promote the aging of the tissues. Cleansing the body of the cells, they hope, could postpone many of the diseases of aging.

headline: Fantasy Politics
text: Americans must be the most polled people in the world. Every morning’s news brings at least half a dozen headlines purporting to tell me how the public feels about their government, or other people’s governments, or maybe other people’s pets. My favorites, for sheer entertainment, are the ones that present completely hypothetical situations.

headline: After Storm, Some Early Decision Deadlines Are Extended
text: The freak snowstorm that swept the Northeast last weekend left many families without electricity at a particularly inconvenient time — just as early applications were due.

headline: Red Bulls Supporters Go Big and Loud
text: In case you missed it, there was a party going on in the New York Red Bulls supporters section this season. A collection of drums, megaphones, smoke bombs, flags, and hundreds of passionate fans make up what is known as the South Ward, populated by the Red Bulls’ most boisterous proponents. And for 90 minutes of every Red Bulls home game, they create one of the most festive and vociferous atmospheres in American soccer.

headline: ‘X Factor’ Gets a 2nd Season on Fox
text: Fox’s new singing competition, “The X Factor,” has won a second season. The network said Wednesday that it would bring the series back next year, potentially extending the scheduling pattern that features “X Factor” in the fall and “American Idol” in the spring.

headline: With 2012 Lineup, Coil Festival Gets ‘Real’
text: A new work about feminism from the downtown playwright Young Jean Lee and a show that incorporates music from the band Of Montreal are among the productions to be presented in January at Performance Space 122’s Coil festival of contemporary performance. The seventh annual event will run from Jan. 5-29, 2012, at multiple locations across New York City.

headline: Graphic Content | ‘Eames Words’
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Next Steps in the Investigation of MF Global
text: With the Federal Bureau of Investigation looking into possible missing customer money at MF Global, executives of the now-bankrupt commodities and securities firm will be hiring lawyers and dealing with questions that go beyond just how the firm will be liquidated. The issue of whether there were any financial improprieties means the government will be digging through the firm’s books to see where the money went, and whether any records or reports were falsified.

headline: Santorum, in Iowa, Questions the Focus on Perry
text: WILLIAMSBURG, Iowa — Rick Santorum, the former Pennsylvania senator, said he was frustrated that the national news media had focused so much attention during the Republican presidential race on Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, even though Mr. Perry has been scoring well below the front-runners in recent polls.

headline: Fears of Fission Rise at Stricken Japanese Plant
text: TOKYO — Nuclear workers at the crippled Fukushima power plant raced to inject boric acid into the plant’s No. 2 reactor early Wednesday after telltale radioactive elements were detected there, and the plant’s owner admitted for the first time that fuel deep inside three stricken reactors was probably continuing to experience bursts of fission.

headline: Obama Taunts G.O.P.  for Ignoring Jobs Bill
text: President Obama on Wednesday visited another bridge in need of repair – this one somewhat closer to home, between Washington and Virginia — to promote his job-creation proposals as the Senate began the latest partisan debate over his plans.

headline: The Buzz
text: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

headline: Libya's War of Lies
text: C.J. Chivers reports on the war of misinformation and propaganda by both loyalists and rebels in the Libyan conflict earlier this year.

headline: The World’s Condom, Electricity and Climate Divides
text: Our fine Economix blog has a post up on the new Human Development Report from the United Nations (Twitter feed). The trends are mainly good in the word’s most struggling places — reprising findings from a year ago. But the report’s authors stress that human-driven climate change could easily derail progress in the world’s least developed places.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 47
text: Updated, 5:07 p.m. | A Zuccotti Park kitchen worker was arrested Wednesday afternoon in connection with two sexual assaults at Occupy Wall Street. [Metropolis]

headline: ‘Harry Potter’ Leads Time Warner to Sharp Gain
text: Helped by the final “Harry Potter” film, Time Warner reported a sharp rise in its quarterly earnings on Wednesday and a record quarter at its film unit, Warner Brothers.

headline: A Historic Home in the Center of Bruges
text: This four-story three-bedroom home, draped in vines and dating to 1895, is on the market for $1.35 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Belgium
text: A HISTORIC HOME IN THE CENTER OF BRUGES

headline: The Once and Future Way to Run
text: When you’re stalking barefoot runners, camouflage helps. “Some of them get kind of prancy when they notice you filming,” Peter Larson says. “They put on this notion of what they think barefoot running should be. It looks weird.” Larson, an evolutionary biologist at Saint Anselm College in New Hampshire who has been on the barefoot beat for two years now, is also a stickler about his timing. “You don’t want to catch them too early in a run, when they’re cold, or too late, when they’re tired.”

headline: Propaganda in a Time of War
text: This video shows one man’s fast-moving effort to generate propaganda in war. Shot during the long-running battle for the Libyan town of Brega in the spring, it presents a doctor working with anti-Qaddafi forces in Ajdabiya as he displayed items he had removed from the pockets of a freshly killed Qaddafi soldier. The doctor then used these items to try to convince two journalists that the soldier was a paid mercenary and that he had been carrying “exploding bullets” in battle.

headline: Concerns About Labor Dispute Prompt Increased Security at Sotheby’s
text: With the world economy in such an uncertain state, Sotheby’s fall auction of Impressionist and modern art Wednesday night was bound to be tense anyway. But the auction house’s continuing contract dispute with its unionized art handlers – who have been locked out for three months and have been staging increasingly publicized demonstrations – recently prompted it to institute much stricter security measures surrounding the fall sale.

headline: Relief Is Slow to Reach Cambodia Flood Victims
text: BATTAMBANG, Cambodia — The high water is devastating even for a country inured to monsoon rains and waterlogged rice fields: wide swaths of Cambodia’s countryside have become giant lakes, with villagers and livestock marooned on scattered patches of dry land.

headline: Djibouti Adds 850 Soldiers to Peacekeeping Force in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The tiny country of Djibouti will send about 850 soldiers to an African Union peacekeeping mission in Somalia this month, a spokesman for the mission said Wednesday. It is only the third country to do so after a series of unmet promises from a number of African nations.

headline: Euro Crisis Shifts Mood for G-20
text: FRANKFURT — The Group of 20 summit meeting in Cannes was supposed to be a chance for Europe and the event’s host, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, to shine. Instead, the two-day meeting is coming at an extraordinarily dark time for the Continent, with Europe in political disarray, its economy tipping into recession and the future of the euro zone in doubt.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 2
text: A view of the day in sports, including Albert Pujols in bronze.

headline: Rethinking McGwire
text: It was hard to ignore Mark McGwire during the baseball post-season. His position at the near end of the dugout made him seem larger than life on the television.

headline: Arab League Says Syria Accepts Its Plan for Talks; Protesters Are Skeptical
text: CAIRO — Syria accepted an Arab League plan meant to halt violence and lead to dialogue with the opposition within two weeks, league officials announced Wednesday, but government opponents and others voiced doubt that Damascus could or would change tactics so abruptly.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Thailand, Ukraine and Yemen.

headline: College Majors Matter
text: We write a lot on Economix about whether college is worth it. In a piece in Investor’s Business Daily, Alex Tabarrok, an economics professor at George Mason University, suggests that Americans are focusing on the wrong question. They shouldn’t be debating whether college in general is “worth it”; they should instead be thinking about whether the specific college degree they’re considering is marketable.

headline: A Mind Is A Terrible Thing To Lose
text: OK, I see that some people are doubling down on the claim that rising inequality is all about education — when what the CBO report drives home is that this is all wrong, the big increase has come from gains at the very top. I have to admit that I have a sneaking suspicion that this is in part driven by KDS (DS for derangement syndrome): some people will rush to take a position precisely because I have debunked it. But anyway, it’s really, really wrong.

headline: TimesCast | Assange Extradition Possible
text: November 2, 2011 - Ravi Somaiya at a London courthouse, where judges ruled that WikiLeaks' founder, Julian Assange, can be extradited to Sweden.

headline: TimesCast | Supporting the Referendum
text: November 2, 2011 - Rachel Donadio reports from Athens, where Greece's prime minister is rallying more support for a referendum on Europe's aid package.

text: 5:48 p.m. | Updated

headline: Strike at US Foods Takes Aim at Private Equity
text: 7:00 p.m. | Updated

headline: Honors For Two City Groups, and a Visit With the First Lady
text: It's not everyday that schoolchildren from New York City get to visit the White House -- plus meet Michelle Obama. But it happened on Wednesday when students from two groups accepted the 2011 National Arts and Humanities Youth Program Award for their programs, which bring together students from across the city and enhance learning.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Thailand, Ukraine and Yemen.

headline: ‘New Girl’ and ‘Glee’ Return to Lineup but Fall Short
text: After a month of riding the pine in favor of playoff baseball, “New Girl” and “Glee” returned to the Fox lineup on Tuesday night, only to be welcomed by diminished audiences. Both shows fell 18 percent in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic compared with their last new episodes, on Oct. 4. “New Girl” was accompanied by a series low of 7.5 million total viewers, while “Glee” dropped to 7.4 million (although “Glee” had shown signs of audience deterioration even before the break).

headline: On Location | Azores
text: Pedro Correia and his wife, Graça, were looking for a dream home for their expanding family on São Miguel Island in the Azores.

headline: Johns Hopkins Student Applies Dark Energy to the Black Art of Racing
text: The team that won the 2011 American Le Mans Series Drivers’ and Team Championships was a bit different than most. In addition to engineers, mechanics, drivers and pit crew, Dyson Racing also retained the services of Dillon Brout, a college student.

headline: A Dream Home Almost a Decade in the Making
text: SÃO MIGUEL ISLAND, THE AZORES — Pedro Correia and his wife, Graça, had lived their entire lives on São Miguel, the largest of nine volcanic islands in the Azorean archipelago. They were content for many years with their two-bedroom bungalow on the north coast of this lush island pocked with cobalt crater lakes and overrun with hydrangeas. But with a growing family and a tight-knit clan of about 50 relatives to entertain, the couple decided about decade ago that it was time to build a larger home.

headline: The Civil Wars: Billie Jean
text: Just because.

headline: What Money Can Buy
text: Million-dollar horses make headlines, but these days, that’s mostly when they pass through the sales ring. In the winner’s circle, a decidedly more blue-collar group is taking home the cash. At this year’s Prix de l’Arc de Triomphe, the most prestigious and richest race on the European calendar, a crowd of more than 50,000 was stunned into silence when Danedream, a cheap filly from Germany, crossed the line well in front of millions of dollars worth of allegedly the world’s finest bloodstock. Danedream was purchased as a yearling for just 9,000 euros (or around $12,500). Her earnings now top 2 million euros.

headline: Woman Who Accused Cain Won’t Go Public, Lawyer Says
text: 8:40 p.m. | Updated Joel P. Bennett, the lawyer for one of the women who has made accusations against Mr. Cain, said that his client had decided not to go public or to make a public statement herself in an effort to shield herself from the media frenzy swirling around the situation.

headline: The Overblown Islamist Threat
text: Washington

headline: Artifacts | Spartacus Chetwynd’s Monster Divas
text: Desperately seeking an antidote to the slick over-professionalism that is flat-lining contemporary art? Look no farther than Spartacus Chetwynd, a 38-year-old British performance artist whose insistently awkward productions are as comic-heroic as her adopted first name.

headline: Rocking Like Clapton, on Batteries
text: You might not suppose that, after more than a thousand years, there’s much room for improvement in the noble guitar. Apart from an electric spinoff about 80 years ago, it’s pretty much always been the same: a body, a neck and six strings.

headline: Not Following the ‘Leader’
text: Almost everywhere I’ve traveled this fall, people have asked me whether it’s true that Justice Clarence Thomas is the real, if under-appreciated, intellectual leader of the Supreme Court.

headline: A Congregation in Skinny Jeans
text: ONE recent Sunday night on the south side of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a crowd of more than 100 men and women in their 20s and early 30s gathered.

headline: Israel Tests a Long-Range Missile
text: JERUSALEM — Israel tested what experts said was a long-range ballistic missile on Wednesday morning, firing it out to sea from an Air Force base just south of Tel Aviv and causing jittery Israelis who saw the launch on their way to work to jam emergency lines.

headline: Commemorating Mussolini
text: Italian authorities sought to hide the burial site of Benito Mussolini after he died, in 1945. But the grave’s location rapidly became a matter of intense interest.

headline: Amtrak Expands Wi-Fi Service on East Coast Routes
text: On Monday, Amtrak expanded its free Wi-Fi service, adding wireless Internet connectivity to 12 East Coast train routes.

headline: Mobile Game Favorites of the Experts, of All Ages
text: With well over 50,000 mobile games on the market, shopping for a new one can be a game in itself.

headline: The One Best Way to Run
text: The best-selling book “Born to Run” popularized the notion of barefoot running, and as a result, scores of runners have given up cushioned shoes and opted to exercise barefoot or in barely-there running shoes. But as the book’s author, Christopher McDougall, explains in this week’s New York Times Magazine, many barefoot runners still don’t know how to run.

headline: The Rebirth of Cool in South Soho
text: Once devoid of retail, Soho has become a mecca for stylish shoppers.

headline: 12 Are Charged in Medicare Fraud Schemes Said to Cost $95 Million
text: Federal agents swarmed several medical clinics and homes in New York City on Wednesday, arresting 10 people on charges of running Medicare fraud schemes that bilked the government out of $95 million, federal officials said.

headline: Rangers to Keep Lineup; Avery Won’t Play
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Sean Avery will not play for the Rangers on Thursday, Coach John Tortorella said. But Avery is fine with that. He is simply happy to be back with the team.

headline: South SoHo, Hip’s Home on the Fringe
text: SOHO is dead. Long live SoHo.

headline: Tennessee Williams Play Set Nowhere Near the South
text: What really stands out about the title of Tennessee Williams’s late one-act “Now the Cats With Jewelled Claws” is not the stylish image, a menacing relative to that more vulnerable feline on a sweltering roof. It’s that unexpected first word. It’s urgent and oddly apt, evoking a ringmaster selling his next act.

headline: Distilling the Spirits of Sages
text: His quotes could belong to Christopher Hitchens. “Men face reality. Women don’t. That’s why men need to drink.”

headline: A Once-Peaceful Yemeni City Under Siege
text: While the violence in Taiz is just one piece of the complicated conflict that has torn apart this country over the past 10 months of political uprising, it is perhaps the most pertinent as Taiz once was a city where law, order and civil society once flourished more than in any other part of Yemen. Now its civilians live with urban warfare on a daily basis.

headline: Vogue Encyclo Is Looking for Contributors
text: Want to pitch a story idea to Vogue Italia?  Earlier this month, the venerable magazine started Vogue Encyclo, a kind of online fashion encyclopedia that invites users to contribute articles on fashion, designers, cinema and other topics, much like a wiki.  Vogue Italia editors will vet and assign ideas, with articles published on Vogue Encyclo with the user’s byline.

headline: Q&A: Locking Up a USB Drive
text: Q.

headline: Fox Renews ‘The X Factor’
text: Fox’s new singing competition, “The X Factor,” has won a second season. The network said on Wednesday that it would bring the series back next year, potentially extending “The X Factor” in the alternating annual schedule it has set up with “American Idol” (“Factor” in the fall, “Idol” in the spring). Regular telecasts of “The X Factor,” created by Simon Cowell, have averaged about 13.5 million viewers since the series started in September. It has sharply improved Fox’s performance on Wednesday and Thursday nights, but it has underwhelmed the television industry, partly because “Idol” is higher rated and partly because Mr. Cowell said ahead of time that he expected 20 million viewers to tune in. In an interview last week he said that he had overstated the ratings potential of the series but expected the ratings to pick up as the viewer voting period began on Wednesday night.

headline: Using Gmail’s Canned Responses
text: If you are tired of sending out the same e-mail response from your Gmail account — say, for an item on eBay that has already sold or directions to your party — the Canned Responses feature from Gmail Labs can save some time and typing. When you turn on the setting, you can save short messages and send them repeatedly as replies with a quick mouse click.

headline: An Opening for Some Song and Dance
text: Wanted: Singing, dancing, comedy, romance and, most of all, original music. When: By the end of April. Where: A Broadway theater, if available (a big if).

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,811 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

text: Prologue: Out of Print and Scared to Death

headline: 3 Prospective 2013 Candidates Find a Stage
text: Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, stressed the need to improve education and infrastructure while he criticized the Bloomberg administration‘s stop-and-frisk policing tactics and poor understanding, as he put it, of Albany.

headline: The China Conundrum
text: What seems at first glance a boon for American colleges and Chinese students is, on closer inspection, a tricky fit for both.

text: Lens: Abd

headline: South SoHo: One-Stop Shopping
text: ONE of the draws of SoSoHo is its motley assortment of shops, from fashion and high design to skateboards and scooters. There’s something fun for the whole family — in chic and slimming black, of course.

headline: After a World Title Is Lost, a Board to Scrutinize
text: When you lose a long match by 4.7 international match points, there will be several deals on which, in hindsight, you could have turned the result around. But the ones that come in for the closest scrutiny are those from the final session.

headline: All the Texts, Without All the Costs
text: Frank Radice, the former president of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences and now a media consultant, is a compulsive texter. But after racking up more than $1,000 in texting charges on a monthly mobile phone bill two years ago, he began searching for a less expensive way to communicate.

headline: Catch-22 Alive and Well in Guantanamo Bay
text: There are many reasons why it has been a horrible mistake to dump this country’s effective and tested federal court system in favor of an ineffective and untested system of military tribunals for prisoners suspected of terrorism – well actually for Muslim prisoners suspected of terrorism. One particularly compelling reason is that tribunals do not seem to have the authority to actually free defendants.

headline: Digital Diary: A Kindle Disconnect?
text: I just finished reading “The Marriage Plot,” Jeffrey Eugenides’s latest novel.

headline: Apple Admits Software Bugs Hurting Battery Life in iPhone
text: Apple has finally broken its silence on battery life of its latest iPhone, the 4S, saying software bugs in its latest operating system are causing the issues.

headline: Styled to a T | Mika Rottenberg
text: The Artist

headline: Now Showing | Mika Rottenberg
text: Mika Rottenberg’s video installations depict dreamlike assembly lines that parse animal, vegetable and mineral elements down to their base materialities, and, through strenuous, ritualized monotony, catalyze the production of weird junk: relatable daily circumstances for most of the world’s population. The Buenos Aires-born artist, raised in Israel and based in New York, casts her workers for their unusual corporeal commodities — jumbo figures, endless hair, freaky joints — and they often seem to perform their tasks without the knowledge of why, or of their ornate connections to one another.

headline: Shopping for Bathroom Faucets
text: The architect Katherine Chia searched for faucets with clean lines.

headline: Tropical Breeze, 2004
text: An excerpt from Mika Rottenberg's 2004 film, Tropical Breeze.

headline: Dough, 2005–2006
text: An excerpt from Mika Rottenberg's film, "Dough."

headline: Squeeze, 2010

headline: The High-Tech Home Office
text: WORKING from home has its charms. My home office is quiet (except when the baby stirs), there’s no dress code, I can choose my own music and I have my own executive washroom. The only downside is that my building’s super — my wife — won’t allow cigars.

headline: Bathroom Faucets
text: THE architect Katherine Chia usually spends her time thinking about buildings and interiors, but recently she has been focusing her attention on smaller-scale design. Her firm, Desai/Chia Architecture, which she runs with her husband, Arjun Desai, has been developing a line of bathroom fixtures.

headline: 21 High Schools Identified as 'Struggling'
text: After the release of high school progress reports last week, city Education Department officials identified 21 struggling high schools that, because of their low performance, could be closed or subject to other interventions beginning next year. That brings to 47 the number of schools deemed 'struggling.'

headline: Stuyvesant Students Mourn a Math Teacher Who Was No. 1
text: "Math is No. 1,'' Richard Geller, a math teacher at Stuyvesant High School, used to shout out to his students during class. On Wednesday the students wrote the phrase everywhere after they learned that Mr. Geller, who had taught at the school for 29 years, had died the day before.

headline: Cuomo Dangles Money for District Performance and Ideas
text: School districts across New York State could win as much as $75 million in grant money if they can prove to state education officials that they have been able to raise performance and have new ideas for further gains, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Wednesday.

headline: Sales at Chilewich, Desiron and Others
text: Many wallpapers are $3 a square foot during the  Trove sample sale, on Thursday from 1 to 7 p.m., and Friday, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. (Hundun, Nyx and Fuoco patterns, regularly $384 each for an 8-foot-by-3-foot roll, will be $72); 54 West 21st Street, Suite 507; (212) 268-2046 or troveline.com.

headline: Ayala Serfaty’s Light Sculptures on Display
text: The ethereal glass filament-and-polymer Soma light sculptures created by the Israeli designer Ayala Serfaty appear to be incredibly delicate, yet a handful of them has safely made the journey to Manhattan for her solo exhibition, “In Vein,” which opened this week at the Cristina Grajales Gallery.

headline: Global Table’s New Northern Outpost
text: After 15 years in SoHo, Global Table, the tabletop and home accessories store, is opening a second location, on the Upper West Side.

headline: A Barstool That Offers a Seat on the 50-Yard Line
text: GrassSit offers a fresh spin on the classic barstool. The stainless steel base is topped with ersatz grass recycled from local school football fields — sometimes complete with a yard line.

headline: In Karen Knorr’s Photography, an Ironic Sense of Place
text: Karen Knorr is an American photographer living in London who was born in Germany, grew up in Puerto Rico and went to art school in Paris and London. Fittingly, she has made a career out of examining the meaning of places: investigating rooms, houses and monuments, and using them to comment on taste, class, gender, art, history and literature. That sounds like an earnest business, except that Ms. Knorr’s images manage to be either wickedly funny or thunderously lovely, or both. In any case, it all began with real estate.

headline: From a Jail Cell, Egyptian Blogger Decries Military Rule
text: In an essay composed in a Cairo prison cell two days after he was detained for refusing to recognize the authority of a military prosecutor, a prominent Egyptian blogger and activist accused the country’s military rulers of “insolence.”

headline: A Minimalist Loft, With Touches of Chipotle
text: MARK CRUMPACKER, a branding expert who created the original Chipotle Mexican Grill logo in the 1990s, became the company’s chief marketing officer three years ago. His partner, Tim Wildin, is the corporate director of concept development, a job Mr. Crumpacker helped him land.

headline: Sheep Lawn Mowers, and Other Go-Getters
text: OBERLIN, Ohio

headline: College Graduates’ Debt Burden Grew, Yet Again, in 2010
text: Students who graduated from college in 2010 with student loans owed an average of $25,250, up 5 percent from the previous year, according to a report scheduled for release Thursday.

headline: From School to the Stage, the Fast Way
text: The pianist George Li is fresh faced even by the standards of the Young Concert Artists series, which presented him in his New York recital debut on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.

headline: Long Live the Pixies
text: So I happened to be in Portland, Me., last night, attending a concert by the Pixies at the State Theater. The band’s frontman, alternatively known as Black Francis and Frank Black, has said that these reunion shows are purely about cashing in on the band’s indie-rock credibility. However, having now seen them live, I can tell you that this is not the whole story. They simply played too well, and were too obviously moved by the unconditional love of the crowd, which cheered as vociferously for the B-sides as for the singles. Frank howled as ferociously as ever, and it was inspiring to see Kim Deal, the bass player, in such apparently sound mental and physical health. This I did not expect. In 2002, a story in this magazine by Ethan Smith detailed the problems, personal and otherwise, she had making a record for her other band, the Breeders. It included this memorable exchange between Kim and her twin sister, Kelley, who had been in and out of the band a few times:

headline: Egyptian Entrepreneur Shares Lessons From Her Playbook
text: DUBAI — When Hanan Abdel Meguid started her first technology company in Cairo nearly 20 years ago, the Web was not publicly available in the Middle East and many big global players like Microsoft did not operate there.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Our wood floors look worn. Is it worth the cost and disruption to refinish them before selling?

headline: Can Yahoo Be Rescued?
text: No foundering Internet giant has ever recovered. Will Yahoo go the way of AOL and MySpace?

headline: The Wilde Boys Salon, for Poetry or Maybe a Hot Date
text: A FEW weeks ago, a gaggle of young men gathered at a large, art-filled apartment on lower Fifth Avenue to discuss poetry. Stylishly disheveled and slimly tailored, they took stock of one another at the bar before settling into the parlor, which was tastefully furnished with books, Midcentury Modern chairs and a large painting by Jay Davis.

headline: Selling Chessy Rayner’s Treasures
text: When the legendary decorator Chessy Rayner died more than 13 years ago, she left behind several homes full of treasures. About 750 of those items will be available at the first estate sale on One Kings Lane, in a 72-hour online event that begins on Saturday at 11 a.m. Eastern time.

headline: In an L.A. Childhood, the First Mysteries
text: MY first memory and so, in some essential way, the beginning of my life starts with me on my knees in front of an old console television set. I was 3 years old and didn’t know where I was or even that the TV was there because my eyes were closed. There was a sense of excitement tingling in my shoulders and thrumming at the back of my head; an electricity that made me want to laugh out loud, but I didn’t laugh.

headline: A Minimalist Loft in Greenwich Village
text: Two Chipotle executives didn’t intend on creating a luxury version of the restaurant in their home, but colleagues have noticed connections.

headline: Google TV Redux and iPhone Battery Woes
text: Claire Cain Miller discusses the recent update to the Google TV software and Nick Wingfield reports on user complaints about the battery life of the iPhone 4S.

headline: Entrepreneurs Look to Sheep, Chickens and Vegetables
text: Sheep lawnmowers, chicken coops built to order in Brooklyn, and other small agricultural businesses.

headline: Browsing Shopping Snapshots: Nov. 3
text: Frank Pizzurro, the owner of Brooklyn Denim Co. answers questions; blankets are worn as ponchos; and shearling bags.

headline: Short Sainthood for Steve Jobs
text: THE glowing obituaries appeared moments after Steve Jobs’s death was announced on Oct. 5. “Silicon Valley’s radiant Sun King,” eulogized The San Jose Mercury News. His name was floated for Time magazine’s Person of the Year, though the honor traditionally goes to the living. Even Gawker, the snarky media blog, adopted the sober tone of a state funeral.

headline: When in Germany …
text: The United States men’s under-23 and under-20 national teams will hold training camps in Duisburg, Germany, from Nov. 7 to 16 at the Sportschule Wedau, a German sporting school.

headline: Running Game Looms Large for Alabama and L.S.U.
text: When Louisiana State played at Alabama two years ago, the game was so physical the Tigers were carting players off the field. The injured included running back Charles Scott, who broke his collarbone in the 24-15 loss.

headline: ‘Jersey Shore,’ Studied
text: To the Editor:

headline: 26 Nations Defy Europe on Airline Emissions
text: China, the United States and 24 other nations backed a declaration on Wednesday urging that their airlines be exempted from the European Union’s Emissions Trading System.

headline: Vonnegut in All His Complexity
text: Charles J. Shields got nowhere with Harper Lee when he tried to interview her for the 2006 biography “Mockingbird.” But he got lucky with Kurt Vonnegut. Mr. Shields found a lonely talkative octogenarian who had scores to settle and a reputation that badly needed restoring. Vonnegut had once told Martin Amis that the only way he could regain credit for his early work, those books from the 1950s and 1960s once so beloved by college kids, would be to die. He died on April 11, 2007, less than a year after Mr. Shields first approached him. And the two did not spend much time together. But Vonnegut gave the go-ahead that has allowed Mr. Shields to construct “And So It Goes,” an incisive, gossipy page-turner of a biography, even if it’s hard to tell just how authorized this book really is. Denied permission to quote from Vonnegut’s letters, Mr. Shields relies on paraphrases and patchwork to create a seamless-sounding account. Astonishingly, this book has nearly 1,900 notes to identify separate sources and quotations. But it doesn’t sound choppy at all.

headline: Homeless at the Protests
text: To the Editor:

headline: Consumer Spending
text: To the Editor:

headline: Arizona Senate, at Governor’s Urging, Ousts Chief of Redistricting Panel
text: PHOENIX — A decision by Gov. Jan Brewer and Arizona’s Senate to oust the chairwoman of the citizens’ commission redrawing the state’s political boundaries prompted legal challenges on Wednesday as critics of the move accused Republicans of meddling in a redistricting process that voters sought to insulate from politics.

headline: Rent Deal Aids Ailing East Village Bookstore
text: A deal has been reached to reduce the rent for St. Mark’s Bookshop, an East Village institution whose problems over the past year prompted an outpouring of support from neighbors and literary figures.

headline: Flamenco Fusion With Argentine Flair Salted by Traditional Modes
text: The form of the flamenco singer Diego el Cigala’s concert on Tuesday night at Town Hall wasn’t much of a story. The members of his five-piece band walked on and off, according to arrangements. The modes and rhythms of traditional flamenco dominated the two-hour concert, no matter where the songs came from originally, and made it feel like one long song. El Cigala, in a dark sharkskin suit, gold jewelry and black velvet slipper shoes, stayed mostly stationary on a high stool at center stage, speaking between a few songs while pulled back from the microphone, as if he had no worries about clarifying or tending to his identity.

headline: A Look at How Brooklyn Nannies Are Paid
text: The going rate for nannies in brownstone Brooklyn in 2011: $15 an hour.

headline: Capturing Subtlety in Spare Sounds
text: In his New York recital debut on Sunday afternoon at the Frick Collection, the young German pianist Martin Helmchen demonstrated the qualities that have already propelled him to a major career in Europe.

headline: Explorations, With Nature as Her Guide
text: History is filled with cautionary tales of people who tarried too long on the stage. This is especially true of older women; we like to tell them when it’s time to go.

headline: Trying to Alter Perceptions, Mexico Uses Candid Chitchat
text: CAMPAIGNS that feature hidden-camera commercials are popular among marketers seeking to change perceptions about products because they offer consumers a chance to watch other consumers share candid opinions. Examples include spots for Folgers instant coffee, Burger King, Pizza Hut and Ford Motor.

headline: Justices Weigh Judges’ Duties to Assess Reliability of Eyewitness Testimony
text: WASHINGTON — Though studies and lower court decisions have found that eyewitness testimony can be both unusually problematic and unusually persuasive, the Supreme Court on Wednesday did not seem inclined to rule that the Constitution requires judges to view such evidence with special skepticism. Ordinary trial procedures, several justices suggested, should be adequate to address the potential unreliability of eyewitness identifications.

headline: Two French Singers With Mixed Languages and Gender Roles
text: Triumphal regular visits from William Christie and his exceptional French ensemble Les Arts Florissants have proved time and again that New Yorkers show a passion for relatively obscure French operas of the Baroque and Classical periods, as long as they are handled with the regal pomp for which they were designed.

headline: A Once-Peaceful Yemeni City Under Siege
text: While the violence in Taiz is just one piece of the complicated conflict that has torn apart this country over the past 10 months of political uprising, it is perhaps the most pertinent as Taiz once was a city where law, order and civil society once flourished more than in any other part of Yemen. Now its civilians live with urban warfare on a daily basis.

headline: AOL Says Ad Revenue Continues to Increase
text: AOL said Wednesday that it had increased its global advertising revenue for the second consecutive quarter, indicating some improvement at the beleaguered digital media company.

headline: Australian Connection to a Premier Matchup
text: An Australian walks into a bar in Calgary during the 1988 Winter Olympics. He meets a fellow reveler, from Baton Rouge, La. They bond over shots of tequila, and a friendship forms that lasts to this day, as do others that sprang from it.

headline: The Joys, and Frustrations, of Snow Days in November
text: With the start of winter still weeks away, the Millburn School District in New Jersey used the last of its three allotted snow days on Wednesday, with three of its seven schools still without power, Internet or phone service since the weekend snowstorm.

headline: A Once-Peaceful Yemeni City Under Siege
text: The violence in Taiz, a city where law and order once flourished, demonstrates the complicated conflict that has torn Yemen apart since the political uprising began 10 months ago.

headline: Renewed Health and Star Filly Have Trainer in Breeders’ Cup Classic
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Two years ago Larry Jones pulled his white cowboy hat over his eyes and rode off the racetrack and into the sunset, swearing he was done training horses. He was cranky on his way out, too, blaming his owners and their incessant demands for taking all the joy out of the only thing he had ever wanted to do.

headline: Ancient City Anchors Political Standoff in Yemen
text: TAIZ, Yemen — This ancient city among the steep cliffs of central Yemen, once known as the commercial and intellectual hub of this south Arabian nation, has emerged as the violent center of a long political standoff between a president who refuses to step down and demonstrators who want him out.

headline: Years Later, Lawsuit Seeks to Recreate a Wedding
text: Of all the many things that make up a wedding, few are more important than the photographs.

headline: Running From Poverty to Fame and Tragedy
text: Gemma Atwal’s documentary “Marathon Boy,” a film-festival favorite that will be shown on HBO on Thursday night, is a wrenching experience largely because it uses the moods and methods of true crime and pulp fiction to tell a story that is nominally about poverty, politics and the toxic mingling of celebrity culture and national pride in modern India.

headline: A Giant’s On-Again, Off-Again Role
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The intricacies of N.F.L. roster machinations are not necessarily common knowledge in places like LaPlace, La., a town about 25 miles west of New Orleans that is perhaps best known as the Andouille Capital of the World. And this is why Barbara Gibbs hears the same questions when she stops in at the market or even when she is sitting in church.

headline: Georgia Men Held in Plot to Attack Government
text: TOCCOA, Ga. — At the Waffle House here, no one can believe that the gray-haired men who came in almost daily for egg sandwiches and coffee could have been terrorists plotting to blow up government buildings and kill masses of people using poison from a bean plant that people in this rural part of the state grow to ward off moles.

headline: Cable TV and Movies Buoy News Corp. Profits
text: News Corporation used its quarterly earnings report on Wednesday to highlight the success of its cable television and film units while trying to redirect investors’ attention from a phone hacking scandal at the company’s British newspaper unit.

headline: Poster Boys
text: Hollywood is full of weird little jobs. You see some of them on the credits at the end of the movie: Gaffer, Best Boy. In a lot of cases, the people in those mysterious-sounding occupations seem to get there by mistake, side-tracked en route to some other career. In fact, Los Angeles is chockablock with talented people who wound up in an entirely different profession from the one they’d originally started out in. I know painters who became art directors and set designers, a singer who started life as an actress and screenwriter. Two would-be novelists who both ended up film editors, though one of them eventually quit to become a yoga teacher.

headline: ‘The Silent Majority’: Directors’ Statement
text: THIS film, “The Silent Majority,” was born out of a larger project. We are making a feature-length documentary using the Super 8 home movies of some of Richard M. Nixon’s aides. As we combed through the home movies, we fell in love with these long shots of crowds out to meet the president. Filming over Nixon’s shoulder, the cameramen lingered on the faces of these ordinary, anonymous Americans. We began referring to this footage in edit-room shorthand as the “Silent Majority” footage.

headline: The Silent Majority
text: Consisting of rare footage filmed by President Richard M. Nixon’s aides, this experimental documentary revisits Nixon’s campaign to win an elusive majority.

headline: Loosening Rules, China Allows Facial and Neck Tattoos to Join Army
text: BEIJING — Seeking to broaden its appeal to China’s better-educated and perhaps more hip youth, the People’s Liberation Army has dropped a longtime bar to enlisting in the service: now, recruits can sport tattoos on their faces and necks.

headline: Fall for Dance
text: The dance festival’s third program at City Center was a mixed bag of ballet, tap and contemporary European dance.

headline: Of Gemini and Fauns and Glimpses of the Past
text: On Tuesday night at City Center the Fall for Dance Festival offered its third program, a mixed bag of ballet, tap, contemporary European dance — the generic variety — and, most mercifully, the Israeli choreographer Ohad Naharin. He defies categorization. The sight of Hubbard Street Dance Chicago performing Mr. Naharin’s “Three to Max” gave the evening a welcome lift.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Comcast Rises on Cable; Film Helps Time Warner
text: Increases in high-speed Internet customers and advertising sales at NBCUniversal’s trove of profitable cable networks helped increase third-quarter profits at the Comcast Corporation, the company said Wednesday.

headline: Firing Sought for One of Two Officers in Bell Shooting Case
text: Prosecutors with the New York Police Department recommended on Wednesday that one of the two officers being tried in connection with the killing of Sean Bell five years ago should be allowed to stay on the force while the other should be fired.

headline: High-Tension N.B.A. Talks Resume, but They’re Between Union Officials
text: Another tense meeting to address the N.B.A. lockout will take place Thursday in Manhattan — only this time without owners or league officials and without a prospect for a deal. If a consensus emerges, it will be solely between the leaders of the players association.

headline: Sending Texts by E-Mail
text: For people who prefer the ease of texting using a computer keyboard rather than fumbling with the tiny buttons or touch screens on cellphones, there is a way to text via e-mail without charge.

headline: Many Alarms Rang Before MF Global Crashed
text: A little before 2 a.m. on Monday, Jon S. Corzine was in MF Global’s offices in Midtown Manhattan, scrambling to cut a deal to save his firm. Haggard from too little sleep, at times pacing the hallways, he at least had a handshake agreement with one suitor for the firm.

headline: Note to Readers
text: As part of its digital expansion, the opinion department introduces Op-Docs, a forum for short, opinionated documentaries, produced with wide creative latitude and a range of artistic styles, about current affairs, contemporary life and historical subjects. Documentary submissions by both renowned and emerging independent filmmakers and artists are welcome.

headline: Low Cash Flow Threatens China
text: The robust earnings growth among Chinese companies does not tell the full story. Despite strong growth in net income, operating cash flow deteriorated sharply in the first half of the year. Many companies lent more to customers to drum up sales as demand weakened. Any resulting bad debt could hit companies and their lending banks. Similar debt triangles haunted Chinese companies in the 1990s.

headline: Fraud Case Seen as a Red Flag for Psychology Research
text: A well-known psychologist in the Netherlands whose work has been published widely in professional journals falsified data and made up entire experiments, an investigating committee has found. Experts say the case exposes deep flaws in the way science is done in a field, psychology, that has only recently earned a fragile respectability.

headline: Cain Says Perry Is Orchestrating a Smear Campaign
text: WASHINGTON — A defiant Herman Cain accused Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, a Republican rival, of orchestrating a smear campaign to destroy his presidential candidacy, as additional accusations emerged Wednesday that Mr. Cain made unwanted sexual overtures to women while he led the National Restaurant Association more than a decade ago.

headline: Trial Begins for Man Charged With Falsely Accusing Ex-Girlfriend
text: A little more than a year after she accused her ex-boyfriend of rape, Seemona Sumasar was pulled over by the police near her Queens home. Before she had a chance to speak, she said, she was handcuffed.

headline: In Local Races, Cuomo Lends a Hand, and a Face and a Voice
text: ALBANY — Gwyn Mannion, an engineer, mother of six and political novice who is running for a seat in the Onondaga County Legislature, is sending a postcard to voters presenting, on its face, a Jeopardy-style clue: “Two leaders who work across party lines to deliver real results.”

headline: Who Speaks for the Silent Majority?
text: Ann Arbor, Mich.

headline: The Storm That Nearly Lost the War
text: How a late-season hurricane almost ended the war for the North.

headline: U.S. Considered Taking Partial Ownership of Solyndra
text: In the days just before the solar panel maker Solyndra sought bankruptcy protection, the Obama administration considered another emergency debt restructuring that would have made the government the owner of 35 to 40 percent of the company, according to e-mail messages provided to House investigators.

headline: Experts Say N.Y. Police Dept. Isn’t Policing Itself
text: Seven narcotics investigators are convicted of planting drugs on people to meet arrest quotas. Eight current and former patrol officers are charged with smuggling guns into the state. Another is charged with making a false arrest, apparently as a favor for his cousin. Three more are convicted of robbing a perfume warehouse.

headline: Day of the Armadillo
text: Important News You May Have Missed Dept.: While you and I have been spending the fall worrying about the secret talks of the Congressional supercommittee or trying to determine whether it would be a fun idea to dress as Rick Santorum for Halloween, other even more fascinating news events have been occurring.

headline: Special Manhattan Court Trims Case Backlog, but Defense Lawyers See Drawbacks
text: The request, made in Manhattan Criminal Court, seemed rather routine: A lawyer, Logan Germick, was asking a judge to postpone his client’s trial, and for only a day, at that.

headline: The Birth Control Solution
text: What if there were a solution to many of the global problems that confront us, from climate change to poverty to civil wars? There is, but it is starved of resources. It’s called family planning, and it has been a victim of America’s religious wars.

headline: Cain to Review Links to a Nonprofit
text: An outside lawyer will review allegations that Herman Cain’s presidential campaign accepted tens of thousands of dollars in goods and services from a tax-exempt organization founded by his chief of staff, a spokesman for the candidate said Wednesday.

headline: Conservative Bloggers Cool to Cain
text: Reacting to new harassment allegations against Herman Cain, the Republican presidential candidate, on Wednesday, some conservative bloggers began tempering their defense of him.

headline: Thursday: One Without a Title
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — When I started here at Wordplay, I promised you all that we would enjoy the variety of ways in which constructors slice, dice, shuffle and mince words. Today, we have a perfect example of that.

headline: The Company to Call for Help With Your Exit Strategy
text: “Goodbye, cruel world!”

headline: Greece on the Brink
text: We are no fans of political referenda, with their simplistic yes or no answers to complicated policy questions. But we understand the dire circumstances that led Prime Minister George Papandreou of Greece to suddenly call for a national referendum in December or January on the terms of the latest European bailout plan.

headline: Deficit Committee Could Seek More Time, a Top Democrat Says
text: WASHINGTON — A top House Democrat said Wednesday that a bipartisan committee seeking ways to slash the budget deficit could seek an extension if it was unable to meet its deadline, just three weeks away.

headline: Oakland’s Port Shuts Down as Protesters March on Waterfront
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Thousands of Occupy Oakland protesters expanded their anti-Wall Street demonstrations on Wednesday, marching through downtown, picketing banks and swarming the port. By early evening, port authorities said maritime operations there were effectively shut down.

headline: Health Guideline Panels Struggle with Conflicts of Interest
text: When a federal panel recently recommended against prostate cancer screening for most men, it tried to steer clear of any suggestions of commercial bias.

headline: Plan to Issue New Permits for Parking Is Debated
text: Nine blocks from the steel shadow of Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn, Gib Veconi circles Prospect Heights nightly in his 13-year-old Volvo wagon looking for a parking spot, like a buzzard scouring for a meal.

headline: Whistling in Cannes
text: The European debt crisis is not the only threat to the global economy, which is already slowing perilously. When leaders of the world’s 20 big emerging economies meet in Cannes, France, on Thursday and Friday, they should agree on an agenda to boost growth. We don’t hold out much hope.

headline: A Tsunami Defense Under Scrutiny
text: Japanese authorities plan to rebuild a $1.6 billion breakwater even though experts are divided over whether it was effective in protecting against the tsunami.

headline: With an App, Your Next Date Could Be Just Around the Corner
text: Christina Wang has her date-night routine down pat. She combs her hair, fixes her makeup and then checks her phone, hoping to find Mr. Right, who might just happen to be nearby, right now.

headline: Mets’ Eyes Are on Reyes as Free Agency Begins
text: Jim Duquette laughed as he recalled the time, more than a decade ago, that he first heard Jose Reyes’s name.

headline: Japan Revives a Sea Barrier That Failed to Hold
text: KAMAISHI, Japan — After three decades and nearly $1.6 billion, work on Kamaishi’s great tsunami breakwater was completed three years ago. A mile long, 207 feet deep and jutting nearly 20 feet above the water, the quake-resistant structure made it into the Guinness World Records last year and rekindled fading hopes of revival in this rusting former steel town.

headline: Postcard From L.S.U.: Tiger Seen as Too Tame
text: BATON ROUGE, La.— A logo is often the visual embodiment of a team, and a point of pride for fans. The logo on L.S.U.’s helmets is simple: a round tiger head with purple stripes, in full growl.

headline: Conflicts of Interest on Federal Guidelines Panels
text: New rules for writing clinical practice guidelines.

headline: The Stumbling Campaign of Herman Cain
text: It is hard to imagine Herman Cain as a major presidential candidate, but, nonetheless, there he sits atop several respected opinion polls as the Republican Party’s nominating contests draw ever closer.

headline: Postcard From Alabama: The Routine of Preparation
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — During a week like this one, with a marquee matchup against top-ranked Louisiana State looming on Saturday, players and coaches for No. 2 Alabama are focusing on staying focused.

headline: Having the Watchdogs to Tea
text: Congress rarely remembers that it is responsible for overseeing the Federal Election Commission — the party-hack-ridden agency that enables campaign abuses. The House elections subcommittee has now summoned commission members to a rare hearing on Thursday about its work. Rather than a severe grilling, it’s more likely to be a meet-and-greet smile among professional backslappers.

headline: Meeting Iowans, County by County, Table by Table
text: SIGOURNEY, Iowa — Three reporters, four campaign workers, a teenage boy, a few prospective voters and one Rick Santorum gathered at the Copper Lantern restaurant here at 8 o’clock Wednesday morning.

headline: Jets Again Relying on Greene and Running Game
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Shonn Greene says he has enough people to listen to at the Jets’ practice facility, where he spends almost all of his time, anyway. He never heard fans or commentators grumbling about how he might not really be the best candidate for his job.

headline: Italy Strains to Resist the Tug of the Debt Whirlpool
text: ROME — As if European leaders needed any more motivation to deal with the mounting debt crisis, one fear stands above all others: Italy may be the next Greece, and if it is, united Europe may not have a future.

headline: Meeting With Chinese, Official Tests Limits Set by Congress
text: WASHINGTON — A fight over whether a White House official broke the law by meeting with Chinese officials has opened a rare window into how executive branch lawyers, working across administrations of both parties, get around legal limits imposed by Congress.

headline: Lots of Debate, Little Value to Awards
text: It is entirely possible that the amount of thought that goes into arguing over the winners and losers of the Gold Glove and Silver Slugger awards far outweighs the amount of effort that went into the actual voting by the coaches and managers.

headline: Colorado: Boulder Votes to Remove Power Company
text: Voters in Boulder passed two measures on Tuesday that would allow the city to lay plans to start a municipal utility and cut ties with Xcel Energy, its current, corporate power provider. Proponents say the move will give the city greater leeway to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The ballot measures, which pave the way for the homegrown utility and include a nearly $2 million tax increase to pay for legal and logistical fees, each passed narrowly by 51.78 percent and 50.27 percent, respectively, according to unofficial election results from Boulder County. Xcel Energy contended that it was better positioned to provide the city with energy at a far cheaper rate.

headline: Sotheby’s Strong Sale Revives Art Market in One Night
text: Rowdy art handlers — who have been locked out of Sotheby’s over a labor dispute since the summer — blew whistles and shouted insults at the crowds who poured into Sotheby’s Upper East Side auction house on Wednesday night for its auction of Impressionist and modern art. But for all the anger outside the building, inside there was excitement and a great deal of relief as an international crowd of collectors and dealers watched the auction market come back to life.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Google TV Redux
text: Google TV, Google’s set-top box software for melding the Internet with the television, was not a huge success when it arrived last year. But while the hardware is staying the same for now, Google announced a software update for Google TV last week with a new user interface, better search tools and new objectives. Claire Cain Miller, a technology reporter in the San Francisco bureau of The New York Times, drops in to explain Google’s latest angle for getting into the living room.

headline: Brownsville Parents Ask Chancellor to Spare Their Schools From Closing
text: At a town hall meeting in Brownsville, Brooklyn, Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott heard from angry parents and teachers who worry that three schools in their district could be closed for poor performance. They urged him to instead put more resources into the schools, and said a recent shooting in the neighborhood was a reminder that their community is in crisis.

headline: Jimmy Savile, TV Personality, Dies at 84
text: Jimmy Savile, an acclaimed English television host whose dress, hair and verbal flummery made all other comers in a nation renowned for eccentrics look like Puritans, was found dead last week at his home in Leeds, in the north of England. He was 84.

headline: Liz Anderson, Who Wrote Hit Country Songs, Dies at 81
text: Liz Anderson, who wrote breakthrough hits for Merle Haggard and other country singers and recorded songs of her own about faithless men and beleaguered women, died on Monday in Nashville. She was 81.

headline: Langoustines With Oysters and Seaweed
text: Time: About 30 minutes

headline: Word of the Day | analogy
text: analogy •\ə-ˈna-lə-je\• noun

headline: Biggest Public Firms Paid Little U.S. Tax, Study Says
text: Warren E. Buffett, take note. It is not just a few wealthy individuals paying unusually low taxes to the federal government. Corporate America is not far behind.

headline: Japan's Failed Breakwaters
text: Nori Onishi reports on the failure of breakwater systems in protecting against large waves along Japan's coastline.

headline: Worker Dies While Using Lawn Mower for Warmth
text: As the cold, heavy snow pelted a disbelieving city last Saturday, a landscaping crew — thoroughly chilled after hours spent working outside a church in the Bronx — loaded their equipment into two trucks and headed back to Queens, ready to call it an early day.

headline: Afghanistan Consults Neighbors on Security
text: ISTANBUL — In the largest meeting of its kind to date, representatives of Afghanistan and 12 nearby countries gathered in Istanbul on Wednesday to discuss regional efforts to rebuild security and stability in and around Afghanistan as NATO-led forces prepare to pull out of the country by the end of 2014.

headline: Corrections: November 3
text: NEW YORK

headline: Russia Declares Deal to Join Trade Group
text: MOSCOW — A Russian negotiator announced late on Wednesday that Russia had reached an agreement with Georgia that would clear the path for Russia to join the World Trade Organization after 18 years of delay, ambivalence and frustration.

headline: Principals and City Reach Impasse in Bargaining
text: The state's labor relations board formally declared that the City Department of Education and the Council for School Supervisors and Administrators had made no progress in their contract negotiations. The next step is the appointment of a mediator to oversee talks.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
text: Pakistan has finally granted India most-favored nation trade status, reciprocating India’s granting of the same status to Pakistan in 1995. The move is largely technical, but is a crucial step in the careful reconciliation under way between the two nations. Experts say that trade between the neighbors could reach $8 billion in five years. (The Hindu)Seeking to counter Anna Hazare’s battle against corruption, the government plans to introduce a bill in Parliament in the winter session that will give citizens the right to demand redressal of their grievances against government departments. According to the draft of the bill, the Hindustan Times reports, citizens will be able to complain via telephone or text message, and if their complaint isn’t dealt with in 15 days, it automatically goes to the head of the concerned department.

headline: NYT Front Page for 11/03/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 11/03/2011

headline: Wartime Ink
text: China announced on Wednesday that recruits with neck or face tattoos can serve in the People’s Liberation Army if the decorations are no larger than two centimeters wide, or about 0.8 inches.

headline: Hot Jazz and the Cold War in 1950s Mumbai
text: One evening in 1958, the pianist Dave Brubeck and his quartet gathered in the home of a jazz-loving industrialist on Mumbai’s Malabar Hill to chat with a group of Indian musicians led by the sitar maestro, Abdul Halim Jaffer Khan. Then they picked up their instruments and put their new knowledge to work. The jam session with Mr. Khan, the American pianist said later, changed the way he approached his art. “His influence made me play in a different way,” Mr. Brubeck told Jazz Journal International. “Although Hindu scales, melodies and harmonies are different, we understood each other … The folk origins of music aren’t far apart anywhere in the world.”

headline: A Site for Data Scientists to Prove Their Skills and Make Money
text: Airlines, insurance companies, hospitals and many other organizations are trying to figure out how to corral all their data and turn it into something useful.

headline: Medvedev’s Time
text: MOSCOW — “What time is it?” asked Ksenia.

headline: Greek Leader Calls Off Referendum on Bailout Plan
text: ATHENS — In a tumultuous day of political gamesmanship, Prime Minister George A. Papandreou called off a referendum on Greece’s new debt deal with the euro zone on Thursday after winning a measure of support from his opposition and managing to repair, at least for a day, a major rupture in relations with Europe.

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 3, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Nov. 3, 1936 | Franklin Roosevelt Re-elected in Landslide
text: On Nov. 3, 1936, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt was re-elected in a landslide over his Republican challenger, Kansas Governor Alfred M. “Alf” Landon. The president won over 60 percent of the popular vote and 523 of the 531 electoral votes, losing only Maine and Vermont.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 3, 2011
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, “All That Authenticity May Be Getting Old.”

headline: Oakland Police Clash With Fringe Protesters
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Protesters and city officials here took a deep breath and tried to calm the waters Thursday after a night of vandalism and tear gas disrupted an orderly day of anti-Wall Street marches. But tensions remained high, both between demonstrators and the police and between Occupy Oakland protesters and a belligerent fringe group that seemed intent on clashing with law enforcement and destroying property.

headline: What Are the Chances for Republicans?
text: Nate Silver models the likelihood of each candidate winning the popular vote.

headline: Is Obama Toast? Handicapping the 2012 Election
text: Americans are usually forgiving when they vote a man into the White House and he wants a second term. Of the last eight elected presidents, all but two — George H. W. Bush and Jimmy Carter — got their four more years. Which is why the conventional wisdom long held that Barack Obama would most likely weather his midpresidency slump to win another term.

headline: Choose Obama’s Re-Election Adventure
text: In conjunction with my New York Times Magazine article on President Obama’s re-election prospects, my colleagues Matt Ericson and Shan Carter have designed an interactive feature that allows you to handicap Mr. Obama’s re-election odds based on the assumptions of your choosing.

headline: Can Anyone Really Create Jobs?
text: The current economic downturn has been called a housing crisis, a financial crisis and a debt crisis, but the simplifying logic of the political season has settled on what is really more a result than a cause. We are now, according to nearly everyone running for office, in a jobs crisis. Every politician currently has a “jobs plan,” very often a list of vague proposals filled with serious-sounding phrases like “budget framework” and “regulatory cap” that are designed, for the most part, to mean both everything and nothing at all.

headline: The China Conundrum
text: This article is a collaboration between The New York Times and The Chronicle of Higher Education, a daily source of news, opinion and commentary for professors, administrators and others interested in academe. Tom Bartlett is a senior writer at The Chronicle covering ideas and research; Karin Fischer is a senior reporter covering international education.

headline: The European Debt Crisis and the G-20 Summit Meeting
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

text: This slide show contains images some viewers could find disturbing.
