text: To the Editor:

headline: Union Reversal on Givebacks Averts 3,500 Layoffs by State
text: ALBANY — Five weeks after rejecting a package of wage and benefit concessions sought by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, members of the state’s second-largest union of public workers have overwhelmingly agreed to accept a nearly identical deal, saving thousands of jobs.

headline: Arms Dealer’s Own Words Convicted Him, Juror Says
text: As a prospective juror in the trial of Viktor Bout, Heather Hobson told defense lawyers and prosecutors that she knew nothing of Mr. Bout’s reputed exploits as an international arms dealer.

headline: Romance Overnight
text: Richard Linklater’s 1995 romantic gem “Before Sunrise” followed Julie Delpy and Ethan Hawke, portraying travelers meeting on a train, on a stroll through after-hours Vienna. In Brady Kiernan’s winning debut feature, “Stuck Between Stations,” Casper (Sam Rosen) and Becky (Zoe Lister-Jones) take an overnight jaunt through Minneapolis. The charm, if not the history, of its principals is similar.

headline: After Tough Year, a Chilean Miner Returns to Run
text: The darling of last year’s New York City Marathon, Edison Peña, was back in the spotlight Thursday in Central Park, but this time he did not display a radiant presence, made no bold statements and declined to impersonate Elvis Presley.

headline: School Has a Charter, Students and a Strong Opponent: Its District
text: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y. — Charter schools, publicly financed but independently operated, have encountered fierce resistance in many suburban communities, criticized by parents and traditional educators who view them as a drain on resources.

headline: Drinking on the People’s Tab
text: Kiev, Ukraine

headline: For Our Allies, Death From Above
text: London

headline: As Regulators Pressed Changes, Corzine Pushed Back, and Won
text: Months before MF Global teetered on the brink, federal regulators were seeking to rein in the types of risky trades that contributed to the firm’s collapse. But they faced opposition from an influential opponent: Jon S. Corzine, the head of the then little-known brokerage firm.

headline: For a Close Aide to Herman Cain, Scrutiny Comes on Two Fronts
text: Until this week, Mark Block was famous as the guy who inhaled in a Herman Cain campaign Web video that went viral.

headline: Political Class Clowns
text: For a Republican Party that has spent the better part of its presidential campaign proving that most of its candidates are not smarter than a fifth grader, the real scandal around frontrunner-of-the-moment Herman Cain is not what he knows. It’s what he doesn’t know.

headline: Oligarchy, American Style
text: Inequality is back in the news, largely thanks to Occupy Wall Street, but with an assist from the Congressional Budget Office. And you know what that means: It’s time to roll out the obfuscators!

headline: Striving to Be Just Like You, Too
text: What could have been a moderately entertaining short film is yanked to intolerable lengths in “Killing Bono,” a shapeless rock-music caper that, like its deluded antihero, just doesn’t know when to stop.

headline: The Troubling Connecticut Power Failure
text: The moneyed folk inhabiting the Connecticut environs of the hedge fund town Greenwich wield plenty of power. But many of them have lately been powerless. For the second time in barely more than two months, a huge swath of the two million captive customers of Northeast Utilities, the power company that covers territory from the Constitution State up through western Massachusetts and into New Hampshire, have spent too many days without electricity.

headline: A Subculture of Random Hedonism
text: Seamlessly dovetailing style and subject, “Dragonslayer,” a poetic and affectionate portrait of the professional skateboarder Josh Sandoval, known as Skreech, vivifies a subculture of random hedonism and future myopia.

headline: Shale Gas Revolution
text: The United States is a country that has received many blessings, and once upon a time you could assume that Americans would come together to take advantage of them. But you can no longer make that assumption. The country is more divided and more clogged by special interests. Now we groan to absorb even the most wondrous gifts.

headline: Get Me Something in Economy Size
text: COMPARING his cost of living to his standard of living, Brad Hock concluded it was no longer worthwhile to live, rent-free, at home with his parents and endure a tedious commute. So he set out to buy a place in Manhattan, aiming to spend as little as possible.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Another Version of Star-Crossed Love
text: The Capulets and Montagues here are Circassians and Bedouins. The two need to live as neighbors when a group of Circassians emigrates from Istanbul to what is now Jordan in 1900. (Mr. Quandour’s film sketches in this history in its first minutes.)

headline: Putting Millionaires Before Jobs
text: There’s nothing partisan about a road or a bridge or an airport; Democrats and Republicans have voted to spend billions on them for decades and long supported rebuilding plans in their own states. On Thursday, though, when President Obama’s plan to spend $60 billion on infrastructure repairs came up for a vote in the Senate, not a single Republican agreed to break the party’s filibuster.

headline: Workers of the World, Employed
text: More than 60 percent of the world’s gross domestic product comes from global trade. This is double what it was in the 1980s. Most economists agree that the astonishing increase in trade over the past quarter century has boosted economic growth and job creation, and, in many countries, led to a decline in absolute poverty. But while the economic superhighway has spread around the globe, in many parts of the world there are still not enough on-ramps.

headline: Israel Faces Questions About News Reports of Eyeing Iran Strike
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s top leadership has spent the week answering and evading questions about widespread reports that it is once again considering a strike on Iran’s nuclear complexes, while President Obama said Thursday that he and his allies would maintain “unprecedented international pressure” on Tehran to keep it from producing a nuclear weapon.

headline: Mr. Draghi Makes a Start
text: Amid Europe’s financial and political disarray, the new president of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, made a sensible decision on Thursday to cut the euro-zone’s benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 1.25 percent. He acknowledged that Europe was headed into recession, and he argued that growth would be much lower than expected next year — offering hope that the bank would cut rates again next month.

headline: Bleak Portrait of Poverty Is Off the Mark, Experts Say
text: WASHINGTON — When the Census Bureau said in September that the number of poor Americans had soared by 10 million to rates rarely seen in four decades, commentators called the report “shocking” and “bleak.” Most poverty experts would add another description: “flawed.”

headline: At Abu Ghraib, Ambivalence on America’s Departure
text: ABU GHRAIB, Iraq — On a recent day off, Hussam Saad stood at a roadside vegetable stand across the highway from the prison where he says he works.

headline: For Bills’ Quarterback, Losing (Wedding Ring) Is Not an Option
text: Ryan Fitzpatrick, married for nearly five and a half years, says he never removes his wedding band. Not when he clips his nails. Not when he changes diapers. Not when he slings footballs around the field on Sundays for the Buffalo Bills.

headline: For Perry, Private Jets Have Been Key to Public Job
text: On a July morning in 2008, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and several aides boarded a plane for Washington to lobby on ethanol use, an issue important to corn growers and livestock owners in his state.

headline: Somalia: Sierra Leone to Send Troops
text: Sierra Leone will send 850 soldiers to an African Union peacekeeping mission in Somalia, a military official said Thursday. The official, Lt. Col. Ronnie Harleston, Sierra Leone’s military attaché to the United Nations, said the troops would deploy in the middle of next year. They will join approximately 9,000 peacekeepers from Uganda and Burundi, who are currently trying to secure the Somali capital, Mogadishu, from Islamist rebels. Djibouti plans to contribute 850 troops to the force this month. The force has a mandate for 12,000 peacekeepers, but African Union officials say they would need 20,000 to try to pacify the entire country, which has been in a state of civil unrest for roughly 20 years.

headline: TPG Capital Enters the Fray for Yahoo
text: The private equity firm TPG Capital has signed a nondisclosure agreement with Yahoo, making it one of the first potential suitors to begin formal due diligence work on the company, which is weighing a sale, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday.

headline: 26 Miles, Each One an Affirmation
text: At age 6, lunatic-boy-age, Kevin Dwyer was running around backstage at his ballet class and banged his head on a cinder-block wall. The puddling blood from the gash froze the other kids and their parents.

headline: Demonstrators Test Mayor, a Backer of Wall St. and Free Speech
text: Shortly before noon on Wednesday, the barricades that impeded foot traffic along Wall Street for weeks came down. Elected officials praised the mayor. Shopkeepers breathed sighs of relief.

headline: Woman Said to Have Felt Hostility at Work After Complaining About Cain
text: WASHINGTON — One of the women who accused the Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain of sexual harassment while working for him at the National Restaurant Association in the late 1990s complained that the workplace turned hostile after she alleged that he made advances toward her during a work-related outing, several people familiar with her account at the time said in interviews.

headline: Market Anxiety Grows Over Italy
text: When Italy issued 3 billion euros in bonds last week at an interest rate of more than 6 percent, it was about 1.5 percentage points higher than it had to pay as recently as last summer — and the most expensive 10-year money it had borrowed since joining the euro a decade ago.

headline: Outerwear’s Spokesman Does Without Outerwear
text: A NEW  commercial for Columbia Sportswear opens on a snowy landscape in the Lapland region of Northern Finland, where a bearded man runs barefoot, wearing only shorts and running across a frozen lake. After jumping into a hole cut into the ice, he resurfaces from another hole, and then is buried up to his neck in snow in an acrylic glass box.

headline: Tainted Witness
text: The Supreme Court heard arguments this week on a critical question about the use of witness identification. In Perry v. New Hampshire, the State Supreme Court ruled that a trial judge cannot exclude witness identification based on suggestive circumstances, unless there was improper police manipulation of the identification. That ruling takes the law backward and should be firmly rejected by the Supreme Court.

headline: A Bus Terminal, Overshadowed and Unmourned
text: THE demolition of Pennsylvania Station in 1963 is still an open sore. People who weren’t even alive then burn with indignation; it’s a kind of permanent ache. But is there no one to mourn the sleek little Greyhound bus station of 1935?

headline: A Star Turn in Housing Court, Then a Bit of a Letdown
text: It was an invitation to a performance not to be missed. An Oscar-winning actress left a voice mail message hinting that she might make her debut in a courtroom drama on Thursday. The show would feature personal conversations with a New York judge and a sober confrontation with a menacing adversary. Further checking showed that even the performance space sounded intriguing: Room 1164B.

headline: Costas Kondylis
text: Mr. Kondylis, 71, is the principal of Kondylis Architecture, which is based in New York. Over the last three decades, he has designed dozens of residential and commercial buildings throughout the city, including several for the Trump Organization, like the Trump World Tower.

headline: Oversight of Brokers Scrutinized
text: Who was in charge of regulating MF Global?

headline: Q & A
text: A Big Jump in the Rent

headline: Landlords No Fans of Fido
text: FRANK P. JAKLITSCH, 38, recently divorced and looking for a new home, has weekend visitation rights with his two children — a son, 4, and a daughter, 3 — and full custody of Bandit, the family dog, the latter being both a curse and a blessing. The problem is that even though his owner says he is no more ferocious than a kitty cat, Bandit is a 116-pound Rhodesian Ridgeback, and when prospective landlords meet him, they tend to cringe.

headline: Afscme Chief to Step Down After 30 Years
text: Gerald W. McEntee, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees for three decades, said on Thursday that he would step down next June when his two-year term expires.

headline: A Bright Spot in the Condo Market
text: HOBOKEN

headline: Friday: Gets Bent Out of Shape
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — BLAST OFF! What a neat way to open a crossword puzzle. Once you “leave the [launch] pad,” so to speak, the solving is Berry smooth, which is pretty much what one expects of a Patrick Berry puzzle.

headline: Log On and Spread the Word
text: BOB LIPP, the owner of a marketing business and a resident of the Great Neck area for 27 years, wondered why the community hadn’t taken any initiative to promote its proximity to Manhattan, “world-class hospitals, great schools and outstanding parks.”

headline: Dr. Muller’s Findings
text: Richard Muller, a prominent American physicist, was so skeptical about data showing a gradual warming of the Earth’s surface that he decided to investigate for himself. The results of his two-year inquiry — partially bankrolled by the Charles Koch Foundation, whose founder is a prominent global-warming denier — are now in. And, voilà, the Earth is indeed warming, just as most scientists have been saying for years.

headline: Painful Family Secrets Laid Bare
text: All family reunions should be this satisfying. Having spent months apart and suffered losses that might have leveled a less resilient clan, the Wyeths of “Other Desert Cities” have reassembled on Broadway at the Booth Theater, and absence and adversity (as they’re supposed to but so seldom do) have made them closer than ever. This means they have even more power to nurture, delight and wound one another and, not incidentally, move to tears anyone who visits them.

headline: Triggers of Lender Scrutiny
text: IN recent years, lenders have stepped up fraud-prevention investigations and checks on mortgage applications. For borrowers, this may mean facing questions on actions like accepting cash gifts from relatives for the down payment or signing up for new credit cards during the application process.

headline: Designing a Duplex
text: Michael Mentesana lives with his fiancée, Nancy Schueneman, and Derby in a sleek duplex on West End Avenue.

headline: Queens Neighborhood Gets a Little TLC
text: SOMETIME this fall ground will be broken in Astoria, Queens, on Hoyt Plaza, a rental building with 34 units, from studios to three-bedroom penthouses, with amenities that include an expansive lobby, a gym, a laundry room, a pool, terraces and a rooftop garden.

headline: Allen J. Bernstein, Owner of Morton’s Steakhouses, Dies at 65
text: Allen J. Bernstein, who greatly expanded the high-end Morton’s of Chicago steakhouse chain during his 17 years as chairman, applying what some in the industry called a Big Mac approach to filet mignon, died on Tuesday at a hospital near his home in Manhasset, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 65.

headline: Bradshaw Injury Will Give Jacobs an Opportunity
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Brandon Jacobs has not been subtle in expressing displeasure over his role with the Giants this season. He spent much of his time with the news media last week explaining the candid (and critical) comments he made about his future with the organization in a recent magazine interview. Days later, he was booed off the field by the home fans after struggling against the Miami Dolphins.

headline: The House of Annotated Corks
text: MICHAEL MENTESANA, the grandson of Italian immigrants on both sides of his family, grew up in a red brick house in Marine Park, Brooklyn, on a quiet street not far from Sheepshead Bay. His father was a dental technician; his mother was a nurse. There was a basketball court in the backyard, along with his mother’s small garden, heavy on roses and mums.

headline: For Some, Halloween in November Is a Sour Idea
text: Hitting the reset button on Halloween is proving harder than expected. Some communities, in the wake of a snowed-out Halloween, have rescheduled the festivities for this weekend, like Little Falls, Montclair and Chatham, N.J., which are having them Friday night, and Brookfield and Naugatuck, Conn., which are planning to have trick-or-treating Saturday.

headline: Gaborik, Poor in Shootouts, Lifts Rangers With Winner
text: Marian Gaborik is one of the top goal scorers of his generation, with 288 goals in 651 career games, including 5 this season. But he is not very good at shootouts: he was 2 for 19, or 11 percent, in his career going into Thursday night’s game against the Anaheim Ducks at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Bloggingheads: Global System Failure
text: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Daniel Drezner of ForeignPolicy.com debate about global political dysfunction.

headline: Living In | SoHo
text: A cosmopolitan atmosphere and crowds of tourists all packed into a historic district that offers an embarrassment of visual riches.

headline: Wealth, Beauty and Their Many Lovers
text: TAKING up residence in SoHo is for neither the light of wallet nor the faint of heart. Home to the world’s largest collection of buildings with cast-iron facades, the area possesses a powerful aesthetic allure, no less for luxury retailers and swarms of tourists than for homeowners.

headline: Surf’s Up Locally, Just Right for the Pros
text: The Association of Surfing Professionals surprised many people this spring when it chose Ocean Beach in San Francisco for its premier surfing contest, which began this week. The city is hardly known for surfing, and even hard-core surfers often malign Ocean Beach — a notoriously deadly, dirty and foggy six-mile stretch of shoreline — for its fickle, and occasionally furious, surf.

headline: A Different Portrait of Poverty
text: The Census Bureau has developed alternate measures to calculate poverty rates that consider cost of living, taxes, medical expenses and benefits like food stamps and housing subsidies.

headline: A Place at School Where Students Can Unload Stress and Worry
text: Last week about 20 students sat in Room 466 at Galileo Academy of Science and Technology, writing down all the ways that people abuse one another. Rapes and beatings topped the lists. One boy asked, “What if you just have someone tell you you’re not going to get far in life?”

headline: The Perils of Taking on the Voters in a Proposition-Happy City
text: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Oakland’s Symphony Season Opens, Mixing It Up
text: Michael Morgan, music director of the Oakland East Bay Symphony, said he did not mean to brag. But with Occupy Oakland demonstrations tearing through the city this week, he said he “deserved some kind of Nostradamus award” for programming “The Age of Anxiety” into the orchestra’s concert on Friday, the opening of its 2011-12 season.

headline: New Attention Paid to Homeless Youth and Families
text: More than 10,000 homeless students are enrolled in Chicago’s classrooms this fall, a 16 percent increase over last year and a record high, according to Chicago Public Schools data for September.

headline: A University’s Emphasis
text: If Louisiana State wavers Saturday, my sister will sprinkle her television in pursuit of divine intervention.

headline: A New Linkage Offers Possibilities in the Anti-Obesity Campaign
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: A Parade of Protesters, in a Court Just for Them
text: Inside a blandly lighted courtroom, a lawyer stood before packed rows of protesters who had been arrested in September, laying out their options: They could take the prosecution’s offer to have their cases dismissed after six months, or ask for a trial.

headline: Matty Alou, Batting Champion for Pirates, Dies at 72
text: Matty Alou, a left-handed slap-hitting outfielder who won a batting championship as a Pittsburgh Pirate and who as a San Francisco Giant once shared an outfield with his brothers Felipe and Jesús, has died in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. He was 72.

headline: Knowing Where the Police Are Posted
text: To provide greater City Hall transparency, Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s administration recently presented information on every one of about 4.7 million crimes reported in Chicago since 2001 at data.cityofchicago.org. The police department’s critics have long suggested more closely matching officer assignments with the greatest concentration of points on a map representing those crimes — the “cops on dots” theory.

headline: Victories, Not Symbolism
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — There are games where the hype looms heavily beforehand and games that appear larger in the rear view. Such was Alabama-Louisiana State in 1958, the season opener for the Crimson Tide, played at Ladd Memorial Stadium in Mobile, Ala.

headline: Epstein & Co. Pass Over the Obvious Choice
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Ricky Wyatt, 57, Dies; Plaintiff in Landmark Mental Care Suit
text: Ricky Wyatt was a rambunctious Alabama teenager who had broken windows, overturned a school desk or two, and been in and out of group homes. His probation officer decided he needed to be committed to a mental institution. His aunt, his legal guardian, agreed.

headline: Mary Hunt Kahlenberg, Native-Textile Expert, Dies at 71
text: Mary Hunt Kahlenberg, a curator and collector of native textiles whose traveling exhibition on Navajo blankets, organized at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in 1972, broke with tradition by presenting Navajo weaving as fine art, died on Oct. 27 at her home in Santa Fe. She was 71.

headline: After 20 Years in Partnership, an Educational Combo Is Getting a Messy Divorce
text: BROWNSVILLE — This weekend, along the border’s southern tip, homecoming at the University of Texas at Brownsville and Texas Southmost College will be bittersweet for many. It will be one of the last, at least for the unique partnership between a community college and an upper-division university that operated as one institution for 20 years.

headline: Jets Still Looking for Their First Road Victory This Season
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Jets Coach Rex Ryan said Thursday that Ralph Wilson Stadium in Orchard Park, N.Y. — the Ralph, as the locals call it — was an intimidating place to play even when the home team, the Buffalo Bills, were not as good as they are now.

headline: Shockingly, Cain’s Mystery Tipster Turns Campaign into High Drama
text: Herman Cain, accused, accuses Rick Perry.

headline: Former G.M. of Dodgers Is Interested in Buying
text: Fred Claire, a former general manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, said Thursday that he was part of a group that wants to buy the team. He will almost certainly be one of many potential suitors for the marquee franchise, which was placed in bankruptcy in June by its owner, Frank McCourt.

headline: Being Texan Doesn’t Mean You Support Perry for President
text: Texans have elected Rick Perry governor three times — with almost 55 percent of the vote in 2010 — but that does not mean Texas’ Republican establishment is falling in line to help elect him president.

headline: Postcard From Alabama: Serenade in the Key of Victory
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — It is one of the most feared victory chants in sports. So much so that there have been groups that have tried to get the N.C.A.A. to prohibit fans from doing it after victories.

text: The first “X Factor” results show got rid of an act that needed to go, but man what a slog getting to that morsel of drama.

headline: Couple Donate $150 Million to Fight Poverty in Developing Nations
text: Stanford University will open an institution aimed at alleviating poverty in developing nations, using $150 million donated by a Silicon Valley investor and his wife.

headline: U.S. Soccer Coach Names Roster
text: The United States national team’s coach, Jurgen Klinsmann, unveiled his roster for two coming international friendly games, at France on Nov. 11 and at Slovenia on Nov. 15. The list includes the known (Jermaine Jones and Timmy Chandler), the lesser known (Danny Williams and Fabian Johnson) and the who-is-this-guy (Alfredo Morales).

headline: Calculating Poverty
text: To preview how the Census Bureau’s new Supplemental Poverty Measure may change the portrait of poverty, The New York Times consulted multiple alternate measures that researchers have quietly published in recent years.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Friday
text: The Special Central Bureau of Investigation court on Thursday dismissed the bail application of Kanimozhi Karunanidhi, a DMK Member of Parliament and one of the accused in the 2G spectrum case. The agency said no concession could be given merely because she is a woman (The Hindu). The court also rejected the bail plea of seven others accused in the case. A weeping Ms. Karunanidhi, 43, hugged a tearful Rajathi Ammal, her mother, while her 10-year-old son, Aditya, broke down, as well. “It’s unfair … there is some conspiracy,” she said, moments before being led away to the court lock-up (The Telegraph).

headline: Player Ratings: Galaxy (2) vs. Red Bulls (1)
text: Say good night.

headline: Rangers Ride Lundqvist to Another Shootout Victory
text: The shootout victory has become routine for the Rangers. Whether they hang on to stay even with opponents or tie the score late, the Rangers enter the shootout for the win (and second standings point) feeling good about their chances. They have Henrik Lundqvist on their side.

headline: Becoming Bionic
text: Robert Woo regains the ability to walk with help from an exoskeleton.

headline: The Mythology of Cold Start
text: A small group of lawmakers gathered last month in Pakistan’s army headquarters, where the country’s head of military operations, Maj. Gen. Ashfaq Nadeem, stiffened their resolve about the threat from India. He warned of one Indian capability in particular: India’s Cold Start army doctrine.

headline: Sick in America, Aching for Africa
text: CHICAGO — I came down with my first African disease in America. It happened after I traveled to Nigeria last April to witness my country elect a new government. I landed with notebooks and questions, but not antimalarial medication. I had been more prudent on dozens of prior stays, but, I thought, no matter: I had already been running around the continent for months with no mishaps. After three rounds of free and fair voting, I returned to my apartment in Nairobi, buoyant about democracy in Africa.

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 4, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Red Bulls Eliminated by Galaxy in M.L.S. Playoffs
text: CARSON, Calif. — The bane of the Red Bulls’ season — conceding goals on dead-ball plays — proved costly in Major League Soccer’s Western Conference semifinals Thursday night.

headline: Nov. 4, 2008 | Obama Is Elected President
text: On Nov. 4, 2008, Barack Obama was elected the 44th president of the United States, defeating the Republican nominee John McCain. Mr. Obama, a United States senator from Illinois who was the son of a Kenyan father and a white mother from Kansas, became the first black commander in chief.

headline: Greek Leader Survives Vote, Bolstering Deal on Europe Debt
text: ATHENS — Prime Minister George Papandreou of Greece survived a crucial confidence vote in the Greek Parliament early on Saturday, a vote that signaled approval of the comprehensive deal reached by European leaders last week to stabilize the euro and to help Greece avoid defaulting on its debt.

headline: Vatican Gardens Open to Public Tours
text: The reforms of Pope Benedict XVI extend beyond strictly liturgical matters. During his six-year reign, there has been greater and more streamlined access to the Vatican and its various complexes, including an easy-to-use public reservation system for the Vatican Museums, regular after-hours visits to the Museums Collections and, most recently, regular visits to the Vatican Gardens, once accessible on a more limited basis.

headline: Week 9 Matchups: Identifying the Best
text: Packers (7-0) at Chargers (4-3)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Packers by 5.5.

headline: College Is Cheaper Than You Think
text: Judith Scott-Clayton is an assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University.

headline: The ‘Entertainer’ Caste Hangs on to What it Knows
text: On a Sunday evening on a traffic island in the midst of south Mumbai’s Colaba Causeway, three children are at work.Raja, age 16, is banging on a dhol, or drum, hanging around his neck, while the younger children begin a series of slow somersaults.

headline: Coming to Terms With Being the Boss
text: Every November, as we start winding down another year and reflecting on what we accomplished, what worked, what didn’t and what we should be planning, I yearn for some time and space to really have some good, deep thought about where we are going and how to get there. I also yearn to reconnect with that girl on fire who started my ad agency 17 years ago.

headline: Spit Takes and Other Topics for a Comedy Critic
text: If a stand-up comic kills in the forest, does it make a sound? I don’t know, but what’s more certain is that no critic from a major paper will review it. Every night in this city, scores of artists take the stage and perform for large, enthusiastic audiences, and are usually ignored by critics in the media capital. Most of those comedians are ordinary or bad, but a few may become the next Richard Pryor of David Letterman.

headline: Mount Vernon District Fights a Charter School's Arrival
text: In New York City, the public has grown accustomed to fights over charter schools and whether to open more of them. Typically, the opposition comes from parents, teachers and members of the city's teachers' union. But in Mount Vernon, the local school district has fiercely opposed the opening of Amani Charter School this year. New York Times reporter Winnie Hu writes that the district sued the State Education Department for chartering the school and has now refused to hand over state, federal and local aid money to Amani, so the state has begun paying the charter directly.

headline: The Lasting Financial Impact of a Layoff
text: Losing a job you wanted to keep is never a good thing. But for those who lost their jobs during the Great Recession, the long-term consequences will probably be very significant.

headline: Japan’s Kirin Buys Stake in Brazilian Brewer for $1.35 Billion
text: The Japanese brewer Kirin Holdings said Friday it had agreed to pay $1.35 billion for the outstanding stake in the Brazilian beer maker Schincariol Participacoes e Representacoes it does not already own as part of the company’s expansion into emerging markets.

headline: Corzine Is Said to Hire Criminal Lawyer
text: Jon S. Corzine has hired Andrew J. Levander, a leading white-collar criminal defense lawyer, according to three people briefed on the matter, as the former New Jersey governor deals with fallout from the collapse of MF Global, the brokerage firm he has run since last year.

headline: Corzine Resigns From MF Global
text: Jon S. Corzine has resigned from his posts at the embattled brokerage firm MF Global, the company announced on Friday.

headline: On Our Radar: A Chinese Mine Accident
text: A sudden rupture of a rock face in a coal mine in central China has killed four miners and trapped 50, Chinese news reports say. Last year, an estimated 2,400 people died in coal mine accidents in China as the industry rushed to meet the country’s growing energy demands. [Reuters]

headline: A Sporting Chance
text: Professors are using sports to teach probability and statistics. Here are some examples lifted from their tests.

headline: The Hidden Meaning of Hand-Raising
text: A psychoanalysis of the different ways to raise your hand in class.

headline: Know-How for Hire
text: Student photographers shoot their classmates. This issue: knitters, tuners, bakers, coffee makers.

headline: Where the Women Are: Biology
text: INCREASING the number of women in science and technology has been an important goal for universities and industries, and substantial progress has surely been made. More women than ever major in so-called STEM fields.

headline: Being a Legacy Has Its Burden
text: HOPE. Fear. Ambition. Desire. Guilt. All parents of children applying to college go through a set of stomach-churning emotions, but parents who graduated from Ivy League schools experience their own particular set of competing emotions and expectations.

headline: My Own Private Librarian
text: FEARFUL that the only search students can do is on Google, librarians are eager to show off what they can do. The latest effort is the personal librarian.

headline: Profile of a Changing Freshman Class
text: EDUCATORS believe, strongly, that exposure to students of different cultures makes for an enriched educational environment. For this issue’s Data column, we asked colleges and universities for a profile of this fall’s freshman class and, for context, matriculants of five years ago. Clearly, the statistical landscape is shifting (some numbers are preliminary).

headline: The Half-Empty Nest
text: ANOTHER day, another how-to book. With every alarming landmark that loomed ahead of my college-bound son — rifling school catalogs, prepping for the SAT, embarking on the college tour, taking the SAT, gathering recommendations, taking the SAT again, writing the application essay, arranging the personal interview, filling out financial aid forms, taking the SAT again — I felt compelled to seek out advice. Friends who had survived the process offered tips, of course, but I kept returning, with touching innocence, to what I came to think of as The Books.

headline: The Evolution of Higher Education
text: WHAT with shrinking government funds and growing competition from online for-profit institutions, American colleges and universities are facing hard times, and being forced to rethink what they do. Richard A. DeMillo, director of the Center for 21st Century Universities at Georgia Institute of Technology, discusses the evolution of universities in his new book, “Abelard to Apple: The Fate of American Colleges and Universities.” Drawing on his experience as the first chief technology officer at Hewlett-Packard, director of the National Science Foundation’s computer and computation research division, and dean of Georgia Tech’s College of Computing, Dr. DeMillo offers an engineer’s view of the challenges facing higher education.

headline: Tweets on Grad School
text: @cindy091896 I will be inspiring today if it kills me.

headline: The Bibliotech: Library of the Future, Now
text: THE University of Chicago’s new Joe and Rika Mansueto Library is a futuristic bubble of a building with nary a stack in site. Many of its nearly one million items — special collections, journals, dissertations, documents — can be accessed online.

headline: Credentials, the Next Generation
text: HAVE a marketable skill, unappreciated and unverified? Or maybe your talents are outside the domain of college certification?

headline: At Moneyball U, What Are the Odds?
text: WATCHING a baseball telecast may not be the best way to learn basic probability.

headline: The Online-College Crapshoot
text: LAST June, when U.S. News & World Report announced plans to add online programs to its college kingmaking franchise, skeptics said it couldn’t be done. Predicted to be published in October, the ranking is now promised only for some time “when it’s cold out,” says Eric Brooks, the data research analyst tasked with developing a methodology.

headline: College Radio Heads: Off the Dial
text: INSIDE a broadcast booth, at the radio station of the State University of New York Fredonia, Jud Heussler was presiding over his hourlong comedy show “The Morning Inferno.”

headline: Why Science Majors Change Their Minds (It’s Just So Darn Hard)
text: LAST FALL, President Obama threw what was billed as the first White House Science Fair, a photo op in the gilt-mirrored State Dining Room. He tested a steering wheel designed by middle schoolers to detect distracted driving and peeked inside a robot that plays soccer. It was meant as an inspirational moment: children, science is fun; work harder.

headline: Closing the Girl Gap in Science
text: GIVE me an “S”! Give me a “T”! Give me an “E”! Give me an “M”! Yaaaaay STEM!

headline: Making Sense of the Breeders’ Cup Is a Workout
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — As a fan, the Kentucky Derby is an interesting race to prepare for. You spend months tracking talented 3-year-olds as they star in various Derby prep races. You start off with a list of over 300 horses, which is finely honed until the top 20 graded-stakes earners are revealed. You come to the track with all the knowledge you can gather about the entries with statistics, past performances and every prediction you can find.

headline: U.S. Adds a Modest 80,000 Jobs; Rate Drops to 9%

headline: Friday Reading: Government Aims for More Accurate Poverty Picture
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Before Signing On: A Checklist
text: WHEN looking for an online program, ask a lot of questions. And remember that call centers are staffed by single-minded salespeople, so speak to someone who isn’t hawking courses, like a program director.

headline: A Need-to-Know List
text: On campus tours, science and engineering schools love to show off their high-tech equipment and promote how many graduates work for Google. But don’t expect them to mention how tough they grade or how many students wash out. To cut through the hype, here are questions to ask each school to gauge where you have the best chance of succeeding:

headline: The Return of Mein Kampf

headline: Not So Super Mario
text: The half-life of eurozone pseudo-solutions has been steadily dropping over the past two years. It used to be that a new plan that would allegedly finance troubled debtors while they austeritied their way to recovery would buy six months of relative calm in the markets. Then that dropped to a month or two, then a week.

headline: Merchants Of Doubt
text: Jonathan Chait has a terrific takedown of inequality deniers. It’s similar in spirit to my own version, but packaged somewhat differently and I’d say more effectively.

headline: Gone, but Still Moving People to Help Young Latinos
text: Before they had mortgages, children or just life’s commonplace commitments, Lisette Nieves and her friends had each other, time and a cause. They rallied to help Puerto Rican youth, organizing an annual conference called Muévete — “Move Yourself” — raising issues and consciousness among teenagers from the South Bronx to Brooklyn’s south side.

headline: Welcome to the Church of ‘Godspell’
text: “GODSPELL,” the 1971 musical about Jesus and his apostles, brings to the stage a vision of spirituality so earnest that it can veer perilously close to self-parody. With its thrift-store costuming and vaudeville-style song-and-dance numbers, the show is the ultimate in accessible feel-good Christianity. In the 2000 movie “Meet the Parents” Ben Stiller’s future in-laws ask him to say grace, and the only words he can conjure are the lyrics to “Day by Day,” the “Godspell” ditty that the composer Stephen Schwartz set to lyrics from a 13th-century Roman Catholic prayer. Everyone, even a nervous Jew under the watchful eye of a C.I.A. agent father-in-law, remembers those tunes.

headline: Fast and Easy Vegan Dishes
text: Every dish on the Thanksgiving table doesn’t have to involve hours of preparation. That’s why Well’s Vegetarian Thanksgiving series is offering four new vegan dishes that can be prepared in 30 minutes or less.

headline: Early Economic Projections Could Haunt Obama in 2012
text: A year out from Election Day: an eon in political time, sufficient to alter circumstances substantially for or against either party. But Friday’s tepid jobs report brings a fresh reminder of the stubborn difficulty President Obama and his team face in overcoming one of their most enduring mistakes, one made before he even took office.

headline: Anxious Over Jobs and Europe, Wall St. Falls for Week
text: Stocks dipped on Wall Street after sinking in Europe on Friday as the Group of 20 nations ended a summit meeting with seemingly little headway in resolving the debt crisis in the euro zone.

headline: Now Booking | The St. Regis Florence
text: Perpetually swarmed with tourists, Florence, Italy, is at last trying to make things a little easier for visitors with across-the-board improvements to its tired infrastructure and dated hotel scene. The abysmal Amerigo Vespucci Airport is nearing completion of an expansion and upgrade to its terminals, and both boutique and big-name hotels, like Il Salviatino and the Four Seasons, are adding much needed up-to-date accommodations. The St. Regis made the biggest splash last month with a $25 million renovation of a 1492 Brunelleschi pile that was once the Grand Hotel Florence.

headline: The Norquist Rebellion
text: It seems like every day brings a fresh reminder of how polarized and paralyzed Washington has become. On Thursday, the Senate took up Mr. Obama’s proposal to spend $60 billion on repairs to roads, bridges, airports – the things that get lumped under the poetic-sounding “instrastructure.” Not a single Republican voted to break their party’s filibuster of this bill, despite the fact that many, if not all of them, have supported such spending before.

But many of those that exist suffer from censorship, their advisers and students say, or at least feel pressure to paint the school in a positive light.

text: When school leaders share their authority with teachers, parents and even the students themselves, they widen the circle of those who are responsible, and ultimately accountable, for student success.

headline: From Roughnecks to Bosses, Ministry Seeks to Save Souls in the Oilfields
text: JEWETT, Tex. — With a box of Bibles as cargo, John Bird steered his Chevy Suburban off a two-lane road in the oil patch of East Texas and pulled up to the isolated derrick of Energy Drilling Company Rig 9. He was delivering the holy books to a man named Robert Bailey, the site superintendent, known in industry jargon as a tool pusher.

headline: A Composer Echoes in Unexpected Places
text: AT home one day in 1956 George Avakian, then one of the top executives and producers at Columbia Records, received a telephone call from the classical music composer Alan Hovhaness, who told him, “There’s a terrific musician from India who is here, and you should meet him.” His friend was so adamant, Mr. Avakian recalled recently, that a few minutes later Hovhaness was knocking on the door, with Ravi Shankar in tow.

text: NEXT week the large-ensemble jazz composer Darcy James Argue and the graphic novelist Danijel Zezelj will be collaborating for four nights on “Brooklyn Babylon,” as part of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It is an hourlong performance involving an 18-piece band conducted by Mr. Argue, with nearly continuous animation and live painting by Mr. Zezelj on a 36-foot long panel.

headline: At Least 15 Are Killed, Activists Say, as Syria’s Stance on Talks Is Tested
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian forces killed at least 15 people on Friday, opposition groups reported, in a spate of bloodshed that activists and some Western officials said called into question the Syrian government’s commitment to a plan brokered this week to halt months of violence.

text: The United States national team will assemble in Paris on Monday to begin training for the two final exhibition matches of 2011 — a Nov. 11 match against France and a game against Slovenia four days later. Coach Jurgen Klinsmann announced his roster selections Thursday and has ambitious plans for the 22 players who made the cut.

headline: Readers Respond: Marriage Equality
text: In a blog post yesterday I argued that Congress should repeal the Defense of Marriage Act, which denies the right of marriage to same-sex couples. I also suggested that we remove the ability of churches to bestow legal legitimacy on marriage. We should imitate France, where marriages must be performed by a civil authority, and religious ceremonies have no legal status.

headline: Ending Bullying by ‘Fixing’ the Victims?
text: An article in The Atlantic magazine on elementary school anti-bullying curricula is sure to be controversial. Its headline suggests the way to go is to “Fix the Victims.” But would a more accurate wording be “Blame the Victims”?

headline: Design Bookshelf | Great Houses of Havana
text: Hermes Mallea’s “Great Houses of Havana” (The Monacelli Press) is one of several books on that city to appear this season, but it may be the most personal. For Mallea, a Cuban-American architect who is based in New York, the book grew out of a longstanding fascination with his family’s history. One of his great-grandfathers was a photojournalist, and Mallea began to collect vintage Cuban photography. “I loved the information that those photographs contained,” he recalled, “and visualizing what life was like at those points in time.” Mallea was invited to Havana to give a presentation on his research, which led to more talks, and before he knew it, the architect had a book contract. He made eight trips in all, accompanied by his partner in life and in the firm M(Group), the interior designer Carey Maloney, who served as a “stylist” —  but only in a manner of speaking, given what Mallea called the “almost guerrilla-style photography” of the book. (He worked with two different photographers in Havana and also used archival photographs.) “Lots of people let me in,” he explained, “but no one wanted me to stay long, so you won’t see flower arrangements.”

headline: Weekend Fare
text: The New York City Marathon takes place on Sunday, and throughout the weekend restaurants will reach out to runners looking to load up on carbs, and more sedentary types simply celebrating the race. The Z NYC Hotel, 11-01 43rd Avenue (Vernon Boulevard) in Long Island City, is offering a $16 four-course race-themed menu all day Saturday that includes three pasta dishes and a dessert. Danny Meyer’s Union Square Hospitality Group, the official food and beverage partner for the marathon, will hold various events throughout the weekend, including opening the Blue Line Lounge in the marathon pavilion at Central Park West and West 67th Street, where spectators can order food and drinks at the end of the race. Ca Va Restaurant, at the InterContinental New York Times Square Hotel, 300 West 44th Street (Eighth Avenue), will offer a $30 carb menu for dinner on Saturday. On Sunday from 4:30 a.m. to 8 a.m., the restaurant will stock a special buffet for runners and their families, with brown rice, oatmeal, pasta, cereal and other hearty choices. Asellina, at the Gansevoort Park Avenue, 420 Park Avenue South (East 29th Street), will feature extra-large pasta portions for $20 a plate. At Spina, 175 Avenue B (East 11th Street), freshly made pastas will be sold for half-price all day Sunday to runners and their guests who bring a marathon bib.

headline: The Arts Bloom in Greece’s Second City
text: IT was early August, and clouds of tear gas drifted through much of Athens, the remnants of protests against austerity measures. But the country’s financial woes seemed far from the minds of the smartly disheveled young Greeks packed onto the roof terrace of the newly opened Fragile bar in Salonika, about 320 miles north of the capital. T-shirt-clad art students shouted over a mix of vintage doo-wop and ’90s alt-rock, or ducked into the covered bar area, which evoked a vaguely postal theme, its corkboard-lined walls cross-hatched with packing tape.

headline: Salonika’s Art Scene
text: Salonika is home to architectural marvels that testify to its centrality in Byzantine, Ottoman and Sephardic Jewish history.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $8.5 million
text: With its cast-iron lattice work, limestone facade, inset Juliet balconies and oversize apartments, the Laureate, a condominium building at 76th and Broadway, was designed to echo the grand prewar elegance of older, better-established neighbors like the nearby Apthorp.

headline: An Undertaker With Purple Nails
text: “SOMETIMES you got to do it all yourself,” said Doris V. Amen late one recent weeknight as she hopped up onto the back of her hearse, clamped her high-heeled pumps onto the back bumper and yanked a stubborn corpse on a stretcher out onto a windswept Brooklyn street.

headline: A Basketball Film About So Much More
text: Melissa Johnson’s new documentary, “No Look Pass,” is alternately a basketball buddy film; a “Love Story” for modern times; and, as Ms. Magazine describes it, a feminist “Hoosiers.” But while the film is ultimately more American dream than “Hoop Dreams,” it does not fit neatly into any category.

headline: Video of Israeli Navy Intercepting Boats Bound for Gaza
text: Updated | 3:38 p.m. My colleague Isabel Kershner reports that the Israeli Navy intercepted two small boats bound for Gaza on Friday, apparently ending the latest effort by international activists to breach Israel’s maritime blockade of the Palestinian coastal enclave.

headline: Introducing a Very Quick Read
text: “This is your nemesis calling,” Will Arnett tells me in his distinctive, grovelly, mock-sinister voice after spending the morning filming his hit NBC sitcom, “Up All Night” (and brushing up on his hockey skills for a future episode). But a funny thing happened to the “Arrested Development” alum en route to becoming Hollywood’s go-to guy for arch comedy roles: Arnett became a father twice, at least. By day, he and his TV wife, Christina Applegate, raise a newborn daughter; by night, he and his real-life wife, Amy Poehler, raise two boys: Archie, 3, and Abel, 1. “I’m pretty childlike,” Arnett explains from his Los Angeles home. “I live a fairly goofy existence. My job requires I mess around a lot and make light of every situation. It turns out, that’s how kids live.” Oh, baby — or should we say, Oh, babies?

headline: Philip Levine Still Knows How to Make Trouble
text: You were recently named America’s poet laureate. What has been most surprising about the gig?  How much attention it’s gotten. People like my doctor or the guy who sells me wine or the people in my gym come up to me and say, “Oh, Phil, this is marvelous.” Some of them didn’t even know I was a poet. Now there are mobs of people when I give readings. I read at a high school in Pennsylvania, and there were 600 people.

headline: The Origin of Spray Paint
text: That a paint salesman from northern Illinois created the tool through which rebels, gang members, artists and anti-Wall Street protesters alike have expressed themselves merely confirms that inventors can neither control nor predict the impact of their innovations. After all, Jack Dorsey never imagined that Twitter would facilitate Anthony Weiner’s self-immolation.

headline: What’s the Easiest Way to Legally Get to the U.S. from Mexico?
text: Given the billions of dollars spent annually on border enforcement, not to mention the long lines at the various crossings, the most pleasant way to travel legally from Mexico to the United States might be on the border’s only hand-drawn ferry. Every day, six wide-backed Mexican men use ropes and cables to pull an ersatz barge, El Chalan, a distance of about 10 car lengths across the Rio Grande from Los Ebanos, Tex., to Gustavo Díaz Ordaz, Mexico, and vice versa. Sometimes passengers help out, too.

headline: Nose Ring of Truth
text: In the very high-end home-furnishings showroom I own, we eliminated a great sales candidate because she had piercings in her nose and tongue. That decision does not fit with my personal beliefs, but I felt others would prejudge her and therefore our showroom. Was I wrong to eliminate her for this reason? Should I have told her why? ANNE AZIZ, TORONTO

headline: Blood in the Water
text: For generations, the whale hunt has been a mainstay of life on the Faeroe Islands. The practice continues today, over the protests of animal rights groups.

headline: After a Soaring Career, Joan Didion Considers Her Final Approach
text: Joan Didion’s new book, “Blue Nights” — the phrase refers to the long summer twilights in the Northeast, where she lives — is her first title in more than half a decade, and the waiting audience has never been as large. For years, Didion has stood as something of a literary beacon, guiding other writers through the chancy straits of narrative reporting. It was not until she published “The Year of Magical Thinking” in 2005, though, that her work became a signal light to travelers along the mainstream too. “Magical Thinking” narrated the unexpected death of her husband, John Gregory Dunne, through the rhythms of obsessive memory. “Blue Nights” takes a similar approach. The book’s chief subject is Didion’s daughter, Quintana, who died in 2005 after a long hospitalization, but the account ranges across several decades, scrutinizing memory fragments and details for clues foreshadowing Quintana’s death. Didion dwells on her own ailments as well — she was 75 at the time of the writing and a victim of shingles, an aneurysm, neuropathy and a mysterious blackout — and although none of this territory is new, her account is sharp and unsettling in the alchemic proportions fans have come to expect. Reading Didion today, more than ever, means submitting almost fully to the strange authority of the voice on the page.

headline: O Pioneers!
text: We moved to the suburbs with my lesbian moms in the summer of 1981. It was the end of Bohemian apartment living — the death knell of batik tapestries that doubled as bedspreads and room dividers and of the butterfly chair that scissored shut on anyone who sat in it.

headline: Listening to the Axis of Evil
text: HOW should the United States and its allies deal with evil regimes that abuse their own people and threaten world order?

headline: The Murakami Chronicle
text: My friend Tony Takitani is a politically active lawyer in Hawaii. ‘‘Tony Takitani’’ is also the title of a short story by Haruki Murakami. The connection? While vacationing on Maui, Murakami found an old campaign T-shirt from my friend’s failed State Senate bid in a thrift shop. Intrigued by the name, Murakami invented a life around it. Fortunately, my friend is nothing like the lonely character in Murakami’s story, but it does make for a unique conversation piece. Art imitating . . . an old T-shirt? Strange imagination, indeed! CURTIS MILHAUPT, New York

headline: Lex Luger Can Write a Hit Rap Song in the Time It Takes to Read This
text: A few years ago, before anyone knew his name, before rap artists from all over the country started hitting him up for music, the rap producer Lex Luger, born Lexus Lewis, now age 20, sat down in his dad’s kitchen in Suffolk, Va., opened a sound-mixing program called Fruity Loops on his laptop and created a new track. It had a thunderous canned-orchestra melody, like an endless loop of some bombastic moment from Wagner or Danny Elfman; a sternum-rattling bass line; and skittering electronic percussion that brought to mind artillery fire. When the track was finished, he e-mailed it to a rapper named Waka Flocka Flame. Luger had recently spent a few months in Atlanta with Waka, sequestered in a basement, producing most of the music for Waka’s debut album. Waka had asked him for one more beat, one that could potentially be the album’s first single.

headline: How Students Can Take Charge of Their Education
text: Last month, The Times’s Sunday Review published an Op-Ed article by Michael Ellsberg called “Will Dropouts Save America?” In it, he argued that our school system tends to stifle rather than promote creativity and that students do not learn essential skills and habits of mind needed to start businesses. He said that when it comes to job creation, he puts his faith in college dropouts who become entrepreneurs.

headline: I Do Not Think That Word Means What You Think It Means, Hypocrisy Edition
text: OK, let me start by talking about Mel Gibson for a minute. Bear with me, this is actually relevant.

headline: Asked & Answered | Stamberg Aferiat Architecture
text: With the opening of the Saguaro hotel in Scottsdale, Ariz., a collaboration between Joie de Vivre Hotels and the Sydell Group, a vibrant design has just blown into “the West’s most western town.” Standing out from Scottsdale’s archetypal gamut of beiges and whites, the Saguaro is a brightly hued haven, with nods to the native flora. The hotel was intended to be about Scottsdale, and, flanked by Old Town and the Civic Center Mall, it very much is, while still managing to look and feel like an oasis. The Moment sat down with the architects, Peter Stamberg and Paul Aferiat of Stamberg Aferiat Architecture, to talk about transforming the Old West into something more luminous and inviting.

headline: An American Dancer Makes a Leap to the Russian Stage
text: David Hallberg, 29, a native of Rapid City, S.D., is the first American ever to be named a principal dancer at the Bolshoi Ballet.

headline: For Prostate Screening Guidelines, Public Comments Are Private

text: The finger-pointing and fierce exchanges that have animated the Republican presidential race may violate Ronald Reagan’s often-cited, yet rarely followed, 11th Commandment to avoid speaking ill of fellow Republicans. But not all party leaders are fretting – yet.

headline: Sam Anderson On “IQ84” by Haruki Murakami
text: This week, Kathryn Schulz and Sam Anderson discuss the new novel “IQ84” by Haruki Murakami; Harvey Araton describes the glory days of the New York Knicks in his book, “When the Garden Was Eden”; and we bid a fond farewell to the Book Review’s best-seller columnist, Jennifer Schuessler. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.
