text: News Corporation has begun a voluntary program that allows people who believe they have been the victims of phone hacking to apply online for compensation.

headline: First, No More Guests; Now, Chelsea Hotel Says No More Art
text: At the end of a dusty hallway on the fifth floor of the Chelsea Hotel, an older woman wobbled from her apartment — Room 503 — on Wednesday and began removing from the hallway walls several of her prints and photographs that have hung in the hotel for years.

headline: Lawmakers Aim to Stop Defense Cuts if Debt Panel Fails
text: WASHINGTON — As pessimism mounted this week over the ability of a bipartisan Congressional committee to agree on a deficit-reduction plan, lawmakers began taking steps to head off the large cuts in Pentagon spending that would automatically result from the panel’s failure.

headline: Off the Charts: Excess Stock Market Volatility
text: Excess stock market volatility ­ — price moves that get reversed in a few days or weeks — has risen to levels seen only three times before in the past 60 years: after the 1987 stock market crash, near the bottom of the market decline in 2002 and during the financial crisis and recession of 2008 and 2009. The charts show the difference between the amount the Standard & Poor’s 500 moved over each 13-week period and the total of the daily changes, without regard to whether the daily move was up or down, and expresses the amount as a percentage of the index value at the beginning of each 13-week period. In a market that went up every day, or down every day, over a 13-week period, the figure would be zero. Highlighted areas show recessions.

headline: In Changing Ecosystems, Winners and Losers
text: Two new peer-reviewed studies, one about forests and the other about oceans, predict that existing ecosystems will rearrange themselves over the next 70-plus years in response to global warming.

headline: The Remains of North Brother Island
text: Daniel Avila, a New York City parks department photographer, documents the remains of North Brother Island, in the East River, where Typhoid Mary was confined until her death.

headline: Lead Guitarist of Metal Band Found Dead on Tour Bus
text: The lead guitarist for the satirical heavy metal band GWAR was found dead on the band’s tour bus Thursday after a concert in Minneapolis, the band announced through a statement posted on a metal Web site. Other members of the band discovered that the guitarist, Cory Smoot, was not breathing just before the bus crossed into Canada, where GWAR was scheduled to appear in Edmonton.

headline: New Sex Scandal Attaches Itself to Strauss-Kahn’s Name
text: While Dominique Strauss-Kahn has faded into the background in the public consciousness in the United States, he has remained part of a front-page scandal in his native France.

headline: Volatile, but Nearly Running in Place
text: RARELY has a stock market been so wild and moved so little.

headline: True North | Mats Gustafson
text: When you walk into the artist and illustrator Mats Gustafson’s apartment in Stockholm, you’re not quite sure what era you’re in. In the foyer, a turn-of-the-century painting of a bourgeois Swedish interior hangs beneath one of Isamu Noguchi’s oversize paper lanterns, and underfoot is a colorful mid-20th-century rug by Barbro Nilsson for the renowned Swedish workshop MMF. Under a midcentury nude painted by Birger Ljungquist, Gustafson’s great-uncle, sits a simple 1950s stool by the Swedish designer Carl Malmsten. Walk through an angled doorway into the living room, a high-ceilinged space with the graceful proportions and architectural ornament typical of late-19th-century buildings, and the mix gets even richer. An upholstered 19th-century Swedish bench along the window and a group of slipper chairs, all from Gustafson’s family, blend easily with sheepskin-covered wood chairs designed in the 1930s by Bruno Mathsson and tables by Josef Frank. Vases by Scandinavian Modern ceramics masters like Axel Salto and Berndt Friberg are clustered atop a traditional tiled fireplace, and the immaculate plaster walls (which are painted, aptly enough, Stockholm White) are hung with Gustafson’s spare, elegant watercolors. Venture into the apartment’s long corridor, however, and you’ll find up-to-the-minute bathrooms and a sunny, south-facing kitchen in which crisp, utilitarian cabinets provide a clean backdrop for an antique wooden table and chairs. This is an interior that’s modern and old-fashioned at the same time, and in all the right ways.

headline: Hard-Line Factions Threaten Latest N.B.A. Negotiations
text: At 4 p.m. Saturday, two groups of weary adversaries will gather once more around a hotel conference table and try to settle the N.B.A. lockout — if they can only hold off the agitating factions behind them.

headline: Rockettes 3-D
text: The classic Rockettes Christmas show at Radio City Music Hall gets revamped, with 3-D effects and karate-kicking dancers.

headline: Rockettes, Rebooted for a New Era
text: FOR nearly 80 years families have been flocking to Radio City Music Hall to bask in the glory of the Rockettes, whose eye-high kicks have as much to do with the holidays as the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center. Attending the “Radio City Christmas Spectacular” is an exercise in nostalgia. So who in her right mind would mess with such a time-honored tradition?

headline: WatchList: A ‘Parks and Recreation’ Road Trip
text: If the minimalist, semi-improvised charms of “Parks and Recreation” on NBC work for you, you can see them distilled to their essence in the show’s first Web series, “April & Andy’s Road Trip.” (Full disclosure: those charms are largely lost on me, except when Amy Poehler is talking.)

headline: Scratch the Ad and Sniff Out the Parody
text: IN the November issue of W magazine, set between a fashion spread on Madonna’s coming film “W. E.” and a piece on the dissident Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, is an advertisement for Pizzazz, an evening-wear line. The campaign spotlights a sweet little girl, her lips streaked in scarlet, her doll-size body swathed in layers of tulle. A towering crown is perched on her curls.

headline: Occupy Wall Street: How Should It Be Covered Now?
text: The Occupy Wall Street movement has certainly generated a lot of ink and bytes. Seven weeks into it, the journalistic challenge of covering it has probably grown in complexity. It is not simply a matter of covering the events attending to the individual protests in New York and scattered around the country. There are larger themes to address.

headline: Laboring in the Shadow of Hollywood
text: IN January 1943 the Russian-born poet, essayist, former radical and future filmmaker Eleanora Deren wrote a friend that her husband, Alexander Hammid, was having a tough time finding work as a cameraman in Hollywood. The union, she wrote, was one of those “racketeer things,” though there might be a job at Paramount Pictures. “There are other prospects,” she added, “but in Hollywood prospects are a dime a dozen.” Four months later she and Hammid carved out a different future in the poetic form of “Meshes of the Afternoon,” a black-and-white, 14-minute silent film and a classic of the American avant-garde cinema that they shot a few blocks from the Sunset Strip.

headline: Two Marathons: Good Idea or Bad?
text: The New York City Marathon made me smile this week. And then it made me frown.

headline: Alabama Quarterback Has the Arm to Win It
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Under Coach Nick Saban, the Alabama quarterback has been asked to go 50 miles per hour in a 55-m.p.h. zone. On third-and-12, the Saban quarterback will not always be asked to make the big throw downfield; often, he will be told to throw short and count on the receiver to break a tackle. Whether the quarterback was John Parker Wilson or Greg McElroy or, nowadays, A J McCarron, there has always been another firm hand — Saban’s — at the wheel of the offense.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Manga Mania
text: There is lots of turnover on the manga list this week. Some of the series – which are in later volumes – seem as if they would be daunting to penetrate. All at Vol. 7: Black Butler, about a loyal servant who drifts from dinner parties to the underworld; Soul Eater, about a living scythe; Pandora Hearts, a riff on the Alice in Wonderland mythology; and Chi’s Sweet Home, about a kitten whose curiosity often leads him to trouble.

headline: MF Global Funds Found at JPMorgan
text: After days of intensifying regulatory scrutiny into missing client money at MF Global, firm funds have been found at JPMorgan Chase, according to several people briefed on the matter. It’s just not the missing money, rather assets that regulators have already counted, one person said.

headline: And All That Stuff
text: SHOPPERS come in many forms, just as fashion critics do. Facebook has become a marketplace, joining eBay, Etsy and members-only sites, not to mention big-box e-commerce.

headline: Here’s to the Distaffers, the Stars of the Show
text: The 25th running of the Breeders’ Cup took place on October 24 and 25 at Santa Anita Park. For the first time that year, the races for females and male were segregated, with the distaff races taking place Friday, and the rest of the races run Saturday. In another historical departure (and another departure from history), the Breeders’ Cup Distaff was replaced with the Ladies’ Classic.

headline: The Caucus | The Cain Non-Strategy
text: Nov. 4, 2011 — Michael D. Shear on Herman Cain’s efforts to deal with the media frenzy around sexual harassment allegations with no discernible strategy.

headline: What Makes an Airline Family Friendly? You Tell Us
text: Flying in coach is tough enough these days with airlines cutting back on services and with planes packed to the brim. Then add kids to the mix. (See related article for more.)

headline: Are We There Yet? When Families Fly
text: SURELY they could spare a little milk, right?

headline: Tracing His Menus Back to Chiang Mai
text: TO drive around Chiang Mai, Thailand, with the chef and restaurateur Andy Ricker is to experience a particular sort of hungry man’s torment. That place, he said, pointing at a storefront or street stall, is known for stir-fried noodles, that other one for fish-head soup. We would pass right by. Elsewhere, he nodded toward a busy restaurant that he called the most famous place in town to get khao soi, a Chiang Mai specialty. Again, we drove past. By this point in his career, his standards are set. “Too sweet,” he said.

headline: Time Warner Said to Bid for Dutch TV Company
text: In a continuing effort to shift its emphasis to content like television shows, movies and journalism, Time Warner has made a bid for the Dutch television production company Endemol.

headline: Caucus Video: The Cain Non-Strategy
text: Michael D. Shear on Herman Cain’s week, during which he seems to be dealing with the media frenzy around sexual harassment allegations with no discernible strategy.

headline: Shurman Celebrating the Marathon’s Every Mile, for the 29th Straight Time
text: On Sunday, fans watching the New York City Marathon will see elite runners finishing the race in just over two hours, legions of teams running for charities and people from around the world embracing the city one step at a time.

headline: A Chef's Tour of Chiang Mai
text: The American chef Andy Ricker talks about the culinary riches of Chiang Mai, Thailand, which inspired his restaurants' menus.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 9’s Toughest Picks
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Nerves of Steel
text: Before she died in 1996 at age 61, the designer Isabelle Hebey said she would leave nothing undone, no aspirations unfulfilled. (Well, almost none: she always joked about redoing the Vatican.) Hebey even drew up new plans for her Paris apartment, tailored to the son who would inherit it, right down to rearranging the furniture. In planning her funeral, however, she did not go as far as another autocratic designer of her generation, David Hicks, who sketched his own coffin. But she did get to choose hers. “It was very surreal,” recalls Emmanuel Hebey, the noted mathematician and Isabelle’s son. “The man who sold it to us was rather surprised.”

headline: A Tidy, Sleepy Stretch of Vancouver Wakes Up
text: Main Street in Riley Park, once quiet and off the tourist radar, has emerged as one of the city’s most vibrant areas.

headline: Restaurant Report: Isla de Flores 1900 in Montevideo, Uruguay
text: One of the best of Montevideo’s restaurants led by young Uruguayan chefs is Isla de Flores 1900, a six-table hole in the wall that specializes in locally sourced offal and meats (lamb, rabbit, beef, pork) prepared in a mix of European styles. The results manage to be both homey and high end.

headline: In Nepal, Gliding With a Feathered Guide
text: THE air whistled past my helmet as I removed a cube of raw buffalo meat from the bag strapped to my paraglider harness and placed it in my gloved hand. While a soup of haze obstructed the views of the Himalayas one afternoon last spring, I was rewarded with tilting glimpses of the Nepalese city of Pokhara and of Phewa Lake below. The paraglider pilot seated behind me blew his whistle twice, and moments later, a brown Egyptian vulture swooped in an effortless arc, landing on my outstretched arm.

headline: Letters: 36 Hours in Albuquerque
text: To the Editor: In addition to your suggestions in “36 Hours in Albuquerque” (Oct. 23), I’d offer: dinner at Jennifer James 101, and paddling on the Rio Grande (Quiet Waters Paddling offers guide-led kayak and canoe trips). And Albuquerque has one of the most vibrant street arts communities in the country. Murals enliven walls along Central Avenue. Neala Schwartzberg

headline: Hotel Review: Mondrian SoHo in New York
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: Letters: Airlines’ Holiday Tidings
text: To the Editor: Re “Airlines’ Holiday Tidings” (Practical Traveler, Oct. 30), flying is now painful. Those of us who traveled extensively decades ago when it was fun are fortunate that we can now enjoy other activities and other means of travel. European train travel can be a joy. Try it after your ship docks.

headline: Thanksgiving Countdown | ‘One of the Most Bizarre Recipes for Stuffing Ever Printed’
text: From the Diner’s Journal mailbag (that is, the comments section):

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, India, Bahrain, and New York.

headline: In the Clicks of a Mouse, a Betrayal
text: THREE years ago I discovered my husband was having an affair with a woman who had answered his ad in the “casual encounters” section of Craigslist. I was a 40-year-old suburban soccer mom and library volunteer. On a typical day I did freelance work in the mornings, picked the kids up from school, fixed dinner and helped with homework. My husband, a tall executive with a winning smile, came home each night around 6 with kisses all around, often straight from a prearranged encounter.

headline: Cain Stands By the Koch Brothers
text: Herman Cain proudly said he stands with the billionaire Koch brothers on Friday, saying he was “their brother from another mother.”

headline: Dear FloFab: We Ate Cheddar and Ritz Crackers for Christmas Eve Dinner
text: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma, or a question about Thanksgiving etiquette? Ask FloFab.

headline: Perry Discloses New Debts From Jet Travel
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on Friday disclosed new travel-related campaign debts of almost $230,000 that appear to largely stem from improper underpayments to owners of private jets used by his presidential campaign.

headline: A Visit to Typhoid Mary’s Domain
text: It took five minutes of wading through jungly vines. “I think we’re standing where her house used to be,” he said.

headline: A Student’s Call for a Learning Revolution
text: Nov. 5, 12:44 p.m. | Updated I was struck last week by a Huffington Post essay written by Nikhil Goyal, a 16-year-old junior from Syosset High School on Long Island who is clearly part of what I call “Generation E.” The piece, “It’s Time For a Learning Revolution,” was a student-eye-view of the need — and glaring opportunity — for innovating teaching (and learning) from the bottom up. (He’s writing a book on the subject.)

headline: Watchdog Asks F.E.C. to Investigate Cain Campaign
text: A watchdog group on Friday asked the Federal Election Commission to investigate whether Herman Cain’s campaign and his campaign manager, Mark Block, violated federal law by allowing a tax-exempt organization to pay some costs associated with Mr. Cain’s presidential run.

headline: Readers Tour Haruki Murakami’s Tokyo
text: Sam Anderson’s profile of Haruki Murakami included an online tour of the author’s favorite spots in Tokyo, complete with block quotes from his novels.

headline: Faboo Food Links
text: Let’s start with some animal news: I guess nobody ever accused China of being the standard-bearer of food ethics, but “braised or stewed” koala? You’ve gotta be kidding.

headline: Now Your Phone Talks Back and Humors You
text: ALEX JOHNSON, a freelance video producer in Indianapolis, has a self-esteem problem. Well, not really, but his new iPhone thinks he does.

headline: Dippin’ Dots, ‘Ice Cream of the Future,’ Files for Bankruptcy
text: Thursday was a sad day for amusement park aficionados, professional sports fans and moviegoers, as Dippin’ Dots, maker of the self-proclaimed “Ice Cream of the Future” that was sold wherever fun and frozen confections met, filed for bankruptcy protection.

headline: Joe Drape’s Breeders’ Cup Picks: Day 2
text: Selections for Saturday’s Breeders’ Cup races at Churchill Downs (listed in order of preference):

headline: Now Online | Design and Living 2011
text: The Design and Living issue starts with the house of the artist and alchemist Christian Astuguevieille, a true cabinet of curiosities. Mats Gustafson’s Stockholm apartment, on the other hand, is a serene and surprisingly warm example of Scandinavian cool. And the artist Laurie Simmons’s classic brick Georgian in northwestern Connecticut is really a dollhouse of magnificent proportions. Elsewhere, we encounter the artist Mika Rottenberg, whose videos transform mundane tasks into exercises in the strange and the sublime; the graphic designer Frith Kerr, whose Calvinist exterior belies a Rococo imagination; and the designer Tino Seubert, whose benches and chairs offer a front-row seat to great moments in history. Finally, there’s a sneak peek at Anne Sebba’s forthcoming biography of Wallis Simpson. It’s a fantastic read — just don’t expect a fairy tale ending. See all the stories here.

headline: National Vehicle Theft Rate Continues to Drop, According to N.H.T.S.A. Data
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration recently released final data on thefts of passenger vehicles from the 2009 model year, the most recent data available.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 4
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a very early snowfall, a statue that moves to the finish line of the marathon and a junkyard soccer game in Queens.

headline: Romney Outlines Entitlement Changes
text: Read an updated version of this blog post.

headline: The Vogues in Tokyo
text: Here’s a first: editors from all the Vogue magazines seated together. They are in Tokyo for a special Fashion Night Out, on Saturday, to help support Japan and Japanese fashion and retailing after the earthquake and tsunami earlier this year.

headline: With Baseball Over, Ratings Race Tightens
text: With baseball out of the way, it was a very close Thursday night battle for ratings supremacy between the broadcast networks.  Fox narrowly won in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic as the detective drama “Bones” posted its highest-rated season premiere in three years to go with 10 million total viewers.  The first ever results show of “The X Factor” held steady, matching its previous 18-to-49 Thursday rating and pulling in 11.3 million total viewers.  CBS had the largest audience overall with “The Big Bang Theory” (15.5 million total viewers) and “The Mentalist” (13.5 million).

headline: Uncovering Amazon Publishing
text: The legacy book publishers are pretty much open shops. If you want to know how many titles they are publishing this fall, just get a catalog and add them up. Amazon is taking a different tack, shrouding much of the plans for its publishing venture in the secrecy it extends to most of its business dealings. (Apple, no slouch at being close-mouthed, at least reveals how many iPads it sells. Amazon does not do the same with Kindles.)

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Saudi Arabia, India and Bahrain.

headline: Saab’s Future in Flux as G.M. Considers Opposing Its Sale
text: DETROIT — General Motors said on Friday that it might block two Chinese carmakers from acquiring Saab, the Swedish brand it cut loose in 2010, throwing Saab’s prospects for survival into doubt just days after it appeared to have been saved from collapse.

headline: Running On
text: That’s the stirring finish of ‘‘The Jericho Mile,’’ above. I happened to see this TV movie when it was shown sometime in, the Internet Movie Database tells me, 1979. It made a big impression on me. Even though I had to ask my dad, sitting beside me, why ‘‘Jericho’’ — the perils of limited churchgoing, I guess — the story moved me. The music even more so: it was my first hearing of ‘‘Sympathy for the Devil.’’

headline: Flying Under the Radar
text: While its A7 sibling gets all the attention, the 2012 Audi A6 may win the hearts of more practical-minded buyers of luxury sedans.

headline: I Do, Briefly
text: IN Hollywood, Monday’s announcement from Kim Kardashian, that she had filed for divorce from the basketball player Kris Humphries, fell decidedly short of making a mark in the annals of short celebrity marriages. Seventy-two days is no record. Still, the hoopla served its purpose, in part, by advancing the plotline of the bride’s reality show, “Keeping Up With the Kardashians.”

headline: Short Celebrity Marriages
text: The record books are full of couples whose marriages dissolved before the wedding china got chipped.

headline: Levine Withdraws Again From Met Production
text: The conductor James Levine is withdrawing from Wagner’s “Götterdämmerung,” the final installment of the Metropolitan Opera’s new “Ring” cycle, as he continues to recover from back surgery prompted by a fall, the Met said on Friday. Fabio Luisi, the Met’s principal conductor, will take over the production for performances on Jan. 27 and 31 and Feb. 3, 7 and 11. Mr. Luisi will also conduct the Met Orchestra at its Carnegie Hall concert on Jan. 15. Mr. Levine, the Met’s music director, has canceled all his performances so far this season because of the back ailment. The Met said he is still scheduled to lead three full “Ring” cycles in April and May.

headline: Citigroup Redraws Organizational Map Again
text: Citigroup’s organizational chart has long required its own field manual. The management shake-ups are always messy, and the changes are often made under duress.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov.4
text: A view of the day in sports, including horse racing at the Breeders’ Cup, sailing in Spain and ice skating in Shanghai.

headline: Anthony D. Weiner, Hiding in Plain Sight
text: ON Halloween night at the Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers, a small group of men huddled around a television set while changing into their hockey uniforms, strapping guards to their shins, securing elbow pads with Velcro straps.

headline: Two Painters: So Alike, So Different
text: PERIPATETIC museumgoers visiting both the Frans Hals show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which closed last month, and “Caravaggio and His Followers in Rome,” which opened on Oct. 16 at the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth (after a run this summer at the National Gallery of Canada, in Ottawa), have a rare chance not just to see 13 Halses and 10 Caravaggios but also to compare these substantial bodies of work by two near-contemporaries: celebrated figure painters who might at first seem an unlikely pairing, but who turn out to share surprising affinities.

headline: Cain: Up, Down or Sideways?
text: Herman Cain seems to have survived his campaign’s roughest week better than most analysts, including yours truly, might have expected. Two polls conducted amid the swirl of accusations this week continued to have him essentially tied for the lead in the Republican field. In an ABC News/Washington Post poll conducted Monday through Thursday, Mr. Cain was at 23 percent, just behind Mitt Romney. And he was just ahead of Mr. Romney in a Rasmussen Reports poll conducted on Wednesday night, where Mr. Cain got 26 percent of the vote.

headline: Keith Urban to Undergo Throat Surgery
text: Keith Urban, the country music star, will undergo surgery this month to remove a polyp from his vocal cords and then must rest his voice for an indefinite period, his publicist, Paul Freundlich, said in a statement.

headline: Journalist’s Arrest Adds to Woes of Murdoch’s British Empire
text: LONDON — A journalist at the tabloid The Sun was arrested Friday on suspicion of making illegal payments to police officers, a sign that a scandal has spread beyond The News of the World to other papers in Rupert Murdoch’s British media empire.

headline: Cardinals, Cubs, Red Sox Sorting Manager Candidates
text: The market is heating up for managers with the Cubs, Red Sox and Cardinals searching for the right candidates. And they all seem to be combing over the same group of names.

headline: L.S.U. Star Toughened at New Orleans School
text: NEW ORLEANS — The practice field used by the St. Augustine High School football team is not a practice field at all. It is a park in this city’s Seventh Ward, complete with a slide, a jungle gym and the smell of marijuana wafting through the air courtesy of loitering locals.

text: 5:06 p.m. | Updated

headline: High School, That Hilarious Minefield

headline: Friday Night Music: More Civil Wars
text: I almost feel guilty for loving this group so much — their sound is so gorgeous that it surely must be bad for you. But it’s Friday, so let’s indulge in a rendition of Leonard Cohen:

headline: Los Angeles Auto Show Design Contest Goes Hollywood
text: The police, waitresses, the gangsters in “Get Shorty” — everyone in Los Angeles is working on a screenplay. Add car designers to the list.

headline: Gatsby En Pointe
text: Something in the air has us reaching for “The Great Gatsby.” From the Elevator Repair Service’s epic, six-hour reading aloud of the novel from cover to cover to Baz Luhrmann’s 3-D Leonardo DiCaprio vehicle set to open on Christmas Day next year, F. Scott Fitzgerald’s meditation on the American dream is stirring a fresh round of adaptations. If there is an advantage to staging “Gatsby” as a ballet, an art form whose language is largely metaphorical, it might be that the storytelling does not compete with Fitzgerald’s lyricism in one’s ear. With the Washington Ballet’s latest production, which had its preview Wednesday night at the Kennedy Center’s Eisenhower Theater, we learn there is another: the story, quite simply, wants to be danced to.

headline: Dear Abby, Ann Landers ... and Me?
text: THE first response to my first-ever Social Q’s advice column, which began appearing in this section of the newspaper in June 2008, hit my in-box at 8:41 on the morning of its debut. It was from Jessica Seinfeld: she loved it.

headline: A Home for Those Who Hate Nursing Homes
text: In case you missed it, The Times reported earlier this week on an experimental type of “resident-centered” nursing home that’s operating in more than 100 places nationwide.

headline: Wild Mushrooms Make the Soup
text: COOL fall weather brings to mind woodsy flavors. Maybe it’s the smell of autumn leaves and damp soil, coupled with the occasional sunbeam. You want something hearty bubbling away on the stove.

headline: Torrisi Partners Will Open a Restaurant on Thompson Street
text: The guys from Torrisi Italian Specialties say they will be taking over Rocco restaurant, the Italian standby on Thompson Street in Greenwich Village, and opening a new restaurant there next fall, Eater reports.

headline: The Privileges of China’s Elite Include Purified Air
text: BEIJING — Membership in the upper ranks of the Chinese Communist Party has always had a few undeniable advantages. There are the state-supplied luxury sedans, special schools for the young ones and even organic produce grown on well-guarded, government-run farms. When they fall ill, senior leaders can check into 301 Military Hospital, long considered the capital’s premier medical institution.

headline: Cultural References
text: A general advisory: if you think I’m making some kind of pop or other cultural reference — to the Princess Bride, Bruce Lee, video games, etc. — I probably am. Economics and politics are too dismal to write about without having some fun along the way.

headline: Auto Ego: Making Corvettes a Habit
text: Donald Pulver of Pennsylvania has been collecting classic Corvettes for decades, keeping most of the sports cars in original condition.

headline: I’ll Have the Cream of Wild Mushroom
text: Canned mushroom soup was a staple in my mother’s pantry (yours, too?), useful for dozens of dishes, mainly casseroles, some memorable, most best forgotten.

headline: Rookie Shows Experience Isn’t Required
text: WHEN Demis Volpi learned that he would be choreographing a new work for American Ballet Theater’s fall stint at City Center, it was almost too big an idea to take in. It felt, he said, a bit like being a little kid and trying to wrap your head around the idea that the universe is endless.

headline: Occupied: Portable Bathrooms for Protesters
text: The banks, the taxation system and the military-industrial complex remain intact, but the protesters of Occupy Wall Street got something on Friday they have been keenly desiring for weeks: round-the-clock portable toilets.

headline: College Football Creates Boisterous Rivalries on the Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — College football has always been a regular topic of conversation in N.F.L. locker rooms, but recently a bit of tension has developed around that subject for members of the Giants’ defensive line.

headline: Posting Photos of Other People’s Children
text: I don’t post photos of my daughter online. My feeling is that she’s exposed enough in my books, articles and blogs. Maybe that’s a rationalization, an arbitrary line, but it’s mine and I stand by it. Only once did I override that instinct: I let the “Today” show film her as part of a lead-in piece when my most recent book was released. I have regretted that decision ever since, not so much because they did anything unseemly with the footage — the clip was actually adorable — but because I relinquished control over how she’d be presented. It was a misstep that still stings: I put my professional opportunity ahead of my parenting. But maybe I had to cross that line to know where it was.

headline: Holly-What?
text: Images from the Alternative Projections series, which shows the avant-garde side of film in Los Angeles.

headline: Nicholson Baker, William Safire and … Me?
text: On Saturday, I am supposed to speak to a group of aspiring journalists from Colgate University about, generally, the state of journalism and, specifically, the roles and duties of a copy editor. My presentation is tentatively called ‘‘How Many Journalism Credits Do You Have Now? And Is It Too Late to Change Your Major to Computer Technology? And Can I Have a Job When Your Start-Up Goes Live?’’ It will be a cautionary tale.

headline: Look of The Moment | Lauren Santo Domingo
text: The Look: Decorated. Red velvet bows on both shoulders and a high/low combination of brooches. “Girls in their 20s should wear costume jewelry and women in their 40s should wear diamonds, but in between it’s fun to mix the two,” according to Lauren Santo Domingo.

headline: Jan Brewer, Fighting for Special Interests and Cynical Politicos
text: Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona has been promoting her new memoir this week. It’s called “Scorpions for Breakfast: My Fight Against Special Interests, Liberal Media and Cynical Politicos to Secure America’s Border.”

headline: Sleep Medication: Mother’s New Little Helper
text: THE indiscriminate worries and ruminations that churn through the mind of Cheryl Downs McCoy are matters most working mothers have rifled through at some point: “I need to call that guy about fixing the car. I think I’ve run out my daughter’s favorite snack. Should I change the batteries in the smoke alarm?”

headline: Quite an Undertaker, in Brooklyn
text: Doris V. Amen, who owns Jurek-Park Slope Funeral Home in Brooklyn has a directing style all her own.

headline: Timescast | Modest Job Growth
text: November 4, 2011 - 80,000 jobs were added in the United States in October, underwhelming economists and the markets.

headline: Autodesk Bolsters 3-D Printing
text: Custom made and mass produced are getting harder to tell apart.

headline: Hey, Isn’t That ...?
text: IT may not have the ring of “gym, tan, laundry,” but former Representative Anthony D. Weiner’s post-scandal life as a new resident of Manhattan seems to revolve around playing hockey, going to the health club and dining out with his wife, Huma Abedin.

headline: Big Apple Circus
text: The circus, now in its 34th season, recently opened a new show titled “Dream Big” at Lincoln Center’s Damrosch Park.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review
text: A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Striving, With a Doppelgänger, to Break Through Corporeal Limits
text: For many current choreographers one dance doesn’t begin to tell the whole story. Maria Hassabi, born in Cyprus and based in New York since 1994, works in cycles: the roots of “Show,” her newest piece performed at the Kitchen on Thursday evening, were planted in 2007 with the creation of “Gloria,” a duet with the Greek dancer Hristoula Harakas. In it, the dancers moved from one position to the next, layering two solos on an empty stage and introducing the choreographer’s view of the body as sculpture.

headline: Six Renovations
text: Before the first open house, it is often a wise idea for sellers to renovate. That can be as extensive as a full gut job, or as limited as painting cabinets and replacing appliances.

headline: A Crown Heights School's Fall From Grace
text: P.S. 161 The Crown went from being top of the heap in test scores a few years ago, to one of the lowest scoring schools in Brooklyn's District 17. The school's admissions policies, formal and informal, changed over the years, and now The Crown faces its middle school grades being phased out.

headline: A C.E.O.’s Support System, a k a Husband
text: Here’s to Mark Rometty.

headline: The Final Countdown | Carlos Quirarte
text: The ING New York City Marathon is Sunday, and Carlos Quirarte, a co-owner of the Smile, is just about ready. “This is my first one,” he says. “And possibly my last.”

headline: Psst, Seller: Your Stove Is Showing Its Age
text: FOR those who wince every time they look at the cracked Formica counters in the kitchen, the decision to sell the old apartment may be especially liberating.

headline: Another Grim U.S. Unemployment Report
text: Jeff Sommer with Catherine Rampell on unemployment, David Gillen and Evelyn Rusli on LinkedIn, Gretchen Morgenson on MF Global and Robert Frank on flat taxes.

headline: Rodent in a Roadster and Other Spectacles in a One-Ring Realm
text: Any circus with a capybara riding in a car impresses me. Any circus with a capybara, period.

headline: The Colors and Sounds of Scriabin
text: Alexander Scriabin, the Russian composer, pianist, mystic and poet, was a stewing cauldron of creative forces. During his life, which was not long (he died at 43 of complications from an infection, in 1915), Scriabin claimed to have synesthetic associations of specific colors with musical keys, harmonies and sounds. The score to his ecstatic orchestra work “Prometheus: The Poem of Fire” includes a part for a color organ, intended to project colors into the concert hall.

headline: Wistful Reflection and No Regrets: A Life Evoked by Mother and Son
text: The singer Sandy Stewart is the queen of calm. In a world in which everyone is shouting to be heard, Ms. Stewart — appearing with her son, the world-class jazz pianist Bill Charlap, at the Algonquin Hotel’s Oak Room — is a voice of reflection. As she and Mr. Charlap performed standards on Wednesday, you had the feeling of being in the presence of an empathic sibyl gently reminding you that life goes on.

headline: Even With a Fancier Car, Mark Harmon Can Still Solve Crimes
text: With “John Sandford’s Certain Prey” on Sunday night, USA takes a gamble on two venerable institutions: the made-for-television movie and Mark Harmon.

headline: Radical Cameras in a Tumultuous Era
text: The work of the Photo League was trailblazing – and sometimes hell-raising.

headline: Sporting Big Feet and a Heart to Match
text: IN five features over two decades Christopher Munch has cultivated a singular career on the margins of the independent film world. Although his debut, “The Hours and Times” (1991), was grouped with the emerging New Queer Cinema, Mr. Munch, 49, has never fit in with a movement, and it’s hard to think of another working American filmmaker with a similar sensibility or array of interests.

headline: Modern Classics
text: Covers from past Penguin editions.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 4
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Books Podcast: Murakami’s Expanding Universe
text: In Sunday’s Book Review, Kathryn Schulz reviews Haruki Murakami’s mega-opus “1Q84.”

headline: A Quest for Corvettes Just as the Factory Built Them
text: HUNTINGDON VALLEY, Pa.

headline: Audi by Another Name
text: The August Horch Museum in Zwickau, Germany, celebrates the achievements of Audi’s founder, one of the most influential figures in German automotive history.

headline: Dreadful Debut for Subaru
text: RUST IN PEACE

headline: Another Nice Set We’re In, Stanley
text: MOST of us who love Laurel and Hardy, I’ve found, came across them first as children. For my generation, that meant the extensive exposure their short films and features received on television in the ’50s and ’60s, when they were a staple of Saturday-morning and after-school programming. The two-reel shorts, with their 20-minute running times, fit nicely into half-hour slots, with time left over for introductions by the local kiddie host and plenty of commercials for toys and candy.

headline: Authorities in Florida Seize Painting on Loan to a Museum
text: A 16th century painting on loan to a Florida museum was seized Friday by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents because it is suspected of having been looted during World War II. The Pinacoteca di Brera in Milan, Italy, had loaned Girolamo Romano’s 1538 painting, “Christ Carrying the Cross Dragged by a Rogue,” to the Mary Brogan Museum of Art and Science in Tallahassee in March as part of an exhibition of Baroque painting.

headline: Honda Considers a Quick Upgrade of Civic
text: AFTER a thorough revamping of its perennially hot-selling Civic for 2012, Honda may return to the drawing board to address complaints that the redesigned car is too dull and too cheaply built.

headline: Need Live Music or Not? Well, Why Not Try Both
text: Live music doesn’t always improve a dance. For some choreographers, live musicians are expensively irrelevant to their work or threateningly distracting. Dusan Tynek is not one of those choreographers. The participation of the string quartet Ethel in the second program of his company’s two-week run at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center made for an especially vibrant Thursday night.

headline: Israeli Juniors, 3 for 3, Keep a Streak Alive
text: The Israeli juniors have been on a tear, going three for three. Last year, they won the World Junior Team Championship. In July, they captured the European junior team title. And last month, they won the open Transnational Teams at the world championships.

headline: Singles, Sex and Race in the Age of Bebop
text: A college jazz student once told me of peers who painstakingly tried to recreate the saxophone solos of Charlie Parker note for note. Parker’s flights, of course, were improvised; the reproductions, naturally, ran the risk of losing spontaneity. “Shadows,” the Hoi Polloi theater company’s staging of the landmark 1959 independent film by John Cassavetes, takes similar chances, and beats the odds.

headline: Jockeys Call for Churchill to Continue to Contribute to Disability Fund
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Thoroughbred racing’s top riders Friday called for Churchill Downs Incorporated to reverse its decision to stop contributing annually to the Jockeys’ Guild’s permanent disability fund.

headline: City Will Take Bids for a Casual Replacement for Tavern on the Green
text: Parks Department officials confirmed a report on the DNAinfo blog thatthey will seek bidders to run a smaller, more casual restaurant at the former Tavern on the Green in Central Park.

headline: Juho Pohjonen
text: Zankel Hall

headline: Schola Cantorum de Venezuela
text: Alice Tully Hall

headline: BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIC
text: Millennium Theater

headline: A Divorce Seems to Resound and the Real Issue Is, Why?
text: All over America this week, parents faced a very modern problem: how to explain the Kim Kardashian divorce to their children.

headline: Storm Has Vermont Scrambling to Find Beds for Mentally Ill
text: WATERBURY, Vt. — Among the casualties of the flooding that ravaged Vermont during Tropical Storm Irene was a faded brick hospital that housed the state’s most seriously ill psychiatric patients.

headline: Artifacts | Maurizio Cattelan Gives His ‘All’
text: All summer long there were rumors. For his retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum, Maurizio Cattelan had a big surprise in store. He was making a secret new work. He was going to do something that had never been done before. Since Cattelan, 51, has anchored his career to provocation, everyone believed it.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 4
text: More Photographs

headline: Oh, Those Blundering Americans!
text: It could be that just this once, the wise and world-weary British spy has it all wrong, and C.I.A. brutality actually prevented a terrorist attack. Maybe, just maybe, Israeli soldiers didn’t deliberately kill an unarmed pro-Palestinian demonstrator.

headline: When Two Beautiful Lives Begin to Unravel
text: NEW HAVEN — The young couple in “Belleville,” a quietly devastating new play by Amy Herzog, would seem to have everything going for them. Attractive, amiable and well educated, they are still playfully affectionate after five years of marriage. Sure, their funky new apartment in Paris is on the scruffier outskirts of the city, in the neighborhood that gives the play its title. But what’s better than to be young, in love and living in Paris — anywhere in Paris?

headline: Greek Leader's Uncertain Future
text: November 4, 2011 - Prime Minister George A. Papandreou faces an uncertain confidence vote, a day after calling off Greece's new debt deal.

headline: Producer Explains Scrapping ‘Funny Girl’
text: The Broadway producer Bob Boyett had never heard so much bad news in a single week: Four longtime investors in his shows had each backed out of his latest, a $12 million Broadway-bound revival of the hit 1964 musical “Funny Girl,” he said in an interview on Friday.

headline: Chic in Review | Occupy Soho?
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 49
text: Rumors circulated of a looming eviction from Zuccotti Park after tensions between Mayor Bloomberg and Occupy Wall Street intensified. On Friday, protesters accused the mayor of twisting facts after he complained that the occupiers were endangering New Yorkers by not reporting crimes committed in Zuccotti Park. [Atlantic Wire, Occupy Wall St., City Room]

headline: Education Law Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: Antifracking Movement
text: To the Editor:

headline: Homeless Veterans?
text: To the Editor:

headline: John R. Opel, Who Made I.B.M. a Colossus, Dies at 86
text: John R. Opel, who presided over I.B.M. in its final period of dominance in the information-processing industry and oversaw the company’s move into personal computers, died on Thursday in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 86.

headline: Due Process for Dictators
text: To the Editor:

headline: The World Leader in Health Care Costs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Royal Delta Wins Breeders’ Cup Ladies’ Classic
text: So much for this being the day of the favorites. There was a few nice payouts on $2 bets to win Friday. However, Royal Delta, a slight 2-1 favorite, captured the $2 million Breeders’ Cup Ladies’ Classic.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,814 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Keeping It Simple and Convenient
text: JUST south of the Tappan Zee Bridge, Bistro Z at the Doubletree Hotel in Tarrytown could not be more convenient — not only for the passing traveler, but also as a gathering spot for local business and social events.

headline: Patriots Are Masters at Learning From Losing
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — There are no signs of black bunting adorning any part of Gillette Stadium and, at 5-2, there is clearly no sense of impending doom among the New England Patriots. In their minds, they remain one of the elite N.F.L. teams.

headline: Protesters Blocked From Returning to Bahrain’s Pearl Square
text: Hundreds of protesters were prevented from returning to a symbolic square in Bahrain’s capital, Manama, on Friday, following the funeral of a man the main opposition party said was beaten to death by security forces this week.

headline: Siri Failure Leaves iPhones Mute
text: No wonder Apple says Siri — its voice-activated “virtual assistant” for the new iPhone — is in beta.

headline: 15 Years That Changed Photography
text: Sixty years ago this week, the Photo League fell victim to Cold War witch hunts and blacklists, closing its doors after 15 intense years of trailblazing – and sometimes hell-raising – documentary photography.  From unabashedly leftist roots, the group influenced a generation of photographers who transformed the documentary tradition, elevating it to heady aesthetic heights.

headline: This Sunday: Butter With Your Toast, Mr. President?
text: Predicting the future may be impossible, but that doesn’t stop millions of people from trying. And because so many of them do try, somebody is bound to be correct, and then that person is hailed as a genius until the next thing comes along and then they’re back to being fools like the rest of us.

headline: Where the Menu Knows Your Name
text: CAN success spoil Chef Luis Restaurant? Not judging by the crowds at lunch and dinner at this cozy New Canaan hangout. Four years ago, the Guatemalan chef Luis Lopez opened a cramped, minuscule eatery that was jammed day and night, even without a liquor license. It was a real sleeper, with delicious food at fair market prices. He credited many of his culinary skills to his apprenticeship at Solé, an Italian restaurant a few doors away on the same street.

headline: Three New Elements Named: Darmstadtium, Roentgenium and Copernicium
text: Calling Tom Lehrer.

headline: Games to Watch on Saturday
text: NO. 1 LOUISIANA STATE AT NO. 2 ALABAMA8 p.m. Eastern, CBS

headline: Bill Cunningham | Fall?
text: There was the expected surge in all-black, but more important were the neutrals mixed with fur vests and yards of scarves.

headline: Free Lodging in Old-Brooklyn Elegance, Just for a Select Group
text: The hotel lobby buzzes like any other in New York on a weekday morning, as families from around the world excitedly examine maps, while bellhops in khaki pants and polo shirts give directions and load luggage carts.

headline: Life Sentence for Possession of Child Pornography Spurs Debate Over Severity
text: Does downloading child pornography from the Internet deserve the same criminal punishment as first-degree murder?

headline: Expressive Cabernet Francs
text: Chilly autumn nights call for warming, filling reds to accompany beef, lamb and other hearty fare. Increasingly, cabernet franc seems a more interesting choice than simpler merlot, long touted as Long Island’s signature grape and wine.

headline: A Pub With Pirogi and Lamb Meatloaf
text: SAPSUCKERS Hops and Grub, on Main Street in Huntington, is a pub with a pedigree. Its owners, Nino Antuzzi and Kelley Danek, also run Red and Osteria da Nino, both in Huntington, and Café Red in Kings Park. Food items served at Sapsuckers have pedigrees of their own: the bread is from Tom Cat Bakery in Queens, the organic eggs are from the nearby Makinajian Farm, the chicken is Bell & Evans and the pork, Berkshire.

headline: Apple Doles Out Stock to Keep Top Executives
text: One of the biggest questions about Apple’s future has been whether its top executives would head for the exits after the death of the company’s chief executive and cofounder Steve Jobs. Apple just gave them a big incentive to stay put.

headline: Mets’ First Off-Season Move: Layoffs
text: The Mets announced Friday that they recently laid off nearly 10 percent of their 180 front-office employees, a development that will only further discourage a fan base bracing for the possible departure of Jose Reyes, their free-agent shortstop.

headline: Hot Vietnamese Crepes or Grilled Chicken Satay
text: WHEN memories of a hot rice crepe trump those of the arugula-rich salad from my fall garden, it’s time to share the name of the restaurant that makes it.

headline: Postcard From L.S.U.: N.F.L. Bloodlines Infuse the Tigers With Talent
text: BATON ROUGE, La. — While success on the field usually materializes because of work ethic and talent, a little boost from the gene pool never hurts.

headline: March Against Pipeline Planned
text: Environmental groups are mobilizing for a demonstration at the White House on Sunday against the proposed 1,700-mile Keystone XL pipeline. A decision is expected from the State Department in coming months on whether to allow construction of the pipeline, which would carry heavy crude oil drawn from Alberta to the Gulf of Mexico. Environmentalists contend that extracting and burning the oil will increase greenhouse gas emissions and contribute to climate change. Some have expressed concern about potential contamination of the Ogallala Aquifer, which lies beneath much of the pipeline’s route, in the event of a spill. President Obama said that the decision would ultimately be his and that he would put a priority on health and safety.

headline: Larceny Pays for Oklahoma State
text: Asked to cut through the smoke and mirrors, Bill Young, the Oklahoma State defensive coordinator, shuffles a few papers and asks for a timeout. Digging through the Cowboys’ defensive statistics rivals the forensic anthropological plot of a “Bones” episode. Even Young needs to pause occasionally as he considers what this season’s evidence means.

headline: Online Protest of Bank Fees Gains Followers
text: Unhappy with the prospect of paying higher bank fees, Kristen Christian, a 27-year-old art gallery owner from Los Angeles, did more than complain to her 500 friends on Facebook. She organized a Facebook event for Saturday, Nov. 5. She called it Bank Transfer Day and urged people to move their money from large private banks to credit unions or somewhere else closer to home.

headline: Operating in the Shadows of Power in Russia
text: MOSCOW

headline: ‘Focus’
text: A decade back, I flirted with jogging enough to get a taste of its unique mix of ecstasy and agony. Ecstagony. It’s an undeniable high, animal and spiritual at the same time. It seems to me, if it doesn’t kill you, it’s actually good for you.

headline: Focus
text: The filmmaker Jeff Scher presents an abstract celebration of the New York City Marathon.

headline: Gov. Brewer’s Power Grab
text: In 2000, Arizonans voted to take the power of legislative redistricting out of the hands of statehouse incumbents and create an independent commission free from the gerrymandering of political bosses. This signal reform for fairer elections was blatantly undermined last week when Gov. Jan Brewer led fellow Republicans in the State Senate to oust the chairwoman of the independent commission on unsubstantiated charges of “gross misconduct.” What it really was was a gross power play by Governor Brewer to ensure a more Republican-friendly map.

headline: More on Calculating Poverty
text: Poverty researchers have been debating alternatives to the traditional poverty rate for years. So it’s not surprising that some people wondered why we chose the particular method that we used for today’s article about poverty.

headline: Corzine Out as Search for MF Global Funds Continues
text: The missing customer money at MF Global is still missing.

headline: Reviewing the Audi A6
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the Audi A6, a perennial thorn in the side of the BMW 5 Series and Mercedes-Benz E-Class that now finds itself in the shadow, at least aesthetically, of its sibling, the A7.

headline: Edging Toward Equality
text: On Thursday, the Senate Judiciary Committee began consideration of a measure that would repeal the Defense of Marriage Act, the deplorable 1996 law that bars federal recognition of same-sex marriages and denies lawfully married same-sex couples benefits granted other married couples, including Social Security survivor payments and unpaid leave to care for a seriously ill spouse.

headline: Salvaging Abandoned Bikes, Making Room for Others
text: THEIR frames molder and peel in the city’s musty depths. Hundreds — perhaps thousands — rest in haphazard jumbles, their surfaces pocked with rust, their tubes airless and stiffened by time.

headline: Facts Blur as Online Feud Ends in a Draw
text: MEXICO CITY — Some bloggers and Twitter users claiming to be part of the hacker movement Anonymous now say they have abandoned plans to expose collaborators working with the Zetas crime syndicate because the friend they say the gang kidnapped has been released.

headline: With a Book, the Last Democrat in the White House Tries to Help the Current One
text: Last summer, as Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton celebrated the former president’s 65th birthday with a party at their rented Hamptons home, talk among their guests turned to President Obama’s travails over the debt crisis and doubts about his re-election. “I’m really trying to help him,” the white-haired former president said, shaking his head, “but he seems to have lost his narrative.”

headline: The Lessons of Genocide, Taught by the Son of Parents Who Survived It
text: Just days after liberation, surrounded by starvation and disease, a young woman looked into a soldier’s movie camera and described the horrors of the Nazi concentration camp at Bergen-Belsen.

headline: Cemetery Walks and Gin Cocktails
text: As executive director of the Historic Districts Council, Simeon Bankoff has been an advocate for the preservation of the city’s historic neighborhoods since 2000. Lately he has been immersed in a high-stakes battle to prevent Donald Trump’s son-in-law, Jared Kushner, from crowning the Puck Building, a designated city landmark, with a two-story glass penthouse. Mr. Bankoff, 41, lives in a 105-year-old brick row house in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, with his wife, Hafina Allen, 40, a candidate for a master’s in social work at N.Y.U.; their cat, Inky; and several pet rodents (three chinchillas, two guinea pigs and a hamster).

headline: Lottery Numbers
Wild Turkeys Get a Taste of Domesticity, Much to a Borough’s Chagrin
text: Michael Budano is fearless. As a teenager in East Harlem, he polished the shoes of mobsters like Frank Costello and Joseph Valachi without blinking an eye.

headline: A Good Day for Groupon and Internet Start-Ups
text: After a months-long journey filled with blunders, Groupon punched its ticket to the public markets on Friday. And the daily deals site got a warm reception, a welcome sign for Internet start-ups still waiting to go public.

headline: Welcome Back
text: A year from now, Americans will choose whether to reelect President Obama or to replace him; they will pick 33 senators and every member of the House; and they will argue about it with each other all along the way. Campaign Stops will join this ongoing conversation by presenting the sharpest opinion pieces on the 2012 election, just as it did in 2008. We’ll hear from Times columnists and contributing writers and many other people who have something to say. Campaign Stops will examine the battle for public opinion state by state, focusing particularly on the ten or twelve states that emerge as key to the election. It will also be a laboratory of sorts for proposals to improve how we make our political choices.

headline: The Prime Minister and the Sunnis
text: The authoritarian tendencies of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq are well known. But the arrest of more than 600 Iraqis whom the government describes as suspected former members of Saddam Hussein’s Baath Party and army is particularly cynical and reckless. With American troops scheduled to withdraw by year’s end, the last thing Mr. Maliki should be doing is stoking sectarian tensions.

headline: Brooklyn Legislator Doesn’t Testify at His Bribery Trial
text: William F. Boyland Jr., a Brooklyn assemblyman accused of taking bribes from a health care organization in return for carrying out official acts in Albany on its behalf, declined to take the stand in his defense on Friday, and his lawyers called only two witnesses before resting their case.

headline: The Great Escape
text: On Nov. 7, 1861, Brig. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant withdrew his federal forces after a creditable but inconclusive battle against Confederates encamped at Belmont, Mo. But as the men withdrew to transports waiting for them along the Mississippi River, four soldiers from the Seventh Iowa Infantry hurried back to the battlefield to rescue their popular lieutenant colonel, Augustus Wentz, who had been struck in the side by a bullet and left behind.

headline: After Years of Conflict, a New Dynamic in Wolf Country
text: JACKSON, Mont. —   As a fourth-generation rancher, Dean B. Peterson has a complicated relationship with wolves.

headline: Bypassing Obvious Stars, for One From Overseas
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

headline: Occupying the National Debate
text: The Occupy Wall Street protest continues to inspire demonstrators across the nation and beyond. At midweek, protesters of the economy’s woeful status quo were reported gathered in more than 70 American cities, while there were similar demonstrations in London, Frankfurt and, of course, Cannes, where the G-20 governments wrestled with the threat of more economic disaster.

headline: Cain Accuser Tells of Pattern of Behavior, Lawyer Attests
text: WASHINGTON — The lawyer for one of the women who accused Herman Cain of sexual harassment said Friday that Mr. Cain engaged in a “series of inappropriate behaviors and unwanted advances” toward his client over two months in the 1990s, and he directly accused Mr. Cain, a Republican presidential candidate, of not telling the truth about his behavior.

headline: Prosecutors Target Gang in Harlem; 19 Charged
text: The street gang that prowled part of West 129th Street went by several names, including Goodfellas, One Twenty-Nine and the New Dons. Its specialty was firearms, authorities said, which members hid in storm drains, on rooftops and beneath mailboxes.

headline: Hello, It’s  a Message From Mitt Romney About Rick Perry
text: Mitt Romney may be skipping some major G.O.P. events in Iowa this week, but he’s still got his eye on someone who isn’t: his rival Rick Perry.

headline: Silicon Valley Wows Educators, and Woos Them
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Three times over the last two years, school officials from Little Falls, Minn., have escaped the winter cold for two-day trips to Silicon Valley. Their destination: the headquarters of Apple.

headline: Finding a Middle Ground for the Gray Wolf
text: The dynamic between ranchers and conservationists over the rebounding gray wolf population has begun to change.

headline: Win Seals Filly’s Title and Bolsters Mott’s Haul
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Bill Mott likes Churchill Downs. He should, as he is this storied racetrack’s leading trainer with more than 650 career victories. He likes the Breeders’ Cup Ladies’ Classic even better. No wonder: when Royal Delta rolled past the finish line Friday it was Mott’s fourth victory in the $2 million race and his second in a row.

headline: Beckham Pushes to Finish Line in Last Year of Contract
text: CARSON, Calif. — In his last game before joining the Los Angeles Galaxy in 2007, David Beckham played on a sprained left ankle that received three cortisone shots. Yet he stayed on the field and helped Real Madrid win Spain’s first division.

headline: The Aging of Spanish Democracy
text: Madrid

headline: Gauging the Impact of Yiddish
text: MORE New Yorkers speak Yiddish at home than Korean, according to the 2010 Census, but that insight only begins to explain the impact of the language and its associated culture on the city. Two new books fill that void: “Yiddishkeit: Jewish Vernacular and the New Land” (Abrams ComicArts), edited by Harvey Pekar and Paul Buhle, and “All Together Different: Yiddish Socialists, Garment Workers, and the Labor Roots of Multiculturalism” (NYU Press), by Daniel Katz.

headline: Opposites, Obama and Sarkozy Attract, if Uneasily
text: CANNES, France — Just a few hours after the United Nations Security Council authorized military action against Libya in March, President Obama placed a call to the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Photos
text: Ruth Madoff spoke out, the crisis in Europe took new turns and Groupon finally went public.

headline: To Fix Housing, See the Data
text: In Miami recently, I met up with Laurie Goodman, a senior managing director of Amherst Securities. I’d been trying to meet her ever since I’d read an article that she had written in March entitled “The Case for Principal Reductions.” But our schedules never seemed to mesh. So when I noticed that we were both going to be at a conference in Miami, I wangled a breakfast appointment. It was one of the more illuminating breakfasts I’ve had in a while.

headline: A Floor Made for Dancing, but Not for Modesty
text: More than art was on display at an after-hours party at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night. A mirrored dance floor shimmered in the Temple of Dendur, but after a few turns on the floor it became clear to anyone wearing a dress — and almost every woman was wearing a dress — that this was a bad idea.

headline: Saturday: One in a Biergarten
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — The first thing I noticed about this grid was the unusual pattern of black squares. It looked like the “line through a circle” symbol for something that’s not allowed. The next thing I noticed was the six 15 letter entries: I’m always impressed when constructors can make their long entries cross like that.

headline: The Best Perk in Politics
text: We have been hearing a lot about important politicians and private jets.

headline: Pursuing Self-Improvement, at the Risk of Self-Acceptance
text: SOMETIMES I get tired of always striving to be better — of knowing there are ways, endless ways, I can improve myself or members of my immediate family.

headline: Romney Debt Plan Includes Medicare Overhaul and Social Security Changes
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney, in a speech before a conservative group here on Friday, offered his most detailed plan yet to cut government spending and lower the federal debt, including an overhaul of Medicare and significant changes to Social Security.

headline: Postcard From Alabama: Playing for the Stones, Rooting for the Tide
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Chuck Leavell has traveled the world with the Rolling Stones, but he still calls Tuscaloosa home. And he still counts himself as a die-hard fan of Alabama football.

headline: Students Repeat a Poem’s Slurs, Surprising the Poets and an Elite Bronx School
text: The poetry assembly on Tuesday morning at the Horace Mann School, in the Bronx, was meant to be provocative. The visiting poets who led it asked students to write words on index cards — remembrances, colors and references to pop-culture icons — that would then converge as poems.

headline: Special Parking Rules
text: Because of Id al-Adha, the Islamic Feast of Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Texas Gun Instructor’s Ad Leads to State Inquiry
text: MASON, Tex. — Crockett Keller, a weapons instructor who runs a general store in this small town in Central Texas, needed a few more students for a recent concealed-handgun course. He decided to put an ad on a local country music radio station, but his attempt to prohibit certain students from signing up has jeopardized his state-certified status and earned him praise, condemnation and even death threats from people around the world.

headline: MF Global Clients Fear for What They Left
text: Igor Gavrylov of Kiev, Ukraine, had about $100,000 at MF Global when it collapsed on Monday, although he managed to pull out $150,000 last week.

headline: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
text: Have you no sense of decency, Twitter-verse?

headline: Settlement Prompts Fear About Cuts to Medicaid
text: When New York City agreed to pay $70 million this week to settle accusations of Medicaid fraud in a program intended to take care of disabled people at home, it seemed like a victory for the disabled.

headline: Old Subway Pros, Separating Drunk From Wallet
text: In the world of crime statistics, there is a certain subsection of victim on the city subways: a reveler who, overserved during a night on the town, nods off on a train. He wakes with a flapping, precision-cut hole in his trousers and cool, thin air where his wallet used to be.

headline: At Jefferies, Laying Bare Its Exposure to Euro Debt
text: After another day of investor anxiety about the Jefferies Group’s exposure to European debt, the brokerage firm took the unusual step of detailing exactly what debt it holds from Greece, Italy, Ireland, Portugal and Spain.

headline: Don’t Call Herman a Monster
text: Oh, Herman.

headline: Corrections: November 5
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 4
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a very early snowfall, a statue that moved to the finish line of the marathon and a junkyard soccer game in Queens.

headline: Pursuing a Piracy Claim Against Apple
text: WOODBRIDGE, Conn. — David Gelernter is known for many things. As a pioneering computer scientist, he first earned renown by connecting computers together into collaborative networks. Then in 1993, he gained the kind of fame no one wants, as a victim of Theodore Kaczynski, the Unabomber, who mailed a pipe bomb to his office at Yale University that left him gravely injured.

headline: A Church. A Shelter. Is It Safe?
text: HARD by the mouth of the Lincoln Tunnel, on one of the last ungentrified blocks of Midtown Manhattan, Metropolitan Community Church sits sandwiched between neighbors with pull-down metal gates, its front doors looking almost like the entrance to a loading dock.

headline: Lufthansa in Preliminary Deal to Sell a British Unit
text: The International Airlines Group, the parent company of British Airways and the Spanish carrier Iberia, said on Friday that it had reached a preliminary agreement with Lufthansa of Germany to acquire its British Midland International unit. Details of the transaction, including a binding purchase agreement, were still being negotiated, I.A.G. said. The sale would also be subject to the completion of due diligence and clearance from competition regulators. News of the prospective takeover came as I.A.G. announced a 31 percent drop in third-quarter operating profit to 363 million euros, from 528 million euros a year earlier. The group blamed rising fuel prices and weaker travel demand from leisure passengers. Lufthansa had sought for several months to sell British Midland, which analysts have valued at 300 million to 400 million euros, or $414.5 million to $552.6 million.

headline: Along the Route, Neighborhood Snapshots of New York’s Progression
text: As dusk fell, a woman, head to toe in black, bounded down the sidewalk, with a leash in one hand and a baby tucked against her chest. By the curb, two men in suits loudly debated the stock market. And at a Mexican bistro, patrons sipped Chardonnay from stemless glasses under graffiti framed as art.

headline: Taming Unruly Wind Power
text: For decades, electric companies have swung into emergency mode when demand soars on blistering hot days, appealing to households to use less power. But with the rise of wind energy, utilities in the Pacific Northwest are sometimes dealing with the opposite: moments when there is too much electricity for the grid to soak up.

headline: Brazil’s Rising Influence Meets Resistance
text: Ambitious Brazilian projects in Latin America are meeting resistance and resentment — none more so than a plan to build a road through an indigenous territory in a remote corner of the Bolivian Amazon.

headline: Brazil’s Long Shadow Vexes Some Neighbors
text: LA PAZ, Bolivia — Sandal-clad indigenous protesters have excoriated their president, calling him a “lackey of Brazil.” Angry demonstrations in front of Brazil’s embassy here denounced its “imperialist” tendencies. Bolivian intellectuals lambasted the “São Paulo bourgeoisie,” likening them to the slave hunters who expanded the boundaries of colonial Brazil.

headline: A Changing Course
text: Snapshots along the New York City Marathon route show the city’s evolution.

headline: Occupy Wall Street Protest Reaches a Crossroads
text: THE signs seemed to point toward the end of Occupy Wall Street. The day after the city stripped the protesters encamped in Lower Manhattan of their generators and fuel, the Northeast was hit with a bone-chilling snowstorm that blanketed their tents and tarps with sleet and ice, and left at least one protester hospitalized for hypothermia. Yet the encampment at Zuccotti Park endured.

headline: At the Film Market, Where Deals Are Made
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — A crusty old film business operative once said the Cannes film festival was like spending a week in Nicky Blair’s. You’d have to remember the late Nicky Blair’s namesake hang-out on Sunset Boulevard to get the joke.

headline: Burdening Children With a Flawed Policy
text: Every fall, thousands of upper-middle-class parents here awake in night sweats, overcome by the anxiety of trying to get their children into costly and prestigious preschools. To say this, of course, is to say something as obvious as “pork chops cost more at Dean & DeLuca than they do at Key Food.” Two years ago an entire documentary film, “Nursery University,” was devoted to the subject. Over the years, the media have lavished so much attention on the difficulties endured by the well-off in the competition for elite education that many of us have retained only vague notions of the real challenges faced in the world of early child care and learning.

headline: Podcast: Jobs Report, European Debt and the Flat Tax
text: Each month, the Labor Department issues a report on jobs and unemployment. It would be a relief to get one showing that jobs are being created in large numbers in the United States, and that unemployment in rapidly sinking.

headline: Giants’ Secondary Faces Test in Patriots’ Passing
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ trip to New England on Sunday will represent the biggest test of their secondary thanks largely to a cast of Patriots’ stars who are in the midst of an impressive season even by their lofty standards.

headline: The Complex 1980s, Viewed by 47 Artists
text: The 1980s were a complicated decade for American art. New York was back from the brink of bankruptcy, but gentrification was killing bohemianism. The art market flourished, but it also created a lopsided demand for painting and other market-friendly mediums. Art stars were born, but artists were dying of AIDS. All of this serves as a backdrop for “Circa 1986” at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art in Peekskill.

headline: L.S.U.-Alabama Assures Tuscaloosa of Many Winners
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — When it comes to the college football showdown between No. 1 Louisiana State and No. 2 Alabama on Saturday night, there are already plenty of winners.

headline: The Fruits of Collaboration
text: In the end, most art is the result of collaboration. Paintings make their way into our lives because art dealers and curators show them and patrons collect them. Music, theater and dance productions require the coordinated efforts of performers and directors from the very beginning. Even literature involves a host of players, from editor to bookseller. But the five exhibitions on view at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield — and one in the garden that was part of the grouping but closed earlier this month — are not about the patron-artist relationship. Nor are they large-scale projects that engage the community, as dozens of artists have done in recent years. Instead, several works showcase creative teams.

headline: Faces Telling American Stories
text: Portraits were not just a popular genre in the early days of this nation; they were among the only art that patrons would pay for. As a result, many American artists went abroad, hoping to test their abilities on juicier subjects, like allegorical or historical epics. But portraiture has remained an important American genre, something that can serve as a springboard to larger ideas. This is evident in some of the works in “American Portraits: Treasures From the Parrish Art Museum” in Southampton.

headline: A War of Currents, and Rival Geniuses
text: The darker side of Thomas Alva Edison is gradually revealed by Ben Clawson in his absorbing new play, “The Dangers of Electric Lighting.” The legendary inventor’s habits are messy, his ego is enormous, and he proves to be ruthless with his competitors.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Liberia: Candidate Withdraws
text: The opposition presidential candidate Winston Tubman, left, said Friday that he would not participate in Liberia’s runoff election set for Tuesday against President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, but the election commission said the vote would take place anyway. “Holding elections when there are outstanding issues and challenges undermines our national peace and endangers our democracy,” Mr. Tubman said in a statement to supporters after returning from a two-day trip to Abuja, Nigeria, where he met with President Goodluck Jonathan. He urged supporters to boycott the polls and said he would not recognize the new government.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Cardinals’ Bob Forsch, Dies at 61; Pitched in 3 World Series
text: Bob Forsch, who threw two no-hitters and won 163 games for St. Louis, more than any other Cardinals pitcher except the Hall of Famers Bob Gibson and Jesse Haines, died Thursday at his home near Tampa, Fla. He was 61.

headline: Italy: Torrential Rains Kill 6
text: Torrential rains killed at least six people in Genoa on Friday, in the worst flooding the port city has seen in years, officials said. Entire neighborhoods were blocked, as water swept through the city after several streams overflowed. Some victims, including three children, drowned when water rushed through the building where they had sought refuge.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Gingrich Tailors Message at Iowa G.O.P. Dinner
text: DES MOINES, Iowa — With two months to go before the Iowa caucuses, Newt Gingrich appeared to help his chances on Friday night at the Ronald Reagan dinner, this state’s marquee G.O.P. fundraiser, winning wide applause with his proposal to challenge President Obama to unmoderated three-hour-long Lincoln-Douglas style debates.

headline: Iraq: American Soldier Killed
text: An American soldier died in an attack in Iraq, the military said Friday in the first report of a combat fatality since President Obama announced last month that all United States troops would leave the country by the end of the year. An Iraqi security service official said the soldier died from a grenade thrown at his convoy in Kirkuk, north of Baghdad, on Thursday. Two other Americans have died in noncombat accidents since Mr. Obama’s Oct. 21 announcement; the last combat fatality had been on Sept. 29.

headline: Leader of FARC Guerrilla Movement Is Killed in Combat, Colombian Officials Say
text: The leader of Colombia’s largest guerrilla group was killed Friday in a military raid, Colombian government officials said.

headline: George Washington’s Men, 200 Years Later
text: New York’s Veterans Corps of Artillery dates to 1790.

headline: Sam Fink, Letterer and Illustrator of Historical Texts, Dies at 95
text: Sam Fink, a calligrapher who in a series of books reverentially inscribed the precise texts of four historical documents — each a beacon of liberty — and illustrated them with sometimes whimsical, often pungent drawings, died on Tuesday in Jerusalem. He was 95.

headline: No. 1 vs. No. 2, Through the Years
text: In the last 40 years, the Nos. 1 and 2 teams have met only 12 times in the regular season (not counting conference championship games). The No. 1 team has won seven times; only four times did the winner go on to win a national title. Here are six of the best No. 1 vs. No. 2 matchups.

headline: Allen Mandelbaum, Translator of ‘Divine Comedy,’ Dies at 85
text: Allen Mandelbaum, whose fluid, sensitive English version of Dante’s “Divine Comedy” stamped his reputation as one of the world’s premier translators of Italian and classical poetry, died on Oct. 27 in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 85.

headline: Leonard Stone, Actor in ‘Willy Wonka,’ Dies at 87
