text: Leonard Stone, a familiar character actor on television and in films who had a memorable turn as an overindulgent father in the 1971 movie “Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory,” died on Wednesday at his home in San Diego. He was 87.

headline: Arctic Hoop Dreams
text: The Tikigaq School of Point Hope, Alaska, with fewer than 60 students, has one of the state’s best basketball teams.

headline: The World This Week, Part 1
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: The World This Week, Part 2
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Hundreds of students took to the streets in Jammu to protest the new recruitment policy of the state government. Under this policy, a new recruit would get only 50 percent of the basic pay for the first two years and 75 percent for the following three years without any allowances (The Indian Express).Manipur: A three-day “total blockade” called by Naga leaders has begun in parts of Manipur, despite an appeal by Home Minister P. Chidambaram and Chief Minister Okram Ibobi to suspend the agitation, reports the Assam Tribune. Naga leaders say this is to protest the Manipur government’s agreement with leaders of the Sadar Hills Districthood Demand Committee to create a new district.

headline: Agudelo Summoned to Olympic Training Camp
text: The Red Bulls’ elimination from the M.L.S. playoffs late Thursday night came with a silver lining for at least one member of the team: with several free weeks on his hands, striker Juan Agudelo was called up to a training camp being held for the under-23 national team next week in Duisburg, Germany.

headline: Despite Leader’s Death, Colombian Rebels Remain Dangerous, Analysts Say
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The killing of the top commander of Colombia’s largest guerrilla group dealt what might be the most severe blow yet to the four-decade-old insurgency, but security experts said Saturday that the rebels still had the ability to regroup and carry on the fight.

headline: Finding a Middle Ground for the Gray Wolf
text: The dynamic between ranchers and conservationists over the rebounding gray wolf population has begun to change.

headline: Concussion Safety and Leather Helmets
text: Bring back leather helmets? A recent study on helmet safety isn’t going that far, saying modern helmets provide better protection against major injuries like skull fractures and brain bleeds. But the study did contain a surprise.

headline: General Fired Over Karzai Remarks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A senior American general stationed in Afghanistan has been fired for criticizing President Hamid Karzai in a published interview.

headline: The Ride of Joseph O’Brien’s 18-Year-Old Life
text: Two years ago on the annual O’Brien family trip from Ireland to the Breeders’ Cup, Joseph O’Brien might have been looking forward to an outing to Disneyland as much as he was to seeing a string of thoroughbreds trained by his father, Aidan O’Brien, run their races at Santa Anita Park.

headline: Andy Rooney, a Cranky Voice of CBS, Dies at 92
text: Andy Rooney, whose prickly wit was long a mainstay of CBS News and whose homespun commentary on “60 Minutes,” delivered every week from 1978 until 2011, made him a household name, died on Friday in New York City.

headline: A Championship That Doesn’t Have All the Best
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — However successful the 2011 Breeders’ Cup turns out to be, it could have been a lot better. Once again thoroughbred racing’s year-end showcase has been robbed of its brightest stars.

headline: Alex Ferguson: A Silver Anniversary for United’s Silver Collector
text: It says a lot about Alex Ferguson’s 25 years at Manchester United that it is hard for many to imagine the club without him. But United had a rich, full history long before Ferguson left the docks in Aberdeen to go into soccer management. There were the Busby Babes of the mid-1950s. The Munich disaster of 1958 that killed or injured many of them. The rebuilt team that won the European Cup in 1968. Stars like Duncan Edwards and Bobby Charlton, Denis Law and George Best.

headline: 25 Years Later, a Marathon Finish Still Inspires
text: In Bob Wieland’s world, obstacles create opportunities and conquests breed inspiration.

headline: Giants’ Cruz Mixing Cultures, and Scoring Touchdowns
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Victor Cruz scored his first regular-season N.F.L. touchdown Sept. 25, he immediately broke into a salsa dance in the end zone. It was meant as a tribute to his grandmother, who used to make him glide around the house with her when he was a child, but it became a point of pride for many Hispanics.

headline: Big Yardage Out of Nowhere for the Bills
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Fred Jackson played football at tiny Division III Coe College in Iowa, in a midlevel arena league and, for one year, in Germany. He was underestimated and overshadowed, dismissed and discounted — even by his wife, Danielle, who selected another running back, Michael Turner of Atlanta, ahead of him in her fantasy football draft. And now?

headline: Cowboys’ Season Is Slipping Away
text: IRVING, Tex. — Judging by all the clichés that surround them, the Dallas Cowboys surely realize their season has reached the Eve of Dysfunction.

headline: Andy Rooney: 1919-2011
text: Long a mainstay of CBS News, his prickly wit and homespun commentary on “60 Minutes,” made him a household name.

headline: Kickers Are Becoming Can’t-Miss Performers
text: When Rob Bironas runs on the field to attempt a field goal for the Tennessee Titans, he usually does not know how long it is. He finds that out by looking at the box score after the game. It is a quirk he developed early in his career, figuring that he uses the same leg swing whether the kick is from 20 yards or 50. Lined up near the team logo that spans the grass at midfield? Bironas knows only that that is pretty deep.

headline: Thanksgiving With Squash on the Side
text: If you’re looking for a new way to spice up your Thanksgiving table, consider one of these new winter squash recipes from Martha Rose Shulman. She writes:

headline: Our Classic Picks
text: The Rail’s handicappers make their Breeders’ Cup Classic selections. Here’s a look at how we did for the Triple Crown races. Make your picks along with us in the comments section below.

headline: Mentors and Students Go on a Hunt
text: Students from the Urban Assembly School for Wildlife Conservation met on Friday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for a scavenger hunt with their mentors from the private sector in a program organized by PENCIL.

headline: Skype Postpones Sweet Sorrow
text: THEY met in Costa Rica, on a summer community service program for teenagers. Within days they had fallen in love.

headline: Controversial Qatari Club Wins Asian Champions League Final
text: JEONJU, South Korea — It has been 12 months to remember for soccer in Qatar as it added the 2011 Asian Champions League to the 2022 World Cup hosting duties as Al Sadd defeated Jeonbuk Motors in a penalty shootout Saturday to win the regional club championship

headline: Another Ewing Plays in New York
text: Randi Ewing rose at the net, soaring to meet a volleyball in flight at Rose Hill Gymnasium in the Bronx. She raised her right arm and spiked the ball. Moments later, she defended the other side of the net, blocking an attempted kill.

headline: Rebuilding the Cubs, Wrigley Included
text: CHICAGO — In hiring Theo Epstein as their team president, the Chicago Cubs are clearly hoping he can do for them what he did for the Boston Red Sox and break a title drought that defies logic.

headline: Genuine Hypocrisy, And Attitudes Thereto
text: Not sure how much blogging I can do this weekend — I’m doing some research for future writing, and need to buckle down for a bit. But here’s an item that caught my eye, given what I wrote about hypocrisy yesterday:

headline: Not All Names Are Fit to Print
text: “How fast do I have to run to get in?”

headline: Qatari Club Takes Curious Route to Asian Title
text: JEONJU, South Korea — It has been 12 months to remember for soccer in Qatar, which added the 2011 Asian Champions League to the 2022 World Cup hosting duties when Al Sadd defeated Jeonbuk Motors in a penalty-kick shootout Saturday to win the regional club championship.

headline: Live Analysis: L.S.U. and Alabama, Among Other Games
text: Paul Myerberg and The Times’ John Branch will be reporting on all of the day’s action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can also follow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

headline: Variety: A Timely Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — People often ask me what the process is for receiving, solving and blogging the New York Times crossword and variety puzzles. The answer is that I get a stack of puzzles about a week ahead of time, then solve them and blog them according to deadline. I often feel like I’m time-traveling into the future, because that’s where my head is when I’m working, and the feeling is particularly present when solvers ask me a question about the current day’s puzzle, because I have to “travel back” to remember the puzzle in question.

headline: 20 Years Later, Still Alive, Still Lively
text: So where were you on the night of Nov. 7, 1991? I was in Madison Square Garden, watching Pat Riley bring his Knicks and the visiting Orlando Magic together to say a pregame prayer for Magic Johnson on the day Johnson revealed that he had tested positive for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

headline: The Zenyatta Experience, One Year Later
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — In many ways, it seems similar to a high school reunion. We seem to know each other well and have spent some great times together. We stood next to each other at race after race and recognize the T-shirts, football-style jerseys, hats and pins all carrying the pink and teal colors. The Zenyatta fans are extremely loyal and flew in from all parts of the country supporting “their” horse when she raced.

headline: Idle N.B.A. Leaves Void in Cities Like Portland
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — A short walk from the Rose Garden, the home of the Portland Trail Blazers, a few customers trickled into the Spirit of ’77 sports bar after it opened Thursday afternoon. They ordered pints of beer, hot dogs and other snacks. Some played a mini basketball game as hockey games blared on the large televisions.

headline: Still Playing Catch-Up
text: Mary Keitany of Kenya is favored to win the women’s race Sunday at the New York City Marathon. She might even set a course record, but one thing she will almost certainly not do is set a world record.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Jets’ Team Records Go All the Way Back, to Atlanta
text: If a player for the Winnipeg Jets scores five goals against the Rangers on Sunday night, will he tie the franchise record for goals in a game, set by the Jets of yore Willy Lindstrom in 1982 and Alexei Zhamnov in 1995?

headline: Political Uncertainty Lingers in Greece
text: ATHENS — Hours after the government won a crucial confidence vote that made it more likely that Greece would receive the foreign aid it desperately needs, the country’s leaders on Saturday reverted to the type of political wrangling that threw Europe and its markets into turmoil last week.

headline: Sad Proof of Europe’s Fallout
text: WHO you gonna believe, me or your own eyes?

headline: The Denials That Trapped Greece
text: ATHENS —   The warning was clear: Greece was spiraling out of control.

headline: Far From Home and Fighting a Rare Disease
text: Numbers tell a stark story of Thonn McMillan’s battle for survival against a rare disease that has wreaked havoc on his body.

headline: Perry the Antigovernment Politician Meets Perry the Government Beneficiary
text: As a Texas governor and presidential candidate, Rick Perry has repeatedly turned to the marketplace for policy solutions to health care and retirement security.

headline: Risks Seen in Perry Plan for Switch to Pensions
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who has long been a vocal critic of Social Security, outlined a plan last month that he said would preserve the program “for all generations of Americans.” But one part of his plan — to let state and local government workers opt out of Social Security — could add risk to their retirements while sapping money from the system.

headline: Mladic’s Poor Health Is New Focus at The Hague
text: THE HAGUE — Each time Ratko Mladic has come to court, he has complained about his health — his fatigue, his stroke-weakened right arm, his kidney pains — emphasizing his ailments as if they were the central focus of his trial on war crimes and genocide charges.

headline: A Tradition of Giving, From the Famous and the Unknown
text: The language of that first appeal in The New York Times was somewhat florid by today’s standards, but it packed the desired punch. “Fathoms deep beneath the exhilaration and joyousness of Christmas,” it began, “there is a world of desolation and hunger which few of the dwellers in light and air have had time or chance to realize.”

headline: Roubini On Internal Devaluation
text: Nouriel Roubini has a very good, very grim new paper on European prospects (no link). I particularly liked this passage:

headline: Neediest Cases | Thonn McMillan
text: Thonn McMillan is a 17-year-old from Grenada who has Wegener’s granulomatosis, a rare disease that causes inflammation of his arteries and veins and has harmed his lungs, kidneys and brains. He and his mother are on visitors’ visas while he is being treated in the United States.

headline: 100 Years of Giving
text: The success of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has depended on the generosity of its donors, famous and not, who have been inspired to contribute. To date, the fund has raised $256,921,136.66. Here is a look back at a century of giving.

headline: Live Analysis: Drosselmeyer Wins Breeders’ Cup Classic
text: Mike Smith and Drosselmeyer rallied in the homestretch to overtake Chantal Sutherland and Game On Dude by one and a half lengths to win the $5 million Breeders’ Cup Classic on Saturday at Churchill Downs.

headline: A Few Minutes With Andy Rooney
text: Andy Rooney’s weekly segment on “60 Minutes,” in which he addressed mostly mundane subjects with varying degrees of befuddlement, vexation and sometimes pleasure, made him one of the most popular broadcast figures in the country.

headline: Pakistan Indicts 7 in Bhutto Assassination
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — A Pakistani antiterrorism court indicted five militants and two police officers Saturday in the assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, prosecutors said.

headline: Former Coach at Penn State Is Charged With Abuse
text: A former defensive coordinator for the Penn State football team was arrested Saturday on charges of sexually abusing eight boys across a 15-year period. Jerry Sandusky, 67, who had worked with needy children through his Second Mile foundation, was arraigned and released on $100,000 bail after being charged with 40 counts related to sexual abuse of young boys.

headline: Tortured by Solitude
text: Oakland, Calif.

headline: The Politics of Austerity
text: The economic collapse of 2008 transformed American politics. In place of shared abundance, battles at every level of government now focus on picking the losers who will bear the costs of deficit reduction and austerity.

headline: Merger of Memphis and County School Districts Revives Race and Class Challenges
text: MEMPHIS — When thousands of white students abandoned the Memphis schools 38 years ago rather than attend classes with blacks under a desegregation plan fueled by busing, Joseph A. Clayton went with them. He quit his job as a public school principal to head an all-white private school and later won election to the board of the mostly white suburban district next door.

headline: Clicking ‘Send’ Spurs Quake Anxiety
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — Already rattled by a swarm of small earthquakes last month, residents here were jolted by an authentic-sounding e-mail that said geologists were predicting a major earthquake in the coming weeks.

headline: A King of Connections Is Tech’s Go-To Guy
Hoping to Save Money for the Government, Some Seek an End to the $1 Bill
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — It is not typical for a politician to admit using a coin to decide critical issues, but there was Representative David Schweikert, Republican of Arizona, fishing out a dollar coin from his pocket the other day.

headline: Boat With 21 North Koreans Found Off South Korea’s Coast
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Twenty-one North Koreans, including women and children, were found adrift in a boat off the west coast of South Korea last Sunday and asked for asylum, the South Korean military said Saturday.

headline: Chirps and Cheers: China’s Crickets Clash
text: BEIJING — Big Red Belly, his thick limbs nourished by a strict liver-tofu-ginger diet, should have been a contender. Instead, as his trainer watched in dismay, the young fighter nervously circled his more menacing adversary and then skittered to a corner of the ring, prompting jeers from a half-dozen spectators.

headline: Deaths in Care: 16 Cases
text: A closer look at the circumstances of death surrounding 16 developmentally disabled people in state or privately run homes over the last decade.

headline: The Death of James Taylor
text: Danny Hakim of The New York Times interviews the mother and sister of James Taylor, who died at age 41 while he was at a group home near Schenectady, N.Y.

headline: In China, Cricket Fighting Undergoes a Revival
text: In the alleys of Beijing, crickets are facing off against one another in a uniquely Chinese bloodsport whose provenance extends back more than 1,000 years.

headline: Term No. 10? Why Not, a Mayor Asks
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — This is a town that cherishes tradition.

headline: Investigating Deaths in State and Privately-Run Homes
text: A selection of cases from the Commission on Quality of Care and Advocacy for Persons with Disabilities

headline: Loulou de la Falaise, a Muse to Yves Saint Laurent, Dies at 63
text: Loulou de la Falaise, a muse to Yves Saint Laurent who was also a designer and a woman whose style resisted classification, died on Saturday at her home in the Vexin region of northwest France. She was 63.

headline: Cricket Fighting
text: In China, crickets are pitted against each other on street corners as their owners watch and place bets on the matches.

headline: Signs of Official Bias and Abuse Deepen Kyrgyzstan’s Ethnic Rifts
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan — Nearly a year and a half after ethnic clashes ripped through this former Silk Road trading hub, ethnic Uzbeks, who suffered the brunt of the violence, face arbitrary arrest and often horrific abuse at the hands of predominantly ethnic Kyrgyz authorities, victims and local and international rights groups say.

headline: Wanted: Worldly Philosophers
text: IT’S become commonplace to criticize the “Occupy” movement for failing to offer an alternative vision. But the thousands of activists in the streets of New York and London aren’t the only ones lacking perspective: economists, to whom we might expect to turn for such vision, have long since given up thinking in terms of economic systems — and we are all the worse for it.

headline: Women on Pedestals
text: I WAS waiting for the other shoe to drop.

headline: Our Reckless Meritocracy
text: HERE is a story about the promise of America. A boy grows up in rural Illinois, the grandson of a farmer who lost everything in the Great Depression. He goes to his small-town high school and then attends his state university, where he walks onto the basketball team and graduates Phi Beta Kappa. He does a stint in the Marine Corps Reserves, gets his M.B.A. and then goes to work for one of the Midwest’s regional banks.

headline: India’s Innovation Stimulus
text: New Delhi

headline: His Libraries, 12,000 So Far, Change Lives
text: CAI LEI, Vietnam

headline: The Invention of Outrage
text: IF you’re just catching up on last week’s news, I suggest you sit down. Fast. What you’re about to learn is incredible. Unthinkable. If you drink, grab one. Certain shocks can’t be borne without absorbers.

headline: Standing in the Schoolhouse Door
text: Surely Alabama’s attorney general, Luther Strange, did not mean to summon the memory of Gov. George Wallace when he picked a fight with the Department of Justice last week over the state’s new immigration law.

headline: America’s Deadly Dynamics With Iran
text: COMMUTING to work in Tehran is never easy, but it is particularly nerve-racking these days for the scientists of Shahid Beheshti University. It was a little less than a year ago when one of them, Majid Shahriari, and his wife were stuck in traffic at 7:40 a.m. and a motorcycle pulled up alongside the car. There was a faint “click” as a magnet attached to the driver’s side door. The huge explosion came a few seconds later, killing him and injuring his wife.

headline: Is This the WikiEnd?
text: IT appears all the more likely that Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, will be extradited to Sweden to be questioned on allegations of sexual misconduct from two women. A British court’s ruling last Wednesday that he could be extradited, which Mr. Assange may appeal, puts his personal freedom in doubt.

headline: If the Cake Isn’t Ready, Just Say So
text: This interview with  Barbara DeBuono, president and C.E.O. of Orbis International, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. Orbis is a global health organization that helps to treat and prevent blindness.

headline: Population Control, Marauder Style
text: Last week, the United Nations announced that the world’s population had reached seven billion, but there have been times when it headed in the opposite direction, and not in pleasant ways. The savagery of the Mongol conqueror Genghis Khan may have culled the global population by about 11 percent; two bloody upheavals in China — the An Lushan Rebellion and the collapse of the Xin Dynasty — each may have felled about 6 percent of humanity. Those are but 3 of the 100 worst atrocities in history, as cataloged by Matthew White in “The Great Big Book of Horrible Things,” an amusing (really) account of the murderous ways of despots, slave traders, blundering royals, gladiators and assorted hordes. Estimating the tolls from such horrors is an inexact science, given war’s nature and the mysteries of antiquity. The deadliest “multicides” are more plentiful in recent centuries, given that there were more people to kill and better ways to kill them on a grand scale. Even so, killings as a percentage of all humanity are probably declining. Here is a look at the sweep of human brutality presented in a timeline.

headline: Is the Era of the Motorcycle Over?
text: ARE motorcycles passé? Are they sort of over? I ask as a rider of two-wheel Italian beauties that go very fast, gracefully streamlined subsonic technology from the Ducati factory in Bologna. I own two sport bikes and two racers. I ride racing motorcycles on the street. One of my motorcycles is capable of nearly 200 miles an hour. I write prose about motorcycles. I write poems about motorcycles.

headline: Telling Americans to Vote, or Else
text: Washington

headline: DNA Exonerations Continue, but Not for One Man
text: Hank Skinner has been pleading with the state since 2001 — to no avail — to test DNA evidence he believes will prove his innocence. On Wednesday, he is scheduled to walk into the execution chamber in Huntsville to face the ultimate punishment for three murders that he maintains he did not commit.

headline: The Court’s GPS Test
text: There were no GPS tracking devices when the framers wrote the Fourth Amendment’s prohibition against unreasonable searches. But that does not mean this sometimes intrusive technology can be used against Americans without meeting constitutional standards.

headline: A New Battle Over Contraception
text: The Obama administration made the right call in August when it issued new standards requiring all insurers to cover contraceptives without a deductible or a co-payment, starting next year. The White House now needs to resist pressure from House Republicans, the Roman Catholic Church and other groups out to eliminate or significantly weaken the contraceptives mandate.

headline: Alms From China
text: As soon as European leaders agreed on yet another plan to stabilize their finances, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France was on the phone to his Chinese counterpart, Hu Jintao, to persuade him to invest in the rescue. Klaus Regling, head of the new financial bailout fund for the euro zone, went to Asia to drum up support.

headline: Stewart Brand
text: Stewart Brand is best known as the editor of the Whole Earth Catalog, a counterculture compendium published twice a year between 1968 and 1972 and the only catalog to win the National Book Award. Its credo, “Stay hungry. Stay foolish,” influenced many of the hippie generation, most notably Steve Jobs. Mr. Brand currently divides his time working for the Long Now Foundation and Global Business Network, organizations he co-founded to encourage forward thinking and long-term development.

headline: When Luck Is the Spark
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wait Wait... Don’t Tell Me
text: NPR’s “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

headline: Considering the Sources
text: Re “The Times Gives Them Space, but Who Pays Them?” (Oct. 30):

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Incentives on Energy
text: A letter argued that large subsidies for renewable energy are not justified. But many readers countered that wind and solar power are vital to our energy future. Here is a sampling.

headline: Why a Fallen Angel Is a Centerfold
text: THE celebrity blogs and the tabloid news sites like TMZ have been all aflutter over reports that Lindsay Lohan, before landing a new jail sentence last week for skipping court-ordered janitorial service at a morgue, managed to find time to pose nude for Playboy magazine for close to a million dollars. Then a couple of dissenting reports said Ms. Lohan had agreed to only partial nudity, which was a distressing comment on the economy these days. What have we come to when a million dollars no longer purchases the complete Montague? Back in the ’50s, when Playboy was just getting started, the going rate for a centerfold shoot was $500.

headline: In State Care, 1,200 Deaths and Few Answers
text: For James Michael Taylor, an evening bath became a death sentence.

headline: The Problem With Flat-Tax Fever
text: CLOSE watchers of presidential politics weren’t surprised to see many of this year’s Republican hopefuls proposing to replace the nation’s progressive income tax with a flat tax. Such plans reliably surface every four years, and, just as reliably, sink without a trace.

headline: In Ohio, a Hint About 2012
text: Republican state lawmakers in the Upper Midwest have been remarkably successful this year in stripping public employees of their bargaining rights, but that campaign could slam to a halt on Tuesday when Ohio voters get a chance to weigh in.

headline: Thousands Still Without Power in Connecticut
text: This has been an excellent week to own a hardware store in Connecticut.

headline: A Russian Robot, a Martian Moon
text: In a bold attempt to revive its long-dormant planetary exploration program, Russia is scheduled to launch a new, technologically sophisticated spacecraft this week to gather soil samples from a Martian moon and bring them back to Earth for analysis. Back in the early 1970’s, the Soviet Union, after losing the race to land humans on the Moon, brought back lunar soil samples with robotic devices. It also became the first nation to put robotic devices on Venus and Mars.

headline: And Now for Something Different
text: With international attention focused on the worsening European debt crisis, the economic, trade and security challenges in Asia have gotten less attention. That could change this week when President Obama hosts the annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting in his home state, Hawaii, on Saturday, before heading to Australia and then to Bali for the East Asia Summit.

headline: For Clues to U.S. Stocks, Look at Greek Bonds
text: IT’S come to this. For day-to-day guidance on the likely direction of American stocks, there’s an unlikely contrarian indicator: the battered Greek bond.

headline: In the School of Innovation, Less Is Often More
text: SINCE the 1980s, the United States has increasingly depended on other nations for shrimp production. As scientists have struggled to find a way to increase yields, they have turned to a technology in which shrimp are farmed indoors in large, rectangular tubs of water, laid out side by side.

headline: Leaving Iraq, U.S. Fears New Surge of Qaeda Terror
text: BAGHDAD — As the United States prepares to withdraw its troops from Iraq by year’s end, senior American and Iraqi officials are expressing growing concern that Al Qaeda’s offshoot here, which just a few years ago waged a debilitating insurgency that plunged the country into a civil war, is poised for a deadly resurgence.

headline: An Online Answer to the DVR
text: SOME people who want to watch a movie at home wait for Netflix to mail it to them on a disc. Others click on a link at Netflix or other Web sites and immediately watch films, TV episodes or sports events streamed to them on the spot.

headline: Ratings Inflation Leads to a Record Ranking
text: There are two firsts in the current ranking of the world’s top competitors, which was released on Tuesday. Four of the players have a rating (the number used to create the rankings) of 2,800 or higher, and 47 players have a rating of at least 2,700.

headline: The Neediest Cases | Where Are They Now?
text: Following up with a beneficiary of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

headline: A New President, and a Union’s Last Stand
text: FOR 30 years, Ronald Reagan’s breaking of the federal air traffic controller strike has often been seen as a turning point in United States history, the moment when labor unions began an inexorable decline and when political conservatism came of age.

headline: Tracking Caribou, Shooting Hoops, Winning Trophies
text: POINT HOPE, Alaska — Spring means murre eggs and bowhead whales. Summer is seals and salmon and berries. Fall and winter are a time to track caribou.

headline: Dr. John F. Burke, Dies at 89; Created Synthetic Skin
text: Artificial skin had been the holy grail in treating burn victims for a century when Dr. John F. Burke began wrestling with some of the perennial obstacles to making it: finding a flexible material that would protect against infection and dehydration, that could be made from ordinary substances, that would not be rejected by a patient’s immune system and that would look like normal skin.

headline: Sunday: Baker’s Dozen
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Mmmm … cake. Who doesn’t love a good slice of cake?

headline: Less ‘He Said, She Said’ in Sex Harassment Cases
text: A PUBLIC figure at the top of his game is suddenly tripped up by reports that he sexually harassed female employees. Whispers ensue, speculation abounds, details are unclear, his statements shift.

headline: James Van Doren Dies at 72; Designer of Popular Shoes
text: James Van Doren, who designed the tenacious shoe that became a mainstay of California skateboard culture — and touched off a national fad after Sean Penn wore a black-and-white-checked pair in the movie “Fast Times at Ridgemont High” — died on Oct. 12 at his home in Fullerton, Calif. He was 72.

headline: Romney, Always Campaigning for Others ... and for Himself
text: State auditors, county commissioners, sheriffs: no Republican candidate, it seems, has been insignificant enough to escape the glow of Mitt Romney’s affections.

headline: Fighting for Literacy, Library by Library
text: My Sunday column is about John Wood, the founder of Room to Read, and his efforts to build libraries around the world. And maybe an even more effective part of the program supports needy girls who might otherwise drop out — 13,500 of them at the moment. I’ve watched Wood’s efforts grow over the years, partly because of his marketing savvy and his compelling marketing story, and I’m delighted that I could attend the ceremony in Vietnam where he handed out his 10 millionth book.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, November 6
text: With reports that Herman Cain was accused of sexual harassment in the 1990s dominating the news cycle, the Sunday talk shows are focused on the 2012 presidential race. But that’s not all: With less than three weeks left for the Congressional panel tasked with deficit reduction to come up with more than $1 trillion in savings, lawmakers weigh in on whether the committee can beat the buzzer.

headline: The Gridlock Where Debts Meet Politics
text: WASHINGTON — With Greece struggling to form a government that can force harsh austerity measures onto a weary public, Europe is in usual form, taking a couple of steps toward solving its fiscal crisis and then a couple of steps backward. Washington, meanwhile, is hoping that the latest deficit-reduction committee in Congress can succeed where others have failed.

headline: Relenting on Car Sales, Cuba Turns Notorious Clunkers Into Gold
text: HAVANA — Until a few weeks ago, Erik González’s decrepit car did little more than devour his tiny income. He spent hundreds of dollars fixing the car, a 30-year-old Moskvich that his grandfather passed down to him in 2000. Even when it worked, Mr. González could rarely afford to buy gas.

headline: The Marathon Route’s Evolving Neighborhoods
text: The New York City Marathon course has changed little since 1976, but the neighborhoods along the route have: most are richer, and their ethnic makeups have shifted.

headline: Grand Jury Report on Jerry Sandusky
text: Read the full grand jury report detailing the charges against Jerry Sandusky.

headline: Action to Fund Illinois Pension System Remains Uncertain
text: Lawmakers have tinkered on the edges of the state budget during the fall veto session, but it now appears they could close shop for the year on Thursday without plugging the deep hole at the budget’s core: Illinois’s underfinanced pension systems.

headline: The Powerbrokers
text: Five Chinese-Americans are among the candidates on the mayoral ballot in Tuesday’s election. Ed Lee, interim mayor; David Chiu, president of the Board of Supervisors; Phil Ting, San Francisco’s assessor-recorder; and Leland Yee, state senator, share their thoughts on the history and progress of the Chinese-American community in San Francisco.

headline: Free Signs for Panhandlers Receive Mixed Reaction
text: There are 93,000 homeless Chicagoans, according to the Chicago Coalition for the Homeless, and many consider panhandling a necessity of life on the streets.

headline: Quinn, Portrayed as Bumbling and Indecisive, Deserves a More Respectful Hearing
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: In Mayoral Election, Chinese-Americans’ Growing Power Is on Display
text: Astella Kung, 64, is known as the unofficial mayor of Grant Avenue, the heart of San Francisco’s Chinatown. A short woman who speaks in a nasally Cantonese dialect, she is the owner of Ming Kee Game Birds, a dingy shop crammed with chickens, ducks and pigeons in wire-mesh cages.

headline: Short, Gray and Trimmed, a New Star in the Campaign
text: Last November, the Bay Area was abuzz over beards — specifically, the beard of Brian Wilson, the San Francisco Giants relief pitcher who captured the nation’s imagination with his jet-black face sweater.

headline: Lawmakers in a Bind Find Cover in Courts
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Occupy Chicago Inspires Some South Side Groups
text: As more than 1,500 supporters of the Occupy Chicago movement prepared to march through the Loop recently, Willie J. R. Fleming, a neighborhood organizer from the South Side, grabbed a bullhorn and wedged his way to the head of the mostly white crowd.

headline: Finally, an Album for a Rock Star Who Never Was
text: In 1979, under the headline “Lone Star Legend,” Rolling Stone profiled the Houston guitarist Rocky Hill, detailing his career, which was too often derailed by stubbornness and self-sabotage. The article refers to an unreleased album that the writer guessed might trigger Mr. Hill’s transition from a regional guitar hero to a national one.

headline: Drosselmeyer Steals Classic in an Uprising of Long Shots
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — They were once engaged, Mike Smith and Chantal Sutherland. He is older and a Hall of Fame jockey. She is an up-and-comer whose interests extend to modeling and acting. Under the lights at Churchill Downs on Saturday night, however, they were just two riders on a couple of horses nobody thought had much chance of winning the $5 million Breeders’ Cup Classic.

headline: Van der Sar Stepping Out of Nets for a Run
text: May 21, 2008, was the high point of Edwin van der Sar’s career. On the final shot of a penalty shootout he dove to his right to stop a waist-high penalty kick by Nicolas Anelka, and Manchester United was crowned European champions. On Friday at Jacob Schiff Playground in Harlem, Van der Sar took part in a penalty shootout of a different sort.

headline: Police Force Wall Street Protesters Off Sidewalks
text: Hundreds of Occupy Wall Street demonstrators streamed into a desolate part of Foley Square on Saturday afternoon, but their slow-moving march turned chaotic as a phalanx of police officers issued orders to vacate the sidewalks — and then swept in to force the issue.

headline: Jets at Bills: Matchup to Watch
text: Jets (4-3) at Bills (5-2), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBSMatchup to Watch: Shonn Greene vs. Buffalo defense

headline: College Football Replay: Nov. 5
text: Two upsets jolted a division race in the Big Ten, as Iowa beat Michigan at home and Northwestern won at Nebraska, and the Wolfpack won a battle for North Carolina.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 5
text: A view of the day in sports, including handball in Germany and bodybuilding in Mumbai.

headline: Carbo Loading for the Masses
text: The marathon eve dinner was held Saturday at Tavern on the Green in Central Park, where 18,000 runners were expected to consume a few thousand pounds of carbohydrates from 3:30 to 8 p.m.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Corrections: November 6
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Cain and Gingrich Meet for a Congenial Debate
text: THE WOODLANDS, Texas — The rancor that defined much of the last week on the Republican presidential campaign trail subsided a bit here on Saturday night, as Newt Gingrich and Herman Cain basked in each other’s company and the warm embrace of the Texas Tea Party for what was styled as an old-fashioned issues-focused debate.

headline: 18-Year-Old Jockey Sets Record While He Can
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — It was a Breeders’ Cup day when the heartwarming collided with the heart-pumping as the best horses in the world convened in front of a crowd of 65,143 to determine which horses were the true champions.

headline: Fast Start Puts Rangers on Path to Victory
text: The Rangers had their most inspired start of the season, taking a 3-0 lead before holding on to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 5-3, Saturday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Catherine Pushchak, Daniel Fitzgerald
text: Catherine Anna Pushchak and Daniel Patrick Fitzgerald were married Saturday at St. George Ukrainian Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Bernard Panczuk, a Ukrainian Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Stephanie Strauss and Blake Stuchin
text: Stephanie Jill Strauss, the daughter of Linda Strauss of Upper Gwynedd Township, Pa., and Charles Strauss of Upper Makefield Township, Pa., was married Saturday evening to Blake Harris Stuchin, the son of Marcie Stuchin and Miles Stuchin of New York. Rabbi Sarah H. Reines officiated at Guastavino’s, a restaurant in New York.

headline: Jess McIntosh and Jon-David Schlough
text: Jess Lane McIntosh and Jon-David Schlough were married Saturday afternoon at the Briar Patch Bed and Breakfast in Middleburg, Va. The Rev. Dr. B. Edmon Martin, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

headline: Tracy Johnson and Scott McKinney
text: Tracy Ann Johnson, the daughter of Susan A. Johnson and William R. Johnson of Pittsburgh, was married Saturday evening to Scott William McKinney, a son of Carol McKinney and James C. McKinney of Minneapolis. The Rev. Dr. Edward Thompson, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Naples, Fla.

headline: Alixandra Gould, Jeffrey Gonzalez
text: Alixandra Gould and Jeffrey Christopher Gonzalez were married Saturday evening in Newark. Rabbi Emily Losben-Ostrov officiated at the Newark Museum.

headline: Beth Dolinsky, Carl Harper
text: Dr. Beth Gillian Dolinsky and Dr. Carl Morrison Harper were married Saturday evening at the William Aiken House in Charleston, S.C. The Rev. Jonathan W. Wright-Gray, an American Baptist minister, officiated, with Gadi Galili, the ritual director of the Park Synagogue in Shaker Heights, Ohio, leading Jewish prayers and rituals.

headline: Elizabeth Morgan and Simon Talbot
text: Dr. Elizabeth Amy Morgan, a daughter of Barbara J. Morgan and David W. Morgan of Vero Beach, Fla., was married Saturday evening at her parents’ home to Dr. Simon George Talbot, a son of Mary Talbot and Dr. Richard Talbot of Nelson, New Zealand. Dr. Richard Milsten, an uncle of the bride who is a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Jessica Winer, Christopher Chaput
text: Jessica Sarah Winer and Christopher Jacques Chaput were married Saturday morning at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Sheldon M. Greenbaum, a justice of the Village of Port Washington North, N.Y., officiated, and Jerrold B. Winer, the bride’s paternal grandfather who is a retired judge of the Massachusetts trial court in Hampden County in Springfield, Mass., conducted the civil ceremony.

headline: Amanda Kramer, William Borden
text: Amanda Susan Kramer and Dr. William Benjamin Borden were married Saturday evening. Rabbi Matthew D. Field officiated at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington.

headline: Sarah Perlman, Christopher Bremner
text: Henrietta Sarah Elizabeth Perlman and Christopher Evan Bremner are to be married Sunday evening at the Vizcaya Museum and Gardens in Miami. Rabbi Steven Weil is to officiate, with Cantor Simon Hass, a grandfather of the bride, also taking part.

headline: Joanna Walters and Lisa McNulty
text: Joanna Mary Walters and Lisa Ann McNulty were married Saturday afternoon in a studio at New Dramatists, the New York playwriting center. Taylor Mac Bowyer, a Universal Life Church minister, led the ceremony.

headline: Sarah Seltzer, Craig Blackburn
text: Sarah Beth Seltzer and Capt. Craig David Blackburn were married Saturday evening at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y. Rabbi Steven Blane led a ceremony incorporating Jewish and Christian elements.

headline: Kimberly Quicksilver, Matthew Salsbury
text: Kimberly Ann Quicksilver and Matthew Heller Salsbury were married Saturday evening. C. Gregory Brown, the municipal judge for the Town of Kiawah Island, S.C., officiated there at the Kiawah Island Club.

headline: Jenna Kaufman, Eric Siegel
text: Jenna Lauren Kaufman, a daughter of Susan Eileen Kaufman and Dr. Brian Stephen Kaufman of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Eric Scott Siegel, a son of Merryl Siegel and Larry Siegel, also of Dix Hills. Rabbi Jeffrey Clopper performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Torah in Melville, N.Y., with Cantor Sandra Sherry-Pilatsky taking part.

headline: Joaquín Tamayo Jr., Ruben Gonzales
text: Joaquín Ricardo Tamayo Jr. and Ruben James Gonzales were married Saturday evening in Washington. Glennda Testone, a friend of the couple who became a minister of the Open Ministry for the event, officiated at the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

headline: Cari Wolfert, Jason Rubin
text: Cari Alison Wolfert and Jason Scott Rubin were married Saturday evening by Cantor Claire Franco at Battery Gardens, a Manhattan restaurant.

headline: Neha Surie, Neel Patel
text: Neha Surie, a daughter of Bhavna Surie and Raman D. Surie of New Delhi, was married Saturday afternoon to Neel Bhaskerrao Patel, a son of Vaishali B. Patel and Dr. Bhasker P. Patel of Melbourne, Fla. Pandit Bhipin Bhatt, a Hindu priest, officiated at the East Ridge Country Club in Shreveport, La.

headline: Lauren Thompson and Geoffrey Starks
text: Lauren Nicole Thompson and Geoffrey Adam Starks were married Saturday at Peachtree Christian Church in Atlanta. The Rev. James L. Bell III, a Disciples of Christ minister, performed the ceremony, with Sharon M. K. Kugler, the Yale University chaplain, assisting.

headline: Michelle Roell, Lance Nealy
text: Michelle Leigh Roell and Sterling Lance Nealy were married Tuesday at the Municipal Marriage Bureau in New York. James Mitchell, a member of the office of the New York City clerk, officiated.

headline: The Day’s Best in College Football
text: DAN HERRON, CARLOS HYDE AND BRAXTON MILLER The Ohio State players each topped 100 rushing yards in a 34-20 victory against Indiana, the first time three Buckeyes had done so since Scottie Graham, Carlos Snow and Dante Lee accomplished the feat against Northwestern in 1989. Herron had 141 yards, and Hyde and Miller each had 105.

headline: N.B.A. Owners Give Players 4 Days to Accept Final Offer
text: A perilous four-month standoff between N.B.A. players and owners has been reduced to a four-day window, with an ultimatum that might destroy the 2011-12 season.

headline: In Battle of No. 1 vs. No. 2, the Difference Is 3 Points
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — The pregame roar from Bryant-Denny Stadium carried long into the cool Alabama night, echoing through just about every corner of this football-mad state. All anyone around here could talk about the past two weeks was the so-called Game of the Century, No. 1 Louisiana State against No. 2 Alabama. But poor quarterback play, sputtering offenses and no touchdowns helped undermine the hype that surrounded this matchup of the nation’s top-ranked teams.

headline: Top 25 Roundup: L.S.U and Oklahoma State Remain Unbeaten
text: 1. L.S.U. (9-0) beat No. 2 Alabama, 9-6

headline: Giants at Patriots: Matchup to Watch
text: Giants (5-2) at Patriots (5-2), 4:15 p.m. Eastern, Fox

headline: At Quarterback, Jefferson Gives L.S.U. the Lift It Needs
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Just four months ago, Jordan Jefferson found himself facing a second-degree battery charge, the possibility of missing his senior season and much vitriol from Louisiana State fans. While the charges were reduced Sept. 30 and he found himself back on the team, his contributions had been minimal.

headline: Oklahoma Hit by Earthquake for a Second Night in a Row
text: For the second night in a row, an earthquake rattled Central Oklahoma late Saturday night, waking residents, breaking dishes and generally startling people more accustomed to natural disasters from above than from below their feet.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Has India’s growth and development been an “unprecedented success or extraordinary failure,” ask Jean Dreze and Amartya Sen in Outlook Magazine this week. Both are true, they conclude. The authors say that what they warned of in a book written in the late 1980s has come to pass – India’s economy resembles Brazil’s of the time, with rapid growth alongside massive deprivation. India has fallen behind Bangladesh on a number of important social indicators, and is “quite far behind China in terms of the use of public resources for social support.”

headline: Occupy Protests Around the Nation
text: Updated | Monday | 4:03 p.m. A protest by hundreds of Occupy Wall Street demonstrators who streamed into a square in New York’s financial district on Saturday afternoon resulted in about 20 arrests when police officers told the slow-moving marchers to get off the sidewalks — and then swept in enforce their command, my colleague Al Baker reports on City Room.

headline: In Pakistan, the Disheartened Cricket Fan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Watching a court in London send three of our cricket players to prison over match-fixing charges has been disappointing for Pakistani cricket fans, naturally, but less so than you may think.

headline: Lord Mayor Celebrations in London Include Parade and Fireworks
text: Almost 800 years of history will convene once again on Nov. 12 as the Lord Mayor of London takes part in an annual tradition started in the year 1215 — shortly after the King of England allowed the city of London to start electing its own leader. This new decree came with a caveat that the newly elected official would appear in person to swear allegiance to the Crown and almost every year since then the city’s Lord Mayor has upheld the pact (even the Plague didn’t stop the procession).

headline: 8 Killed in Afghan Bombing Days After Mullah’s Rebuke
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber killed eight people during religious celebrations in northern Afghanistan on Sunday, defying an admonition by the Taliban’s leader not to attack civilians.

headline: Thailand Flooding Cripples Hard-Drive Suppliers
text: BANG PA-IN, Thailand — In the neck-deep floodwaters of an industrial zone here, workers are using Jet Skis and wooden skiffs to transport stacks of computer components out of waterlogged factories.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Trashopolis’
text: We humans figured out practically as soon as we were invented that we needed clothing of some kind. And it was well back in the B.C.’s that we realized agriculture was more efficient than the foraging-and-hunting thing. So why the heck was it only yesterday, comparatively speaking, that we tumbled to the fact that life would be vastly improved if we’d stop walking around in our own trash and bodily wastes?

headline: Live Blog: Mutai, Dado Finish Strong for New York City Marathon Victories
text: Geoffrey Mutai of Kenya proved how much more important it is to finish the New York City Marathon strong than to start it that way.

headline: Greek Leaders Reach Deal to Form a New Government
text: ATHENS — Prime Minister George A. Papandreou and his chief rival agreed Sunday night to create a new unity government, under a new prime minister, that will move ahead with the country’s debt-relief deal with the European Union and then hold new elections. Mr. Papandreou agreed to resign once the details are completed on Monday.

headline: Bracing for a Bullfrog Invasion
text: The consequences of climate change for animals can seem very direct, as with polar bears in a warming Arctic. Others involve leaps, like the case of an invasive bullfrog: by 2080, it could splash into some of South America’s most ecologically rich protected areas, disrupting unique hotbeds of biodiversity. At least, that is the prediction of a new study in the journal PLoS One.

headline: Hip-Hop Kings, Shorn of Excess
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Just two guys sitting on a stoop, telling stories, lamenting the mistakes they’ve made, expressing hope that the next generation might learn something from them.

headline: Online and by Paper Airplane, Contributions Pour In to Chinese Dissident
text: BEIJING — In the days since the Chinese government delivered a punitive $2.4 million tax bill to the artist Ai Weiwei, thousands of people have responded by contributing money in a gesture that is at once benevolent and subversive.

headline: Already Set to Sign Up for Next Year? Not So Fast
text: As if they can’t get enough, many runners of the New York City Marathon log on to the New York Road Runners Web site the day after the marathon to register for the next year’s race.

headline: 2011 New York City Marathon
text: Officially, 47,107 people started the New York City Marathon, the largest field in the marathon’s history.

headline: Huntsman and Barbour Urge Cain to Come Clean on Accusations
text: Herman Cain faced fresh criticism on Sunday from some prominent Republican colleagues, and at least two of them called on him to be much more forthcoming about the allegations of sexual harassment that appear to be weighing on his presidential candidacy.

headline: For the Women’s Winner, Steady Race Beats a Bold One
text: For more than half of the women’s race at the New York City Marathon, Mary Keitany of Kenya appeared to be turning conventional wisdom about this course on its head. She was flying through the early miles, ignoring all cautionary tales of the toll the course can take, seemingly intent on shattering the course record. By the 15-mile mark, her lead over the nearest competitor was nearly two and a half minutes.

headline: ‘Puss in Boots,’ Not ‘Tower Heist,’ Leads the Pack
text: “Tower Heist,” an $85 million action comedy starring Eddie Murphy and Ben Stiller, was clawed at the weekend box office, landing in second place behind the animated holdover “Puss in Boots.”

headline: Geoffrey Mutai Wins New York Marathon With Course Record
text: The footsteps keep getting faster, pounding like a drumbeat on the city streets. From Boston to London to Chicago this year, Kenya’s marathon men have smashed course records in frenzied fashion, and they drilled the world record in Berlin.

headline: Half a Century of Order and Discipline for a Junior High Principal
text: As she nears retirement next year after 50 years, a principal still believes that "if rules are firm and consistent, children and adults will flourish and rise to meet expectations.''

headline: Does Flying With Children Have to Be So Bad?
text: Airlines don’t much want us families, it’s true. Nor do many of our fellow passengers. And it’s not as if, as parents, we enjoy squashing ourselves and our children and our belongings into the tiny seats on crowded flights that now make up the flying experience. As Michelle Higgins writes in this Sunday’s New York Times, perks once offered to families, like  early boarding, coloring books and cockpit tours, have disappeared on most flights (some long ago), while new baggage and seat fees can disproportionately affect the large flying family.

headline: An Outspoken Mark Webber
text: Formula One suffers from having drivers who are constantly thinking of their sponsors and their image and hence not speaking their minds. They are talking in platitudes and trying to stay out of trouble. Actually, the same thing is starting to happen in the way they drive — or it risks happening, with all the penalties that are given for the least little failed overtaking effort.

headline: An Outspoken Mark Webber
text: Formula One suffers from having drivers who are constantly thinking of their sponsors and their image and hence not speaking their minds. They are talking in platitudes and trying to stay out of trouble. Actually, the same thing is starting to happen in the way they drive — or it risks happening, with all the penalties that are given for the least little failed overtaking effort.

headline: Quick Hits On A Busy Day
text: Column is going into some new territory for me, so more time on research than usual. Also, doing a local event in about an hour …

headline: Finding Inspiration in Drosselmeyer’s Victory
text: The 2010 Breeders’ Cup Classic was devastating. It did not have the fairy tale ending we were expecting. Watching Mike Smith as he wrestled with his emotions was very upsetting. How does one pick up the pieces when the reality of your life fails to match the movie in your mind?

headline: With Friends in Both Places, Milbury Will Analyze Bruins-Islanders
text: In a rare visit to the press box, Mike Milbury is set to broadcast a game between the two N.H.L. franchises he worked for. Milbury will serve as the color commentator for the Versus telecast Monday night when the Boston Bruins host the Islanders.

headline: Electric Carrier in Connecticut Still Counts 7% Without Power
text: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut said on Sunday that the state’s largest electricity carrier would not meet its goal of restoring power to 99 percent of its customers by midnight, and those affected entered a second week without electricity since the freak October snowstorm.

headline: Twenty-Six Miles Along Recovery’s Road
text: Joao Silva completed his first New York City Marathon in less than three hours, camera in hand. A year ago, he was lying in a hospital bed, his legs lost to a land mine.

headline: Bodies in Motion: An Exchange
text: Do the humanities really need to be protected from the encroachment of the sciences?

headline: Weighing Pentagon Cuts, Panetta Faces Deep Pressures
text: WASHINGTON — Under orders to cut the Pentagon budget by more than $450 billion over the next decade, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is considering reductions in spending categories once thought sacrosanct, especially in medical and retirement benefits, as well as further shrinking the number of troops and reducing new weapons purchases.

headline: Jets Meet One Challenge, and Then Fortify for Another
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — Shouts of jubilation followed the Jets as they sauntered off the field, into a tunnel and inside the visitors’ locker room at Ralph Wilson Stadium on Sunday. Their hollering had nothing to do with the first-place team they had just vanquished. It had everything to do with the first-place team they will play next week.

headline: BP’s Sale of Pan American Energy Stake Falls Apart
text: BP’s plan to sell its majority stake in the Argentine oil producer Pan American Energy for $7.1 billion collapsed on Sunday after the would-be buyer, the Bridas Corporation, backed out.

headline: Monday: Something That’s Fed Along a Street
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle is by our young friend David Steinberg, who was last seen getting us hip to all that text-speak the kids are using these days.

headline: A Man Who Knew About the Electric Chair
text: Nobody killed more people, with more regret, than Lewis E. Lawes.

headline: Operatic Pageantry With Gandhi, Dr. King and a Message of Pacifism
text: Over the decades before the New York Philharmonic discovered Philip Glass last week, with two performances of “Koyaanisqatsi,” the Metropolitan Opera paid sporadic but serious attention.

headline: Downbeat Realms of Grunge
text: Set 20 years after Kurt Cobain’s death, “Verse Chorus Verse,” at the Cherry Lane Studio Theater, is one bitter valentine to the legacy of grunge. Written by Randall Colburn, a Chicago playwright, it extols that musical phenomenon even as it sifts through the lives of survivors wandering its smoking embers. The show, a collaboration between the Barefoot Theater Company and East 3rd Productions, has a heart clearly in rock: the business, the musicians’ way of life. But the story probes dark corners, using a ghastly actual incident that happened in Tacoma, Wash., as its historical point of origin.

headline: A Shadowy Goddess as Musical Muse
text: The conductor Robert Spano has a well-deserved reputation for innovative programming, bolstered by 10 high-growth seasons as music director of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra. Many New Yorkers remember his dynamic eight-year tenure as music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic, which ended in 2004.

headline: Troupes From Abroad Get a Warm Welcome
text: Are there any dance audiences more eager to love than those that sell out the Fall for Dance Festival at City Center? When the companies on the bill all come from abroad, as was the case on Friday night for the festival’s fourth program, the quick-trigger ovations can feel like a form of hospitality. Basking in the warm welcome can be enjoyable, even if you don’t agree on the merits.

headline: Music For Tomorrow’s Column
text: A bit of golden oldies, for once.

headline: An Aloof Romney in a Plane Encounter
text: Mitt Romney was polite as he took his seat in coach next to Carolyn McClanahan of Jacksonville, Fla., on a recent Delta flight to Boston. He thanked her when she said she appreciated his efforts to reform health care as the governor of Massachusetts and even posed for a photo with her.

headline: Cain ‘Back on Message,’ if His Rivals Will Allow It
text: THE WOODLANDS, Tex. — If Herman Cain has been less than clear about exactly what happened during his tenure as head of the National Restaurant Association in the late 1990s, when he was accused of sexual harassment, he is being perfectly clear about how he intends to conduct himself now.

headline: For a Weekend, Oklahoma is Earthquake Country
text: Usually, the earth-moving events on an autumn weekend in Oklahoma are at the college football stadiums in Norman and Stillwater.

headline: Born Along the Racial Fault Line
text: As a social studies major in his junior year at Harvard, Mark Whitaker attended a debate on the subject of ethnicity. One participant was the chairman of the department. Mr. Whitaker stood up to raise some questions.

headline: Real People, Fake Tans, True-ish Stories
text: The most talked-about British television show of the last year is now freely available in the United States — not that you’d know it. Previously visible only to those with all-region DVD or media players, “The Only Way Is Essex” has made its American premiere not on television but online at Hulu.com, a victory for Internet video in its guerrilla war against the TV industry.

headline: Playwright’s Ambitions, Reconsidered
text: What is the best new American drama of the first decade of this century?

headline: Staying in the Vanguard for 25 Seasons, and Counting
text: Carnegie Hall is celebrating its 120th anniversary this year and many artists appearing there are heralding the 200th birthday of Franz Liszt. For the classical-music world, almost any coming or going prompts a party; in this, the New York composers’ collective Bang on a Can is no exception. Still, when David Lang, a founder of Bang on a Can along with Michael Gordon and Julia Wolfe, introduced the first event of the organization’s 25th season from the Zankel Hall stage on Saturday night, his announcement was hardly boilerplate.

headline: A Russian Touch Delivered Lovingly, With Gusto
text: These days for a foreign company to bring a program of ballets by the Russian choreographer Alexei Ratmansky to New York is to invoke the cliché about hauling coals to Newcastle. You can’t avoid his product here, and a contract at American Ballet Theater guarantees more through 2023.

headline: Fusions in Song and Life
text: Instead of science fiction, think of it as alchemy. That is one way to view John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey’s brilliant new show, “When Worlds Collide,” at the Café Carlyle. Their pairings of songs and voices from different eras and genres (the Beatles with Woody Herman, Antonio Carlos Jobim with Stephen Sondheim, and many more) are not destructive musical collisions in which planets explode. Instead of repelling each other, these alien climates, once in proximity, fuse, generate electricity and create an environment larger and more complex than the sum of its parts.

headline: Sirius’s Move to Bypass a Royalty Payment Clearinghouse Causes an Uproar
text: The flow of royalty payments, counted in pennies and nickels, may be the least glamorous part of the music industry. But because those royalties are the foundation of almost everyone’s paycheck, any change to the system can be controversial.

headline: On the Ropes With Herman Cain
text: As a math major, Herman Cain undoubtedly knew from the start that running for president, if you’re already rich and your main interest is in enhancing your revenue stream, makes no sense as a career move. Or, to cite the erstwhile presidential contender Mike Huckabee, “Running for president is like sticking your face in the blade of a fan.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: A Site to Help Marketers Appeal to African-Americans
text: Advertisers are increasingly looking for ways to appeal to consumers of color, but first they need to understand that consumer.

headline: What’s Thanksgiving Without Lady Gaga?
text: ABC announced that Lady Gaga, below in a dress made of meat, would perform and cook, and be interviewed by Katie Couric, over the course of a 90-minute prime-time special titled “A Very Gaga Thanksgiving” on Nov. 24. Lady Gaga will also direct the show for good measure. Eight songs will be performed, including a duet of “The Lady Is a Tramp” with Tony Bennett, and a Thanksgiving feast of deep-fried turkey and waffles will be prepared with the help of the chef Art Smith.

headline: Is Nothing Sacred? Lip Syncing on ‘X Factor’
text: Producers of the singing competition show “The X Factor,” on Fox, have come under fire after a contestant’s noticeable lip-syncing gaffe occurred in a live episode on Thursday night. The contestant, Leroy Bell, left, was clearly out-of-sync with his own audio track during a performance of “Without You” by David Guetta and Usher, according to Entertainment Weekly’s Web site. All 12 finalists took part in the opening number, but Mr. Bell missed his cue just enough that the cameras, and a portion of the show’s audience, caught him not moving his mouth at all while his voice was heard through the speakers. In a statement released to Entertainment Weekly on Friday, Fox and the show’s producers said: “All competitive songs, including survival songs, are performed live to a backing track. Due to the finalists’ extensive preparation for their Wednesday night performances, the opening ensemble number on the results show is prerecorded, the same way as on other shows.” One of those shows is Fox’s “American Idol,” which dealt with a similar situation two years ago. After accusations of lip syncing were leveled then, a spokesman for FremantleMedia North America, the company that produces “American Idol” for Fox, admitted that the contestants sang along to their own recorded vocal tracks during group performances.

headline: Paul Rudnick to Write a Young-Adult Novel
text: After a heated bidding war, Scholastic has acquired the rights to publish a new young adult novel by Paul Rudnick, the “I Hate Hamlet” playwright and New Yorker contributor, that will bring fantasy elements to the contemporary worlds of fashion and celebrity, according to his agent, David Kuhn. The still-untitled novel — Mr. Rudnick’s first foray into the young-adult genre — depicts an 18-year-old girl’s journey to New York, where she meets a fashion designer who makes her an offer that seems too good to be true. “The designer offers her a chance to become not only the most beautiful woman in the world but the most beautiful woman who has ever lived,” Mr. Rudnick said in a telephone interview. “And that’s just the first chapter.” He also said the book would explore “the power of duty and the importance the world attaches to physical perfection, something that I’d imagine young women have to deal with 24 hours a day.” The deal includes an option for a second book that, according to Mr. Rudnick, may or may not be a direct sequel.

headline: At the World Championships, Down One Is, Yes, Good Bridge
text: Has anyone won a best-played award for going down one in a contract? Probably not, but if it were ever to be given, perhaps this performance would earn it.

headline: Star Show-Jumping Horse Dies During Competition
text: One of Canada’s top Olympic athletes — a stallion named Hickstead — collapsed and died in front of hundreds of spectators while competing in Italy on Sunday. The horse had completed a nearly flawless round of show jumping at the sport’s highest level, the grand prix, before he crashed to the ground under his rider and died in the ring, as fans gasped in horror in the grandstands.

headline: In the Shadow of Grand Resorts, a Town Hill Struggles
text: JACKSON, Wyo. — The ski slope that rises up the mountain just off downtown, called Snow King, dates from the 1930s, when this corner of the West all but folded up in winter, isolated and dark, and local people needed something to do. Getting rich from the snows that fall early and deep on the edge of the Teton Range in western Wyoming did not factor in.

headline: Bit by Bit, Work Exchange Site Aims to Get Jobs Done
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Philip Rosedale tried to change the nature of play with Second Life, a virtual world of colorful online avatars that got a lot of attention a few years ago.

headline: Employing Softest of Sells for a Resort in Sun Valley
text: SEVENTY years after Sun Valley was a star of a Hollywood movie, the resort is producing films of its own.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Consumer credit for September (Monday); wholesale trade inventories for September (Wednesday); trade deficit for September and import prices for October (Thursday); Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment for November (Friday).

headline: 26.2 Miles to Be Faster at 3.1
text: When the hotel phone rang at 5 a.m. Sunday, Lauren Fleshman was already awake. Along with about 25,000 others in the New York field, she was running her first marathon. And she had the same hope, curiosity, excitement and anxiety as anyone else who had never run 26.2 miles.

headline: A Lesson in Self
text: Joao Silva, a photographer for The New York Times who lost both legs in Afghanistan, discusses his recovery and competes in the handcycle competition of the New York Marathon, finishing in 2:38:14.

headline: A Provocative French Newspaper Is Attacked, and Support Is Swift
text: PARIS — Adored by many, reviled by some, offensive to most everyone, the French satirical weekly called Charlie Hebdo has long reveled in the arch, if simple, art of provocation. Its pages are filled with vulgar caricatures and caustic humor, lampooning politicians, entertainers and media personalities of all stripes, and the newspaper has found itself a frequent presence at Paris courts, accused on several dozen occasions of defamation or inciting hate.

text: Murong Xuecun is a novelist who writes about corruption in China. In the last year, he has emerged as one of the most outspoken critics of censorship.

text: Joao Silva, a staff photographer for The New York Times who lost both his legs in an Afghanistan land mine explosion in 2010, discusses his recovery and competes in the handcycle competition of the New York City Marathon, finishing in 2 hours 38 minutes 14 seconds.

headline: Delicate Dance of Daytime
text: I had a dream about Anderson Cooper the other night. He was in a vast, cavernous studio and was hanging from the ceiling in a harness, far above the stage.

headline: De Beers Makes Anglo American a Better Merger Catch
text: By taking full control of the De Beers Group, the world’s top diamond producer, the mining company Anglo American adds prestige to its holdings. At $5.1 billion, the price agreed to on Friday to buy the Oppenheimer family out of De Beers seems reasonable. But there is more to it: the deal is also another step toward a more straightforward Anglo, making it a more attractive merger partner.

headline: Thrills Take Detour to a Sleepy Block
text: Most of the time what passes for excitement on 74th Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is figuring out which neighbor will get to feed a lurking stray white cat.

headline: For Markets in Europe, the Focus of Fear Moves to Italy
text: European efforts to solve a growing sovereign debt crisis have failed to quell market unease on the Continent, and the skepticism over Greece points to continued volatility this week.

headline: Pushing China’s Limits on Web, if Not on Paper
text: BEIJING — When the novelist Murong Xuecun showed up at a ceremony here late last year to collect his first literary prize, he clutched a sheet of paper with some of the most incendiary words he had ever written.

headline: An Excerpt from ‘Leave Me Alone: A Novel of Chengdu’
text: An Excerpt from “Leave Me Alone: A Novel of Chengdu.”

headline: ‘NewsHour’ Changes Raise Questions at PBS
text: It’s never good when a news organization loses its political editor just a year before a presidential election. But in the next two weeks, “The PBS NewsHour” will say goodbye not only to its political editor, David Chalian — he is becoming the Washington bureau chief for Yahoo News — but also its managing editor for digital news, Maureen Hoch, who is headed to the World Bank.

headline: Murong Xuecun’s Acceptance Speech for the 2010 People’s Literature Prize
text: If I am not mistaken, the People’s Literature magazine “special action award” was not bestowed for my literary achievement, but for my courage. I’m embarrassed because I am not a brave person.

headline: For the First to Run, a Separate Peace
text: The New York City Marathon welcomed its 47,438 runners on Sunday with a sprawling village on Staten Island where loudspeakers blared directions in English, German and French. Refreshment stands offered bagels and coffee. Grassy lawns beckoned runners to huddle in a sleeping bag while they waited for the marathon to begin.

headline: U.S. Hangs Back as Inspectors Prepare Report on Iran’s Nuclear Program
text: WASHINGTON — An imminent report by United Nations weapons inspectors includes the strongest evidence yet that Iran has worked in recent years on a kind of sophisticated explosives technology that is primarily used to trigger a nuclear weapon, according to Western officials who have been briefed on the intelligence.

headline: In Echo of ’08, Giants Beat Patriots
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — All week the questions came and all week the Giants repelled them, trying desperately to avoid reminiscing about their dramatic victory in Super Bowl XLII even as they prepared to play their first meaningful game against the New England Patriots since that 2008 night in the Arizona desert.

headline: Frame-Up Suspect Levels a Murder Charge
text: It has all the makings of a Hollywood police thriller, a case in which the facts are decidedly stranger than fiction.

headline: NBC Struggles for Its Footing
text: Coming into a new television season, about the only solace for the new management regime at NBC was that the network’s prime-time fortunes had been so bad for so long, things could not get much worse.

headline: In Tennessee, Following the Rules for Evaluations Off a Cliff
text: MURFREESBORO, Tenn. — Last year, when Tennessee was named one of the first two states to win a federal Race to The Top grant, worth $501 million, there was great joy all around.

headline: Reefer Madness
text: MARIJUANA is now legal under state law for medical purposes in 16 states and the District of Columbia, encompassing nearly one-third of the American population. More than 1,000 dispensaries provide medical marijuana; many are well regulated by state and local law and pay substantial taxes. But though more than 70 percent of Americans support legalizing medical marijuana, any use of marijuana remains illegal under federal law.

headline: The Dark Side of the ‘Green’ City
text: Phoenix

headline: D.E.A. Squads Extend Reach of Drug War
text: WASHINGTON — Late on a moonless night last March, a plane smuggling nearly half a ton of cocaine touched down at a remote airstrip in Honduras. A heavily armed ground crew was waiting for it — as were Honduran security forces. After a 20-minute firefight, a Honduran officer was wounded and two drug traffickers lay dead.

headline: Accolades for Rooney, a Doubter of Accolades
text: Andy Rooney carried around the label for so long, it almost came to be his official title: national curmudgeon.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of Id al-Adha, the Islamic Feast of Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Monday and Tuesday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Race Barrier May Topple as Voters Pick Mayor
text: SAN FRANCISCO — This city with the country’s oldest Chinatown appears likely to elect a Chinese-American mayor for the first time on Tuesday, and for many residents it is a milestone long overdue.

headline: Nicaragua Is Poised to Re-elect Ortega
text: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua was leading the polls for an election to a third term on Sunday, buttressing his status as one of Latin America’s most resilient voices at a time when Western powers, civic groups and the country’s news media are challenging his domineering ways.

headline: Normal Life on Pause, and a Sense of Simmering Rage
text: ATHENS — The tiny jewelry shop in the working-class Athens neighborhood was open for business — barely.

headline: Former General Elected President of Guatemala
text: GUATEMALA CITY — Otto Pérez Molina, a former general during this country’s bloody civil war, was elected president on Sunday after promising to tackle rising crime with an “iron fist” and an expanded military.
