text: Accounts

headline: In Sexual Abuse Case, a Focus on How Paterno Reacted
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — On Saturday, March 2, 2002, according to Pennsylvania prosecutors, a Penn State University graduate student went to visit Joe Paterno, the university’s football coach. The student had a horrific story to tell: the night before, the graduate student had witnessed one of Paterno’s former coaches sexually assaulting a 10-year-old boy in the football facility’s showers.

headline: On CBS, a Final Tip of the Hat to Andy Rooney
text: CBS on Sunday replayed Andy Rooney’s words one more time, two days after the legendary “60 Minutes” commentator died in New York City.

headline: Penn State Scandal Shakes the Happy Valley Family to Roots
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Nestled in a mountain range, the idyllic community that surrounds the campus of Penn State is often referred to as Happy Valley. But on an otherwise sunny, peaceful Sunday, residents throughout the area awoke to blaring headlines and news of unthinkable child abuse crimes that led to the arrests Saturday of a prominent former assistant football coach and two top university officials.

headline: Satirical Song, a YouTube Hit, Challenges Extremism in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A satirical song that takes a tongue-in-cheek swipe at religious extremism, militancy and contradictions in Pakistani society has become an instant hit here, drawing widespread attention as a rare voice of the country’s embattled liberals.

headline: Rehearsal for Reconstruction
text: On the clear, crisp morning of Nov. 7, 1861, Sam Mitchell, a young slave living on the island of Port Royal off the coast of South Carolina, thought he heard thunder — which seemed odd, since there was not a cloud in the sky. He asked his mother, Tyra, what he’d heard. It wasn’t thunder, she said. The Yankees had come to give them freedom. A few miles away the largest fleet ever assembled by the United States was bombarding Fort Walker and Fort Beauregard, the two forts on either side of the entrance to Port Royal Sound.

headline: Ever Wondered About Andy Rooney and Stationery?
text: When I was about to graduate from Colgate University, in 1980, I knew I wanted to be a journalist. But I also knew that there are no “normal” career paths in the news business. There are no formal training programs — and newspapers do not send recruiters to college campuses.

headline: Committee of Players to Discuss Next Move
text: With weary gazes and weary voices, the leaders of the N.B.A. players union shuffled out of a hotel conference room early Sunday morning and tried to focus on a hazy horizon.

headline: Communications Director Finds Energy in Fight Against Cancer
text: Steve Mendelsohn is not a luminary to the many thousands of spectators of the New York City Marathon, but he is a familiar sight to its legions of officials and volunteers, having worked every race since 1976, when it first came to encompass all five boroughs.

headline: As Trial Nears, ‘Carlos the Jackal’ Retains His Bluster
text: PARIS — He has lost much of his hair and, after a 10-day prison hunger strike last month, a bit of his signature paunch. But as he prepares to stand trial on Monday for a series of bombings he is accused of orchestrating in the early 1980s, Ilich Ramírez Sánchez, better known as Carlos the Jackal, seems to have lost little of his bravado.

headline: Obsessed With Taking the Plunge
text: It can get pretty lonely being the kind of person who goes over Niagara Falls in a barrel. Anna Edson Taylor (1838-1921) made her name more than a century ago by doing just that, and received oceans of publicity. Yet during the many years of her life portrayed in “Queen of the Mist,” Michael John LaChiusa’s obsessive musical portrait of an obsessive woman, she encounters only one true kindred spirit. And he’s not exactly someone whose name you’d want linked to yours for eternity.

headline: Giants Find a Way; A Scuffling Brady and the Patriots Look a Bit Lost
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.

headline: Catskill Town, Slow to Rebound, Shows Signs of Energy
text: PRATTSVILLE, N.Y. — More than two months after flood waters that engulfed this remote Catskill Mountains town knocked Dave Rikard’s Victorian house off its foundation, it remains frozen in a bow — as if bidding farewell to Main Street after a 100-year performance.

headline: East River Copter Crash Takes 3rd Life
text: A third person has died as a result of a helicopter crash in the East River last month, the authorities said on Sunday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Deaths Put Focus on Pastor’s Advocacy of Spanking
text: Scrutiny of a book written by a Tennessee preacher and his wife advocating physical discipline of children intensified after the death of a third child at the hands of parents who used the book.

headline: Preaching Virtue of Spanking, Even as Deaths Fuel Debate
text: PLEASANTVILLE, Tenn. — After services at the Church at Cane Creek on a recent Sunday, a few dozen families held a potluck picnic and giggling children played pin the tail on the donkey.

headline: After a Bad Accident, Finding Resilience in Balloons
text: Inside a small, colorful shop in Brooklyn, Minnie Mouse is five feet tall and made entirely of balloons. This incarnation of the Disney character was the creation of Ianthe Cupid, who took pride in putting the finishing touches on it recently for the store’s street display.

headline: Jets’ Big Win Produces a Three-Way Tie for First
text: A capsule look at the Jets’ 27-11 victory over the Bills on Sunday.

headline: Can They Police Themselves?
text: A series of scandals and crimes — very few of them uncovered by the New York Police Department — should leave no doubt that New York needs a strong, independent agency to investigate serious complaints about the city’s police.

headline: Gun Walking the Mexican Border
text: It turns out that Fast and Furious, the foolhardy government operation that allowed high-powered weapons to cross the border to Mexican drug cartels, was not a one-off. The Bush administration used the same improper tactic in Operation Wide Receiver in 2006-7.

headline: Jamaica Bay’s Delights
text: At the outermost edges of New York City sits some of the most biologically productive public parkland on the Eastern seaboard — the 10,000 or so acres of open spaces, wetlands and waterways of Jamaica Bay. Not many New Yorkers know of this urban wilderness and for those who do, getting there and enjoying its natural beauty is a formidable task.

headline: The Next Fight Over Jobs
text: The way the job market is going, it will never be robust enough to bring down the unemployment rate, now at 9 percent, or 13.9 million people. Monthly job growth has slowed to an average of just 90,000 new jobs a month over the past six months, a pace at which growth in the working-age population will always exceed the number of new jobs being created.

headline: We Found Oil! Is That Good?
text: New ways to extract oil and natural gas could buy the U.S. some time to develop renewable energy. Or they could keep us addicted to dirty fuels.

headline: A Hidden Toll as States Shift to Contract Workers
text: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — Like many states and local governments struggling to cut costs, Michigan hopes to replace some government employees with contract workers who will do the same job for less.

headline: Here Comes the Sun
text: For decades the story of technology has been dominated, in the popular mind and to a large extent in reality, by computing and the things you can do with it. Moore’s Law — in which the price of computing power falls roughly 50 percent every 18 months — has powered an ever-expanding range of applications, from faxes to Facebook.

text: Seven years ago, Ms. Cupid lost part of her leg in a highway accident, and she has been proving her resilience to friends, family, customers and, most important, herself ever since.

headline: A Rematch Isn’t Out of the Question
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Long after Bryant-Denny Stadium emptied on Saturday night, Louisiana State Coach Les Miles stood on the field surrounded by friends and support staff. Miles grabbed someone’s cellphone and roared in laughter at a picture of himself tripping on the stadium’s turf as he came out of the tunnel before the game.

headline: 48 Years at Helm, Doing What’s Always Worked
text: Madeleine P. Brennan maintains Dyker Heights Intermediate School 201 in Brooklyn as something of a time capsule.

headline: Winning Prescription: First, Do No Harm

headline: Nasty, Brutish and Long: The Brilliance of the Modern Campaign
text: There we go again. After nonstop headlines a year before Election Day and nine debates between the Republican candidates (number 10 is scheduled to take place on Wednesday in Michigan), Americans are already grumbling that the 2012 presidential campaign is ugly and interminable. But these quadrennial complaints about campaigning miss the point.  Presidential campaigns are nasty, long and expensive because they should be. Many aspects of campaigns that Americans hate reflect democratic ideals we love.

headline: The Marathon in a Minute
text: Photographer Benjamin Norman recorded the entire New York City Marathon, and condensed it to a one minute video.

headline: Norman Ramsey Dies at 96; Work Led to the Atomic Clock
text: Norman F. Ramsey, the Nobel Prize-winning physicist who developed a precise method to probe the structure of atoms and molecules and used it to devise a remarkably exact way to keep time, died on Friday in Wayland, Mass. He was 96.

headline: Galaxy Advance to Cup With Win Over Salt Lake
text: CARSON, Calif. — The Los Angeles Galaxy advanced to M.L.S. Cup 2011 with a 3-1 victory over Real Salt Lake on Sunday night in Major League Soccer’s Western Conference final at the Home Depot Center.

headline: Disney and YouTube Make a Video Deal
text: LOS ANGELES — Two powerful media companies, the Walt Disney Company and YouTube, are betting that a new partnership will help them surmount separate but equally worrisome hurdles as they each strive for greater Web dominance.

headline: Backup Goalie Gives Rangers First-Rate Performance
text: Martin Biron seldom plays, but when he does, the Rangers win. Perhaps he should be in goal more often.

headline: At Long Last, a Glimpse of a Shipbuilding Past
text: The site of the Brooklyn Navy Yard has hosted Lenape Indians and Riveting Rosies, Hollywood royalty and lecherous seafarers, Brooklynites and Breuckelenites.

headline: Phyllis Love, Actress on Broadway Stage, Dies at 85
text: Phyllis Love, who often played ingénues on Broadway in the 1950s and who originated the part of Rosa Delle Rose in Tennessee Williams’s “Rose Tattoo,” died on Oct. 30 at her home in Menifee, Calif. She was 85.

headline: Marathon Replay
text: Beautiful weather greeted the field of 47,438 runners, a record for the New York City Marathon.

headline: Sid Melton, Comic Actor of Film and TV, Dies at 94
text: Sid Melton, a jug-eared character actor best known for his regular roles in the television shows  “Green Acres” and “The Danny Thomas Show” and for his unflagging reliability as the comic relief in many science fiction and noir films of the 1950s, died on Wednesday in Burbank, Calif. He was 94.

headline: Bowl Championship Series Standings
text: The B.C.S. rankings are determined by three components: the Harris Interactive poll, the USA Today coaches poll and the average of six computer rankings. Each component counts one-third toward a team’s B.C.S. score.

headline: Running to Honor Grete Waitz
text: Sunday’s race was dedicated to the memory of Grete Waitz, the nine-time winner who died of cancer in April at 57. Her husband, Jack, ran in her honor, his seventh marathon in New York. He finished in 3:50:41, his slowest clocked time but about a half-hour faster than he expected.

headline: A First and a Record in the Wheelchair Divisions
text: History was made Sunday in the New York City Marathon wheelchair divisions. Masazumi Soejima became the first Japanese champion in any of the marathon’s races by winning the men’s division in 1 hour 31 minutes 41 seconds, his personal best in New York. Soejima’s previous best time was 1:37:31 last year, when he finished second to David Weir of Britain by two seconds.

headline: Flu Can Be Fatal in Children With MRSA
text: A nationwide study has found that previously healthy children hospitalized with flu were significantly more likely to die if they were also infected with MRSA, or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. The findings are important because MRSA, which can cause skin and internal infections, is a growing concern among healthy children.

headline: National Study Finds Widespread Sexual Harassment of Students in Grades 7 to 12
text: Nearly half of 7th to 12th graders experienced sexual harassment in the last school year, according to a study scheduled for release on Monday, with 87 percent of those who have been harassed reporting negative effects such as absenteeism, poor sleep and stomachaches.

headline: Victory for Pro-Beijing Candidates in Hong Kong Local Elections
text: HONG KONG — Democracy advocates suffered a long series of defeats in neighborhood council elections here on Sunday, as pro-Beijing politicians successfully tapped anti-immigrant sentiment as well as public hostility toward environmental measures perceived as harming employment and increasing the government’s construction costs.

headline: Giants Replay: Week 9
text: Eli Manning threw a 1-yard touchdown pass with 15 seconds left in the Giants’ 24-20 victory over the New England Patriots.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Monday
text: Former President A.P.J. Abdul Kalam said there is no reason to panic about the Kudankulam nuclear power project, as the structural and safety systems are state-of-the-art, The Hindu reports. His remarks disappointed protesters. S.P. Udhayakumar, coordinator of one opposition group, claimed that a mishap the nuclear power plant would “wipe out several southern districts of Tamil Nadu and neighboring Kerala.”

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: Alicia Wriggles Out of One Jam; Will Lands in Another
text: It was a high-stakes episode of “The Good Wife” on Sunday night. In the case of the week — which started on time; no football overruns — Alicia faced eight years in prison and a hefty fine as fallout from Lockhart Gardner’s defense of an American translator charged with aiding terrorists. (The firm was initially representing him in a lawsuit against the government, before things went south in a manner too complicated to get into here.) As a bonus, the case brought Titus Welliver back for a guest appearance as Glenn Childs, now a nasty federal prosecutor.

headline: Slow Pace of Greek Talks Raises Fears About Italy
text: ATHENS — Greeks awaited word Monday on the formation of a unity government under a new leader after Prime Minister George A. Papandreou and his chief rival agreed to create a transitional administration to oversee the country’s debt-relief deal with the European Union and then hold early elections. Mr. Papandreou agreed to resign once the details were completed.

headline: Moving Month for Jets?

headline: Carlos the Jackal Goes on Trial for Bombings in France

But as his trial for a series of bombings he is accused of orchestrating in the early 1980s began on Monday, Ilich Ramírez Sánchez, better known as Carlos the Jackal, seemed to have lost little of his bravado.

headline: Straight Talk on Rising Seas in a Warming World

Valid gripes all.

Do you have personal goals you’ve been working for a long time to accomplish? How do you stay motivated?

headline: Trigger Fingers
text: “We accept that Africa is a place that comes with risks,” says the Ethos Water creator Peter Thum, but “seeing a little kid with a gun is very jarring.” So Thum (right) and John Zapolski (left) founded Fonderie 47, a company aimed at reducing Africa’s estimated 20 million assault weapons by turning the metal into jewelry. Working with the Mines Advisory Group, the company has helped remove more than 5,000 AK-47s from Congo. Designed with the jeweler Philip Crangi, each steel-and-gold signet ring (price on request; e-mail contact@fonderie47.com) finances the demolition of 75 more guns and is etched with the serial number of the weapon it once was.

headline: Doctor Groups Seem Less Wary of Medicare Changes

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Monday, Nov. 7
text: Bill Carter and Brian Stelter ask the question: With NBC trailing the other networks in prime-time ratings, is it possible that things could get worse for NBC? The answer is yes. “While every other network has generated a new hit, NBC, which needs hits the most, has not,” they write, noting that without the strong ratings of the N.F.L. on Sundays, “NBC would be struggling to stay out of fifth place in the ratings. Without football, NBC is now tied with the Spanish-language network Univision in those 18-49 ratings.” [NYT]

headline: A Long-Serving Principal in Brooklyn Tells All

headline: Vain Glorious | The Dancing Hairdresser
text: After a two-year salon hiatus, I re-entered the hair world by way of the new Misin Shin salon on Manhattan’s Lower East Side for what I heard would be the cut of a lifetime. My hair was like a born-again virgin — free from color, styling and heavy processing. It was ripe for the shearing. Shin, who was formerly with Frédéric Fekkai (shampoo boy turned stylist with a cult following), opened his namesake salon a few months before my visit and offers cuts, color, keratin treatments, digital perms and Japanese straightening.

headline: Government of France Proposes Austerity Cuts
text: PARIS — Ten days after President Nicolas Sarkozy of France warned that the European debt crisis had imposed a “new reality” on the country’s finances, his government on Monday presented a dose of realism: about 19 billion euros’ worth, about $26 billion, of proposed new budget cuts and tax increases as part of an aggressive effort to preserve the country’s top-level credit rating.

headline: China’s ‘Third Affliction’
text: HONG KONG — “Almost a full house!” Zhao Dayong said, his eyes glinting as we gazed over rows of filmgoers shuffling into their seats. It was a moment neither of us could have imagined two years earlier, as we filmed the Lisu tribespeople through a chilly Christmas in mountainous Fugong, in southwest China, not far from the border with Myanmar.

headline: Berlusconi Dismisses Resignation Reports
text: ROME — The European debt crisis threatened a second European government on Monday as the remnants of support for Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy seemed to be eroding rapidly in face of increased calls for his resignation on the eve of a critical vote in Parliament.

headline: Bin Laden Memorabilia a Big Presence in Panetta’s Office
text: WASHINGTON — The Central Intelligence Agency’s secret code name for Osama bin Laden’s compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan, was A1 — A for Abbottabad and 1 for its importance to the C.I.A. So when the Navy Seals who raided the compound in May discovered a yellow brick in the compound’s wall stamped “A1,” they knew what to do with it.

headline: There’s a Kebab in My Tapestry!
text: ISTANBUL — In 1990, the year that globalization shifted into high gear and McDonald’s opened an outlet in Moscow, a paper delivered at the Oxford Symposium on Food and Cookery entitled “The Bayeux Tapestry Shish Kebab Mystery” had French academics reaching for indigestion tablets. Its author, the textile specialist Robert Chenciner, pointed to a panel of that famous embroidery in which Norman knights celebrate their victory over the Saxons by grilling skewers of meat over an open fire. From this, Chenciner drew the bold conclusion that the tapestry must be a forgery or at least a much oversewn bit of cloth. There were no kebab takeaways in the Hastings of 1066, he reasoned, and it wasn’t until the Ottomans visited Versailles in the mid-18th century that Turkish food came to France.

headline: Museum Seeks State Money for Space Shuttle’s Home

headline: Recruiting Energy Customers to Use More

headline: Five Tips for Identifying a Good School

headline: Thanksgiving Side Dishes, Part 2: Gluten-Free Stuffings
text: Stuffing has always been high on my list of favorite Thanksgiving dishes. This year I wanted to play around with gluten-free dishes based on whole grains that could go inside a bird but also stand alone. So I looked in my pantry and pulled out all the half-full bags of the different colorful types of grains that I’ve been working with lately. First I combined them in visually pleasing ways, and then I decided what else I’d put into each stuffing (or pilaf, which is what these dishes really are).

headline: TimesCast | November 7, 2011
text: Greek leaders agree to form a new unity government; Italy's prime minister faces a crucial confidence vote; and Formula One racing comes to New Jersey in 2013.

headline: My Three Favorite Rapper Debut Album Covers
text: Hip-hop album covers today have become pretty slick. The album art is often as anticipated as the album itself.

headline: AMD Betting on Power Consumption
text: Advanced Micro Devices, the biggest producer of computer semiconductors after Intel, announced Thursday that it was cutting 10 percent of its staff, some 1,100 people.

headline: Syria Unleashes Assault to Take an Unbowed City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government has launched a bloody assault to retake Homs, the country’s third-largest city, facing armed defectors who have prevented the government’s forces from seizing it as they did other restive locales this summer, in what may stand as one of the most violent episodes in an eight-month uprising.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: AdKeeper, New York, hired two executives and promoted two others. Jon Gregg joined as senior vice president for advertiser solutions and Ravi Pillai joined as vice president for publisher relations. Also, MaryAnn Bekkedahl, president for advertiser solutions, was promoted to president, and David Murnick, vice president for client services and operations, was promoted to senior vice president for client services and operations.

headline: On Television, a Big Crowd for L.S.U.-Alabama
text: Louisiana State’s 9-6 win over Alabama Saturday night was seen by an average of 20 million viewers–the most for a college football game on CBS since 1989 when 22.5 million viewers watched Miami defeat Notre Dame 27-10. The win solidified L.S.U.’s no. 1 spot in the B.C.S. rankings. Alabama dropped from second to third.

headline: Pine Trees Help Reconstruct a Long-Ago Drought
text: As they struggle to understand modern climate change, scientists have long realized the importance of reconstructing past climate variability. That’s the only way to gain a sense of perspective, to understand how anomalous modern climate events are or aren’t.

headline: These Ad Stars Know All About Ads
text: Among the popular creative trends on Madison Avenue is using actual consumers — so-called real people — in ads rather than actors, models or celebrities. Now comes a campaign with a twist: The ads use real Madison Avenue people.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: In Letter to Union, Stern Details His Ultimatum
text: The ultimatum issued by the N.B.A. to its players over the weekend not only threatens them with a worse labor deal, but also a massive pay cut if they do not make a deal by Wednesday afternoon.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 52
text: Occupy Wall Street protesters are marching from Washington Heights to Zuccotti Park on Monday, almost the length of a half-marathon, in an attempt to unite city neighborhoods with the protest (albeit without leaving Manhattan). [End to End for 99 Percent]

headline: I.R.S. Asked to Investigate Nonprofit Linked to Cain Campaign
text: A liberal-leaning watchdog group based in Wisconsin asked the Internal Revenue Service on Monday to investigate whether a tax-exempt organization linked to Herman Cain’s top campaign aide violated the law by providing air travel and other help to Mr. Cain earlier this year when he was exploring a presidential bid.

headline: Joe Romm On Solar
text: The estimable Joe Romm explains the issues better than I did:

headline: Monday Motorsports: In Nascar Sprint Cup Chase, Tony Stewart Writes a Comeback Narrative
text: Tony Stewart continued to play the upsetter of the 2011 Nascar Chase for the Sprint Cup, securing his fourth victory in eight tries on Sunday at Texas Motor Speedway.

headline: Number Of The Beast Blogging
text: Under “summary”, see “value” — the current yield on Italian 10-years.

headline: The Dangerous Cocoon of King Football
text: Really, we need to do something about big-time college sports.

headline: Think Twice About That ‘Hot’ New I.P.O.
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: Bill Clinton Lays Out His Prescription for America’s Future
text: Bill Clinton’s new book, “Back to Work,” is really several books in one slender volume. It’s a lucid one-man rebuttal of the Tea Party’s anti-government agenda. A series of shrewd talking points for Democrats trying to hold on to the White House and battling for control of Congress in the midst of a sour economy and growing voter discontent. A self-serving reminder of the prosperity the country enjoyed during Mr. Clinton’s tenure in the White House, meant to burnish his legacy. And a practical set of proposals — some borrowed and some new, some innovative and some highly sketchy — for restoring economic growth and creating jobs.

headline: Finger-Pointing From Within London
text: LONDON — Workers in Britain’s financial services sector have come in for criticism from all sides since the onset of the Great Recession. Now the critics are coming from within.

headline: Floaters and Flashes, but Only a Preview
text: Dinner had just arrived at one of my favorite restaurants last month when the room began to swarm with insects and drifting bits of yarn. A moment later, I realized that they were actually inside my right eye — a mini-avalanche of the spots that doctors call floaters.

headline: Act Fast to Save Sight if Signs of Danger to the Retina Appear
text: The eyes may be windows to the soul, but the retina is the brain’s window to the world. When the retina is injured, vision is seriously threatened and may be lost entirely if the problem is not quickly addressed.

headline: Israel Denies Hackers Knocked Government Sites Offline
text: Several Israeli government Web sites, including those of the country’s military and security services, crashed on Sunday, just hours after a statement issued in the name of the hackers who call themselves Anonymous had threatened to target the country in retaliation for its blockade of Gaza.

headline: US State Balances Of Payments
text: A number of readers have asked why the United States doesn’t have internal problems with balance of payments imbalances comparable to those afflicting the euro zone.

headline: Paterno Losing Public Opinion Battle
text: Penn State Coach Joe Paterno may not be a target of the legal system in the case against his former defensive coordinator Jerry Sandusky for sexually abusing children — as the case’s prosecutors confirmed in a news conference Monday in Harrisburg, Pa. — but he has not fared well in the court of public opinion. That case is being tried in real time in the comments sections of various Web sites that have reported the story, including The Times’s.

headline: Woman Accuses Cain of Lewd Behavior; He Denies It
text: 9:33 p.m. | Updated The full report of this article is available here.

headline: One Option for Corzine in MF Global Inquiry: the Fifth Amendment
text: Will Jon S. Corzine take the Fifth?

headline: Unfamiliar Candidate for Mayor Strikes First in TV Ad Battle
text: The 2013 mayoral election is still two years away, but the first television advertisement of the campaign will make its debut on Tuesday.

headline: TimesCast | Greece's New Government
text: November 7, 2011 - Greek leaders reach a deal for a transitional government, headed by a yet-to-be-named interim Prime Minister.

headline: TimesCast | Berlusconi's Future
text: November 7, 2011 - Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi faces an uncertain future, as parliament prepares for a confidence vote on Tuesday.

headline: Starz Gives Thumbs Up to Season 3 of Gladiator Series ‘Spartacus’
text: We can’t predict for certain how the coming season of “Spartacus: Vengeance” will end, but we’re feeling confident that the gladiator hero of its title will live to fight another day. That’s because on Monday, the Starz cable channel announced that it has already committed to producing a third season of “Spartacus” even before its second season has begun.

headline: Pleasures of Life in the Slow Lane
text: New Yorkers should love bicycling. We’re control freaks. We want to get from here to there in a New York minute and moan about the subways and the buses, about lunatic taxi drivers and the gridlock that slows us down.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov.7
text: The day in sports, from surfing in San Francisco to soccer in Jakarta, Indonesia.

headline: An Injured War Photographer’s Marathon
text: Joao Silva, a photographer for The New York Times, lost both his legs last October when he stepped on a mine in Afghanistan. In February, he took his first steps on prosthetic legs. Amazingly, he competed this weekend in the New York City Marathon in the handcycle division, racing across the finish line in 2 hours 38 minutes 14 seconds.

headline: Google+ Lets In the Corporations
text: Google is opening its social network, Google+, to companies, organizations and brands. With the move, it hopes to create novel kinds of relationships between people and products, while making inroads against Facebook’s own popular corporate pages, partly by using Google search to promote pages.

headline: Some War-Weary Somalis Find Respite at the Beach
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — After years of surviving under the yoke of fundamentalist Islamist militants, Somalis here are getting their swagger back.

headline: After the Splat: Our Critic Is Back on the Bike
text: It was years ago, bicycling home from school. I hit a pothole, flew over the handlebars, and went splat against the brick wall of the building at the corner of Minetta Lane and Minetta Street. I managed to limp home. But the incident put me off biking for a long while.

headline: 20111107-lens-7billionnew
text: 20111107-lens-7billionnew

headline: Style in the Rough

headline: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company at Stanford
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the 18th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from Stanford, Calif.

headline: A Calm Guide to Afghan Chaos Moves On
text: The New York Times lost its longest-tenured journalist in Afghanistan in October. While foreign reporters rotate in and out of the country, Waheed Abdul Wafa was a perennial mainstay, dedicating his life to telling stories about a war that the rest of the world is becoming increasingly immune to.

headline: Hartung Hoard Brings $4 Million at Auction
text: As the gavel dropped time and again, Lee Roy Hartung’s motley collection of cars, motorcycles and automobilia was broken up at a highly anticipated auction outside of Chicago last weekend, ultimately bringing $4 million.

headline: Subway Predators, Captured in Verse
text: Saturday’s Crime Scene column was a cautionary tale of sorts about passing out on the subway after too many drinks and being relieved of your wallet by an old man with a razor.

headline: Finding the Right C.F.O., Working With a Spouse and Other Thoughts From Readers
text: Thoughts, comments, questions and other feedback from readers:

headline: ‘Wife’ Taking Late Hits by N.F.L.
text: “The Good Wife” on CBS is an Emmy-winning show (for its star Julianna Margulies) with a committed, devoted audience.

headline: Poison Centers Facing Greater Risks All Around
text: As a medical student, I took care of a small child hospitalized for an aspirin overdose. During my residency, I tended to a toddler who took his grandfather’s cardiac pills, which touched off arrhythmias in his heart. From years of taking calls at night, I remember too many children who drank from a bottle of some household cleaning product hidden away under the sink.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: These days, if you sing on television, you must also have a scent. Just ask Beyoncé, Jennifer Lopez, Katy Perry or any of the following pop stars who introduced new perfumes this fall.COUNTRY STRONG The country pop singer-songwriter Taylor Swift has partnered with Elizabeth Arden for her first fragrance, Wonderstruck (starts at $49.50). Its name was taken from one of her songs, “Enchanted,” and its notes include freesia, apple blossom and vanilla.BERRY DANCING The Colombian-born, belly-dancing chanteuse Shakira has come out with S by Shakira Eau Florale (starts at $17; sold at mass retailers and drugstores nationwide). “It’s similar to the process you go through when writing a melody: certain chord combinations inspire different feelings in the listener,” Shakira said in a press statement of her involvement in its creation. Notes are floral (jasmine, heliotrope) and fruity (blackberry, raspberry and blueberry).

headline: Ravens and Steelers Deliver Viewers to NBC
text: After nearly a month of blowouts and less-than-appealing matchups, “Sunday Night Football” on NBC returned to form on Sunday in a hotly contested rivalry game in which the Baltimore Ravens defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers, 23-20, with a touchdown in the final seconds. The game dominated all ratings categories among the broadcast networks, according to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates. Elsewhere, “Once Upon A Time” on ABC held steady in its third week, with 11.4 million total viewers. That fantasy drama was given a full-season order last Thursday, and its continued strong performance provides some welcome news for ABC since another freshman entry, “Pan Am,” has faded in the ratings after a strong start. It hit a series low of 5.2 million total viewers on Sunday.

headline: State Officials Blast Penn State in Sandusky Case
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — The Pennsylvania attorney general and the state police commissioner excoriated Penn State officials on Monday for failing over several years to alert the authorities to possible sexual abuse of young boys by a prominent football assistant.

headline: Really? The Claim: Drink Eight Glasses of Water a Day to Protect the Kidneys
text: THE FACTS

headline: Eggs Aren’t People
text: It is so rare to hear a Republican presidential candidate defy the extreme right on social issues that I had to take notice of Jon Huntsman’s opposition to “personhood” activists.

headline: Lying to Get My Children More Sleep
text: This weekend I set all the clocks back. About 7 on Sunday night (which was feeling a whole lot like 8 to me and four cranky children), I set them forward again. But not all the way. About half an hour. Just enough to give the children a little edge on what’s always a sleepy week without my having to declare an early bedtime — and then listen to a chorus of complaint. I admit it: I lied, or at least, I created an atmosphere in which a lie was implied. But it was all for an excellent cause.

headline: Thanksgiving Countdown | A Vegetarian Feast
text: A meat-free Thanksgiving dinner can be a colorful, hearty, robust Thanksgiving dinner. For those of you seeking festive vegetarian or vegan dishes, our colleagues on the Well blog have it covered, posting recipes every day as part of their Vegetarian Thanksgiving feature. Even more vegetarian recipes for entertaining can be found here.

headline: Kala Azar: Four-Year Test Seeks Better Ways to Treat a Persistent Disease Spread by Sand Flies
text: A four-year test of drugs to treat a widespread parasitic disease called kala azar was announced on Monday by the governments of India and Bangladesh, Doctors Without Borders, the Drugs for Neglected Diseases Initiative and other groups.

headline: Test for Hospital Budgets: Are the Patients Pleased?
text: “I’m a great kvetcher,” said Pearl Schwartz, sitting in her hospital bed at NYU Langone Medical Center.

headline: De Niro Could Play Madoff in Film for HBO
text: Robert De Niro, who has played all manner of menace to society, may next play Bernard L. Madoff. HBO confirmed Monday that Mr. De Niro is attached to play the Ponzi-schemer in a made-for-television film that is in development for the cable channel. But it cautioned that the film has not yet been put into production.

headline: Intern Gap Frustrates Clinicians in Training
text: They call it “the match.” Every year, thousands of graduate students in clinical psychology pick the hospitals and clinics where they would like to do yearlong internships. They rank their choices. The internship programs also rank the applicants.

headline: Orioles Expected to Name Duquette as General Manager
text: It’s looking as if a fresh start is on the horizon for Dan Duquette, who was run out of Boston and vilified for the Red Sox’ failings during his run as general manager from 1994 to 2002. Duquette is expected to be named as the general manager for the Baltimore Orioles, according to The Baltimore Sun, to replace Andy MacPhail. The team has scheduled a news conference Tuesday to announce Duquette’s hiring.

headline: Keystone XL Pipeline Decision to Be Investigated
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department’s inspector general will conduct a special investigation of the handling of the pending decision on the proposed Keystone XL pipeline in response to reports of improper pressure on policy makers and possible conflicts of interest, according to documents released on Monday.

headline: In Iowa, Mitt Romney Outlines Programs He Would Cut as President
text: DUBUQUE, Iowa — Mitt Romney, clad in Tommy Bahama blue jeans and a blue plaid work shirt, took that stage at a metal fabrication shop here and offered two different scenarios a year from now.

headline: ‘Learn Your Lessons Well': The Alumni of ‘Godspell’
text: When the Broadway revival of “Godspell” opens Monday night, it will likely trigger memories of rainbow suspenders and recorder solos for many a former drama club member. The 1971 musical, conceived and first directed by John-Michael Tebelak, is a retelling of the story of Jesus and his disciples, told through parables and a rock-pop score by Stephen Schwartz (“Wicked”). As Mark Oppenheimer wrote in his Arts & Leisure essay: “One school-gym performance after another of ‘Bless the Lord’ and ‘Save the People,’ among other hard-to-shake tunes, helped American religion accept contemporary music, even welcome it. It was what the kids wanted.”

headline: Selling Junk to Kids Department
text: In a USA Today story (can you tell I’m traveling?) with the headline “Burger King kids meals come with wearable cardboard crowns,” we learn that the non-leading burger chain is equipping its non-happy-meals – “BK Crown Meals” (real creative: they used to be called BK Kids Meals) – with a cute little crown your tyke can wear on her cute little head. She can also check out interactive games that will, assuming BK is following the lead of other marketers of junk, encourage further purchases.

headline: A Troubled Deal and the Law of Unintended Consequences
text: The effort by Skyworks Solutions to escape its $262.5 million deal to buy Advanced Analogic Technologies is a curious affair.

headline: The Critic, the Commissioner and the Bike Lanes
text: Michael Kimmelman, The New York Times’s architecture critic, recently cruised the bike lanes with Janette Sadik-Khan, transportation commissioner for New York City.

headline: Hop Farmers Reviving Heady Days of Brewing
text: Cazenovia, N.Y.

headline: A Hops Harvest in Brooklyn
text: They were hard to miss: flowering vines that climbed more than a dozen feet above a cramped garden patch near the busy intersection of Smith and Bergen Streets in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. The flowers, it turns out, were hops — the sticky green buds that put the bitter into English bitter and the spicy snap into Czech pilsner. And with their recent harvest, New York City has made a small contribution to a brewing renaissance.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from India, Pakistan, Iran and Scotland.

headline: Doctor Is Guilty in Michael Jackson’s Death
text: LOS ANGELES — Michael Jackson, among the most famous performers in pop music history, spent his final days in a sleep-deprived haze of medication and misery until finally succumbing to a fatal dose of potent drugs provided by the private physician he had hired to act as his personal pharmaceutical dispensary, a jury decided on Monday.

headline: Former ‘Blue Man’ President Will Be Public Theater’s Executive Director
text: The board of the Public Theater announced its new executive director on Monday, entrusting its $18.5 million operating budget and other business operations to a somewhat unusual pick: Patrick Willingham, the former president and chief operating officer of Blue Man Productions, a for-profit company that turned the Off Broadway production “Blue Man Group” into an international entertainment attraction.

headline: Dream Weavers
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: In Portland, Ore., Being an E.V. Pioneer Brings Unforeseen Challenges
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Sightings of the Nissan Leaf are a regular occurrence here on streets and freeways. Residents are retrofitting their older cars to run purely on electricity. D.C. fast chargers are being installed. And in August, a block on the campus of Portland State University became Electric Avenue.

headline: Adele Undergoes Surgery on Her Vocal Cords
text: Adele, the British singer and songwriter, underwent surgery at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston on Monday to stop recurrent bleeding from a benign polyp on her vocal cords, a condition that forced her to cancel more than a dozen concerts this year in the United States and Britain, a spokesman for the hospital said.

headline: Iraqi Governor Survives Assassination Attempt
text: BAGHDAD — The governor of Anbar Province survived an assassination attempt on Monday, the latest of several, when a homemade bomb blew up beside his convoy near the town of Abu Ghraib. The Sunni governor, Qasim al-Fahadi, was unharmed in the attack, but his spokesman said three guards were wounded.

headline: Space: The Final Stimulus
text: Fools! Fools! The White House has issued a statement denying that there is any evidence that extraterrestrials exist.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from India, Pakistan, Iran and Russia.

headline: Zuckerberg and Sandberg Discuss Facebook’s Future
text: 2:21 p.m. | Updated Adding information about Mark Zuckerberg receiving advice from Steve Jobs.

headline: The Truth About College Weight Gain
text: It’s popular wisdom that college students put on 10 or 15 pounds their first year of school, a phenomenon often dubbed “the freshman 15.” But new research suggests that the notion of early college weight gain is a myth.

headline: A Photographer in a Handcycle: He Works Fast
text: The great media critic A.J. Liebling was fond of saying about himself, in comparison to other writers, and we paraphrase: “No one better was faster, and no one faster was better.” But for 26.2 miles?

headline: Preventing Accidental Poisonings
text: With an increasingly complex array of drugs found in many medicine cabinets, parents need to be reminded all over again about the importance of keeping medications away from young children, writes Dr. Perri Klass in the latest 18 and Under column:

headline: Media Decoder: New Nook Is Latest Entry in Tablet Wars
text: Barnes & Noble answered Amazon’s challenge in the tablet wars on Monday, introducing a $249 color device called the Nook Tablet. Speaking at Barnes & Noble’s store in Manhattan’s Union Square, William Lynch, the company’s chief executive, set the new Nook directly up against Amazon’s recently released Kindle Fire, promoting what he described as the Nook’s advantages in memory and multimedia capability. Read the full post at Media Decoder.

headline: Vet Who Spoke About Carriage Horse’s Death Is Suspended
text: Updated Nov. 8, 11:06 a.m. | Two weeks ago, a carriage horse collapsed and died on its way to Central Park. The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which has oversight over New York’s carriage horses, issued preliminary findings that the horse “was not a healthy horse and was likely suffering from pain” from stomach ulcers.

headline: Michele Bachmann Warns Against Supporting ‘Frugal Socialists’
text: It is probably news to her rival Republicans, but in Michele Bachmann’s eyes their policies mark them as no better than “frugal socialists.’’

headline: A Before-Its-Time Machine
text: Researchers are planning to build a working version of the Analytical Engine, which Charles Babbage conceived of in the 1830s but never completed.

headline: It Started Digital Wheels Turning
text: Researchers in Britain are about to embark on a 10-year, multimillion-dollar project to build a computer — but their goal is neither dazzling analytical power nor lightning speed.

headline: The Vietnam War, Retold in Images
text: Francis Ford Coppola and Michael Herr should demand credit. More than 30 years after they defined how the Vietnam War would look and feel in the American memory — in Mr. Herr’s book “Dispatches” and Mr. Coppola’s film “Apocalypse Now” — they should still be getting a special thanks in every Vietnam movie and television program.

headline: Cain Video Directs Appeal to Iowa Farmers
text: Herman Cain‘s campaign put out a new web video on Monday that assails the impact of environmental regulations on farmers.

headline: Q&A: A Young Sailor’s Guide to the Islands
text: IN 2003, 8-year-old Alex Ellison and his family set sail in the Caribbean on their 46-foot Beneteau 473, Promise. They had intended to take a one-year trip from Essex, Conn., through the Caribbean to South America and back, but ended up spending almost five years living in the islands, celebrating birthdays in Grenada, Christmas in the Pitons and spending three years in the rain forest of Nevis. “The world was now our classroom,” Mr. Ellison wrote in his memoir, “A Star to Sail Her By” (May 2011, iUniverse).

headline: Voter Fraud: Does It Happen?
text: Earlier today I dared the Internet to send me examples of voter fraud — particularly of a scale that would justify erecting barriers against whole groups of voters through photo ID requirements and other such pernicious nonsense.

headline: Albums by Florence and the Machine and Meshell Ndegeocello
text: FLORENCE AND THE MACHINE

headline: Citigroup and the S.E.C. Defend Their Settlement
text: Citigroup and the Securities and Exchange Commission filed legal papers on Monday defending their settlement of allegations of fraud in the bank’s sale of mortgage-backed securities.

headline: Spotted Horses in Cave Art Weren’t Just a Figment, DNA Shows
text: Roughly 25,000 years ago in what is now southwestern France, human beings walked deep into a cave and left their enduring marks. Using materials like sticks, charcoal and iron oxides, they painted images of animals on the cave walls and ceilings — lions and mammoths and spotted horses, walking and grazing and congregating in herds.

headline: Update: Building a Visual Time Capsule
text: Update | View “Picturing 7 Billion,” the completed visual time capsule.

headline: Fireworks at the Beach
text: Q. Recently, at the San Diego ocean beach at night, we watched light emanating from every wave crest. News reports said it was caused by the red tide. How does it work?

headline: Science, Skin and Ink
text: Photographs of science tattoos from the book “Science Ink,” by Carl Zimmer.

headline: A Starry Roster Singing Arias Fiery and Hilarious
text: Last-minute changes to the program have become part of the tradition at the annual Richard Tucker Music Foundation’s gala concert. So it was on Sunday night, when a starry roster of singers — joined by members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, conducted by Emmanuel Villaume, and the New York Choral Society — performed diverse arias and ensembles for a packed house at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: The mouse that got old gracefully, a computer way, way, ahead of its time and keeping patients happy.
text: The mouse that got old gracefully, a computer way, way, ahead of its time and keeping patients happy.

headline: Critics’ Picks: ‘The Wild Bunch’
text: A. O. Scott looks at Sam Peckinpah’s epic western.

headline: Adventures Worthy of the Big Screen
text: Uncharted 3: Drake’s Deception is the finest, most exciting action-adventure movie in years.

headline: Obama Presses Job Aid for Veterans
text: President Obama renewed his campaign on Monday for measures to help veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan break into the work force, amid signs that the Senate was moving toward passing a provision of the president’s jobs bill that would give companies a tax incentive to hire returning veterans.

headline: For a Baby Okapi, Don’t Push Too Hard
text: M’bura, an okapi calf revealed to the public at the Bronx Zoo last week after more than 18 months of delicate husbandry work, was stretching out her stubby zebra-striped legs before a crowd of young admirers on Thursday.

headline: Soda Bans in Schools Have Limited Impact
text: State laws that ban soda in schools — but not other sweetened beverages — have virtually no impact on the amount of sugary drinks middle school students buy and consume at school, a new study shows.

headline: The New New List
text: Tracking the latest ideas in travel and where they’ll take you next.

headline: A Tool to Quit Smoking Has Some Unlikely Critics
text: If you want a truly frustrating job in public health, try getting people to stop smoking. Even when researchers combine counseling and encouragement with nicotine patches and gum, few smokers quit.

headline: Focus on Home, Not Meals, Led Spiders to Diversify
text: There are thousands of species of orb-weaving spiders, found on every continent but Antarctica.

headline: Old Story: Krazy Kat’s Love Triangle
text: It wasn’t just another game of cat and mouse at the Joyce SoHo on Friday night. In “Love Letters in Ancient Brick,” a performance piece conceived and directed by the Swiss visual artist Mai-Thu Perret in collaboration with Laurence Yadi, characters were plucked from a treasured comic strip and brought to life on a stage. Or that was the attempt. “Love Letters,” a presentation of Performa 11 and the Swiss Institute, didn’t really go there. It didn’t really go anywhere.

headline: In Andes, 2 Wrens Sing What Sounds Like a Solo
text: As plain-tailed wrens dart through Chusquea bamboo in the Andes, they can be heard singing a kind of song that no other bird is known to sing: a cooperative duet.

headline: Should Joe Paterno Resign?
text: Jerry Sandusky, a former defensive coach for Joe Paterno at Penn State University, has been charged with 40 counts of sexually abusing children over 15 years, including during his tenure on Paterno’s staff. Tim Curley, the athletic director at Penn State, and Gary Schultz, an administrator at the university, have been charged with lying to a grand jury about what they had been told about Sandusky’s behavior. (Curley has since taken an administrative leave and Schultz has retired.)

headline: Fat Layer on Vocal Cords Gives Big Cats Their Roar
text: In the open savanna, a lion’s roar travels up to five miles, proclaiming the extent of its territory: If you can hear it, get out.
