headline: Horse Racing Par Avion
text: The three-time Breeders’ Cup winner Goldikova was unable to take home a fourth championship, but she is returning to France in style, nonetheless. After shipping from Churchill Downs to Chicago on Monday, Goldikova will fly home in a comfortable jet stall on Air France on Tuesday.

headline: At Sony Music, a Plan to Dominate the Industry
text: A huge self-portrait of Bono hangs in the Madison Avenue office of Doug Morris, the new chief executive of Sony Music Entertainment, and on a nearby table sit his snapshots, arm-in-arm with Tupac Shakur and Snoop Dogg. Along with a determination to dominate the music industry, Mr. Morris brought them from his last job as head of the Universal Music Group.

headline: On Election Day, the Candidates Have No Monopoly on Stress
text: Election Day is seldom associated with raging hormones. But three professors from Israel, where all politics is vocal, suggest that the very act of voting generates stress levels that could affect the outcome.

headline: Tired of Feeling the Burn? Low-Acid Diet May Help
text: Stomach acid has long been blamed for acid reflux, heartburn and other ills. But now some experts are starting to think that the problems may lie not just in the acid coming up from the stomach but in the food going down.

headline: Restored: Fading Account From the Heart of Africa
text: Researchers have rescued a 19th-century field diary by the Scottish missionary and explorer David Livingstone from literal obscurity, using 21st-century imaging and processing technology to make his writing legible after the ink had nearly vanished from the page.

headline: For the Chosen Fliers, Security Check Is a Breeze
text: For the first time since 2001, travelers are going through airport security checkpoints with their shoes and jackets on, and without having to remove laptops from cases or adhere to rules like displaying carry-on liquids in containers of 3.4 ounces maximum, all packed in a single quart-size plastic bag.

headline: Urban Life on a Bike
text: Michael Kimmelman considers New York from the vantage point of a bicycle seat.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Wild Bunch’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Sam Peckinpah‘s 1969 western “The Wild Bunch.” The film, which was controversial when it was released because of its violence, is sometimes thought of as a revisionist western — an effort to update a time-worn genre. But Mr. Scott sees it more as a “terminal western, a final flowering of the dusty, epic spirit that had dominated American cinema in the ’40s and ’50s.”

headline: Tower Has Its Own Lawn, but Neighbors Still Look for Their Open Space
text: The view from the penthouse atop 144 North Eighth Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn — the much-loathed “finger building” that by virtue of a fluke of timing and rezoning is far taller than its neighbors — goes on for miles.

headline: Climate Change
text: To the Editor:

headline: Euro Zone Urges Greek Parties to Commit to Bailout Terms
text: BRUSSELS — Greece’s two main political parties have been told they must co-sign a letter pledging support for the country’s bailout terms in order to secure an 8 billion euro loan needed to stave off default, the head of the 17 euro zone finance ministers, Jean-Claude Juncker, said late Monday.

headline: Is Death Row a Form of ‘Psychological Torment’?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Word on Andy Rooney
text: To the Editor:

headline: Court Blocks Graphic Labels on Cigarette Packs
text: A federal judge on Monday blocked a Food and Drug Administration requirement that tobacco companies put big new graphic warning labels on cigarette packages by next September.

headline: Reflections on Self-Improvement
text: My Shortcuts column on Saturday, “Pursuing Self-Improvement, at the Risk of Self- Acceptance,” looked at the notion, embedded in American culture, that we should constantly strive to make ourselves better. I talked to several experts who noted that there are limits to self-improvement, including one who found that mothers who were constantly striving to be the best at everything were often unhappier than those who accepted being good enough.

headline: Giving Up on Math and Science Careers
text: To the Editor:

headline: 26.2 Miles, 46 Sketches
text: My attempt at live-illustrating the New York City Marathon.

headline: Justices Will Hear 2 Cases of Life Sentences for Youths
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear a pair of cases on whether sentencing young teenagers involved in killings to die in prison violates the Eighth Amendment’s ban on cruel and unusual punishment.

headline: Head of Google’s Public Policy Operations Resigns
text: Updated 8:20 p.m.: Added more detail on Google’s lobbying spending.

headline: U.S. Attorney in Brooklyn Names New Criminal Chief
text: The United States attorney’s office in the Eastern District of New York will have a new criminal division chief.

headline: Pre-Election Liberia Protests Turn Violent
text: MONROVIA, Liberia — Hundreds of protesters clashed with the police and United Nations peacekeepers here in the Liberian capital on Monday afternoon, leaving at least one person dead the day before a presidential runoff that the opposition has vowed to boycott.

headline: A Reputation Lies in Tatters
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — With his thick-framed glasses and rolled-up pant legs, Coach Joe Paterno has long been the public face of Penn State. But a driving force behind the on-field identity of many Nittany Lions football teams was Jerry Sandusky.

headline: A Camera With a Phone for a Viewfinder
text: The Samsung SH100 camera is remotely interesting. That is, the most interesting thing about it is the remote.

headline: The Blooey Factor
text: A thought before tomorrow’s markets open in Europe: might we be seeing Italy go careening off the edge in the next few days? I mean, even more than it has?

headline: America’s Unnecessary Secrets
text: Washington

headline: Marathon App Doesn’t Go the Distance
text: It’s an event designed to showcase and test the human spirit. But Sunday’s New York City Marathon also proved to be a test of human patience. Specifically for those who purchased the Official ING New York City Marathon Mobile Spectator App.

headline: U.S. Clears Art Project by Christo in Colorado
text: DENVER — Federal regulators on Monday approved a $50 million installation of anchored fabric over the Arkansas River in southern Colorado by the artist Christo, whose larger-than-life vision has divided environmentalists, residents and politicians for years over questions of aesthetics, nature and economic impact.

headline: Murdoch-Owned Tabloid Had Lawyers Investigating Phone Hacking Followed
text: The News of the World hired a detective to spy on two lawyers representing victims in the News Corporation’s phone-hacking scandal, and the lawyers’ families, Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper group confirmed Monday.

headline: Wall St. Pay Expected to Fall 20% to 30%
text: Wall Street bonuses are set to fall by an average of 20 to 30 percent this year from a year ago, according to a closely watched compensation survey. It would be the weakest bonus season since the financial crisis and a reflection of the leaner times confronting the industry.

headline: End Bonuses for Bankers
text: I HAVE a solution for the problem of bankers who take risks that threaten the general public: Eliminate bonuses.

headline: Ex-Lair of Tyrant, Now Just Any Place
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Toothpaste and moisturizing cream, aftershave, shoes, sheep and dogs, pigeons, toilet plungers and bicycle pumps now populate the once-forbidden grounds that were the Brother Leader’s private domain, a sudden reversal of fortune that must rank with the Sack of Rome in its completeness. Up to five months ago anyone lingering near the Bab al-Aziziya complex, much less trying to buy a mattress there, could expect arrest.

headline: New Way to Tally Poor Recasts View of Poverty
text: WASHINGTON — The Census Bureau on Monday released what it says is a more accurate measure of poverty in America. The new measure shows more poverty among the elderly, but less among children and African-Americans.

headline: Penn State President Facing Calls for Ouster
text: Among university presidents, Graham B. Spanier is known for having an unusually close rapport with students at Penn State: entertaining them with magic tricks; teaching a leadership class; even stepping in as the school mascot, the Nittany Lion.

headline: China Tries to Add Cultural Clout to Economic Muscle
text: BEIJING — Last month, the cream of the Communist Party leadership gathered here to proclaim a national effort to make China a cultural tastemaker, one whose global creative influence matches its economic clout. “A nation cannot stand among great powers,” the official party newspaper People’s Daily said on its front page, “without its people’s spiritual affluence and the nation’s full expression of its creativity.”

headline: This Grisly Find? A Bear Paw, It Turns Out. (It Happens a Lot.)
text: The discovery was unnerving, to say the least. A severed limb found Sunday evening in a yard in Rosedale, Queens, appeared to be the foot of a young child.

headline: Handling Waves and Young Rivals, Slater Wins Another Title
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Just 10 events into the 11-stop schedule, Kelly Slater clinched his 11th world title, at the Rip Curl Search San Francisco. He proved that at 39, he is still surfing’s most dominant force after a year in which he occasionally wavered on making a full-time commitment to the tour.

headline: Big Ratings for Big Game
text: Louisiana State’s 9-6 overtime victory against Alabama on Saturday night was seen by an average of 20 million viewers, the most for a college football game on CBS since 1989, when 22.5 million viewers watched Miami defeat Notre Dame, 27-10.

headline: Britain: Tabloid Spied on Lawyers, Newspaper Company Confirms
text: The News of the World hired a detective to spy on two lawyers representing victims in the phone-hacking scandal and their families, Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper group confirmed Monday. The detective, Derek Webb, told the BBC he had been commissioned in 2010 to follow Mark Lewis and Charlotte Harris, lawyers who represented multiple clients who claimed that The News of the World, since closed, had illegally intercepted their voicemail.  The BBC, citing internal newspaper documents, said the company hoped to prove that the lawyers were romantically involved, which could have forced them to decline further phone-hacking cases. News International, the British arm of Mr. Murdoch’s newspaper chain, said in a statement that though the surveillance was not illegal, “it was clearly deeply inappropriate in these circumstances,” and that no current executive had condoned it.

headline: Surgery for Rangers’ Wolski
text: Forward Wojtek Wolski will have surgery Tuesday to repair a sports hernia and is expected to be out for four weeks, the Rangers announced. Wolski, a seven-year veteran acquired from Phoenix last season for defenseman Michal Rozsival, has two assists in six games this season. He has missed six games because of the injury, including the last two.

headline: A Wedding Planner Has Many Big Days, and Flights
text: I’M a big shuttle guy, usually traveling from Boston to New York City, Washington, Palm Beach or Miami. So I don’t have those long flights where I can really unwind after producing an event. Plus, in the busy season, I usually have to get to Cape Cod about three times a week from Boston. That’s a puddle jumper flight, so there’s not much time to do anything.

headline: Wall Street’s Repeat Violations, Despite Repeated Promises
text: Many big Wall Street firms have settled fraud cases brought by the government with a promise to never violate the same law. But an analysis of Securities and Exchange Commission documents by The New York Times found that since 1996, there have been at least 51 repeat violations by those firms. Bank of America and Citigroup have each had six repeat violations, while Merrill Lynch and UBS have each had five.

headline: Houston Overcomes Obstacle to Reach Final
text: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — Losing one of your most experienced veterans in the first half, especially one who led the league in assists during the regular season, is not usually part of the plan to win an M.L.S. playoff game — or any game, for that matter.

headline: The Molester Next Door
text: The longest, most exhaustively researched article I ever wrote for a newspaper or magazine was about a child molester who had sexually abused a little boy living down the street. The abuse went on for more than two years, beginning when the boy was 10.

headline: G.O.P. Field Attacks Obama Foreign Policy With Tough Talk on Iran
text: As United Nations inspectors prepare to unveil a new report on Iran’s nuclear capabilities, some Republican presidential candidates have taken increasingly forceful tones on the issue, saying they would sanction or consider supporting an attack on Iran’s nuclear program by either Israel or the United States.

headline: In Mayor’s Contest for a New Engineering School, Only One Judge Counts
text: Midway through a third term marked by budget-cutting and a series of political and managerial setbacks, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and members of his inner circle are increasingly focused on the competition they created to build a high-tech graduate school in New York City, which many of them believe could become a major part of his legacy.

headline: With Eyes on First, Jets Sweated Giants’ Win
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — When the Jets’ flight from Buffalo landed Sunday at Newark Liberty International Airport, the clock read 1:36. Not in New Jersey, but in Foxborough, Mass.

headline: Q&A: Stopping Mobile Text Ads
text: Q.

headline: High Bank Fees Give Wal-Mart a Money Aisle
text: DICKSON CITY, Pa. — Americans say they are fed up with banks. They are protesting on Wall Street and raising a ruckus over outsize fees. Now there is a surprising beneficiary: Wal-Mart.

headline: The Serious One
text: In the Marx Brothers movie that is the Republican presidential race, Mitt Romney is Zeppo. He doesn’t spin out one-liners. He’s not the rambunctious one. He’s just the earnest, good-looking guy who wants to be appreciated.

headline: Library President Charged With D.W.I.
text: Anthony Marx, the president of the New York Public Library, was arrested on drunken-driving charges on Sunday after the library-owned car he was driving backed into a parked vehicle in Upper Manhattan, the police said.

headline: Dispute Over Jerusalem Engages Court
text: WASHINGTON — The justices seemed divided during arguments on Monday over whether the Supreme Court should wade into a dispute between Congress and the executive branch over the status of Jerusalem.

headline: A Mother Fights the Past, for the Future
text: When Jeanette Rivera, 29, gets excited, her hands pinwheel, her sentences tumble and her voice nearly squeaks.

headline: Sharing Catches On at Airports
text: For years, frustrated air travelers have wondered why they had to sit on the tarmac waiting for a gate to open up when they could see empty gates outside the plane’s windows.

headline: For McNamara, a Final Out That Wasn’t Meant to Be
text: The former manager, now 79 years old, watched the World Series at his home outside Nashville. John McNamara would see the veteran baseball men on the screen and remember them in their athletic primes, when they wore the same uniform as he did.

headline: Gilded Blinders to the Reality of a Collapse
text: Our mayor encompasses multitudes.

headline: N.B.A. Players Face Choices, None Too Appealing
text: Thirty players, the designated union representatives for their N.B.A. teams, will gather Tuesday afternoon in Manhattan to mull their negotiating options — none of them particularly attractive.

headline: A Greek Political Scion Undone by Economics
text: ATHENS — George Andreas Papandreou, elected prime minister of Greece in 2009, is a son and grandson of popular former prime ministers. But two years later, with Greece on the verge of default and a possible exit from the euro, not even the Papandreou name could save him.

headline: A Seasoned Combatant of Tornadoes Now Finds the Earth Is Moving, Too
text: SHAWNEE, Okla — The Rt. Rev. Lawrence R. Stasyszen, the chancellor of St. Gregory’s University here, gazed up at the damage inflicted this weekend by the most violent earthquake ever recorded in Oklahoma and found “a teachable moment.”

headline: Its Leader on Sidelines, Regulator Faces Biggest Test in MF Global
text: A few days before MF Global’s collapse, regulators stationed at the firm were assured its books were in order.

headline: Voters Head to the Polls in an Array of Local Races
text: Voters in New York City’s suburbs and upstate will decide on Tuesday in numerous local elections who they believe is best suited to create jobs and face challenging budgets in an election season colored by the bleak economy.

headline: Reyes Looms as Giants Get Cabrera From Royals
text: The San Francisco Giants, one of the teams believed to be in the running for the free-agent shortstop Jose Reyes, made a preliminary move to aid their lineup Monday, dealing Jonathan Sanchez and the minor league pitcher Ryan Verdugo to the Kansas City Royals for Melky Cabrera.

headline: Big Paydays in a Merger
Memory Lapse
text: Memory…  is nothing else than a certain concatenation of ideas…Baruch Spinoza, Ethics

headline: Behind the Woes at H.P., Wall St. Banks Lurk
text: How much would you pay for advice that turned out to be questionable? Would about $81 million sound unreasonable?

headline: In Tebow Debate, a Clash of Faith and Football
text: Tim Tebow is an N.F.L. quarterback, and Tim Tebow is an outspoken Christian. And while quarterback controversies are almost as common as quarterbacks, who play perhaps the most scrutinized position in American sports, what has erupted around Tebow this season is altogether different.

headline: The World’s Largest Sandbox
text: If it bleeds, it leads, goes the journalistic dictum. But the reverse is also true, which is why, through all the millions of words published in the last nine months about Libya, you’ve never heard of UNASOG, the United Nations Aouzou Strip Observation Group. Stuck along the Libyan-Chadian border, the 1994 peacekeeping mission has neither suffered casualties nor inflicted any, but it does have one particular claim to fame: at a duration of only one month, with a mere nine observers and a $64,000 price tag, it is reputed [1] to have been the United Nations’s shortest, smallest and cheapest peacekeeping mission ever.

headline: Woman Accuses Cain of Groping; He Denies Charge
text: Putting a face and a name for the first time to accusations of sexual harassment against the Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain, a woman stepped forward on Monday to say that Mr. Cain made an unwanted physical advance on her 14 years ago when he was the chief of the National Restaurant Association.

headline: Showdown in the Atlantic
text: The Old Bahama Channel, lying between the Bahamas and the northern coast of Cuba, must have seemed worlds away from the deepening hostilities of the American Civil War on Nov. 8, 1861. Yet for a short while around noon that day, it would become the war’s most important battleground.

headline: Teaching With the Enemy
text: Last month, Randi Weingarten held a book party for Steven Brill, the veteran journalist and entrepreneur who had just published “Class Warfare: Inside the Fight to Fix America’s Schools,” his vivid account of the rise of the school reform movement. When Brill told me this recently, I nearly fell out of my chair. Weingarten, you see, is the president of the American Federation of Teachers, and for much of his book, Brill treats Weingarten the way reformers always treat her and her union: as the enemy.

headline: Staring Into the Budget’s Abyss
text: Republicans, looking for leverage to slash federal spending, created the phony debt-ceiling crisis that led to creation of the Congressional deficit-cutting “supercommittee.” But with the committee close to a deadlock — largely because Republicans will not agree to higher taxes on the rich — and the deadline for an agreement approaching, some Republicans are now talking about undoing the process.

headline: Who Gets to Vote?
text: Next November more than 5 million Americans will not be allowed to vote because of a criminal conviction in their past. Nearly 4 million of these people are not in prison, yet they remain disenfranchised for years, often for decades and sometimes for life.

headline: Bad Theory, Bad Legislation
text: The House’s campaign to undercut environmental laws has now migrated to the Senate. Rand Paul, a Republican of Kentucky, is expected to offer a resolution this week to block a new federal regulation requiring cuts in soot- and smog-forming gases from power plants east of the Mississippi River. Joe Manchin III, a Democrat of West Virginia, and Dan Coats, an Indiana Republican, are then expected to try to delay all new rules governing power-plant pollution.

headline: In Turmoil, Greece and Italy Deepen Euro Crisis
text: ROME — With political turmoil still plaguing Greece and descending upon the much larger economy of Italy on Monday, the fate of the euro and market stability worldwide hinged on whether two of Europe’s most tangled and unresponsive political cultures could deal with their tightening fiscal gridlock.

headline: Good First Half Is Nothing New for Giants; Neither Is Worse Second Half
text: The Giants hit the midway point of their regular season Sunday by rallying for a victory over the New England Patriots that was so stirring that their beaming 65-year-old coach, Tom Coughlin, actually allowed running back Brandon Jacobs to pick him up for six seconds in the locker room afterward before carefully placing him back down.

headline: Imagining Local Roads as the Scene of a Race
text: It might seem unlikely, the notion of turning a stretch of local streets in New Jersey — peppered with speed bumps, traffic and stoplights — into a Formula One racecourse.

headline: Frustration in Connecticut as Wait for Power Drags On
text: NEWTOWN, Conn. — It is not that Roger Sprung has gotten used to 10 days and nights in the dark at the end of his narrow 1,200-foot-long, dirt driveway in this sprawling Fairfield County town.

headline: Special Parking Rules
text: Because of Election Day and Id al-Adha, the Islamic Feast of Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Tuesday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: A Vision of Spirituality Returns to Broadway
text: Go easy on the caffeine if you’re heading to the Broadway revival of “Godspell” that opened on Monday night at the Circle in the Square. The cast of this relentlessly perky production of the 1971 musical, which transformed parables from the Gospels into a series of singable teaching moments, virtually never stops bopping, bouncing, bounding, even trampolining across the stage and up the aisles of the theater. It’s like being trapped in a summer camp rec room with a bunch of kids who have been a little too reckless with the Red Bull.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Tuesday: Cookie With Creme in the Middle
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Some constructors like to hang out in certain parts of the week. I’m an early-week constructor, although I’ve also made my share of Sunday puzzles. I hang out in those parts because I’m so attached to the process of theme development, and frankly, I’m just not that great at stacking quads.

headline: For Birthplace of Hip-Hop, New Life
text: After a long struggle, ownership of a Bronx building known as the birthplace of hip-hop, which had fallen into neglect and foreclosure, was taken over on Monday by a group that specializes in preserving working-class housing.

headline: A Gridiron Family: The Star Quarterback Is Just Daddy’s Little Girl
text: Not so long ago, for a reviewer to compare a work of theater to a television show would have been a sign of obvious displeasure. That’s hardly the case anymore, as the cable stations have pushed the series form forward artistically and the networks have scrambled to follow suit. So when I say that Julia Brownell’s play “All-American” reminded me in many ways of the superlative NBC show “Friday Night Lights,” which ended its five-season run this year, I certainly mean it as a compliment.

headline: Man Is Convicted in the Rape and Harassment of Women
text: A man from Ivory Coast who convinced several women in Manhattan to go on dates with him by claiming he was a renowned international journalist was convicted on Monday of raping one of them and harassing and stalking others.

headline: The F.D.A. Ups Its Numbers
text: The Food and Drug Administration recently reported that in the last fiscal year it had approved 35 new drugs, a near-record for the decade, of which 24 were approved here before they were approved in any other country. The new report is consistent with a similar finding in June by independent analysts that new cancer drugs were approved in greater numbers and faster times in the United States than in Europe between 2003 and 2010.

headline: Lavin Era Begins Next Phase, With Lavin at Home
text: St. John’s began a new era for its basketball program last year, with the newly installed coach Steve Lavin pacing the sideline with his slick hair and quick tongue. The excitement Lavin injected into the Red Storm was palpable in that first season, but the real Lavin era — with nearly an entirely new roster of his choosing — did not tip off until Monday night at Carnesecca Arena. Lavin, however, was not in the building with the 4,142 fans.

headline: All That Glimmers
text: Gold has had a remarkable ride — doubling in price over the last three years, as investors who lost faith in equities and bonds piled into the stuff. Conservative politicians are even more bullish, pushing gold to replace the dollar and get the government out of the business of managing the economy. “It has been money for 6,000 years,” Representative Ron Paul, a Republican presidential candidate, told the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben Bernanke, during Congressional hearings in July. It’s an “economic law.” Other Republicans, including Newt Gingrich and Herman Cain, have hinted that they might also like to peg the dollar to gold, which would limit the growth of money in the economy to the growth of gold in reserve, stopping the Fed from printing more dollars.

headline: Ivory Soap Refreshes Its Ads and Its Look, but Is Resolutely Simple
text: PROCTER & GAMBLE is bringing one of its oldest and one of its most known brands, Ivory soap, into the 21st century with new packaging, advertising and social media initiatives.

headline: G.O.P. Talks of Limiting Tax Breaks
text: WASHINGTON — Republican members of a Congressional panel seeking ways to cut the federal budget deficit indicated on Monday that they might allow some additional tax revenue as part of a deal with Democrats.

headline: Promises Made, and Remade, by Firms in S.E.C. Fraud Cases
text: WASHINGTON — When Citigroup agreed last month to pay $285 million to settle civil charges that it had defrauded customers during the housing bubble, the Securities and Exchange Commission wrested a typical pledge from the company: Citigroup would never violate one of the main antifraud provisions of the nation’s securities laws.

headline: Senate Acts on 2 Pieces of Proposal on Hiring
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Monday cleared the way for a measure that would repeal a tax withholding program on government contractors and provide tax incentives for companies that hire veterans, making them the first pieces of President Obama’s jobs plan to gain some momentum in Congress.

headline: California Dispensaries Moving to Block U.S. Marijuana Crackdown
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Lawyers for the medical marijuana industry said on Monday that they would seek court orders to halt a threatened federal crackdown on marijuana dispensaries, their landlords and marijuana growers.

headline: Australian Senate Approves Emissions Trading Plan
text: SYDNEY, Australia – The upper house of Australia’s Parliament on Tuesday approved the government’s proposal to adopt an ambitious emissions trading program, marking the end of a prolonged political battle that the business community has watched anxiously and that dragged Prime Minister Julia Gillard’s public approval ratings to historic lows.

headline: Theadora Van Runkle, Costume Designer, Dies at 83
text: Theadora Van Runkle, a self-taught costume designer who earned an Oscar nomination for her first picture, “Bonnie and Clyde,” and whose signature outfit for Faye Dunaway’s Bonnie Parker — beret, calf-length skirt and sweater — ignited a fashion trend on the film’s release in 1967, died on Friday in Los Angeles. She was 83.

headline: Should Voting Be Mandatory?
text: Or are there already too many people casting ballots?

headline: Word of the Day | prevaricate
text: prevaricate •\pri-ˈver-ə-ˌkat, -ˈva-rə-\• verb

headline: Racing Weehawken
text: A reporter takes a 2007 Chevy Malibu through its paces on the recently announced 2013 Formula One race course in Weehawken and West New York, New Jersey.

headline: Texas: Court Halts Execution of Henry Skinner
text: The state’s highest criminal court on Monday stopped the execution of a man who claims that DNA tests of evidence will prove his innocence. The inmate, Henry Skinner, who was convicted in 1995 of murdering his girlfriend and her two sons and was scheduled to be executed on Wednesday, has fought for the tests for 10 years. His lawyers had not requested DNA testing on all the evidence available at trial out of fears that the results would go against him. After the state enacted a broad postconviction DNA testing law in 2001, Mr. Skinner began a string of appeals that reached the United States Supreme Court. The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals on Monday cited recent changes in Texas law on DNA testing, and said it would be “prudent” to “fully review the changes in the statute as they pertain to this case.”

headline: Olympus Hid Investing Losses in Big Merger Payouts
text: TOKYO — Olympus said Tuesday that more than $1 billion in merger payouts were used to hide years of losses on investments, an acknowledgment that is an abrupt about-face for the company, which had denied any wrongdoing in the wake of a widening scandal.

headline: Vermont: New Bridge Opens
text: A new Lake Champlain Bridge, between Addison, Vt., and Crown Point, N.Y., opened Monday after a two-year replacement project. The previous 80-year-old bridge was deemed unsafe in October 2009 and demolished two months later, leaving the 3,400 drivers who used the bridge daily to take a ferry or roundabout routes to cross between the two states. Gov. Peter Shumlin of Vermont and Lt. Gov. Robert Duffy of New York attended the ribbon-cutting for the $70 million bridge.

headline: $71 Million in Art Is Sold at Phillips, Near Low Estimate
text: Perhaps it was the wobbly economy or high estimates, or it could just have been that collectors were saving up for the next two nights, when the auction giants Sotheby’s and Christie’s hold their fancier postwar and contemporary art sales.

headline: Cuba Takes Lead Role in Haiti’s Cholera Fight
text: MIREBALAIS, Haiti — The family from a nearby village arrived at the small hospital here vomiting and with uncontrollable diarrhea, at first glance maybe a typical case of consuming bad food or water.

headline: Joe Frazier, Ex-Heavyweight Champ, Dies at 67
text: Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight champion whose furious and intensely personal fights with a taunting Muhammad Ali endure as an epic rivalry in boxing history, died Monday night at his home in Philadelphia. He was 67.

headline: Journalists Overhear Private Exchange Between Obama and Sarkozy, Report Says
text: It marks another chapter in the close, if occasionally awkward, relationship between President Obama and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France. After the two leaders appeared together at a news conference during a G20 summit meeting in Cannes last Thursday, they retired to a room for what they thought was a private conversation.

headline: Numberplay: The White Halloween Horror
text: A set of puzzles on why trees shed their leaves in the winter – inspired by the recent White (and for many, Dark) Halloween. Plus a Scrabble puzzle.

headline: A Champion Who Won Inside the Ring and Out
text: Some people mean more together than they do apart, whatever the stage. Churchill and Hitler. Bogart and Bacall. Ali and Frazier. And for all the deserved accolades for Muhammad Ali, I’ve always believed that each at his best, Joe Frazier, who died Monday night at age 67, was the better fighter. And the better man.

headline: A Heartburn-Free Thanksgiving
text: If you think heartburn and Thanksgiving always go together, think again. Choosing the right foods and being careful not to overeat can put you well on your way to a heartburn-free holiday.

headline: For Christmas, J.C. Penney Ads Emphasize Fun and Frugality
text: You do not need to know “Who’s your daddy,” J. C. Penney declares in its Christmas 2011 advertising campaign, as long as you know “Who’s your Santa!”

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
text: A committee formed by the Union government to address residents’ safety concerns about the Kudankulam nuclear power project is planning to meet the Tamil Nadu government on Tuesday, and the former president, A.P.J. Abdul Kalam, has developed a 40-page special development plan for villages surrounding the project site following his visit to the plant (The Hindu). The $40 million plan includes connecting villages within a radius of about 19 miles to nearby highways with four-lane roads, the creation of industries around the project site that employ 10,000 and self-employment loans for young entrepreneurs.

headline: Corrections: November 8
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: NYT Front Page for 11/08/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 11/08/2011

headline: Looking Back at the Life of a Boxing Great
text: Joe Frazier, former heavyweight champion and rival of Muhammad Ali, died Monday at 67.

headline: Top Obama Aide, Under Pressure, Relinquishes Some Duties
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s chief of staff, William M. Daley, has turned over some of his day-to-day management responsibilities to another senior aide, Pete Rouse, according to several officials with knowledge of the change. The shift comes after a turbulent period in which the White House has struggled with a weak economy and a hostile Congress.

headline: Cain, on Late-Night Television, Speaks to Accusations
text: Herman Cain used the forum of late-night television to confront the latest accusation of sexual impropriety against him, which was leveled on Monday by a woman who said Mr. Cain had made advances 14 years ago when she sought his help in finding a job.

headline: At the G-20, Small Victories for India
text: “History is being written in Cannes,” trumpeted billboards around the Mediterranean resort city when world leaders met there last week.  And it was, though not as the French might have hoped.Nicolas Sarkozy had no lesser ambition when France assumed the presidency of the Group of 20 last year than to oversee a complete overhaul of the international monetary system.  His ambitions were dashed by the European debt crisis and a failure by the advanced economies to provide solutions for a global economic crisis largely of their making.

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 8, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: In Turmoil, Greece and Italy Deepen Euro Crisis
text: ROME — With political turmoil still plaguing Greece and descending upon the much larger economy of Italy, the fate of the euro and market stability worldwide hinged Tuesday on whether two of Europe’s most tangled and unresponsive political cultures could deal with their tightening fiscal gridlock.

headline: Nov. 8, 1960 | Kennedy Is Elected President
text: On Nov. 8, 1960, Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts defeated Vice President Richard M. Nixon for the presidency in one of the closest and most contentious elections in American history. Mr. Kennedy would end up defeating Mr. Nixon by just 0.1 percent in the popular vote, and the results of the election were still uncertain on Tuesday night.

headline: South Korea Approves Sending Medical Aid to the North
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea on Tuesday authorized the World Health Organization to resume the distribution of medical aid to North Korea, financed by the South Korean government, amid growing international calls for assistance for malnourished North Korean children.

headline: The True Measure of a Pass-Heavy Offense
text: The popular perception is that the Green Bay Packers are great because of Aaron Rodgers and the passing offense. And for good reason: Rodgers (and by extension, the entire Green Bay passing offense) is on a record-breaking pace. Rodgers leads the league in completion percentage, touchdowns, touchdown percentage, yards per attempt, adjusted net yards per attempt and adjusted yards per attempt. He’s averaging 11.2 adjusted yards per attempt, the highest mark after a team’s first eight games of any quarterback in over 50 years.

headline: Verdict: Guilty
text: WHO was found guilty on charges related to the death of Michael Jackson?

headline: Passers-By, Preoccupied
text: Growing up in New York as a street photographer, I knew I always had to be aware of my surroundings. I’d scan the sidewalks not only to look for the perfect moment, but also to avoid any problems that could blindside me.

headline: How to Save Money on Train Trips in Italy
text: Taking a train has always been one of the most economical, and easiest, ways to travel around Italy. And thanks to promotions from Italy’s main train operator, Trenitalia, taking the train just got even cheaper.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 8, 2011
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article, “Sleep Medication: Mother’s New Little Helper.”

headline: Societe Generale Profit Falls 31% in Third Quarter
text: PARIS — Société Générale said on Tuesday that its third-quarter net profit fell by nearly a third, weighed down by the cost of writing down its exposure to Greece.

headline: Have You Experienced Sexual Harassment?
text: A new national survey found that nearly half of students in 7th through 12th grades experienced sexual harassment – defined as “unwelcome sexual behavior that takes place in person or electronically” – in the past year. Have you experienced sexual harassment in any way? What, if anything, do you think can and should be done to address it?

headline: With Profit Down 19%, Toyota Withdraws Its Forecast
text: TOKYO — Just as Toyota has seemed to find its footing after the devastating earthquake and tsunami in Japan, a painful jump in the yen is weighing on quarterly profit and a shortage of parts from flooded suppliers in Thailand has led the company to scrap its outlook.

headline: Roadside Bomb Kills 11 in Western Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan officials said Tuesday that insurgents once again attacked during the Id al-Adha holiday, killing 11 people, most of them civilians.

headline: Part 2: Answers to Your Questions on Applying with a Learning Disability
text: Marybeth Kravets is fielding questions this week on The Choice about applying to college with a learning disability, the subject of my column published over the weekend in The Times’s Education Life supplement.

headline: Driving the Rolls-Royce 102EX Phantom Experimental Electric
text: Rolls-Royce found 2,700 buyers worldwide for its Phantom and Ghost models last year. And to hear company executives tell it, roughly 2,699 of them are perfectly content with their V-12 gasoline engines. But that hasn’t stopped the 102EX, a 6,000-pound, all-electric version of the brand’s Phantom sedan, from barnstorming around the globe. It brought its nearly silent stump speech to Manhattan on Monday.

headline: The Early Word: Accusations
text: Today’s Times

headline: Can the Fed Stimulate Growth or Only Inflation?
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the coming book “The Benefit and the Burden.”

headline: As Syria Hits City, U.N. Says Toll Climbs
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — More than 3,500 Syrians have been killed in a crackdown by the government of President Bashar al-Assad on an uprising that has persisted for eight months, the United Nations said Tuesday, as the government pressed its assault on Homs, the city where the uprising has demonstrated its greatest strength.

headline: Linnaeus Tripe’s 19th Century India
text: On Nov. 15, Sotheby’s in London will auction off some of the earliest photographs ever taken in India, which have been out of public view for more than a century. The collection of more than 220 images from India and Burma, taken by Linnaeus Tripe shortly before the first war of independence in 1857, is unusual both for its content and its provenance.

headline: What’s Behind Dynegy’s Unusual Bankruptcy
text: A big piece of Dynegy, the company that once tried to save Enron from bankruptcy, has entered Chapter 11 bankruptcy.

headline: What Can Happen When You Try to Go Big
text: In my last post, Carissa Reiniger, a member of our business group and founder of Silver Lining Limited, described the missteps that left her $410,000 in debt by early 2008. We pick up her story here, as she explained it to the group.

headline: Profit Slumps 22% at Lloyds Banking Group
text: LONDON — The Lloyds Banking Group reported on Tuesday that third-quarter pretax profit fell 22 percent, to £644 million, from the period a year earlier, and the bank said it was unlikely to meet its financial goals by the end of 2014.

headline: On the Streets, Discovering the Voice of the City
text: “I have a fancy that every city has a voice. Each one has something to say to the one who can hear it.” — O. Henry

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 8
text: The guilty verdict in the trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, Michael Jackson’s doctor, was covered live on Monday by HLN, CNN, Fox News and MSNBC, Variety reported. “The Big Four broadcasters broke in with special reports, with Diane Sawyer anchoring for ABC, Harry Smith for NBC, Scott Pelley for CBS, and Bill Hemmer anchoring for Fox stations,” it wrote, while taking note of a very special absence, the HLN anchor Nancy Grace:

headline: TV Watch: Cain Charts New TV Territory in Dealing With Charges
text: “When I made the statement that I’m done talking about it, I was talking about the firestorm last week.” That is how Herman Cain on Monday explained why he was addressing a fresh accusation of sexual harassment on the ABC late night show, “Jimmy Kimmel Live!”

headline: The Case for Not Paying Matt Forte
text: Brian Burke of Advanced NFL Stats had a suggestion for the Titans in August, when the team was locked in a contract dispute with running back Chris Johnson: “Take the $12 million per year, put it into your offensive line, and draft a couple 4th round RBs. You’ll thank me later.”

headline: The G.O.P. Campaign Goes On Unnoticed
text: The biggest surprise in the Republican presidential campaign? That it’s still going on, despite the news media frenzy surrounding Herman Cain.

headline: Ranking History’s Atrocities by Counting the Corpses
text: Browsing the bookstore shelves can pose its grim challenges for the ordinary mortal. The reproachful cover of “1,000 Places to See Before You Die” is bad enough. There’s also “100 Birds to See Before You Die,” “100 Belgian Beers to Try Before You Die!” and “1,001 Video Games You Must Play Before You Die.” Make your way through “50 Places to Play Golf Before You Die” and you’re still not done: “50 More Places to Play Golf Before You Die” is staring right at you.

headline: PPR Acquires Italian Suit Maker Brioni
text: LONDON — The French luxury goods group PPR said on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement to buy the Italian men’s fashion brand Brioni for an undisclosed price.

headline: Tapping the Tappan Zee for Wind
text: Replacing the Tappan Zee Bridge, which carries the New York State Thruway across the Hudson River between Westchester and Rockland Counties, is expected to be one of the biggest infrastructure projects in the New York region in coming years. Some experts have suggested including some green features, like tracks for commuter trains or a bus rapid transit lane.

headline: Russian Lessons
text: MOSCOW — “The university is no place for spreading leaflets or shouting out slogans.”

headline: Mississippi Voters Reject Anti-Abortion Measure
text: Voters turned a skeptical eye toward conservative-backed measures across the country Tuesday, rejecting an anti-labor law in Ohio, an anti-abortion measure in Mississippi and a crackdown on voting rights in Maine.

headline: Political Tensions Dampen Liberia’s Runoff Vote
text: MONROVIA, Liberia — President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, who won the Nobel Peace Prize this year for helping to stabilize her country after years of conflict, was poised to win a second term in an uncontested presidential runoff on Tuesday.

headline: Nokia’s Comeback Strategy in Smartphones
text: The challenge Nokia faces in the smartphone market was grimly detailed last week. In the third quarter, according to IDC, Nokia’s worldwide smartphone sales fell 37 percent to 16.8 million phones from 26.5 million a year ago.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Wall St. Bonuses Expected to Fall 20% to 30%  |  Wall Street bonuses are set to fall by an average of 20 to 30 percent this year from a year ago, according to a closely watched compensation survey. It would be the weakest bonus season since the financial crisis and a reflection of the leaner times confronting the industry.

headline: Trouble for a Library Chief and for a Tappan Zee Protester
text: For more local news, including a look at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg as the deciding judge on which of seven engineering school proposals will be accepted, a severed bear’s limb that was mistaken for human in Queens and New Jersey streets as a Formula One race course, see the N.Y./Region section.

headline: Tweed Protesters Denounce 'Privatization' of Schools

headline: Students Say Sexual Harassment Is Pervasive in Schools
text: A study by the American Association of University Women, a nonprofit research organization, found that nearly half of 7th to 12th graders it surveyed said they had experienced sexual harassment in the last school year.

headline: The Get | Hermès Collier de Chien Bracelet
text: The latest and most extreme-slash-sparkly-slash-jaw-dropping addition to Hermès signature Collier de Chien series is this: a studded rose gold cuff fully encased in brown diamonds. Introduced by the company’s artistic director for jewelry, Pierre Hardy, as part of the house’s Haute Bijouterie collection, the significant cuff comes in at 30 carats. O.K., so maybe a high-res image is as close as we’re going to get to this piece, but look (and dream) all you like. Or better yet, add it to your holiday wish list and see what happens.

headline: Fired From a Shelter After Photographing the Animals
text: Photography was not part of Emily Tanen’s job description at the Manhattan branch of Animal Care and Control of New York City. But soon after she started working there in August 2009, she began taking photos of animals who were scheduled to be euthanized.

headline: In the Flooded Thai Capital, Residents Are Now Refugees
text: BANGKOK — At the flood-ravaged Don Muang airport, children play with luggage carts while their parents hang laundry above check-in counters. The signs read “Departures,” but the families camped out at the airport will not be leaving anytime soon.

headline: Everybody Laugh: Sarah Silverman Sings Broadway
text: As if to compensate for last week’s announcement that a new revival of “Funny Girl” won’t be coming to Broadway any time soon, the universe delivered a different funny girl to Broadway — or at least to its general vicinity — to surprise us with a few selections from her personal songbook.

headline: European Debt Crisis as Berlusconi’s Last Stand
text: ROME — The European debt crisis appeared to claim its most prominent victim on Tuesday when Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy, cornered by world markets and humiliated by a parliamentary setback, pledged to resign after Italy’s Parliament passes austerity measures demanded by the European Union.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Hospitals Now Seek Patient Approval
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

text: Stocks gyrated Tuesday before ending higher on a day of significant political developments in Italy, the latest country to come under fire in the drawn-out euro zone debt crisis.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Food Safety News: A study found that three-quarters of the honey bought in groceries had no pollen, indicating that it had been ultrafiltered so its origin couldn’t be traced. Safety advocates fear that much of it could have come from China, which has been a source of contaminated honey. The F.D.A. says honey without pollen isn’t honey. — Nick Fox

headline: States Versus Countries, Rodrik Edition
text: Dani Rodrik has just posted on the same subject I briefly addressed yesterday — why aren’t US states subject to the same stresses facing European nations? He asks, Why is the bankruptcy of the Greek government different from the bankruptcy of California?

headline: Christie’s Backing Starts Paying Dividends for Romney
text: Less than a month after endorsing Mitt Romney on the day of a Republican debate in New Hampshire, Gov. Chris Christie will make his debut as a surrogate for Mr. Romney, once again on the day of a debate in New Hampshire.

headline: Mayor Presses Both Parties to Cut U.S. Deficit
text: 10:17 p.m. | Updated Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday that it was time for Washington to take serious steps to address the federal deficit, starting with a measure certain to be unpopular with some of his financial industry friends: a change to the way that hedge fund managers are taxed.

headline: A New Edition of Betsy-Tacy Greets Fans, Old and New
text: A ramshackle four-story brownstone in mid-20th-century Manhattan. A Lower East Side tenement at the turn of the last century. The woods of Wisconsin in 1964.

headline: Evangelicals Woo Brazil’s Upwardly Mobile
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The neighborhood of Xerém, 30 miles north of downtown Rio, sits at the foot of mountains. It has made a name for itself as a home to the car industry, drug-related violence and the Fluminense Football Club. For the better part of the last century, wealthy Brazilians cut through it on their way to fancy weekend mountaintop hideaways.

headline: How Is a Grizzly Bear Like a Wolf?
text: In Saturday’s paper, I wrote about the repercussions of a Congressional decision in April to remove the gray wolf from the endangered species list through legislation.

headline: Help Us Choose Sentence of the Week
text: Close all the other tabs in your Web browser. Turn off your satellite radio. Call a baby-sitter for your dependents. Throw your iPhone into the garbage disposal. Anesthetitize your co-workers. Tell your boss that you’re tired of his incessant yakking, that something crucial has come up — something bigger than you, bigger than your boss, bigger than all of us put together.

headline: David C. Utz, Surgeon Who Operated on Reagan, Dies at 87
text: Dr. David C. Utz, a prominent urological surgeon at the Mayo Clinic who drew wide attention when he performed prostate surgery on President Ronald Reagan in 1987, died on Oct. 30 in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 87.

headline: Liberia Holds Presidential Runoff Election
text: Tension hangs over the Liberian runoff election the day after deadly pre-election clashes and with the opposition party planning a boycott.

headline: Remembering Joe Frazier, the Working Man’s Champion

headline: Express Scripts Cuts Termination Fee in Medco Deal
text: Express Scripts announced on Tuesday that it had cut the termination fee for its  $29 billion takeover of Medco Health Solutions as part of an effort to settle lawsuits tied to the deal.

text: The U.S. Coalition for Advanced Diesel Cars, a Washington-based advocacy group whose members include Bosch, Honeywell and BorgWarner, all major automotive suppliers, released a white paper on Monday to make the case for technology-neutral policy-making on fuel efficiency.

headline: No Link Seen Between Low Credit Scores and Bad Job Behavior
text: 12:15 p.m. | Updated  To more clearly distinguish between credit reports and credit scores. Employers don’t use credit scores in employment screening, but they can and do access credit reports.

headline: If I Don't Grade My Students' Regents Exams, Who Will?
text: The Board of Regents recently decided to ban teachers from scoring their own students’ state exams. To any outsider, this seems like a simple decision. However, it is actually a reactionary decision that will hurt a large number of students, one teacher says.

headline: Black and White Quinoa Dressing With Butternut Squash and Pecans
text: The light-colored version of quinoa is a fluffier grain than the black version, so it’s almost as if there are two completely different grains in this colorful mixture.

text: This is particularly colorful because of the beautiful salmon-colored red lentils. They are soaked, not cooked, and contribute a fresh flavor and crunchy texture to the mix.

headline: Top Obama Aide Relinquishes Some Duties
text: WASHINGTON — A year before Election Day, President Obama has realigned the West Wing to consolidate power among his closest and most trusted campaign advisers, putting Pete Rouse, a confidant with decades of Capitol Hill experience, at the center of White House operations.

headline: In North Dakota, After the Water, the Winter
text: MINOT, N.D. — There are four seasons up here, the joke goes: winter, winter, winter and construction.

headline: On Our Radar: Gas Pipeline Links Russia and Germany
text: The leaders of Germany and Russia inaugurate a $10.2 billion pipeline that links Western Europe directly with Siberia’s vast natural gas reserves for the first time. The pipeline will transport gas under the Baltic Sea from Vyborg, near St. Petersburg in northern Russia, to Lubmin, Germany. [Associated Press]

headline: Oppression Is Not a State’s Right
text: Stop me if you’ve heard this one: Elected officials in Southern states barring the schoolhouse door, shaking their fists at the federal government over civil rights, the Constitution and their right to oppress minority groups without Washington’s meddling.

text: While I’m talking about inequality and the crisis, I realized recently that there’s another channel not usually talked about, via the misperception of success.

headline: Black and Brown Rice Stuffing With Walnuts and Pears
text: Pears and walnuts complement dark black and pale brown rice in this sweet and savory mixture. Make sure you don’t overcook the pears; they need only a quick sear in the pan. The optional red lentils or cranberries add some color to the mix.

headline: Cain Speaks Out to Deny Accusations; 2nd Voice Heard
text: Herman Cain, the embattled Republican candidate for president, convened a nationally televised news conference Tuesday in which he insisted that he is innocent of all sexual harassment accusations, even as another woman put her name to allegations that he had approached her inappropriately.

headline: I’m Number 97
text: For what it’s worth — or rather, what it’s Worth — Worth magazine says I’m the 97th most powerful person in finance. That plus $5.65 gets me a sandwich at the Wilson School cafeteria.

headline: Sarkozy Reportedly Called Netanyahu ‘a Liar’ in Overheard Remarks to Obama
text: Updated | 5:53 p.m. During a private conversation last week that was accidentally broadcast to several journalists covering the Group of 20 economic summit meeting in Cannes, France, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France reportedly told President Obama that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was “a liar.”

headline: Jackson Doctor Trial Fails to Ignite Audience Interest
text: In a bit of anticlimax, Dr. Conrad Murray was found guilty late in the day on Monday of involuntary manslaughter two-and-a-half years after the death of Michael Jackson. Networks broke in for live coverage, cable networks hit the hyperdrive button and pundits played Ping-Pong with the verdict deep into the night, but audiences seem to shrug. Ratings on the verdict coverage are not known yet, but The Hollywood Reporter said during the trial that the case failed to ignite audience interest on HLN, CNN’s sibling networked that had promised wall-to-wall coverage.

headline: Depression Drug Results Disappoint Targacept and AstraZeneca
text: An experimental drug for depression, developed from studies of how nicotine affects the brain, has failed in its first late-stage clinical trial, the companies developing the drug said Tuesday.

headline: An Infusion of Money for Soundtracking, a Social Music App
text: SoundTracking, a social mobile application that allows people to create “musical postcards” that can then be shared with friends on social sites,  announced Tuesday that it had received $4.75 million in financing.

text: After Amylin Pharmaceuticals accused longtime partner Eli Lilly of cavorting with another partner, it was perhaps only a matter of time before they split.

headline: Penn State Said to Be Planning Paterno Exit Amid Scandal

headline: Tragedy on the Banks of the Ganges

headline: More Churn in Job Market Is Hopeful Sign
text: The number of people leaving or receiving jobs picked up in September, the Labor Department reported Tuesday, a sign that that the labor market may be regaining its health.

headline: With Real Presence
text: AT the Fivestory pop-up, on the third floor of an Upper East Side town house, shoppers will get a sneak peek at what Claire Distenfeld plans for the boutique she will open there in February. Ms. Distenfeld, who was raised on the U.E.S., fled an art-world job to hone her sophisticated retail aesthetic. For the preview, she filled two rooms with contemporary wares in a range of prices that includes, yes, affordable.

headline: Protester Arrested During Bomb Scare Evacuation
text: An Occupy Wall Street protester in Zuccotti Park was arrested Tuesday morning after refusing to obey police orders to evacuate the park steps during a bomb scare, the authorities said.

headline: NBC to Televise Derby Preps
text: The Jockey Club, making good on its promise to bring more television coverage of horse racing, announced Tuesday it was partnering with the NBC Sports Group to broadcast six major Kentucky Derby prep races next spring.

headline: In Overheard Comments, Sarkozy Calls Netanyahu a ‘Liar’
text: JERUSALEM — The president of France, Nicolas Sarkozy, told President Obama that he could no longer bear Benjamin Netanyahu, the prime minister of Israel, and went on to call Mr. Netanyahu a “liar” in a private conversation overheard by several French journalists last week at the Group of 20 summit meeting in Cannes.

headline: Government Counting Sheep? Now, Only in Its Dreams
text: Last year, Wisconsin led the nation in mink farming, producing 833,430 pelts. Texas was the undisputed king of pansies, growing 1.8 million flats of the flowers. And no state harvested more hops than Washington, with 24,336 acres.

headline: Air Force Officials Disciplined Over Handling of Human Remains
text: WASHINGTON — Three senior officials at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware, sacred ground for the military and the main entry point for the nation’s war dead, knew they had lost body parts of two service members killed in Afghanistan but did nothing to correct sloppy practices at the base mortuary, the Air Force said Tuesday.

headline: Shirley Bassey | A Fan’s Notes
text: Shirley Bassey, the 74-year-old Welsh pop singer beloved and berated for her brassy excess, rose to fame on the success of “Goldfinger,” the theme song to the 1964 James Bond film of the same name. A tabloid-ready love life and a closetful of fishtail bumster frocks, paved with kilos of caviar beads, have also done their part.

headline: Gloves Are No Guarantee Your Doctor’s Hands Are Clean

headline: Hey, Officer! What Do You Mean I’m a Skylarker?
