headline: TimesCast | November 8, 2011
text: The longtime football coach Joe Paterno is expected to step down; A key ally of Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi asks him to resign; and Herman Cain confronts sexual harassment allegations.

headline: Greek Squabbles Delay Selection of New Leader
text: ATHENS — Lucas Papademos, a respected economist, seemed on the verge Tuesday night of being named Greece’s next prime minister, Greek news outlets reported, but party leaders were still engaged in a bitter and drawn-out fight over the makeup of his cabinet.

headline: Ghost Hunters Captured Oklahoma Earthquake on Video
text: There was a bump in the night. And then another, and another. The ghost hunters have it all on tape.

headline: No Such Place as ‘Post-Racial’ America
text: Dear America,

headline: I Do Not Think That Word Means What Politico Thinks It Means
text: In case anyone thought that my post about widespread misunderstanding of the meaning of the word “hypocrisy” was arguing with a straw man, now comes Politico, telling us — without a hint that there might be some misunderstanding here — that Elizabeth Warren may not be credible in her campaign against economic injustice because she’s personally affluent.

headline: U.N. Agency Says Iran Data Points to A-Bomb Work
text: United Nations weapons inspectors have amassed a trove of new evidence that they say makes a “credible” case that “Iran has carried out activities relevant to the development of a nuclear device,” and that the project may still be under way.

headline: Pairings: Black-Bean Cakes With Smoked Salmon
text: Thanksgiving generously welcomes white, red or sparkling. But no matter what direction the drinks take, the host must also provide some food as guests arrive and mingle. Something small, a tidbit in a modest quantity, is the goal, not an appetite assassin. Bowls of nuts, olives and even popcorn would be fine.

headline: Wines for Thanksgiving Dinner
text: THE Thanksgiving wine panel, in which the home team gathers for a preliminary holiday feast, is one of our traditions here at the Dining section. We test specific bottles with representative dishes, and, even more important, we reassess the coherence of our assumptions about which wines to serve with the bird.

headline: A Fracking Method With Fewer Water Woes?
text: Here’s a quick review of developments related to the fast-expanding extraction of natural gas using hydraulic fracturing, otherwise known as fracking, that point to a route forward amid concerns about everything from earthquakes to water pollution.

headline: Cain Campaign Goes After Accuser’s Credibility
text: Herman Cain’s campaign began an outright assault on the credibility of his latest accuser on Tuesday, saying in an e-mail to supporters that Sharon Bialek had a “long and troubled” financial history that should undermine her allegations against him.

headline: Political Ad Spending Spurs Local TV Mergers
text: A period of consolidation is under way in local television — and with it, a renewed debate about the implications of merger and acquisition activity on the industry.

headline: A Silly World of Little Outrage and No Consequences
text: So much for golf’s silly season. The period from Halloween to New Year’s Day used to be when the sport switched into sleep mode. This regenerative time, when games were repaired and rebuilt, has gradually given way to a global dash for cash that would make Phileas Fogg proud.

headline: How J. Hilburn Managed to Expand Online
text: Last week, we profiled a dilemma facing J. Hilburn, a Dallas clothing company that uses direct sales and multilevel marketing to sell custom shirts and other menswear. Founded in 2007 by Hil Davis and Veeral Rathod, two Dallas financial industry workers, the company’s sales rose from $1 million in 2008 to $3.25 million in 2009 and $8 million in 2010, a year in which it sold 60,000 shirts (starting at $89).

headline: Little, Brown Pulls Novel, Citing Plagiarism
text: 4:30 p.m. | Updated Little, Brown & Company has pulled a mystery novel from the shelves after passages in the book were found to have been plagiarized from “a variety of classic and contemporary spy novels,” the publisher said on Tuesday. The book, “Assassin of Secrets,” a debut novel by Q. R. Markham, was released last week by Mulholland Books, an imprint of Little, Brown.

headline: Yelp Hires Goldman and Citigroup to Lead I.P.O.
text: Yelp, the online reviews site for local businesses, has hired Goldman Sachs and Citigroup to lead its initial public offering of stock, according to several people briefed on the situation.

headline: Vucciria Will Bring Puglian Food to the Film Center Cafe Space
text: What had been the Film Center Cafe in Hell’s Kitchen will become Vucciria, an Italian restaurant to open in December. Though it is taking its name from the main food market in Palermo, Sicily, the food will be from Puglia and Sardinia, the specialties of the chef, Giovanni Tenace, who is Puglian. The menu is likely to include burnt wheat pasta with blood sausage and broccoli rabe, chestnut fettuccine with porcini and black truffle sauce, Adriatic fish soup with langoustines, razor clams and mackerel, and braised veal cheeks.

headline: Beer Authority Primes Its Taps Across From the Port Authority
text: Beer Authority, a sprawling restaurant and bar set to open in a few weeks, gets its name from its neighbor across West 40th Street, the Port Authority bus terminal.

headline: Sadie’s Kitchen, ’30s-Style Comfort in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn
text: The macaroni and cheese that will be the signature at Sadie’s Kitchen, a 1930s-style retro cafe and prepared-food shop that opens in Brooklyn on Monday, comes from Sadie Smith.

headline: Thanksgiving Countdown | You’re Going to Need Wine With That Dinner
text: It’s time to consider a crucial part of the Thanksgiving feast. Should the wine on the table be light, agile and versatile? Or should it be heavy, big and over-the-top? Eric Asimov, Florence Fabricant, Julia Moskin, Pete Wells and Bernie Kirsch, The Times’s tasting coordinator, each brought a red and a white — costing no more than $25 apiece — to the annual pre-holiday tasting. Their suggestions, and some lively debate, are here.

headline: A Reservation With Reservations
text: When Saddam Hussein fell from power following America’s 2003 invasion of Iraq, widespread looting of his palaces scattered valuables of every ilk to the far corners of Iraq and of the world. Among the most plentiful and otherwise banal were also among the most symbolic: Hussein’s plates, upon which the autocrat and his cohorts supped well at the expense of the citizenry. Through Nov. 26, New Yorkers can dine on some of those plates, through the latest collaboration between Creative Time, a Manhattan-based nonprofit arts group, and Park Avenue Autumn restaurant, at 63rd Street and Park Avenue.

headline: Whose Woods These Are I Think You’ll Know
text: You might not arrive at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx knowing who underwrote the lovely restoration of its venerable 50-acre forest along the banks of the Bronx River. But you won’t leave ignorant.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 8
text: The day in sports included land-mine victims playing soccer and more flies than birdies during preparations for the Australian Open golf tournament in Sydney.

headline: Q. and A. | Times Reporters Answer Student Questions
text: Several weeks ago, in honor of the National Day on Writing, we asked seven Times reporters from a variety of beats to answer questions about what they write, how and why.

headline: Head Start Is Given New Rules for Grants
text: YEADON, Pa. — President Obama visited a schoolhouse in this suburb of Philadelphia on Tuesday to announce stricter financing standards for the government’s Head Start program, which offers preschool training for children from low-income families.

headline: Paterno’s Tenure Coming to an End
text: November 8, 2011 — Penn State’s head football coach Joe Paterno is expected to step down at some point this season.

headline: On the Bright Side of Heritage
text: STOP me if you’ve heard this one before: Williamsburg, heritage, durables, outdoorsy, Americana, elbow patches, tie-dye, artisan. Men’s fashion — the nontailored sort — has become reducible in recent years, almost to the point of parody.

headline: In N.B.A. Proposal, an Option Worth Considering
text: Player representatives from all 30 N.B.A. teams will meet in New York Tuesday to consider each of the possible ways to navigate David Stern’s Wednesday deadline to accept a deal. They should have a full docket; there is a long list of issues pertaining to the N.B.A.’s current offer, its “reset” proposal, and the growing possibility of union decertification that will need to be addressed, all while tension continues to build and emotions run high.

headline: Five Workers Injured in Brighton Beach Building Collapse
text: For the final version of the article that appeared in the newspaper, click here.

headline: ‘Transformers’ Director Michael Bay Produces Trailer for Need for Speed: The Run
text: Michael Bay, the director of the “Transformers” franchise of films, has made high-adrenaline action sequences his trademark. It shouldn’t surprise, then, that EA Games would ask Mr. Bay to direct the trailer for its new racing-simulator title, Need for Speed: The Run, which is being released on Nov. 15.

headline: My Three Favorite Reasons to End It
text: Before anyone out there begins to worry: a little back story. I was tooling around the Web site of the Dalkey Archive Press, a great, tiny nonprofit press, and found the new issue of their literary review, “Context.” One of the articles has the too-good-not-to-click-on-it title “100 Good Reasons to Kill Myself Right Now.”

headline: Signature Postpones New Albee Play
text: The Signature Theater Company has indefinitely postponed its world-premiere production of Edward Albee’s play “Laying an Egg,” which was to have been a part of its inaugural season at its new Midtown space. Replacing it will be a revival of Mr. Albee’s play “The Lady From Dubuque,” starring Jane Alexander and directed by David Esbjornson, who was to direct “Laying an Egg” and who directed Mr. Albee’s “The Goat, or Who is Sylvia” on Broadway in 2002. “Lady From Dubuque” had a very brief Broadway run in 1980.

headline: Einhorn Playing G.M. Long and Green Mountain Short
text: David Einhorn is nothing if not a contrarian. He called out Lehman Brothers for its accounting, has taken Microsoft‘s chief executive to task and bet against the most darling stock this year, Green Mountain Coffee Roasters.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Liberia, Italy, Brazil, Russia, India and South Korea.

headline: Draw for Concacaf Champions League Quarterfinals
text: Concacaf, soccer’s regional governing body for North and Central America and the Caribbean, held the draw for the quarterfinals (which begin in early March) of the Champions League Tuesday at its offices in Trump Tower in Manhattan.

headline: Boston, Free and Easy (and Campus-Oriented)
text: “Joyce, this cookie is as big as your face,” one M.I.T. business student said to another, as they pounced on the oversize chocolate chip and oatmeal raisin treats left over from a lunchtime lecture on the Chinese economy.

headline: Many Employers Have Restored Suspended 401(k) Matches, Analysis Finds
text: An analysis of 260 employers that suspended their 401(k) matching contributions in the depths of the recession has found that most have restored them, although some now offer a lower level of benefits.

headline: A Board Complicit in MF Global’s Bets, and Its Demise
text: The easy explanation for MF Global’s downfall is that it was killed by Jon S. Corzine’s risky trading bets. Yet MF Global was torpedoed not only by Mr. Corzine but by its board.

headline: Holder Urges Lawmakers to Support Efforts to Stop Gun Trafficking
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Tuesday sought to move past the political furor over Operation Fast and Furious, the disputed Arizona gun trafficking investigation, to the wider problem of the flow of American firearms to Mexican drug cartels — and what he portrayed as roadblocks members of Congress have thrown up to stemming that flow.

headline: Michigan State’s Aircraft Carrier Adventure
text: Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo loves to challenge his basketball team during the nonconference season, and he’s come up with a doozy to kick off this season on Friday: playing No. 1 North Carolina on an aircraft carrier docked in the Naval harbor in San Diego, in a game called the Carrier Classic. President Obama is scheduled to attend, along with many active duty military in celebration of Veterans Day.

headline: Networks Rebound From Scary Halloween
text: ABC was the most-watched network Monday night, and CBS claimed the top spot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic as ratings for almost the entire network programming slate improved from last week’s poor Halloween performance. A two-hour edition of “Dancing With the Stars” on ABC averaged just over 18 million total viewers, by far the largest audience on the night. Meanwhile, “Two and a Half Men” on CBS has leveled out nicely at 14.5 million viewers while remaining the highest-rated Monday program in the 18-to-49 demo.

headline: Mission Accomplishment: Exploring Veterans’ Challenges and Achievements
text: Overview | What veterans return home from war, what challenges and opportunities await them? How are some veterans finding meaning in their post-service lives? In this lesson, students examine some of the struggles that veterans face when they return home and then create displays that honor veterans and details the ways that veterans are making a difference in their communities.

headline: Butz and Reaser to Star in ‘How I Learned to Drive’
text: Norbert Leo Butz (“Catch Me if You Can”) and Elizabeth Reaser (“Twilight”) will co-star in Second Stage’s production of Paula Vogel’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play “How I Learned to Drive,” the theater announced Tuesday. Directing duties will go to Kate Whoriskey, the former artistic director of Seattle’s Intiman Theater, which laid off its entire staff and closed its doors in April. (In August the theater took a step toward reopening when it hired a consulting artistic director.) The show is to begin previews on Jan. 24, 2012, with opening night set for Feb. 13.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Good Wife'
text: The CBS drama, starring Julianna Margulies, has lost viewers since moving to Sundays.

headline: Julie Taymor Sues ‘Spider-Man’ Team Over Royalties
text: The director Julie Taymor, a key creator of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” sued the producers of that $75 million show in federal court on Tuesday, claiming that they were profiting from her creative contributions without compensating her. The lawsuit seeks at least $1 million from the producers, as well as future royalty payments.

headline: Finding the Humanity in the F.B.I.’s Feared Enforcer
text: Even with all the surprises that have characterized Clint Eastwood’s twilight film years, with their crepuscular tales of good and evil, the tenderness of the love story in “J. Edgar” comes as a shock. Anchored by a forceful, vulnerable Leonardo DiCaprio, who lays bare J. Edgar Hoover’s humanity, despite the odds and an impasto of old-coot movie makeup, this latest jolt from Mr. Eastwood is a look back at a man divided and of the ties that bind private bodies with public politics and policies. With sympathy — for the individual, not his deeds — it portrays a 20th-century titan who, with secrets and bullets, a will to power and the self-promotional skills of a true star, built a citadel of information in which he burrowed deep.

headline: Photo Ops
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Iowa Might Matter in ’12 After All
text: So how much does Iowa matter? In recent Republican nominating contests, the state’s caucuses have hardly mattered at all. Republican nominations have tended to be predictable, with the party throwing its support behind a candidate early in the process.

headline: Romney Says Allegations Against Cain Are ‘Serious’
text: Mitt Romney addressed the accusations of sexual harassment surrounding his Republican rival Herman Cain for the first time Tuesday, calling them “particularly disturbing” and “serious” in an ABC News and Yahoo interview with George Stephanopoulos.

headline: Wheelies: The Facelift Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Making the Case for Minnie Minoso
text: It turns out that Minnie Minoso, the former Chicago White Sox star, is being remembered for the wrong decades — and it just might keep him from achieving baseball’s greatest individual honor.

headline: 20111108_FERRATO
text: 20111108_FERRATO

headline: One Bank Dominates Headlines (Take a Wild Guess)
text: A single investment bank received 15.9 percent of all Wall Street media mentions in the first 10 months of 2011, according to a new study by HighBeam Research, a firm that monitors the media. Last year, the same bank received 17 percent in the same study. The bank also dominated headlines in 2009, picking up 15 percent of all mentions of major Wall Street firms.

headline: Should You Worry About a Chubby Baby?
text: Should you, would you, put a baby on a diet and exercise program? Harvard obesity researchers have found that unusually rapid growth in infants doubles the risk that a plump, adorable baby will become an obese child. The author of the study, Dr. Elsie Taveras, says that such rapid growth should alert doctors to the possibility that babies “might be overfed or spending too much time in strollers and not crawling around.”

headline: Trailer: Uncharted 3
text: The action sequel game is for the Sony Playstation 3.

headline: Study Debunks Operation to Prevent Strokes
text: An operation that doctors hoped would prevent strokes in people with poor circulation to the brain does not work, researchers are reporting. A $20 million study, paid for by the government, was cut short when it became apparent that the surgery was not helping patients who had complete blockages in one of their two carotid arteries, which run up either side of the neck and feed 80 percent of the brain.

headline: Students Press Congress to Sustain Investment in Science
text: 5:23 p.m. | Updated A group of graduate students has posted a letter and video message to Congress aimed at sustaining federal investment in basic science in an era of cost-cutting and political paralysis and polarization. They are looking for other graduate students to sign on. The letter is at standwithscience.org. Here’s their YouTube callout:

headline: Cain Rejects Latest Allegations
text: November 8, 2011 — Republican Presidential candidate Herman Cain more forcefully confronts the sexual harassment allegations that have roiled his campaign for over a week.

headline: Video: Crosby and Nash at Zuccotti Park
text: Graham Nash and David Crosby lead the Zuccotti Park occupants in a chant of “No More War.”

headline: 200 Years Later, France Claims a Missing Artwork
text: PARIS – A painting that vanished without explanation from a museum in southwestern France nearly 200 years ago is expected to return shortly to French hands after officials informed the owner of the work, currently on display in Paris, that he is not, to his surprise, the owner.

headline: The Gun Lobby and Military Suicides
text: Of all of the lobbying organizations that feed off fear, and rely for their funding and power on dividing Americans, one of the worst is the National Rifle Association.

headline: A Vintage Trove in South Beach
text: Patti Stoecker is a hoarder, the rarefied kind. In the 1980s, Ms. Stoecker, then a model, used to party all night at the Mudd Club, wearing, as often as not, one of her mother’s silky old slips. By the early ’90s, she had begun collecting her own ’40s-era variations, amassing them by the score and tie-dyeing them on her stove top in Easter-egg hues. For a time she consigned her slinky designs to local secondhand shops, but before long she was selling them from her house, against a dreamy backdrop of mottled peach-tone walls.

headline: Beep Beep
text: Ryan Avent shocks me:

headline: A Second Accuser Goes Public Against Cain
text: Karen Kraushaar, one of the two women who settled sexual harassment claims against Herman Cain with the National Restaurant Association, spoke publicly for the first time on Tuesday about her allegations against him.

headline: Japanese Company Develops Robot Guide Dog
text: Guide dogs for the blind could soon be out of a job.

headline: To Stop Iran, Lean On China
text: Washington

headline: Mad About Bike Lanes. In Both Senses of the Word.
text: Boy, there’s a load of free-floating anger out there. So many of the readers who commented on my ArtsBeat post and critic’s notebook praising New York City’s new bike lanes pointed fingers – at bikers, pedestrians, drivers or politicians. (And yes, I promise, AJ Michel, to work hard to keep my journalistic distance from city officials and everyone else I cover. I appreciate your vigilance.)

headline: Look of the Moment | Florence Welch
text: The Look: Golden. A décolleté lace mermaid dress with long sleeves and a Victorian collar is completely enchanting.

headline: Would a Swiss Bank Mash-Up Work?
text: Everyone knows two wrongs don’t make a right, but one banking analyst, Kian Abouhossein of JPMorgan Chase, thinks that two less-than-perfect investment banks could make a compelling whole.

headline: Document: Taymor’s ‘Spider-Man’ Lawsuit
text: Julie Taymor, a creator of the $75 million Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” has filed suit against the show’s producers over unpaid fees. Here is the lawsuit Ms. Taymor’s lawyer filed. The full news story about the lawsuit is here.

headline: Sex Education: Don't Fear It, Use It
text: What do you think of the new sex education mandate for middle and high school students? The chief executive of Planned Parenthood argues that formal sex education can be an opportunity for parents to talk with their children and share their beliefs and values.

headline: Well-Bred, and Flailing on the Rocks
text: The playwright A. R. Gurney has proved a steadfast cartographer of shrinking territory: upper-class white Anglo-Saxon Protestantism in decline. In works like “The Dining Room,” “The Cocktail Hour” and “Ancestral Voices,” he has examined that culture’s customs, analyzed its adherents, assessed its challenges. You can debate whether WASPdom is truly dying, but if so, Mr. Gurney has spent his career taking measurements for the coffin.

headline: Top Seeds in Women’s Soccer: Duke, Stanford, Florida State, Wake Forest
text: Duke, Florida State and Wake Forest — all of the A.C.C. — are three of the four top seeds in the N.C.A.A. women’s soccer championship tournament. Stanford of the Pac-12 is the other No. 1 seed.

headline: Scene City: Glamour’s Women of the Year
text: Jennifer Lopez, Laura Bush, Tory Burch and others are honored at Carnegie Hall.

headline: A Bird, a Plane, an Upside-Down Rhinoceros
text: If you do nothing else today, please look at these remarkable photos of the airlifting of a black rhino, part of a conservation program for endangered species.

headline: Close Encounters of the Rocky Kind
text: 7:55 p.m. | Updated |Tonight is a good time to track NASA’s @asteroidwatch Twitter account, which I’ve held out as a great example of how social media can help agencies, or individuals, track misinformation and spread solid information on important subjects.

headline: Qaddafi’s Ex-Prime Minister Ordered Extradited to Libya
text: A Tunisian appeals court on Tuesday approved the extradition of Libya’s former prime minister, making him the first escaped member of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s felled government to be ordered returned home into Libyan custody since the revolution that officially ended last month.

headline: The New Generation of Cooking Apps
text: A look at the Baking With Dorie and Professional Chef cooking apps.

headline: Israeli Minister Stresses Military Readiness
text: JERUSALEM — With rising tensions over Iran’s nuclear program fanning Iranian fury toward Israel, Ehud Barak, the Israeli minister of defense, said that if the country was forced into a war, the casualties on the home front would not likely amount to more than 500, if that many, and that the state of Israel would not be destroyed.

headline: At Zuccotti Park, a Sound of the ’60s
text: Jenna Mandaglio swayed gently to the music, waving a hand-crafted sunflower in her right hand.

headline: (Very) Young Voice, Filling an August Hall
text: Attention, fans of fairy tales: This is the story of how Jackie Evancho, 11, came to perform before a mostly full Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night, for a crowd whose average age was somewhere in the area of grandparent, sprinkled with a few dozen wide-eyed young girls in Sunday dresses.

headline: Democrats Criticize Romney for Opposing Auto Bailout
text: When Mitt Romney arrives in Michigan for the latest Republican debate on Wednesday, the Democrats will have a message waiting for him — “Hit the road, Mitt.”

headline: Tribute to the Man of ‘Mame’ and ‘Dolly’
text: Broadway musical aficionados — a quarrelsome breed — could argue until the cows come home about which larger-than-life diva is the ultimate Jerry Herman Girl. The word “girl,” of course, doesn’t begin to do justice to the ageless, fun-loving matriarchs who inspired shows like “Hello Dolly!” and “Mame.” These women are such irrepressible life forces that the world gravitates around them like planets orbiting the Sun.

headline: Crosby & Nash Occupy Wall Street
text: David Crosby and Graham Nash played an acoustic set at the site of the Occupy Wall Street protests that included “Teach Your Children Well.”

headline: Closing With Surprises and Some Stumbles
text: When the tap dancer Maurice Chestnut and his jazz-funk band quickly kicked into a groove on Sunday at the opening of the final program of this year’s Fall for Dance Festival at City Center, the show was immediately on the right foot.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Liberia, Italy, Brazil and Russia.

headline: Somebody’s Lying
text: Herman Cain just went all in.

headline: Creating a Pantheon of Beloved Underdogs
text: Jonathan Lethem’s fat, hip and garrulous new essay collection, “The Ecstasy of Influence,” is self-consciously in the tradition of books like Norman Mailer’s “Advertisements for Myself” and John Updike’s “Hugging the Shore,” brilliant grab-bag volumes that blended criticism, journalism and introspection. So it makes a kind of sense that Mr. Lethem debated, he tells us, calling this book either “Advertisements for Norman Mailer” or, even better, “Shugging the Whore.”

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 53
text: A bomb scare near Zuccotti Park on Tuesday morning turned out to be a false alarm. [City Room]

headline: Bob Costas Will Host Show on NBC Sports Network
text: The NBC Sports Group’s overhaul of the Versus network will continue next year with Bob Costas hosting a monthly interview show and quarterly town hall meetings similar to the ones he held during the years worked at HBO Sports.

headline: ‘Perfect Lives,’ Reinterpreted
text: Varispeed’s one-day production of Robert Ashley’s video opera.

headline: A Fresh Stamp on a Veteran Composer’s Work
text: For any composer who also serves as his or her own primary interpreter, the question of legacy eventually arises. What happens when an artist is no longer able or available to perform?

headline: Music to the Ears of the City Reeling From 9/11
text: Shot in the tense autumn of 2001 and only recently completed, “The Love We Make” is one of the most chipper responses to tragedy you are ever likely to experience. While the 10th anniversary of Sept. 11 played out on a television schedule crammed with heart-wrenching memorials and remember whens, a couple of cable networks began showing this cheery ride-along with Paul McCartney and friends as they prepared for the Concert for New York City.

headline: Study Clarifies the Energy Savings in Retrofitted Buildings
text: While the practice of retrofitting buildings with energy-conserving technology like efficient boilers, high-quality windows and compact fluorescent light bulbs has been around for years, data on whether these changes result in any real savings has been virtually nonexistent. Now, a new study shows that these relatively straightforward fixes can significantly reduce spending on fuel and electricity.

headline: Reviewing Rouge et Blanc
text: You don’t hear much about fusion cuisine anymore. For that, we can largely be grateful. You can understand the excitement, back in the 1980s, as chefs trained in the European traditions discovered the wonders of the various Asian cuisines. How could they restrain themselves from trying to fuse east and west into dazzling dishes highlighting cultural contrasts?

headline: From Britain, the Sounds of a Century
text: Tenebrae, a 17-voice British choir founded 10 years ago by Nigel Short, a former member of the King’s Singers, is best known to American listeners through its recordings: about a dozen of its own (on the Signum Classics label) and a few notable collaborations with Colin Davis and the London Symphony Orchestra (on LSO Live).

headline: How to Speak French-Vietnamese
text: PART joy, part conundrum, Rouge et Blanc defies expectations.

headline: App Smart Extra: Word Games
text: In last week’s App Smart column, I let the experts lead me toward a handful of great mobile games that I had somehow overlooked in recent years.

headline: Health Law Survives Test in Court of Appeals
text: A federal appeals court in Washington upheld the Obama administration’s health care law on Tuesday in a decision written by a prominent conservative jurist.

headline: Week 9 Film Review: Palmer vs. Tebow
text: A closer look at Week 9, with the benefit of film analysis:

headline: In a Queens Enclave, Often Shopping in Vain
text: When Nick Bate and his wife decided they wanted to rent an affordable apartment with a third bedroom, they looked across the East River from their Manhattan home to Hunters Point in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Pairing Bartok With Haydn
text: Turnover among musicians in longstanding ensembles is inevitable. Some, like the Guarneri String Quartet, simply disband. The esteemed Tokyo String Quartet — founded at the Juilliard School in 1969 by four Japanese musicians who studied together in Tokyo — will soon have none of its original members. The violist, Kazuhide Isomura, a founding member, and the second violinist, Kikuei Ikeda, who joined in 1974, recently announced that they would retire from the quartet in June 2013.

headline: Rajaratnam Ordered to Pay $92.8 Million Penalty
text: A federal judge on Tuesday ordered the convicted hedge fund titan Raj Rajaratnam to pay a $92.8 million penalty, the largest ever assessed against a person in a Securities and Exchange Commission insider trading case.

headline: The Hardening of Easy Dave
text: David Stern was not always fully sold on going the distance as the entrepreneurial shepherd of professional basketball, as the commissioner of the N.B.A.

headline: All Together, ‘Brava!’
text: AMONG the women who were honored at Glamour’s annual Women of the Year awards on Monday night, Jennifer Lopez made the most memorable entrance, twice.

headline: Facebook Says It Provides a Big Boost to Digital-Music Sites
text: How much have the new features that Facebook introduced in September helped digital-music services like Spotify, MOG and Slacker? According to Facebook, quite a bit. But some of those companies are still waiting for the new features to take effect.

headline: A Glimpse Into North Korea
text: The Associated Press photographer David Guttenfelder takes a rare look at the lives of North Koreans.

headline: N.B.A. Union Signals a Shift That May End the Lockout
text: The path to an N.B.A. labor deal, and the end to a 131-day lockout, came into sharper focus Tuesday, with the players signaling for the first time that they would accept the league’s proposed 50-50 split of revenues.

headline: Baking With Dorie: Bundt Cake Icing
text: In a video from her new app, the baking expert Dorie Greenspan makes icing for a bundt cake.

headline: The Professional Chef: Fresh Pasta
text: A video on how to make fresh pasta from the Professional Chef app.

headline: Regulators Say Social Network Violated Child Privacy Law
text: Skid-e-Kids describes itself as a Facebook for children ages 7 to 14. It allows them to watch “age-appropriate” movies and socialize with their friends, and it stipulates that “parents are in charge.”

headline: People Who Mistook Life for a Museum, and Vice Versa
text: The Performa biennial, now in full outrageously outsize swing across the city, is known for its big events: parties and premieres that, as is usually the case in the arts, have far more flash than substance.

headline: The ‘Serious Eats’ Book, Stuffed to the Cover
text: It’s hard to know which is more astonishing, the amount of food stuffed into the 368 pages of “Serious Eats” by Ed Levine and the editors of Serious Eats (Clarkson Potter, $27.99 paperback), or its comprehensive coverage. It digs with gusto into what’s mostly everyday fare across the country, deconstructing breakfast with sections on eggs, pancakes, breakfast sandwiches and the like, then moving on to burgers, pizza, sandwiches and hot dogs, barbecue, fried things, street food (carts and trucks) and baked goods. Venerable spots like Neptune Oyster bar in Boston and Faicco’s Pork Store in New York share the pages with newer places, including Delancey, a pizzeria in Seattle. You’ll find hash-slingers and locavore chefs, a White Castle burger as well as the finesse of breakfast at Boulettes Larder in San Francisco. Guides to styles of burgers, pizzas, hot dogs, lobster rolls and the like, and how to conquer some of these delicacies at home are included. I plan to tear out the essential seven-page directory of places listed in the book, and make several photocopies, to keep in the car and with my travel stuff.

headline: A Spice Infuser for Simmering
text: This high-tech replacement for a length of cheesecloth can enclose herbs and whole spices to season a pot of stock, soup, stew, fruit simmering in wine or even holiday glogg. The perforated stainless steel orb, about the size of a tennis ball, has an opening for its snap-on top, a jaunty silicone cap sporting a tiny pom-pom so it can actually hang over the edge of the pan. It can withstand temperatures up to 240 degrees, well above boiling. And thinking ahead, is there a better stocking stuffer for a cook?

headline: The Patriots Waive Haynesworth, Once a Defensive Star
text: It sounded like an experiment from an alternate football universe from the moment it happened late this summer: Albert Haynesworth, whose career has been marked by flashes of pass-rushing brilliance interrupting long stretches of uninterest and minimal effort, traded to the New England Patriots?

headline: The New Generation of Cooking Apps
text: A look at the Baking With Dorie and Professional Chef cooking apps.

headline: Are Cookbooks Obsolete?
text: FOR many cooks, the pleasure of Thanksgiving is in the planning. In early November, the recipe folders come out, along with dreams of learning to perfect a lattice pie crust, and the cookbooks covered with splatters and sticky notes that evoke holidays past.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,475 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,815 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: City Plans to Move a School and Start a New One in East New York
text: The city's Education Department is planning to open two secondary schools next September in East New York, Brooklyn, one of the poorest and lowest performing neighborhoods in the city.

headline: Hurricanes’ Staal Reflects on Check That Injured Brother
text: NEWARK — Eric Staal, the Carolina Hurricanes’ captain and a winner of the Stanley Cup and an Olympic gold medal, is off to the worst start of his career, and one of the worst starts endured by any N.H.L. player this season. But he is sure that guilt is not behind it.

headline: Media Decoder: Facebook’s Boost to Digital-Music Sites
text: How much have the new features that Facebook introduced in September helped digital-music services like Spotify, MOG and Slacker? According to Facebook, quite a bit. But some of those companies are still waiting for the new features to take effect. Read more…

headline: Index Ventures Raises $700 Million Growth Fund
text: The venture capital firm Index Ventures has raised 500 million euros ($692 million) for a new fund that will focus on later-stage investments.

headline: For Better Stuffing and Pie, Get Cracking
text: AFTER my uncle Sheldon moved to Dallas, he returned to Brooklyn for a visit flaunting a bolo tie, a splashy pair of cowboy boots and a nascent drawl.

headline: To Raise Cash, Restaurants Turn to the Crowd
text: AARON LEFKOVE was struggling to raise close to $200,000 to open a New England-style clam shack in a Gowanus, Brooklyn, storefront.

headline: Red Bulls: The View From the Back Line
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J. — Tim Ream could be a poster boy for the Red Bulls’ season gone awry.

headline: Getting the Crowd on Board the Flight, and Off
text: To the Editor:

headline: Heavy D, Smooth-Talking Hip-Hop Star, Dies at 44
text: Heavy D, the smooth-talking and cheerful rapper who billed himself as “the overweight lover M.C.,” died in Los Angeles on Tuesday. He was 44.

headline: On War and Redemption
text: When I returned from Afghanistan this past spring, a civilian friend asked, “Is it good to be back?” It was the first time someone had asked, and I answered honestly. But I won’t do that again. We weren’t ready for that conversation.  Instead, when people ask, I make it easy for everyone by responding, “It’s fine.” That’s a lie, though. It’s not fine.

headline: Q&A: YouTube’s Rules for Video
text: Q.

headline: In Videos, Glimpses of a Besieged Syrian City
text: Updated | Wednesday | 12:36 p.m. | As my colleague Nada Bakri reports, Syrian activists said, “After six days of near-continuous bombing, the army and security forces sought Tuesday to tighten their grip on parts of Homs, in central Syria near the Lebanese border.”

headline: Court Casts a Wary Eye on Tracking by GPS
text: WASHINGTON — In an argument studded with references to George Orwell’s “1984” and the possibility that rapid advances in technology would soon allow the government to monitor everyone’s movements, the Supreme Court on Tuesday struggled to articulate how the Fourth Amendment’s ban on unreasonable searches and seizures should apply to the tracking of cars using GPS devices. The fit between 18th-century principles and 21st-century surveillance seemed to leave several justices frustrated.

headline: Haiti: Group Seeks $250 Million From U.N. Over Cholera Epidemic
text: A human rights group filed claims on Tuesday seeking at least $250 million in damages from the United Nations and its peacekeeping force in Haiti on behalf of 5,000 cholera victims. The group, the Institute for Justice and Democracy in Haiti, accuses the peacekeeping force, known as Minustah, of inadequate troop screening and improper sanitation that, the group said, had caused Haiti’s cholera epidemic. More than 6,600 people have died and nearly a half-million more have been sickened since the cholera outbreak began in October 2010. The group also seeks establishment of a forum to hear its claims, which were filed with Minustah’s claims office in Port-au-Prince. United Nations peacekeeping missions generally have immunity from actions in national courts. A spokesman for the United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations said the agency would have no comment until it had studied the claim.

headline: Questions About the Safety of Fracking
text: To the Editor:

headline: Amid Anger Over Idea of Charging Tuition, an Inquiry Is Urged on Cooper Union’s Finances
text: As Cooper Union officials try to quell the uproar over news that the college may start to charge tuition, some students, alumni, faculty members and college trustees are advocating an inquiry into how the school got into such serious financial trouble.

headline: Venezuela: Chávez to Hold ‘Cancer Summit’ for Latin Leaders
text: President Hugo Chávez said he would host a “cancer summit” meeting in early 2012 for South American leaders who, like himself, have been treated for the disease. Mr. Chávez, left, who said he had surgery in June to remove a malignant tumor, said he would invite President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil; her predecessor, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who began treatment for throat cancer late last month; and President Fernando Lugo of Paraguay. “There will be no cancer or force that can hold us back because Latin America is experiencing a rebirth,” Mr. Chávez told Venezuelan state television on Sunday. He said would wait to hold the summit meeting until after Mr. da Silva completed his chemotherapy. After several rounds of chemotherapy, mostly in Cuba, Mr. Chávez, 57, said last month that he was cancer-free. Ms. Rousseff, 63, received a diagnosis of lymphatic cancer in 2009 before her election, and doctors have said she is currently free of cancer. Mr. Lugo, 60, who was found to have lymphatic cancer in August 2010, has undergone treatment in Brazil and has also been declared cancer-free.

headline: In Defense of Corzine: A Former Aide Speaks Out
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cooper Union’s Finances
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bloggingheads: “Occupy” and Violence
text: Adam Serwer, left, of Mother Jones and Katherine Mangu-Ward of Reason debate about violent protesters and the Occupy movement.

headline: Clinton Aims for ‘AIDS-Free Generation’
text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday called on the United States and other countries to use new scientific discoveries to create an “AIDS-free generation” in the world, but offered no clues about where the money would come from to finance that inspirational and costly vision.

headline: Jury Begins Weighing a Legislator’s Fate
text: A federal jury in Manhattan ended its first afternoon of deliberations on Tuesday in the corruption trial of William F. Boyland Jr., a Democratic assemblyman from Brooklyn, by reporting in a note to the judge that it was at “an impasse.”
