text: Opening

headline: Questions on Sandusky Are Wrapped in a 2005 Mystery
text: One of the questions surrounding the sex-abuse case against Jerry Sandusky is why a former district attorney chose not to prosecute the then-Penn State assistant coach in 1998 after reports surfaced that he had inappropriate interactions with a boy.

headline: Birreria
text: 200 Fifth Avenue (23rd Street); (212) 937-8910; eatalyny.com/eat/birreria.

headline: A Multigenerational Home
text: A living arrangement that eases financial burdens in tough economic times.

headline: Three Generations, Two Comfy Homes a Few Steps Apart
text: ON a recent Sunday evening, Wanda Urbanska and her family gathered around the table to catch up over cabbage and potato pierogies. Her 89-year-old mother, a retired college professor, sat across from Henry, her 14-year-old grandson, whose blue T-shirt matched the swaths of color in his hair. He told the women about the rave he attended the night before, where he “jumped up and down for three hours.”

headline: Election Day, Nov. 8, 2011
text: Voters were to decide on contentious ballot measures in Ohio and Mississippi.

headline: Co-Producer for Oscar Telecast Resigns
text: LOS ANGELES — Brett Ratner on Tuesday abruptly resigned as the co-producer of next year’s Oscar broadcast, after he used an anti-gay slur at a public event and made frank sexual remarks on Howard Stern’s radio show.

headline: Bien Cuit
text: 120 Smith Street, Boerum Hill, Brooklyn; (718) 852-0200; biencuit.com.

headline: James Murdoch to Face More Questioning by Lawmakers
text: LONDON — James Murdoch may have embarrassing questions to answer when he returns to Westminster on Thursday to testify before a parliamentary committee investigating the phone hacking scandal that has engulfed the News Corporation. Documents released since his first round of testimony in July have cast doubt on his version of events, while fresh revelations have spilled out about his company’s questionable practices.

headline: A Dream of Homeownership, Still Beyond Reach
text: LIKE many young married people, Steve and Logan Kinney dream of owning a home. So after several years of diligent saving, the couple, both teachers, scoured the listings in Boerum Hill, the leafy Brooklyn neighborhood where they rented. But before long, they realized that home ownership would require living within the four walls of a studio. And even that was a stretch.

headline: Pandit Proposes Benchmark for Comparing Banks’ Risks
text: Walter B. Wriston, the vaunted former chairman of Citibank, famously said that risk was a four-letter word. Vikram S. Pandit, chief executive of the larger successor organization, Citigroup, reckons it has nine letters: benchmark.

headline: Report Undercuts Iran’s Defense on Nuclear Effort
text: WASHINGTON — Even as Iran on Tuesday angrily dismissed a new United Nations report on its nuclear ambitions as an American fabrication and a pretext for military action, some analysts said the report’s wealth of data could complicate efforts by Iran and its allies to defend the nuclear program as peaceful.

headline: They Walked Away, and They’re Glad They Did
text: JON WITTENBERG and Bill Sawyer have never met. One lives in Walnut Creek, Calif., the other in Wilsonville, Ore. But if they did, the conversation might be littered with exclamations like, “That’s exactly what happened to me!”

headline: Grand Experiment Meets an Inglorious End
text: So this is how the Grand Experiment — as Joe Paterno self-righteously called his campaign to prove that football excellence and academic integrity could coexist — ends: the most respected coach in the history of college football, maybe even all of college sports, is brought down by a sexual abuse scandal whose scope we are surely just starting to grasp. (Investigators have counted eight victims; there could well be dozens more.)

headline: Moving to U.S. and Amassing a Fortune, No English Needed
text: More than 40 years after arriving in New York from Mexico uneducated and broke, Felix Sanchez de la Vega Guzman still can barely speak English. Ask him a question, and he will respond with a few halting phrases and an apologetic smile before shifting back to the comfort of Spanish.

headline: Despite Critics, Mortgage Deduction Resists Change
text: IF you ask most people about the possibility of reducing or eliminating the tax deduction for interest on home mortgages, you will generally hear the same things that you would if you suggested altering Social Security benefits.

headline: Letting the Banks Off Easy
text: The banks want California, and the Obama administration hopes they can get it.

headline: Palestinian Bid for U.N. Membership Faces Near-Certain Defeat
text: The Palestinian bid to become a full member of the United Nations headed toward certain failure on Tuesday after the Security Council’s membership committee deadlocked on the issue, according to a draft report by the committee.

headline: The Secret Farm Bill
text: The Republican-manufactured budget crisis of this past summer — remember? — resulted in a “solution” that’s hijacking what little representative democratic process we have left. Equally sad is that the so-called supercommittee — charged with creating an outline for reducing the deficit by $1.2 trillion over 10 years — may preclude full discussion of the farm bill.

headline: Work Program for Foreign Students Will Not Expand During Review
text: The State Department will limit a popular cultural exchange program for foreign university students to its current size of about 100,000 students a year, a senior agency official said Tuesday.

headline: For Duquette, a Chance and a Challenge
text: We know from “Moneyball” that a major league general manager can be a compelling lead character for a film. So consider this script outline.

headline: Penn State’s Culpability
text: The sex-abuse scandal that has threatened the tenure of Pennsylvania State University’s legendary football coach, Joe Paterno, and led to criminal charges against two high-level administrators offers a tragic example of the willful blindness that sets in when colleges worship sports.

headline: How to Toast Nuts
text: In this week’s column, I write about finding the freshest nuts, which means, for the most part, buying them raw and toasting them yourself.

headline: Estimating Expenses Before Buying Your First Home
text: If you are like most people embarking on their search for a first home, you will do a certain amount of math. You will look at your current budget, size up your down payment and figure out what sort of monthly mortgage payment you may be able to afford.

headline: Cheerios Cheer Commercial
text: A promotion by Cheerios to bring “cheer” to military families and support the United Service Organizations is the subject of a commercial.

headline: Acknowledging the Veterans on Their Day in the Limelight
text: FOR Veterans Day 2011, Madison Avenue will seem redder, whiter and bluer than it has in a long time.

headline: After Long Ordeal, a Homeowner Can Stay Home
text: FOR two years, Althea Girard-Blakey toted a black canvas bag when she went to work, full of the enormous collection of papers documenting her request for a mortgage modification.

headline: Wealthy Buyers Fuel Market for Second Homes
text: FAIGIE RICHMAN used to tell everyone that she never wanted to live in Florida. She enjoyed visiting her husband’s family in Boca Raton, but the lifestyle simply did not suit her. She didn’t play golf or tennis and had no desire to learn either. And she and her husband already owned a second home, on a pond in Rhode Island, that their three children loved.

headline: Panel Emphasizes Safety in Digitization of Health Records
text: Poorly designed, hard-to-use computerized health records are a threat to patient safety, and an independent agency should be set up to investigate injuries and deaths linked to health information technology, according to a federal study released Tuesday.

headline: Paterno, the King of Pennsylvania, Until Now
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — It is hard to fully capture the stature and impact of Joe Paterno.

headline: How a Financial Pro Lost His House
text: ONE night a few years ago, when the value of our home had collapsed, our debt was out of control and my financial planning business was shaky, I went to take out the trash.

headline: Mom to N.B.A.: Play Ball!
text: I HAVE never followed basketball. Personally, I don’t really care what happens in these talks the owners and players are having. I will never turn on the TV to watch a game. I’m sure I wouldn’t even know what team was in the playoffs when that time came. I’m not the N.B.A.’s audience. No money to be made off of me. My interests lie elsewhere.

headline: Report on Nuclear Efforts Draws a Muted Response From the White House
text: WASHINGTON — When American intelligence agencies concluded four years ago that Iran had suspended efforts to build a nuclear weapon in 2003, the findings undercut the Bush administration’s arguments for harsher international sanctions or even, from its more hawkish quarters, military intervention.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Ticket-Fixing Scandal and a Charge That Needed Dropping
text: By any measure, the arrest of Samantha Zucker seemed absurd: a 21-year-old college student, she and a friend wandered into Riverside Park after it had closed for the night, and she wound up being charged with trespassing. Because she did not have identification with her, the police did not issue her a summons. Instead she was arrested and held for 36 hours.

headline: Syria and the Arab League
text: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has made a mockery of the Arab League peace initiative. Since he signed the document, his security forces have mercilessly attacked the city of Homs with heavy weapons, hunted down army defectors and killed scores of pro-democracy protesters. The United Nations says 3,500 protesters have been killed in the crackdown on the popular uprising.

headline: Bid to Alter Pension Plans Is Criticized
text: Two of New York City’s top labor leaders voiced anger on Tuesday about the agreement by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Comptroller John C. Liu to overhaul the city’s pension plans.

headline: Outsourcing Is Not (Always) Evil
text: On Friday, I wrote about two social enterprises ― Samasource and Digital Divide Data ― that extend computer-based employment to people with modest educations in developing countries. The strategy of harnessing the Internet to bring low-cost data management jobs to remote and impoverished communities has been called “impact sourcing.” Some estimate that the market for these services, $4.5 billion today, could rise to $20 billion by 2015, providing jobs to 780,000 people (pdf, p.14).

headline: 78s, Photos, Even Sweat From Brow of a Legend
text: Another fragment of Louis Armstrong’s legacy is back where it belongs.

headline: Shares Dive as Olympus Scrambles for Answers
text: From the board room to the trading floor, Olympus struggled on Tuesday to contain a crisis that erupted after its admission that it had used $1 billion in payments to cover up losses on investments.

headline: New From the Injured Rib of a Mastodon
text: Just when did humans first appear in North America? For years, scientists based that calculation on stone tools found in the 1930s near Clovis, N.M. They suggest, through radiocarbon dating, a culture that existed 13,000 years ago. But those weapons were too late to explain the hunting out of megafauna, like mastodons, near the end of the Pleistocene era. There was either a “Clovis blitzkrieg,” — a swift, cataclysmic killing by humans — or there were hunters living long before the Clovis tools were made.

headline: Justices Rebuke a New Orleans Prosecutor
text: WASHINGTON — Donna R. Andrieu, an assistant district attorney in New Orleans, had the unenviable task at the Supreme Court on Tuesday of defending her office’s conduct in withholding evidence from a criminal defendant. She made the least of it.

headline: A Long-Awaited Apology for Shiites, but the Wounds Run Deep
text: BAGHDAD — As the United States ends its second war in Iraq, the legacy of the first one still haunts. The memory of the first President Bush’s urging Iraqi Shiites to rebel against the government in 1991, and standing by as thousands were slaughtered, is a tragic counternarrative to the revolutions that have swept the Middle East and a torment that even now complicates relations between the countries.

headline: Sleeping at Work to Keep Her Home
text: The view outside the train window never changes, save for the tint, or total absence, of the leaves across the Hudson River.

headline: At Scene of Wall St. Protest, Rising Concerns About Crime
text: The arrest of a Crown Heights man last week on charges of sexually assaulting a protester at Zuccotti Park added to an already raucous public discussion of lawlessness at the site, where a revolving group of demonstrators has been camped for nearly eight weeks. Stories of crimes and dangerous behavior, mostly anecdotal, have been used as fuel by those who say the protesters must go.

headline: Study Finds Homeless Veterans Stay Homeless Longer Than Others
text: Once veterans become homeless, they are likely to remain homeless longer than non-veterans. And they are also more likely to report having serious health problems, according to a new report by an advocacy group, the 100,000 Homes Campaign.

headline: Two Peas in a Pod
text: Goa, India

headline: Wednesday: Call of a Siren
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — As we approach the time of year where some people remember whether there was enough room at the inn for a very special family, Paula Gamache returns to remind us that, while there might not be room at the inn for everyone, we can always fit the INN into other things. That’s a pretty neat trick, and keeping the accommodations for us is the INNKEEPER, smack in the middle of the grid at 36 Across.

headline: What the Mortgage Interest Deduction Is Worth
text: Here’s what a married couple, filing their taxes jointly, would save each year in federal income taxes depending on how much they earn, the size of their mortgage and the interest rate they are paying on a 30-year interest-only loan. The analysis uses interest-only loans to keep the principal and interest consistent through the year; it assumes no other itemized deductions for things like state income taxes, real estate taxes or charitable contributions.

headline: A Defiant Cain, Newly Serious, Goes for Broke
text: It has been 20 years since Anita Hill accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment on live television and transfixed the nation. People are no longer as shocked, but they can still be tantalized by high-stakes brinkmanship. On Tuesday, viewers watched Herman Cain try to tamp down a scandal that has spread from “he said she said” to “he said they said.”

headline: Struggling Actress Who Wields Script and Whip
text: Lightning flashes intermittently throughout “Venus in Fur,” the spooky sex comedy by David Ives that sizzled open on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater on Tuesday night. But you’re not really likely to notice. The flickering of those stage lights barely registers beside the incandescent Nina Arianda, the sensational young actress recreating the role that made her a name to watch when she first starred in the play Off Broadway. Portraying an actress giving the audition of a lifetime, Ms. Arianda is giving the first must-see performance of the Broadway season, a bravura turn that burns so brightly you can almost feel the heat on your face.

headline: A Fool, His King and the Madness That Engulfs Them
text: Bill Irwin pops up like a daffodil in February amid the gray slush of the Public Theater’s “King Lear,” which opened on Tuesday night, starring Sam Waterston and directed by James Macdonald. The image of a single bright flower in a bleak landscape comes to mind not just because Mr. Irwin is wearing a blazing yellow Pierrot outfit.

headline: Ohio Turns Back a Law Limiting Unions’ Rights
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — A year after Republicans swept legislatures across the country, voters in Ohio delivered their verdict Tuesday on a centerpiece of the conservative legislative agenda, striking down a law that restricted public workers’ rights to bargain collectively.

headline: Ex-Fugitive Is Suspected of New Plot
text: An inmate who led hundreds of police officers and state troopers through the woods of western New York in the summer of 2006 after escaping from jail using a can opener is once again proving to be a far-from-model prisoner.

headline: Report Faults Border Patrol on Bus and Train Searches
text: For years, Border Patrol agents have been boarding domestic trains and buses in upstate New York, often many miles from the Canadian border, inspecting passengers’ IDs and arresting illegal immigrants.

headline: Occupy Movement Inspires Unions to Embrace Bold Tactics
text: Organized labor’s early flirtation with Occupy Wall Street is starting to get serious.

headline: Trouble Beside the Bay
text: Oakland, Calif.

headline: U.S. Won’t Investigate Former S.E.C. Lawyer Over His Madoff Ties
text: The Justice Department has decided not to pursue an investigation into the role played by a former top lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission in the calculation of payouts to victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.

headline: Worker Dies After Being Rescued From Building Collapse in Brooklyn
text: Firefighters frantically dug through the debris of a five-story apartment building in Brooklyn that collapsed during construction on Tuesday, rescuing five workers from shards of corrugated metal that fell under the weight of freshly poured concrete. One of those workers later died, the Fire Department said.

headline: Euro Crisis’s Enabler: The Central Bank
text: THE escalating debt crisis in Europe has claimed the political career of one prime minister, George A. Papandreou of Greece, and threatened that of another, Silvio Berlusconi of Italy. Despite popular resistance, governments are racing to stay ahead of the bond markets by slashing their budgets. The drama of meetings, proposals, counterproposals and popular unrest seems destined to end in tragedy.

headline: Paterno Speaks to Students at His House
text: Although his news conference Tuesday was canceled at the last minute, Penn State Coach Joe Paterno spoke to students who had gathered outside his home in State College, Pa., around 6 p.m.

headline: Learning to Save Like the Japanese
text: Are economists right to fear that Americans might follow the Japanese model of saving to the point of stagnation?

headline: Two Presidents Sharing a Moment
text: After another tense day of politicking and diplomacy, Derek Fisher pushed through a crowded hotel corridor and found himself staring at a master in the field. Bill Clinton smiled and quickly enveloped him in a hug — two Arkansas-born presidents sharing a fantastic moment of serendipity.

headline: Further Tests Fail to Detect Salmon Virus
text: SEATTLE — Canadian fisheries and food safety officials said Tuesday that new government tests showed no evidence of a deadly salmon virus in fish that advocates for wild salmon reported last month contained traces of the virus.

headline: Personal Foul at Penn State
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Recuperating St. John’s Coach Stays Connected
text: As a pregame video played above center court at Carnesecca Arena on Monday night, the members of the St. John’s men’s basketball team twisted their necks and gawked. For all but one of them, it was their first Division I basketball game. They needed somewhere to turn.

headline: Deficit Panel Members Seeking to Avoid Blame
text: WASHINGTON — Members of a Congressional panel on deficit reduction are no longer trying just to solve the nation’s fiscal problems. Some are desperately trying to avoid blame for the possible collapse of a process concocted by Senate leaders to break an impasse between those who want to raise taxes and those who would prefer to cut spending by focusing on entitlement programs.

headline: U.S. to Open New Areas to Offshore Drilling
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday announced its proposed five-year plan for offshore oil drilling, which calls for opening new areas in the Gulf of Mexico and Alaska but bars development along the East and West Coasts.

headline: Word of the Day | chisel
text: chisel •\ˈchi-zəl\• noun and verb

headline: After the Breeders’ Cup, Fitting Finales
text: It didn’t take but a day or so and the announcements of retirements of Breeders’ Cup contenders began to hit the Internet and social media.

headline: Hal Kanter, a Creator of ‘Julia’ Series on TV, Dies at 92
text: Hal Kanter, an Emmy-winning comedy writer, director and producer known for creating “Julia,” the first television series to center on the life of a black professional woman, died on Sunday in Encino, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Margaret Field, TV Actress, Dies at 89
text: Margaret Field, an actress who appeared in countless television shows in the 1950s and ’60s and who was the mother of the Academy Award winner Sally Field, died on Sunday at her home in Malibu, Calif. She was 89.

headline: Who Believes Herman Cain?
text: I saw that. I saw you grimace when you read Herman Cain’s name in yet another headline. (Well, at least I imagined it.) Relax. This is about a narrow subject: conflicting poll results from major polling groups on who does or doesn’t believe the allegations against him. All my numbers nerds say, “Yeah!”

headline: David Ives’s Sexy Comedy, “Venus in Fur”.
text: David Ives’s Sexy Comedy, “Venus in Fur”.

headline: After Drab Season, Red Bulls Regroup
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J. — The Red Bulls’ season ended where they wanted it to end — Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif. — but not when they wanted to end it — Nov. 20, the date of the M.L.S. championship game.

headline: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan
text: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan

headline: Postwar and Contemporary Artworks Draw Record Prices at Christie’s
text: The world’s financial markets may be in turmoil, but for nearly three hours on Tuesday night the collectors and dealers at Christie’s overflowing salesroom seemed to be focused only on the price of art. “People would rather have art than gold or paper,” suggested the Los Angeles financier Eli Broad.

headline: Corrections: November 9
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: How the Richards Family Lost Its Home
text: A personal financial planner, Carl Richards, got caught in the housing bubble.

headline: My Parents Were Home-Schooling Anarchists
text: Tired of the constraints of the 40-hour workweek, my father, in 1972, quit his job in publishing. My parents were in their early 30s, and they had four children under 7. “But we still wanted to explore the world,” my father recalled recently. They bought six one-way tickets to Europe, leaving only a laughable $3,000 to subsist on. Young and idealistic, they thought they could easily educate us along the way. “Life itself would become a portable classroom.”

headline: Aging Well Through Exercise
text: Is physical frailty inevitable as we grow older? That question preoccupies scientists and the middle-aged, particularly when they become the same people. Until recently, the evidence was disheartening. A large number of studies in the past few years showed that after age 40, people typically lose 8 percent or more of their muscle mass each decade, a process that accelerates significantly after age 70. Less muscle mass generally means less strength, mobility and among the elderly, independence. It also has been linked with premature mortality.

headline: F.C.C. Push to Expand Net Access Gains Help
text: To sign up some of the estimated 100 million Americans who are not online, the Federal Communications Commission and private providers are trying to make broadband Internet access both less expensive and more valuable.

headline: Gingrich Rises in Polls But Has Major Obstacles to Nomination
text: I forget whether I posted something on Twitter to this effect or simply kept the thought to myself, but there was a point in time at which I would have given Newt Gingrich not more than a 1-in-1,000 chance of winning the Republican nomination.

headline: Democrats Expand Their Hold on New Jersey Legislature, Despite Christie’s Efforts
text: Gov. Chris Christie put his popularity, fund-raising clout and boasts of reining in government to work for his fellow Republicans in New Jersey’s legislative elections on Tuesday, but he came up empty, as Democrats added slightly to their hold on power.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
text: The Municipal Corporation of Delhi overpaid 150 employees, costing taxpayers about $2 million, according to an enquiry conducted by the agency’s chief auditor (Hindustan Times). R.K. Jain, the deputy chief auditor, is seeking recovery of the amount overpaid to the employees, who are all vaccination staff members. Recovery may be difficult though, as almost 30 of the employees have already retired.Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Mayawati is likely to announce the reorganization of her sprawling state, in a move that her supporters see as a pre-election master stroke. The Times of India reports that Mayawati is planning to carve four new states out of Uttar Pradesh, the country’s biggest state, citing sources from her party. The state remains unwieldy even after the hilly region was sliced off to form Uttarakhand.

headline: Bellone, a Democrat, Elected Suffolk Executive
text: The Democratic Party scored a pivotal victory on Tuesday as Steve Bellone was elected Suffolk County executive, enhancing the party’s standing on Long Island and giving Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo a prominent new ally in the New York City suburbs.

headline: NYT Front Page for 11/09/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 11/09/2011

headline: A Start-Up Offers Help With Advertising on Facebook
text: Just as Google spawned hundreds of thousands of experts in picking the right keywords for search ads, social networks have spawned a new industry of people with expertise in social networking ads.

headline: The Developing World, Leading on Climate Change?
text: In what may turn out to be one of the abiding ironies of global geopolitics, leadership on climate change seems to have suddenly passed from the developed to the developing world, as has public anxiety about the damaging effects of a changing climate.As recently as the Copenhagen summit in late 2009, the West blamed large developing countries such as China and India for scuppering the chances of a “grand agreement” to curb the emission of greenhouse gases. Poor developing countries argued they needed the right to pollute in order to catch up to the West in terms of economic development, while the rich nations clucked that the world could ill afford more carbon emissions.On the flip side, at the Cancun summit a year later, India’s then environment minister, Jairam Ramesh, was pilloried in the domestic press, and accused, by his own admission, of “caving in to the United States” in the final near-consensus plan that was agreed.

headline: Gay Rights, Homophobic Wrongs
text: JOHANNESBURG — On April 28, 2008, the partially clothed body of Eudy Simelane was found in a ditch in Kwa Thema, a black township near Johannesburg. A national soccer star and a well-known lesbian human rights activist, she had been beaten up, gang-raped and stabbed 25 times in the face, chest and legs — even under the feet. This past April, in a case remarkably similar, the body of another lesbian was found in an alley in Kwa Thema. Noxolo Nogwaza’s head had been bashed to a pulp. Her eyeballs were found outside their sockets.

headline: Nov. 9, 1965 | Northeast Is Hit by Blackout
text: On Nov. 9, 1965, at 5:27 p.m., a blackout occurred as several Northeastern states and parts of Canada were hit by a series of power failures lasting as long as 13 hours. The blackout covered 80,000 miles and affected more than 30 million people.

headline: HSBC Warns of Challenges Even as Profit Rises 66%
text: 8:30 a.m. | Updated

headline: Inside the C.B.I. (Well, the Building, Anyway)
text: The 5,000 employees of the Central Bureau of Investigation, India’s anti-corruption agency, seem to have an ever-expanding portfolio of high-profile cases. The agency’s investigations run the gamut from the illegal mining case in the Bellary district of Karnataka state, to the tumultuous 2G spectrum allocation scam, to a new probe in the airline industry.For more than three decades the C.B.I. headquarters sat nestled next to the ministries it sometimes targeted, in the North Block of the government secretariat, a sandstone labyrinth of offices built during the British Raj era. But this April, the C.B.I. moved into a swanky, modern 11-story glass building, modeled after the Interpol headquarters in Lyons, France. The building houses 2,000 employees, and looks more like a multinational company’s headquarters than a typical Delhi government office.

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 9, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: China to Join Effort to Patrol Mekong River
text: BEIJING — China announced on Wednesday that it would join its southeastern neighbors to conduct police patrols on the Mekong River, after the killings last month of 11 Chinese crewmen in an area plagued by drug smuggling.

headline: No Interim Government as Greek Disarray Goes On
text: ATHENS — Prime Minister George A. Papandreou went on national television on Wednesday evening to announce that a new interim government had been formed.

headline: It’s Not Just About the Millionaires
text: This election is about stark differences on economic policy, but one of the few fiscal issues on which Democrats and Republicans agree — surprisingly — is how to tax corporations. Every Republican presidential candidate, and even the guy who currently has the job they’re after, wants to lower rates. Raising them, or even maintaining them, might satisfy the anti-corporate angst of protesters and populists, but it won’t come anywhere near paying off our debt.

headline: 5×15, London Salon, Offers Lectures Short and Sweet
text: Since the early 19th century, when throngs of carriages clogging the road to the Royal Institution prompted the creation of London’s first one-way street, public lectures have never really gone out of fashion in the British capital. The latest incarnation is 5×15, a lecture series that’s tuned this London tradition to the staccato attention spans of the Twitter generation.

headline: Gilad Shalit and the Rising Price of an Israeli Life
text: On the afternoon of June 27, 1976, Palestinian and German terrorists hijacked an Air France flight originating from Israel and directed it eventually to Entebbe Airport in Uganda, where most of the non-Israelis on board were immediately released. More than 100 hostages remained, 83 of whom were Israeli. They were held for the next six days, until an elite team of Israel Defense Force commandos freed them in the famous raid known as Operation Entebbe. The name of the mission became synonymous with Israel’s refusal to give in to the demands of terrorists and its willingness to go to extraordinary lengths, and risk many lives, to free Israeli hostages.

headline: Helping the People Beyond the Pain
text: Donna Ferrato started out photographing pleasure. She ended up confronting pain.

headline: How Colleges Can Retain Science Majors
text: WHAT is STEM?WHAT is “the math-science death march,” according to David E. Goldberg, an emeritus engineering professor?

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 9, 2011
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article “Public Schools Face the Rising Costs of Serving Lunch.”

headline: Do Leaders Have Moral Obligations?
text: Joe Paterno, the long-serving head coach of Penn State’s football team – and other university officials, including the athletic director and the school’s president – have been accused of doing nothing after hearing allegations that assistant coach Jerry Sandusky was responsible for sexually abusing at least one young boy. Some have called Paterno’s inaction a moral failure, while others contend that handling the matter was not his responsibility. What do you think?

headline: Crisis in Italy Deepens, as Bond Yields Hit Record Highs
text: ROME — A day after Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi pledged to step down once the Italian parliament passes austerity measures, Italy was engulfed in political chaos that has pushed the euro zone to its biggest test yet and raised the once unthinkable prospect of a major industrial economy going bankrupt.

headline: Rivers, Manning and Interception Follies
text: San Diego Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers insists there is nothing wrong with him. He has a league-high 14 interceptions; the most he has ever thrown in a season is 15. “I’m not hurt,” Rivers told reporters. “I’ve thrown a handful of picks that I normally don’t throw, and I’ll probably throw some more throughout my career. There won’t always be a reason why.”

headline: The Early Word: Defiant
text: Today’s Times

headline: Part 3: Answers to Your Questions on Applying With a Learning Disability
text: Marybeth Kravets is fielding questions this week on The Choice about applying to college with a learning disability, the subject of my column published over the weekend in The Times’s Education Life supplement.

headline: Who Gets Unemployment Benefits
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Football Outsiders Has Jets Rated No. 1
text: You get the sense, in reading Aaron Schatz’s explanation for how this is possible, that even he is scratching his head — at the same time as Rex Ryan would be nodding his.

headline: 31 Indians Convicted in Violence That Killed Muslims in 2002
text: NEW DELHI — An Indian court found 31 people guilty on Wednesday of killing 33 Muslims in Gujarat State in 2002 during sectarian riots that left more than 1,000 dead. Convicted of murder, arson, rioting and criminal conspiracy, they were sentenced to life in prison and fined. Forty-two other defendants were acquitted.

headline: Can You Trust Your Child’s Coach?
text: How often do you think hard about the adults who work with your children? The teachers and coaches who lead sports teams, church groups and other programs make our lives as parents easier, and they make our children’s lives better. They’re often parents themselves, and many of us find ourselves in coaching roles, working with other people’s children. I tend to take for granted my children’s safety when I send them off to a hockey game in a coach’s car, or to an after-school club run by a teacher — until something happens to remind me to be less sanguine.

headline: Stone Links
text: A gathering of philosophy-related links from the past week.

headline: My Grand Experiment: Turning Off AdWords
text: Monday, October 24, 9:36 a.m.: As I explained in my last post, I recently found myself with a surprising new problem: all the work we can handle. Because our backlog of orders is as high as I want it to be, I decided to take the opportunity to run an experiment: What would happen if I stopped running Google AdWords?

headline: For an Immigrant, a Shrinking Business and a Maze of Obstacles
text: In better times, Abel Cherubin maintained a staff of six at his tax preparation business in Brooklyn, drove a BMW and even purchased a plot of land in his native Haiti, where he planned to build a school.

headline: How Bubbles Affect Our Financial Behavior
text: Those of you familiar with the collected works of Carl Richards know that he has a keen sense of how uncontrolled emotion and errant behavior can make a mess of your financial life. And now, with the story of his own short sale in Las Vegas, you know that he learned these things the hard way.

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 9
text: Herman Cain held a news conference Tuesday afternoon to deny the accusations of sexual harassment made by a number of women who worked for him when he led the National Restaurant Association. He charged that the accusations had been ginned up by a “Democratic machine” and been kept alive by a hostile news media, particularly the Web site Politico, which broke the story. [NYT]

headline: Nearly 500 Birds Found Dead Near Wind Farm
text: A West Virginia wind farm that I wrote about last month because of its battery installation was the site of a big bird kill in October, according to a consultant’s report for the Fish and Wildlife Service.

headline: Schlumberger in Russian Joint Venture Deal
text: LONDON — Integra, a Russian oil services group, announced plans on Wednesday to spin off a joint venture with the American energy giant Schlumberger and list the company on the London Stock Exchange.

headline: Kenya’s Uncertain Campaign
text: NAIROBI — When on Oct. 16 Kenya sent hundreds of troops into Somalia, its perennially problematic neighbor, it was going to war for the first time in three decades. The operation was ostensibly a response to recent raids by Somali militants into northern Kenya to kidnap tourists and aid workers. More likely, though, the Kenyan government seized the occasion to try to root out the Shabab, a group of Islamist insurgents, which has become increasingly meddlesome and dangerous. But it is stepping into a political mess, and for the moment the Kenyan government seems to be shooting from the hip.

headline: Payne’s Productive Period
text: From 1999 to 2004, Alexander Payne wrote and directed three feature films. But it took him seven years to get his next movie, “The Descendants,” to the big screen.

headline: Darren Aronofsky Gets a Reality Check from the Margaret Mead Film Festival
text: While his 2010 feature “Black Swan” could have presaged a career transition into ballet, Darren Aronofsky is sticking with the cinema for the time being. This month, Mr. Aronofsky, whose films include “Requiem for a Dream” and “The Wrestler” (as well as a disturbing new series of anti-drug public service announcements) is temporarily trading his director’s chair for a different seat at the American Museum of Natural History, where he is heading the jury of its Margaret Mead Film Festival.

headline: Hollywood Plans Big Binge for Christmas
text: LOS ANGELES — Six Oscar-caliber directors. Nine movies (at least). And just one Christmas.

headline: The Director of ‘Sideways’ Sees His Life Go Forward
text: SEVEN years. That’s how long it has been since the release of “Sideways,” which cemented Alexander Payne’s status as one of this country’s most exciting movie directors, won him an Oscar for screenwriting and ratcheted up the anticipation for his next film — the sooner, the better.

headline: Fear of Contagion Rocks Markets
text: Europe’s efforts to stem financial contagion foundered on Wednesday as investors dumped their holdings of Italian government bonds, prompting a global stock market sell-off.

headline: Spending on Political Ads Spurs Local TV Mergers
text: The broadcast business is becoming more attractive to buyers after several painful years, Brian Stelter of The New York Times reports. Analysts say private equity firms that bought into the business years ago are ready to sell. Read more »

text: State legislatures across the country have passed or proposed laws against what they call cyberbullying. But how do young people parse bullying from being mean online? And when it happens, what do they do about it?

text: From the editorial page

headline: G.M. Posts Quarterly Profit, but Chief Calls It Insufficient
text: DETROIT — General Motors  reported its seventh consecutive quarterly profit on Wednesday but stressed the need for more cost cutting as profit margins declined. It also warned of a more difficult end to the year than Wall Street was anticipating.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Rajaratnam Ordered to Pay $92.8 Million Penalty  |  A federal judge on Tuesday ordered the convicted hedge fund titan Raj Rajaratnam to pay a $92.8 million penalty, the largest ever assessed against a person in a Securities and Exchange Commission insider trading case.

headline: A Plan to Send TriBeCa Students to Chinatown
text: For more local news, including local election results for Suffolk County executive, crime concerns at Occupy Wall Street, the successes of past immigrant entrepreneurs, and financial concerns at the free public college Cooper Union, see the N.Y./Region section.

headline: Hanging on to Home, Even After a Fall
text: BERNIE AND JOYCE MURPHY are still convinced that they did everything right when they bought their home. And by all indications, they did.

headline: Ultimate Grave Dance? Ruling Could Help Zell Recoup Part of Tribune Investment
text: On Monday, word came in The Chicago Tribune that Sam Zell, the architect of a deal that left the Tribune Company in bankruptcy with $13 billion in debt, may now be in line to recoup some of his initial $315 million investment because of a judge’s ruling on another class of debtor.

headline: Tent Revival
text: To accompany her spring collection’s sporty graphic dresses and jumpers, the designer Stella McCartney teamed up with the International Trade Center’s Ethical Fashion Program on a line of Kenyan-made accessories. “I have actually never been to Kenya,” says McCartney, who has done similar collaborations with Oceana and the Natural Resources Defense Council. “But the project helps to use the widely available and affordable materials there.” The tote bags ($330) and strappy sandals ($300) in python-patterned screen prints are made of recycled cotton safari tents and sewn by seamstresses in Nairobi. Go to saks.com.

headline: After Ratner’s Resignation, a Single Question for the Academy
text: On Tuesday, Brett Ratner, the designated co-producer of this year’s Oscars, resigned after he used a gay slur during a Q. & A. session about “Tower Heist,” his latest blockbuster. One of the stars of that film, Eddie Murphy, is still scheduled to host the event.

headline: Early Admission Returns to Princeton, and So Do the Applicants
text: Four years ago, Princeton and Harvard ended their early admission programs, in an effort to delay the beginning of the annual frenzy of applicants to secure a precious seat in the next freshman class. But when none of its main competitors followed suit, both institutions announced in February that they would once again offer applicants an opportunity to apply for admission in November, two months before the deadline for regular applications.

headline: An Accounting of Programs That Aim to Help Troops
text: As the Iraq and Afghanistan wars have taken their toll on the physical and mental health of America’s service members and their families, the number of Pentagon programs intended to treat traumatic brain injury, or provide psychological, marital or spiritual support to the troops and their loved ones, has proliferated.

headline: I Am A Frankfurter
text: And I say that with relish — although actually I’m in Mainz, doing a couple of talks.

headline: Children’s Books: Little Brothers, Good and Bad
text: There is little more annoying to a 4-year-old boy than his 2-year-old brother. But in this clever, offbeat picture book, there is little more endearing, or starkly amusing either.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Choosing Wines for Thanksgiving Dinner
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: This Is The Way The Euro Ends
text: This is the way the euro ends.

text: Reuters: Check those food labels, if you can. China says about 10 percent of its farmland is contaminated with heavy metals. — Nick Fox

headline: In Tuesday’s Election Results, Democrats See Hope for 2012
text: Just hours after polls closed Tuesday night, Democrats seized on scattered results across the country as evidence that voters are rejecting Republican policies and will return President Obama to the Oval Office in 2012.

headline: Mayor Merryl Tisch? The Post Floats the Idea
text: It is already evident that the New York City school system will figure prominently in the race for mayor in 2013, both in terms of policies and in union and other support. But now The New York Post, in a blind item on Page Six, is trying to entice a full-out education person to run: Merryl H. Tisch, the chancellor of the state's Board of Regents.

headline: Six Steps to a Thanksgiving Stir-Fry
text: This Thanksgiving, put your wok to work.

headline: Voters Defeat Many G.O.P.-Sponsored Measures
text: Voters turned a skeptical eye toward conservative-backed measures across the country Tuesday, rejecting an anti-labor law in Ohio, an anti-abortion measure in Mississippi and a tightening of voting rights in Maine.

headline: Ryan Skeen Joins Pera as It Expands
text: Ryan Skeen, of Resto, Irving Mill, Allen & Delancey, 5 & Diamond and Fish Tag will be the executive chef for the growing Pera enterprises. Joining the company’s first restaurant, Pera Medtierranean Brasserie in Midtown, and the Pera Turkish Taco Truck, Pera Soho will open next month at 54 Thompson Street (Broome Street). Mr. Skeen will be in charge of its kitchen there.

headline: Medicaid Whistle-Blower Wins in Court, but Not Yet at Love
text: There were a few matchmaking offers from people in his sister-in-law’s shul, and one from an actual shadchen (Jewish matchmaker), offering, by e-mail: “sister and granddaughter of rabbi; graduate of Wesleyan; entrepreneur, passionate foodie; VERY beautiful (soulmate?).”

headline: Discovery Executive to Leave
text: After two years as the chief operating officer of Discovery Communications, Peter Liguori will leave at the end of the year, the company said Wednesday.

headline: Italy Bound
text: Just in time for Italy’s 150th anniversary (and a major financial crisis), a flurry of new books present the country as frustrating, inscrutable and magnificent.

headline: Accused Al-Qaeda Leader Is Arraigned in U.S.S. Cole Bombing
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — A Saudi man accused of plotting the 2000 bombing of the American destroyer Cole walked into a military courtroom at the naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, on Wednesday morning, appearing in public for the first time since his capture nine years ago.

headline: Sun and Sand on Your Agenda? It’s Time to Book
text: LOOKING for a bargain beach vacation? Better act fast.

headline: It’s the Economy: ‘The Patient Is Having a Heart Attack’
text: Over on the Planet Money blog, Adam Davidson, author of our new It’s the Economy column, has posted responses from John Cochrane of the University of Chicago and Dean Baker of the Center for Economic and Policy Research to his first column, “Can Anyone Really Create Jobs?”

headline: It’s Official: American Is Now a Bolshoi Dancer
text: Last Friday night, David Hallberg made his debut as a principal dancer at the Bolshoi Ballet, becoming the first American in history to do so.

headline: Toyota Recalls 420,000 Models for Possible Steering Flaw
text: Toyota is recalling about 420,000 of some of its most popular vehicles because an engine issue may cause an unexpected increase in steering effort.

headline: Memo to Penn State: Ignoring a Scandal Doesn’t Make It Go Away
text: Anyone with an ounce of sense happening by the Penn State campus these days might want to deliver a message to the people ostensibly running the place: Your scandal isn’t going away. With hundreds of reporters roaming their campus looking for answers to the obvious questions that come with a sexual abuse case university officials — including Coach Joe Paterno — allegedly sat on for years, and a public cry for some defense for what appears to be an institution-wide moral collapse, the university brain trust has found a very large sand pit for those brains and decided not to deal with it. So, on top of a crisis, the university has heaped a public relations catastrophe.

headline: Paterno Is Finished at Penn State, and President Is Out
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Joe Paterno, who has the most victories of any coach in major college football history, was fired by Penn State on Wednesday night in the wake of a sexual abuse scandal involving a prominent former assistant coach and the university’s failure to act to halt further harm.

headline: Retro Games, and a Joystick to Play Them
text: Remember plunking down your whole allowance in quarters to play Centipede and Asteroids at the local arcade?

headline: Which Way Home? A Special Section on Home Ownership
text: In a special section — called Which Way Home? — the Your Money team takes a look at housing, including the continuing fallout from the bursting of the real estate bubble, through the stories of homeowners who run the gamut. One negotiated a short sale, others walked away from underwater houses and yet another persevered to get a loan modification. Other features include a family that consolidated several generations on one property.

headline: Former Moscow Mayor Returns to Russia
text: MOSCOW — Moscow’s former mayor, Yuri M. Luzhkov, returned to Russia on Wednesday, ending speculation that he might remain abroad rather than submit to questioning in an embezzlement case against the Bank of Moscow.

headline: Georgia and Russia Sign Trade Deal
text: MOSCOW — Georgia and Russia on Wednesday signed an agreement that clears the path for Russia to join the World Trade Organization, ending nine months of often rocky negotiations between the two countries on monitoring trade flows over the Georgian-Russian border.

headline: Romney Seizes on Obama’s Netanyahu Comments
text: Mitt Romney has added his intentional comments Wednesday to the mix of ones  unintentionally overheard last week about Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

headline: Questions for the Candidates
text: The Republican presidential candidates are meeting in Michigan tonight for a CNBC-hosted debate. I often feel that moderators are too soft on the candidates, so, in collaboration with Times editorial board members Lawrence Downes, David Firestone, Carol Giacomo, Juliet Lapidos, Teresa Tritch and David Unger, I’ve come up with some questions (actually, a whole lot of questions, but we’re talking about the presidency, not an application to run a pizza franchise). CNBC, if you’re reading, please feel free to plagiarize.

headline: When Ozone Drops, Farm Workers Step Up the Pace
text: Opponents of stricter regulation of air pollution typically argue that jobs would be lost if the federal government tightened limits on industrial emissions of ozone. A new study presents a counterpoint: lower ozone levels seem to increase worker productivity.

headline: Regis May Be Going, but We’ll Have Kelly for a While
text: Regis Philbin is leaving the daytime talk show “Live! with Regis and Kelly” later this month, but his co-host, Kelly Ripa, is planning to stay awhile.

headline: With Anger Over Dirty Air Rising, Beijing Tries Tours of Monitoring Center
text: BEIJING — Environmental officials who have resisted releasing comprehensive data about air pollution here in the capital announced that they would take action to address increasing complaints that the government’s monitoring system fails to report on the most dangerous airborne particles emitted by the growing ranks of cars and trucks.

headline: E.U. Poised to Overtake U.S. as Biggest Oil Importer
text: LONDON — The European Union is expected to overtake the United States as the world’s biggest oil importer in 2015, the International Energy Agency said Wednesday in its annual report.

headline: Reporting From Syria in Secret
text: Updated | 2:17 p.m. As The Lede has reminded readers for months, because of restrictions imposed by the Syrian government on independent reporting, much of the information about the uprising there, including video of the security crackdown on protesters this week, reaches the Web only after it has been smuggled out of the country by a network of activists.

headline: Iran Escalates Anti-U.S. Rhetoric Over Nuclear Report
text: WASHINGTON — Angered by the release of an incriminating United Nations report on their nuclear ambitions, Iran’s leaders sought on Wednesday to cast it as an American fabrication.

headline: Energy Forecast: Fracking in China, Nuclear Uncertain, CO2 Up
text: This year’s World Energy Outlook report has been published by the International Energy Agency, and says wealthy and industrializing countries are stuck on policies that threaten to lock in “an insecure, inefficient and high-carbon energy system.”

headline: For Soldiers, the End of the Mail Means the End of the War
text: When the war was violent and stupid and terrifying, and I was hot and cold and tired, I joked that my goal in life was to have a job in which I would walk into the office each day in a suit and tie, carrying a briefcase, a newspaper and a cup of coffee. I would say hello to my office assistant on the way to a comfortable chair by my nice desk. There would be no ruck laden with mortar rounds, no ammo magazines with tracer rounds carefully interspersed, no disembodied voice on a radio.

headline: Stay Calm: It Is Just a Test. Probably.
text: Nov. 10: Read Brian Stelter’s post on Media Decoder to see how the test turned out.

headline: Stage Scenes: Alan Rickman
text: A look at some of the actor’s past performances.

headline: Judge to Release Summary of Detective’s Notes in British Phone-Hacking Scandal
text: Rupert Murdoch’s son James, the deputy chief operating officer of News Corporation, will most likely face tough questions at a hearing by a British parliamentary committee on Thursday over his role in the phone-hacking scandal at The News of the World tabloid, as my colleagues Sarah Lyall and Don Van Natta Jr. reported, and a ruling by a judge released on Tuesday could add to the pressure.

headline: Union Negotiator Apologizes for ‘Plantation’ Comment
text: Jeffrey Kessler, the chief negotiator for the N.B.A. players union, apologized Wednesday for making a racially charged comment about N.B.A. owners. Discussing the taut labor negotiations between the league and the union, he had told The Washington Post that the league was treating the players “like plantation workers.”

headline: Move Over, Christie’s, U.S. Marshals Want a Piece of the Action
text: Even the United States Marshals Service is getting in on the fall auction season.

headline: 2011 Milan Motorcycle Show
text: Highlights from the industry’s annual showcase.

headline: A Neglected Vaccine
text: Like many other grown-ups, I hadn’t given any thought to what we used to call the D.P.T. vaccine — for diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus — for decades. I got the shots when I was a child, and I made sure my daughter got them during her childhood immunizations. Every now and then, my doctor tells me it’s time for a tetanus booster, so I get one. That’s enough, right?

headline: Have an N.F.L. Question? Judy Battista Has Answers
text: Can the Bears beat the Lions in this Sunday’s rematch? How worried should Patriots fans be? Why can’t the Eagles sustain any momentum? Judy Battista,The Times’s N.F.L. reporter, will again answer selected questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below to ask your questions, and the answers will appear on The Fifth Down on Friday.

headline: Designer Lipstick: A New Splurge
text: KATHLEEN MUKAMAL, a homemaker who lives in Miami and New York, was waiting in a long line last Tuesday evening in the beehive-like basement of Bergdorf Goodman to meet Tom Ford, the designer who has introduced a cosmetics line there, with plans to arrive at Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue in the months ahead.

headline: The Renault 4 Gets Reimagined for Design Competition
text: In the pantheon of emblematic European passenger cars, right alongside the Volkswagen Beetle, Fiat 500 and Citroën 2CV, is the Renault 4, a family mover of petite proportions.

headline: On Our Radar: ‘Viciously More Expensive’ Energy
text: The global demand for energy is set to increase 40 percent by 2035, the International Energy Agency says. And it will become “viciously more expensive” and more polluting if governments do not promote renewable energy and nuclear power in the next two decades instead of burning coal, it warns. [Bloomberg News]

headline: Short and Shapely, the Town Coat Steps In

headline: The Caucus | Debate Preview
text: Nov. 9, 2011 — A look ahead as Republican candidates prepare to gather for their first debate since sexual harassment allegations were uncovered against Herman Cain.

headline: Ahead of Vote, Egypt’s Parties and Skepticism Are Growing
text: CAIRO — At the rally kicking off his campaign for Parliament, Basem Kamel, a core member of the youthful council that helped spur the end of the Mubarak government, wrestled with his stump speech calling for civilian rule.

headline: ‘Home Is Where the School Is’
text: An article by Patricia Heidenry from the October 19, 1975 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

headline: A New Book Argues Against the SAT
text: When Wake Forest University announced three years ago that it would make the SAT optional for its undergraduate applicants, among those cheering was Joseph Soares, a sociology professor at the university. Mr. Soares has channeled his enthusiasm for Wake Forest’s decision — as well as for similar policies at several hundred other colleges — into a new book, “SAT Wars,” that argues for looking beyond standardized test scores in college admissions. (The book was published last month by Teachers College Press.)

headline: ESPN Acquires Rights to Euro Playoffs (but There’s a Twist)
text: ESPN, which will carry next summer’s Euro 2012 from Ukraine and Poland, said Wednesday that it has acquired the rights to the eight-team playoffs for the four remaining spots in the tournament. But there is a twist: the games will only be available on ESPN Deportes, a Spanish-language channel, and ESPN3, its online service that is not available to all.

headline: TimesCast | November 9, 2011
text: Investors remain skeptical Italy can tackle its financial crisis; Wednesday is the first G.O.P. debate since allegations against Herman Cain surfaced; and N.B.A. owners give players a 5 p.m. deadline.

headline: E.U. to Tighten Web Privacy Law, Risking Trans-Atlantic Dispute
text: BERLIN — The European Commission is planning a legal change next year that may prompt U.S. Web giants like Google and Facebook to rethink how they store and process consumer data, raising the prospect of a trans-Atlantic dispute over Internet privacy.

headline: Powerful Storm Pummels Western Alaska
text: A powerful storm with hurricane-force winds slammed into western Alaska on Wednesday, causing power failures in some tiny coastal villages and warnings that the area could suffer major flooding.

headline: The Case for Optimism
text: All right, hope had a good run. It elected a president, made people feel good for a while, and sold some expensive artwork. Three years later, the unemployment rate is still high, most homeowners are still licking their wounds from diminished values, and many companies are not back to where they were before the Great Recession.

headline: Caucus Video: Debate Preview
text: A look ahead as Republican candidates prepare to gather for their first debate since sexual harassment allegations were uncovered against Herman Cain.

headline: Cain to Appear on ‘Letterman’
text: Herman Cain is making one more stop on the late-night television comedy circuit. Next up, “Late Show With David Letterman.”

headline: The Off-Year Election
text: One of the big mistakes that the more extremist Republican politicians make is thinking that when they campaign on conservative ideas like small government and lower taxes, and then get elected, that they have a mandate to pursue every wing-nut idea that pops into their heads.

headline: Lens: Lively Morgue Aviators
text: Lens: Lively Morgue Aviators

headline: Focus on a Star and a System
text: TOKYO — Other than their quirky and often misunderstood name, the Nippon Ham Fighters do not arouse much interest in the United States.

headline: Trade War in Solar Takes Shape
text: HONG KONG — The United States and China are gearing up for a trade war that could catch American users of solar energy in the crossfire.

headline: Cuomo Declares ‘Big Victory’ at the Polls
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Wednesday declared the Democratic Party’s successes in several major local government elections on Tuesday to be “a big victory for the people of the state,” and he said that he believed the races offered evidence that voters wanted the same kind of reforms in their communities that Mr. Cuomo has pushed on the state level.

headline: Adobe to Kill Mobile Flash, Focus on HTML5
text: Adobe Systems, the software company, said Wednesday that it is killing its Flash for mobile browsers, and will instead focus its efforts on HTML5 for mobile developers.

headline: It Was Only a Test, but What a Test
text: 3 p.m. | Updated  At 2 p.m. Eastern time on Wednesday, all television channels and radio stations in the United States were supposed to be interrupted by a brief test of the nation’s Emergency Alert System. But, like most tests, some passed and some failed.

headline: The Fulton
text: FANCY Manhattan therapists have, on occasion, been known to steer their single female clients to a rarefied southern swath of the island, where men outnumber women to an extent not often witnessed outside a gay club. The odds are certainly in their favor at the Fulton, a new gastropub in a former Blarney Stone space, which draws a steady stream of finance guys fresh out of the office, who talk shop over cold beers and beefy sliders. The men’s rooms are stocked with toiletries like cologne and hair gels, should the occasional female enter their fraternal cave.

headline: Tip of the Week: Selecting the Right Program to Open a File
text: Need to open a file in a program other than the one that automatically pops open when you double-click? In either Mac OS X or Windows, right-clicking in the file’s icon and choosing “Open With” lets you select a different program from a list of applications that can also handle that file type.

headline: Cashman Says It’s Still Too Early for Dealing
text: Brian Cashman, the general manager of the Yankees, said Wednesday that it was still too early in the off-season for any serious discussions about free agents or potential trades.

headline: ‘Today’ to Show an Interview With Michael Jackson’s Doctor
text: Dr. Conrad Murray, who was convicted on Monday of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Michael Jackson, did not take the stand while on trial, but he did defend himself to television interviewers.

headline: TimesCast | Italy's Financial Crisis
text: November 9, 2011 - Investors remain skeptical Italy can tackle its financial crisis

headline: Oscar Show Replaces Key Player After Furor
text: LOS ANGELES — Brian Grazer, a prominent film producer with recent credits on both “J. Edgar” and “Tower Heist,” is stepping in to produce next year’s Oscar awards show, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Wednesday, a move intended to quickly repair the damage caused by the sudden departures of the ceremony’s co-producer, Brett Ratner, and its host, Eddie Murphy.

headline: Afghan Soldier Said to Attack His Instructors From Australia
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Australian troops on a training mission in southern Afghanistan were attacked Tuesday by one of the Afghan soldiers they were training, officials said Wednesday.

headline: France Can’t Afford to Give Up Nuclear Energy, Utility Chief Says
text: So you are thinking that, after the Fukushima nuclear disaster in Japan, you would like to drop nuclear energy? Fine. But you had better be prepared to pay the price.

headline: Thoughts of a Peacetime Veteran
text: I’m marching in my first Veterans Day parade this week and I doubt whether I really belong.

headline: Italy Pushed Closer to Financial Brink
text: A day after Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi offered his resignation in the face of rising global market skepticism, investors revolted Wednesday, suggesting they do not believe that even a new leadership could fix Italy’s intransigent financial problems and revive its economy.

headline: A Tokyo With Two Moons and Many More Puzzles
text: One of the many longueurs in Haruki Murakami’s stupefying new novel, “1Q84,” sends the book’s heroine, a slender assassin named Aomame, into hiding. To sustain her through this period of isolation she is given an apartment, groceries and the entirety of Marcel Proust’s “Remembrance of Things Past.”

headline: Bookshelf: Grandparents
text: LOVE, MOUSERELLA  Written and illustrated by David Ezra Stein.  30 pp. Nancy Paulsen Books. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 4 to 8)

headline: The Cain Scrutiny
text: Here’s a revealing snapshot of race and American politics in the year 2011. Just hours after Sharon Bialek came forward to accuse Herman Cain of sexual harassment, the liberal panelists on Martin Bashir’s MSNBC show took turns ruminating about how Cain’s conservative backers would no doubt freak out over the idea of a black man putting the moves on a blond white woman. “I think it will be interesting to see if these guys rally around Herman Cain,” the Democratic strategist Karen Finney commented, “now that it’s clear that a whole other layer of black sexuality has been infused into this.”

headline: Grandparents
text: Children’s books about grandparents.

headline: China Investigates Pricing by 2 Broadband Companies
text: SHANGHAI — In a rare move, China’s state economic planning agency said Wednesday that it was investigating whether two of the country’s biggest state-run telecommunications companies were engaging in monopolistic behavior and overcharging consumers for broadband Internet.

headline: Into the Wild
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Beauty Spots
text: These days, if you sing on television, you must also have a scent. Just ask Beyoncé, Jennifer Lopez, Katy Perry or any of the following pop stars who introduced new perfumes this fall.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov.9
text: A look at the day in sports, including weight lifting championships and cricket with a view.

headline: Global Markets Are Buffeted as Italian Bond Yields Surge
text: Italy’s economic and political situation has highlighted a range of unpleasant possibilities for the European Union. The New York Times’s Graham Bowley reports on investor reaction to the crisis in the world’s eighth-largest economy.

headline: Regents Chief Says No to a Run for Mayor
text: Merryl H. Tisch, chancellor of the New York State Board of Regents, is not interested in running for mayor, despite the buzz that has circulated in recent weeks about her possible candidacy.

headline: Overseas Update, How N.B.A. Players are Faring
text: While professional basketball in the United States is on hold until further notice, the show goes on around the world, and many N.B.A. players have sought temporary employment overseas. Most have gone to Europe, but some have gone to China and South America. Many are Europeans simply picking up where they left off in their native countries, while others are Americans enjoying varying degrees of success in new environments. Almost all the players have an out clause should the N.B.A. season commence.

headline: Kaat, Tiant, Reynolds: Who Belongs in the Hall?
text: The Baseball Hall of Fame should be a place to celebrate the best players of each era. That’s it, a nice simple criteria — the nuances of that definition are what we get to argue about.

headline: Iowa Grants Nelson’s Graduation Dream
text: It is not unusual for a star basketball player to leave college for the pros before earning his degree. But it is unusual when the player finishes the requirements for graduation — at age 71.

headline: In Some Areas, Home Ownership Is Still Out of Reach
text: The housing market may have crashed in many parts of the country, but there is still a contingent of would-be buyers living an alternate reality. They make a decent living, they save, but it’s still not enough to break into the gated communities formerly known as New York, Los Angeles and Boston.

headline: Panel Rules Against Regulators in Thomas Weisel Case
text: In a victory for Thomas Weisel Partners, a hearing panel for the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority has cleared the investment bank of nearly all charges related to the sale of auction-rate securities during the last financial crisis.

headline: Have Your Spray Paint and Eat It Too
text: Of all the adjectives that come to mind when speaking of spray paint, “edible” is not generally one of them. Until now. The Deli Garage, a self-titled “Food Cooperative” based in Germany, has recently released “Food Finish,” a metallic spray paint specifically made for food. According to their Web site, it’s “tasteless”; an adjective many people used to describe graffiti in response to our recent article on spray paint of the nonedible variety.

headline: Why I Didn’t Search for My Daughter’s Birth Parents
text: Two months ago, I turned down the opportunity to search for my adopted daughter’s birth parents.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Coast Guard Alaska’
text: We’ve had “Alaska State Troopers.” We’ve had “Sarah Palin’s Alaska.” And on Wednesday night, the Weather Channel rolls out “Coast Guard Alaska.”

headline: ‘NCIS’ Locks Down TV Audience
text: Can anything stop the television ratings juggernaut that is the “NCIS” franchise? Apparently not. On Tuesday night the original “NCIS” on CBS scored its highest ratings of the season, breaking the 20-million-total-viewer barrier (at 20.3 million to be exact), while its spin-off, “NCIS: Los Angeles” reached 15.9 million.

headline: Images and Ink: Identifying Significant Science Symbols
text: Overview | In this lesson, students view a collection of science-themed tattoos. They consider the scientific significance of the tattoo designs and their meaning to the people who have them. They then create their own designs using personally meaningful science images and share their choices with the class and a larger community.

headline: Tailgating Recipe: Big Red Bear’s Smoked Salmon Club Sandwich
text: Just because your team doesn’t play in prime time doesn’t mean your tailgate party lacks championship quality fare. They prove as much at Cornell. Of course, the Big Red festivities have to be declared semiprofessional. The students at the university’s School of Hotel Administration — led by the Hotel Ezra Cornell organization — throw a tailgate party every year that is open only to hotel school students, alumni and registered guests. There have been reports of people trying to sneak under the ropes.

headline: Justin Bieber’s Holiday Album Is a Surprising No. 1
text: In a week crowded with new music releases, Justin Bieber’s new holiday album topped the Billboard chart with more than 200,000 sales.

headline: Homebody Cuomo Will Venture Out of State, Briefly
text: After steadfastly refusing invitations to attend events outside New York State throughout his first 10 months in office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is finally going on a business trip. But he will not be taking his overnight bag.

headline: Thanksgiving Countdown | Notes on Brining
text: The questions are starting to pour in to the Help Line, and a theme has emerged: widespread confusion over the ifs and hows and whens of brining. You may want to refer to this brining primer that Sam Sifton wrote last year. Have more specific questions on brining or anything else Thanksgiving? Just ask.

headline: More Penalties Possible in Base Mortuary Scandal
text: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is holding out the possibility of further action against three top officials at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware who knew about lost body parts at the base mortuary but did nothing to fix a sloppy system, Pentagon officials said Wednesday.

headline: Bird Diversity on the Trobriand Islands
text: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.

headline: Eddie Murphy Follows Ratner Off the Oscars Telecast
text: Eddie Murphy is dropping out as the host of the Oscars telecast, the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences said on Wednesday, just one day after the show’s co-producer, Brett Ratner, stepped aside amid a storm of criticism over his use of an antigay slur.

headline: New School Guide for Parents Now Available
text: A new, free resource to help parents understand the school enrollment process and connect with school personnel was released on Wednesday.

headline: In Prospect Heights, a Celebration of Play
text: Getting a new school playground is certainly something worth celebrating. So local officials, parents, staff members and students at Public School 9 and Middle School 571, at 80 Underhill Avenue, Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, turned out on a gorgeous fall day to dedicate the colorful new yard that the two schools share.

headline: Tisch Says She Will Not Run for Mayor
text: Merryl H. Tisch, chancellor of the New York State Board of Regents, says she is not interested in running for mayor, despite the buzz that has circulated in recent weeks about her as a potential candidate. “It’s a distraction,” she said. “I am the chancellor, 24 hours a day, seven days a week.”

headline: He Wants to Retire?
text: There is still a lot we don’t know about what happened at Penn State, or why the school remained silent for so long about child sexual abuse allegations against former football coach Jerry Sandusky. But we know enough for me to feel appalled at the idea that head coach Joe Paterno thinks it is sufficient to retire at the end of the current season.

headline: Five Things to Watch: The Michigan Debate
text: Debate season is back.

headline: Penn State Scandal Foreseen by a Few
text: Considering that the grand jury investigating sexual abuse charges against former Penn State defensive coordinator Jerry Sandusky did so over 18 months, and several newspapers — particularly the Patriot-News of Harrisburg, Pa. — were reporting on its progress, it is not entirely surprising that some people were pondering its impact before the entire world found out last week when Sandusky was finally charged.

headline: Egypt's Liberal Political Rally
text: Basem Kamel is campaigning for parliament as a member of the liberal Egyptian Social Democratic party.

headline: Agency Restores Doctor Discipline Files — With a Catch
text: A federal health agency on Wednesday restored to its Web site a database of doctor disciplinary actions two months after pulling it off the Internet in response to a doctor’s complaints.

headline: Live Blogging the Michigan Debate
text: After a hiatus of several weeks, the Republican candidates for president will gather in Michigan on Wednesday night for a 90-minute exchange meant to focus on economic issues.
