headline: Clip: 'Into the Abyss'
text: A clip from “Into the Abyss,” Werner Herzog’s documentary about a triple homicide that took place in Conroe, Tex.

headline: 7 Charged in Web Scam Using Ads
text: It was a subtle swap: a cheesy advertisement for a vacation timeshare site atop the home page of ESPN.com, in a spot that might have been claimed by a well-known brand like Dr Pepper.

headline: Second Solyndra Loan Discussed With Energy Dept., E-Mail Suggests
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Wednesday tried to use newly released e-mails to tie an Obama campaign donor with a stake in the troubled Solyndra solar energy company to an effort to lobby the White House for approval of loan guarantees to the company. But Democrats said the complete record showed exactly the opposite.

headline: Pictures of the Day: England and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from England, Chile, India and Thailand.

headline: North Carolina Is Top Seed in Field Hockey
text: In the 2011 N.C.A.A. field hockey championship tournament, North Carolina (20-1) is the top seed in the field of 16. Old Dominion (20-2) is second, Syracuse (18-3) third, and Connecticut (17-2) is fourth.

headline: Security Forces Kill at Least 26 in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian security forces killed at least 26 people on Wednesday across Syria, according to activists and residents, while defectors clashed with armed men loyal to the government of President Bashar al-Assad in central Syria.

headline: Burst of Interest in Penn State Tickets
text: The allegations against Jerry Sandusky and officials at Penn State have led commentators to wonder how fans will react when the Nittany Lions play the Nebraska Cornhuskers on Saturday in State College, Pa.

headline: A Brief Programming Note
text: Beginning with today’s offering (on race and Herman Cain) and continuing through the November election, I”ll be writing a Wednesday column for the Times’ Campaign Stops page, where I’ll be joined by Charles Blow, Thomas Edsall, Timothy Egan and a rotating cast of talented contributors. So please stop by and check it out.

headline: Returning to Form After Some Fancy
text: Sting was alone onstage, cradling an acoustic guitar, during the final moments of his supremely self-possessed show at the Roseland Ballroom on Tuesday night. It was the third encore, and as has been customary during his “Back to Bass” tour, he was playing a stripped-down version of “Message in a Bottle,” one of the springier No. 1 singles from his tenure with the Police. The lyrical gist of the song — in brutal shorthand, crushing isolation softened by a bleak epiphany — came across more clearly than usual, even as the crowd giddily sang along. “Love can mend your life, but love can break your heart,” Sting admonished, his singing nearly drowned out by cheers.

headline: Investment Groups Prod Other Companies on James Murdoch’s Board Membership
text: 5:46 p.m. | Updated The problems at News Corporation could eventually affect other companies — in industries ranging from art to health care to baseball.

headline: Philippine President Offers to Fly Doctors In to Treat Predecessor
text: MANILA — President Benigno S. Aquino III offered Wednesday to bring in foreign doctors to examine his predecessor, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, but he insisted that a travel ban for Mrs. Arroyo stay in place until corruption allegations against her were resolved.

headline: N.B.A. Talks Yield Progress but No Breakthrough Yet
text: Pushing aside ultimatums, threats and caustic rhetoric, N.B.A. owners and players returned to the bargaining table Wednesday for a 12-hour session that produced modest movement, but nothing close to a final deal.

headline: A Deco Moment
text: Among the unexplained trends to appear with some regularity in the spring 2012 runway shows — aside from a preponderance of mesh — Art Deco took the cake. Frida Giannini was the biggest proponent of the streamlined 1920s look with her collection for Gucci, called “Hard Deco,” but there were echoes at Etro as well, and flappers could be found at Ralph Lauren and elsewhere. But why?

headline: RIM Critic Pushes Change, but His Sway Is in Doubt
text: TORONTO — With its stock down about 65 percent this year, Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry, has no shortage of unhappy shareholders. But few of its investors have sought and received as much attention over the past few months as Victor P. Alboini, the chairman and chief executive of Jaguar Financial.

headline: Excerpt: 'Milk Like Sugar'
text: A scene from Kirsten Greenidge's play at Playwrights Horizons. (Video courtesy of the theater.)

headline: Moderator for a Day
text: Earlier on I listed dozens of questions I’d love to hear asked during tonight’s Republican debate at Oakland University in Michigan. I also invited readers to chime in. Here’s a selection from the comments section. (N.B.: Some of these have been trimmed or edited for clarity. Links are to the original comments.)

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 54
text: Occupy Wall Street goes to Washington, with about two dozen protesters leaving Zuccotti Park on a two-week march to support a repeal of the Bush tax cuts. The marchers are posting on Twitter feverishly, of course:

headline: The Horror Show at Penn State
text: Gail Collins: David, I can’t get over the horror show at Penn State. I wish I knew more about football so I could make some smart comments about the meaning of Joe Paterno. But all I can think about is: If you’re the coach and you hear that a man is hurting a kid in the shower, this was not the moment to send a report up the chain of command.

headline: For a Family of Israeli Settlers, Eviction Before Salvation
text: To whom does the West Bank belong?

headline: Separating Royal Myth From Fact
text: IRVINGTON, N.Y. — Robert K. Massie’s new book, a biography of Catherine the Great, is out this week, and although Mr. Massie is 82, he is already thinking ahead to his next one. “There are all these things I want to do when I don’t have to finish a book,” he said last week, sitting in the upstairs study at his home here in Westchester County. “But I have to keep writing because I keep having children.”

headline: Exercise Alternatives to Boot Camp
text: If boot camp isn’t your bag, try some of New York’s other fall fitness offerings.

headline: Boot Camps Vie to Make You Sweat
text: SINCE June, New Yorkers have been paying for the privilege of doing sprints and hills on treadmills, alternated with weightlifting, to the blare of nightclub music in a mirror-lined Chelsea studio. The class is Barry’s Bootcamp, a West Hollywood staple that migrated east in search of a wider audience, much like Spinning before it. The cost is $285 for 10 hourlong sessions, compared with $165 at the original outpost — this despite the absence of the instructor Barry Jay, a founder of the company with John Mumford, the chief executive, and his wife, Rachel Mumford, the president.

headline: Hedi Slimane, at the Top of His Game, Again
text: Mr. Slimane seems to have left fashion behind with nary a second thought, reinventing himself as a photographer.

headline: In Charlotte Gainsbourg, Indifference and Whispers Prove Alluring
text: STANDING near her co-star Alexander Skarsgard, Charlotte Gainsbourg looked every bit the glamorous French star ready to seduce America. Her dark brown mane was sexily volumized, her eyes were rimmed in kohl, and she wore a simple black silk jersey, strappy high heels and pleated, silver-spangled trousers — all by Balenciaga, the French fashion house for which she is a muse.

headline: Fire Prompts Partial Evacuation at Bronx Hospital
text: Updated 6:55 p.m. | A fire in the boiler room at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx on Wednesday afternoon shut down two emergency rooms and two intensive care units, prompting a partial evacuation but causing no serious injuries or deaths.

headline: A Monitor of Health, Worn Lightly
text: Maybe you’ve heard. We Americans are not, ahem, the very models of physical fitness. We’re overweight, underexercised and underslept.

headline: Returning to a Renovated Stage, Exuding a Dash of Modernity
text: For just this one week, American Ballet Theater is presenting itself as modern, up to date, adventurous — if not by all standards, then by those of most ballet companies. Returning for the first time in three years to New York City Center, newly renovated, it’s dancing a different assortment of four or five works in each program, totaling nine in all. Seven of these are by four famous American choreographers from nonballet backgrounds — Merce Cunningham, Paul Taylor, Twyla Tharp and Martha Clarke — and five of them do not involve pointwork. Only some of Ballet Theater’s usual stars are involved; a good many of the company’s soloist and corps dancers are being given individual opportunities. The season avoids the standard ballet clichés of familiar stories and displays of conventionally bravura technique. The emphasis is on freshness and contemporaneity.

headline: Public Opinion and the Occupy Movement
text: What are your thoughts about the movement? Do you agree with the protesters methods?

headline: Samurai Shopper | The Razor’s Edgy
text: Samurai Shopping often depends on serendipity: wanting nothing, needing less, one stumbles across a jewel of a thing, and stuff-lust suddenly sparks your amygdala. “Youth & Beauty: the Art of America in the 20s” is an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum (till Jan. 29) full of low-key charms and even some revelations. Take Gerald Murphy’s 1924 painting “Razor”: a vividly rendered matchbox, Parker fountain pen, and Gillette safety razor, looking so fresh and modern, and yet, it’s an elegy to everyday tools beautifully rendered but quaint in today’s plastic, junk-tastic universe.

headline: A Familiar Site for Bachmann’s Foreign Policy Speech
text: Attention campaign advance teams: Looking for a photo opportunity for a foreign policy speech? Need to project strength and military preparedness? Bonus if it is in an early primary state?

headline: Cain Camp Turns Google Searches to Its Benefit
text: Searching Google for information about “Cain Sharon Bialek” and other keywords related to the sexual harassment allegations against Herman Cain?

headline: 2 Stars Spice Up Verismo Opera
text: From the packed house at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night for the Opera Orchestra of New York’s concert performance of Cilea’s “Adriana Lecouvreur,” and from the ecstatic ovations for the soprano Angela Gheorghiu and the tenor Jonas Kaufmann, the evening’s stars, you would not have guessed that two years ago it looked as if this valuable company might go under.

headline: Cisco’s Quarterly Results Beat Analysts’ Estimates
text: SAN FRANCISCO — John T. Chambers, chief executive of Cisco Systems, said Wednesday that he had largely completed the task of reshaping the company, a maker of the gear that runs the Internet.

headline: Note to Self: Remember to Read This Article
text: Like a lot of people in the ’80s, I bought a microcassette recorder to capture great ideas the way Michael Keaton’s character did in “Night Shift.” (“Idea to eliminate garbage: edible paper.”)

headline: For Beethoven and Eliot, Missed Connections
text: The connection between Beethoven’s String Quartet No. 15 (Op. 132) and T. S. Eliot’s poem cycle “Four Quartets” seems undeniable.

headline: A Three-Bedroom Town House With Skylights in Southwest London
text: A three-bedroom town house in Ramsden Gate, in Southwest London, is on the market for 1 million pounds ($1.6 million.)

headline: Spinning Gold
text: Hip clubgoing fans of the D.J. known as Kaskade might be surprised to learn that he is a 40-year-old former Mormon missionary who does not drink.

headline: Parsing Many Forces in Nature
text: The world is suddenly upside-down. Or at least it feels a little that way with all the Australian dance in New York these days. Last week the Australian Ballet performed at City Center as part of the Fall for Dance Festival, and Chunky Move, a contemporary troupe, appeared at the Joyce Theater. On Tuesday evening the Joyce hosted another group, Sydney Dance Company, making its return to the theater under its still-relatively new artistic director, Rafael Bonachela.

headline: How Ryan Raddon Became the $200,000-a-Night D.J. Known as Kaskade
text: “KASKADE is actually God,” said Ivy Daniels, 23, waiting in line at the Roseland Ballroom near Times Square at around 9 p.m. It was a few nights before Halloween, and her rave-girl costume — black tutu, kandi bracelets — was ambiguously self-referential. Was she going to a rave?

headline: House Hunting in ... London
text: A THREE-BEDROOM TOWN HOUSE WITH SKYLIGHTS IN SOUTHWEST LONDON

headline: The Game Will Go On for the Nittany Lions, but Sports Books Struggle to Set the Odds
text: LAS VEGAS — Oddsmakers rely on precedent to help them set wagering lines and anticipate betting action for sporting events. Over the years, games have been played under so many circumstances and in so many different conditions that there is almost always something to look back upon for guidance.

headline: Sources Say EMI Sale Will Split Company in Two
text: EMI, the storied music company that is home to the Beatles, Pink Floyd and Coldplay, is nearing a sale that would split the company in half.

headline: Gmail’s New Look: Easier to Read, Easier to Use
text: Sometimes, less really is a lot more.

headline: A Fashion Designer’s Second Act
text: WHEN Hedi Slimane stepped down as artistic director at Dior Homme in 2007, Fashion Wire Daily summed up his tenure this way: “Slimane leaves Dior with the well-earned reputation as the single most influential men’s designer this century, the most copied of his peers and the only one to achieve the status of a rock star.”

headline: Defiance With a Demure Smile and Tunes of the ’60s and ’70s
text: As Maureen McGovern sang a forceful rendition of Jonatha Brooke’s ballad “The Angel in the House” on Tuesday evening at Birdland, I had a vision of Ms. McGovern as the traditionally perfect woman and the pop-jazz singer rolled into one, and the limitations of perfection.

headline: Power Envy
text: WHEN the snowstorm hit a week ago Saturday, Evan Sidel was driving home from the supermarket, having stocked up on soup ingredients, thinking she and her two daughters would have a cozy evening in. But while she was unpacking the groceries, the power went out with an audible bang, said Ms. Sidel, who lives in a 100-year-old farmhouse in Wilton, Conn.

headline: Keystone XL’s Cousin Shuts Down Twice
text: The company proposing a contested oil pipeline that would stretch from Canada to the Texas Gulf Coast had a related pipeline that it operates shut down over the last two days after the line experienced power problems.

headline: Study Finds Signs of Awareness in 3 ‘Vegetative’ Patients
text: Three severely brain-injured people thought to be in an irreversible “vegetative” state showed signs of full consciousness when tested with a relatively inexpensive and commonly used method of measuring brain waves, doctors reported Wednesday. Experts said the findings, if replicated, would change standards in treating such patients.

headline: The People Have Spoken, and They Have Spoken for Beckett
text: It was a late, tense night at Sentence of the Week headquarters. We were up well past midnight counting election results. Our chief statistician had a nervous breakdown just before dawn, and at some point one of the interns managed to lose her engagement ring in the coffee machine. It was, in other words, another wild ride on the unbroken horse of democracy.

headline: Russia Dismisses Calls for New U.N. Sanctions on Iran
text: MOSCOW — Russia on Wednesday sharply dismissed calls for further sanctions against Iran in the aftermath of a new United Nations report on suspect Iranian nuclear activities, signaling the Kremlin’s departure from the cooperation on Iran that was a hallmark of the “reset” in relations with the United States.

headline: Programming for Children, Minus Cryptic Syntax
text: When Howard Abrams, a software engineer in Beaverton, Ore., wanted to teach his daughter, now 10, and son, now 8, how to program computers, he thought of the fun he had playing with Logo, the first programming language he learned.

headline: Another Service Interruption for BlackBerrys
text: 8:09 p.m. | Updated  Adding RIM saying that service is back to normal.

headline: Coping With the Flies of Fall
text: NEARLY a million people live alone in New York City, according to Census Bureau figures. And at one time or another, almost all of them have probably had the same thought: if I die unexpectedly tonight, watching an episode of “The Millionaire Matchmaker,” who will find the body?

headline: Cork Furniture From Portugal
text: Ana Mestre, 33, a Portuguese furniture designer interested in sustainability, has been researching the uses of cork since 2004. “It grows as the bark of a tree,” she said. “You can extract it without damaging the tree, and every nine years, you can extract again. You keep the forest, the biodiversity and the eco-system.”

headline: Moroso Plans a North American Pop-Up
text: Over the coming year, the Italian furniture company Moroso will present a traveling road show with a pop-up showroom and exhibition making stops across North America.

headline: Sales at Green Depot, Denyse Schmidt and Others

headline: Todd Oldham’s ‘Alexander Girard’
text: At 672 pages and a hefty 15 pounds, “Alexander Girard” ($200; Ammo Books), by Todd Oldham and Kiera Coffee, might appear to be a catalog raisonné featuring all of the prolific designer’s textiles, graphics, illustrations, furniture, interiors, products and buildings.

headline: Cranbrook Art Museum Reopens
text: The designer Charles Eames studied at the Cranbrook Academy of Art in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and Harry Bertoia taught there. The Cranbrook Art Museum owns works by both men, including one of the largest collections of Mr. Bertoia’s monoprints. But what’s the point if no one can see them?

headline: Roz Chast Brings Her Characters to Fishs Eddy
text: October has never been one of Roz Chast’s favorite months. The New Yorker cartoonist, who has made a career out of anatomizing anxiety, is particularly skittish around Halloween, which her husband, the fiction writer Bill Franzen, celebrates with gusto, in an annual spectacle involving a guillotine, severed hands, scented smoke machines and multitudes of other props, on their Ridgefield, Conn., front lawn. In recent years, though, he has scaled back the production, from 26 tableaus to just eight, she said.

headline: When the Neighbors Are Renzo Piano and Philip Johnson Icons

headline: Retail Site Raids a Big Closet
text: SINCE its debut in February, Moda Operandi, the online retailer that sells designer clothes right off the runway, has become a surprise competitor on the lucrative trunk show circuit. During the September fashion shows, for example, the average transaction on the site reached $1,800, and one customer, on a single visit, spent $42,000 on clothes that won’t be available in other stores until spring.

headline: Thursday Matchup: Raiders at Chargers
text: Raiders (4-4) at Chargers (4-4), Thursday, 8:20 p.m. Eastern, NFL NetworkLine: Chargers by 6.

headline: Liu Delays Giving Names of Campaign Fund-Raisers
text: John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, is declining to reveal the identities of the people who raise money for his campaign, despite a pledge several weeks ago to do so after reports of irregularities in his fund-raising operation.

headline: A Treehouse Grows in Brooklyn
text: “I THINK everyone has this special place in their brain — a primal nostalgia — for a treehouse,” said Alexandra Meyn, bundled up in a sweater on a recent afternoon inside the airy perch she built behind her garden apartment in Brooklyn. “People’s eyes light up when you tell them you have a treehouse.”

headline: A Treehouse in Bed-Stuy
text: Secured to an old mulberry, a backyard treehouse mixes refined and bohemian elements.

headline: Michigan Governor Warns Candidates on Auto Bailout
text: ROCHESTER, Mich. – Gov. Rick Snyder, a Republican, offered a word of warning on Wednesday to his party’s field of presidential candidates: don’t spend time trashing the bailout of the auto industry.

headline: Bar Stools
text: MICHAEL BARRETT has worked as a New York City police officer, an antiques dealer and an exterminator, doing some of those jobs simultaneously. He has also owned several bars, including Chelsea Central, which opened on 10th Avenue in 1980, where the Red Cat restaurant is now, and the once-hot China Club, which he sold last year.

headline: Despite Tepid Ratings, ‘Anderson’ Nears Renewal
text: Anderson Cooper’s two-month-old talk show was effectively renewed for a second season on Wednesday when several big station owners said they had signed up for another year.

headline: On Location | Berlin
text: Christoph Roedig and Uli Schop live in a duplex in the 10-unit co-op building they designed in Berlin’s Mitte neighborhood.

headline: Angels Rushing In Where Others Fear to Tread
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — Angels are not a common sight here in Mexico’s most violent border city, where the public cemetery is putrid and overflowing, and where a handful of churches worship the skeletal saint of death, Santa Muerte.

headline: A Showpiece of Communal Living in Berlin
text: BERLIN — One day in 2002, the architect Christoph Roedig and his partner in business and life Uli Schop were biking through what was then an ungentrified corner of Berlin’s Mitte neighborhood, on a street not far from where the Berlin Wall once divided the city. World War II-era bombings had knocked down 19th- and early-20th-century housing developments in that part of the former East Germany. Though the former East German government had cleared away the rubble, they had never rebuilt.

headline: Judge Picks Monitor to Oversee Minority Hiring by the Fire Department
text: Five weeks after issuing a ruling that called the New York Fire Department a “stubborn bastion of white male privilege” based on its unsuccessful efforts at racial integration, a judge on Wednesday named a monitor to oversee the department’s minority recruitment and hiring.

headline: One by One, Marketers Plan for a Singular Event
text: MARKETERS are betting on a daily numbers game again, taking advantage of a calendar coincidence to drum up interest in their goods and services.

headline: N.H.L.’s Revised Rule Gives Referees an Option
text: The Ottawa captain, Daniel Alfredsson, had just passed the puck on Oct. 29 when he collided with the Rangers’ Wojtek Wolski, who lifted his elbow reflexively as Alfredsson’s head hit Wolski’s arm. Alfredsson went down in a heap and lay flat on the Madison Square Garden ice before being helped off to be treated for a concussion.

headline: Somali Lawmaker Killed in Mogadishu Shooting
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — A Somali lawmaker was gunned down on a Mogadishu street on Wednesday, a day after four explosions in several neighborhoods of Somalia’s capital killed at least one person and injured several more, including government soldiers.

headline: Ohio Vote on Labor Is Parsed for Omens
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The landslide vote to repeal an Ohio law that limits collective bargaining has sounded a strong note of caution for Republican governors and lawmakers across the country, raising questions about some of their legislative efforts, especially those that would weaken labor unions. But the victory, while trumpeted by labor leaders, may not necessarily improve the prospects of unions or the Democrats, their traditional allies, in 2012, political analysts said.

headline: O’Malley Interested in Owning the Dodgers Again

headline: An Unruly Election Campaign Mirrors Congo’s Lingering Political Instability
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — First, Cmdr. Ntabo Ntaberi Sheka ordered his militia to join an attack on a group of villages in eastern Congo, where the fighters gang-raped at least 387 women, men, girls and boys, according to a United Nations report of the atrocities.

headline: Mets Could Go From Bad to Dreadful
text: We are conditioned to think of the American League East as baseball’s superpower division. The Yankees and the Boston Red Sox spend lavishly. The Tampa Bay Rays have made three playoff appearances in the past four seasons. The Toronto Blue Jays have stockpiled young talent and are expected to spend when the time is right.

headline: Are We a Democracy?

text: At 2 p.m. Eastern time on Wednesday, during the first nationwide test of the Emergency Alert System, all television channels and radio stations in the United States were supposed to be interrupted by piercing emergency tones. Not a song by Lady Gaga.

text: In 1998, the Penn State campus police and local law enforcement authorities investigated an allegation that Jerry Sandusky, then a prominent coach with the university’s football team, had engaged in inappropriate and perhaps sexual conduct with a boy in the football facility’s showers.

text: The athletic director and an assistant football coach at the University of Central Florida resigned Wednesday amid an N.C.A.A. investigation into illicit recruiting practices tied to a man identified by the N.C.A.A. as a recruiter for a sports agent.

headline: L.I. Inquiry on Cheating Now Covers Five Schools
text: The Nassau County district attorney’s office has broadened its inquiry into suspected cheating on college admissions exams to at least 35 students in five schools, including students believed to have paid for a stand-in to take the ACT, a standardized test that is growing in popularity in the Northeast, as well as the more common SAT.

headline: Don’t Book That Trip Just Yet. Mercury Will Be in Retrograde.

headline: Giants Thrive on Manning’s Late-Game Poise

headline: Ed Macauley, Basketball Hall of Famer, Dies at 83
text: Ed Macauley was voted the national college basketball player of the year in 1949 and the most valuable player in the N.B.A.’s first All-Star Game in 1951. The second-highest-paid player in the N.B.A. in the early 1950s, he made the all-star team in 7 of his 10 pro seasons.

headline: Panel Is at Impasse, but Obama Sees No Reason to Step In
text: WASHINGTON — The White House’s expectations for the special Congressional committee on deficit reduction, never high, have been all but dashed now that the panel has reached a partisan impasse less than two weeks before it is supposed to recommend a compromise plan.

headline: Superseding Indictment Against Larry Seabrook
text: A superseding indictment stated that Larry Seabrook solicited a stream of checks from Arlington Leon Eastmond, totaling about $50,000, most of which went to a political club with which Mr. Seabrook was affiliated.

headline: Seeking a Cure for Troubled Hospitals in Brooklyn
text: When the pain in his groin was too great to bear, Ralph Hutchins, who works as a mover, headed to the crowded emergency room at the nearest hospital one recent Tuesday, his life at risk. Tanya Boynton, a mother of four who works 12-hour shifts, hobbled into another emergency room from a homeless shelter, afraid illness would end her job.

headline: Corporate Japan Rocked by Scandal at Olympus
text: TOKYO — In June 1998, a disturbing rumor tore through trading floors in Tokyo: Olympus had suffered colossal losses on derivatives trading, punching a large hole in its balance sheet. The company’s shares spiraled down 11 percent in three days.

headline: An Aspiring Coach in the Middle of a Scandal
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — When Mike McQueary went to Penn State Coach Joe Paterno’s house on the morning of March 2, 2002, he was a graduate assistant — the lowest rung on the coaching ladder beneath Paterno. Still, McQueary, 28 years old and a football lifer, had aspirations of one day becoming a head coach, maybe even at Penn State.

headline: Tighter Controls on Market Funds
text: American money market funds have played a supporting role in the euro zone crisis: they are short-term lenders to European banks. Before that, they lent to the likes of Lehman Brothers.

headline: Back to Common Sense at the Polls
text: It might have been “too much too soon,” a chastened Gov. John Kasich of Ohio admitted on Tuesday night, after his state’s voters overwhelmingly rejected his attempt to break public employee unions. He certainly was right about “too much,” an analysis that also applies to other examples of Republican overreach around the country that were kicked into the gutter: an anti-abortion amendment in Mississippi, a voting restriction in Maine, the radical anti-immigrant agenda of a politician in Arizona.

headline: The Truth About Iran
text: Tehran was in full dudgeon on Wednesday, denouncing the International Atomic Energy Agency — calling its top inspector a Washington stooge — after it reported that Iran’s scientists had pursued secret activities “relevant to the development of a nuclear device.” The agency did not back down, and neither should anyone else.

headline: Google’s Chief Works to Trim a Bloated Ship
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Larry Page, Google’s chief executive, so hates wasting time at meetings that he once dumped his secretary to avoid being scheduled for them. He does not much like e-mail either — even his own Gmail — saying the tedious back-and-forth takes too long to solve problems.

headline: Checkpoints: A U.S. Veteran in Baghdad
text: ‘Checkpoint, Sorry’

headline: Euro Fears Spread to Italy as the Debt Crisis Deepens
text: PARIS — Since the start of the euro crisis two years ago, the big fear has been contagion, that market unease about the high debt and slow growth in Europe’s southern rim would infect the core. On Wednesday, contagion arrived with brute force.

headline: After Losing Their Father, Finding Small Ways to Cope

headline: My Second-Rate Red Carpet
text: When I moved to Los Angeles to write for “The Tonight Show with Conan O’Brien” in 2009, I was careful not to offend the locals. I’d heard many stories of New Yorkers relocating to Los Angeles, only to bemoan the inferior bagels, early bar curfews and glaring absence of public transportation. Not me, though.

headline: Sherman’s Demons
text: By the end of the Civil War, William T. Sherman was one of the most important and celebrated Union commanders, and the most reviled in the Confederacy. During the last year of the conflict, his army conquered Atlanta, reversing a flagging Union war effort and securing Abraham Lincoln’s re-election. After that his men scorched much of Georgia in his famous March to the Sea, then cut a huge swath up through the Carolinas. Not only did his army destroy men and material, but Sherman articulated a ruthless policy of destruction that deeply demoralized Southern morale. He gained perpetual infamy in the South as the grim reaper of the Union war effort, a task he undertook quite consciously, with both anger and joy.

headline: Taking Aim at Internet Rules
text: The Senate is expected to vote on Thursday on a resolution that would stop the Federal Communications Commission from enforcing rules that prohibit Internet service providers from discriminating against the transmission of content that might compete with their own.

headline: Cain’s Lawyer on Accusing: ‘Think Twice’
text: L. Lin Wood, the lawyer hired by the Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain to fend off sexual harassment accusations, has warned that any other women who might be considering coming forward with similar allegations “should think twice.”

headline: Do You Need a Place to Stay? Can You Prove It?
text: Ask about home, and Calvin Miller points to a soot-gray hulk of a former psychiatric hospital on East 30th Street, where dead vines run like varicose veins up the brick.

headline: Jets Rediscover Their Center
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Many interviews with Nick Mangold begin with a smile and some sarcasm, and so it was on Wednesday afternoon when he was asked how his right ankle felt.

headline: A Bad Ruling on Cigarette Warnings
text: A Federal District Court judge in the District of Columbia has blocked new regulations requiring tobacco companies to put large graphic warnings on cigarette packages. If his ruling stands, the government will not be able to warn against the hazards of smoking in a way that’s actually noticed.

headline: After Chef’s Hitler Remark, Bankers Change Lunch Plans
text: Del Posto and Babbo have the same celebrity chef as an owner, reputations for impossible-to-get reservations, and customers who can afford, say, Del Posto’s seven-course “menu tradizionale” at $145 a person. It is not unreasonable to imagine that a good number of those customers make a living on Wall Street.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Hal Bruno, Director of Election Coverage at ABC, Dies at 83
text: Hal Bruno, who helped shape political coverage at ABC News for nearly two decades and was a frequent analyst on its radio and television broadcasts, died on Tuesday, Election Day, in Bethesda, Md. He was 83. The cause was heart arrhythmia after a fall, his son Harold III said.

headline: Piers Morgan to Leave Talent Show
text: Piers Morgan, the host of a prime time interview show on CNN and a judge on a prime time talent show on NBC, said Wednesday night that he was quitting the latter of the two.

headline: Parks Chief Blocked Plan for Grand Canyon Bottle Ban
text: Weary of plastic litter, Grand Canyon National Park officials were in the final stages of imposing a ban on the sale of disposable water bottles in the Grand Canyon late last year when the nation’s parks chief abruptly blocked the plan after conversations with Coca-Cola, a major donor to the National Park Foundation.

headline: A Clash of Titans Exposes Russia’s Seamy Underside
text: LONDON — In one corner sits Oligarch No. 1, Boris A. Berezovsky, beefy, pugnacious, litigious, voluble, intent on revenge. In the other sits his erstwhile associate and current archenemy, Oligarch No. 2, Roman A. Abramovich, trim, reserved, terse, angry, extremely rich and extremely unhappy about being here.

headline: Man Not Charged for Shooting After His Son Was Wounded
text: The first shot went straight up in the air. The second one struck Bobby Baltazar’s 4-year-old son, Cincere, in the chest as the father was returning the boy to his mother’s home.

headline: Italian Bond Yields Soar
text: Italy’s benchmark 10-year bond yield soared above 7 percent in market trading Wednesday. Such high levels led to bailouts of Greece, Ireland and Portugal.

headline: Quake Kills at Least 3 in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — A 5.6-magnitude earthquake on Wednesday in the same region hit by a larger quake two weeks ago killed at least three people and trapped others who had moved into damaged buildings that collapsed Wednesday, the Turkish media reported.

headline: Witness Says Councilman Never Asked for Kickbacks
text: A key prosecution witness in the corruption trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook had been expected to testify that Mr. Seabrook had solicited kickbacks. But the witness appeared to surprise prosecutors on Wednesday when he said that Mr. Seabrook had not.

headline: Thursday: Fills, as Black Squares
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — O.K., let’s get this one out of our systems right from the start: yes, we all loved the Patrick Berry suite of puzzles featured in the “Crossing” Words contest a few weeks ago.

headline: Inside the Whirlwind Set Spinning by War
text: Portraying an eccentric Austrian artist in the new musical “The Blue Flower” at Second Stage Theater, Marc Kudisch performs the challenging feat of singing several snatches of song in a made-up language created by his character, Max. It’s called Maxperanto, and it’s incomprehensible, naturally, although the talented Mr. Kudisch sings it with the same expressive gusto he brings to the rest of his performance. Unfortunately these moments of sweetly sung gibberish are not the only ones in this high-minded muddle of a musical that may leave you scratching your head.

headline: ‘The Blue Flower’
text: Photos from the musical at Second Stage.

headline: Learning from Phung, and Helping Her
text: My Thursday column argues that we need to absorb more of an education culture, like the one so common in the Confucian belt of East Asia. I make the argument partly through the story of a teenage girl named Phung who won my heart with her amazing work ethic and vaulting ambition. I’m pretty sure that I’ll be deluged with readers who want to help Phung, and so an aid group named Room to Read — the subject of my Sunday article about it and its founder, John Wood — has set up a fund to help Phung and girls like her. You can find out more at its website here.

headline: Alabama Governor Fails to Prevent County’s Record $4 Billion Bankruptcy Filing
text: Last-ditch efforts by the governor of Alabama to prevent a record-breaking municipal bankruptcy in his state broke down on Wednesday, as the Jefferson County Commission voted 4 to 1 to declare bankruptcy on roughly $4 billion of debt.

headline: Russians Fight to Save Mars Probe After Mishap
text: Russian space engineers scrambled Wednesday to salvage an ambitious science mission to Mars after the unmanned spacecraft became stranded in Earth orbit. If they are not successful, the probe, which is loaded with toxic fuel, could re-enter the atmosphere within days or weeks.

headline: Panel Votes to Reduce a Forage Fish Catch
text: BOSTON — A fishing oversight group voted Wednesday to sharply reduce the allowable East Coast catch of menhaden, an oily forage fish that does not show up on dinner plates but is vital, scientists say, to the ocean ecosystem.

headline: GPS Units So Faulty, They Showed Fire Trucks in New York Harbor
text: The Bloomberg administration spent millions of dollars to put custom-made GPS tracking units in fire and garbage trucks, only to have vehicles inexplicably show up on computer screens as if they had sunk to the bottom of Long Island Sound or New York Harbor, the city comptroller has found.

headline: Cuomo Calls Vote Results ‘Big Victory’ for New York
text: Facing an increasingly worrisome budget and eager for additional political allies, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Wednesday celebrated Democratic triumphs in several important local government races, calling the election results “a big victory for the people of the state.”

headline: Air Force Mortuary Sent Troop Remains to Landfill
text: WASHINGTON — The mortuary at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware disposed of some body parts of the nation’s war dead from 2003 to 2008 by burning them and dumping the ashes in a Virginia landfill, an Air Force official said on Wednesday. The practice has since been stopped and the ashes are now put in urns and buried at sea.

headline: Database on Doctor Discipline Is Restored, With Restrictions
text: A federal health agency on Wednesday restored to its Web site a database of doctor disciplinary actions two months after removing it from the Internet in response to a doctor’s complaints.

text: Few coaches ever attained the level of success and longevity that Joe Paterno enjoyed at Penn State.

In her handwriting are the words: “Cereal, tea, soap.” Following on the list, in sloppy kid’s scrawl: “Ice cream, cookies, plastic soldiers” — with all the S’s reversed.

headline: After ‘Oops’ in Debate, Perry Says He’ll Stay in Race
text: ROCHESTER, Mich. —   A day after an embarrassing stumble raised new questions about his presidential candidacy, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said Thursday that he had no intention of leaving the race, and he tried using humor to deflect a fresh round of stinging Republican criticism.

headline: Lou Maletta, Gay-Television Pioneer, Dies at 74
text: Lou Maletta, who founded the Gay Cable Network in 1982, when the gay rights movement was not receiving broad media attention, died on Nov. 2 in Kingston, N.Y. He was 74.

text: The Republican candidates for president gathered in Michigan on Wednesday night for a 90-minute exchange that mostly focused on economic issues.

headline: The Role of Regulation in Holding Back Business
text: In Wednesday night’s Republican debate on the economy, Herman Cain suggested that the chief problem holding back companies was regulatory uncertainty. Other candidates, including Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, have made similar claims about regulatory burdens.

headline: Perry’s Other Debate Mistake
text: With pundits lining up post-debate to declare Rick Perry’s oops-I-forgot-one-of-the-agencies-I-would-get-rid-of gaffe disastrous for his once high-flying candidacy, another flubbed line was largely overlooked.

headline: A Rebound in Europe, Followed by the U.S.

headline: Alan Mootnick, Who Studied and Gave a Home to Gibbons, Dies at 60
text: Alan Mootnick once said he felt a certain kinship with gibbons, a small, acrobatic and endangered member of the ape family. Like them, he said, “I was lean, agile and comical.”

headline: As Stocks Fall, Art Surges at a $315.8 Million Sale
text: Despite (or perhaps because of) the stock market’s nearly 400-point plunge, on Wednesday night collectors raced to put their available cash — and lots of it — into art.

headline: Is Perry Toast?
text: Almost immediately after what will probably be remembered as the Bill Buckner moment of primary debates, when Gov. Rick Perry  of Texas literally forgot which governmental agencies he would cut and concluded his answer with a sheepish “Oops,” Mr. Perry’s stock on the betting market Intrade dropped in half. Tabbed as having about a 9 percent chance of winning the Republican nomination before the debate, the market revised his odds downward to 4 percent just moments after the gaffe.

headline: Obama Cuts $4 Billion, Then Uses It Elsewhere
text: WASHINGTON — Cutting wasteful government spending is one of those exercises that even the most ardent political opponents agree is a good thing. But what one does with those savings is quite another matter.

headline: David Utz, Surgeon Who Removed Reagan’s Prostate, Dies at 87
text: Dr. David C. Utz, a prominent urological surgeon at the Mayo Clinic who drew wide attention when he performed prostate surgery on President Ronald Reagan in 1987, died on Oct. 30 in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 87.

headline: Honoring Ernie Pyle, Hometown Hero and the Grunts’ Bard
text: Two years ago, the state of Indiana cut off funds to a museum in Dana, Ind., that honors Ernie Pyle, the acclaimed war correspondent. A local group is now managing the site, which still has a lot to offer.

headline: Gunman Wounds Nurse and Guard at Bronx Hospital
text: A man pulled out a gun and fired at least one shot in a waiting area at a hospital in the Bronx on Wednesday night, injuring a nurse and a security guard, the police said.

headline: Justices Likely to Overturn California Law Against Slaughtering ‘Downer’ Animals
text: WASHINGTON — A California law that seeks to keep animals that are unable to walk out of the food supply seemed unlikely to survive scrutiny from the Supreme Court, judging from the justices’ questions during arguments on Wednesday.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Four-Star Vegetables From Eleven Madison Park

We love the look of these Butternut Squash Cannoli from chef Daniel Humm, who modified his recipe for Well to make it vegetarian by omitting the gelatin. A note of caution: For the truly ambitious cook — the kind who keeps N2O cartridges in their kitchen.

headline: Wal-Mart to Start Its Sales at 10 P.M. on Thanksgiving
text: With major retailers, including Kohl’s, Macy’s, Target and Best Buy, saying they will open at midnight on Thanksgiving this year to offer holiday deals, Wal-Mart is trying to do them one better. It is expected to announce Thursday that it will start deals at 10 p.m. on Thanksgiving Day nationwide.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press on Thursday
text: The Gujarat riot decision dominated headlines Thursday, with The Hindu calling it the “First Whiff of Justice” for riot victims. Thirty-one people were convicted on Wednesday of murder and sentenced to life in prison for their involvement in the violence and arson that killed 33 Muslims, mostly women and children, one evening in March of 2002. “Almost all the accused were Patels, people who owned land in the village, while the victims were mostly laborers in their own farms,” The Indian Express writes in a recap of the events. As riots in the village escalated, Muslim men “herded their women, children and elders into the locality’s only concrete house,” the paper writes. “Inside the 10 foot-by-12 foot room in which they were cramped, bales of cotton were stacked. The rioters doused these bales in oil, locked the house from the outside and set it on fire.”

text: In politics, certain things are not supposed to happen: Liberals never reject a tax increase. Conservatives always favor the strongest anti-immigration leader. And big corporations can’t really buy an election because voters see through them.

headline: CMA Winners Look Familiar, With Minor Disruptions

That would be Taylor Swift, the pop phenom, who outmuscled her competition on the heels of her triple-platinum album “Speak Now” (Big Machine).

headline: Penn State Students Take to the Streets After Paterno Is Fired
text: Thousands of Penn State students and others took to the streets in State College, Pa., on Wednesday night after the university’s board announced that Joe Paterno, the 84-year-old head football coach who had led the team for 46 years, had been fired in the wake of a child sex-abuse scandal involving a former assistant coach. The university’s president, Graham B. Spanier, also stepped down.

headline: Recall Election Claims Arizona Anti-Immigration Champion

headline: Princeton Is Swamped in Early Applications
text: Princeton, along with Harvard, canceled its early-admission program four years ago to delay the beginning of the annual frenzy of applicants hoping to secure a precious seat in the next freshman class. But when none of their main competitors followed suit, both institutions announced in February that they would once again offer applicants an opportunity to apply in November, two months before the regular deadline.

headline: Supporters of P.S. 161 Ask for More Time

headline: Remembering Mr. Geller
text: Stuyvesant High School held a memorial for Richard Geller, a beloved math teacher who died last week. Friends and colleagues told stories of his many interests. But his son, Jason Geller, said his father was a teacher through and through. On the night he died, he said: “He looked up at me and said, ‘Take one and pass it down, take one and pass it down; are there any questions?' ”

headline: TransCanada Shuts Pipeline After Troubles With Power
text: The company proposing a controversial oil pipeline that would stretch from Canada to the Gulf Coast had a related pipeline shut down twice this week after it experienced power problems. The company, TransCanada, said that its Keystone pipeline, which runs from Alberta to Cushing, Okla., went down for three hours on Tuesday after a Canadian utility that powers the pipeline dealt with shortages. It shut it down again on Tuesday night to inspect equipment, but restarted it on Wednesday morning after finding nothing amiss, the company said. “Nothing was related to the safety of the pipeline or compromised the safety of the pipeline in any way,” a company spokesman said. The interruptions were ill timed for TransCanada, which is in the midst of a bitter battle over whether its proposed Keystone XL line will be approved by the State Department. Opponents of the pipeline, which would carry Canadian oil sands crude, are increasing efforts to have it rejected or rerouted amid concerns that a spill could damage the Ogallala Aquifer in Nebraska. And the State Department’s inspector general agreed this week to look into assertions that an environmental review of the project was mishandled by the State Department because it was conducted by a company with financial ties to TransCanada.

headline: For Some Special Ed Students, Inclusion Is Deferred

Yet the city spends about $5 billion a year to educate students with special needs, more than a fifth of the total budget for schools. The city has been heavily criticized for spending so much money and getting such poor results. It is now trying to improve the way these students are educated. But going forward sometimes means taking a step back.

Given your stated opposition to the death penalty, why not focus on a man like Troy Davis, who might have been innocent?  What’s wrong about Truman Capote writing “In Cold Blood”? Did he need to prove the innocence of someone? Perry knew I was not in the business of guilt or innocence. Rick Perry of Texas. His very public, very awkward inability to come up with the name of a third federal agency he would like to eliminate was taken as a devastating error. headline: Lounge Act | Moss and Maharam
text: Talk about a makeover. Among the latest offerings at the SoHo design mecca Moss is this pair of vintage Eames Lounge Chairs, which Murray Moss decided to re-cover in Hella Jongerius’s Repeat Dot fabric from Maharam. The chairs (which have been manufactured by Herman Miller since 1956) have a built-in pedigree because they’re made with Brazilian rosewood veneer, the material that was originally specified by Charles and Ray Eames, but which was discontinued in 1992 when Brazilian rosewood landed on the endangered species list. Jongerius’s eye-popping fabric, however, is what really makes them — it takes a design icon from the “Mad Men” era and catapults it into the 21st century. (As with many Moss creations, these don’t come cheap: the chairs are $16,000 each, or $30,000 for the pair.) They’re just the first (or first two) in a planned series of one-off furniture pieces on which Moss and Maharam will collaborate. And for a glimpse of what other designs Maharam might bring to the project, see “Maharam Agenda” (Lars Müller Publishers), a new book on the innovative textile company by Michael Maharam, who has run the family-owned business with his brother, Stephen, since 1997. The book not only describes the brothers’ risk-taking design agenda, but it looks like an agenda, too, complete with a soft cover (an embroidered design by Jongerius) and woven bookmark — a tip-off right there that this isn’t going to be your average corporate coffee-table book.

headline: Thursday Reading: Home Generators Become Status Symbols

headline: Why Are College Students Defending Joe Paterno?
text: On Wednesday night I was watching ESPN’s coverage of the firing of Joe Paterno, the Penn State football coach (an event whose magnitude one announcer just compared indirectly to the Kennedy assassination), and wondering how I’d feel if my child was standing on Paterno’s lawn, or on the streets of State College, Pa., supporting a man who could hear a graphic description of a sexual assault on a young boy and then choose to walk away. I’d like to hear one of those students support the argument that the coach deserves “one more game.” And then I’d like them to tell me how they’d explain it to a 10-year-old.

headline: Leading Off: Campus Chaos on a Sorry but Necessary Day
text: At Penn State, the adults finally showed up. They had been long awaited and inexplicably slow, as the university devolved into a leaderless circus in the days after its sexual abuse scandal unfolded. Early Wednesday, Coach Joe Paterno was still calling his own shots, as if his moral authority had somehow survived the tsunami of a scandal fueled by his own inaction. When the Board of Trustees did the right thing Wednesday night — and really, firing Paterno and Graham B. Spanier, the university president, was the only thing it could do — the Paterno cult of personality tried to strike back. Students protested, clinging to the mythic hero they did not want unmasked.
