headline: Bankruptcy Rarely Offers Easy Answer for Counties
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — When Alabama’s Jefferson County filed for the largest municipal bankruptcy in American history this week, it looked a little like another domino had fallen.

headline: A Final Proposal, With Hopes of a Vote
text: With one final proposal and one last ultimatum, the N.B.A. put the wheels in motion Thursday for a delayed season that could begin Dec. 15, or perhaps not at all.

headline: After Downfall, Veteran Finds New Purpose
text: From his 12th-story window in the Bronx, Joseph Tomasello took in a panoramic view of the landscape by the evening light.

headline: To Save Our Economy, Ditch Taiwan
text: Washington

headline: Senate Approves Two Pieces of Jobs Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate overwhelmingly approved two elements of President Obama’s jobs bill on Thursday as members of a Congressional committee on deficit reduction struggled to overcome bitter partisan disputes over how much to raise taxes.

headline: Concerns Raised for Boys in Sandusky Case
text: A lawyer who is advising some of the young men who said they were sexually abused by Jerry Sandusky, a former assistant football coach at Penn State, said Thursday that the university did not take into account how the firing of the longtime coach Joe Paterno might affect the accusers.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Children’s Books on Tablets
text: Many children have become early adopters of touch-screen technology. They’ve taken to smartphones and tablets with ease. But what makes a good app for kids? Deborah Forte, the president of Scholastic Media, discusses how her publishing company approaches the app-creation process and what types of children’s books and characters adapt well to the transition from printed page to digital screen.

headline: Mexico: Trafficking Suspect Caught
text: The army said Thursday that it had detained a man whom the United States considers one of the most-wanted drug traffickers from Mexico. Mexican authorities describe the man, Ovidio Limón Sánchez, as a leader of the Sinaloa drug cartel, one of the largest and most powerful in Mexico. The United States, which accuses him of sending cocaine across the border, had offered a reward of up to $5 million for his capture. He was arrested Wednesday in the city of Culiacán and is expected to face extradition to the United States.

headline: In N.H.L., Disclosure of Concussions Is Lagging
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Concussions continued to cast a long shadow over the N.H.L. on Thursday.

headline: Cain on Camera Joking About Anita Hill
text: Watch the latest video at video.foxnews.com

headline: War Resonates Anew on Hallowed French Ground
text: CHÂTEAU-THIERRY, France — The remains of some of the last American doughboys of World War I to be identified were found just a few years ago, buried in a vegetable garden in this little town, wine bottles clasped in their crossed arms. They had died of their wounds in a field hospital set up in an adjoining farmhouse.

headline: Lottery Numbers
New to City, Statue Seeks Resting Place
text: One of the guest stars in the Veterans Day Parade on Friday is a 5,000-pound statue that just arrived in New York and still needs a permanent home.

headline: Friday: Happy 11/11/11!
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Today is a special day, and it’s not just because we have a new puzzle by wunderkind Alex Vratsanos to solve. If you remember, Mr. Vratsanos set himself a goal to have a crossword puzzle published in The New York Times before he graduated from high school, and he succeeded. His debut was on the day of his graduation ceremony. Now, he is a student at the University of Delaware and is back to help us celebrate another big day.

headline: The Inequality Map
text: Foreign tourists are coming up to me on the streets and asking, “David, you have so many different kinds of inequality in your country. How can I tell which are socially acceptable and which are not?”

headline: An End to China’s Real Estate Boom
text: Real estate transactions in China have slowed so quickly that thousands of brokers have been laid off and hundreds of offices have closed.

headline: A Master of Mass Flirtation
text: Hugh Jackman practices safe sex like nobody else. His sweet-and-hot new show “Hugh Jackman: Back on Broadway,” which opened on Thursday night at the Broadhurst Theater, is a great, guilt-free platonic one-night stand. O.K., so maybe the guy tends to run on about himself (his dreams, his job, his family, you know the drill) and cracks a few too many hokey jokes.

headline: McQueary Won’t Coach in Game vs. Nebraska
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — The Penn State assistant Mike McQueary will not coach against Nebraska on Saturday, the university said Thursday evening, because there had been “multiple threats” against him.

headline: Government Policies Cool China’s Real Estate Boom
text: SANYA, China — China’s nationwide real estate boom became so manic last year that many would-be buyers camped in tents on the sidewalks of this tropical island city to be at the front of the line when condominiums went on sale — even though the condos had not yet been built.

headline: Legends of the Fail
text: This is the way the euro ends — not with a bang but with bunga bunga. Not long ago, European leaders were insisting that Greece could and should stay on the euro while paying its debts in full. Now, with Italy falling off a cliff, it’s hard to see how the euro can survive at all.

headline: Of Kentucky
text: The photographer Shelby Lee Adams captures the people who live in a holler where he was raised in Hazard, Kentucky.

headline: City Delays Tighter Rules for Homeless People Seeking Shelter
text: Facing mounting criticism from the City Council and a lawsuit from advocates for the homeless, the Bloomberg administration on Thursday postponed until next month the imposition of tighter rules for homeless people seeking shelter.

headline: Now, Italy
text: There was nothing unpredictable about the financial crisis now threatening to engulf Italy and perhaps bring down the euro. Economists and analysts have been writing about it for months, but Italian politicians, starting with Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, did almost nothing to head it off. And European leaders like Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France did far too little to prepare for it.

headline: Posada’s Former Teammate Dissects His Own Path
text: Jorge Posada said earlier this week that his Yankees career was most definitely over.

headline: Unesco Trims Its Budget
text: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, known as Unesco, will trim its budget, restrict travel and publications, put all spending under review, and freeze any new projects between now and the end of the year after the United States withdrew its funding, its director general, Irina Bokova, said Thursday. Washington stopped providing funding, including about $65 million for the 2011 budget, after Unesco admitted the Palestinians as a full member. The United States has said it had no choice because legislation dating back to the 1990s mandates a complete cutoff of money to any United Nations agency that accepts the Palestinians as a full member. The United States provides 22 percent of the Unesco budget, and the withdrawal of funding has thrown the organization into crisis. Also on Thursday, Gabon announced that it would provide an extra $2 million for this year’s budget.

headline: Passport Control
text: The Supreme Court heard argument this week in an unusual case about the executive branch’s authority over foreign policy and whether the court can adjudicate a dispute between the president and Congress on the issue. The court should rule on the merits and hold that Congress overstepped its power.

headline: Coal Project Hits Snag as a Partner Backs Off
text: WASHINGTON — The leading American effort to capture carbon dioxide from coal plants has hit a stumbling block that could imperil the project and set back a promising technology for addressing global warming, people involved in the venture said.

headline: Russia: Hopes for Space Probe Fade
text: Hopes of salvaging an ambitious unmanned mission to Mars dwindled on Thursday, with Russian scientists failing to make contact with a multimillion dollar space probe that stalled in a low-earth orbit after the engines responsible for sending it toward Mars did not fire. Experts said that there was still a small chance the probe’s software could be reprogrammed and the mission saved, though there were growing fears that the craft, filled with toxic fuels, could crash to earth within days or weeks. “With every orbit around the earth, the craft is losing altitude and speed,” an official told the news agency Interfax. Officials involved with the space program told Russian news agencies that they made several failed attempts on Thursday to restart the engines on the Phobos-Grunt spacecraft, which was supposed to bring back soil samples from the Martian moon Phobos.

headline: Rethinking Ways to Divide Living Space
text: IS there a mismatch between the housing New Yorkers need and the housing that gets built? Only 17 percent of dwelling units in the city are occupied by parents raising children under 25, according to the nonprofit Citizens Housing and Planning Council, but most new homes are designed with such traditional families in mind.

headline: As Oil Production Rises, Libya Expects to Hit Prewar Levels by June
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The acting Libyan oil minister, Ali Tarhouni, said on Thursday that so much progress was being made in resuscitating the country’s oil fields that production would return to more than 40 percent of its prewar level by the end of the year and completely recuperate by June.

headline: Penn State’s Response
text: The Pennsylvania State University Board of Trustees made the only rational choice on Wednesday when it dismissed the football coach Joe Paterno for failing to pursue a horrific allegation of sexual assault of a child that was brought to his attention by a subordinate in 2002. Mr. Paterno, who failed to call the police, now concedes that he did not do enough to curb what prosecutors describe as a 15-year cycle of child rape and sexual assaults, perpetrated partly on university property, by Jerry Sandusky, Mr. Paterno’s former assistant coach.

headline: Protection for the Ocean Food Chain
text: People do not eat menhaden, an oily little forage fish. But the fish that people do eat — like bluefish and striped bass — depend heavily on menhaden for their diet. So it is very good news that the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, representing 15 eastern states and the federal government, has now moved to protect the menhaden, an essential link in the food chain whose numbers have plummeted over the last half-century. The commission voted to cut the menhaden harvest 37 percent by 2013, compared with 2010 levels.

headline: Europe’s Banks Found Safety of Bonds a Costly Illusion

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Friday

Pakistan declared that Ajmal Kasab, accused in the November 26, 2008, attacks in Mumbai, is a “terrorist” who should be “sent to the gallows.” The two premiers pledged to write a “new chapter” in bilateral relations by resuming dialogue on all issues, including ones that had “bedeviled” ties (The Indian Express). Mr. Singh announced that India has decided to move toward a Preferential Trade Agreement with Pakistan, his return gift for Pakistan’s most-favored nation gesture. He also said that a liberalized visa regime would soon be implemented, replacing the current system (The Hindu).

headline: High Ideals and Corruption Dominate Think Festival Agenda

Known to Ethiopians as Alem Bekagn, or “farewell to the world,” this plot of land has been a symbol of human rights abuses for three generations.

headline: Spinning Webs, Then Chasing Sugarplums

It was an unlikely place for this choreographer, who a little over a month earlier had been consumed by the biggest and most expensive spectacle to hit Broadway in history: “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” for which he had created movement both onstage and in the air. Monthly trips to Shanghai, as he was starting to make, would have seemed out of the cards.

headline: Art Exchange Makes Prado in Madrid a ‘Mini-Hermitage’
text: Rarely do two major museums share their most precious holdings. But in celebration of the Spain-Russia Dual Year — dedicated to strengthening cultural and economic ties between the two countries — the Prado National Museum and the  State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg  agreed to exchange treasures, giving visitors to both institutions an unprecedented opportunity to see works outside their usual environment. Last winter, the Prado Museum sent 60 works to St. Petersburg. Now it’s Russia’s turn.

headline: Week 10 Matchups: The Rivalry Everyone Is Talking About
text: Patriots (5-3) at Jets (5-3)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Jets by 1.5.The seventh annual Patriots Dynasty Deathwatch is under way. The team has lost two straight games, prompting the usual hand-wringing about eras ending and la belle époque coming to a melancholy fin. We have now endured over a half-decade of laments about how a team that routinely wins 11 to 16 games per year is not what it used to be, simultaneously criticizing Bill Belichick for his recent personnel decisions and genuflecting before the altar of his past accomplishments. No wonder otherwise sane people ardently root against this team.The Patriots’ need to prolong their dramatic swoon to William Shatner lengths, coupled with the usual noisy Jets’ chest thumping, has turned this into the most torturously overblown rivalry in the N.F.L. Unless you are a lifelong Jets or Patriots fan, you feel you have been clamped to your seat, eyelids taped open, neck immobilized and forced to watch. It’s less a battle of two great teams (both are highly flawed this season) than a battle of attention hounds of differing styles. The Jets should win easily — the Patriots have only one starting-caliber cornerback to handle three very good Jets receivers — but “let us again bid fond farewell to the glorious Patriots” conversations that will dominate the following week make it almost not worth the trouble. Pick: Jets.

headline: It’s Carbon and Monoxide, the Old Detroit Perfume
text: I didn’t think I could love Philip Levine any more than I already did, but then he gave this interview to Andrew Goldman in our Nov. 6 issue (in which, of his diminishing hostility — or at least overt hostility — toward the rich, he says: “I’ve met them now under silly circumstances, and they seem like hopeless jerks to me, for the most part”). If you’ve ever worked a terrible job or felt some kinship with people who have to work too hard and who get too little of what they deserve, then Levine was your personal poet laureate long before he became America’s official poet laureate.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Glenn Jones
text: A master of the art of fingerpicking, Glenn Jones performed several covers and original pieces recently at the West Park Presbyterian Church on the Upper West Side. In lieu of vocals, Jones paused between songs to talk about the stories behind them — say, a friend’s daughter, a landscape that moved him. The audience, absorbed in a silent spell, hung on every word. The performance was organized by the music curator Kate Lesta, who also stages the annual Communikey festival in Boulder, Colo.

headline: From Romania, One Sweet Cylinder
text: A long rope of sweet yeast dough is tightly wrapped in a spiral around a wooden form, something like a rolling pin. It is then baked, slowly turning, often in a hearth. But unless you happen to be from a Transylvanian village, do not try this at home. Anna Kozma, who hails from Romania, said this special-occasion cake (called kurtoskalacs, or chimney cake) was just a provincial treat until after the fall of Communism, when entrepreneurs began opening city shops in Romania, Hungary and elsewhere in Europe.

Poster Boy
text: Shepard Fairey, the influential street artist who last month designed an invitation for an Occupy Wall Street party in Times Square, is once again unfurling the income equality banner, this time to raise money for the homeless. The Robert Rauschenberg Foundation selected Fairey to inaugurate its Artist as Activist series; 100 signed prints of the new Fairey poster, “The Future is Unwritten,” will be available for purchase later today at artnet.com/auctions, starting at $1,250. Almost all of the proceeds benefit the nonprofit organization Coalition for the Homeless, which provides soup kitchens and job training for destitute New Yorkers. Fairey said that his poster references Depression-era styles like Art Deco, and that its title comes from Joe Strummer of the Clash, whom he called “a dedicated advocate for the working class.”

headline: Body and Brain Both Stretched To Their Limits

headline: Site to Be Seen | ASOS
text: Fitting rooms, sales racks and lines at the register seem to stoke fear in many men, so a surplus of e-commerce sites have popped up to make online shopping not only convenient but appealing. Take, for example, ASOS, the Britain-based e-tailer that stocks a range of labels — from heritage (Filson) to high-end (Prada) to Scandinavian (Henrik Vibskov) — under one URL. The site’s extensive mix of prices and styles caters to the male buyer who appreciates one-stop shopping. And streamlining the process even more is ASOS’s affordable namesake line, which offers everything from slim, tailored classics (like these houndstooth trousers, $72) to trendier pieces (knit jacket, $198, and Fair Isle hoodie, $87).

headline: Times political reporters discuss the so-called “brain freeze” displayed by GOP presidential candidate Rick Perry during the latest Republican debate and how — or whether — it will affect his candidacy.
text: Times political reporters discuss the so-called “brain freeze” displayed by GOP presidential candidate Rick Perry during the latest Republican debate and how — or whether it will affect his candidacy.

headline: Stephens Sisters Are in Select Company
text: Not much more than 20 minutes after I hit  the buzzer at Phoebe Stephens’s apartment on East 18th Street (after barging in on the upstairs neighbor, who took the intrusion in stride), Ms. Stephens and her sister, Annette, both jewelry designers, were talking about Loulou de la Falaise, a muse to many exotic creatures, who died on Nov. 5.

headline: Eleanor Roosevelt Has an Ivy League Visitor
text: Amy Gutmann, president of the University of Pennsylvania, visited Eleanor Roosevelt High School, where she talked with 200 high school juniors and seniors about the college application process. “Are you anxious about getting into college?” Dr. Guttman asked. "You're not human if you're not anxious."

headline: Citing Possible Brake Failure, Cadillac Recalls 700 CTS Models
text: Cadillac is recalling almost 700 of its 2012 CTS models because they might, without warning, lose brake power, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Reader Idea | Developing Critical Thinking and Writing Skills for Test Prep
text: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

headline: New Charges Against Ex-Leader of Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — In a move certain to further strain already fractured relations between Ukraine and the West, the opposition leader Yulia V. Tymoshenko has been formally charged with tax evasion and embezzlement in a recently reopened case dating back more than 15 years.

headline: DealBook: EMI Record Label Sold to Vivendi for $1.9 Billion
Police Open Investigation of Sino-Forest
text: OTTAWA — Sino-Forest, a Chinese company listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange, confirmed on Friday that it was the subject of a criminal investigation by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

text: The Moment’s exclusive of “Dance Party,” a video by the synth-pop duo Bubbles, directed by ioulex.

headline: Taylor Takes on Dickens in ‘A Christmas Carol’
text: The American balladeer James Taylor will plunge into the world of Charles Dickens. Mr. Taylor will play the role of Bob Cratchit in a production of “A Christmas Carol” by the Berkshire Theater Group next month. The show is adapted by Eric Hill from Dickens’ ghostly tale; Mr. Hill will co-direct along with E. Gray Simons III, the theater group said in an announcement on Friday. “I know that James will bring his inherent charm and gentleness to bear in his portrayal of Bob Cratchit, a good and unpretentious man,” Mr. Hill said. “A Christmas Carol” will run Dec. 17-30 at the Colonial Theater in Pittsfield, Mass.

headline: Now Showing | ‘Dance Party’ by Bubbles
text: The synth-pop duo Bubbles is currently playing a monthlong residency at the Spencer’s Gifts party at Santos Party House every Friday night in November. Here, exclusively on The Moment, is the band’s new video “Dance Party,” directed by ioulex.

headline: S.&P. Error on Rating of France Incites Inquiry
text: BRUSSELS — Just days before it was to propose sweeping regulations for credit rating agencies, the European Commission on Friday joined calls for an investigation into Standard & Poor’s after the company erroneously sent out an e-mail suggesting that it had lowered the rating on France’s sovereign debt.

headline: Ultimate Fighting Dips a Toe Into the Mainstream
text: In the beginning, the Ultimate Fighting Championship was like a brawl at a carnival, the mismatched combatants entering an octagonal cage to go at it until there was a “knockout, surrender, doctor’s intervention or death.” The very first match pitted a 415-pound sumo wrestler against a Dutch kickboxer who zestfully launched his foot into the bigger man’s face. The blow left two teeth embedded in the attacker’s foot, with a third flying into the crowd.

headline: Report Gives New Details of Chaos at Stricken Plant
text: Fukushima Daiichi Unit 1 was stuck in darkness, and everyone on site feared that the reactor core was damaged. It was the day after a huge earthquake and a towering tsunami devastated the plant, and the workers for Tokyo Electric Power Company knew they were the only hope for halting an unfolding nuclear disaster.

headline: MF Global Lays Off Vast Majority of Broker-Dealer Employees
text: The court-appointed trustee overseeing the liquidation of MF Global’s broker-dealer unit laid off 1,066 employees on Friday, keeping only a skeleton staff to assist in the dissolution of the business.

headline: Penn State Ticket Prices Fall Sharply After Firing
text: The brief burst of interest in tickets to see Penn State host Nebraska on Saturday ended with the dismissal of Nittany Lions Coach Joe Paterno.

headline: Building Sustainable and Affordable Homes in Brentwood
text: Brentwood

headline: In Warming North, Some Trees Thrive as Others Ail
text: In a new study, a team led by researchers from the tree-ring lab at Columbia University’s Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory has found that white spruce trees on the edge of the tundra in Alaska’s far north have thrived in the past 100 years, and especially the last 50, in the face of sharp Arctic warming.

headline: Baked Broccoli Rabe With Parmesan
text: Mark Bittman combines greens with spicy-sweet garlic and rich, salty cheese.

headline: New Canaan’s New Openness to Affordable Housing
text: NEW CANAAN

headline: What Lies Beneath, and Behind
text: ON top of the obvious hurdles to getting a home sale finalized these days, some brokers say hidden environmental issues are more often showing up at the last minute: a new inspection turns up an underground oil tank no one knew was there; air quality monitoring suggests mold is growing behind basement wallboards; or perhaps the radon levels are high.

headline: Seeking Your Questions on Scholarships and Student Loans
text: To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them — as well as to further their understanding of President Obama’s recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans — I’ve once again asked Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, to spend a week in our virtual Guidance Office. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of “Secrets to Winning a Scholarship,” published in February.

headline: The Minimalist: Baked Broccoli Rabe With Parmesan
text: Broccoli rabe usually doesn’t make it past a sauté pan with garlic and olive oil, nor does it need to. But the extra step of baking it in the oven with a shower of grated Parmesan on top – which was suggested to me by the chef John Schenk, now at the Strip House, and which I wrote about in a 1997 Minimalist column — is one you should try.

headline: The European Car Wreck
text: As I watched the governments in Italy and Greece change hands from the politicians who helped create the current disasters to little-known technocrats who will be conveniently blamed for not fixing them right away, I couldn’t help but wonder – with a shudder – what would happen if one of the crop of Republican presidential hopefuls were put in charge there.

headline: To Cut Costs, Dallas Symphony to Drop Five Concerts Next Season
text: The Dallas Symphony Orchestra will cut back on the number of subscription concerts it performs amid a cash crunch. Orchestra officials said this week that subscription concerts will go from 21 weeks this season to 16 next season; the five weeks instead will be devoted to community concerts. The move will save on production costs and fees paid to guest conductors, said David J. Hyslop, the orchestra’s interim president and chief operating officer. The orchestra’s musicians have agreed to forgo wages increases for the past two seasons and agreed to a wage freeze for this season and next, reflecting the same straitened circumstances experienced by many orchestras around the country. Mr. Hyslop said the orchestra has projected a $6.5 million budget deficit this season, but after an emergency appeal for donations to the board on Tuesday and the cost-cutting steps, that number should drop.

headline: Wantful Aims to Revamp Gift-Giving Process
text: The holiday shopping season is just around the corner, and a new San Francisco start-up wants to make it easier to give the perfect gift — by letting the recipient have a say in the matter.

headline: Inclusion: The Right Thing for All Students
text: In an open letter to the New York City schools' chief academic officer, Shael Polakow-Suransky, a disabilities expert argues that integrating special education students into the general classroom is a proven method that improves the education both of children with disabilities and those without.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Though the events, all weekend long, are varied — exhibits, tastings, cooking demonstrations and sales — they share a single obsession: chocolate. The 14th annual Chocolate Show, at the Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street (between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue), in Chelsea, will feature leading chefs like Jacques Torres, as well as small artisanal producers. This year’s show has a Kids’ Zone, where children can grab a handful of chocolate and win tickets to a production of “Peter Pan” at Madison Square Garden if they find a specially wrapped sweet. The show runs from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. on Friday and Saturday, and from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Sunday. Adult tickets are $30 in advance or $35 at the door Friday and Sunday. Saturday tickets are $35 for adults and $40 at the door. Two children ages 5 through 12 can enter free if accompanied by an adult. Each additional child is $8, and children 4 and under are admitted free.

headline: Nebraska Concerned About Safety of Its Fans
text: Nebraska knows there will be a football game Saturday at Penn State. And it’s a pretty big game, too, with the Huskers (7-2 over all, 3-2 Big Ten) tied for second in the Legends Division and the Nittany Lions first in the Leaders Division at 5-0, 8-1 over all.

headline: A Gold Rush of Subsidies in Clean Energy Search
text: WASHINGTON — Halfway between Los Angeles and San Francisco, on a former cattle ranch and gypsum mine, NRG Energy is building an engineering marvel: a compound of nearly a million solar panels that will produce enough electricity to power about 100,000 homes.

headline: Styled to a T | Hotel Bel-Air
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Films of Ernie Gehr
text: A selection of works from the filmmaker whose work will be shown in Los Angeles.

headline: No Blockbusters Here, Just Mind Expanders
text: THERE are a multiplicity of adjectives that fit Ernie Gehr’s experimental film and digital work: abstract, beautiful, mysterious, invigorating, utopian. The work can also be oblique; this is not a bad thing! His 14-minute film “History” (1970), to take one extreme example, largely consists of what looks like a sparkly black-and-gray blob that brings to mind a hallucination of a desert night sky, like van Gogh on acid. What you’re looking at, and perhaps losing yourself in, isn’t a representation of something outside the camera, but film itself: those clouds of dye in color film and churning grains in black and white that make up the actual image you see.

headline: Wheelies: The ‘What, Me Worry?’ Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Friday Reading: Room 77, a New Way to Search Hotel Rooms
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: A Scorched Earth Debut for Call of Duty
text: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 produced a record $400 million in sales and 6.5 million units sold in its the first 24 hours after going on sale in the United States and United Kingdom, Reuters reported. The game, from Activision Blizzard, went on sale at midnight on Tuesday. The figure surpassed the previous record of $360 million set by “Call of Duty: Black Ops,” set last year. By contrast, the movie “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part 2,” had gross receipts of $169 million for its opening weekend, tops for the year so far, according to Box Office Mojo.

headline: Misunderstanding Racial Justice
text: There’s no more polarizing legal battle in America today than the one over the meaning of discrimination. On the left, many progressives insist that any policies and practices that disadvantage people on the basis of race, sex, age or disability should be illegal, and some have carried this principle to illogical extremes — suing to block ladies’ nights at singles bars, for example, or even to forbid Mother’s Day. On the right, many conservatives insist that the Constitution is so colorblind that the government may never take race into account under any circumstances, and the Supreme Court under Chief Justice John Roberts has carried this principle to similarly illogical extremes — claiming that policies designed to integrate public schools, for example, are impossible to distinguish from those designed to segregate them.

headline: The Writing Cure
text: Early in Joshua Cody’s sprightly, manic cancer memoir, “[Sic],” the author pauses to explain the musical significance of the “golden ratio” — the moment, almost two-thirds of the way through a composition, when the work often “asserts its presence and opens up to take you in and it feels like the pilot has moved the throttle and you feel motion again.” Curious readers may take this as a cue to flip ahead to Page 164, which is where (according to the Euclidean formula Cody graciously provides) the golden ratio falls in his own narrative. There they will find Cody on the verge of death, joined at his hospital bedside by his mother and the emotionally unstable pain management doctor who is about to become, disastrously, his girlfriend. They will find, in other words, the throttle shoved all the way forward. The resulting G-force of sex and death and insanity — and also, improbably, of music and math and modernist poetry — is the only evidence you need that for all its seeming formlessness, “[Sic]” is in fact as artfully constructed as a Tarantino film.

headline: Premier Says Japan Will Join Pacific Free Trade Talks
text: TOKYO — In a contentious move that could make or break his government, Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda said Friday that Japan would join talks toward an ambitious pan-Pacific free trade pact. The accord would potentially open up new markets for Japanese exporters but enrage the nation’s powerful farmers, who say their livelihoods would be wiped out.

headline: ‘The Rubber Duck Knows No Frontiers’
text: While repainting Her Majesty’s bathroom in Buckingham Palace in 2001, a decorator noticed a particularly quirky object befitting a queen: a rubber duckie with its own crown. Naturally, he told a tabloid. The Sun was also amused: “The queen,” it reported, “shares her royal bathtimes with a yellow rubber duck.”

headline: The Topic of Cancer
text: My boyfriend of one year has been given a diagnosis of terminal cancer. He has no family around, and I have been his primary caretaker. We had a wonderful relationship, but we had not discussed long-term plans, and his declining health has changed much between us. It is becoming harder for me to continue at this level. My desire to look after my own needs, personal and professional, and my guilt for feeling that I could be deserting him are becoming overwhelming. What is my responsibility? ANONYMOUS

headline: Hurt All Over
text: ‘Will you please see my sister?’ the young woman asked Dr. David Podell, who was a friend of a friend and had a reputation as a kinder version of TV’s Dr. Gregory House. People told her that Podell was a doctor who specialized in diagnosing odd diseases, and she hoped he might finally solve the puzzle of her older sister’s mysterious illness.

headline: Forest of the Ancients
text: High in the White Mountains of eastern California is a group of trees that are among the oldest living things on earth.

headline: Confessions of a Tweeter
text: It started June 25, 2008: “Testing, testing. Is this thing on?” My first tweet. I began by trying to make a few friends laugh. I had no idea how quickly tweeting would consume me. Before long I was posting 20 to 30 times a day, seven days a week. Some of my posts were funny, some sad, some vaguely existential — “Living happily ever after is killing me” — some flirty, some filthy. I posted daily for three years with only one exception — the day my father-in-law died. Eventually, I attracted about 25,000 followers. Not bad for a noncelebrity.

headline: We Are Still Not Ready
text: Wil Hylton’s article “How Ready Are We for Bioterrorism?” raised important concerns about how hard it is to protect the country from naturally occurring and man-made biological threats. He outlined how the lack of profitability and the bureaucratic hoops required to get vaccines and medical countermeasures to market can mean we’re often our own worst enemy. But he missed an equally important and extremely troubling part of the equation: cuts to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and to state budgets mean that even when we have medicines and vaccines, we aren’t in a position to get them to Americans quickly. Federal support for preparedness has been gutted, dropping 37 percent since fiscal year 2005, and state and local health departments have cut an estimated 44,000 workers between 2008 and 2010. After Sept. 11 and anthrax, we built up biodefense capabilities, but we’re moving backward. When the next tragedy strikes, we will not be ready. The price tag for lack of preparedness will be American lives.

headline: Lynda Barry Will Make You Believe In Yourself
text: I had the pleasure of being in one of Lynda Barry’s two-hour writing workshops. I will never forget how she talked about the critical voice inside our heads. She said that if someone walked up behind you and said the story you were writing was stupid, you wouldn’t listen to them, so why do you listen to the voice inside your head telling you that very thing? It was life changing.

headline: Reader Responses: Hurt All Over
text: Reader responses regarding a medical mystery of a young woman who endured a decade of relenting pain.

headline: Jennifer Miller and Jason Feifer
text: IT all began with a semicolon.

headline: Battered Souls, Seeking Salvation in Each Other
text: FOUR years ago the British actor Paddy Considine made his directing debut with a short film, called “Dog Altogether,” that begins with a man drunkenly kicking his dog to death. For Mr. Considine the challenge was clear. “If in 15 minutes you have any compassion for this guy, I’ve succeeded,” he said. Now he has raised the stakes — widening both the emotional palette and the spectrum of human and canine abuse — in a feature-length film he wrote and directed, “Tyrannosaur,” centered on the same less-than-lovable protagonist. A menacing alcoholic whose fits of rage mask a lifetime of pain, Joseph (played by Peter Mullan) eventually lets down his guard when he befriends a battered wife.

headline: More Screen Time for Kids Who Create Instead of Watch
text: Should those of us with firm limits on our kids’ technology time be rethinking our stance?

text: “New Cadet Wilson, it’s raining on your R-Day! Do you know what that means?”

headline: TimesCast | November 11, 2011
text: Italy is one step closer to a government without Silvio Berlusconi; Arab League leaders consider suspending Syria’s membership; and honoring America’s veterans.

headline: Living In | Bay Shore, L.I.
text: A 12-square-mile hamlet in Islip that has a diverse housing stock, from upscale waterfront houses to more modest Capes and colonials to mobile homes.

headline: 2014 World Cup: North Korea Eliminated; China on Brink
text: North Korea became the first nation that played in the 2010 World Cup to be eliminated from contention for the 2014 World Cup in Brazil when it lost, 1-0, to Uzbekistan in Tashkent in a World Cup qualifying match in the Asia region Friday.

headline: A Hamlet With a Liquid Playground
text: AS the district director of guidance for the Bay Shore Union Free School District, Louis Balsamo gives tours to prospective students and their parents who are interested in moving to Bay Shore, a diverse Suffolk County hamlet on the shores of the Great South Bay.

headline: Sweetness With Spine
text: THERE are some movie stars — like Joan Crawford or John Wayne — who are able to sustain their popularity across several decades, either maturing with their audiences or finding fresh ways to appeal to new generations of fans.

headline: Eurofile | Weekend in Belgrade
text: Sometimes there’s a pleasure in arriving in a place unburdened by too much knowledge of your destination: with none of the usual guidebook prepping, everything comes as a revelation. Aside from the fact that it’s the capital of Serbia, is located at the confluence of the Danube and Sava rivers, and was a pawn between the Turks and Austrians for several centuries, I knew almost nothing about Belgrade, the former capital of Yugoslavia. With blissful ignorance whetting my curiosity, I and a friend recently arrived at the Nikola Tesla airport and hopped a diesel-fume-spewing bus into the city.

headline: 421a Tax Exemption: Don’t Say You Didn’t Know
text: TOD ABRAMS’S condo at the Orion on West 42nd Street has a custom Valcucine kitchen, floor-to-ceiling windows and views that stretch from the George Washington Bridge to the Chrysler Building.

headline: Protesters Urge Arab League to Suspend Syria as Deaths Mount
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of Syrians took to the streets on Friday, urging the Arab League to suspend the membership of the Syrian government, which they say has violated an initiative the league brokered to end the armed crackdown on the eight-month-old political uprising.

headline: The Topsy-Turvy Dynegy Bankruptcy
text: As the Dynegy Chapter 11 case unfolds, the only thing that is certain is that nothing is exactly as it seems. Indeed, one has to worry that the entire case involves looking through the wrong end of the telescope.

headline: Before the Kindle Fire, Some Misfires
text: The late Steven P. Jobs has been widely celebrated in recent weeks for his uncanny ability to anticipate what the masses want. Most mortals have no such forecasting skills, but that doesn’t prevent some from making all sorts of predictions. Usually, these lie safely buried in the past, but occasionally they get resurrected to pound a point home.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 10’s Toughest Picks
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Thanksgiving Countdown | Just Add Bacon
text: There’s always a way to work in some bacon. Here are four recipes that will help you reach that goal this Thanksgiving. Add your suggestions in the comments section.

headline: Why Do the Republican Debates Seem to Matter So Much?
text: There have been nine Republican presidential debates this year, and each one seems to have more influence over the course of the campaign than the last one. (And there will be another one on Saturday at 8 p.m. on CBS.)

headline: Beyond Patience and Fortitude, an Incursion of Decibels
text: “I’ve been reading up on the history of the place,” the composer and performer Ben Frost said. “It’s important to know your enemy.”

headline: Stacking Clean Energy Subsidies
text: Since 2009, extensive federal and state subsidies have been offered for solar power. An analysis by Booz & Company shows the ways in which government subsidies have turned one such project — NRG’s California Valley Solar Ranch — into an almost surefire investment.

headline: At Methuselah Grove, Where Trees Wait 5,000 Years for Their Close-Up
text: Domingo Milella first saw a bristlecone pine when a friend showed him an iPhone picture of a tree growing along the Methuselah Walk. It was one of the world’s oldest living trees, but at the time it didn’t interest Milella as a photographic subject. He says, “It came back to me only after a year, as if a presence that lingered, but never disappeared.” That’s when Milella, whose work has previously appeared in T Magazine, suggested he shoot the tree for the magazine. In our business, a good idea doesn’t ordinarily have a shelf life of a year, but given that some trees in the ancient bristlecone pine forest are likely 5,000 years old, we had a little more wiggle room with the publication date than usual. This one gave new meaning to “evergreen,” a journalistic term signifying a feature that can run at any time.

headline: The New York Times Comedy Challenge
text: All around town this weekend you can’t help but run into standups. Though, as Jason Zinoman has written, New York is a “something of a sprawling comedy festival the entire year,” there is actually a reason for the crush of jokes: the New York Comedy Festival is officially under way through Sunday. Of course, much of the bits you see onstage aren’t exactly Times-appropriate, so we decided to pose a challenge to select comedians: tell us your best clean joke. Watch them in action and vote for the one you think killed.

headline: Off the Charts: Tracking the Rise in Sovereign Default Fears
text: As worries over the safety of some European sovereign bonds grew this year, volume in credit default swaps rose sharply, particularly in September. But the changes in net contracts outstanding rose at a much slower pace. The charts show the daily market rate on 10-year government bonds and the annual cost of a credit default swap to insure against default for a $10 million government bond for five years. They also show the weekly volume in such swaps and the net positions of all holders. The charts begin in July 2010, when information on swap volume became available.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov.11
text: A look at the day in sports, including ice skating in Japan, cricket in South Africa and soccer in Budapest.

headline: Duane Buck, Race and Capital Punishment
text: One of the things I would like to do with this blog is provide a space to discuss issues with a level of detail that’s just not possible in a typical editorial, or perhaps issues that don’t lend themselves to formal editorials, but are still worth talking about. Such posts might get a little wonky at times, but I hope you find them worth your while.

headline: Off the Beaten Path
text: From obscure islands to boutique hideaways, destinations away from the crowds.

headline: In Jamaica, a Musical Revival
text: Beaches, waterfalls and jerk chicken, all to a mento beat.

headline: On Jamaica’s Other Coast, a Musical Revival
text: LATE on a balmy Saturday evening in August, as Hurricane Irene churned far out in the Caribbean, the singer Albert Minott and his mento band, the Jolly Boys, were charming the crowd at the Bush Bar, a jungle-shrouded watering hole at the GeeJam resort in the Jamaican harbor town of Port Antonio. Nattily dressed and slim as an exclamation point, Mr. Minott, 73, slunk sensually across the stage as he delivered a soulful, gravelly voiced set that included Jolly Boys originals and covers of the Velvet Underground and Amy Winehouse.

headline: Blithe Spirits
text: On a recent Saturday night in Boulder, Col., a warehouse in an industrial park on the city’s southeast side was humming with live music, food trucks and people who’d dropped by on bicycles for a martini. Which may seem customary in the People’s Republic of Boulder — except that the warehouse isn’t a new cocktail bar exactly but rather Boulder Distillery, one of the many small spirit producers that are multiplying all over the state.

headline: Copter Crash Kills a Leader in Mexico’s Drug Fight
text: MEXICO CITY — A helicopter crash killed Mexico’s second-most-powerful official and seven others on Friday, dealing yet another blow to the country’s battle against a drug-and-crime scourge and leaving a battered nation in shock.

headline: Touring Bequia
text: An hour from Barbados, an island of both simple and extravagant pleasures.

headline: Saving Pets From Radiation in Japan
text: Eight months after the nuclear crisis in Japan, emergency workers are still struggling to understand the effects on the thousands of dogs and cats left wandering the streets in towns and villages near the damaged Fukushima nuclear plant. Many were left behind in the rush to evacuate by families who did not expect to be away for more than a short period.

headline: Tax Burdens Tilt Coastal, and System’s Fairness Is Debated
text: THE wealthy have been the subject of much discussion lately, from the protesters on Wall Street to lawmakers in Washington. President Obama has even provided a definition of who’s wealthy in arguing that taxes should be raised for those households with incomes of at least $250,000 a year.

text: 4:58 p.m. | Updated

text: Corey Kilgannon speaks to service members on Veterans Day.

headline: TimesCast | Italy Beyond Berlusconi
text: Italy's Senate passes an austerity bill, bringing it one step closer to a future without Silvio Berlusconi.

headline: Perry Makes $1 Million Ad Buy on Fox News
text: Read an updated version of this blog post.

headline: Out-of-the-Way Stays, Rugged to Refined
text: MOST hotels want attention. They advertise, bundle discounts and offer news-making packages. But if you want to escape the clamor, the following intimate accommodations — all off-the-beaten-path hideaways — offer island home-away-from-home experiences with all the privacy of a residential stay. All qualify as romantic, but each plays a different variation on the theme, ranging from rugged to refined. Each features owner management, cottage or suite quarters and, in most cases, kitchens that give you an excuse to shop at the local produce markets. Seekers of beach parties should book elsewhere.

headline: Bequia: Getting Away From the Getaways
text: I JUST wanted to make a dinner reservation. But the restaurant owner had other uses for me.

headline: A Young Sailor’s Guide to the Caribbean
text: IN 2003, 8-year-old Alex Ellison and his family set sail in the Caribbean on their 46-foot Beneteau 473, Promise. They had intended to take a one-year trip from Essex, Conn., through the Caribbean to South America and back, but ended up spending almost five years living in the islands, celebrating birthdays in Grenada, Christmas in the Pitons and spending three years in the rain forest of Nevis. “The world was now our classroom,” Mr. Ellison wrote in his memoir, “A Star to Sail Her By” (May 2011, iUniverse).

headline: Your Go-Bag for the Caribbean
text: BAREFOOT all the time, and a lot of freedom.

headline: A New Wave of Cool Drinks
text: An informal survey of cocktail enthusiasts around the Caribbean revealed four of the most popular drinks this season.

headline: I’ll Have the Red: Hot Sauce, Island by Island
text: JAMAICA is a land of deep and profound greens: hurricane-battered jungles, untrimmed coconuts delivered to villa doorsteps, sticky cannabis held in lacquered wooden humidors. But when I first visited the island in 2005, no green fascinated me as much as the contents of the glass jar handed to me one evening by Darren Lee, then the chef at Strawberry Hill, a luxurious resort in the mountains above Kingston. This green was rough and wet, but also glassy, and I recognized it immediately: These were puréed Scotch bonnet chiles — hot as habaneros, but fruitier, almost sweet.

headline: 14 Ways to Ditch the Crowds
text: There’s more to the Caribbean than mega-resorts and limbo contests. From Creole markets and cozy inns to local zouk joints and volcanic beaches, 14 ways to escape the predictable.

headline: Yep, That’s Me on the Tasting Menu
text: Since 1992, Caribbean reefs have been invaded by lionfish, showy-looking but venomous and barbed Pacific natives. They most likely escaped from aquariums into the wild, where they have found plenty to feed on — and no natural predators.

headline: Shooting Layups Where Publishers Dined
text: They’ve already turned the newsroom into a bowling alley. Why shouldn’t the publisher’s dining room on the 11th floor of the old New York Times headquarters be turned into a basketball court?

headline: Brands Lost in Translation
text: When Western products are translated into Chinese, the results can range from poetic to the metaphysical.

headline: The U.F.C.: No Holds Barred
text: Fans of mixed martial arts know that Ulitimate Fighting Championship bouts can be a windmill of fists, two exhausted men wrestling on the ground or an exhibition of chokeholds.

headline: Puppets on Film
text: Images from the BAMcinématek series covering puppets (and muppets) in the movies.

headline: Picking Brand Names in China Is a Business Itself
text: BEIJING — After a hard day’s labor, your average upscale Beijinger likes nothing more than to shuck his dress shoes for a pair of Enduring and Persevering, rev up his Precious Horse and head to the pub for a tall, frosty glass of Happiness Power.

headline: Where You’ll Still Find Judy Garland
text: Tommy Femia has been performing as Judy Garland for more than 20 years at an Off Off Broadway cabaret in Manhattan, and his parents and brothers are usually on hand.

headline: The Boy Who Became Judy Garland
text: DOWN some dark stairs, past cases of empty beer bottles, in the brick warren beneath the Off Off Broadway cabaret called Don’t Tell Mama, a middle-aged man helps his middle-aged brother adjust the blue sequined top that complements his black sequined skirt. Fifteen minutes to showtime.

headline: Romney Comments on Perry Debate Gaffe
text: MAULDIN, S.C. — After a round table with veterans here, Mitt Romney on Friday offered his most expansive comments yet on Gov. Rick Perry’s “Oops” moment in Wednesday night’s debate, though he still steered clear of criticizing his rival.

headline: Dot Connection: From Palestinian Politics to Tsunami Warnings
text: You may have followed developments as the United States pulled its funding for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, known as Unesco, after the organization voted to make Palestine its 195th full member on Oct. 31. United States laws dating from the 1990s require an automatic cutoff of American funds under such a circumstance. On Thursday, the organization announced big budget cuts. Why is this relevant to Dot Earth?

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $19.5 million
text: It took six months from the day the contract was signed, a grueling approval process from one of the city’s toughest co-op boards, and nearly $20 million, but a new apartment owner was finally able to join the illustrious ranks of the Manhattan elite who call 778 Park Avenue home.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Worlds Apart
text: New to the hardcover list is “Flashpoint,” written by Geoff Johns and illustrated by Adam Kubert. The story, at No. 2, will likely go down in comics history as “the event that changed everything” right before the next event that really changed everything. The focus of the action is the Flash, who one morning wakes up in a world that is very different than the one he had fallen asleep in the night before. Aquaman and Wonder Woman are at war, Superman is missing and someone unexpected is wearing Batman’s cowl. This was presented to fans of the DC Universe as a notable event in the adventures of the heroes.

headline: Future Farmers of America Convention
text: The Future Farmers of America has gone beyond its roots in agriculture, adding fields like genetics and logistics.

headline: Seriously, Men Only Think They’re Funnier
text: The Gist Men aren’t much funnier than women. They just think they are.

headline: Veterans Old and Young Gather to March, and to Contemplate
text: The wind whipped through Madison Square Park in Manhattan on Friday as military men and women young and old mustered at the starting point for the Veterans Day Parade.

headline: Kal Penn, a Star Turn on Both Coasts
text: WHAT’S the slacker half of the stoner duo of the “Harold & Kumar” movies to do when faced with an elaborate F.B.I. questionnaire for his White House security clearance?

headline: Geeks Beat Out Aspiring Pop Stars Overall
text: The second live results episode of “The X Factor” carried Fox to another Thursday night ratings victory in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic despite falling 11 percent in that demo compared to last week and dropping to 10.2 million total viewers from 11.5 million last week.

headline: Chain Saw Gang
text: The men’s-wear designer Adam Kimmel is no stranger to a statement scarf or skinny, bare-chested male models. But Kimmel can also toughen things up, as he proves with his newest collection for Carhartt, a work-wear brand for hardy men with callused hands and steely stares who nevertheless find occasions to don $410 canvas blazers. The Moment recently sneaked a peek at the Adam Kimmel x Carhartt look book, which outfits three roguish, chain-saw-wielding members of the art collective Paintallica. This group, made up mostly of University of Iowa alums, works in nightlong spurts, carving totemic wooden structures with power tools. Paint, fire, beer, a range of motor vehicles and sometimes guns are involved. “We’re interested in the same things that guys who shop in Wal-Mart in Des Moines, Iowa, are interested in,” said Dan Attoe, a founding member of the group (he’s the bearded one pictured above). “But we also know what’s out in the world. Adam has a similar approach with Carhartt. He’s making something that’s fashionable but that someone in a rural area can still appreciate.”Adam Kimmel x Carhartt, $40-$425. Available next month at Barneys.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Washington, Virginia, Yemen and China.

headline: What Will Bella Wear?
text: WHEN “The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn — Part 1” opens on Friday, fans won’t be at all surprised to see Edward utter, “I do.” They already know the plotlines of the books better than their own ancestries. But there is one mystery — the design of Bella’s wedding dress — that has “Twihards” all astir and the studio behind the film, Summit Entertainment, as tightlipped as a sorority pledge.

headline: Having Fun With Economy
text: The Sonic, Chevy’s replacement for the Aveo, offers distinctive styling and impressive performance, traits sorely lacking in its predecessor.

headline: Q&A: Troubleshooting the Self-Restarting PC
text: Q.

headline: Moody’s Calls Pipeline Delay a ‘Positive’ for TransCanada
text: OTTAWA — While some in Canada view the Obama administration’s decision to delay the approval process for the Keystone XL pipeline, which would carry oil from Alberta’s oil sands to the Gulf Coast, as a serious blow to relations between their country and the United States, Moody’s Investors Service offered a more positive take on Friday.

headline: Puppets on Film at BAM
text: Heroes in half-shells, frogs with banjos and even killer tires are a part of a lively film series being presented by BAMcinématek called Puppets on Film. For two weekends, Nov. 12-14 and 18-20, the Brooklyn Academy of Music will screen a variety of films that trade high-tech computer graphics and special effects for old-fashioned foam and fabric. The series comes just before the Muppets make a big-screen comeback in a new feature film. The Muppets are a part of this series as well, and for those nostalgic for Jim Henson’s creations, the series will include both the original “Muppet Movie,” “Muppet Treasure Island” and the Henson-directed fantasy film “The Dark Crystal.” The slide show above looks at some of the kid-friendly (“Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles”) and not-so-kid friendly (“Team America: World Police”) movies the festival has to offer. More can be found at the BAM Web site.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Washington, Virginia, Yemen and China.

headline: Release the Memo!
text: The Senate Judiciary Committee held an oversight hearing on Tuesday, and most of the news reports focused on Operation Fast and Furious. NPR said there were “unanswered questions” regarding what Attorney General Eric Holder knew about the bungled gun-trafficking scheme while it was still a scheme and before it was bungled.

headline: Hi-Fi Phone Earbuds at a Sound Price
text: There are lots of earphones that produce good sound, and a lot that incorporate a microphone for phone use, but few that do both. And to find one that does both at a value price? It’s a short list.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 56
text: Although many veterans have joined Occupy Wall Street, some believe the 99 percent  are “blissfully unaware of the daily triumphs and tragedies” of those serving abroad in the military. [Washington Post]

headline: Preventing Hospital Delirium
text: My family and I watched my mother suddenly descend into delirium during her hospital stay after surgery. I can assure you that anyone who has seen somebody lose her mind within a matter of hours — even if she comes back from the dark side — doesn’t ever want to see it happen again.

headline: Cars Burned and Swastikas Scrawled in Brooklyn Jewish Area
text: One or more vandals on Friday set fire to several parked cars and scrawled anti-Semitic graffiti on nearby benches in Brooklyn, in what the police said was a hate crime in a heavily Jewish neighborhood.

headline: CME Group Offers $300 Million for MF Global Customers
text: The CME Group, the major exchange where MF Global did business, took the unusual step on Friday of pledging $300 million to help ailing customers of the bankrupt brokerage firm.

headline: Turning Up the Pressure to Keep Gas in the Game
text: IT should come as no surprise when the headlines coursing out of news conferences during this week’s press previews of the Los Angeles auto show turn out to be strongly flavored with terms like hybrid and electric.

headline: A Plan for Efficiency in the Rest of the Car
text: IN the Mazda canon, Skyactiv is a term that describes the company’s systematic approach to improving fuel efficiency. Under the Skyactiv umbrella are gasoline and diesel engines, 6-speed manual and automatic transmissions, lightweight body structures and a host of chassis improvements.

headline: Seeking Out the Elegant Quail
text: Jennifer Calkins, a biologist who teaches at Evergreen State College in Olympia, Wash., writes from Mexico, where she is studying the ecology, behavior and evolution of the elegant quail.

headline: Kraft Gives Plum Assignment to Crispin Porter & Bogusky
text: Kraft Foods, the largest American marketer of packaged foods, is expanding its relationship with a new favorite agency, Crispin Porter & Bogusky, awarding it plum assignments in connection with the introduction of a Kraft product in the United States.

headline: Crossing Over, No Translation Needed
text: FOR the last decade Anthony Santos, the lead singer of the bachata group Aventura, has been something of a secret hidden in plain sight. Though Aventura regularly fills Madison Square Garden and other arenas around the country and sells millions of records, Mr. Santos, known to his Latino fans as Romeo, has remained pretty much anonymous outside the Spanish-speaking world.

headline: The Prince, the Showgirl, and the Stray Strap
text: IT all turned on a pin.

headline: Batteries in Electric Cars Examined After Chevy Volt Fire
text: DETROIT — Federal safety regulators said Friday that they were examining lithium-ion batteries used in electric cars because a Chevrolet Volt ignited three weeks after it underwent a crash test.

headline: Future Farmers Look Ahead
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Gamaliel Rizzo grew up in a brownstone apartment in Brooklyn and is studying to become a doctor. Still, he spent his high school years learning how to raise chinchillas, goats and alpaca and growing radishes, sunflowers and cilantro. He even worked on a dairy farm in the summer, all as a member of the Future Farmers of America.

headline: Music, Not Movies, But Still Exploring Places of Darkness
text: THE creepiness in a David Lynch film comes as much from the soundtrack as from the Surrealistic images: the subtle melancholy of Laura Palmer’s theme in “Twin Peaks,” Isabella Rossellini’s come-hither rendition of the title song in “Blue Velvet.” Mr. Lynch, the filmmaker, devotee of transcendental meditation and coffee distributor, has long dabbled in music himself; he has written songs for his films and others (often in collaboration with the composer Angelo Badalamenti), and he sang with Danger Mouse and Sparklehorse for their 2010 album, “Dark Night of the Soul.” Last week he released his solo debut, “Crazy Clown Time” (Sunday Best Recordings/PIAS America), a brooding electronic blues album with his highly processed vocals, created in his home studio with the engineer Dean Hurley. “Mostly it starts with a jam,” Mr. Lynch said. “Dean now lately on drums and me on guitar, and out of the jamming comes some kind of form, like, lots and lots of garbage — you can picture a landfill — but some chunks of gold.”

headline: A Big Market, but Not Necessarily Dangerous
text: AS worries grew about sovereign credit in Europe this fall, the volume of trading in credit-default swaps on Italy, Spain and France soared. But there appears to have been little actual purchasing of insurance in all that activity.

text: TESTED 2011 Jeep Patriot Latitude X 4X4 70th Anniversary Edition

headline: Les Paul Dies at 94
text: Mr. Paul was a virtuoso guitarist and inventor whose solid-body electric guitar and recording studio innovations changed the course of 20th-century music.

headline: Jazz Guitar Shrine Expands Beyond Jazz to Survive
text: For years the Iridium has been known as not only the home of Les Paul, the electric-guitar pioneer, but also as one of the city’s premier jazz clubs, where on any given night you can hear big-name performers like the pianist McCoy Tyner or the bassist Charlie Haden.

headline: At Last, a Small Chevy That Makes Some Waves
text: AS new-car names go, Chevrolet Sonic has a decent ring. It implies speed, amped-up sound, maybe a dash of pizazz. As with most auto names, interpretation is up to you.

headline: For New-Car Buyers, Taking a Test Drive Now Seems So 1995
text: AT a time when consumers have become accustomed to buying flat-screen televisions from Amazon.com without ever seeing the picture quality and ordering shoes through Zappos.com without trying them on, is it any wonder that some would buy a vehicle without ever taking a test drive?

headline: Last Impressions?
text: The Patriot, improved somewhat since its ignominious debut, hopes to get a second look from compact S.U.V. buyers before it’s too late.

headline: Look of the Moment | Vanessa Paradis
text: The Look: Caped Crusader. A dash of metallic tweed does wonders to dress up a jacket and jeans.

headline: Perry Finds Voters in S. Carolina Warm but Wary
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas strode down Sumter Street in the Veterans Day parade here on Friday morning, a day after doing a series of network interviews and an appearance on the David Letterman show — all meant to atone for his debate flub on Wednesday night.

headline: This week: Floyd Norris on Italy and the global economy, Gretchen Morgenson on taxpayer-funded pensions for defense contractors, Amy Cortese on starting a community-owned store, David Segal on cellphone charges, and Tyler Cowen on Occupy Wall Street.
text: This week: Jeff Sommer with Floyd Norris on Italy and the global economy, Gretchen Morgenson on taxpayer-funded pensions for defense contractors, Phyllis Korkki and Amy Cortese on starting a community-owned store, David Segal on cellphone charges, and Tyler Cowen on Occupy Wall Street.

headline: For Joan Baez, Another Protest
text: After Occupy Wall Street protesters received permission from the city to hold a Veterans Day concert in Foley Square, not far from Zuccotti Park, the organizer of the event, Aaron Black, had to improvise in finding an area to serve as a green room, where musicians could stay warm before performing.

headline: The Life Report: David Leshan
text: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

headline: A Visit to Fukushima Begins
text: Eight months after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station was crippled by an earthquake and tsunami, the Japanese government is opening the compound and surrounding area to the media for the first time. On Friday, officials took a group of reporters, including Martin Fackler of The New York Times, on a tour of J-Village, a former sports center near the plant that is now being used to house workers laboring to bring the plant’s reactors under control. On Saturday, the reporters will tour the plant itself.

headline: Nissan to Market D.C. Fast Charger for Under $10,000
text: Nissan North America, with its partner Sumitomo, will market a 480-volt D.C. fast charger in the United States next year, the automaker announced Thursday night. The charger will sell for less than $10,000, a precipitous drop compared to units now on the market, which cost as much as $50,000.

headline: Stanford vs. Oregon: Ducks Have Speed; Cardinal Have Injuries
text: No. 3 Stanford plays No. 6 Oregon Saturday night in Palo Alto, Calif. This week, The Quad will feature fans’ views of a game that has national title implications. This post is by Dick Benster, a 1975 Stanford graduate. And as always, we want to hear what you think.

headline: Final: France 1, U.S. 0; No Offense Again
text: Loïc Rémy split open the United States defense in the 72nd minute and the American offense again failed to produce a goal as France defeated the United States, 1-0, in a friendly at the Stade de France in Paris on Friday.

headline: DeKalb Avenue in Fort Greene, Brooklyn
text: Scenes from DeKalb Avenue in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, include dogs and children running free.

headline: DeKalb Avenue Arrives, Tourists and All
text: DEPENDING on the time of day, DeKalb Avenue in Brooklyn can look like a sepia-toned photograph from the 19th century, a chic international playground, or, at its best, the New York City melting pot at a nice, gentle simmer.

headline: ‘Wall Street Wives’ Lines Up a Wife With Some Buzz
text: The reality TV show “Wall Street Wives,” which plans to track the lives of the women married to the barons of finance, may not yet have a development deal, but it has been steadily adding to its cast.

headline: An American Look at Fukushima, Minute by Minute
text: The new chronology of events at Japan’s Fukushima Daiichi plant, which we write about here, contains no new bombshells about the disaster. But in dry prose, it gives some additional indications of how bad things were after the quake and tsunami there and will probably be the basis for some lessons learned for the American industry.

headline: Airbnb’s Lodging Gets Tested, Yielding a Mixed Bag
text: For any fan of disruptive consumer technologies, watching Airbnb’s rise has been all sorts of fun.

headline: After Winning N.Y. Times Contest, Lifeboat No. 6 Makes Headlines
text: Writing headlines, take it from us, is hard work. So we were gratified when more than 20 of you stepped up and entered our Nov. 1 contest to write a New York Post-style headline about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s third term, in homage to hizzoner’s performance on Conan O’Brien spitting out “Diddy in Doghouse Over Dingo Damage” and the like.

headline: U.S. Ambassador Explores His Roots

headline: Sisterhood Is Still Powerful
text: Two excellent reads: The oral history of Ms. in New York magazine and Caitlin Flanagan’s ode to Oprah Winfrey in The Atlantic. Read them together and you are reminded that modern feminism had, at its core, a mission to expose the private abuse of power. This was accomplished by talking — women talking in pairs, in groups and eventually in the pages of a mainstream magazine — about entitled men and concealed abortions and sexual harassment and other private humiliations and injustices. Oprah took it further, to national television and a truly mass audience. As Flanagan writes:

text: GUANGZHOU, China

headline: Federal Dollars Pledged to Math and Science Programs
text: Three programs that promote math and science education will receive a big lift in the form of millions of dollars in federal grants. Now New Visions for Public Schools, the city's Education Department and the New York Hall of Science in Queens must drum up some matching funds to acquire the money.

headline: Romney Hosts Veterans Round Table in S.Carolina
text: MAULDIN, S.C. — Mitt Romney spent Veterans Day with a table full of veterans on Friday, sharing plastic plates of barbecue as well as ideas for improving conditions facing the nation’s service members as they return from war.

headline: A Guest Conductor Leads Familiar Pieces
text: Returning to the New York Philharmonic podium for the first time since 1978, Bernard Haitink conducted the orchestra in Strauss and Beethoven on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Next week he leads a program of Haydn and Bruckner.

headline: A Single Mom Gambling on Christmas Spirit
text: Is there an Unlikely Pairing of the Month prize? If so, the Hallmark Channel wins it for connecting the stripper from the sleazy “Showgirls” and the bumbling police lieutenant from “Monk” in “Lucky Christmas,” a pleasant if improbable original movie it serves up on Saturday night.

headline: Renaissance Works in Which Exceptions Rule
text: If you ask an early-music fan to describe Renaissance sacred music in general terms, you will probably hear about seamlessly flowing Masses and motets, usually for five voices. But the Renaissance was a period of unusual invention and limit testing, and as soon as you think you have defined its norms, exceptions come plentifully to mind.

headline: Penn State Puts McQueary on Leave
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — The Penn State assistant coach Mike McQueary, who has emerged as a central figure in the sexual abuse scandal that has roiled the university, was placed on administrative leave, the acting president, Rodney A. Erickson, announced Friday.

headline: Nature in the City
text: Marielle Anzelone, a botanist and urban ecologist, reports from Inwood Hill Park in week eight of her “Autumn Unfolds” series on City Room.

headline: Good Deed, Punished
text: I am a charitable person without deep pockets. So I usually volunteer my time. Recently I drove to a shopping center, and some high school boys asked me to donate to a food pantry. They handed me a list of items to buy. But I was running late for work and offered money instead. All I had in my wallet was 80 cents, which I gave them. (I’m sure many items on the list cost less.) As I drove away, I saw them snickering at me, which made me feel awful. Should I call the charity or let it go?

headline: Exploration With Myth, Memory and Movement
text: As far as immersive installation performances go, Emily Johnson’s “Thank-you Bar” is as disarming as they come. Much of that is due to the light touch of its creator, who has lived in Minneapolis for 17 years but was born in Alaska of Yu’pik descent. Everything about her exudes charisma.

headline: Readers’ Photos: Picturing Our World
text: What does the world look like today?

headline: Letters
text: Sleepless in America

headline: Individual Links in a Rolling Chain
text: It must be a pleasure to dance the choreography of Lar Lubovitch. To yield appropriately to beautiful music, secure in the hands of a master craftsman who will never let you look less than attractive: This safe satisfaction must be what draws dancers to his company. No matter that the three typically well-made works on the first program of his two-week season at the Baryshnikov Arts Center were structurally similar and underwhelming.

headline: When the Tarot Trumps All
text: IF you were to peruse all the decks of tarot cards listed on the Aeclectic Tarot Web site, you might want, in poker parlance, to fold then and there.
