headline: Looking at Intimacy, for Bodies and Minds
text: Desire, as the choreographer Gesel Mason knows, is only one part of sex. Another may be guilt. Or insecurity. Or shame. But what’s wrong with being an independent spirit and sleeping with whomever you want? In “Women, Sex, & Desire: Sometimes You Feel Like a Ho, Sometimes You Don’t,” which opened at the Joyce SoHo on Thursday evening, Ms. Mason explores sexual behavior using two extremes — the whore and the prude — as a starting point.

headline: Pent-Up Feelings Set Free by Puppets
text: Satan, the great tempter of men’s souls, takes deceptively innocuous form in the frisky new comedy “Hand to God,” by Robert Askins, at the Ensemble Studio Theater. The particular demonic presence in Mr. Askins’s play has nasty teeth and spooky eyes — fairly standard attributes — but he’s also made of felt and yarn. Yes, the Devil is a sock puppet in this foul-mouthed, fun-packed play about the urges that drive good men (and women, and boys) to dirty deeds.

headline: On Screen Wedding Gowns
text: Photos of wedding gowns from movie weddings.

headline: Green Fades, Ambers and Golds Radiate
text: For a moment, I am rendered motionless, too much in awe to move. My eyes linger on the forested crest of the park ahead of me at the top of the road. It is a dazzling display of autumnal splendor. Loud, raucous and bright hues welcome us into the woods this Monday morning. The trees themselves seem to say, “Come in.”

headline: Penn State Has Exemption From Disclosure Law
text: The criminal allegations against Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State assistant football coach accused of sexually abusing young boys, have prompted questions about what officials at Penn State knew and when.

headline: Rural French Baking, From Oven to Recipes
text: ON a splendid autumn Saturday in Hudson, in Columbia County, it is all but impossible to find a place to park on Warren Street — a mile-long stretch that hums with antiques shops, boutiques and storefront restaurants. But on most days, when Lisa Brickman, the baker in chief at Cafe le Perche, walks to work at midnight, she has the street pretty much to herself.

headline: Last Call for Your Time Capsule Photos
text: Update | View the visual time capsule here.

headline: Show of Hands, Please: Who Can Buy Art?
text: THE artist Cindy Sherman stood underneath “Bangkok II,” a new large-scale photograph by Andreas Gursky that was being unveiled Nov. 4 at the fortress-like Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea. Ms. Sherman stared in amusement as Mr. Gursky and Klaus Biesenbach, the MoMA P.S. 1 director, fawned over her sequined Marni handbag. “Oooh, nice,” cooed Larry Gagosian, the super gallerist. “Are you coming by later?”

headline: On Patrol With Syrian Army Defectors
text: As my colleague Nada Bakri reports, a deadly crackdown on dissent continued in Syria on Friday, even as protesters returned to the streets in several cities.

headline: All About Your Airbnb Experiences
text: In this weekend’s “Your Money” column, I took a weeklong lap of New York City, staying in five Airbnb rentals in five different neighborhoods. My goal was to see how much hassle I would have to endure in exchange for what amount of savings over comparable hotels.

headline: In Ad Agency Merger, Vitro Takes on Skinny
text: Two smaller advertising agencies owned by MDC Partners are merging to form a single agency with offices on the East and West Coasts.

headline: Trustee Cuts 1,066 Jobs at MF Global; CME Pledges Backing for Customers
text: The court-appointed trustee overseeing the liquidation of MF Global’s brokerage unit laid off 1,066 employees on Friday, the biggest wave of job cuts at the firm since it collapsed into bankruptcy nearly two weeks ago.

headline: Martha Raddatz Tells War Stories With a Human Angle
text: If there has been a glamour beat in television news in recent years, it may well be war correspondent.

headline: Sandusky Earned $456,000 From Charity
text: The tax-exempt charity founded by Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State defensive coordinator charged with 40 counts of abusing young boys, paid him $456,000 from 2000 to 2008, according to Deadspin’s lengthy look at the organization’s federal tax filings.

headline: Telling the Stories of War Through Many Voices
text: EVEN for a woman who has been known to jump out of helicopters, this fall has been “particularly crazy,” says Martha Raddatz, the senior foreign affairs correspondent for ABC News.

headline: This Sunday: 1,028 Itty-Bitty People
text: It stands to reason that when we put a story on the cover we think it’s worthy of your time and effort, and this week there is no doubt about that. With the singularity of purpose that an intelligence officer brings to an interrogation room, Ronen Bergman has powerfully illuminated the past and present of Israeli prisoner exchanges, focusing on the recent swap of 1,027 Palestinians for a single Israeli soldier named Gilad Shalit. How can such a deal be justified in a nation that prides itself on not negotiating with terrorists? What about the citizens who’ve been killed and maimed by those now being freed? These are the questions that drive Bergman’s story.

headline: Local Ingredients Make an Ever-Shifting Menu
text: WITH its pale clapboard siding and mature rose bushes by the front porch, the Millstone Café blends in so well with its neighbors that it appears to have been a fixture of Kent for years. The cafe actually opened 14 months ago, a long time for a restaurant, but a mere blip in the life of a village.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (0) vs. France (1)
text: Drab. Dull. Defeatist. Depressing. Dreadful. If we gave letter grades here at Goal, the U.S. would get a “D.”

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Fleet
text: In New York everything is over the top, and the New York City Marathon is no exception.

headline: Museum of the Great War
text: Photos of the new museum in Meaux, France.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,816 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Back Again From Italy, With Boar and More
text: THE culinary career of Nicola Moncada, the owner of Il Cinghiale in Little Ferry, has never left him in one place for all that long. Born in Sicily, he made his way to Florence, London, Paris and New York before returning to Italy and opening his first restaurant in Novara, 30 miles west of Milan, in 1995. In 2000, he followed a brother to New Jersey and opened Nicola Due in Little Falls, a small but popular B.Y.O. that, he says, served up a lot of “chicken parm.”

headline: Annabelle Lyon, Dancer for Balanchine, Dies at 95
text: Annabelle Lyon, an American ballerina who danced with some of the most important companies in the formative years of 20th-century American ballet, died on Nov. 4 at her home in Mansfield, Mass. She was 95.

headline: Bringing the War Home
text: MEAUX, France — Despite the opening on Friday of a Museum of the Great War here, it is difficult to conceive of what took place in 1914, in pastoral farm country just outside this small industrial town about 25 miles northeast of central Paris. But you can get some idea from the ornately writhing figure of Liberty entwined with the dead and dying in the seven-story-tall stone statue that was mounted here in 1932, a gift of Americans and sculptured by Frederick MacMonnies.

headline: Herman Cain’s Wife Plans to Sit Down for a Television Interview
text: Introducing … Gloria Etchison Cain.

headline: If It Involves Performing, Does That Make It Art?
text: After attending two Performa events — “Performa Ha!” and Simon Fujiwara’s “Boy Who Cried Wolf” — and witnessing six different performances, I find myself wondering, what is performance art, anyway?

headline: In Georgia, Some Vote to Stay Dry on Sundays
text: ELBERTON, Ga. — The joke in Georgia after Tuesday’s election was that the most popular name on the ballot was Jack Daniel’s.

headline: Henry D. Owen, 91, Dies; Shaped Global Fiscal Order
text: Henry D. Owen, an influential diplomat who helped institutionalize global economic summitry in the 1970s and who was considered an intellectual framer of the elite round table known as the Trilateral Commission, died on Nov. 5 in Washington. He was 91.

headline: Lebanon: Hearing on Hariri Trial
text: A United Nations-backed court on Friday heard arguments on holding a trial in absentia for the four Hezbollah members who have been indicted in the killing of a former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, in 2005. The prosecution of the Special Tribunal for Lebanon, near The Hague, argued that the Beirut government should do more to track down and hand over the men, or else present evidence to the court on why it cannot. The court issued arrest warrants for the men in June, but leaders of the powerful Hezbollah militia vowed that its members would never be found or detained. A prosecutor, Iain Morley, said it was too early to begin a trial without the defendants because “a trial in absentia should be a last resort.”

headline: The Best of Scuttlebot–the Weekend Reading Edition
text: For your enjoyment over the weekend, here’s what the reporters and editors of the New York Times tech staff found on the Web. You’ll find the day’s full Scuttlebot feed on this page in the right-hand column.

headline: City Opera’s Growth Plan Depends on Donors
text: When New York City Opera faced a financial emergency early this year, its leadership promised to overhaul finances and live firmly within the company’s means. Last spring City Opera even decided to move out of its prestigious home at Lincoln Center to save money. But an internal planning document that lists a creeping deficit shows how hard it is to stick to such intentions in the costly world of opera.

headline: Virginia: Shaken Reactors Cleared
text: The twin North Anna nuclear reactors, located about 10 miles from the epicenter of the Aug. 23 earthquake, are safe to restart, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Friday. The reactors were shaken more than their designers anticipated, and they are the first in the United States to have faced an extended shutdown because of an earthquake. Dominion, their owner, said it spent $21 million on inspections. Government regulators will monitor the start-up, which is expected to take about 10 days. The company agreed to improve its monitoring of  the fault that caused the quake, which was felt across the East.

headline: Iraq: Two Shot After Soccer Victory
text: Celebratory gunfire wounded two people in Baghdad on Friday after Iraq defeated China, 1-0, in World Cup qualifying play. Before the Asia Cup earlier this year, the Iraqi government banned celebratory gunshots, which are in part a legacy of looting of military arsenals in 2003 that widely dispersed guns to the population. Iraqis seem to pay no heed and shoot anyway, probably making victory shooting, and injuries from falling bullets, a part of soccer culture in Iraq for some time.

headline: Blake Is Playing With Purpose and Supporting a Cause
text: James Blake doesn’t mind bringing his comeback tour through New York a second time this year. Blake, a former top 5 player who sunk as low as No. 173 in the ATP rankings earlier this year, will recall his New York roots and the memory of his father at a fund-raiser Nov. 28 at Lincoln Center.

headline: Timeline: The Penn State Scandal
text: A grand jury report detailed the alleged incidents of sexual abuse committed by Jerry Sandusky, who went on trial on June 11.

headline: Turkey: Ferry Hijacker Killed
text: A Kurdish militant who had hijacked a ferry with 18 passengers on board Friday afternoon in northwestern Turkey was shot to death by Turkish commandos. The militant had threatened to detonate explosives if he failed to get media exposure, local officials said. The governor of Istanbul, Huseyin Avni Mutlu, told The Associated Press that the passengers were all safe and that the hijacker “was a member of the terrorist organization.” Earlier, Binali Yildirim, the transportation minister, told the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency that four or five militants, identifying themselves as members of a subdivision of the Kurdistan Workers Party, had overpowered the captain and demanded food and fuel. The ferry, named Kartepe, was en route to Golcuk from Izmit, both coastal towns on the Sea of Marmara.

headline: Giants’ Bradshaw Out for 49ers Game, but Nicks May Play
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants running back Ahmad Bradshaw did not practice again Friday and was ruled out of Sunday’s game against the San Francisco 49ers, which was no positive development for a team hoping to try to pierce the N.F.L.’s toughest run defense.

headline: Japanese Décor, Pan-Asian Menu
text: IN June, when Ten Ten Bistro moved into the Northgate Plaza in Mount Sinai, right next door to the highly regarded Chinese restaurant Lotus East II, this strip mall became the headquarters for Asian food in the area.

headline: 2 Computers in Battle for Title Evaluate a Hand Differently
text: The 15th World Computer-Bridge Championship was held concurrently with the 40th World Team Championships in the Netherlands last month.

headline: Podcast: Europe, Pensions, Wealth and Phone Bills
text: For much of the past week, financial markets have fretted more about Italy than about Greece, which had been the main focus of worries for many weeks.

headline: Allies Have Doubts About Protesters in Wisconsin
text: MADISON, Wis. — They wander the marble halls, day after day, hollering at passing lawmakers. They have turned up in committee meetings wearing peculiar masks. They are occasionally carried away by the police for filming official proceedings (not allowed in the chamber galleries) and for holding small signs (also barred in the galleries) quoting from documents like the Constitution. One is accused of pouring a beer over the head of a Republican leader, the co-chairman of the joint finance committee.

headline: The Gingrich Surge Has Come
text: There’s lots of buzz on Friday about national polls that are variously being interpreted as good news for Newt Gingrich, good or bad news for Mitt Romney, and good or bad news for Herman Cain. So let’s take a step back and focus on the bigger picture.

headline: Soy Diet Is Cruel and Unusual, Florida Inmate Claims
text: MIAMI — One too many bouts of flatulence and cramping has led a Florida inmate to sue the Department of Corrections, arguing that the prison’s soy-based turkey dogs and sloppy Joes amount to cruel and unusual punishment.

headline: Vicious Brats? No Wonder
text: We may prepare exquisite desserts, arrange tulips in crystal vases and pile rare art books atop the coffee table. But suitably provoked, even the most civilized among us will unleash the ferocious child who lives within — the one who scarfs down sweets with two hands, smashes the tulips, vomits on the books.

headline: Happy to Call the City Home, More Now Move In Than Out
text: Juan Rosales had tired of his predictable life in Chicago, where he worked in City Hall. “I had reached a point in my life when I, essentially, wanted to reboot and start over,” Mr. Rosales said, “and wanted to do so in a city that would make such a big decision worth the risk.”

headline: Win or Lose, a Big Game Comes With the Possibility of a Big Letdown
text: Alabama defensive end Jesse Williams decided he was going to crouch on the grass of Bryant-Denny Stadium late last Saturday night and rest a moment after the tumult of a big game.

headline: To Catch Up, Perry Makes a Big Ad Buy
text: Ramping up his effort to recover from his embarrassing debate performance on Wednesday, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas purchased nearly $1 million in advertising time on Fox News Channel, an extraordinary commitment of resources intended to jolt his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination back on track.

headline: Arms and the Corrupt Man
text: London

headline: Guess What It’s Time For!
text: It’s the weekend. The air is brisk, the leaves are tumbling, so it’s time for — yes! — another Republican debate!

headline: A Skipper’s Dream Outlives His Beloved Yacht
text: PORTSMOUTH, R.I. — When a wooden yacht called the Petrel was recently demolished on Martha’s Vineyard, two generations of sailors and boat enthusiasts blanched — including some on another island, Manhattan, where the yacht’s former owner used to offer $3.75 rides in New York Harbor.

headline: Unrest in Syria Divides a Region as a Border Never Did
text: GORENTAS, Turkey — Rostom, a Syrian refugee, stood near the peak of this hilltop village, peering through binoculars in hopes of catching a glimpse of troop movements across the Syrian border, which lay at the bottom of the valley floor below.

headline: Veterans Day Parade in New York
text: The 92nd Annual New York Veterans Day Parade took place on Fifth Avenue and included active officers, veterans’ groups, junior ROTC members and the families of veterans.

headline: After 33 Years, Still Promising to Behave
text: You wouldn’t know, watching the spiffy Long Wharf production — or is it really a re-production? — of “Ain’t Misbehavin’,” that this Tony-winning musical has become something of a cottage industry. The stars have all performed it before. The director, choreographer and two of the main designers have been doing the show since its beginnings, in 1978. It’s only the ninth go-round for the musical director.

headline: Cain’s Paine
text: Who knew that all you need to be president of the United States is a modicum of common sense? All year, the candidates for the Republican nomination have been touting their intimate relationship with this humdrum way of seeing the world. Michele Bachmann claimed that “everything I needed to know in life I learned in Iowa,” which she left at the age of 12. Rick Perry told Iowans that unlike the current president, he doesn’t have a lot of interest in “studies” when it comes to restoring economic health. “We know what the problem is,” he said. “It’s not magic, it is actually common sense.” We shouldn’t “spend all the money.” Even decidedly unfolksy Mitt Romney announced this week at a gathering of Americans for Prosperity, “I believe we can save Social Security with a few common-sense reforms.”

headline: The Right Move on Keystone XL
text: President Obama made just the right call on Thursday when he delayed a final decision on the Keystone XL oil pipeline from Canada until 2013.

headline: S.E.C. Punishes 8 Workers in Errors Tied to Madoff
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission disciplined eight employees for missteps related to Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, with punishments as varied as suspensions or written reprimands, an agency spokesman said.

headline: To Keep Up With Yankees, Look Beyond Sports Pages
text: The Yankees have long been famous for making news, even in the off-season. George M. Steinbrenner could make headlines by dropping millions on the latest free agent or by complaining publicly about the one he had dropped millions on a couple of off-seasons before.

headline: Power Broker Savors a Victory in San Francisco
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Perhaps no one took more pleasure in the city’s first election of a Chinese-American mayor than Rose Pak.

headline: Coded Messages
text: In the 1970s, a military junta took over Uruguay, and repression and violence pervaded the everyday life of ordinary citizens; Rimer Cardillo made art that protested these conditions. Working in a dangerous atmosphere, however, he needed a visual language that would disguise and code his critiques. And so he did what artists in similar circumstances have often done. He turned to the natural world, specifically, insects.

headline: Up Against the Wall
text: The scene is a freshman room at Yale, mid-’50s. Four occupants. First week of classes.

headline: A Bid to Get Film Lovers Not to Rent
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood has had enough of the sharp consumer shift toward renting movies through Netflix. Desperate to raise home entertainment profits, studios want people to start buying movies outright again, either digitally or on little silver discs.

headline: As Foes Flounder, Gingrich Gets Bump in Poll
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Newt Gingrich got his meltdown out of the way early. Last spring he endured a series of setbacks, culminating with the resignations of nearly his entire campaign staff, a fund-raising drought and a descent into margin-of-error territory in the polls.

headline: Tennessee’s Push to Transform Schools
text: Tennessee has a long way to go in improving its schools, but it has made significant headway in turning itself into a laboratory for education reform. It was one of the first states to test a rigorous teacher evaluation system, which was put in place this school year. Yet even before the results are in, political forces are now talking about delaying the use of these evaluations. State lawmakers and education officials must resist any backsliding.

headline: Affirmation of Health Care Reform
text: A federal appeals court in the District of Columbia endorsed the constitutionality of health care reform this week in an opinion as notable for its authorship as for its legal reasoning. The majority opinion in the 2-to-1 decision was written by Judge Laurence Silberman, a stalwart of conservative jurisprudence whose views are said to be enormously influential in conservative legal circles.

headline: Season Tips Off in Location Unlike Any Other
text: ABOARD U.S.S. CARL VINSON, CORONADO, Calif. — The premise seemed closer to fiction: the first college basketball game held on a 95,000-ton, Nimitz-class aircraft carrier, the court constructed on its flight deck, where fighter jets normally speed away, propelled by catapults that shoot them off at 150 miles an hour into war zones. Normal this was not.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Photo Replay: North Carolina vs. Michigan State
text: North Carolina and Michigan State played each other on the deck of the aircraft carrier U.S.S. Carl Vinson.

headline: A Taste for Reality TV Seen in Popularity of Presidential Debates
text: On Saturday night, eight Republican candidates will gather in South Carolina for the 10th presidential debate — and much will be riding on the outcome.

headline: A Room of Her Own
text: Two years ago, when Naterly Perez was 18, she woke up in the hospital alive, and she was disappointed. She had tried to kill herself by swallowing a handful of Xanax and Tylenol after being arrested for intervening in a fight between a friend and another girl. A judge, after hearing her story, ordered her into a one-year mental health program at Brooklyn Community Services, where she now participates in daily group sessions and creative arts therapies.

headline: Was Freedom Enough?
text: In recent years, scholars have begun to see emancipation from slavery as more than just a legal step, but as a long historical process.

headline: The Institutional Pass
text: “Joe is a devout Catholic,” a retired football coach named Vince McAneney told a reporter the other day. He was referring, of course, to Joe Paterno.

headline: Loves, New and Old: A Comedy of ‘Kinship Structures’
text: Cindy and Greer, when they were together, were the kind of couple — New England lesbian academics of a certain age — who would never have had a television set in the house. Yet later, the sitcom “Friends” insinuates its way into their lives, and into the plot of “Seven Homeless Mammoths Wander New England.”

headline: Atticus Teaches a Lesson in Racism
text: At first the set bothered me. For the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey’s fine and very touching, if sometimes off-key, production of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” the scenic designer, Anita Tripathi Easterling, has put the Finch family’s homey front porch within spitting distance of Boo Radley’s ominous front door. It can’t be much of a dare for a child to run up and touch that door, despite the presence of the scary, reclusive man on the other side, if it’s never far away.

headline: Penn State Officials, Including Paterno, Could Face Civil Lawsuits
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — It may take years, but Penn State, its administrators and possibly even the former coach Joe Paterno could be the targets of civil lawsuits seeking extensive monetary damages once the criminal case against a former assistant coach is concluded, trial lawyers with experience in similar cases said Friday.

headline: Subway Thief? Or Just an Expert on Wallets and Razor Blades?
text: The jailhouse visiting room was filling up and getting louder on Thursday, and so the oldest inmate there did not quite hear the question.

headline: Plan Would Delay Sales of Generic for Lipitor
text: The biggest introduction of a generic drug in pharmaceutical history is being met with tough business strategies by Pfizer and pharmacy benefit companies, according to recent letters to pharmacists.

headline: U.N. Officials Accuse Sudan of a Bombing
text: Senior United Nations officials sided with newly independent South Sudan on Friday in accusing Sudan of bombing a southern civilian encampment the day before. One United Nations official called for an investigation, suggesting that a war crime might have been committed.

headline: EMI Is Sold for $4.1 Billion in Combined Deals, Consolidating the Music Industry
text: EMI, the venerable music company that is home to the Beatles, the Beach Boys and the Motown song catalog, has been sold for $4.1 billion through a pair of deals that usher in a new wave of consolidation in the music industry.

headline: Discussion with Edward L. Ayers
text: Join Disunion on Monday, Nov. 14, at 2 p.m. on our Facebook page for a conversation with Edward L. Ayers, a noted Civil War historian and Disunion contributor, about his new book, “America’s War: Talking About the Civil War and Emancipation on Their 150th Anniversaries.” Dr. Ayers, the president of the University of Richmond, will answer questions about the book, the sesquicentennial and Civil War history.

headline: Net Migration: A Bigger Apple
text: More people are calling New York City home.

headline: No Goals, Again, for Struggling U.S.
text: ST.-DENIS, France — For the moment, Jurgen Klinsmann could scarcely care less about losses and victories.

headline: CNN Sets Off a Debate on Race and Technology
text: For nearly two weeks, a debate ignited by a CNN documentary has raged on the Internet about the obstacles to success in Silicon Valley and whether the technology industry is as meritocratic and as color-blind as it aspires to be.

headline: Norton Dodge Dies at 84; Stored Soviet Dissident Art
text: Norton Dodge, a genially rumpled economics professor who in the course of research trips to study arcana like tractors and workforce demographics managed quietly to amass the world’s largest collection of nonconformist Soviet art, died on Nov. 5 in Washington. He was 84.

headline: Friend With Benefits
text: Government is not the enemy. Not always. Don’t believe that right-wing malarkey.

headline: Saturday: People Who See What You’re Saying
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Barry C. Silk’s puzzles have really grown on me.

headline: Yemeni Forces Heighten Deadly Assault on Protesters in City Central to Uprising
text: ADEN, Yemen — Yemeni government forces attacked protesters and residential areas on Friday in the southern city of Taiz, killing at least 15 civilians and wounding dozens of others, residents said.

headline: How One Company Performed Under Bain Capital
text: How an Illinois medical company performed under Mitt Romney’s private equity firm, Bain Capital.

headline: Sinopec Buys Stake in Portuguese Energy Company
text: Sinopec has agreed to invest almost $5.2 billion in the Brazilian operations of the Portuguese energy company Galp Energia, the latest move in a global expansion by Sinopec, China’s largest oil refiner. Under the terms of the deal, the state-owned Sinopec will invest $4.8 billion for a 30 percent stake in Petrogal Brasil, a subsidiary of Galp Energia. The Chinese company will make lend an additional $390 million to the Brazilian business. Galp Energia will retain the remaining 70 percent of Petrogal Brasil. The deal values the company’s Brazilian assets at $12.5 billion. China’s energy companies have spent billions of dollars in recent years to gain access to new energy resources. In October, Sinopec agreed to buy Daylight Energy, a Canadian oil and natural gas producer, for about $2.1 billion. The Chinese company also paid $7.1 billion last year for a 40 percent stake in the Brazilian assets of the Spanish energy firm Repsol YPF.

headline: Murdoch’s Former Allies Deliver a Counterpunch
text: LONDON — The day after James Murdoch appeared before a parliamentary panel investigating allegations of phone hacking at The News of the World tabloid, he was firmly locked in a high-stakes battle of wills with the tabloid’s last editor, Colin Myler, and a former legal manager, Tom Crone.

headline: Europe’s Woes Pose New Peril to Recovery in the U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — For the second time in two years, European debt troubles threaten to slow the momentum of the fragile recovery in the United States.

headline: On Campus, a Law Enforcement System to Itself
text: After the body of an Eastern Michigan University freshman was found in her dorm room in December 2006, naked from the waist down with a pillow over her head, the chief of the university police said there was “no reason to suspect foul play,” and let her parents believe she had died of natural causes.

headline: Often at Center of Mayhem, Emergency Rooms Tend to Be Gunfire-Free Zones
text: It would seem almost inevitable, yet still hard to fathom: rival gang members, angered and perhaps aggrieved over some recent disagreement, seek to continue or end the dispute the next time they meet — even if that encounter occurs at a hospital.

headline: Phillies Lure Papelbon From Boston
text: Jonathan Papelbon will depart the perennially pressure-packed American League East for the emerging crucible that is the National League East.

headline: Classical Piano and Modern Design
text: Rafael Viñoly, the globetrotting architect who designed Jazz at Lincoln Center, has just completed the first “green” police station for the New York Police Department, scheduled to open on Staten Island in July, and is responsible for the master plan for the conversion of the Domino Sugar plant in Brooklyn to a residential development. He divides his Sundays between the drawing board and the keyboard: he owns nine pianos, and as a child in Uruguay he trained to be a classical pianist. Mr. Viñoly, 67, lives in TriBeCa with his wife, Diana, an interior designer. The couple, whose three grown children and three grandchildren live in the neighborhood, also have homes in Water Mill, N.Y., and London.

headline: Milkshakes by Day, Spiked Ones at Night
text: On the gastronomically arriviste stretch of the Bowery near Second Street sits Peels, the latest from Taavo Somer, the trend-maker partly responsible for Freemans, where diners slip down an alley to eat venison under an array of antlers, and the Rusty Knot.

headline: N.B.A. Players Weigh Legitimacy of Latest Ultimatum
text: One hundred-thirty-four days into the N.B.A. lockout, the bargaining calculus for players has changed. Their immediate concern is no longer revenue splits or tax rates, but how to gauge another league ultimatum.

headline: Obama Trip Stresses Ties to Economies Across Pacific
text: SAN DIEGO — After a decade in which wars in the Middle East have dominated American foreign policy, President Obama began an eight-day trip around the Pacific Rim on Friday to inaugurate what he hopes will be a new era in which engagement with the fast-growing economies of Asia is paramount.

headline: Independent Once Again After a Devastating Blaze
text: The blaze started on a chilly morning in February, in the basement below the first-floor apartment in Brooklyn that Mariya Vakhlis had rented for 20 years. It engulfed the two-story building, turning to cinder all her worldly possessions save for a blanket from her native Belarus and an album of photographs of relatives lost to the Nazis during World War II.

headline: An AIDS Gala, With Honors and a Few Red Carpet Jitters
text: Miguel Bosé is a big deal in Latin America. He has won a Latin Grammy Award, recorded more than 20 albums and starred in more than 35 films. He has also raised significant money to fight H.I.V. and AIDS. We were impressed, and at an Aid for AIDS gala in TriBeCa on Tuesday honoring Mr. Bosé and others for their good works, Nocturnalist’s correspondent wanted to hear more about what brought him here, in his own words.

headline: For Disabled Care Complaints, Vow of Anonymity Was False
text: ALBANY — For years, New York State has assured its employees who care for the developmentally disabled that there was a way they could confidentially report any concerns they had about the treatment of those in their care.

headline: Where to Eat?
text: APP Immaculate Infatuation

headline: Cuomo Pledges to Fight Joblessness Among Minority Youths
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, in a speech aimed at reaffirming his standing with the Hispanic community, vowed on Friday that in the next legislative session he would take on joblessness among young people in New York’s State’s minority communities.

headline: Rangers Roll to Sixth Straight Victory
text: Three goals in three minutes in the third period Friday night gave the Rangers a 5-1 win — their sixth straight victory — over Carolina at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Somewhere There's a Cowboy
text: Orville Davis has retained his cowboy image, in the saddle and on the bandstand, for the past 35 years he has lived in New York City.

headline: A Cowboy at Home in the City
text: Orville Davis, a cowboy and musician, first came to New York in 1976 for a two-week vacation and has been here ever since.

headline: Horses, Music and a Happy Cowboy
text: ORVILLE DAVIS jokes that there are plenty of city-slickers who make a living shoveling horse dung, but he does it literally.

headline: Jets’ Receivers Looking to Maintain Momentum
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Wearing sweat pants, gloves and a thermal turtleneck, Jeremy Kerley was prepared for the coldest practice of the week Friday.

headline: As Schools Sacrifice, TV Shows Flourish
text: On Tuesday afternoon, a hundred or so parents of New York City public-school children, most of them mothers from the leafier precincts of Brooklyn, gathered outside the Manhattan office of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to rally against the potential extinguishing of the so-called millionaires’ tax. With $1.4 billion for schools cut from the state budget last year, these parents wondered why the governor was so committed to helping the well-off become even better positioned. “Millionaire rhymes with fair and share,” one placard announced.

headline: Kidnapped Ballplayer Ramos Found Alive in Venezuela
text: Venezuelan security forces rescued the kidnapped Washington Nationals catcher Wilson Ramos in an airborne operation on Friday after finding him in a mountainous area of northern Venezuela, officials said.

headline: Dragster Kings Resume a Rivalry, Slowly
text: Nearly 21 years after he was paralyzed when his top fuel dragster crashed on an exhibition run in England, Darrell Gwynn strapped himself into a red racecar at a track in Gainesville, Fla., and once again took on his flamboyant nemesis, the legendary Big Daddy, Don Garlits.

headline: Shots Fired Near White House
text: Shots were fired from at least one car about a block away from the White House Friday night, and a loaded AK-47 assault rifle was recovered from the scene, the Secret Service said. The episode does not appear to be connected to the White House. President Obama was in California and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was in New York for Veterans Day observances, according to their public schedules. Secret Service officers heard gunfire near Constitution Avenue and 16th Street around 9 p.m., said Ed Donovan, a spokesman for the Secret Service. Two cars drove off west on the avenue before one, a black Honda, was found abandoned near 23rd Street, Mr. Donovan said. Witnesses told officers that a man fled the car on foot. Officers found the loaded assault rifle in the car, Mr. Donovan said. The authorities were searching for the people who may have been involved.

headline: The World This Week, Part One
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: The World This Week, Part Two
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: Games to Watch on Saturday
text: NO. 6 OREGON AT NO. 3 STANFORD8 p.m., ABC

headline: Data-Crunching Mayor Now Sees Power in Words
text: MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG is not, by his own admission, much of a wordsmith. He is forever mispronouncing names — even those of his own commissioners. He is impatient with speechwriters. And he rarely, if ever, practices his remarks.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: The Costs of Child Care

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: The Supreme Court of India on Friday expressed shock over the detention of two Pakistani nationals in Jammu and Kashmir jails for more than 40 years without facing trial. The court was hearing a plea filed by the state political party, Jammu & Kashmir National Panthers Party seeking the release of Pakistanis in prisons across India. The court has demanded a comprehensive status report from the national government on Pakistani detainees in Indian jails. (Kashmir News Live)

headline: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
text: Ra.One: The hot topic in Bollywood this week was “Ra.One” number-crunching. As the dust settled on Shah Rukh Khan’s ambitious video game-romance-revenge movie, the question remained: is it a hit or a flop? Kishore Lulla, CEO of Eros International, which co-produced and distributed the film, said that the film was a profitable venture from the first week itself.

headline: Berlusconi Steps Down, and Italy Pulses With Change
text: ROME — With his country swept up in Europe’s debt crisis and his once-mighty political capital spent, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi resigned on Saturday, punctuating a tumultuous week and ending an era in Italian politics.

headline: Hodges Added to Hall Credentials After Playing Days
text: My son recently scored in the upper 80s on a math test, a perfectly fine score but below his own standards. He also got the extra-credit question correct, which catapulted him into the 90s, his threshold for excellence.

headline: Understated Rookie Fuels Bengals’ Makeover
text: CINCINNATI — The wish list was prepared in March: a receiver, a quarterback, cornerbacks, linebackers, interior offensive linemen. After a season with only four victories and with a franchise quarterback intent on never returning, Coach Marvin Lewis could not be shy about all the parts the Cincinnati Bengals had to replace. It had been his job to relay to the front office that Carson Palmer would not play for them again, and now it was the Bengals’ job to find Palmer’s replacement.

headline: Sights and Sounds on the Grounds of a Nuclear Disaster
text: Updated | Sunday | 7:19 p.m. Eight months after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station was crippled by an earthquake and tsunami, the Japanese government has opened the compound and surrounding area to the media for the first time. On Saturday, a group of reporters, including Martin Fackler of The New York Times, toured the plant. In this post, he describes his trip to the damaged facility:

headline: The Angry Aftermath for a Program Gone Awry
text: A former Penn State defensive coordinator, Jerry Sandusky, was charged Nov. 5 with sexually abusing eight boys over a 15-year stretch. Two university officials stepped down after being charged with perjury in the case. Neither Joe Paterno, the longtime football coach, nor Graham B. Spanier, the university president, was charged, but questions were raised about whether they and an assistant, Mike McQueary, did as much as they could have done to stop the suspected assaults. Paterno and Spanier were fired last week, and McQueary was put on administrative leave. Here are some of the many letters readers sent to The Times.

headline: A.F.C. East Title Is the Divide in an Otherwise Tight Rivalry
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — A veteran of Baltimore’s bruising twice-a-season tangles with Pittsburgh, Rex Ryan flung himself into his new rivalry — a decidedly lopsided one — with all the subtlety of a bazooka. He used his new platform as the Jets’ coach, in 2009, to spread his audacious gospel, that they would topple the mighty Patriots, that he would never smooch Bill Belichick’s Super Bowl rings.

headline: The Haas Family Tree Has Many Offshoots
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Whether by phone, text or in person, Bill Haas conducts a postround analysis of his play with his father, Jay, a professional golfer for more than 30 years.

text: THERE are millions of Americans seeking love on the Internet. Little do they know that teams of scientists are eagerly watching them trying to find it.

headline: For Obama, a Little Basketball Before the Diplomacy
text: ABOARD THE U.S.S. CARL VINSON – The presidency does have its perks. And for President Obama, basketball’s fan in chief, one was the opportunity on Friday night to watch the No. 1 ranked college basketball team, the University of North Carolina Tar Heels, play the Michigan State Spartans on the flight deck of an aircraft carrier whose mission six months ago was to bury Osama bin Laden at sea.

headline: Of Rookies and Symmetry at Abu Dhabi Practice

Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can also follow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

headline: Tackling the 49ers’ Gore Doesn’t Mean You’ve Stopped Him
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — With about three minutes remaining in last month’s game between San Francisco and Philadelphia, 49ers running back Frank Gore took a handoff at the Eagles’ 12-yard line and cut through a hole in the line of scrimmage.

headline: On Wikipedia, the Western Black Rhino Moves from ‘Is’ to ‘Was’
text: In tracking the erosion of the world’s diverse array of living things, a new phenomenon is emerging: the spread of the past tense on wildlife entries in Wikipedia. The latest case of a description tipping from is to was comes in the listing for the western black rhinoceros, one of four subspecies of the black rhinoceros. On the new species “red list” issued by the International Union for Conservation of Nature, this subspecies has been declared extinct — moved from red to black.

text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — It’s been a while since we’ve had a cryptic crossword from Richard Silvestri, and I, for one, am glad he’s back. Mr. Silvestri can bring the clever clues and the laughs, and after the busy week I had, I’m all for that.

headline: A Small Town, Almost Waterless, Takes a Big Gamble

text: THE Occupy Wall Street movement has raised important questions about the respect paid to wealth in our society. There is a good deal of unfairness in the American economy, and by deliberately targeting the “top 1 percent,” the demonstrators have opened up a dialogue that is quite useful.

headline: A Store for the Town, by the Town
text: Saranac Lake, N.Y., has not had a department store since 2002, and a push by Wal-Mart to build a supercenter proved divisive, even if residents had to drive 50 miles to buy basics. A community-owned store has finally opened, and other small towns are watching.

headline: Nuns Who Won’t Stop Nudging
text: ASTON, Pa.

headline: Even as Governments Act, Time Runs Short for Euro
text: BERLIN — The window of opportunity to save the euro is rapidly closing, as the sovereign debt crisis erodes the solvency of Europe’s banks and drives up borrowing rates for even once rock-solid countries like France.

headline: Your Begonia Is Texting You
text: IT was only a matter of time. Plants have begun texting for help. Thanks to clever new digital devices, a dry philodendron, undernourished hibiscus, or sadly neglected wandering Jew can send its owner a text or Twitter message. Humans like to feel appreciated, so a begonia may also send a simple “Thank-you” text — when it’s happy, as gardeners like to say, meaning healthy and well-tended. Picture your Boston fern home alone placing Botanicalls. But why should potted plants be the only ones to reassure their humans? Another company has found a way for crops to send text messages in unison, letting their farmer know if she’s doing a good enough job to deserve a robust harvest. What is the sound of one hand of bananas clapping? Probes monitoring the soil can send a range of prerecorded messages specific to each plant’s needs.

headline: 100,000 Football Fans at Penn State Cheer, but the Mood Is Numb
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — The tone for a Saturday football game under a bright sun was born in the darkness of a Friday night vigil at the epicenter of the Penn State campus. Spread across a grassy plain yards from the streets where demonstrators clashed with the police days earlier, several thousand students gathered holding lighted candles, a quickly organized rally in support of sexual abuse victims that concluded when a university bell tower chimed 10 times to mark the hour.

text: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y.

headline: A Singer’s Search for an AIDS Cure
text: MY father was in the military and was reassigned about every two years, so we moved around a lot. When he was sent to Vietnam in the early 1970s, the rest of us moved to Buffalo, where my parents were from.

headline: Billions Wasted on Billing
text: LAST year I had to have a minor biopsy. Every time I went in for an appointment, I had to fill out a form requiring my name, address, insurance information, emergency contact person, vaccination history, previous surgical history and current medical problems, medications and allergies. I must have done it four times in just three days. Then, after my procedure, I received bills — and, even more annoying, statements of charges that said they weren’t bills — almost daily, from the hospital, the surgeon, the primary care doctor, the insurance company.

headline: Robert A. Scalapino, a Scholar of Asian Politics, Dies at 92
text: Robert A. Scalapino, an eminent scholar of Asian politics who achieved prominence during the Vietnam War for his strong defense of American policy as opposition to it was growing, died Nov. 1 in Oakland, Calif. He was 92.

headline: After a Romney Deal, Profits and Then Layoffs
text: By the green-hued yardsticks of Wall Street, the 1990s buyout of an Illinois medical company by Mitt Romney’s private equity firm was a spectacular success.

headline: Matching Volunteers to the Right Missions
text: THE recession dealt a double blow to many nonprofits. Just as it ratcheted up demand for their services, it also forced them to cut their budgets. So in times like these, volunteers are more valuable than ever.

text: Italian Prime Minister steps down, Ending a 17-Year Political Era

headline: Markets in Sync: Finding the Downbeat
text: STOCKS have been moving largely in lock step with one another, and with many other assets as well. Especially when prices fall, this can be a source of great frustration.

headline: Young Farmers Find Huge Obstacles to Getting Started
text: Emily Oakley, who had worked on an organic farm in California, moved with her husband, Mike Appel, to Oaks, Okla., in pursuit of cheap farmland. But even though they had $25,000 saved, the couple could not get a bank loan. When they applied for a government loan, the loan officer threw back his head and laughed.

headline: NASA Hitches a Ride on a Russian Craft, and Begins a New Dependent Phase
text: A Russian Soyuz rocket with three astronauts — two Russians, one American — is set to lift off from Kazakhstan on Monday morning, ferrying the men to the International Space Station.

headline: Face Recognition Makes the Leap From Sci-Fi
text: FACIAL recognition technology is a staple of sci-fi thrillers like “Minority Report.”

headline: Chinese Study Says Dam Didn’t Affect Climate Change
text: BEIJING — A scientific study has found that the Three Gorges Dam, the world’s largest hydropower project, has not contributed to climate change, according to a report by Xinhua, the Chinese state news agency.

headline: Deportations Under New U.S. Policy Are Inconsistent
text: A new Obama administration policy to avoid deportations of illegal immigrants who are not criminals has been applied very unevenly across the country and has led to vast confusion both in immigrant communities and among agents charged with carrying it out.

headline: Dirty Harry Meets Dirtier Edgar
text: WASHINGTON

text: WHEN I think about the sins of Joe Paterno, and the ignominious ending of his long and famous career, I think about Darío Castrillón Hoyos.

headline: The Campaign Jungle
text: A series of television ads began running a few days ago supporting Gov. Rick Perry’s presidential bid. They were the usual fare — “conservative leadership that works” — and they featured old photos of him in the Air Force and video from the trail. A casual viewer might assume they were run by his campaign, but they were run by a new phenomenon this year: the candidate “super PAC” — by far the most noxious weed yet to emerge in the lawless new jungle of campaign finance.

headline: Gall in High Places
text: SILVIO BERLUSCONI isn’t comfortable with English. Brett Ratner, I’m guessing, hasn’t mastered Italian. What a pity. They’d probably get along like a palazzo on fire.

headline: Generation Sell
text: EVER since I moved three years ago to Portland, Ore., that hotbed of all things hipster, I’ve been trying to get a handle on today’s youth culture. The style is easy enough to describe — the skinny pants, the retro hats, the wall-to-wall tattoos. But style is superficial. The question is, what’s underneath? What idea of life? What stance with respect to the world?

headline: Will This Election Be the Mormon Breakthrough?
text: THIS fall, we behold omens that will darken a year hence in the final phase of President Obama’s campaign for a second term. His likely opponent, the Mormon Mitt Romney, will be a pioneer figure whatever the outcome, since no previous member of that very American church, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, has ever secured a major-party nomination. Even should Mr. Obama triumph, a crucial precedent will have been established.

headline: The New Progressive Movement
text: OCCUPY WALL STREET and its allied movements around the country are more than a walk in the park. They are most likely the start of a new era in America. Historians have noted that American politics moves in long swings. We are at the end of the 30-year Reagan era, a period that has culminated in soaring income for the top 1 percent and crushing unemployment or income stagnation for much of the rest. The overarching challenge of the coming years is to restore prosperity and power for the 99 percent.

headline: A New Era of Gunboat Diplomacy
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Remembering Flight 587, 10 Years Later
text: Under a canopy of bright blue sky, the 10th anniversary of the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 in Belle Harbor, Queens, was recognized on Saturday by some 500 relatives and friends of the victims.

headline: Why Are Political Cartoons Incendiary?
text: AS the founding editor and publisher in the late 1950’s of Monocle,  a “leisurely quarterly of political satire” (that meant we came out twice a year) whose motto was “In the land of the blind the one-eyed man is king,” whenever the offices of a satirical magazine are firebombed, I’m interested.

headline: Hit and Run
text: RECENTLY my dog, Honey, was taking a walk in the neighborhood with her dog walker, Lauren, when she was clipped by a car. Honey bolted, yanking the leash out of Lauren’s hand — apparently dogs get a huge surge of adrenaline after being hit by cars.

headline: Brady’s Mandate
text: The duty of every American prosecutor is to see that justice is done, not to convict criminal defendants by any means. For a generation, the district attorney’s office in New Orleans brazenly flouted this standard.

headline: Russia, in From the Cold
text: After 18 years of stop-and-go negotiations, it is good news that Russia, the world’s 11th largest economy, finally sealed a deal on Thursday to enter the World Trade Organization and subject its unruly form of capitalism to the strictures of international law.

headline: A Long, Winding Road to Marriage Equality
text: The fight for gay rights won important victories in the past few months. In July, it became legal for same-sex couples to marry in New York State. September saw the official end of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy that prevented gay people from serving openly in the military. On Thursday, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved a bill that would repeal the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act, the law that bars the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriages.

headline: Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me
text: NPR’s “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

headline: Who Is Occupy Wall Street?
text: OCCUPY WALL STREET has proved to be a difficult, sprawling story to report. Almost immediately after protesters began arriving at Zuccotti Park in downtown New York on Sept. 17, Times readers weighed in with concerns about the coverage.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Ideas for Cutting Military Spending
text: Readers respond to a former assistant secretary of defense’s suggestions for Pentagon cuts.

headline: Of Kentucky
text: Throughout my life I have experienced cultural diversity and continue to travel between two worlds, the hollers and cities. I was born in Hazard, Ky., and raised primarily in a holler called Johnson’s Fork, in Letcher County, where only mountain people had lived for generations. People from both sides of my family were born, lived and died here. Neither of my grandfathers ever lived anywhere else. In true mountain tradition, they both gave land to my parents to build their home.

headline: The Benefits of Fracking
text: To the Editor:

headline: Money-Laundering Case Speaks to Border Fears
text: LAREDO — The high walls of Alexander Estates, an affluent development nestled near this border city’s country club and golf course, were supposed to keep the narcotics world at bay. But when federal agents raided the stately home of a downtown perfume salesman in January, it reinforced a notion that is feared by Texas leaders: the drug war spillover from Mexico is much broader than shootouts and kidnappings — it is cloaked in the seemingly routine business transactions of the border economy.

headline: Silvio Berlusconi: From Publisher to Politician

headline: In Favor of Dirty Jokes and Risqué Remarks

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, November 13
text: The arrest of a former assistant football coach at Penn State, Jerry Sandusky, on charges that he sexually abused young boys, put the university in the middle of a scandal over the last week and led to the removal of longtime coach Joe Paterno and the president, Graham B. Spanier. On Sunday, Gov. Tom Corbett of Pennsylvania, who has begun an investigation into the abuse accusations as the state’s attorney general, joins NBC’s “Meet the Press,” “Fox News Sunday” and ABC’s “This Week” to discuss the case.

headline: As 9/11 Remains Are Identified, Grief Is Renewed
text: On Nov. 19, 2001, Susan Ainbinder Hutchins received a call saying that her son, Kevin Colbert, who worked at an investment bank on the 89th floor of 2 World Trade Center, had been identified among the ground zero remains.

headline: With Sleepaway Camp, Trying to Keep Stability

headline: Joining on Somaly Mam’s Brothel Bust
text: My Sunday column returns to a regular theme — human trafficking — and recounts a raid on a brothel in northern Cambodia with one of my heroes, Somaly Mam. The youngest girl in the brothel had been trafficked from Vietnam a few months ago when she was in the seventh grade, meaning that she was born in 1999. That makes her about 12 years old.

headline: Sunday: Either Way
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — The last time we saw Jeremy Newton and Tony Orbach team up, it was for the spectacular Sunday grid where we had to escape each room via an invisible door in the black squares (Across Lite, Solution, blog).

text: Tobias Harris left Tennessee for the N.B.A. after his freshman year, but he returned to take classes and work out during the lockout.

headline: Masters of the Game and Leaders by Example
text: Fewer than 2 percent of the 77,000 members of the United States Chess Federation are masters — and just 13 of them are under the age of 14.

headline: Occupy Oakland and News Media Coexist Uneasily
text: Immediately after a man was shot to death Thursday afternoon near the Occupy Oakland encampment, Randy Davis, a cameraman for KGO-TV, turned his lens on a group of protesters helping the victim. Then part of the crowd turned on him.

headline: In Richmond, Foreclosed Homes Breed a New Kind of Problem
text: When Deborah Huey was about to show two empty units of an apartment building she managed to a prospective tenant earlier this year, the deal was scuttled by views of a dilapidated, empty house across the street.

headline: Sprinkle Chili Powder Over the Pineapple and Throw In Crab Meat? Why Not?
text: Last weekend in Napa Valley, at the 14th annual Worlds of Flavor conference hosted by the Culinary Institute of America in St. Helena, some of the world’s most notable chefs were taking culinary diversity to new, somewhat dizzying heights.

headline: Tough Questions on Changing Teacher Evaluations
text: For the first time next year, thousands of Chicago Public Schools teachers will be evaluated based partly on how well their students are doing academically. Many fear they will face dismissal if the standards are not applied fairly.

headline: An Unusual Library Finds a New Home
text: On a recent Saturday afternoon in Humboldt Park, a small band of volunteers scrambled to put the finishing touches on their library’s new home — the sixth in as many years for the Read/Write Library, Chicago’s largest depository of grass-roots printed materials.

headline: Liberal or Conservative, the Problem Is Ignorance
text: James Warren writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: It’s-It Factory
text: People living east of the Rockies may not have heard of this ice cream treat, but most in the Bay Area know the It’s-It. There are several stories about the origin of the name, but the company’s Web site says that in 1928, at a San Francisco beachfront amusement park called Playland, a pie shop owner named George Whitney put a scoop of vanilla ice cream between oatmeal cookies and dipped it in chocolate. “It’s It!” he announced, and a local star was born. LOUISE RAFKIN

headline: Evelyn H. Lauder, Champion of Breast Cancer Research, Dies at 75
text: Evelyn H. Lauder, a refugee of Nazi-occupied Europe who married into an illustrious family in the beauty business and became an ardent advocate for breast cancer awareness, raising millions for research, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 75.

headline: Wary Legislators Approve Speed-Detection Cameras
text: It took just seven days for Mayor Rahm Emanuel and his lobbying team to persuade a reluctant state legislature to pass a bill allowing speed-detection cameras near hundreds of schools and parks throughout Chicago.

headline: After Berlusconi Resigns, Some Italians Rejoice
text: Ending an era in Italian politics, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi resigned Saturday after Parliament approved austerity measures, my colleagues Rachel Donadio and Elisabetta Povoledo reported on Saturday.

headline: Penn State-Nebraska Replay
text: In their first game since the firing of Coach Joe Paterno, the Penn State Nittany Lions lost at home to Nebraska, 17-14.

headline: Gingrich: Bring the Debates On
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — There may be one Republican candidate prone to memory lapses who wishes he never had to debate again, but Newt Gingrich cannot get enough of these events.

headline: Highlights From the Republican Debate in S.C.
text: The Republican candidates for president gather for a debate Saturday night in South Carolina, where Gov. Rick Perry of Texas will get a chance to redeem his fumbling, forgetful performance in Michigan on Wednesday night.

headline: On a New Stage, Rutgers Keeps Its Wits to the End
text: Greg Schiano took his team to Yankee Stadium on Saturday earlier than he would have if Rutgers had played almost anywhere else. He sent his players onto the grass field and told them to take all the photographs they wanted with their cellphones.

headline: Berlusconi, Magnetic and Divisive, Whose Politics Were Personal
text: ROME — With a combination of savvy media domination, old-fashioned party politics and a salesman’s preternatural charm, Silvio Berlusconi has dominated Italy more than anyone since Mussolini.

headline: Obama Sees an Opening on China Trade
text: HONOLULU — President Obama promised to continue “a frank dialogue” on economic disputes with China as he met with its president, Hu Jintao, on the sidelines of a trade summit here on Saturday. But, he added, “We should be rooting for China to grow.”

headline: A Paterno’s Long Walk to Cap an Emotional Day
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — The Penn State quarterbacks coach, Jay Paterno, grew up here on McKee Street, less than a mile from campus and a short walk from the football field that his father’s coaching helped nearly triple in size to a 108,000-seat stadium.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 12, 2011
text: A look at the day in sports, including Formula One racing in Abu Dhabi and golf at the Australian Open.

headline: Republicans Debate in South Carolina
text: Republican presidential candidates discussed foreign policy in South Carolina on Saturday night.

headline: Gov. Rick Perry on Foreign Aid
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas says that if he were president, foreign aid would start at zero for every country including Israel.

headline: Police in Denver Move on Protesters
text: DENVER — The Denver police cleared a protest encampment allied with the Occupy Wall Street movement in a downtown square Saturday evening. Sixteen people were arrested, according to the police.

headline: Rumors Drown Truth on N.B.A.’s Proposal
text: Hours after the N.B.A. delivered its final collective bargaining proposal to the players union, the rumors and the rhetoric began to flow.

headline: Bachmann Campaign Accuses CBS News of Bias
text: While Michele Bachmann was debating Saturday evening, her campaign turned to Facebook to harshly accuse CBS News, a co-sponsor with National Journal, of limiting questions to her and “suppressing our conservative message.”

headline: Up for Debate: Foreign Policy and Obama
text: SPARTANBURG, S.C. — The eight major Republican candidates for president joined in a united attack against President Obama as commander in chief during a debate here Saturday, but at times differed sharply over how to block Iran’s nuclear ambitions, the way forward with Pakistan and the use of torture.

headline: PATH Service Returns After a Fire
text: 1:20 a.m. | Updated  Train service in the entire PATH system was suspended for several hours on Saturday night because of an electrical fire at a station in Jersey City, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

headline: When Stanford’s Moment Arrives, It’s a Disaster
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Early Saturday afternoon, Stanford’s campus was alive, a fervent optimism lingering in the air from the tree-lined parking lots (where tailgaters took turns beating an Oregon Duck piñata) to the student section waiting area (where cheers and chants were led by bare-chested fans who painted letters on one another’s torsos).

headline: In Tight 12 Rounds, Pacquiao Retains His Title
text: LAS VEGAS — In the back room inside his locker room deep in the MGM Grand, with security stationed inside and outside the closed door, with his post-fight suit-and-fedora ensemble hanging neatly in the corner, Manny Pacquiao could not have appeared more relaxed.

headline: Top 25 Roundup: Stanford and Boise State Fall From Ranks of Unbeaten
text: 1. LOUISIANA STATE (10-0) beat Western Kentucky, 42-9

headline: The Day’s Best in College Football
text: Brandon Weeden passed for 423 yards and 5 touchdowns and Joseph Randle, right, ran for 3 scores as Oklahoma State improved to 10-0 with a 66-6 rout of Texas Tech. Weeden, who completed 31 of 37 passes, threw touchdown passes of 2, 27, 28, 48 and 66 yards before leaving late in the third quarter. Randle scored on runs of 2, 1 and 10 yards.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: In “The Fall of the Middlewoman,” Open Magazine looks at Niira Radia’s decision to “vanish into the blue” by closing up the public relations shop she built. Ms. Radia, who became a central figure in the investigation into the sale of second-generation wireless spectrum after Open published transcripts of her various conversations with businessmen and politicians, closed her business on October 30. In this speculative story, Open suggests, without a named source, that she left at the behest of political establishment types who were eager to see that the name of Tata Group, her largest client, was not dragged through the mud any more than it had been. “Her disappearance would give a legitimate excuse to the CBI and ED to quietly close the relevant ‘Radia’ files in the near future,” the magazine said, referring to the Central Bureau of Investigation and the Enforcement Directorate.

headline: In Paris, First-Ever French Retrospective of Diane Arbus
text: Though she has been celebrated widely in the United States, an exhibition of the work of Diane Arbus at the Jeu de Paume in the Tuileries gardens of Paris, is the first-ever French retrospective of the American photographer. The show, titled simply “Diane Arbus,” runs through Feb. 5 at the museum (1 Place de la Concorde; www.jeudepaume.org).

headline: Iraq Criticizes Exxon Mobil for Its Deal With the Kurds
text: BAGHDAD — A deputy prime minister overseeing Iraq’s oil industry criticized Exxon Mobil on Sunday over its effort to expand into the semiautonomous Kurdish region in the country’s north.

headline: Canadian Cultural Imperialism
text: OK, that was fairly strange. Yesterday I appeared on a panel discussion in Puebla, Mexico along with Nick Kristof, Mark Spitz, and Oliver Stone.

headline: After a Romney Deal, Profits and Then Layoffs
text: Mitt Romney’s business career is a cornerstone of his campaign, reports Michael Barbaro of The New York Times. But his brand of capitalism had human costs and some messy financial consequences. Read more »

headline: Supply-Side Solutions? Beware (Wonkish)
text: There’s a new Vox paper suggesting that supply-side policies — structural reform that makes workers more productive, prices more flexible, or whatever — may be the answer to a liquidity trap. Some people may seize on this claim. So it’s worth pointing out that a casual interpretation here gets it all wrong.

headline: Spam, Spam, Spam, Spam
text: You may see a lot of “this comment was rejected” tags. That’s because some vendor of knockoff clothing has somehow breached the Times spam filter, and I had to find a quick way to make a large number of comments go away. It’s not personal!

headline: Beyond Fracking, Another Use for Marcellus Shale
text: Via my friend Amy Lipton, a curator at EcoArtspace, I just discovered “The Marcellus Shale Experiment.” In this fascinating blog, the Philadelphia-based artist Jennie Shanker is chronicling her efforts to create ceramics using clay from the Marcellus Shale region — best known as a big new source for natural gas through the much–debated method called fracking, or hydraulic fracturing (recently explored by Times columnist David Brooks).

headline: For Executives, Cases for Hall Are Not Strong Enough
text: For five days last week, I blogged about the players eligible for the Hall of Fame on the Golden Era ballot, advocating for three to be inducted and five to be turned away. I feel strongly that Minnie Minoso has been unfairly overlooked, and I’m convinced that Gil Hodges’s managerial magic combined with his playing career should put him over the top and that Ron Santo, as one of the 10 best third basemen to play the game before 1990 (despite having the advantage of hitting in Wrigley Field), deserves entry. And while I wouldn’t be horrified if Jim Kaat, Allie Reynolds, Louis Tiant, or especially Tony Oliva and Ken Boyer made it in, I don’t think they belong.

headline: Rio Slum Is ‘Pacified’ in Advance of Games
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — About 3,000 police officers and soldiers moved into one of the largest slums here on Sunday in a pivotal effort by the government to assert control over lawless areas of the city ahead of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Summer Olympics.

headline: TNT, in Tie-In With Hyatt, Will Hold ‘Armchair Detective’ Weekends
text: One of the more interesting trends in media is the effort by television channels and networks to find ways to bring their programming to life in the real world.

headline: Getting Control of a Rio Slum
text: About 3,000 police officers and soldiers backed by helicopters and armored cars occupied one of Rio de Janeiro’s largest slums on Sunday.

headline: Deficit Panel May Put Off Tax Deliberation
text: WASHINGTON – The top Republican on the joint Congressional committee on deficit reduction did not exactly radiate confidence on Sunday about the panel’s ability to reach a sweeping bargain by its Nov. 23 deadline. Instead, he signaled that the committee was contemplating a procedure that would allow it to delay the toughest choices about how to raise taxes.

text: ABU DHABI — Long before the sun set at Abu Dhabi’s twilight Grand Prix, the day had ended for the driver who had until then had a nearly flawless season.

headline: 2 ‘Nutcrackers,’ One Apartment
text: This started long before all the stores put up the holiday stuff — before, even, they put up the Halloween stuff. David Parker and Keith Michael’s apartment in the West Village has been all Christmas, all the time, since August.

headline: Disruptions: The 3-D Printing Free-for-All
text: Downloading — quite often stealing, in the eyes of the law — music, movies, books and photos is easier than bobbing for apples in a bucket without water. It has kept legions of lawyers employed fighting copyright violations without a whole lot to show for their efforts in the past decade.

headline: With Clock Ticking, an Economist Accepts a Mandate to Rescue Italy
text: ROME — Mario Monti, a former member of the European Commission, conditionally accepted a mandate on Sunday to form a new government in Italy whose main task will be to keep the country from being dragged under by Europe’s debt crisis.

headline: Billy Crystal Is Gilded as Hero of Oscar Night
text: LOS ANGELES — Oprah Winfrey snagged an Oscar here on Saturday night, but the evening’s hero — not present, though never out of mind — was Billy Crystal.

headline: Paris Masters Triumph Is a First and a Boost
text: PARIS — A two-set lead was not enough for Roger Federer to shake free of Jo-Wilfried Tsonga at Wimbledon this year. But a two-set lead is all that is required for victory at this late stage of the tennis season, and so Federer finally got to hold up a trophy on the other side of Paris.

headline: Occupy Wall Street Protesters Shifting to College Campuses
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — Goodbye, city park, hello, college green.

headline: Man Held in Beating of an Elderly Woman
text: Updated, 10:35 p.m. | A homeless man accused of clubbing an elderly woman with a piece of wood on a Midtown street had to be subdued after acting erratically while awaiting arraignment on Sunday night, the authorities said.

headline: Documents: Felons and Guns
text: The Times examined data from courts across the country on convicted felons who had their firearms rights reinstated and reviewed hundreds of pages of documents associated with those cases. In many instances, people who got their gun rights back went on to commit new crimes. Here are court records associated with several people with felony convictions who had their firearms privileges restored. Related Article »

headline: The Correct Pronunciation Of EC Is Eek
text: I’ve managed to go a whole day without thinking about the euro, but tomorrow’s FT is online and I couldn’t help myself.

headline: Is Neuroscience the Death of Free Will?
text: Some scientists are convinced that advances in brain science have overturned the idea of free will. They’re wrong.

headline: Civil Wars: If I Didn’t Know Better
text: Why do I keep drinking?

headline: Messiaen Moments, in Swells and Fanfares
text: You needn’t be a pipe organ cabalist or an initiate of the new-music illuminati to be moved, even shaken, by Olivier Messiaen’s music for the instrument he played most of his life. “Apparition of the Eternal Church,” a 2006 film by Paul Festa, makes the point vividly; in it, Mr. Festa claps headphones on writers, performers and quasi celebrities, then captures their reactions of bemusement, perplexity and awe as they listen to Messiaen’s landmark 1932 piece, “Apparition de l’Église Éternelle.”

headline: Chords of Repose at Composer’s Memorial
text: The Polish composer Henryk Gorecki died last Nov. 12, and to commemorate the first anniversary of his death Le Poisson Rouge and the Polish Cultural Institute presented two of his substantial chamber works in a free concert on Tuesday evening. Le Poisson Rouge was packed for the occasion: 45 minutes before the performance listeners who thought they had arrived early enough to get a seat were filling the standing room.

headline: At Least Six Are Killed as Libyan Militias Clash on Coastal Highway Near Tripoli
text: ZAWIYAH, Libya — Two rival militias fought a sporadic but deadly gun battle just west of Tripoli over the weekend, blocking traffic on the vital coastal road between the Libyan capital and the Tunisian border. The outburst of violence was among the worst to come to light since the killing of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi last month.

headline: France Keeps a Watchful Eye on Turmoil in Italy
text: First it was Athens. Then Rome. Could Paris be next?

headline: Gaining Maximum on Defense at a Computerized Showdown
text: The second semifinal at the World Computer-Bridge Championship in the Netherlands last month was between Wbridge5, one of the pretournament favorites, and Shark Bridge.

headline: Roger Christian, Olympic Hockey Star, Dies at 75
text: Roger Christian, whose four-goal game propelled the United States to its first gold medal in Olympic ice hockey, an improbable championship at the 1960 Squaw Valley Winter Games, died Wednesday in Grand Forks, N.D. He was 75.

headline: Returning One Kind of Kiss With a Kiss-Off
text: It turns out, a kiss is never just a kiss.

headline: A Pianist’s Composition Rounds Off Debut Recital
text: The 23-year-old pianist Nobuyuki Tsujii, blind from birth, is said to have achieved pop-star status in his native Japan since he shared the gold medal at the 2009 Van Cliburn International Piano Competition with Haochen Zhang, from China.

headline: Legendary Gaze Burns Through Time and Trouble
text: Albert Grossman, who had put together Peter, Paul and Mary as a folk-singing trio, once suggested to Judy Collins that she become part of a trio too. She would sing with two other women, Judy Henske and Jo Mapes. “We can call you the Brown-Eyed Girls,” he said.
