text: Nov. 26, 12:29 a.m. | Update |Here’s a fresh NASA remix of Space Station time-lapse imagery, in this case with Peter Gabriel’s “Down to Earth,” from “Wall-E”:

headline: Monday: Bridge Positions
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Are you a good bowler? Mark Feldman offers us a bowling theme today, and if you’re really good, you will score a strike, a spare and a split. Technically speaking, this counts as a double theme, because the second half of each theme entry has to do with money. And, as the final theme entry, Mr. Feldman wraps things up with the entry BOWLED OVER at 61 Across. Nicely done.

headline: Newsweek, Mired in Red Ink, Cancels Longtime Political Series
text: It has been one of Newsweek’s signature ventures and a staple of American political journalism since 1984.

headline: At His Essence, Smokin’ Joe Was More Than Just a Symbol
text: On Monday at Enon Tabernacle Baptist Church in Philadelphia,  thousands of mourners paid their respects to Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight boxing champion who died last week.

headline: Bitter Departure for Miami’s Ballet Patriarch
text: Morning class at the Miami City Ballet had just ended one day in late September when the dancers and staff gathered in the main studio for a companywide meeting with their founder, artistic director and patriarch, Edward Villella.

headline: Cities and Global Warming: San Francisco’s Experience
text: To the Editor:

headline: Keeping It Honest: Choreography That Stays True to Itself
text: The most intense performance at the Merce Cunningham Studio on Friday was given by a dead choreographer. No, not the ghost of Mr. Cunningham, but rather Anna Sokolow, who died in 2000 at the age of 90. She appeared in a film shot at Ohio State University in 1966. Teaching students her “Odes,” created the year before, she corrected them with such barking ferocity that I feared she might bite.

headline: Sharing Hoop Dreams of a Compositional Strategist
text: Virtually every consideration of George Lewis, an imposing performer and scholar now serving as a professor and the vice chairman of the music department at Columbia University, will invoke the term trombonist-composer. If you’ve encountered Mr. Lewis’s playing, stressing instrumental prowess seems natural; if you haven’t, dip into an album like Anthony Braxton’s “Quartet (Dortmund) 1976,” and you will hear instantly why Mr. Lewis is revered among avant-garde jazz aficionados.

headline: Putting the Brakes on Web-Surfing Speeds
text: BERLIN — State-of-the-art Web surfing, for all of its breathtaking speed, can be baffling. A favorite page gets hung up. A data-intensive application, like playing a video or downloading large files, stutters or stops. Is it the telecommunications operator? Is it the Web site? Is it the smartphone or the computer? Or just a sign of Internet thrombosis?

headline: A Creature’s Comforts in a Time of Need
text: Animal Planet is familiar as the home of garish shows like “Fatal Attractions” and “My Extreme Animal Phobia.” On Monday night, though, it goes for the touching rather than the tacky with “Saved,” a new series about people who were in need of some kind of spiritual boost and received it from an animal.

headline: Antihunger Campaign Forgoes Images of Starving Children
text: ACTION Against Hunger, a nonprofit group that fights malnutrition, is running a public service ad campaign that uses nontraditional, abstract imagery, rather than photos of starving children, to gain support.

headline: Singer and Pianist Continue Their Onstage Dialogue
text: The collaboration between the Austrian mezzo-soprano Angelika Kirchschlager and the French pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet at Zankel Hall on Saturday evening may have looked like a luxury pairing of established artists at the top of their games. But these two go way back. When Mr. Kirchschlager made her memorable United States debut, at Alice Tully Hall in 1995, Mr. Thibaudet, though already commanding attention as a soloist, was her accompanist.

headline: Is Mandatory Voting a Good Idea?

headline: 3 Guys Grow Up One Night
text: There is only one note in “Two-Man Kidnapping Rule,” and even that’s not well played. A story of three guys who find that their lives get more complicated as they grow older, “Rule” makes this less-than-profound discovery in its first 15 minutes then spends the large part of two hours repeating it again and again, and then some more.

headline: Blast Kills Commander at Iran Base
text: One of the top commanders in Iran’s ballistic missile program was among those killed Saturday in an explosion at a base for the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, the group said in a statement on Monday.

headline: Steelers Turn Things Around
text: CINCINNATI — The oddity of the Pittsburgh Steelers’ season could be summed up in one statistic: the defense that produced 35 turnovers last season on the way to the Super Bowl had just four this season, leaving the Steelers struggling for consistency. They could not make a critical play to stop the Baltimore Ravens’ 92-yard touchdown drive in the waning moments of their game last week, and on Sunday, against the A.F.C. North-leading Cincinnati Bengals, the Steelers were again faced with the possibility of a painful collapse.

headline: Gloria Cain Says Allegations Don’t Square With Her Husband
text: Two weeks after accusations of sexual harassment against Herman Cain emerged, his wife, Gloria Cain, has opened up publicly about the matter, saying, “I’m thinking he would have to have a split personality to do the things that were said.”

headline: Another Look at ‘Sweeney Todd’
text: “Sweeney Todd” will return to the West End in London early next year when the latest production of the Stephen Sondheim-Hugh Wheeler musical takes up residence at the Adelphi Theater, just a mile from the fictional barbershop in the show, the BBC News Web site reported. The production recently concluded a run at the Chichester Festival Theater in Sussex, England, where it garnered high praise from London critics, especially for its lead actors, Michael Ball (“The Woman in White”) and Imelda Staunton (“Vera Drake”). Mr. Ball played the serial-killing barber while Ms. Staunton filled the role of Mrs. Lovett, his landlady. Previews of the London production are to begin on March 10 with a planned run of six months.

headline: Showtime Renews the Series ‘Weeds’
text: Showtime has announced that its comedy “Weeds,” with Mary-Louise Parker as a suburban mom turned drug kingpin, will return for an eighth season. Production will start next year on 13 new episodes. Despite diminishing returns in the ratings — the most recent season averaged less than one million viewers an episode — the show is still the highest-rated comedy for that premium cable channel and has earned multiple Emmy nominations, including one for best comedy series in 2009.

headline: Israeli Government Backs Limits on Financing for Nonprofit Groups
text: JERUSALEM — A committee of Israeli cabinet ministers voted Sunday to back two bills aimed at curtailing the support of left-wing nonprofit groups from foreign governments.

headline: Protest T-Shirt Generates Anger
text: A T-shirt inspired by the Occupy Wall Street movement and created by Rocawear, whose founders include the hip-hop star Jay-Z, was pulled from the company’s Web site over the weekend. The move came after a company spokesman told Business Insider that proceeds from sales of the shirts would not be donated to the protest movement, Entertainment Weekly reported on its Web site. Photos of Jay-Z in the shirt — with the phrase “Occupy Wall Street” altered to read “Occupy All Streets” — appeared on Twitter earlier in the week, and the shirt was to be released on Friday. But the spokesman’s statement led to accusations on Twitter and elsewhere that the rapper was trying to profit from the protests, and the shirt soon disappeared from the company’s Web site. Jay-Z, near left, with Russell Simmons, is currently touring with Kanye West to promote their album, “Watch the Throne.”

headline: ‘Sweet Judy Blue Eyes’
text: Judy Collins has written a new memoir.

headline: The Governors Awards
text: Photos from the third annual event in Los Angeles.

headline: Reality TV’s Instant Stars Populate a Magazine
text: Reality television stars tend to lack certain attributes: discretion, shame, gainful employment. One thing they don’t seem to want for is exposure.

headline: Barbara Grier, Publisher of Lesbian Books, Dies at 78
text: Barbara Grier, a founder of one of the most successful publishing houses for books by and about lesbians, including a nonfiction chronicle about lesbian nuns that became a phenomenon after it drew complaints from Roman Catholic officials, died on Thursday in Tallahassee, Fla. She was 78.

headline: For Pacquiao, a Victory Comes at a Painful Cost
text: LAS VEGAS — Shortly after his latest fight, Manny Pacquiao lay flat on his back on a wooden table in Locker Room No. 2 at the MGM Grand. Tissue paper covered all of his face except for the area around his right eye. He gripped the arm of his wife, Jinkee, with his right hand, squeezing tightly.

headline: Newspapers’ Digital Apostle
text: Last week, John Paton met with executives of the MediaNews Group, the second-largest newspaper chain by circulation in the country, home to papers like The Denver Post, The Detroit News, The Salt Lake Tribune and a broad swath of dailies throughout California, including The San Jose Mercury News.

headline: Israel Lobbies Discreetly for More Sanctions After U.N. Report on Iran
text: JERUSALEM — Israel hopes that a United Nations report released last week cataloging suspect activities in Iran’s nuclear program will finally force major countries to make sanctions painful enough that Iran will stop its uranium enrichment program.

headline: Fox’s U.F.C. Broadcast a Hit With Viewers
text: Fox’s hourlong Ultimate Fighting Championship broadcast Saturday night was seen by an average of 5.7 million viewers — more than for any previous U.F.C. event and the most for a televised fight of any kind in eight years, the network said Sunday.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Recruiting Veterans, Columbia Finds an Impressive Applicant Pool
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif. — Two years ago, in an effort to attract more veterans to Columbia, Curtis Rodgers, a dean of admissions, began recruiting at military bases. Almost immediately he noticed differences between the Marines and the typical 18-year-old Ivy League applicant.

headline: In Twist, Manning and the Giants Fall Short in the Fourth
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The ball was batted down almost as soon as it left Giants quarterback Eli Manning’s hand, and he could only stare after it. Red jerseys were bouncing all around him, but Manning stayed rooted to his spot, one hand resting on his hip. The San Francisco 49ers were giddy; Manning just looked stunned.

headline: Now Funny People Can Get Respect (and Course Credit at U.S.C.)
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Crammed into a booth at the Nate ’n Al Delicatessen — the professionally funny call it “the commissary” — Barnet Kellman, David Isaacs and Jack Epps Jr., from the University of Southern California’s School of Cinematic Arts, were trying to explain over a plate of pickles why those who create screen comedy deserve academic respect.

headline: Why Do Top Schools Still Take Legacy Applicants?
text: The children of alumni still have an edge getting into Ivy League schools, even with the oversupply of talented applicants. Why is that?

headline: When Sites Drag the Unwitting Across the Web
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Can an online algorithm track down your child?

headline: William Aramony, United Way Leader Who Was Jailed for Fraud, Dies at 84
text: William Aramony, who built United Way of America into one of the nation’s premier charities but was forced out as president and went to prison for six years for misusing funds to support a lavish lifestyle and a teenage mistress, died on Friday in Alexandria, Va., where he lived. He was 84.

headline: A Lifetime of Battling Bias
text: In Richard Lapchick’s long battle against racial bias in sports, numbers have been his oral weapon of choice, reliable and irrefutable, though admittedly not the most effective means of commanding a room.

headline: Restoring Gun Rights to Felons
text: Every year, thousands of felons across the country have their gun rights reinstated, often with little or no review.

headline: Massachusetts Mulls Letting Bars Offer Happy Hours
text: BOSTON — This city has a robust bar culture, with trivia nights, $1 oyster specials and plenty of other perks to keep patrons coming. But not since 1984, when “Cheers” was new to television, has Massachusetts allowed bars to hold happy hours.

headline: Some Lessons in Damage Control
text: While the turmoil at Penn State has been the academic equivalent of a Category 5 storm, it will probably not have much long-term impact on the university, experts say.

headline: Mobs Strike Embassies After Group Bans Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Turkey sent planes to evacuate its diplomats’ families from Syria on Sunday after a night of attacks on foreign embassies in Damascus, the capital. The events seemed sure to deepen Syria’s most pronounced isolation of the four decades of Assad family rule.

headline: Banks Quietly Ramping Up Costs to Consumers
text: Even as Bank of America and other major lenders back away from charging customers to use their debit cards, many banks have been quietly imposing other new fees.

headline: Rising Bank Fees
text: Banks are raising fees to make up for revenue declines elsewhere.

headline: Well Qualified, but Facing Uphill Fight
text: ROME — In the news media he is known simply as “Super Mario.” But Mario Monti, the likely leader of Italy’s new government, which is being formed amid a crisis that threatens the European monetary union itself, will face a strong challenge in living up to his admiring nickname as he tries to steer his country from the brink of economic turmoil and through the machinations of Italian politics.

headline: How League Offer Could Alter Movement and the Market
text: In the reimagined, recalibrated N.B.A. of the future, Carmelo Anthony would have a tougher time forcing his way out of Denver. LeBron James would take a steeper pay cut to flee Cleveland. Gilbert Arenas would be a free agent, instead of a payroll albatross.

headline: Costume Shot Unnecessary, Obama Says
text: HONOLULU — Is the “silly shirts” photo of Asia-Pacific leaders now history?

headline: Felons Finding It Easy to Regain Gun Rights
text: In February 2005, Erik Zettergren came home from a party after midnight with his girlfriend and another couple. They had all been drinking heavily, and soon the other man and Mr. Zettergren’s girlfriend passed out on his bed. When Mr. Zettergren went to check on them later, he found his girlfriend naked from the waist down and the other man, Jason Robinson, with his pants around his ankles.

headline: Cuomo Tries to Shore Up the Support of Minorities
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — The crowd of Hispanic legislators and business leaders from New York, sipping cocktails at a sleek hotel overlooking the Atlantic Ocean, abruptly halted their conversations as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, fresh off a 1,600-mile flight, came in through a side entrance on Friday.

headline: Traffic to Stymie Even the Batmobile Shows the Two Sides of Movie Production
text: The Queensboro Bridge was where Simon and Garfunkel felt groovy, where Woody Allen and Diane Keaton watched dawn break in “Manhattan,” where the city could be seen, as F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, “in its first wild promise of all the mystery and the beauty in the world.”

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include retail sales for October, the Producer Price Index for October and business inventories for September (Tuesday); Consumer Price Index for October and industrial production and capacity utilization for October (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, housing starts for October and Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for November (Thursday) and leading economic indicators for October (Friday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

Alternate-Side Parking Brings Peace

headline: EMI and Warner Not Meant to Be
text: The music gods have meddled again with EMI’s destiny. In the minds of many, the union of the British music company — home to the Beatles and the Beastie Boys — with its American rival Warner Music was supposed to be just a matter of time. But the star-crossed match has been knocked off course again by an EMI breakup involving Sony and Vivendi’s Universal Music.

headline: Neo-Nazis Suspected in Long Wave of Crimes, Including Murders, in Germany
text: ZWICKAU, Germany — Neo-Nazi terrorists are responsible for a crime wave reaching back more than a decade that includes the murders of at least 10 people, including immigrant shopkeepers and a police officer, German government officials said Sunday. The group is also suspected in more than a dozen bank robberies and a bombing in Cologne, they said.

headline: Deficit Panel Seeks to Defer Details on Raising Taxes
text: WASHINGTON — With a little over a week left to reach a deal, members of the Congressional deficit reduction panel are looking for an escape hatch that would let them strike an accord on revenue levels but delay until next year tough decisions about exactly how to raise taxes.

headline: Tie to Penn State Seems Unlikely for Its Next Coach
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — After a loss to Nebraska on Saturday, it became apparent that Penn State was attempting to create a narrative to move forward. Rodney Erickson, the university’s interim president, and the football team’s interim coach, Tom Bradley, pushed themes of solidarity, healing and trying to bring some good of an awful scandal.

headline: Health Law Puts Focus on Limits of Federal Power
text: WASHINGTON — If the federal government can require people to purchase health insurance, what else can it force them to do? More to the point, what can’t the government compel citizens to do?

headline: Obama Talks Up Free Trade and Jobs at Asia-Pacific Meeting
text: HONOLULU — With the weak domestic economy and his re-election hopes as the backdrop, President Obama made job creation the theme of an annual trade summit meeting on Sunday as the United States, for the first time in nearly two decades, hosted leaders of Pacific Rim nations.

headline: They Like Transparency, Until They Don’t
text: The New York City public advocate, Bill de Blasio, has started an investigation into why the city fails so miserably to release even the most routine data requested under the state’s Freedom of Information Law. Mr. de Blasio cited a request his office made last November for documentation on delays in school bus service. He is still waiting for the documents, but he recently got one of many “lovely letters” that explain how the Department of Education is still working on his request.

headline: Internet Architects Warn of Risks in Ultrafast Networks
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — If nothing else, Arista Networks proves that two people can make more than $1 billion each building the Internet and still be worried about its reliability.

headline: A Blue-Ribbon Indictment
text: A 645-page report from the United States Sentencing Commission found that federal mandatory minimum sentences are often “excessively severe,” not “narrowly tailored to apply only to those offenders who warrant such punishment,” and not “applied consistently.” That is especially so for sentences of people convicted of drug-trafficking offenses, who make up more than 75 percent of those given federal mandatory minimum sentences.

headline: A New Civil Rights Movement
text: Alabama’s ruling class has dug in against the storm it caused with the nation’s most oppressive immigration law. But Latinos in the south are moving now to protect themselves.

headline: On the Rise in Alabama
text: Alabama’s ruling class has dug in against the storm it caused with the nation’s most oppressive immigration law. Some of the law’s provisions have been blocked in federal court; others won’t take effect until next year. But many Alabamans aren’t waiting for things to get worse or for the uncertain possibility of judicial relief or legislative retreat. They are moving to protect themselves, and summoning the tactics of a civil rights struggle now half a century old.

headline: Vouchers for Veterans
text: American health care is remarkably diverse. In terms of how care is paid for and delivered, many of us effectively live in Canada, some live in Switzerland, some live in Britain, and some live in the unregulated market of conservative dreams. One result of this diversity is that we have plenty of home-grown evidence about what works and what doesn’t.

headline: Zealots’ Remorse
text: A welcome touch of resistance is in the air toward Grover Norquist, the conservative lobbyist and Capitol Hill fixture who has been brilliant at wrenching a simplistic pledge from all but six House Republicans to never, ever increase taxes.

headline: Week 10 Live: Jets-Patriots Win Probability
text: The Fifth Down will track the win probability for the Jets and the Patriots throughout Sunday night’s showdown at MetLife Stadium. We did it for the first meeting between the teams in Week 5, but a quick review for those unfamiliar with the metric from Advanced NFL Stats.

headline: How Romney Could Win
text: Election Day is nearly a year off and the first primaries aren’t until January, but I’m ready to skip ahead to the main event. The last serious hope of the Tea Partiers, Rick Perry, and their last not-so-serious hope, Herman Cain, are in campaign death spirals. Unless God has a cruel sense of humor, Newt Gingrich will pass like a tantrum. That leaves us with a general election between two serious and certifiably sane candidates. Phew!!

headline: New Austerity Incites a Bitterness the Postwar Generation Did Without
text: LONDON — Before he died of Lou Gehrig’s disease in 2010, the historian Tony Judt recalled childhood days just after World War II in a debilitated Britain that was slowly ceding its empire and its pre-eminence.

text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Growing violence along the border between Sudan and South Sudan caused a major humanitarian aid group to withdraw over the weekend.

headline: You Won the Right to Wed; Now Comes the Tough Part
text: It would not be inappropriate to bring a few handfuls of rice to toss at the climax of “Standing on Ceremony: The Gay Marriage Plays,” a collection of monologues and short plays that opened on Sunday night at the Minetta Lane Theater. This mostly genial, often funny omnibus is essentially a staged celebration of the recent advances in winning marital rights for gay and lesbian couples, and how the changing laws are changing lives.

headline: A Finger Slips, and the Bachmann Camp Pounces
text: It is not exactly a state secret that the news media tend to lavish more coverage on perceived front-runners in presidential campaigns.

headline: N.Y. Lawmakers Confer in Puerto Rico
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — For a few days every November, the place for New York State politicians to see and be seen is not Angelo’s 677 Prime in Albany or the Regency Hotel in Manhattan, but a resort hotel in the Caribbean.

headline: Economy in Japan Shows Signs of Strength
text: TOKYO — Japan’s economy grew at a 6 percent annualized rate in the third quarter, signaling a strong recovery after the devastating tsunami in March. Still, a slowing global economy and a stubbornly strong yen cloud the outlook for Japan, the world’s third-largest economy.

headline: For a Homeless Child, a Long Ride to 4th Grade
text: Every night, N-Dia Layne would set the alarm on her mother’s cellphone to 4:45 a.m. If the two of them were not on the subway platform at 103rd Street and Broadway by 6:20 a.m., there was no way N-Dia would be on time for school.

headline: Jamestown Thought to Yield Ruins of Oldest U.S. Protestant Church
text: JAMESTOWN — For more than a decade, the marshy island in Virginia where British colonists landed in 1607 has yielded uncounted surprises. And yet William M. Kelso’s voice still brims with excitement as he plants his feet atop a long-buried discovery at the settlement’s heart: what he believes are the nation’s oldest remains of a Protestant church.

headline: Bowl Championship Series Standings
text: The B.C.S. rankings are determined by three components: the Harris Interactive poll, the USA Today coaches poll and the average of six computer rankings. Each component counts one-third toward a team’s B.C.S. score.

headline: Hispanics Reviving Faded Towns on the Plains
text: ULYSSES, Kan. — Change can be unsettling in a small town. But not long ago in this quiet farming community, with its familiar skyline of grain elevators and church steeples, the owner of a new restaurant decided to acknowledge the community’s diversity by adding some less traditional items to her menu. Cheeseburgers. French fries. Chicken-fried steak.

text: “There’s a gulf as wide as the ocean between the average politically active conservative and the average politically active liberal. We don’t just have political differences; we view the world through very different eyes.” So wrote John Hawkins, who runs Right Wing News, at the beginning of the year.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Monday
text: A report on Jammu and Kashmir State recommends that the central government “recognize the ‘dual’ and ‘special’ status of Jammu and Kashmir; review all laws imposed on the state after 1952 and respect the right of Kashmiris to travel freely across both sides of the Line of Control,” India’s border with Pakistan, reports The Indian Express. Kashmir’s tenuous relationship with Delhi lies at the heart of its political problems, the report says.

headline: Changing Face of the Rural Plains
text: Growth in the population of Hispanics in the Great Plains — especially in rural areas, where even small growth can have an outsize impact — is filling some of the void left by a declining white population. The Hispanic population in the seven Great Plains states shown below has increased 75 percent, while the overall population has increased just 7 percent.

headline: Mark Howe, the Proto-Nicklas Lidstrom, Is at Last in the Hall of Fame
text: On Monday night, Mark Howe will at long last be where he belongs: in the Hockey Hall of Fame. Howe became eligible for election to the Hall in 1998, three years after his distinguished 22-season career ended, but only now is he being ushered into a club in which he has long deserved membership. Yet even that is somehow fitting for Howe, whose quiet excellence tended to be overlooked throughout his career.

headline: Jets Reminded Who’s in Charge
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was all there for the Jets, everything they wanted, everything they craved. The opportunity to unseat New England in the A.F.C. East, to hasten the Patriots’ decline, to shift the balance of power in a division long ruled by Tom Brady and his loyal foot soldiers, perhaps once and for all. Instead, the soaring Jets and the plummeting Patriots swapped roles.

headline: H. Gobind Khorana, 89, Nobel-Winning Scientist, Dies
text: H. Gobind Khorana, who rose from a childhood of poverty in India to become a biochemist and share in a Nobel Prize for his role in deciphering the genetic code, died on Wednesday in Concord, Mass. He was 89.

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: Many Cases, Not Much Movement
text: The best moment of “Death Row Trip,” Sunday’s episode of “The Good Wife” (Season 3, No. 8): Cary’s response when Dana assures him that there’s nothing going on between her and Kalinda. “I am not a lesbian,” Dana announces, to which Cary replies, “I know a lot of people who weren’t anything until they met Kalinda.”

headline: India’s Godot: Economic Reforms 2.0
text: The World Economic Forum’s India Economic Summit in Mumbai has hosted several prominent figures from the business and political worlds – Mukesh Ambani, chairman of Reliance Industries, and Anand Sharma, the commerce minister, have been among them – but one guest seems to have disappointed many by not showing up: Economic Reforms 2.0.

headline: Russian Rocket Gives NASA a Lift to Space Station
text: MOSCOW — A Russian Soyuz rocket blasted off through heavy snowfall in Kazakhstan on Monday morning, beginning a two-day trip to ferry three astronauts to the International Space Station. The flight opens a new era of American dependence on Russia, and eventually on commercial enterprises, for manned space travel, after the end of NASA’s space shuttle program in July.

headline: Spokesman for Taliban Denies Report of His Arrest
text: KHOST, Afghanistan — A Taliban spokesman whose provocative and taunting media reports have often infuriated Afghan and Western officials firmly denied that he had been captured Monday.

headline: Nov. 14, 1889 | Nellie Bly Begins Trip Around the World
text: On Nov. 14, 1889, two female journalists, Nellie Bly of The New York World and Elizabeth Bisland of Cosmopolitan magazine, left New York to begin a trip around the world. The 25-year-old Bly had conceived of the idea after reading Jules Verne’s book “Around the World in 80 Days,” and Cosmopolitan decided to raise the stakes by sending Bisland to challenge her.

headline: One Destination in Common: The Bronx
text: The Bronx is no stranger to the Dutch. After all, they employed the Swedish seafarer Jonas Bronck, who in 1639 — along with his Dutch wife — settled the area that would adopt his name. Despite that long history, some of Chantal Heijnen’s friends in Amsterdam thought it was odd she chose to live there when they moved to New York in 2008.

headline: Far From Washington, Obama Defends His Policies
text: KAPOLEI, Hawaii — President Obama will be far from Washington this week meeting with Pacific Rim allies, but on Sunday he weighed in on simmering domestic issues, warning Congressional Republicans that voters will turn them out if they do not pass some of his job-creation proposals.

headline: The Black Market Peso Exchange’s NRI Connection
text: Vikram Datta, who moved from India to the United States in 1983, was known by his neighbors as a “polite family man.” United States prosecutors say he is also a “major player in the decades-old system of laundering drug money and reinvesting it back into the economy,” writes Julian Aguilar, with The Texas Tribune, a non-profit news organization partnered with The New York Times.

headline: Dining Club in Mumbai Brings Foodies Together
text: Dining in Mumbai can be overwhelming for new visitors. So what better way to familiarize yourself with the local cuisine than to meet up with other food lovers over dinner? That’s the mission behind Pet Pujaris — literally, “devotees of the stomach.” As the group’s key descriptor on its Facebook page says: “foodie meet ups and foodie bonding.”

headline: Do You Shop at Locally Owned Businesses?
text: So-called “big box” stores and online retailers have been changing the shopping landscape for years. Where does this leave locally owned businesses? Does your community have “Mom and Pop” shops or a downtown shopping district where you can buy everyday items like greeting cards? If so, do you shop there? What, in general, guides your decisions about where you spend your money?

headline: Wyoming Congresswoman to Endorse Romney
text: The presidential campaign of former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts is scheduled to announce the endorsement of Representative Cynthia M. Lummis of Wyoming on Monday morning, adding a Tea Party voice to its chorus of Congressional endorsements.

headline: On Fourth-and-Inches, Why Not Use a Quarterback Sneak?
text: There’s a healthy debate to be had about whether Falcons Coach Mike Smith made the right decision to go for it on fourth-and-inches from his own 29 in overtime against the Saints on Sunday. The results said No, and afterward Smith took “full responsibility” for the loss.

headline: Pattern of Illegality Is Cited at News of the World
text: LONDON —As a government-commissioned inquiry into Britain’s journalistic practices opened on Monday, its chief lawyer delivered a series of bombshell revelations about what he called a “thriving cottage industry” of illegality at the defunct News of the World tabloid.

headline: For McConnell, a Case for Divided Government
text: Mitch McConnell, the Senate Republican leader and a cagey political thinker, got a lot of attention last year when he said his No. 1 political goal was to topple President Obama. headline: Complaint Box | Patter by Proxy

headline: Why Mike Smith’s Fourth-Down Call Against Saints Was Correct
text: An analysis of a fourth-down call by Falcons Coach Mike Smith against the Saints has become almost an annual occurrence on the Fifth Down.In December 2010, the Falcons punted, and the Saints won. Smith was criticized on The Fifth Down. In December 2008, the Falcons punted, and the Saints won. Smith was criticized on the Fifth Down.

headline: In a California Vineyard, Bluebirds Earn Their Keep
text: In an innovative study, nest boxes installed at a California vineyard attracted hundreds of birds that picked the farmers’ crops clean of pests in exchange for the free housing. The experiment is heartening news for conservationists amid reports of shrinking habitats and population declines for so many species.

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 14
text: Steven Levy of Wired magazine profiles Jeff Bezos as Amazon ships its first Kindle Fire tablets today. The piece sets up Amazon vs. Apple. “Apple is fundamentally a hardware company — 91 percent of its revenue comes from sales of its coveted machines, compared to just 6 percent from iTunes,” he writes. “Amazon, on the other hand, is a content-focused company — almost half of its revenue comes from sales of media like books, music, TV shows, and movies — and the fire-sale-priced Fire is designed to be primarily a passport to the large amount of that content that’s available digitally.” [Wired]

headline: Study Finds Co-Payments Discourage Drug Treatments
text: A new study published on Monday shows patients are more likely to take their medicine when they do not have to help pay for the prescriptions. The study, which appears online in the New England Journal of Medicine, focused on patients with health insurance who had heart attacks.

headline: Berkshire Amasses 5.5% Stake in I.B.M.
text: Warren E. Buffett, the chairman and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, revealed on CNBC that his conglomerate had amassed 64 million shares of I.B.M, a stake of about 5.5 percent.

headline: Opinion Report: Civil Rights in Alabama
text: From the editorial page

headline: King of Jordan Becomes First Arab Leader to Tell Syria’s Assad to Quit
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — King Abdullah of Jordan added his voice on Monday to the growing pressure on the president of Syria to relinquish power, becoming the first Arab leader on Syria’s doorstep to call for a change in government to end the increasingly bloody political uprising there.

headline: Rex Ryan Transcript: An Apology to Jets Fans
text: Jets Coach Rex Ryan, who will play a Patriots fan in a coming Adam Sandler movie, sounded like a fan of the Patriots when he said early Monday morning: “They beat us twice. We think we’re as good as they are, but clearly, we’re not.”

headline: Bank of America to Sell Most of Its Stake in Chinese Lender
text: Bank of America announced on Monday that it would sell most of its remaining holdings in China Construction Bank to a group of unidentified investors, in a bid to bolster its capital buffer.

headline: CNBC’s Interview With Buffett
text: Warren E. Buffett, chairman and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, sat for a lengthy interview on CNBC on Monday.

headline: Immigrant Aid, Special Ed on Regents Agenda
text: The state's Board of Regents meets to vote on a measure to help illegal immigrants pay for college. The board will also vote on new rules affecting the delivery of special education services, including some that school districts say drive up costs.

headline: Sheldon Benardo: The Accidental Principal
text: Sheldon Benardo became the principal of a 2,300-student school in the Bronx because his brother had connections to the superintendent. But he has grown into the job, and Public School 86 in the Bronx, where he has been principal for 21 years, has received A's on its city progress report for the last five years. In a candid interview, he talks about his journey from Nantucket to the principal's office.

headline: A Homeless Child Struggles for Stability
text: In the news, a look into the lives of a homeless child enrolled in the city's schools: N-Dia Layne and her mother, Whitnee Layne, made a valiant attempt to keep N-Dia in the Brooklyn school she  had attended for four years. But mother and daughter were transferred from their Brooklyn shelter to one in Manhattan, and the hour and 15 minute commute proved daunting.

headline: Wading in Thailand’s Murky Waters
text: BANGKOK — In the industrial estate of Lat Krabang, a few kilometers from Bangkok’s international airport, Honda workers clad in ghost white are standing around the shuttered factory, like the idle employees of a suspended space program. The floodwaters are approaching from the north and the east, raising canal levels and bubbling up through drainage systems. One of the men says that the defenses — sandbags and plastic sheets — can withstand one meter of water, but no more.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Berkshire Amasses Big Stake in I.B.M.  |  Warren E. Buffett, the chairman and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, revealed on CNBC that his conglomerate had amassed 64 million shares of IBM, a stake of about 5.5 percent.

headline: Reporters Suit Up, Visit Fukushima Nuclear Plant
text: The Japanese government has begun allowing reporters to visit the area in and around the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station, including The Times’s own Martin Fackler. It wasn’t pretty, but it was hard to look away at the combination of a man-made and natural disaster, one with catastrophic consequences:

headline: From ‘Excelsior’ to ‘Where Is Mine?’
text: For a couple of centuries, New York State’s official motto has been “Excelsior,” which presumably has nothing to do with an inordinate early American fondness for wood shavings. It is usually translated from the Latin as “Ever Upward.” A lovely sentiment. Would that it were always true.

headline: Superfraud
text: It’s a bird! It’s a plane! It’s a turkey!

headline: Vain Glorious | Soap & Glory
text: What: Soap & Glory

headline: Fall of Berlusconi Has Domino Effect at Venice Biennale
text: The newly appointed president of the Venice Biennale has withdrawn, mainly because to the demise of his chief supporter, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian minister of culture, Giancarlo Galan, has announced.

headline: Austerity Then And Now
text: Alan Cowell has an interesting piece contrasting public attitudes toward austerity now with attitudes toward the austerity that was the norm in postwar Britain — and beautifully described by the late Tony Judt. As he notes, one major difference is that back then the sacrifice was shared.

headline: Monday Reading: Time to Book Trips Involving Sun and Sand
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: The 1% Across Space And Time
text: How is it possible that I didn’t know about the World Top Incomes Database until I stumbled across it this morning? Aren’t the people at INET supposed to let people like me know about these things?

headline: Readers’ Street Style: Winter Whites
text: The best of readers’ street fashion for the week of Nov. 7.

headline: Bookshelf
text: Before she was made empress, how Catherine the Great suffered! In his gripping new biography, “Catherine the Great” (Random House, $35), Robert K. Massie reveals a young woman lorded over by a tempestuous monarch, a meddling mother and a man-child husband who raised hunting dogs in her sleeping chambers. (She couldn’t even get a tooth pulled without insult; the palace surgeon tore out a piece of her jaw in the process.)

headline: Police Officer Accused of Infiltrating Occupy Oakland Says He Supports the Movement
text: Updated | 12:41 p.m. As my colleague Malia Wollan reports, “Hundreds of police officers in riot gear circled the Occupy Oakland encampment downtown on Monday morning, making arrests and flattening tents.”

headline: A Personal View of the Bronx
text: Some of Chantal Heijnen’s friends in Amsterdam thought it was odd when she moved to New York with her husband in 2008 and took up residence in one room of a five-room flat in the Bronx.

headline: Flying on Chicken Fat
text: Gasoline for cars is commonly blended with corn ethanol. In the last few weeks, airlines have started using blends, too, but their feedstocks are more varied, including chicken fat, algal oil, used fryer grease and parts of inedible plants.

headline: Justices to Hear Health Care Case as Race Heats Up
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear a challenge to the 2010 health care overhaul law, President Obama’s signature legislative achievement, setting the stage for oral arguments by March and a decision in late June as the 2012 presidential campaign enters its crucial final months.

headline: Unicredit Looks to Raise $10.3 Billion
text: Confronted by a quarterly loss and new capital requirements, UniCredit, the largest Italian bank, said on Monday that it would raise $10.3 billion and eliminate 5,200 jobs in Italy in the next few years.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Guardian: Jay Rayner takes on slow eaters. “They never notice the rest of their party of six stabbing themselves in the back of the hand with forks, or fixing nooses to the light fittings as an exit strategy, while they poke laboriously at whatever they have ordered.” — Nick FoxInside Scoop SF: To those who say no wine is worth more than $3 or so a bottle, Jon Bonné says, “Pshaw” (or words to that effect). — Eric Asimov

headline: Research Offers Hope for More Efficient Oil Sand Industry
text: Several years ago, Paul Painter, a professor of polymer science at Pennsylvania State University, saw a news report about the deaths of hundreds of ducks that landed on a tailings pond near an oil sands mine in the Canadian province of Alberta. The ducks had become coated with residual petroleum floating on the pond, which was filled with wastewater from the process used to extract oil from the strip-mined sands.

headline: Split Personalities and Political Spouses
text: Herman Cain’s wife, Gloria, has been pretty quiet so far, but in an interview conducted Sunday on Fox News (it’ll be broadcast Monday evening), she defended her husband against the sexual harassment accusations that surfaced about two weeks ago. She told Greta Van Susteren that her husband “totally respects women.” She also noted: “I’m thinking he would have to have a split personality to do the things that were said.”

headline: Investigation Into Saturn Aura Transmission Flaws Is Broadened
text: 12:03 p.m. | Updated

headline: More Depression for Mothers and Singles With Breast Cancer
text: Women who have children living at home and single women have higher levels of depression in the months after treatment than other breast cancer patients, new research shows.

headline: Afghan Oil Fields Aren’t a Curse – Yet
text: SAR-E POL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government has a knack for botching everything: if Afghan officials were cooks, as the saying goes, they could ruin rice. The Chinese, by contrast, have an impressive record over the last couple of decades, and their achievement in the sphere of rice-cooking goes without mentioning.

headline: Monday Matchup: Vikings at Packers
text: Vikings (2-6) at Packers (8-0), 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPNLine: Packers by 13

headline: Chinese Students Flock to U.S., as Americans Seek Out ‘Less Traditional’ Countries
text: A record 723,277 international students were enrolled at United States colleges and universities last year, according to “Open Doors,” the Institute of International Education’s annual report, released on Monday.

headline: Numberplay: The Missing Slice
text: “Thirty-two slices?” You hesitate slightly. “We can do that. One Deluxe cut into 32 slices.”

headline: Cromer to Direct ‘Tribes’ at Barrow Street Theater
text: 3:38 p.m. | Updated Nina Raine’s new comedy, “Tribes,” will have its North American premiere at the Barrow Street Theater starting in February, the producers announced on Monday. The production will be directed by David Cromer, who in 2009 collaborated on “Our Town” at Barrow Street with the producers of “Tribes,” Scott Morfee, Jean Doumanian and Tom Wirtshafter.

headline: Chimpanzee Stories
text: Photos and biographies of a few of the chimps, some with long histories, others with uncertain futures, at Chimp Haven and The New Iberia Research Center, both in Louisiana.

headline: Lending a Hand to Banks, but Not to Nations
text: FRANKFURT — Is it time for the European Central Bank to be as generous to countries as it is to banks?

headline: Chimps’ Days in Labs May Be Dwindling
text: NEW IBERIA, La. — In a dome-shaped outdoor cage, a dozen chimpanzees are hooting. The hair on their shoulders sticks straight up. “That’s piloerection,” a sign of emotional arousal, says Dr. Dana Hasselschwert, head of veterinary sciences at the New Iberia Research Center. She tells a visitor to keep his distance. The chimps tend to throw pebbles — or worse — when they get excited.

headline: Edible Selby | Olive Garden
text: La Tête Dans les Olives, a sliver of a food shop and restaurant in the 10th Arrondissement, is the work of Cédric Casanova, a slack-rope walker who spent 15 years performing in traveling circuses, most recently Cirque du Soleil. Casanova developed a passion for Sicily’s fruity olives during summers he spent there as a child — his father is Sicilian — and wanted to share them with his hometown, Paris. The tiny épicerie offers oils and handpicked olives from his favorite growers, along with tapenades, sun-dried tomatoes and other seasonal delicacies. “The way people react to good olive oil is like what I see in the circus,” Casanova says. “People smile. They love it.” Go to interactive feature >>

headline: Taking the Air Out of a Season
text: It was comforting to realize the frauds we had to deal with Sunday were merely of the professional football variety. It required no soul-searching to watch the Jets’ being exposed as 90 percent hot air, the Lions unmasked as unthreatening bullies, or the Chiefs as ... gee, I’m not even sure what analogy fits there but for some reason they evoke the image of squashed Bubble Wrap. Sure, you could comb the injury bin and start to feel queasy about the real toll the N.F.L. takes, but for a day, gosh, it sure beat contemplating college football’s full-scale ethical seizure.

headline: Police Clear Occupy Oakland Encampment, but Protesters Return
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Protesters returned to a downtown plaza Monday evening, after hundreds of police officers raided the Occupy Oakland encampment there early Monday, arresting 33 people and flattening tents.

headline: The New York Times Comedy Challenge: Standings Update
text: With so many shows scheduled over the last five days in conjunction with the annual New York Comedy Festival, we decided to pose a challenge to select comics: Tell us your best clean joke. (The networks may have relaxed their standards but we at The New York Times are standing firm.) A mix of established performers and up-and-comers took us on: Jim Gaffigan, Michael Che, Rachel Feinstein, Leah Bonnema, Angelo Lozada and John O’Donnell. We posted their entries here and asked you to vote. Whose bit killed? Voting closes at the end of the day, so you still have a chance to weigh in.

headline: New Policy on Substitutes Leads to More in Permanent Slots
text: The city and the teachers' union say more teachers have picked up permanent assignments this fall because of a new agreement, in which substitute teachers rotate to different schools every week.

headline: Long Road Ahead for Most American States
text: Michigan, Nevada and Rhode Island will probably have to wait another six years before they are back to the number of jobs they had before the recession struck, according to economists at IHS Global Insight.

headline: DealBook: Berkshire Amasses 5.5% Stake in I.B.M.
text: Warren E. Buffett, the chairman and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, revealed on CNBC that his conglomerate had amassed 64 million shares of I.B.M, a stake of about 5.5 percent. Read the entire post on DealBook.

headline: App City: Where to Eat?
text: NYT Tech’s own Joshua Brustein moonlights as a columnist in Sunday’s Metropolitan section. Check out his latest on dining apps for New Yorkers here.

headline: Daily Report: Google’s Secret Projects
text: A story that is sure to be at the center of the tech conversation today is “Google’s Lab of Wildest Dreams,” a look by Claire Cain Miller and Nick Bilton of The New York Times at Google X, the top-secret lab where Google is working on a list of 100 shoot-for-the-stars ideas — from robots to space elevators (in theory, rocketless travel to outer space along a cable attached to Earth) to ways to connect the Internet to ordinary household items like coffee cups and refrigerators.

headline: Will Cloud Computing Make Everything (and Everyone) Work Harder?
text: What do the following have in common: Computers, limousines, empty beds and stay-at-home moms?

headline: Moody’s Buys Majority Stake in Indian Research Firm
text: NEW DELHI — Moody’s said on Monday that it had bought a majority stake in Copal Partners, a company that provides research and analysis for banks, hedge funds and private equity firms using analysts in India and other emerging markets.

headline: Can Virtual Schools Really Replace Classrooms?
text: If the home-schooling anarchist parents in the Sunday Magazine played to a fantasy of what home schooling could be — the traveling, the rebellion against the authority of the classroom, the rugged individualist children — then The Wall Street Journal’s counterpoint, “My Teacher Is an App,” is the disillusioning reality for many.

headline: Reaching a Comfort Level With Geoengineering
text: Until recently, the idea of coping with climate change by means of geoengineering was something it seemed no one wanted to talk about. Even people who saw potential merit in deliberately altering conditions on Earth or in the atmosphere to mitigate climate change feared that if people thought there was an engineering fix, it would encourage them to abandon efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions

headline: Karzai Call for Meeting of Elders Questioned
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Despite criticism from neighboring countries, threats from the Taliban and calls for a boycott from some political opponents, President Hamid Karzai has called a loya jirga, the traditional grand council of Afghan elders and leaders, in an attempt to gain popular support for a long-term partnership with the United States, Afghan officials and analysts say.

headline: I Like the New Coldplay. Sue Me.
text: I mentioned to the magazine’s editor that the new Coldplay record was pretty good. He told me to leave his office. Actually, first he said, “Oh, I’m gonna tweet this.” Then he kicked me out.

headline: How Closing a Credit Card Affects Your Credit Score
text: Do you have a chunk of credit-card debt that you keep bouncing from card to card to take advantage of an attractive balance transfer offer? Or have you opened new credit card accounts just so that you can collect extra miles or some other enticing bonus?

headline: Klinsmann Has Time on His Side
text: It probably shouldn’t be a surprise that some fans of the United States national team expect Jurgen Klinsmann to be further along in his makeover of the squad. Klinsmann and U.S. Soccer danced around each other for so long before he finally got the job that it almost seems as if he has had it for three years, not three months.

headline: The Meatball Shop Goes Vegetarian
text: The Meatball Shop in Manhattan is famous for its meatballs, of course. On a given day you might find a Reuben Ball or a Chicken Cordon Bleu Ball or just a classic beef meatball with tomato sauce.

headline: The S.B.A. Says Its Culture Has Changed
text: In a recent post about the incidence of fraud in federal contracting programs for small businesses, the Small Business Administration came in for some criticism from the agency’s inspector general, Peggy E. Gustafson. Ms. Gustafson, whose office is independent from the rest of the agency, testified before Congress recently that the agency needed to “change its culture” and become more aggressive in punishing contractors who misrepresent themselves as small companies in order to win government work.

headline: Ex-Coach Denies Charges Amid New Accusations
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Close to 10 additional suspected victims have come forward to the authorities since the arrest of the former Penn State defensive coordinator Jerry Sandusky on Nov. 5 on 40 counts of sexually abusing young boys, according to people close to the investigation. The police are working to confirm the new allegations.

headline: Q. & A. With a Newspaperman Who Thinks Print Is Overrated
text: On Monday, we ran a story about John Paton, a long-time newspaper executive who thinks the problems with print media may be solved by printing less. The conventions of a news story require that a long conversation get boiled down to a few pithy quotes. Because of the size of Mr. Paton’s gamble — he is now running both the Journal Register and MediaNews newspaper chains — we thought it might be worthwhile to run a longer version of the interview. The following conversation has been edited for clarity.

headline: Site to Be Seen | Patrik Ervell
text: For the brand loyalist there’s an abundance of designer-specific e-commerce sites. Leave it to the minimalist Patrik Ervell to be ahead of the curve with an online destination that’s one of the cleanest and easiest to shop. Organized into only a few basic categories, Ervell’s perennial favorites (like this padded shirt, $370, and leather backpack, $670) are brilliantly presented on models in motion, so that shoppers can get all angles and details of the clothing they’re considering. Should they be looking to branch out beyond the staples, there are runway offerings like this pleather flight suit, $1,200, too, that make the web site — like the collection — anything but monotonous.

headline: Really? The Claim: Exercise Can Ward Off Migraines
text: THE FACTS

headline: Bachmann Goes Negative on Rivals Online
text: Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota hasn’t spent much lately on traditional advertising, but she is waging a campaign to secure as much free media attention as she can.

headline: The Caucus Click: Cain Family Photo
text: From left, Karol Cain, Mr. Cain’s daughter in law; Vincent, his son; Celena Jackson, his granddaughter; Melanie Cain-Jackson, his daughter; Mr. Cain; Gloria Cain; Preston Jackson, his grandson; and Greta Van Susteren.

headline: Combat Injuries Can Change Lives in Surprising Ways
text: As I walked through the sliding doors at my local Veterans Affairs clinic last week, I couldn’t help but cringe at the morose scene in front of me. Sitting in the small, overcrowded waiting area were the former fighters of our nation’s wars, both past and present. Veterans from every conflict since Korea seemed to be represented. The Vietnam vets, with their worn out olive-drab field jackets, outnumbered the rest, but a few Korean, Desert Storm, Iraq and Afghanistan veterans were scattered throughout.

headline: Friend-of-Court Filings Mushroom, and a Law Professor Takes Issue
text: WASHINGTON — Not long ago, a law professor at Harvard received a routine request. Would he add his name to a brief from a group of law professors urging a federal court to uphold the health care overhaul law?

headline: Buy This House, and Wave Hello to the Governor
text: The listing is not particularly remarkable: a World War II-era, Cape-style house just outside Mount Kisco, N.Y., with a cherry wood and granite kitchen and four bathrooms selling for $699,000, a modest price by the standards of leafy Westchester County villages. But what the listing does not reveal is that buying the house will make one a neighbor of New York’s governor.

headline: Video Sports of The Times: Will Mark Sanchez Ever Grow Up?
text: The Jets’ latest loss to the New England Patriots raises the question of whether quarterback Mark Sanchez will ever be able to lead the team to elite status.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Edwards and Stewart Enter Sprint Cup Finale In Virtual Dead Heat
text: The chatter preceding the Kobalt Tools 500 centered on Carl Edwards, the points leader in the Nascar Chase for the Sprint Cup, and Tony Stewart, who trailed him by three points. Though neither driver logged a victory on Sunday at Phoenix International Raceway, the post-race focus remained fixated on the two drivers and the three points that still separated them.

headline: Bolshoi Is Stung by Loss of Two Stars
text: Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev, major stars of the ballet world and two of Russia’s best-known classical artists, said on Monday that they were leaving the storied Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow for the Mikhailovsky Theater in St. Petersburg.

headline: Rahul Gandhi, Angry Young Man?
text: Rahul Gandhi, the heir-apparent of India’s ruling Congress party, seems to be trying to transform his image from a mild-mannered, reluctant politician to an angry firebrand.

headline: Is Mark Sanchez Good Enough?
text: William C. Rhoden on the Jets loss to the Patriots.

headline: Can Extreme Climate Confusion be Avoided?
text: This post is a tale of two climate conferences, and a forecast for a substantial risk of climate confusion later this week.

headline: A Famous Neighbor: Is Having One a Good Thing?
text: Even the most hardcore celebrity hound might not be excited to find the paparazzi on the lawn next door. But wouldn’t the presence of a famous neighbor bump property values, providing measurable cachet to one’s block or building?

headline: The Euro Zone Crisis and the U.S.: A Primer
text: The potential effect of the euro zone crisis on the United States has been the subject of several recent articles, including Annie Lowrey’s on Saturday. Here’s a primer summarizing the three main channels through which the fiasco across the Atlantic could hurt the American economy: trade, stock markets and (most worrisome) a contagious credit crisis.

headline: Performa Takes on Bergman
text: I’ve never been so happy to see death as I was Friday night at the Museum of the Moving Image. Alas, my happiness was short lived.

headline: Moody’s Invests in Indian Research
text: Moody’s said on Monday that it had bought a majority stake in Copal Partners, a company that provides research and analysis for banks, hedge funds and private equity firms using analysts in India and other emerging markets.

headline: Google’s Mobile Stars Fall on Alabama
text: The song “Blues in the Night” includes a lyric that begins, “From Natchez to Mobile, from Memphis to St. Joe.” Now, marketers will be watching the results of a campaign that extends from Mountain View to Mobile.

headline: Look of the Moment | Tilda Swinton
text: The Look: Icy. A crisply tailored satin and silk tuxedo in slightly off shades of shimmery ivory and winter white looks terrifically slick and smart.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Quarterback Shuffle Is Keeping the Redskins Running in Place
text: For the Washington Redskins, there was some good news Sunday despite their fifth consecutive loss. When Philadelphia lost to the Arizona Cardinals at home, it ensured that the biggest debacle in the N.F.L. this season would be the Eagles, whose fans called for Andy Reid’s job on the way out of the stadium.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Leo Burnett Canada, Toronto, was named the winner of the first Agency of the Year honor presented by the Advertising and Design Club of Canada at its 62nd annual awards show. Leo Burnett Canada is part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Publicis Groupe.

headline: Publisher and Two Top Editors Are Out at Newsweek/Daily Beast
text: 3:15 p.m. | Updated The publisher and two high-ranking editors at Newsweek and The Daily Beast are leaving their jobs, a string of departures that signal distress inside the company as it struggles to turn its fortunes around.

headline: Part 1: Answers to Your Questions on Scholarships and Student Loans
text: To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them — as well as to further their understanding of President Obama’s recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans — Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is spending this week in our virtual Guidance Office. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of “Secrets to Winning a Scholarship,” published in February.

headline: Screening: Doctors Paid for Heart Tests Order More
text: Doctors who earn money for cardiac stress testing are much more likely to prescribe the tests than those who don’t, a new study has found.

headline: No Time to Sulk for the Jets
text: If the season ended today – and, boy, are the Jets glad it doesn’t – they would rate as the seventh-best team in the A.F.C. The problem for them is, only the top six reach the playoffs. Their hopes of winning the division were all but squashed Sunday night by a 37-16 loss to New England, a defeat that forced the Jets to recalibrate their expectations. Once again a wild-card berth – and the road games that come with it – appears their best chance at making the postseason.

headline: A Watch-and-Wait Prostate Treatment
text: With controversy raging over whether men should be screened for prostate cancer with the PSA blood test, the experience of one man in his 80s suggests an alternative to a simple yes-or-no response, as well as options for prevention and treatment that men of all ages might consider.

headline: Death of a Heavyweight
text: Friends, family and fellow boxers paid their respects to the boxer Joe Frazier at a funeral on Monday after he died last week from liver cancer at age 67.

headline: Black Sabbath, the Iron Men of Rock, to Reunite
text: The four original members of Black Sabbath have announced they will reunite next year to release their first album of new songs in three decades and to embark on a world tour.

headline: Farmers Find Rewards in Helping Bog Turtles
text: The future of the bog turtle, North America’s tiniest reptile and one of its rarest, is in the hands of private landowners who are being given incentives to help it recover, wildlife biologists say.

headline: Deutsche Bank’s Ackermann Won’t Take Chairman Role
text: FRANKFURT — Josef Ackermann unexpectedly canceled plans to become chairman of Deutsche Bank when he retires as chief executive in May, possibly heralding his departure from the public stage after a decade as one of the most powerful and controversial figures in European banking.

headline: Hazards: Solvent Linked to Higher Parkinson’s Risk
text: A new study of twins has found that trichloroethylene, or TCE, a solvent widely used in refrigerants and as a metal degreaser, is associated with an increased risk of Parkinson’s disease.

headline: TimesCast | November 14, 2011
text: The Supreme Court agrees to hear a health care overhaul law challenge; police raid the Occupy Oakland protest; and one police officer accused of infiltrating that protest says he supports it.

headline: Should Hall of Famers Have to Shine Internationally Too?
text: Four new members will be enshrined in the Hockey Hall of Fame in Toronto tonight, and the consensus is that a better quartet has not been so honored in many years. Ed Belfour, Doug Gilmour, Mark Howe and Joe Nieuwendyk are all names familiar to any hockey fan and each had a lengthy and successful career in the N.H.L.

headline: Jets Down, and at Their Most Dangerous
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Fred Neuhouser
text: The philosopher Fred Neuhouser on inequality and secular theodicy.

headline: Hilary Mantel to Write ‘Wolf Hall’ Sequel
text: Hilary Mantel, winner of the 2009 Man Booker Prize for “Wolf Hall,” a historical novel about Henry VIII’s adviser Thomas Cromwell, will follow it with a sequel, “Bring Up the Bodies,” her publisher said on Monday. The book is scheduled for release in fall 2012 by John Macrae Books, an imprint of Henry Holt and Company.

headline: An Interview with Fred Neuhouser
text: This video is part of a weekly series of interviews with contemporary thinkers and philosophers on questions that matter.

headline: Near Zuccotti Park, Protesting the Protest
text: Businesses and neighbors of the protesters in Zuccotti Park plan to attend a counter-rally on Monday objecting to the demonstrators’ continued presence. Local restaurant administrators said they believed the protest would begin at 5 p.m. on the steps of City Hall.

headline: Cardinals Find Their Manager; Cubs and Red Sox Continue Searching
text: The interviews are chugging along as the big managerial openings with the Cardinals, Cubs and Red Sox entail differing obstacle courses.

headline: Exploring China, Taste Buds First
text: Alice Waters and Amy Tan dine in Beijing.

headline: Teenagers Having Sex Are a Minority
text: About 43 percent of unmarried teenage girls and 42 percent of unmarried teenage boys have had sexual intercourse at least once, according to new research from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In 2002, the last year such a report was published, 45.5 percent of girls and 45.7 percent of boys had had sex by 19.

headline: Exploring China, Taste Buds First
text: BEIJING – The historic restaurants in Beijing are often best avoided. Residents here leave it to tourists to go to Quanjude for roast duck. Likewise, Dong Lai Shun, a famous mutton hotpot restaurant near the Forbidden City, has seen better days.

headline: Prognosis: No Competition Yet Between HPV Types
text: The two vaccines against human papillomavirus together target the four types of HPV that cause a large majority of cervical and anal cancers. But there are more than a dozen other cancer-causing HPV types, and scientists have been concerned that as more people are vaccinated, these types could begin to flourish.

headline: Google Reveals Tweaks to Its Search Algorithm
text: Google on Monday revealed 10 recent changes to its search algorithm that affect results as diverse as those that are date-specific and those that are in Hindi.

headline: In TV Special, Gabrielle Giffords Reveals Her Struggle to Recover
text: video platformvideo managementvideo solutionsvideo player

headline: The Best of Scuttlebot
text: Here’s what the reporters and editors of The New York Times tech staff found on the Web. The full Scuttlebot feed is on this page in the right-hand column.

headline: Cornmeal for Thanksgiving and Year-Round
text: My Recipes for Health this week aren’t Thanksgiving recipes per se (enough already!), but they’d be welcome at a Thanksgiving table. I include cornmeal in my grouping of Thanksgiving foods, as corn is one of the Native American foods that sustained the Pilgrims during their first difficult years in the colonies.

headline: N.B.A. Season in Peril as Players Reject Offer
text: The union representing National Basketball Association players formally disbanded Monday and declared it would take its labor standoff with the league’s owners into federal court, a development that pushed the league as close as it has ever been to losing an entire season of play.

headline: Consumer Reports Poll Shows Support for Stronger Fuel-Economy Standards
text: A poll conducted by Consumer Reports in late October showed that an overwhelming majority of American consumers would support higher fuel-economy standards and would be willing to pay a premium for high-efficiency vehicles.

headline: Case Study | Quinine Syrup
text: As befits the pointy-headed elevation of all simple things, gourmet attention is now being paid to the humble gin and tonic. Specifically, to the tonic. Why would one bother? What’s broke? Well, since the 1970s, the default Schweppes and Canada Dry tonics in the United States have been made with high-fructose corn syrup, which renders them blowsy and a bit toothless. If you are the type of imbiber who seeks out a specific gin (or vodka) on which to base your drink, doesn’t the larger proportion of that drink — which in this case comprises at least twice the volume of the spirit — deserve equal scrutiny and care?

headline: Thanksgiving Countdown | Gravy Alternatives
text: As Mark Bittman has pointed out, gravy is but one of many sauces that can bring flavor and moisture to a plate of turkey and stuffing, like parsley purée, eggless béarnaise or bourbon barbecue sauce. There’s homemade cranberry ketchup, or cherry ketchup, tangy and sweet. Or you could top your turkey with a different kind of staple sauce altogether: simple, classic pesto.

headline: Gathering at the Wake for Western Dominance
text: In his 2003 book,  “Empire,” which was published here in the immediate wake of the United States-led invasion of Iraq, the popular British historian Niall Ferguson argued that the United States was “an empire in denial” and was “capable of playing an imperial role” in the world today, much the way Britain once did, in the 19th century.

headline: Keeping Greens Green
text: Q. When greengrocers drench vegetables with water every few minutes, does it keep them fresh or hasten spoilage?

headline: It’s Spelled T-O-R-T-U-R-E
text: There are moments when a politician’s character bursts through the spin, sound bites and ideological chanting. Voters have to watch for them, because they can be fleeting.

headline: Drawing Dance: Cunningham in Minneapolis
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the 19th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from Minneapolis, Minn.

headline: A Busy Love Life, Built With a Mother’s Help
text: The muriqui monkeys of the Atlantic Forest in Brazil, a highly endangered species numbering only about 1,000, live in an egalitarian society.

headline: On a Mountaintop, Dreaming of the Next Step
text: As some of you may know, we’re a family of five who embarked in July on a year of living in the Maine woods, relocating from our house in the New Jersey suburbs. We spent the first few months off the grid on a lake in the north woods, and we’ve been in what we call the “winter house” for about five weeks now. (As an aside, we are renters, not owners, in Maine.)

headline: MF Global and the Problems With Murky Accounting
text: The collapse of MF Global shows how easy it is to obscure risky investments and the pitfalls that can occur when those problems surface. By minimizing its exposure to European sovereign debt, the firm lost credibility in the market and eventually got hammered as fears over possible bond defaults rose.

headline: JPMorgan Names 2 Executives to New Posts
text: After moving several members of his senior leadership team this summer, Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase‘s chairman and chief executive, has started to reshuffle the ranks a layer or so down.

headline: Disney Acquires Parent Blogging Network
text: In a bid to expand its digital footprint, the Walt Disney Company announced on Monday that it had purchased Babble Media, an online site for parents that features hundreds of bloggers.

headline: Cain Accuser’s Ex-Boyfriend Supports Harassment Claims
text: Nov. 15, 9:10 a.m. | Updated  Victor Zuckerman, a pediatrician, said on Monday that he was dating Sharon Bialek in the 1990s when she told him that Herman Cain had touched her inappropriately.

headline: Last-Drink Playlist: Extended Play Edition
text: As I put together my “Perfect Last-Drink Playlist” for my column about nightcaps, I was surprised to discover how few—among the gazillions of songs about drinking—take on the nightcap directly. So I loosened the parameters a bit, to include songs about the moments when one might drink a nightcap (“The Wee Small Hours of the Morning”), and what one might drink (“Cognac Blues”). Of course, by the time I’d given my editor the playlist, I thought of other numbers I wished I’d included, especially Lotte Lenya’s unrivaled “Alabama Song.”

headline: PAC Sponsors Huntsman Ad Campaign in New Hampshire
text: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. has staked his ailing presidential bid on a strong showing in the New Hampshire Republican primary. Now he’s going to have some help.

headline: Krzyzewski: Paterno a Great Man in Horrific Situation
text: DURHAM, N.C. – In June, Penn State football coach Joe Paterno and Duke basketball coach Mike Krzyzewski sat down together to tape a show for ESPN about ethics, integrity and issues associated with college athletics called, “Difference Makers: Life Lessons with Paterno and Krzyzewski.”

headline: Timescast | Occupy Oakland Raids
text: Hundreds of police officers raid the Occupy Oakland camp, and a police officer accused in a viral video of infiltrating Occupy Oakland speaks out in support of the movement.

headline: What Can I Prepare Before the Actual Day of Thanksgiving?
text: Q.

headline: Cloaks of Invisibility, Switched in a Flash
text: About half a mile below the surface of the Pacific Ocean, small squid and octopuses face a camouflage conundrum.

headline: TimesCast | New Focus on Health Care Law
text: November 14, 2011 — The Supreme Court agrees to hear a health care overhaul law challenge.

headline: Ask About Restoring Gun Rights to Convicted Felons
text: In an article and a video report in Monday’s New York Times, Michael Luo examined how easy it is in many states for people with felony convictions to get their gun rights reinstated.

headline: Cain Appears Flustered When Asked About Libya
text: 4:28 p.m. | Updated Herman Cain appeared flustered when asked during an interview Monday about his views on the Obama administration’s support of the Libyan uprising.

headline: Two Sides to Every Store
text: CHRISSIE MILLER of Sophomore, a line of sportswear basics with a bit of an edge, and Lindsey Thornburg, known for her wool blanket cloaks, have gone into business together: their new boutique, named 143, will open Friday at 143 Ludlow Street, (212) 780-0900. “We had crushes on each other’s lines,” Ms. Thornburg said. On one side of the whitewashed and baby-blue shop are the Thornburg cloaks and bohemian layered-chiffon dresses, which run from $700 to $2,000; on the other side is Sophomore, designed with Madeleine von Froomer, with drawstring pants and floral dresses, $50 to $400.

headline: Ordering Thanksgiving Pies From Artisanal Bakers
text: THE best pie is personal, made from a stained recipe card in your grandmother’s ringlety handwriting, with flour on your nose and eyelashes.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov.14
text: The day in sports included the Southeast Asian Games in Indonesia and a victory by Brazil over Egypt in an international soccer friendly.

headline: Towers of Power
text: CINEMATIC villains love modern architecture: just think of all the Bond baddies holed up in their sleek hideaways, or maybe Jackie Treehorn, the pornographer-shylock of “The Big Lebowski,” who surveys the Los Angeles oceanfront from the luxury of a mod mansion by the architect John Lautner (who also designed the Elrod House in Palm Springs, Calif., featured in the Bond classic “Diamonds Are Forever”). The sharp lines and minimal interiors of modern architecture make a convenient shorthand for filmmakers who wish to telegraph a character’s malevolent intent, and a counterpoint to the traditional values ostensibly conveyed by traditional architecture.

headline: Calming Schools by Focusing on Well-Being of Troubled Students
text: Mark Ossenheimer, principal of the Urban Assembly School for Wildlife Conservation in the Bronx, threw out a name to add to the list of teenagers in trouble.

headline: Want More Parents? Make Them Want to Come
text: Parents will come to a parent-teacher meeting if they believe teachers have gone the extra mile for their children, a teacher says. At the Urban Assembly School for Applied Math and Science in the Bronx, where teachers make home visits, about 90 percent of parents come to meetings.

headline: Shirin Neshat’s Performa Contribution
text: Performa lore is inextricably bound up with the Iranian artist Shirin Neshat. In 1998, RoseLee Goldberg, the visual-art performance biennial’s founder, wondered what would happen if Ms. Neshat translated her work in video and photography into live art. One result, in 2001, was “Logic of the Birds.” Ms. Neshat’s first foray into performance, it led to the creation of Performa as a vehicle for pushing performance forward while educating people about its past.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Oakland and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from California, Thailand, Pennsylvania and Iran.

headline: Biochemistry: Scientists Decode the Protective Element Sickle Cell Anemia Offers Against Malaria
text: Scientists believe they have finally figured out how the mutation that causes sickle cell anemia also protects against fatal malaria.

headline: Greek Greens Pie With Cornmeal Crust
text: This is a beautiful, rustic and comforting dish adapted from recipes from Epirus, a mountainous region of northwestern Greece. The cornmeal crust is like a thin layer of polenta both above and below the greens, which are fragrant with dill, mint and parsley. I use fine cornmeal, which is sometimes packaged as corn flour. It’s important to let the pie sit for 30 minutes after baking so that the crust can set.

headline: A Portable Glow to Help Melt Those Winter Blues
text: Jan Brehm lives in rainy Portland, Ore., and she has always dreaded this time of year, when the days get shorter, her mood plummets and all she wants to do is crawl into bed and eat cookie dough.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Oakland and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from California, Thailand, Pennsylvania and Iran.

headline: Behind the Veil
text: BLACK veils, usually reserved for religious ceremonies, goth brides and Daphne Guinness, are bringing some dramatic flair to street and cocktail dress. In Paris, at last month’s round of fashion shows, the French designer Faustine Rome looked like a latter-day Marlene Dietrich from “Shanghai Express,” in a veiled cloche, ruffled cape (in lieu of feathers) and studded bangles (today’s pearls?).

headline: Thank You, Supercommittee
