text: Whenever people worry that the American electorate has become hopelessly divided, I like to point out that we’re remarkably united on at least one issue: Everyone dislikes Congress. The latest New York Times/CBS News poll found that only 9 percent of Americans approve of the way lawmakers are handling their jobs. And more than four out of five Republicans, Democrats, and Independents actively disapprove. (President Obama’s 46 percent approval rating looks like massive support by comparison.)

headline: The Art of Science
text: Selected images from Princeton University’s Art of Science competition.

headline: Polls Apart
text: An interesting day for polling. On one side, a majority of Americans now support the individual mandate. Since that’s the core of health reform, this basically means that proponents are slowly winning the argument. If we make it to actual full implementation, this reform will be irreversible.

headline: Critics’ Picks: ‘The Public Enemy’
text: A. O. Scott looks back at the 1931 gangster classic starring James Cagney.

headline: With New Service, Speeding Up the Commute on 34th Street
text: Manhattan’s 34th Street is known for the Macy’s flagship store and city buses that move like mud. Macy’s is here to stay, but the Bloomberg administration is hoping the pokey buses will be going the way of Gimbels.

headline: A Wave of Partner Retirements at Goldman Sachs
text: The cost-cutting at Goldman Sachs is now reaching the top ranks of the firm.

headline: Turning a Page | Cara Benedetto at Taxter and Spengemann
text: Cara Benedetto’s debut solo show at Taxter and Spengemann, “Breaking Waves (How Fake Stakes Ate the Cake),” hard-core in every sense of the phrase, is a puzzling and provocative accumulation of imagined correspondences written and signed by a cast of vivid, often angry authors to the people who have done them right and wrong in life.

headline: Mental Monetary Disorders
text: Brad DeLong has been blogging about von Mises and his belief — shared by a number of people to this day — that any economic expansion driven by monetary expansion must somehow be unsound and destructive.

headline: Saints Continue Winless Streak on Coin Flips
text: With the Saints losing both coin tosses in Sunday’s victory against the Falcons — the one before the game and the one before overtime — they have now lost all 11 tosses this season. The odds of that are 1 in 2,048.

headline: Medical Nuances Drove ‘No’ Vote in Mississippi
text: JACKSON, Miss. — When her children woke up on Wednesday morning, Atlee Breland told them, “Mama won her election.”

headline: Credit Suisse Changes Compensation Practices
text: All signs suggest bonuses on Wall Street will be lower this year. But on Monday, employees at Credit Suisse Group received some good news: less of their compensation will be deferred to future years.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 59
text: These are turbulent times in Occupy encampments around the country. City officials closed down camps in at least six cities over the weekend and early Monday, after three people died in encampments late last week. Salt Lake City police ordered the closing of the camp in Pioneer Park after a man was found dead in his tent in what the police said was possibly a drug overdose combined with carbon monoxide poisoning. Last week, a protester in Burlington, Vt., shot himself in an apparent suicide, and in Oakland, a 25-year-old protester was shot and killed on the outskirts of the encampment in Frank Ogawa Plaza. Evictions in Portland, Denver, St. Louis, Salt Lake City, Burlington and Oakland were largely peaceful, but more than 60 people were arrested nationwide. [Daily Kos, MSNBC, CNN]

headline: For Beginning Runners, Advice Can Be a Hurdle
text: I wrote a column last month discussing whether runners should train with a coach — and not a single reader wrote in to ask how to find a coach. But many asked about something else.

headline: A Rout for NBC as Well as the Patriots
text: The “Sunday Night Football” game between the New England Patriots and the New York Jets was by far the No. 1 program in all ratings categories, giving NBC an easy victory over all for the night (the Patriots also had an easy win, 37-16). “Once Upon a Time” on ABC was the highest-rated scripted program and has been very steady the last three weeks, hovering between 11 and 12 million total viewers (with 11.3 million this week).

headline: In the Wild, Finding More Than a Feminine Side
text: The Western marsh harrier is a typical hawk. It has a sharp beak and talons, which it uses to kill other creatures for food and to defend its territory. It’s the kind of bird that exemplifies military virtues, and it’s no wonder that it has a fighter jet, the British-made Harrier, named after it. Recent science, however, has discovered another side to the harrier that may not fit as well with the rather macho military image. Some harriers have evolved an alternative lifestyle — cross-dressing.

headline: Light Therapy for Dark Days
text: For the millions of Americans who suffer from mild to severe winter blues — a condition called seasonal affective disorder, or S.A.D. — bright-light therapy is the treatment of choice, with response rates comparable with those of antidepressants, reports today’s Consumer column.

headline: Witnesses’ Recordings Help Explain Air Accidents
text: When the oxygen masks dropped from their overhead compartments on a Frontier Airlines flight from Denver on Oct. 13, Andrew Vos put his on and looked out the window. “We were dropping down into these mountains,” he said.

headline: Update: The Pumpkins of Kane Street
text: As promised, a return visit to the pumpkins of Kane Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.

headline: Recipe for the Moon’s Magnetic Field: Spin and Stir
text: When astronauts from the 1969 Apollo 11 mission returned to Earth with about 50 pounds of lunar rocks and soil, scientists were surprised to find that some of the samples were magnetized. The Moon has no magnetic field, so it must have had an unknown magnetic past.

headline: Flashy Pieces From a Flashy Composer
text: Liszt, one of the most innovative composer-pianists of the 19th century, pioneered the modern solo recital format and performed both his own works and those by other musicians during his flamboyant concerts. So it seemed fitting that the 29-year-old Hungarian pianist Adam Gyorgy offered one of his own compositions during a concert dedicated to Liszt at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening.

headline: Barriers to Bone Care (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tomorrow’s Psychologists (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Philbin Packs Up His Desk, but Not His Stories
text: In Regis Philbin’s office at the studios of WABC television on the Upper West Side, the shelves were about half empty last week, as he wound down the days to his final appearance, Friday morning, on “Live With Regis and Kelly.”

headline: Jury Out on E-Cigarettes (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Little Old Work Fills a Big New Space
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Across the street from my hotel here is the stately stone Lyric Theater. Built as a Shriners’ hall in 1926, it has also served as a Red Cross blood collection center, a playhouse, a radio studio and a movie theater called the Capri.

headline: A Crab Walk Amid Quiet of a Library
text: At the New York Public Library on Sunday night the musician Ben Frost issued a sublime rejoinder to the institution’s usual hush. The Rose Main Reading Room shook with the sound of six electric guitars being endlessly strummed and a brass sextet on the balcony. Before that, inside the entrance guarded by the library’s marble lions, the Australian choreographer Lee Serle presented a dance.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Public Enemy’
text: America’s love affair with movie gangsters shows no signs of letting up. A. O. Scott looks back at one of the films that helped spark that passion, “The Public Enemy” from 1931. Directed by William Wellman, the film stars James Cagney as a prohibition-era Chicago mobster named Tom Powers. Tom and his cohorts begin as petty thieves, but they rise in the criminal underworld once alcohol is outlawed. Mr. Scott praises Cagney’s performance, along with that of his co-star and love interest Jean Harlow.

headline: Today, Chelsea Clinton Became a Journalist
text: The hiring of Chelsea Clinton by NBC News was greeted with skepticism by some in the news business on Monday.

headline: A New Video Series From Sony Masterworks
text: Sony Masterworks will begin offering a new series of online video called “Legends of Broadway” featuring interviews with notable theater artists. The series, at MasterworksBroadway.com, begins Wednesday with a clip of Stephen Sondheim, above, discussing the making of the original cast recording of “West Side Story.”

headline: In China, Car Brands Evoke an Unexpected Set of Stereotypes
text: BEIJING — Cars in the United States tend to come fully equipped with stereotypes. Ford Crown Victoria: law enforcement professional. Toyota Prius: upscale yuppie environmentalist. Hummer: gas-guzzling egotist.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Ronen Bergman on the Gilad Shalit Swap
text: Ronen Bergman is a political and military analyst for the Israeli newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth and the author of, among other books, “By Any Means Necessary: Israel’s Covert War for Its P.O.W.’s and M.I.A.’s.” He is currently at work on a history of the Mossad. The story about Israel’s exchange of 1,027 prisoners for Gilad Shalit, who was abducted five years ago by Hamas in a firefight on the border of the Gaza Strip, is Ronen’s first cover article for the magazine.

headline: Death of a Heavyweight
text: Friends, family and fellow boxers paid their respects to the boxer Joe Frazier at a funeral on Monday after he died last week from liver cancer at age 67.

headline: Beyond planet Earth, taking care of our closest relatives and when your brain just won’t deliver.
text: Beyond planet Earth, taking care of our closest relatives and when your brain just won’t deliver.

headline: Priming Germans for the Holocaust
text: “Engineering Evil,” a History Channel special on Tuesday night, is devoted to the details of how the Nazis carried out the Holocaust, so you expect to learn about things like crematorium design, and you do. But another kind of engineering — call it human engineering — is also revealed here.

headline: Lens: 911 Aerials
text: Lens: 911 Aerials

headline: New Albums From Caveman, Los Campesinos! and the Fall
text: CAVEMAN

headline: Mayor Reports Steady Growth, and Demand, for City’s Hotels
text: At a tourism promotion whistle-stop in Long Island City, Queens, on Monday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg celebrated the rising number of hotels opening in the city and the “important jobs” they provide.

headline: Herman Cain on Libya
text: I’ve already devoted one blog post to Herman Cain today, so I’m reluctant to spill more e-ink on the Republican candidate. But do yourself a favor and watch Mr. Cain attempt to talk about Libya.

headline: I’m Tired of Canned ‘Cranberry Sauce.’ Can You Recommend a Recipe?
text: I’m tired of canned “cranberry sauce” that still holds the shape of the can. Can you recommend a recipe? — @DavidOchoa

headline: ‘Porgy’: No New Scene, Some Hard Feelings
text: There will be no revisionist happy ending in the coming Broadway production of “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess.” A new scene, in which the title characters have a final emotional encounter meant to deepen their love story, has been dropped. But some hard feelings remain, at least on the part of the show’s director and its lead producer.

headline: State Names Lawyer to Investigate Cheating
text: Henry M. Greenberg, a former assistant United States attorney and senior legal adviser to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo when he was attorney general, will review how the state's Education Department receives and investigates complaints of alleged test tampering.

headline: Rushdie Runs Afoul of Web’s Real-Name Police
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The writer Salman Rushdie hit Twitter on Monday morning with a flurry of exasperated posts. Facebook, he wrote, had deactivated his account, demanded proof of identity and then turned him into Ahmed Rushdie, which is how he is identified on his passport. He had never used his first name, Ahmed, he pointed out; the world knows him as Salman.

headline: Happy Trails
text: It can feel as though you’ve somehow gone back in time when you’re driving up the looping curves of Route 17 in northern Vermont and take one last turn, toward the spine of the Green Mountains, to suddenly find what appears to be the movie set of a small 1960s ski resort brought painstakingly to life. There is a cluster of quaint yellow and blue rustic clapboard buildings. A rutted dirt parking lot. A single-chair lift rising into the clouds over narrow trails that seem to pitch and hurtle down the mountain.

headline: Bishops Open ‘Religious Liberty’ Drive
text: BALTIMORE — The nation’s Roman Catholic bishops opened a new front in their fight against abortion and same-sex marriage on Monday, recasting their opposition as a struggle for “religious liberty” against a government and a culture that are infringing on the church’s rights.

headline: Where No Museum Has Gone Before
text: A sneak peek at the exhibition “Beyond Planet Earth: The Future of Space Exploration,” at the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: Oh, the Places We Could Go
text: The high point was when I got to bomb Mars.

headline: Assembly Speaker Injured in Bicycle Accident
text: Many New York politicians returned to work on Monday with a fresh suntan from their time at a conference in Puerto Rico this weekend.

headline: Liz Magic Laser’s Political Theater of the Absurd
text: The artist Liz Magic Laser’s commissioned work for Performa11, “I Feel Your Pain,” promised both a romance drawn from the playbook of political theater and a 21st-century version of the “living newspaper” (a bit of Russian Constructivist agitprop). It does not disappoint on either count.

headline: Post-Madoff, a Greater Awareness of Ponzi Schemes
text: Nearly three years after Bernard L. Madoff’s gigantic fraud imploded, federal authorities say they are cracking down on Ponzi schemes in greater numbers.

headline: Hawaiian Singer Played Occupy Protest Ballad for Asian Conference Leaders
text: Updated | 11:47 p.m. As my colleague Jackie Calmes reported, President Obama decided not to force world leaders attending the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Honolulu over the weekend to wear Hawaiian shirts. But the White House did arrange for a local musician, Makana, to serenade the world leaders with tunes played in the Hawaiian slack-key guitar style known as ki hoalu.

headline: A Russian Artist’s Fashionable Flights
text: There are plenty of arresting moments in “Idols,” an exhibition of photographs by Gilles Larrain of the denizens of Max’s Kansas City in the 1970s. Mr. Larrain’s searingly colorful portraits — the likes of Harvey Fierstein, Taylor Mead, Holly Woodlawn and the New York Dolls vamping in shrill makeup and assorted states of dishabille — were first published in the ’70s. Since going on view earlier this month at the Steven Kasher Gallery in Chelsea, they’ve drawn a steady stream of visitors.

headline: Lens: Winter Aerials
text: Lens: Winter Aerials

headline: Former MF Global Employees Sue Over Layoffs
text: Former employees of MF Global sued the failed brokerage firm on Monday in separate lawsuits, arguing that they were laid off in violation of labor laws and seeking class-action status.

headline: Site to Resell Music Files Has Critics
text: Music fans looking to clear out some clutter can always try to sell their old CDs. But can someone resell an old digital music file of “Thriller” that’s languishing on a computer?

headline: Whatever Court Rules, Major Changes in Health Care Likely to Last
text: This article is by  Reed Abelson,  Gardiner Harris and  Robert Pear.

headline: NBC Overhauls Prime Time, Benching ‘Community’ and ‘Prime Suspect’
text: Facing problems on almost every night of the week, NBC announced wholesale changes to its prime-time schedule Monday, which were focused mainly on strengthening two nights, Mondays and Thursdays.

headline: Chilean Judge Drops Abuse Case but Condemns Priest
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — A Chilean judge dismissed criminal charges on Monday against the Rev. Fernando Karadima, once one of Chile’s most prominent and respected Roman Catholic priests, allowing him to avoid prosecution over accusations that he had sexually abused three teenagers.

headline: Elizabeth, an Iguana With Many Friends, Dies at 19
text: Her blood was cold, but her heart, her keepers said, was warm.

headline: Comparing Two Health Care Laws
text: The similarities and differences between the Massachusetts health care plan that Mitt Romney signed into law as governor in 2006 and the federal plan that President Obama signed into law in 2010.

headline: Qatar Wields an Outsize Influence in Arab Politics
text: DOHA, Qatar — Qatar is smaller than Connecticut, and its native population, at 225,000, wouldn’t fill Cairo’s bigger neighborhoods. But for a country that inspires equal parts irritation and admiration, here is its résumé, so far, in the Arab revolts: It has proved decisive in isolating Syria’s leader, helped topple Libya’s, offered itself as a mediator in Yemen and counts Tunisia’s most powerful figure as a friend.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,817 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Staterooms, Not Dorms, All Thanks to Mold
text: ST. MARY’S CITY, Md. — Kimberly Fitzgerald, a freshman at St. Mary’s College of Maryland here, loves it when people ask where she lives.

headline: Why Herman Cain Is Unfit to Lead
text: HARD as it has been to watch, harder still to live through, the spectacle of Herman Cain’s dodging sexual harassment allegations is a real step up for the status of women. Their sexual treatment is now part of the open political process, rather than a smarmy rumor to be passed among cognoscenti in the dark.

headline: Some Students Grumble About Higher One’s Debit Card Fees
text: Students on some college campuses are simmering with discontent over Higher One Holdings Inc., a company that provides debit cards and bank accounts to students receiving financial aid.

headline: Before We Bomb Iran, Let’s Have a Serious Conversation
text: It is common for candidates in presidential primaries to use bellicose language to prove their toughness. This kind of rhetoric is especially useful in Republican primaries, where audiences have a firm belief in the use of military power to solve problems. But toughness and wisdom are not the same thing.

headline: Still Full of Fire, Krzyzewski Is Set to Break Record for Wins
text: DURHAM, N.C. — Duke was set to tip off last Dec. 29 against North Carolina-Greensboro, a team that had virtually no chance of knocking off the Blue Devils, who were ranked No. 1. And most everybody knew it.

headline: Rhode Island: East Providence Gets an Overseer
text: For the second time in 18 months, the state of Rhode Island intervened in the fiscal affairs of a city Monday, saying East Providence was too low on cash to keep providing essential services to its 48,000 residents.

headline: Barclays Capital Rises, ‘Big-Boy Checkbook’ in Hand
text: The American pipeline operator Kinder Morgan struck one of the biggest deals of the year nearly a month ago with its $21.1 billion purchase of a rival, the El Paso Corporation.

headline: Britain: Missiles May Be Used to Protect Games
text: Britain will deploy ground-to-air missiles if they are judged “operationally necessary” to protect the 2012 summer Olympic Games in London, Defense Minister Philip Hammond told Parliament on Monday. With less than nine months to go before the Games, Mr. Hammond offered reassurances about safety in the wake of British newspaper articles saying concerns about the adequacy of security arrangements had been raised by the United States. “All necessary measures to secure the security and safety of the London Olympic Games will be taken, including — if the advice of the military is that it is required — appropriate ground-to-air defenses,” Mr. Hammond told the House of Commons. Police spokesmen have said that 12,000 officers will be deployed to protect the Olympic sites, as well as at least 10,000 private security guards, and that British military units will be on standby if needed.

headline: An App Answers, ‘What’s Your Name Again?’
text: There are only so many times and ways you can politely say, “Uh, I’m sorry, your name again is…?”

headline: Norway: Accused Oslo Gunman Appears in Court
text: Anders Behring Breivik, an avowed anti-immigrant extremist who has admitted to killing 77 people in a rampage in Norway last summer, appeared at his first public court hearing in Oslo on Monday, declaring himself “a military commander in the Norwegian resistance movement.” It was the first time victims and families of those killed in the shooting spree at a youth camp on Utoya Island were permitted in the courtroom with Mr. Breivik, left. At one point Mr. Breivik asked permission to address survivors, but the judge refused. The judge turned down a request by defense lawyers to move Mr. Breivik from solitary confinement, but ruled that he should be allowed access to newspapers, television and other media starting Dec. 12.

headline: Do Nice Phones Finish Last?
text: The new HTC Radar is the first 4G Windows phone on the market. It is a nice phone. Really nice. But with the recent release of LTE network phones with brawny dual-core processors and the recent iPhone 4s, is nice good enough?

headline: Agencies Fulfill Their Holiday Wishes With New Executives
text: THIS time of year, advertising agencies are focused on the mad dash to Christmas, helping clients maximize opportunities to reach consumers during the crucial holiday shopping season.

headline: Merkel Urges More Unified Continent to Save Euro
text: LEIPZIG, Germany — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany warned reluctant members of her conservative party in no uncertain terms on Monday that deeper political integration was necessary if Europe’s common currency was to be saved.

headline: Where Soccer Has Been a One-Way Ticket Out
text: KIGALI, Rwanda — In the fading light and steady rain at Amahoro Stadium, the Eritrea national soccer team trained in silence Monday as it prepared for one of its most important matches since securing independence from Ethiopia in 1993.

headline: Affiliation, Before and After Scandal
text: In the wake of the sexual abuse scandal that is roiling Penn State’s football program, some are wondering whether there could be long-term effects on recruiting, donations and the long-term reputation of the university.

headline: Romney’s Team Prepares for Obama, Too
text: WASHINGTON — As Mitt Romney prepares for Republican contests in Iowa, New Hampshire and beyond, his aides have been traveling the country filming stories for the battle they hope will follow against President Obama, spotlighting unemployed Americans who have given up on hope and change.

headline: A Nuclear Facility We Don’t Need
text: Los Alamos, N.M.

headline: Lawyer for N.F.L. in Lockout Joins Players in N.B.A. Fight
text: Sports and law apparently make strange bedfellows. David Boies, the prominent lawyer who just months ago defended the N.F.L. during its lockout, has switched sides and will now represent the N.B.A. players in their fight against the league’s lockout.

headline: Libya: Town Rallies Against Pro-Qaddafi Label
text: Residents from a town outside of Tripoli that had been accused on Libyan news broadcasts of supporting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who was captured and killed last month, rallied in the capital Monday to demand an apology for what they called slanderous reports. The protesters, from Warshefana, claimed that a television station supporting the transitional government, Libya al-Ahra, had falsely labeled them as pro-Qaddafi and incited gunmen from another town, Zawiyah, to take up arms against them. Fighting between gunmen from both towns has killed several men since last Thursday. The violence subsided by Monday, after mediation from the transitional government and elders. Many Libyans say Warshefana’s population did include many people with pro-Qaddafi sentiments.

headline: Knuckleheads and Worse, Bringing Guns in Carry-ons
text: EVERY day, screening officers find four to five guns in carry-on bags at American airports, according to John S. Pistole, the head of the Transportation Security Administration.

headline: Rule Changes to Be Discussed
text: The N.H.L.’s general managers will convene in a Toronto hotel Tuesday and debate whether a rule change is needed to limit the neutral-zone trap. The trapping issue emerged last Wednesday at Tampa Bay when the Philadelphia Flyers refused to advance the puck against the Lightning’s 1-3-1 trap. The Lightning, in turn, refused to forecheck. So on several occasions, totaling about four minutes of playing time, a Flyers defenseman stood motionless in his own zone with the puck while four Lightning players stood motionless at their various stations in the neutral zone and a fifth stood idle deep in his own zone.

headline: Sending a Harsh Message, U.S. Issues First Fine for Tarmac Delays
text: Airlines are warned: no lengthy delays this winter.

headline: Fund-Raising by City Comptroller Is Investigated
text: Federal authorities are investigating the fund-raising operation of the New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, seeking records from his campaign and from a city contractor whose employees were listed as having contributed thousands of dollars to his campaign, people with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: Deficit Panel Still Talking as Others Focus on Spending Bills
text: WASHINGTON — As members of the Congressional deficit reduction panel retreated to conference rooms Monday to continue negotiations, House Republicans and Senate Democrats were putting their final touches on a series of spending bills that they hope will avert another showdown over short-term financing of the government.

headline: Q&A: Finding Fonts for All
text: Q.

headline: Departures Unsettle Newsweek
text: Newsweek was jolted by three high-level departures on Monday, a sign that the merger a year ago with The Daily Beast has left the magazine deeply unsettled.

headline: Major Ad Blitz for Huntsman in New Hampshire, by Group Backed by His Father
text: Providing perhaps a last-chance boost to the flagging presidential hopes of former Gov. Jon M. Huntsman Jr. of Utah, an outside group that is supported by his father, a billionaire chemical executive, and other wealthy backers plans a major advertising campaign on his behalf in New Hampshire starting on Tuesday.

headline: N.H.L. General Managers to Discuss Rule Changes
text: The N.H.L.’s general managers will convene at a suburban Toronto hotel Tuesday for their annual fall meeting to debate whether a rule change is needed to limit the neutral-zone trap, after exactly one mildly controversial game.

headline: Mexico: President’s Sister Loses Governor’s Race
text: The sister of President Felipe Calderón lost a tight race for governor of his home state, Michoacán, in an election marred by threats and violence attributed to organized crime. Luisa María Calderón, who like her brother belongs to the conservative National Action Party, lost by two percentage points to Fausto Vallejo Figueroa, the candidate of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which is making an aggressive effort to retake the presidency next year. Mr. Vallejo garnered 35 percent of the vote, Ms. Calderón, 33 percent, and a candidate from the Democratic Revolutionary Party, which has dominated there recently, got 29 percent. Ms. Calderón had hoped to score a symbolic victory for the party, which is trailing in presidential polls. But it has lost several recent elections for governor there.

headline: Margaret Atwood Named Mentor in Rolex Arts Program
text: The Canadian author Margaret Atwood and the French theater director Patrice Chéreau are among the six artists who will serve as mentors in dance, film, literature, music, theater and visual arts as part of a program sponsored by Rolex.

headline: The Tobacco Horror Show
text: I’m sure you’ve noticed those TV ads for pharmaceutical products that include an incredibly long list of side effects and possible hazards recited by a cheerful voice as men and women are shown living the happy lives made possible by a drug that can inflict on them everything from bloating and joint pain to death. This combination of positive and negative communications is mandated by the government requirement that drug manufacturers must disclose all the risk factors attending the product they are hawking.

headline: Geron Is Shutting Down Its Stem Cell Clinical Trial
text: The company conducting the world’s first clinical trial of a therapy using human embryonic stem cells said on Monday that it was halting that trial and leaving the stem cell business entirely.

headline: Plan for Bus Terminal Tower Is Dropped
text: For more than a decade, a prominent New York developer has sought to build a glass skyscraper over the Port Authority Bus Terminal, transforming an eyesore at the west end of Times Square into an architectural showpiece.

headline: Philadelphia and the Boxing World Pay Tribute to Frazier
text: PHILADELPHIA — Joe Frazier answered the final bell Monday, a pair of boxing gloves and a championship belt draped across his coffin, eulogized as an ordinary man who achieved extraordinary greatness in the ring, an “average Joe” who brought decency to a brutal sport.

headline: Giving Their Children a Place to Lay Their Heads
text: When Olga and Alexander Vartsaba won the green card lottery and moved from Russia to the United States in 2002, they believed their luck had finally changed.

headline: Bank Excuses on Foreclosure Growing Stale
text: The Bank of America lawyer laid down a patented rhetorical move heard in courts across America. Your Honor, this Orange County, N.Y., homeowner — a New York City police officer — didn’t make enough money to qualify for a mortgage modification. He didn’t send us the right documents.

headline: Odd Receipt Has Star Turn at Official’s Trial
text: Of the many misdeeds that federal prosecutors have attributed to City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook, one has received more attention than any other: the purchase of a snack (a bagel and a drink) and a request for reimbursement of $177.

headline: Lacking Experience as a Manager, but Not Confidence in Doing the Job
text: The day before he interviewed to be the next manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, Mike Matheny visited the Busch Stadium office of the man he hoped to replace. Tony La Russa was there, clearing out the mementos of more than 2,500 games with St. Louis and more than 5,000 as a major league manager.

headline: Book Shopping for the Holidays
text: Sunday’s Times Book Review included the Children’s Books section, which always precedes the holidays, and which I look forward to every year. Besides being the usual good read for lovers of children’s books, it’s an ideal shopping guide for the aunt, parent or friend who does all of her holiday shopping for the younger set at the bookstore. I was a book-obsessed child, and the flat packages that meant hours of vacation pleasure to me were what I most wanted to find under the tree. I give books for the simple reason that I love books, but unless a child has a favorite series (and doesn’t yet possess them all), it’s tough to book-shop for kids past the picture-book age and feel reasonably confident in your chances of success.

headline: Viktor Bout Trying to Overturn Conviction in Arms Plot
text: A lawyer for Viktor Bout, the Russian businessman convicted in a plot to sell weapons to Colombian terrorists, has asked a federal judge to overturn the verdict and hold a new trial because one of the jurors may have been unduly influenced by a Nicolas Cage movie based on Mr. Bout’s life.

headline: One Secret Buffett Gets to Keep
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission usually doesn’t let investors keep many secrets. Except if you’re a major player like Warren Buffett.

headline: Experiment on Subways Will Shift Pain to Weekdays
text: They are the three words no subway rider wants to see: weekend service advisory, a sure sign that smooth travels do not lie ahead.

headline: Boley Injury Could Leave the Giants Weakened
text: In a season in which the Giants have dealt with numerous injuries to critical players, defensive end Justin Tuck — himself one of the afflicted this year — offered a telling statement when asked late Sunday about middle linebacker Michael Boley’s potentially missing a game or more.

headline: An Apology of Enclaves
text: No, “apology” is not the collective noun for enclaves. The accepted term is a complex of enclaves — although more imaginative suggestions are welcome. Nor do I feel the need to apologize for enclaves. Yes, these geopolitical anomalies — for the uninitiated, a chunk of one political or ethnic unit lying wholly within another — have caused their fair share of misery and grief. But fascination with a subject does not equal approval of all its phenomena; herpetologists need not apologize for snakebites.

headline: Even in Bankruptcy, Dodgers Can Make Big Offer to Kemp
text: The Los Angeles Dodgers are operating under bankruptcy protection, yet they are on the verge of signing their star outfielder, Matt Kemp, to a contract said to be worth $160 million over eight years.

headline: Cain Stumbles in Assessing Foreign Policy
text: Herman Cain became badly flustered on Monday when asked to assess President Obama’s policy toward Libya, raising new questions about his command of foreign policy as he lurched over five minutes from awkward pauses to halting efforts to address the issue.

headline: Quietly, Google Gets Its View of the Park
text: As gold leaves drifted to the ground in Central Park on Monday, a strange-looking vehicle joined the park’s stream of pedicabs, bicycles, baby carriages and skateboards. It was straight out of Roald Dahl’s imagination, at once sinister and innocent — an ungainly contraption cooked up by, say, Good Humor and the K.G.B.

headline: Students Lose Zeal for Aiding Obama Again
text: LAS VEGAS — For much of the presidential election of 2008, Barack Obama’s campaign was Emma Guerrero’s life. She was one of a dozen volunteers who showed up at an Obama campaign office here every night, taking time from her studies at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, to be part of what she still remembers as the most exciting period of her life.

headline: Cuomo Sees Budget Gaps This Year and Next
text: Continued tumult in the financial markets and the prospect of a weak bonus season on Wall Street have significantly darkened the state’s financial condition and could force legislators back to Albany to find additional spending cuts before the end of the year, officials in the state budget office said on Monday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Place to Occupy and Get Results
text: Occupy Congress has garnered far less attention than the global protest movement that started as Occupy Wall Street in Lower Manhattan. But politicians helped create the financial crisis. Fresh news of American lawmakers trading on inside information is further reason for mistrust.

headline: Learning About Nerves and Sudden Noises
text: I GREW up traveling. I’m not one of those people who can sit still on a beach or at a pool. I have to be doing something, going somewhere.

headline: Farewell to the Business Center
text: The hotel business center is not what it used to be.

headline: Indian State’s Roads Become a Protest Tool
text: IMPHAL, India — All summer, Homindon Singh Lisam’s phone rang off the hook. As a doctor and hospital administrator in India’s remote Manipur State, he is no stranger to triage. But this was different.

headline: Keystone Pipeline Will Be Rerouted
text: At a special session of the Nebraska Legislature, a state senator announced Monday that TransCanada had agreed to adjust its intended route of the Keystone XL oil pipeline to avoid the environmentally sensitive Sand Hills region of the state.

headline: The Conspiracy at Lick Creek
text: As the forests surrounding the Great Smoky Mountains passed their autumnal peak foliage in early November 1861, a group of potters and farmers gathered at the Greene County, Tenn., home of Jacob and Henry Harmon. There the brothers, joined by Christopher Haun, Henry Fry and Jacob Hinshaw, finalized their plot to destroy the nearby Lick Creek railroad bridge on Nov. 8. This was no local conspiracy, however. More than 100 fellow East Tennessee Unionists plotted to simultaneously burn eight other railroad bridges as far away as northeast Alabama, effectively severing all rail and telegraph connection between Virginia and the heartland of the Confederacy.

headline: Cain’s Wife Steps Into Role She Has Long Avoided
text: The part of candidate’s spouse vouching for her husband’s character is not a role Gloria Cain ever prepared herself to play.

headline: In Esquire, Taymor Says She Was Unfairly Maligned by U2 Leaders Over ‘Spider-Man’ Woes
text: In a new interview with Esquire magazine, the theater director Julie Taymor accuses Bono and the Edge of U2 – her former collaborators on the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” – of maligning her as exhausted and overwrought as a bogus explanation for ousting her from the production in March and then overhauling the show as they saw fit.

headline: High Emotion and Intrigue After Iran Blast
text: Iran’s supreme leader presided Monday over a vast state funeral for a founder of Iran’s missile program and 16 other members of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps who were killed in an explosion Saturday, in an emotional ritual that underscored the commander’s importance and Tehran’s rising sense of confrontation with the West over its nuclear program.

headline: Syrian Refugees Languish in Turkey
text: About 7,600 Syrian refugees live in camps in Turkey after fleeing a brutal crackdown in Syria by President Bashar al-Assad. With the violence continuing in Syria, some appear to be settling in for what may be a long stay.

headline: For Refugees From Syria, a Visit With No Expiration Date
text: BOYNUYOGUN, Turkey — The Turkish government describes the refugee camp here as a “temporary residence” for the country’s Syrian guests, but very little about it looks temporary.

headline: The Butcher and the Frazier-Stander Bout
text: Ron Stander’s hard knocks didn’t end after his four-round fight against Smokin’ Joe Frazier in 1972.

headline: Where Nothing Is Black and White, or Even Gray
text: It doesn’t seem right to call the zone that’s occupied by Thomas Bradshaw’s “Burning” a gray area. This repellent and magnetic play, which opened on Monday night at the Acorn Theater in a New Group production, is way too lurid to be gray.

headline: The Torture Candidates
text: As hard as it is to believe, the Republican candidates for president seem to have learned very little from the moral calamities of the administration of George W. Bush. Three of the contenders for the party’s nomination have now come out in favor of the torture known as waterboarding. Only two have said it is illegal, and the rest don’t seem to have the backbone to even voice an opinion on the subject.

headline: A Light in the Barn
text: Every now and then, I forget to turn off the lights in the barn. I usually notice just before I go to bed, when the farm’s boundaries seem to have drawn in close. That light makes the barn seem farther away than it is — a distance I’m going to have to travel before I sleep. The weather makes no difference. Neither does the time of year.

headline: Taking, and Restoring, the Rights of Felons
text: When, if ever, should an ex-convict regain the right to own a gun? Or to vote?

headline: In Egypt, Fears of Mubarak’s Outlawed Party, ‘the Remnant,’ Loom Over Vote
text: MANSOURA, Egypt — Mortada Mansour, the man accused of directing the notorious Battle of the Camel during the Tahrir Square protests in February, came to a courtroom in this provincial city to defend the right of former regime stalwarts to run in the coming parliamentary elections.

headline: Perry Asks Voters to Overlook His Lack of Polish at the Podium
text: BETTENDORF, Iowa – Gov. Rick Perry of Texas declared Monday night, “I’m the first to admit, I’m not the most polished candidate out there,” but he urged Republicans to look beyond his rhetorical shortcomings and focus on his plan to upend the status quo in Washington.

headline: Health Reform and the Supreme Court
text: The Supreme Court’s decision to review the constitutionality of health care reform means it will be issuing a ruling in the middle of the 2012 presidential campaign. This can be a highly politicized court, and, for the public good and its own credibility, it must resist that impulse.

headline: Torture and Exceptionalism
text: If we truly believe ourselves to be exceptional, a model for all the world and an example for all of history, then why would we practice torture?

headline: Penn State’s Long Road Back
text: I can’t remember the last time I watched a regular season college football game, but, on Saturday, I turned on the Penn State-Nebraska game. Coming into it, Penn State was ranked 12th in the country and Nebraska was No. 19, so the experts expected a close game. I can’t say that’s why I watched.

headline: Let’s All Feel Superior
text: First came the atrocity, then came the vanity. The atrocity is what Jerry Sandusky has been accused of doing at Penn State. The vanity is the outraged reaction of a zillion commentators over the past week, whose indignation is based on the assumption that if they had been in Joe Paterno’s shoes, or assistant coach Mike McQueary’s shoes, they would have behaved better. They would have taken action and stopped any sexual assaults.

headline: Les Daniels, Historian of Comic Books, Dies at 68
text: Les Daniels, one of the earliest historians of comic books — from the launching (off the doomed planet Krypton) of Superman in 1938 through the countercultural comix movement of the ’60s — and an author of horror novels, died on Nov. 5 at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 68.

headline: Irving H. Franklin, 93, Dies; Improved Batters’ Grip
text: For many decades, almost no major league baseball players wore batting gloves. Partly because of Irving H. Franklin, almost all do today.

headline: Dr. Paul Epstein, Expert in Public Health, Is Dead at 67
text: Dr. Paul Epstein, a public health expert who was among the first to warn of a link between the spread of infectious disease and extreme weather events, adding a new dimension to research into the potential impact of global climate change, died on Sunday at his home in Boston. He was 67.

headline: Giving Fraud a Bad Name
text: Charles Ponzi didn’t invent his eponymous pyramid scheme — but he lent star power to one of the oldest scams in the book. He also believed that his plan could have become a legitimate business.

headline: A Start-Up Offers a New Way to Search the Web
text: Though Web search is dominated by Google and supplemented by link-sharing on Facebook and Twitter, a start-up, Trapit, which opens to the public Tuesday, thinks it can offer a smarter, more personalized way to search for topics.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
text: Chief Omar Abdullah met the prime minister and other top leaders on Monday, in a bid to create consensus at the highest level of government on the withdrawal of the Armed Forces Special Powers Act (The Hindu). The meetings came after a army officers in the state argued last week against the law’s revocation, claiming there is a Pakistani presence in the area (Hindustan Times). Mr. Abdullah “expressed confidence” in the partial withdrawal of the law.The parliamentary committee scrutinizing the Lokpal bill says it should not cover the judiciary branch of government (Indian Express). In a move that was denounced by Team Anna, the panel also recommends reducing the penalties for “frivolous complaints” from five years imprisonment to six months.

headline: Why Is the U.S. on the ‘Wrong Track’?
text: Woe is us.

headline: City Reopens Park After Protesters Are Evicted
text: New York City on Tuesday reopened the park in Lower Manhattan where the Occupy Wall Street movement was born not long after a judge upheld the city’s move to clear the park and bar the protesters from bringing back their tents or sleeping overnight.

headline: In Mumbai, the $50,000 Slum Shack
text: You reach the house of Indu Prakash Vaidya, a 32-year-old housewife, by trekking down a two-foot-wide alley through an inch of stinking, wet mud, filled with plastic bags and kitchen scraps.Her 200-square-foot shanty, in Rajiv Gandhi Nagar, in the Dharavi neighborhood of Mumbai, has faulty electrical lines, no water supply and a non existent sewage system. Still, Ms. Vaidya’s house is her most prized possession. “If I decide to sell it, it will fetch me more than Rs 10 lakh” rupees, or about $24,000, she estimates, based on the offers she has been getting.

headline: Don’t Forget the Clients You Already Have
text: At Door Number 3, we spend a lot of time and energy focused on growth. Our 15-person shop has a full-time person dedicated to bringing in new business, leading the response to requests for proposals, getting out there networking, building and working databases. But we don’t always give as much attention to the customers we already have. As 2011 rolls to an end, I am reminding myself that it’s time to set in motion something I began last year.

headline: For Obama, a Day Off in Hawaii for Fund-Raising and Golf
text: KAPOLEI, Hawaii – Monday was a down day for President Obama between rounds of Pacific Rim summitry, and he made the most of it with some golf and fund-raising among friends old and new on a day of idyllic weather in his native state.

headline: Mrs. Obama Reaches Out to Military Women
text: KAPOLEI, Hawaii – Michelle Obama, who traveled here with her husband for an economic summit of Pacific nations, attended a job fair for military veterans and spouses on Monday and commiserated with the women in the group.

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 15, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Occupy Movement Could Declare ‘Victory’ and Scale Back Camps, Founder Suggests
text: In a new “tactical briefing” issued on Monday, hours before the Occupy Wall Street camp was raided by the police, the editors of Adbusters, the Canadian, anti-consumerist magazine that dreamed up the movement, suggested that it might be time for the protesters to “declare ‘victory’ ” and scale back the camps before winter sets in.

headline: Nov. 15, 1969 | Anti-Vietnam War Demonstration Held
text: On Nov. 15, 1969, the Vietnam Moratorium Committee staged what is believed to be the largest antiwar protest in United States history when as many as half a million people attended a mostly peaceful demonstration in Washington. Smaller demonstrations were held in a number of cities and towns across the country.

headline: UBS Names Sergio Ermotti as Chief Executive
text: LONDON — UBS has chosen Sergio P. Ermotti, who has run the Swiss bank on an interim basis since September, to become its permanent chief executive.

headline: Above Ground Zero With a Camera and a Bluff
text: Gregg Brown recalls walking to his East Village home three days after Sept. 11, 2001, unable to escape the sight of makeshift “Missing” posters and the smell of destruction that hung in the air like funeral incense. Late that night, the phone rang in his apartment — not unusual, since it was the number he listed in the Yellow Pages for his photography business under the words: “We Do Photo Video — 24 Hr. Rush Jobs Welcome.”

headline: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 15, 2011
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Reality TV’s Instant Stars Populate a Magazine.”

headline: From Nablus to Jerusalem
text: NABLUS, West Bank — Last Saturday, I arrived at the Nablus train station, a low, thick-walled stone structure, in time to board the 3:20 pm to Jerusalem. Some 20 passengers were waiting at the entrance, mostly young men and women, with a few people old enough to remember the days of train travel during the British Mandate over Palestine. The excitement was palpable: It was our chance to take a ride to Jerusalem, a city we are barred from visiting, bypassing the Israeli checkpoints along the way. As I entered the station, a porter in a dark blue uniform issued me a ticket on the Green Line. The journey would take 30 minutes, with stops planned at Hawwarah, Zatara, Uyun al Haramiya, Attarah and Kalandia — all existing checkpoints. I made my way to the waiting room. It was barren, except for low tables with brochures entitled “Palestine Connected” showing local train networks and their destinations. Gaza. Jaffa. Haifa. Beersheba.

headline: Are You a Brand?
text: An Op-Ed writer argues that youth culture today is characterized by an entrepreneurial spirit in which everyone’s selling something — themselves, an idea, a lifestyle, social responsibility. Do you think that description characterizes you and your friends, and your generation?

headline: Chinese Artist Posts $1.3 Million to Seek Tax Bill Review
text: BEIJING — The celebrated Chinese artist and dissident Ai Weiwei on Tuesday posted the equivalent of $1.3 million with Chinese tax authorities in an effort to contest accusations of tax fraud that he says are politically motivated.

headline: Signs of Broad Contagion in Europe as Growth Slows
text: The borrowing costs of nations at the heart of Europe jumped sharply on Tuesday, the latest evidence of broader contagion across the Continent as economic growth stalled.

headline: Champagne House Outside of Paris Hosts Sound-Themed Art Show
text: Less than an hour from Paris, in the historic city of Rheims, Champagne and contemporary art rub shoulders in the depths of Pommery’s vaulted cellars.

headline: Tebow’s Numbers, in a More Positive Light
text: Tim Tebow was 2 of 8 passing for 69 yards on Sunday. He has completed less than 50 percent of his passes in each of his games this year. He’s averaging just 131.5 passing yards per game in his four starts, not counting an average of 24 yards lost because of sacks in each game.

headline: Part 2: Answers to Your Questions on Scholarships and Student Loans

Mr. Kantrowitz is also the author of “Secrets to Winning a Scholarship,” published in February.

headline: Ask the Elder Law Attorney: Family Loans
text: Craig Reaves, past president of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, practices elder law in Kansas City, Mo., and fields occasional questions from New Old Age readers.
