text: Today’s Times

headline: Nisshin Steel and Nippon Metal to Merge
text: Nisshin Steel and Nippon Metal Industry on Tuesday announced plans to merge in a deal that would create the second-largest maker of stainless steel in Japan.

headline: Updates on the Clearing of Zuccotti Park
text: Updated, 5:38 p.m. | The day after the police cleared Zuccotti Park of the Occupy Wall Street protesters in an overnight raid and arrested hundreds of people, a judge ruled Tuesday afternoon that the city had the right to enforce rules against having camping gear in the park.

headline: As the Police Moved In, the Word Went Out: ‘It’s Happening’
text: The police began showing up by the hundreds just after midnight. Scores of officers arrived in vehicles that had been staging over by the Brooklyn Bridge but were now at Zuccotti Park. They surrounded the encampment of tents and tarps and booths that the Occupy Wall Street protesters had built and lived in for nearly two months.

headline: Doubling Down on Southfork Kitchen
text: It’s November in the Hamptons. Your restaurant isn’t half full half the week. You have become a Saturday night special, a destination for weekenders and anniversary celebrators; the fall-off from the summer is not a surprise, just steeper than expected. You don’t know if it’s the weather, the uncertain economy, the occupation of Wall Street, or your own particular issues.

headline: On the Soccer Field, a Roster Full of Refugees
text: In a Wednesday night league held on Roosevelt Island, the sidelines are clearly marked, but the games are very much without borders.

headline: Carbon Trading Initiative a Success, Study Says
text: The Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, a 10-state program that has been testing a carbon dioxide cap-and-trade system, may be in trouble, with New Jersey planning to drop out and other states considering doing the same.

headline: Help Document the 2012 Ground Game
text: Elections, for most people, can be like icebergs: what you see is only a small portion of the whole campaign. In an age of micro-targeted direct mail, Facebook ads and “robocalls,” voters can experience a campaign in very different ways than their neighbors do, to say nothing of the view that reporters traveling with candidates get.

headline: Loss Puts Head of Kingfisher Airlines on Defensive
text: MUMBAI, India — At a raucous news conference on Tuesday that began almost two hours late and lasted almost that long, Vijay Mallya defended Kingfisher Airlines from accusations of mismanagement and instead blamed taxes, oil prices and a competitive industry for the company’s financial troubles.

headline: Court Health Care Decision Poses Risks For Romney
text: The court’s move to hear the health care case next year will force a high-profile debate just as Mitt Romney may be trying to secure the Republican nomination.

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 15
text: The New York Police Department’s late-night move on Zuccotti Park, the home of the Occupy Wall Street movement, caught the news media off-guard as much as it caught the protesters, with Twitter becoming a vital way for reporters to communicate during the police action. Of course, Mayor Bloomberg’s office took to Twitter to notify the public at roughly 2 a.m., media members and protesters alike.

headline: Phrases Gone Astray
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Phrases Gone Astray
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: The Debut of the Collection
text: Today, The New York Times introduces the Collection, a fashion app exclusively for the iPad that brings together in one spot all the fashion coverage offered by Thursday and Sunday Styles, T Magazine, The Moment and The International Herald Tribune. The Collection is a visual playground where you are encouraged to explore the latest in fashion news, from reviews by Cathy Horyn and Suzy Menkes to Bill Cunningham’s On the Street videos. You can also click on more than 150 designer galleries from the current season.

headline: Syria Faces New Threats as Opposition Seeks Allies
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Buoyed by rising international pressure on the Syrian government, Syria’s opposition courted support from the Arab League and Russia on Tuesday, and Turkey, a central player in the growing crisis, threatened new economic penalties against Syria, its increasingly isolated neighbor.

headline: Thai Army Uses Flooding to Take on Friendlier Role
text: BANGKOK — Troops and army trucks are rolling through the streets of Bangkok again. But this time it is not to battle protesters or overthrow a prime minister.

headline: Supreme Court Order Would Allow Arroyo to Leave Philippines
text: MANILA — The Philippine Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, the former president, could leave the country despite accusations of corruption and electoral fraud.

headline: Opinion Report: Health Care and the Supreme Court
text: From the editorial page

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: TimesCast | Zuccotti Park Is Cleared
text: Nov. 15, 2011 — New York City police cleared Zuccotti Park of protesters early Tuesday.

headline: A Telecom Pushes Its Cloud Strategy
text: 10:19 a.m. | Updated with AT&T announcement.

headline: Bali Wood
text: The sun was about to set on the Indonesian island of Bali when Ben Ripple and Frederick Schilling, owners of the artisanal food company Big Tree Farms, led me through their new chocolate factory near Ubud. It was still under construction as we stepped into a titanic inner chamber with a high pitched roof, the last light of the day streaming dramatically through a long, narrow skylight at the peak, allowing the 30 or so builders to keep working. Several of them cheerfully called down to us from their tinkertoy-like scaffolding as we picked our way through the piles of construction materials. “We’re building the Big Tree cathedral,” Ripple said.

headline: Brees Has Unitas’s Streak in His Sights
text: Before the final week of the 2010 regular season, I noted that  Drew Brees and Tom Brady had thrown at least one touchdown pass in each of their team’s first 15 games. Brady threw a pair of touchdown passes against Miami in the season finale last season, and has thrown at least one touchdown pass in every game this year, giving him 25 consecutive games with a touchdown pass. But Brees also kept his streak alive in Week 17 last season. In fact, after throwing for two touchdowns against the Falcons on Sunday, Brees has now thrown a touchdown pass in 37 consecutive regular-season games.

headline: Axa Retires Its Gorilla, Who Pushed Retirement Planning
text: Advertising in the insurance category is filled with colorful characters, among them the Geico gecko, Flo the clerk for Progressive and the menace known only as Mayhem in Allstate campaigns.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg Steps In
text: Forty-five years ago — long before most Occupy Wall Street protesters and perhaps some of their parents were born — a Republican senator from Vermont named George D. Aiken proposed a way for the United States to ease out of a war in Vietnam that was widening and starting the tear this country apart.

headline: A Program to Turn Around Troubled Students
text: A nonprofit program, Turnaround for Children, is focusing on students' psychological and emotional well-being. In doing so, it "occupies a middle ground between the educators and politicians who believe schools should be more like community centers, and the education-reform movement, with its no-excuses mantra," The Times reports on Tuesday.

headline: Zuccotti Park Is Cleared and Cleaned in the Dark
text: The New York Police Department moved in early Tuesday and ordered the Occupy Wall Street protesters out of Zuccotti Park.

headline: Breathtaking, Still
text: I think I’m supposed to be jaded about views like this, which I’ve had many times. But the wonder of the world’s greatest city never fades.

headline: New York Police Clear Zuccotti Park
text: After the New York Police Department cleared Zuccotti Park of Occupy Wall Street protesters, many were allowed to move back in, though without tents.

headline: Jeff Kinney’s Favorite Books From Childhood
text: Today marks the publication of “Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Cabin Fever,” the sixth book in Jeff Kinney’s blockbuster series of illustrated chapter books for young readers. The latest arrives with much fanfare and a jaw-dropping 6 million copies in its first print run, making a total of 58 million copies of Wimpy Kid books in print in the United States and Canada.

headline: In Innovation Race, China Is Not Yet a Rival, Study Says
text: Innovation is a decidedly tricky thing to measure. Patents are the most widely used yardstick, but they are an imperfect gauge of innovation at best.

headline: Home Cooks Rethink Sweet Potatoes
text: Sweet potato casserole topped with marshmallows has become a staple of many Thanksgiving tables. But if you’re ready to rethink this iconic holiday dish, a community of home cooks is here to help.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Light Boxes Help Fend Off Winter Blues
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The E-Advisor Blog: Not all fast food turns a quick buck. From McSpaghetti to Wendy’s Superbar to the Taco Bellbeefer, 10 innovations that fell flat. — Patrick Farrell

headline: Children’s Investment Fund Takes Stake in News Corp.
text: LONDON — The British hedge fund manager Chris Hohn recently bought an $833 million stake in News Corporation, even as police investigations about the media company’s illegal phone-hacking practices continue on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Closeup: Climate Extremes and Global Warming
text: Later this week, as I noted on Monday, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, meeting in Kampala, Uganda, will issue its report on ways to manage risks from extreme events in a changing climate.

headline: Bad Times for Mr. Good Times
text: Vijay Mallya faced a hostile audience Tuesday, as his Kingfisher Airlines reported a third quarter loss, Vikas Bajaj writes.

headline: Insurance Mandate May Be Health Bill’s Undoing
text: WASHINGTON — As Barack Obama battled Hillary Rodham Clinton over health care during the Democratic presidential primaries of 2008, he was adamant about one thing: Americans, he insisted, should not be required to buy health insurance.

headline: On Our Radar: Rerouting the Keystone XL Pipeline
text: TransCanada agrees to find a new route for the Keystone XL pipeline that will skirt the environmentally sensitive Sand Hills area and the Ogallala aquifer in Nebraska. Still, the project cannot move forward anytime soon; a State Department spokesman says the federal government’s own review “could conclude as early as” the first quarter of 2013. [Reuters]

headline: Jean-Paul Goude’s Bodies of Work
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Quietly, Google Gets Its View of the Park
text: Google, which already offers 360-degree street-level views of New York City and other cities, has turned its attention to parks and other locations inaccessible by car with its Trike, a panoramic camera system with nine lenses mounted on an oversize tricycle. Read the full New York Times article by Lisa W. Foderaro.

headline: If Charles Dickens Had Been Jewish . . .
text: Ebenezer Scrooge might discover he would die laughing if the Ghost of Christmas Future took him to see Jackie Hoffman’s new show, “Jackie Hoffman’s a Chanukah Charol.” This wacky comedian, whose holiday shows have become a tradition for New Yorkers, will star at New World Stages in a new pseudo-autobiographical one-woman production inspired by “Patrick Stewart’s a Christmas Carol.”

headline: Amid New Lawsuits, Prospects Weaken for 2012 Baltimore Grand Prix
text: BALTIMORE — Drivers, race officials, broadcasters, government agencies and local businesses were nearly unanimous in their praise for the inaugural Baltimore Grand Prix, held over Labor Day weekend this year on the streets around the city’s Inner Harbor.

headline: Retailers See a Split in Behavior of Shoppers
text: At Wal-Mart, shoppers cut back on staples like milk and meat that had price increases of a few cents. At Saks Fifth Avenue, they paid full price for shoes and designer fashions at a rate higher than before the recession.

headline: Investing in Packers, Wallet and Soul
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — In any other place, they would be called souvenirs, documents suitable for framing, or even a sham. But here in the heart of Packers country, they are stock certificates that confer to the owner a microscopically thin and perhaps meaningless slice of the hometown team.

headline: Box.net Looks Towards Custom Applications
text: Cloud computing may be entering its next big test: Can the big players make lots of other people rich?

headline: English King to Have Brief Reign in Beijing
text: 9:25 a.m. | Updated After more than 18 months of negotiations  “Richard III,” starring Kevin Spacey, opened in Beijing last Friday, according to Agence France-Presse.

headline: Sino-Forest Report Rejects Fraud Claims, With Caveats
text: OTTAWA — A panel of directors of the Sino-Forest Corporation rejected claims of fraud at the Chinese company in a report released on Tuesday. But the document also makes clear that the panel was unable to verify some of the company data and statements at the heart of the case.

headline: Once Wary, Apple Warms Up to Business Market
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Steven P. Jobs never cared much for selling Apple products to big businesses.

headline: Reporters Say Police Denied Access to Protest Site
text: 4:26 p.m. | Updated As New York City police cleared the Occupy Wall Street campsite in Zuccotti Park early Tuesday morning, many journalists were blocked from observing and interviewing protesters. Some called it a “media blackout” and said in interviews that they believed that the police efforts were a deliberate attempt to tamp down coverage of the operation.

headline: Joseph Altuzarra Wins His Prize
text: During that tense moment Monday night between the now-traditional serving of chicken potpie and the announcement of the Council of Fashion Designers of America/Vogue Fashion Fund winners for the year, while the designers of the 10 nominated labels sat anxiously, Diane von Furstenberg walked over to the table where Joseph Altuzarra was sitting and pinched the designer on his cheek. She held that pinch for a good 30 seconds and asked him a question in French.

headline: My Three Favorite Terrible Cover Songs
text: I don’t know why, but I’ve always loved novelty songs. The first cassette I ever asked my parents for was “Weird Al in 3-D.” One of my favorite subgenres of novelty music is “the wrong and inappropriate cover song,” as pioneered by the great William Shatner. (My other favorite subgenre? Jazz-singing rodents.) Of course there are a million awful cover songs out there, but only a few are truly, spectacularly Shatner-level awful. Rolling Stone recently took a poll of the 10 worst covers, and Miley Cyrus’s cover of “Smells Like Teen Spirit” won first prize. I’ll leave that one out, was kind of obvious. So here are my top three. They are the worst, and I love them.

headline: Wheelies: The King of the Road Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Romney’s Early-State Obstacle Course
text: We’re getting to the point where it’s worth paying a fair amount of attention to the early-state polls. At the same time, with all the volatility in the Republican field, it’s sometimes hard to tell whether a strong poll in Iowa or a weak one in Florida reflects something unique to that state or a national trend instead.

headline: Fee-Free A.T.M.s, in Exchange for Advertising
text: A young New York entrepreneur has one word in response to complaints about high A.T.M. fees: Advertising.

headline: U.S. 3, Slovenia 2: Pushing Early on Offense, the U.S. Gets by Slovenia
text: 2:13 p.m. | Updated Edson Buddle, Clint Dempsey and Jozy Altidore scored first-half goals as a surprisingly offense-minded United States national team beat Slovenia, 3-2, in a friendly in Ljubljana on Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Eclectic Lineup for Humana Festival of New American Plays
text: Premieres of works by Lisa Kron, Idris Goodwin, Mona Mansour, Courtney Baron, Greg Kotis and Lucas Hnath will be offered at next spring’s Humana Festival of New American Plays in Louisville, Ky., one of the most prestigious showcases for original theater in the country.

headline: The 2011 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Awards
text: Designer Joseph Altuzarra takes the top prize at the 2011 CFDA Awards.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg's Press Conference
text: November 15, 2011 — Mayor Bloomberg addresses the clearing of Zuccotti Park at a news conference.

headline: For Putin, a Peace Prize for a Decision to Go to War
text: BEIJING — The Chinese committee that awarded this year’s Confucius Peace Prize minced no words in honoring the winner, Vladimir V. Putin, prime minister of Russia.

headline: Only One in Three Full-Time Students Pays Full Tuition
text: Many students are actually paying less now to attend college than they would have five years ago, Judith Scott-Clayton writes over on the Economix blog. (The Choice somehow missed this post a few days ago, but it’s still worth bringing to your attention today.)

headline: ReDigi, Reseller of Digital Music, Responds to Industry Criticism
text: In Tuesday’s New York Times, Ben Sisario wrote about ReDigi, a company in Cambridge, Mass., that has taken up a novel mission — developing a system for reselling digital music files that is legal and secure. Last week, the Recording Industry Association of America sent the company a cease-and-desist letter, saying that the service, in fact, infringes on copyright.

headline: For Australian Golfers, Success Starts at Home and Continues Abroad
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Like a proud parent, the Australian golf legend Greg Norman snapped a photograph of the television screen for posterity. It was late Sunday afternoon on April 10, and three Aussie golfers — Geoff Ogilvy, Jason Day and Adam Scott — were in a logjam near the top of the leader board in the final round of the Masters.

headline: F.D.A. Is Urged to Issue More Alerts About Drug Risks
text: The Food and Drug Administration’s efforts to issue “safety signals” when it is alerted to potential health risks of prescription drugs isn’t working well to notify the public or guide doctors to alternative medicines, new research indicates.

headline: More Parents Sought for Teacher Conferences
text: Parents and guardians of elementary school students have the opportunity to meet with their child's teacher on Tuesday; for middle schools, parent-teacher conferences are on Wednesday. While teachers are preparing, here are some resources that parents and guardians can use to make the most of their conference.

headline: For the N.B.A., the Battle Goes to Court
text: The N.B.A.’s idiocy finally hit the big fan on Monday, spraying whatever tiny shards remained of the league’s credibility into the ether. The players finally had enough of the league’s collective “bargaining” and hit the red button sitting in front of them, even as you got the sense they had no idea what the red button meant. To them, it represented their only way to fight back against owners intent on crushing them and braying about it afterward.

headline: Brooklyn’s Dekalb Market: A Tidy Flea, but What to Buy?
text: WHEN I visit a rural area, which I do only with great reluctance, there is often someone there urging me to awake before dawn with flashlight and steaming thermos, as if for a whale watch, and visit the local flea market.

headline: The Get | Cole Haan Wingtips
text: Once you get a load of these new hand-stained brogues from Cole Haan, you will never think of a wingtip in quite the same way again. For its winter collection, the iconic American brand worked hard at blending its comfortable technology (Nike Air cushioning — even in heels) with cutting-edge design. This includes everything from sexy stilettos in the Maria Sharapova line to these iridescent oxfords for women. At first glance they seem totally traditional, except for an odd sheen. But shine a light on them and you’re suddenly wearing twinkle toes.

headline: Men’s Soccer Top Seeds: North Carolina, Creighton, Connecticut, and Boston College
text: The University of North Carolina is the No. 1 seed in the 2011 N.C.A.A. men’s soccer championship tournament. Creighton is the No. 2 seed, the University of Connecticut is third and Boston College is fourth. The first round begins Thursday, with the national championship game scheduled for Dec. 11.

headline: Other Sites Hope N.Y. Raid Will Energize Cause
text: BOSTON — Hours after New York Police officers raided Occupy Wall Street, the protest that spurred a nationwide movement of demonstrators camping in front of government buildings and financial institutions, protestors around the country said Tuesday that they hoped the breakup of the New York encampment would energize the movement but that it would otherwise have little impact on their own protests.

headline: Daily Report: Apple Now Wants Your Workplace
text: A lot has been written about Apple’s appeal with consumers. Nick Wingfield, a Times technology reporter, takes a look at how the company is faring with corporate customers.

headline: Drawing Each and Every Tiny Palestinian for the Cover
text: Our most recent cover was quite the challenge for the illustrator Tim Enthoven. He spent 60 hours illustrating 1,028 people for our article on Gilad Shalit. By hand.

headline: A New Poll Shows a Tight Four-Way Race in Iowa
text: With seven weeks to go before the Iowa caucuses, a new poll finds the contest there far from settled, with four Republican candidates locked in a tight race and most voters saying they could still change their minds.

headline: Answers on Felons and Gun Rights
text: Updated | 4:40 p.m. On Tuesday, the reporter Michael Luo of The Times is answering reader questions prompted by his recent article on how easy it is in many states for people with felony convictions to get their gun rights reinstated.

headline: Perry Proposes Overhaul of Washington
text: BETTENDORF, Iowa — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on Tuesday announced a proposal to alter the federal government that ranks among the most radical plans offered by any major Republican presidential candidate this year — and one that legal analysts say will almost surely never happen: making Congress operate part time with half pay, and ending lifetime tenure for federal judges.

headline: Slice Aims to Organize Your Shopping, Electronically
text: As shopping swings into gear for the holidays, a new service called Slice aims to help consumers organize and track their purchases electronically. Slice’s service first appeared earlier this year as a tool on Yahoo, and last month it introduced its own Web site. Now, it’s unveiling a mobile app that lets you track your items on your iPhone. (An Android version is also in the works).

headline: Intiman Theater Cites Progress in Fund Raising for Summer Season
text: The Intiman Theater in Seattle may be down, but it’s not yet out. After suspending its operations the financially struggling regional theater is trying to raise $1 million to stage four productions next summer, and the board announced on Monday that it had so far raised $100,000 from board pledges and $100,000 from an anonymous donor, according to The Seattle Times.

headline: Assembly Speaker in No Mood to Discuss His Bruise
text: WASHINGTON — Sheldon Silver, speaker of the New York State Assembly, is always tough to pin down, but never more so than this week, as the most powerful Democrat in the State Legislature has repeatedly declined to release basic information about a bruising injury to his face and head.

headline: U.F.C. Sues State Over Ban on Mixed Martial Arts Bouts
text: For four years, the Ultimate Fighting Championship has lobbied the New York State Legislature to overturn its 1997 ban on live professional mixed martial arts fighting.

headline: Maine Republicans Want to Get There (Vote Suppression) From Here (Vote Turnout)
text: Republicans in Maine are a determined lot.

headline: Moving the Movement: Analyzing the Future of Occupy Wall Street
text: Overview | What is the current status of the Occupy Wall Street movement? What effects has it had so far, and where is it going from here? In this lesson, students react to current news, read an Opinion piece about its role in history, and do an analysis of the strengths and weaknesses of the movement to make predictions about its future.

headline: Just a Minute: Keeping the Press at Bay in Zuccotti Park
text: During Tuesday morning’s police action to clear Zuccotti Park, the home and birthplace of the Occupy Wall Street protest, members of the press were cleared out, too. Brian Stelter describes the scene early Tuesday morning, as he interviewed reporters who were prevented from covering the way the police carried out the order by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to remove the protesters from the park.

headline: Report Calls for Changes in the Energy Department
text: WASHINGTON — Already under fire for granting a $535 million federal loan guarantee to Solyndra, the Department of Energy now faces a critique from within.

headline: Bain Capital Seeks to Cash Out of LinkedIn
text: With LinkedIn‘s shares still flying high six months after their debut, one of the company’s early backers is cashing out.

headline: Naked Ambition | Marina Abramovic’s Museum Gala
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Charlie Rose and Gayle King Join ‘The Early Show’ on CBS
text: 1:35 p.m. | Updated CBS News on Tuesday announced a top-to-bottom reboot of “The Early Show,” its long-suffering morning news broadcast, with Charlie Rose and Gayle King at the helm. The moves will take effect in January.

headline: After Almost 11,000 Miles, Jay Leno Closes In on a Year Without Refueling His Chevy Volt
text: LOS ANGELES — Jay Leno is nearing a milestone.

headline: More Wizardry for ‘Harry Potter’ Director: A ‘Dr. Who’ Film
text: After spending much of the last decade directing films in the Harry Potter series, David Yates is ready to embark on a new film franchise: “Dr. Who,” Daily Variety reported. This British television series, which ran from 1963 to 1989 before beginning a second broadcast life in 2005, is one of the BBC’s most popular exports.

headline: In Its Ads, Target Sees Itself as Playing the Helpful Elf
text: Another combatant is climbing into the ring for the battle for consumer dollars as the 2011 Christmas shopping season gets under way.

headline: And the Winner of the New York Times Comedy Challenge Is…
text: …Jim Gaffigan, whose lack of sympathy with slow-moving pedestrians in Times Square — so they use walkers? they’re still in his way — made 2,102 of you laugh.

headline: After an Earlier Misstep, a Minutely Planned Raid
text: Hundreds of police officers were involved, some of them wearing riot helmets. The overnight hours of Monday into Tuesday were chosen because Zuccotti Park would be at its emptiest. The operation was kept secret from all but a few high-ranking officers, with others initially being told that they were embarking on an exercise.

headline: Miami After Dark (Without the Swells)
text: There are some easy tricks to keeping things cheap in Miami. Before you go, keep an eye out for flight specials and do some savvy hotel room bidding on Priceline. Once you’re there, spend your days on the beaches of South Beach (free) and at the galleries of the Design District (free), while taking your meals at Cuban diners and sandwich shops (cheap and cheap). (See If You Go, below, for details.)

headline: A Complicated Maneuver for Control of Yahoo
text: The Yahoo sale process may be taking a detour.

headline: Should Penn State Bow Out of Bowl Consideration?
text: On the Op-Ed page of Tuesday’s Times, the columnist Joe Nocera took a hard look at what he saw as seriously warped priorities at Penn State after the child sexual abuse scandal surrounding the football team’s former defensive coordinator Jerry Sandusky. Nocera wrote that he was not only bothered by the institution’s response over the years to reports of possible abuse, but how the student body has reacted since Sandusky’s arrest and the subsequent firing of Coach Joe Paterno.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov.15
text: A view of the day in sports, with stunt drivers and World Cup soccer qualifying.

headline: Support Workers' Union Will Sue City Over Layoffs
text: Hoping to reverse last month's layoffs of 672 school support workers, the union representing them plans to sue the city. The union, District Council 37, is claiming the layoffs were unnecessary and discriminatory because of their disproportionate impact on schools that serve poor students.

headline: Are Teenagers Really Having Less Sex?
text: The number of unmarried teenagers between the ages of 15 and 19 who reported to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that they’ve had sex has dropped below 50 percent. The C.D.C.’s research, based on data collected from 2006 to 2010, shows that about 43 percent of unmarried teenage girls and 42 percent of unmarried teenage boys say, on a survey administered by a C.D.C. interviewer but conducted largely on a laptop with headphones, that they’ve had sexual intercourse at least once. In 2002, the last year such a report was published, 51.1 percent of girls and 60.4 percent of boys said they had had sex by 19.

headline: Romney Assails Obama for ‘Lazy’ Remark
text: 4:35 p.m. | Updated  COLUMBIA, S.C. — Mitt Romney attacked President Obama on Tuesday for making what Mr. Romney described as “disparaging” remarks about Americans, singling out comments over the weekend in which the president said the United States had gotten “lazy” in trying to attract new business.

headline: Monetary Fund Urges China to Ease State Controls on Banking
text: SHANGHAI — The International Monetary Fund warned China on Tuesday that tight government management of the nation’s banking and financial system was creating “a steady build-up in vulnerabilities” that could eventually damp economic growth.

headline: American Migration Reaches Record Low
text: The share of Americans who move their homes in a year has reached a record low, the Census Bureau reported today.

headline: New Report Cites Strong Start-Up Culture of Dance in the City
text: Dance organizations in New York City are entrepreneurial and innovative, despite having to scramble for money and rely on part-time, contract and volunteer labor, according to a 30-page report by Dance/NYC, the city’s dance advocacy group, which will be released this week. The group drew on information about 127 nonprofit dance makers and organizations, culled from the statewide Cultural Data Project, which offers detailed data on finances, programs and employment in arts and culture.

headline: A Mission’s Troubles Offer Window on an Unsteady Region in Afghanistan
text: They came carrying cases of frozen meat, downloaded episodes of their favorite TV shows, baby wipes and enough firepower to light up the surrounding mountains for three days. First Platoon, Charlie Company would be spending the next week protecting the only road in Kunar Province from inside of Checkpoint 2.5; a cramped, heavily fortified American outpost.

headline: Almodóvar on Almodóvar
text: Pedro Almodóvar had put on his sunglasses, even though we were in a basement office. “There’s too much light,” he said of the fluorescents. “I work with light, but I don’t like too much.” Almodóvar appears just as you imagine him, like a stubby human exclamation point, inverted in the Spanish style, topped with a porcupine poof of gray-white hair. He’s charming. “Don’t worry,” he whispered when a publicist indicated that our time was already running short. “I’m the boss here.”

headline: ‘One Man, Two Guvnors’ Coming to Broadway From Britain
text: The National Theater of Britain’s production of “One Man, Two Guvnors,” directed by Nicholas Hytner, is coming to Broadway in the spring. James Corden, who is reprising his role as the hapless Francis Henshall, has appeared on Broadway before in “The History Boys” and in a BBC television sitcom, “Gavin and Stacey.”

headline: ATP Finals: Will There Be Any Room for a New Face?
text: Eight men have qualified for next week’s Barclays ATP World Tour Finals at the O2 Arena in London, a considerable achievement for each given the number of players vying to play in the year-end championships and the scarcity of available spots. But based on the recent distribution of tennis’ most sought-after hardware, it would be reasonable to suggest that half of them might as well book an early flight now.

headline: European Union Softens Bid to Rein in Ratings Agencies
text: BRUSSELS — The European Commission on Tuesday backed away from tough measures to blunt the power of credit ratings agencies, but insisted that its new proposals could still help tamp down volatility in the financial markets.

headline: Discover Canada, With the Help of Canadians
text: For travelers in Canada seeking the midnight sun, native wood carvings or the best mountains to ski, there’s a new online resource.

headline: Landmarks Panel Rejects Second Penthouse Plan for Puck Building
text: The Landmarks Preservation Commission has not shut the door entirely on Jared Kushner‘s plan to construct a residential penthouse atop the Puck Building at Lafayette and Houston Streets, but it told him Tuesday that he had to try a lot harder to reduce its bulk and visibility.

headline: Iraqi Cabinet Approves Royal Dutch Shell’s Natural Gas Contract
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s cabinet approved a multibillion-dollar contract on Tuesday for Royal Dutch Shell, the Anglo-Dutch energy giant, to collect the vast amount of natural gas emitted, and currently burned off, as oil is pumped to the surface at three major oil fields in the south.

headline: New Consumer Agency Beefs Up Its Staff
text: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is going through a growth spurt.

headline: After Eviction, Zuccotti Protesters Scramble to Respond
text: Occupy Wall Street protesters were trying to organize a response to their eviction early Tuesday morning from Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Greek Polenta With Onions and Raisins
text: This is adapted from a recipe I came across in “The Glorious Foods of Greece,” by Diane Kochilas. During World War II, when many Greeks died of starvation, cornmeal was one of the few foods people had to eat. Older Greeks eschewed it after the war because it reminded them of those difficult years. Diane has unearthed some wonderful dishes in her travels throughout the country. I use my easy oven method rather than the traditional top-of-the-stove method for cooking the polenta.

headline: Yeasted Country Bread With Cornmeal
text: Cornmeal is used in many breads in the Mediterranean and southern Europe, especially in Turkey and Portugal. It contributes wonderful texture.

headline: Class Parent: What if Nobody Wants to Play With Me?
text: You know that feeling when you finish setting up for a party, and you're waiting for what seems like forever for your fashionably late friends, and you convince yourself that they've all conspired against you not to show up? It's even worse when your 4-year-old daughter keeps asking, "Where are all the guests?" So began Sunday's parents and child brunch, as recounted in the latest post by a new class parent.

headline: A Longer Stairway to a Better Complexion?
text: LIKE the progressively more-complex choreography on “Dancing With the Stars,” expanded steps are coming to skin care.

headline: Levin and McCain Strike Deal Over Detainee Handling
text: 7:50 p.m. | Updated A highly charged political dispute over the handling of terrorism detainees is taking a turn: the top Democrat and Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee have reached a tentative agreement on a proposal. But their deal cut out the White House and could provoke a rebellion by other Senate Democrats.

headline: MF Global Trustee Seeks Approval of Customer Claims Proceedings
text: The court-appointed trustee overseeing the liquidation of MF Global’s brokerage unit sought permission on Tuesday to set up a claims process for customers of the failed firm, helping pave the way for additional payouts.

headline: What a Cain Administration Might Look Like

headline: NYC’s Mayor Bloomberg Confronts Occupy Wall Street
text: Like so many other people in New York, I’ve been riveted by the reports of last night’s confrontation between the city and the Occupy Wall Street protesters – the 1:30 am police raid to clear Zuccotti Park of tents and sleeping bags, followed by a courtroom hearing.

headline: S.B.A. Loan Questions Answered on C-Span
text: On Monday, The Agenda took to the airwaves to talk about the Small Business Administration’s loan programs. Well, not really the airwaves, as the program appeared on cable. For about 40 minutes on C-Span’s “Washington Journal,” I spoke about the S.B.A.’s record year for lending and answered questions from small-business owners.

headline: F.H.A. Audit Sees Possible Bailout Need
text: WASHINGTON — Chances are nearly 50 percent that the Federal Housing Administration will need a bailout next year if the housing market deteriorates further, the agency’s independent auditor said in a report released Tuesday.

headline: For One Man, Hawaii Is a Land of Problems
text: In a voice-over at the beginning of “The Descendants,” Matt King (George Clooney) challenges the myth, endemic among mainlanders, that Hawaii, where he lives, is a paradise on earth. His brief rant is buttressed by images of poverty and grime that are powerful but also slightly misleading, since Matt’s story is not — or at least not explicitly — one of deprivation or social inequality.

headline: Clearing a Park, and Reviving a Movement
text: Give Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg credit — he cleared a park and probably revived an occupy movement all at once, and without the tear gas, nightsticks and rubber bullets that seem de rigueur in Oakland.

headline: 11 States Seek Relief From ‘No Child’ Provisions, in Return for Raising Standards
text: Eleven states applied for waivers exempting them from key provisions of the No Child Left Behind law by the federal government’s first deadline, promising in return to adopt higher standards and carry out other elements of the Obama administration’s school improvement agenda, the Department of Education said on Tuesday.

headline: The Times Names a New Restaurant Critic and Dining Editor
text: The New York Times named Pete Wells, its Dining editor for the last five years and a veteran of Food & Wine and Details magazines, as its new chief restaurant critic, the newspaper announced on Tuesday.

headline: Players Express Frustration With Lockout
text: As the N.B.A. labor dispute slides further toward “nuclear winter,” as Commissioner David Stern put it, players are not keeping their thoughts quiet. They’re frustrated, want to get back to playing basketball, and are turning to Twitter to express themselves. And as always, proper spelling and punctuation are optional on Twitter, so read their thoughts without your grammar police hat on.

headline: Baby Sweet Potatoes, Big Enough to Stand Alone
text: Here’s the best argument against putting marshmallows on the sweet potatoes: Serve baby sweet potatoes, which need only be scrubbed and roasted to turn into rich candy themselves.

headline: For Costas, Sandusky Interview Came as a Surprise
text: When Bob Costas arrived at the studios of the new NBC newsmagazine program “ Rock Center” Monday night, he was prepared to interview Joseph Amendola, the lawyer for Jerry Sandusky, the man at the center of the pedophilia accusations that have rocked Penn State University.

headline: ‘Leap of Faith’ Heading to Broadway Next Fall
text: Broadway producers are planning a fall 2012 opening for “Leap of Faith,” a musical starring four-time Tony Award nominee Raul Esparza (“Company”) that was adapted from the 1992 Steve Martin film about an evangelical con man who is offered a chance at redemption. Thomas Viertel, one of the lead producers, said on Tuesday that closed-door developmental readings of the musical last week drew strong feedback from an invited audience, including potential investors, leading the producers to deem the show ready for Broadway.

headline: Mining Life’s Hardships for a Vein of Comedy
text: Laughs are always erupting, like bubbles from the depths of tar pits, in the writings of Samuel Beckett. I sometimes wonder if his reputation for annihilating pessimism owes as much to photographs of him in the winter of his life — the glowering eyes, the craggy face and the set mouth beneath a shock of hair that seemed to scream, “Egad! No more!” — as it does to his actual writing. A good production of “Waiting for Godot” is as funny as any given episode of “Curb Your Enthusiasm.” (In fact, Larry David’s vision of life may be a few shades darker than Beckett’s.)

headline: Prosecutions for Bank Fraud Fall Sharply
text: Federal prosecutions for financial institution fraud have tumbled over the last decade, despite the recent troubles in the banking sector, according to a new analysis of Justice Department data by the Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse (TRAC) at Syracuse University.

headline: Female Comedians, Breaking the Taste-Taboo Ceiling
text: In a Rolling Stone interview from 1979, Johnny Carson, host of “Tonight” and the most important gatekeeper in comedy for decades, gave his take on female comics.

headline: Familiar Police Presence in Park Says He Was Kept in the Dark

headline: Kansas City Bishop Makes Deal to Avoid More Criminal Charges
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — In a deal to avoid a second round of criminal charges, a Roman Catholic bishop in Kansas City has agreed to meet monthly with a county prosecutor to detail every suspicious episode involving abuse of a child in his diocese for the next five years.

text: Is pizza a vegetable? Maybe not in most homes, but in public school cafeterias it is.

headline: Apple Makes Changes to Its Board
text: Apple on Tuesday named Arthur D. Levinson as its nonexecutive chairman. Mr. Levinson, chairman of the biotechnology company Genentech, has been a member of Apple’s board since 2005. Apple also announced that Robert A. Iger, president and chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, would join Apple’s board. They were the first changes to Apple’s leadership since the death last month of Steven P. Jobs, the co-founder and chairman. Read the article by Nick Wingfield.

headline: Why Turkey Turned Away From Syria
text: Turkey is no longer humoring its harshest neighbors, like Syria and Iran. What will that mean for the region?

headline: From an Heir Apparent, European Earthiness and an Abundance of Energy
text: The New York musical world’s courtship dance with the conductor Fabio Luisi took a few more turns on Sunday afternoon and Monday evening, when Mr. Luisi brought the Vienna Symphony Orchestra to Avery Fisher Hall. Mr. Luisi, the Metropolitan Opera’s principal conductor and James Levine’s heir apparent as music director, has been getting a workout at the opera house as Mr. Levine’s health problems have kept him off the podium. Mr. Luisi has already picked up the company’s new productions of “Don Giovanni” and “Siegfried,” with “Götterdämmerung” still to come, and he has also deputized effectively for Mr. Levine with the Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.

headline: A Military Alliance on Full Display
text: Thousands of American and Filipino marines carry out military exercises in the Philippines.

headline: A Haircut Returns From the 1930s
text: CLEAN-CUT young men have been going to F.S.C. Barber in the West Village and asking for the same haircut: buzzed on the sides, longer on top and slicked back with a dab of pomade. You could call it a modified McSqueeb, a J. Edgar Hoover or maybe a Jimmy Darmody, after the character in “Boardwalk Empire.”

headline: Surprise Eviction at Zuccotti Park? One Twitter-Friendly Celebrity Saw It Coming
text: It turns out that the Paul Revere for the Occupy Wall Street movement has 1.76 million followers on Twitter. He also plays the drums for The Roots.

headline: Dispute Over Bare Islands Underscores Philippines’ Rocky Relations With China
text: PALAWAN, Philippines — The rhetorical missiles fired by a state-owned Chinese newspaper late last month landed squarely on the shores of this westernmost province and a few dozen kilometers from the coral reefs and scrub-covered islets claimed by China, the Philippines and a number of other nations.

headline: Quiet, Please: Sushi Being Served
text: WHEN a good friend insisted a few years back on dining by herself at the French Laundry, the renowned Napa Valley restaurant, I found it hard to comprehend. Wouldn’t she miss out on the communal relishing of shared flavors, delights and memories?

headline: Reviewing Sushi Yasuda
text: Like many people, I love seafood but I’m confused by the many conflicting reports over what is abundant and fished in a sustainable manner, and what is threatened and ought to be avoided. I try to keep up with things by consulting Web sites like the Monterey Bay Aquarium Seafood Watch. But even that information can be perplexing because of the many variables. Was that Atlantic cod line-caught? That’s O.K., Seafood Watch says, but not if was caught in a trawl net.

headline: Facebook Fights a Nasty Spam Attack
text: Facebook said a deliberate spam attack was behind a flood of graphic images that some users had reported seeing in their news feeds.

headline: Cain Defends His Handling of Libya Question
text: URBANDALE, Iowa – Herman Cain said on Tuesday that he had nothing to explain and no reason to apologize for a rambling pause-filled response when asked in a videotaped interview about President Obama’s policy on Libya, raising new questions about his command of foreign policy and his readiness to serve in the Oval Office.

headline: Meyer Discusses and Dismisses Arizona Job
text: Urban Meyer met with Arizona’s athletic director, Greg Byrne, in Miami early last week to discuss the Wildcats’ job, according to a person with knowledge of the meeting, but ultimately decided he was not interested. The person said that Meyer, who has expressed his desire to return to coaching, was intrigued but informed Byrne in a telephone call Monday night that he was not going to pursue the job.

headline: Google Allows Wi-Fi Owners to Opt Out of Database
text: BERLIN — Google, under pressure from privacy regulators in the Netherlands, said Tuesday that it had agreed to give people around the world the option of keeping the names and locations of their home or business Wi-Fi routers out of a company database.

headline: Site to Be Seen | C’H’C’M
text: Established retailers have long sought a presence online, in the hopes of establishing a virtual foothold every bit as solid as their traditional stores. Now, in reverse order, shops that originated on the Web are opening up their own brick-and-mortars. C’H’C’M (Clinton Hill Classic Menswear) just celebrated its first anniversary at 2 Bond Street in New York City, even though the owner, Sweetu Patel, has been selling clothes via the site from his Brooklyn apartment for almost three years. Whether online or in NoHo, shoppers can expect to find a mix of classic brands (Mackintosh parka, $975) and more obscure, under-the-radar labels (Fil Melange sweatshirt, $255; Chauncey turtleneck, $325; and Ovadia and Sons trousers, $265).

headline: How Can I Convince My Mother-in-Law to Let Me Cook?
text: Q.

headline: E! Keeps Chelsea Handler
text: The star of the late-night hours on E!, Chelsea Handler, will remain attached to the channel through 2014, the channel’s president, Suzanne Kolb, said Tuesday. Ms. Handler has been the host and a producer of the 11 p.m. talk show, “Chelsea Lately,” since 2007. Five months ago, in what was perhaps a bit of public negotiating, Ms. Handler hinted to The Hollywood Reporter that she might leave the channel. “I can’t keep doing the same thing; my brain is bleeding,” she said then. “I want to do something that’s more mindful and isn’t celebrity-centered.” Already she is involved in a scripted adaptation of her book “Are You There, Vodka? It’s Me, Chelsea” for the NBC network which, like E!, is owned by NBCUniversal. Through the contract announced on Tuesday, Ms. Handler’s production company will develop and produce new programs for E! and for other NBCUniversal properties. She will continue to produce “After Lately,” a semiscripted show that has run after her talk show. Terms of the contract were not disclosed.

headline: Facebook Timeline Bumps Online Narcissism Up a Notch
text: There is really only one word to describe Facebook’s coming Timeline feature: Mine.

headline: ‘Grobanites’ Get What They Came For
text: Josh Groban, the 30-year-old pop-classical heartthrob, stages his grandiose concerts to show off his assets: his inordinately charming stage presence, his cherubic features and tousled long locks, and (not least) the crystalline baritone he brings to a repertory of operatic ballads. On Monday night at Madison Square Garden his two-hour set, the final show of his “Straight to You” national tour, was replete with heart-rending orchestral laments and deadpan interludes: “You all smell like Chanel No. 5 and pizza.”

headline: Nets Hold a Rally Amid a Lockout and an Uncertain Season
text: On Tuesday, the day after one of the bleakest in the history of the National Basketball Association — when the players rejected the league’s contract offer, disbanded their union and the season seemed closer to being doomed — the Nets held a rally to promote their “Brooklyn Experience” outside Borough Hall.

headline: A Summer of Freedoms in Boyhood
text: If you didn’t know the title of the French movie “Tomboy,” an intimately scaled film about a 10-year-old girl who wants to be a boy, or at least enjoy some boyish freedoms, you might not know the sex of the pretty child in the opener. And you might not think it mattered. The short hair gives nothing away and neither does the image of this sprite standing up in a car’s open sunroof, face in the wind under the light-dappled trees. The driver — the father, you think — has one hand on the wheel and the other on the child, a nice image for a story about life’s balancing acts.

headline: Eye Shadow Pencils as an Alternative
text: EYE shadow pencils are a no-fuss way to perk up eyes: they don’t crumble like shadows in a pan, or require swabs and brushes. And many have a creamy consistency that feels soothing on the eyelid. But what’s their staying power?

headline: Bringing Back the Baroque in a Revival Tailored to the Met
text: The Metropolitan Opera’s production of Handel’s “Rodelinda,” created in 2004 as a showcase for the soprano Renée Fleming, went a long way toward establishing Baroque opera — and with it, elements of period performance practice — as something more than a novelty item at the house. So it is fitting that as the Met prepares a grand antiquarian experiment — “The Enchanted Island,” a Baroque-style pastiche with music by Handel, Vivaldi, Rameau and others, to open on New Year’s Eve — the signal “Rodelinda” production should usher it in, in a revival that opened on Monday evening.

headline: Apple Appoints New Chairman and Elects Disney’s Chief to Board
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple on Tuesday named a new board chairman, in another signal that the technology giant would not be run the same way as it was under its co-founder, Steven P. Jobs.

headline: Tommy Tune Reimagines Disco Era’s Glittery Mecca
text: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — Tommy Tune was once the fleet-footed prince of Broadway, whose flair and Tony Awards triumphs put him in the company of musical auteurs like Bob Fosse and Michael Bennett. And then he disappeared. A pair of painful flops in the ’90s led to a self-imposed exile from commercial New York theater, which has not seen anyone quite like Mr. Tune — a triple-threat actor, director and choreographer — since.

headline: Limited Broadway Run for Disney’s ‘Newsies’
text: In a break from its traditionally lavish approach to Broadway, Disney Theatrical Productions announced plans on Tuesday to mount a low-budget, three-month run of its new show “Newsies the Musical” in New York this spring, limiting its financial risk after two costly flops.

headline: J. C. Penney Shakes Up Ad Agency Roster, Just Before Christmas

headline: Union Loses Appeal on Teacher Ratings
text: The New York City teachers' union lost another round in its yearlong court battle to keep performance ratings of about 12,000 city teachers secret, with the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan ruling that it would not take up the case.

headline: How Much Nokia Has Lost
text: A report from Gartner says consumers bought 115 million smartphones in the third quarter of 2011, up 42 percent from the third quarter of 2010. As Nokia slipped, its Symbian operating system fell to 16.9 percent of smartphones sold from 36.3 percent. Android’s market share doubled, while Apple’s iOS slipped slightly.

headline: Foley Square: A Runner’s View
text: Odd day. There were helicopters overhead during the night. That happened last for the marathon, and before that when they killed Osama bin Laden. (They’ll be there Thanksgiving, for sure.) But I’ve learned that if there’s no big event scheduled it means Something Is Going On.

headline: Step Right Up!
text: Casey Spooner, of the art-rock performance group Fischerspooner, recently spent time in Sarasota, Fla., the resort town better known as the longtime winter quarters of the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, to perform in the Wooster Group’s production of “Hamlet” at the Ringling International Arts Festival. Here, he shares his photo and audio diary of the Ringling Circus Museum and the Ca’ d’Zan, a marvelous Venetian Gothic mansion built by John and Mable Ringling. Go to interactive feature >>

headline: Square Updates App to Highlight Customer Rewards
text: I have piles of loyalty cards from my local coffee shop sprinkled around my house. Each one is half-empty, just a few stamps away from a free cup of coffee. The problem is, I keep losing the cards and have to start over.

headline: Got More Voters? Get More Electoral Votes
text: Republicans in many states are pursuing two avenues to tilt elections their way — changing the electoral college rules in the middle of the game and using laws and regulations to block likely Democratic voters from exercising their legitimate franchise. Both ploys demand new thinking to enhance our elections, not constrain them in partisan ways.

headline: The Life Report: Matthew Kirk Gooding

headline: A Kentucky City Reinvents a Faded Downtown
text: OWENSBORO, Ky. — Ron Payne, the energetic and determined 65-year-old mayor of this small city on the Ohio River, keeps a map of new development projects in a corner of his City Hall office. There are more than a dozen sticky notes fixed to the map, each designating the location and cost of a local construction project recently completed, under way or planned.

headline: Q&A: Answers To ‘Where on Earth to Eat?’
text: IT’S no secret that Anthony Bourdain knows his way around food — but he’s also a world traveler. His new show, “The Layover,” on the Travel Channel, has him visiting cities for 48 hours or less, looking for the best places for travelers to eat and drink. Here are excerpts from a conversation about some of his all-time favorites.

headline: Shrinking Middle as Income Inequality Rises
text: The share of American families living in middle-income neighborhoods has decreased, while the share in affluent or poor neighborhoods has increased.

headline: Netflix Goes Android First, but Barely
text: The bounty of apps for iPad and iPhone are one of the cornerstones of Apple‘s strategy for promoting the devices. It isn’t a great sign for the company then, when an important developer says it’s going to do a superior app first for Google‘s rival Android operating system.

headline: S.E.C. Claws Back $2.8 Million From CSK Executive
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Tuesday that it had reached a deal to claw back $2.8 million in compensation from CSK Auto Corporation’s former chief executive and chairman, who ran the company during an accounting fraud scandal.

headline: The Right Questions
text: Bob Costas’s interview on Monday night with Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State assistant coach who has been charged with 40 counts of sexual abuse, underscored his ability to ask the right questions, and in this case, ask the right questions despite the lurid and unsettling details of the accusations.

headline: A Room of Their Own for 2-Wheeled Commuters
text: Creating a bicycle room for tenants at 345 Hudson Street turned out to be a good fit. The blocklong building in the quiet streets of northern TriBeCa has a low carbon footprint, and many employees of businesses there, like Penguin Putnam, Starbucks and CBS Radio, were already biking to work. And there was an unused storage space off Charlton Street, adjacent to a loading dock and with access to the lobby.

headline: Class Sizes Grew Again, New City Figures Show
text: Another year of cuts to schools' budgets has brought with it an anticipated rise in class sizes across the city, with elementary schools seeing the biggest increase, according to city figures. There are now, on average, two more kindergartners per class than there were in 2008, and roughly three more third graders per class from three years ago.

headline: Apple Releases iOS Update With Fix for Battery Drain
text: Apple is pushing out its i-device update, which is supposed to cure battery problems that have plagued some iPhone 4Gs owners, although owners report uneven results from the update.

headline: Solyndra Was Asked to Delay Layoff News Till After Midterms, Memo Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Energy Department asked the Solyndra solar equipment company to delay an announcement about impending layoffs until after last year’s midterm elections, according to a memo by the Republican staff of the House subcommittee that will call the energy secretary to testify Thursday about a government loan to Solyndra.

headline: Debating Legacy Preferences in Admissions
text: Why do top schools still take legacy applicants? The Times’s Room for Debate team asked that very question this week, assembling an online forum of six academics, administrators and admissions experts who delivered their own, different answers and arguments.

headline: Larry and Paul and Dave and Ian
text: A belated note on the Munk debate. Felix Salmon has a summary. The weird thing is that to the extent there was an argument about the economics, it was three-sided, and didn’t correspond to the “teams”: Larry Summers and me basically doing liquidity-trap macro, David Rosenberg not too different in analysis of the problem but expressing deep pessimism about the prospects for policy even given the political will, and Ian Bremmer making the case that America is better than other countries, which even if true had no bearing on the question, as far as I could see.

headline: Paterno Passes on Home to His Wife for $1
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Joe Paterno transferred full ownership of his house to his wife, Sue, for $1 in July, less than four months before a sexual abuse scandal engulfed his Penn State football program and the university.

headline: As U.S. Looks to Asia, It Sees China Everywhere
text: The last time the remote Australian city of Darwin played a significant role in American military planning was during the early days of World War II, when Gen. Douglas MacArthur used the port as the base for his campaign to reclaim the Pacific from the Japanese.

headline: Middle-Class Areas Shrink as Income Gap Grows, New Report Finds
text: WASHINGTON — The portion of American families living in middle-income neighborhoods has declined significantly since 1970, according to a new study, as rising income inequality left a growing share of families in neighborhoods that are mostly low-income or mostly affluent.

headline: A.L. Cy Young Winner, and Perhaps More
text: Voters for the Cy Young Awards did not have to dig too deeply into advanced statistics this season. By every meaningful metric, modern or traditional, the best pitchers in the league were obvious.

headline: Campaigns Bring Art and Artists to Life
text: A NEW commercial for the Detroit Institute of Arts opens with a woman responding to an off-camera interviewer, although the question is not revealed: “He had olive skin.”

text: LONDON — The news reached London as the first dim glimmers of dawn crested the great dome of St. Paul’s Cathedral.

headline: Inaction on Goalie Hit Is Criticized
text: TORONTO — Brendan Shanahan, the N.H.L. director for player safety, was handed something of a rebuke by general managers Tuesday at their annual fall meeting. Many agreed that the Boston Bruins’ Milan Lucic should have been suspended for the hit he delivered on Buffalo Sabres goalie Ryan Miller last Saturday.

headline: When DNA Evidence Suggests ‘Innocent,’ Some Prosecutors Cling to ‘Maybe’
text: CHICAGO — For 17 years, Terrill Swift and three other men convicted in the 1994 rape and strangulation of a prostitute here have insisted on their innocence. And last May, a powerful new piece of evidence emerged that appeared to back their claim: a DNA profile, constructed from semen found in the victim’s body, matched a man who was convicted of raping and strangling another prostitute a few years later.

text: Q.

headline: Dell’s Profit Improves as Sales Miss Expectations
text: Dell, the maker of personal computers, reported quarterly sales that missed estimates, even as its focus on higher-margin technology helped its profit.

headline: On Fire Island, Blaze Destroys Hub of the Gay Social Scene
text: The Pavilion dance club, the locus of the social scene in gay-centric Fire Island Pines, was destroyed Monday night in a spectacular fire that illuminated the eastern horizon opposite Long Island.

headline: Austrian Returns, Unrepentant, to Online Jihad
text: VIENNA — Mohamed Mahmoud, a 26-year-old Austrian, wears a traditional white tunic and a light-brown hat and keeps his hair long, as is the tradition in the Pashtun tribal areas of Pakistan and Afghanistan. Only his camouflage vest and dark-blue sneakers place him in the modern world here in Europe, which he re-entered Sept. 12 after serving a four-year prison sentence for joining and actively supporting Al Qaeda and its affiliates.

headline: Mohamed Mahmoud
text: Mohamed Mahmoud talks about the U.S. and nuclear weapons.

headline: Ronaldo Leads Portugal Into Euro 2012
text: LISBON — The match was only seven minutes old when Cristiano Ronaldo’s 35-yard free kick dipped and swerved, eluding the grasp of goalkeeper Asmir Begovic.

headline: Sandusky Turns to TV to Break Silence
text: Jerry Sandusky’s voice was halting, and his affect was oddly flat. He denied charges of pedophilia but didn’t flash the indignant anger of a person wrongly accused. Sandusky, the former Penn State defensive coordinator who is charged with sexually abusing young boys, told Bob Costas of NBC over the telephone on Monday night that he had done nothing wrong, but that “in retrospect,” he regretted the showers and “horseplay.”

headline: In a Wrestling Match Over Space, a Sudden Shove
text: Over the routine din of Union Square, you could hear the drills and their spiraling whines. All around were sights that went with the sounds. Sheets of raw plywood, set on sawhorses, measured twice and cut once to size. A woman on a stepladder, a pan of red paint in reach, the swabs of her brush laying holiday color on the wood. A man atop a counter, clipping light fixtures onto a rack that ran overhead, fed by electrical cables that roped along the back of the stall.

headline: Novelist Fights the Tide by Opening a Bookstore
text: NASHVILLE — After a beloved local bookstore closed here last December and another store was lost to the Borders bankruptcy, this city once known as the Athens of the South, rich in cultural tradition and home to Vanderbilt University, became nearly barren of bookstores.

headline: Out of Camps in Africa and Into Debt in America
text: Ndayishimiye Gabo sat motionless in a damp Bronx apartment with peeling wallpaper, leaking faucets and dilapidated floors, staring at an eviction notice in one hand and a court order in the other.

headline: Presidents Cup Pairings Pit Woods and His Ex-Caddie
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The first day of the Presidents Cup will feature the matchup golf fans have been craving. The Americans Tiger Woods and his partner Steve Stricker will face the International teammates Adam Scott and K. J. Choi in Thursday’s anchor foursomes matchup. Or, as this heavyweight bout will be better known: Tiger Woods versus his former caddie Steve Williams.

headline: Arizonans Vie to Claim Cross-Cultural Fried Food
text: PHOENIX — Florida has its key lime pie, Idaho its potatoes and Georgia favors grits as its official state food. Arizona, hungry to lay claim to a state food of its own, is circling the chimichanga.

headline: CBS Details Its Broad Overhaul of ‘The Early Show’
text: Pain is evident in the voice of the CBS News chairman, Jeff Fager, when he talks about the ratings performance of “The Early Show,” the network’s long-suffering morning news broadcast.

headline: For Weight Loss, a Recipe of Teamwork and Trust
text: On Friday I wrote about Saddleback Church, which is using its small groups as an infrastructure to help its members lose weight and live healthier lives. The megachurch has megaplans for this idea — the church’s pastor, the Rev. Rick Warren, hopes to expand it through the worldwide network of thousands of churches that are affiliated with Saddleback and the 150,000 pastors who subscribe to his newsletter.

headline: Stop the Great Firewall of America
text: China operates the world’s most elaborate and opaque system of Internet censorship. But Congress, under pressure to take action against the theft of intellectual property, is considering misguided legislation that would strengthen China’s Great Firewall and even bring major features of it to America.

headline: Bell Ringers Go Digital This Season
text: Soon, the holiday sounds of coins clinking into red kettles may disappear, replaced by the silence of a credit card swipe.

headline: Swings of Fortune Continue as G.O.P. Candidates Return to the Trail
text: BETTENDORF, Iowa — A Republican presidential race that has been dominated by debate appearances and television interviews took a turn back to the rigors of retail politicking on Tuesday, with candidates making their cases directly to voters who are struggling to find clarity in an unusual boom-to-bust primary campaign.

headline: Across U.S., Demonstrators Face Arrests and Evictions
text: ATLANTA Late last month, 52 protesters in Woodruff Park, downtown, were arrested for violating an ordinance that prohibits people in the park from 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. Protesters have taken to rallying in front of banks and foreclosed houses.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Success and Advice Cast a Giant as a Villain, Not a Model, in Europe
text: BERLIN — Throughout the crisis in the euro zone, as governments have fallen, debt burdens have mounted and economies have stagnated or shrunk, Germany has floated above the fray. While its economy has hummed along nicely, its leaders have steadfastly insisted that the path to redemption for the debtors lies in austerity and suffering.

headline: In Attempt to Force Talks, N.B.A. Players File Antitrust Suit
text: Locked-out players began their legal assault on the N.B.A. on Tuesday, filing an antitrust lawsuit that demands an end to what they contend is an illegal boycott of the work force. They are seeking monetary damages for lost wages, which would be tripled under antitrust law.

headline: The Broccoli Test

headline: Jolted, Wall St. Protesters Face Challenge for Future
text: Emergency-service trucks rumbled up Broadway to positions on two sides of Zuccotti Park. Powerful klieg lights blinked on, illuminating about 220 protesters in tents and sleeping bags. The one-square-block plaza was as bright as day. But it was only 1 a.m.

headline: Why China Won’t Listen
text: Guangzhou, China

headline: Whistler’s Brother
text: Shortly after the Civil War broke out, Dr. William McNeill Whistler, scion of a storied Anglo-American military family and brother of the artist James McNeill Whistler, arrived in Richmond, Va., to lobby Confederate leaders for a medical officer’s commission. Described as a genial, refined man with a soft and pleasant voice, the 25-year-old, Massachusetts-born Whistler was firmly determined to put his medical training to use.

headline: In Court, Confronting Man With Story of a Rape and a Ruse
text: It was the moment that Seemona Sumasar said she had been waiting for.

headline: For Jets, Abbreviated Turnaround May Help
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It is good to have a short memory in the N.F.L. For the Jets, who play Thursday night against the Denver Broncos, their two-and-a-half-day turnaround is the quickest way to move beyond their sobering 37-16 loss to the New England Patriots on Sunday night.

headline: Authentic Filipino Moderno
text: OF every ethnic restaurant it is inevitably asked: Is it authentic? Check Maharlika’s bona fides. On the cocktail list is Tang. On the menu is Spam. By the front door is Jesus, in embossed metal, presiding at the Last Supper.

headline: After $5.1 Billion Loss, Postal Service Predicts Weaker 2012
text: The United States Postal Service is forecasting a record $14.1 billion loss for the 2012 fiscal year as a drop in mail volumes accelerates.

headline: Buffett Makes a Value-Growth Bet
Who’s the Decider?
text: Driving to the covered bazaar in the exotic western Indian town of Jodhpur last week, our Indian guide stopped to point out a modern landmark. “Do you see that stoplight?” he asked, pointing to a standard green-yellow-red stoplight in the busy intersection. “It’s the only stoplight in Jodhpur. There are 1.2 million people living here.”

headline: Flubs Are Rubbing Some Republicans the Wrong Way
text: The Republican presidential candidates have served comedians a full platter of laughs this year — a steady diet of gaffes, misstatements, puzzled looks and long, awkward pauses.

headline: Basketball in Doubt, TV Tries to Fill a Gap
text: With the full National Basketball Association season in jeopardy now that talks between the players’ union and the league have collapsed, television stations are scrambling to put together a prime-time schedule without professional basketball.

headline: Dining Calendar
