headline: Skimming the Fat Without the Fuss
text: A fat separator helps get turkey drippings in shape for the gravy boat. There are various glass, plastic and metal cups, pitchers and ladles to simplify the job of skimming, but this separator has some clever features. The one-quart plastic container does not have a spout near the base, as many separators do. Instead, it works by releasing the liquid below the layer of fat or oil through a little trapdoor at the bottom opened by squeezing the spring-loaded handle, like a sifter. Its silicone lid is a screen to catch pieces of onion or other solids that might clog the opening at the bottom, and there is a small pouring spout near the container’s rim. The device is also dishwasher safe.

headline: Witness Says Councilman Led Him to a Contractor
text: To anyone familiar with Bronx politics, it should come as little surprise that Stanley K. Schlein would make an appearance at the criminal trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook.

headline: Spared in War, Libya’s Oil Flow Is Surging Back
text: ZAWIYAH, Libya — The bullet holes in the oil tanks have been patched, the damaged backup generator is being repaired, and most important, the pipeline that feeds the giant oil refinery here has been reopened.

headline: Sandusky’s Roots
text: Memories and landmarks of Jerry Sandusky’s past are scattered throughout his hometown of Washington, Pa.

headline: In Sandusky’s Birthplace, the Man They Knew
text: WASHINGTON, Pa. — The Brownson House, the old red-brick recreation center on Jefferson Avenue, was like a hearth the whole community huddled around. Every child played there, one generation after another, bouncing a basketball on an undersize court that had an inconvenient pillar in the middle.

headline: Wednesday: Shot Follower
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Ready to party? Gary Cee is, and he’s invited us to toss back a few boilermakers. That’s a beer followed by a shot of harder alcohol as a BEER CHASER (or the shot can be dropped into the mug of beer and consumed together).

headline: G.O.P. Is Optimistic but Democrats Are Glum on Deficit Panel
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders began to insert themselves more deeply Tuesday into the work of a joint committee charged with taming the deficit, as Republicans in both chambers embraced a plan devised by Senator Patrick J. Toomey, one of their party’s representatives on the panel. Democrats appeared to be less united and struggling to come up with a counteroffer.

headline: Celebrating Peace and Unity in Libya, but Feeling Tension Beneath the Surface
text: ZINTAN, Libya — Few towns sacrificed or contributed as much to the Libyan insurrection as this dusty mountain town southwest of Tripoli. On Tuesday there was joy, poetry, exhibitions of masterful horsemanship, parachute jumps, speeches and symbols of national unity. Dozens of war prisoners were even quietly freed.

headline: Bloggingheads: Too Dumb To Win?
text: Ann Althouse, left, of the University of Wisconsin Law School and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate Rick Perry's intelligence.

headline: A Special Day at the Office as Krzyzewski Sets a Record
text: Mike Krzyzewski solemnly walked down the sideline to shake the hand of Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo, then walked back toward the Duke bench and made a sharp left. He crossed the court at Madison Square Garden and walked purposefully toward an old coach in a green sweater.

headline: Mexico: A Familiar Candidate
text: Andrés Manuel López Obrador announced on Tuesday that he would lead Mexico’s leftist Party of the Democratic Revolution, or P.R.D., in the 2012 presidential election. Mr. López Obrador beat Marcelo Ebrard, the mayor of Mexico City, in a poll of 6,000 people that the two men had agreed would determine which of them would be the party’s candidate. Mr. Ebrard has agreed to throw his support behind Mr. López Obrador, who lost to President Felipe Calderón in 2006 by half a percentage point. Mr. Obrador never accepted that result, and his loss set off mass protests.

headline: Colombia: Rebels Pick New Leader
text: The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, the rebel group known as the FARC, disclosed Tuesday that its secretariat had named Rodrigo Londoño as its new top commander. The FARC said in a statement that the decision was made unanimously by the group’s leadership on Nov. 5, a day after Colombian forces killed Alfonso Cano, the previous commander. Mr. Londoño, 52, who uses the aliases Timochenko and Timoleón Jiménez, is considered one of the FARC’s leading intelligence operatives and a mastermind of its cocaine trafficking activities. The United States Department of State is offering a reward of as much as $5 million for the capture of Mr. Londoño, who American officials say has ordered subordinates to increase production of coca, the plant used to make cocaine, and kidnap American citizens.

headline: The Mayor Confronts the Protesters
text: The Occupy Wall Street protesters had achieved a great deal before they were rousted from Zuccotti Park by New York City police on Tuesday morning. This ragged group, living in tents and tarps for two months in the financial district in Lower Manhattan, helped focus everyone’s attention on the growing income inequality in this country. They made “99 percent” into popular language for the have-nots. They spawned protests against further enriching the already rich 1 percent, like those in Chicago, Boston, Oakland, Calif., New Haven, and even London.

headline: Hip Procedure Grows Popular Despite Doubt
text: It is one of the most popular operations in sports medicine. It comes in various forms, all with the same name: Hip impingement or bone shaving surgery. World-renowned athletes have had the operation — the Yankees’ third baseman Alex Rodriguez had it about two years ago and the sprinter Tyson Gay had it last summer.

headline: Rangers Top Isles for 7th Straight Win
text: Disparities in victories, statistics and payroll rarely register when the Rangers and the Islanders meet. Although the Rangers entered the latest installment of the rivalry having won their last six games — and the Islanders having lost 9 of 10 — the Rangers could not exhale until the final seconds of their 4-2 victory Tuesday night at Nassau Coliseum.

headline: Egypt’s Elections
text: Egyptians are embarked upon the next step in their Arab Spring evolution — electing a democratic civilian government. Tunisia’s elections went smoothly last month. But the signs in Egypt, a far more influential player, are not good. The army, which is still running the show, appears to be far more interested in protecting its power than promoting real democratic change.

headline: Donya Feuer, Modern-Dance Choreographer, Dies at 77
text: Donya Feuer, an American modern-dance choreographer who moved to Sweden in 1963 and became a close collaborator of Ingmar Bergman as well as a theater director and filmmaker in her own right, died on Nov. 6 in Stockholm. She was 77.

headline: Another Plan for Tax Cuts
text: Facing an effective deadline at the end of this week for the Congressional “supercommittee” to come up with a plan for cutting the deficit, Republicans have offered an approach that would raise revenues by $300 billion and cut spending by $1.2 trillion. That is the first time party leaders have acknowledged that any new money should be raised to cut red ink. But the proposal is highly deceptive — the main goal seems to ensure even deeper tax cuts for the wealthy — and demonstrates why the committee seems headed toward a deadlock.

headline: Latest Dirty Water Bill
text: Republicans just won’t give up on their misguided attempts to subvert the Clean Water Act. Senators John Barrasso of Wyoming and Dean Heller of Nevada plan to offer a rider denying protections to one-fifth of the nation’s wetlands and as many as two million miles of small streams. The House has approved a similarly destructive measure, so it is crucial that the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, and his Democratic colleagues block this legislation.

headline: After Fall, Silver Talks About His Stitches
text: ALBANY – In Puerto Rico for a legislative conference Thursday, the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, decided to make the most of the pleasant weather. So, he said, he rented a bicycle and set off for a jaunt in San Juan.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,819 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: The Second Coming of Gingrich
text: Rick Tyler knew it would come to this. When Newt Gingrich kicked off his presidential campaign in May by criticizing Congressman Paul Ryan’s Medicare reforms as “right-wing social engineering,” thus incurring the wrath of the very conservatives that he presumably needed to win over, there was a rush to write the former House speaker’s political obituary. But Tyler, then Gingrich’s spokesman, had an answer for the doubters – a statement so epic that it deserves to be reproduced in its entirety.

headline: The Kitchen Rescue Team
text: The cranberries won’t gel. The pie crust broke. The turkey’s frozen. The mashed potatoes are as lumpy as a sack of olives. Aunt Miriam is bringing her well-known marshmallow tartare. There are 17 guests and only 9 chairs. Meanwhile, the children … Wait, where are the children?

headline: Pat Passlof, Abstract Expressionist Painter, Dies at 83
text: Pat Passlof, an Abstract Expressionist painter whose canvases vibrate with unpredictable line and thick, luminous color, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83.

headline: Giants Were Present During Killing at Club
text: A gunman opened fire at a crowded Manhattan nightclub early Tuesday morning, killing a 44-year-old man and wounding two other people while many professional athletes and entertainers — including several players on the Giants — were nearby, the police said. No connection has been made between the shooting at the Juliette Supper Club on West 21st Street and any of the athletes.

headline: Some Troops to Stay in Iraq as Trainers, Top Officer Says
text: WASHINGTON — Some United States forces will remain as military trainers on 10 bases in Iraq even after an end-of-year deadline for all American troops to be out of the country, Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told a Senate committee on Tuesday.

headline: A Surprise Nighttime Raid, Then a Tense Day of Maneuvering in the Streets
text: Almost two months after Occupy Wall Street protesters took over Zuccotti Park, police cleared out the encampment in the early hours of Nov. 15. Shortly after midnight, police trucks moved in and took up positions along the park’s perimeter.

headline: Ilya Zhitomirskiy Dies at 22; Co-Founded Social Network
text: Ilya Zhitomirskiy, a co-founder of the start-up social network Diaspora*, which has been described as the “anti-Facebook” for its emphasis on personal privacy and decentralized data collection, died on Saturday at his home in San Francisco. He was 22.

headline: Turkish Family Braces for Jolts and Uncertainty
text: VAN, Turkey — The once busy sidewalks of this city in eastern Turkey have morphed into a desolate maze of partly collapsed buildings, broken glass and windows hanging dangerously askew.

headline: Village in Iraq Falters With Exit of U.S. Troops
text: SOKUR, Iraq — The name of this dusty little village means falcon in Arabic, a reference to its history as a residential community for workers at a nearby airport. But most people in Iraq call it Traitor Town.

headline: Rangers Win 7th Straight Against Floundering but Feisty Isles
text: Disparities in victories, statistics and payroll rarely register when the Rangers and Islanders meet. Although the visiting Rangers entered the latest installment of the rivalry having won their last six games, while the Islanders had lost 9 of their previous 10, the Rangers could not exhale until the final seconds of their 4-2 victory Tuesday night at Nassau Coliseum.

headline: Canada: Top Scientists Urge Allowing Assisted Suicide
text: In a study released on Tuesday, Canada’s leading scientific and academic body recommended the legalization of voluntary euthanasia and assisted suicide. The six authors from a variety of fields and countries who conducted the study for the Royal Society of Canada said there was no evidence that legalizing those acts “poses a threat to vulnerable people, or that decriminalization will lead us down a slippery slope from assisted suicide and voluntary euthanasia to non-voluntary or involuntary euthanasia.” But they did conclude that there is a “moral right” to allow competent and informed people to decide when their lives are no longer worth living. (The group defined “voluntary euthanasia” as taking the life of someone who has expressed a wish to die but is incapable of performing the act.) Any system to assist suicides, the report said, must be carefully regulated and monitored. The issues have been debated extensively in recent years after several high-profile court cases.

headline: Protesters Return to Zuccotti Park
text: New York City on Tuesday reopened the park in Lower Manhattan where the Occupy Wall Street movement was born not long after a judge upheld the city’s move to clear the park and bar the protesters from bringing back their tents or staying overnight.

headline: Protesters Return to Zuccotti Park
text: New York City on Tuesday reopened the park in Lower Manhattan where the Occupy Wall Street movement was born.

headline: Romney Tax Return Offers a Glimpse
text: Ann Romney, the wife of Mitt Romney, increased her donations to a family foundation by $1.5 million last year, raising its total assets to $10 million, according to a tax return filed on Tuesday.

headline: Pairings for Day 1 of the Presidents Cup
text: The pairings for the first day of the Presidents Cup were released today, with everyone’s attention falling on the final pairing that puts Tiger Woods and Steve Stricker against Adam Scott and K.J. Choi. Woods’s former caddie Stevie Williams now caddies for Scott, making for a potentially tense round. The rest of the pairings and tee times are as follows:

headline: Supporters of Giffords Find Reasons to Cheer
text: PHOENIX — Jeff Rogers, who is chairman of the Democratic Party in southern Arizona where Representative Gabrielle Giffords is the congresswoman, admits he had his doubts about her political future in the opening moments of her first public interview since she was shot in the head in January.

headline: For a Change, the Marlins Are Center Stage at the General Managers’ Meetings
text: MILWAUKEE — Dozens of reporters were mingling with team executives Tuesday afternoon in a seventh-floor ballroom at the Pfister Hotel, the site of baseball’s general managers’ meetings, when Larry Beinfest’s entrance sent a ripple through the crowd.

text: A gunman opened fire at a crowded Manhattan nightclub early Tuesday morning, killing a 44-year-old man and wounding two people while several entertainers and professional athletes — including up to five Giants players — were nearby, the police said.

headline: Toyota and Lexus Are Back on Top in Kelley Blue Book Resale Value Survey
text: Toyota and Lexus are the brands with the best resale value for 2012 models, according to Kelley Blue Book.
