text: Revealed on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2013 Ford Escape.

headline: The Right Reasons to Stretch Before Exercise
text: For an article being published in next month’s issue of The British Journal of Sports Medicine, researchers at the University of Sydney in Australia reviewed dozens of recent studies of stretching, hoping to determine whether the practice prevents people from getting sore after they exercise. The authors found 12 studies completed in the past 25 years that looked directly at that issue. Most were small and short-term. But each produced essentially the same result, the review authors write, showing that “stretching does not produce important reductions in muscle soreness in the days following exercise.”

headline: EMBARGOED UNTIL 12:01AM on 11/16!!
text: 2013 Ford Escape slide show

headline: Word of the Day | demented
text: demented •\di-ˈmen-təd\• adjective

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
text: The Uttar Pradesh cabinet led by Chief Minster Mayawati on Tuesday approved the division of the state into four regions: Purvanchal (eastern region), Bundelkhand, Avadh Pradesh (central region) and Paschim Pradesh (western region). Ms. Mayawati announced that a resolution will be tabled in the winter session of the state Assembly, then forwarded to the central government for approval (The Hindu). This decision comes ahead of the state elections scheduled for early next year. An editorial in The Indian Express, Wednesday titled “Four State Solution,” argues that if the division comes through, “four states would mean four capitals, with attention lavished on each. There will, hopefully, be a rejuvenation of the fabled old towns strewn across the current Uttar Pradesh,” the author says.

headline: NYT Front Page for 11/16/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 11/16/2011

headline: New Muppet, New Movie
text: Walter, the latest addition to the Muppets family, stars in “The Muppets.”

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 60
text: After a swift raid emptied Zuccotti Park early Tuesday morning, uncertainty lingered the rest of the day and  into the night, with a late-night march heading toward police headquarters, hundreds of protesters crashing on friends’ couches and dwindling crowds at the reopened park, now a no-sleeping zone. [The New York Times]

headline: A ‘Radical Centrist’ View on Election Forecasting
text: Ron Klain, the former chief of staff to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., has a long critique up at Bloomberg about the piece that I published in The New York Times Magazine recently about President Obama’s re-election prospects. His article takes the view that campaign strategy and other intangibles are quite important in presidential campaigns and that statistical forecasts do a poor job of accounting for these.

headline: Iraq Village Falters With U.S. Exit
text: Andrew E. Kramer reports on the lingering effects of the American presence in Sokur, Iraq, a village many Iraqis have nicknamed Traitor Town.

headline: Bollywood’s ‘Rockstar’ Disappoints Tibetans
text: A group of Tibetan fans of Bollywood films said they were disappointed over the blurring of images in the movie.

headline: Of Militants and Boy Bands
text: LONDON — Two videos have gone viral in Pakistan over the past few weeks. Both feature three young Pakistani men. Both flay the establishment. In one, the men wield Kalashnikovs; in the other, they brandish microphones. Such are the tools of change in a country that seems to have lost its way.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 16, 2011
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article “U.N. Says 7 Billion Now Share the World.”

headline: Nov. 16, 1933 | U.S. Establishes Diplomatic Relations With the Soviet Union
text: On Nov. 16, 1933, at 10 minutes before midnight, the United States and the Soviet Union established diplomatic relations. President Franklin D. Roosevelt sent a telegram to the Soviet leader Maxim Litvinov, expressing hope that United States-Soviet relations would “forever remain normal and friendly.”

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 16, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Karzai Details Vision for Long-Term Partnership With U.S.
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai for the first time publicly laid out his vision of a long-lasting agreement that could keep the American military in Afghanistan for years, in a speech to Afghans on Wednesday that seemed both a warning to neighboring Pakistan and Iran and an attempt to win over a skeptical domestic audience.

headline: A U.S. Marine Base for Australia Irritates China
text: CANBERRA, Australia — President Obama announced Wednesday that the United States planned to deploy 2,500 Marines in Australia to shore up alliances in Asia, but the move prompted a sharp response from Beijing, which accused Mr. Obama of escalating military tensions in the region.

headline: Reaching Toward the Future at Google
text: WHAT is Google X?WHAT are some projects in development there?WHAT do you want in the future?

headline: Faces, and Voices, From Zuccotti Park
text: Before he moved to California to become a photographer, August Bradley had what he calls “the coolest job I can think of in corporate America,” brainstorming on long-term concepts for major clothing brands.

headline: Teaching Good Sex
text: “First base, second base, third base, home run,” Al Vernacchio ticked off the classic baseball terms for sex acts. His goal was to prompt the students in Sexuality and Society — an elective for seniors at the private Friends’ Central School on Philadelphia’s affluent Main Line — to examine the assumptions buried in the venerable metaphor. “Give me some more,” urged the fast-talking 47-year-old, who teaches 9th- and 12th-grade English as well as human sexuality. Arrayed before Vernacchio was a circle of small desks occupied by 22 teenagers, six male and the rest female — a blur of sweatshirts and Ugg boots and form-fitting leggings.

headline: Could Every Day Be Black Friday?
text: If an alien with an accounting degree touched down in America, it might conclude that we’re a weird cult that spends 11 months living frugally and four crazy weeks buying tons of stuff we don’t need. It wouldn’t be entirely wrong, either. Retailers make around a fifth of their sales during the holiday season — close to half a trillion dollars — when the ratio of frivolous to necessary purchases spikes. It’s not unusual for large chains to operate in the red from New Years’ Day through Thanksgiving and then make it all up in those crazy weeks.

headline: Do You Sympathize With the Occupy Wall Street Movement?
text: The New York Times recently asked readers to plot their opinions about the Occupy Wall Street movement on a graph. Do you know what those in the “Occupy” movement are protesting? Do you sympathize with their complaints? Do you agree with the protesters’ methods? Why or why not?

headline: Comfort Food a Phone Call Away for New York’s ‘Desis’
text: It was the summer of 2002, I was getting married, and my in-laws were coming to New York from Mumbai for our wedding.

headline: Peabody Energy Wins Full Control of Macarthur Coal
text: LONDON — Peabody Energy said on Wednesday that it had acquired more than 90 percent of Macarthur Coal of Australia. The announcement allows Peabody, an American coal company, to require Macarthur’s remaining shareholders, including the South Korean steel maker Posco, to sell their stakes.

headline: Week 10 Film Review: Cutler and Bears Look Sharp
text: A closer look at Week 10 via film review:

headline: The Sharp Increase in the Food Stamps Program
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Where to Find Holiday Gifts in Rome’s Markets
text: Looking for a unique gift to bring home from Rome? Don’t waste time in souvenir shops. Instead, the city’s markets are a great way to get some of that holiday shopping done early.

headline: Part 3: Answers to Your Questions on Scholarships and Student Loans
text: To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them — as well as to further their understanding of President Obama’s recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans — Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is spending this week in our virtual Guidance Office. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of “Secrets to Winning a Scholarship,” published in February.

headline: The Early Word: Next!
text: Today’s Times

headline: Arab League Offers Reprieve for Syria as Toll Rises
text: RABAT, Morocco — In what amounted to a surprise reprieve, the Arab League offered to send civilian and military monitors to Syria on Wednesday to determine whether it was abiding by a league-brokered peace plan to end the crackdown on the country’s eight-month uprising. The move countered the league’s startling decision five days earlier to suspend Syria.

headline: What It’s Worth to Be Committee Chairman
text: A gavel and a bigger staff are not all that come with the job as chairman of a House committee. As is widely known, it almost certainly translates into a surge in donations to campaign accounts, as corporations and lobbyists whose business affairs are regulated by the committee attempt to make nice with the new bosses.

headline: Imagining Housing for Today
text: Bronx Park East opened last year opposite the New York Botanical Garden. It consists of a five-story brick pavilion with triple-height windows facing the street, and a seven-story wing for 68 small studio apartments. “A good neighbor,” is how its designer, Jonathan Kirschenfeld, described the building’s look.

headline: Can a Marketing Contest Increase Sales for This Online Retailer?
text: More than 10 years ago, Don Chernoff introduced SkyRoll.com with the idea that a Web site could better explain his unique carry-on luggage and provide another sales channel for his products. Those sales, however, have been disappointing.

headline: Overnight, Zuccotti Largely Unoccupied and Quiet
text: As a steady drizzle fell early Wednesday morning, only a few dozen protesters remained in Zuccotti Park.

headline: Prices of Rare Earth Metals Declining Sharply
text: HONG KONG — After nearly three years of soaring prices for rare earth metals, with the cost of some rising nearly thirtyfold, the market is rapidly coming back down.

headline: Clinton Reaffirms Military Ties With the Philippines
text: MANILA — During a high-profile visit to the Philippines on Wednesday, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton stood on the deck of a American warship in Manila Bay and reaffirmed the strong military relationship between the United States and the Philippines.

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 16
text: The day after the nighttime raid that cleared protesters from Zuccotti Park, the New York Police Department was criticized by local politicians and news organizations for its treatment of reporters and the restrictions it placed on how they do their work. The Associated Press reported that at least half a dozen reporters were arrested in and around the park, home of the Occupy Wall Street movement, including a reporter and photographer from the agency. Michael Oreskes, senior managing editor for The A.P., said: “Journalists should not be restricted from access to news events or detained for attempting to do their jobs. We were unhappy that two of our staff members were swept up in the police operation, but we appreciate the N.Y.P.D.’s decision to release them.”

headline: Markets Fall on Report of Risk to U.S. Banks
text: Stocks tumbled on Wednesday as Fitch Ratings said further contagion from Europe’s debt crisis will pose a risk to American banks and concerns rose that higher oil prices would hamper economic growth.

headline: 2 Views of Aerosols and Climate Change
text: Aerosols are small particles or droplets suspended in a gas. While consumers tend to think of them as being dispensed from a pressurized container, some are natural and some are produced by pollution generated by humans. Two recent studies suggest that the latter variety plays an important role in the environment, actually changing weather and climate.

headline: Larry, Larry, Larry! N.F.L. Drama in Spanish
text: Sports is drama, and when you’re lucky enough to witness a memorable moment, it’s nice to have a voice to match — to have the accompaniment of a Gus Johnson during March Madness or an Andres Cantor during the World Cup.

headline: To Fix Failing Schools, Target Troubled Students?
text: One kid at a time. That’s how Turnaround for Children, a nonprofit organization based in New York, approaches schools in tough neighborhoods, where principals “say they can hardly see their teachers’ work through the fog of students’ extreme behavior.” The organization is involved with 20 schools in New York City and three in Washington, helping teachers identify and work with individual students in trouble, not just for their sakes, but for the sake of the school. These are students, writes Anna M. Phillips, who could “shatter a classroom’s composure or a school windowpane in an instant.”

headline: The Bridge to Nowhere
text: ISTANBUL — I suspect that many Istanbul residents, even those caught in the tailgate eternity of the daily commute to work, don’t spend much time worrying about the broad-leafed knapweed. Like the small meadow saffron, it is one of the 2,000 species of flora that thrive in the greater metropolitan area — that’s 150 varieties more than exist in all of Britain, a landmass 50 times the size. Famous as the juncture between Asia and Europe, Istanbul is also the meeting point of the climate systems of the Black Sea and the Mediterranean, which means that a diverse plant life complements its rich history.

headline: Opinion Report: OWS
text: From the editorial page

headline: Citi to Shed 3,000 Jobs; BNP Paribas Plans to Cut About 1,400
text: The ax continues to fall on Wall Street.

headline: It’s Not Just What You Protest, It’s Where
text: Many important issues in New York involve real estate, and a well-worn cliché is that it’s all about three things: location, location and location. Why should it be any different with demonstrations? As we see once again, where you protest can be as important as what you protest.

headline: Facing Crisis, Technocrats Take Charge in Italy
text: ROME — As dubious European bond markets looked on, a former member of the European Commission and well-respected economist, Mario Monti, was sworn in as prime minister and finance minister on Wednesday, unveiling a cabinet of technocrats charged with repairing Italy’s ailing economy to help keep the debt crisis at bay.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: The Wisest Entrepreneurs Know How to Preserve Equity  |  So you want to be an Internet billionaire. It’s not just about having a great idea and building a world-class business at light speed, writes Steven M. Davidoff in his Deal Professor column.

headline: 11 States Seek No Child Left Behind Waivers
text: No Child Left Behind waivers, no changes in school lunch nutrition standards and no easy way to choose a high school in New York City are among the topics in the news. And seven city schoolteachers will be honored for their excellence in teaching science and math.

headline: The Early Line on Early Applications for the Class of 2016
text: The window for applying to many colleges and universities under early admission programs closed late Tuesday night. While it will be some time before a definitive statistical portrait emerges of this early admissions season, The Choice has been dutifully requesting application figures from a range of more than 100 institutions. The chart above, which we’ll be updating regularly as other figures trickle in, represents the equivalent of early returns in an election, with results from two dozen “precincts.”

headline: The Life Report: Ray Olson
text: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

headline: Unis Heads to Hollywood
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Wednesday Reading: Cooking Ahead to Ease Thanksgiving Stress
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Children’s Books: Days and Nights at the Museum
text: For every third-grade boy who obsessively reads the labels accompanying the dinosaur skeletons at the natural history museum, there seem to be at least eight other school-age children aimlessly roaming the exhibits, bewildered by the towering piles of bones surrounding them.

headline: Gingrich on Defensive Over Freddie Mac Fees
text: 9:01 p.m. | Updated For roughly six years, Newt Gingrich worked closely with high-level officials at the government-sponsored mortgage company Freddie Mac. As a highly paid consultant, he coached them on how to win over the conservatives who consider their company an anathema, spoke to their political action committee and offered general advice as they worked to stave off various threats to Freddie Mac’s survival, several people familiar with his role there said Tuesday.

headline: After Bullet Hits White House, a Manhunt and Arrest
text: WASHINGTON — Law enforcement officials on Wednesday arrested a 21-year-old Idaho man suspected of firing a semiautomatic rifle at the White House on Friday night, and the Secret Service reported finding that at least one bullet had struck the presidential residence.

headline: Decline And Fall
text: Ed Harrison has a good essay on how the world euro ends if the ECB doesn’t step in on a massive scale. I don’t agree with everything — I think he’s wrong to attribute the commodity spike of 2010-2011 to monetary policy — but he’s basically right about how the thing unravels. I might place greater emphasis on the immediate channel through which falling sovereign bond prices force bank deleveraging, but we’re picking nits here.

headline: The Urns Return
text: At the headquarters of Atria Senior Living, a nationwide operator of retirement and assisted-living homes, it must have seemed like a no-brainer. Sixteen big masonry urns, from 1,000 to 1,500 pounds each, had been standing on the parapets of Atria West 86 — the former Franklin Towers Apartment Hotel at 333 West 86th Street — since 1927; through freeze and thaw, countless storms and the incessant stiff winds off the nearby Hudson River. Heaven only knew what held them fast to their precarious ledges, but heaven help anyone in the path of a falling half-ton urn.

headline: Caravans Between Covers
text: The lengths that collectors will go to, the money and legwork they will sink into exotic antiques completely unrelated to their daily lives, can make for transporting reading. The year’s five best books in the genre show how owners have traveled, researched and bought obsessively, and pressed dealers for background information on every acquisition. The collections slowly fill homes and storage spaces, survive wars and natural disasters, and occasionally turn up on public view far from their homelands.

headline: The Very Brave BoE
text: The new Bank of England inflation report (pdf) is out, and it offers a defense of the Bank’s decision to pursue expansion, not contraction, despite 5.2% headline inflation. It’s basically a core inflation argument. The Bank says that a lot of recent inflation reflects temporary shocks:

headline: Employers Step Up Efforts to Curb Health Care Costs
text: Employers remain concerned about the relentless increase in the cost of providing health coverage for their workers, according to a new survey, and many companies are trying to do more about it.

headline: Barney Frank, Master Of Disguise
text: Who knew he could manage to look like this?

headline: Common Sense and the New Cooking Science
text: The eagerly anticipated debate was titled “Traditionalist Versus Modern Cuisine,” about the controversy over the new molecular gastronomy. But for a discussion of what is often called a culinary revolution, it turned out to be a surprising celebration of traditionalism.

headline: Drake Pushes Rap Toward the Gothic
text: THE new kid is a bit of an oddball. He struggles to be heard and then to find his footing. He is jostled from every side, knocked off balance. He doesn’t give in. He holds his ground until suddenly, despite everyone’s efforts, he’s standing tall. He inches closer and closer to the center, until the center starts moving toward him. Before long he’s the new normal; everyone has to fit in around him.

headline: Accel Raises $155 Million for India Fund
text: Accel Partners, an early backer of Facebook and Groupon, has raised $155 million for a new India fund that will focus on early stage investments, the venture capital firm announced on Wednesday.

headline: Equal Parts Heart and Abrasiveness
text: GUELPH, Ontario

headline: The Place | Florida, Part Three
text: COLLECTIVE BARGAINING

headline: Leading Off: Krzyzewski Milestone Can’t Lift College Sports
text: The college sports myth machine definitely needs a new gear. Because even cranked all the way up to max for Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski’s record-breaking 903rd victory Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden — with all proper hype machinery in place to coat him in heroism — it still wasn’t strong enough to overcome the feeling that the mountain Krzyzewski just climbed was a pile of dirt that had been heaped for many years on the top of a sinkhole. And that sinkhole is giving way.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Atlantic Cities: A geographic-economic analysis of where the best restaurants in the world are. The urban theorist Richard Florida links great food to “the open and tolerant values that go with a creative, knowledge-based economy.” — Julia Moskin

headline: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
text: How many games can the Texans win without Matt Schaub at quarterback? Are the Eagles pretty much done? And what happened to the Bills? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will will again answer selected questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below to ask your questions, and the answers will appear on The Fifth Down on Friday.

headline: From the Yellow Pages to Ground Zero
text: In the fall of 2001, Gregg Brown had a simple ad in the Yellow Pages advertising his photography business. “We Do Photo Video,” it said. “24 Hour Rush Jobs Welcome.”

headline: Superheroes for the Stockings
text: Superheroes are the cornerstones of graphic novels, and this year that genre had some big events. In January the Human Torch met his demise, but that was just one stitch in the compelling tapestry that the writer Jonathan Hickman has been weaving for Marvel’s Fantastic Four. In September DC Comics reintroduced its heroes with new No. 1s, a decision that resulted in great sales and produced a handful of stellar series.

headline: Where Can I Find Lingonberry Preserves?
text: Q.

headline: Pose Retirement Questions to a Financial Planner
text: You can pose your retirement questions to a certified financial planner for free on Wednesday, during two hourlong online sessions run by the National Association of Personal Financial Advisors and Kiplinger.

headline: Power Surge: 650 Horsepower for the Shelby GT500
text: Shown on Tuesday, Nov. 15: 2013 Ford Shelby GT500.

headline: Thirsty Power Plants Threaten Watersheds, Study Finds
text: The first chapter of a new report on the effect of power plants on freshwater systems has the feel of a documentary film. Imagine a camera panning the dessicated Texas landscape as a voice intones statistics from the brutal 2011 drought — a dried-up Brazos River, 80 days of 100-degree-plus temperatures in some locations, and so on.

headline: Orioles Look to Past for Inspiration
text: After 14 consecutive losing seasons, the Orioles have clearly decided that it is time to look to the past to regain the team’s glory.

headline: Wocka, Wocka, Wocka! Muppet Antics Resume
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Honors for Math and Science Teachers Who Make Students Think
text: Seven New York City math and science teachers who try to make learning experiential and (gasp!) fun will receive Sloan Awards for Teaching Excellence in Science and Mathematics, an honor that seeks to recognize exceptionally dedicated and creative high school educators.

headline: Room Service Watches Your Calories and More
text: Room service used to be the stepchild of hotel dining: the menus were an afterthought, and guests often ordered in as a last resort. But recently, many independent and chain hotels have been rethinking room service to make it more desirable.

headline: Crazy Sexy Thanksgiving
text: Kris Carr is a self-described “wellness warrior,” a cancer survivor best known for her upbeat advice about a “healing” lifestyle that includes a plant-based diet and spiritual sustenance.

headline: In Los Angeles, Driving the Dark Horse in the Green Car of the Year Sweepstakes
text: LOS ANGELES — The 2012 Green Car of the Year Award, bestowed by the automotive Web site Green Car Journal, will be presented Thursday at the Los Angeles auto show. The diverse field of finalists includes two all-electric vehicles, a gasoline-electric hybrid, a diesel-powered model and another that runs on compressed natural gas, or CNG.

headline: Daily Report: Holiday Donations by Smartphone
text: Square, the mobile payments company, is one of the most closely watched companies in Silicon Valley. Founded by Jack Dorsey, one of the co-founders of Twitter, it could be a challenge to the credit card companies. Indeed, Stephanie Strom and Claire Cain Miller report Wednesday in The Times that the Salvation Army has begun shifting into digital donations through Square, as fewer and fewer shoppers carry much change or bills.

headline: DealBook: A Complicated Maneuver for Control of Yahoo
text: Instead of selling the company outright, Yahoo is reportedly contemplating a large sale of stock to one or more private equity firms using a controversial structure known as a PIPE, or private investment in public equity. But does Yahoo’s latest turn mean battle-scarred shareholders will lose out on a valuable sale opportunity? Read the entire post on DealBook.

headline: Fiery Sweet Potatoes for a Virtual Feast
text: Two years ago, Kim Severson and Julia Moskin faced off over the quintessential Thanksgiving question: Is it all about the turkey, or the sides?

headline: Manifesti Destiny
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Conversation Many Doctors Won’t Have
text: At Home and Hospice Care of Rhode Island, where she’s a medical director, Dr. Joan Teno has grown accustomed to patients being admitted with no clear understanding of their condition or prognosis. “The oncologist has told them, ‘It’s time to take a holiday from chemo,’” she said. “It’s a way not to have a conversation he or she finds hard to do.”

headline: World Cup Qualifiers Spanning the Globe
text: No. 146 in the FIFA rankings will have three months to ponder how close it is to advancing to the next round of World Cup qualifying in Asia.

headline: Is Verlander the A.L. Most Valuable Player Too?
text: Major League Baseball award voters did not need to think very hard to tab Detroit’s Justin Verlander as the American League Cy Young winner; his season was so spectacular that his unanimous selection came with zero drama on Tuesday.

headline: Regulator Calls for New Steps After Collapse of MF Global
text: A Republican regulator on Wednesday called for new measures to restore public confidence in the futures industry after $600 million went missing from MF Global, the bankrupt brokerage firm.

headline: Entrepreneurs Looking For Capital Investment Seek Kindred Spirits
text: On the last day of the fourth quarter in 2008, BC Krishna was trying to clinch a deal with a large, name-brand company. The transaction would have put his small start-up, Memento, a fraud-detection company, on the map. When the deal fell through, Mr. Krishna worried about how his venture capitalist investors would react — especially because it meant that Memento was going to fall short of its performance targets.

headline: McCartney Letter Seeking Drummer for Beatles Sells for $55,000
text: If artistic reputations were judged by memorabilia auction prices alone the letter that sold at Christie’s in London on Tuesday night would place Paul McCartney – at least in the current economy – decidedly below both his former bandmate John Lennon and John Keats but well ahead of the novelist Harper Lee.

headline: Americans Waking Up to Light Bulb Changeover
text: The first step in getting people to change the way they consume energy is making them aware that change is afoot. When it comes to lighting technologies, in particular, it seems that consumer awareness is growing.

headline: Jasmine, Tuberose and Power
text: The Little Book of Perfumes: The Hundred Classics. By Luca Turin and Tania Sanchez. 128 pages. Viking. $18.

headline: Do Former Entrepreneurs Make Better Venture Capitalists?
text: Most small-business owners never seek venture capital, writes Pamela Ryckman in an article we’ve just published, but for those who do, it can feel like a deal with the devil. Venture-backed companies are expected to grow quickly, and their boards can impose rigorous controls, audits and metrics. A founder who takes venture capital gets the opportunity to grow but also risks losing control of the company. One way entrepreneurs mitigate the tension in the relationship is to work with venture capitalists who may have more patience during the company-building process — because they have been through it themselves.

headline: Sandusky Accuser Would Testify of Severe Sexual Assault, Lawyer Says
text: Ben Andreozzi, a Pennsylvania lawyer representing one of eight boys alleged to be victims in the Penn State sexual child abuse case, called Jerry Sandusky a “coward” on Wednesday and said that Sandusky’s recent comments on television had emboldened his client to pursue sexual assault charges against Sandusky.

headline: Practicing on Patients
text: My hospital recently decided to ask nurses, rather than the phlebotomy team, to handle blood draws. This wasn’t a big deal, except that I’d never done it before, and to learn, I would have to practice on patients.

headline: Reform Adds More Twists to a Convoluted Derivatives World
text: When the architects of the Dodd-Frank regulatory overhaul flinched from the most effective solution — breaking up the banks so that none would be too big to drag down the financial system — they forced regulators of the derivatives market into a cumbersome and potentially dangerous workaround.

headline: Smith Electric to Build Trucks in the Bronx
text: New York would never be mistaken for the Motor City, but on Tuesday, Smith Electric Vehicles announced that it intended to assemble electric trucks in the South Bronx, adding 100 jobs to the region. A package of more than $6 million in state and city incentives sweetened the deal.

headline: Catching Up on TV Shows, Past and Present
text: THE ADVENTURES OF TINTIN: SEASON ONE (Shout! Factory, 2 discs, $19.93) Before Steven Spielberg’s “Adventures of Tintin” arrives this winter and imprints its motion-capture versions of Tintin, Snowy and Captain Haddock on our brains, devoted readers of Hergé’s comic strips might want to check out this 1991-92 television series. A Canadian-French production that was later shown on HBO, it’s pedestrian, as far as the drama is concerned, but has one inestimable advantage for the purist: The 2-D animation remains absolutely faithful to the look of the original. Season 1 adapts seven of the “Tintin” books in 13 episodes, including classics like “The Crab With the Golden Claws” and “The Blue Lotus.”

headline: OWS at the Crossroads
text: Now that Mayor Michael Bloomberg and the New York courts have taken the “occupy” out of Occupy Wall Street, there’s a lot of buzz about what the movement should do next. That’s obviously not up for me to decide, nor do I want to, but the group has reached a crossroads.

headline: App Smart Extra: Stylin’ Styluses
text: Last week’s App Smart column, on note-taking apps, mentioned a few apps aimed at people who like to scrawl on their tablets, whether with a finger or a stylus. That prompted a few letters from readers who wondered which stylus they should use.

headline: Services That Feed Nostalgia for the Recent Digital Past
text: A year ago today, I spent the day working from a local coffee shop. As the sun began to set, I picked up some takeout from my favorite eatery and spent the rest of the night writing in my living room.

headline: Big City Book Club: Coming Attractions
text: Next up for the Big City Book Club is “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” Truman Capote’s classic 1958 novella of bittersweet Manhattan self-invention. (You can catch the live online conversation on the City Room blog on Tuesday, Nov. 29, between 1 and 4 p.m.) Some of you may be reading the book for the first time, but I suspect you’ve all seen the 1961 Blake Edwards film that followed. The book and movie are, of course very different in tone, which is something we’ll be talking about. In anticipation of our conversation, I’ve pulled some articles from The New York Times’s archives that cover the complications of adapting the book for Hollywood (pdf) at a time, well in advance of “Pretty Woman,” when depictions of prostitution weren’t necessarily welcome onscreen, including Janet Maslin’s review of “Fifth Avenue, 5 A.M.,” Sam Wasson’s recent book about the making of the film.

headline: Tip of the Week: Barcode Scanning Apps
text: Serious shoppers can use their smartphone’s camera for more than just snapping photos of the things they want to buy. With a barcode scanner app installed, the phone’s camera can be used to scan an item’s bar code (also known as the Universal Product Code). Once scanned, most apps present a list of places and prices the scanned item can be found, which makes comparison-shopping even easier on the go. RedLaser and PriceGrabber are two apps that offer iOS and Android versions, as does Pic2Shop, which also works on Windows Phone. Search your phone’s app store for others.

headline: Judge Temporarily Bars Eviction of Boston Protesters
text: BOSTON — A judge granted a temporary order on Wednesday requiring the city to refrain from any police action to evict the Occupy Boston demonstrators from Dewey Square, where a small city of about 150 tents has functioned for a month and a half.

headline: Reader Feedback: Why American Migration Might Be Falling
text: In response to my post Tuesday on the record low level of migration in the United States last year, an astute reader referred me to a recent paper in The Journal of Economic Perspectives on this subject.

headline: To Behold, Maybe Even to Read
text: This year’s best gift book, for a crazy person you really, really like — as opposed to those people for whom you simply need to purchase a safe, distinguished, booklike object — is almost certainly this one: WHAT THE HELL ARE YOU DOING?: THE ESSENTIAL DAVID SHRIGLEY (Norton, $35). It’s a funny, sick, morally stimulating mind-bender, the best bathroom book of the new decade.

headline: The Economy Isn’t Obama’s Only Challenge
text: There’s a lot of talk now about the many reasons that President Obama faces a perilous path to re-election — starting, of course, with the torpid economy and a dysfunctional political system. But I wouldn’t overlook the underlying, more structural challenge in the electoral map that would be vexing Mr. Obama and his strategists even if the economic picture weren’t quite so bleak.

headline: Interim Greek Government Wins Confidence Vote
text: ATHENS — Greece’s new interim government comfortably won a vote of confidence on Wednesday, though the unity of the coalition, which must secure crucial rescue financing and save the country from default, appeared tenuous.

headline: A Self-Immolation in Tiananmen Square Is Reported
text: A man set himself on fire in China’s heavily policed Tiananmen Square last month, according a report in The Daily Telegraph on Wednesday, in the first known case of a self-immolation at the politically sensitive site in Beijing in nearly a decade.

headline: Evernote Takes On Web Reading With Clearly
text: Evernote, an application that has gained momentum by providing an easy way for people to quickly capture things they want to remember, is determined to branch out past its humble note-taking origins.

headline: Fund-Raiser for Liu Is Accused of Role in Illegal Donations
text: A fund-raiser for the New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, whose campaign finances are under federal investigation, was arrested on Wednesday morning on charges that he helped illegally funnel thousands of dollars into Mr. Liu’s campaign account, according to court papers and people briefed on the case.

headline: Berkeley Reveals Plan for Academic Center in China
text: SHANGHAI — The University of California, Berkeley announced this week that it plans to open a large research and teaching facility here as part of a broader plan to bolster its presence in China.

headline: Chrysler to Hire 1,100 Workers in Toledo, Ohio
text: TOLEDO, Ohio — Chrysler said Wednesday that it would add 1,100 jobs at a sport utility vehicle plant here as it spends $1.7 billion developing new models for its Jeep brand.

headline: Irving, Maynard, and Me (Wonkish)
text: I’m going to be a bit grouchy right now, and unfairly so. Via Mark Thoma, I see that David Glasner is worried about what appears to be a need for negative real interest rates, and suggests that this may be close to concerns about the liquidity trap.

headline: Look of the Moment | Joan Smalls
text: The Look: In the Mood for Love. An intricate black lace dress and long sleeves are all romance, even when paired with tougher Deco-metallic heels.

headline: A Record Win for Coach K
text: Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski set the men’s Division I record for coaching victories by beating Michigan State on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 Puts the Power, and the Top, Down
text: Shown on Tuesday, Nov. 15: 2013 Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 convertible.

headline: Lightning Round
text: David Brooks: Gail, there have been a lot of news events of minor importance hitting us all at once so let’s play lightning round. First, did you see the Herman Cain video clip on Libya, the one in which he is asked whether he supports Obama’s policy there and he stumbles around desperately trying to remember which country Libya is (the little one north of Israel maybe?), what just happened there (Lawrence of Arabia?) and what Obama’s policy might actually be.

headline: TimesCast | November 16, 2011
text: Arab League foreign ministers meet to formalize Syria's suspension; Hamas' public relations efforts; and the media blackout of the clearing of Zuccotti Park.

headline: Where Is Microsoft’s Office for Tablets?
text: During a very brief annual shareholder meeting on Tuesday, Microsoft’s chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, said: “We are in an era where the range of smart devices is continuing to expand. That is a fantastic thing for Microsoft.”

headline: CO2 on the Up and Up
text: To my eye, this animated graph, produced by the federal Earth Systems Research Laboratory, is one of the best attempts to put the recent human-driven surge in carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere into long-term context:

headline: Warning to Rahm and Ari Emanuel: Big Brother Was Watching, and He Has a Book
text: Zeke Emanuel, perhaps the least-known brother in the power trio that includes Rahm and Ari, has written a memoir of his childhood and adolescence as a member of the Emanuel family, his publisher said on Wednesday.

headline: DVDs, From Fresh Offerings to Old Favorites
text: We keep reading that the silver disc has died and gone to technology heaven, its place to be taken by streaming media from the Internet cloud. But if DVDs and Blu-rays are obsolete, they are showing an awful lot of life this holiday season, with a wide selection of new and classic titles presented with depth, definition and supplementary features that streaming video is not yet in a position to provide.

headline: Angry Landscapes Up Close and Far
text: “The Angel Esmeralda,” the title story in Don DeLillo’s first ever collection of short fiction, is a dazzlingly told tale of despair and ruination, the dream of redemption and the testing of faith. Set in the Bronx and featuring a nun on the lookout for a miracle, this 1994 story prefigures portions of Mr. DeLillo’s 1997 masterwork, “Underworld,” but it also stands on its own as a beautifully realized and singular work of fiction.

headline: A Long, Long Road to Recycling Nuclear Fuel
text: The question of what to do with spent nuclear fuel from civilian power reactors has stirred renewed interest in reprocessing — that is, chopping up the fuel, retrieving materials that can power a reactor and possibly recovering the most troublesome waste products so they can be broken up in the reactor into easier-to-handle elements.

headline: Xing Wu Pan Criminal Complaint
text: Xing Wu Pan, who gathered donations for a citywide candidate in New York in the 2013 election, is accused of fraud. The candidate is said to be New York City comptroller, John C. Liu.

headline: Jets Head to Denver With Memories of a Season-Altering Victory
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It looked bleak for the Jets, safety Jim Leonhard said. Like a complete long shot, guard Matt Slauson said. Just hope and pray, running back LaDainian Tomlinson said.

headline: Joe Paterno’s House and the Estate Tax Question
text: So why did Joe Paterno, the former Penn State football coach, “sell” his home to his wife for the paltry sum of $1?

headline: Appeals Court Allows New Trial for Bruno
text: A federal appeals court on Wednesday overturned, as was expected, the corruption conviction of Joseph L. Bruno, the upstate Republican who was once one of the most powerful men in New York State government.

headline: Ristretto | Bear Pond Espresso: How Much Sexy?
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: From Bad Boy to ‘Good Dog’
text: JOHN BARTLETT, the men’s wear designer, stood outside an empty store on Seventh Avenue near Charles Street in the West Village. Until recently he would have been inside, selling his men’s line to charmed shoppers. Some would have known him from his glory days as a fashion darling who staged hot-ticket runway shows and made pronouncements to the news media. Now, the windows were covered with butcher paper; with some trepidation, Mr. Bartlett, 48, stuck his head inside the debris-covered space and sighed as he looked at racks and shelves that once held his assertive and playful clothes.

headline: App Design and Cloud Work
text: The author and creative team discuss the new app version of “1,000 Places to See Before You Die,” and Quentin Hardy finds new uses for cloud computing.

headline: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan
text: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan

headline: Exiled Tibetan Abbot Rebukes China Over Monks’ Troubles
text: The chief abbot and spiritual leader-in-exile of a Tibetan monastery at the epicenter of a series of self-immolation protests against Chinese rule spoke out forcefully in New York on Wednesday, detailing what he called new and harsh repressive measures taken against the monks at the monastery since the immolations started in March.

headline: Shooting for Global Change
text: Some serious photographers might cringe at being called amateurs. Not Antonio Amendola — he wears the badge proudly.

headline: Adele Speaks (on Her Blog)
text: Writing on her blog, the British soul singer Adele joked with fans that she was practicing a mime show after undergoing surgery in Massachusetts to stanch the bleeding on a benign polyp on her vocal cords.

headline: With a Russian in a Tajik Jail, Moscow Aims Its Reprisal at Migrant Workers
text: MOSCOW — The imprisonment of a Russian citizen in Tajikistan has touched off reprisals against ethnic Tajik migrant workers in Russia who say they have been unjustly targeted for arrest and deportation.

headline: TimesCast | Suspending Syria
text: November 16, 2011 - Arab League foreign ministers meet in Morocco to formally suspend Syria.

headline: Play About Abuse in Ireland Will Arrive in New York
text: A critically acclaimed one-man play about institutional abuse of children that created waves in Ireland when it was first produced in 2003 will be coming to New York. “James X,” written and performed by Gerard Mannix Flynn, will begin performances on Dec. 6 and open on Dec. 9 at 45 Bleecker Theater.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Lebanon, Italy and Russia.

headline: Noorman’s Kil
text: TO the list of newfangled bar trends (speakeasies, rooftop lounges, faux Victorian saloons) comes another — specialty bars that focus on a single liquor. Case in point: Noorman’s Kil, a whiskey-and-grilled-cheese bar that opened in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in August.

headline: It’s Not Just the Economy
text: A few weeks back, Nate Silver, The Times’s resident statistical wizard, wrote a fascinating cover article for the magazine about President Obama’s chances for re-election, based on a bunch of different data. One challenge facing Obama that hasn’t been talked about, though, is the modern disadvantage inherent in being a Democratic nominee. Here’s a column I just wrote over on the Caucus blog, putting this campaign in the context of recent political history.

headline: It’s Delicious. But Is It a Vegetable?
text: I’m finding it hard to figure out what, exactly, Republicans think about vegetables. Herman Cain, who as we know always chooses his words with the greatest of care, called vegetable pizza “sissy pizza” on Monday. But House Republicans are suggesting that pizza is itself a vegetable. So does that mean all pizza is for sissies?

headline: Company Offers Web Sites a Button for Visitors’ Privacy Settings
text: For businesses that want an easy way to put a privacy button on their Web sites, a company called BrightTag has introduced a new method for them to offer one, and for consumers to find the button.

headline: Anger Erupts in Thailand Over Plans for Amnesty
text: BANGKOK — The Thai government faced a political uproar on Wednesday after details surfaced of a proposed prisoner amnesty that the country’s opposition says is designed to pardon Thaksin Shinawatra, the prime minister ousted in the 2006 military coup.

headline: Opposition May Rejoin Political System in Myanmar
text: BANGKOK — After more than two decades of persecution by Myanmar’s military, the party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi says it will decide Friday whether to rejoin the political system, a potential milestone for a country that appears to be gradually emerging from years of dictatorship and oppression.

headline: ‘Glee’ Hitting Some Sour Notes With Viewers
text: O “Glee” fans, where hast thou gone? A year ago the musical dramedy was a dominant force for Fox on Tuesday nights in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, easily finishing first in the segment.

headline: A TV Character and a TV Critic, Both Named Genzlinger: Coincidence?
text: I don’t know how many Genzlingers there are in the United States, but I do know there are so few of us that when one encounters another to whom he’s not related, both consider it an odds-defying miracle on a par with winning the lottery or being struck by lightning. So you can imagine my surprise when, on Tuesday night’s episode of “New Girl” on Fox, a character named Genzlinger turned up.

headline: Fox Plans Early Sneak Preview to Help Film
text: Updated, 5:38 p.m. | LOS ANGELES — What’s old is new: 20th Century Fox said on Wednesday that it would use a modern twist on one of Hollywood’s hoariest marketing tactics — the sneak preview — to help sell the forthcoming comedic drama “We Bought a Zoo.”

headline: Photo Replay: Nov.16
text: A look back at the day in sports, from the South East Asian Games to the N.I.T. Season Tip-Off.

headline: Re-election Strategy Is Tied to a Shift on Smog
text: WASHINGTON — The summons from the president came without warning the Thursday before Labor Day. As she was driven the four blocks to the White House, Lisa P. Jackson, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, suspected that the news would not be good. What she did not see coming was a rare public rebuke the president was about to deliver by rejecting her proposal to tighten the national standard for smog.

headline: ‘South Park’ Team to Keep at It for Five More Years
text: Some “South Park” fans wondered if the end was near for the animated series earlier this year when Trey Parker and Matt Stone turned in an episode that centered on the cynicism and unhappiness of the main characters, complete with the playing of the Fleetwood Mac song “Landslide.” A metaphor, maybe? Maybe not. On Wednesday Comedy Central, the channel that has shown 15 seasons of “South Park,” said it had signed up Mr. Parker and Mr. Stone to write, direct and edit the series through 2016, thus reaching a 20th season.

headline: The Place | Florida, Part Four
text: BOAT TO TABLE

headline: Young Rapper Rides Internet to the Top of the Chart
text: The Internet, we hear all the time, “levels the playing field” for music. With the global and instantaneous reach of digital distribution, and social media’s ability to quickly amplify any trend, you might expect that the top rungs of Billboard’s sales charts would frequently be filled with unknown acts that have broken through with a catchy song.

headline: The New Head of the M.T.A. Is Cool, for Now
text: Joseph J. Lhota, whose captainship of the lumbering vessel that is the Metropolitan Transportation Authority began this week, has a reputation for being gruff and blustery: just the qualities, many civic watchers say, that are necessary to keep the agency afloat.

headline: What Should I Bring to My Boyfriend’s Parents’ Home?
text: Q.

headline: Female Cadets Signal Slow Change in Afghan Police Force
text: In a class of almost 300 Afghan men, Tamana Tanha, 20, is the only woman training to become a noncommissioned police officer in Mehtar-Lam, the capital city in Laghman Province in East Afghanistan. There are approximately 20 to 30 female police officers in the entire province.

headline: Live Updates: Inside MF Global’s Bankruptcy Hearing
text: A proposal to set up a claims process for customers of MF Global is the focus of a hearing on Wednesday at the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan. DealBook is proving live coverage of the proceedings beginning at 3:30 p.m.

headline: Four Astronauts Are Honored by Congress
text: Congress awarded the Congressional Gold Medal on Wednesday to four American astronauts, including the first American man to orbit the Earth and the crew of the first mission to land on the moon.

headline: The Caucus | Scrutinizing Newt Gingrich
text: Nov. 16, 2011 — Michael D. Shear reports on the increased focus on the former speaker of the House, not only on his work for Freddie Mac but also on his shifting stands on issues.

headline: Porsche Unveils Design Plans for Corporate H.Q. in Atlanta and Experience Center in L.A.
text: In two years, frequent fliers circling above Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport may glimpse a Porsche badge out their windows. The atrium of the automaker’s new North American headquarters, scheduled to open in late 2013, will be shaped to resemble the shield adorning Cayennes, Panameras, Caymans, 911s and Boxsters.

headline: Mazda CX-5 Aims at the Compact-Crossover Market
text: Introduced on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2013 Mazda CX-5 crossover.

headline: Widening Split in Europe on the Virtue of Austerity
text: PARIS — Throughout Europe’s long debt crisis, Germany has prescribed the same strong remedy to its troubled neighbors: a stiff dose of fiscal discipline.

headline: A Radio Gig for Bill Wyman, Erstwhile Rolling Stone Bassist
text: Bill Wyman, the former bass player for the Rolling Stones, will host a three-part series on satellite radio starting this month, Sirius XM Radio said on Wednesday. He plans on playing the songs of his favorite blues and rock musicians, discussing his musical influences and telling anecdotes from his long career, the network said.

headline: Tailgating Recipes: Better Than Seven-Layer Dip
text: Football without tortilla chips is like the Colts without Peyton Manning. So any tailgate party worth its weight in cheese needs some sort of dip to go with those chips. Regan Jones, an Auburn graduate and registered dietitian, offers a variation on the classic seven-layer dip, with fresh ingredients and reduced-fat cheese. “It’s a nutritionist-approved option perfect for even the pickiest of football food fans,” she writes.

headline: Caucus Video: Scrutinizing Newt Gingrich
text: Michael D. Shear reports on the increased focus on the former speaker of the House, not only on his work for Freddie Mac but also on his shifting stands on issues.

headline: Scene City: Rosy Night for Silver Screen
text: Karl Lagerfeld and Anna Wintour honor Pedro Almodóvar at MoMA Film Benefit.

headline: What Sweden Knows About Orgasms
text: As part of my research for my cover article in this Sunday’s magazine on sex-positive sex education, I read academic Kristin Luker’s excellent 2006 book, “When Sex Goes to School: Warring Views on Sex — and Sex Education — Since the Sixties.” Near the end of the book, in the chapter “Politics of Sex,” she addresses the issue of sex education and pleasure in a way that really resonated with my own reporting. She tells how she visited sex-education classes in Sweden — considered a kind of nirvana for people who are comprehensive sex-ed advocates — and reported on an instructor’s response to the question “What is an orgasm, and why do people talk about it so much?”

headline: A Night for Art, Fashion and Film
text: WONDERING who’s behind the hedges is usually a summertime activity. But on a drizzly Tuesday evening, the lobby of the Museum of Modern Art was walled off behind verdant dividers, shielding the powerful, talented and glamorous at the museum’s fourth annual Film Benefit.

headline: When Did Childbirth Become Everyone’s Business?
text: I was tricked into a natural childbirth. As the midwife hauled me from birthing tub to hallway walk to music-filled, softly lit delivery room, I kept saying, no, thanks. No more tub. No music. Narcotics. Now. Actually, birth being what it is for me, I screamed it. But my midwife was determined that I would become the natural childbirth success story I’d never particularly wanted to be.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 61
text: Details of the raid on Zuccotti Park continued to emerge Wednesday. City Councilman Ydanis Rodriguez held a news conference Wednesday to talk about what he called an assault on him by police officers arresting him during overnight eviction Tuesday of the protesters in the park. “I did not provoke the N.Y.P.D.,” said Mr. Rodriguez, his left eye visibly bruised and cut. He said that as he tried to cross Broadway after encountering officers nearing Zuccotti Park, an officer forced him to the ground. [Daily News]

headline: Primates in the Lab: Debating the Use of Chimpanzees in Medical Research
text: Overview | In this lesson, students learn about legislation to end research on chimpanzees in the United States. They debate the issues surrounding research on chimpanzees, consider their own opinions on the topic, and draft letters to their representatives in Congress.

headline: Video: When Journalists Get Evicted Along With Their Subjects
text: Brian Stelter and David Carr discuss the rough handling of journalists during the clearing out of the Occupy Wall Street protesters early Monday morning, and how that influenced the way the story was reported. For one thing, much of the footage of those events was taken by the protesters themselves, rather than journalists.

headline: For Felicity Jones, Her Clothes Play the Role, Too
text: THE night before filming a wedding scene for the Sundance Film Festival hit “Like Crazy,” Felicity Jones had a vision of the exact shade of nail polish that would make her character — the desperately besotted Anna — seem duly childish. So the 27-year-old British actress spent hours driving from pharmacy to pharmacy in Los Angeles until she found it: OPI Baby Blue.

headline: Site to Be Seen | LN-CC
text: In the luxury men’s-wear market, a ton of e-tailers have emerged to service the Dior Homme fan in Boise, Idaho, and the Givenchy fanatic from Boulder, Colo. And while sites like Ssense and Park & Bond serve a broad, appeal-to-all selection of designer items in a department store sort of way, the lesser-known London-based boutique LN-CC’s Web supplement takes a more specific, avant-garde approach to merchandising. There, in addition to music and books, you’ll find Balenciaga bombers among Junya Watanabe Fair Isle blazers and Ann Demeulemeester trousers. Here, a Maison Martin Margiela coat, about $1,768, Jil Sander sweater, about $577, Comme des Garçons Homme Plus T-shirt, about $230, and Dries Van Noten pants, about $292.

headline: The Inner Pat Nixon
text: It was the vice presidency that John Nance Garner invidiously compared to a bucket of warm spit, but the role of first lady of the United States has got to be just as bad. Only Eleanor Roosevelt and Hillary Clinton notched autonomous accomplishments of historical weight, though Abigail Adams and Dolley Madison also hover in the national pantheon. Sad to say, most presidential spouses — not necessarily through any fault of their own — achieve little of lasting note. Constrained by high-stakes politics and society’s sexism, they can at best champion a safe, domestic cause like literacy or fitness before dissolving into the history books as yet another presidential helpmate.

headline: Religious Groups Offer Help to Evicted Protesters
text: A loose coalition of religious leaders from around the city, calling themselves Occupy Faith, are trying to assist the Occupy Wall Street protesters, who are now barred from sleeping overnight at Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Q. and A. With Donatella Versace on H&M Collection
text: THE Versace for H&M collection, which goes on sale in Europe today and in the United States on Saturday, has already generated enough buzz that it can qualify as a success for the designer Donatella Versace, even if she doesn’t sell a single hot-pink suit. Not that that’s likely, given the track record of such collaborations and the hype they create. Here, excerpts from a Q&A with Ms. Versace.

headline: On the Alert for Misleading Ads
text: Kevin Tuerff’s message is clear: Companies should not be making false claims about how green their products are to gain an incremental improvement in market share.

headline: Have a Little Faith?  At NYU, the Debate Rages On
text: Pascal’s wager met “American Idol” Tuesday night when a capacity crowd gathered at a New York University auditorium to vote on the resolution: “The World Would Be Better Off Without Religion.”

headline: Lunchtime in Los Angeles
text: Sprints, or even modest power walks, between press conferences will set many a belly rumbling on the first day of press previews at the Los Angeles auto show. Here, a few early birds beat the throngs to the Nissan stand on Wednesday, where a converted NV200 van dispensed grilled-cheese sandwiches.

headline: Rancho San Jose, Quelele and a Flat
text: Jennifer Calkins, a biologist who teaches at Evergreen State College in Olympia, Wash., writes from Mexico, where she is studying the ecology, behavior and evolution of the elegant quail.

headline: Extensions for ‘Desert Cities,’ ‘Hand to God,’ ‘Lughnasa,’ ‘Mountaintop’
text: Lincoln Center Theater has extended the Broadway run of “Other Desert Cities,” Jon Robin Baitz’s play about dark secrets in a wealthy Palm Springs family. Originally scheduled to run through Jan. 8, tickets are now on sale through March 25 and the run is open-ended. The show, with a cast that includes Stockard Channing, Rachel Griffiths, Stacy Keach, Judith Light and Thomas Sadoski, received mostly positive reviews when it opened earlier this month at the Booth Theater.

headline: The Life Report: Judy Eddy
text: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

headline: Romanian Film Festival Heads to Lincoln Center
text: After five years in TriBeCa, the annual Romanian Film Festival in New York is moving uptown. In a sign of expanding interest in the innovative cinema coming out of the Eastern European country, this year’s edition, which is scheduled to begin on Nov. 30 and conclude on Dec. 6, will be held at Lincoln Center, where the Film Society of Lincoln Center has signed on as a partner.

headline: Deficit Panel Urged to Resist Gimmicks
text: A progressive group in Washington is urging members of the Congressional deficit committee to resist what it calls a “siren song” from liberals and conservatives to protect their pet projects, according to a letter obtained by The Caucus.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Lebanon, Italy and the Philippines.

headline: TimesCast | Media Decoder
text: November 16, 2011 — Brian Stelter and David Carr discuss the rough handling of journalists during the clearing out of the Occupy Wall Street protesters early Monday morning.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Nov. 17
text: Black veils; an Isabel Marant t-shirt; and store 143 opens up on Ludlow Street.

headline: Coda Prices Sedan at $40,795
text: Coda Holdings said in Los Angeles Wednesday that its long-delayed battery sedan has gone into production as a 2012 model and would be sold, with a 10-year, 100,000-mile battery warranty, for a base price of $40,795, inclusive of the destination charge.

headline: Paying Tribute to a Jazz Legend, in Spanish This Time
text: In his musical career the jazz saxophonist David Murray has always been omnivorous, which helps explain why, after playing on more than 150 albums, he has finally turned his sights to the Nat King Cole repertory. But Mr. Murray’s taste can also be quirky, which is why his latest project focuses on a relatively obscure phase of Cole’s career: two albums that the singer and pianist recorded in Spanish in 1958 and 1962.

headline: Politics and Pizza
text: The pizza, it turns out, is political.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: Homes for $535,000
text: A 1781 house in the Hudson valley, a penthouse in Houston and a contemporary in Iowa city

headline: ‘Pox Parties’ in the Age of Facebook
text: The offer – for lollipops infected with chickenpox virus – appeared on Facebook last month and quickly circulated among parents who oppose vaccinating their children against diseases.

headline: Sharpening Tone, Perry Ad Takes On Obama
text: A new advertisement by Rick Perry takes a sharper tone than his previous ads, taking aim at President Obama’s comment last weekend that American businesses had been “a little bit lazy” in taking for granted that new investment would want to come to the United States.

headline: Say It With Tickets Under the Tree
text: As the recently opened “Other Desert Cities” reminds us so compellingly, the holidays are the time when families gather together, drink too much, say too much and ultimately scream too much. If you want to save the wear on your psyche — not to mention your vocal cords — why not give the gift that says it all for you? I mean theater tickets — to plays and musicals that implicitly speak the confessions, lamentations and recriminations that you wisely refrained from spilling all over the turkey and cranberries so that your loved (and not so loved) ones might eat in peace.

headline: What You Get for ... $535,000
text: HOUSTON

headline: Fun With Khrushchev in ’50s Moscow
text: You may not always belly laugh during “Iron Curtain,” but you’ll probably smile throughout. A musical comedy that delights in the pun, the groaner and the quick aside, the show is sometimes far from great. But it is consistently good. And that’s no small praise.

headline: Controlling the Message in Gaza
text: Stephen Farrell reports on Hamas and its growing use of propaganda to solidify support in Gaza.

headline: The Best of Scuttlebot
text: What the editors and reporters of The New York Times tech staff spotted on the Web:

headline: What’s the Best Way to Serve Baby Sweet Potatoes?
text: Q.

headline: TV Picks, Crowd-Sourced
text: The New York Times Fall TV Ratings Game has come and gone. Times readers who thought they knew better than the network executives which shows would succeed and which would fail submitted their fantasy lineups by Oct. 1 and predicted which shows would be cancelled first. And who can argue with them?

headline: National Book Awards Go to ‘Salvage the Bones’ and ‘Swerve’
text: 11:08 p.m. | Updated  Jesmyn Ward won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night for “Salvage the Bones,” a haunting tale of the struggles of a 15-year-old pregnant girl as a hurricane bears down on her fictional Gulf Coast town of Bois Sauvage, Miss.

headline: Former Assistant Paints a Less-Than-Flattering Picture of Paterno
text: Matt Paknis has a unique view of Penn State, its football program and former coach Joe Paterno and most of all, the child sexual abuse scandal that has enveloped all three. Paknis, 49, was a graduate assistant under Paterno for two years in the late 1980s and says that he is also a survivor of childhood abuse.

headline: An Island Adviser Sees Promise in Durban Climate Talks
text: It feels like a bit of a stretch. But Mark Lynas, the author of “The God Species” and an adviser to the leadership of the low-lying Indian Ocean nation of Maldives, swears there could be meaningful outcomes when the annual climate-treaty talks, after a bland performance in Cancún, Mexico, open in Durban, South Africa, at the end of the month.

headline: Asked & Answered | Lawrence Weschler
text: It’s hard to keep up with Lawrence Weschler. The celebrated author of over a dozen books of literary nonfiction is, in this age of self-branding, defiantly unbrandable. An artist who draws money and tries to spend his drawings; the eccentric proprietor of Los Angeles’s Museum of Jurassic Technology; the aftermath of the Yugoslav wars: this is Weschler’s idea of a beat. (Fittingly, a journal he founded some years back was called “Omnivore.”) He has devoted years of inquiry into political movements and the curious nature of artistic expression, most famously in his 1982 biography of the artist Robert Irwin, “Seeing Is Forgetting the Name of the Thing One Sees.” His newest book, “Uncanny Valley: Adventures in the Narrative” (Counterpoint Press), collects pieces, previously published in Artforum, The New Yorker, Wired and elsewhere, about such disparate subjects as digital animators and human-rights monitors, but which are connected by the kind of distinct, inimitable narrative thread only Weschler can weave. On the eve of a discussion of the book at the Open Society Institute in New York, The Moment spoke to Weschler about Richard Avedon, war films and why he was so embarrassed to discover a drawing of him by David Hockney, pictured above, in the home of a Chicago art collector.

headline: A Stone House in a Majorca Wine-Making Village
text: Residential property prices are selling 10 to 20 percent below levels reached during the height of Spain’s housing bubble.

headline: The Last of the Wicked Years, and Other New Books
text: One Broadway blockbuster and 7 1/2 million books in print later, Gregory Maguire pulls the final curtain on his Wicked Years fantasy series. For several other writers this month, questions of good and evil are far more down to earth.

headline: Voices: A Thoughtful Debate Over Inclusion
text: The issue of inclusion for special education students drew many commenters to SchoolBook, expressing a range of opinions. Most commenters took the approach that inclusion is not right for every child, and some argued that it is harmful. But others depicted inclusion as the civil rights struggle of the era. Here is a sample of the comments.

headline: At a Bronx School Where They Are Welcome, Parents Turn Out
text: Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott wants parents to get more involved in their children’s education. Parent-teacher night at one elementary school in the Bronx displays a winning formula for engaging parents: keep them in the loop, give the parent coordinator lots of responsibility and make the parents come to the conferences to see their children's report cards.

headline: House Hunting in ... Majorca
text: A STONE HOUSE IN A MAJORCA WINE-MAKING VILLAGE

headline: A French Instrument for a Piece From Paris
text: Though the American organist Jon Gillock lives in Paris, he has maintained his close association with the Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village. He returned on Tuesday to play the church’s new Manton Memorial Organ, a magnificent French-built instrument rare to New York that was dedicated in May.

headline: Adolf and Eva
text: Hitler could not have wished for a better girlfriend. In this first full-scale biography of Eva Braun, the German historian Heike B. Görtemaker examines the known sources for Braun’s life and emerges with a highly readable and consistent portrait of an ordinary woman who loved sports, fashion and jazz; and who was, without a doubt, utterly devoted to the man history has seen as “evil incarnate.”

headline: Agent Says Cuban Defector Plans to Be in Big Leagues
text: MILWAUKEE — The uncertainty associated with pursuing international free agents has been one of the recurring themes of the general managers’ meetings this week at the Pfister Hotel.

headline: Cadillac XTS: A Flagship Equipped With a Search Engine
text: Introduced on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2013 Cadillac XTS.

headline: Racewalking, but Not to London
text: OWEGO, N.Y. — After training along the country roads of this village to the south of the Finger Lakes, Erin Taylor-Talcott recently achieved a qualifying time for the 2012 Olympic trials in the 50-kilometer racewalk.

headline: It’s Not About Them. It’s About the Sad Stuff
text: I’m an instagrammer. A casual one. Not like this guy, but a garden-variety one. I was forcibly dragged into it by a tech-savvy friend. But now I’m committed. I yearn for the little hearts of collective approval. And I look at the world with fresh eyes. On my lunch break.

headline: ‘Wait Wait …’ It’s the BBC!

headline: Sleeping vs. Lying Down, and Other Murky Issues
text: The rules posted — and now enforced — at Zuccotti Park seem straightforward enough. No camping. No sleeping bags. No lying down. No bikes or skateboards or in-line skates. No engaging in “any other activities prohibited by law or statute.”

headline: Curtain Up, Light the Lights, Open the Books
text: If you like to take the easy route when doing your holiday shopping rounds — and who doesn’t? — there’s a natural choice this season for that theater lover on your list. Last year you probably snapped up and wrapped up that shiny new book of lyrics by Stephen Sondheim. This year you can do precisely the same.

headline: Cornel West to Take a Job in New York
text: Cornel West, the peripatetic public intellectual and political activist, plans to finish out a teaching career that has taken him from Yale to Harvard to Princeton by moving back this coming summer to Union Theological Seminary in the City of New York, where he began as an assistant professor in 1977.

text: A look at some of the actress’s past performances.

headline: The 3 P.M. Brunch With the 4 A.M. Vibe
text: BRUNCH, an occasion for flapjacks, Bloody Marys and meandering conversation, is traditionally the most sluggish of meals. But a smorgasbord of clubby New York restaurants have transformed lazy midday gatherings into orgies of overindulgence with blaring music, jiggling go-go dancers and bar tabs that mushroom into five figures.

headline: Kia GT, the Brand’s Rear-Drive Concept, Arrives in Los Angeles

headline: Embracing Handel’s Leaping Arias and Duets
text: The Theater of Early Music, a Canadian period-instrument and vocal ensemble led by Daniel Taylor, the countertenor, expands and contracts to suit the project at hand. Mr. Taylor brought a compact version to Weill Recital Hall for a Handel program on Tuesday, and though he was listed in the program book as both countertenor and conductor, there was no conducting to be done. When the instrumentalists had the spotlight — in trim, zesty accounts of a passacaglia (from HWV 432) and the “Giulio Cesare” Overture — Mr. Taylor left them to it.

headline: Tied to Songs of the Past, but a Nod to the Present
text: The page turner may soon go the way of the rotary phone if more pianists use iPads instead of old-fashioned paper scores, as the pianist Sam Haywood did during a recital with the violinist Joshua Bell at Carnegie Hall on Monday.

headline: Decision 2013
text: For some time the Obama administration had appeared to be signaling its likely approval of a plan to lay a high-pressure oil pipeline from Canadian tar sands right on top of the main water supply to much of the Midwest. Last week, however, after thousands of protesters — ranging from ranchers and farmers to ordinary Americans concerned about the catastrophic harm that could be done if that pipeline were to leak — surrounded the White House, the administration announced that it was delaying a decision until 2013.

headline: Hillarycare: The Sequel
text: Barack Obama achieved more significant change in domestic policy during the first two years of his presidency than any president since Richard Nixon has over the course of four or eight. That’s because in 2010 Obama signed into law the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. We don’t know how this story will end, but there’s now a law on the books that, for all its many shortcomings and unpopularity, will extend health coverage to most of this country’s uninsured. According to the Congressional Budget Office, the share of legal nonelderly residents who have health insurance will rise from 83 percent to 94 percent. Thanks to the Affordable Care Act, some unquantifiable number of people will live who would otherwise die.

headline: Ricky Gervais Will Return to Golden Globes, Despite Past Controversy
text: LOS ANGELES — The Hollywood organization behind the Golden Globe Awards will give the British comedian Ricky Gervais another chance as host despite his barbed comments that overshadowed its last ceremony. Mr. Gervais, in Twitter posts late Wednesday, indicated that he had agreed to return as the ringmaster for the Jan. 15 show, which will be telecast live.

headline: Hyundai Azera Finds Niche Between Sonata and Genesis
text: Introduced on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2012 Hyundai Azera.

headline: This World Can Be Far From Easy, and It’s Time for You to Face That Truth
text: If you have illusions about anything, Bebe Neuwirth is here to remind you in no uncertain terms that that’s what they are: illusions. Her show, “Stories With Piano #3” at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, an improved version of a brilliant act she brought to the club three years ago, might as well be called “Tough Love.”

headline: Pepper Spray and Ayn Rand Deployed Against Occupy Seattle Protesters

headline: Grover and the Giant No-Taxes Pledge
text: Polls will tell you that a majority of Americans recognize the need to raise taxes. A group of about two-dozen American millionaires have signed a letter to Congress asking for tax hikes that would affect them directly. They even sent a delegation to Washington today to make that case.

headline: Spain’s Leader Faces Debt Worries
Protesters Find Their Belongings in ‘Chaos’ at a City Garage

headline: Dodgers Sue Prime Ticket in TV Rights Dispute
text: The Los Angeles Dodgers, intent on selling their future television rights as soon as possible, filed suit against Prime Ticket, which currently carries the team’s games, for interfering in the sale process.

headline: The Place | Tee Time Meets Me Time
text: Camilo Villegas, 29, is a professional golfer whose notoriety can be attributed to both his athletic achievements and his curious public image. A fitness freak, the handsome Colombian’s hard-won physique sets him apart even among his increasingly toned competitors on the P.G.A. tour. “The muscles in Villegas’s arms are like a bas-relief when he grips the golf club,” Karen Crouse noted last year in The Times. “His tight shirts set off his boxer’s biceps.” Indeed, Villegas cuts quite the swath: he belly-flops onto the green to size up a putt, like a stalking lioness. He has posed nude for ESPN The Magazine. He color-coordinates his wristbands, hats and belts. (He’s a clotheshorse off the course, too, gushing on Twitter about the latest collection at the J. Lindeberg store in SoHo.)

headline: The School Tour: Eyes Wide Open
text: Visiting a school gives you an opportunity to see it in action.  Here are five tips from a former city teacher on how to make the walk-through most effective, so you can choose the best school for your child.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Drug for Bone Marrow Disease
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved the first drug to treat myelofibrosis, a rare but potentially life-threatening bone marrow disorder.

headline: The Designer — Retailer Union Remains Lucrative
text: Collaborations are proving to be both a reliable business model for retailers and a business in themselves.

headline: A Marriage of Economic Convenience
text: THE scene on Nov. 8 at a shopping party to preview the new Versace for H&M collection was fairly predictable, if you didn’t count the midnight concert by Prince. When the racks of gold-studded dresses and tropical-print shirts were finally unveiled, in a temporary store on a Hudson River pier, the invited fashion editors, celebrities and Nicki Minaj quickly picked them clean. “Many of the women in the crowd made beelines for the collection’s men’s clothes,” Style.com said. There was still a line outside the shop at 2:30 a.m.
