headline: Route Proposals May Ease an Oil Pipeline Bottleneck
text: OTTAWA — With the timing, and perhaps the future, of the Keystone XL pipeline project from Canada’s oil sands to the Gulf Coast now uncertain, two alternatives to the hotly contested project have begun emerging.

headline: Two Giants Rattled by Fatal Shooting in Chelsea Nightclub
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When shots rang out early Tuesday morning at the Juliet Supper Club, Victor Cruz and Chris Canty hit the floor. The two Giants, who were among a number of professional athletes at the Chelsea nightclub, said Wednesday that the experience left them reflective and considerably shaken.

headline: Open the Records at Penn State
text: The sexual abuse scandal that has engulfed Penn State is looking more and more like a cover-up, even as more potential victims step forward. Those investigating the case need to determine what university officials knew, when they knew it and what they did about allegations of sexual assault lodged against Jerry Sandusky, a former assistant football coach, in 1998 and afterward.

headline: Thursday: Something Lost in the Wash
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — This is a magical puzzle, but I didn’t realize how magical it was until after I had finished.

headline: Lawyer Outlines Methods Used by British Paper in Hacking Case
text: LONDON — A lawyer representing 51 people who say they were victims of phone hacking and press intrusion told a hearing on Wednesday that his clients and their families had been followed, spied on, threatened, harassed, vilified, blackmailed and driven to suicide attempts by a British tabloid run amok.

headline: Visa to Offer Mobile Payments in Developing Nations
text: Visa has been hard at work on a mobile digital wallet that it hopes to roll out early next year. But that’s not the only mobile market the credit card company has its eye on.

headline: Required Reading From Senator Coburn
text: Senator Tom Coburn, a Republican from Oklahoma, has once again broken with his party’s dogma, this time with a new report — “Subsidies of the Rich and Famous.” It convincingly argues that there’s real revenue to be netted to help wrestle down the deficit if Congress dared to crack down on indefensible boons for the top brackets.

headline: Sharp Decline in Revenue Is Forecast for California
text: LOS ANGELES — California’s budget problems show no signs of abating.

headline: From Shore to Forest, Projecting Effects of Climate Change
text: While the long-term outlook for grape-growers in the Finger Lakes region is favorable, it is less than optimal for skiers and other winter sports enthusiasts in the Adirondacks. Fir and spruce trees are expected to die out in the Catskills, and New York City’s backup drinking water supply may well be contaminated as a result of seawater making its way farther up the Hudson River.

headline: Old Times, Not Necessarily Good Times
text: Thickets of George Orwell’s robust prose fill the stage in Ryan Kiggell’s adaptation of “Burmese Days,” which opened on Wednesday night at 59E59 Theaters as part of the Brits Off Broadway festival. But only rarely do these relatively purple passages transcend their literary origins, despite Mr. Kiggell’s efforts to hack through the verbiage of an author still finding his voice.

headline: Something to Shoot For
text: You may have noticed that Congress is unpopular.

headline: Lunch in Zuccotti Park: Carry In, and in the Rain, Carry Out
text: As I surveyed the menu at a halal food cart, two women in jeans and scarves walked up and placed their orders. They said they worked in 1 Liberty Plaza, one of the buildings facing Zuccotti Park, but had not ventured out to buy their lunch in weeks.

headline: Mayor Urges Detroit to Accept Drastic Action to Fix Finances
text: DETROIT — In an address broadcast live on television stations across this city, Mayor Dave Bing told Detroit on Wednesday evening that its finances were in dismal shape and that without major concessions from unions, the privatizing of some city services and layoffs, Detroit would run out of money by early next year.

headline: World Cup Qualifying Set
text: The schedule for the next round of qualifying for the World Cup in the United States’ region was released. The Americans are in a four-team group with Jamaica, Guatemala and Antigua and Barbuda. The top two teams will advance to the next round. The schedule for the United States team is: June 8 versus Antigua and Barbuda, June 12 at Guatemala, Sept. 7 at Jamaica, Sept. 11 versus Jamaica, Oct. 12 at Antigua and Barbuda, and Oct. 16 versus Guatemala.

headline: Cutting Off Unesco, U.S. May Endanger Programs in Iraq and Afghanistan
text: PARIS — Some important programs affecting American interests in Iraq are at risk because of Washington’s cutoff of money to Unesco, officials of the organization say. Unesco programs in Afghanistan will also be affected, but to a lesser degree.

headline: The Face of Modern Slavery
text: Phnom Penh, Cambodia

headline: Professor of Profits
text: As a young graduate student pursuing an advanced degree in modern European history, Newt Gingrich wrote a dissertation titled “Belgian Education Policy in the Congo: 1945-1960.” Thereafter, in the course of writing 23 books, the scholar-politician pontificated on many subjects, from the pope to a “pouting sex kitten,” who appears for a quick romp in a novel about the Civil War.

headline: Majority Leader Gives Deficit Panel Wide Berth
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the powerful House majority leader, enjoys expressing his views. He travels frequently around the country selling the House Republican agenda, makes flattering YouTube videos, holds lengthy weekly news conferences and is a regular on the talk show circuit.

headline: Speaking of Blast, Iranian Describes Work on Weapons
text: The explosion last weekend in Iran that killed 17 members of the armed forces, including a founder of the country’s missile program, occurred while researchers were working on weapons capable of delivering Israel a “strong punch in the mouth” and disrupted their project by a few days, the Iranian military chief of staff said Wednesday.

headline: Gingrich’s Freddie Mac Payday
text: In a column in today’s Campaign Stops, Timothy Egan writes:

headline: China: Bus Crash Kills Students
text: Eighteen preschoolers died Wednesday when their badly overloaded school minibus was rammed head-on by a coal truck, according to the official Xinhua news agency. The bus driver and a teacher also died, and 44 children were injured. The bus — with just nine seats, according to Xinhua — had been carrying 64 people. The crash immediately generated outrage on Twitter-like microblogs, with commentators accusing the government of poorly regulating school buses. The truck driver was taken into custody, Xinhua reported.

headline: Energy Secretary to Defend Solyndra Loan to Congress
text: WASHINGTON — An unrepentant energy secretary will square off on Thursday with a Republican-led committee that has spent months arguing that his department showed political favoritism and incompetence when it approved a $535 million loan guarantee for Solyndra, a California manufacturer of solar modules that later went bankrupt.

headline: Reasonable Expectations
text: The other day, stopped at a red light in downtown New Haven, I looked up and noticed cameras pointing in all four directions of the intersection. Probably they were cameras designed to detect red-light runners. Or maybe their purpose was general surveillance. No matter – the point was that big brother was watching. Big brother, as we all have plenty of reason to believe, is watching everyone.

headline: Lee Pockriss, Songwriter Behind ‘Itsy Bitsy’ Bikini, Dies at 87
text: Lee Pockriss, who wrote the music for midcentury pop hits like “Itsy Bitsy Teenie Weenie Yellow Polka Dot Bikini,” “Catch a Falling Star” and “Johnny Angel,” died on Monday at his home in Bridgewater, Conn. He was 87.

headline: Heavy-Duty Lenses for Smartphone Cameras
text: Attachments for smartphone cameras are turning the smartphones into much more flexible tools.

headline: Irwin Schneiderman Dies at 88; Guided the City Opera
text: Irwin Schneiderman, a lawyer and a philanthropic leader who guided the New York City Opera through a decade of ups and downs, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Corrections: November 17
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Al Boeke, Architect Who Sought Ecological Harmony, Is Dead at 88
text: The Pomo Indians, who once inhabited the land, were long gone the day in 1962 when Al Boeke flew in a small plane over the pristine beaches, steep bluffs, wind-swept woods and sheep-grazed meadows along the Pacific Coast in Sonoma County, Calif., about 150 miles north of San Francisco.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,819 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Man Arrested After Video Threat
text: A man who said he planned to firebomb Macy’s was arrested on Wednesday on charges of making terrorist threats, after a video of remarks he had made at an Occupy Wall Street protest in Manhattan surfaced online.

headline: Electronics Price Predictor Is Now Mobile
text: In June, Oren Etzioni, the brains behind airline price predictor Farecast, brought forth Decide.com, a Web site that predicted the future prices of laptops, cameras and televisions. With a Wait or Buy signal, it gave you the probability prices would change or that a new model was coming.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Excruciating Stomach Pain
text: The Medical Mystery: Can you solve the case of a young man with stabbing abdominal pain and an unusual family cancer history?

headline: Accenture Calls on Clients to Help Make a Statement
text: THE Chinese have the year of the tiger. Accenture has life after Tiger.

headline: U.S. to Review Cases Seeking Deportations
text: The Department of Homeland Security will begin a review on Thursday of all deportation cases before the immigration courts and start a nationwide training program for enforcement agents and prosecuting lawyers, with the goal of speeding deportations of convicted criminals and halting those of many illegal immigrants with no criminal record.

headline: Would-Be Engineers Hit Books the Hardest, a Study Finds
text: Business majors spend less time on course work than other college students, but they devote more hours to nonschool duties, like earning money and caring for family members. In contrast, engineering students spend the most time studying and the least on outside demands.

headline: Word of the Day | seethe
text: seethe •\ˈseth\• verb

headline: District 2 Council Rejects Two Rezoning Plans
text: In a surprise move, a parent council representing much of Lower Manhattan and the Upper East Side unanimously rejected two city proposals to rezone public schools.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
text: The government published rules outlining the liability that nuclear equipment suppliers to India’s government-operated power plants would face in the case of an accident. The rules are unlikely to completely satisfy concerns of the U.S. government, which signed a landmark civilian nuclear agreement with India in 2006, and American vendors like General Electric, which have lobbied for India to exempt suppliers from liability. The new rules place a 15 billion rupee ($300 million) cap and effectively limit liability to the first five years of operation. (The Hindu)A special court in Mumbai freed seven Muslim men who were accused of planning and carrying out a series of bomb attacks in 2009 in Malegaon, a town in Maharashtra. The men, who have said they are innocent, have been in jail for five years. The case against them weakened significantly last year after a right-wing activist reportedly confessed to the crime. (Indian Express)

headline: House Approves Bill Making Travel Easier for Gun Owners
text: WASHINGTON  — The House passed legislation on Wednesday that would require states that issue concealed gun permits to recognize similar licenses from other states. The vote was 272 to 154.

headline: Illinois: Rape and Murder Convictions Vacated
text: A Cook County Circuit Court judge, noting that new DNA evidence would “probably change the result in a new trial,” on Wednesday vacated the convictions of four men in the 1994 rape and murder of Nina Glover, a prostitute whose body was found in a dumpster in Chicago. Judge Paul P. Biebel Jr. said that although the men had initially confessed in great detail, DNA recovered from semen in the victim’s body cast significant doubt on the confessions. DNA testing shortly after the murder excluded all four men. And last May, the DNA was matched to another suspect, Johnny Douglas, who had been convicted of a very similar rape and murder. The state’s attorney, Anita Alvarez, who had opposed vacating the convictions, has three options: she can appeal the ruling, retry the men — Terrill Swift, Michael Saunders, Harold Richardson and Vincent Thames — or dismiss the charges.

headline: Illinois: Chicago Budget Gets Unanimous Consent
text: The inaugural budget of Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago, which pits unpopular cuts and fees against the city’s growing fiscal crisis, won unanimous approval from all 50 aldermen on Wednesday. The $8.2 billion budget leans heavily on politically charged cost-saving measures like consolidating police and fire departments, closing mental health clinics, laying off city workers, reducing library hours and increasing some fees.

headline: NYT Front Page for 11/17/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 11/17/2011

headline: Jets at Broncos: Matchup to Watch
text: Jets (5-4) at Broncos (4-5), 8:30 p.m. Eastern Thursday

headline: ‘X Factor’ Watch: Not Quite Rocking Out
text: It was rock night Wednesday on “The X Factor,” but only one real rock star turned up: Josh Krajcik, who owned the evening with his rendition of the Foo Fighters song “The Pretender.” The performance brought all four judges to their feet and solidified Mr. Krajcik’s place as one of the top contenders.

headline: In Bihar, Turning Guns into Farm Tools
text: Blacksmith Sunil Thakur had never felt as important in his life as he did on Nov. 4, when the district police chief, an executive magistrate and a posse of junior officials visited his makeshift roadside furnace.

headline: Pakistan: U.S. Strike Is Said to Kill Taliban Militants
Pakistan: Suicide Bombing Kills 2 Police Officials
text: Two police officials were killed in a suicide bomb attack late Wednesday night when three people, including a woman, blew up their vehicle during a police chase in the southern port city of Karachi, according to police and government officials. The bombers were driving in an upscale neighborhood when the police tried to stop them, leading to the chase. The police said they were unsure whom the bombers had meant to attack. Karachi has a history of ethnic, sectarian and militant-related violence.

headline: Nuclear Watchdog Seeks Mission to Iran
text: LONDON — Adding new pressures on Tehran over its disputed nuclear program, the head of the United Nations nuclear watchdog group said Thursday that he wanted to send a high-level mission to Iran to investigate a report by his agency that Iranian scientists had engaged in secret and possibly continuing efforts to construct a nuclear weapon.

headline: Nov. 17, 1973 | Nixon Declares ‘I Am Not a Crook’
text: On Nov. 17, 1973, President Richard M. Nixon held a news conference before Associated Press managing editors in Orlando, Fla., in which he defended himself against a number of allegations. Most of the questions related to the Watergate break-in, which had become even more of a scandal a month earlier with the “Saturday Night Massacre.” Other questions focused on reports that he had cheated on his tax returns.

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 17, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Reading About Recent Exhibits in the Art & Design Section
text: Note: This edition of 6 Q’s About the News uses several recent Times articles about art and design. Each question links to the article in which an answer can be found.

headline: Why Not Break Up Citigroup?
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: The Fracturing of Pennsylvania
text: Amwell Township is a 44-square-mile plot of steep ravines and grassy pasturelands planted with alfalfa, trefoil and timothy in the southwestern corner of Pennsylvania. It’s home to some 4,000 people, most of whom live in villages named Amity, Lone Pine and Prosperity.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 17, 2011
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Joe Frazier, Ex-Heavyweight Champ, Dies at 67.”

headline: How They Move Your Whole House
text: FOR anyone who has ever suffered through the agony of a move (towers of boxes, miles of packing tape, untold numbers of annoyed friends), it seems like the ideal solution: just take the whole darn house, beds and all, and plop it in another location.

headline: What Do You Read, and How Do You Read It?
text: We recently did a post on “the future of reading” about how books and reading habits are changing because of technology. What kinds of things do you read in an average day, and how do you read them? For instance, do you read novels you find at bookstores or libraries, or do you buy and read them on an e-reader? Do you read news or follow current events about a hobby or interest? If so, do you do so mostly on your computer or phone, or in print? Do you often follow links on social networks like Facebook or Twitter? How would you characterize the kinds of things you read that way?

headline: Branson’s Empire to Buy Bank Owned by Britain
text: LONDON — The British government agreed on Thursday to sell Northern Rock, the lender it nationalized more than three years ago, to Virgin Money, which is controlled by Richard Branson, in a deal that represents a loss for Britain’s taxpayers.

headline: The Early Word: China
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: ‘Confrontations’ Abound at Outdoor Art Show in Prague
text: Expect to be confronted with the unexpected at an open-air exhibition in Prague with the appropriate title of “Confrontations.” Jaroslav Andel, the artistic director at DOX Center for Contemporary Art created the show, which takes inspiration from an older Czech art form: the pairing of contrasting images. The exhibition runs Nov. 18 to 26 on the plaza between the National and Nova Scena theaters.

headline: Sneak Peek at Our Great Performers Shoot
text: Here’s a behind-the-scenes peek at the filming last week of one of the videos for our annual presentation of original films starring the actors who gave the year’s most memorable performances. This year’s concept is supercool, and our director is having wicked fun with it. The films will make their premiere online in advance of a corresponding portfolio of photographs in the Dec. 11 issue of the magazine.

headline: Week 11 N.F.L. Game Probabilities, and the Tebow Factor
text: Tim Tebow is breaking the game probability model. How can a quarterback lead his team to victory while going 2 for 8, for 69 total passing yards? It’s widely accepted that passing efficiency is the main driver of team success, but what if an astounding 8.6 yards per attempt comes on only two completions?

headline: Part 4: Answers to Your Questions on Scholarships and Student Loans
text: To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them — as well as to further their understanding of President Obama’s recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans — Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is spending this week in our virtual Guidance Office. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of “Secrets to Winning a Scholarship,” published in February.

headline: Arab League Offers Syria a Reprieve as Deaths Mount
text: RABAT, Morocco — In what amounted to a surprise reprieve, the Arab League offered to send civilian and military monitors to Syria on Wednesday to determine whether it was abiding by a league-brokered peace plan to end the crackdown on the country’s eight-month uprising. The move countered the league’s startling decision five days earlier to suspend Syria.

headline: Billions Lost by Olympus May Be Tied to Criminals
text: TOKYO — Japanese officials say that at least $4.9 billion is unaccounted for in a financial scandal at Olympus and are investigating whether much of that money went to companies with links to organized crime.

headline: Dear Dr. Mallya, Sir Richard Is On the Line
text: A lion-maned airline baron with a voracious appetite for publicity, love of fast cars and a bevy of beautiful, red-skirted female employees was suddenly under fire.

headline: Engineering Majors Most Likely to Burn the Midnight Oil
text: Students who major in engineering and the physical sciences can expect to spend more hours in the library than those who take a concentration of courses in business and social sciences, according to a national survey of more than 400,000 undergraduates at nearly 700 colleges and universities.

headline: Obama Addresses Troops at Final Stop in Australia
text: DARWIN, Australia — Fresh from announcing an expanded American military presence in Australia, a plan that has angered China, President Obama came to this remote northern town that will be the base of operations and told American and Australian troops it is “the perfect place.”

headline: Is It Improper to Turn Thanksgiving Into a Potluck? And How Do I Tell My Guests?
text: Q.

headline: Bringing the Tasting Room to the Living Room
text: Using a technology that sounds more NASA than Napa, TastingRoom.com “reformats” wines from their original retail packaging into 50- and 100-milliliter, single-serving bottles. Technicians re-pour some 1,000 varieties of wine inside an oxygen- and particle-free Plexiglas clean room, which is 40 feet long and protected from contamination by a pair of airlocks, similar to the entry and exit vestibules on a spacecraft. Tiny bottles mean consumers can sample high-quality individual wines without committing to buy a traditional 750-milliliter bottle of each one.

headline: Storybook Ballerina’s True-Life Adventure
text: IN the fall of 1976 “A Very Young Dancer” leaped into the imaginations of a generation of little girls. This children’s book by the photographer Jill Krementz chronicled the day-to-day life of a 10-year-old student from the School of American Ballet, following her to class and through her starring role as Marie in New York City Ballet’s “Nutcracker,” for which she was handpicked by George Balanchine himself. (“George Balanchine’s Nutcracker,” performed by City Ballet, begins its 57th season on Friday at the Koch Theater.)

headline: A Radical Rethinking of Thanksgiving Leftovers
text: Everyone (yes, literally) says that leftovers are “the best part of Thanksgiving,” but I’m not psyched for dry meat on bread with a ton of mayonnaise, or even that exotic alternative, cranberry sauce.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: App Design and Cloud Work
text: In this week’s podcast, we ask how you convert a popular 1,200-page travel guide into an interactive iPad app. As the latest edition of “1,000 Places to See Before You Die” arrives in stores this week, its author,  Patricia Schultz — along with David Link and Joe McCambley of the Wonderfactory digital design studio — discuss how they created the book’s companion app.

headline: Long Past Knocking Heads, Nightstick Now Kneads Bread Instead
text: Harry Rosenblum spent a recent afternoon rolling out dough to make egg noodles at the Brooklyn Kitchen, a food emporium he owns in Williamsburg.

headline: Commodities Lead a Downward Trend
text: Stocks and commodities slid on Thursday and the euro erased an earlier gain as concern grew that Europe’s debt crisis would worsen and lawmakers would fail to agree on plans to cut the American deficit.

headline: A Phone App for Switching Out Your Light Bulbs
text: How many mobile-phone apps does it take to change a light bulb?

headline: Republican Ads Turn More Aggressive
text: As the Republican presidential candidates begin to turn their attention to the airwaves in the final six weeks before voting begins, two strategies are starting to become clear.

headline: Gadgetwise: Electronics Price Predictor Is Now Mobile
text: In June, Oren Etzioni, the brains behind the airline price predictor site Farecast, brought forth Decide.com, a Web site that predicted the future prices of laptops, cameras and televisions. With a Wait or Buy signal, it gave you the probability that prices would change or that a new model was coming. There was one flaw with it. You need this information in the store as much as at home or in the office on your PC. The company promised a mobile app and it is now in the Apple App store.

headline: Media Decoder: Google Opens a Digital Music Store
text: Looking to extend its reach as a hub for entertainment and social networking, Google introduced a set of music features on Wednesday, including a download store to compete with iTunes.

headline: Which Pitcher Should the Yankees Sign?
text: Mark Buerhle, C.J. Wilson and Edwin Jackson are free agents. John Danks, James Shields, Gio Gonzalez, Gavin Floyd and Wandy Rodriguez could be available through a trade. Does the Yankees’ rotation need one of these guys (and if so, who)?

headline: Edward, You May Now Bite the Bride
text: Dawn isn’t the only thing that gets broken in “The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn — Part I,” the latest and best of the movies about a girl, her vampire and their impossible, ridiculously appealing — yes, I surrendered — love story. Marked by a canny mix of violence and chastity, the franchise has always had plenty of broken heads to go along with its pure thoughts, but here it also features a marital bed reduced to kindling after a rough night. If that doesn’t sound like the series that has kept millions of prepubescent viewers virtuously rapt, you’re right. But little Bella is all grown up now, and while Edward is still more zomboid than juicily predatory, this time not everything else on screen is dead too.

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 17
text: The National Book Awards were announced Wednesday night at Cipriani Wall Street, and Julie Bosman reports in ArtsBeat that the winner for fiction was Jesmyn Ward for “Salvage the Bones,” from Bloomsbury, a novel about a Gulf Coast family’s preparations as a hurricane bears down.

headline: Scheduling Chaos at Another Queens High School
text: In the news, a new Queens high school is in a state of confusion over scheduling, with students experiencing changes to their day as many as 10 times since the school year started, Gotham Schools reports.  The principal of Queens Metropolitan High School said she had been working night and day to try to clear up the mess.

headline: Clashes and More Than 240 Arrests on Protest’s ‘Day of Action’
text: Two months after it began in New York, Occupy Wall Street carried out a “Day of Action” on Thursday featuring an attempt to delay the opening of the New York Stock Exchange, demonstrations on the subways, a sit-in in the roadway at the base of the Brooklyn Bridge and unscheduled clashes with the police in Zuccotti Park that left a protester with a bloodied face and an officer with a lacerated hand.

headline: Default, Inflation, the Blooey Factor, and the Rubicon Effect
text: Antonia Fatas has a thoughtful post questioning whether the lack of one’s oneown currency really matters; he writes,

headline: Gingrich on Defensive Over Freddie Mac Fees
text: For roughly six years, Newt Gingrich worked closely with high-level officials at the government-sponsored mortgage company Freddie Mac. As a highly paid consultant, he coached them on how to win over the conservatives who consider their company an anathema, spoke to their political action committee and offered general advice as they worked to stave off various threats to Freddie Mac’s survival, several people familiar with his role there said on Wednesday.

headline: A Silicon Valley Dream Grows in Guatemala
text: For now, it is just a single brick building in Guatemala City called Campus Tecnológico, with workspaces, programming classes and eco-friendly signs asking people to turn off lights in unused bathrooms. But Damien Cave reports in The New York Times that the developers’ goal is to turn this five- or six-block area in the city’s center into an entrepreneurial campus and a residential outpost for the hip, savvy, successful and young.

headline: Is It Safe to Cook a Reagan-Era Frozen Turkey?
text: Q.

headline: Subsiding Inflation
text: Calculated Risk informs us that key measures of inflation have subsided. Still no hyperinflation by 2010.

headline: Opinion Report: Before It’s Too Late
text: From the editorial page

headline: Welcome to the News Business, Ms. Clinton
text: If ever a development was bound to create jealousy and an urge to ridicule, it was the announcement the other day that Chelsea Clinton started working at NBC News as a special correspondent. She had to be the most untrained and least experienced new hire by a major network since, oh, since NBC in 2009 made Jenna Bush Hager, another presidential daughter with questionable credentials, a correspondent on its “Today” show.

headline: Thursday Reading: An App To Help You Find Better Lightbulbs
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: A Day of Protest, and Arrests
text: Two days after the Occupy Wall Street encampment was cleared at Zuccotti Park, demonstrators held a “day of action’ in New York, resulting in more than 175 arrests.

headline: Lawyer Resigns After Liu Asks Him to Suspend an Internal Fund-Raising Review
text: Updated, 9:25 p.m.|The former state attorney general hired last month by City Comptroller John C. Liu’s campaign to conduct an internal review of its fund-raising practices resigned on Thursday, a day after a federal inquiry focused on Mr. Liu led to criminal charges against one of his fund-raisers.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: With MF Global Money Still Missing, Suspicions Grow  |  Nearly three weeks after $600 million in customer money went missing from MF Global, the search for the cash has been hampered by the bankrupt brokerage firm’s sloppy record-keeping, an increasingly worrisome situation that has left regulators frustrated and customers in the lurch.

headline: Timely | Reel People
text: The artist and filmmaker Meredith Danluck and the director of photography Jake Burghart met while working on “Garbage Island,” a documentary about the North Pacific Gyre for Vice magazine’s Web site.

headline: Not All Rivers Reach the Sea
text: When the conservation writer Jonathan Waterman decided to investigate the health of the Colorado River, he took it to extremes. In the spring of 2008, he packed up his supplies and set out on a 1,450-mile source-to-sea journey down the Colorado River.

headline: Gingrich May Have Unlikely Ally in Obama on Lobbying
text: Newt Gingrich explains away his work for the Freddie Mac mortgage giant by insisting on the rather fine distinction that he was never, officially, a registered lobbyist.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Poetry Foundation: It’s only a week away, folks. Time to start summoning that kitchen magic. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Star Manager Giving Up Legg Mason Fund
text: Bill Miller, a legendary mutual fund manager, said Thursday he was stepping down from the Legg Mason fund that had long made him a star on Wall Street until the volatile years after 2006 brought his fund and his stellar track record hurtling to earth.

headline: The Big Sleazy
text: For the third time in 16 years, the Supreme Court is taking up the question of why prosecutors in New Orleans seem to have so much trouble with the law. Smith v. Cain, a case heard last week, outlines truly shocking misdeeds going back decades. And an article in The Times-Picayune makes clear that problems continue.

headline: The Place | Florida, Part Five
text: MIAMI BEATS

headline: On Our Radar: Arguments Fly at Hearing on Fracking
text: More than 850 people pack a middle school auditorium in Dansville, N.Y., to express their views on the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation’s proposed rules for natural gas drilling in the Marcellus Shale. [The Buffalo News]

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘To My Dear and Loving Husband’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches Anne Bradstreet’s ‘To My Dear and Loving Husband” with a Metro column about a husband whose wife recently died.

headline: FARC Forever?
text: BOGOTÁ — On Nov. 4, after years of military raids and a number of near-misses, Colombian troops killed the 63-year-old Guillermo León Sáenz, a k a Alfonso Cano, the commander of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC. President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia called this “the biggest blow” to the Marxist group in its 47-year history.

headline: Words of a Euro Doomsayer Have New Resonance
text: LONDON — The euro zone was crumbling, just as he had long predicted, yet Bernard Connolly, Europe’s most persistent prophet of doom, still faced a skeptical audience.

headline: ‘End of the Rainbow’ Finds a Broadway Home
text: “End of the Rainbow,” a hit London drama-with-music about Judy Garland’s final months, will play in New York this spring at the Belasco Theater, one of the last Broadway houses to announce its booking for the coming theater season. The show’s producers announced on Thursday that its star, the British actress Tracie Bennett, who received critical praise for the West End production, will be joined on Broadway by Michael Cumpsty (the 2008 revival of “Sunday in the Park With George”) as her gay pianist, Anthony; Tom Pelphrey (a daytime Emmy Award winner on “Guiding Light”) as her young fiancé, Mickey; and Jay Russell in various other roles. Written by Peter Quilter and directed by Terry Johnson (a Tony Award winner in 2010 for “La Cage aux Folles”), “End of the Rainbow” will begin preview performances on March 19; the show will open on April 2 instead of the previously announced April 3.

headline: How Do We Define Bullying?
text: Does it matter that we can’t define bullying if we know it when we see it?

headline: A Fair A.T.M. Fee? Many Consumers Say ‘Zero’
text: As the events of the last couple of months have shown, Americans do not like to pay bank fees. Indeed, a new survey shows, a majority think the only acceptable A.T.M. fee is no fee at all.

headline: Lens: Klaus Pinchler’s Museum
text: Lens: Klaus Pinchler’s Museum

headline: Jets Defender Improves With Help From Revis
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — After dressing for practices in a lonely corner as a rookie, Kyle Wilson became Darrelle Revis’s neighbor in the Jets’ locker room this year, apparently because Revis insisted on it. Time to move onto the block, Revis told Wilson with a smile.

headline: Day 2: Inside MF Global’s Bankruptcy Hearing
text: A proposal to make cash distributions to MF Global customers was the focus of a hearing on Thursday at the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan. DealBook provided live coverage of the proceedings.

headline: Guess Where This Is
text: It’s time again for our weekly contest: guess the location of the photograph above.

headline: Pairings for Day 2 of the Presidents Cup
text: The United States team leads the International team, 4-2, after the first-round matches at the Presidents Cup in Melbourne, Australia. Despite a surprising rout of Tiger Woods and Steve Stricker by Adam Scott and K. J. Choi, the Americans put on an impressive show, particularly by two Presidents Cup rookies, Bubba Watson and Webb Simpson, who teamed up to beat Ernie Els and Ryo Ishikawa, 4 and 2. Concerns about the weather led officials to move up tee times for the second round by two hours to 9:35 a.m. local time, which is 5:35 p.m. Thursday in the Eastern time zone. Here are the pairings for the fourball matches.

headline: U.N. Court in Cambodia Recommends Freeing Defendant Ill With Dementia
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — A tribunal backed by the United Nations that is trying top leaders of the Khmer Rouge announced on Thursday that a sister-in-law of the regime’s former leader, Pol Pot, was unfit to stand trial and should be released because she suffers from dementia.

headline: How Far in Advance Can I Buy a Fresh Turkey?
text: Q.

headline: 36 Hours in Santa Barbara
text: Over the past few years, the city has made room for a new downtown scene humming with cool shops and laid-back wine bars.

headline: Eritrean National Team Heads Home Intact
text: KIGALI, Rwanda — The Eritrea national soccer team might have been knocked out of 2014 World Cup qualification after its 3-1 defeat to Rwanda in Kigali on Tuesday, but the team’s management scored a small victory of sorts.

headline: No Basketball, Fewer Bar Customers
text: The players are locked out. The fans are depressed. And now the N.B.A. stalemate has claimed a whole new class of victims: New York’s bar owners, who say they’re losing as much as a third of their revenue because sports fans and tourists aren’t showing up to watch games.

headline: TV Picks, Crowd-Sourced
text: The New York Times Fall TV Ratings Game has come and gone. Times readers who thought they knew better than the network executives which shows would succeed and which would fail submitted their fantasy lineups by Oct. 1 and predicted which shows would be cancelled first. And who can argue with them?

headline: Newly Surfaced Tagore Manuscript Up for Auction
text: A previously unknown manuscript by the Nobel Prize-winning poet and artist Rabindranath Tagore is being sold at Sotheby’s in New York on Dec. 13.

headline: 36 Hours in Santa Barbara, Calif.
text: RECOMMENDATIONS about what to do in Santa Barbara invariably include references to the celebrities who have settled along this beautiful stretch of California’s central coast. Want to take an afternoon hike? Head into the hills near Oprah’s house. Looking for a place to eat? Try the taqueria that Julia Child adored. Just 100 miles north of Los Angeles, this quiet beach community has long been a hideaway for celebrity heavyweights. But over the past few years, the city has also made room for a new downtown scene humming with cool shops and laid-back wine bars, mobile food trucks and casual restaurants. It’s Santa Barbara for every budget — whether you debarked from a private jet at the city’s new $63 million airport terminal or cruised into town off Highway 101.

headline: Protests Illustrate Dire Economic Anxiety, Bloomberg Says
text: As Occupy Wall Street protesters massed in Lower Manhattan on Thursday morning, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was in Midtown, telling an audience of business leaders that the protests were a dire sign of the public’s economic fears.

headline: Can’t Anybody Here Play These Games?
text: The sports world has been positively prolific in producing villains these days. They seem to roll off the assembly line daily now. Penn State, of course, has created a category all its own, but the field around them is crowded with Tiger Woods and Michael Vick; the N.B.A., which occupies the unique position of having a fight where no one is rooting for either side; the still-screwing-things-up Red Sox.

headline: How LaMichael James Got Back Into the Heisman Conversation
text: LaMichael James edged his way back into the Heisman Trophy race in much the same way that the Oregon Ducks regained their standing in the B.C.S. championship conversation: through a perfect mix of stellar play and unforeseen stumbles from other contenders.

headline: Hearty Holiday Main Courses for Vegans
text: While vegetarian diners are happy to fill their plates with Thanksgiving side dishes, many chefs still want to serve their non-turkey-eating guests a substitute for the meaty main course.

headline: Online Advertising Group Hires New Chief
text: The Network Advertising Initiative, a group promoting self-regulation in online advertising, announced on Thursday that Marc Groman, the chief privacy officer for the Federal Trade Commission, would become the organization’s next executive director and general counsel.

headline: New albums from Drake, Romeo Santos and The Fall
text: This week: Jon Caramanica on Drake; Larry Rohter on Romeo Santos; and reviews of new releases by Caveman, Los Campesinos! and the Fall. Ben Ratliff is the host.

headline: Paprika, a Recipe App That Lets You Get Organized
text: Over in the Tech department, The Times’s App Smart columnist, Bob Tedeschi, has a roundup of food-related apps.

headline: With New M5, BMW Finds Itself on the Redemption Trail
text: LOS ANGELES — The M5 badge has been around since 1988. By some automakers’ standards, the intervening 23 years would be pretext to make the fifth-generation M5, which was introduced to a North American audience on Wednesday here — and to the world at the Frankfurt auto show in September — something of a throwback.

headline: Angie’s List Soars, But Delphi Disappoints
text: For the initial public offerings market, it’s still a tale of the haves and the have-nots.

headline: France Nouveau
text: Most foreigners who come to the south of France think of Marseille as an exit or entry point. It’s convenient, only an hour’s drive from Avignon and the hill towns of the Vaucluse and so many other lovely places in Provence. In Marseille’s small airport, you buy a 1 euro cup of machine coffee and you get on a plane headed for Paris or home, your mind filled with one version of France: idyllic little towns with churches and castles, lush green valleys, fruit trees in serried ranks, Provençal linens, village markets, antiques, lace, espadrilles, vineyards, lavender, handcrafted pâtés, local wines, artisanal goat cheese.

headline: Interview With Scott Bateman
text: Scott Bateman, Ph.D. student at the University of Saskatchewan showed this poster at the HCIR research conference at Google in October.

headline: Design Unveiled for Tower at Atlantic Yards
text: The developer Bruce C. Ratner unveiled the design Thursday for what would be the world’s tallest prefabricated steel structure, a 32-story residential building in Brooklyn at the corner of Flatbush Avenue and Dean Street in the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project.

headline: Zombiegate!
text: Every week, when The New York Times Book Review goes live on our Web site, Twitter lights up with links and opinions about its contents. But when Glen Duncan’s review of Colson Whitehead’s new zombie novel, “Zone One,” appeared a few weeks ago, the response was heavier — and harsher — than usual. Mr. Duncan, like Mr. Whitehead, is a highly literary prose stylist who ventured into supernatural territory with his well-received last novel (“The Last Werewolf”), and his thoughts on genre touched a nerve. We asked him if he wanted to clarify his review or reply to his critics; his response is below. — The Editors

headline: The Life Report: D.R.G.
text: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

headline: Coda and General Electric, Joined at the Power Cord
text: LOS ANGELES — GE Energy announced Wednesday evening that its 240-volt wall-mounted WattStation electric vehicle charging unit would be official equipment for the coming Coda E.V.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Leeds Radio
text: A Williamsburg electronics shop, one of the oldest in the country, carries hundreds of thousands of analog electronic parts, all manufactured before 1968.

headline: A Canceled Meeting Between Cain and a Newspaper
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Has the usually gregarious Herman Cain become camera-shy and taciturn, at least when it comes to meeting with newspaper editorial boards? It might seem that way. On Thursday, Mr. Cain, back in this early voting state for the first time since early October, was scheduled to meet with The Union Leader of New Hampshire for a one-hour question-and-answer session that would be videotaped for the paper’s Web site.

headline: Daily Report: Voting With an iPad
text: The spread of the iPad beyond the consumer market to business is one of the most noteworthy trends of the year. The device has also found advocates among educators and, in many remarkable ways, among the disabled. Katharine Q. Seelye, a New York Times reporter, reports that Oregon became the first state in the country to use iPads to allow people with disabilities to vote, and it intends to use them again for another election in January. Several other states are expected to follow suit with iPads or other tablets, possibly as early as for next year’s presidential election.

headline: Pajama Caper
text: It’s nice to see that Kinsey Millhone hasn’t grown cynical (or, worse yet, mellowed) since she took on her initial case almost 30 years ago in Sue Grafton’s first alphabet mystery. In V IS FOR VENGEANCE (Marian Wood/Putnam, $27.95), the California private eye is still so hard-nosed about upholding the law that she gets a buzz from turning in a respectable-looking woman who’s boosting silk pajamas from the lingerie department at Nordstrom’s. But when the humiliated thief dives off a 400-foot-high bridge, apparently a suicide, Kinsey regrets her superior attitude and goes to work for the woman’s fiancé, trying to track down her criminal associates and find out who might have helped her off that bridge.

headline: Smiling at the Old Days, and the Ones Still Ahead
text: FORGET her signature song, “Memory.” Elaine Paige’s real signature is her laugh: deep, throaty, suggestive of indiscreet and dishy stories to come: Heh-heh-heh-heh. A little bit of a tease, that laugh; getting dirt — even nice, sweet who-you-going-out-with-these-days dirt — from the first lady of British musical comedy, now featured in the Broadway revival of “Follies,” is at first a bit of a slog.

headline: ‘Life’s a Happy Song’
text: Bret McKenzie and Kermit the Frog sing a song from the coming movie “The Muppets.”

headline: Not Two Words, but One; Trust Becomes an Issue
text: A decade after 9/11, and nine years after a the New York Police Department created a unit devoted to understanding terrorism and working against it, the Police Department has decided on a name change.

headline: Return of ‘The Munsters’? Maybe.
text: Though no clamor for a comeback had been heard, “The Munsters” may be returning to television.

headline: House Leaders Plan Facebook Hackathon
text: While House Republican and Democratic leaders are finding it difficult to agree on spending cuts, they are coming together next month for Capitol Hill’s first-ever Facebook Hackathon. The goal is to find new ways to use the social network to make information about the legislative process more transparent and to help members of the public more easily engage with lawmakers.

headline: Cat-and-Mole Games on the Mexican Border
text: Authorities in San Diego and Tijuana, Mexico, trumpeted the news this week that they had seized more than 17 tons of marijuana and closed down a tunnel used to smuggle drugs under the border between the two countries.

headline: Armed Groups Are on Rise in Syria, as Are Civil War Fears
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For the second day in a row, deserters from the Syrian Army carried out attacks on symbols of the Assad government’s centers of power, targeting the youth offices of the ruling Baath Party on Thursday after firing rocket-propelled grenades on a military intelligence base on Wednesday, activists said.

headline: Battles Begin Early for Female Recruits in Afghan Army
text: Zainab is a cadet at the female Officer Candidate School called Malalai Company at the Kabul Military Training Center, roughly eight miles east of the capital. She sat on her bed at the female barracks on a recent day being comforted by two other female cadets. She said she did not feel well because two days before, her fiancé had threatened her with knife and told her he would kill her if she did not leave the Army.

headline: On Composing for Kermit the Frog
text: Before we get to the Flight of the Conchords or the tricky art of writing funny songs for beloved puppets to sing, we need to talk about Figwit. Because should you enter “Bret McKen­zie” into Google, you’ll find that the first suggested search is not, say, “Bret McKenzie Conchords” or even “Bret McKenzie Muppets” but “Bret McKenzie Lord of the Rings.” Intrigued, you will investigate further. And you will learn that McKenzie, a native New Zealander, had a three-second role as a nameless elf in “Lord of the Rings: Fellowship of the Ring” in 2001. (His father, Peter McKenzie, is a part-time actor who played a larger role in the film, as the human Elendil.) Furthermore, a sharp-eyed Israeli woman spotted the then-not-famous McKenzie and, smitten by his elfin beauty, dubbed him Figwit. (It’s an acronym for Frodo Is Great . . . Who Is That?!?? which she claims is a more or less accurate transcription of her original reaction to seeing the elf.) This woman then established a Web site, Figwitlives.net, dedicated to all things Figwittian. There were local news stories. There were roving bands of Tolkienites that trailed McKenzie to Conchords shows. There was even a tongue-in-cheek documentary created in part by McKenzie’s girlfriend (now his wife), Hannah Clarke, which contains this quote from Ian McKellen when asked about Figwit: “I do remember there were some very attractive young girls. Which one was he?” McKenzie explains the Figwit phenomenon like this: “My brother was also an extra. Basically all tall and skinny New Zealanders were elves in the film.”

headline: What’s a Good Entree for a Vegan/Vegetarian Thanksgiving?
text: Q.

headline: Reuters Will No Longer Let Reporter Who Worked for Saleh Cover Yemen
text: 3:41 p.m. | Updated  The Reuters news agency on Thursday defended the work of one of its Yemen correspondents amid outrage from opposition activists over his employment by the government as a personal translator to President Ali Abdullah Saleh.

headline: Getting the Message Across to Your Employees
text: How do you get your employees to think like you? During a recent meeting of our business group, Alexandra Mayzler raised that question as she weighs expanding her business, Thinking Caps Tutoring, into new markets. Thinking Caps currently has locations in New York City and Austin, Tex. Ms. Mayzler is considering opening a Houston outpost,but said she wants to be sure systems are in place before taking the plunge.

headline: Tracing the History of the Pilgrims
text: Walking in the footsteps of America’s first settlers, from English farmlands to the urban streets of the Netherlands.

headline: Excerpt: 'Private Lives' on Broadway
text: Paul Gross and Kim Cattrall in the Broadway revival of Noel Coward’s “Private Lives,” at the Music Box Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: A Haven for Lovers of the Analog
text: WHEN an insurance company declared the merchandise at Leeds Radio “not pilferable” last year, it meant that the store’s hundreds of thousands of analog electronic parts — all manufactured before 1968 — were unlikely to be stolen anytime soon.

headline: An Edge in Science Among the Foreign-Born
text: I’ve previously written about the wage advantage — as well as the simple likelihood of finding and holding onto a job — that comes with a bachelor’s degree in science, technology, engineering or math.

headline: Without Fanfare, Belichick and Brady Become Top Coach-Quarterback Combination
text: An under-reported story line from last Sunday’s Jets-Patriots game was that Bill Belichick and Tom Brady became the winningest head coach-quarterback tandem of the Super Bowl era (since 1966). They registered their 117th regular-season victory to move past Don Shula and Dan Marino, who totaled 116 for the Miami Dolphins from 1983-95.

headline: Protesters Shutting Down the Subway? Depends on What You Watch
text: Much of what is said on television about the Occupy Wall Street movement is opinion. Some is factual. And sometimes, it’s hard to tell the difference.

headline: Now Showing | ‘Eames: The Architect and the Painter’
text: More than any other American designers, Charles and Ray Eames helped define the postwar Modernist aesthetic. Their furniture filled houses, offices and airport terminals. Their films, like “Powers of Ten,” (video) made us think about big questions and small in new ways. Their “information overload” approach produced multiscreen installations, like “Glimpses of the USA,” for the National Exhibition in Moscow in 1959 and their I.B.M. Pavilion at the 1964 World’s Fair in New York, which foreshadowed the way information is presented on the Internet. And their work was presented with an artistry that made it look effortless. Of course, it wasn’t.

headline: Among Compact Crossovers, ‘Best in Class’ Proves a Highly Contentious Title
text: LOS ANGELES — At the unveiling of the Mazda CX-5 on Wednesday, the automaker promised press conference attendees that the new small crossover would deliver “best-in-class fuel mileage.”

headline: Euro Debt Worries Shift to Spain and France
text: PARIS — Italy, the third-largest economy of the euro bloc, has spent days struggling in the market spotlight. On Thursday, however, investors turned their attention to the No. 2, France, and No. 4, Spain, whose borrowing costs spiked during the day.

headline: Mushroom Magic
text: Hedgehogs, fairy clubs, hawk’s wings and candy caps: these are just a gladeful of the fungal eruptions that have captivated Eugenia Bone, the intrepid — when not encountering grizzly bears — author of one of the most beguiling books I’ve read this year. A generous sprinkling of amateur photos only adds to the charm of “Mycophilia.” I was especially taken by a black-and-white snapshot of 30 sturdily dressed mycophiles trotting briskly en masse across a field, heading toward the day’s quarry: delectable, hard-to-find morels. Some morel-pickers, Bone informs us, carry extremely tiny baskets — because they don’t want to alert the mushrooms to their intentions.

headline: TimesCast | November 17, 2011
text: Occupy Wall Street protesters clash with the police while trying to reach the New York Stock Exchange; and a Pennsylvania town becomes a focal point in the contentious fracking debate.

headline: Food Truck Fight Shifts to SoHo
text: The long-simmering feud between merchants and mobile food carts on the sidewalks — as well as food trucks established on the street — has boiled over once again, this time in SoHo. At a Community Board 2 dustup on Monday night, first reported on Thursday by DNAinfo.com, residents and merchants blamed the city for lax enforcement of the laws governing street vendors.

headline: Don DeLillo and the Varieties of American Unease
text: The older you get, the more jarring it can be to turn on the news and behold newly minted pundits sounding off on the import of dramatic changes rocking the nation — pundits who look as if they’re barely out of high school. How do these youthful commentators come by their rapid-fire insights? Does somebody tweet them their lines? Is there a meme? Don DeLillo takes this sense of generational perplexity one absurdist step further in “Hammer and Sickle,” the longest of the nine excellent stories in “The Angel Esmeralda,” the first collection of his short fiction.

headline: Tanglewood Planning a Trip Down Memory Lane
text: A vivid purple and pink sunset dissolved into night while bright lamps blazed inside a vast tent as the Boston Symphony Orchestra began playing Beethoven’s “Leonore” Overture No. 3 before 5,000 people. The date was Aug. 5, 1937, and it was the orchestra’s first concert at an estate known as Tanglewood. Next July 6, 75 years later, the Boston Symphony will reproduce the program (which included Beethoven’s symphonies No. 5 and 6) during the latest version of the Tanglewood Music Festival, the orchestra said on Thursday. The festival runs from June 22 to Sept. 2.

headline: Week 11 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Subaru BRZ Concept STI Breaks Loose From All-Wheel-Drive Template
text: Introduced on Wednesday, Nov. 16: Subaru BRZ Concept STI

headline: Panel Hears Defense of Loan to Solyndra
text: WASHINGTON — The bankruptcy of Solyndra, the solar power company that took $528 million in government loans, was “extremely unfortunate,” Steven Chu, the energy secretary, told lawmakers on Thursday. But he rejected a suggestion put forward by a Republican that he or his department should apologize.

headline: How to Make Creamy Mashed Potatoes
text: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to make rich mashed potatoes without lumps.

headline: A Mother’s Fight for Newborn Hearts
text: As a pediatric cardiologist, I had grown increasingly concerned over the years about the many seemingly healthy newborns who left the hospital, only to return a few hours or days later in shock as a result of undetected heart problems. Two years ago, I wrote about the problem on the Well blog in an article, “Screening Babies for Broken Hearts,” in which I described a simple, cheap and painless screening test to check newborns for potentially lethal heart defects.

headline: 4 … 3 … 2 … 1 …  Beaujolais Nouveau!
text: “Cadillac” and “Detroit” were originally French words —one a proper name, the other a geographic term. So maybe it was not so far-fetched that this year’s batch of Beaujolais nouveau, the wine many Americans consider quintessentially French, arrived at a party where it was drunk for the first time in a Cadillac that was made in Detroit.

headline: Imagining the Lives of the Great Explorers
text: Just like the subjects of her singular new collection of stories, Sabina Murray is an explorer — someone with a hankering to visit places others tend to avoid. Where better for such a writer to poke around than inside the heads of those extraordinary individuals who themselves set off to survey the unknown?

headline: John Casey’s Work Out Book
text: In his author photos, the aggressively bearded John Casey often glares at the camera as if he’s just ordered the landlubbing cameraman off his skiff. Casey is the author of four novels, but he’s best known for the National Book Award-winning “Spartina,” a beautifully written portrait of a Rhode Island fisherman, and “Compass Rose,” a sequel devoted to the fisherman’s daughter. I’d always assumed the author spent his mornings writing and his afternoons mending trawl nets.

headline: Dead Dog Comes Back to Haunt Artist
text: The New York sculptor Tom Otterness may be known for his whimsical and warm sculptures of animals and cartoon-like characters, but in San Francisco, a lurid act from his past has come back to haunt him.

headline: World War II, From the Ground Up
text: Do we really need another history of World War II? The book market is overflowing with them, and new ones seem to appear at almost weekly intervals. Vast though the conflict was, we probably know more about it than any other war in history. Sir Max Hastings, author of this latest survey, has already written no fewer than eight books about key campaigns and personalities of the war. Has he got anything new to say?

headline: Backers of Proposition 8 Can Challenge Court Ruling
text: The California Supreme Court ruled Thursday that proponents of Proposition 8 — which banned same-sex marriage in California — have legal standing to challenge the decision by a lower court judge overturning the ban, after the state’s governor and attorney general refused to defend the proposition.

headline: From Homelessness to an Ad Campaign, With Employment Along the Way
text: When Betty Jo Fain was a homeless woman struggling with a drug and alcohol problem, the last thing she imagined was being the face for an advertising campaign promoting jobs at a naval shipbuilding company. On Thursday, her face was that face for Austal USA, the shipbuilding company where she works as a welder.

headline: What Do I Need to Know to Make Delicious, Not-Lumpy Mashed Potatoes?
text: Q.

headline: To Study Quail, With a Little Help
text: Jennifer Calkins, a biologist who teaches at Evergreen State College in Olympia, Wash., writes from Mexico, where she is studying the ecology, behavior and evolution of the elegant quail.

headline: Winter Wonders | Buttoned Up
text: T tracks what stylish women are wearing to keep warm.

headline: United States of Hunger
text: Casey Mulligan noted Wednesday on Economix that United States spending on food stamps had skyrocketed since the recession began. A new Census Bureau report provides a look at just how big the program has become. Last year, more than one in 10 families received food stamps, with some states having significantly higher participation rates. In Oregon, the share was nearly one in five.

headline: Bernadette Peters and Martin Short Linked to Possible Revival of ‘I Do! I Do!’
text: The Tony Award-winning actors Bernadette Peters and Martin Short will meet with a team of theater producers this month to discuss a possible Broadway revival of “I Do! I Do!,” the 1966 Tom Jones-Harvey Schmidt musical about the trials and tribulations of a married couple over a 50-year period, according to theater executives familiar with the discussions.

headline: Banks in Italy Find an Unusual Liquidity Lifeline
text: LONDON — The London Stock Exchange is becoming the lender of last resort for many banks in Italy as concerns over the country’s debt levels squeeze liquidity out of the Italian financial market.

headline: Consumer Agency Seeks Comments on Private Student Loans
text: 10:30 p.m. Updated to revise email address for submitting comments.

headline: Court Refuses to Extradite Killer Wanted in Hijacking
text: MADRID — A Portuguese court denied on Thursday an American request to extradite the fugitive murderer and hijacker who was apprehended in September in a village outside Lisbon where he had lived since the 1990s, his lawyer said.

headline: A Day of Protests as Occupy Movement Marks Two-Month Milestone
text: Protesters across the country demonstrated en masse Thursday, snarling rush-hour traffic in several major cities and taking aim at banks as part of a national “day of action” to mark the two-month milestone of the Occupy Wall Street movement.

headline: Hints of Tension Chip at a Hero’s Welcome for Cuomo
text: COLONIE, N.Y. — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was received as a hero on Thursday at a meeting of the state’s Democratic Party, with elected officials crediting him for several critical victories in local government elections last week, and the governor highlighting those elections as a referendum on his first 10 months in office.

headline: TimesCast | Protesters Clash with Police
text: Nov. 17, 2011 — Occupy Wall Street protesters clashed with the police while trying to reach the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Outfits That Walk Between 2 Worlds
text: A mainstay on the city’s charity circuit, Muffie Potter Aston was formerly the United States executive vice president of marketing and advertising for Van Cleef & Arpels. A Washington, D.C., native, she lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, the plastic surgeon Dr. Sherrell Aston, and their twin 6-year-old daughters, Ashleigh and Bracie.  BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

headline: Gothic Fantasy, Hard-Boiled Crime and Zombies
text: As a gift, a video game really should keep on giving. When you give someone a game that truly appeals to his or her tastes, skills, motivations and interests, you should be providing many hours of stimulation and entertainment. Here are some of my favorite games of 2011; there ought to be something for just about any player except hard-core shooter fans (who have all bought Battlefield 3 or Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 already) and superhero fans (who are playing Batman: Arkham City).

headline: Zynga Shakes Up Ranks
text: Zynga, which is headed for an initial public offering in the next few months, is shaking up its upper ranks.

headline: Kuwait Tightens Security After Protest in Parliament
text: Stung by a surprise burst into Parliament by protesters, Kuwait’s ruler ordered tighter security in the building on Thursday and vowed that his oil-rich country, which has so far dodged the Arab Spring upheavals that have shaken the region, would not tolerate “preplanned sabotage.”

headline: Bombing Continues in Sudan, Creating a Crisis
text: With journalists and outside observers mostly prevented from entering the Southern Kordofan and Blue Nile areas of Sudan, it’s very difficult to track the developing human rights crisis there. But Donatella Rovera, Amnesty International’s Senior Crisis Response Director, recently visited the area, and has provided a rare look from behind enemy lines.

headline: Ground-Floor Internet Meme Oppty! Buy Now!
text: I’m never early on the Internet-meme cycle. I’m always happy to be delighted by biting Charlie or baffled by Amber Lamps. But by the time I get the link to whatever hilarious video is shooting around the Web, 388 million others have already viewed it, made their own spoofs and moved on.

headline: Yale Reviewing Coach’s Rhodes Candidacy
text: Yale University said Thursday that it would review a claim made by its football coach, Tom Williams, that he was a Rhodes scholar candidate when he was a student at Stanford University.

headline: Italy’s New Premier Offers Broad Plan to Reform Finances and Spur Growth
text: ROME — Mario Monti, the newly chosen prime minister of Italy, unveiled an ambitious growth-boosting program before the Italian Senate on Thursday, warning that Italy and Europe faced a moment of “serious emergency” and calling on lawmakers for national unity and responsibility.

headline: A League of Their Own?
text: Instead of caving to the unreasonable demands of N.B.A. owners, players should use their star power and take their show on the road, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: The X-Men Go to College
text: Chris Claremont, one of the most influential writers of “X-Men” comics, known for his engaging, complex plot lines and strong female characters, is donating his archives to Columbia University’s Rare Book and Manuscript Library. The archive will be the first step in establishing Columbia as a research resource for cartoonists and comic book writers.

headline: Sports of The Times: A League of Their Own?
text: Instead of caving to the unreasonable demands of N.B.A. owners, players should use their star power and take their show on the road, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: Lessons Learned: Creating a Life Reports Project
text: Overview | How can we tap into the wisdom of the older members of our families and communities? What useful lessons can be learned from looking back at the choices made over the course of a long lifetime? In this lesson, students share what they have learned from the experiences and wisdom of the older people in their lives, read Life Reports written by Times readers over the age of 70 and write and share their own reports from the present or their imagined futures. They end by soliciting and displaying Life Reports from community members.

headline: Will They Stay or Will They Go?
text: Back in June senior officials in the Department of Homeland Security announced a new deportation policy: They would encourage prosecutors to use more discretion, to focus on removing illegal immigrants who’d committed serious crimes. This was a good thing, but hardly an epic breakthrough, since they should have been doing that all along.

headline: Pelosi Mocks Perry in Rejecting Debate Request
text: A potentially epic debate between Representative Nancy Pelosi of California and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas isn’t going to happen after all.

headline: How I Became a Teacher
text: A first-year teacher writes: "As a high school student, I never once considered the training my teachers had received or what their personal teaching philosophies may have been. I did not know what a lesson plan was." Now she knows.

headline: Competition for Cobble Hill School Site
text: As the Department of Education moves to bring a charter school to Brooklyn's Cobble Hill neighborhood, a state assemblywoman and a former city schools official are backing a different school proposal that would compete with the charter school for space.

headline: A New Twist on Airline Fees: Pay to Arrive?
text: PARIS — While air travelers have grown accustomed to paying extra for everything from an in-flight meal to pillows to checked bags, a group of passengers traveling from India to Britain on Thursday were confronted with what may be a new low in the industry’s pay-as-you-go trend.

headline: Popcast: Drake and Romeo Santos
text: This week the New York Times pop music writers discuss a platinum-selling rapper in search of new sounds and a Latin music superstar in search of new audiences.

headline: A West-Meets-East Feast
text: “The New York dining scene is crazy. I mean, you can eat practically anything you want at any given hour,” says James Lelonde, the chef and co-owner of San Francisco’s acclaimed pop-up cafe SloMoSF. “New York chefs visit San Francisco to showcase their cooking all the time but not vice versa. So we’re trying to offer something a little different.”For three days, starting tomorrow, Lelonde and his SloMoSF partner Ryoji Kajikawa will team with Kelly Geary of Brooklyn’s Sweet Deliverance to host a series of weekend dinners featuring their unique culinary spin. Equipped with diverse backgrounds, each chef brings something different to the table: Kajikawa’s skills are rooted in traditional Japanese techniques; Lelonde is heavily influenced by fresh Californian cuisine, favoring unusual twists on classics; Geary is passionate about cooking with what’s seasonal and local. Just imagine the possibilities when you combine the skill sets of these three spirited epicureans.

headline: Task Force Urges Greece to Improve Tax Collection
text: BRUSSELS — Greece is owed billions in unpaid taxes, but the prospects for collection are “very low” because the authorities have not yet simplified the system nor taken measures to curb tax evasion, the European Commission said Thursday.

headline: Reading Club | Sex Ed
text: For our first Reading Club selection, on “character education,” we heard from 536 students, and were delighted and impressed by the conversation.

headline: Vaulting Back to Form Using a Long Putter
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The question of when Adam Scott will fulfill his potential has dogged him for years. He won the Players Championship at age 23, and with each passing year the pressure has mounted. Only a victory for Scott in one of golf’s four majors will satisfy those posing the questions.

headline: Astros Get New Owners and a Different League
text: MILWAUKEE — Baseball’s yearly general managers’ meetings and quarterly ownership meetings, held jointly this week here at the Pfister Hotel, ended Thursday with a sequence of activity that ensured significant changes to the sport moving forward.

headline: The Cunningham Countdown: A Day for Merce in Chicago
text: The choreographer Merce Cunningham (1919-2009) was born in Centralia, Wash., and spent 70 years of his life based in New York. But his work, like that of so many dancers and choreographers who travel the country and the world, had many homes.

headline: Occupy Wall Street Protesters Clash With Police
text: Hundreds of Occupy Wall Street protesters marched on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, engaging in scuffles with the police throughout the day.

headline: In the Pilgrims’ Footsteps, Through England and the Netherlands
text: LAST Thanksgiving my wife was trying to explain to our granddaughter, Lizzie, 5 at the time, that some of her ancestors had been participants at the original 1621 feast in Plymouth. “I know,” said Lizzie, who apparently had been learning about Thanksgiving in school. “We’re Indians!”

headline: Science and the Dangerous Climate Question
text: Richard Betts, the head of the climate impacts section of Britain’s Met Office, recently left a comment on the “skeptic”* blog Bishop Hill stating that thresholds for climate danger, such as the much ballyhooed 2-degree limit enshrined in recent climate pledges, were not determined by science:

headline: Fox and CBS Rebound, but ABC’s ‘Modern Family’ Rules on Its Own
text: Fox and CBS both rebounded from their substandard performances last week (when they faced off against the Country Music Awards on ABC) to achieve a ratings split on Wednesday: Fox won the night in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic thanks to “The X Factor” while CBS had the most total viewers. “Modern Family” on ABC was once again the highest rated show of the night, though it dropped to a season low in the 18-to-49 category and in total viewers (12.9 million). “Criminal Minds” on CBS was a close second with 12.5 million total viewers.

headline: Thanksgiving Re-enacted
text: November is showtime for a certain segment of the re-enactor set, a month in which they try to gently correct that stereotypical image of the first Thanksgiving.

headline: Thanksgiving Re-enactments, From Utah to Plymouth, Mass.
text: NO journalist wants to have to begin an article this way, but the record must be kept straight.

headline: Yelp Files for I.P.O.
text: Yelp officially threw its hat into the I.P.O. ring on Thursday, with the filing of its prospectus.

headline: New Porsche 911 Greets Its North American Public
text: Shown on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2012 Porsche 911 Carrera and Carrera S.

headline: Arrest Warrant and Criminal Complaint for Oscar Ortega-Hernandez
text: Federal authorities charged a 21-year-old Idaho man on Thursday with attempting to assassinate President Obama.

headline: For N.B.A. Players, China Is Up (and the D-League Down )
text: When Deron Williams signed with Besiktas back in July, he was supposedly opening the floodgates. N.B.A. players were expected to follow him across the Atlantic in search of steady income and legitimate competition. The various European leagues were seen as a plentiful resource for players without any obligation to their N.B.A. employers, and a first-class fallback plan in case the collective bargaining negotiations stalled.

headline: Demand, Demand, Demand
text: Calculated Risk sends us to two papers by Amir Sufi and Atif Mian using county-level data to investigate the causes of the recession. Their work strongly supports the balance-sheet view: a fall in demand from highly indebted households is the big story, and you can confirm that by showing that the big declines in nontradable employment — that is, employment in industries that sell locally — is in those countries where debt levels were high.

headline: Cain Says ‘We Need a Leader, Not a Reader’
text: NASHUA, N.H. – Herman Cain began his stump speech at a rally here today with one of his signature lines: “Aw, shucky ducky!” he said. “I feel good today.”

headline: Green Car of the Year: The Full-Contact Edition
text: LOS ANGELES — Traditionally, the second day of the Los Angeles auto show begins with the announcement of the Green Car of the Year award. At this, a show that generally has a green tint to it, the award can act as a lightning rod of guilt: Think that 650-horsepower Shelby GT500 is sexy? Meet its natural born buzzkill, the Prius V.

headline: MF Global Is Said to Have Used Customer Cash Improperly
text: MF Global improperly diverted customers’ cash for its own use in the days before its bankruptcy, an act that regulators believe may help explain why $600 million of customer funds remains missing, people briefed on the investigation say.

headline: Nook’s Specs Are Exaggerated, Again
text: 6:51 p.m. | Updated with comment from Barnes & Noble and Amazon.

headline: In Gunshots, a Trail of Threats Is Reported
text: WASHINGTON — Federal authorities on Thursday charged a 21-year-old Idaho man with attempting to assassinate President Obama — saying he had told one friend that the president was “the Antichrist” and that he “needed to kill him,” according to a complaint filed in federal court.

headline: A Tea Party ‘Hearing’ in the Senate That Wasn’t
text: UPDATED 5:12 p.m.: A self-styled Tea Party debt commission was foiled Thursday in its effort to hold a Senate hearing on its proposals to reduce the deficit.

headline: Vows: Frederick & Lawrence
text: In this homemade video, Lawrence Rodriguez says that 25 years later, Frederick Barnfield is still the first person he's ever dated.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov.17
text: The day in sports included high school football championship games in Wisconsin and ice dancing in Paris.

headline: Block Party
text: It was our managing editor, George Gene Gustines, who suggested we do a T made of Legos for our winter travel issue. “I’m a huge fan of Legos and spent hours building houses and superheroes out of them as a kid,” he said. “Of all my childhood toys, I probably miss them the most.” Representatives at Lego led us to Sachiko Akinaga.
