headline: Madoff Explains Everything
text: As i watch the politics swirl around the Occupy Wall Street movement, I find myself thinking about Bernie Madoff. Bear with me here; this might even make sense.

headline: A City Light on Tourists
text: Gothic architecture, winding streets and hearty cuisine await in Rennes, a medieval city just two hours from Paris.

headline: Q&A: Multitasking on Mobile Phones
text: Q.

headline: History and Youth in Rennes, Brittany
text: WHILE ogling an oversize wheel of Camembert at a bountiful summer farmers’ market in Rennes, Brittany, I momentarily perked up from my lost-in-cheese stupor at the surprising sound of two British tourists in conversation. It was the first time I had heard someone else speaking English since we had arrived in Rennes 24 hours earlier. It was August, when Parisians leave for their holidays and the Americans arrive, a phenomenon that’s hard to miss while trailing crowds in the French capital.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Nov. 18-24
text: Classical

headline: San Diego Newspaper Sold to Powerful Local Developer
text: The hotel developer Doug Manchester bought his hometown newspaper, The San Diego Union-Tribune, for “above” $110 million, voiceofsandiego.org reported on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Why Don’t More Moms Coach?
text: Mothers are rare sights on the coach’s bench for youth sports at every level. Co-ed, boys, girls; it doesn’t much matter. Overall estimates for women coaches of youth sports range from 4 percent all the way up to nearly 10 percent, with the numbers being a little lower for boys’ teams and a little higher (up to 11 percent!) for girls’. Whatever your sport: hockey, soccer, baseball, softball — it’s Dad, not Mom, who’s in the dugout, on the sidelines or behind the bench.

headline: Dance Listings for Nov. 18-24
text: Dance

headline: Manager Who Claimed to Own Facebook Shares Charged With Fraud
text: It may be the new, new thing in fraud.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 18-24
text: Art

headline: City’s Jobless Rate Climbs to 8.8%
text: New York City’s unemployment rate rose to 8.8 percent in October, as the city’s recovery from the recession continued to falter.

headline: Inside the New Clyfford Still Museum
text: Sandra Still Campbell narrates a look at a new museum in Denver that is dedicated to the work of her father, the artist Clyfford Still.

headline: Theater Talkback: Why the ‘Funny Girl’ Cancellation Is No Laughing Matter
text: “Say ‘Hello Gorgeous’ to a new star,” runs a tag line in the ad for “Funny Girl” in the Ahmanson Theater programs being passed out at performances of the new musical “Bring It On.” But the theater’s 28,000 subscribers won’t be getting a chance to do any such thing.

headline: Seven Tips for Better Group Portraits
text: Group shots are always a challenge, but family holiday gatherings present a special set of problems. You can’t hold a group together long amid the distractions of bowl games, family Xbox tournaments and sweet-potato pie. Andrew Boyd, a photojournalist and educator, has written extensively about group shots on his blog, The Discerning Photographer. Here’s his recipe for getting it right.

headline: Crushing the Cost of Predicting the Future
text: Large and diverse sets of data have become abundant as more information is posted on the Internet, from stock prices and news pages to sensor readings. Now the cost of analyzing and visualizing that data is dropping fast, too, with implications for all kinds of decision-making.

headline: African Union Considers Sending Ethiopian Troops to Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The African Union is considering an ambitious plan to stabilize Somalia that could involve using thousands of Ethiopian troops to open a new front against the Shabab militant group, officials of the union said Thursday.

headline: Amid the Grim Streets, a Pair of Weary Souls
text: In the first few minutes of “Tyrannosaur,” Joseph — played with granitic intensity by the great Scottish actor Peter Mullan — kicks a dog to death, smashes a store window and picks a fight with three much younger men in a bar. It should be noted that he is one of the nicer people in this movie, the directing debut of the actor Paddy Considine (“My Summer of Love,” “In America”).

headline: Spare Times: For Children for Nov. 18-24
text: ‘AKC MEET THE BREEDS’

headline: UBS Outlines How It Plans to Carry Out Turnaround
text: When Sergio P. Ermotti entered the chandelier-drenched ballroom at the Waldorf Astoria hotel in Manhattan for his first investor day at UBS as chief executive, he started choking on a piece of food, prompting a few attendees to joke that he may have bitten off more than he can chew in taking the top spot at the beleaguered Swiss bank.

text: Around Town

text: Gladstone Gallery

headline: Supervillains Everywhere and Barely Time to Think
text: The title character of Jérôme Salle’s picturesque international thriller “The Heir Apparent: Largo Winch” is the swashbuckling hero of a series of Belgian graphic novels by Jean Van Hamme and illustrated by Philippe Francq. As played by Tomer Sisley, a lean, handsome 37-year-old French actor, he is a charismatic screen presence so long as he doesn’t speak. When he delivers the movie’s wooden dialogue (in three languages) in a near monotone, his glamour evaporates.

headline: Channel Surfing: The Shrimp Combo Platter
text: I don’t know if the Endless Shrimp promotion is still running at Red Lobster, but it’s certainly Endless Shrimp night Thursday on television.

headline: Abstract Expressionist Made Whole
text: Denver

headline: Highlighting Influence of Asia Behind Artwork
text: Exhibitions at Asia Society often reveal an unfamiliar dimension to an artist’s work. When the society presented a show about the Japanese neo-Pop artist Yoshitomo Nara last year, for example, it examined how his passion for music influenced his art. A new exhibition by the installation artist Sarah Sze will explore her process and her interest in traditional Chinese painting.

headline: Romance’s New Format
text: EVEN though my mother has a wonderful marriage with my father, she keeps her ex-boyfriends alive for my siblings and me like guest stars on a sitcom. Each is drawn in quick strokes according to how generous she is feeling on that particular day.

headline: 2012 Honda CR-V: Cautious Makeover for a Best-Selling Crossover
text: Introduced on Wednesday, Nov. 16: 2012 Honda CR-V.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Greece, New York, Thailand and Ghana.

headline: They Have Standing
text: Some gay rights groups were disappointed today when the California Supreme Court ruled that the sponsors of Proposition 8, ProtectMarriage, have standing to defend the discriminatory law, even though Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and Attorney General Jerry Brown had refused to do so.

headline: Rwandan Is Convicted in 1994 Killings
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — It was one of the most notorious cases in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda. In a normally sleepy lakeside town, more than 2,000 Tutsis driven from their homes accepted a local priest’s offer of refuge in his church. But it was a ruse, and after days of siege the building was bulldozed, killing them all.

headline: Annie Hall and Family, Off the Screen
text: Diane Keaton’s book about her life is not a straight-up, chronological memoir. It’s a collage that mixes Ms. Keaton’s words with those of her mother, Dorothy Deanne Keaton Hall, who died in 2008. Since Ms. Hall left behind 85 scrapbooklike journals, a huge and chaotic legacy, there is every reason to expect that Ms. Keaton’s braiding of her own story with her mother’s in “Then Again” will be a rambling effort at best.

headline: 200 Are Arrested as Protesters Clash With the Police
text: Thousands of protesters across the country flooded streets, squares, bridges and banks on Thursday, snarling traffic and often clashing with the police in a show of support for the Occupy Wall Street movement, two months to the day after the demonstration began.

headline: Navigating Through Time and Space
text: There’s a way that the distressed walls of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater resemble compressed layers of sediment: the exposed brick, the peeling paint, the rough plaster patches, everything seemingly crumbling like sheered-off rock exposed to the elements.

headline: A Fresh Devotion to the Older Ways
text: The young vibraphonist Warren Wolf, from Baltimore, plays music that doesn’t argue with the most popular and usable parts of jazz’s past. It doesn’t hesitate or erase its own tracks. It uses swing, blues, virtuosity, cuteness, directness and seldom wanders from a sense of tune. His working band, which played at 92Y Tribeca on Wednesday night, is called Wolfpack, and in the way the music dominated the audience, that made sense.

headline: Solyndra Has a Cousin in the Poorhouse
text: At a hearing on Thursday that lasted five and half hours, Republicans on the House Energy and Commerce Committee grilled the energy secretary, Steven Chu, on the bankruptcy of the solar panel manufacturer Solyndra and asked what other loan recipients might be in financial trouble.

headline: At the Altar of Design, When Self-Expression Met Mass Production
text: All that has been written since the death of Steve Jobs last month is a reminder of how passionate modern consumers can be about the things we buy and how fascinated we are by the people who make and sell them. The appeal of those Apple gadgets — so sleek and logical, so cool and friendly and flattering to whoever picks them up — is obvious enough, but the exact nature of Mr. Jobs’s contribution has been harder to specify. Was he a visionary innovator or, as Malcolm Gladwell recently argued in The New Yorker, a tireless “tweaker” of the inventions of others? Was he primarily a designer, an engineer, a computer nerd or an artist? A benevolent guru or the center of a cult of personality?

headline: Jim Parsons May Go From Sheldon to ‘Harvey’
text: The Emmy Award-winning actor Jim Parsons (“The Big Bang Theory”) is in talks to return to Broadway this spring to play Elwood P. Dowd in the Pulitzer Prize-winning comedy “Harvey,” about a man who claims to be friends with a six-foot-tall rabbit no one else can see. Two theater executives familiar with the discussions, who would only disclose the unconfirmed production on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Parsons was negotiating with Roundabout Theater Company about starring as Elwood. Representatives for Mr. Parsons and for Roundabout declined comment on Thursday.

headline: A London Design Maverick as a Pragmatist
text: Thomas Tait was in New York last week for London Showrooms, a presentation of young British fashion talent. Actually, Mr. Tait is Canadian, educated at a technical school in Montreal. In 2010, he completed the master’s program in women’s wear at Central Saint Martins in London, whereupon he joined that distinguished race known as the Young Fashion Designer.

headline: Nude Blogger Riles Egyptians of All Stripes
text: CAIRO — Aliaa Magda Elmahdy apparently thought she was striking a blow for sexual equality and free expression in Egypt when she posted nude photographs of herself on a blog. Instead Ms. Elmahdy set off a wave of outrage here, stoking conservative Islamist sentiments that many liberals fear will undermine their prospects in the country’s parliamentary election next week.

headline: Filthy Gorgeous
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Greece, Italy, New York and Texas.

headline: Arts and Crafts Pioneer Is Subject of New Book
text: Marie Zimmermann, an heiress to a straw-importing fortune, did not need to work for a living. She nonetheless ran a metalsmithing studio in New York from the 1910s to the late ’30s, partly to prove herself to the men who doubted women could succeed in that gritty profession.

headline: Two Weeks in Kolkata
text: The photographer Max Vadukul and his son, the writer Alex, discuss their trip to Kolkata for the Winter Travel issue of T Magazine.

headline: 2013 Spark Broadens, but Doesn’t Ignite, Chevrolet Product Portfolio
text: LOS ANGELES — Chevrolet gave journalists their first viewing of its subcompact 2013 Spark on Wednesday at the 2011 Los Angeles auto show. The car is expected to go on sale next summer.

headline: Lens: Crime Scenes
text: Lens: Crime Scenes

headline: Down the Aisle, Laden With Family Baggage
text: Watch as the mighty Ellens — Burstyn and Barkin — go head to head, playing an embattled mother and daughter, in “Another Happy Day,” the emotionally overwrought debut feature from Sam Levinson (son of Barry). This wedding melodrama, in which generational and marital factions of a strife-torn family collide, seems acutely aware of its place in the lineage of a genre that it carries to a screeching decibel level.

headline: A Small World, With All the Bells and Whistles
text: THE Kingston Model Railroad Club has been meeting in Kingston, N.Y., since 1937. Mostly it’s a members-only affair, with enthusiasts gathering to build and maintain their trains and generally schmooze, but once a year they invite the public into their intricate miniature worlds on rails in the Hudson Valley. Tony Cenicola has been photographing them for the last decade. Here are some of his favorite scenes, like the diner from 2009, which could be straight out of an Edward Hopper painting, and an image, from 2003, of a 3-year-old named Elizabeth waiting for a tiny train to chug by. In another photograph, Bill Brandt reattaches a trolley to an overhead wire in a tableau from this year’s exhibition. The open house runs through Dec. 4, Sundays only, noon to 5 p.m., on Susan Street; (845) 334-8233. The trains are old and new, from kits and from scratch, all customized by club members.

headline: H.P. Gives Relational’s Whitworth a Board Seat
text: Hewlett-Packard said on Thursday that it had named Ralph V. Whitworth, the head of the hedge fund Relational Investors, to its board as the computer giant seeks to head off potential campaigns by activist shareholders.

headline: Medieval Foes With Whimsy
text: If, by some typically improbable turn of events, Homer Simpson were to unearth from his backyard an old chest containing a chess set from medieval times, what would the pieces look like? Chances are they would resemble the lovable little contestants beautifully carved from walrus tusks by anonymous artisans in the famous cache known as the Lewis Chessmen.

headline: A Search for Self-Discovery, Two Left Feet and All
text: All dancing, all singing, all wisecracking, the animated penguins from down under (way under) return in “Happy Feet Two,” an amiable sequel with not much on its mind other than funny and creaky jokes, and waves of understated beauty. Lighter in mood, softer in political outlook and less narratively ambitious than the first “Happy Feet” (2006), the new movie takes place in Antarctica, where thousands of emperor penguins hang out doing familiar animated penguin things, like gobbling fish, braving the weather and breaking into tightly choreographed song and dance.

headline: A Classified-Ads Site for Lonely Scribes
text: If writers have a way with words, that’s not always the case with love, and even less so with money. That’s why the Miser is thankful for people like Kaitlin Phillips, the creator of n+personals, a free classified-ads site for lonely scribes seeking companionship.

headline: A Son’s Favorites Are an Acquired Taste
text: My 23-year-old son is in his first semester of graduate school. He e-mailed us that he would be bringing his brand-new 28-year-old girlfriend home for Thanksgiving. In the same message, he told us they had become vegans and made several suggestions about dishes I might cook for them: quinoa, seitan and tempeh. I have never heard of these foods. And I’m not thrilled that my son is going out with an older woman in what is supposed to be the beginning of a challenging graduate program. Your thoughts? Anonymous

headline: New Acquisition: A Welcome Mat
text: THIS month, the New-York Historical Society reopened its Central Park West fortress, with renovations designed to entice more visitors to what was designed as an airtight vault for history. The society’s president, Louise Mirrer, said the governing idea was “all about opening history up to the public; it’s not just dead people.” The transformed main floor of the old tomb is a stunner.

headline: All the Single (Old) Ladies
text: I sometimes hear women in New York lament that there are many more single gals than single guys around. To that I say: Just wait until you turn 90.

headline: The City, Inside Yet Out
text: DON’T think David Roffe is only a New York City tour guide.

headline: Enlightenment by Way of Adventure
text: What do you do in New York once you tire of the bar scene, eat your way through Yelp’s “Best of” restaurants and conclude that watching Film Forum documentaries is simply too passive? If you’re just the right amount of curious, adventurous or even a touch voyeuristic, you might sign up for a SideTour.

headline: The New Bad Boys Decide to Do the Reforming
text: Filmed in shades of blue and gray, the dour Norwegian drama “King of Devil’s Island” evokes a blood-chilling climate of eternal winter. Its setting is the Bastoy Residential School, a reformatory for “maladjusted” boys, 11 to 18, that operated for a half-century until the 1950s on an Alcatraz-like island.

headline: Inheriting a Home, and a Loan
text: THE death of a family member may bring a barrage of sadness, a bequest of property — and a mortgage to repay.

headline: Cryogenically Frozen in the 1970s
text: There’s a noticeable imbalance in “Woody Allen: A Documentary,” a three-and-a-half-hour “American Masters” biography spooling out on Sunday and Monday on PBS. The first chapter, the longer and better of the two, follows its subject through just the first 10 films of his career, ending with “Stardust Memories.” Then the program’s director, Robert Weide, stuffs Mr. Allen’s 31 subsequent features into the 90 rushed minutes of the second night.

headline: Excerpt: Woody Allen: A Documentary
text: A scene from a new “American Masters” special about Mr. Allen that will debut on PBS on Sunday.

headline: And the Winner in New Hampshire Is …
text: The votes are in in the first-in-the-nation primary state — at least the votes among 250 fifth and sixth graders from across New Hampshire who voted in the Kids Primary conducted by the Institute of Politics at St. Anselm College in Manchester.

headline: A Rising Rental Market in the North
text: IT appears another housing boom is under way, but just for rentals.

headline: Excerpt: 'Woody Allen: A Documentary'
text: A scene from a new “American Masters” special about Mr. Allen that will debut on PBS on Sunday.

headline: In Poland, an Architect’s-Eye View
text: It’s probably safe to say that Kacper Kowalski is one of few people in Poland — or anywhere  — hoping for a bitterly cold and snowy winter. He’s an aerial photographer who floats over the landscape in paragliders and geoplanes, as he did last year when an wicked winter freeze wreaked havoc on roads, airports railways and ports.

headline: How Do You Drink Your Vodka? Fluffed, No Chaser
text: To stand out in the crowded vodka category of the distilled spirits market, brands try all manner of methods to get attention. A particularly popular tactic is to go naughty in advertising and marketing efforts, with themes and images that walk the fine line between wicked and evil.

headline: Your Home, Your Castle
text: Sea Cliff

headline: Huntsman Plays Down Father’s Role
text: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. on Thursday addressed questions about his relationship with his wealthy father amid speculation about whether Jon M. Huntsman Sr. would come to the aid of his son’s flagging campaign.

headline: Three Realtor Associations Under One Umbrella
text: LENGTHY commutes to cheaper houses far from New York City jobs are not a new trend, but stubborn unemployment and a stalled housing market seem to have affected the outward march like adrenaline.

headline: Q & A
text: Clean the Windows, or Buy New Ones?

headline: David Cooper
text: Mr. Cooper, 52, is the president and chief executive of WSP Flack + Kurtz, a building systems engineering company and a subsidiary of the WSP Group of Britain. WSP Flack + Kurtz provides a wide range of consulting, design and engineering services. Current projects include work at the Waldorf Astoria hotel and the Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn. Mr. Cooper recently celebrated 30 years at the company.

headline: Time Capsule With Pulse on Present
text: The Mexican muralist Diego Rivera (1886-1957) was one of the great artists of his time. Is he one of ours? The Museum of Modern Art, which is revisiting the retrospective it awarded to Rivera in the 1930s, certainly thinks so. I’m not convinced, even though some of the paintings in “Diego Rivera: Murals for the Museum of Modern Art” seem ripped from today’s headlines. In “The Uprising,” protesting laborers are brutally suppressed by uniformed soldiers; the stratified New York cityscape of “Frozen Assets” tops a bank vault with a crowded homeless shelter.

headline: Preoccupying Opera: Youthful Acts of Dissent
text: There are many impressive things about “Kommilitonen!,” the new opera by Peter Maxwell Davies, with a libretto by David Pountney, which had its American premiere at the Juilliard School on Wednesday night. Best of all is Mr. Davies’s exhilarating score. Here, for once, is a modern opera that exudes musical modernism. The spirited conductor Anne Manson drew an incisive, colorful performance of this demanding score from the Juilliard Orchestra.

headline: Period Instruments Breathe New Life Into a Musical Hero
text: During the last few weeks in New York it has been hard to miss a familiar baleful countenance staring out from a poster pasted up at a construction area, or perhaps from a banner on a Web site. Thanks to a clever advertising campaign for the classical radio station WQXR-FM, Beethoven is everywhere, rendered in the style of the street artist Shepard Fairey and adorned with a quirky logo: “OBEY THOVEN.”

headline: Elephants and Bishops
text: Besides being exceptional works of art, the Lewis Chessmen are a historical marker in the development and spread of the game.

headline: Loans Lose All Value, and More
text: Boscov’s, a regional chain of department stores based in Reading, Pa., has received an honor few companies get. Its name, like Google’s, has become a verb.

headline: Dealbook: H.P. Gives Relational’s Whitworth a Board Seat
text: Hewlett-Packard said on Thursday that it had named Ralph V. Whitworth, head of the hedge fund Relational Investors, to its board of directors as the computer giant seeks to fend off potential campaigns by activist shareholders. Read the entire post on Dealbook..

headline: The Fight Over Vaccines and Autism, Continued
text: If the title of your documentary is “The Greater Good,” shouldn’t you at least define what that is? Apparently not, as this emotionally manipulative, heavily partial look at the purported link between autism and childhood immunization would much rather wallow in the distress of specific families than engage with the needs of the population at large.

headline: More Power and New Noses Define Lincoln MKS and MKT
text: Introduced on Thursday, Nov. 17: 2013 Lincoln MKS and MKT.

headline: The Wish List Is Not Negotiable
text: FOR the first years of their marriage, Jennifer Betit Yen and Peyton Worley were bicoastal. They had met in law school at Boston University. But Ms. Betit Yen soon fell into acting. After she got a role in an independent film, she seized the opportunity, left her job and moved to Los Angeles.

headline: Enticing Renters to Cross the Bridge to Queens
text: ON a recent afternoon the view across Court Square, in eastern Long Island City, Queens, took in an auto body shop and parking lots, and aging factories beyond. The Citicorp Building and other office towers cast shadows across streets. Places to shop were nonexistent.

headline: This Gay American Life, in Code or in Your Face
text: “Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture,” a diligent exhibition centering on 20th-century portraits and self-portraits of or by gay artists, is now at the Brooklyn Museum, and it is more or less intact. Which is to say that once again, nearly a year after it was first mounted at the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery in Washington, it includes “A Fire in My Belly,” a four-minute excerpt from a video made in 1986-87 by David Wojnarowicz, who died of AIDS in 1992, at 37.

headline: Recovering Artifacts of Holocaust Victims
text: We don’t know who among the prisoners at Maidanek, a Nazi concentration camp in Poland, first decided to bury some personal items in a field just before being sent to the chamber. But we do know that many other prisoners followed suit and that the gesture was not futile.

headline: A Wide Audience for the Republican Debates and the Developing Shadow Campaign
text: A Wide Audience for the Republican Debates and the Developing Shadow Campaign

headline: Revisiting a Brazilian Dance Troupe’s Brush With Fame
text: “Dzi Croquettes,” about an all-male dance and theater troupe of that name that had a moment of fame in the 1970s in Brazil and then Europe, is in one sense a lazy sort of documentary. It asserts the group’s importance primarily through interviews with the members themselves and a handful of ardent fans (Liza Minnelli among them). But if the film doesn’t measure up as a piece of historical scholarship, it does manage to be a rather touching exploration of the troupe’s life cycle: achieving notoriety, then being torn apart by fame, then being destroyed by forces beyond its control.

headline: Smashing Glass Guitars
text: The disappointing “Women Who Rock” begins with a clip of James Brown singing “It’s a Man’s World,” which hints that what’s coming might be a serious exploration of the obstacles women faced in achieving rock stardom. But the film, by Carol Stein and Susan Wittenberg, quickly degenerates into cheerleading, serving up exactly the names you’d expect and only the most obvious of insights.

headline: Drone Journalism Arrives
text: Now that cellphone cameras have turned every protester with a Twitter account or a YouTube channel into a potential multimedia journalist, police officers in several American cities appear to be having trouble distinguishing between activists and reporters.

headline: ‘Hide/Seek’
text: Photos from the exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Cain Gets Secret Service Protection
text: 7:13 p.m. | Updated Herman Cain will get protection from the United States Secret Service starting Thursday night as he continues to campaign for the presidency,  representatives of the agency and Mr. Cain’s campaign said.

headline: From Edison’s Trunk, Direct Current Gets Another Look
text: Thomas Edison and his direct current, or DC, technology lost the so-called War of the Currents to alternating current, or AC, in the 1890s after it became clear that AC was far more efficient at transmitting electricity over long distances.

headline: Bloggingheads: Are We the 99%?
text: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Conn Carroll of The Washington Examiner debate whether Americans agree with Occupy Wall Street.

headline: Living Along a Contentious Border
text: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Before and After (the Kids)
text: THIS is one way Jay and Julie Rossi sum up their nearly 13 years of marriage: 16 jobs, 4 apartments, 2 houses, 2 Subarus, 2 children, 8 fish and 4 couches.

headline: Portrait of a World War II Double Agent
text: What do you call a spy who may be the best actor in the world? Bovril (a brand of beef extract) doesn’t quite sing, though the British handlers of Juan Pujol García used it before settling on the more apt Garbo.

headline: The Life Cycles of a Jewish Cemetery
text: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Frankfurt Goes to Hollywood
text: The 2011 Los Angeles auto show offered the first chance for many automotive journalists to glimpse cars that were first unveiled at the Frankfurt auto show in September.

headline: Leveraged Moveouts
text: WHEN real estate was booming, many New Yorkers joined in the rush to turn their houses and apartments into ATMs, withdrawing cash through home-equity loans, or flipping them.

headline: Rampant Sociopaths Messing With People’s Heads
text: “Silver Tongues,” like its twisted antiheroes, is a cynical, ice-cold tease. At its center lurk Gerry (Lee Tergesen) and Joan (Enid Graham), a pair of mysterious, middle-aged sociopaths who move from town to town messing with people’s heads. On its fringes lie the remnants of their victims, regular people whose lives will never be the same.

headline: Tips for Starter Landlords
text: HOMEOWNERS who become landlords, either by choice or by circumstance, may find that new and unfamiliar tasks like collecting rent, dealing with late-night repairs and sifting through potential tenants will sour even the sunniest personality.

headline: Twentysomething in Need of a Life Coach
text: Comprising small, near-perfect scenes played out largely at dinner tables and on couches, “The Lie” wonders if it’s possible to rewrite lives and remake choices.

headline: Homemaker Devises a Suburban Smackdown
How Can I Reheat My Turkey Without Drying It Out?
text: I have to cook the turkey the day before Thanksgiving, but I don’t want to serve it cold the next day. How do heat it up, so it doesn’t dry out and my guests don’t know it was cooked the day before? It’s 18-20 lb turkey. — Veronica, Princeton

headline: A Day of Protest, and Arrests
text: Two days after the Occupy Wall Street encampment was cleared at Zuccotti Park, demonstrators held a “day of action’ in New York, resulting in more than 175 arrests.

headline: A Simple Menu for a Bipartisan Breakfast Club
text: WASHINGTON — Every two weeks or so, a dozen House Republicans and Democrats repair to an office on Capitol Hill for bad croissants and lukewarm coffee, and to chat about the legislation they would like to enact together. They are not a committee, they are not a caucus; their group does not really even have a name. But in the 112th Congress, what they are is sort of remarkable.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot
text: What the editors and reporters of The Times’s tech staff spotted on the Web:

headline: The Finger-Pointing Over Penn State
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is It Time to Take Away the Bankers’ Bonuses?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Computer Programmer Is a Child
text: To the Editor:

headline: Failure Is Good
text: It’s a bird! It’s a plane! It’s a complete turkey! It’s the supercommittee!

headline: Dok-Ing Automotiv: A Show-Stealing Croatian Upstart Makes Debut in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — If there were an award for Most Unique Car at the 2011 Los Angeles auto show, a judge would be hard pressed to explain a vote in favor of anything other than the XD electric vehicle from Dok-Ing Automotiv.

headline: Disenfranchise No More
text: Mississippi voters just approved a new law requiring voters to show photo identification at the polls. But that law will not go into effect immediately, thanks to the Voting Rights Act. Instead Mississippi will get in line behind Texas and South Carolina as the Department of Justice examines each state’s voter ID laws, in a process known as “preclearance.” The Justice Department will allow each law to go into effect only if the state can show its law will not have a racially discriminatory purpose or effect. Such proof may be hard to come by: a recent study by The Associated Press found that African-American voters in South Carolina would be much harder hit by that state’s ID law than white voters because they often don’t have the right kind of identification.

headline: Sale of Astros Gets Baseball’s Ducks in a Row
text: The Houston franchise has played 50 years in the National League. First named for a handgun — the Colt .45 — and then for the space program, the Astros have specialized in innovations whose time has passed: artificial turf, the domed stadium, uniforms with colorful horizontal stripes. No Hall of Famer wears the open-ended star on his plaque, and the Astros, who have never won a World Series game, bottomed out with 106 losses last season.

headline: An Ill-Fated Firm Is Ready to Move On
text: Is the Washington Research Group the Wall Street version of Joe Btfsplk, the “L’il Abner” comic-strip character who walked around with a dark cloud over his head and brought misfortune to everyone around him?

headline: For Struggling Tuck, a Sackful of Concerns
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Justin Tuck does not like what he sees when he looks in the mirror these days, and part of it, admittedly, is the beard.

headline: Cubs Name Manager as Red Sox Consider Valentine
text: MILWAUKEE — The Chicago Cubs named Dale Sveum as their manager on Thursday, selecting a veteran coach who, just a day before, seemed about to become the new manager of the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Dulcie Gray, Stalwart British Actress, Dies at 95
text: Dulcie Gray, a stalwart of British stage, screen, radio and television who won enthusiastic reviews when she made her Broadway debut at age 80 with her husband and frequent acting partner, Michael Denison, died on Tuesday at Denville Hall, a home for elderly actors in Middlesex, England. She was 95.

headline: Sears Loss Hits $421 Million, and Gap’s Profit Is Off 36%
text: The Sears Holdings Corporation, the retailer controlled by the hedge fund manager Edward S. Lampert, reported a steeper third-quarter loss than a year ago on Thursday as sales declined in Canada.

headline: At Penn State, a Bitter Reckoning
text: State College, Pa.

headline: Gingrich Staffers Who Quit in June Return to Campaign
text: For Newt Gingrich, the latest twist on “what goes around, comes around” has an unusual personal dimension. On top of his surge in polls and fund-raising, Mr. Gingrich has rehired two of the Iowa staff members who quit during a mass exodus from his campaign in June.

headline: Coach’s Rhodes Claim Under Review by Yale
text: NEW HAVEN — Yale University began an internal review Thursday to determine if its football coach, Tom Williams, was being truthful when he listed himself as a Rhodes scholarship candidate on his résumé.

headline: Lincoln and the Mormons
text: Mormons! America just can’t get enough of them.

headline: The Oops in the ‘O’ for Oregon
text: EUGENE, Ore. — When University of Oregon football fans cheer their team, they often hold out their hands in the shape of the letter “O,” for Oregon.

headline: John Liu’s Credibility
text: With the arrest of one of his fund-raisers and the federal investigation into his campaign finances, John Liu, the New York city comptroller, needs to shut down his fund-raising operation immediately. His explanation — that he did not know about illegal donor practices — is not good enough. If he cannot manage his own campaign, why should the public trust him to oversee the city’s $66 billion budget and its $120 billion pension fund?

headline: Lyrics Briefly Draw a Penalty After a Columbia Loss
text: The history of university band mischief is long and colorful, stretching back to the irreverence of the 1960s. In some of the most notable instances, bands have staged a tribute to birth control, mimicked the napalming of a Cambodian village, ridiculed the spotted owl controversy in Oregon and made fun of Notre Dame’s Catholicism by dressing the drum major in a habit and using a cross as a baton.

headline: Politics and Clean Air
text: President Obama’s decision in September to scuttle stricter national standards for smog may well go down as the worst environmental decision of his administration — unless, of course, even more damaging retreats lie ahead. The decision was a setback for public health, a victory for industry, which had lobbied strongly against the standards, and a public embarrassment for the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Lisa Jackson, who had proposed them.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Group in U.S. Hoped for Big Payday in Offer to Help Qaddafi
text: WASHINGTON — To a colorful group of Americans — the Washington terrorism expert, the veteran C.I.A. officer, the Republican operative, the Kansas City lawyer — the Libyan gambit last March looked like a rare business opportunity.

headline: Out of the Spotlight, Until the Met Needed a Tenor
text: Until a few weeks ago, Jay Hunter Morris had spent much of his early 40s in the invisible universe of the backup opera singer, a life that included selling Rollerblades in Central Park and passing out towels at gyms.

headline: New Offenses Speed the Demise of College Records
text: Houston quarterback Case Keenum threw his 135th touchdown pass on Oct. 27, breaking the Football Bowl Subdivision record. He also threw his 136th, 137th, 138th and 139th, reaching the end zone a total of nine times in a 73-34 win over Rice.

headline: From Elephants to Bishops
text: Discovered in Scotland more than 800 years ago, the Lewis chess set, featured in "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone," is now on display at the Cloisters.

headline: Williamson Prosecutor Asserts a Change of Heart
text: GEORGETOWN — John Bradley says he is evolving.

headline: Thinking Outside the Bus
text: When public transportation finds the people who need to use it, and gets them where they want to go, it can grow organically.

headline: A Push to Promote Familiar Brands Online
text: BETWEEN now and New Year’s Eve, food marketers are hoping their products become the soup, frosting, snacks, candy, gravy, cereal and stuffing as dreams are made on.

headline: Pillsbury Commercial
text: Pillsbury is wooing shoppers through a campaign carrying the theme "Holiday ideas made easy."

headline: Exceptional Court Coverage
text: C-Span asked Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. this week to let the network televise the upcoming Supreme Court arguments in the case challenging the health care law. The justices have not permitted TV cameras in their courtroom, but this landmark case, which will affect every American, should surely be an exception to that rule.

headline: The End Game Lands the N.B.A. in Court
text: David Stern tried optimism, transitioned to gloom and dabbled in threats before turning alarmist.

headline: Utility Reform Eluding Japan After Nuclear Plant Disaster
text: TOKYO — In a direct act of rebellion against Tokyo Electric Power Company, which owns the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant, the local government in Tokyo is moving swiftly to build a huge natural gas facility that would generate as much electricity as a nuclear reactor.

headline: Gingrich Faces More Scrutiny Over Corporate Clients
text: In July 2009, before the health care debate became a topic of angry discussion around the country, Newt Gingrich weighed in on what would be one of its flashpoints — end-of-life care provisions to help families decide whether terminally ill patients should avoid aggressive, and costly, medical measures.

headline: San Diego Union-Tribune Sold to Hotelier for More Than $100 Million
text: The San Diego Union-Tribune, one of the largest and most influential newspapers in California, was sold to a local developer for “above” $110 million, voiceofsandiego.org reported Thursday afternoon.

headline: Ricky Wyatt
text: After Ricky Wyatt died, the circle that gathered around him to say goodbye was small. Just a clutch of people in a funeral chapel in Tuscaloosa, Ala., friends and family members and some of those who had traveled beside him on a long journey toward justice for the mentally ill and disabled.

headline: Hamas-Appointed Court Fines Gaza Banks
text: GAZA — In what could be the first of many such decisions, a Hamas-appointed court this week ordered two major banks in Gaza to pay tens of millions of dollars in back fees and fines for refusing to accept the taxing power of the Hamas government, rather than its West-Bank-based rival, the Palestinian Authority.

headline: Eritrea Players Return Home After Losing World Cup Qualifier
text: All 18 players on Eritrea’s national team flew home after a 3-1 defeat at Rwanda in a match Tuesday that knocked the team out of 2014 World Cup qualification. It was Eritrea’s first away match since 2009, when 12 members of the team did not return after a regional tournament in Kenya. They claimed asylum, and 11 were later granted political asylum in Australia. More coverage at nytimes.com/goal.

headline: Connecticut Utility Chief Quits After Delays in Restoring Power
text: Jeffrey D. Butler, who was the beleaguered face of Connecticut’s biggest utility as it struggled for more than 10 days to restore power to hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses after a late-October snowstorm, resigned under pressure on Thursday.

headline: Patent Case Will Test Court
text: The United States Supreme Court has a chance to reverse the mission creep in patent law. The system is supposed to reward inventors but not stifle innovation. Fuzzy and overly broad concepts like thought processes generally are not protected. Yet one company, Prometheus Laboratories, reckons it owns a method for interpreting how patients react to a drug.

headline: Boeing Reports a Record Sale
text: The Boeing Company said Thursday that Indonesia’s Lion Air would sign an agreement to buy 230 new 737-model jetliners with a list value of $21.7 billion, a record transaction for the company.

headline: Friday: Lead-In To an Exciting Announcement
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome to Friday the 13th. Don’t bother looking at your calendar; it’s not really the 13th. But there are a whopping 13 fresh entries in Joe DiPietro’s grid today, and I had so much fun solving this puzzle that I’ve decided it has to be some sort of notable day. If you have any other standards-friendly suggestions, feel free to leave them in the comments.

headline: Drug Highs and Irreversible Lows
text: Dael Orlandersmith’s “Horsedreams” begins with a paean to Saturday night. At first it seems like mere scene-setting when Desiree, dancing at a club, describes her week as a prelude to letting loose, but it becomes an apt metaphor for an unbalanced life.

headline: An Enduring Marriage of Wit and Lust
text: There’s more than one way to wear a bath towel. That’s the sum total of Kim Cattrall’s entrance costume in Richard Eyre’s larky revival of Noël Coward’s “Private Lives,” which opened on Thursday night at the Music Box Theater.

headline: Should Candidates Have to Pass a Civics Test?
text: The federal government requires applicants for certain civil service jobs to take a written exam. The same holds true for the foreign service.

headline: Pakistani Envoy Offers to Resign Over Memo
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s ambassador to the United States, Husain Haqqani, has offered to resign amid a political and diplomatic storm in Pakistan over a mysterious memo, which asks for American help in dealing with the Pakistani military and Mr. Haqqani is accused of orchestrating.

headline: Low Expectations, and Trepidation, Over Meeting a Debt Deadline
text: Expectations that the special Congressional committee will strike a deal on debt reduction by Wednesday’s deadline could not be much lower. The committee’s own members have played down the odds. Stock prices may already reflect the likelihood of a punt. And one of the major ratings agencies has said the lack of an agreement, by itself, will not result in a downgrade of government debt.

headline: Inspector Visits Sardi’s. Free Cheese Ends.
text: It was a tradition at bars like the ones in Sardi’s in the theater district: a communal cheese pot with a knife sticking out, and some crackers. First-nighters or late-nighters grabbed the knife and a cracker, spread the cheese — cheddar — and ate. Some called it dinner.

headline: In ‘Late Show’ Preview, Cain Talks 9-9-9 Plan
text: Herman Cain will appear on CBS’s “Late Show With David Letterman”  on Friday, and a short preview of the appearance, which was taped Thursday, shows a smiling, relaxed candidate chatting about his economic plan.

headline: Lawmakers at Loggerheads on Deficit
text: WASHINGTON — With just days remaining before their final deadline, members of a Congressional panel on deficit reduction made frenzied efforts on Thursday to overcome an impasse, but appeared to be talking past one another and reported no tangible progress toward an agreement.

headline: The Technocratic Nightmare
text: During the first half of the 1990s, I lived in Brussels and wrote about the European Union, among other subjects, for The Wall Street Journal. This was the heyday of European integration. Helmut Kohl, François Mitterrand and Jacques Delors were in power, negotiating the Maastricht Treaty and organizing the common currency.

headline: Syracuse’s Boeheim Stands By Assistant Accused of Abuse
text: Syracuse University placed the associate head basketball coach Bernie Fine on administrative leave Thursday night after a former ball boy for the team told ESPN that he was molested by Fine.

headline: Even in Churches, Wall Street Protesters Can’t Escape Watch of Police
text: Several dozen Occupy Wall Street demonstrators were sleeping on the cushioned pews of a United Methodist church on the Upper West Side on Thursday morning when one of them spotted a man in plainclothes wandering through the sanctuary, apparently counting heads.

headline: European Rift on Bank’s Role in Debt Relief
text: FRANKFURT — The financial stability of Europe has come down to one institution, the European Central Bank, which is now under heavy new pressure to rescue the euro — or possibly see it collapse.

headline: U.S. Military Goes Online to Rebut Extremists’ Messages
text: MacDILL AIR FORCE BASE, Fla. — The morning sun had barely cast its fresh light over Tampa Bay when Ardashir Safavi — born in Iran, a refugee to Turkey, educated in the mid-Atlantic states — was up and patrolling two dozen Persian-language Web sites, hunting militant adversaries in cyberspace.

headline: First Lady Takes On the Role of Staff Energizer
text: Young campaign workers looked up from their pizza at Obama re-election headquarters in Chicago one evening last month to find an unexpected guest: the first lady of the United States, there to deliver a surprise pep talk.

headline: New York Family Courts Say Keep Out, Despite Order
text: New York State’s Family Courts were ordered to be opened to the public with much fanfare in 1997, supposedly allowing anyone to witness the cases of domestic violence, foster care and child neglect that inch through by the hundreds of thousands every year. But now, 14 years later, the Family Courts remain essentially, almost defiantly, closed to the general public.

headline: Laid Off and Struggling to Provide, but Hoping Daughters Will Get Out
text: Ever since her high school took her on a college tour, Natalia Burks has had her heart set on going to Morgan State University in Baltimore to study forensic science. She has no connection to Baltimore, having grown up in subsidized housing on Edgecombe Avenue in West Harlem. But there was something about the romance of that tour that made Ms. Burks, now 18, believe she could go outside the customary boundaries of her life.

headline: ‘I’m a Mormon’ Advertising Campaign
text: To counter negative perceptions of their religion, leaders of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints commissioned an advertising campaign highlighting the lives and diversity of regular Mormons.

headline: Mormons’ Ad Campaign May Play Out on the ’12 Campaign Trail
text: After Sunday worship in recent months, Mormon bishops around the country gathered their congregations for an unusual PowerPoint presentation to unveil the church’s latest strategy for overcoming what it calls its “perception problem.”

headline: Perry’s Latest Attacks Distort Obama’s Words and Past
text: Over the past several days, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has claimed that President Obama called Americans “lazy.” And then he sharpened the attack, suggesting that Mr. Obama grew up a child of privilege.

headline: A Mormon Ad Buy, and the Political Sensitivities
text: The ads that the Mormon Church is running to soften its image are notable not only for where they are being shown — but where they are not.

headline: Texas Right Offers Fast Embrace to G.O.P. Newcomer
text: Like Senator Marco Rubio in Florida, Ted Cruz is trying to stage an upset in the Republican primary for the Senate race.

headline: A Test for the Tea Party in Texas Senate Race
text: RICHLAND HILLS, Tex. — The National Review cover proclaimed him “the great conservative hope.” George Will declared him “as good as it gets.” Influential conservatives endorsed him and gave him speaking slots alongside presidential candidates at national gatherings, where the crowds rewarded him with standing ovations.

headline: Clinton Set to Visit Myanmar as Obama Cites Progress
text: BANGKOK — Citing “flickers of progress” in Myanmar’s political climate, President Obama announced Friday that he was sending Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on a visit next month, the first by a secretary of state in more than 50 years.

headline: Vatican Threatens Legal Action to Stop Benetton Ad
text: The Vatican said Thursday that it would take legal action to prevent the distribution of an advertisement by the Benetton clothing company showing Pope Benedict XVI kissing a prominent Egyptian imam. The Vatican said it had told its lawyers in Italy and abroad to “take the proper legal measures” to block the use of an altered photo it considered “damaging to not only to the dignity of the pope and the Catholic Church but also to the feelings of believers.” Responding to earlier protests, Benetton said Wednesday that it would withdraw the ad, part of a campaign of photo montages showing religious and political leaders kissing. A company spokesman apologized for causing offense, saying the ad campaign was intended to combat hatred.

headline: The Cocktail Party: A Subtle Blend of Political Views
text: Do you enjoy a cocktail? Do you also have disgust for the state of the political discourse in this country?

headline: Britain: ‘Occupy’ Protesters Defy London Deadline
text: Protesters occupying land around St. Paul’s Cathedral, part of a worldwide movement against economic inequality, defied a deadline from London authorities on Thursday to remove their sprawling encampment or face legal action. City officials left eviction notices across the camp on Wednesday, saying that unless tents were removed by 6 p.m. Thursday, the city would seek a court eviction order. Hundreds of tents remained after the deadline. Protesters said they had no intention of moving and were wary after forceful police evictions in similar camps across the United States. The legal action will be likely to take weeks, the city said, though the initial hearings could take place as soon as next week. “We’d still like to sort this without court action,” a spokesman said, “but from now on we will have to have any talks in parallel with court action, not instead.”

headline: Deadly Storms Tear Through the South
text: ATLANTA — A severe weather front that ripped through five Southeastern states on Wednesday, killing at least six people and injuring scores, marked the beginning a fall storm season that is likely to bring more trouble to a region that has barely recovered from an unusually deadly string of spring tornadoes.

headline: Corrections: November 18
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: NYT Front Page for 11/18/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 11/18/2011

headline: Word of the Day | ignominy
text: ignominy •\ˈig-nə-ˌmi-ne, -mə-ne also ig-ˈnä-mə-ne\• noun

headline: Another Poor Showing by Sanchez
text: A capsule look at the Jets’ 17-13 loss to Denver.

headline: Mayor’s Next Big Test: Negotiations With Labor
text: After Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s highly public five-week push to win City Council approval for his first annual budget, the next phase of the mayor’s efforts to restore Chicago’s fiscal health will take place mostly behind closed doors.

headline: In the End, the Jets Can’t Stop Tebow
text: DENVER — This is what frustration looks like: Rex Ryan, standing behind a lectern, appearing to fight back tears, his eyes red, his voice quavering. This is what frustration sounds like: Darrelle Revis saying that he was shocked, over and over and over again. This is what frustration feels like: abject helplessness, as Eric Smith watched Tim Tebow sprint around the corner, watched him race to the end zone, watched him celebrate the touchdown that sank the Jets on Thursday night and, maybe, for the year.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 62
text: Although protesters did not achieve their goal of shutting down the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday morning, one protester was able to get to the second floor of the stock exchange wearing a suit and posted a pro-OWS sign there.

headline: Berkeley Crackdown Raises Fear of Move Backward
text: On Tuesday, protesters wheeled blackboards and pianos onto Sproul Plaza at the University of California, Berkeley. Thousands gathered near the famous steps for a day of teach-ins, music and speeches — one of the largest protests on the campus since the 1960s.

headline: Financing for Meals on Wheels Threatened
text: On Tuesday morning, an elderly woman lowered a wicker basket tied to a rope from the second-floor window of a low-income apartment building in South Berkeley. On the sidewalk outside the building’s gate, Freya Fuchs, a volunteer driver for Meals on Wheels, caught the basket and put a hot meal into it: baked catfish with Veracruz sauce, toasted barley, soup, broccoli and a banana. The woman hoisted the food back up into her home.

headline: Changes in Redistricting Are Near, but March Is Still the Month to Watch
text: Federal judges proposed new political maps for the state late Thursday, and hope to have new Congressional and legislative maps in place for Texas on the Monday after Thanksgiving.

headline: Humphries’s Endorsement Party: It’s Not About the Watch
text: With the N.B.A. season on hold, with visions of David Stern and David Boies dancing in your basketball-deprived head and with the issues of contracts, fairness and what is due consuming more time than it should, we turn to more weighty issues.

headline: Graffiti Taggers Turn to Trees, With Some Possibly Harmful Effects
text: Outside Elixir bar in the Mission district of San Francisco, graffiti taggers have left their mark — not on the wall, but on the living. Every tree on that 16th Street block has been spray-painted in shades of purple, red, white and black.

headline: Award Unites Artists, Collectors and a Museum

For six Saturdays, the well-heeled lot traipses through small studios and edgy galleries, looking at delicate line drawings and sprawling sculptural installations alike, to meet the people they hope will become the next generation of Bay Area visual art stars.

The steps come two days after the government announced it would allow foreign direct investment of up to 26 percent in pension funds and establish a pension regulator.

headline: Nov. 18, 1976 | Spanish Parliament Chooses Democracy

headline: U.S. Plans New Sanctions Against Iran’s Oil Industry

headline: Should People Be Allowed to Obscure Their Identities Online?
text: The writer Salman Rushdie emerged victorious in a spat with Facebook over his identity, in which the social network company required him to use his legal given first name, Ahmed. The conflict has given more attention to the whole question of identity online. Should people be allowed to be anonymous, or obscure their identities, online? Or should they be required to identify themselves? Something in between?

headline: Are We All Ugly Indians?
text: On a warm, sunny Saturday morning this month, about a hundred men and women gathered on Church Street in the heart of Bangalore. Dressed in white T-shirts, plastic gloves and masks that concealed their identity, they held brooms, mops and small buckets of paint. The group set out to clean the major roads of Bangalore, wielding placards that read “Kaam chalu, mooh bandh” (speak less, work more).

headline: ‘Filthy, Gorgeous’ Kolkata
text: Father and son Max and Alex Vadukul traveled to Kolkata this summer, to photograph the city’s thinkers, writers and artist. “The misunderstood city welcomed our curiosity. Its grim slums, incessant Ambassador taxi horns and unpleasant street odors tested us at first, but we eventually developed a great affection for the place,” Alex writes in this article for “T,” the New York Times Style Magazine. A slide show of their portraits is here.

headline: Russia’s War Against Rainbows
text: MOSCOW — “Propaganda of homosexuality”: the wording sounds almost quaint in English, like a panicky phrase out of the 1970s backlash to the early gay liberation movement in the United States. But in Russia, the phrase is current: This week lawmakers have been talking of banning “propaganda of homosexuality” — whatever the phrase may mean.

headline: A Musical-Satire Interlude
text: Recently I saw Tim Minchin perform at Town Hall in New York. Minchin is an Australian comic who plays a mean piano and sings satirical songs — a modern Tom Lehrer in skinny jeans and teased hair who cavorts onstage barefoot. Seeing Minchin and then reading Adam Sternbergh’s profile of Bret McKenzie, who is one-half of the duo Flight of the Conchords, in this week’s magazine made me think a lot about the clever art of musical satire. And by ‘‘think a lot,’’ I mean that I spent a great many hours on YouTube laughing at guys singing funny songs and tirelessly culling the ones not too profane to post. This was work, people. Here you go:

headline: Send in the Clouds
text: Like pretty much everyone in Ecuador, Roque Sevilla drives fast. I hurtle with him from the capital of Quito down two and a half hours of gut-stirring switchbacks, losing elevation with every turn. The sugar-cane and cattle farmsteads tumbling past on either side dwindle steadily, while the surrounding forests gain in age and power.

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 18
text: 8:55 a.m. | Updated  The business of politics is good business for TV, CBS’s chief executive, Leslie Moonves, said Thursday during a question-and-answer session at a Hollywood Radio and Television Society luncheon at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills, The Los Angeles Times reported. With its range of TV and radio stations, CBS could collect as much as $250 million of the estimated $2.4 billion that is expected to be generated by political campaigns across the country, The Times wrote. Such sums have only grown larger because of a 2010 Supreme Court ruling allowing unlimited campaign spending by corporations and unions.

A group of soldier-singers had taken the stage, but when a woman started her solo, the nine cadets stormed out. Four of them refused to come back to the hall, despite being warned that they were breaching an order, and two days later were expelled from the school.

headline: Inside the List
text: ‘UNBROKEN’ STREAK: Happy B-day — that’s B for “best seller” — to Laura Hillenbrand, whose book “Unbroken” has now spent a full 52 weeks on the hardcover nonfiction list: long enough to sit up and respond to its name, according to that other perennial best seller, “What to Expect When You’re Expecting.” “Unbroken” tells the story of Louis Zamperini, an Olympic runner who was taken prisoner and tortured by the Japanese during World War II. It entered the list at No. 2 last Dec. 5, just below another book about war and torture, George W. Bush’s “Decision Points,” and just above Jay-Z’s “Decoded.” Hillenbrand’s book has outlasted more than a hip-hop star’s and a two-term president’s, though. Impressively, it’s also vanquished her own previous best seller, “Seabiscuit,” which logged 30 weeks on the list back in 2001-2 before making way for the paperback edition. We’ll never know whether Man O’ War could have beaten his grandson Sea­biscuit, but now we have proof that Prisoner O’ War can.

headline: 2013 Infiniti IPL G Convertible: More of Everything, Except a Roof

headline: Editors’ Choice

headline: Amgen Agreement on Anemia Drug
text: Moving to protect a lucrative monopoly against impending competition, Amgen has reached an agreement that will preserve its status as the main supplier of anemia drugs to one of the nation’s two large kidney dialysis chains. The dialysis chain, DaVita, agreed that Amgen’s drug, Epogen, will account for at least 90 percent of its purchases of that type of anemia drug through the end of 2018. DaVita will get discounts and rebates on the drug, Amgen said in a regulatory filing Friday morning. Read the article by Andrew Pollack.

headline: Paperback Row
text: AT HOME: A Short History of Private Life,  by Bill Bryson (Anchor, $15.95.) In “A Short History of Nearly Everything” (2003), Bryson took a cosmic perspective on the creation of the universe. With “At Home,” he set out to “write a history of the world without leaving home.” Guiding readers on a tour of his house — a former rectory built in 1851 in an English village — Bryson uses each room as a means to explore the domestic artifacts we take for granted.

I begged off when it came to the cornbread stuffing because I’ve been trying to go easy on the carbs these days, and also, you know, um, it wasn’t actually Thanksgiving.

headline: Did Israel Actually Lose the 1967 War?
text: Let me list, at the outset, the many things that the diminutive but disproportionately interesting state of Israel is not. I do this in recognition of the fact that mere mention of Israel can send its critics into paroxysms of rhetorical excess seldom heard outside ESPN. So: Israel is not a fascist state, nor is it a theocracy nor, for that matter, is it a fascist theocracy. It is not an apartheid state, a totalitarian state or, God forbid, a Nazi state. It is, for its region in particular, a model of Western values, a country in possession of a robustly independent judiciary; a boisterous, appropriately unkempt press; a mature and activist civil society; and an assortment of fearless and effective human rights organizations.

headline: F.D.A. Revokes Approval of Avastin for Use as Breast Cancer Drug
text: The commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration on Friday revoked the approval of the drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer, ruling on an emotional issue that pitted the hopes of some desperate patients against the statistics of clinical trials.

headline: This week, historian David Greenberg assesses Ann Beattie’s new novel, “Mrs. Nixon: A Life”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Alexander Star takes an anthropological view of Afghanistan; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news.
text: This week, historian David Greenberg assesses Ann Beattie’s new novel, “Mrs. Nixon: A Life”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Alexander Star takes an anthropological view of Afghanistan; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news.

headline: Umberto Eco and the Elders of Zion
text: When I was first learning quantum mechanics, I would occasionally feel compelled to lodge a complaint on behalf of common sense. My physics teacher would fix me with his twinkling gaze and intone, “Truth is stranger than fiction.” He was right, and not only about the behavior of elementary particles. Umberto Eco’s latest fiction, “The Prague Cemetery,” is choreographed by a truth that is itself so strange a novelist need hardly expand on it to produce a wondrous tale. Eco forthrightly explains that all his major characters but one are historical figures; but a reader unaware of how close to the truth Eco is hewing might be inclined to award him more points for inventiveness than he earns. This is not to say that Eco doesn’t earn points for inventiveness, nor that a novel can’t succeed on other grounds. It is just to say that sometimes truth is stranger than fiction.

headline: A Marc Jacobs Collection Goes Missing
text: It has been described as a heist, the fashion crime of the season: the announcement, Thursday afternoon, that the Marc Jacobs spring/summer 2012 collection had been stolen on the way from Paris to London, where it was to be paraded in front of the press.

headline: Afghanistan: What the Anthropologists Say
text: Ten years after the Taliban’s leaders fled their country in apparent defeat, the war in Afghanistan has become what one observer calls “a perpetually escalating stalemate.” As in Iraq, the United States military has responded to bad news with counterinsurgency: eliminate troublemakers in the dark of night, with the most lethal arts, and befriend tribal elders by day, with cultural sensitivity and expertise. The Army has gone so far as to embed credentialed social scientists with front-line troops in “Human Terrain Teams” that engage in “rapid ethnographic assessment” — conducting interviews and administering surveys, learning about land disputes, social networks and how to “operationalize” the Pashtun tribal code.

headline: Families That Most Need Guidance Counselors' Help Don't Always Get It
text: Public middle schools in New York City can decide for themselves how much guidance to provide eighth graders about the high school choice process, so many parents, especially those without the means to hire someone, are often left adrift to make decisions that will be consequential for their children.

headline: From Here to Oaxaca

Before the end and after the beginning, one celebrates a perfect sixth birthday, looks for a job, has an affair, remembers old girlfriends, suffers a stroke. These are the moments Dagoberto Gilb describes in his elegiac third story collection, “Before the End, After the Beginning.”

headline: Importing Italian Cuisine
text: There was absolutely no reason for Alfred A. Knopf to publish a substantive book on high-end Italian cooking in the 1950s. Few homemakers at the time were even aware that Italian cooking had a high end. America’s aspirational cuisine was French, and ambitious home cooks had their hands full trying to perfect coq au vin and crêpes suzette. Unless you were lucky enough to have grown up in an Italian family, Italian food meant spaghetti and meatballs, and Betty Crocker had a nice, easy recipe for it.

headline: Paperless Boarding?
text: To the Editor: Re “A Boarding Pass on Your Screen” (Practical Traveler, Nov. 6), it’s a young technology, but when it works, it works really well. While it may not be terribly useful on vacation, the technology really shines when you’re traveling on business and making last-minute flight changes. More than once I’ve been able to make earlier flights by checking in from my phone and getting to the airport 20 to 30 minutes before my flight.
