headline: A Pause in the Tebow Argument
text: To enjoy the conclusion of Thursday night’s Broncos-Jets game, you did not have to buy into the legend of Tim Tebow or care one whit about his religion or politics or the ridiculousness of the Tebowing craze. You didn’t even have to hate the Jets or detest the word “Sanchize,” although that would be a plus. Even without all of that, it was possible to sit back and marvel at how preposterous Tebow’s winning touchdown drive was, after 54 minutes of acting as if he had stumbled into a football game for the first time and decided to play quarterback.

headline: Answers to ‘Where on Earth to Eat?’
text: IT’S no secret that Anthony Bourdain knows his way around food — but he’s also a world traveler, who has eaten in hundreds of spots around the globe. His new show, “The Layover,” on the Travel Channel, has him visiting cities for 48 hours or less, looking for the best places for travelers to eat and drink. Here are excerpts from a conversation about some all-time favorites.

headline: How Graphic Should Sex Education Get?
text: How much time should a high school student devote to sex education? In four years of school, a student in a district on a semester schedule might take a total of 48 classes, with more than half going to core subjects and some smaller number of electives: language, music, art, theater  (more in a school that offers more than six classroom periods daily). Starting in January, New York City public high school students will spend at least one of those semesters in a mandatory sex education class (as will middle schoolers). The sex ed can take place in (or take the place of) existing health education classes or be added to the curriculum, and what is taught and how is left to the discretion of the schools.

headline: At Agriturismo, Mark Strausman’s Farm-to-Table Approach
text: Mark Strausman has built his reputation as a chef creating Italian food for the haute crowd at Fred’s at Barneys New York, one of Manhattan’s top see-and-be-seen lunch spots. But Mr. Strausman always dreamed of opening a country restaurant that would become a draw for its good food and country setting.

headline: Can’t Place the Name, but the Typeface Is Familiar
text: With the opening two months ago of the National September 11 Memorial, the black-white-and-blue “9/11 Memorial” trademark has turned up just about everywhere in Lower Manhattan, even on subway signs that have never before been branded with the logo of a private corporation.

headline: Eating in Copenhagen? Lucky You
text: NOT since the ‘90s, when El Bulli’s establishment as the most heralded restaurant in the world sparked a culinary transformation in northeastern Spain, has a city changed its image as an eating destination the way Copenhagen has done recently, leaving the rest of Scandinavia — and indeed Northern Europe — to catch up. In the last couple of years, as the city’s most prominent restaurant, Noma, has received one accolade after another, insiders have flocked to Copenhagen to sample what Noma’s chef, René Redzepi, has done with Nordic cuisine. Down-to-earth but remarkably novel, his hyperlocal approach combines woods and sea in ways that are distinctively, if not Danish, then at least Scandinavian.

headline: Made-for-TV Movies, Reborn on Cable
text: IT’S a scene a movie studio might once have spilled a little blood for: Bill Pullman, stepping into the shoes of Harrison Ford as Rusty Sabich, the prosecutor turned suspected murderer in “Presumed Innocent,” the 1990 hit based on the thriller by Scott Turow. Marcia Gay Harden as Rusty’s brilliantly deranged spouse. Alfred Molina as the defense lawyer Sandy Stern. And Mr. Turow himself, who, despite initial resistance to writing a sequel, revisiting the Sabich saga some 20 years later.

headline: Going Abroad, Staying Authentic
text: SLUMPED in the back seat of a Singapore cab, punchy after a 17-hour flight but rising to the challenge of the omnipresent camera, Anthony Bourdain gets a little silly about the odorous consequences of long-distance air travel combined with subpar airplane food. Bringing up one of his favorite whipping girls, his fellow Travel Channel host Samantha Brown, he grins like a schoolboy and delivers the zinger: “Sam Brown has an assistant who stands outside the bathroom and runs in and takes the blame.”

headline: Fresh Gospel and Old Schools
text: Jessica Reedy

headline: Weekend Fare
text: For every burger sold between 11 a.m. and midnight on Friday at Fresh and Fast Burgers, 111 East 23rd Street (Park Avenue South) in the Flatiron district, a burger will be donated to the Bowery Mission, which serves people who are homeless, to supplement Thanksgiving donations next week.

headline: Smart Finds in San Francisco Amid Its Grit
text: At the north end of the Valencia Street corridor you’ll find the Mission Police Station and the odd shouting inebriated denizen on the same block as camera-phone-wielding French tourists and high-end home-design stores.

headline: Friday Reading: Don’t Cook That Reagan-Era Turkey
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Hotel Review: La Belle Juliette, in Paris
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: D.H.S. Responds on Deportation
text: A representative from Homeland Security, Matt Chandler, took issue with a blog post I wrote yesterday about a new deportation policy, arguing that I’d unfairly questioned the department’s intentions.

headline: Where Should I Go Out for Thanksgiving Dinner?
text: Q.

headline: Japan’s Capsule Hotels Go High Tech and High Style
text: EVENING was falling in the old Japanese capital of Kyoto, and I was tucking myself into a container slightly larger than a refrigerator. I pulled down the shade and, after a bit of contorting, lay down, the wall a few inches from my feet. It was a dainty little space, about 3 ¼ feet wide and 6 ½ feet long, charmingly traditional with rice-paper latticework and two woven-reed mats. I felt like an origami crane as I folded my 6-foot-2-inch frame into this “tatami capsule.”

headline: Mayor Warns of Potential School Bus Strike
text: The bus drivers' union, Amalgamated Transit Union Local 1181, has told the city it will order a strike if the city does not include provisions in the bid guaranteeing seniority-based job protections for their members in case the companies that employ them are not awarded new city contracts. The mayor called the threat "outrageous."

headline: At Murrow, Missing Mr. Fattorusso, Ms. Totillo, Ms. Leone and Ms. Senia
text: Edward R. Murrow High School lost four members of its staff to the budget cuts that hit schools all over the city last month. Reporters for the student newspaper talked with them about losing their jobs.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $15.5 Million
text: A four-bedroom apartment in the Superior Ink building at 400 West 12th Street that sold for $15.5 million was the most expensive sale of the week, according to Streeteasy.com. And with each square foot of gilded space costing $4,234, it is one of the priciest non-penthouse purchases of the year, brokers said.

headline: Lens: Turning Point — Liz Hingley
text: Lens: Turning Point — Liz Hingley

headline: Dodge Charger Super Bee and Challenger Yellow Jacket Pack Hemis and Heritage
text: LOS ANGELES — Back in the day, 1968 to be exact, a Dodge Coronet was stripped down, offered with a Hemi, renamed the Super Bee and rolled out as part of the Scat Pack, Dodge’s exclusive coterie of high-performance cars. In 1971, the Charger inherited the Super Bee name. In either configuration, the Bee distinction was a hit with muscle-car enthusiasts, who could enlist the limited-edition cars as commuters or as fierce drag-strip competitors.

headline: Fill-In | Chinese Brands
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in several paragraphs in this article from the Business section, “Picking Brand Names in China Is a Business Itself.”

headline: Lady Miss Kiev
Deal Assures Market for Anemia Drug
text: Moving to protect a lucrative monopoly against impending competition, Amgen has reached an agreement that will preserve its status as the main supplier of anemia drugs to one of the nation’s two large kidney dialysis chains.

headline: Rembrandts on Exhibit, for Adults Only
text: Long dismissed as dirty little secrets, Rembrandt’s erotic etchings have been known to collectors for centuries but rarely seen by the public. In 2001 the British Museum exhibited several of the prints. Now, the World Erotic Art Museum (weam.com) in Miami Beach is showing the entire collection together — 20 etchings — for the first time.

headline: James Franco and Laurel Nakadate Rough It With Tennessee Williams
text: A certain rough-around-the-edges improvisational looseness – a sense of something coming together before your eyes, or not quite – may be one of the things that distinguishes performance art from theater. Even so, the commissions brought forth by Performa 11 over the past two weeks have tended toward an excessive disjointedness, alleviated by brief flashes of brilliance. This was the case Sunday afternoon at the Abrons Art Center on Grand Street, where the video artist Laurel Nakadate and the versatile actor James Franco collaborated on “Three Performances in Search of Tennessee.” It seemed very much a work in progress.

headline: A New Wall Street Photo Meme: Bankers Carrying Boxes
Delusions Of Mobility
text: Greg Sargent sends us to Paul Ryan’s latest — an attempt to debunk the CBO report on income inequality. As usual, Ryan makes me think of Ezra Klein’s old line about Dick Armey: he’s a stupid person’s idea of what a smart person sounds like.

headline: Off the Charts: Germany’s Strong Recovery
text: Since the world economy hit bottom in 2009, Germany has mounted one of the strongest recoveries of any major country. But the rest of the euro zone has lagged. The charts show changes in real gross national product since the second quarter of 2009 of nine countries in the euro zone, as well as the three largest industrial nations not in it — the United States, Britain and Japan.

headline: The Barefoot Way
text: Christopher McDougall is an ardent proponent of barefoot running, but as the number of tendo-achilles and calf injuries related to running barefoot rises, it is clear to those of us who treat ailing runners that this is not the ideal form for everyone. Just as there are alternate styles of swimming or hitting a baseball, biomechanics shows us that runners should develop their own style to maximize performance.

headline: Obama By the Numbers
text: I read with great interest Nate Silver’s article, “Handicapping Obama 2012,” in connection with the models used in his and others’ analyses. One question I would have liked to see addressed: Per Silver’s model, if the categories of approval ratings and the national economic performance are still unimproved (or if they worsen) by the 2012 election, Obama will not be able to defeat Romney, given the latter’s moderate ideological score. Yet large percentages of Republicans are still displaying an “anybody but Romney” attitude sufficient to propel a series of extremist candidates into a tie with him. That being the case, why the assumption that the multitudes of apparent Romney haters (that is, those rejecting him when he is manifestly the most electable candidate in the pack) will support him in 2012?

headline: ‘Housewives,’ Rebranded
text: In 2000, Charlotte Brunsdon published a book called “The Feminist, the Housewife and the Soap Opera,” which asked: Why were the feminist critics of the 1970s so interested in the soap-opera genre? The reasons, Brunsdon argued, varied but were largely tied to the fact that soap operas helped feminist theorists define themselves in opposition to what the book’s jacket refers to as “an imagined other, the soap-opera-watching housewife.”

headline: Damage Control
text: My daughter briefly dated a boy who clearly had many psychological problems. He confided in my daughter that his brother molested him throughout his childhood, until he was old enough to put a stop to it. He said he never told the many therapists his parents dragged him to, and would die before telling his parents. Now he works part time in child care and is considering a career in nursing. Based on my limited knowledge that certain behaviors often repeat, am I wrong that he poses a danger to children? Don’t his parents have a right to know? What, if anything, should I do? ANONYMOUS

headline: Stephanie Madoff Mack Keeps Busy
text: In your book, “The End of Normal,” you write about a girlfriend setting you up on a blind date with your future husband, Mark Madoff, whom she described as “one of the wealthiest men in New York.” Was that appealing?  No. I never wanted to be some sort of socialite, and I don’t think that’s what Mark wanted. He always told me that one of the reasons he liked me so much from the beginning is because I wore a Timex.

headline: The 1.7-Sketch-Per-Mile Marathon
text: Christoph Niemann draws and tweets 45 sketches during the New York Marathon.

headline: Packing Heat at the Gate
text: The first thing you notice upon entering Mitiga Airport in Tripoli is a series of signs with the word “No” in capital letters next to illustrations of automatic weapons. The second thing is just how liberally most Libyans interpret these rules.

headline: The Turkey-Lurkey Bowl
text: By far the worst place to play football in Central Park is the raised field adjacent to the Metropolitan Museum. On all four sides there are opportunities for catastrophic injury. The least dangerous boundary is the west end zone, with its two tulip trees and their thick, spread branches — excellent for dashing in your brains while sprinting at full speed after a Hail Mary. The east end zone is worse. It terminates at a chest-high fence, beyond which is a 20-foot drop onto a concrete ramp. One sideline falls off in a steep, ankle-mangling declivity; the other is the Met’s Temple of Dendur gallery — a wall of glass.

headline: The Brüning Thing
text: Joe Weisenthal tells us about an analyst willing to risk a Godwin’s Law citation; Dylan Grice of SocGen points out that it was the deflationary policies of 1930-32, not the inflation of 1923, that brought you-know-who to power.

headline: Can You Suggest a Vegetarian Main Course That Is Also Dairy- and Gluten-Free?
text: Q.

headline: TimesCast | November 18, 2011
text: Steps toward liberalization in Myanmar lead to a planned United States visit; tens of thousands of Islamists protest Egypt's military; and this week in the 2012 Republican presidential race.

headline: 5 Ways to Think About Nuisance Fees
text: If you have any doubt about the impact of the Bank of America debit card fee episode, consider a couple of things.

headline: Or Maybe Jabba The Hutt
text: An email to Brad DeLong:

headline: ‘Annoying Orange’ Parlays YouTube Success Into a TV Series
text: The Cartoon Network has decided to do a deal with the Annoying Orange, the smart-alecky Web series that attracted over 800 million views on YouTube.

headline: For Some, Free Music Is an Investment That Pays Off
text: What’s the value of a career’s worth of Internet buzz? Approximately 175,000 albums sold in one week — then look out below from there.

headline: Heaven Is a Place Called Elizabeth Warren
text: On the campaign trail in Massachusetts last month with the Senate candidate Elizabeth Warren, I bore witness to acts of extreme giddiness: a 20-year-old student jumping up and down, exclaiming, “Oh, my God, I am obsessed with her”; a third-year law student of Warren’s comparing her to a superhero (“Wonder Woman wishes she could be Professor Warren”); a man stopping Warren on the street and introducing himself as the guy who recently passed her a mash note on a plane (“I was hitting on you,” he said).

headline: The Glamorous Way to Carve a Turkey
text: By the 1960s, when consumers were besotted with electrical appliances, companies searched for new products to meet demand. The markets for larger goods were already saturated, so they experimented with smaller kitchen conveniences. And despite sometimes dubious utility, they were easy to sell: Don Drapers used electric ice-crushers for martinis; homemakers bought electric can openers. It was in this culture of demand that Jerome L. Murray — he of the audible pressure cooker and airplane boarding ramp — patented an early electric knife in 1964. G.E., which introduced its own model at a 1963 homes show, was quick to enter the market.

headline: With Rainfall and Aid, the Number Facing Starvation in Somalia Drops by Half a Million
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The drought-induced famine crisis in Somalia has eased somewhat, United Nations officials said on Friday, with the number of people facing imminent starvation dropping to nearly 250,000 from 750,000 because of rainfall and increased aid deliveries.

headline: U.S. Racing and the Rocky Factor
text: Within a few minutes on Friday I read a really funny and inspiring story in the French sports daily L’Equipe, and then the depressing news that the organizers of the United States Grand Prix had confirmed that they were likely to push the race in Austin back to 2013.

headline: U.S. Racing and the Rocky Factor
text: Within a few minutes on Friday I read a really funny and inspiring story in the French sports daily L’Equipe, and then the depressing news that the organizers of the United States Grand Prix had confirmed that they were likely to push the race in Austin back to 2013.

headline: The New Rules About Consumer Fees
text: Does the fee have any relationship whatsoever to the cost of the service? Do companies understand that they don’t have much leeway if we already are angry with them? Is a company telling the whole truth when it imposes a new fee? Are we getting something really neat in return? And are we worrying too much about the wrong types of fees — and not enough about ones that are truly consequential?

headline: Designing Malcolm Gladwell’s Doorstop
text: This February, e-book sales surpassed those of their paper counterparts for the first time. While digital books are clearly here to stay, the New York Times best-selling author Malcolm Gladwell recognizes that printed books can be beautiful, covetable objects that enhance the experience of reading. He hired Brian Rea, a frequent Times Magazine illustrator, and Paul Sahre, a designer who also frequently contributes to the magazine, to collaborate on the visuals for a new art box set, “Malcolm Gladwell: Collected.” It’s an illustrated collection of three of his books: “The Tipping Point,” “Blink” and “Outliers.”

headline: New Calls to Press Syria From France and Turkey
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — France joined Turkey in calling for greater international effort to exert pressure on Syria to stop its bloody crackdown on protesters, as at least 15 more people were reported killed on Friday.

headline: Sunny Jacobs and Peter Pringle
text: MOST married couples will tell you that the things they hold in common helped cement their relationships. For Sonia Jacobs, 64, and Peter Pringle, 73, married in New York last Sunday, common ground was the decade and a half each had served on death row before their convictions were overturned for the murders that they steadfastly maintained they did not commit.

headline: In the Labyrinth of Turkey Pricing, a Reason Under Every Giblet
text: I’M about to go out and buy a turkey. And naturally, because I write about finance, I was thinking about how much I would pay for it and, more specifically, whether the rising price of agricultural commodities and fuel had affected the cost.

headline: Which Economic Indicators Best Predict Presidential Elections?
text: I’ve written quite a bit in the past about the use and abuse of economic indicators in forecasting presidential elections.

headline: For a Changing Myanmar, the Real Tests Lie Ahead
text: BANGKOK — From dictatorship to quasi democracy in less than a year, the pace of change in Myanmar has stunned even the most cynical observers of the country.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Twin Sightings
text: The ever-imaginative writer Alan Moore pulls off a nice trick this week as his “Neonomicon,” illustrated by Jacen Burrows, arrives on the hardcover and softcover graphic novels list. The tale, about two F.B.I. officers investigating murders that are tied to a rogue agent, is at No. 6 on the hardcover list and No. 2 on the softcover one.

headline: European Union Blocks Afghanistan Film That It Financed
text: The documentary “In-Justice: The Story of Afghan Women in Jail” was financed by the European Union to show what Afghan justice can mean for its women.

headline: Goldman Names Managing Directors
text: Goldman Sachs has appointed 261 new managing directors, according to a list obtained by DealBook. It is the smallest class since 259 were named managing director in 2008, reflecting a broad cost-cutting effort at the firm.

headline: Bavaria Returns to the Upper East Side
text: Friends whose short memories did not register that the Yorkville section of Manhattan was once home to numerous German and Eastern European beer halls tried to discourage Pamela and Alan Rice from opening a beer store there. “They said that the Upper East Side is too upscale for beer, and people drink wine,” Ms. Rice said.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Is Sentenced to 5 Years
text: Joseph F. Skowron had everything going for him.

headline: Comptroller, Facing Inquiry, Promises ‘Full Accounting’ of His Fund-Raising
text: City Comptroller John C. Liu, whose campaign finances are under federal investigation, called the accusations of fund-raising improprieties “quite embarrassing” on Friday and promised New Yorkers “a full accounting.”

headline: Fire and Ice
text: AS if two 25-carat black opals weren’t enough, these showstoppers by the New York jeweler  Kimberly McDonald also contain white and gray diamonds, rubies and natural Burmese sapphires that were hand-carved in the 1920s. “These are bar none, my all-time favorite earrings,” Ms. McDonald said. “Opal is the only material that seems to possess an internal light. And, of course, no two are the same. The sapphires are unusual and exquisite.” Available at Bergdorf Goodman, for $142,670.

headline: A New Perspective on Crime Scenes
text: Using a camera called the Panoscan, the New York City Police Department creates 360-degree panoramic images of crime scenes.

headline: Winner in Redistricting Is Still to Be Determined
text: Republican legislative victories in the 2010 elections were hailed as a major opportunity for the party to redraw district lines to their benefit ahead of next year’s Congressional voting.

headline: The Caucus | This Week in the 2012 Race
text: Jeff Zeleny reports from Iowa on Herman Cain's new secret service protection and other events this week in the nominating contest.

headline: In Europe, Even a Powerhouse Is Losing Steam
text: SINCE the world economy hit bottom in early 2009, Germany has been the engine of growth in Europe. No major industrial economy — in or out of Europe — has grown as rapidly. But new figures released this week indicated that the German economy was growing at its slowest rate since the recovery began, and that much of Europe was no longer growing at all.

headline: U.S. Rookies Lead Way At the Presidents Cup
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Matt Kuchar had something to say. It was the start of the United States team’s news conference after the second day of play at the Presidents Cup, and a roomful of reporters sat armed with questions. Kuchar had other thoughts.

headline: TimesCast | A Milestone For Myanmar
text: November 18, 2011 - Democracy campaigner Daw Aung Sann Suu Kyi returns to politics, a show of Myanmar's sudden and stunning pace of change.

headline: TimesCast | Protesting Egypt's Military
text: Tens of thousands of Islamists descend on Tahrir Square to protest the Egyptian military's continued hold on power.

headline: Iger Says No Hurry to Replace Regis Philbin
text: Now that Regis Philbin has completed his long run on his ABC morning show, attention will naturally focus on who might replace him alongside Kelly Ripa. But Robert A. Iger, the chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, which owns ABC, said the search for the next Regis Philbin may be protracted.

headline: Face-to-Face With the Protesters
text: As a commercial photographer, August Bradley spends much of his time shooting projects for large corporate clients.

headline: Beyond Cornbread
text: Cornbread often makes an appearance at the Thanksgiving table, but as Martha Rose Shulman explains in this week’s Recipes for Health, home cooks can find lots of creative ways to use cornmeal.

headline: A Retailer’s Base Camp in Manhattan
text: Outdoor adventurers keep lists of life’s places to explore: Everest, El Capitan, the Middle Fork of the Salmon. On one unseasonably warm November day, Dyckman Street and 10th Avenue in Manhattan became one such destination, at least for nine newcomers to New York City.

headline: Rereading Joe Paterno, 2004 Edition
text: As the sexual-abuse case at Penn State continues to unfold, much of the unfolding means looking back. Above all, there are the law-enforcement and institutional investigations into what happened over the last dozen-plus years. Then there’s the journalistic impulse to cast a now-darker eye over past events, both small and innocent as well as large and iniquitous. In that first category, some of those lesser moments were themselves journalistic ones. There’s Jack McCallum’s 1999 Sports Illustrated profile of Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State assistant football coach accused of molesting several young boys, which McCallum returned to last week on SI.com. Bill Lyon’s column about Sandusky that same year in The Philadelphia Inquirer, which Josh Levin reconsiders at Slate.

headline: An Uprising With Plenty of Potential
text: In the wake of this week’s eviction of protesters from Zuccotti Park in New York and other urban campgrounds around the country, it’s tempting to dismiss the Occupy Wall Street movement as little more than a short-lived media phenomenon. The issues that spawned the movement — income inequality, money in politics and Wall Street’s influence — were being drowned out by debates over personal hygiene, noise and crime.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov.18
text: A look at the day in sports, from rhythmic gymnastics at the Southeast Asian Games to cricket in Johannesburg.

headline: Gym, Tan, Raise Venture Capital?
text: If it works for the cast of MTV’s Jersey Shore, can the faux-glow of a spray tan also bolster the image of a newly minted tech founder?

headline: New York as Venice, Minus the Romance
text: In Thursday’s Metro section, I wrote about a new report that details how climate change will affect New York State.

headline: Video of Remarks by Aung San Suu Kyi and Obama on Myanmar
text: As my colleagues Jackie Calmes and Thomas Fuller report, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of Myanmar’s democracy movement, “announced on Friday that she would rejoin the political system of the military-backed government that persecuted her for more than two decades.”

headline: Hungary Turns to I.M.F. For an ‘Insurance’ Pact
text: PARIS — Hungary is heading back to the International Monetary Fund for help, a year after slamming the door on the fund, the government said Friday. The move is the latest proof that the European debt crisis is spreading east.

headline: Scientists Report Second Sighting of Faster-Than-Light Neutrinos
text: Few scientists are betting against Einstein yet, but the phantom neutrinos of Opera are still eluding explanation.

headline: Once Again, Protesters Occupy the New School
text: Much of New York City may be having a hard time getting used to the presence of protesters, but at the New School, the progressive liberal-arts bastion in Greenwich Village, occupation is a semiregular occurrence.

headline: Brooklyn Gets a Marathon of Its Own, and Fills a Void for Runners
text: Ashley Schmidt will have the home-course advantage at the inaugural Brooklyn Marathon on Sunday.

headline: Egypt’s Islamists Confront the Military
text: Tens of thousands of Islamists and young activists massed Friday in Tahrir Square, confronting Egypt’s ruling military council with the largest crowd in months to protest the generals’ attempt to give themselves special powers over a future elected government.

headline: Familiar Last Week, Forest Is Now a Stranger
text: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the blow-up of last week.

headline: How Coffee Affects Biodiversity
text: S. Amanda Caudill, a doctoral student at the University of Rhode Island, writes from Costa Rica, where she is assessing mammal diversity on coffee farms.

headline: Bad Deal, Good Veto Threat on Detention
text: Sometimes I marvel at what passes for compromise in Washington.

headline: London Eyes
text: In a sea of bespoke everything, from suits to shoes, it is surprising that bespoke glasses are hard to come by. Cutler and Gross just introduced what it says is the first bespoke frame service in the world, at its chic flagship store in Knightsbridge, London. Frames fanciers can make a selection from more than 4,000 styles, dating from 1969 to present, in the store’s top-floor mirrored atelier. Frames can be made in the exact color to match a suit or dress, or even feature vintage lace. If the “perfect” frames are hard to find, you can design your own shape. All of the glasses are handmade in Italy and take a minimum of six weeks to make, so order now for the holidays. The kicker? Your name, or your beloved’s if you so choose, laser-inscribed on to the inside temple. Madonna, Kate Moss and Claudia Schiffer are fans.Bespoke service starts at $950. 16 Knightsbridge Green, London; 011-44-207-581-2250; cutlerandgross.com.

headline: Reading Bones to Identify Genocide Victims
text: Bones are life’s records. The forces of a lifetime — diet, accidents, age — are inscribed upon them. Forensics experts use bones to interpret these stories, or so-called osteobiographies, which can identify a person’s identity and cause of death.

headline: The Film ‘Soccer City’ Is Now Available
text: Soccer City: Comeback Kid from Nick Fitzhugh on Vimeo.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 11’s Toughest Picks
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Is It Ever Too Late to Extend a Thanksgiving Invitation?
text: Q.

headline: The Red Sox and Bobby Valentine: A Better Fit Than We Think?
text: Last winter, when a storm descended on Stamford, Conn., residents received a recorded phone message from the city’s director of public health and safety. The voice was authoritative and effusive, with a bit of a carnival barker mixed in. It was unmistakably Bobby Valentine.

headline: A Throwback Is True to Form, Feisty Right to the End
text: He is not irreplaceable.

headline: Caucus Video: This Week in the 2012 Race
text: Jeff Zeleny reports from Iowa on Herman Cain’s new secret service protection and other events this week in the nominating contest.

headline: Showtime Extends ‘Dexter’ for Two Seasons
text: The long bloody reign of “Dexter” on Showtime will continue for at least two more seasons.

headline: Monti Wins Broad Support in Parliament
text: Prime Minister Mario Monti of Italy on Friday won broad support in Parliament for his new government — whose mission will be to spur growth and reduce debt during a Europe-wide economic crisis — and called on lawmakers to work with him in a moment of hard decisions and sacrifice.

headline: Balanced Budget Amendment Falls Short in House
text: The House failed Friday to approve a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution, a central piece of the Republican fiscal agenda.

headline: Film Is Dead? What Else Is New?
text: A few weeks ago I traveled to a college on Long Island to give a lecture — in other words, to stand up in front of a room full of people, ramble for a few minutes about movies and movie criticism, and then spend the rest of the hour answering questions. It was the middle of the day, and the audience was composed, in what looked like roughly equal numbers, of undergraduates and older students enrolled in continuing education courses. Half of the people were 25 and under, the other half 65 and over, leaving me smack in the generational middle and, as it happened, bouncing vertiginously, from one question to the next, between the future and the past.

headline: In London, Wireless Charging for E.V.’s Gets a Power Surge
text: With the ink barely dry on its announcement that it had acquired HaloIPT, the wireless electric-vehicle charging company, Qualcomm, the wireless technology conglomerate, said this week that it planned to demonstrate HaloIPT’s technology in London next year. The project would be supported by the British government, city agencies and private industry partners.

headline: After 2 Years, Joy Behar Is Leaving HLN
text: The HLN cable channel is ending the comedian Joy Behar’s two-year-old talk show.

headline: This Weekend: What’s Your Sunday Routine?
text: As part of the Metropolitan section’s special Digital City issue, we’re turning the Sunday Routine column over to you, our readers.

headline: Accessible, From All 4 Corners of the World
text: THERE are still places where 18th Avenue, as it runs through Bensonhurst, looks like the Italian-American stronghold that it once was. Spaced at intervals along the street, also known as Cristoforo Colombo Boulevard, are businesses like Gino’s Focacceria, the Bari Pork Store, S.A.S. Italian Records and the Villabate Alba bakery.

headline: Photo Graphic
text: It’s not often that pieces from a designer’s collection end up in a gallery before they make it into stores, but such is the case for the designer Dries Van Noten. An exhibition that opened in Vienna yesterday, and that will later travel to Hong Kong, Tokyo and Paris, features a selection from Van Noten’s spring 2012 collection alongside photographs by the London-born artist James Reeve that inspired them. Among the pieces are Reeve’s photo of buildings in La Rouviere, a housing complex in Marseille, and the shirt that Van Noten applied it to. “I liked the mystery, the lights at night, the moment of wonder, where you’re questioning what’s happening on the other side of the windows,” says Van Noten of the image. Reeve, too, considers the picture quite voyeuristic. “It’s like 1,000 small colorful television screens all lined up in rows on the hillside,” he says. “I have often seen people peering into the windows, trying to discover what kind of activity is going on inside.” Other pieces on view with their corresponding photographs include Van Noten’s bridge shift and “Circus, Circus” top. “I’m used to seeing my work as two-dimensional,” Reeve says. “It was inspiring to see Dries translate it into dynamic forms –– the way the ruffle skirts seem to almost play with the lights as they move, the colored crystals that he sewed into the windows of La Rouviere. I thought that was a really beautiful idea.”

headline: Wasting Medicare Money?
text: Here’s a clever idea for how to save Medicare some cash without hurting patients. Don’t pay for treatments found to be useless.

headline: ‘X Factor’ Sags

headline: ‘Breaking Dawn’ Breaks ‘Twilight’ Opening Record
text: The fourth movie in the Twilight Saga series earned $30.25 million at its midnight screenings, doing better than the previous three movies in the lucrative vampire franchise and boding well for its prospects this weekend. Producers have predicted the new film, “The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn – Part 1,” will bring in more than $140 million at United States and Canadian box offices before the weekend is finished.

headline: Charity Founded by Accused Ex-Coach May Fold

headline: Conductor Flies Freely Over Critical Gulfs
text: THERE seems to be no crisis in the classical recording industry as far as René Jacobs and Harmonia Mundi are concerned. To judge from his astonishing number of CDs and DVDs, Mr. Jacobs, the 65-year-old Belgian-born conductor and former countertenor, is one of the biggest stars in the proliferating world of early-music performance. He might seem to be right up there with the conductors John Eliot Gardiner and William Christie, who both recently appeared in New York.

King told the WNYC host Brian Lehrer that New York education officials plan to bring schools up to higher standards and use more flexibility when they evaluate schools and distribute money. Listen to the interview and his response to listeners' questions on test scores, cheating and teacher performance.

headline: Site to Be Seen | J. Crew
text: J. Crew’s business was founded on catalog orders and customer service, so it’s no surprise that its Web site offers one of the most thorough and pleasant online shopping experiences. What is a revelation, however, is the brand’s enthusiasm for collaborating with and supporting up-and-coming, lesser-known and top-quality heritage brands, which it does on the site’s In Good Company service. (The Hill-Side, Mister Freedom and Barbour are among the labels featured.) Though that’s not to discount the company’s own in-house merchandise, including the Ludlow suit, which remains to be the best-fitting suit under $700. Here, the Ludlow two-button suit jacket ($425) and pants ($218), Western shirt ($128) and Fair Isle camp socks ($18.50).

headline: Is It Inappropriate to Watch Football While Eating Thanksgiving Dinner With My Family?
text: Q.

headline: Bringing a Roadster Up to Speed
text: The Mercedes-Benz SLK roadster finally has the performance chops to make it more than a luxury bauble.

headline: Books Podcast: Pat Nixon’s Receding Self
text: Why did the novelist Ann Beattie compose an intimate portrait of Pat Nixon, whom she describes as “a person I would have done anything to avoid”? In this week’s Book Review, the historian David Greenberg reviews Ms. Beattie’s unlikely quasi-biography, quasi-novel and notes that Nixon’s “inscrutability, her otherness, makes her an inviting subject for the novelist to imagine.”

headline: Fashion Without End
text: It’s clear that one could board a plane after the Paris ready-to-wear shows and keep going, traveling to the various fashion weeks around the world. It’s not exactly a dream. But you do wonder: what happens in places off the Milan-Paris-New York grid?

headline: City Opera Begins a Season That Is Set on Many Stages
text: “Who Are You New York?: The Songs of Rufus Wainwright,” presented at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center on Thursday night, was not just an evening for this singer and songwriter’s ardent fans to savor his music, which was performed sensitively by four young singers in the first half and inimitably by Mr. Wainwright at the piano after intermission. It was also the official opening of New York City Opera’s first peripatetic season.

headline: State Judge Assures Family Courts Will Be Open to All
text: New York State’s chief judge said Friday that he was taking steps to assure that the state’s family courts are open to the public, after a report was published showing wide disregard for the open-courts policy in the city’s family courts.

headline: Picture Framing, the Cukor Method
text: OVER the course of his long career in Hollywood (he directed his first film, “Grumpy,” in 1930 and his last, “Rich and Famous,” in 1981) George Cukor came to be known as a great director of actors — or more specifically, of actresses. Among his more famous female collaborators were Greta Garbo (“Camille,” 1936), Joan Crawford (“A Woman’s Face,” 1941), Judy Holliday (“Born Yesterday,” 1950) and Katharine Hepburn, whom he directed in 10 films, from “A Bill of Divorcement” (1932) to “The Corn Is Green” (1979).

headline: New Manager Ready to Hold Cubs to Higher Standard
text: CHICAGO — Chicagoans with a dismissive attitude toward anything involving their country cousins from Milwaukee are going to have to accept the idea of a Brewers influence on their beloved Cubs.

headline: Three-Goal Comeback Puts North Carolina Into Field Hockey Championship Game
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.–North Carolina junior forward Kelsey Kolojejchick scored the game-winning goal in double overtime to complete a three-goal comeback against the University of Connecticut and vault top-seeded U.N.C. into the N.C.A.A. field hockey championship game on Sunday.

headline: Formations in China Desert Are Still a Mystery
text: In the areas of the Internet that buzz with delight at strange formations writ large on the landscape, a mystery appeared to be solved this week: giant shapes seen on Google Maps in China are simply geometric targets for satellite calibration.

headline: How About a Hand for the Muppets!
text: Quick: Name three things Kermit the Frog and Kurt Cobain have in common.

headline: Guru Sentenced to Prison in Sweat Lodge Deaths
text: LOS ANGELES — James A. Ray, the self-help guru who was found guilty of negligent homicide in the deaths of three followers in a botched sweat lodge ceremony in Arizona, was sentenced to two years in prison on Friday.

headline: Thanksgiving and Wine in the Willamette Valley
text: Visitors to the Willamette Valley in Oregon, the state’s most celebrated wine region, now have a mobile app to help them navigate, featuring varietals, locations and tasting room hours.

headline: Natalie Wood’s Death Is Being Reinvestigated, Los Angeles Authorities Say
text: MONTEREY PARK, Calif. — The Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department said on Friday that it had reopened its investigation into the actress Natalie Wood’s death 30 years ago because of new information from multiple sources.

headline: Lil’ Buck Jooks His Way Through Beijing With Yo-Yo Ma and Meryl Streep
text: BEIJING – One of the more surprising moments of this week’s four-day United States-China arts forum came at the start, on Thursday morning, when the cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the dancer Lil’ Buck held a private performance for Liu Yandong, China’s highest-ranking female politician.

headline: Iona Rozeal Brown Moves From Canvas to Dance Floor With ‘Battle of Yestermore’
text: Kabuki and Noh theater, kung fu, hip-hop, and the ballrooms of “Paris Is Burning” converged on Thursday in the debut of Iona Rozeal Brown’s “Battle of Yestermore.” This Performa Commission, at Skylight Studios, where it will be performed again on Friday at 8 p.m., was Ms. Brown’s first foray into live performance (unless you count her activities as a D.J.). It was like her paintings, but better.

headline: Bert Rodriguez Cooks a Meal With His Mother
text: Back in 2008, when the artist Bert Rodriguez was finishing up a residency in Paris, he took funds that had been earmarked for an exhibition of whatever it was he was supposed to have been working on and used them to fly his parents over from Miami.

text: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to make cranberry sauce that will gel in the fridge.

headline: Crime Scene Investigation: 360 Degrees
text: This essay will appear in the Metropolitan section on Sunday. The Panoscan images were published in an interactive Friday afternoon. (The scenes are not for the faint of heart. Images of blood and the corpses themselves have not been doctored or blurred.)

headline: Are You a V.I.P.? Check Your Klout Score
text: IN September, during a Fashion’s Night Out event in the upscale Miami neighborhood of Bal Harbour, guests decked out in Marc Jacobs and Herve Leger could not help but notice a separate velvet-roped V.I.P. area. There, a privileged few shared one denominator: each guest had accumulated a Klout score above 40.

headline: Greek debt; businesses that shoot themselves in the foot; Dr. Dre’s headphones
text: This week: Jeff Sommer with Gretchen Morgenson on Greek debt, Richard Thaler on businesses that shoot themselves in the foot, and David Gillen and Andrew Martin on Dr. Dre’s pricey headphones.

headline: For N.B.A. Owners, It’s a Waiting Game
text: Here’s a sobering thought: as the N.B.A.’s fans wait for word that negotiations over a new collective bargaining agreement will resume in some form, the league’s owners will instead focus their efforts on projecting an image of power. The urgency that brought those owners and the now-defunct National Basketball Players Association within a few minor system considerations of a deal is now gone, and in its place is a vague time line formed by a drop-dead date for cancellation of the entire season (likely in early January), a relatively slow-moving legal process, and the owners’ whims.

headline: For Homeless Students, Many Unanswered Questions
text: How many homeless students are enrolled in the city schools? How many live within walking distance of their schools? Those and other questions came into sharp focus this week with a news report about N-Dia Layne, a 4th grader searching for stability, with no clear answers from city agencies readily available.

headline: Brin and Wojcicki Give $500,000 to Charity Behind Wikipedia
text: Keep an eye on Sergey Brin’s Wikipedia page. It might just get a more positive spin soon.

headline: Regis Signs Off

headline: ‘Radio City Christmas Spectacular’
text: The annual extravaganza, now in its 79th year, includes 3-D projections in addition to the usual Rockette dance numbers.

headline: New York’s Leggy Darlings Saving the Holiday, 36 Karate Kicks at a Time
text: On Wednesday night this dance critic went to Radio City Music Hall to watch a video game. Really, I was there to check in on the Rockettes and the latest edition of the “Christmas Spectacular,” now in its 79th year. Those New York darlings are still kicking high, but it was a new number that I had to view through 3-D glasses that proved nearly the best dance in the show.

headline: Head of Joint Chiefs Outlines Challenges
text: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, kicked off his keynote speech Friday at the Military Reporters & Editors conference in Washington with a joke.

headline: A Power Surge From Audi

headline: Blatter Apologizes for Remarks on Racism
text: Sepp Blatter, the head of world soccer’s governing organization, apologized in a BBC interview on Friday for saying this week that racism does not exist on soccer pitches, amid two high-profile inquiries into racist comments made during recent matches in Britain.

headline: Communion of Movement and Fatherhood
text: When you walk into the Chocolate Factory for Chase Granoff’s new work, “intuition is preceding over my understanding,” you find him behind a table serving bread on plates and wine in mason jars. As at a tasting, he describes what he’s offering, his quiet, genial manner the opposite of a hard sell. After a while, he moves to the center of the room, takes off his glasses and shoes, and dances a solo in a similar key.

headline: Now Online | T Travel Winter 2011
text: The winter travel edition of T sets out on a quest for adventure, starting in Utah’s Canyonlands, where the model Heidi Mount takes a hike through her childhood stomping grounds. Next it’s off to Ecuador for a look at how an ambitious new lodge hopes to save the cloud forest by opening it to tourism; then father and son Max and Alex Vadukul make a pilgrimage to the divine chaos of Kolkata, to meet the city’s leading cultural figures. We also meet Bali’s own Willy Wonkas and their new bamboo chocolate factory; the shadowy mistress of Ukraine’s fashion set; and a former circus performer who now preaches the gospel of olive oil in Paris. Along the way, T touches down in the skiing utopia of Vermont’s Mad River Glen; in the eternal French melting pot of Marseilles; and in Florida, for a tour of what’s buzzing in the Sunshine State.

headline: Jabra’s Sport Bluetooth Headset Is Just Right For Rainy Runs
text: Runners of a certain age will remember a time, not too long ago, when the idea of a light pair of wireless sports headphones was ludicrous. Devices that even partially fit the bill were large, bulky, and had a surprisingly short battery life. However, the Jabra Sport Bluetooth headset may finally set us all free.

headline: Porsche to Build in Atlanta and California
text: IN two years, air passengers circling above Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport may glimpse a Porsche badge out their windows. The atrium of the automaker’s new North American headquarters, scheduled to open in late 2013, will take the shape of the shield on Cayennes, Panameras, Caymans, 911s and Boxsters.

headline: Signs of Solitude in a Bustling City
text: We tend to think of cities — and New York in particular — as noisy, nerve-jangling places. So it’s surprising how many of the 60-plus paintings, photographs and other items on view in “New York, New York! The 20th Century” exude silence.

headline: If You Don’t Have a Bundt Pan …
text: Not everyone has a bundt pan, and if you don’t, you can bake this apple bourbon cake in two 9-inch loaf pans instead. The baking time might be shorter, so start checking at 45 minutes. An added advantage, you’ll have two cakes, meaning you can bring (or serve) one and save the other.

headline: Spitting Sad About the Bloody Uprisings in Iran
text: If you asked people to name one image they associated with the violent Iranian protests in 2009, many would probably pick the horrifying video of Neda Agha-Soltan, the young woman shot to death on a street in Tehran: blood everywhere and, more than that, her unfathomable eyes meeting the camera’s gaze.

headline: Haydn and Bruckner, Confidently Sketched
text: In the second of two programs offered by the eminent Dutch conductor Bernard Haitink during his present guest engagement with the New York Philharmonic, he plotted a steady course through the tried and true: Haydn’s Symphony No. 96 and Bruckner’s Symphony No. 7. As another reviewer noted last week, a conservatism seems evident in the Philharmonic this season; on the other hand, it made sense that Mr. Haitink, absent from the Philharmonic podium since 1978, would want to focus on music that he clearly holds dear.

headline: High Fives, 56 Times
text: At another school, it might have been a football rally. At Bronx Prep Charter School on Friday, it only looked like one. Seniors, many of them wearing college sweatshirts, marched out of the school one-by-one to cheers, high-fives and handshakes as they headed to the post office to send off their college applications. The school is in one of the poorest neighborhoods in the city, but every one of the school's 56 graduating seniors are applying to college, school officials said, including to institutions like Yale University,  University of Pennsylvania, Amherst College, Northeastern University and Tufts University. The school calls this tradition "mail-out day." Here's hoping that every one of the students celebrates "fat-envelope day," with the arrival of packets of admissions materials to the college of their choice.

headline: Rogue Web Sites
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Patience of a Computer Can Make It Useful as a Teacher
text: A couple of days ago I received an e-mail from a reader saying that I should not write about computer programs because they play so badly.

headline: The Week in Metro Pictures for November 11
text: Subjects include the Annual Veterans’ Day Parade, the 10th anniversary of the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 and the eviction of Occupy Wall Street.

headline: A Night to Ponder Birth, Death and Dreams
text: “How Much Is Enough? Our Values in Question” is theater as encounter group. It feeds off audience members, who are called on to talk about things like birth, death and time; to bow their heads and raise their hands if they feel frightened or lonely; to slow dance (the show’s most theatrical moment); and even, in one case, when a male performer asked a straight man what it would be like if they had sex, to agree to a kiss.

headline: Some Songs About Travel, Sung by a Carefree Guide
text: Charm. To what extent is it an innate gift, an emanation some people are born with like an especially pleasing body scent? And to what extent is it a cultivated set of manners whose goal is seduction? Watching the cabaret singer Andrea Marcovicci glide through her paces at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Wednesday evening, I decided it must be both. In any dedicated charmer, I figured, instinct and guile fuse into an irresistibly captivating presence; after that, it all seemingly comes naturally.

headline: Rangers Surge Behind Balanced Scoring and Stalwart Defensemen
text: The Rangers enter Saturday night’s game in Montreal with a seven-game winning streak. Even after skating-intensive workouts, there were smiles in every corner of the Rangers’ practice facility this week.

headline: Kindle Fire Said to Bleed a Bit Less Red Ink
text: After Amazon announced it would charge $199 for the Kindle Fire, a big question was how much — not whether — the company would lose money on every device sold. According to a new teardown report on the device, the answer is: not as much as expected.

headline: Advances in Medicine Lead Stars to Surgery
text: The rash of singers who have canceled concerts this fall to undergo throat surgery — Adele, Keith Urban, John Mayer — might suggest that touring takes a terrible toll on the vocal cords. Yet doctors who specialize on vocal issues point to something else to explain the cancellations: new diagnostic tools and surgical techniques.

headline: Reminiscences of a ‘Gay Utopia’
text: THE Pavilion dance club, a hedonistic playground for three generations of gay men in Fire Island Pines, burned down Monday night, stirring memories in gay communities in New York City and beyond.

headline: This Sunday: A Pennsylvania State of Mind
text: As states go, Pennsylvania is not one to crave attention, certainly not the kind it’s receiving now with the Penn State scandal. In this week’s magazine, we don’t delve into that story — our colleagues at the newspaper are doing an excellent job with it, and a few years back, we published a profile of Joe Paterno that’s worth rereading — but our two biggest features happen to take place in the state.

headline: Seeing in Crisis the Last Best Chance to Unite Europe

headline: Capitalizing on Collapse
text: A new political calculus is emerging on both sides of the aisle now that it looks as if the Joint Select Committee on Deficit Reduction may fail to reach an agreement by Wednesday’s deadline.

headline: California: Crystal Cathedral Will Be Sold to Catholic Diocese
text: A bankruptcy judge has allowed the Roman Catholic Diocese of Orange to buy the Crystal Cathedral, the megachurch where the “Hour of Power” religious program is filmed, for $57.5 million. The sale will allow Crystal Cathedral Ministries to pay its creditors and emerge from bankruptcy. The diocese plans to consecrate the church, in Garden Grove, as a Catholic cathedral. The judge’s decision came on Thursday after a bidding war between the diocese and Chapman University. The university had hoped to use the property as a satellite campus and had offered Crystal Cathedral Ministries a hope of buying back some of it. The cathedral board endorsed the Catholic plan. The ministry will be allowed to remain in its current location for three years, and its leaders have vowed to continue operations at another location.

headline: Heart Rate Monitors Fine-Tune Players’ Fitness
text: STORRS, Conn. — As soccer practice began one recent afternoon, each University of Connecticut player grabbed a puck before he kicked a ball. The puck was a small rectangular transmitter that attached to a chest strap and was worn beneath the players’ jerseys.

headline: Doing the Ethical Thing May Be Right, but It Isn’t Automatic
text: FOR the last few weeks, the sex abuse scandal at Penn State and the harassment claims against the Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain have been fodder for discussion at my house. The same is true, I assume, around the country.

headline: De Rosario Named M.L.S. M.V.P.
text: D.C. United midfielder Dwayne De Rosario was named Major League Soccer’s Most Valuable Player on Friday, capping a year that saw him play 33 games for three teams, but none in the playoffs.

headline: Towers, a Tunnel, Noise, Lessons and a Library
text: “WHEN it comes to buildings, size matters — more so today than ever before,” Kate Ascher writes in “The Heights: Anatomy of a Skyscraper” (Penguin Press). In this lushly illustrated book, Ms. Ascher meticulously and lucidly deconstructs the design of manmade towers from the foundation on up to the imperatives of physical and psychological security in a terror-conscious society.

headline: Pairings for Day 3 Fourball Matches at the Presidents Cup
text: After Saturday’s morning session at the Presidents Cup, the United States team leads the International squad, 11-6. The American duo of Bubba Watson and Webb Simpson, Presidents Cup rookies, remained undefeated in the morning session Saturday, beating Robert Allenby and Geoff Oglivy, 3 and 2. Below are the pairings for the afternoon fourball session. The American captain Fred Couples chose to rest Phil Mickelson, who is undefeated so far, because he wanted Mickelson fresh for the singles matches Sunday. David Toms is also sitting out this round for the U.S., with Robert Allenby and Ryo Ishikawa out for the International squad.

headline: Europe Fears a Credit Squeeze as Investors Sell Bond Holdings
text: Nervous investors around the globe are accelerating their exit from the debt of European governments and banks, increasing the risk of a credit squeeze that could set off a downward spiral.

headline: Gingrich Answers Attacks on His Web Site
text: After a week of revelations about his business dealings after he left Congress, the former House Speaker Newt Gingrich has added a new page to his Web site answering the new questions, and some old ones, too.

headline: Brazil Officials Criticize Chevron Over Oil Spill
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Chevron came under intense scrutiny in Brazil on Friday over an oil spill at an offshore field the company operates, with federal investigators here threatening fines for Chevron and potential prison terms for its officials if they are found guilty of violating environmental contamination laws.

headline: Selling Candy to Kids
text: To combat the rise in childhood obesity, Congress in 2009 asked the Federal Trade Commission and three other government agencies to create voluntary nutritional standards for foods that are marketed to children. In April, the interagency group released sound recommendations to guide self-regulation by the food industry.

headline: Toasting Architecture at Lincoln Center, With Wine by the Grass
text: Our work started early Monday evening. Riding the D train to Lincoln Center, we spotted a celebrity standing across from us, and thought to rifle for our notebook. A straphanger beat us to it. “You’re John Lithgow,” the commuter said. Mr. Lithgow confirmed it. The man said he was surprised to see the actor taking the subway. (We admired the man’s gall. Need a job? Call us.) “It’s the best way to get around,” Mr. Lithgow said. The subway doors opened.

headline: Gary Chapman’s ‘Growing Marriage’ Seminar
text: Hundreds of couples attended Gary Chapman’s “Growing Marriage” seminar at an Ohio church.

headline: Honk if You Agree There Is a Difference Between Free Speech and Noise
text: DENVER — Horn-honking, as a statement of frustration or joy or who knows what behind the wheel, has been part of the American fabric since the first Ah-OO-gah from the first Model A.

headline: Satirizing Putin With Boldly Poetic Flair
text: MOSCOW — An elegant after-work crowd packed into the Estrada Theater last week, having shelled out as much as $250 for an evening devoted to laughing at Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Republican Financial Plans
text: Our topic for today is: Where do the Republican candidates for president get their money?

headline: An Incremental Change
text: In the summer, the Obama administration promised it would review its deportation policies, and, this week, it promised that it really means it. Maybe one day immigration officials will even tell the public the results. In the meantime, the review is a good idea, but its serious pitfalls are reminders of the rising costs of our national failure to fix a broken immigration system.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,476 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,822 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Natural History, Not-So-Natural Setting
text: Klaus Pichler was wandering home from a bar one morning when he noticed a light coming from a basement window at Vienna’s Museum of Natural History.  Even at that hour, he thought, someone was hard at work inside.

headline: N.C.A.A. Begins Penn State Inquiry
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — The N.C.A.A. has sent Penn State a letter announcing it will begin an inquiry into the university’s institutional control and ethical conduct stemming from the sexual abuse charges against the former assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky.

headline: As Deadline Nears, Deficit Panel Is Still at Deep Impasse
text: WASHINGTON — Just 72 hours before a deadline to present Congress with a plan to cut $1.2 trillion from the nation’s deficit, members of a joint Congressional committee remained at a deep impasse on Friday after Democrats rejected a new Republican proposal devised with the help of Speaker John A. Boehner.

headline: Don’t Give Up on Sanctions

headline: Deal With the Devil Foreseen by Romney
text: With something of a literary flourish, Mitt Romney expressed pointed doubts on Friday about the ability of the members of a Congressional panel on deficit reduction to reach an acceptable solution, predicting that any recommendations could be a “Faustian bargain” that would cut money from the military budget.

headline: Militias and Army Jostle for Influence in Libya
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The armed militias that emerged from Libya’s civil war and units of the fledgling Libyan National Army are pressing the interim government for places in a new cabinet, which is expected to be seated shortly.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Tinted Town
text: The fashion statements are varied, but sleeveless fur jackets are the hit of the season.

text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the Annual Veterans’ Day Parade, the 10th anniversary of the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 and the eviction of Occupy Wall Street.

headline: Labor Board May Speed Union Votes
text: A proposed federal rule to speed union elections, a step opposed by business groups, may be adopted before the end of the year, a Republican member of the National Labor Relations Board said on Friday.

headline: ABC Plans Midseason Replacements of ‘Man Up’ and ‘Pan Am’
text: ABC, which has seen the needle for its prime time fortunes turn upward with the introduction of several successful new series this fall, on Friday announced mid-season changes to its schedule. The changes include the introduction of some stop-gap reality shows, a new drama the network is especially high on and a comedy featuring cross-dressing to replace an expected cancellation.

headline: Modern Chinese, Bold and Flavorful
text: AS a child, I loved to dine out with my parents in San Francisco’s Chinatown. Off a steep side street, we would descend a short flight of stairs and squeeze into a traditional wood-paneled stall. The waiter would tap on the door before entering with each course: egg-drop soup, fried rice, chicken chow mein, black tea and, at meal’s end, brittle fortune cookies whose sometimes inscrutable pronouncements I always took to heart.

headline: Jamie Pierre, Free Skier Known for Feats of Daring, Dies at 38
text: In 2006, Jamie Pierre skied off a 255-foot cliff in the backcountry of Grand Targhee, Wyo., plummeting nearly headfirst and without a helmet for more than four seconds. He struck the deep powder at the base of the cliff with such force that friends had to dig him out.

headline: U.S. Foursomes Widen Lead
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Tiger Woods won his first Presidents Cup match, and the United States won four of five foursomes on Saturday morning and extended its lead to 11-6.

headline: The Inside Man
text: For months, Newt Gingrich tried to ingratiate himself with the Republican Party’s right wing by tearing down the two government-sponsored mortgage companies, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. He joined the counterfactual conservative chorus that prefers to blame the companies for the housing crisis rather than the banks. He lamented their cozy relationship to Washington’s insiders. And he was rewarded with a swell of support from the anybody-but-Mitt-Romney crowd.

headline: Syracuse Assistant Denies Sexual Abuse Claims
text: SYRACUSE — Bernie Fine, an associate head basketball coach at Syracuse University who has been accused of sexually assaulting a former ball boy, issued a denial Friday through his lawyer, saying, “These allegations are patently false in every aspect.”

headline: Vilifying Rival, Wall St. Rallies for Senate Ally

Brown, the Republican from Massachusetts, just got a little more interesting.

headline: A Trip to the Pub on Memory Lane

headline: There but for Fortune Go the Straphangers
text: There’s no Wayne Newton serenading in the lounge yet, but the city’s first casino is already booming on the fringe of Queens, offering less-than-Vegas glitz at the end of a long subway ride from Manhattan. Bird watchers on their way to the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge used to be the main enthusiasts taking the A train that far. But thousands of beaming gamblers poured from the trains to wait in long lines at the opening last month, anxious for action.

headline: Decline of American Exceptionalism

Are we, indeed, the “shining city upon a hill” that Ronald Reagan described? Are we “chosen by God and commissioned by history to be a model to the world” as George W. Bush said?

headline: Saturday: Pattern of Highs and Lows
text: Administrivial Non-Standard Puzzle Alert! The puzzle for tomorrow, Sunday, Nov. 20, has some unusual features. In the print version of this crossword, some squares (containing slashes) in the Across and Down answers do not actually cross. Write both parts of the answers in those squares. Then use the central Across answer to interpret them properly to spell an appropriate final word. In the online version of this puzzle, the slashes are replaced by circles, and the program will accept either one of the answers that goes in that square, but not both (because of electronic restrictions). Although this Across Lite version does work, it is recommended that solvers download and print out the PDF version of this puzzle. As a second-best alternative, print out this Across Lite version and solve on paper. Don’t worry. Just give it a try; it will make much more sense as you go.

headline: Older, Suburban and Struggling, ‘Near Poor’ Startle the Census
text: WASHINGTON — They drive cars, but seldom new ones. They earn paychecks, but not big ones. Many own homes. Most pay taxes. Half are married, and nearly half live in the suburbs. None are poor, but many describe themselves as barely scraping by.

text: By her own account, the composer Jennifer Higdon’s life has taken a “surreal” turn. Swept up in a swirl of lectures, performances and awards ceremonies — last year she won the Pulitzer Prize and a Grammy — she has, in rapid fashion, been accepted into the rarefied ranks of contemporary composers whose works are both widely played and wildly praised.

headline: Clean and Sober, but Still Addicted
text: Romeo and Juliet they are not. Jackie and Veronica, the lovers at the center of “The ____________ With the Hat,” are foulmouthed, uncouth and long past the first fine careless rapture that made them a couple. Yet somehow this harsh, funny, ultimately affecting play by Stephen Adly Guirgis lets us see right through their fights and lies and egregiously bad behavior to their eternal but star-crossed love.

headline: From Cain, More on Libya

His confused-looking pause, stares at the ceiling and mangled response were captured on video by The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, and reporters have been asking about the five-minute clip ever since.

headline: An Uncomfortably Small, and Shrinking, World
text: Nothing draws people together like a crisis. The reigning global conversation at the moment — if one is to judge by newspaper headlines — is about the worldwide economic mess. Before that, however, the state of our environment dominated our collective consciousness. It is this second issue that is addressed in “Marina Zurkow: Friends, Enemies and Others” at the Montclair Art Museum.

headline: Haiti: Plans for Army Are Delayed
text: President Michel Martelly on Friday put off a plan to reinstate Haiti’s armed forces until a commission he plans to appoint next week reports on the best way to proceed. The plan to bring back the military, disbanded in 1995 after years of participating in coups and human rights abuses, has been criticized by diplomats, who believe fortifying the national police would be the better use of resources. But Mr. Martelly, playing up national pride as much as security, promised the new military would be apolitical and could eventually replace United Nations peacekeepers, in place since 2004.

headline: It’s Not All Fun and Games
text: Kati London, head of products for the social-game developer Zynga in New York, spends her week experimenting with ways to make interactions between machines and humans more social. She has worked on games like CityVille and Drop7. On Sundays, she turns her attention to her personal life, visiting friends and exploring in Manhattan or hiking upstate; she also finds time for projects like Botanicalls, a system to send Twitter posts or voice messages to caretakers from plants that need watering. Ms. London, 35, lives in Chelsea with her long-time partner, the artist Kjell Otterness, and their baby daughter, Ulla London Otterness.

headline: From Safety of New York, Reporting on Distant Home
text: WHEN news breaks in Nigeria, Omoyele Sowore is there. His Web news operation was the first to publish a photo of the Nigeria-born “underwear bomber” arrested in December 2009, and when a suicide bombing this summer shook a United Nations building in Abuja, Nigeria’s capital, he was the first to publish on-the-ground reports and photos. During the presidential election in Nigeria in April, he published real-time photos, videos and reports from the field, exposing instances of ballot rigging, and attracting over eight million page views in one month.

This is a part of the continuing negotiations between the Nationalist Socialist Council of Nagaland and the Ministry of Home Affairs on its demand for a “sovereign” Nagaland. “While state boundaries would not change, the proposed councils for Naga-dominated areas outside Nagaland would exercise effective control there,” reports the Nagaland Post.

headline: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
text: Baby Bachchan: Bollywood’s First Baby arrived on Nov. 16. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, wife of actor Abhishek Bachchan and daughter-in-law of iconic superstar Amitabh Bachchan (Time magazine once referred to them as “Bollywood’s Father, Son and Holy Babe”) delivered a baby girl. At 9.52 a.m. on Wednesday Abhishek broke the news on Twitter and immediately, the social networking site went into overdrive with other celebrities (Shah Rukh Khan, Karan Johar, Javed Akhtar) congratulating the family and discussing her cute-quotient (director Ram Gopal Varma tweeted “I just hope that she has more Aishwarya than Abhishek”). Within the hour, Baby B was trending on Twitter. The electronic media, however, was unusually restrained. In early November, the Broadcast Editors’ Association had circulated an internal memo dictating conduct for coverage of the birth (guidelines included that the story would not be treated as breaking news and no cameras or broadcast vans would be sent to the hospital). Television channels stuck to the code and both Bachchans – Amitabh and Abhishek – thanked the media (on Twitter again) for respecting the family’s privacy. Bachchan senior also assured the media that time would be allotted to them, for both print and television, but said that the immediate priority was to get some sleep.

text: To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them — as well as to further their understanding of President Obama’s recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans — Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is spending this week in our virtual Guidance Office. headline: Letters to the Editor

If you’re lucky, everyone brings a dish that everyone else finds palatable, taking a lot of pressure off the family chef.
