The post merits standalone “Your Dot” display (a feature reserved for cogent or compelling non-anonymous commentary.)

headline: Kris Jenkins’s View of Life in the N.F.L. Trenches
text: The Carolina Panthers selected Kris Jenkins in the second round of the N.F.L. 2001 draft. He was on four Pro Bowl teams and named All-Pro three times in seven seasons with them. In 2002 and 2003, he was a dominant player on the Panthers’ defensive line, helping them reach the Super Bowl for the first time.

headline: Want to Lead? Learn to Nurture Your Butterflies
text: This interview with  Kathleen L. Flanagan, president and chief executive of Abt Associates, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. Abt is a consulting firm specializing in health, social and environmental policy, and international development.

headline: Scare Tactics in Greece
text: AS the debt mess in Europe deepens, bankers are pressing Greece’s bond holders to swallow big losses.

headline: Mobile Deals Set to Lure Shoppers Stuck in Line
text: As retailers battle to draw customers into their stores on Black Friday, online merchants are plotting a cunning ambush — offering an arsenal of mobile-only deals intended to pick off shoppers as they wait in line.

headline: Police and Protesters Clash in Tahrir Square
text: Thousands of police clashed with protesters for control of downtown Cairo’s Tahrir Square on Saturday after security forces tried to stop activists from staging a long-term sit-in there.

headline: Headphones With Swagger (and Lots of Bass)
text: DR. DRE, the sonic architect of gangsta rap, is surrounded by a gaggle of slack-jawed journalists and micro-skirted cocktail waitresses. It’s not quite 5 in the afternoon, and already the scene is a testosterone fantasy of swaggering grooves and flowing vodka.

headline: Fox Again Will Shift to Soccer After N.F.L.
text: It may be an N.F.L. Sunday, but are you ready for that other kind of football?

headline: For Job Hunters, Digital Merit Badges
text: CLOTH and metal badges have long been worn by Boy Scouts, soldiers and others to show off their accomplishments.

headline: When Business Can’t Foresee Outrage
text: A  GOOD rule of thumb for companies and politicians is to avoid becoming the butt of jokes on late-night TV. While most business executives understand this principle, they evidently don’t know how to act on it.

headline: From Gingrich, an Unconventional View of Education
text: 4:57 p.m. | Updated Newt Gingrich has some unconventional ideas about education reform. He wants every state to open a work-study college where students work 20 hours a week during the school year and full-time in the summer and then graduate debt-free.

headline: From the Mouths of Executives, Little Comfort
text: EIGHT times a year, legions of policy wonks, bankers and traders devour a Federal Reserve survey of the American economy known simply as “the beige book.”

headline: Christo
text: THE artist Christo Vladimirov Javacheff, who goes by Christo, is known for environmental works that are monumental yet ephemeral. The Department of the Interior just approved his latest project, “Over The River,” which will entail suspending 5.9 miles of silvery fabric along a stretch of the Arkansas River in Colorado, at an estimated cost to the artist of roughly $50 million. He conceived of the project with his wife and collaborator of more than 50 years, Jeanne-Claude Denat de Guillebon, who died in 2009.

headline: A Pioneer at Heart
text: I  GREW up in East Falls, a neighborhood of northwest Philadelphia. My father spent his career as a radiologist, working and teaching at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. My mother, who was a nurse, stayed at home to raise my three siblings and me.

headline: Sectarian Strife in City Bodes Ill for All of Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A harrowing sectarian war has spread across the Syrian city of Homs this month, with supporters and opponents of the government blamed for beheadings, rival gangs carrying out tit-for-tat kidnappings, minorities fleeing for their native villages, and taxi drivers too fearful of drive-by shootings to ply the streets.

headline: New Contract Will Enable Baseball to Test for H.G.H.
text: Major League Baseball’s owners and players are on the verge of completing a new labor deal that for the first time will include blood testing for human growth hormone, according to two people in baseball briefed on the matter. The testing will be a significant step for baseball, allowing it to move ahead of other professional sports leagues, including the N.F.L., in confronting the troublesome issue of a drug that has long evaded detection.

headline: Perry Ad Seems to Take Aim at Republican Rivals
text: Rick Perry‘s poll numbers may be lagging. But he still has millions of dollars to spend on ads and that effort now appears to be turning its sights on his Republican rivals.

headline: Deficit Panel Faces a Rift Over Who Ought to Pay
text: WASHINGTON — The second-ranking Senate Republican declared Saturday that the work of a special Congressional committee on deficit reduction was all but over, and said efforts to strike a bipartisan deal had been worthy but unavailing.

headline: 30 Seconds With Annika Sorenstam
text: With 85 tournament victories worldwide, 10 major championship trophies and a place in the L.P.G.A. and the World Golf Halls of Fame, Annika Sorenstam earned a restful retirement when she left competitive golf. She is instead involved in more ventures than ever, with a golf academy, a charitable foundation, a clothing line, a wine label, a fragrance and an international golf course design business. Sorenstam and her husband/manager, Mike McGee, have two young children.

headline: Voices of the Near Poor
text: When the Census Bureau this month released a new measure of poverty, meant to better count disposable income, it began altering the portrait of national need.

headline: Afghan Council Supports Karzai on U.S. Troop Presence
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The grand council of Afghan delegates known as the loya jirga drew to a close Saturday, choosing to support President Hamid Karzai’s vision for negotiating a strategic agreement that could keep a long-term American military presence in Afghanistan.

headline: In the Footsteps of the Forty-Niners
text: On the East Fork of the San Gabriel River in California, visitors have been chasing gold.

headline: Distracted? It’s Time to Hit the Reset Button
text: Q. You enjoy being fully immersed in your work but find yourself becoming distracted by e-mail, the Internet and other things throughout the day. Why do you lose focus so easily?

headline: What They Don’t Teach Law Students: Lawyering
text: PHILADELPHIA — The lesson today — the ins and outs of closing a deal — seems lifted from Corporate Lawyering 101.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, November 20
text: The countdown has begun. The Joint Select Committee on Deficit Reduction has until Monday to submit a plan for review by the Congressional Budget Office before presenting that proposal to Congress on Wednesday. But with Democrats rejecting the Republicans’ latest proposal, it is unclear whether the committee can overcome the impasse and avoid deep cuts to federal services and defense spending.

headline: One Dies in Truck Crash at Yale Tailgate Party
text: NEW HAVEN — A truck carrying beer kegs went out of control during a tailgate party on Saturday before the Yale-Harvard game at Yale Bowl, swerving into a crowd and hitting three people, the authorities said. One person, a 30-year-old woman, was fatally injured.

headline: San Francisco May Not Be as Green as Advertised, Energy Experts Say
text: One foggy day last month, Mayor Edwin M. Lee of San Francisco stood on the windswept roof of the California Academy of Sciences. He was there to celebrate what he called the city’s “tremendous accomplishment” in reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Russia Attacks Sentence of Adoptee’s Parents
text: MOSCOW — The Russian government reacted furiously on Saturday to what it described as an unjustly lenient sentence in the case of a Pennsylvania couple who were originally charged with murder in the death of their 7-year-old son adopted from Russia.

headline: A New Voice Grips South Korea With Plain Talk About Inequality and Justice
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Two days before Seoul elected a mayor last month, an unassuming man slipped into the campaign headquarters of Park Won-soon, an independent candidate. Amid flashing cameras, the man, Ahn Cheol-soo, a soft-spoken university dean who had earlier been seen as a contender for mayor himself, affirmed his support for Mr. Park, entrusted him with a written statement and then left.

headline: A Diplomatic Face Seeks to Counter Iran’s Critics
text: Mohammad Javad Larijani never finished his mathematics studies at Berkeley. Instead, he became one of the quotable, English-speaking, official defenders of Iran’s Islamic Revolution.

headline: Fortunes, and Tables, Turn for Portugal and Angola
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The world-turned-upside-down of the European debt crisis reached a new extreme last week when Europe came pleading for lucre where it once only seized it: Africa.

headline: How Big Was That Protest: The Trickiness of Crowd-Counting
text: In the comments on our coverage of Thursday’s “day of action” for Occupy Wall Street, many of you wondered – that’s a polite word for it – why we didn’t provide crowd estimates for the huge gathering that thronged Foley Square near City Hall on Thursday night and flowed over the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: Costly Aircraft Suggests Cuts Won’t Be Easy
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta shoved his head into a snug aviator helmet topped with goggles one September morning and swooped into Lower Manhattan on a V-22 Osprey, a $70 million aircraft that Marines use for battlefield assaults in Afghanistan.

headline: René Morel, Master Restorer of Rare Violins, Dies at 79
text: René A. Morel, a world-renowned surgeon whose clients had names like Perlman, Zukerman and Ma and whose patients had names like Stradivari, Guarneri and Amati, died on Wednesday in Wayne, N.J. He was 79.

headline: My Coney Island Crime
text: Summers are tidal but beaches remain. I’d taken an apartment for the summer in Coney Island to write but found myself staying on after Labor Day — because I hadn’t made any progress, my novel didn’t have an ending, or a middle, or even a continuable beginning (“Summers are tidal but beaches remain”) — and because I’d become something of an island myself.

headline: In Nevada, a City Hall Is a Reminder of Flush Days
text: NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev. — The view from the top floor of the new City Hall here stretches for miles. At nine stories high, the building is the tallest around, making it possible to easily survey the pockmarked landscape below. Down there, homes in foreclosure dot nearly every block of the suburban housing that stretches through the desert, just a few miles away from the glittery Strip.

headline: Worker Beaten to Death at Sex Shop in Brooklyn
text: A Sri Lankan immigrant working the overnight shift at a 24-hour adult video store in the shadow of the Gowanus Expressway in Brooklyn was killed early Saturday in a violent encounter with a man in the store, the authorities said.

headline: A Love Language of My Own
text: WHEN my wife, Linda, and I were married eight years ago, a devout friend in my hometown, Savannah, Ga., gave us a copy of “The Five Love Languages.” With its cover image of lovers walking hand-in-hand on a sunset beach, the book looked as if it came free with a fruitcake at a truck stop.

headline: Romney Shifts in Iowa, Playing to Win Quickly
text: DES MOINES — The answer to one of the great lingering questions about the Republican presidential race has suddenly turned up here along Ingersoll Avenue, where Mitt Romney’s Iowa campaign headquarters is opening for business.

headline: No Turkeys Here
text: There are days when it seems — both in and out of the food world — that Everything Is Going Wrong. That makes it easy enough to complain, and I’m not alone in doing so routinely. Nothing tastes the way it used to. Even pricey restaurants have lost their glow. Quality is shot. People die from eating melons. The dominance of hyper-processed, industrialized food (and, more to the point, food-like products) is spreading globally, and we’re all gaining weight faster than ever, while wrecking the planet.

headline: Sorry, Strivers: Talent Matters
text: HOW do people acquire high levels of skill in science, business, music, the arts and sports? This has long been a topic of intense debate in psychology.

headline: How About Better Parents?
text: IN recent years, we’ve been treated to reams of op-ed articles about how we need better teachers in our public schools and, if only the teachers’ unions would go away, our kids would score like Singapore’s on the big international tests. There’s no question that a great teacher can make a huge difference in a student’s achievement, and we need to recruit, train and reward more such teachers. But here’s what some new studies are also showing: We need better parents. Parents more focused on their children’s education can also make a huge difference in a student’s achievement.

headline: Occupy the Agenda
text: YOU have to wonder: Could Mayor Michael Bloomberg and police chiefs around the country be secretly backing the Occupy Wall Street movement?

headline: Conspiracies, Coups and Currencies
text: The murmurs about Barack Obama being forced out began in Berlin and Beijing. After his party lost the midterm vote, there were hints that a government of technocrats would be imposed on America, to save the country from a debt crisis and the world from a depression.

headline: Reneging on Justice at Guantánamo
text: In 2008, the Supreme Court ruled that Guantánamo Bay prisoners who are not American citizens have the right of habeas corpus, allowing them to challenge the legality of their detention in federal court and seek release.

headline: Democrats Urge Obama to Protect Contraceptive Coverage in Health Plans
text: WASHINGTON — A dispute has erupted between President Obama and Democrats in Congress over a proposal to broaden the exemption from new rules that require health insurance plans to cover contraceptives for women free of charge.

headline: Canadian Modesty Meets Icelandic Imagination
text: If you have read “Independent People,” the great novel by Halldor Laxness, Iceland’s only recipient of the Nobel Prize for Literature, you might experience déjà vu while watching and listening to Guy Maddin’s magical film-and-live performance “Tales from the Gimli Hospital: Reframed.” The novel chronicles the incredibly difficult lives of early-20th-century Icelandic sheepherders in excruciating detail, and the narrative is leavened by weirdly fantastic and darkly comical episodes. The movie similarly looks back on the experience of Icelandic immigrants to Canada in the late 19th century.

headline: Online High Schools Attracting Elite Names
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — In June, about 30 seniors will graduate from a little-known online high school currently called the Education Program for Gifted Youth. But their diplomas will bear a different name: Stanford Online High School.

headline: Goodbye, Golden Years
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: ‘Anybody but Mitt’
text: THE WALL STREET JOURNAL editorial page, that irascible voice of high-minded conservatism, has taken a rather dim view of Mitt Romney. “It’s hard to discern any core beliefs beyond faith in his own managerial expertise,” it wrote in September.

headline: Poet-Bashing Police
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Secret Dread at Penn State
text: WHAT if it had been a 10-year-old girl in the Penn State locker room that Friday night in 2002?

headline: Sunday: Figure It Out
text: Administrivial Non-Standard Puzzle Alert! The Sunday, Nov. 20, puzzle has some unusual features. In the print version of this crossword, some squares (containing slashes) in the Across and Down answers do not actually cross. Write both parts of the answers in those squares. Then use the central Across answer to interpret them properly to spell an appropriate final word. In the online version of this puzzle, the slashes are replaced by circles, and the program will accept either one of the answers that goes in that square, but not both (because of electronic restrictions). Although this Across Lite version does work, it is recommended that solvers download and print out the PDF version of this puzzle. As a second-best alternative, print out this Across Lite version and solve on paper. Don’t worry. Just give it a try; it will make much more sense as you go.

headline: A Parent’s Determination and an Unbreakable Bond
text: Edwin Muñoz was never fond of body art. His skin was already home to a few scars, souvenirs from past confrontations: a shattered jaw, a knife wound in his back and a bullet hole in his leg. But that aversion changed when he sought custody of his son, Malachi.

headline: A Magical Musical Moment, Extended to 12 Hours
text: You know those moments in certain operas that you wish would last forever? As you read this, the Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson is extending one of the most exquisite — from Mozart’s “Marriage of Figaro” — to the length of 12 hours. He is doing this in “Bliss,” an effort perhaps best characterized as a work of endurance/appropriation/performance art that was commissioned by Performa 11. It is playing until midnight Saturday at the Abrons ArtCenter at 466 Grand Street on the Lower East Side. If Mozart, opera or performance art interest you, consider dropping by. It is also free.

headline: Southern Hospitality, but Not for Newcomers
text: IMAGINE this: It’s Sunday morning, beautiful and quiet, except for the mockingbird practicing comic routines on the sweet gum tree in the backyard. As usual, you get ready and drive your family to church. Everyone is well dressed, and the kids are singing in the back seat.

headline: After a Killing, Cancer and Financial Problems, Trying to Ensure His Son’s Happiness
text: Charles Smith has a plan to make sure someone will always be around to take care of his son Cie-Jay, 7.

headline: Rethinking Gang Years, and Choosing Safe Path for 2
text: Jordan McKay patiently urged his 3-year-old daughter, Skylah, up the malodorous steps to their fifth-floor studio apartment in the Bronx. To calm her from bouncing herky-jerky on her tiny bed, he got a video going, got her a banana. That did it. Soon, in all her blatant cuteness, she was radiating joy. In this way, a day moved forward.

headline: ... But There’s a Slim Hope in History
text: Beirut

headline: Is Your Dog Smarter Than a 2-Year-Old?
text: “I heard that, in intelligence, dogs are like 2-year-old children.”

headline: A Push for Online Privacy
text: Internet companies have a worrisome leeway to use data they glean about the people who use their services. Despite bipartisan concern about potential abuses, Congress has not acted to protect consumer privacy, and there is little chance legislation will pass anytime soon. So the Federal Trade Commission has stepped into the breach to set minimum standards of behavior — pursuing companies for deceiving consumers about how they will use names, e-mails and browsing habits.

headline: Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me
text: NPR’s “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

headline: The Case of the Distracted Driver
text: Here is a quick quiz. In states where it is illegal to use a hand-held phone while driving, talking when you are paused at a red traffic light is:

headline: Reading Between the Poverty Lines
text: A new and improved gauge of poverty, released this month by the Census Bureau, shows that 49.1 million Americans are poor, and that the ranks of those just above poverty are larger than previously believed. The middle class is under pressure, too, battered by stagnating incomes and unavoidable expenses like medical bills.

headline: Confusing Sex and Rape
text: AS the Jerry Sandusky case at Penn State University shows, reporting on allegations of sex crimes poses a challenge not only to get the story right but to deliver it in language that puts the facts in the proper light.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Judging the Health Law
text: Readers react to a letter saying the health reform law is reasonable and needed, and should be upheld by the Supreme Court.

headline: After Egypt’s Revolution, Christians Are Living in Fear ...
text: THE images streaming from Cairo’s streets last month were not as horrifying as those of the capture and brutal death of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, but they were savage all the same. They were a sobering reminder that popular movements in some parts of the world, however euphorically they begin, can take disquieting and ugly turns.

headline: Gingrich Site Seeks to Allay Conservatives’ Fears
text: Surging in polls and seeking to avoid the plight of those in the Republican race for president who have risen before him — only to plummet under scrutiny — Newt Gingrich has released a message for the party activists who will be crucial to his hopes of winning his party’s nomination: Those positions I once held that are now out of step with current-day conservative orthodoxy? I’ve changed.

headline: President Obama in Asia
text: Early in his term, President Obama was too deferential to China. On his Asia trip last week, he sent a clear message that this country is not ceding anything in the Pacific. That is good news.

headline: Top Republican Is Doubtful Deficit Panel Deal Can Be Reached
text: WASHINGTON — The second-ranking Senate Republican declared Saturday that the work of a special Congressional committee on deficit reduction was all but over, and said that efforts to strike a bipartisan deal had been worthy but unavailing.

headline: A Pepper Spraying on the Way to Occupying the Agenda
text: My Sunday column argues that the Occupy movement’s success isn’t about encampments at bits of real estate around the country, but about putting the issue of income inequality on the national agenda. The moral high ground it occupies is the issues, and that’s why it doesn’t matter if protesters lose control of parks here or there.

headline: Penn State Faculty Seeks Inquiry
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Penn State’s faculty senate called on Friday for an independent review of the university’s actions in the wake of a sexual abuse scandal involving the former football assistant Jerry Sandusky.

headline: A Sit-In Fails to Save Clinics, but the Fight Continues
text: N’Dana Carter has learned a few things about fighting city hall.

headline: U.C. Davis Calls for Investigation After Pepper Spraying
text: Police use of pepper spray on a dozen protesters at University of California, Davis, on Friday sparked calls for the resignation of the university’s chancellor and the start of an investigation into the incident.

headline: Milestone for a Benefactor of Historic Matches
text: Jacqueline Piatigorsky, one of the most important figures in American chess in the 1960s, turned 100 this month.

headline: Sitting Atop the State’s Gambling Board, a One-Man Hurdle to Expansion
text: James Warren writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: A Revolution in Canvassing Among Voters
text: When political candidates ring doorbells this election season, the people who answer should not be surprised if the stranger on the stoop seems particularly intuitive.

headline: Girl Defeats Boys to Win Girls Swim Title
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — The Haverhill High School girls swimming team has a war cry, three initials that rang in the ears of its star sprinter, Sarah Broderick, in the days leading to the girls fall state swimming and diving championships.

headline: New Cubs Manager Fits a Moneyball-Era Pattern
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: In a Stunning Coda, Columbia Wins One
text: Evan Miller, a senior linebacker for a Columbia team that had not won a game, was all but positive the Lions had ended the Saturday’s game and the season by tackling Brown’s Matt Sudfeld short of the goal line. But the officials gathered at the goal line to deliberate the play.

headline: In Battle of the Beleaguered, The Nittany Lions Prevail
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — A grizzled coach wearing Coke-bottle glasses did not lead Penn State onto the field at Ohio Stadium on Saturday. And a sweater-vest-wearing coach who once was so persistently present on the Ohio State sideline was missing as well.

headline: College Football Replay: Nov. 19
text: It was an easy day for No. 3 Alabama and No. 6 Arkansas, but No. 7 Clemson stubbed its toe against North Carolina State.

headline: Eagles at Giants: Matchup to Watch
text: Philadelphia Eagles (3-6) at Giants (6-3), Sunday at 8:20 p.m. Eastern, NBC

headline: Cheers Fade as Harvard Wins Handily
text: NEW HAVEN — After two quarters of quick scoring that suggested that Saturday’s Harvard-Yale game would be an exciting addition to the 128-game rivalry, the festive mood at The Game became one of confusion and then seriousness.

headline: Gap Between Rich and Poor in Area Is Widest in Berkeley
text: Berkeley, the leftist city whose University of California campus erupted in protest this week as part of the Occupy Wall Street movement, has the widest gap between rich and poor in the Bay Area, according to recently released data from the Census Bureau.

headline: Muni and Mayor Collide Over the Transit Deficit
text: Edward D. Reiskin, the new chief of the San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency, has begun to make progress with the nearly impossible project of winning over the city’s embittered transit riders.

headline: Draline Tong Herbs
text: Since 1979, those with ailments ranging from high blood pressure to infertility visit Draline Tong Herbs in Oakland’s Chinatown for Chinese medicines, salves or just to chat with the owner, Henry Lau, a herbalist. Mr. Lau spends his days concocting combinations of up to 20 different seeds, roots and dried plants to boil into pungent teas. LOUISE RAFKIN

headline: Lottery Numbers
Changing a College With Prose and Patience
text: DALLAS — At 11:11 a.m. on Nov. 11, in the Moisés E. Molina High School library, the handful of boys that make up nearly the entire black male population in the nearly 1,900-student school sat listening to Michael Sorrell.

headline: 2 Mayors, 2 Views on Using War-Zone Equipment Along Border
text: Mayors of cities along the Texas-Mexico border intent on protecting the images of their communities are drawing vastly different conclusions about a proposal that would bring in equipment from overseas war zones to bolster border security.

headline: Sometimes It’s Just Easier to Run Against Obama
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: The Devil Is in the Details of a Bluesman’s Legacy
text: DALLAS — Few figures in pop culture are more closely linked to the devil than Robert Johnson. Not only did the blues hero write “Me and the Devil Blues” and “Hellhound on My Trail,” but legend has it that he sold his soul in exchange for his guitar skills.

headline: Neediest Cases | Where Are They Now?
text: Before receiving help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Thakane Masando lived in a homeless shelter while attending high school.

headline: Rangers Find No Traction in Montreal, Ending a Winning Streak
text: MONTREAL — All good things must come to an end, but, for the Rangers, this good thing came to an end pretty badly.

headline: Corrections: November 20
text: SPORTS

headline: Emanuel, in Iowa, Takes Aim at Romney
text: DES MOINES – President Obama’s re-election campaign offered an extensive preview of how he intends to fight for a second term, dispatching Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago here Saturday night to belittle the Republican field and to push back against a drumbeat of criticism aimed at the president.

headline: Sara Echenique Catinchi, Ondrej Staviscak Diaz
text: Sara Elena Echenique Catinchi and Ondrej Staviscak Diaz were married Saturday at San Juan Evangelista church in Guaynabo, P.R. The Rev. Nicolas Colacho Navarro, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Lindsay Pennington and Timothy Mosher
text: Lindsay Rae Pennington and Timothy Ross Mosher were married Saturday evening at the Majestic Halls, an event space in Los Angeles. Timothy McMullan, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism and a friend of the couple, officiated.

headline: Sarah Pease and Jeremiah Murphy III
text: Sarah Hoyt Pease and Jeremiah Patrick Murphy III were married Saturday evening at Marsh Chapel on the campus of Boston University. The Rev. Philip L. Rountree Jr., an Episcopal priest and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

headline: Leslie Azarian, Alex Karapetian
text: Leslie Maral Azarian and Alex Lazari Karapetian were married Saturday at St. Vartan Cathedral in Manhattan. Archbishop Khajag Barsamian, the primate of the Eastern Diocese of the Armenian Church in North America, performed the ceremony.

headline: Lucy Fagan, Adam Kweskin
text: Lucy Faith Fagan and Adam Reginald Kweskin were married Saturday evening in New York. Rabbi Robert N. Levine officiated at Battery Gardens, a restaurant.

headline: Ariel Fried, Steven Korn
text: Ariel Sonia Fried and Steven Chad Korn are to be married Sunday afternoon in Closter, N.J. Rabbi David-Seth Kirshner is to perform the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El with the assistance of Rabbi Lawrence S. Zierler.

headline: Jerry Arko and Henry Baker Jr.
text: Jerry Arko and Henry Lamar Baker Jr. were married Saturday evening at the Tribeca Grill in Manhattan. Lauren J. Berrol, a niece of Mr. Arko who became a minister of American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

headline: Beth Lutzker, Michael Levick
text: Beth Lynn Lutzker and Michael Dankner Levick are to be married Sunday afternoon in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert is to officiate and Cantor Shayna Postman is to assist at the Fountainhead, an event space.

headline: Richard Molinaroli, Samuel Carabetta
text: Richard Alexander Molinaroli and Samuel John Carabetta Jr. were married Friday evening at St. John’s Episcopal Church, Georgetown Parish, in Washington, where Mr. Carabetta is the organist and choirmaster. The Rev. Sarah Helene Duggin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. W. Bruce McPherson, also an Episcopal priest, taking part.

headline: Kimberly Rhoades, Brian Yarnell
text: Kimberly Elizabeth Rhoades and Brian Eric Yarnell were married Saturday by the Rev. C. William Mercer, a Church of Divine Science minister, at the Palm House in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Elyse Lehrfeld, Evan Burrows
text: Elyse Rachel Lehrfeld and Evan James Burrows are to be married Sunday afternoon in Rockleigh, N.J. Rabbi Henry A. Sosland is to officiate at the Rockleigh, an event space.

headline: Daniela Weber and Benjamin Tisch
text: Daniela Weber, the daughter of Zipora B. Weber and Bernard M. Weber of New York, was married Saturday evening to Benjamin Jacob Tisch, a son of Merryl H. Tisch and James S. Tisch, also of New York. Rabbi Philip Hiat, the bridegroom’s maternal grandfather, performed the ceremony at the Central Synagogue in New York.

headline: Frederick Barnfield, Lawrence Rodriguez
text: Frederick Lindon Barnfield and Lawrence Rodriguez were married Wednesday evening at their home in New York. Deborah S. Roth, an interfaith minister affiliated with the Sanctuary of the Beloved, officiated.

headline: Fairlie Lawrence and Richard Coxe Jr.
text: Fairlie Townsend Lawrence and Richard Badham Coxe Jr. were married Saturday evening at the Hillsboro Club in Pompano Beach, Fla. The Rev. Andre O’Dell, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Rachel Nance and Chaka Wade
text: Rachel Greenfield Nance and Chaka Luthuli Wade were married Saturday at the James K. Herbert Alumni Center at the United States Military Academy in West Point, N.Y. Gary Belsky, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism and a friend of the couple, officiated at a ceremony that incorporated Jewish and Baptist wedding traditions.

headline: Elizabeth Guillory, Stuart Oravetz
text: Elizabeth Marie Guillory and Stuart Bromley Oravetz were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. John A. Kamas, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Otto Kahn Mansion of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, a private girls’ school where the bride serves as the associate director of admissions and financial aid.

headline: Anna Webman, Aaron Silverman
text: Anna Julia Webman, a daughter of Susan Ginsburg Webman and Jerry A. Webman of Short Hills, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Aaron David Silverman, a son of Susan Silverman and Edward B. Silverman, also of Short Hills. Rabbi Steven Bayer officiated at the Ritz-Carlton Battery Park in Manhattan, with Justice Martin Marcus, of State Supreme Court in the Bronx, taking part.

headline: Jennifer Grossman, Daniel Fuchs
text: Jennifer Leigh Grossman, a daughter of Ilene M. Grossman and Mark D. Grossman of Livingston, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Daniel Hochman Fuchs, a son of Dr. Judith S. Hochman and Dr. Richard M. Fuchs of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Joshua Strom officiated at the St. Regis in Manhattan.

headline: Alexis Newman, Bradley Brodie
text: Alexis Robins Newman and Bradley Harris Brodie were married Saturday evening at Pier Sixty at Chelsea Piers, a banquet space in Manhattan. Allan Sugarman, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated, with Cantor Mark Kula taking part.

headline: Nicholas Grinder, Daniel Cole
text: Nicholas Myles Grinder and Daniel Lewis Cole were married Wednesday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an employee of the City Clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Bonus Beckham: A Few Extra Touches
text: As a preview of Sunday’s M.L.S. Cup final between the Los Angeles Galaxy and the Houston Dynamo, John Godfrey took a look at David Beckham’s impact — good and bad — on the league since arriving five years ago. But he had plenty from Beckham left over in his notebook when he was done writing.

headline: The Day’s Best in College Football
text: MONTEE BALL The Wisconsin running back rushed 38 times for 224 yards and 2 touchdowns and caught a touchdown pass as the 15th-ranked Badgers (9-2, 5-2 Big Ten) scored 21 straight points in the second half to rally at Illinois, 28-17. “We started off pretty slow,” said Ball, who has 30 touchdowns to extend his Big Ten season record.

headline: How the Top 25 Fared
text: 1. LOUISIANA STATE (11-0) beat Mississippi, 52-3

headline: U.S. Takes Presidents Cup
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The American Hunter Mahan pointed at the gold trophy and said, “So much for 20 1/2-11 1/2 .”

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: “What’s Your Foreign Degree Worth?” the Economic Times asks in its Sunday Magazine. “For decades, the foreign degree has been a great Indian middle-class dream,” the article says, and the crisis in India’s higher education system is only pushing more students overseas. But foreign education options are expensive, sometimes fraudulent and don’t always guarantee a good job overseas or at home. “The days when Indian employers used to be fascinated with a foreign degree are gone,” one human resources company executive says.

headline: Bringing Animation Where the News Is
text: Next Media, a Hong Kong-based company with gossipy newspapers in Hong Kong and in Taiwan, has gained an appreciative following for its news cartoons: short animated segments, often humorous and sometimes racy, that provide a visual narrative for major stories.

headline: Feriarte Fair in Madrid Offers Array of Art, Antiques and More
text: The annual Feriarte Art and Antiques Fair will bring together over 100 Spanish and international antiques dealers and gallery owners from Nov. 19 to 27 at the Feria de Madrid (Avenida del Partenón; www.ifema.es. Participants will offer an impressive array of furniture, paintings, sculptures, timepieces, lamps, jewelry and Asian and tribal art. Nearly 50 experts oversee the entries to guarantee their quality and authenticity.

headline: Last of 7 Parts: Answers to Your Questions on Student Loans and Scholarships
text: To help readers of The Choice navigate the maze of scholarships available to them — as well as to further their understanding of President Obama’s recent proposal to ease the repayment of some student loans — Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, spent this past week in our virtual Guidance Office. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of “Secrets to Winning a Scholarship,” published in February.

headline: Readers Share Their #SundayRoutine
text: As part of the Metropolitan section’s special Digital City issue, we’re asking readers to share their Sunday Routines with us. Throughout the day, let us know what you’re up to on Twitter using the hashtag #SundayRoutine, on Facebook and in the comments below. (More information about the project is here.) Below are some highlights from what we’ve received so far.

headline: Facing Calls to Give Up Power, Egypt’s Military Battles Crowds
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers struggled Sunday to contain an explosion of protests demanding their ouster, as a growing crowd of demonstrators pushed security forces out of Tahrir Square for a second night in a row and new clashes broke out across the country.

headline: Excerpts From an Interview with Mohammad Javad Larijani
text: Here are excerpts from an interview with Mohammad Javad Larijani, the Secretary General of the Iran High Council For Human Rights. The interview was conducted in English by The New York Times at Iran’s Mission to the United Nations in New York on Nov. 14:

headline: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
text: Their camp was evicted. Their property was removed. Many had not slept. But as dawn began to break over Lower Manhattan on Tuesday morning, just hours after the Occupy Wall Street protesters had been driven from Zuccotti Park in an overnight police operation, a hush fell over the huddled masses reconvened in Foley Square.

headline: Alex Stratta Is Opening Bigoli in Greenwich Village
text: Alessandro (Alex) Stratta, who developed quite a reputation in Las Vegas, will open his first New York restaurant next week. He will be executive chef and co-owner of Bigoli, with serious but fairly simple Italian food.

headline: Libyan Fighters Seize Qaddafi’s Intelligence Chief
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Revolutionary fighters captured Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s feared intelligence chief on Sunday as the interim government struggled to manage the increasingly thorny quandary of how to get custody of the former dictator’s son from a second armed group that had captured him only the day before.

headline: Headphones With Swagger (and Lots of Bass)
text: Dr. Dre is the pitchman for the hot new sound in — headphones. To the surprise of almost everyone, except him and his partners, Beats have redefined the lowly headphone, as well as how much people are willing to pay for a pair of them. Andrew Martin of the New York Times reports that whether Beats are worth the money is open to debate. Reviews are mixed, but many people love them.

headline: Headphones With Swagger (and Lots of Bass)
text: Dr. Dre is the pitchman for the hot new sound in headphones. To the surprise of almost everyone, except him and his partners, Beats have redefined the lowly headphone, as well as how much people are willing to pay for a pair of them. Andrew Martin of the New York Times reports that whether Beats are worth the money is open to debate. Reviews are mixed, but many people love them.

headline: Mobile Deals Set to Lure Shoppers Stuck in Line
text: As retailers battle to draw customers into their stores on Black Friday, online merchants are plotting a cunning ambush, reports Stephanie Clifford of the New York Times. She says the merchants are offering an arsenal of mobile-only deals intended to pick off shoppers as they wait in line.

headline: Mobile Deals Set to Lure Shoppers Stuck in Line
text: As retailers battle to draw customers into their stores on Black Friday, online merchants are plotting a cunning ambush, reports Stephanie Clifford of the New York Times. She reports that the merchants are offering an arsenal of mobile-only deals intended to pick off shoppers as they wait in line.

headline: An Extra Set of Eyes at the Museum
text: New York’s museums have moved beyond the audio wand, reports Joshua Brustein, the App City columnist at The New York Times. He reports that the American Museum of Natural History is opening a new exhibit, Beyond Planet Earth, this weekend, with an ambitious mobile application that conjures up three-dimensional images of solar systems and spacecraft on visitors’ phones. The Guggenheim recently introduced its first mobile application, for its retrospective on the Italian-born artist Maurizio Cattelan.

headline: New Phase for Syria in Attacks on Capital
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Insurgents fired rocket-propelled grenades at the offices of the ruling Baath Party in Damascus on Sunday in a highly symbolic strike that signaled a new chapter in the eight-month uprising against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: A Little Soul-Searching in Iowa
text: DES MOINES – Six Republican presidential candidates on Saturday night diverged from their usual campaign conversations about the economy, foreign policy and President Obama to offer a glimpse into how hardships and faith have shaped their lives.

headline: Are You a V.I.P.? Check Your Klout Score
text: Status has long been based on appearance, accomplishment and notoriety, but social media reach is becoming a new criterion, reports Beth Landman in the New York Times. Klout is trying to measure it by rating social media influence on a scale of 1 to 100, as a means of determining V.I.P. status.

headline: Re-engineering New York: More Than a Sci-Fi Dream?
text: New York remains envious of the wealth and success of Silicon Valley. It has tried to duplicate it and failed. But it is trying again, reports Gina Bellafante, the Big City columnist at the New York Times. Positioning New York for 21st-century global supremacy has been a preoccupation of the Bloomberg administration, she write, and one central to the mayor’s vision of greatly expanding the technology sector by ratcheting up elite science education.

headline: Yipit, on the Move, in a Thriving Tech Sector
text: Yipit, which aggregates and filters daily deals from companies like Groupon and Living Social, is an example of the high-tech start-up that is altering the employment picture in New York. Alan Feuer, of the New York Times, reports that high-tech employment in New York is shooting up by 30 percent in the last five years, at a time when overall private-sector employment has decreased. New York recently surpassed Boston in the amount of venture capital invested in Internet start-ups, and lags behind only San Francisco.

headline: Sunday Routine: Kati London of Zynga
text: Kati London, head of products for the social-game developer Zynga in New York, spends her week experimenting with ways to make interactions between machines and humans more social. She has worked on games like CityVille and Drop7. On Sundays, she turns her attention to her personal life, visiting friends and exploring in Manhattan or hiking upstate, reports Jenna Wortham of The New York Times.

headline: Novel Approach in N.H.L.: Turning Other Cheek
text: When Boston’s Milan Lucic freight-trained Buffalo goalie Ryan Miller on Nov. 12, it set off an unusual chain of events. After the N.H.L.’s chief disciplinarian, Brendan Shanahan, did not suspend Lucic, the league’s general managers gave him new marching orders, saying that similar future incidents should be punishable by suspension. The N.H.L. will protect goalies the way the N.F.L. protects quarterbacks.

headline: Felt Like Old Times
text: Ah. Three conservatives and one liberal on This Week.

headline: Latest ‘Twilight’ Movie Packs Theaters
text: It was a gooey, cheesy weekend at the multiplex as the movie series that teenage girls love and many adults love to hate — “The Twilight Saga” — returned with a sonic boom. “Breaking Dawn — Part I,” the fourth and the worst-reviewed film in the franchise, as judged by RottenTomatoes.com, was an enormous No. 1 at North American theaters, taking in about $139.5 million. “Breaking Dawn — Part I,” directed by the Oscar-winning Bill Condon, cost Summit Entertainment an estimated $110 million to make. Summit said that 80 percent of the audience was female; 60 percent of ticket buyers were over 21.

headline: Excerpt: 'Seminar' on Broadway
text: A scene from Theresa Rebeck's new comedy about a class led by a formidable writer, played by Alan Rickman. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: Second Day of Clashes in Cairo
text: Violent confrontations between protesters and the military continued for a second day.

headline: Quietly, Google Puts History Online
text: PARIS — When the Israel Museum in Jerusalem, home to the Dead Sea Scrolls, reopened last year after an extensive renovation, it attracted a million visitors in the first 12 months. When the museum opened an enhanced Web site with newly digitized versions of the scrolls in September, it drew a million virtual visitors in three and a half days.

headline: Lawmakers Trade Blame as Deficit Talks Crumble
text: WASHINGTON — With the hours ticking away toward a self-imposed deadline, Congressional leaders conceded Sunday that talks on a sweeping deficit agreement were near failure and braced for recriminations over their inability to reach a deal.

headline: Theodore Forstmann, Private Equity Pioneer, Is Dead at 71
text: Theodore J. Forstmann, a colorful financier and philanthropist who helped pioneer leveraged buyouts, died on Sunday at the age of 71.

headline: Metro Pucks Weekly: Grading the Rangers, Devils and Islanders
text: Our review of the recent performances by New York and New Jersey’s N.H.L. teams.

headline: Arts Center Reflects a New Dawn on the Prairie
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — In America the arts are always on the lookout for a new home.

headline: M.L.S. Tweaks Regular and Postseason Schemes (Again)
text: Hours before the start of Major League Soccer’s championship game Sunday, the league released its updated “competition format” for the 2012 season (the regular season will again begin in March and end in October).

headline: Remembering Teddy Forstmann
text: 4:28 p.m. | Updated Over his more than 40 years as a financier and philanthropist, Theodore J. Forstmann rubbed shoulders with prominent figures from the worlds of Wall Street, Washington and Hollywood alike.

headline: Officers Placed on Leave After Pepper-Spraying Protesters
text: The University of California, Davis, said on Sunday that two police officers had been placed on administrative leave after using pepper spray on seated protesters in a widely recorded encounter on Friday afternoon.

headline: Missed Kick Didn’t Kill Oregon’s Season
text: EUGENE, Ore. — When they talk about this Oregon-Southern Cal game — the pundits, the fans, the casual observers — they will probably focus on the missed field goal at the end of regulation that would have sent the game into overtime.

headline: Spanish Voters Deal a Blow to Socialists Over the Economy
text: MADRID — Spaniards struggling with high unemployment and a credit squeeze delivered a punishing verdict on almost eight years of Socialist government at the ballot box on Sunday, turning to the conservative Popular Party in the hopes of alleviating the pain of Europe’s debt crisis.

headline: Stocks, So Far Resilient, Face a Week of Challenges
text: Despite one negative headline from Europe after another, the stock market in the United States has held up pretty well lately, rising 10 percent since the beginning of October. But that could change this week, amid mounting investor doubt about the ability of political leaders on both sides of the Atlantic to slash spending and control budget deficits.

headline: When Disaster Threatens, Instinct Can Be a Pilot's Enemy
text: PARIS — The sinking sensation of an airplane in a stall is not one that many pilots forget.

headline: Federer Survives Sloppy Three-Setter vs. Tsonga
text: Though his ranking has slipped from No. 1 to No. 4, it’s hard to see much decline in Roger Federer’s game simply by watching him play a given point. His foot speed, serve and ground strokes have maintained their original pop (if not their accuracy), and his 30-year-old body remains devoid of a significant injury or seemingly even sweat.

headline: The Mark-To-Market Amplification Of Financial Distress
text: A nice phrase from my colleague Hyun Song Shin (pdf), describing what’s happening in Europe right now.

headline: Janeane Garofalo Joins ‘Russian Transport’
text: Janeane Garofalo, well-known for her comedic roles in television and film, will have a chance to show her dramatic chops on the stage for the first time in January, when she is set to appear in the New Group’s production of “Russian Transport,” the company announced. Directed by Scott Elliott and written by Erika Sheffer, the play focuses on a Russian family living in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, and struggling to assimilate to American life. Ms. Garofalo will portray Diana, a wife and mother of two.

headline: Violence Rages in Cairo
text: David D. Kirkpatrick reports on the standoff between protesters in Tahrir Square and the interim military council whose ouster they are demanding.

headline: For Their Children, Many E-Book Fans Insist on Paper
text: Print books may be under siege from the rise of e-books, but they have a tenacious hold on a particular group: children and toddlers. Their parents are insisting this next generation of readers spend their early years with old-fashioned books.

headline: Maryland Stuns No. 1 North Carolina for Field Hockey Title
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The Maryland sophomore forward Jill Witmer scored the game-winning goal on an unassisted breakaway in the 81st minute as the Terrapins came from two goals down to defeat top-seed North Carolina, 3-2, in overtime and claim the N.C.A.A. field hockey national championship.

headline: Strategies for the Bibliophile and Player on Your Gift List
text: With the holiday season rapidly approaching, let’s consider some of the bridge books that have been published this year for good players.

headline: A Dapper Music Magnate and the Empire He Built
text: Robert Greenfield is the author of “S.T.P.: A Journey Through America With the Rolling Stones,” one of the most rollicking accounts ever written about a rock band at the peak of its powers. But Mr. Greenfield’s latest book is much more respectful and sedate. No wonder: the subject of “The Last Sultan” is Ahmet Ertegun, the Turkish-born record company executive who set the high-water mark for personal panache and who remains a sacrosanct figure to most who knew him. Much of “The Last Sultan” is devoted to hyping and preserving the Ertegun legend.

headline: A Historic Harlem Hothouse Swings Again (With a Modern Orchestra)
text: Leading the list of pleasures to be savored in “Cotton Club Parade,” a thrilling 90-minute celebration of that famous Harlem nightclub in the Duke Ellington years (1927-31) at City Center, is the sound of the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra with Wynton Marsalis. At the show’s opening-night performance on Friday, this peerless ensemble created by Mr. Marsalis made period jazz come to life with a focused intensity and rhythmic savvy that left me open-mouthed with wonder.

headline: Cruel and Unusual: A President’s ‘Pardon’ as Dark Parody
text: In just a few days, we will once again endure the annual spectacle of the president of the United States  pardoning a turkey that would otherwise have been fated for the Thanksgiving table. This event is typically covered in the media as a light-hearted bit of fluff — and fluff is what it might well be, if there were not actual humans on death row awaiting similar intervention. In the current American context, however, the turkey pardon is a distasteful parody of the strange power vested in politicians to decide the earthly fates of death-row prisoners. There is in it an implicit acknowledgment that the killing of these prisoners is a practice that bears real, non-jocular comparison to the ritual slaughter of birds for feasts.

headline: Penguins’ Crosby Will Return Monday Against Islanders
text: The comeback of the superstar center Sidney Crosby begins Monday, when he makes his return to the Penguins’ lineup in a home game against the Islanders.

headline: Oprah Winfrey’s Show Has a Premiere Date
text: Oprah Winfrey, below, has set a premiere date for “Oprah’s Next Chapter,” the cable successor to her syndicated talk show. The new show will start in prime time on Jan. 1, her cable channel, OWN, announced on Friday. The episode will include a two-hour interview and visit with the musician Steven Tyler at his home in New Hampshire. The premiere will come exactly one year after the debut of OWN, short for the Oprah Winfrey Network, and seven months after the end of “The Oprah Winfrey Show.” The channel said the show would feature interviews on location with “newsmakers, celebrities, thought leaders and real-life families.” On the schedule are interviews with Joel Osteen, Tony Robbins, Deepak Chopra, Sean Penn, George Lucas and Paula Deen. In a promotional video Ms. Winfrey says, “We’re not sitting on ‘The Oprah Winfrey Show’ in those chairs anymore, people.” Executives at Discovery, which jointly owns the channel with Ms. Winfrey, have said that new episodes could run two or three times a week, but OWN said on Friday that it would run weekly, on Sunday nights.

headline: Netflix to Back ‘Arrested Development’
text: Nearly six years after Fox canceled the quirky sitcom “Arrested Development,” the series is being resuscitated by a new distributor, Netflix, the online streaming service. Netflix said on Friday that it had struck a deal for new episodes with the makers of the show, 20th Century Fox Television and Imagine Television. The episodes are to start appearing on the service in 2013. “Bringing a series back from cancellation almost never happens, but then, ‘Arrested’ always was about as unconventional as they get, so it seems totally appropriate that this show that broke the mold is smashing it to pieces once again,” the founders of Imagine, Ron Howard and Brian Grazer, said in a statement. Streaming episodes of the critically acclaimed show have remained popular among Netflix subscribers, giving the company the confidence to make more. Netflix did not say how many episodes it had ordered or whether the original cast members, like Will Arnett, above, had signed up for the revival. The deal comes as Netflix is eager for original programming. Earlier this year it commissioned a drama, “House of Cards,” which is to have its debut next year.

headline: O’Brian Novels Are Going Digital
text: Patrick O’Brian’s popular seafaring novels featuring Jack Aubrey and Stephen Maturin will be released as e-books for the first time, their publisher said on Sunday. The 20-book series, set during the Napoleonic wars, includes “Master and Commander,” “Desolation Island” and “The Commodore.” About 7.5 million copies have been sold in the United States since the first book was published in 1969. The publisher, W. W. Norton, wants to open the series to a wider audience and take advantage of the holiday book-buying season. “Now that the novels are available digitally, readers who prefer the e-book format can have this collection instantly at their fingertips — as well the enviable pleasure of reading O’Brian’s astonishing series for the first time,” Starling Lawrence, editor at large at Norton, said in a statement. O’Brian died in 2000.

headline: Documentary Shortlist Is Released for Oscars
text: The Oscar documentaries shortlist is in, some industry favorites are out and that makes it a typical year for the documentary branch of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, which almost always manages to puzzle and provoke with its choices. Among the 15 films on the list, from which nominees and the winner will be drawn, are “Battle for Brooklyn,” directed by Michael Galinsky and Suki Hawley; “Bill Cunningham New York,” directed by Richard Press; “Buck,” directed by Cindy Meehl; and “Semper Fi: Always Faithful,” directed by Tony Hardmon and Rachel Libert. Not included were “Into the Abyss,” from Werner Herzog; “The Interrupters,” from Steve James; and “Senna,” from Asif Kapadia. The shortlist is at Oscars.org.

headline: Orchestra Keeps Up Hunt to Fill Its Top Job
text: No, no, no, no and no. And no.

headline: Solo Violin Concerto With Flair
text: The violinist Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg likes to call her relationship with the conductorless New Century Chamber Orchestra “a marriage that worked.” Leaving aside whatever aspersions may be implied on other marriages, you could hardly argue with her basic premise when the orchestra made its New York debut on Tuesday evening at Symphony Space.

headline: Puccini’s 99 Percent, Living and Dying in Zeffirelli Style
text: “I live in contented poverty,” sings the idealistic poet Rodolfo in “La Bohème,” before declaring that he has “the soul of a millionaire.” Puccini’s young bohemians, cheerily impoverished members of the 99 percent, initially occupy their freezing garret with carefree abandon. But the shabby attic becomes the scene of painful loss, when the central character Mimi dies of consumption, a disease that killed the poor much faster because of malnutrition and inadequate living conditions.

headline: How a Banana Tycoon Lured Bolshoi Stars to His Theater
text: MOSCOW — He is often called Banana King. But Vladimir Kekhman — the fruit magnate who stunned the dance world last week by enticing two of the biggest stars in ballet to quit the eminent Bolshoi and join his far lesser-known Mikhailovsky Theater in St. Petersburg — considers this title an understatement. “I was sort of the Emperor of the Banana,” he said.

headline: Troupe Makes a Signature Out of Its Intimate Scale
text: It has been nearly 15 years since Medhi Bahiri and Judith Fugate formed Ballet NY, and the company is as intimate as ever, which is a polite way of saying that it’s small in both size and scale. At the Ailey Citigroup Theater, where Ballet NY performed on Friday night, little about the evening rose beyond serviceable. Yes, there was a pas de deux by Agnes de Mille from “The Other,” but with that was yet another ballet set to Bach and called, most unimaginatively, “Concerto.” (Mr. Bahiri was responsible.)

headline: Monday: Older Woman’s Plaything, in Slang
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Before we get into today’s puzzle, I would like to take this opportunity to wish Will Shortz a happy anniversary.

headline: Open Letter From N.B.A. Coaches Association Chief
text: “Don’t it always seem to go, that you don’t know what you’ve got ‘til it’s gone…” Joni Mitchell (Big Yellow Taxi)

headline: At 154, a Digital Milestone
text: The Atlantic owes its name and legacy to the 154-year-old monthly magazine founded by New England literary greats likeRalph Waldo Emerson. But in October, the company marked a very modern milestone: digital advertising revenue exceeded print advertising revenue for the first time.

headline: ‘The Last Sultan’
text: A new book looks at the career of the music executive Ahmet Ertegun.

headline: Ethiopian Troops Said to Enter Somalia, Opening New Front Against Militants
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Witnesses along the drought-stricken Ethiopia-Somalia border reported Sunday that hundreds of Ethiopian troops had crossed into Somalia with armored personnel carriers, heavy artillery and tanks, opening a new front in an intensifying international offensive against the Shabab militant group.

headline: Ayotte Backing Signals Conservative Support for Romney
text: NASHUA, N.H. — Mitt Romney collected the backing of the freshman Senator Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire on Sunday, a coveted endorsement from a conservative Republican and rising star in state politics, amid growing signs that leaders from the party’s right wing are making peace with the possibility of Mr. Romney as their nominee.

headline: Man Arrested and Charged in Bomb Plot
text: Updated 7:47 p.m. | The authorities have arrested a man who law enforcement officials believe was planning to build and detonate a bomb in New York with government workers, returning military personnel and elected officials as the target, two people briefed on the case said on Sunday.

headline: Don’t Overlook Electricity’s Power
text: Northeast Utilities made an offering at the altar of the regulatory gods last week. The utility parted ways with the executive who had headed its biggest division, Connecticut Light & Power, over its poor handling of two storms that left millions of customers without power for weeks. Investors seem to think that will smooth approval for a $4.7 billion takeover of Nstar, its rival. Their optimism looks misplaced.

headline: ‘Cotton Club Parade’
text: Photos from the show at City Center.

headline: Redefining Public Relations in the Age of Social Media
text: THE public relations industry has decided that it may be a good time for, well, a public relations initiative.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Fantasies of a Debt Deal From a Convivial Congress
text: NEW ORLEANS—Let’s play Congressional supercommittee! — the fantasy football version.

headline: Drugs Used for Psychotics Go to Youths in Foster Care
text: Foster children are being prescribed cocktails of powerful antipsychosis drugs just as frequently as some of the most mentally disabled youngsters on Medicaid, a new study suggests.

headline: Periodic Novel, Coming Soon
text: Could people talk about books with the same timely intensity that they do the latest episode of “Mad Men” or “Top Chef”?

headline: International Court Faces Key Test on Libya Captives
text: PARIS — The brewing conflict over the fate of two high-ranking Libyan figures — Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, once Libya’s heir apparent, and Abdullah Senussi, the former intelligence chief — is not only a test for the country’s stated commitment to the rule of law, but also a moment of reckoning for the International Criminal Court as it tries to expand its reach.

headline: Pakistani Leader Faces Pressure Over Memo
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pressure mounted Sunday on President Asif Ali Zardari to investigate allegations that Pakistan’s ambassador to the United States had sought American help to rein in the Pakistani military, as opposition politicians called for action and records appearing to implicate the ambassador were leaked to the news media.

headline: Using Taiwan as a Bargaining Chip
text: To the Editor:

headline: Disruptions: For Teenagers, a Car or a Smartphone?
text: The auto industry has a lot of problems. It has to worry about workers’ pension and health care costs, too-frequent recalls and the rising cost of gas. I think there is something else that should concern the automakers.

headline: Woods and Furyk Reclaim Their Games at Presidents Cup
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The American Hunter Mahan rubbed his fingers across the gold Presidents Cup trophy and said to Tiger Woods, seated next to him, “So much for 20 ½-11 ½.”

headline: Survivors Seek Answers at Khmer Rouge Trial
text: CHOEUNG EK, Cambodia — With opening statements about to begin in the most important phase of the Khmer Rouge trials, survivors of the regime’s violence kneeled before a huge pyramid of skulls at a killing field here on Sunday as monks chanted a prayer for the souls of the dead.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Nameless on the Web?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cutting Health Costs by Reducing the Bureaucracy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rare Music Videos, for a Price
text: How do you sell something people can get free? That is a central question in the music industry today, particularly when it comes to music videos, which are abundantly available on YouTube, Vevo and other sites.

headline: Guns and Felons
text: To the Editor:

headline: Preparing to Meet Red Sox, Valentine Emerges as Favorite
text: As Bobby Valentine prepares to meet with the Boston Red Sox on Monday to interview for their managerial opening, there is an increasing sense around baseball that the job may be his to lose. The Red Sox have been canvassing the game for opinions on Valentine, the former manager of the Texas Rangers and the Mets, who would replace the departed Terry Francona.

headline: Trolling Overseas for TV Concepts to Mine
text: American media companies may be cutting back on the domestic front, but they are shopping heavily overseas. The object of their desires? Reality shows like “Big Brother,” “Promzillas” and “Freaky Eaters.”

headline: Week 11 Live: Giants-Eagles Win Probability
text: The Fifth Down provided live updates and analysis during the Giants’ 17-10 loss to the Eagles on Sunday night, while tracking the probability of a win throughout the game. A quick review for those unfamiliar with the metric from Advanced NFL Stats: Win probability measures just that — the probability that each team will win the game at any moment.

headline: Looking Ahead This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Existing home sales for October (Monday); revised third-quarter gross domestic product (Tuesday); durable goods for October, weekly jobless claims, personal income and spending for October, and Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for November (Wednesday).

headline: Theodore J. Forstmann, a Takeover Pioneer, Dies at 71
text: Theodore J. Forstmann, a colorful financier and philanthropist who helped pioneer leveraged buyouts, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 71.

headline: Success Long in Coming for Eylea, a Vision Treatment
text: It has three Nobel Prize winners on its board. Its chairman, P. Roy Vagelos, is a pharmaceutical industry star who ran Merck during its heyday. Its chief scientist has written frequently cited biomedical papers.

headline: How China Can Defeat America
text: Beijing

headline: Free of Concussion Symptoms, Penguins’ Crosby Is Set to Play
text: The comeback of Sidney Crosby will begin Monday night, when he is scheduled to return to the Pittsburgh Penguins’ lineup against the visiting Islanders.

headline: Boring Cruel Romantics
text: There’s a word I keep hearing lately: “technocrat.” Sometimes it’s used as a term of scorn — the creators of the euro, we’re told, were technocrats who failed to take human and cultural factors into account. Sometimes it’s a term of praise: the newly installed prime ministers of Greece and Italy are described as technocrats who will rise above politics and do what needs to be done.

headline: For a Movement, a Question: What Now?
text: After last week’s dead-of-night operation in New York to break up the protest site in Zuccotti Park, and similar actions in other cities, it is inevitable that Occupy Wall Street will eventually become more of an idea than a place.

headline: Bowl Championship Series Standings
text: The B.C.S. rankings are determined by three components: the Harris Interactive poll, the USA Today coaches poll and the average of six computer rankings. Each component counts one-third toward a team’s B.C.S. score.

headline: Balancing U.S. Policy on an Ally in Transition
text: For the United States, the weekend clashes in Cairo crystallized the defining policy quandary of the Arab Spring: how to square contradictory American impulses that include support for democratic change, a desire for stability and wariness of Islamists who have become a potent political force.

headline: Archdiocese to Speak Out at Rally Urging City Council to Pass Bill on Wages
text: Supporters of a bill that would raise wages at city-subsidized projects are celebrating the introduction of a formidable voice to the debate: the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

headline: Columbia Fires Coach in Football
text: Columbia University fired Norries Wilson as its football coach Sunday, a day after the Lions staved off the university’s first winless season in the sport since 1987 by rallying for a 35-28 overtime victory over Brown.

headline: Central Bankers: Stop Dithering. Do Something.
text: London

headline: M.L.S. Cup Final: Galaxy 1, Dynamo 0
text: The Los Angeles Galaxy won the Major League Soccer championship on Sunday night with a goal conjured by three of the league’s most high profile — and most highly paid — players, defeating the Houston Dynamo, 1-0, at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif.

headline: Upsets Leave SEC Teams Ruling the B.C.S. Race
text: Perhaps the most fitting image from a chaotic weekend of college football came from the sideline of Oregon’s Autzen Stadium on Saturday night. Southern California receiver Robert Woods paid homage to the sideline guest LeBron James, whose Nike ties brought him to the Pacific Northwest to check out Phil Knight’s pet program.

headline: Protest Puts Coverage in Spotlight
text: As police officers cleared protesters last week from Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, the birthplace of Occupy Wall Street, they made sure most reporters were kept blocks away, supposedly for their own protection.

headline: Miami Says It Will Not Play in Bowl Game
text: The University of Miami announced Sunday that it would not participate in a bowl game, in response to the N.C.A.A. investigation of its football program and athletic department.

headline: For the Rich, Cargo Vans on Steroids
text: Steve Kantor admits that he likes to travel in style. He is an affable investment banker, concerned about flaunting his wealth, but he drives around Manhattan in what looks like a simple black delivery van.

headline: Two Ex-Jets Have Moved On, but Concussion Effects Linger
text: In 1992, Al Toon, a wide receiver for the Jets, became one of the early forecasters of the concussion tsunami that would strike the N.F.L. Toon retired at age 29 after sustaining his ninth diagnosed concussion. Thirteen years later, Wayne Chrebet, another Jets receiver, ended his career after sustaining the sixth known concussion of his 11 years with the team.

headline: Fixing Medicare
text: There is no way to wrestle down the deficit without reining in Medicare costs. Ensuring that the program provides quality health care coverage to millions of older and disabled Americans is essential. These goals are not incompatible, but they require a judicious approach to policy making that is depressingly absent in Washington.

headline: Gov. Brewer’s Overreach
text: The Arizona Supreme Court has dealt a stinging defeat to Gov. Jan Brewer’s attempt to favor Republican lawmakers by derailing the state’s independent redistricting commission. The court ordered the reinstatement of the commission’s chairwoman, Colleen Mathis, finding no grounds for the charge of “gross misconduct” leveled by Governor Brewer when she engineered Ms. Mathis’s removal in a party-line State Senate vote this month.

headline: Mixed Results as Google Enters Microsoft’s Turf
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Michael O’Brien, vice president for information technology at Journal Communications, would prefer not to have the employees of the Milwaukee media company use Microsoft’s Office software any more.

headline: Up-and-Down Ravens Reassert Themselves at Home
text: BALTIMORE — The Baltimore Ravens’ season has been marked by such impressive victories and confounding losses that a few hours before Sunday’s game against the Cincinnati Bengals, one Ravens fan said he hoped his home team would lose, so that the paying customers would have a chance to vent their frustration.

headline: Occupy Honolulu
text: Wall Street and Oakland get all the attention, but there’s an Occupy Honolulu, too. Its tents and lawn chairs have taken over Thomas Square, a green expanse downtown all set about with banyan trees.

headline: President Hits His Stride on Foreign, but Familiar, Territory
text: BALI, Indonesia — President Obama had more than the usual spring in his step on Saturday as he bounded up the stairs into Air Force One for a 25-hour flight home after an eight-day Pacific spin.

headline: Tennessee’s Fighting Parson
text: Of all the men arrested after the Nov. 8, 1861, bridge-bombing plot in eastern Tennessee, perhaps none was as surprising as William Gannaway “Parson” Brownlow. As late as 1861, Brownlow was nationally renowned as the South’s — and slavery’s — most ardent defender.

headline: White House Shooting Suspect’s Path to Extremism
text: IDAHO FALLS — A referee lifted Oscar Ortega’s hand high into the clear Rocky Mountain night last summer. Mr. Ortega had not yet been accused of trying to kill the president. He had not yet told the world he was Jesus Christ. Not until the next morning would all the blows to his body make him urinate blood.

headline: How Can We Prevent Military Suicides?
text: Why do so many veterans and service members kill themselves?

headline: Racial Justice in Britain on Trial
text: LONDON — In one sense, almost everything unfolding in Court 16 at the Old Bailey is déjà vu. In the first week of a murder trial that is expected to last many weeks, the jury has heard a grim recounting of the death of Stephen Lawrence, a black teenager who was stabbed on a chilly south London street in 1993, an event that has been exhaustively chronicled through years of public inquiries, inconclusive court proceedings and graphic coverage in Britain’s newspapers.

headline: Prospect Park Takes Steps to Slow Cyclists
text: On a stretch of Prospect Park’s main drive, bright orange traffic barrels are the most visible symbols of an urgent and emotional debate over whose rights should have priority in Brooklyn’s largest park: pedestrians’ or cyclists’?

text: Though the match did not begin much after its projected start time of 8 p.m., Rafael Nadal appeared completely flustered and unprepared as his first round-robin match at the ATP World Tour Finals was set to begin Sunday in London.

headline: At Night, a Cafe Reveals It Has a Split Personality
text: At 3:55 p.m. five days a week, Jeremiah Fox heads down the block from the Juice Box, a wine store he manages in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, and enters the Crossroads Cafe.

headline: Rookies In Middle Of Giants’ Defense
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — There are several ways to quantify just how inexperienced the Giants’ linebackers were for Sunday night’s game against the Philadelphia Eagles, but perhaps the most glaring reality is this: Mathias Kiwanuka was by far the most seasoned of the group, and he began his N.F.L. career in 2006 as a defensive end.

text: The gap between first class and coach has never been so wide.

headline: The Deficit Deal That Wasn’t: Hopes Are Dashed

headline: With Daring, Stewart Takes His Third Nascar Title
text: HOMESTEAD, FLA. — Every time Tony Stewart reached the lead during the Sprint Cup season finale Sunday, something dropped him back into the pack. But bad luck, poor execution in the pit, a 74-minute rain delay and the incredible consistency of Carl Edwards were ultimately no match for the hard-charging Stewart.

headline: David Invites Some Goliaths Over to Play
text: LAHAINA, Hawaii — Imagine Mike Krzyzewski regularly having to separate blues from whites to launder Duke’s uniforms. Or Bill Self at Kansas having a mere $5,000 for his entire recruiting budget.

headline: Shredding Egos, One Semicolon at a Time
text: Maybe you can’t judge a book by its cover, but apparently you can come up with a spot-on appraisal just by eyeballing a couple of sentences. That, anyway, is the impression left by “Seminar,” the shiny, facile new comedy by Theresa Rebeck, which stars Alan Rickman as the posturing celebrity teacher of a writing workshop.

headline: Boy Scouts, Binoculars and a Wilderness Agenda
text: Identity crises are epidemic in Thomas Higgins’s “Wild Animals You Should Know,” the undercooked new comedy that opened on Sunday night at the Lucille Lortel Theater. The nerdy business consultant who has lost his job; the loutish beer swiller who has lost his wife; the overachieving, sexually ambivalent Boy Scout who has lost his cellphone: they’re all flailing, groping to figure out who and what they are. So, I regret to add, is the play.

headline: Homeless, Abandoned by Parents and Now Preparing for College
text: During the first week of classes in September, the College of Staten Island was a locus of anticipation. Students were hustling through the courtyard, striking up new friendships and chatting nervously about the coming workload. Hermon Joseph sat in a shaded area near the library, soaking it all up with a wide grin.

headline: Loudly Protesting Park Eviction, if Not Outside Mayor’s Window as Planned
text: The sounds of snare drums, bongo drums and bucket drums, a familiar and frequent annoyance to those who live near Zuccotti Park, moved uptown on Sunday to the East Side home of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Retailers Enliven Catalog Offerings Through Apps
text: When you browse Anthropologie’s stores, you feel as if you’re wandering through an artsy home, where there are sure to be closets full of eclectic outfits, bedrooms with bohemian quilts and kitchen tables with mismatched dishes. But when you visit its e-commerce site, you get none of that feel; you’re just scrolling through an unimaginative grid of clothes worn by wooden mannequins.

text: Sanford D. Garelik, a former New York City mayoral candidate and a City Council president who served the city amid the fiscal and criminal turmoil of the 1970s, died Saturday in Manhattan. He was 93.

text: Eva Monley, a Hollywood location manager whose fluency in Swahili made her a linchpin in the creation of scores of movies filmed in Africa between 1950 and the 1990s, including “The African Queen” and “Out of Africa,” died on Nov. 12 at her home in Nanyuki, Kenya. She was 88.

What happened in previous years is irrelevant, they said, from Coach Tom Coughlin on down. This year is different, they said. We are different.

headline: Torture’s Future
text: As a candidate in 2008, President Obama stated categorically, “We’ll reject torture — without exception or equivocation.” During his first month in office, he made good on his pledge, signing an executive order prohibiting torture or inhumane treatment. There is no reason to doubt that the order has been followed. This was a huge step forward for the United States.

headline: Egypt’s Cabinet Offers to Resign as Protests Rage
text: CAIRO — The cabinet offered its resignation on Monday to Egypt’s transitional military rulers as security forces carried out an increasingly lethal crackdown on three days of violent street protests, reviving the uncertainty about Egypt’s future that marked the earliest days of the Arab Spring.
