text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: In First Class, a World Apart
text: The gap between first class and coach has never been so wide, as airlines compete for the lucrative business and first-class traveler on long-haul international flights.

headline: Nov. 21, 1964 | Verrazano-Narrows Bridge Opens
text: On Nov. 21, 1964, the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge was opened, connecting Staten Island and Brooklyn. It surpassed San Francisco’s Golden Gate Bridge as the world’s largest suspension bridge, with a 4,260-foot-center span between two 693-foot towers. The bridge is so large that its design called for the towers to be angled slightly away from each other to compensate for the curvature of the Earth.A large ceremony was held for the opening of the upper deck of the two-deck bridge, attracting dignitaries like Mayor Robert Wagner, Gov. Nelson Rockefeller and Robert Moses, known as the “master builder” of mid-20th century New York City. The ironworkers who built the bridge, however, boycotted the ceremony when Moses did not invite them to participate.

headline: Dissident Leader Expected to Run for Myanmar Parliament
text: HONG KONG — Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of Myanmar’s main opposition movement, is likely to run for Parliament in a coming election, senior members of her party said on Monday. It would be the first time Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel laureate who is the face of democracy in Myanmar, has run for office.

headline: When the Walls Come Down
text: JOHANNESBURG — I am sitting in front of the entrance to my new two-story flat in upmarket Sandton in northern Johannesburg, admiring the colorful bed of flowers planted at my doorstep. Two women in their sixties walk around the block several times, and each time they pass I notice their increasingly sweaty brows, evidence of an impressive effort to stay fit. They look like they might be training for a race, complete with sport shoes and sweat bands on their wrists.

headline: Carnegie Hall Benefit Honors the Rolling Stones
text: The annual concert at Carnegie Hall to benefit music education programs for the poor will have a Rolling Stones theme this spring, the event’s organizer, Michael Dorf, announced. Rosanne Cash, Steve Earle, the Carolina Chocolate Drops and others have signed on to perform all 21 tracks from the Rolling Stones classic collection “Hot Rocks 1964-1971,” on the 40th anniversary of its release. The concert will take place March 13 and the proceeds will go to support nonprofit organizations that provide music classes to impoverished youths, among them the Church Street School of Music, Young Audiences, Music Unites and the Pinwheel Project. Mr. Dorf, who owns the City Winery, has raised about $600,000 for charity with similar concerts over the last seven years, asking contemporary musicians to pay tribute to the music of older artists. Past shows have focused on the songs of Joni Mitchell, Bob Dylan, Bruce Springsteen and the Who, among others. This year, at least 21 solo artists and groups will be on the bill to interpret songs by the Stones, including the Mountain Goats, Rich Robinson of the Black Crowes and Glen Hansard.

headline: Christmas Cribs Celebrated at Rome Exhibition
text: Few holiday traditions are more Italian than making presepi — the cribs that sit in Christmas nativity scenes. It’s said that, all the way back in 1223, St. Francis of Assisi himself created the world’s first nativity scene. Now, nearly 800 years later, many worry that the craft of creating and displaying handmade presepi is languishing.

headline: Which Is More Important: Talent or Hard Work?
text: We’ve all heard that hard work is the key to success. But a recent study found that the “profoundly gifted” still have an edge over peers who have less natural talent but are perhaps more dedicated to improving their skills. Have you experienced the power of talent over hard work? Or have you found that success comes to the person willing to put in the most time and effort to achieve it?

headline: United States and Its Allies Expand Sanctions on Iran

The measures, a response to a recent United Nations report warning about Iran’s nuclear activities, tighten the vise on Iran but still fall short of a blanket cutoff.

headline: Prosecutors Describe Khmer Rouge Leaders’ ‘Organized and Systematic’ Atrocities

headline: Tom Coughlin Transcript After Loss to Eagles
text: As Sam Borden noted, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin  “ripped into his team during his postgame address” after the loss to the Eagles. The Giants’ offensive line was pushed around, and that didn’t sit well with Coughlin. The offense’s troubles also led to this Yogi Berra-like pronouncement: “It was what they were doing; it wasn’t what we were doing because we didn’t do anything.”

headline: Sex Ed, With an Emphasis on the Sex
text: As New York City moves toward its first mandated sex education courses in many years, a school in the Philadelphia suburbs embraces a new type of program that embraces the sexual aspects of sex ed.  Can explicit lesson that assume high school students are having sex and coaches them on how to make the most of it be an effective way to deal with safety, unwanted pregnancies, stigmas and sexual stereotypes?

headline: Fairy Tales
text: One repeated gripe I’ve had about news coverage in the Lesser Depression is the way deficit-hawk myths about markets are often reported as facts. Again and again, slight upticks in interest rates have been attributed — in news stories, not opinion pieces — to debt fears, despite the complete absence of any actual evidence to that effect.

headline: Shop, Look, Listen
text: Danielle Kosann may have gone into the family business (her mother is the jeweler Monica Rich Kosann), but this 25-year-old’s forte is tech style. With her new e-commerce site, shoplooks.com, visitors get to browse through their favorite look books — from Madewell to Carven — without ever having to switch tabs. Call it stream-of-consciousness shopping. “It’s the kind of thing that sparks imagination,” Kosann says. Straight from the source, here’s what we’ll want this holiday season.

headline: For the Giants and the Bears, Cloudy Days Are Here Again
text: In the N.F.L., fortunes can change in a minute. One minute, you’re the Giants team that just beat the Patriots and are leading your division and boasting the only Manning healthy enough to play quarterback, and the next minute you’ve hacked up two straight games, including one to an Eagles team given up for toast. And one minute, you’re the resurgent Bears, puffing out your chests and telling everyone about the magic of Jay Cutler, and the next you’re staring down a future field-generaled by Caleb Hanie. Yikes!

headline: Springsteen and E Street Band Plan First Tour Since 2009
text: Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, who have not toured since 2009, will be going out on the road beginning in mid-2012 on what Mr. Springsteen’s Web site describes as a global tour, with some dates in Europe already announced and performances in North America and other locations confirmed. The shows will be the first for the band since Clarence Clemons, the saxophonist who for decades served as Mr. Springsteen’s onstage foil, died of complications of a stroke in June.

headline: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
text: How many games can the Bears win without Jay Cutler? How good is Carson Palmer this season? And how important is the Giants-Saints game? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will again answer selected questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below to ask your questions, and the answers will appear on The Fifth Down on Wednesday.

headline: Opposition Meeting With British Highlights Syria’s Isolation
text: ISTANBUL — Syria’s political opposition widened its outreach on Monday, sending representatives to Britain as the Syrian government withstood signs of further isolation over an uprising that is increasingly resembling a prolonged armed struggle to oust President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: MF Global Trustee Says Shortfall Could Exceed $1.2 Billion
text: The amount of customer money missing from the collapsed trading firm MF Global may be more than $1.2 billion — double previous estimates — the trustee dismantling the firm’s brokerage unit said on Monday.

headline: Look of The Moment | Emma Watson
text: The Look: Cropped. A crystal-embellished top and a high-waisted skirt come together neatly with a skinny bow belt.

headline: Monday Matchup: Chiefs at Patriots
text: Chiefs (4-5) at Patriots (6-3), 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN Line: Patriots by 15 1/2

headline: Turkey Tips: Unwrapping the Turkey
text: Melissa Clark provides tips on taking the turkey out of the bag and getting it ready to season and cook.

headline: Excerpt: 'Blood and Gifts'
text: A scene from J. T. Rogers's new play about the Soviet-Afghan war of the 1980s. (Video courtesy of Lincoln Center Theater.)

text: Q.

headline: China Bends to U.S. Complaint on Solar Panels but Plans Retaliation
text: HONG KONG — Chinese solar panel makers plan to shift some of their production to South Korea, Taiwan and the United States in hopes of defusing a trade case pending against them in Washington, according to industry executives.

headline: Do Pies Need to Be Defrosted Before They Are Baked?
text: Q.

headline: Women Rule at American Music Awards
text: Young female vocalists dominated the American Music Awards on Sunday night, with Taylor Swift and Adele each winning in three different categories and Rihanna, Beyoncé and Nicki Minaj also picking up trophies.

headline: Unearthing the Surprises Within a Child's Mind
text: A middle-school teacher writes: Often I read a child’s paper, or talk to him or her, and am startled at the interpretation of events in his or her life.  It is as though no one has explained the world to these children, and so they try to understand it based on what they can see. We must remember to ask, or we will never know.

headline: Protesters Arrested at Bank-Account Closing  Sue City
text: Updated, 4:44 p.m. | On the afternoon of Oct. 15, Heather Carpenter walked into a Citibank branch in Greenwich Village and closed her account as a form of protest against bank fees.

headline: About Op-Docs
text: Op-Docs is The New York Times editorial department’s award-winning section for short, opinionated documentaries, produced with wide creative latitude and a range of artistic styles, covering current affairs, contemporary life and historical subjects.

headline: Waiting for Failure
text: As I read the background story on the collapse of the “super committee” talks in the Times today, I felt depressed. It’s not like I wasn’t prepared for this: The committee’s membership and rules seemed certain to produce a stalemate.

headline: Republicans and Obama Can Agree on Criticizing China’s Trade Practices
text: WASHINGTON — China’s swift economic rise, and a presidential election dominated by fears of a declining American economy, have produced a rare convergence: Republican contenders talking tough about China, and a president who is already getting tough on it.

headline: On a Dispiriting Night for the Giants, Herzlich Is a Highlight
text: Mathias Kiwanuka was mostly glum as he discussed the Giants’ Sunday night loss to the Philadelphia Eagles. His expression, particularly as he answered questions about how the team appeared to be pushed around by the Eagles, remained dour and downcast.

headline: Bahrain’s Forgotten Revolt
text: The Bahrain government managed a tactical victory over the revolt but may have destroyed a society that took pride in its cosmopolitanism.

headline: Jefferies Continues Its Defense
text: The Jefferies Group can’t seem to shake its critics.

headline: Is It O.K. for Doctors to Turn Away Unvaccinated Children?
text: Ariel Kaminer, the Ethicist for The Times Magazine, will respond to readers’ comments on the 6th Floor blog from 1 to 5 p.m. today on the subject of whether it’s ethical for pediatricians to refuse routine care to families who do not immunize their children. Will she address whether parents who don’t vaccinate their kids would even want that care? Or if allowing pediatricians to turn away certain patients would effectively limit the antivaccine choice to parents who can afford to pick and choose among providers? Will the whole thing devolve into yet another online debate on vaccination, and how society should handle the families — like 77 percent of kindergarten parents at a Waldorf school written about recently in The Times — who (without medical necessity) skip the shots?

headline: Bahrain Is Nervously Awaiting Report on Its Forgotten Revolt
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — Bahrain’s forgotten revolt sometimes reads like the script for a film of international intrigue, where the truth remains elusive.

headline: A Step Forward for RNA Interference
text: The once hot and then cold field of RNA interference might not be dead yet.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: It’s holiday gift-set time. If you’re looking for a collection of luxurious makeup to brighten up the season, here are three standouts:

headline: Customer Service, Ranked Either ‘Naughty’ or ‘Nice’
text: For a second year, Consumer Reports has compiled a holiday report card of customer service policies that it deems either “naughty” or “nice.”

headline: In Dance, Borrowing Is a Tradition
text: The “Nutcracker” season is almost upon us — but can you be sure who choreographed all of the versions you might see? Last year, as I toured the United States in a “Nutcracker” marathon, I observed how more than 12 American productions featured the Sugar Plum pas de deux that Lev Ivanov choreographed for the 1892 original in St. Petersburg. But in only one case was the pas de deux — whose adagio, early on, features a beautifully spectacular phrase unlike anything else in 19th-century ballet, with the ballerina seeming to peel herself open in her partner’s arms — actually credited to Ivanov.

headline: California’s Campus Movements Dig In Their Heels
text: LOS ANGELES — It has become something of an annual tradition on California college campuses, in what is perhaps the most prestigious state university system in the country: the state makes large cuts in public universities, they in turn raise tuition, and students respond with angry protests.

headline: Ravenous | The Stuffing Theory
text: “He who controls the stuffing, controls the universe!” In a recent Thanksgiving-themed episode of “South Park,” these portentous words came from the mouth of Myles Standish, the military leader of the Plymouth Colony. If you missed the episode, the Pilgrims and Indians were both from outer space, and had a long-held but recently broken truce over their respective rights to “the stuffing caves” — and mayhem and hilarity ensues.

headline: Talking Comedy With John Landis
text: For many American moviegoers in the 1980s, John Landis was a household name. He sealed a place in the pop-culture canon by directing a series of blockbusters that often starred some of the country’s biggest comedians.

headline: Retailers Enliven Catalog Offerings Through Apps
text: Many retailers, as varied as Saks Fifth Avenue and Wal-Mart, are putting out new iPad apps in time for the holiday season, reports Claire Cain Miller of The New York Times. She says these apps do away with scrolling through pages of items online and make shopping more entertaining. About 60 percent of tablet owners use them to shop and many, especially young people, say they prefer shopping on tablets to smartphones and even computers.

headline: The Shifting Balance Between Raising Taxes and Cutting Spending
text: The percentages from tax increases versus spending cuts in past deficit reduction deals

headline: A Gingrich Alternative to Social Security
text: Contending that Social Security provides “a dismal return” to retirees on a lifetime of “burdensome tax payments,” Newt Gingrich proposed giving younger workers the option of a private savings account.

headline: Videos Capture Violent Scenes in Egypt
text: Protesters clashed with police for a third straight day in the streets around Cairo’s Tahrir Square on Monday, as my colleagues David D. Kirkpatrick and Liam Stack report.

headline: How a Foul Worked in the Giants’ Favor
text: When is a penalty a good thing? The Giants found an odd way to make a foul work in their favor Sunday night against the Philadelphia Eagles.

headline: Patterns: Heart Study Suggests Place Matters
text: In the so-called stroke belt in the Southeast, cardiovascular disease rates are much higher than in the rest of the country. Scientists generally believe that is because people in the region have higher rates of such risk factors as smoking, obesity and diabetes.

headline: Many Layers of Meaning in Royal Trip to Ramallah
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — King Abdullah II of Jordan visited the West Bank for the first time in a decade on Monday and conferred with President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority as both men begin risky reconciliation efforts with the Islamists of Hamas.

headline: Egypt Clashes Enter Third Day
text: Egypt’s military leaders struggled to contain protests as demonstrators clashed with forces in Cairo.

headline: Happy Hour at the Thanksgiving Table
text: If you are among the skeptics who think vegan cooking is boring, maybe you’re just not adding enough alcohol.

headline: 25 Recordings Chosen for Grammy Hall of Fame
text: The National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences, which oversees the Grammy awards, is adding another 25 recordings to its Grammy Hall of Fame, which honors works at least 25 years old that “exhibit qualitative or historical significance.” The works to be inducted in 2012 are an unusually diverse lot, ranging from Cole Porter’s “Anything Goes,” a single from 1934, and the Rolling Stones’ “Exile on Main Street,” an album from 1972, to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr’s historic “I Have a Dream” speech, taken from a spoken-word album issued in 1963, and the influential “Anthology of American Folk Music,” from 1952.

headline: Update: Pumpkin Horror of Kane Street Worsens
text: The pumpkins of Kane Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, continue on their disgusting trek toward their certain demise. As reported by Corey Kilgannon of The Times, an array of 100 carved pumpkins created by Jane Greengold  of Cobble Hill will attempt to cling to their stations for several more weeks.

headline: Informer’s Role in Terror Case Is Said to Have Deterred F.B.I.
text: The suspect had little money to speak of, was unable to pay his cellphone bill and scrounged for money to buy the drill bits that court papers said he required to make his pipe bombs. Initially, he had trouble drilling the small holes that needed to be made in the metal tubes.

headline: Romney Blames Obama for the Collapsing Deficit Talks
text: 2:36 p.m. | Updated NASHUA, N.H. — Mitt Romney sought to blame President Obama for the collapsing talks on deficit reduction, intensifying criticism on Monday that he had been delivering over the weekend in New Hampshire.

headline: Daily Report: Google Keeps Pushing at Microsoft’s Windows
text: It has been more than 4 1/2 years since Google began its cloud computing challenge to Microsoft’s lucrative Office division, maker of Microsoft Word and PowerPoint. It has had some wins, reports Quentin Hardy in an article on Google Apps in Monday’s New York Times. But the question remains how much of a dent Google is making in Microsoft’s business.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 21
text: The day in sports worldwide, from college basketball in Hawaii to a soccer final in Indonesia, where two people died as a wave of fans entered the stadium.

headline: At Mercedes-Benz Stand, AMG Muscles In on the Spotlight
text: LOS ANGELES — There is plenty of eye candy at the Mercedes-Benz stand during the 2011 Los Angeles auto show, which opened to the public on Nov. 18. But the real treats are to be found mostly under various hoods.

headline: TimesCast | November 21, 2011
text: Violent clashes continue in Cairo and spread to other cities; Congressional leaders concede that a sweeping deficit agreement is near failure; and Khmer Rouge leaders go on trial.

headline: Breakfast Comrade to Write Memoir of Lucian Freud
text: The painter Lucian Freud, who died in July at the age of 88, spent many of his Saturday mornings with an intimate group of friends at Clarke’s restaurant in London, only steps from his home. Those Saturdays will be recalled in “Breakfast With Lucian,” a memoir by Geordie Greig, the editor of The London Evening Standard, his publisher said on Monday.

headline: Facebook Chat With Andrew Rosenthal
text: On Tuesday at 1 p.m. EST, I’m hosting an hour-long Facebook conversation about domestic politics and the presidential campaign. The chat will take place on the New York Times’s Facebook page: facebook.com/nytimes.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 66
text: The police chief at the University of California, Davis, and two police officers were placed on leave after pepper-spraying sitting protesters “like a gardener using pesticide,” as Gawker put it. [New York Times, Gawker]

headline: For a Bills Fan, All Hope Is Lost
text: Three weeks ago, my four-year-old son, Leo, wore a brand-new Bills hat his grandfather in Buffalo sent him to his Virginia preschool.  It was a gift purchased in celebration of the team’s glorious 5-2 start that had all of Western New York in the kind of delirious fog of Bills fever that hasn’t gripped the region since the glory days of the 1990s.

headline: Polls Highlight Risks to G.O.P. in Breakdown of Budget Talks
text: The likely failure of the special Congressional deficit committee to reach an agreement will come as no surprise to most Americans, with recent polls showing broad majorities lacking confidence in the committee’s ability to reach a deal.

headline: Disparities: In the E.R., the Elderly Get Less Pain Relief
text: Older people who go to an emergency room in pain are less likely to get medication for it than younger people with similar levels of distress, a new analysis has found.

headline: Court-Appointed Investigator Offers Scathing Report on Prosecution of Senator Stevens
text: WASHINGTON — A court-appointed investigator has found that the high-profile prosecution of the late Senator Ted Stevens was “permeated” by the prosecutors’ “serious, widespread and at times intentional” illegal concealment of evidence that would have helped Mr. Stevens defend himself at his 2008 trial, a federal judge disclosed on Monday.

headline: Prognosis: Stroke’s Risk Factors Warn of Mental Harm
text: The risk factors that predict stroke also predict mental impairment, a new study has found, even in people who have never had a stroke.

headline: Thought Of The Day
text: From David Rosenberg’s Breakfast with Dave (no link):

headline: ‘Cancer’ or ‘Weird Cells’: Which Sounds Deadlier?
text: My friend’s mother got terrifying news after she had a mammogram. She had Stage 0 breast cancer. Cancer. That dreadful word. Of course she had to have surgery to get it out of her breast, followed by hormonal therapy.

headline: Romney to Show First TV Ad of Campaign
text: Mitt Romney is set to show his first television ad of the presidential campaign on Tuesday in New Hampshire, spending $134,000 for spots scheduled to run until Sunday. The ads will attack President Obama over his economic leadership and begin on the day the president will visit the state to discuss his plans for turning around the economy.

headline: Occupy Ec10
text: I have nothing useful to say about the walkout on Greg Mankiw. Robin Wells does, however, have some judicious thoughts. And yes, that’s her speaking for herself.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Greenberg Sues U.S. Over A.I.G. Takeover
text: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, sued the United States Treasury and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York on Monday, contending that their takeover of the insurer in the fall of 2008 was improper and that the Fed breached its duty to A.I.G. shareholders when it unwound the company’s disastrous bets on mortgage securities.

headline: Ex-Saturn Plant to Reopen, And G.M. to Add 700 Jobs
text: DETROIT — General Motors on Monday said it planned to bring nearly 700 jobs back to its idled assembly plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., next year for work on any of the company’s cars whenever extra production is needed.

headline: 5 Reasons Selling Your Business Is Like Thanksgiving Dinner
text: I had a professor in graduate school who once compared the world of business to Thanksgiving dinner. His comment was directed at a room full of students who, at the time, were intent on climbing the corporate ladder. According to him, those of us who were willing to work hard and get advanced degrees would have the ability to leave the chaos and humiliation of “the little kids’ table” (supervisory and front line management positions) and graduate to sitting with the grown-ups (director level and above). And wasn’t that what we all aspired to?

headline: Festive Mood Accompanies Crosby’s Return to Penguins
text: PITTSBURGH — It’s a great day for hockey, as they say in this city, and Monday has been just that. Sidney Crosby will play tonight after a 320-day absence, forced by the most closely chronicled concussion in the sport.

headline: Which Sides Can Be Adapted for a Slow Cooker?
text: Q.

headline: The Get | Thakoon Boot
text: The printed shoe is all the rage right now. (If you can imagine, heel height is almost beside the point.) From Thakoon, this graphic paisley on a moto-cowboy boot is a clever extension of the designer’s fall collection, which was full of energetic prints that were inspired by royal courts and the Masai tribe’s colorful dress code; consider this the perfect take-away. And if the print is a little loud for you, it comes in deep navy velvet, too. We know, tough call.

headline: Jaguar Continues to Push Limits of Performance and Price
text: LOS ANGELES — In the hierarchy of luxury brands once owned by the Ford Motor Company, Jaguar operated under a glass ceiling.

headline: Verlander Named A.L. Most Valuable Player
text: Detroit pitcher Justin Verlander was named the American League most valuable player Monday, becoming the 10th pitcher to win the award and the first since 1992.

headline: Looking For Insight In All The Wrong Places
text: One ongoing source of puzzlement for me — something I’ve written about before — is the continuing popularity of inflationista/deficit hawk views among many investors, on and off Wall Street, despite the fact that this world view has been disastrously wrong again and again for the past few years.

headline: Trailer: North of South, West of East
text: A look at “North of South, West of East,” a new film by Meredith Danluck.

headline: President Obama Signs Veterans Tax Credit Bill
text: If anyone doubted that veterans remain potent political symbols, they need look no further than Congress’s ability to set aside partisan gridlock last week and overwhelmingly enact legislation providing tax credits to businesses that hire veterans. Flanked by veterans advocates, President Obama signed the bill into law this morning.

headline: Rihanna’s ‘Talk That Talk’ Synth-Perfect for an Earlier Time
text: Distinctionlessness has become something of a calling card and a weapon for Rihanna, the most consistent pop star of the last five years. Last month she became the fastest solo artist in history to have had 20 Top 10 singles on the Billboard Hot 100, slower only than the Beatles. And she has pumped out these hits with little regard for style or mood — breezy dance tracks rub up against poignant, gothically ruptured rock-soul ballads. Her voice is, for the most part, certifiably blank, which is to say it belongs everywhere.

headline: Juilliard and Signature Theater Team Up for New Program for Drama Students
text: Beginning next fall the Juilliard School and the Signature Theater company will collaborate on a new program for Juilliard’s drama students, to be based at the new rehearsal and performance space being built for Signature on West 42nd Street. The partnership coincides with the creation of a new master’s degree in theater that Juilliard will offer as of next year and is meant to give drama students there a transition to a working actor’s career through readings and workshops in a professional setting.

headline: In Body’s Shield Against Cancer, a Culprit in Aging May Lurk
text: Until recently, few people gave much thought to senescent cells. They are cells that linger in the body even after they have lost the ability to divide.

headline: Kicking Cans, Budget Woes and Other Risks Down the Road
text: 11:26 p.m. | Updated below |The failure of Congress to take meaningful steps on debt and taxes, yet again, is reminiscent of society’s treatment of other looming risks.

headline: Giving Shad a 30-Year Chance
text: State and federal wildlife officials have a rare opportunity to stem the decline of American shad on the Susquehanna River, a Chesapeake Bay tributary crucial to annual spawning runs.

headline: Jay Bernstein
text: The philosopher Jay Bernstein on the social subject and dependency.

headline: Ferrer Surprises Murray
text: No. 5 seed David Ferrer provided the first real surprise of the 2011 ATP World Tour Finals, dismissing third-seeded native son Andy Murray 6-4, 7-5 and throwing what had looked like a straightforward round-robin group into considerable upheaval.

headline: An Interview With J.M. Bernstein
text: This video is part of a weekly series of interviews with contemporary thinkers and philosophers on questions that matter.

headline: A Struggle for Financing After a Promising Discovery
text: The discovery that aging can be delayed in mice is just the kind of experiment one might suppose would be supported by the National Institutes of Health, the government agency that spends $30 billion a year on financing biomedical research.

headline: Panel Fails to Reach Deal on Plan for Deficit Reduction
text: WASHINGTON — Leaders of the Congressional committee charged with finding at least $1.2 trillion in deficit reductions conceded on Monday that panel members had failed, setting up what is likely to be a yearlong political fight over the automatic cuts to a broad range of military and domestic programs that would go into effect starting in 2013 as a result of their inability to reach a deal.

headline: How Do VapoRub Ads Spell Relief? ‘D-A-D’
text: After finding success with a campaign that declared, “Thank you, Mom,” a leading marketer is turning its attention to Dad.

headline: Foreclosure Firm Steven J. Baum to Close Down
text: A law firm that had become a lightning rod in the controversy over mortgage-foreclosure practices has shut down, costing 89 employees their jobs.

headline: Stringer Tries to Give Transportation Projects a Push
text: Scott M. Stringer has seen the future, and it is creaky, over budget, and behind schedule.

headline: Turmoil in Egypt
text: No one knows what the revolution in the Arab world’s largest and once most important country will bring — a state dominated by Islamists, perhaps, or a country mired in misery, disappointment or simmering unrest.

headline: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company in South Bend
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year legacy tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the 20th in a series of graphite drawings that Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from South Bend, Ind.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Allen & Gerritsen, Watertown, Mass., hired three employees for new posts. They are Andrew Mastrangelo, director for corporate communications; Marcy Rose, quality assurance manager; and Elizabeth Sklar, emerging technology and digital strategist.

headline: How to Attack Your Opponent for Things He Didn’t Do
text: As a journalist who’s covered American politics for the last 24 years, and who covered the Soviet Union as a foreign correspondent before that, I’ve learned to appreciate the dark art of political propaganda.

headline: Student Crossword | Giving
text: Play our crossword (PDF) to learn more about giving to others, through philanthropy and service. You can find the answers here.

headline: What Can I Make With Leftover Turkey Besides Sandwiches?
text: Q.

headline: The Long Haul
text: Between sitting all day, eating fast food and sleeping poorly, truckers have major challenges when it comes to staying healthy. Here, five truckers speak about what they are doing to try to drop few pounds and get fit.

headline: A Rare Isotope Helps Track an Ancient Water Source
text: The Nubian Aquifer, the font of fabled oases in Egypt and Libya, stretches languidly across 770,000 square miles of northern Africa, a pointillist collection of underground pools of water migrating, ever so slowly, through rock and sand toward the Mediterranean Sea.

headline: A Hard Turn: Better Health on the Highway
text: After driving hundreds of miles, the last thing Roy Williams, a truck driver from Denton, Tex., wanted to do was exercise. After a day trapped in the cab, stopping only to gorge on greasy fare at truck stops, who could think of working out?

headline: True Romance
text: She was a designer learning the ropes at Levi’s and Ralph Lauren. He was a photographer and drummer playing the Brooklyn music scene. They met after a concert, fell in love and started making clothes. Les Aperizes is Laurence Nguyen and Brian Tamborello’s debut spring collection. And like their story, the couple’s style is wildly romantic: preciously made petal-collar silk dresses, blouses detailed with hand-embroidered French knots and fluidly tailored trousers (all priced between $240 and $1,350). “Before ever sketching, we like to talk about a woman as if we’re writing a character and imagine what she wears throughout different times in her life,” says Nguyen, who sees herself as the line’s dreamer and Tamborello as its down-to-earth craftsman. Regarding the latter, the cut is slouchy sexy and thoughtfully undone. Tamborello says: “We ask ourselves, ‘Can we picture our clothes on every character? Will they age beautifully with her?’ ” Stores like Barneys New York and Ikram in Chicago sure think so.

headline: TimesCast | Violence in Egypt Continues
text: Violent clashes continue for a third day in Tahrir Square, as protesters demand the ouster of the military government.

headline: TimesCast | Khmer Rouge Trial Begins
text: Three former leaders of the Khmer Rouge face charges related to the deaths of 1.7 million Cambodians.

headline: Hugh Grant Testifies at Phone-Hacking Inquiry
text: 5:18 p.m. | Updated The actor Hugh Grant on Monday testified before a commission investigating the practices of British newspapers, giving extensive details about how a variety of tabloids had managed to insinuate themselves into his life.

headline: Finding a Better Name for Certain Cancers
text: Not all cancers are created equal. Some low-grade prostate cancers, for instance, may never spread. Even some early-stage breast cancers may never turn deadly. Now some experts believe it’s time to rethink what we call cancer. As Gina Kolata writes in this week’s Science Times:

headline: With iPad Boost, Apple Set to Become Top PC Vendor
text: Is the iPad a PC?

headline: Stopping Unwanted Catalogs
text: The holidays are coming, and right on cue, my mailbox is filling up with catalogs. I like getting some of them because it’s fun to browse for gift ideas. (Hmm. I’d spring for the $35 golden Hufflepuff Cup for my Harry Potter-loving children, but the fine print in the catalog from the Noble Collection warns it “cannot be used as drink ware.”)

headline: Nearly 4,250 Apply to New Harvard Early Admission Program
text: Last week, The Choice published a chart with early admission application figures — most of them increases over last year — at 25 colleges. That chart has now grown to include nearly 40 schools.

headline: LinkedIn Falls After Lock-Up Period Ends
text: LinkedIn had a bonanza of an initial public offering in May, when its stock price doubled and many of its employees became paper millionaires.

headline: Shareholders Whack Gilead and Alleghany for Expensive Deals
text: The phrase buyer beware appears to apply to the latest edition of Merger Monday.

headline: Football Players Clobber Pop Stars
text: Not even the combined musical might of Justin Bieber, Katy Perry, Taylor Swift and others was enough to knock NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” from its usual perch as the highest-rated program of the night.

headline: For Some, Psychiatric Trouble May Start in Thyroid
text: In patients with depression, anxiety and other psychiatric problems, doctors often find abnormal blood levels of thyroid hormone. Treating the problem, they have found, can lead to improvements in mood, memory and cognition.

headline: First Play by Nathan Englander Postponed From Public Theater Season
text: The opening of “The Twenty-Seventh Man,” the first play by the novelist Nathan Englander, originally scheduled to run at the Public Theater next spring, has been pushed back until November 2012, the theater announced Monday. In its place, the Public will be reviving “Gatz,” the popular Elevator Repair Service theatrical adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s “The Great Gatsby,” for seven weeks between March and May.

headline: LuPone and Patinkin on Broadway
text: Patti LuPone and Mandy Patinkin sing “In Buddy’s Eyes,” from the musical “Follies,” in their new Broadway show at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Laurie Abraham on Sex Education
text: Laurie Abraham is a senior editor at Elle and the author of “The Husbands and Wives Club: A Year in the Life of a Marriage Therapy Group,” which came out of her last cover article for the magazine, and “Mama Might Be Better Off Dead: The Failure of Health Care in Urban America.” She wrote yesterday’s cover story about Al Vernacchio’s sex-positive sex education class.

headline: From Cairo to California, Controlling Crowds With Chemicals
text: The wave of protests around the world this fall — from Cairo to the University of California — has drawn increased attention to the tools employed by police forces trying to subdue crowds, and in particular to those based on the use of painful chemicals.

headline: No Sag Yet for Planking
text: PLANKING has become the annoying trend that just won’t go away.

headline: For Art Lovers, Volumes Meant to Awe and Inspire
text: Who knows if the wave of holiday art books that has descended this year is bigger or better than before? You can’t really see the edges anymore. You just have to wade in and try to grab the good stuff as it rushes past.

headline: Deficit Deals Weren’t Always So Antitax
text: I had an article over the weekend about how previous deficit-reduction deals were much more tax-heavy than anything on the table today — until, that is, 1997. Here’s a breakdown of the deficit reductions that came from higher tax revenue versus spending cuts in the deals passed in the last 30 years:

headline: Debt Crisis Lurches Toward Heart of Euro Zone as Rifts Grow
text: BRUSSELS — Sharply divided European leaders faced mounting signs on Monday that the debt crisis was striking at the heart of the euro zone.

headline: Parent Complains of Bias in Sixth-Grade Lesson
text: Sixth graders in New York City regularly study the Middle East, but it is up to individual schools to craft the lessons. At Public School 101 School in the Gardens in Queens, a parent has filed a complaint about a lesson, written by a teacher, that told sixth graders the countries surrounding Israel “seek to destroy Israel and the Jewish people. They do not want peace.”

headline: Streep and Coen Discuss Foreign Film in China

Then there are the tight limits on the importing and screening of foreign movies, which cast a shadow on attempts to bring new film experiences to China.

headline: Shedding New Light on Retro Sunglass Frames

Three retro Warby Parker shapes — wayfarers, oversize aviators and Lennon-round frames — were custom-made with three Suno-designed prints: a pixelated geometric design, roses on a grungy brown background and an abstract stained-glass print.

headline: Suspect Held in White House Shooting Appears in Court
text: WASHINGTON — An Idaho man accused of firing a semiautomatic rifle at the White House in what prosecutors say was an attempt to assassinate President Obama appeared Monday in federal court, where his lawyer asked that the charges against the man, Oscar Ramiro Ortega-Hernandez, be dismissed.

headline: 4 in Brooklyn Charged With Sex Trafficking
text: One pair of defendants, prosecutors say, forced a 12-year-old Brooklyn girl to perform sex for money for nearly a year. Another pair, they say, kidnapped a 13-year-old who had run away from a group home, beat her and forced her into prostitution.

headline: On Our Radar: Made With the Wind
text: Companies including Motorola Mobility, Lego, Deutsche Bank and Bloomberg L.P. signed up to use a new trademark, WindMade , to show that at least 25 percent of their electricity was generated by wind power. The brand is sponsored by Vestas, a wind turbine manufacturer. The company hopes to develop a widely recognized industry trademark akin to the Fair Trade and Organic labels.

headline: Conquering Your Clutter

headline: Dwight Garner’s Picks for 2011
text: ALFRED KAZIN’S JOURNALS by Alfred Kazin. The great American literary critic Alfred Kazin’s passions — for sex, for novels, for ideas, for talk, for city life — spill from these journals, edited by his biographer, Richard M. Cook. This is one of the great diaries and moral documents of the past American century. What it lacks in cohesiveness it makes up in its frankness, its quick-pivoting angularities. Kazin dismisses his journals at one point as a “disorderly pile of shavings.” That disorder only adds to their amplitude. (Yale University Press, $45)

headline: Michiko Kakutani’s Picks for 2011
text: MOONWALKING WITH EINSTEIN: THE ART AND SCIENCE OF REMEMBERING EVERYTHING by Joshua Foer. A smart, funny meditation on the mysteries of memory featuring the author, in a Plimpton-esque turn, undergoing a year of memory training and competing against the country’s best mental athletes in the U.S.A. Memory Championships. (The Penguin Press, $26.95)

headline: Arrest of a Top Adviser to Iran’s President Is Reported
text: A simmering rivalry between Iran’s president and powerful adversaries within the conservative hierarchy spilled into the open on Monday when security forces briefly arrested his top media adviser, who also runs the official news agency and a leading newspaper, witnesses and Iranian news accounts said.

headline: A Symphony of Floorboards, Pipes and Stairs

It was a bizarre instrument, one he had never seen before in his years as a hip-hop producer, but he was going to play it that night in concert.

headline: Perry Signs an Evangelical Pledge
text: In an effort to woo evangelical voters in Iowa, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has become the third Republican presidential candidate to sign a pledge to oppose gay marriage, to appoint only “faithful Constitutionalists” as judges, to stay loyal to his spouse, to shrink the size of the federal government, and to oppose Islamic law, among other things.

headline: Solitary Refinement
text: On Nov. 13, the celebrated Modernist designer Eva Zeisel turned 105. As if this weren’t impressive enough, Zeisel marked the occasion by publishing a memoir about the 16 months she spent in a Soviet prison in the 1930s, during which time she tried to commit suicide by cutting her wrists with a copper wire pulled from a toilet. “For many years Eva did not want to make her prison experiences public, in part because she was afraid that the K.G.B. would come after her in the U.S.,” said her daughter, Jean Richards.

Included in the company’s recent acquisitions are RedLaser, a bar-code scanning application; Milo, a price comparison tool; and GSI Commerce, a provider of online services that will help the company work with larger retailers.

headline: Microscopes and Math Reveal a Moth’s True Hue
text: The brilliant hues of moths and butterflies are not from pigmentation, like the colors of our skin or eyes. Rather, they come from tiny structures in the scales that scatter light to produce colors.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Hannah and Her Sisters’
text: This week, A. O. Scott gives thanks to Woody Allen for his film about family and renewal, “Hannah and Her Sisters.” Mr. Scott is not certain whether this is Mr. Allen’s greatest film, but he says “it’s the film that offers the clearest and most coherent expression of his view of the world.”

headline: Violins Take Center Stage in a Repertory Reincarnated
text: According to the Bach-Werke-Verzeichnis (Bach Works Catalog, commonly abbreviated as BWV), Johann Sebastian Bach composed more than 1,100 works. For some performers that prodigious output isn’t enough. Fresh arrangements of Bach’s music have been a booming industry for ages, especially among musicians whose instruments or ensembles Bach did not use. And Bach was himself an inveterate tinkerer, with both his own pieces and those of other composers.

headline: Wresting Bach’s Music From Its Western Moorings
text: Lincoln Center has been exploring the idea of transcendence in its White Light Festival this year by way of early and modern works from the classical music canon, as well as several theatrical offerings in which music was a central component. Whether each performance proved a portal to transcendence is a matter for individual listeners to decide; the ones I heard succeeded more often than not. And you could hardly have hoped for a finale better suited to the theme than “Passio-Compassio,” the Ensemble Sarband concert that closed the festival on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

headline: A Sextet From Mendelssohn, Made for Showing Off
text: Mendelssohn was one of the most precociously talented musicians in history, and his cultured, affluent parents knew it. Twice a month their Berlin home became the site of elaborate Sunday musicales featuring members of the family and musicians brought in for the occasion. Like any attention-grabbing teenager, Felix enjoyed showing off.

headline: A Big Bolshoi Opening From a Cinema Seat
text: Excitement was high in the sold-out BIG cinema on East 59th Street in Manhattan on Sunday morning when Ballet in Cinema screened a live HD transmission of the Bolshoi’s production of “The Sleeping Beauty,” starring David Hallberg. Mr. Hallberg is making ballet history by becoming the first American to join this Moscow company permanently. The first glimpse of him in a pre-performance warm-up prompted some members of the cinema audience to applaud.

headline: The White Party
text: In the wake of the 2008 election, conservative Republican strategists like Karl Rove, Grover Norquist and William Kristol warned that their party faced even worse defeats if it continued in its anti-immigrant posturing.

headline: Getting a Handle on Why 4 Equals Green
text: Grapheme-color synesthesia is a peculiar neurological condition in which people involuntarily experience colors when thinking about letters, numbers or words.

headline: An Idea as Much as a City
text: In “The Aeneid,” his classic epic about the founding of Rome, Virgil wrote of that city’s destiny — of its leader young Romulus building “walls of Mars” and of its people, the Romans, for whom there would be “no limits, world or time,” only “the gift of empire without end.”

headline: After Rhino Horn Seizure, Conservationists Seek Enforcement
text: Authorities at the Hong Kong International Airport made a record seizure of illegal rhino horns last week, estimated to be worth about $2.2 million, officials said.

headline: Timely | Alex and Victor Carril: Paris Match
text: Over the 26 years they’ve spent growing up in the Marais, the identical twins Alex and Victor Carril have earned a reputation for street brawling — with each other — in their picturesque Paris neighborhood. When the director Pascal-Alex Vincent caught wind (as all locals eventually do) of these “hot twins who fight,” he cast them in his short film “Bébé Requin,” which competed at Cannes in 2005, and later as the leads in “Donne-Moi la Main,” a movie inspired by their bellicose proclivities. As villains in this month’s “Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows,” the twins will undoubtedly earn even wider recognition. But until then they keep busy making hip-hop music videos and working on their fashion line, Is Not Dead. And they both hold court nightly in the cafes near their family home on the Place du Marché Sainte-Catherine.

headline: A Quiet Push to Grow Crops Under Cover of Trees
text: HELENA, Mont. — On a forested hill in the mountains north of Montana’s capital, beneath a canopy of pine and spruce, Marc and Gloria Flora have planted more than 300 smaller trees, from apple and pear to black walnut and chestnut.

headline: Joan of Arc Tells Her Story, and a Choral Force Replies
text: Joan of Arc, the national heroine of France, has inspired innumerable literary and musical works, including an oratorio in 1935 by the Swiss composer Arthur Honegger. The 600th anniversary of her birth, though a matter of some dispute, will be celebrated next year, and the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, choosing not to wait, presented Honegger’s infrequently performed “Jeanne d’Arc au Bûcher” (“Joan of Arc at the Stake”) on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Crosby Returns to Form, and the N.H.L. Exhales
text: PITTSBURGH — Sidney Crosby spent 320 days recovering from the most closely chronicled concussion in hockey history. When he finally returned to the ice Monday night after missing 61 games, it took him 5 minutes 24 seconds to do what he does best.

headline: Breaking New Ground
text: Nevin Cohen teaches sustainable food systems, environmental policy and urban planning at the New School, and focuses on the evolution of municipal food policy. Kubi Ackerman is a research coordinator at the Urban Design Lab at the Earth Institute at Columbia University; he focuses on food systems and urbanization projects. I’m an admirer of the work both of them do and invited them to write about the New York City Department of Environmental Protection’s important proposals for environmental infrastructure initiatives.

headline: A Millepied Work
text: Benjamin Millepied, the recently retired principal dancer of New York City Ballet, is forming a collaborative performing arts company and has been commissioned to create a full-length work to be performed in September at the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles, the group’s producer, Charles Fabius, said on Monday. The group will be called L.A. Dance Project and involve filmmakers and visual artists, Mr. Fabius said, as well as the composer Nico Muhly, who will write the score for the work, which was commissioned by Glorya Kaufman Presents Dance at the Music Center. Mr. Fabius described L.A. Dance Project as a “curatorial arts collective” that would perform and recreate collaborative dance works. Mr. Millepied, 34, who spent 16 years at City Ballet, created the steps for the movie “Black Swan.”

headline: Dispute Over Money Delays 9/11 Museum
text: The scheduled opening next year of the National September 11 Memorial Museum has been delayed because of a $156 million dispute between the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the foundation responsible for running the museum, according to people familiar with the discussions. The Port Authority, which is responsible for the construction, has stopped approving new contracts, slowing work on the underground museum, which was to open on Sept. 11. The organizations have been arguing over the money for nearly 18 months, and tensions rose recently as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has sought to exert more control over construction projects in the city. Last month Mr. Cuomo nominated one of his deputies, Patrick Foye, to run the Port Authority and asked the agency to take over the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, a joint city and state enterprise that has been working on the redevelopment of the World Trade Center site. The National September 11 Memorial and Museum at the World Trade Center Foundation, whose chairman is Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has maintained that poor management and delays by the Port Authority between 2006 and 2008 cost it more than $100 million. The delay in approving construction contracts was reported by The Wall Street Journal on Monday. Michael Frazier, the foundation’s communications director, said Monday, “We are working with the leadership of the Port Authority to come to an immediate resolution that allows this historic project to move forward.” Steve Coleman, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said, “We’re working cooperatively with New York City and the memorial foundation” and that “work is continuing.”

text: AS I’ve been saying for some time, the golden age of air travel wasn’t back in those Pan Am glory days celebrated on television. Actually, the golden age is now — but only if you’re traveling in the front of the plane on an international flight.

headline: Vatican: Cardinal Who Resigned Amid Scandal Retires
text: Cardinal Bernard Law, who resigned as archbishop of Boston in 2002 amid a sex abuse scandal in the Roman Catholic Church, has retired from his post at the St. Mary Major Basilica in Rome, the Vatican said Monday. The Vatican said that the pope had accepted Cardinal Law’s resignation upon his turning 80, and had replaced him with Monsignor Santos Abril y Castello of Spain. Cardinal Law, the first United States bishop to step down in the scandal, that began in Boston and spread nationwide. He was accused in hundreds of lawsuits of moving around priests known to have abused children and not reporting the abuse to the police. Victims had criticized the Vatican for having given Cardinal Law the post at St. Mary Major and for allowing him to serve on a Vatican committee that appoints bishops. Cardinal Law will remain a cardinal but being over 80 cannot vote in a conclave.

headline: Rupert Murdoch Sells Nearly All His Nonvoting News Corp. Shares
text: Rupert Murdoch has sold almost all of his nonvoting shares in News Corporation, but because of the company’s dual-class voting shares he still controls the company.

headline: Pepper-Spray Incident Spawns Remixes
text: Not long after a video of police officers dousing seated Occupy Wall Street protesters in the face with pepper spray surfaced online, it incited anger and disbelief.

headline: India: Court Orders Murder Charges Against Police
text: A state high court ordered Monday that murder charges be filed against police officers who killed four people, including a 19-year-old college student, claiming they were terrorists gunned down in a shootout in 2004. An investigation later found that the victims had been shot at point blank range. The Gujarat state high court agreed with the investigation’s findings and ruled that the police officers should face charges. Advocates for the victims, who included a 19-year-old college student, said the killings were part of a pattern of so-called encounter killings, in which Gujarat police officers killed people, usually Muslims, and later claimed they were terrorists.

headline: Parking on the Holidays: A New York Story
text: To the Editor:

headline: American Music Awards Red Carpet Highlights
text: The red carpet at music awards shows isn’t as stuffy as the ones at other awards shows, like the Oscars or the Golden Globes. Musical artists seem to feel more comfortable experimenting with their looks. That said, there were some hits, misses and surprises on the red carpet at the 39th annual American Music Awards in Los Angeles on Sunday night. The highs and lows were as diverse as the looks themselves.

headline: How to Cook Butternut Squash for a Crowd
text: Melissa Clark roasts butternut squash, a simple, delicious Thanksgiving side dish.

headline: News Organizations Complain About Treatment During Protests
text: A cross-section of 13 news organizations in New York City lodged complaints on Monday about the New York Police Department’s treatment of journalists covering the Occupy Wall Street movement. Separately, 10 press clubs, unions and other groups that represent journalists called for an investigation and said they had formed a coalition to monitor police behavior going forward.

headline: What Is the Best Way to Cook Butternut Squash?
text: Q.

headline: Pakistan: 15 Soldiers Killed in Baluch Ambush
text: An army major and 14 paramilitary soldiers were killed Monday when they were ambushed by Baluch nationalist militants in Baluchistan Province, a military spokesman said. The attack, the worst suffered by the Pakistani military in the province in several years, occurred in Kohlu district, a stronghold of the Marri tribe, which has been at the forefront of the Baluch armed resistance movement.

headline: Russia: Missiles May Be Deployed if U.S. Talks Fail
text: A Russian official said Monday that if talks with the United States on missile defense broke down, Russia was prepared to deploy tactical missiles to Belarus, the southern region of Krasnodar and the western enclave of Kaliningrad. The deployment would ensure that American interceptor missiles could not neutralize Russia’s nuclear capability, a military official told Interfax, speaking on the condition of anonymity. President Dmitri A. Medvedev said Monday that Russia’s response to the American missile shield “should not close the door to negotiation.”

headline: At PWC, They Now Have Names
text: The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board today released its annual inspection reports on two of the Big Four: KPMG and PricewaterhouseCoopers. They are the first to come out this year. The reports on Ernst & Young and Deloitte & Touche will presumably follow.

headline: Brazil: Chevron Faces Fines of $83 Million in Oil Spill
text: Chevron faces fines of as much as $83 million for an  oil spill this month off the coast of Rio de Janeiro, the authorities said Monday. The fines reflect the government’s anger over Chevron’s handling of the spill. Chevron may also face additional fines and legal penalties, officials said. Haroldo Lima, head of the National Petroleum Agency, said the spill could complicate Chevron’s hopes of gaining access to new offshore exploration areas. Federal investigators said Chevron employees might also face prison terms. Chevron said in a statement that it had not yet received official notice of any fines and would respond if it did.

headline: Tax Write-Off Now, Charity Later
text: Newton, Mass.

headline: Djokovic Ends Series of Struggles With Three-Set Win
text: Most books written about a given tennis season start with the Australian tournaments in January and end with the United States Open in September. The remaining months at the end of the campaign are usually relegated to an epilogue, if included at all.

headline: Early Applications Flood Harvard
text: Harvard said on Monday that 4,245 students filed single-choice early action applications by its Nov. 1 deadline. That number is more than double the size of Harvard’s anticipated incoming freshman class for 2012, and a 5.9 percent increase from 2007, when early admission was last in effect at Harvard. Under the program, students are prohibited from filing early applications with other private colleges in the United States. Yale University has reported that it received 4,310 early applications for admission, an 18 percent decrease from last year, perhaps influenced by the reinstatement of early admissions at Harvard and Princeton. Application figures at 40 schools are available on The Choice blog, nytimes.com/thechoice.

headline: N.B.A. Players Merge Lawsuits; No Hearing Date Set
text: Two antitrust lawsuits filed by players against the N.B.A. were merged on Monday in the hope of bringing a swifter judgment against the league, and a swifter end to the lockout.

headline: Republicans Are Endangering National Security
text: Washington

headline: Hearing Set in Leak Case
text: Pfc. Bradley Manning, accused of providing thousands of secret documents to the antisecrecy organization WikiLeaks, will face an evidentiary hearing beginning Dec. 16, Army officials said Monday. The public hearing at Fort Meade, Md., is the military’s equivalent of a grand jury and is called an Article 32 hearing. Private Manning, 23, was arrested in Kuwait. He faces a possible life sentence if convicted of three dozen charges, including “aiding the enemy,” for passing secret military reports and diplomatic cables to WikiLeaks.

headline: Arizona’s Coach to Be Rodriguez
text: Rich Rodriguez, fired last winter after a miserable 15-22 record with Michigan, will become the new Arizona coach, according to a person briefed on the decision.

headline: Does the U.S. Need Troops in Australia?
text: Obama says the move will shore up alliances in Asia. China sees darker motives.

text: Last week’s App Smart column featured cooking and shopping apps for Thanksgiving and Black Friday. The shopping apps mentioned, however, failed to include a brand new one that deserves consideration.

headline: A Vroom of One’s Own
text: Why bother with die-cast cars that you have to push with your fingers, adding your own sound effects? Mattel has created a lifelike Lightning McQueen, the star of the Disney Pixar “Cars” movies, that does it all for you.

headline: Inspired by High Line, Park Is Envisioned With Sights Set Low
text: Ever since it opened in 2009, the High Line has drawn out-of-town visitors who hope to replicate its success. Observers of the elevated park on the West Side of Manhattan have come from nearby municipalities like Jersey City and Philadelphia and places as far away as Hong Kong.

headline: Q&A: Finding New Finance Software
text: Q.

headline: As Layoffs Rise, Stock Buybacks Consume Cash
text: When Pfizer cut its research budget this year and laid off 1,100 employees, it was not because the company needed to save money.

headline: Euro Blind
text: The past days, weeks and months have seen countless descriptions in the news media of the crisis in the euro zone and Greece’s role as its leading actor as a tragedy. But is it? Well, yes, but not in the sense in which it is usually discussed, and the difference is important and revealing.

headline: Share Buybacks by Companies Are Rising
text: Companies are buying back more of their shares

headline: Doctor Is Accused of Selling Prescriptions
text: A doctor suspected of prescribing thousands of painkillers to a man who murdered four people in a Long Island pharmacy pleaded not guilty on Monday in the sale of prescriptions to a Queens man who died of an overdose.

headline: The Supercommittee Collapses
text: The smoke from the smoldering failure known as the deficit “supercommittee” spread heavily across Capitol Hill on Monday, allowing Republicans to obscure the simple truth about the failure to reach an agreement. The only reason the committee failed was because Republicans refused to raise taxes on the rich, and, in fact, wanted to cut them even below their current bargain-basement level.

headline: Screening Still a Pain at Airports, Fliers Say
text: The lines will still be long and the screening still invasive at airport checkpoints this Thanksgiving.

headline: A Reasonable Decision on Avastin
text: The Food and Drug Administration’s withdrawal of its approval for Avastin to treat advanced breast cancer is causing understandable anguish and anger among women who believe the drug has saved or prolonged their lives. But the agency followed the scientific evidence, which showed the drug was not as effective as it first seemed, and that its severe side effects outweighed its benefits for a vast majority of patients.

headline: Postal Chief Seeks Ability to Cut Costs to Stem Loss
text: WASHINGTON — Unless Congress passes far-reaching legislation soon to give the Postal Service the flexibility it needs to cut costs, the agency will suffer disastrous losses that could jeopardize its long-term future, Patrick R. Donahoe, the postmaster general, warned on Monday.

headline: Alabama’s Shame (Cont.)
text: The self-inflicted wounds from Alabama’s most-abusive-in-the-nation immigration law just keep on coming. Last week, a manager for Mercedes-Benz, visiting from Germany, was pulled over in his rental car by a police officer in Tuscaloosa near where a Mercedes plant builds sport-utility vehicles. The manager didn’t have his driver’s license with him, and only a few months ago he just would have been given a ticket. But Alabama’s new law, now in effect, demands tougher action against suspected illegal immigrants. The manager was arrested and taken to police headquarters.

headline: A Community With Money? Of Course Marketers Want In on That
text: PROFESSIONALS of all stripes have no end of networking possibilities, with social networks like LinkedIn and Facebook. Now one particular segment, the gay professional, has a new networking venue — and advertisers are taking note.

headline: The Two Moons
text: In 1951, Samuel Lubell invented the concept of the political solar system. At any moment, he wrote, there is a Sun Party (the majority party, which drives the agenda) and a Moon Party (the minority party, which shines by reflecting the solar rays).

headline: Expansion Draft Best XI
text: Major League Soccer released the protected and unprotected players from each team in advance of Wednesday’s expansion draft, when the Montreal Impact will select 10 players. The complete list is here. Teams can only lose one player. Most designated players are not exposed to the draft; players classified as Generation Adidas and Homegrown are protected automatically.

headline: Jury in Trial of a Newark Lawyer Says It Is Split
text: NEWARK — Jurors in the case of a Newark defense lawyer charged with taking part in the murder of a witness in a drug case said Monday that they were divided.

headline: Granny Loves Gingrich
text: Young Republicans have a message for their party’s newest rising star, Newt Gingrich: they’re just not that into him.

headline: Romney Heats Up Campaign in New Hampshire With an Ad Attacking Obama
text: NASHUA, N.H. — Moving the campaign into a more combative phase, Mitt Romney is set to show his first television commercial of the campaign on Tuesday in New Hampshire, attacking President Obama over his economic leadership on the same day the president will visit the state to discuss his plans for turning around the economy.

headline: Low-Tax Cigarettes, Made in Store, Draw City Lawsuit
text: Sometimes a cigar is just a cigar, as Freud supposedly said, but when is a cigarette a cigarette?

headline: Republican Debates Put Moderators in Hot Seat, Too
text: Weeks of work can go into preparing for political debates. There is anticipating possible questions, composing snappy rejoinders and reviewing hours of television footage.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Verlander Returns the M.V.P. to Pitchers
text: Early in the last decade, when he was still an unblemished legend, Roger Clemens invited me to Houston to interview him in the trophy room of his home. The centerpiece of the display was a stone wall with his Cy Young Awards encircling the most sacred and rarest prize for a pitcher: the most valuable player.

headline: A Way to Finance Europe’s Rescue
For Deficit Panel, Failure Cuts Two Ways
text: WASHINGTON — The latest Congressional failure to agree on a plan for balancing the government’s books could yield a surprising result: a sharp reduction in annual federal deficits, larger than anything contemplated by the special panel that reached its fruitless finale on Monday.

headline: Popular Talk Show on Bravo Will Expand to 5 Nights
text: The crowded world of late-night television will have a new and potentially imposing competitor in January when Bravo will turn its successful “Watch What Happens Live” show, hosted by Andy Cohen, into a five-night-a-week entry at 11 p.m.

headline: Trusting Transparency Will Work

headline: Libya Tries to Build Army That Can March Straight and Defang Militias
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The marching can hardly be called crisp as the new Libyan National Army takes form in daily drills at an abandoned air force base here.

headline: Artists at Home
text: Many of the original residents of Westbeth, which opened as subsidized housing for artists in 1970, still live there.

headline: Why Doesn’t No Mean No?
text: In 1998, The New York Times published a front-page article suggesting that two new drugs, angiostatin and endostatin, might finally win the war on cancer.

headline: The Umbrella Man
text: On the 48th anniversary of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, Errol Morris explores the story behind the one man seen standing under an open black umbrella at the site.

headline: A Transcendent, if Rare, American Outreach
text: BEIJING — It was the kind of moment that the organizers of the Asia Society’s cultural mission to China had been hoping for. As the Chinese-American cellist Yo-Yo Ma performed an eclectic, quirky concert showcasing American culture, one of China’s rising political stars gave her blessing, standing up to wave to the crowd between pieces.

headline: A Blow to Pinstripe Aspirations
text: Earlier this fall, Steve Ferdman celebrated getting a job offer from Credit Suisse in the usual Wall Street fashion. Over expensive oysters and dark rum cocktails at a trendy Manhattan restaurant with his parents, he toasted landing the full-time position after working six months as a consultant without benefits.

headline: The Way We Were
text: We live in a time of lead. Gone is the Golden Age. Today, things are bad. Tomorrow, they’ll be worse.

headline: France, and Sarkozy, Look Vulnerable as Euro Crisis Persists
text: PARIS — With the humiliating defeat on Sunday of the Socialists in Spain, the two-year euro crisis has already toppled eight governments, sending shivers of anxiety through the Élysée Palace and even the White House.

headline: Rich in Success, Rooted in Secrecy
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — One of the great paradoxes of the Penn State scandal is evident on the face of Graham B. Spanier, the university’s ousted president.

headline: Romney’s First Television Ad Attacks Obama on Economy
text: Mitt Romney previewed his first television ad — set to go on the air in New Hampshire on Tuesday, with a $134,000 buy behind it — to Sean Hannity of Fox News on Monday evening.

headline: ‘The Umbrella Man’
text: For years, I’ve wanted to make a movie about the John F. Kennedy assassination. Not because I thought I could prove that it was a conspiracy, or that I could prove it was a lone gunman, but because I believe that by looking at the assassination, we can learn a lot about the nature of investigation and evidence. Why, after 48 years, are people still quarreling and quibbling about this case? What is it about this case that has led not to a solution, but to the endless proliferation of possible solutions?

headline: Police Suspect Mother in 5-Year-Old’s Disappearance in Phoenix Suburb
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — The police here arrested the mother of a missing 5-year-old girl on a child abuse charge on Monday and said they believed she might have played a role in the disappearance of the girl, Jhessye Shockley, who they said was presumed dead.

headline: Tuesday: One Called “Hizzoner”
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Victor “No, Not the Film Director” Fleming is a busy man. In addition to his day job as a judge in a Little Rock, Ark., traffic court, he constructs puzzles for many different venues (more about that below), and is an official at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. Even so, he was kind enough to send some notes on the evolution of this interesting theme, which follow.

headline: Old Friends Reunited Once Again
text: A serious case of whiplash hovers as a distinct possibility throughout “An Evening With Patti LuPone and Mandy Patinkin,” a concert performance and mutual lovefest from these veteran musical theater stars that opened on Monday night at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

headline: Choosing Sides in Afghanistan: Spies Playing in the Great Game
text: The gifts referred to in the title of “Blood and Gifts,” a superb new play by J. T. Rogers about the long history behind the American involvement in Afghanistan, are on ominous view throughout the play. Big boxes are carried onstage and cracked open to reveal piles of artillery. Shiny new rifles are waved in the air like harmless toys. Suitcases full of dollars are handed over with a cool smile.

headline: John Neville, Shakespearean Actor and ‘Munchausen’ Star, Is Dead at 86
text: John Neville, who played Romeo to Claire Bloom’s Juliet, Hamlet to Judi Dench’s Ophelia and Othello to Richard Burton’s Iago (and vice versa), but who may be best known in the United States as the title character in the exuberantly loopy film “The Adventures of Baron Munchausen” and a recurring one in the television series “The X-Files,” died in Toronto on Saturday. He was 86.

headline: Republicans in Indiana to Seek Law Limiting Unions
text: Republican leaders in Indiana on Monday declared as their top legislative priority making Indiana a “right to work” state, setting the stage for a new battle over union rights that has already consumed many states.

headline: Corrections: November 22
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Mariners’ Dutch Outfielder Killed; Brother Is Suspect
text: Greg Halman retreated to Rotterdam whenever he could, looking for respite from the long grind of the baseball season. Halman, a promising outfielder for the Seattle Mariners, loved returning to the Netherlands, where he was born, as it allowed him to be closer to his family.

headline: Pull of Family Reshapes U.S.-Cuban Relations
text: MIAMI — For two consecutive years, Stephanie Várcia, 11, a sixth grader here, has done something that was unimaginable five years ago. She has spent four weeks in Havana, playing hide-and-seek with her cousins and going to the beach with her aunts and uncles. When summer vacation ended, her mother flew out to bring her back to Miami.

headline: Fresh Look for Author, and for Land He Lauded
text: PETRÓPOLIS, Brazil — When the Viennese-born writer Stefan Zweig moved in 1941 to this city of imperial palaces nestled in the mountains near Rio de Janeiro, he was one of world’s most translated authors, renowned for his taut novellas exploring passion, obsession and despair.

headline: Moogy Klingman, Songwriter and Original Member of Utopia, Dies at 61
text: If pop music, at its best, can be called a series of evanescent but magically eternal moments, Moogy Klingman lived the concept. He jammed with the likes of Jimi Hendrix, Chuck Berry and Bo Diddley, produced a rare album featuring Eric Clapton, Jeff Beck and other superstars, and helped write the song that Bette Midler made her theme, “Friends.”

headline: After Tropical Storm, Flooded Apartment Is Just One More Obstacle to Overcome
text: The day after Tropical Storm Irene hit New York, in August, Yugely Nuñez walked into her basement apartment in Brooklyn and stepped into a nightmare.

headline: Baseball Signs Off on an Owner’s Past
text: Sports leagues prefer to approve new team owners who are trouble-free and will be grateful supporters of their commissioners. Dull, quiet, extremely rich and publicly charitable are also prized qualities.

headline: Sharpton Calls Limbaugh’s Remarks About First Lady a ‘Distraction’
text: Just how racially heated will the 2012 presidential election get?

headline: CUNY Students Protesting Tuition Increase Clash With Police
text: A daylong rally by City University of New York students against a planned tuition increase turned turbulent Monday evening when marchers ignored police requests to clear the lobby of a building where the university’s trustees were meeting and 15 people were arrested.

headline: In Art Fraud Case, Defendant With a History Receives a Six-Year Sentence
text: In the small 19th-century painting, a young girl is seated in a straight-backed chair, looking forlorn, as if troubled by her role in the strange story of theft and deception that culminated in a Manhattan courtroom on Monday.

headline: A Failure Is Absorbed With Disgust and Fear, but Little Surprise
