headline: Romney’s Making the Right Play in Iowa
text: Jeff Zeleny’s weekend story about how Mitt Romney’s campaign will exert more rather than less effort in Iowa deserves your attention. It reflects what is perhaps the most important strategic decision that any Republican candidate will make this year.

headline: The Perfect Stocking Stuffer: A Chocolate Lady Gaga Shoe
text: Among the 220 Lady Gaga-themed holiday gifts that went on sale Monday night at Barneys New York was a shoe made of chocolate for $95.

headline: Obama Weighed Risks of Engagement, and Decided to Give Voters the Final Say
text: WASHINGTON — In remaining aloof from the special deficit committee in Congress even as it collapsed on Monday, President Obama showed his calculation more clearly than ever before: Republicans will never agree to raise taxes on the wealthy to balance any spending cuts, so let the voters decide.

headline: Youth Pleads Guilty to Killing Gay Classmate
text: LOS ANGELES — Brandon McInerney, the teenager accused of killing a gay eighth-grade classmate in 2008, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder, the Ventura County District Attorney’s Office announced Monday. He will spend 21 years in prison.

headline: Islanders’ Response to Late-Night Meeting? Another Blowout Loss
text: Disgusted with his team’s performance in a 6-0 home loss to the Bruins last Saturday, Islanders Coach Jack Capuano decided he was not going to wait until a scheduled practice Sunday to address his team. After the news media completed their interviews and the players were finished with their postgame workouts and medical treatments, Capuano conducted a lengthy team meeting in the Islanders’ locker room at Nassau Coliseum.

headline: Stimulus Measures Set to Expire at Year’s End Will Be Next Fiscal Battle
text: WASHINGTON — The likely failure of the bipartisan Congressional deficit committee has opened the door for a year-end showdown on expiring stimulus measures that are adding billions of dollars to workers’ pockets and, economists say, buoying the fragile recovery.

headline: Numberplay: Personality or Issues?
text: What’s the best way to elect the most appropriate candidate to public office – the one most likely to do a good job? How do we prevent trivialities from clouding the issues and allow a person’s true qualities to shine through? Is there any voting system that does this better than the others? This is the focus of a scenario submitted by a prolific Numberplay puzzle contributor, Ravi Kumar Meduri. Here is his make-believe voting simulation:

headline: After Getting Pushed Around, Giants Are Angry at Not Pushing Back
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Group therapy convened here Monday as the Giants players sat together — as they always do — to dissect the film of the game from the night before, then broke into their positional units — as they always do — for a more casual breakdown.

headline: Red Sox Put Valentine’s Strategy to Test
text: The Boston Red Sox have set up an extensive and rigorous interview process for their vacant managerial position involving pointed questions about in-game strategy, with video accompaniment and specific scenarios of almost every situation a manager might encounter in the course of a baseball season.

headline: Jets Project Confidence, but Victories Matter Most
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — After a weekend off, the Jets returned to practice feeling confident that they would win their next game. Not only that, they said, but they still believe in one another and, if they execute correctly and play mistake-free football, they can win two in a row and, eventually, even make the playoffs.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
text: The rupee closed at an all-time low of 52.15 to the dollar, as foreign investors fled riskier assets, the Business Standard reports.  The Bombay Stock Exchange’s Sensex index also fell 2.6 per cent.A special investigation team told the Gujarat High Court on Monday that Ishrat Jahan, a 19-year-old college student, was murdered along with two others by the Ahmedabad Crime Branch on June 15, 2004 (Hindustan Times) The investigation team, headed by officer Rajiv Rajan Verma, implicated more than 20 policemen, pointing to forensic, medical and material evidence which they claim shows the victims were shot before the “encounter date” of June 15, 2004. Gujarat police maintain that the three were Lashkar-e-Taiba members, aiming to kill Chief Minister Narendra Modi. The court may pass the case to a central investigation agency (Times of India).

headline: Tape Tops a Live Game
text: Overnight television ratings showed that Fox’s tape-delayed broadcast of the game between Chelsea and Liverpool on Sunday afternoon was almost twice the rating of the M.L.S. final that evening. The E.P.L. game drew a 1.5 rating, according to Nielsen, which translates to about 1.5 percent of viewers in 56 of the biggest markets in the United States. The M.L.S. final attracted a rating of 0.8.

headline: Ferrer Turns Back Murray
text: David Ferrer, the fifth seed, provided the first real surprise of the ATP World Tour Finals in London, defeating third-seeded Andy Murray, 6-4, 7-5. Murray appeared weary throughout the match. He made only 46 percent of his first serves, and hit more than twice as many unforced errors (44) as winners (21). In a later match, Novak Djokovic beat Tomas Berdych, 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (3).

headline: Wisconsin Men Win Title
text: Wisconsin won the N.C.A.A. men’s cross-country title in Terre Haute, Ind., finishing 42 points ahead of second-place Oklahoma State. The Arizona freshman Lawi Lalang was the individual winner. Sheila Reid of Villanova won her second straight women’s title, while Georgetown was the women’s team champion.

headline: Back on Big Stage, Crosby Dazzles
text: PITTSBURGH — After scoring two goals and two assists in his first game back from a 61-game absence with a concussion, Sidney Crosby was momentarily at a loss for words. “Just being back out there, I can’t really describe it,” he said.

headline: UConn Shows Resolve, if Not Star Power
text: HARTFORD — So this is what it is like for Connecticut women’s basketball when the second-ranked Huskies must climb a mountain instead of starting at the preseason summit.

headline: Rapid Redux Breaks Record
text: Rapid Redux won his 20th consecutive race, breaking Zenyatta and Peppers Pride’s modern record for consecutive wins, at Mountaineer Racetrack.

headline: Eunuchs Mourn After Deadly Blaze
text: Footwear, mangled plastic bottles and tattered fabric mixed with charred debris at the fire-ravaged site in the east Delhi neighborhood of Nand Nagri on Monday afternoon. This is all that was left at a community center compound where a makeshift tent – erected for a large congregation of eunuchs, or transgender people, from across India – went up in flames on Sunday evening.

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 22, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Champions League Tuesday Preview: Bayern Wants a Win, City Needs One
text: The Champions League returns on Tuesday with the first day of the penultimate round of the group stage. Manchester City is hoping to bring its English league form to the continent, Inter Milan is hoping to leave its league form at home, and Bayern Munich is hoping to leave everyone else behind and clinch a place in the next round. Here’s Tuesday’s schedule (all games start at 2:45 p.m. Eastern unless noted):

headline: Deal to Hasten Transition in Egypt Is Jeered at Protests
text: CAIRO — Egypt careened through another day of crisis with no end in sight as hundreds of thousands of people occupying Tahrir Square jeered at a deal struck on Tuesday by the Muslim Brotherhood and the military that would speed up the transition to civilian rule on a timetable favoring the Islamist movement.

headline: China Outlines Cuts in Carbon Emissions
text: BEIJING — With global climate talks set to begin next week, China on Tuesday issued the most comprehensive document yet on its plans and negotiating positions on emissions.

headline: Nov. 22, 1963 | President Kennedy Is Assassinated
text: On Nov. 22, 1963, President John F. Kennedy was fatally shot while riding in an open-top car through Dealey Plaza in Dallas. Two bullets struck the president, the first in his back and throat and the second in the back of his head. Gov. John Connally of Texas, another passenger, was also shot, though he survived. Jacqueline Kennedy and Nellie Connally, the men’s wives, were also in the car but were not injured.The New York Times reported on the assassination: “Mr. Kennedy apparently was hit by the first of what witnesses believed were three shots. He was driven at high speed to Dallas’s Parkland Hospital. There, in an emergency operating room, with only physicians and nurses in attendance, he died without regaining consciousness.”

headline: Pepper-Spraying of Students Puts University Campus in Spotlight
text: WHO was placed on administrative leave after students were pepper sprayed?

headline: In Indiana, a Hometown Soon to Change
text: Robb Hill  grew up among farms and forests several miles outside  Utica, Ind., a small town along the Ohio River. He helped neighbors bale hay and fished in a nearby creek almost every weekend, rain or shine. It wasn’t Tom Sawyer, but it was a good life.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 22, 2011
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “U.S. Troops to Leave Iraq by Year’s End, Obama Says.”

headline: Do Your Parents Support Your Learning?
text: According to a recent study, parental involvement is strongly associated with high performance on a standardized test that measures 15-year-olds’ reading comprehension as well as math and science problem-solving. Do your parents support your learning? Did they read to you when you were little? Do you think their level of involvement now has anything to do with your test scores and grades?

headline: An App to Help Win Black Friday
text: Black Friday, the busiest shopping day of the year, is just around the corner, but a free iPhone app called TapBuy can help you get a jump on the other holiday shoppers.

headline: At Madrid Show, Colorful Posters and Stark Photography
text: Though Juan Gatti’s many accomplishments in photography, fashion and graphic design have established him as an artist with a wide range, he is probably best known for designing influential posters for Pedro Almodóvar’s films. Starting with a poster for “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown” in 1988, Mr. Gatti has collaborated with the filmmaker many times, leaving his mark on the visual aesthetics of many of the director’s films. Indeed, posters for films including “Talk to Her,” “Broken Embraces” and this year’s “The Skin I Live In” line the walls of “Contraluz,” the first exhibition that traverses the length of Mr. Gatti’s career — although the actual focus of the show lies elsewhere.

headline: Analyzing ESPN’s Total Quarterback Rating
text: In August, ESPN announced a new way to measure quarterbacks: Total QBR. As you would expect, many writers weighed in with their thoughts. Few football fans have faith in the traditional passer rating system; even fewer understand how it works. That’s one of the reasons ESPN spent several years charting every N.F.L. play and seven months devising a system that would not only represent a step forward from the traditional passer rating but would also be easier for fans to understand.  Total QBR grades quarterbacks in some innovative ways:

headline: Economic Insecurity
text: With the Census Bureau fine-tuning its definition of poverty, a group of “near poor” has emerged — those who are not officially poor but are perilously close to it.

headline: The First Word on the London Riots
text: LONDON — Is anything in art more overrated than distance? Distance, we’re told, is what must come between a momentous event and any work of art created around that event, or else the art may be short on reflection and digestion. The long view, a step back, space to unknot our emotions — all are necessary for art. This point of view was thrown around with abandon on the 10th anniversary of 9/11: “too soon” was a phrase much overused to explain the absence still of any great art about that day. Yet if reflection and digestion have their place, there’s a problem with distance and it’s distance.

headline: South Korea Approves Free Trade Pact With U.S.
text: SEOUL — Members of President Lee Myung-bak’s governing party, coughing from tear gas sprayed by an opposition legislator, rammed a free-trade agreement between South Korea and the United States through Parliament on Tuesday, ratifying a deal that has sharpened a political divide between the government and the opposition and between big business and voters unhappy with deepening economic inequality.

headline: After an Eviction, Digging Through a Surplus of Donations
text: In a back room on the first floor of an office building on lower Broadway, with wires dangling from tent-sized holes in the ceiling and organizers folding piles of sweaters across the room, Occupy Wall Street opened its mail on Monday.

headline: One Way to Simplify Phone Chaos
text: Four years ago, Andie Jones found herself overweight, out of shape and feeling generally unhealthy, thanks in large part to the demands of a high-powered career in marketing. After figuring out a new set of eating and exercise habits that got her health back on track, she started helping family, friends and colleagues do the same — and got so much satisfaction out of it that two years ago she walked away from her job for a career reboot. After taking some certification courses, she put up a shingle for Be Well Nutrition, a nutrition and weight-loss coaching service specializing in helping time-strapped business executives and parents.

headline: Tokyo and Osaka Exchanges Reach $1.1 Billion Merger Deal
text: TOKYO — The Tokyo Stock Exchange, Japan’s largest, on Tuesday announced a $1.1 billion merger deal with the Osaka Securities Exchange that would create the world’s third-largest exchange, as measured by the value of listed stock

text: 5:37 p.m. | Updated Democrats reacted ferociously on Tuesday to Mitt Romney’s first campaign commercial, an ad that distorted comments by President Obama to make it look like he was running away from his record on the economy.

headline: Judge Extends Plea Deadline for Former UBS Trader
text: LONDON — A London judge ruled on Tuesday that Kweku M. Adoboli, a former UBS trader charged with fraud, could have an additional four weeks to look at evidence and get legal advice before entering a plea in a case that grew out of a $2.3 billion trading loss at the Swiss bank.

headline: Getting the Gang Together Again

headline: A Son of Santa Claus Takes the Reins
text: Why is it that out of all the holidays, only Christmas ever needs to be saved? When was the last time you saw a movie about a madcap, heroic effort to save Flag Day?

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 22
text: Facebook has decided to create its own smartphone — code name Buffy, as in the vampire slayer — enlisting the Taiwanese company HTC to build it with the social network “integrated at the core of its being,” according to report in AllThingsD, part of Dow Jones. (Neither Facebook nor HTC would confirm the report.) The phone will not make it to market for 12 to 18 months and is expected to use a modified version of the Android operating system created and released by Google, the Web site reported. While some online commentators questioned the wisdom of Facebook entering the hardware business from scratch, the AllThingsD account described the decision as about independence: “Google and Apple run the two major smartphone operating systems, giving Facebook little say over its mobile destiny.”

headline: South Africa Passes Law to Restrict Reporting of Government Secrets
text: JOHANNESBURG — Brushing aside protests by press-freedom advocates and heroes of South Africa’s anti-apartheid struggle, Parliament overwhelmingly passed a contentious bill on Tuesday that will severely restrict the ability of journalists to report any information deemed to be a government secret.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Patients Raise Funds on the Internet, Too
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Pinterest Appeals to Online Collectors

But the prep school created under the Bloomberg administration is now on a list of struggling schools the city may opt to phase out starting next fall.

headline: Janet Maslin’s Picks for 2011
text: DESTINY OF THE REPUBLIC: A TALE OF MADNESS, MEDICINE AND THE MURDER OF A PRESIDENT by Candice Millard. A staggering tale about the American presidency by a historian who, as she did in “The River of Doubt,” her book about Theodore Roosevelt, zeroes in on what other historians overlook. Ms. Millard digs deeply into the turmoil that got James A. Garfield elected, the lunacy that got him shot and the medical malfeasance that turned a minor wound into a mortal one. Her story is so full of outsize figures — not least of them the unexpectedly noble Garfield — that Alexander Graham Bell is only a bit player. (Doubleday, $28.95)

headline: Books to Send, Recommend Or Just Lend
text: PARALLEL universes are a hot topic for scientists these days. They’re a hot one for book critics too. In some parallel world it is theoretically possible that a critic could read every single book published by English-speaking Earthlings in 2011 and list the 10 that are best. Some of those books might even be about parallel-universe theory.

headline: Abortion Case Loses Ground, but Issue Stays Hot in Kansas
text: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — The prosecution of a Planned Parenthood affiliate here, the first such criminal case in the nation, has been treated locally as something of a proxy in the battle over abortion rights. Derided by supporters of the organization as politically motivated, the prosecution was celebrated by opponents as the capstone of increasingly aggressive actions here and elsewhere against Planned Parenthood, which provides abortions and other services at clinics around the country.

headline: Should Airlines Police What We Watch in Flight?
text: Daniel Craig as James Bond, naked and tied to a broken cane chair, being whipped. That was the scene that taught me to think twice about in-flight movies, although in this case we were on the bus to Boston, with “Casino Royale” (rated PG-13) shown on dangling, inescapable screens above us. The two 5-year-olds in my care observed it silently, then turned their attention back to the Disney movie they’d chosen to bring along, fortunately not intrigued by either the torture or a variety of other educational scenes that followed.

headline: More From the Financial Pro Who Lost His Home

headline: Samurai Shopper | The 1% Solution
text: What? Haven’t finished holiday shopping yet? The Samurai Shopper, as usual, is leagues ahead of you. This is not due to my overarching fabulousness, it’s just that the Samurai family consists of the Samurai Spawn, born on Boxing Day, Dec. 26. We still apologize to Spawn for creating her at such an awkward moment. Who knew?

headline: Ask an Expert: Where to Find Treasure in Trash

headline: Daily Report: Separating You and Me? 4.74 Degrees
text: One of the most talked-about articles Tuesday is the revelation that there are not six degrees degrees of separation between any two people, but 4.74 degrees. John Markoff and Somini Sengupta, reporters for The New York Times, write that the original “six degrees” finding, published in 1967 by the psychologist Stanley Milgram, was drawn from 296 volunteers who were asked to send a message by postcard, through friends and then friends of friends, to a specific person in a Boston suburb.

headline: If You’re a Venture Capitalist, You’re Most Likely a White Man
text: The color of money is rarely discussed in Silicon Valley. Which is why, when a CNN program recently brought it up, it unleashed an intense outpouring in the technology blogosphere. Cleverly, it also generated a flurry of free publicity for a provocative CNN documentary on African-Americans in technology, weeks before it aired.

headline: Taxing Job Creators
text: Mark Thoma sends us to the new Journal of Economic Perspectives paper (pdf) on optimal taxes by Peter Diamond and Emmanuel Saez. It’s a tough read (I’m still working on it myself), but there’s one discussion that I think helps make a useful point about current political debate.

headline: There Is a Safe Way to Cut Military Spending. Think Congress Will Do It?
text: Now that members of the Congressional deficit reduction committee have failed to do their jobs (with a BIG assist from leaders of the House G.O.P.), the Pentagon could be looking at more than $500 billion in required spending cuts. That’s on top of about $450 billion in cuts that are already planned for the next 10 years. As they say in Washington, a few billion here, a few billion there and eventually it adds up to real money.

headline: ‘Let It Bleed’ Cover Art Up for Sale
text: If you are ready and able to stand a little blood-letting of your bank account, the original cover artwork for “Let It Bleed,” the Rolling Stones album that has been described as having one of the greatest covers of all time, is for sale at the next Entertainment Memorabilia auction at Bonham’s in London on Dec. 15. The artwork is estimated to sell for £30,000-40,000, roughly $47,000 to $62,500.

headline: Maryland’s Unlikely Run to the Field Hockey Championship
text: In the latter part of the last decade, the University of Maryland field hockey team entered each season as the prohibitive favorites to capture the national championship. It didn’t only have a chance to make a run to the title-game; it was a near-guarantee.

So in her makeup trailer, Michelle went trough the transformation one last time.

headline: Can the Bulldog Be Saved?
text: In the first half of Georgia’s football game against South Carolina in 2009, Uga VII, who had been dozing on a bag of ice in his air-conditioned sideline doghouse, was cajoled onto the field to pose for pictures with some cheerleaders and Gov. Sonny Perdue. Uga (pronounced UGH-uh) wore his trademark red Georgia jersey and spiked red leather collar, and he looked bored as an ESPN cameraman shoved a camera in his wrinkly, smooshed bulldog face.

headline: Shake Up in the Top Ranks at Glamour
text: Glamour magazine, long the reliable cash cow for Condé Nast, has replaced its publisher after a string of recently disappointing advertising results.

headline: Glamorous Sex Goddess, Longing to Be Human
text: In 1976, the year that Marilyn Monroe would have turned 50, Larry McMurtry wrote that she “is right in there with our major ghosts: Hemingway, the Kennedy brothers — people who finished with American life before America had time to finish with them.” Almost a half-century after her death, the world, or at least its necrophiliac fantasists, still haven’t finished with Monroe and try to resurrect her again and again in movies, books, songs and glamour layouts featuring dewy and ruined ingénues. Maybe it’s because it’s so difficult to imagine her as Old Marilyn that she has become a Ghost of Hollywood Past, a phantom that periodically materializes to show us things that have been.

headline: For Distressed Young Bankers, a Symphony of Small Violins
text: In “Bonfire of the Vanities,” the 1987 novel that would become the canonical chronicle of Wall Street’s era of excess, Tom Wolfe described the financial sector as a gilded playpen where “mere boys, with smooth jawlines and clean arteries, boys still able to blush, were buying three-million-dollar apartments on Park and Fifth.” These aspiring Masters of the Universe, he wrote, were living in the “season of the rising sap.”

headline: Ad Watch: Romney Takes On Obama
text: Mitt Romney’s campaign began broadcasting its first television ad in New Hampshire on Tuesday — the same day that President Obama visited the state to talk about his plan to turn around the economy.THE SCRIPTThe words, “On October 16, 2008 Barack Obama Visited New Hampshire,” flash across the screen before spliced video of Mr. Obama’s campaign in 2008 begins: “Thank you. Thank you New Hampshire. How is everybody doing today? I am confident that we can steer ourselves out of this crisis. Who’s been in charge of the economy? We need a rescue plan for the middle class. We need to provide relief for homeowners. It’s going take a new direction. If we keep talking about the economy, we’re going to lose.”

headline: Updating Facebook Status, to Divorced
text: Soon after I married my Army officer husband, an acquaintance gave me a photocopied page of an old-school military spouse handbook as a lark. As part and parcel of being a “good” military spouse, it entreated new spouses to have at least two pairs of white gloves on hand at all times as well as a well-stocked stationery box. The first was deemed necessary to make the best possible impression on all the higher-ups a wife might meet as her husband made his ascent through the ranks.The second, of course, was recommended to help the new spouse stay connected with friends and family as she started her wonderful new adventure as a soldier’s rock and helpmeet.

A woman, clumsily restrained by nondescript handlers, writhes and howls inside a horse-drawn carriage, her mania at once drowned out and underscored by the thunder of hooves and the shrieking of strings on the soundtrack.

headline: Sexist Messages on Baby Clothes
text: Do clothes make the baby? If you’ve shopped for kids’ clothes even once in the past decade, you know that if that’s true, then what clothes make the baby girl, at least, is ready to fit right into her assigned gender category. She’s a Cutie Pie, she’s a Cupcake, she’s a Very Important Princess — and she’s “Pretty Like Mommy” but not, unless you shop for her in the boys’ section (and why not?), “Smart Like Daddy.”

headline: Presents Wrapped in Strings (Chords, Too)
text: For years now we have been hearing dire warnings that recordings — at least the kind you can hold in your hand and wrap up as gifts — will become extinct at any moment. And it is certainly true that the major classical labels are mere shadows of their former selves. But with smaller, independent labels and, increasingly, performing institutions themselves picking up the slack, CDs and DVDs continue to pour in, many of them of the highest quality. So the classical music critics of The New York Times had little difficulty in once again filling out a list of 25 records, as fine a lot as in many a boom year. Here are the choices. JAMES R. OESTREICH

headline: Ratings Shrink President’s List for Judgeships

headline: N.B.A. General Managers Descend on Maui Invitational

headline: Pakistan’s Ambassador to the U.S. Is Forced Out

headline: Bag of Tricks
text: In honor of Art Basel Miami, which opens next weekend, Christian Dior asked the Berlin artist Anselm Reyle to design a collection of colorful accessories. Of his collaboration with the Avenue Montaigne couture house, Reyle notes: “As an artist, I have a fascination with dubious taste, so collaborating with Dior, a symbol of ‘good’ taste was exciting.” He didn’t turn the house on its head so much as on its side. The neon stitching on Dior’s quilted cannage bag has been tilted to reflect the artist’s fiddling with tradition. The limited-edition flats, totes and jewelry will be available in Christian Dior boutiques come January. They might be camo, but don’t expect to blend in.

headline: Following in Forstmann’s Footsteps
text: Two newspapers have paid advertisements on Tuesday honoring the memory of Theodore J. Forstmann, the colorful Wall Street deal maker who died of brain cancer on Sunday. headline: Robin van Persie Is the Best Striker in Britain. Discuss.
text: I support a one-man team. All you need to know about Arsenal, which has won five Premier League matches in a row, and has dragged itself all the way from 19th after three matches up to seventh, level on points with Chelsea and Liverpool above them, is defined by the winning goal Robin van Persie scored in Saturday’s match at Norwich. Aaron Ramsey won the ball in midfield and was tripped, ending up on his stomach. Alex Song, who had an otherwise desultory, wasteful match, hurdled the prone Ramsey and advanced rapidly. He had Gervinho, streaking alone on the left, and van Persie, between two defenders on the right. He twitched, almost passing the ball to Gervinho, the lively Ivoirian who had already missed three sitters in the match, then changed his tune, rotated his body to pick out van Persie, who touched once, ran into space, and on his second touch lifted the ball over John Ruddy with his right foot, his weaker one, and just inside the near post.

headline: Sovereign Dress Crisis
text: It was the 10th of May when a letter marked “On Her Majesty’s Service” dropped through our letter box. I wasn’t home, because, in one of life’s rare strokes of serendipity, I was presiding over the selection committee for London’s Newgen at the British Fashion Council, the panel that X-rays young designers for runway-worthiness. My husband thought he ought to call, anyway. “Listen to this,” he began, and as soon as I heard the words “Dear madam, the prime minister has asked me to inform you . . .” Jonathan Anderson’s paisley-print pantsuit melted before me into a psychedelic fudge, “. . . that Her Majesty may be graciously pleased to approve that you be appointed a Member of the British Empire (M.B.E.) in the 2011 Birthday Honors List.”

headline: Major Archaelogical Find: Graffiti by Johnny Rotten
text: An apartment with graffiti by the Sex Pistols front man Johnny Rotten is an important historical and archaeological site and could be of greater significance than the discovery of early Beatles recordings, according to a paper published in the journal Antiquity, the BBC reports.

headline: Market-Inspired Pastas
text: By now you’ve probably got your Thanksgiving menu organized, and like me, you may be getting a bit tired of the holiday recipes that have been dominating food pages and recipe features like this one for weeks now. So this week I’m focusing on what I’ve been craving: comforting pasta dishes. They have nothing to do with Thanksgiving, but they have a lot to do with what’s available at my farmers’ market, as well as what was lingering in my refrigerator at the beginning of the week. I decided I’d use some new pasta shapes, so I went to an Italian market to see what they had on offer. The fun part was figuring out the best vegetable/pasta shape pairings.

Muammar el-Qaddafi, the former Libyan leader, along with his co-defendant, Colonel Qaddafi’s onetime military intelligence chief, may be tried in Libya as long as the international court is involved.

headline: Europe’s Banks Relying on Money From E.C.B.
text: FRANKFURT — Banks clamored for emergency funds from the European Central Bank on Tuesday, borrowing the most since early 2009 in a clear sign that the euro region’s financial institutions are having trouble obtaining credit at reasonable rates on the open market.

headline: Pepper Spray at UC Davis
text: There were a few possible reactions to the police repeatedly pepper spraying a seated row of non-violent student protesters at an Occupy Wall Street-inspired event at UC Davis on Saturday. The university Chancellor, Linda Katehi, apologized to her students for the attack. The university put two officers on leave while investigating their behavior. Protesters were outraged.

headline: Florida A&M Suspends Band After Drum Major Death
text: The yet-unexplained death of a drum major after the Florida A&M’s band performance on Saturday has prompted the university’s president, Dr. James H. Ammons, to suspend all band activities Tuesday amid reports that a hazing incident might have led to the death of 26-year-old Robert Champion.

headline: ABC Dances to Top Rating
text: The final performance hour of “Dancing with the Stars” carried ABC to a first-place finish in total viewers on Monday night with more than 20 million people tuning in. Although it was the show’s largest audience since the season premiere, when compared to same period last year the overall ratings trend points downward. The first hour of last fall’s finale drew 23.3 million total viewers and Monday night’s episode fell more than 27 percent in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic from last year.

headline: Congressional Panel Seeks to Question Corzine
text: A Congressional panel has asked Jon S. Corzine to testify about the downfall of MF Global, and the hundreds of millions of dollars in customer money that went missing in the brokerage firm’s final days.

headline: Perciatelli With Cauliflower, Spicy Tomato Sauce, Capers and Pecorino
text: Perciatelli are hollow long noodles that also go by the name bucatini. Their texture is robust, supporting a robust sauce like this one. Because the noodles are hollow, they cook much more quickly than spaghetti, so keep your eye on them so they don’t get too soft.

headline: Pappardelle With Beets, Beet Greens and Goat Cheese
text: If you don’t mind eating pink pasta and you like beets with goat cheese, you’ll love this. I roasted my beets, blanched the greens and paired them with wide pappardelle noodles and goat cheese, both excellent partners. Make sure that you don’t drain the water from the pasta pot when the noodles are done (lift them out with a pasta insert or with a skimmer), as you need some of the cooking water to thin out the goat cheese.

headline: Orecchiette With Grated Squash, Walnuts and Ricotta Salata
text: I don’t know why it had never occurred to me to grate hard winter squash until I started envisioning this pasta. If you have a food processor with a grater blade, this will be the easiest way you’ve ever prepared winter squash, short of sticking it in the oven skin and all. The cooked grated squash lodges in the indentations of the ear-shaped orecchiette, a perfect pairing.

headline: Giant Shells Filled With Spinach and Ricotta
text: These are comforting and easy to put together. You can make them ahead and heat them in the oven when you’re ready for dinner.

headline: New Deal Extends Labor Tranquillity
text: Against a backdrop of labor strife in other professional sports, Major League Baseball and its players union unveiled a new collective bargaining agreement on Tuesday that was completed weeks before the old one expired and will introduce significant changes in drug testing, the playoff format, instant replay and the manner in which amateur players can be signed.

headline: Grinnell’s Lentsch (89 Points) Grabs the Single-Game Scoring Record from Clement (77)
text: Not long after Griffin Lentsch of high-scoring Grinnell College in Iowa scored 89 points on Saturday afternoon, setting a Division III record in his team’s 145-97 victory at Principia College, Jeff Clement’s in-box started filling up, too.

headline: Another Debate, Another Top Candidate
text: November 22, 2011 — The latest poll shows Newt Gingrich to be tied with Mitt Romney ahead of Tuesday night’s debate in Washington between Republican presidential candidates.

headline: Sports Replay: Nov.22
text: The day in sports, including action from the ATP World Tour Finals in London and Champions League soccer.

headline: Caucus Video: Another Debate, Another Top Candidate
text: The latest poll shows Newt Gingrich to be tied with Mitt Romney ahead of Tuesday night’s debate in Washington between Republican presidential candidates.

headline: Merck to Pay $950 Million Over Vioxx
text: Merck has agreed to pay $950 million and has pleaded guilty to a criminal charge over the marketing and sales of the painkiller Vioxx, the company and the Justice Department said Tuesday.

headline: Big Trucks Returned Big Profits for Detroit
text: In 2008 and 2009, as the American automotive industry foundered, critics often cited Detroit’s fixation with light trucks and S.U.V.’s, which had fallen out of favor as gas prices rose, for the industry’s agita. A new study authored by Max Warburton of Bernstein Research, a market trends and analysis firm, suggests that automakers’ fondness for big iron was, and continues to be, driven by the outsize profit margins generated by the machines.

headline: What to Look for in Tonight’s Debate
text: Whom will Professor Gingrich lecture this time?

headline: Shootings by Police Continue to Decline
text: New York City police officers shot and killed fewer people last year than at any other time since the Police Department began keeping track in 1971, according to a department report released Tuesday.

headline: Iranian Paper Protests Raid by Judiciary
text: Iran’s main government-run newspaper was published Tuesday without a front-page headline, replaced by photographs of its headquarters during an assault a day earlier by forces working for the judiciary who briefly arrested the newspaper’s top official — the media adviser to the president — and more than 30 others.

headline: Make Your Own Brazilian Cheese Puffs
text: Each week, Brazilian Specialty Foods in North Bergen, N.J., which I write about this week, makes about 24,000 pão de queijo, Brazilian cheese puffs that are chewy on the inside and lightly crisp on the outside. Mixing, shaping and baking pounds of the gooey dough would require too much time and labor for the 15 Brazilian restaurants in New York City that buy the company’s bread.

headline: BPA Lurks in Canned Soups and Drinks
text: A new study by Harvard researchers may provide another reason to skip the canned pumpkin and cranberry sauce this Thanksgiving. People who ate one serving of canned food daily over the course of five days, the study found, had significantly elevated levels — more than a tenfold increase — of bisphenol-A, or BPA, a substance that lines most food and drink cans.

headline: A 300-Duck Day and Cabbages by the Thousands
text: THE food cognoscenti like to know the source of their vegetables, fish and meat. Is that lettuce organic? Did that chicken range freely and merrily during its short life?

headline: Noose, Our
text: Update: Oh, geez. Pronounce the headline phonetically. It’s PBS, tonight at 6.

headline: The Big Drag
text: The CBO has released the latest assessment of the American Recovery and Reconstruction Act, aka Obama stimulus. What it tells us is that the US federal government has been practicing destructive fiscal austerity since the middle of 2010 (and that’s not even talking about what’s happening at the state and local level). Here’s the average of CBO’s high and low estimates of the impact of the ARRA on the level (not the rate of growth) of GDP by quarter:

headline: Way Back Machine: Long Before Cuomo, Slaying the Gerrymander
text: If Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo keeps his vow to veto a partisan redistricting plan, he will be in good company. Governors Alfred E. Smith and Franklin D. Roosevelt both rejected legislative reapportionment plans that they regarded to be gerrymandering.

headline: Defendant Says Khmer Rouge’s Aim Was to Protect Cambodia From Vietnam
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — The highest-ranking surviving Khmer Rouge leader, accused in the deaths of 1.7 million people, defended himself on Tuesday by casting his actions as part of a patriotic struggle to keep Vietnam from annexing Cambodia and exterminating ethnic Cambodians.

headline: Thanksgiving Thrift: The Holiday as a Model for Sustainable Cooking
text: ““WE have too few holidays,” wrote Sarah Hale in her 1827 novel “Northwood; or, Life North and South.” She wanted Thanksgiving declared a national holiday, and petitioned four presidents for it before Lincoln finally did the stubborn lady’s bidding in 1863.

headline: Another Treaty Negotiation, Another Batch of Climate Science E-Mail
text: [Nov. 23, 2:43 p.m. | Update |  There’s now a searchable cache for the newly disclosed East Anglia e-mails. Here’s the “Revkin” search result. | 12:30 p.m. |  I’ve posted a fresh piece in which I acknowledge the importance of issues raised by the e-mail exchanges, but return to the broader context that quickly gets lost.]

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, South Korea, Kazakhstan and Hawaii.

headline: Week 11 Film Review: Rise of the Dolphins
text: Analysis of some of the games from Week 11, with the benefit of film review:

headline: The Grunge That Stole Christmas
text: “It’s a mix of raided grandma’s closet and classic punk with a little bit of boudoir on the side,” explains Lyndsey Butler, the designer for Veda reclaimed leather, which collaborated with Reformation by Yael Aflalo on a holiday collection. The resulting 10 pieces channel Kate Moss and Johnny Depp circa 1994 and all things grunge — downtown motorcycle jackets paired with silk burgundy pajama pants and camisoles; festive red leather vests with indigo blue slip dresses and denim miniskirts. In other words, a very Courtney Love Christmas.

headline: The Golden Age of Republican Deficit Hawks
text: I’ve written a few pieces in the last several days about the history of deficit reduction packages, and how Republicans used to be on board for tax increases. I suggested that at the very least, Republicans were more willing to compromise on using tax increases to cut deficits, even if they preferred to balance the budget wholly through the spending side.

headline: Charting Balam Acab at Le Poisson Rouge
text: The artist Andrew Kuo charts the the Pennsylvanian singer and producer also known as Alec Koone.

headline: Rome Gets New Respect at European Union
text: BRUSSELS — They may not have been the exact words José Manuel Barroso used during a lunch with the new Italian prime minister, Mario Monti, on Tuesday, but the message was clear: Welcome back to Europe’s top table.

headline: Private Markets Offer Valuable Service but Little Disclosure
text: Information is the lifeblood of capital markets. In the movie “Wall Street,” Gordon Gekko demanded confidential information from a young would-be Master of the Universe, Bud Fox, played by Charlie Sheen. The value of stocks is based on information, which is why securities laws are intended to ensure that all investors have at least minimum amounts of information.

headline: Inventing a World, Just Like Clockwork
text: “Hugo,” an enchantment from Martin Scorsese, is the 3-D children’s movie that you might expect from the director of “Raging Bull” and “Goodfellas.” It’s serious, beautiful, wise to the absurdity of life and in the embrace of a piercing longing. No one gets clubbed to death, but shadows loom, and a ferocious Doberman nearly lands in your lap. The movie is based on the book “The Invention of Hugo Cabret,” but is also very much an expression of the filmmaker’s movie love. Surely the name of its author, Brian Selznick, caught his eye: Mr. Selznick is related to David O. Selznick, the producer of “Gone With the Wind” — kismet for a cinematic inventor like Mr. Scorsese.

headline: Panel’s Failure Means Education Cuts in ’13
text: On Monday, Congressional leaders failed to agree on a plan to balance the country’s budget. As a result, automatic cuts to federal programs are set to take place beginning in 2013. Student financial aid programs — including Pell Grants — will find their current funding levels in jeopardy unless government officials reach consensus on an alternate approach.

headline: Would You, Could You, in the Rain?
text: S. Amanda Caudill, a doctoral student at the University of Rhode Island, writes from Costa Rica, where she is assessing mammal diversity on coffee farms.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, South Korea, Nepal and Kazakhstan.

headline: Enduring but Confusing at Barneys
text: POP quiz: who’s more stylish, Usher or Cuba Gooding Jr.?

headline: Can I Tell My Family They Can’t Come to Dinner?
text: Q.

headline: Common Sense Prevails in New Baseball Agreement
text: Read through the new collective bargaining agreement between the Major League Baseball players and owners, and you will find one overriding theme: common sense. Lots of little rules that seemed silly or archaic have been eliminated or improved.

headline: F.C.C. Seeks Review of AT&T Merger With T-Mobile
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission took steps Tuesday to block the proposed $39 billion merger of the mobile phone companies AT&T and T-Mobile USA.

headline: Covering a Penn State Game, and Dancing Around the Facts
text: Call it a cocoon. Call it a cone of willful ignorance. But watching the Penn State-Ohio State game on ABC last Saturday should have made a viewer wonder why the announcers Brad Nessler and Todd Blackledge tiptoed so carefully, but not deftly, around the sexual abuse scandal that led to the firing of Nittany Lions Coach Joe Paterno and the university president Graham B. Spanier and the indictments of two Penn State officials.

headline: The Allure of the Odd
text: LET’S just say it straight out: Isa is one peculiar restaurant. It’s warm, it’s welcoming, the dining room smells great, and, despite the hard chairs and benches, it’s fairly comfortable. The food’s pretty good, too.

headline: Reviewing Isa
text: What is it about small plates? When I stopped reviewing restaurants regularly, eight years or so ago, I don’t remember so many places that, in addition to the conventional appetizers and main courses, offered all manner of snacks, shellfish and other sorts of pre-appetizer tidbits that one might cynically believe are aimed principally at getting consumers to spend more money.

headline: Oregon Governor Says He Will Block Executions
text: Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon on Tuesday said he would halt the execution of a death row inmate scheduled for next month and that he would allow no more executions in the state during his time in office.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Personal Finance Tips and a Look Inside Twitter
text: Here’s what the technology reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web:

headline: On Thanksgiving, Stepping Up to the Plate
text: Scooping his food with a spork, Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott shared a pre-Thanksgiving meal with the children at Public School 56 Lewis H. Latimer in Brooklyn, and talked about the importance of healthy eating. “It's fun because we can come together and we don’t get to see each other on Thanksgiving,” said Mahagany Young, 9, a fourth grader. “Everyone here is friends and family to us.”

headline: Mitt Romney’s First TV Ad
text: Mitt Romney released his first television ad  on Tuesday. He could have made a pretty powerful ad criticizing President Obama’s handling of the economy and pointing out how high the unemployment rate is. Unfortunately, Mr. Romney wasn’t satisfied with just the facts.

headline: Torre Draws Inquiries From Suitors for Dodgers
text: Is Joe Torre interested in joining a group that would buy the Los Angeles Dodgers?

headline: Turkey Tips: Stuffing
text: To stuff or not to stuff? Melissa Clark demonstrates how to stuff a turkey, and how to add extra flavor to your stuffing if you cook it separately.

headline: Federer, Quite Quickly, Defeats Nadal
text: Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal may have never played one another with less on the line.

headline: Museum Finds a Home for the Enterprise
text: The Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum now owns a space shuttle, and museum officials say they have figured out where to put it – at least for a while.

text: Q.

headline: Power Struggles Over Pep and High School Popularity
text: LOS ANGELES — The jubilant young dancers in the new musical “Bring It On,” at the Ahmanson Theater here, should probably be racking up frequent-flier miles, so often are they airborne in this featherweight show about competing high school cheerleading squads.

headline: For Sanchez, Ryan Tries Another Round of Motivation
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. – Innovative as he is as a defensive coach, Rex Ryan tends to stick with tactics that work in other areas – like motivation. For the second consecutive year, Ryan responded to two poor games for Mark Sanchez by giving the backup, Mark Brunell, a few snaps with the first-team offense this week. Brunell said he ran four plays.

headline: How to Become a Big Fish in an Indie-Rock Aquarium
text: Jeffrey Lewis was crouched on the floor of his East Village apartment one recent evening, stuffing his self-made CDs and comic books into a backpack while his brother, Jack, prodded him to hurry. They had a gig to get to, and not a moment to spare.

headline: Live Blogging the National Security Debate
text: The eight Republican candidates for president will take the stage in Washington at 8 tonight, but all eyes will be on Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the House.

headline: Lens: LUCEO
text: Lens: LUCEO

headline: Chestnuts Roasted, and Sometimes Burned
text: Too often holiday music is about comfort: familiar melodies, familiar sentiments, familiar styles. And for some that may well be enough: never underestimate the power of the reliable. But so much great music comes from artists who understand that the holiday season is just another topic — it can inspire reverence and jubilation, of course, but also self-doubt, skepticism, comedy, fear, resentment and so much more. Here, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times highlight the best of the traditional, the best of the progressive and some others with room to grow. (Prices may vary from those listed here, depending on where you shop.) JON CARAMANICA

headline: 3 American Students Held in Protests, Egyptians Say
text: Three students at the American University in Cairo were arrested and accused of participating in violent protests in the Egyptian capital, the university said Tuesday, after images of the men were broadcast on satellite and cable television channels around the world.

headline: Evoking Edelweiss and Stirring Hope in India
text: There are incongruities atop incongruities in “The Sound of Mumbai: A Musical,” a documentary by Sarah McCarthy that has its debut Wednesday night on HBO2.

headline: Plaza Food Hall Is Growing
text: CALL it the food hall that ate the concourse.

headline: World Bank Issues Alert on Afghanistan Economy
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan will suffer a recession in 2014 and beyond after foreign troops leave and aid dwindles, and if the security situation gets worse, the country could face complete economic collapse, according to an ominous report released in Kabul on Tuesday by the World Bank.

headline: Occupy at Berkeley
text: To the Editor:

headline: Prepare to Indulge
text: ASK Crazy Legs Conti, a professional eater, what he thinks of your average Thanksgiving feaster, and you can almost hear him choke.

headline: Bloggingheads: Avoiding War With Iran
text: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Heather Hurlburt of the National Security Network debate about preventing a war with Iran.

headline: Nokia’s Microsoft Phones May Not Get Traction, Analyst Says
text: Microsoft and Nokia have yet to prove whether their marriage will give birth to healthy handset sales. One analyst is not expecting much.

headline: Inviting a Turkey to Dinner
text: Thanksgiving already came and went safely for Skip, Payton and Amelinda as well as the dozens of rescue turkeys housed by Farm Sanctuary, an animal welfare organization with shelters in upstate New York and California. In anticipation of the holiday, the shelters hosted their annual “Feeding of the Turkeys” celebration last weekend, where turkeys eat stuffed squash, cranberries and pumpkin pie as the guests of honor — but are never the main course.

headline: Libyan Leader Seeks to Unite Factions With Cabinet
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Bowing to pressure from a local militia holding one of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s sons as a prisoner, Prime Minister Abdel Rahim el-Keeb on Tuesday appointed the militia’s commander to be the new defense minister.

headline: Post-Mortems on the Supercommittee
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: Rink Cuisine

headline: My Three Favorite Philip Roth Books, or Rereading ‘Herzog’
text: Since the only questions anyone asks me in the “three favorite” category are about restaurants, I’m not going there. I thought I might do my three favorite Philip Roth books, which I’m qualified to do only — maybe — because a) I write for The Times and b) I’ve read them all.

headline: On a Final Tour, a Dancer Translates Poetry and Prose Into Sinew and Snap
text: Since Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson founded Complexions Contemporary Ballet in 1994, the company has had one clear reason for existing: as a showcase for the virtuoso dancing of Mr. Richardson. Because this will be his last year touring with the group, a new justification will soon be required.

headline: Alfama
text: 214 East 52nd Street, (212) 759-5552, alfamanyc.com.

headline: The Old Order Stifles the Birth of a New Egypt
text: CAIRO — If the demonstrations that culminated in February were an uprising against President Hosni Mubarak, the revolt today is against his legacy.

headline: A Foray to Finland, Where Sibelius Isn’t the Only Star Composer
text: The turn of the 20th century was a difficult time to be a lesser Finnish composer: Sibelius pretty much sucked the air out of the room. But other composers did exist, even if they have faded to posterity, and they creep into concerts now and then.

headline: Baristas Lock Restrooms, but the Revolt Doesn’t Last
text: For many workers at Starbucks in New York City, the worst part of their jobs may not be the hordes of demanding tourists. Or the irritation of making ever-more-complex skim Frappuccinos and green tea lattes. Or the unflattering elf hats that some baristas have been asked to wear even before Thanksgiving.

headline: Despite a Rough Year, Hedge Funds Maintain Their Mystique
text: Hedge funds, the golden children of finance, are having a very rough year.

headline: Agua Fresca
text: 207 East 117th Street (Third Avenue), East Harlem, (212) 996-2500, AguaFrescaRestaurant.com.

headline: The Mysterious Mind of a Cop Who Goes Bad
text: A sun-scorched noir, “Rampart” tells a familiar story with such visual punch and hustling energy that it comes close to feeling like a new kind of movie, though it’s more just a tough gloss on American crime stories past. Directed by Oren Moverman from a fast, nasty, at times queasily funny screenplay by him and James Ellroy, it stars Woody Harrelson as Dave Brown, one of those dirty cops who ooze out of the smog-kissed Los Angeles sprawl to keep the peace in paradise, usually by breaking heads and gunning for trouble.

headline: America’s Cold War Sage and His Discontents
text: This may be the most long-awaited single-volume biography ever. In 1981, the renowned cold war historian John Lewis Gaddis approached the pre-eminent cold war diplomat George F. Kennan about writing his life story. Kennan, who was 78 at the time, turned over mountains of papers, diaries, letters, even dream notebooks, on the condition that the book not be published until after he died. Who knew that he’d live to be 101, or that Mr. Gaddis would take more than a half-decade after his subject’s death to finish writing?

headline: Protesters Give Education Department an F for Failure
text: UPDATED: Holding up an oversize report card on the steps of the Tweed Courthouse on Chambers Street, parents and elected officials gave an F to the city's Department of Education in a protest to prevent the closing of several schools.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,824 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Pop and Classical in the Same Voice
text: Gabriel Kahane has been living a double musical life, spending some of his time as a pop singer-songwriter and some as a composer with an ambitious style suited to the classical concert hall. As composer in residence with the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, he has been living both lives at once, which is probably as it should be.

headline: There’s Always Room for Mousse
text: A classic mousse au chocolat is always a delectable crowd-pleaser, elegant in its simplicity yet demanding to prepare. So leave the melting, whisking and chilling to La Maison du Chocolat, which has added a bittersweet chocolate mousse to its line of high-quality chocolates and pastries.

headline: Israel and ‘Pinkwashing’
text: “IN dreams begin responsibilities,” wrote Yeats in 1914. These words resonate with lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people who have witnessed dramatic shifts in our relationship to power. After generations of sacrifice and organization, gay people in parts of the world have won protection from discrimination and relationship recognition. But these changes have given rise to a nefarious phenomenon: the co-opting of white gay people by anti-immigrant and anti-Muslim political forces in Western Europe and Israel.

headline: A New Mushroom-Cultivating Kit
text: That impulse to grow your own, recycle and even give a worthwhile holiday gift? Satisfy it with mushrooms.

headline: Iran: Sanctions Likely to Grow
text: Iran’s economic isolation over suspicions that it may be working on a nuclear weapon deepened as the European Union agreed in principle to expand its sanctions, adding to measures announced by the United States, Britain and Canada. The added steps would bar Europeans from commercial transactions with 200 Iranian individuals, companies and groups, but would not stop European purchases of oil from Iran. Tehran, which has insisted its nuclear program is peaceful, denounced the new sanctions.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Sues in Latest Sex Scandal
text: PARIS — Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, struck back Tuesday against a political foe and several newspapers and magazines over their coverage of the latest sex scandal to which he has been linked.

headline: Federer Routs Nadal
text: Roger Federer obliterated Rafael Nadal, 6-3, 6-0, in only 61 minutes at the ATP World Tour Finals in London. The three games Nadal managed to win were the fewest either has won against the other in their 26 meetings (Federer won four in the 2008 French Open final, a best-of-five-set match). Federer did not face a break point on his serve, and gobbled up Nadal’s serves, winning a stunning 53 percent of points off Nadal’s first serve. Federer had 28 winners to Nadal’s 4. It was the first time in their meetings that neither was ranked No. 1.

headline: Mexico: Candidate Drops Out
text: Manlio Fabio Beltrones, the Senate leader for the Institutional Revolutionary Party, has announced that he will not seek the presidency in 2012. Mr. Beltrones said he chose to step down for the sake of party unity during “the difficult political battle that is coming.” His move leaves Enrique Peña Nieto uncontested for the nomination.

headline: Tajikistan: Moscow Tensions Ease
text: A court in Tajikistan on Tuesday released two men — a Russian and an Estonian — whose prosecution had led to a confrontation with Moscow. The men, Vladimir Sadovnichy and Aleksei Rudenko, are pilots who landed at an airport in Tajikistan for emergency refueling in mid-March, although air traffic controllers had denied them permission to land. On Nov. 8, a court sentenced them to eight and a half years in prison. The case infuriated Russian officials, and last week Russia’s Federal Migration Service began rounding up ethnic Tajik migrant workers in Moscow. On Tuesday, the Russian Foreign Ministry said it was “satisfied” by the men’s release.

headline: U.S. Attorney in Manhattan Is Said to Name New Criminal Chief
text: Lorin L. Reisner, deputy director of enforcement for the Securities and Exchange Commission, will become the new chief of the criminal division of the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan, according to two people familiar with the decision.

headline: Guatemala: War Victims Found
text: The bodies of two Guatemalan men who disappeared in 1984 have been found at a former military base and identified through DNA testing, validating an exhumation process tied to the roughly 40,000 people who disappeared during Guatemala’s civil war. The two men, Amancio Samuel Villatoro, a union leader, and Sergio Saúl Linares Morales, an engineering professor, were captured by security forces. Experts said the discovery of the two bodies could lead to new investigations.

headline: Forstmann Equity Firm to Name New Leader
text: Julian H. Robertson Jr., the hedge fund manager, is expected to be named chairman of Forstmann Little, succeeding Theodore J. Forstmann, the co-founder of the private equity firm and prominent financier who died on Sunday.

headline: Braun Most Valuable in the Clutch
text: With the score tied in the bottom of the eighth inning, on a frenzied Friday night at Miller Park in late September, Ryan Braun stepped to the plate and destroyed a pitch to straightaway center field. Braun, the Milwaukee Brewers’ left fielder, knew it was a home run and pointed his bat to the roof, like the Statue of Liberty holding up her torch, before gliding around the bases.

headline: Egypt’s Doomed Election
text: Chapel Hill, N.C.

headline: Public Opinion and Executive Pay
Passing Out Turkeys While Awaiting a Settlement
text: Under a broad tarp, on a sidewalk along Harlem’s Lenox Avenue, two rows of people found momentary shelter from the rain and cold. On one side were some of the neighborhood’s neediest residents, receiving free Thanksgiving turkeys. On the other side, distributing the turkeys, were locked-out N.B.A. players.

headline: Brews as Complex as Wine
text: NOT so long ago I visited an American craft brewery whose beers I greatly admired. The brewery is best known for its excellent versions of traditional English styles: pale ale and porter, stout and India pale ale. But did the brewers want to talk about these beers? No way.

headline: How the Future Looks From High School
text: Middlebury? The military? Beauty school? How do 18-year-olds in 2011 see the rest of their lives?

headline: A Giver to the Community Learns to Accept Its Help
text: In the hallways and classrooms of Public School 225 in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, Carolina Martinez is something of a celebrity. Students can be heard vying for her attention — “Ms. Carolina! Ms. Carolina!” — and often greet her with hugs.

headline: Boeheim Holds His Ground With All His Heart, if Few Facts
text: Surrounded by reporters at a small round table, Jim Boeheim folded his arms and pronounced himself done talking about “that situation,” the one that he had already weighed in on quite contentiously over the weekend.

headline: Voice Recognition Software
text: Still leaves a lot to be desired. Two recent messages:

headline: Visions of a Development Rising From the Sea
text: New Yorkers are fond, perhaps overly so, of assembling ever-creative names for newly hot neighborhoods, from NoMad (north of Madison Square Park) to SoBro (the South Bronx) to BoCoCa (Boerum Hill, Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens).

headline: The Tricky Task of Renovating a Building Without Altering Its Landmark Insides
text: Soon after buying 510 Fifth Avenue, a 1954 Gordon Bunshaft design praised as a paradigm of the International Style, Vornado Realty Trust began an interior renovation that it hoped would attract new street-level retail tenants. The work was to include new doorways on Fifth Avenue and to move escalators, among other things.

headline: At Rikers, Roasting Turkeys for a New Start
text: For the last few years, Richard Powell, a young man who saw himself as “alone in the world,” has marked Thanksgiving with a slice of pizza. The day after, he would go back to work at one of his jobs, at Burger King, the American Museum of Natural History or the Frick Collection.

headline: New Momentum for Hamas Entering Talks With Fatah
text: Hamas’s leader, Khalid Meshal, arrives at talks in Cairo this week with Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, with a sense of regional winds at his back, as Islamic-inspired movements replace dictators.

headline: New Winds in Mideast Favor Hamas
text: GAZA — For years, the imposing black gate that sealed the border between Egypt and Gaza symbolized the pain and isolation that decades of conflict have wrought on this tiny coastal strip, especially under Hamas in recent years.

headline: Baseball Strides Forth on H.G.H., but Carefully
text: When testing for human growth hormone begins in Major League Baseball next spring, the sport will be moving cautiously into uncharted territory.

headline: Despite Threat of Cuts, Pentagon Officials Made No Contingency Plans
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta has painted such an apocalyptic vision of America’s national security under $500 billion in automatic defense budget cuts that Pentagon officials said Tuesday they were pushing back at Congress — and not even planning for the spending reductions, which are to take effect in January 2013. But independent military budget analysts described the cuts, which would bring the Pentagon base budget back to 2007 levels, as agonizing but manageable.

headline: Go Big, Mr. Obama
text: President Obama has a clear choice on how to approach the 2012 election: He can spend all his energy defining Mitt Romney, Newt Gingrich or whoever ends up as the Republican nominee in as ugly a way as possible, or he can spend all his energy defining the future in as credible a way as possible. If he spends his energy defining his Republican opponent, there is a chance the president will win with 50.00001 percent of the vote and no mandate to do what needs doing. If he spends his time defining the future in a credible way and offering a hard, tough, realistic pathway to get there, he will not only win, but he will have a mandate to take the country where we need to go.

headline: Obama Aide Says Iran’s Leaders Are Feeling the Strain of Sanctions
text: WASHINGTON — A day after the United States imposed fresh sanctions on Iran over its nuclear program, President Obama’s national security adviser argued Tuesday that the administration’s pressure campaign had left Iran’s leaders economically strained, diplomatically isolated and rent by internal divisions.

headline: Fate of Euro May Hinge on Italian Savers
text: LONDON — Even though Europe’s debt crisis has turned Rome into financial ground zero, Italy has been able to lean on at least one solid support: the relatively large amount of government debt held by Italians themselves.

headline: Lottery Numbers
20 Students Now Accused in L.I. Case on Cheating
text: MINEOLA, N.Y. — Schools do not write the SAT or administer it. But when school officials at Great Neck North High School suspected that students were cheating on the exam, their investigation led prosecutors down a trail that has resulted in criminal charges against 20 students and calls for widespread test reform.

headline: Fight Ends as Actress Gives Up Apartment
text: With little fanfare, the actress Faye Dunaway agreed this week to give up the rent-stabilized apartment on the Upper East Side that her landlord had sued to evict her from.

headline: In Terror Case, Legal Aid Society Exits Because Informer Was Client
text: The Muslim convert accused of building pipe bombs for use in a terrorist plot was given a new court-appointed lawyer on Tuesday after it was determined that the Legal Aid Society, which initially represented him, has also served as counsel in a separate case for a confidential informer involved in the terrorism inquiry.

headline: City Says Don’t Fault It for $3 Cheese at Sardi’s
text: Attention, bar-hoppers: The cheddar cheese in the communal pot is still gone at Sardi’s. But New York City’s health department says it is not to blame.

headline: New Trove of Stolen E-Mails From Climate Scientists Is Released
text: The anonymous hacker who shook the world of climate science two years ago by posting a trove of stolen e-mails delivered a new batch on Tuesday, stirring up climate-change contrarians a little more than a week before global negotiations on greenhouse gases are to begin in Durban, South Africa.

headline: For Some Marketers, Brand Investment Beats Black Friday
text: THE holiday shopping season this year is playing out like a tale of two Christmases, giving marketers a, well, dickens of a time figuring out how best to reach consumers: hype the sale or bolster the brand.

headline: How Many Primaries in New York?
text: New York State, which will struggle with a deficit projected to be more than $3 billion in 2012, is facing the ridiculous and costly possibility of holding three primaries next year instead of the usual two in presidential election years.

headline: Health Care and the States
text: In reviewing the constitutionality of health care reform, the Supreme Court said it would consider the legality of the Medicaid expansion included in the reform law. The question seems narrow, but it could have significant implications for redefining Congress’s spending power.

headline: In the Land of the Salamanders, the Newt is King
text: Presidential primary fields of dubious quality often receive derisive nicknames. The seven Democratic candidates of 1988, for instance, in part because some of them were of short stature and in part because none of them seemed like formidable challengers to George H.W. Bush, were often referred to as the “Seven Dwarfs”.

headline: Richmond’s Medical Miracle
text: During the opening months of the Civil War, the streets of Richmond, Va., filled with bloodied bodies. The thousands of Confederate wounded were treated in a range of makeshift hospitals hastily established in hotels, factories and private homes. But by autumn, as hopes the conflict would be brief faded, it became clear a war of this magnitude required a modernized medical response.

headline: Lessons in Transit Innovation
text: Reader responses to  last week’s column about transit innovation revealed a lot of love for transit: Readers reported their appreciation for light rail in Trenton, N.J.; buses in Austin, Tex.; the pedicabs of the Philippines; the transit planners of Portland, Ore.; dollar vans in Ghana and Guatemala; the SLUGS of Washington D.C. (an informal car pool system); and the Skytrain and songthaews — pickups with benches in the back — of Bangkok.

headline: Guitar Heroes
text: Gibson’s guitars and their players through the decades

headline: For a Reported Penn State Victim, a Search for Trust
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Two years ago, Thom Hunter, a volunteer coach at Central Mountain High School in Mill Hall, Pa., saw something special in a 15-year-old boy at the school: a remarkable natural running ability.

headline: New Mexico Black Groups Claim Bias at University
text: DENVER — A group of African-American pastors in New Mexico, along with the Albuquerque chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., said Tuesday that they have filed a complaint with the Justice Department alleging that black faculty and staff members at the University of New Mexico and its hospital are subject to discrimination.

headline: Former Obama Fund-Raiser Gets Over 10 Years in Fraud and Bribery Case
text: CHICAGO — More than three years after his conviction on fraud and bribery charges, Antoin Rezko, a former real estate mogul and a once-powerful fund-raiser with ties to President Obama’s early political career, was sentenced on Tuesday to 10 and a half years in prison.

headline: Democrats Cry Foul Over New Romney Ad
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats reacted ferociously on Tuesday to Mitt Romney’s first campaign commercial, which they said distorted comments by Barack Obama to make it look as if he was running away from his record on the economy.

headline: Penn State’s Inquiry
text: The Pennsylvania State University Board of Trustees announced Monday that Louis Freeh, a former F.B.I. director, had been asked to lead an independent investigation into the sexual abuse scandal surrounding Jerry Sandusky, a former assistant football coach charged with sexually assaulting eight boys over a span of 15 years.

headline: At Dalton, a Student Survey Reveals Dual Identities
text: The qualities that students at the Dalton School strive to embody are confidence, friendliness and intelligence. But the ones they associate with their classmates, and with the high-priced education they are receiving, are competitiveness and ambition.

headline: A Discussion of Russia’s Future Is Long on Pessimism
text: KALUGA, Russia

headline: Financial Finger-Pointing Turns to Regulators
text: In the whodunit of the financial crisis, Wall Street executives have pointed the blame at all kinds of parties — consumers who lied on their mortgage applications, investors who demanded access to risky mortgage bonds, and policy makers who kept interest rates low and failed to predict a housing market collapse.

headline: M.T.A. Halts Blasting for 2nd Ave. Subway Around 72nd St.
text: Transportation officials have temporarily halted blasting on the Second Avenue subway project around 72nd Street, after receiving complaints from Upper East Side residents about smoke and dust, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Who’s on the Line? Increasingly, Caller ID Is Duped
text: Caller ID has been celebrated as a defense against unwelcome phone pitches. But it is backfiring.

headline: Old, Bald and Still Kicking
text: ALLEN PARK, Mich. — The biggest shock for Jason Hanson during his first N.F.L. training camp was not the size or the speed of his new teammates. It was their age.

headline: Wednesday: Record Producer Brian
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Ian “I Only Look Innocent” Livengood, he of the friendly face and gentle demeanor, is the kind of constructor who always makes me forget that there will usually be some sort of twist in his puzzles. Today is no different, as I had to make my way down to the payoff at 55 Across before I truly understood what was going on.

headline: Council Speaker Hears Sharp Debate on Wage Proposal
text: The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, under pressure from both sides, carefully questioned supporters and opponents at a hearing on Tuesday about a proposed law that would raise wages for workers in city-subsidized developments.

headline: Spirited Foreign Policy Debate Includes a Test of Gingrich’s Rise
text: WASHINGTON — The Republican presidential candidates highlighted their party’s lack of a single national security vision a decade after the Sept. 11 attacks, differing on Tuesday night over the pace of withdrawal from Afghanistan, aid to Pakistan and, in an exchange that could resonate dangerously for Newt Gingrich, what to do with illegal immigrants in the United States.

headline: UConn, Seeking a Lift, Goes to Its New No. 23
text: HARTFORD — It would become, in the words of Stanford Coach Tara VanDerveer, a heavyweight basketball fight. But in the first five minutes hardly anyone had scored a point, much less landed a threatening punch.

headline: Republican Might Quit Labor Board
text: The National Labor Relations Board, the subject of particularly intense partisan sniping this year, could soon be completely paralyzed.

headline: Hezbollah Holds Lebanese C.I.A. Informants, Officials Say
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Hezbollah, the Lebanese Shiite militant group, has identified and captured several people it accuses of being informants and spies for the Central Intelligence Agency, according to a Lebanese security official and news agency reports quoting Hezbollah officials and current and former American officials.

headline: Former Stars Cheer New Rules on Hits to the Head
text: Two former N.H.L. scoring stars whose careers were curtailed by multiple concussions said Tuesday that the league’s campaign to curtail hits to the head with suspensions and stiff fines will only benefit Sidney Crosby.

headline: College Live Blog Bar-Hopping
text: This week’s schedule features many of the top rivalries in the country: Ohio State-Michigan, Alabama-Auburn, Georgia-Georgia Tech and Ole Miss-Mississippi State, to name a few. Teams will be playing for assorted bells, cups, trophies, jugs and an old oaken bucket. And while the fans in the stands figure to be more rabid than usual when their team’s rival comes to town, we’re expecting college watch parties across the land to kick it up a notch as well.

headline: Billboard Called Anti-Semitic Is Quickly Pulled
text: A billboard promoting a budget brand of vodka was taken down Tuesday amid a firestorm of criticism that its advertising slogan was anti-Semitic.

headline: Eli Hurvitz, Founder of Pharmaceutical Giant Teva, Dies at 79
text: JERUSALEM — Eli Hurvitz, who began his career washing lab equipment at a drug company and went on to build Teva Pharmaceutical Industries into the largest generic drug maker in the world, died on Monday night. He was 79.

headline: One of My Guests Does Not Drink. What Can I Substitute for Alcohol in Recipes?
text: Q.

headline: George Gallup Jr., of Polling Family, Dies at 81
text: George Gallup Jr., who led the firm that his father made all but synonymous with polling and expanded it to become a barometer of Americans’ views on religion as well as their political attitudes, died on Monday in Princeton, N.J. He was 81 and lived in Princeton.

headline: Automatic Military Cuts May Stand in Congress
text: WASHINGTON—Mere seconds after the leaders of a joint Congressional committee announced their failure to reach a deficit deal, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee announced he would try to undo the consequences.

headline: A Corner of American Outreach Has Few Visitors, and Plenty of Dust
text: BAGHDAD — In a nook of the library at Baghdad University, sturdy histories of the American Revolution and the Vietnam War line up next to Alexis de Tocqueville and John Updike. Paperbacks from Tom Clancy and Michael Connelly, even Judy Blume, dangle guilty pleasures. And, as if to close the loop on Americana, baseball makes a token appearance with a copy of “Farm Team,” a novel about a boy who builds a ball field in a cow pasture.

headline: Pepper Spray’s Fallout, From Crowd Control to Mocking Images
text: Some women carry it in their purses in a pink, lipstick-shaped container. Hikers use it to deter bears. People in most states can buy a small canister of it on a quick-release key ring on Amazon.com for $7.07.

headline: Danielle Mitterrand, Former First Lady of France, Is Dead at 87
text: Danielle Mitterrand, the widow of former President François Mitterrand of France, who pushed beyond stereotypical notions of a first lady to champion leftist causes, once kissing Fidel Castro on the steps of the Élysée Palace, died on Tuesday in Paris. She was 87.

headline: Occupy Los Angeles Camp Is Allowed to Stay, for Now
text: LOS ANGELES — While Occupy protesters in other cities have been rousted from their tents in early-morning police raids or doused with pepper spray, the tent encampment encircling City Hall in Los Angeles has so far been allowed to stay.
