headline: Commercial Colleges Broke Rules in U.S. Inquiry
text: Most of the commercial colleges tested by undercover investigators posing as students allowed them to enroll with fake high school graduation credentials, according to a report released Tuesday by the Government Accountability Office, an auditing arm of Congress.

headline: NYT Front Page for 11/23/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 11/23/2011

headline: German Debt Auction Weighs on Markets
text: Stocks in the United States and Europe declined and the dollar rose sharply on Wednesday after a German bond auction disappointed investors and new data pointed to continued uncertainty in the global economy.

headline: Discussing Israel, Detainees’ Rights, Terrorism and a Different Birth Certificate
text: During Tuesday night’s debate, Mitt Romney implied that the Obama administration has not shown that it cares about Israel.

headline: Turkey Tips: Trussing
text: Melissa Clark demonstrates an easy way to truss a turkey.

headline: Arizona: Details Emerge in Abuse Case
text: The older sister of a missing 5-year-old girl from Glendale told the police that her mother kept the girl, Jhessye Shockley, locked in a bedroom closet and that she had cuts and bruises on her face and body. According to a court document filed Tuesday in connection with the arrest of Jerice Hunter, the missing girl’s mother, on child abuse charges, the older sister, who is 13, also told investigators that Jhessye had looked like a “zombie,” had not been seen in the apartment well before she was reported missing on Oct. 11 and that the closet smelled, prompting the mother to clean it. The police said Monday that they suspected that Jhessye was dead and that Ms. Hunter, who has denied any involvement in her daughter’s disappearance, had played a role in it.

headline: Montana: Grizzlies Remain Protected
text: The government cannot go ahead with its plan to remove grizzly bears in the Greater Yellowstone region from the Endangered Species Act, an appellate court said Tuesday. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has argued since 2007 that grizzly bears and their habitat in the greater Yellowstone ecosystem have recovered enough that bears could be placed under state management, which is generally less restrictive. But the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals found for conservationists who argued that the government had not adequately considered the impact of the decline of Whitebark Pines, a major food source for the bears.

headline: Turkey Tips: Roasting
text: Melissa Clark offers tips for roasting the bird. Correction: This video gives an incorrect roasting time for the turkey. It should be 12 to 15 minutes per pound, not 20 minutes per pound.

headline: Turkey Tips: Taking It Out of the Oven
text: Melissa Clark checks the temperature of her turkey and pulls it out of the oven.

headline: Staying Trim When Fat Runs in the Family
text: Just in time for Thanksgiving, a major new study offers some hopeful news about fat and fate, as well as about the consequences of the choices we make.

headline: Economic Dislocation
text: Just over a week ago, Glenn Hubbard, the dean of Columbia University’s business school and an economic adviser to Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign, gave a pair of interviews on economic policy – one to a liberal writer, Ezra Klein of the Washington Post; the other to a conservative, Jim Pethokoukis of the American Enterprise Institute.

headline: Poll Finds Religion Is Early Drag on Romney
text: Mitt Romney’s Mormon faith will most likely cost him support in the primaries, but even Republicans with reservations about his religion would rally to his side in a general election against President Obama, according to a poll released Wednesday.

headline: Republicans Debate National Security
text: The candidates differed over the pace of withdrawal from Afghanistan, aid to Pakistan and what to do with illegal immigrants in the United States.

headline: Gingrich, Immigration and ‘What Would Reagan Do?’
text: Newt Gingrich was having what seemed to be a pretty strong debate on Tuesday night before being asked a question about immigration policy. He suggested that illegal immigrants should be evaluated on a case-by-case basis and that some who have been in the United States for a long time should be allowed to stay, while others should be deported.

headline: Champions League Wednesday Preview: Apoel on Brink of Advancing
text: When it comes to minnows, Apoel of Cyprus is about as far down the food chain as possible in European soccer. The Nicosia-based club is unbeaten in Group G and needs only a draw at Zenit St. Petersburg on Wednesday to advance to the knockout stage, which begins early next year. In Group H, Barcelona and A.C. Milan will battle for the top spot at Stadio Giuseppe Meazza in Italy. In Group F, Arsenal faces a tricky match against visiting Borussia Dortmund, which knocked off Bayern Munich last weekend in the German Bundesliga. And in Group E, Chelsea is unbeaten in the group stage but is coming off a difficult Premier League loss to Liverpool last weekend ahead of its game at Bayer Leverkusen.

headline: The Caucus | Debate Wrap-Up
text: Nov. 22, 2011 - Michael D. Shear on some of the highlights from the Republican foreign policy debate, including an exchange on immigration that might hinder the rising candidacy of Newt Gingrich.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
text: Seven passengers died and another 12 were injured after two train cars belonging to the Howrah-Dehradun Express caught fire in the early hours of Tuesday when it was passing through the Giridih district in the state of Jharkhand. Two 5-year old girls and an Australian national were among the dead, The Indian Express reports. Authorities are still investigating the cause of the fire.Already facing stiff criticism from the opposition, Congress party leader and federal Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee on Tuesday turned to Left party leaders to prevent the looming standoff in Parliament over rising prices. Left leaders had issued a notice for an adjournment motion on high prices in the Parliament yesterday, which had stalled parliamentary proceedings. During the meeting, Mr. Mukherjee is believed to have warned the leaders about the consequences for the government in the event of a vote following the adjournment motion, The Hindu reports. A discussion on prices is likely to be held on Wednesday, the federal parliamentary affairs minister said yesterday.

headline: Thune Endorses Romney
text: UPDATED 12:02 DES MOINES – Senator John Thune of South Dakota endorsed Mitt Romney’s bid for the Republican presidential nomination on Wednesday, making him the second conservative United States senator to declare support for Mr. Romney’s candidacy this week.

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 23, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Nov. 23, 1943 | United States Captures Tarawa and Makin Atolls From Japan
text: On Nov. 23, 1943, as World War II raged, United States forces seized control of the Tarawa atoll from the Japanese; a day later it secured the nearby atoll of Makin.

headline: Chaos Builds in the Streets of Cairo as a Truce Fails
text: CAIRO — The outskirts of Tahrir Square, the iconic landmark of Egypt’s revolution, plunged into chaos on Wednesday, after attempts by the Egyptian military, religious clerics and doctors failed to stanch a fifth day of fighting that has posed the greatest crisis to the country since the fall of President Hosni Mubarak in February.

headline: Failure on Deficit Reduction Plan
text: WHO are the leaders of a Congressional committee charged with cutting the deficit?

headline: The Murdochs Hug It Out
text: The writer of “Tropic Thunder” imagines a succession squabble, Rupert-style.

headline: The Dwindling Power of a College Degree
text: The 2012 presidential election can be seen as offering a choice between two visions of how to return us to this country’s golden age — from roughly 1945 to around 1973 — when working life was most secure for many Americans, particularly white, middle-class men. President Obama said his jobs plan was for people who believed “if you worked hard and played by the rules, you would be rewarded.” Mitt Romney explained his goal was to restore hope for “folks who grew up believing that if they played by the rules . . . they would have the chance to build a good life.” But these days, many workers have lost a near guarantee on a decent wage and benefits — and their careers are likely to have much more volatility (great years; bad years; confusing, mediocre years) than their parents’ ever did. So when did the rules change?

headline: The Machine That Makes You Musical
text: In a dimly lighted conference room in the Palo Alto, Calif., offices of Smule, a maker of music apps, Ge Wang was sitting in a meeting with his colleagues, humming, singing and making odd whooshing noises into the microphone of an iPad, checking the screen, and then pounding fugues of code into an attached laptop. Poking at his devices, he reminded me of a child obliviously amusing himself while the grown-ups natter on around him. Nobody else in the meeting seemed to notice Wang’s behavior as they listened to a debriefing about recent updates to Smule’s Mini Magic Piano app.

headline: A Whirling Document of Turkish Culture
text: Before the Bursa Photo Fest in October,  Lens called the event “a bold attempt to make Turkey a center for international photography.” Last week, a project spearheaded by Istanbul’s Zaman Daily Newspaper turned the country into the focus for international photographers.

headline: Overlooked and Unheard, Ahead of the Mumbai Attacks
text: The United States government had several chances to nab David Coleman Headley, the American who helped plan the Mumbai attacks, Indian officials did not react to several alerts and a French investigative judge’s long-running warnings about Lashkar-e-Taiba were ignored, according to new reports.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 23, 2011

headline: Pakistan Quickly Names New Envoy to U.S.
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan quickly appointed a new ambassador to the United States on Wednesday, a day after the previous envoy was forced out over allegations that he sought American help in reining in the country’s powerful military, which now appears to be solidifying its role in managing Pakistan’s foreign affairs and national security policy.

headline: What Are You Grateful For?
text: Psychologists say that being conscious of who and what you are grateful for has real benefits, from sleeping better to being kinder and less aggressive. What are you grateful for? If your gratitude involves people in your life, have you shared your thanks with them?

headline: Yemen’s Leader Agrees to End 3-Decade Rule
text: SANA, Yemen — After more than three decades of autocratic rule, President Ali Abdullah Saleh signed an agreement on Wednesday that immediately transferred power to his vice president, bowing to unrelenting street protests and raising hopes for an end to a political crisis that brought this impoverished nation to the brink of collapse.

The surprise star of the show may be the Z-Car I automobile, a nonfunctioning three-wheeler commissioned by a gallery owner, Kenny Schachter.

headline: Young Adults’ Coverage May Cost Parents Even More
text: A popular part of the federal health care legislation that allows young people to stay on their parents’ insurance coverage until they are 26 is prompting some creative pricing by employers who are turning to new strategies to charge their workers extra for children on their benefit plans.

headline: So You Want to Start a Business
text: People start businesses for all kinds of reasons. Some expect to get rich, some want to be their own boss, some want to follow their passion and some want to control their own destiny (or at least try). Many have one thing in common; they fail. More than half, depending on whose number you use and how much time you give it.

headline: Time for a Pop Pop Quiz!

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 23
text: The Tribune Company, which is trying to emerge from bankruptcy protection, agreed to pay its former chief executive, Randy Michaels, $675,000 in a settlement stemming from his abrupt resignation from the company last year, The Chicago Tribune reported. The company will also cover $50,000 in Mr. Michaels’s legal fees. Mr. Michaels resigned under pressure, following reporting in The New York Times that detailed numerous instances of outlandish, often sexual behavior by Mr. Michaels and other top executives. The Tribune reported that he had demanded $900,000, the pro-rated portion of his 2010 management bonus, arguing that he “was effectively ‘terminated without cause,’ which would trigger the payment under terms of the bonus plan.” The payment needs to be approved by a bankruptcy court judge.In Tuesday night’s Republican presidential debate on CNN, which was devoted to national security issues, The Caucus live blog took note of the higher profile of Representative Ron Paul, the libertarian from Texas, who often can be hard to spot at these seemingly weekly encounters. As Trip Gabriel wrote for The Caucus, Mr. Paul’s campaign “had claimed after the last debate hosted by CBS News that he got only 90 seconds of air time,” but Tuesday night he played a more central role, serving as a dramatic foil to his rivals. He clashed with Newt Gingrich over the the Patriot Act, and Rick Santorum over profiling of travelers, including Muslims.

headline: Wednesday Reading: When Caller I.D. Becomes Fake I.D.
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Europeans Clear Western Digital Deal for Hitachi Unit

headline: The Tussle Between Energy and Ecology Moves to the Australian Outback

headline: Me and My Man Shed
text: In a world where even “man caves” — the dimly lit redoubts where men are left to tinker and socialize with other men — are falling prey to D.I.Y. home improvement television shows, two men on the South Shore of Long Island have found shelter for their creature comforts in the most unlikely of places.

headline: A Sullen March Toward Winter
text: There are strange days on the streets of New York. A buoyant autumn, in which occupy protests became almost a carnival and New Yorkers gloried in cacophonous complaint, has devolved into a sullen march toward winter.

headline: JPMorgan Said to Buy MF Global Stake in London Metal Exchange
text: LONDON — JPMorgan Chase has agreed to buy a 4.7 stake in the London Metal Exchange for $38.9 million from the bankrupt brokerage MF Global, according to people with knowledge of the deal.

headline: Group Led by K.K.R. to Buy Samson for $7.2 Billion
text: A consortium led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed on Wednesday to buy the Samson Investment Company, one of the largest privately held energy companies in the country, for about $7.2 billion. It would be one of the biggest leveraged buyouts since the financial crisis.

headline: The Unintended Consequences of Tech Stock Repurchases
text: My colleague Nelson Schwartz has a story in Tuesday’s paper about share buyback programs, and how companies can sacrifice their growth when they repurchase their own shares. The way this story has worked out recently in the high technology sector makes the story particularly timely.

headline: Student Rumors Triggered Long Island Cheating Investigation
text: The SAT cheating scandal in Nassau County has grown to 20 arrests and half a dozen schools. Prosecutors said that it began with student rumors, which led school officials to examine inconsistencies in performance. Some people argue that it is not a criminal matter and that the College Board should have handled it administratively. What do you think?

headline: New York Film Critics Circle Will Vote Without Seeing ‘Extremely Loud’
text: In an effort to be the first critics group to announce its picks for the best films of 2011, the New York Film Critics Circle will be leaving at least one possible contender off its list: the film adaptation of Jonathan Safran Foer’s novel “Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close.”

headline: Patent for Amgen Drug May Undercut Health Care Plan
text: Amgen said Tuesday that a new patent had been granted that could protect its big-selling drug Enbrel from generic competition for 17 more years, a development that could undermine some of the savings contemplated in the federal health care legislation.

headline: Microsoft Signs Nondisclosure Agreement With Yahoo
text: 8:03 p.m. | Updated

headline: Tailgating Recipes: Mini Mile-High Apple Pies
text: Thanksgiving weekend is on the way, so we thought this week’s tailgate party needed a little holiday flavor. For that, we turned back to Celia Erickson, executive chef and member of the class of 2012 at Cornell’s School of Hotel Administration.

headline: Week 12 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Harbaugh vs. Harbaugh
text: Thursday night’s game is intriguing because the two teams are so similar, right down to the DNA of the head coaches. The 49ers visit the Ravens in a contest of middling offenses and strong defenses. Here’s how the two teams stack up in the core facets of team efficiency:

headline: When Is a State’s Right Not Right? When Big Donors Are at Stake
text: Two questions come to mind when I think about states’ rights. First, why are we still having this conversation 150 years after the Civil War? And then, what principles govern its modern-day proponents? That second question might just be harder to answer than the first.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Times: Follow-ups on two raging New York controversies: The city health department insists it did not order the end of the venerable pots of free cheese at Sardi’s bars; the restaurant, begging to differ, says the communal snack is history. And Starbucks baristas who locked bathrooms out of disgust with sloppy customers face a new antagonist: their company, which has ordered the restrooms reopened. … — Patrick FarrellThe Local/East Village: … Also, news of two breaking battles: Neighbors complain of the smell of rancid bacon from the new IHOP. (At times it’s so pungent, one said, that it clouds her thinking.) And DNAInfo.com reports that a West Side community board has told the city that the new Tavern on the Green should be a casual restaurant, after an East Side board said they wanted a fancy one. — Nick Fox

headline: Sandwiches After a Vegetarian Thanksgiving
text: The post-Thanksgiving sandwich is a favorite tradition for eating up leftover turkey. But what about the rest of the leftovers?

headline: Meyer Takes Time to Think About Ohio State Job
text: Ohio State met with Urban Meyer on Wednesday, and the possibility that he will become the football coach there next season is close to becoming a reality. Still, the final word on Meyer and Ohio State will not come until after Saturday, when the Buckeyes play Michigan in their final game of the regular season.

headline: More Students Charged in Long Island SAT Cheating Case
text: The Metro and education reporters Jenny Anderson and Winnie Hu provide an update in Wednesday’s Times on the Long Island SAT fraud investigations, which began two months ago after a college freshman was caught impersonating high school students on test day and sitting for the exam under their names.

headline: How ‘The Sound of Music’ Became One of Salzburg’s Favorite Things
text: More than a half-century after “The Sound of Music” immortalized the von Trapp family’s flight from Austria on stage and screen, the first-ever Salzburg production of that Rodgers and Hammerstein musical has made audiences (if not the hills themselves) come alive with approval, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Cease-and-Desist for a Sculptor on the Shore
text: Four Fridays ago, Doug Schwartz spent the morning as he has most Fridays for more than a decade: stacking rocks and bits of ruin into pillar-like sculptures on a desolate stretch of the South Shore of Staten Island.

headline: A Holiday Crash Course in Manners
text: My kids have terrible table manners.

headline: Outward Bound
text: The next vacation fix for been-there-done-that travelers.

headline: Tata Empire Chooses a New Chairman
text: HYDERABAD, India — The largest Indian business group, Tata Sons, on Wednesday appointed an insider whose family owns about 18 percent of the company to succeed its longtime chairman, Ratan N. Tata.

headline: Tip of the Week: Cleaning Up the Desktop
text: Desktops can get quickly littered with stray icons for files and folders, but there is a quick way to tidy things up. In both Windows 7 and Mac OS X, just right-click on the desktop (or hold down the Control key while clicking with a one button Mac mouse) to see your options on the contextual menu.

headline: Kicking Off an Animated Holiday Season
text: Thanksgiving and football: firmly established. Thanksgiving and animation: coming on fast.

headline: Mobile Money for the Next 2 Billion People
text: Mobile phones are probably the most successfully deployed technology in history, effectively reaching more people than computers, electricity or plumbing in less than 15 years. Now they may start taking over money.

headline: In a Small Texas Town, a Fight Over Late Drinks
text: GUN BARREL CITY, Tex. — The American political divide is often characterized as red versus blue. But some of the most intense political battles in small-town Texas are fought on a far older division: wet versus dry.

headline: Daily Report: Can You Trust Caller ID?
text: Plenty of people rely on a quick glance at their phone’s caller ID screen to decide whether a call is worth picking up. But as Matt Richtel reports in Wednesday’s Times, caller ID is not foolproof. Regulators in many states have been hearing increasing numbers of complaints about spoofing: the name on the screen looks innocuous or even alarming, like “F.B.I.,” but answering the call reveals a telemarketer on the other end.

headline: Questions Over Whether Terror Suspects’ Aid in Inquiries Was Voluntary
text: The government’s disclosure of a plot to assassinate the Saudi ambassador to the United States last month came with some reassuring news: the suspect, an Iranian-American, was in custody, had confessed and had provided valuable intelligence on Iran’s role in supporting the plan.

headline: How to Really Tell Time
text: Impatient children have been known to wonder: “What’s the difference between ‘in a moment’ and ‘in a little while’?”

headline: Checking Eligibility for U.S. Mortgage Refinance Program
text: Last month the federal government announced changes aimed at making it easier for many borrowers who owe more on their home loans than their houses are worth to refinance into lower-cost mortgages.

headline: Russia Elevates Warning About U.S. Missile-Defense Plan in Europe
text: MOSCOW — Russia will deploy its own missiles and could withdraw from the New Start nuclear arms reduction treaty if the United States moves forward with its plans for a missile-defense system in Europe, President Dmitri A. Medvedev warned on Wednesday.

headline: Thanksgiving Is Un-American
text: Think, for a minute, about what happened on the original Thanksgiving. (Yes, I know that there are doubts about what really happened, but never mind.)

headline: Is Tebow More Mobile Than Vick? (And Other Questions from Readers)
text: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answers readers’ questions:

text: Here:

headline: Harbaugh Infuses the 49ers With His Will to Win, at All Costs
text: Can a player’s career be defined by a single play?  In Jim Harbaugh’s case, the traits that made him a successful player and now a head coach can be traced to a game on Sept. 23, 1996.

headline: A Gigantic Scam
text: That’s pretty much what Andrew Haldane, the executive director for financial stability at the Bank of England, is calling a large part of modern finance:

headline: Appeals Court Keeps Yellowstone Grizzlies on Threatened List
text: The government may not yet go ahead with its plan to remove grizzly bears in the Greater Yellowstone region from the endangered species list because of the Endangered Species Act, an appellate court found on Tuesday.

headline: Seeing Things | The Newest Branch
text: The designer David Wiseman’s delicate site-specific installations, which include a canopy of cherry blossoms, a cascade of lilies of the valley, and sinuous wisteria vines, are most often commissioned for intimate private spaces. Until now, that is. With the opening of the new West Hollywood Library this fall, Wiseman’s work goes public for the first time.

headline: Report of the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry
text: The study on Bahrain’s upheaval marks the most comprehensive document on security force actions during any of the revolts that have flared across the Arab world this year.

headline: Thanksgiving Videos
text: To get you in the spirit.

headline: Week 12 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: The Harbaughs’ Sibling Rivalry
text: The Brothers Harbaugh don’t quite spark the same moral and ethical questions that the Brothers Karamazov did, although little brother Jim’s emotionally charged postgame handshake with Detroit’s Jim Schwartz this season could have been a nice plot device in a sprawling Russian epic.

headline: All Shook Up? Try All Boxed Up
text: Are collectors and music nerds now the only people buying albums? Apparently that’s the judgment behind many of this year’s gargantuan boxed sets.

headline: Clues to Raymond Chandler’s Life and Career in Sale of His Books and Papers
text: “The very nicest thing Hollywood can possibly think of to say to a writer,” Raymond Chandler wrote, “is that he is too good to be only a writer.” Chandler may have been only a writer himself, but he was a singularly influential one, whose body of work includes the classic detective novels “The Big Sleep” and “Farewell, My Lovely” and contributions to the screenplays for “Double Indemnity” (written with Billy Wilder) and “Strangers on a Train.” Now a sale of books and papers from Chandler’s personal collection offers a unique look at his legacy and literary influence, not to mention his uneasy relationship with that “showman’s paradise,” as he called it, known as Hollywood.

headline: Why Not Pull the Trigger on Greek Default Swaps?
text: The question about why credit-default swaps written on Greek debt will not be triggered by the “voluntary” exchange of private debt that is in the works has been the subject of much recent commentary but little deep analysis.

headline: Man Cleared of 1978 Newark Killings; He Says Doubts Will Linger
text: NEWARK — Lee Anthony Evans, a mason, plumber and father charged last year with committing five cold-case murders that no one could prove ever happened, turned around and went back to his old life on Wednesday with the same scowl he wore at his arrest.

headline: Health Tips From the Thankgiving Help Line
text: The Dining section has been fielding questions from readers about Thanksgiving quandaries, including health-related concerns among holiday diners.

headline: Continental Drift in Manchester
text: From their lofty perch at the top of the English Premier League, Manchester City and Manchester United have a combined record of 20-1-3, a gaudy combined goal differential of plus-48. But after Tuesday’s games in the UEFA Champions League, both teams from England’s northwest are in danger of not progressing past the group stage of the top continental club tournament.

headline: From a Military Wife, Words on War
text: In 2001, I was standing on a street, watching a plane hit a tower and watching bodies, the bodies of people who were jumping out of windows, watching them fall through the sky and down. I ran that day, away from the fiery towers and dust. And in the days that followed, I ran away from the rubble, away from New York City — all the way to another state, where I would meet a man who was in the military, who would become my husband.

headline: 36 Hours in Porto, Portugal
text: Portugal’s second-largest metropolis has a jam-packed new nightlife district and a blossoming creative scene.

headline: The Art of Destruction
text: YAFRAN, Libya — In a country where creativity was stifled to ensure the pre-eminence of one man, art can be the best revenge. Inside the gutted shell of a building that once housed a Qaddafi-regime intelligence unit, the paint of a new mural of a tree whose roots are feeding on the blood of fallen rebel fighters is drying on the wall. The house was half-destroyed in fighting between Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces and the rebels who brought him down — and that’s exactly the way the artist Belgassem Grada hopes it will stay.

headline: Torture Used on Protesters in Bahrain, Report Says
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Security forces in Bahrain used excessive force, including torture and the extraction of forced confessions, against detainees who were arrested in a sweeping crackdown early this year during protests that deeply polarized the country, according to a report  by an independent commission that investigated the uprising and its aftermath.

headline: For Penn State, a Strange Idea of Normal
text: Now that the tide of national outrage has ebbed, moved on to places like Davis, Calif., the atmosphere at Penn State has begun to change. Sure, there are still stories of new victims of the former assistant coach Jerry Sandusky reportedly coming forward and harrowing tales of alleged victims already identified. But they are hardly enough to counter a stronger wave, the pull toward everything getting back to “normal” at the university.

headline: 36 Hours in Porto, Portugal
text: FOR years, Porto’s motto was, in essence, “You’ve tried the wine; now try the city!” But these days Portugal’s second-largest metropolis — an attractively faded hillside city of venerable town houses and Baroque churches — no longer needs to coast on the reputation of its famous digestif. A jam-packed new night-life district is taking shape, and a blossoming creative scene features everything from an upstart design center to the avant-garde Rem Koolhaas-designed Casa de Música, a stunning concert space. And there’s great news for oenophiles as well. With the Douro region’s emergence as a hotbed of prize-winning red wines — not just port — Porto (also known as Oporto) can now intoxicate you with myriad vintages, new ambitious restaurants and even wine-themed hotels.

headline: Winter in Moscow
text: The colder months don’t stop the city from enjoying itself. Just bundle up, go ice skating and follow the locals into bustling shops and restaurants.

headline: It’s Mild Cognitive Impairment. Now What?
text: How would you react to a diagnosis of mild cognitive impairment — memory problems that allow you to continue normal daily activities, but presage an increased likelihood of developing Alzheimer’s disease within a few years?

headline: Giving Thanks for Teachers
text: As you prepare for the Thanksgiving holiday, remember the teachers in your life. Post a memory or shout-out here, or participate in the project by public radio's StoryCorps to track down former teachers as part of a yearlong National Teachers Initiative.

headline: The Competition Between Solar and Nuclear Energy Moves to Mars
text: NASA’s last two Mars rovers, Spirit and Opportunity, launched in 2003 and carried solar panels, but the new Mars rover that the space agency is scheduled to launch on Saturday morning from Cape Canaveral uses nuclear power, a fact that did not escape the partisans of nuclear power here on Earth.

headline: Does Trussing Make the Turkey Cook Faster?
text: Q.

headline: In 1962, a Thanksgiving Stunner for Lombardi’s Packers
text: The undefeated and seemingly unstoppable defending champions from Green Bay sweep down into Detroit, where a determined bunch of Lions await.

headline: Moscow in the Snow
text: THEY’RE like mountain goats, these women. Skittering up, over and around the ice sheets and the snow slicks on every sidewalk in central Moscow, their spike-heeled boots somehow finding purchase on the sharp, crusty surface. Some of them are texting while they do it.

headline: G+ Hangout | November 22, 2011
text: Jenna Wortham and Sam Grobart discuss technology, social networking and journalism with The Times’s Google+ community in their first video hangout.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Editor: Re “What Makes an Airline Family Friendly?” (In Transit blog, Nov. 4), I travel with my 3-year-old daughter a few times a year and I always bring snacks, toys and books for her and something to drink. I’m not clear why parents expect the airlines to provide them with things for their child that they can easily bring from home. I do feel sympathy for the mother separated from her 2- and 5-year-old, though. That is sheer lunacy!

headline: It’s Not the Carriers, It’s the Kids
text: HORRIBLE. Annoying. Distasteful. Miserable. These are a few of the words used by readers to describe traveling with children — whether their own or someone else’s — on planes in response to my Nov. 6 article, “Are We There Yet? When Families Fly.”

headline: Where to Find Treasure in Trash
text: AMY HUGHES turns junk into treasure.

headline: Hands Off, Mom and Dad. This Tablet Is for Children.
text: Created specifically for children, Nabi is a $200 Android tablet from Fuhu that doesn’t kid around when it comes to things like the ability to plug into a HD screen, by way of a mini-HDMI port, or a multitouch screen that plays “real” apps like Cut the Rope and Fruit Ninja.

headline: Downtown Beirut Finds Its Pulse
text: A new city center is emerging with a number of alluring new independent art galleries, fashion showrooms, stylish restaurants and cocktail lounges.

headline: Oakland Gets a New ‘There’
text: ON a recent warm afternoon in the Uptown neighborhood of Oakland the streets were alive with activity. Crowds participating in Art Murmur, a monthly art walk, spilled out of galleries like Johansson Projects (2300 Telegraph Avenue; johanssonprojects.com) and Hatch Gallery (492 23rd Street; hatchgallery.org). It’s hard to imagine that this area, just north of downtown Oakland, was abandoned and plagued with crime just a few years ago. Now it bustles with hip bars, places to hear music and interesting restaurants that have even lured San Franciscans across the bay.

headline: More Than a Road Trip
text: While other photo collectives have done fine group work, Luceo‘s  project on rural America, “Few And Far Between,” stands out.

headline: On Eve of 2011 Finale, Formula One Faces Problems From a Strange Land Called America
text: Formula One, the open-wheel race series, subsists on high drama. But after the 2011 season concludes with the Brazilian Grand Prix on Sunday in São Paulo, off-track intrigues from a land long shunned by the sport, the United States, await reconciliation by race officials and teams.

headline: White House Turkeys Walk the Walk, Talk the Talk
text: WASHINGTON — A president’s work is never done.

headline: Haciendas and Pulque in Tlaxcala, Mexico,

headline: What Can I Do to Lighten Up Thanksgiving?
text: What can I do to lighten up Thanksgiving dinner? — John M., Overland Park, Kan.

headline: Di Fara Pizza Reopens After Passing Inspection
text: The popular Brooklyn restaurant Di Fara Pizza reopened around noon on Wednesday, a week after the city health department closed it for 67 sanitary violations, including mice and fly infestation.

headline: Amid Scandal, Chairman of Troubled Lender Will Quit
text: HYDERABAD, India — SKS Microfinance, a once-admired lender to poor Indian women that has had a stunning fall from grace in the last year, said Wednesday that its executive chairman, Vikram K. Akula, would step down from his post.

headline: An Old-World Escape Near Mexico City
text: I ARRIVED in Tlaxcala, the small capital of Mexico’s smallest state, on the Sunday before Mexican Independence Day, Sept. 16. The town was overlaid with banners and lights in the red, green and white of the national flag. At dusk, there were celebratory firecrackers and, in the morning, the cloudless sky was a piercing aquamarine.

headline: Pimp My Gun
text: It’s illegal to import high-powered, semiautomatic weapons unless they are recognizably for “sporting purposes.”

headline: For American Samoa, a Win Ignites a World Cup Dream
text: APIA, Samoa — American Samoa had played 30 men’s soccer matches since starting international play in 1994. It had lost all 30, by a combined score of 229-12, and was tied for last in the FIFA world rankings.

headline: Q. and A. With Pat LaFontaine on N.H.L.’s Progress on Head Injuries
text: Pat LaFontaine spoke Monday about Sidney Crosby’s return from the concussion that kept Crosby out for 10½ months for an article in today’s Times. But LaFontaine, the scoring star of the 1980s and ’90s whose career was marked by a series of concussions, spoke at much greater length and depth on the subject.

headline: My Brother Owes Me $25,000. Do I Ask Him for the Money Before or After We Carve the Turkey?
text: Q.

headline: Finding the Cheap Gaps in the Holiday Calendar
text: Looking for inexpensive holiday-time getaways? Go for the dead zones: the weeks between Thanksgiving and Christmas, or right after New Year’s.

headline: Links for Thanksgiving Eve
text: First, the really bad news: Spain’s famously long lunches appear to be under threat. Everything else pales next to that.

headline: Our Teenage Photographer of Teenage Lust
text: Please meet last week’s cover photographer, Olivia Bee. She’s 17, and it’s a challenge to describe her without using the word “wunderkind.” She started taking photos at 11, quickly established a devoted cult following and has since exhibited her work all around the world. Olivia has an exceptional way of capturing the sweet side of being a teenager. Her photos are romantic and innocent-seeming, even when the kids in the pictures are doing not-so-innocent things. So of course we thought she’d be perfect to shoot our cover story about sex-positive sex education. The concept was to illustrate teenage lust without actually showing anything. No faces and nothing explicit, just gestures.

headline: Drake’s Rise and Adele’s Record on the Album Charts
text: This week on the pop music charts, Drake has a big opening and Adele breaks a record set by Michael Jackson.

headline: The Supper Clubs of Wisconsin
text: From Madison to Milwaukee, these old-fashioned fine-dining establishments are still going strong.

headline: In Wisconsin, Supper Clubs Open to All
text: IN the era of the eyedropper-wielding cocktail artiste, I take pleasure in the fact that there are still guys like Tom Kelly around. Mr. Kelly, the longtime bartender at the Al-Gen Dinner Club in Rhinelander, Wis., has a neatly trimmed gray mustache, wears a shamrock tie pin and makes what I will unreservedly call the perfect gin martini. It is served limpid and glacially cold with two plump olives (or, if you’re feeling particularly old-school, two pickled mushrooms) and a minimum of conversation. “I’m just part of the real estate,” he said genially when asked how long he’s been at the job.

headline: Back to the ’50s, Trying to Escape Freedom’s Pitfalls
text: “I’VE never understood why slide shows were supposed to be this terrible thing to be put through,” said the playwright Jordan Harrison, recalling the prevideo age. “I thought they were endlessly fascinating — people would put in this carousel, and I would see their cruise to Capri, and there would be photos of the menu with their oysters Rockefeller.”

headline: Heel Height Times Tweets?
text: THE 1920s notion of a “hemline index,” in which the economist George Taylor posited that skirt lengths rise and fall in relation to the economy, suggests that fashion is socially determined. In a modern twist, a report about the direction of high heels, issued by I.B.M., proposes that fashion can now be determined through social media.

headline: As Investors Flee Groupon, Outlook for I.P.O.’s Darkens
text: Unable to break a three-day slide, shares of Groupon tumbled again on Wednesday, as more investors dumped shares.

headline: James Murdoch Has Quit British Newspaper Boards
text: LONDON — James Murdoch, widely seen as the heir apparent to the News Corporation global media business of his octogenarian father, Rupert, has stepped down as director of two subsidiaries that publish Murdoch-owned newspapers in Britain, the company said on Wednesday. It was the first publicly acknowledged adjustment in the younger Mr. Murdoch’s newspaper responsibilities since the British tabloid phone hacking scandal that has enveloped the company.

headline: Himalayan Highway
text: A frozen river becomes a highway connecting Zanskar’s few dozen villages to the rest of the world during a two-month window in the heart of the Himalayan winter.

headline: A Himalayan Highway, but Only in Winter
text: WE had been walking on the slick, frozen surface of the Zanskar River for 20 minutes when Urgain Dorjay, our lead guide, motioned for us to halt. He squinted up at the rock face, uncharacteristically tense as a voice called out from above.

headline: Can Record Shops Make Themselves Heard on Black Friday?
text: When Record Store Day began in 2007, the idea was to create a sort of retail holiday that would help out struggling music shops — and celebrate the successful ones — by offering exclusive releases by big-name musicians. That year about $30,000 worth of special records were sold at stores, according to Michael Kurtz, a founder of Record Store Day and the president of Music Monitor Network, a coalition of independent shops.

headline: Kielbasa
text: IT’S not quite the same as a sausage fest. Kielbasa is the name of a new gay party held every two weeks in the traditionally Polish neighborhood of Greenpoint, Brooklyn. While the name may sound lewd or over-the-top camp, the party itself is pretty tame.

headline: New School Is Squeezed Between Landlord and Occupiers
text: 6:11 p.m. | Updated

headline: Nibbles for Holiday Entertaining
text: Mark Bittman prepares simple, sophisticated bites for your holiday platter.

headline: Obama’s Pick to Head Medicare and Medicaid Resigns Post
text: WASHINGTON — Dr. Donald M. Berwick, the official in charge of Medicare and Medicaid, who became a symbol of all that Republicans dislike in President Obama’s health care policies, said on Wednesday that he was resigning.

headline: TimesCast | November 23, 2011
text: Yemen’s president agrees to step down; protesters gather in Tahrir Square for a fifth day; and a peculiar Thanksgiving tradition lives on in Washington.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Cairo and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, Yemen, South Korea and Switzerland.

headline: All About Food
text: Updated: November, 2014

headline: The Cunningham Countdown: An Exhibition at the Walker Art Center
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Merce Cunningham, John Cage and Robert Rauschenberg are seated in a row and talking about their artistic partnership, delighted to be together. This is in a 1987 filmed interview that’s playing on perpetual loop in the current “Cunningham/Rauschenberg” exhibition at the Walker Art Center here. “There was a carte blanche trust,” says Rauschenberg about their radically modernist collaborations between 1952 and 1977, in which music, dance, and design were brought together only in performance or at dress rehearsal. “Independence was to be respected.”

headline: Retailers Push Fed for Yet Lower Debit Fees
text: WASHINGTON — Retailers won a big victory last summer when the Federal Reserve halved the fees that banks and credit card companies were charging them to process debit card transactions.

headline: Given a Reprieve, Tipsarevic Falls Again (Literally)
text: It had all been going so well for Janko Tipsarevic.

headline: Mothers Create a Grammar Guide for the Text Generation
text: Geraldine Onorato was surprised by the gaps in her son's grammar education, so she and a friend, Donna Harrow, developed a grammar guide suitable for the age of texting and social media. The booklet was given to students in her son's school earlier this month.

headline: How Are We Defining College Readiness?
text: A former principal of Bronx Engineering and Technology Academy wonders whether the city's standard for college readiness is set too low.

headline: Fewer Viewers Tune In for Dancing and Singing
text: While the two-hour season finale of “Dancing with the Stars” on ABC was the highest rated program of the night on Tuesday, it was unable to reach the bars set by previous season-ending episodes of that show. When J.R. Martinez won the title, 19.4 million total viewers tuned in, down from 24 million last year, with a 23 percent drop in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. It was the lowest rated fall finale ever for “Dancing” in the 18-to-49 category.

headline: What Are Snacks I Can Serve That Are Not Too Filling?
text: Q.

headline: Ex-Khmer Rouge Leader Blames U.S.
text: PHNOM PENH — A Khmer Rouge leader told a court Wednesday that a secret campaign of U.S. bombing during the Vietnam War had contributed to the rise of the radical Communist movement that ravaged Cambodia three decades ago in one of the bloodiest episodes of mass killing in the last century.

headline: Politics? Nah, Too Easy. Let’s Talk Religion.
text: Gail Collins: David, we almost always talk about politics. Today let’s pick something less contentious. How about religion?

headline: 7 in Renegade Amish Group Charged With Assaults
text: Federal agents arrested the leader of a renegade Amish group and six others in eastern Ohio on Wednesday and charged them with hate crimes for a series of beard- and hair-cutting assaults against Amish men and women.

headline: N.B.A. and Players Resume Negotiating, With Christmas Day in Their Sights
text: Negotiations to end the N.B.A. lockout have quietly resumed, with the goal of reaching a deal in time to stage a 66-game season that would start Christmas Day.

headline: A Question of Fairness

headline: Fatalism and the American Dream

headline: James Murdoch Has Stepped Down From Newspaper Boards

headline: Sugarland Is Sued By Victims of Indiana Stage Collapse
text: A lawsuit filed by 44 survivors and the families of 4 people who were killed when a stage collapsed in August at the Indiana State Fair has named the country band Sugarland in the suit, along with producers and other organizers of the concert, The Associated Press reported. Sugarland, the country music duo of Jennifer Nettles and Kristian Bush, was minutes away from performing at the fairgrounds in Indianapolis on the evening of Aug. 13 when a gust of wind that exceeded 60 miles per hour caused the stage to collapse. The accident, which occurred hours after a severe thunderstorm watch was issued, resulted in the deaths of seven people and injuries to dozens more, and video of the frightening scene spread rapidly across the Internet.

headline: Melancholy Frontiers
text: At a glance, 2011 seems to have been a banner year for the Internal Revenue Service in fiction. It began with “The Pale King,” David Foster Wallace’s orphaned novel about employees at an Illinois branch of the organization. Now comes Lydia Millet’s “Ghost Lights,” in which an I.R.S. agent goes looking for his wife’s missing boss in a Central American jungle. If Philip Roth puts out the story of a retired tax collector’s amour fou with a young libertarian by January, we might look for fireworks over the Treasury ­Department.

headline: Children of the Hyphens, the Next Generation
text: WHEN my parents married in 1977, women’s liberation was in full swing and my mother was a consciousness-raiser. She was about as likely to take my father’s name as she was to sport a veil at the wedding. She would remain Ms. Tuhus. Nine months later, the surname for their new baby (me) was self-evident. My parents yoked their names into a new one: Tuhus-Dubrow.

headline: Mama’s Boy
text: The concept novel, like its musical equivalent, has always been a risky endeavor. At its ingenious best — Nabokov’s “Pale Fire,” say, or more recently, David Mitchell’s “Cloud Atlas” — the result has moved the needle of serious fiction forward, proving, as it nowadays must always be proved, that the novel is a still-evolving form. For a certain type of author this is rarefied and intoxicating air, a culmination of years of experimentation with voice and structure. That the atmosphere so far up is also cluttered with spectacular misfires and out-of-print debris only makes the challenge that much greater — or foolhardy.

headline: Kingdom of Shadows

Unfortunately, in “Parallel Stories,” one is too often merely lost.

headline: What Muncie Read
text: As we lurch into the digital age, people are kicking up hoary generalizations about Americans and their reading habits. “No one reads anymore,” “Kids used to read ‘Hamlet,’ not ‘Twilight,’ ” “We used to have more time to read.” But these canards are based upon conjecture, anecdote and idealized views of the past. In fact, we know very little about which books Americans used to page through: the history of reading is largely circumstantial, based upon diary entries or sales figures.

headline: Digital Downloads Sub for Weighty Scores
text: Digital gadgetry has increasingly been making its mark on classical music performance. It hit a milestone this week at the New York Philharmonic. Jeffrey Kahane, the pianist and conductor who is making a guest appearance at the orchestra, used an iPad on Tuesday instead of a score to lead the orchestra in a Mozart symphony.

headline: Standing by Their New Musical, Fingers Crossed
text: When the $16 million musical “Wonderland” flopped on Broadway in May, after New York critics once again eviscerated the work of its composer, Frank Wildhorn, theater investors envisioned a bull’s-eye target on his next show, “Bonnie & Clyde.” A few pulled their money out of that Broadway-bound musical, recalled one of its lead producers, Kathleen Raitt, while others dropped from a $250,000 to a $25,000 commitment.

headline: Classical Conducting? There’s an App for That
text: Jeffrey Kahane offered glimpses of both the past and a possible future in his performance with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening. In the first half of the program he conducted works by Bach and Mozart from the harpsichord, a nod to the practice of the time, and later he was both soloist and conductor in Beethoven’s Piano Concerto No. 1. He played the Beethoven from memory, but for the Mozart, he used an iPad instead of a conventional score. Seeing the device perched on the harpsichord’s music stand called to mind the cover of Wendy Carlos’s “Switched-On Bach” album, on which the bewigged composer stands before a Moog synthesizer, though the iPad is elegantly miniature by comparison.

headline: An Actress and a Role Balance Two Worlds
text: The playbill for the new Broadway comedy “Chinglish” identifies the actress who plays Xi Yan as Jennifer Lim. But on her passport, Ms. Lim’s given name is Zhenhua, whose meaning can be translated as “authentically Chinese.”That very quality helped Ms. Lim win the role of the imperious Chinese government bureaucrat who becomes the unexpected ally of a hapless American businessman in David Henry Hwang’s play, her Broadway debut. Born in Hong Kong and trilingual in English, Mandarin and Cantonese, Ms. Lim, 32, saw in the character of Xi Yan traits that strongly reminded her of her own family and background and was quick to incorporate them into the performance.

headline: Generous Exuberance, Inspired by the 1980s, Fresh From France

Cynicism is often the preferred mode, every moment of optimism and good will threatened by at least one shadow. Listening to an artist express sheer joy has become rare, a pleasure so unfamiliar it sometimes no longer feels like pleasure, but shock.

headline: A Cornucopia of Thanksgiving Multimedia
text: My Thanksgiving Day will begin in earnest around 8:30 a.m. with the starting gun of the Port Washington Turkey Trot, the five-mile road race through my hometown. I took an unconventional approach to training this year — I began carbo-loading in August. I’ll be easy to find on the course; just look for the drooling vultures overhead. And then sometime Thursday afternoon, my mother will roll out a Thanksgiving dinner for 30, which the 10 of us will dutifully attack as if we are the Spartans at Thermopylae. Surviving these two feats of strength and endurance, I will have earned some serious couch time, and thus will commence the perfect Thanksgiving multimedia extravaganza:

headline: Who Should Speak for Activists in China?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Let’s See What’s Inside That Pretty Head
text: IN general, movies would rather look at women than analyze them — except when the lady in question is (at least apparently) a little screwy. David Cronenberg’s “Dangerous Method” seems an unlikely subject for a film: it’s about the beginnings of psychoanalysis, when Sigmund Freud (played by Viggo Mortensen) and Carl Jung (Michael Fassbender) were trying to figure out the best techniques for teasing revelations from the reluctant subconscious of a disturbed patient. But because the analysand, a young Russian woman named Sabina Spielrein, is played by the lovely Keira Knightley, her mental-health issues are therefore interesting, just as they were when the sufferer was Ginger Rogers (“Lady in the Dark”), Olivia de Havilland (“The Snake Pit”), Joanne Woodward (“The Three Faces of Eve”), Tippi Hedren (“Marnie”), Catherine Deneuve (“Repulsion”), Gena Rowlands (“A Woman Under the Influence”), Isabelle Adjani (“The Story of Adele H.”), Liv Ullmann (“Face to Face”), Jessica Lange (“Frances”), Naomi Watts (“Mulholland Drive”) or Natalie Portman (“Black Swan”). Some of the movies’ disturbed women get the proper treatment — psychiatric and cinematic — and many do not, but even when the analysis fails, the looking remains.

headline: Language and the Limits of Coherence
text: Robert Ashley, certainly since composing the groundbreaking multimedia opera “Perfect Lives” from 1977 to 1983, has been a profound and evocative storyteller, however obliquely his tales may resonate. Language — the idioms, cadences and signature jargon of spoken American English — is central to Mr. Ashley’s idiosyncratic conception. Even so, his fusion of text, music and stage action rarely refutes a tenuous connection to opera as conventionally defined.

headline: Rhythmic Traditions, Crossing Paths Again

It is far from the first time that Irish and African-American dance have crossed paths. The braiding of those traditions over a few centuries is what gave the world American tap dance.

headline: Like His Creator, a Busy Guy
text: Michael Connelly begins “The Drop” as if it’s a work already in progress. Maybe that’s because there is always a Connelly project in progress, or so it seems. So far this year he has already published “The Fifth Witness” and welcomed the  film version of his novel “The Lincoln Lawyer.” He also played himself in a couple of short films, one on the making of “The Lincoln Lawyer.” And these are only the parts of his life that have been well publicized. There’s no mistaking the fact that Mr. Connelly is a busy guy.

headline: Tracy Letts Steps in, Complete With Speedo
text: The actor John Mahoney has left the Steppenwolf Theater Company production of “Penelope” in Chicago because of a death in his family, allowing the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright (and actor) Tracy Letts (“August: Osage County”), left, to take his place in the cast, the theater company announced. Mr. Letts joined the Steppenwolf ensemble in 2002. “Penelope,” by the Irish playwright Enda Walsh, is a comedy directed by Amy Morton, a member of the company. Scheduled to open next Thursday, it is set on an island off the coast of Greece, where a contemporary Penelope awaits her husband’s return from war and serves as the object of competition among four Speedo-clad men — including Mr. Letts — camped in an empty swimming pool.

headline: How to End the Black Friday Madness

headline: Students Take Reins and Find Their Way

But if that has long been the standard model of symphonic performance, it is no longer the only one. With the success of the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, the art of building an interpretation and performing it without a conductor has gained currency, and now Juilliard is teaching that method as well.

headline: A New Troupe Begins With Blend of Then and Now
text: The costume designed by Anja Mlakar for Jorma Elo’s “One Overture” is a half-and-half affair — literally: the dancer in the solo has a tutu encircling half of her waist and a jagged line bisecting her bicolored leotard. It’s a rather obvious visual metaphor for Mr. Elo’s brand of slice-and-dice choreography, but it could also be the poster for many a ballet company these days: half-classical, half-contemporary, stuck together with no real sense of a governing vision or even personality.

headline: An Earlier November in the New World
text: On Thanksgiving it’s usual to think back to that first feast, one far better known in custom and imagination than it is in fact. What is certain is that in 1620, when the Mayflower was rounding into shoal waters near Cape Cod, there was little reason, apart from faith, to expect that the settlement its passengers hoped to found would succeed. By the following autumn more than half of the 101 humans on board the Mayflower would be dead.

headline: On Aging Baby Boomers, and the Question of Where to Live
text: The 72 million American baby boomers, born between 1946 and 1964, are turning 65 at the rate of roughly 10,000 a day, and many are considering not just how to age (with or without annuities? soy sauce? crow’s feet?), but also where. Wid Chapman, an architect, and Jeffrey P. Rosenfeld, a gerontologist who specializes in the relationship between aging and the built environment, collected 33 examples of residences that have been recently designed to bridge the distance between one’s vital and declining years.

headline: Witness in Councilman’s Trial Says His Signature Was Forged

headline: China: Fatal School Bus Crash Heightens Calls for New Standards
text: China’s government had been drafting new safety standards for school buses for two years when an accident last week killed 21 preschoolers and two adults, a state newspaper reported. Many Chinese were outraged by the crash, in which a nine-seat minivan crammed with 62 children rammed into a coal truck in Gansu Province. Xu Mei, a spokeswoman for the Ministry of Education who was quoted in The Legal Mirror of Beijing, said at least 10 government agencies had been researching school bus systems for two years “and had collected good experience from schools with good solutions.” She said the Education Ministry had ordered the standards to be quickly issued in the wake of the crash. “The priority now,” the article quoted her as saying, “is to make sure that there will be no more accidents with existing school buses.”

headline: Opening Day for Shoppers Shows Divide
text: As the busiest retail weekend of the year begins late Thursday night, the differences between how affluent and more ordinary Americans shop in the uncertain economy will be on unusually vivid display.

headline: Mets Owners Will Face Jury if Madoff Case Goes to Trial
text: The owners of the Mets will face a jury should there be a trial in the case filed against them by the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud, a federal district judge ruled Wednesday. The Mets’ owners had opposed a jury trial.

headline: 2 Views on Subway Project: Delay Work to Clear Air, or Carry On and Profit Sooner
text: Francisco R. Quijada and Gus Sofronia, both longtime business owners along Second Avenue, know how frustrating the construction of the new subway line can be. Both have watched their businesses suffer from the huge enclosures that have been built in front of their buildings. And both have asked customers to ignore the steady drilling and hammering that emanate from beneath their feet.

headline: The Poor, the Near Poor and You
text: What is it like to be poor? Thankfully, most Americans do not know, at least not firsthand. And times are tough for the middle class. But everyone needs to recognize a chilling reality: One in three Americans — 100 million people — is either poor or perilously close to it.

headline: Secrets of a Great Spiral: The Grip and the Release
text: Organized Thanksgiving football is believed to date to 1876, when the Intercollegiate Football Association decided to schedule its inaugural championship game on the holiday. The first professional game to be played on Thanksgiving came almost a half-century later, in 1920, when Fritz Pollard and the Akron Pros defeated Jim Thorpe and the Canton Bulldogs, 7-0.

headline: France: Noriega to Be Extradited
text: A Paris court on Wednesday approved the extradition of Panama’s onetime dictator, Manuel Antonio Noriega, left, to his homeland, clearing the way for his return after two decades in French and American prisons. Prime Minister François Fillon of France signed an extradition order for Mr. Noriega, 77, earlier this year, but a date of departure has not been determined, officials said. Panamanian courts have convicted Mr. Noriega in absentia in connection with the killing of political opponents, as well as on charges of embezzlement and corruption. He faces three 20-year prison terms in Panama, which he ruled from 1983 until 1989, when he was ousted by an American invasion. Convicted in a United States court in 1992 on charges including drug trafficking, Mr. Noriega was imprisoned in Florida before his extradition to France last year. A French judge sentenced him to seven years in prison on charges that he laundered $3 million in Colombian drug money through international banks and into French accounts in the late 1980s. The Panamanian president, Ricardo Martinelli, has vowed that Mr. Noriega will serve his Panamanian sentences in prison, and not under house arrest, despite his age and reported ill health, according to The Associated Press. The A.P. also quoted Mr. Noriega as telling the court through an interpreter: “I want to return to Panama and prove my innocence.”

headline: Egypt’s Unfinished Revolution
text: More than 100,000 Egyptians did not risk their lives in Tahrir Square last winter just to see another military-backed tyranny. Military leaders — supposedly only running things until civilians can be elected — have used the nine months since they helped oust Hosni Mubarak to try to stifle democratic change and protect their own power.

headline: Corruption Case Against Developer Is to End
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have agreed to drop charges against a real estate developer who was charged in the political corruption case that ensnared State Senator Carl Kruger and seven other people, according to a court document.

headline: Second Coalition Leader in Greece Backs Debt-Relief Deal
text: ATHENS — After refusing to do so for weeks, the leader of New Democracy, the second-largest party in Greece’s interim government, sent a letter to the country’s foreign creditors on Wednesday pledging to support a debt-relief deal. But it was not clear whether the move would break a political deadlock that was preventing Greece from receiving badly needed rescue funds.

headline: Kyrgyzstan Sees Instability at End of Afghan Mission
text: The departing president of Kyrgyzstan, the small but strategically important Central Asian country that houses a vital American air base for supplying the NATO war effort in neighboring Afghanistan, expressed deep concern on Wednesday about the potential for a contagious economic collapse in Afghanistan when foreign military forces withdraw.

headline: Turkey: Apology for ’30s Massacres
text: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan publicly apologized for the killings of thousands of Kurds in the southeast part of the country by the Turkish military from 1936 to 1939. “If it is necessary to apologize on behalf of the state, I will apologize, and I am apologizing,” Mr. Erdogan said in a televised speech during a party meeting in Ankara. The apology, however, followed the recent arrests of thousands of Kurdish activists, including academics, writers, lawyers and prominent social figures, on terror-related charges as part of the government’s campaign against the Kurdish insurgency. Nearly 14,000 Kurds were killed in attacks by the army and air force in Dersim, which is now called Tunceli.

headline: Gingrich’s Words on Immigration Become a Target
text: DES MOINES — An intense debate over immigration flared among the Republican presidential candidates on Wednesday as Mitt Romney declared that Newt Gingrich “offered a new doorway to amnesty” when he called for a “humane” immigration policy to avoid deportation for people who are deeply rooted in their churches and communities.

headline: Spotlight Back on Kerry, but Reshaped Role Eludes Him
text: WASHINGTON — A feverish scrum of reporters was in such pursuit of Senator John Kerry last Friday that he was chased all the way from a Senate meeting room to the subway under the Capitol, where in the chaos a blizzard of secret papers from debt reduction talks went flying from his arms. It was an inelegant moment, particularly for a onetime Democratic nominee for president, but Mr. Kerry stooped down and gathered up his own documents before he made an escape.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
text: India’s two key stock indexes plunged more than 2 percent on Wednesday, weighed down by a slumping rupee and a global economic downturn that shows no sign of abating, Mint reports. The Sensex dropped 2.27 percent Wednesday, and is down 10.6 percent in the last 10 trading sessions, the paper reports. The broader Nifty dropped 2.2 percent. The rupee’s slide continued, which raises the price of crucial imports and further imperils the government’s hopes of robust growth this year.

headline: Ruth Stone, a Poet Celebrated Late in Life, Dies at 96

headline: Switched at Rebirth
text: When the musical “On a Clear Day You Can See Forever” opened on Broadway in 1965, the main character was Daisy Gamble, a daffy young woman who turned out to be the reincarnation of a 18th-century English aristocrat named Melinda Wells. The show’s composer, Burton Lane, wrote lush melodies to reflect the dreamy Daisy, while Alan Jay Lerner’s script was a star vehicle for Barbara Harris, playing both Daisy and Melinda. On hand to propel the plot was another character, a psychiatrist who draws out Melinda through hypnosis and then falls for her.

headline: Sparkling, Swooning and Suffering Wordlessly
text: Remember the old days, when movies were glorious, magical and mute? Neither do I. But the passing of the silent era from memory into myth is what “The Artist,” Michel Hazanavicius’s dazzling cinematic objet d’art, is all about. This is not a work of film history but rather a generous, touching and slightly daffy expression of unbridled movie love. Though its protagonist mourns the arrival of sound, “The Artist” itself is more interested in celebrating the range and power of a medium that can sparkle, swoon and suffer so beautifully that it doesn’t really need to have anything to say.

headline: Get Her to the Greek

So it makes sense that the Greek native Christina Martini chose the island of Crete for embarking on her first footwear line, Ancient Greek Sandals. “Our idea was to make our sandals look like they were archaeological finds but with a modern twist,” says Martini, who spent a number of years designing shoes at Balenciaga and Louis Vuitton before branching out on her own. With subtle nods to the goddesses — Persephone, Aphrodite and Athena — the sandals’ vegetable-tanned leather and handmade construction will merit compliments of mythic proportions.

headline: In Thanksgiving Address, a Note of Gloom
text: With the failure of the deficit-reduction committee fresh in people’s minds, President Obama urged Americans on Thursday not to give up hope that the nation can unite to find solutions to its economic troubles. But he acknowledged people’s frustrations over the intractable partisanship standing in the way.

headline: How Can I Cook a Buttered Bird at Very High Heat?
text: Q.

headline: Accusers Plan to Sue Sandusky’s Foundation
text: One of the young men who has accused the former Penn State coach Jerry Sandusky of sexual abuse sought an injunction Wednesday to stop the Second Mile charity from transferring or divesting its assets. In court papers, the accuser said he and others planned to sue the charity, which was founded by Sandusky in 1977 and reported assets of more than $9 million last year.

headline: Federer Cruises to Semifinals in London
text: If only everyone could have an annus horribilis quite as wonderful as Roger Federer’s 2011.

headline: How Do I Fix a Thin, Salty Gravy?

headline: What’s That Plastic Part Holding the Drumsticks in Place?

headline: German Leader Rules Out Rapid Action on the Euro
text: PARIS — Quashing recent speculation of a softening in Germany’s hard-line stance on the euro, Chancellor Angela Merkel repeated on Thursday her firm opposition either to bonds issued jointly by the euro zone countries or to an expansion of the role of the European Central Bank as quick responses to the sovereign debt crisis.

headline: Can a Hand Mixer Replace a Stand Mixer?
text: Does this week’s bundt cake recipe really require a mixer with a paddle attachment, or will it work with a hand mixer or food processor? — Sam, Wantagh, N.Y.

headline: India to Ease Retail Rules for Foreign Companies
text: MUMBAI — The Indian government decided on Thursday to allow foreign retailers like Wal-Mart and Tesco to open stores in the country, the first time that policy makers have moved to open India’s vast and fast-growing retail market to outsiders.

headline: Making It Easier to Head for the Hills
text: FOR three years, Kim and Stephen Allen rented a 750-square-foot one-bedroom in a small walk-up row house in Hoboken, N.J.

headline: To the Caribbean, by All Means
text: By air, sea and auto, travelers have new ways to reach and roam the Caribbean this season.

headline: What Should I Eat if I Have Type 2 Diabetes?
text: Q.

headline: Keds Are Cool
text: Remember the days when Keds shoes were seen primarily on moms and preteens? Nowadays, the shoes, worn by trendsetters like Chloë Sevigny and Natalie Portman, have once again become cool. As of Friday, the brand’s first clothing line hits the racks at Opening Ceremony, further confirming its place in hipster wardrobes.

headline: Tucked Away and Neatly Tricked Out
text: THE cemeteries that line southern Queens have moonlighted for decades, standing as a natural fence around Glendale, a subdued working- and middle-class neighborhood.

headline: How Much Will the Earth Warm Up?
text: Scientists say the Earth will warm in response to increasing carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere, but since the 1970s, they have not made much headway in narrowing down exactly how much it will warm.

headline: Is It O.K. to Use Paper Plates at Thanksgiving Dinner?
text: Is it ever O.K. to use paper (heavy duty-type) plates? I have enough plates to serve the 25 people I’m expecting, but I don’t want to have to wash them all! We will, of course, have silverware and real crystal wine glasses. I’m hoping you’ll tell me that it won’t be too tacky to serve the feast on paper plates. — K.H., Phoenix

headline: For an Artist-Developer, No Ordinary Doors
text: ON the typical apartment house, the front door is a cookie-cutter item, straight out of a catalog. But 7 Gracie Square, just off East End Avenue, is hardly typical, the project of a muralist who got into real estate.

headline: Renters Should Be Sprinters
text: AT first blush, it doesn’t make much sense: If you know you’ll need an apartment in New York in several months, why can’t you start a serious search now, rather than wait until your move-in date is just a few weeks away?

headline: When a Co-Borrower Has Poor Credit
text: IN most cases it is easier to qualify for a home mortgage by applying with another person — be it a spouse or partner, or even a close friend or sibling. But problems may arise if the other person’s credit score is less than stellar.

headline: Is It Tacky to Bring Tupperware for Leftovers?
text: Q.

text: GRISWOLD

text: How Travel Can Affect Succession Rights

headline: In Debt Crisis, a Silver Lining for Germany
text: BRUSSELS — Someone, somewhere, usually makes money from bad news. With Europe’s debt crisis, that — at least until this week — was Germany.

headline: Bob Dylan’s Songs Honoring Amnesty International
text: The year 1962 produced two debuts: the establishing and formal naming of Amnesty International as a permanent human rights advocate, according to its official history, and Bob Dylan’s first album. Nearly 50 years later, those two facts will become indelibly joined when a benefit recording project of Mr. Dylan’s music is released. More than 80 performers are covering four CDs’ worth of his songs, numbering about 75, Amnesty said. The album is called “Chimes of Freedom: The Songs of Bob Dylan Honoring 50 Years of Amnesty International” and will be released in North America on Jan. 24 and elsewhere on Jan. 30. The performers include Sting, Patti Smith, Pete Seeger, Miley Cyrus, Joan Baez, Jackson Browne, Maroon 5 and Elvis Costello. Most of the recordings are being released for sale for the first time, except for “Chimes of Freedom,” recorded by Mr. Dylan in 1964, Amnesty said.

headline: Do I Really Have to Chill a Pie Crust for Three Hours?
text: Q.

headline: National Gallery Cracks Down on Scalped Tickets
text: The National Gallery in London says it is cracking down on ticket-scalping for a major exhibition of the works of Leonardo da Vinci, which opened on Nov. 9. BBC News reports that the gallery will enforce warnings that resold tickets “will be cancelled without refund and admission will be refused to the bearer,” and is asking resale Web sites to halt the practice. The museum declined to say how it would identify scalped tickets, according to the BBC. The show has drawn large crowds, and on Thursday, the U.K. eBay site listed the starting bid for a pair at up to $250 and the Viagogo site had a ticket as high as $389.01. Tickets through the museum cost 16 pounds, or about $25. “Leonardo Da Vinci: Painter at the Court of Milan” runs through Feb. 5.

headline: Ilan Bracha
text: Mr. Bracha, 36, is the chairman of the newly opened Manhattan office of Keller Williams Realty — Keller Williams New York City. Before opening the franchise earlier this year, the Israeli-born Mr. Bracha was a managing director of Prudential Douglas Elliman and, through his Bracha Group, one of Elliman’s top-producing residential brokers.

headline: How Can I Peel the Inner Skin Off Chestnuts?
text: Q.

headline: Spreading Inner Peace, but Living With Turmoil
text: “Crazy Wisdom,” Johanna Demetrakas’s documentary about Chogyam Trungpa, a Tibetan who was instrumental in bringing Buddhism to the West, clearly loves its subject well. Too well. Ms. Demetrakas’s film bathes in Trungpa’s glow and spends much time with his followers, who talk about his teachings and his impact on their lives. (He died in 1987, at 48.) But the movie goes mushy when it should be critical, and leaves you with questions that it’s not prepared to answer.

headline: Wish List for a Fairy Tale End to the Season
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – The titles were already decided four races ago, but the season’s final race in São Paulo this weekend already looks like a big party. The paddock was full of journalists and other visitors on Thursday and the drivers were in a mood to sum up their seasons.

headline: Wish List for a Fairy Tale End to the Season
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – The titles were already decided four races ago, but the season’s final race in São Paulo this weekend already looks like a big party. The paddock was full of journalists and other visitors on Thursday and the drivers were in a mood to sum up their seasons.
