headline: L.S.U.–Arkansas at Halftime: B.C.S. Chaos Is a Possibility
text: BATON ROUGE, La. –There are 30 minutes left in L.S.U. vs. Arkansas. Thirty minutes before we could have some real chaos in the Bowl Championship Series.

headline: Where to Party at Art Basel Miami Beach
text: HAS it been a decade? Art Basel Miami Beach marks its 10th edition this week, no longer the new kid on the collector circuit, but a mandatory stop for any self-respecting art player. In some very social circles, it even overshadows the original in Switzerland, as far as the partying, the opulent dinners and the unbridled hobnobbing are concerned.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $15.5 Million
text: The $15.5 million sale of an apartment at the Carlyle Hotel on the Upper East Side, that cynosure of all things civilized and repository of secrets for presidents and starlets alike, was the most expensive of the week.

headline: What’s in a Name? Ask Google
text: KALIA is a stripper name, but Kaleya is not, her parents-to-be concluded.

headline: Road Trip to Cuba
text: Players from the Eastern Massachusetts Senior Softball League traveled to play a series of games against teams in Cuba, the league’s fourth such visit there since 2009.

headline: A Special Woman as Inspiration
text: IN today’s style landscape, chockablock with twentysomethings who were weaned on fashion-happy films like “Clueless” and “Unzipped,” the dream of a fierce or frolicsome career (or both) as a fashion designer has exercised a serious pull.

headline: A Strange New Role: The Star
text: Photographs of Michelle Williams throughout her acting career.

headline: Banks Build Contingency for Breakup of the Euro
text: PARIS — For the growing chorus of observers who fear that a breakup of the euro zone might be at hand, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has a pointed rebuke: It’s never going to happen.

headline: For Michelle Williams, an Unfamiliar Role: The Star
text: HERE is 45 minutes in my life. Actually, 58 minutes 50 seconds, according to the counter on my tape recorder when I finish my conversation with the actress Michelle Williams in the bar of the Bull and Bear Steakhouse in the Waldorf-Astoria, and her publicist, a harried-looking woman named Cari, whisks her away. A bottle of red wine sits unfinished on the table. I pay the check for my $30 hamburger — she wanted only cocktail nuts — and for the glass of wine I ordered while I was waiting for her, and my thoughts skip a beat, releasing me from the scene. ...

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 25
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Beer-Related Gifts for Wedding Registries
text: Beer glasses and other accessories as gifts.

headline: A Toast!
text: A GIFT of wineglasses has long been a staple on wedding registries. But with beer drinkers refining their tastes to frothy heights once seen only among wine connoisseurs, why not consider a gift of fancy beerware to match couples’ tastes for the latest double I.P.A. or exotic-flavor stout?

headline: Don’t Complicate It
text: WHEN it comes to what they wear, men seem to be sandwiched between fashion and nostalgia. At least they have been for the last decade or so.

headline: In Commodities World, Safe and Secure Sometimes Isn’t
text: THE scariest thing about MF Global’s bankruptcy four weeks ago is not that a venerable firm led by a former Goldman Sachs chief executive and New Jersey governor collapsed. It is that MF Global’s customers have not yet gotten all their money back. And with the report this week from the court-appointed trustee that as much as $1.2 billion appears to be missing, many customers are worried that they’ll ever see that money again.

headline: Lessons for Investors in MF Global’s Collapse
text: Customers of the bankrupt commodities brokerage firm MF Global have not had an easy time since the firm collapsed on Oct. 31. Some customers’ commodities trading accounts have been transferred to other firms, though not the full value. And those who had securities accounts or who held cash in their accounts have not seen any of their money yet.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Spotting Cats
text: One of the few discernible fashion trends is the prevalence of spotted cat. It is most often sighted in shoulder bags and scarves.

headline: On Black Friday, a Steady Business for Traffic Agents
text: Black Friday may be a boon for retailers, but they aren’t the only ones who do a brisk business on that day. New York City’s traffic enforcement agents are notoriously busy on the day after Thanksgiving, when many car owners mistakenly assume that parking regulations, like alternate-side parking rules, are suspended.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 25
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the possibility of a school bus strike, a thwarted bomb plot and preparation for the Thanksgiving holiday.

headline: Syria Lets Arab League Deadline on Observers Pass
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria on Friday ignored an Arab League deadline to accept observers to oversee a peace deal to end more than eight months of bloodshed, with activists saying that several protesters and soldiers were killed during clashes across the country.

headline: M.L.S. Cup: A View From Mexico
text: After spending most of the last 45 days in Mexico Guadalajara with an eye planted on the States — as the M.L.S. final drifts into memory and American soccer goes into hibernation — the action in Mexico is heating up.

headline: Out of the Darkness
text: THERE was a time when my wife, Giulia, said “Yes” to almost everything I suggested. But before she consented, there was always an unnatural pause, a pause so small it may have gone unnoticed by others. But it was painfully obvious to me. That pause did not come from her; it came from the antipsychotic medication she had to take.

headline: An International Flavor at the Fall Championships
text: The Fall North American Championships, organized by the American Contract Bridge League, began in Seattle on Thursday.

headline: In the Right Age
text: I am on a dating site called OKCupid.com and list my age as 33, even though I am actually 43. When people meet me, they assume I am in my late 20s or early 30s. I feel fortunate to get away with looking so much younger than I am without Botox. My plan is to admit my true age on a second or third date, and hope he’ll forgive me. Or should I correct my age now?

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Gender Bending Romance
text: Though I’m often reluctant to begin reading a series several volumes in, there are two arrivals on the manga list this week that have me reconsidering that stance. At No. 9 on the list is vol. 5 of “Arisa,” by Natsumi Ando, about Tsubasa who impersonates her twin sister Arisa at her school and remains undercover to find out why she attempted suicide. Apparently everyone in Arisa’s class has a secret and it involves mysterious text messages to someone named King. At No. 10 on the list is vol. 5 of “Until the Full Moon,” by Sanami Matoh. That series follows Marlo, a half-werewolf-half-vampire, who becomes something else in the light of a full moon: a girl. Adding to the complications is the fact that David, a vampire playboy, is interested in Marlo’s female form. And Marlo’s parents are not the least bit frazzled: if their doctor friend can’t help Marlo, their son, they seem fine with David marrying Marlo, their daughter.

headline: So Big, Performa Now Misses the Point
text: Performa 11, the visual art performance biennial, has come and gone, completing its sprawling three-week marathon with an awards ceremony on Monday. It left me feeling once more grateful for its artistic largesse and revelations, if a bit more dazed and confused than usual.

headline: College Students Replace Poverty With Creativity
text: LIKE so many college students these days, Margaux Malyshev was desperate for cash.

headline: The Agony of Gift-Giving in a City That Has Seen It All
text: Several years ago, while roaming around a used-book store on a trip to Rhode Island, I found a pristine old copy of Randall Jarrell’s 1954 novel, “Pictures From an Institution.” It had a great cover done in bold graphics and cost $5. I bought it with the intention of giving it to a friend later in the year, someone who would appreciate both the object itself and the scavenger manner in which it had been found.

headline: Podcast: Derivative Trading, Unemployment and the American Gun Business
text: The Dodd-Frank law aimed to tighten financial regulations in hopes of preventing another meltdown. Among other things, it called for greater transparency in the trading of derivatives.

headline: A Look at Apple’s Spot-the-Shopper Technology
text: A Black Friday visit to the Apple Store in Palo Alto, Calif., offered a glimpse of the new technology Apple is using to speed purchases.

headline: A Nod to St. Cecilia, Patron Despite Herself
text: Whatever you make of St. Cecilia, the patron saint of music, the ensemble Tenet’s idea of honoring her feast day in a concert presented by Trinity Wall Street on Tuesday was a lovely one. What others have made of her is a long story, or several of them.

headline: The New Roomie Proves That Three Is a Crowd, Especially When He Overshares
text: At TV Land, the creation of new comedies goes beyond simple formula — it’s closer to cloning, or something involving algorithms. Feed the computer a premise — three guys share an apartment because they all have the same divorce lawyer — and it tells you which sitcom veterans you need to hire.

headline: Gail Marquis and Audrey Smaltz
text: AUDREY SMALTZ said that she wanted to stop being a “complainer,” as she put it, and that she needed to know who she was. “I really had no idea,” she said.

headline: French Museums Atone for a Colonial History
text: PARIS — You walk through a garden lush with overgrowth, a cultivated wilderness with exotic grasses gone deliberately to seed. Inside the effect is the same: You enter the eerily atmospheric hall where you meander past artifacts from Oceania, Africa and other realms beyond Europe’s borders, as speckled daylight seeps through window scrims decorated with forest foliage. The displays are lush with miscellany: here, an ivory statuette of a goddess from the Tonga islands that once was shown in an 18th-century curiosity cabinet; there, a desiccated human skull, covered in black-colored beeswax, acquired in early-20th-century Papua New Guinea.

headline: Fugazi Rises Again, in Online Archive
text: Fugazi, the single-mindedly independent post-punk band from Washington, was famous for how it operated in concert. From its first shows in 1987 until it went on indefinite hiatus 15 years later, the group kept ticket prices low — $5 or so — and, to the relief of some fans and the annoyance of others, often paused when things got too wild in the mosh pit.

headline: Australia Eases Policy on Detaining Asylum Seekers
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The government announced a significant shift on Friday in its policy toward asylum seekers who try to reach the country by sea, moving away from its use of open-ended detention in favor of a plan that allows applicants to live and work in the country while their claims are processed.

headline: Grading a Teacher Evaluation System
text: To the Editor:

headline: Schmekel, a Band Born as a Laugh
text: THE basement auditorium of the Jewish Community Center on the Upper West Side is a sincere space. Big, brown and bare, it suggests a school gym, a place for officially sanctioned fun — which made a recent concert by Schmekel, a raucous klezmer-core punk band made up of “100% trans Jews,” all the more surprising.

headline: Weekend Guide Nov. 26-27: Non-U.S. Edition
text: By popular demand, Rob Hughes of The International Herald Tribune previews some of this weekend’s matches in Europe.

headline: Former F.B.I. Chief Asked to Oversee MF Global’s Bankruptcy
text: Louis J. Freeh, the former director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was asked on Friday to become the trustee for MF Global as it seeks to unwind itself in bankruptcy court.

headline: The Unbelievers
text: RONNELLE ADAMS came out to his mother twice, first about his homosexuality, then about his atheism.

headline: 35 Floors Above the Floats
text: Each Thanksgiving, Asiate — the Asian-fusion restaurant on the 35th floor of the Mandarin Oriental Hotel at Columbus Circle — becomes a skybox where smart-set locals and affluent out-of-towners gather early to look down at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade. Starting at 7 a.m., there is a prix fixe breakfast — this year, $68 for adults and $48 for children — during which Asiate’s normal menu (wagyu beef, butter poached lobster) is set aside for more traditional parade-watching fare (scrambled eggs, Special K). On Thursday, the diner-viewers included a group of visiting Saudis, a silver-haired gentleman and his date, and the Peters family of Hinsdale, Ill., on a six-day whirlwind tour of the big city.

headline: After Slow Start, L.S.U. Stays Perfect
text: BATON ROUGE, La. — L.S.U. is simply different this season. The Tigers have shed their reputation as a somewhat flaky, burlesque team led by a quirky coach whose daring sideline decisions always seemed to come with one second left on the clock.

headline: Inequality in the Air: The 1 Percent and the 99
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tour Guides Nobody Tips
text: APP UrbandigPLATFORM iPhone and iOS devicesPRICE Free

headline: Veterans’ Medical Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Witch Wears Silk Suits
text: IT was the night before Thanksgiving, and the Witch Queen of New York was not stirring her brew or flying on her broom.

headline: ‘Religious Liberty’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Formal Defect Inquiry of Volt Battery Begins
text: DETROIT — Federal safety regulators on Friday said they have begun a formal defect investigation of the Chevrolet Volt because a second battery caught fire after a crash simulation.

headline: Anti-H.I.V. Trial in Africa Canceled Over Failure to Prevent Infection
text: A new trial of a microbicide gel to protect women from infection with H.I.V. was canceled Friday after researchers reported that it was not working.

headline: At Harbor, Answering an S.O.S.
text: SUSAN HENSHAW JONES, the new president of the comatose South Street Seaport Museum and the captain, by default, of its deteriorating fleet of historic vessels, dug the heels of her black pumps deeper into the splintered boardwalk at Pier 16, bracing herself against the November wind pirouetting off the harbor.

headline: AT&T Spars With F.C.C. Over Withdrawal of T-Mobile Deal
text: Nothing is easy when it comes to AT&T‘s proposed $39 billion takeover of T-Mobile USA — apparently not even when it comes to withdrawing the deal from the government approval process.

headline: Letter
text: To the Editor:

headline: Uganda’s Oil Could Be Gift That Becomes a Curse
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — When billions of barrels of oil reserves were found in Uganda five years ago, the discovery seemed like a gift from heaven to many in this poor, landlocked country.

headline: Djokovic Out After Loss
text: Novak Djokovic lost his second match in round-robin play at the ATP World Tour Finals in London, falling to his fellow Serb Janko Tipsarevic, 3-6, 6-3, 6-3. It was Tipsarevic’s first win over Djokovic, as well as his first over a No. 1-ranked player.

headline: In Quiet Part of Russia, Putin’s Party Loses Steam
text: ARSENYEVO, Russia — It was a grim-faced crowd that gathered last week at the Palace of Culture in this village, making its way past decrepit housing blocks, broken streetlights and a statue of Lenin.

headline: Good Words for Grietje
text: The Aug. 7 F.Y.I. column had an item, “First Lady of the Night,” about Grietje Reyniers, whose scandalous conduct in the New Amsterdam of the 1630s was written up in official records at the time. Marie E. Velardi, a 10th great-granddaughter of Ms. Reyniers who has studied genealogical records and histories of New Amsterdam, wrote that while there was no one definitive work on the Reyniers-Van Salee family, she believed that the view of Ms. Reyniers as a highly immoral woman was one-sided. An edited version of Ms. Velardi’s letter follows.

headline: A New Capital of Call Centers
text: MANILA — Americans calling the customer service lines of their airlines, phone companies and banks are now more likely to speak to Mark in Manila than Bharat in Bangalore.

headline: Multicultural One-Man Team
text: At Northwestern University, inside the office of fellowships, Steven Hill likes to tell visitors that he advised the Mexican wrestling team. He adds: “His name’s Larry. He’s really big.” This is true. Strange, yes, but true, too.

headline: Romney Dominating Race for Endorsements
text: When we last checked in on Republican candidates’ endorsements — an important measure of party and institutional support that historically has some predictive power for nomination races — we found former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts in a good but not great position.

headline: Legal Education Reform
text: American legal education is in crisis. The economic downturn has left many recent law graduates saddled with crushing student loans and bleak job prospects. The law schools have been targets of lawsuits by students and scrutiny from the United States Senate for alleged false advertising about potential jobs. Yet, at the same time, more and more Americans find that they cannot afford any kind of legal help.

headline: Family Fun, Out of the House
text: Landscapes dotted with tiny dolls, a scale model of a candy-making machine, an all-Lego city with running trains and a frosted gingerbread replica of Radio City Music Hall are among the diverse works in four family-friendly exhibitions now open in and around the county.

headline: Tom Wicker, a Columnist Not Afraid of Controversy
text: Tom Wicker, an iconoclastic columnist for The New York Times, became one of postwar America’s most distinguished journalists.

headline: Fair Pay for Hard Work
text: Something akin to justice may finally be at hand for the nation’s nearly two million home care aides.

headline: Meaning in Madness
text: Milton Greek, who has been diagnosed with schizophrenia, believes that decoding the messages in delusions can help some people recover.

headline: As Catholics Prepare for New Mass Translation, Parish Carves Its Own Path
text: The midmorning Mass held at Corpus Christi Church in Morningside Heights last Sunday was either a week ahead or nearly 40 years behind the mainstream of American Roman Catholicism, depending on how one looked at it.

headline: China Looks Into U.S. Energy Trade Policies
text: HONG KONG — China’s ministry of commerce announced on Friday that it had opened an investigation into whether American subsidies and other policies in the solar, wind and hydroelectric sectors had unfairly hurt the industrial development of China’s renewable energy industries.

headline: The Battle Hymn of John Brown
text: On Nov. 17, 1861, Julia Ward Howe traveled with her husband Samuel, then director of the Army’s Sanitary Commission, to review a Union camp outside of Washington. Howe recalled the troops singing “the army songs so popular at the time,” noting especially their enthusiasm for the lyrics, “John Brown’s body lies a-mouldering in the ground; His soul is marching on.” One of Howe’s companions, the Rev. James Freeman Clarke, made a suggestion: “Mrs. Howe, why do you not write some good words for that stirring tune?”

headline: Police and the Press
text: In many countries, using a camera or taking notes can get you into trouble. That is not supposed to happen in New York City. Yet as police cleared Occupy Wall Street protesters from Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan on Nov. 15, a number of journalists were roughed up and arrested. Many were prevented by police from documenting what happened that night.

headline: Finding Purpose After Living With Delusion
text: ATHENS, Ohio — She was gone for good, and no amount of meditation could resolve the grief, even out here in the deep quiet of the woods.

headline: The Rain It Raineth
text: “It’s raining,” I think, and then wonder what the “it” is that is doing the raining. Ordinarily, that’s just a linguistic question. But on a cold November day, it feels like a philosophical problem. It makes no sense to say the clouds are raining when the sky is so solidly, grayly felted. In the pasture, the horses stand, hair slicked, hind legs cocked. I conclude that what is raining is the rain, a phrase that sounds like the opening of a grim, Anglo-Saxon lyric.

headline: O.K., Now Ron Paul
text: Ron Paul, the libertarian congressman from Texas, now seems to have an outside chance of winning the Iowa caucus vote. Not the presidential nomination. It seems highly unlikely that the Republicans are going to give the nod to a guy who disapproves of the Patriot Act and marriage licenses.

headline: Wedding Bells Drown Out Locker-Room Chatter
text: An N.F.L. locker room is a temple of masculinity. There are jock straps on the floor. Helmets hung on hooks. Shoulder pads resting on shelves, with ribbons of dried-out sweat running along the seams.

headline: Under Rule, Hailing a Cab for a Stranger Can Be Illegal
text: Recently, a man named Juan Bannister approached a stranger on Seventh Avenue in Midtown Manhattan. “Do you need a taxi?” Mr. Bannister asked, according to a subsequent police report. “Can I get you a taxi? Just wait here; you’re next.”

headline: For U.S., Risks in Pressing Egypt to Speed Civilian Rule
text: WASHINGTON — Ever since tens of thousands of protesters converged on Tahrir Square in Cairo for the first Day of Revolution exactly 10 months ago, the Obama administration has struggled to strike the right balance between democracy and stability. In the early morning hours on Friday, President Obama came out on the side of the Arab street, issuing a call for the Egyptian military to quickly hand over power to a civilian, democratically elected government.

headline: Panasonic Plans a Plant for Solar Equipment
text: Panasonic said on Friday that it would invest 45 billion yen ($582 million) to build a plant for solar cells and modules in Malaysia in a move to increase its share of the global market. The factory will also produce wafers and have a production capacity of 300 megawatts a year, the company said. Panasonic, based in Osaka, Japan, intends to sell modules worth 1.6 gigawatts worldwide in the year ending March 2016, Masato Ito, an executive officer, said at a news conference. The company’s previous target was 1.5 gigawatts. The company picked Malaysia for the new plant to hedge risks of a strong yen and for its reliable infrastructure for power and water, Tetsuhiro Maeda, a senior vice president of Sanyo, a unit of Panasonic, said at the conference. Production will begin in December 2012 and the plant, which will be built in the Kulim Hi-Tech Park in Kedah, in northern Malaysia, will employ about 1,500 people.

headline: Nursing a Marble Horse Back to Health
text: A COUPLE of years ago, Franklin Hill Perrell, the executive director of the Roslyn Landmark Society, got a surprising phone call from an acquaintance. There was a historically important statue in the backyard of a house that was being sold, the caller said, urging Mr. Perrell to go look at it.

headline: Eating, Sleeping, Praying, and Writing All About It
text: LAST Sunday, we asked you to tell us how you spent the day, as New Yorkers like Henrik Lundqvist, Mario Batali and Star Jones have done in this space over the last two and a half years, and here’s what we discovered: for tens of thousands around the globe, at least part of Sunday was spent using Twitter or Facebook to tell The New York Times what you did on Sunday.

headline: Stars Flock to Atlanta, Reshaping a Center of Black Culture
text: ATLANTA — Cynthia Bailey, arguably the most glamorous of the “Real Housewives of Atlanta,” shivered in a sleeveless red shift, microphone in hand.

headline: Irish Life Suspends an Effort to Sell a Unit
text: Irish Life and Permanent, the mortgage lender controlled by Irish taxpayers, said it had suspended efforts to sell its life assurance unit after bids were too low. The lender halted the sale process amid “very challenging” market conditions, Eoin Dorgan, a spokesman for the Irish Department of Finance, said in a statement. The Irish government plans to split insurance operations from the unprofitable bank unit. Taxpayers injected 2.7 billion euros into the company in July as part of the country’s 62 billion euro bailout of its banking system. The government owns 99.5 percent of the firm.

headline: The Death of the Fringe Suburb
text: Washington

headline: To Rethink Sprawl, Start With Offices
text: San Francisco

headline: Inquiry Into Press Tactics Turns the Tables on Tabloids
text: LONDON — It is a story made to order for the sensation-hungry tabloid newspapers that have millions of avid readers in Britain: a roll call of A-list celebrities and crime victims pouring out — day by day, live on the Internet — the personal miseries they say they have endured in seeking to protect the everyday normality of their private lives.

headline: Jeno Paulucci, a Pioneer of Ready-Made Ethnic Foods, Dies at 93
text: First it was Chun King, the canned Chinese food that became a mainstay in American cupboards in the postwar decades. Then it was the pizza roll, a hybrid of Italian and Chinese fast food that acquired similar status in the kitchen freezer. Jeno Paulucci, a food magnate, had a hand in both of those contributions to the American diet, founding the companies that produced them. He died at 93 on Thursday at his home in Duluth, Minn.

headline: Occupy L.A. to Be Evicted on Monday
text: LOS ANGELES — The Occupy Los Angeles protesters have probably received a warmer reception than most of their counterparts elsewhere in the country. With vocal support from the City Council, the protesters have been allowed to remain on the lawn outside City Hall for almost two months, without any major confrontations with the police.

headline: The Ballad of John and Jessica
text: For the last five years, the Cafe Carlyle, perhaps the premier cabaret venue in New York City, has devoted the month of November to an act featuring John Pizzarelli, a jazz guitarist and vocalist, and his wife, Jessica Molaskey, a Broadway actress and singer.

headline: U.S. Uses an Insurgent Attack to Send a Message to Iraqis
text: BAGHDAD — The American military command in Iraq usually declines to acknowledge insurgent rocket strikes on its bases, not wanting the enemy attackers to know whether they have hit something. But the Americans made an exception on Friday.

headline: Egypt Military Tries to Woo Wider Public to Keep Power
text: CAIRO — Some call it the silent majority. In Egypt these days, the preferred term is the Party of the Couch. And in that ill-defined constituency, sometimes more myth than reality, Egypt’s ruling military has staked its credibility as it seeks to fend off the greatest challenge yet from protesters seeking to force it from power.

headline: Blind Man in New Jersey Challenged Again on Guns
text: ROCKAWAY, N.J. — Judging by what the authorities say about him, Steven Hopler has really been testing the limits of the Second Amendment.

headline: Oil Rigs Bring Camps of Men to the Prairie
text: TIOGA, N.D. — As much as the drilling rigs that tower over this once placid corner of the prairie, the two communities springing up just outside of town testify to the galloping pace of growth here in oil country.

headline: A Housing Shortage’s Imperfect Solution
text: Man camps are filling the holes for housing as thousands of workers floods parts of North Dakota to work the bustling oil fields.

headline: Taking on Beckett, in One Act
text: THE last time Brian Dennehy was at Long Wharf Theater, three years ago, he was in a one-act production, Eugene O’Neill’s “Hughie,” playing a lonely, aging man pretty much talking to himself.

headline: Small Wonders, Made by Hand
text: A COMBINATION of remarkable ingenuity and pure fun can be found in two exhibitions at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center: “Visions of Gingerbread III: The Sweetest Architects” and “All Aboard With Bill Probert and Friends II,” each of which demonstrates meticulous planning, design and construction skills.

headline: Jets Have the Blueprint for a Playoff Run: Their Big Finish in 2009
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — With the postseason fast approaching, Rex Ryan said this week that the Jets had run out of “breathing room.”

headline: Israel’s Other Occupation
text: Jerusalem

headline: After Easing Burden on Body and Mind, a Young Man Begins to Follow His Dream
text: Not so long ago, Marcos Vargas was an overweight, depressed high school dropout who could not face what he called a hostile learning environment and troubles with a girlfriend. He spent most of his time wallowing in his mother’s apartment in the Bronx, subsisting on a diet of fried chicken, pork chops and soda.

headline: Lottery Numbers
For Gruff Yankee Pitcher, Another Chance at the Hall
text: With 182 victories and 1,423 strikeouts over 13 seasons, the hard-throwing Yankees pitcher Allie Reynolds lacked the shoo-in credentials of 300 wins or 3,000 strikeouts to usher a pitcher into the Baseball Hall of Fame.

headline: Talks on Cluster Bomb Restrictions Collapse
text: GENEVA — Despite last-minute attempts to broker a compromise, American-led efforts to conclude an international treaty restricting use of cluster munitions collapsed on Friday in the face of opposition from countries that said it did not address their humanitarian concerns and would undermine existing international law.

headline: Stumbling Upon a Castle in the Forest and Deciding to Finish It
text: TUPPER LAKE, N.Y. — Moving through his unfinished mountain home, Andy Ramsgard carries a leatherbound book full of sketches.

headline: Freshening Up a Holiday Classic
text: TRADITION plays a large part in spurring the annual march of “Nutcracker” ticket holders into New Jersey theaters and arts centers each holiday season. And while there are real differences among the many companies presenting it, change often takes the form of tweaks rather than dramatic overhauls.

headline: In Judge’s Brooklyn Courtroom, Made-for-TV Drama Without the Cameras
text: Wearing wide hoop earrings and an Italian gold costume ring that rested as heavy as a gavel on the bench, Judge Patricia Mafalda DiMango leaned forward to address the teenage defendant.

headline: For Perry, Life Was Broadened and Narrowed by the Military
text: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. — Rick Perry arrived on the campus of Texas A&M University in the tumultuous fall of 1968, cut his hair short, regulation military style, and donned a uniform. College students across America were rising up against the Vietnam War, but Mr. Perry, a member of the Corps of Cadets here, would not be among them.

headline: Saturday: Plane For a Space Cadet
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — O.K., time to work off the turkey, people. This is a tough grid and we’re going to burn some calories figuring out some of these entries, but we can do this. It’s also an interesting visual appetizer to the big Sunday entree coming up. There’s no connection between the grids, but you’ll see what I mean.

headline: A First in Cup Qualifying for a Player and a Team
text: APIA, Samoa — Jonny Saelua did not always envision herself as an international soccer player. What she really wanted to do was join a dance company and “travel the world just performing.”

headline: Last Chance, Visitor: Leave the Cake With the File in It Right Here
text: The boxes are opened on Tuesdays. Inside this week: six cellphones, three canisters of pepper spray, eight blades of various sorts (including a steak knife). Also, two forks, two pairs of scissors, something wrapped in plastic, a hypodermic needle and — now here was something strange — a calculator.

headline: Evangelical Leader Rises in Brazil’s Culture Wars
text: FORTALEZA, Brazil

headline: Russian Ballet, Brooklyn Flavor
text: Most of the teachers at the Brighton Ballet Theater School of Russian Ballet hail from the former Soviet Union, and most of their pupils are of Russian descent, but the borough’s diversity still comes through.

headline: Classic Greek Fare, Above the Fray
text: GEORGE and Nick Kringas, who opened Nemea Greek Taverna in Mamaroneck about six months ago, learned a good deal about the restaurant business at Niko’s, their parents’ place, in White Plains. That experience, combined with George’s training at the French Culinary Institute, seems to be paying off.

headline: Talks Resume in Hope of a Christmas Tip-Off
text: On a frantic Black Friday in Midtown Manhattan, the most enticing deal in reach was not in an expensive Fifth Avenue department store, but in a cavernous office building next door. There, in a quiet law office, negotiators tried one last time to end the N.B.A.’s labor crisis and to bring back pro basketball in time for the holidays.

headline: J. Edgar Hoover, ‘Sex Deviates’ and My Godfather
text: Baltimore

headline: Traditional Thai, but With Surprises
text: WHEN was the last time you were surprised by mee krob, those sweet, crispy rice noodles that appear on many a Thai menu, or by pad Thai, which has a way of losing its luster after only a few bites? You might find yourself surprised, and pleasantly so, at Ridge Thai, a tiny but well-focused restaurant in downtown Ridgewood.

headline: Games to Watch on Saturday
text: OHIO STATE AT NO. 17 MICHIGAN

headline: Known for Big Portions, a Local Chain Expands
text: BUTERA’S is a well-known name on Long Island. The first outpost of this homegrown mini-chain opened 20 years ago in Massapequa, followed by Woodbury in 1999, Smithtown in 2007 and Sayville just last year. The original moved to Seaford from Massapequa in 2008.

headline: Gas Deal With Belarus Gives Control of Pipeline to Russia
text: The Russian government agreed on Friday to offer Belarus loans and a discounted price on natural gas worth more than $14 billion, tying Belarus, Russia’s small, authoritarian neighbor, into an even tighter union with Moscow.

headline: All of the Flavor With Little of the Effort
text: THE greater part of the holiday season is still ahead, but entertaining can be simplified, and kitchen time reduced, through the use of in-store prepared foods — if not on the actual holiday, then during those hectic days preceding it. The three shops that follow are representative of the kinds of efforts being made by independent grocery stores around Connecticut.

headline: Events in Connecticut
