text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Financial woes at the United States Postal Service, a vote on a free trade pact in South Korea, a tempest in the fair trade movement and the (barely) post-Thanksgiving start to the holiday season were among the week’s top business stories.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Mexico: Complaint Over President Is Filed With Hague Court
text: A Mexican human rights lawyer, Netzaí Sandoval, filed a complaint on Friday against President Felipe Calderón with the International Criminal Court in The Hague, claiming that Mr. Calderón covered up and tolerated war crimes and crimes against humanity. The document, signed by 23,000 Mexicans, also accuses organized crime syndicates, Public Security Minister Genaro García Luna, and the country’s army and navy of partaking in the “systematic repetition” of abuses against civilians. Mr. Sandoval said he wanted to ensure that the court’s chief prosecutor, Luis Moreno-Ocampo, begins monitoring the situation in Mexico, where more than 45,000 people have been killed since Mr. Calderón began his offensive against drug traffickers in 2006.

headline: After Taking In Refugees for Years, a New Hampshire City Asks for a Pause
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — This city has long been a resettlement site for refugees, sent here by the State Department for a chance at a better life. More than 60 languages are spoken in the school system, with Somalis, Sudanese, Iraqis and other recent arrivals mixing with children whose ancestors came from Quebec to work in the mighty textile mills along the Merrimack River.

headline: Sena Jurinac, Longtime Soprano in Vienna, Dies at 90
text: Sena Jurinac, whose creamy soprano and elegant, sincere musical style made her a favorite of opera fans and critics alike during a career spanning four decades, died on Tuesday at her home near Augsburg, Germany. She was 90.

headline: Rev. Maurice Chase, ‘Father Dollar Bill,’ Dies at 92
text: Every Sunday morning for three decades, the Rev. Maurice Chase would drive to Los Angeles’s most desperate neighborhood, where he would hand out crisp new one-dollar bills, along with a handshake and a blessing.

headline: Jimmy Norman, R&B Singer Who Worked With Marley and Hendrix, Dies at 74
text: Jimmy Norman, a rhythm-and-blues singer and songwriter who worked with Bob Marley and Jimi Hendrix early in their careers and was involved in a longstanding dispute over songwriting credit for the song “Time Is on My Side,” died on Nov. 8 in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: Corrections: November 26
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: For Obscure Iranian Exile Group, Broad Support in U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — At a time of partisan gridlock in the capital, one obscure cause has drawn a stellar list of supporters from both parties and the last two administrations, including a dozen former top national security officials.

headline: Belarus: Rights Activist Sentenced
text: A prominent human rights activist in Belarus was sentenced to four and a half years in prison after a trial for tax evasion that Western governments denounced as politically motivated. As head of the well-known rights group Vyasna, the activist, Ales Belyatsky, has provided legal assistance and moral support to opponents of Belarus’s authoritarian president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko. The authorities in Belarus opened a criminal case against Mr. Belyatsky after officials in Poland and Lithuania mistakenly handed over information about his financial accounts in those countries. Officials from both countries later apologized.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: On Wednesday, the federal minister of state for home, Jitendra Singh, informed the Rajya Sabha, or the upper house of the Parliament, that police fire had killed 91 civilians and injured 494 civilians in the state during 2010 (Kashmir Live).

headline: For American Samoa, a Series of Firsts
text: James Montague writes again from Samoa, where American Samoa earned its first international victory this week, followed that up with a tie and did both with a defender who is believed to be the first transgender athlete to appear in a FIFA world championship competition.

headline: Phillipines Overtakes India as Hub of Call Centers
text: The Philippines has overtaken India as the world’s call-center capital, Vikas Bajaj reports.

headline: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
text: Desi Boyz: On-screen professions in Hindi cinema are getting more unconventional. Heroes no longer play doctors, engineers or executives and heroines aren’t towing the teacher/nurse/college gal line, either. Case in point: this week’s release “Desi Boyz,” in which the heroes Nick Mathur (played by John Abraham) and Jerry Patel (played by Akshay Kumar) become pole dancers in a London strip club. A look at some of the new-fangled Bollywood jobs:

headline: N.B.A. Reaches a Tentative Deal to Save the Season
text: Six weary figures rose from their chairs early Saturday morning, their expressions telegraphing the conclusion to the N.B.A.’s five-month labor crisis: Basketball is back in business, with a new labor deal that heavily favors the owners, despite some last-minute concessions.

headline: Tensions Flare Between U.S. and Pakistan After Strike
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani officials said on Saturday that NATO aircraft had killed at least 25 soldiers in strikes against two military posts at the northwestern border with Afghanistan, and the country’s supreme army commander called them unprovoked acts of aggression in a new flash point between the United States and Pakistan.

headline: Forecasting End of Rex Ryan Era
text: Will Leitch of New York Magazine writes that no matter what happens against the Bills on Sunday .…

headline: Egypt Braces for Fresh Clashes After Protester’s Death
text: CAIRO — The killing of an unarmed demonstrator by the police on Saturday threatened to stir up new protests here as Egypt’s military rulers and political parties braced for potential chaos surrounding the parliamentary elections scheduled to start on Monday.

headline: A Facebook Chat on the Plight of Rare Wildlife – With a Twist
text: Thanks to a Tumblr post by Cem Aridag, a Turkish journalist in my new Blogging a Better Planet course at Pace University, I became aware of a creative approach to conveying the plight of endangered wildlife — a mock Facebook chat involving a tiger, panda, rhinoceros and other species facing various threats:

headline: Banco Santander Chief Executive Is Given Pardon
text: LISBON — Spain’s departing Socialist government granted a pardon on Friday to Alfredo Sáenz, chief executive of Banco Santander, commuting a three-month prison sentence and a temporary ban from working as a banker. Instead, Mr. Sáenz must pay a fine.

headline: A Large Side of Drama at Waffle House Diners
text: AVONDALE ESTATES, Ga. — The two men accused of robbing a string of Waffle House restaurants in Georgia and Alabama had a routine. They placed to-go orders, and after the food was cooked, the police say, they pulled out guns and demanded all the store’s cash. Sometimes they ate, sometimes they did not.

headline: Variety: Ring Toss
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — What a refreshing palate-cleanser! Ring Toss is a new puzzle — to me, at least — and I have to say I really enjoyed the multiple layers of detective work that I had to do in order to get to the alleged “activity” I was supposed to be performing (I admit to nothing).

headline: Mysterious Europe
text: What I have never understood, and still don’t understand, is how European leaders think this is going to work out. What’s the plan? Or lacking a plan, what’s the story with a happy ending?

headline: In Iraq, Bombs Kill at Least 11 in 2 Attacks
text: BAGHDAD — Bombs exploding in and around Baghdad on Saturday shattered the stillness of a crystalline autumn day in the desert as violence continued during the American military withdrawal from Iraq.

headline: Homeless Youth Struggles to Build a Life in Chicago
text: Dressed in black baggy jeans, a gray tank top and a Harley Davidson cap skewed backward, Juan Gallaher stood under a cool late-fall drizzle devouring a peanut butter and jelly sandwich from the Night Ministry’s homeless-youth-outreach van at Belmont Avenue and Halsted Street.

headline: Live Analysis: Rivalry Weekend
text: Paul Myerberg will be reporting on all of the day’s action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can also follow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

headline: Egyptian Bloggers Document Deadly Clash
text: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, tensions between Egypt’s military-led government and protesters increased on Saturday after a man who was run over by a police vehicle at a demonstration died from his injuries.

headline: Moderate Islamist Party Winning Morocco Election
text: RABAT, Morocco — A moderate Islamist party appeared Saturday to have won parliamentary elections in Morocco, the second time in weeks that voters in the region have chosen Islamists in elections brought on by the Arab Spring.

headline: In London, Federer Reaches 100th Final
text: The 16-time Grand Slam champion Roger Federer reached the 100th final of his career by holding off David Ferrer, 7-5, 6-3, in the first semifinal of the ATP World Tour Finals on Saturday in London. Federer, seeded fourth in the tournament, is 69-30 in his previous 99 finals.

headline: Protests Continue as Elections Draw Near
text: One person died in clashes with police in Cairo as protesters rejected the military’s appointment of new Prime Minister Kamal el-Ganzouri and demanded the generals cede power.

headline: Policy-Making Billionaires
text: OVER the past 30 years, as the gap between wealthy and poor grew ever wider, total philanthropic giving almost tripled, according to annual estimates published by the Giving USA Foundation and the Center on Philanthropy at Indiana University. In an age of widening partisanship and plummeting trust in government, this outpouring of philanthropy has produced a distinct breed of philanthropist: The policy-making billionaire.

headline: Vettel Beats Mansell’s Record of Pole Positions in a Single Season
text: SAO PAULO — Sebastian Vettel scored the 30th pole position of his career in qualifying for the Brazilian Grand Prix, but more importantly, it was his 15th pole spot of the season, which tops the record set in 1992 by Nigel Mansell.

headline: Vettel Beats Mansell’s Record of Pole Positions in a Single Season
text: SAO PAULO — Sebastian Vettel scored the 30th pole position of his career in qualifying for the Brazilian Grand Prix, but more importantly, it was his 15th pole spot of the season, which tops the record set in 1992 by Nigel Mansell.

headline: Parity, Great for N.F.L., May Hurt N.B.A.
text: All along, Commissioner David Stern was dreaming of an N.B.A. Christmas, a gift reopening on ABC. In announcing the tentative settlement of a five-month lockout early Saturday with the players’ leader, Billy Hunter, Stern said the league intended to begin what can technically be classified as the 2011-12 season with a televised tripleheader on Dec. 25.

headline: Maria Wing and Albert Motley
text: Maria Joan-Margariete Wing and Albert Bernell Motley were married Saturday by the Rev. Stephen D. Thorne, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

headline: Myriam Cifuentes and Nicholas Goodbody
text: Myriam Yovanna Cifuentes, the daughter of Myriam C. Vargas and Raúl W. Cifuentes of Bogotá, Colombia, was married Saturday afternoon to Nicholas Toll Goodbody, the son of Sandra T. Goodbody and Thomas B. Goodbody of Washington. Richard A. Levie, a retired District of Columbia Superior Court judge, officiated at the home of the bridegroom’s parents.

headline: Laurie Goodman, Peter Andresen
text: Laurie Renée Goodman and Peter Ragnar Andresen were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton, South Beach, in Miami Beach. Rabbi Jonathan S. Kaplan officiated.

headline: Sarah Odio and Andrew Torlage
text: Sarah Prío Odio, the daughter of Marían Prío Odio and Cesar H. Odio of Miami, and Andrew Michael Torlage, a son of Gilbert and Jenny Torlage of Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, are to be married Sunday at Giants Castle Nature Reserve in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. The Rev. Mabel Dalby, an Anglican priest, is to perform the ceremony with the assistance of the bridegroom’s father, a deacon at the Anglican Cathedral of the Holy Nativity in Pietermaritzburg.

headline: Elyse Katz and Jeffrey Lavine
text: Dr. Elyse Bari Katz, a daughter of Dr. Terri F. Katz and Dr. Lawrence A. Katz of Cresskill, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Dr. Jeffrey Seth Lavine, a son of Eileen Lavine and Norman Lavine, also of Cresskill. Rabbi Aaron Leibowitz, a cousin of the bride, officiated at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York.

headline: Dana Winik, Joseph Kekst
text: Dana Sara Winik, a daughter of Esther F. Winik and Dr. Steven P. Winik of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Joseph Jacob Kekst, a son of Carol S. Kekst and Gershon Kekst of New York. Rabbi Malcolm Thomson officiated at the Pierrein New York.

headline: Shari Swaaley, Noah Suchoff
text: Shari Brooke Swaaley and Noah Avraham Suchoff were married Tuesday evening at their Manhattan apartment. Mitchell J. Danziger, an acting State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx and a cousin of the bride, officiated. On Sunday, Rabbi Craig Scheff is to perform a religious ceremony at the Wilshire Grand Hotel in West Orange, N.J.

headline: Allison Raisfeld, Robert Jaeger
text: Allison Rose Raisfeld, the daughter of Jane G. Raisfeld and Lee J. Raisfeld of Merrick, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Robert Harris Jaeger, the son of Peggy Jaeger and Steven M. Jaeger of North Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Barry Dov Schwartz performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y.

headline: Thomas Kelly, Gregory Reardon
text: Thomas James Kelly and Gregory Joseph Reardon were married Saturday evening in New York. Colleen Kelly Sanders, a sister of Mr. Kelly who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, led the ceremony at the New Leaf restaurant in Fort Tryon Park.

headline: Aliza Wohl, Avi Sadiky
text: Aliza Grabel Wohl and Avi Hirsh Sadiky are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Congregation Brothers of Israel in Elberon, N.J. Rabbi Yudy Shemtov is to perform the ceremony.

headline: Laura Banish, Siddique Abbasi
text: Laura Nichole Banish and Dr. Siddique Akbar Abbasi were married Thursday evening at Monty’s Banquets, a catering hall in Chicago. Imam Omer M. Mozaffar officiated in a ceremony that incorporated Muslim and Christian wedding traditions.

headline: Dan Kempson and Zachary Altman
text: Alexander Mackay-Smith Kempson and Zachary Clayton Altman, both baritones, were married Saturday evening at the Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in New York. Dona D. Vaughn, a Universal Life minister who taught them in the opera program at the Manhattan School of Music, officiated.

headline: Susanne Menden-Deuer and Tatiana Rynearson
text: Susanne Menden-Deuer and Tatiana Ann Rynearson were married Saturday on the shore of Lake Placid in Lake Placid, N.Y. Erik K. Rynearson, Ms. Rynearson’s brother, who became a Universal Life Church minister for the occasion, officiated. On Dec. 23, Gabi Hüffel, a registrar for Wachtberg, Germany, is to officiate at a civil ceremony in the Wachtberg town hall.

headline: California Bullet Train Project Advances Amid Cries of Boondoggle
text: SACRAMENTO — Across the country, the era of ambitious public works projects seems to be over. Governments are shelving or rejecting plans for highways, railroads and big buildings under the weight of collapsing revenues and voters’ resistance.

headline: The Importance of Painting a Clear Picture
text: This interview with  John Riccitiello, chief executive of Electronic Arts, the video game maker, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: On Twitter, Comments by Basketball Players Are Gleeful
text: In an age when technology has all but erased anonymity, Twitter has turned into the microphone of choice for those who want a voice. Within hours of the handshake agreement early Saturday that all but ended the nearly five-month N.B.A. lockout, players started posting messages to express their relief and happiness.

headline: Inventive or Error Filled, Draws Have Their Charms
text: It is natural to focus on tournament games that ended decisively. After all, they determine the winners.

headline: For Occupying Protesters, Deadlines and Decisions
text: PHILADELPHIA — “Cooperative” is the word usually used here to describe the relationship between the campers of Occupy Philadelphia and the city, a birthplace of the constitutional right to free speech and assembly.

headline: Out of Work, and Trying to Stay Positive
text: She had to miss her father’s funeral in Jamaica last year because she could not afford to go. Fresh fruits and vegetables are now a luxury. She keeps her hair short, cutting it herself to avoid the expense. Her only new clothing in more than two years has been a dress her sister paid for and a $25 blouse she bought for an interview. These are the sacrifices, large and small, that Dionne Henry has had to make since losing her job.

headline: A Stealth Giant in the Gun Industry
text: Many major gun makers, including the 195-year-old Remington Arms, have quietly passed into the hands of one private company, the Freedom Group.

headline: Occupiers Evicted From the New School; Graffiti Is Left Behind
text: A weeklong occupation at the New School in Greenwich Village ended with a whimper on Friday morning when university officials evicted the handful of remaining protesters from a campus gallery that was defaced sometime before they left.

headline: How Freedom Group Became the Big Shot
text: SCARBOROUGH, Me.

headline: Bachmann Renews Attack on Gingrich Over Immigration
text: Representative Michele Bachmann renewed her attack on Saturday of Newt Gingrich over illegal immigration, saying once again that he favored “amnesty” for the 11 million illegal immigrants in the United States.

headline: Slipping Backward on Swaps
text: WALL STREET loves to do business in the shadows. Sunshine, after all, is bad for profits.

headline: Oklahoma Wallets and Pride Were Hurt
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The Thunder are Oklahoma’s only major pro sports franchise, and few N.B.A. cities viewed the news of a labor agreement with more welcome relief. The team, in its third season, reached the Western Conference finals last season, and Thunder fans have an emotional stake unlike their counterparts most other places.

headline: In Coming Elections in Congo, Expectations of Fraud and Fears of Violence
text: KINSHASA, Congo — A sense of menace hangs over the long, dirty boulevards of this African metropolis.

headline: Critics Say Budget Cuts for Courts Risk Rights
text: NASHUA, N.H. — For years, state courts across the nation have been scraping by on the support they get from state and local government budgets. Since the financial crisis of 2008, those budgets have been tightened in new ways that are being felt in courthouses and communities across the country.

headline: Engineer’s Return to China Leads to Jail and Limbo
text: BEIJING — After two decades of working as a successful engineer in the United States, Hu Zhicheng decided to return to China in 2004 and apply his rich experience to designing catalytic converters for the nation’s booming automotive industry.

headline: Cairo Undone
text: All these months later, the revolution’s ardor fading, Tahrir Square feels less a model, more an inspiration.

headline: A History of Violence
text: In Argentina, a rise in street crime is reflected in the increasing aggression among groups of soccer hooligans.

headline: In Argentina, Violence Is Part of the Soccer Culture
text: BUENOS AIRES — Three fans of the soccer club San Lorenzo de Almagro slipped past security guards after a closed-door practice last month and berated players on the field for their recent losses.

headline: Schottenheimer Feels the Pressure as the Jets’ Offense Sputters
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — On top of his offensive call sheet, Brian Schottenheimer regularly writes four words that are important to him. Three are the names of his wife and their two children. The fourth is fist.

headline: A Family’s Billions, Artfully Sheltered
text: As he stood in the opulent marble foyer of a Fifth Avenue mansion late last month, greeting the coterie of prominent guests arriving at his private art gallery, Ronald S. Lauder was doing more than just being a gracious host.

headline: TV Attack Ads Aim at Obama Early and Often
text: Inside the debate halls, the clash may be Republican versus Republican. But offstage, conservatives are mounting a unified and expensive air assault on the candidates’ common opponent: President Obama.

headline: Redefining a Position, With 15 Years of Catches
text: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga. — The N.F.L. tight end once belonged to the brotherhood of big uglies — unheralded offensive linemen whose main duties were confined to blocking, not flinching before the snap and not being caught holding. What distinguished him from peers was the sporadic pass aimed his way.

headline: Working Hard, Yes, but for Fair Pay?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Store of Their Own
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Language of Sexual Assault
text: Re “Confusing Sex and Rape” (Nov. 20):

headline: Don’t Know How? Well, Find Someone Who Does
text: IS advanced technical knowledge necessary to become an inventor? Look at the story of Katherine Bomkamp, and you will see that it isn’t.

headline: 3 Men Forged 2 Decades of Labor Peace
text: Sometime early in Bud Selig’s celebration of baseball’s new collective bargaining agreement on Wednesday, he wondered if the two sides had needed to go through the pain of 1994 in order to achieve the peaceful — and very profitable — coexistence they enjoy today. It was almost certainly meant as a rhetorical question. Selig answered with a casual “perhaps.” But there is nothing rhetorical about the question. And the answer to it is a most emphatic yes.

headline: Turn On the Server. It’s Cold Inside.
text: TO satisfy our ever-growing need for computing power, many technology companies have moved their work to data centers with tens of thousands of power-gobbling servers. Concentrated in one place, the servers produce enormous heat. The additional power needed for cooling them — up to half of the power used to run them — is the steep environmental price we have paid to move data to the so-called cloud.

headline: Ovechkin Slows, as Do Capitals
text: Sidney Crosby’s comeback is front and center in the N.H.L., but prominent in the background are the struggles of Alex Ovechkin, who less than two years ago was neck and neck with Crosby for the title of best player in hockey.

headline: They Are Still Penn State, but They Aren’t the Same
text: It was the morning after the Penn State scandal broke when my son Alex called from State College to say he had just read the 23-page grand jury finding of fact and was sick to his stomach. He asked if I had seen it and I told him that I had, that it was going to be the darkest episode in the university’s history and that I didn’t see how Joe Paterno could survive.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Kelly Rowland
text: Kelly Rowland is a recording artist who got her start with the group Destiny’s Child. More recently, she collaborated with several European performers, notably the French singer Nâdiya and the Italian singer Tiziano Ferro, and the French D.J. David Guetta, with whom she recorded the international dance hit “When Love Takes Over.” Her solo album “Here I Am,” released in August, made its debut at No. 1 on Billboard’s R&B/Hip-Hop chart.

headline: Two Wall Street Titans, and a Seven-Year Tiff
text: AS Wall Street smackdowns go, this one’s a doozy.

headline: The Fire Bell of Unemployment
text: THE failure of the Congressional supercommittee to come up with any agreement on the budget deficit makes it even less likely that Congress will rise above its partisan divisions and act on behalf of the millions of out-of-work Americans.

headline: Craven Political Crudités
text: BARACK OBAMA hates Thanksgiving and all that it represents.

headline: The Enduring Cult of Kennedy
text: THE cult of John F. Kennedy has the resilience of a horror-movie villain. No matter how many times the myths of Camelot are seemingly interred by history, they always come shambling back to life — in another television special, another Vanity Fair cover story, another hardcover hagiography.

headline: In the Arab World, It’s the Past vs. the Future
text: IN 2001, a book came out about George Mitchell’s diplomatic work in Northern Ireland that was entitled “To Hell With the Future, Let’s Get On With the Past.” One hopes that such a book will never be written about today’s Arab awakenings. But watching events unfold out there makes it impossible not to ask: Will the past bury the future in the Arab world or will the future bury the past?

headline: President as Piñata
text: A YEAR before President Obama faces re-election, take a look at what has happened to other Western leaders confronting voters in this economic vortex.

headline: Team Obama Gears Up for 2012
text: AS North Carolina Republicans tell it, the Obama for America volunteers stole in under cover of night and stayed, undetected — noticed belatedly only because of election results across the state.

headline: Thanksgiving With Grammy Hall
text: EVERY Thanksgiving Mom and Dad and my siblings, Randy, Robin and Dorrie, and I piled into the station wagon and headed to Grammy Hall’s Spanish duplex on Rangeview Avenue in Highland Park, Calif. Dad pulled the car up the concrete driveway to the home of his mother, Mary Alice. Nobody knew where she got the money to buy a building, but she did. And she managed to hold on to her 3,000-square-foot stucco box until she and her sister, Sadie, died next to each other on hospital beds in the dining room, the same room where we ate our annual Thanksgiving dinner.

headline: Going After the Pirates
text: Online piracy is the bane of the Internet. Still, bills proposed in the House and the Senate have overreached. The legislation needs to be tightened to protect intellectual property without hindering online speech and innovation.

headline: In Showdown, Cameras Roll and Fists Fly
text: The HBO crews were out in full force at Madison Square Garden on Saturday to record the first Rangers-Flyers game of the season, and the teams were most accommodating. It took them only four seconds to start fighting and begin an afternoon of wild fisticuffs, nonstop chirping, rampant hostility — all the makings of good television.

headline: The Famine Next Time
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: The Curious Don Young
text: Say this for Congressman Don Young: He is thoroughly predictable and, on energy and environmental matters, almost always wrong.

headline: Willpower: It’s in Your Head
text: IS willpower an illusion? Is the traditional notion of a deep mental reservoir of strength a fiction?

headline: Small Plates
text: Now that appetizers are often served as entrees in restaurants, life seems more complicated.

headline: Tom Wicker, 1926-2011
text: THE first thing that comes to mind about Tom Wicker is his reporting on the assassination of John F. Kennedy. He was in Dallas with the president on Nov. 22, 1963. He was as stricken as the rest of us, but he was a professional. He wrote fast and accurately, making us feel the chaos in Dallas, raising the questions that would be explored in the years ahead.

headline: Of Poor Farmers and ‘Famous Men’
text: To people in parts of Hale County, Ala., it isn’t “Let Us Now Praise Famous Men,” it’s “that book,” the one everyone knows, even those who haven’t read it. The one that even now can stir the descendants of the families in it to feelings of irritation, weariness and sometimes seething anger.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Anonymity and Incivility on the Internet
text: Readers debate the benefits and drawbacks of requiring real names in online postings.

headline: Mr. Romney on Foreclosures
text: Since the housing bubble began to burst six years ago, prices nationwide have fallen by a third. Nearly $7 trillion of home equity has been wiped out. Currently, some 14.7 million homeowners owe $700 billion more on their mortgages than their homes are worth. Going forward, prices are likely to fall further as banks put a backlog of foreclosed properties on the market. As home prices fall and more homeowners sink underwater, there will be more foreclosures and more price declines.

headline: Cairo Undone
text: THERE is a notion of Cairo, and of Egypt, in which its residents have long sought refuge. Unlike other Arab countries, their borders drawn with imperial whim, lines too straight on a map to make sense, Egypt is a true nation, and Cairo a true capital. Celebrated is the sense of its unity.

headline: Money At The Top
text: A bit more on the subject of whether there’s significant money to be raised through higher taxes on the very rich. As it happens, there’s a recent analysis from the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center that bears quite closely on this subject.

headline: Family Struggles Over Justice, Charity and Memory
text: WHEN my wife’s family gathered for a reunion this summer, the 60 or so cousins who made it to Santa Cruz, Calif., agreed to create a fund that would channel donations to a cause they all cared about: the plight of refugees.

headline: A Family Debate
text: A family debate becomes a window into many Jews’ struggle with what seem to be increasingly contradictory commitments: to Israel, to justice, to the alleviation of suffering, to the preservation of memory.

headline: Stony Brook Arrives, Marching Band and All
text: When Stony Brook won the Big South Conference football title on Nov. 19, nearly 8,000 fans cheered in a $22 million stadium; many of those spectators stormed the field to celebrate as time expired. Sixty-three Seawolves players were on athletic scholarships. And a 170-piece marching band, that staple of college football pomp, provided a soundtrack for the team’s triumph.

headline: Readers Weigh in on Obama
text: My Sunday column argues that President Obama is, in market terms, oversold; as we approach an election year, let’s look at other candidates and remember the context. Sure, we have our disappointments with Obama, but he also has legitimate achievements that tend to be overlooked in this economic downturn. And he’s tacking against unbelievable headwinds, economic and political: no president is going to be popular with 9 percent unemployment. All in all, I think he’s been better than many critics on left and right acknowledge.

headline: The 50-50 Solution
text: THE euro crisis is deepening, the government in Washington can’t cut the deficit or reduce unemployment, and the economy is lurching into recession.

headline: Sunday: Yin/Yang
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — First things first: What a gorgeous grid! Jeff Chen returns to us today with what I consider to be a kind of masterpiece: not only has he set the grid swirling with Yin and Yang, but some of the entries/elements themselves exhibit Yin and Yang characteristics. I’ll explain.

headline: Running a Red Light. Stealing a Wallet. The Cameras Are Watching.
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Odumegwu Ojukwu, Breakaway Biafra Leader, Dies at 78
text: Odumegwu Ojukwu, an Oxford-educated Nigerian colonel who proclaimed the Republic of Biafra in 1967 and led his Ibo people into a secessionist war that cost more than a million lives, many of them starved children whose skeletal images shocked the world, has died at a hospital in London. He was 78.

headline: At Quarterback, the Non-Cutler, but Fear Not
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Basil D’Oliveira, a Symbol for Cricket and for Equality, Dies at 80
text: Just as Jesse Owens and Jackie Robinson pursued their athletic dreams and developed superlative skills before altering history, Basil D’Oliveira, who was classified as colored under South African apartheid, wanted only to play at the highest levels of his sport, cricket. His struggle to do that in a country of government-enforced racial segregation became a powerful symbol in the ultimately successful fight against apartheid.

headline: Sergio Scaglietti, Sculptor of Sleekly Tailored Ferraris, Dies at 91
text: Sergio Scaglietti, who used intuitive genius and a hammer — seldom blueprints or sketches — to sculpture elegant Ferraris that won Grand Prix races in the 1950s and ’60s and now sell for millions of dollars, died on Nov. 20 at his home in Modena, Italy. He was 91.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, November 26
text: Congressional leaders from both parties will gather Sunday to examine the collapse of the deficit deal, which could lead to significant cuts in military and domestic programs. Contenders for the Republican presidential nomination and a leader from the Congressional Progressive Caucus will also discuss the political fallout from the deal’s collapse.

headline: Sure, Post a Review. But the Last Word Won’t Be Yours.
text: YOU would like to move your car across the country, but you’d rather not drive it. So you hunt around online for a car transportation company, which will strap your vehicle to a truck and roll it to your destination.

headline: College Football Replay: Nov. 26
text: Rivalries mark the last big weekend of the regular season, with Michigan defeating Ohio State, Auburn battling Alabama and Kentucky notching its first win against Tennessee in 26 years.

headline: A Military Camp Works to Be a Good Neighbor
text: CAMP BULLIS — Reddish-brown cedar chips from recently cleared trees spread across a patch of ground in this United States military installation, in sharp contrast to the jungle-like growth nearby.

headline: For-Profit Certification for Teachers Is Booming
text: DENTON — One afternoon in mid-November, Jeff Arrington scattered 80 paper gingerbread men labeled with numbers across the floor of his high school disaster-response class.

headline: Bills at Jets: Matchup to Watch
text: Bills (5-5) at Jets ( 5-5), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

headline: With a Formula One Race Now Iffy, It Remains Unclear Who Is the Lead Driver
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Border Fence Upends a Valley Farmer’s Life
text: Oscar Casares wrote this column for texasmonthly.com.

headline: Starting a Business: The Romance vs. the Reality
text: SOME people who toil discontentedly in corporate cubicles regard entrepreneurship as the cure for all workplace ills. Only when they’ve experienced running a business personally do they find that the reality is much different.

headline: A Passion for Coaching
text: I WAS born in Harrisburg, Pa., the oldest of four children. My father owned and managed a gas station. When I was 7, my parents decided that they wanted to live in a warmer place, and decided on South Florida.

headline: Assessing the Roles of Lee’s Top Supporters
text: On election night a couple of weeks ago, former Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco celebrated Mayor Edwin M. Lee’s victory in style at the downtown Palace Hotel, toasting friends as he twirled through the room.

headline: Creative Financing Deals May Cost City $68 Million
text: An effort by the San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency to earn money nearly a decade ago through “creative solutions” could end up as a financial debacle that costs the city $68 million or more, a delayed effect of the nationwide subprime mortgage crisis, financial analysts and legal experts said.

headline: Even Unfinished, the New Bay Bridge Inspires Artists
text: Millions of pounds of hulking concrete. A $50 million blue crane, rising hundreds of feet in the air above the Bay. Deep red scaffolding girding huge stretches of the unfinished span.

headline: Post-Uprising, a New Battle
text: CAIRO — Through elections, protests, government formations and armed struggle, Arab countries in an arc from Libya to the gulf were engaged this past week more than ever in attempts not to simply overthrow leaders, but to decisively shape the orders that follow.

headline: Noise Abatement Display Room
text: Travelers who peer into a particular small, dark room at San Francisco International Airport may wonder about its colorful monitors. The machines, which are usually unmanned, collect information on Bay Area flight traffic to be analyzed by the airport’s Noise Abatement Office. Behind the room, away from public view, workers in a hive of cubicles study data and decibel levels — of both the aircraft and the complaining public.  LOUISE RAFKIN

headline: New Turmoil as President Comes Back to Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen — President Ali Abdullah Saleh returned to Yemen on Saturday night, days after he signed an agreement in Saudi Arabia yielding his powers to his deputy and amid increasingly confusing signals about the structure of the country’s leadership.

headline: Phone Hacking Tied to Terrorists
text: Four people in the Philippines hacked into the accounts of AT&T business customers in the United States and diverted money to a group that financed terrorist attacks across Asia, according to police officials in the Philippines.

headline: Woman Who Escaped From Police Car in Handcuffs Is Recaptured
text: A woman who escaped from the back of a police car on Friday after being arrested for robbing a cabdriver in Brooklyn was recaptured by the police a day later, the authorities said.

headline: Rangers-Flyers Alumni Game Rosters
text: Some Rangers old-timers who will skate Dec. 31 in the Rangers-Flyers alumni game at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia as part of the Winter Classic festivities were on hand at the Garden on Saturday. Mike Gartner, looking trim at 52 after a career in which he scored 708 regular-season goals, was asked if he still had his legendary speed. “If I did, I’d still be playing,” he said.

headline: Alabama Looks Set for a Rematch With L.S.U.
text: AUBURN, Ala. — In the dim light outside the visitors’ locker room under Jordan-Hare Stadium on Saturday night, the politicians in Crimson wondered why there should even be a debate about whether they were fit to play for a national championship.

headline: Tsonga Edges Berdych to Reach Final
text: Jo-Wilfried Tsonga held off Tomas Berdych, 6-3, 7-5, to book his spot in the final of the ATP World Tour Finals in London, the Frenchman’s biggest final since his improbable run to the Australian Open final in 2008.

headline: N.B.A. Players Held Firm on Some Points
text: For nearly 150 days of an anxiety-filled lockout, N.B.A. players made every concession imaginable — on salaries and free-agent rules and payroll limits. But in the final hours of negotiations, they at last extracted some key compromises from the league.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 26
text: A view of the day in sports, from golf amid the lush foliage of southern China to soccer on the sands of Dubai.

headline: Boston U. Edges Cornell
text: Ross Gaudet’s overtime goal gave Boston University a 2-1 win over Cornell in the Red Hot Hockey game at Madison Square Garden.

headline: In Argentina, Violence Is Part of the Soccer Culture
text: Don’t miss the article on the often-violent Argentine supporters clubs known as barra bravas by Alexei Barrionuevo and Charles Newberry in Sunday’s Times.

headline: The Queen Is Dead; Long Live the Queen
text: WATCHING a video of their dance, “Supernatural Wife,” on a laptop in the sunny kitchen of Annie-B Parson’s and Paul Lazar’s Brooklyn home last August, one could easily imagine how the couple work together. They stood over the computer, Mr. Lazar uncomfortable because of back pain, but as eager as his wife of 23 years to talk about their process. At first, it seemed as if he took a back seat in the conversation. But his shyer demeanor masks a tough certainty, whereas she surprisingly quite often follows his lead.

headline: Corrections: November 27
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Day’s Best in College Football
text: MATT ROARK The Kentucky wide receiver, with the Wildcats missing their top two quarterbacks, filled in behind center with 124 yards on 24 carries as the Wildcats (5-7, 2-6 Southeastern Conference) ended a 26-game losing streak to Tennessee with a 10-7 victory in Lexington.

headline: How the Top 25 Fared
text: 1. L.S.U. (12-0) beat No. 3 Arkansas, 41-17, Friday

headline: Newswallah: Long reads edition
text: Tehelka digs deep into the story of a young man killed by Gujarati police in 2003 on suspicion of being a terrorist, part of a pattern of such police shootings, almost all involving young Muslims. A court ruled last week that the most sensational of these killings, that of a young college student named Ishrat Jehan, was staged. But as the Tehelka article reports, hers was hardly an isolated case:

headline: Win for Stanford, Record for Luck, but No Title Shot
text: STANFORD, Calif. — The fourth- and fifth-year Stanford football players were introduced in alphabetical order before their game Saturday night against Notre Dame. In the middle of the pack was quarterback Andrew Luck, who received the loudest ovation of the 23 players from the packed house at Stanford Stadium.

headline: Federer Saves His Best for Last
text: No matter the year, Roger Federer always seems to find his form at the ATP World Tour Finals.

headline: (Very) Old Meets New at Manuscripts Show in London
text: A trove of medieval- and Renaissance-era illuminated manuscripts, collected by the kings and queens of England between the 9th and 16th centuries, is on display in London.

headline: Isolating Syria, Arab League Imposes Broad Sanctions
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Arab League deepened Syria’s international isolation on Sunday by imposing a battery of economic sanctions meant to sever most trade and investment from the Arab world, an unprecedented step against a member state.

headline: In Cypress Hills, a Little-Known Monument to Journalism’s Short Memory
text: Aging reporters know, long before they are gone, that they are already forgotten; their scoops and exclusives and front-page triumphs no more than historical footnotes. If that.

headline: In Russia, Evidence of Misstep by Putin
text: MOSCOW — Two months after Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin revealed his intention to reclaim the Russian presidency, he returned on Sunday to the same podium, facing the same sea of rippling flags, to accept his party’s nomination.

headline: Gingrich Gets Key Endorsement in New Hampshire
text: 10:38 a.m. | Updated New Hampshire’s largest newspaper, The Union Leader of Manchester, endorsed Newt Gingrich in the 2012 Republican presidential race, a rebuke to Mitt Romney, who holds a commanding lead in most polls in the state.

headline: NATO Giving Afghans More Areas to Control
text: SAROBI, Afghanistan — Afghan forces will assume control of their own security in 18 new areas, some of them still troubled by insurgents, bringing half of the country’s population under the government’s nominal authority, Afghan officials said Sunday.

headline: Hedge Fund Ireland
text: Update: And here’s the paper (pdf). A bit more complicated — among other things, Ireland seems to have run up debt in part by becoming a major importer of errors and omissions. But still broadly it looks like the nation-as-hedge-fund picture.

headline: The Obama Spending Non-Surge
text: Blogging is a lot like teaching the same class year after year; you’re always encountering the same arguments you’ve refuted in the past, and you want to demand why they weren’t listening the last time.

headline: In Mexico, Querétaro Ousts Chivas
text: With so much attention in the soccer world focused on the Manchester Uniteds, Barcelonas, Real Madrids, Milans, et. al., in Europe it was easy to miss the ground shifting in Mexico Saturday night when unfancied Querétaro sent mighty Chivas of Guadalajara packing in the quarterfinals of the Apertura playoffs. It was the first time Querétaro had won a playoff series.

headline: PBS Introduces New Television Channel in Britain
text: As Britain takes its news media to task, an American import, the Public Broadcasting Service, hopes to make a name for itself by offering a sober antidote to the tales of tabloid newspaper excesses that have been leading the news bulletins of late.

headline: After Strike in Pakistan, Rage and Damage Control
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The political fallout from a NATO airstrike in Pakistan that was operated out of Afghanistan and killed at least two dozen Pakistani soldiers became clearer on Sunday, as Pakistan seethed over the attack and the United States scrambled to contain the damage to an already frayed relationship.

headline: Time Runs Short for Europe to Resolve Debt Crisis
text: LONDON — Eighteen months into a sovereign debt crisis — and after many futile efforts to resolve it — the endgame appears to be fast approaching for Europe.

headline: Liverpool and Manchester City Share Points
text: In the finest of British soccer aphorisms … it was a cracking contest.

headline: Cain Acknowledges Shift in His Fortunes
text: WASHINGTON — On a day when Newt Gingrich received the endorsement of an influential New Hampshire newspaper and remained atop the frequently shifting Republican field, Herman Cain acknowledged the slip in his own presidential fortunes but blamed it on “false accusations” and news media “confusion.”

headline: For B.U. and Cornell, Red-Hot Rivalry Continues at Garden
text: The junior forward Ross Gaudet scored with 2 minutes 12 seconds left in overtime to send No. 15 Boston University past No. 17 Cornell, 2-1, on Saturday night in front of a capacity crowd of 18,200 at Madison Square Garden.

headline: The Euro Curse
text: Joe Weisenthal has a smart post comparing Sweden and Finland. Both look solid, and fiscally are in good shape. But where Swedish bond yields have been plummeting, Finnish yields have risen. As he says, this looks like the penalty Finland is paying for being part of the euro and lacking a lender of last resort.

headline: Feeling Thankful: Lockout Edition
text: With the lockout over and the players getting ready to go back to work, I find myself very thankful, even if Thanksgiving was a few days ago.

headline: Webber Wins  After Vettel Loses Gearshift
text: SAO PAULO, Brazil — Mark Webber won the Brazilian Grand Prix on Sunday after mechanical problems slowed his Red Bull teammate, the world champion Sebastian Vettel, who started the race from a record 15th pole position of the season.

headline: Webber Wins  After Vettel Loses Gearshift
text: SAO PAULO, Brazil — Mark Webber won the Brazilian Grand Prix on Sunday after mechanical problems slowed his Red Bull teammate, the world champion Sebastian Vettel, who started the race from a record 15th pole position of the season.

headline: Words of Praise for an Iranian Exile Group Described as a Cult by Its Critics
text: As my colleague Scott Shane reports, several former United States officials have been paid to make speeches in support of a banned Iranian exile group, the Mujahedeen e-Khalq, or People’s Mujahedeen, known as the M.E.K.

headline: New Translation of Catholic Mass Makes Its Debut
text: Roman Catholics throughout the English-speaking world on Sunday left behind words they have prayed for nearly four decades, flipping through unfamiliar pew cards and pronouncing new phrases as the church urged tens of millions of worshipers to embrace a new translation of the Mass that more faithfully tracks the original Latin.

headline: The Tweets of War: What’s Past Is Postable
text: Hitler spent decades plotting his campaign for world domination. Alwyn Collinson, 24, a recent graduate in Renaissance history from Oxford University, hatched his own plan to invade Poland in a mere five days.

headline: The Physics of the Laboratory, and the Chemistry of the Heart
text: LOS ANGELES — Despite much learned talk about the game-changing scientific discoveries in radioactivity it portrays, “Radiance,” a new drama by Alan Alda at the Geffen Playhouse here, doesn’t emit much in the way of theatrical light.

headline: A Crucial Win With a Postseason Feel
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Again and again, the Jets have expressed their desire to host a playoff game, for the route to the Super Bowl to travel through a loud and hostile MetLife Stadium. That goal eluded them two seasons ago. Last season, too.

headline: Scaling the ‘Wall in the Head’
text: Walls are back in fashion. Walls and fences. Not long ago, you may recall, Republican presidential candidates expressed their devotion to them. In October Michele Bachmann  signed a pledge to support the construction of a fence that would run the entire length of the United States-Mexico border. Not to be outdone, Herman Cain voiced his support for an electrified border fence, one juiced up enough to be lethal: Touch it and die. As someone who grew up behind the Iron Curtain, I happen to know how the device works; in a certain way, we invented it (we should have copyrighted it). The ability to cross  the “lethal fence” used to be part of the East-European survival kit.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: After Nightmarish Crash, Safety’s N.F.L. Dream Lives On
text: When the Giants march onto the Superdome field on Monday night to play the New Orleans Saints, Chad Jones will run out with them. Jones will be wearing his Giants uniform; he will be on the sideline. He will do everything except play.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: A Wrathful God, or Not, if You Buy His Book
text: He hates the Ten Commandments “in exactly the same way Don McLean hates ‘American Pie.’ ” He adores the most obscure and antiquated Old Testament strictures, “for each outdated relic of an obsolete mode of living is like a child to me.” He identifies himself as “Maker of Little Green Apples; Rester of Merry Gentlemen; and Sole Knower of the Beach Boys.” He inflicted the Potato Famine on Ireland because he was angry at the potatoes. Why? “They know why.”

headline: Trading a Loser and Gaining an Extra Winner
text: SEATTLE — At the Fall North American Championships here the Nail Life Master Open Pairs was won late on Saturday by Justin Lall of New York City and Ishmael Delmonte from Australia. They finished one-ninth of a board ahead of Doug Doub of West Hartford, Conn., and Adam Wildavsky of New York City. Third were Eric Greco of Wynnewood, Pa., and Geoff Hampson of Las Vegas.

headline: ‘Twilight’ Beats Newcomers at Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — A family film free-for-all over the holiday weekend ended with puppets doing cartwheels, elves wondering what went wrong and Martin Scorsese somewhere in between.

headline: Dewdrop, Candy Canes and Sugarplum Fairy, Liberated by Familiarity
text: On Friday, after shoppers had battled one another for bargains that might not have existed, balletgoers of many ages gathered at the David H. Koch Theater for a more reliable holiday ritual. As New York City Ballet’s “Nutcracker” began its annual run of performances there, the tree telescoped on cue, the seven-headed Mouse King was vanquished, snowflakes swirled, and flowers waltzed. The Christmas magic in George Balanchine’s imperishable staging, as in Tchaikovsky’s score, is built in, guaranteed.

headline: Bills’ Johnson Mocks Burress Shooting in Celebration
text: Touchdown celebrations are all about drawing attention to yourself, but the Bills’ Stevie Johnson ventured into edgy territory Sunday when he mocked Jets receiver Plaxico Burress by pretending to shoot himself in the leg after scoring on a short catch in the second quarter.

headline: A Composer Lets the Birds Call the Tune
text: As the composer John Luther Adams once said of his work in an interview, “It began with birds.” The earliest piece in what Mr. Adams calls his active catalog is “songbirdsongs,” written from 1974 to 1980. In nine movements lasting just under an hour it places the listener in the middle of the natural world, the controlled chaos of birds, water and wind.

headline: A Digital Future Not Quite Here for City Ballet
text: More than a year after its completion at a cost of several million dollars, a sleek media control room equipped to help the New York City Ballet record its performances for digital archiving and for theater broadcasts has languished unused.

headline: Goth Stalwarts in Gloomy Fettle Recall 3 Albums
text: At the Beacon Theater on Friday night there were fans of the Cure, the long-running and influentially dismal British band; fans of the first three Cure albums, which the band was playing back to back; and people who were just excited to be at a Cure show — any Cure show — in 2011. The Venn diagram of those three groups probably doesn’t include anyone overly keen to hear “Descent,” a sulking instrumental B-side from 1981.

headline: Human Treasure Hunt: Scavenging for Moldable Models
text: In the annals of tell-alls about how pristine raw materials become shinier and tastier and more palatable, you have “The Jungle,” “Fast Food Nation” and now “Scouted,” the reality show about scavenging for potential models that has its premiere Monday on E.

headline: Opera Based on the Play ‘Doubt’ Is in the Works
text: John Patrick Shanley is set to create an opera based on his Pulitzer Prize-winning play, “Doubt,” with the help of the composer Douglas J. Cuomo (“Arjuna’s Dilemma”), Playbill.com reported. Commissioned by the Minnesota Opera, the production will feature a libretto by Mr. Shanley and music by Mr. Cuomo and is slated to have its premiere in 2013 as part of the company’s 50th anniversary season. The original play won four Tony Awards in 2005, including best play and best director. The 2008 film adaptation, directed by Mr. Shanley and starring Meryl Streep and Philip Seymour Hoffman, received five Academy Award nominations, including for best adapted screenplay.

headline: George Michael Cancels Tour Dates
text: George Michael has canceled the remaining dates for his European tour after being hospitalized in Vienna with severe pneumonia, the BBC News Web site reported. Mr. Michael, 48, right, who sang with the 1980s pop group Wham! before starting a successful solo career, was admitted last Monday. Although his condition has stabilized, and he is responding to treatment, Mr. Michael has been advised by doctors not to perform the remaining 14 dates of his “Symphonica” tour, according to a statement from Mr. Michael’s publicist.

headline: Stockard Channing Makes Quick Return
text: Less than a week after having arthroscopic surgery on her right knee,  Stockard Channing returned on Friday to her role as Polly Wyeth in Jon Robin Baitz’s “Other Desert Cities” at the Booth Theater, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Channing, 67, missed seven performances after injuring her knee backstage on Nov. 18. She plans to continue to perform in the role, though her understudy, Lauren Klein, will take over for Wednesday’s matinee performance, according to Lincoln Center Theater representatives. This drama about a dysfunctional family also stars Rachel Griffiths, Stacy Keach and Judith Light.

headline: Pentagon Invites ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Winner
text: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta has invited the soldier-turned-actor J. R. Martinez, who won the most recent “Dancing With the Stars” competition, to meet him at the Pentagon, The Associated Press reported. During a call on Friday, Mr. Panetta told Mr. Martinez that he demonstrated the strength and resilience of wounded veterans, said Capt. John Kirby, a Pentagon spokesman. Mr. Martinez, 28, has credited his military training for his performance on the show. He and his professional partner, Karina Smirnoff, above, defeated the partners Rob Kardashian and Ricki Lake in the finale broadcast on Tuesday. Mr. Martinez was severely burned over more than 40 percent of his body when the Humvee he was driving in Iraq struck a land mine in 2003. After dozens of operations over nearly three years, he became a motivational speaker and in 2008 won a role on the former ABC soap opera “All My Children.”

headline: Moderate Islamist Party to Lead Coalition Government in Morocco
text: RABAT, Morocco — A moderate Islamist party achieved major gains in Morocco’s parliamentary election, according to final returns announced by the government on Sunday, giving it the right to lead a coalition government. King Mohammed VI is now expected to choose a prime minister from the party, Justice and Development.

headline: Monday: Much-Kicked Body Part
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — What? Oh, the title of today’s post? The answer is SHIN. Why, what were you thinking?

headline: From Previews to Success, a Tangled Web
text: After myriad problems in previews, “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” is now making money.

headline: Turn on the Cash: After a Year, ‘Spider-Man’ Earns Its Weekly Keep
text: One year after naysayers were predicting a quick death, the musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” is doubling down on Broadway, forgoing potentially lucrative overseas tours in the near term to try to refine the New York production and burnish the long-term value of the show.

headline: Weinstein Sends Hollywood an Oscar-Time Mash Note
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — There he was, Harvey Weinstein, master of the movie awards game, flanked by a golden Oscar much taller than he, and two dark- haired granddaughters of Charlie Chaplin, the King of Silents.

headline: Protecting Clean Water

headline: Denying Public Access to Family Court Proceedings
text: To the Editor:

headline: Disruptions: Fliers Must Turn Off Devices, but It’s Not Clear Why
text: Millions of Americans who got on a plane over the Thanksgiving holiday heard the admonition: “Please power down your electronic devices for takeoff.”

headline: Asset Sale May Be Next for AT&T
text: Rethink possible. That is both AT&T’s marketing slogan and an apt summary of the challenges it faces now that its planned $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile USA looks increasingly doubtful.

headline: Hollywood Labor Fight Looms as Money for Benefits Wanes
text: LOS ANGELES — Bitter disputes over health and pension payments to union members have created plenty of drama in states and cities this year. But do not look for a movie about it — Hollywood will be too busy dealing with a labor crisis of its own.

headline: ‘The Nutcracker’
text: Photos of ‘George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker’ at Lincoln Center.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include new home sales for October (Monday); the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price index for September and the third quarter, and consumer confidence for November (Tuesday); pending home sales for September and the Federal Reserve beige book (Wednesday); the ISM manufacturing index for November and construction spending for October (Thursday); and unemployment for November (Friday).

headline: The Show Is Starting, Please Turn On Your Cellphones
text: It’s a taboo of the digital era: using a cellphone in a darkened theater. Some performance spaces, like Carnegie Hall, politely flash a notice reminding patrons to turn off electronic devices, while others, like the Alamo Drafthouse cinema chain in Texas, go so far as to eject violators.

headline: Montserrat Figueras, Catalan Soprano, Dies at 69
text: Montserrat Figueras, the glamorous, powerfully emotive Catalan soprano who along with her husband, Jordi Savall, created ensembles that revitalized the performance of early music, died on Wednesday at her home in Bellaterra, Spain. She was 69.

headline: In Liverpool, Moment of Silence Followed by Impassioned Roar
text: On a night as hard as any in recent times to feel the love for English soccer, Liverpool and Manchester City fought out a compelling, ferocious and ultimately equal Premier League game Sunday at Liverpool’s Anfield stadium.

headline: Ron Lyle, Who Met Ali for Title, Dies at 70
text: Ron Lyle, who learned to box while in prison for murder and went on to fight Muhammad Ali for the heavyweight championship and wage a memorably furious battle with George Foreman, died on Saturday in Denver. He was 70.

headline: Recovery Doesn’t Stop After Injuries Heal
text: Almost four years after sustaining severe head injuries and having his nose severed by a skate during an N.H.L. game, the former linesman Pat Dapuzzo is working as a scout for the Toronto Maple Leafs. The move, although an important step on the road to physical and emotional recovery, follows a decision he made earlier this year whose implications could extend well beyond his personal healing.

headline: The Branding of the Occupy Movement
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Kalle Lasn, the longtime editor of the anticonsumerist magazine Adbusters, did not invent the anger that has been feeding the Occupy Wall Street demonstrations across the United States.

headline: In Newark, a More Welcoming Response to Occupiers
text: NEWARK — The protesters attracted no drum circles but bobbed their heads to the rap music blasting from a passing sedan.

headline: A Reporter Entangled in the Story
text: Last summer, Amelia Hill, a special investigations correspondent for the British newspaper The Guardian, helped crack open the country’s hacking scandal for all to see. Working with her colleague Nick Davies, she pulled back the veil on the mind-boggling hacking of the murder victim Milly Dowler’s phone by The News of the World.

headline: Just Asking About J. Lo, Coke Zero and Cookies
text: IT is time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing, the media and popular culture.

headline: Francis H. Cabot, 86, Dies; Created Notable Gardens
text: Francis H. Cabot, a financier and self-taught horticulturalist who created two of the most celebrated gardens in North America and helped preserve scores of others, died on Nov. 19 at his home in La Malbaie, Quebec. He was 86.

headline: Election Financing: Paths and Pitfalls
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Giant of Strength From Toe to Head
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When the Giants and the New Orleans Saints play Monday night, there will be at least 20 players in the Superdome who weigh more than 300 pounds. There will be fleshy linemen and muscle-bound pass rushers battling to be proved the stoutest.

headline: I. Michael Heyman, Smithsonian Leader, Dies at 81
text: I. Michael Heyman, who led the Smithsonian Institution in the 1990s during a period of significant expansion and fierce controversy over the exhibiting of the Enola Gay, the plane that dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima, died on Nov. 19 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Disney Releases Marvel App
text: When reading books, some children like to turn the page, others like to swipe the screen.

headline: An Amateur With a Pro’s Resolve
text: SAN MARTIN, Calif. — Collegiate golf is the acoustic version of the pro game: unamplified by applause, announcers, grandstands, clacking electronic scoreboards or chattering caddies. For upward of five hours, the competitors are essentially alone with their thoughts.

headline: Vasily Alekseyev, 69, Champion Weight Lifter, Dies
text: Vasily Alekseyev, the Soviet super heavyweight lifter who won 2 Olympic gold medals and set 80 world records, reigning as the so-called world’s strongest man in the 1970s, died Friday at a heart clinic in Badenhausen, Germany. He was 69.

headline: Texans Begin to Feel the Pain of One Injury Too Many
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.

headline: Oklahoma Continues String of Recent Mild Earthquakes
text: The generally placid, well-mannered state of Oklahoma has developed a very West Coast habit of late: the state, it seems, has got the shakes.

headline: Santas Schooled in Restraint
text: The economic downturn is forcing some to help curb children’s expectations.

headline: Deadline Passes for Occupy Philly to Dismantle Camp
text: In center city Philadelphia, hundreds gathered outside City Hall in a show of solidarity ahead of a city-imposed Sunday evening deadline to clear a campsite there. The protesters braced for a police sweep, but it did not take place immediately after the 5 p.m. deadline, surprising few.

headline: An Olympic Youth Appeal
text: Continuing its effort to make sure young media consumers don’t miss the coming Olympics, the International Olympic Committee is focusing the latest iteration of its promotional campaign on the 12- to 19-year-old market.

headline: Educating Santa
text: The Charles W. Howard Santa Claus school in Midland, Mich., teaches aspiring Santas everything from dance lessons to beard grooming.

headline: In Gloomy Economic Times, Santas Learn to Help by Curbing Expectations
text: MIDLAND, Mich. — Here, at the nation’s oldest, most celebrated, school for would-be Santa Clauses, much has stayed exactly the same over its nearly 75 years. A proper Claus ought to have pleasant breath, his beard curled just so and a hearty laugh that rumbles not from the throat but from deep below the diaphragm.

headline: Hey, Hey, Hey, Goodbye?
text: Under the N.B.A.’s new labor deal, every team can waive one player and remove his salary from the cap. The so-called “amnesty” provision could help teams create cap room or save millions on the luxury tax. (The player is still paid.) Here are five bad contracts worth expunging:

headline: Poof! Goes a Bad Contract, if Any N.B.A. Team Wishes
text: In the N.B.A., where bad contracts are more common than lane violations, every team executive dreams of a way to expunge his mistakes.

headline: Newspaper’s Endorsement Has Been Leading Indicator in New Hampshire
text: On Sunday, The Union Leader of Manchester, New Hampshire’s largest newspaper, endorsed Newt Gingrich for president. The endorsement represents one of the most tangible signs of parts of the conservative establishment coming around to Mr. Gingrich, who to date has received very few endorsements from Republican elected officials. It also represents a blow to Mitt Romney, who had led all polls of the state.

headline: In Fog of War, Rift Widens Between U.S. and Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON — The NATO air attack that killed at least two dozen Pakistani soldiers over the weekend reflected a fundamental truth about American-Pakistani relations when it comes to securing the unruly border with Afghanistan: the tactics of war can easily undercut the broader strategy that leaders of both countries say they share.

headline: Chinese Exports Show Trouble for Asian Economies
text: China’s manufacturing engine is sputtering, which bodes ill for other Asian exporters like Japan and South Korea. They’re counting on China to offset slowing demand from the United States and Europe. But much of what China imports goes into making its own exports. And even what bona fide domestic demand is left is likely to be affected by a trade slowdown.

headline: Partnership Preserves Livelihoods and Fish Stocks
text: HALF MOON BAY, Calif. — Stevie Fitz, a commercial fisherman, was pulling up his catch in one of his favorite spots off of Point Reyes in June when he saw something terrifying — in his nets were nearly 300 bocaccio, a dwindling species of rockfish protected by the government.

headline: Once a Protector, Now Grateful for Her Own Rescue
text: Once, while most New Yorkers slept, Marjorie Suarez would be wide awake.

headline: For a Weekend, at Least, Retailers See Record Numbers
text: Spurred by aggressive promotions from retailers, American consumers opened their wallets over the holiday weekend in a way they had not since before the recession, setting records in sales and traffic.

headline: Greeks Balk at Paying Steep New Property Tax
text: NEA IONIA, Greece — Ioannis Chatzis is 86 and lives in a tiny, single room, surviving on a pension that is just enough to pay for food and care for his bedridden wife.

headline: Syracuse Fires Fine After New Allegations in Molestation Case
text: With clipboard in hand, the Syracuse associate head coach Bernie Fine was a continual presence at the side of Jim Boeheim as the Orange men’s basketball program bloomed into a national power. But as the scope of molestation allegations against Fine grew over the weekend, the university decided to fire him.

headline: Senator Questions Extension of Tax Cut
text: WASHINGTON — The No. 2 Senate Republican, Jon Kyl, expressed concern on Sunday about President Obama’s proposal to continue a reduction in the Social Security payroll tax and questioned whether the tax cut had fostered the creation of jobs, as Democrats say.

headline: The Perils of Celebrating Before Anything’s Won
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Power Ceded, Yet President of Yemen Declares Amnesty
text: SANA, Yemen — Ignoring calls by his opponents to stop announcing decisions that affect the country, President Ali Abdullah Saleh declared a general amnesty on Sunday for people who had committed “follies” during the uprising and political crisis that began in Yemen 10 months ago.

headline: Bowl Championship Series Standings
text: The B.C.S. rankings are determined by three components: the Harris Interactive poll, the USA Today coaches poll and the average of six computer rankings. Each component counts one-third toward a team’s B.C.S. score.

headline: Bees and the City
text: To the 19,200 species of bees on this planet, a researcher named Jason Gibbs at Cornell University has just added 11 more, all of them from the Eastern United States. More interesting still, four of the bee species come from New York City and its immediate environs.

headline: Zynga’s Tough Culture Risks a Talent Drain
text: Zynga’s chief executive, Mark Pincus, got an earful from employees last month.

headline: A Vacancy That Needs to Be Filled
text: Now that Congressional Republicans will no longer have Dr. Donald Berwick to demonize as head of the federal agency that runs Medicare and Medicaid, is it too much to hope that they will declare a cease-fire and allow quick confirmation of his proposed successor?

headline: Still Fighting Against AIDS
text: The latest report from the United Nations agency in charge of the global fight against AIDS reveals substantial success by some measures and stagnation by others. The challenge, in tough times, that must be met is to find enough resources to capitalize on scientific breakthroughs and keep the campaign moving forward.

headline: Friend? Foe? A Republican Scorecard
text: Moments before the start of a recent presidential debate at Dartmouth College, Mitt Romney and Herman Cain flung open the doors to their closet-size green rooms and ran into Newt Gingrich.

headline: Lincoln’s Do-Nothing Generals
text: The Civil War’s first year was one marked by inactivity and battlefield frustration. There was just one major battle, at Bull Run, and only a handful of minor engagements, most of them semi-guerrilla fighting in and around Missouri.

headline: L.S.U.-Alabama Rematch for Title Is All but Certain
text: Advocates of the Bowl Championship Series, the relentlessly criticized method college football uses for picking its national title game, often stick to the talking point that every week feels like a playoff.

headline: Youth Leader in Egypt Straddles Line of Revolution and Electoral Change
text: CAIRO — Over the past week, just as his campaign to capture a Parliament seat for Egypt’s strongest liberal party should have reached its zenith, Zyad Elelaimy stopped giving speeches and migrated back to the place where he made his mark 10 months ago: Tahrir Square.

headline: Thanksgiving Weekend Sales Were Strong This Year
text: Retail sales were up sharply this Thanksgiving weekend

headline: Lottery Numbers
Rough Times Take Bloom Off a New Year’s Rite, the Rose Parade
text: PASADENA, Calif. — With its peppy bands, whimsical floats and flood of flowers, the Rose Parade here has long been a symbol of the hopes of a New Year.

headline: From Ashes of Olympic Bid, a Future Rises for the Far West Side
text: Late in his first term, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suffered a stinging defeat when, after an extensive planning and public relations effort, New York City lost its bid to host the 2012 Summer Olympics.

headline: Federer Comes Out on Top
text: In his 100th final, Roger Federer outsteadied Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, 6-3, 6-7 (6), 6-3, Sunday at the ATP World Tour Finals in London, capturing his 70th career singles title. The victory made Federer the first man to win the year-ending championships six times and extended his winning streak to 17, his longest since 2009.

headline: Are Germany and France Drifting Apart?
text: At first the debt crisis brought them closer. Now it may be splintering a decades-old alliance.

headline: Things to Tax
text: The supercommittee was a superdud — and we should be glad. Nonetheless, at some point we’ll have to rein in budget deficits. And when we do, here’s a thought: How about making increased revenue an important part of the deal?

headline: The Price of Intolerance
text: It’s early yet for a full accounting of the economic damage Alabama has done to itself with its radical new immigration law.

headline: New Life, Surprisingly, for ABC Prime Time
text: The prospects for ABC and its new chief programmer, Paul Lee, hardly looked rosy at the start of the fall television season.

headline: The Politics of Economics in the Age of Shouting
text: I share a virtual neighborhood with a legion of Times reporters, editors and columnists who know more than I will ever know about business and economics. (Look! Right over there: a Nobel-prize-winning economist!) In this humbling company, on this intimidating matter, who am I to tell anyone what to think? And so my plan was, frankly, to avoid the subject.

headline: Lululemon Athletica Combines Ayn Rand and Yoga
text: OTTAWA — Lululemon Athletica, the retailer of yoga pants and hoodies, has long decorated shopping bags with slogans that appear to have been lifted from self-help books. But this month its bags have asked a question that some may find more provocative: “Who is John Galt?”

headline: A Laugh on the Subway, and Other NYTimes.com Reader Stories
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: ‘Today’ Repeats Come to the Late-Night Rescue
text: This fall, NBC quietly started to repeat the fourth hour of the “Today” show, starring Kathie Lee Gifford and Hoda Kotb and usually seen at 10 a.m., the next day at 2 a.m.

headline: With Blocks, Educators Go Back to Basics
text: Huddled together on the reading rug of a prekindergarten classroom on the Upper West Side, three budding builders assembled a multilayered church with a Gothic arch. Nearby, another block artist created a castle with a connecting courtyard. Meanwhile, a fifth toiled earnestly on a shaky tower, eliciting oohs and aahs from across the room when it came tumbling down.

headline: Euro Zone Leaders Weigh New Budget Rules
text: BERLIN — Euro zone leaders are discussing a deal among themselves to institute strict new budget rules for their countries, rather than go through the long, complicated process of amending European Union treaties. By acting more quickly, they hope to reassure skeptical financial markets and encourage the European Central Bank to do more to fight the deepening sovereign debt crisis on the Continent.

headline: Speeding Through an Intersection of New and Old
text: For years, the prospect of an oblong intersection on West 72nd Street was part of a larger battle over the future of the Upper West Side. Now that that future has arrived, the intersection has become a gateway between two parts of the neighborhood with very different approaches to resolving community problems.

headline: Federal Cuts Give Maine a Chill as Winter Approaches
text: BANGOR, Me. — Michele Hodges works six days a week but still cannot afford a Maine winter’s worth of heat for her trailer in Corinth, a tiny town where snowmobiles can outnumber cars.

headline: Gingrich Eager to Be More Than an Anti-Romney
text: For Newt Gingrich, this is when it gets serious.

headline: Egypt’s Turmoil Overshadows First Post-Mubarak Vote
text: CAIRO — Egyptians braced for mayhem and disappointment but clung to their hopes for democracy Sunday, on the eve of their first parliamentary election since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak 10 months ago.

headline: Egyptians Await Elections
text: Egyptians braced for mayhem and disappointment but clung to their hopes for democracy the day before the first parliamentary election since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: At Meeting on Climate Change, Urgent Issues but Low Expectations
text: WASHINGTON — With intensifying climate disasters and global economic turmoil as the backdrop, delegates from 194 nations will gather in Durban, South Africa, starting Monday to try to advance, if only incrementally, the world’s response to dangerous climate change.

text: A look at the Jets’ 28-21 victory over the Buffalo Bills.

text: Now that David Stern’s nuclear winter has turned into a mere snow day, the N.B.A. will most likely sign a new collective bargaining agreement in a few days and resume operations on Dec. 9.
