text: A look at the metropolitan area’s three franchises at the quarter mark of the N.H.L. season.

headline: ‘Spreading the Wealth’ in Democrats’ Favor
text: WASHINGTON — Fighting from behind in the final days of the 2008 presidential election, Senator John McCain found a weapon in an unscripted encounter between his opponent, Senator Barack Obama, and a voter.

headline: The Future of the Obama Coalition
text: For decades, Democrats have suffered continuous and increasingly severe losses among white voters. But preparations by Democratic operatives for the 2012 election make it clear for the first time that the party will explicitly abandon the white working class.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 27
text: A view of the day in sports, from hard-fought football games across the United States and Canada to a historic tennis victory in London.

headline: New Scrutiny of Federal Dollars for Tutoring
text: The No Child Left Behind law required struggling schools to set aside some of their federal assistance to provide tutoring for low-income students. New York City now spends $100 million a year on tutoring. But with New York and other states seeking waivers from the No Child Left Behind Law, tutoring has come under scrutiny.

headline: Prosecution Explains Jury Tampering Charge
text: Julian P. Heicklen, a 79-year-old retired chemistry professor, has often stood on a plaza outside the United States Courthouse in Manhattan, holding a “Jury Info” sign and handing out brochures that advocate jury nullification, the controversial view that if jurors disagree with a law, they may ignore their oaths to follow it and may acquit a defendant who violated it.

headline: Word of the Day | asymmetric
text: asymmetric •\ˌa-sə-ˈme-trik\ • adjective

headline: Shares Soar on Talk of a Europe Deal
text: Stocks and the euro rose sharply Monday, as investors took heart at signs that European leaders were pushing toward new measures to rescue the currency union.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Monday
text: India and Pakistan will hold their first-ever joint court proceedings, when a judicial commission from Pakistan comes to India to authenticate Ajmal Kasab’s statement in Mumbai. Mr. Kasab has been convicted for his role in the 2008 Mumbai terror attacks. “It is a unique case, where the lawyers are from Pakistan, the witnesses are from India, and the judge will be an Indian,” a source told The Indian Express.

headline: Los Angeles Police Withdraw After Occupy Eviction Deadline Passes
text: LOS ANGELES — It had all the makings of a showdown: shouting protesters, police officers in riot gear, with batons drawn as they pushed forward to disperse the crowd. But in the end, as the deadline for Occupy Los Angeles protesters to clear their tents from City Hall passed early Monday morning, there was hardly a commotion.

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 28, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Hanging By a Thread
text: After a tumultuous year, the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” turns one.

headline: After Mumbai Remembrances, Anger
text: This past weekend, the third anniversary of the three-day siege of Mumbai that began Nov. 26, 2008, and left more than 170 dead, a series of remembrances were held.

headline: In a Surprise, Calm Prevails in Egypt’s Elections
text: CAIRO — Unexpectedly large crowds of Egyptians on Monday defied predictions of bedlam and violence to cast their votes in the first parliamentary elections since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Killings and Intimidation Mar Elections in Congo
text: KINSHASA, Congo — Ballot boxes on fire, rebel fighters gunning down poll workers and outbursts of mob violence marred Congo’s national elections on Monday, only the second time this vast and troubled country has held anything resembling a democratic vote.

headline: Nov. 28, 1943 | Allied Leaders Meet at Tehran Conference
text: On Nov. 28, 1943, President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Prime Minister Winston Churchill of Britain and the Soviet leader Josef Stalin met in Tehran during World War II for the start of a four-day conference. It was the first meeting between the “Big Three” Allied leaders.News of the conference was not released until three days after its completion, when it was announced by Moscow radio. The Dec. 4 New York Times reported that “Moscow radio had not indicated the nature of political and military discussions that took place in the Iranian capital, but it was generally assumed they dealt with the coordination of military plans for the final assault on Nazi Germany and with the unification of political plans for making peace with Germany on the basis of ‘unconditional surrender.’”

headline: In Cairo, a Painterly Cast of Characters
text: The most recent images of Egypt’s ongoing upheaval depict chaotic crowds of anonymous young men and women. But since Miguel Angel Sánchez moved to Cairo in 2009, he has singled out the individual, bathing them in dramatic light and shadows like old master portraits.

headline: The Start of a New Era for Roman Catholics
text: WHAT change occurred over the weekend in the Catholic Mass?WHAT are two examples of the new wording?

headline: Hack a Mole
text: MONTREAL — Something is amiss in Venezuela’s Twittersphere: all of a sudden, opposition figures with a long history of criticizing the government of President Hugo Chávez have flipped, posting hearty praise for Chavismo and streams of invectives against their own camp. Has the government made a great leap in winning over new followers? Hardly. Instead, one after another, opposition figures have had their accounts taken over by progovernment hackers.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 28, 2011
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article “Stone-Washed Blue Jeans (Minus the Washed).”

headline: Dire Warnings Are Building on European Debt Crisis
text: PARIS — European leaders faced mounting pressure on Monday to overcome divisions and move ahead quickly with new plans to prevent the euro currency region from fracturing, as warnings multiplied that the crisis could endanger the global economy and cause credit to dry up in the banking system.

headline: Berlin Exhibit Explores Magnitsky Case
text: A permanent exhibition at the Checkpoint Charlie Museum (Friedrichstrasse 43-45; mauermuseum.de) in Berlin exposes a modern-day saga of governmental corruption, coercion and torture. The Sergei Magnitsky case revealed egregious abuses of power that continue to plague Putin’s Russia and which ultimately led to the tragic demise of the 37-year-old tax attorney Magnitsky, while he was held captive in a maximum security Russian prison.

headline: Week 12 Quick Hits: Denver’s Defense Wins Another
text: A quick tour of Sunday’s Week 12 games, including an eerie silence in Philadelphia, a star turn by a punter and a costly celebration by a receiver.

text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Lawmakers Look to Rein In Their Investing
text: The coverage was hard-hitting and shocking to some: Members of Congress received special opportunities to get in on the ground floor of stock offerings, and were actively trading in shares of companies “whose prosperity they influence and whose conduct they help to regulate.”

headline: What Time Should Black Friday Sales Start?
text: In addition to the shopper who was said to have used pepper spray on her competitors, Black Friday 2011 will be remembered for store openings that took place at midnight or earlier, meaning that Black Friday actually started on Thanksgiving. What do you think about this? Did you shop the early sales or know people who did?

headline: Ken Russell, Director Fond of Provocation, Dies at 84
text: Ken Russell, the English filmmaker and writer whose outsize personality matched the confrontational brashness of his movies, among them “Women in Love” and “The Devils,” died on Sunday at his home in Lymington, England. He was 84.

headline: Transforming the Sarangi into a ‘Supple Human Voice’
text: Ustad Sultan Khan, the renowned sarangi player and classical singer who died Sunday, was sought after by Bollywood composers and traveled with George Harrison, but in India he earned the most respect for reviving a dying art.

headline: Joe Kapp, the C.F.L.  and a 48-Year-Old Grudge
text: They played the Grey Cup on Sunday  in Vancouver, but  the C.F.L. battle that many people wanted to discuss happened at the Canadian Football League alumni luncheon two days earlier. Joe Kapp, 73, fought an old C.F.L. adversary, Angelo Mosca, also 73, on the stage.

headline: Complaint Box | Gift Registries
text: The joy of gift-giving is over. Finding that certain something that will elicit shrieks of surprise: a thing of the past. Lost forever is the warmth of knowing that a friend or family member thought long and hard about just what to give you. Also gone — the laughter when a loved one opens a third blender or fourth wok.

headline: This Week In Small Business: What Would Canada Do?
text: What’s affecting my clients, my small-business and other small-business owners this past week.

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 28
text: Ticket sales for Hollywood’s five-day Thanksgiving sales period — an important springboard to Christmas — totaled about $234 million, an 11 percent decline from the period a year earlier, Brooks Barnes reported. The No. 1 film was a holdover, “The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn — Part 1” (Summit Entertainment), which took in an estimated $62.3 million during the long weekend. It had a two-week total of $221.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticket data. At No. 2 was a new release, “The Muppets” (Walt Disney Studios), which had estimated ticket sales of $42 million.

headline: A Note to Readers
text: This week I’m in Paris, France. I’ll still write in this space, but not as much as usual. So I’ve asked David Firestone, who covers politics for the editorial board, to pick up the slack. You’ll notice his byline throughout the week.

headline: The New Oscar Season
text: Melena Ryzik looks at the newest slate of Oscar contenders and polls New Yorkers for their opinions.

headline: Andy Reid, DeSean Jackson and Endings for Eagles
text: The two longest-tenured coaches in the N.F.L. met on Sunday in Philadelphia. After the game, fans and columnists questioned whether Andy Reid, No. 1 on the list, should keep his job. Of course, it was Philadelphia, so that’s never not going to be a question.

headline: Monday Reading: The Dwindling Power of a College Degree
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: We’re Baaa-ack
text: It’s post-Thanksgiving, pre-NBA return and at least a few weeks until the next Republican debate. All of which means that it’s time once again for the Carpetbagger to strap on our heels and our celebrity bull detector (who are we kidding; we wear these every day) and hit some red carpets in pursuit of the latest news about stars, filmmakers, hangers-on, enablers and their enduring, ever-shimmering quest for Oscar glory, or at least a nice bump in DVD sales.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: DEAL NOTES

headline: Breakeven Bad
text: One measure I’ve been tracking lately is the German 5-year breakeven. That’s the difference between the interest rate on ordinary German 5-year bonds and the interest rate on 5-year bonds that are indexed to inflation (as measured by the euro area harmonized CPI); because one bond is protected against inflation while the other isn’t, the breakeven amounts to an implicit market forecast of inflation.

headline: Guardians of the Peace, and Guardians in the Press
text: Antigovernment demonstrators took to the streets of Manhattan, marching helter-skelter from the Battery to the United Nations. Several hundred were arrested.

headline: Daily Report: Zynga’s Big Risks
text: As Zynga, the maker of popular social games like FarmVille and CastleVille, moves toward a public stock offering, its business practices and its chief executive, Mark Pincus, are getting plenty of scrutiny. Evelyn M. Rusli writes in Monday’s Times that the company’s internal culture is something like an endless war: “Employees log long hours, managers relentlessly track progress, and the weak links are demoted or let go.” She talked to former senior employees who fear that this relentlessness could damage the company. Start-ups including Rovio, the maker of Angry Birds, have rebuffed acquisition offers from Zynga.

headline: Opinion Report: Alabama’s Immigration Law
text: From the editorial page

headline: Principals' Rebellion Against Evaluations Grows
text: The suburbs are the breeding ground for a growing rebellion by New York principals against the new system of evaluating teachers.  The principals do not object only to the use of student test results as a significant portion of teacher evaluations, the fulfillment of a pledge the state made to acquire $700 million in federal Race to the Top grants. They also object to the willy-nilly way that they say the evaluation system is being devised.

headline: On Black Friday, Pepper Spray Carried the Day
text: Each year, retail reporters are expected to step to Black Friday, that hardy perennial of trend stories, and find a fresh angle. (Before the opening gong even sounded, we learned that $395,000 Ferraris were hot and Wal-Mart was not.)

headline: The Author as Your Average Joe
text: Joseph Gordon-Levitt’s star turns in “50/50” and “Inception” may have overshadowed the recent success of his online passion project, hitRECord.org. The Web site invites artists from all walks of life to collaborate with the actor, resulting in music, short films and, now, a picture book called “The Tiny Book of Tiny Stories” ($15). The sweetly amateurish story collection is the first in a trilogy of titles from It Books, part of the publishing giant HarperCollins. Here Gordon-Levitt, 30, explains why this book deal is not just a coup for his young company but also an object lesson in how it works.

headline: So Did Tebow Play Well?
text: Not according to ESPN’s Total QBR, a relatively new rating system that assigned Tim Tebow a low score of 29.7 in Denver’s overtime victory against San Diego on Sunday.

headline: A Shopping Day Invented for the Web Comes of Age
text: Cyber Monday may have started as a made-up occasion to give underdog e-commerce sites jealous of Black Friday a day of their own, but it has become an undeniably real thing — surprising even the people who invented it.

headline: Monday Matchup: Giants at Saints
text: Giants (6-4) at Saints (7-3), 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPNLine: Saints by 7

headline: Bowie Shoots Down Report of Musical Based on His Songs
text: The idea of a stage musical shaped around the songbook of David Bowie may sound like a beautiful moonage daydream, but it apparently won’t come to fruition unless the godfather of glam rock ch-ch-ch-ch-changes his mind.

headline: With Asset Sale, Tepco to Raise $2.4 Billion
text: TOKYO – The Tokyo Electric Power Company, operator of the crippled nuclear power plant at Fukushima, said on Monday that it would raise 186 billion yen, or $2.4 billion, by selling its entire stake in the mobile network operator KDDI.

headline: Syria Calls the Arab League’s Sanctions ‘Economic War’
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — The Arab League declared “economic war” on Syria when it leveled broad trade sanctions against it, Syria’s foreign minister, Walid al-Moallem, said on Monday, warning that the country could use its strategic location to retaliate.

headline: On Our Radar: Global Climate Talks in Durban
text: Nearly 200 nations open a global conference on climate change, with industrialized countries arguing that big developing economies like China, India and Brazil must submit to emissions targets regardless of whether wealthier countries set global warming in motion. [Reuters]

headline: New Wave of Bombings Raises Toll for Iraqis
text: BAGHDAD — A yellow taxi loaded with explosives blew up at the crowded front gates of a prison north of Baghdad on Monday morning, killing at least 13 people, many of them security guards or civilians waiting to visit jailed family members.

headline: The Case Against Banning Chocolate Milk
text: Here’s the clearly very sensible Penny McConnell of the Fairfax County school system, in Virginia, on chocolate milk: “Banning a food may not be as helpful as the more complicated task of teaching kids to look at their whole plates, and make good choices.”

headline: Barney Frank to Quit House After 30 Years
text: 5:32 p.m. | Updated  NEWTON, Mass. — Representative Barney Frank, the tart-tongued liberal who has served in the House of Representatives for 30 years, said Monday that he had decided to retire in 2012 after his Massachusetts district was recently redrawn and it became clear that he would have to fight harder than he wanted for re-election.

headline: Works by Disney, Before He Started Mousing Around, Are for Sale

headline: Laura & Siddique
text: In this homemade video, Laura Banish and Dr. Siddique Abbasi share their modern-day Romeo and Juliet story where she wasn't the traditional Indian bride his parents were expecting.

headline: Waiting on Word From Boston, Valentine Visits Japan
text: As he waits to learn whether the Boston Red Sox will hire him to be their next manager, Bobby Valentine took time to visit the tsunami-ravaged city of Sendai in Japan on Monday.

headline: Street Style: Pleats
text: The best of readers’ street style for the week of Nov. 21.

headline: Numberplay: Beads on Wire
text: It’s bead versus bead — each about to slide down a wire and into a soft wax disk. The wires are identical except for a bump. On one wire the bump faces up, and on the other wire it faces down.

headline: Surprise! There Are Already  Oscar Controversies
text: If you were busy following the Greek debt crisis – and of course you were; Kardashian is a Greek name, right? – let the Bagger catch you up as, lo and behold, there has been scandal in awards land already. In descending order of interest to water-cooler watchers, cinephiles and film industry insiders:

headline: Shocker: Readers of News of the World Vanish
text: News of the World, the 168-year-old newspaper that was closed in July by News Corporation in the wake of phone-hacking revelations, seems to have taken its readers with it.

headline: Monday Motorsports: A Win for Mark Webber Closes Historic 2011 Formula One Season
text: Not always dutifully, Mark Webber played second fiddle in 2011 to Sebastian Vettel, his Red Bull teammate, as Vettel strung together one of the most dominant seasons in Formula One history. At the Interlagos circuit in the state of São Paulo, Brazil, he finally got the upper hand, though it required an assist from an ill-tempered gearbox.

headline: Icahn Offers to Buy Metals Company
text: 1:07 p.m. | Updated

headline: Pakistan Rejects U.S. Account of NATO Strikes Along Border
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani angrily protested the NATO strikes that killed two dozen Pakistani soldiers over the weekend, even as early American and Pakistani accounts of the events diverged sharply and it remained unclear exactly what precipitated the attack.

headline: Julie Conason: Learning Through Relationships
text: The principal of one of the smallest high schools in the city, Humanities Preparatory Academy in Chelsea, embraced the opportunity to lead a school that does not "live and die by the Regents scores." With its alternative assessment system, the school has managed to raise the graduation rate to 95 percent  from 41 percent in 2008. It also emphasizes strong values and a sense of responsibility by students,  and, she says, "I’ve never seen it in action as much as I see it here."

headline: Bad Tidings
text: After the wave, the author, a self-absorbed Frenchman filled with self-pity, experienced a life-changing emotion: empathy. The following excerpt is adapted from ‘‘Lives Other Than My Own,’’ which was published in September by Metropolitan Books.

headline: The Fallout Over Syracuse’s Abuse Scandal
text: On the heels of the recent and continuing events at Penn State University, another college is also under scrutiny surrounding allegations of child molestation.  As Pete Thamel reported in Monday’s Times, Syracuse University dismissed its longtime associate head basketball coach Bernie Fine on Sunday night after three accusers came forward and a graphic taped telephone conversation from 2002 emerged.

headline: Gingrich Says He’s ‘Conservative Alternative’ to Romney
text: Newt Gingrich, who not long ago was urging his fellow Republican candidates to avoid tearing one another apart in pursuit of the party’s presidential nomination, took a new approach on Monday by explicitly declaring: “I don’t claim to be the perfect candidate; I just claim to be a lot more conservative than Mitt Romney.”

headline: 40 Years on the Court, and It’s Not Even Halftime
text: How many basketball players in pickup games around New York City still have a killer two-handed set shot?

headline: A Deeper Scowl for the Pumpkins of Kane Street
text: The sidewalk seems a not-so-distant resting place for some pumpkins in an array of 100 carved by Jane Greengold of Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. The wretched decline of the tortured scowls is a Halloween tradition being closely watched by City Room.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Names New Artistic Director
text: 12:46 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Immigrant Fitness Test
text: Last week, the editorial board praised Newt Gingrich for breaking from the Republican pack and supporting a path to legal residency for long-time illegal immigrants. Now Mr. Gingrich is starting to flesh out that idea–since he has revived his standing on the right wing of the party and appears to think he’s got a shot at the nomination–but it turns out to be much less thoughtful and generous than it appeared during the debate.

headline: Iran Moves to Downgrade Its Relations with Britain
text: Iran enacted legislation on Monday to downgrade relations with Britain, in retaliation for intensified sanctions imposed by Western nations last week to punish the Iranians for their suspect nuclear development program. Britain promised to respond “robustly.”

headline: The Sudden Pivot at Syracuse
text: Sometimes scandals make the accompanying outrage easy. At Penn State, it was all but served on a platter complete with a doily and silverware. The child sexual abuse scandal of Jerry Sandusky came with an 18-month grand jury investigation and a university in full turtle mode. With Syracuse, even if you wanted to greet the firing of the assistant basketball coach Bernie Fine for similar abuse allegations with the same sense of horror, even if it’s the right thing to do, it’s just more complicated.

headline: A New Old Way to Fish
text: Fisherman and an environmental group are working together to bring a collapsed fishery back from the brink by using older fishing methods and new technology.

headline: Backup Quarterbacks Lead Playoff Chase
text: It has become the portrait of the season, a quarterback standing disconsolately on the sideline, sometimes surrounded by trainers, but often alone with his splint or brace or sling.

headline: Plan for a Memorial Splits Newport’s Old Guard
text: NEWPORT, R.I. — When Doris Duke was clearing a patch of derelict buildings here in the late 1970s to create a modest patch of open space known as Queen Anne Square, she was sometimes spotted personally directing the backhoe drivers at dusk, acting as both foreman and steward of the enormous fortune that she lavished on such restoration projects.

headline: What Rikers Visitors Saw, and What Really Happened
text: The long line of women and children and, much more scarce, men outside Rikers Island on visiting day is never what you’d call happy to begin with, with mothers corralling cranky children and shouting over the roar of jets, practically within reach, leaving neighboring La Guardia Airport. It does not take much to set this group of people off.

headline: Drowning in Grover’s Lake
text: Never mind drowning the US government in a bathtub: Grover Norquist is trying to drown the whole economy in a lake:

headline: Barney Frank’s War of Words With Wall Street
text: Barney Frank, the famously grumpy Massachusetts representative, who announced on Monday that he will not seek re-election next year, has had a 16-term legacy studded with legislative accomplishments.

headline: How the Fed Rescue Benefited Banks
text: A report by Bloomberg News offers a new way of quantifying the Federal Reserve’s vast efforts to save financial companies from collapse during the crisis that peaked in 2008.

headline: Lens: Harvey Wang
text: Lens: Harvey Wang

headline: Children’s Weight Does Not Affect Safety of Child Seats, Researchers Find
text: As long as children ride in a properly positioned seat for their height and weight, child safety and booster seats provide adequate protection in a crash, regardless of whether a child is underweight or overweight, according to a study released by the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia’s Center for Injury Research and Prevention.

headline: Judge Blocks Citigroup Settlement With S.E.C.
text: WASHINGTON — Taking a broad swipe at the Securities and Exchange Commission’s practice of allowing companies to settle cases without admitting that they had done anything wrong, a federal judge on Monday rejected a $285 million settlement between Citigroup and the agency.

headline: Steven Pinker
text: An interview with the Harvard psychologist and linguist on violence, language and Twitter.

headline: Baseball’s New Schedule Should Be All About Rivalries
text: Baseball, that most traditional of sports, is once again making a radical shift. For the third time in two decades, it is realigning. The latest move will transfer the Houston Astros from the National League Central to the American League West, giving each division 5 teams and each league 15 teams, creating the need to schedule at least one interleague series at all times.

headline: Human Nature’s Pathologist
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Steven Pinker was a 15-year-old anarchist. He didn’t think people needed a police force to keep the peace. Governments caused the very problems they were supposed to solve.

headline: On the Campaign Trail with Harvey Weinstein
text: LOS ANGELES — “The Artist,” a mostly silent film that played well abroad, is finally open — and into the Oscar race — in the United States. As we reported here, Harvey Weinstein is doing his best to make the film a contender, even bringing two granddaughters of Charlie Chaplin to a screening at the Academy itself.

headline: The Power Politics of Water Struggles
text: When you’re driving through a war zone, your instinct may be to roll up the car windows. Wrong move. A bullet is less likely to hit you than to strike the glass, which will shatter and probably cause injuries. It takes firsthand experience to learn these tricks of the trade, and for years, Mark Zeitoun has sought out such experience.

headline: Pinkerisms
text: Selections from Steven Pinker’s writings on language, evolution and the mind.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Benoit Denizet-Lewis on Bulldogs
text: Benoit Denizet-Lewis, the author of Sunday’s cover article on bulldogs, began writing for the magazine in 2002, when he was 26. Since then, he has written six cover articles and numerous features, including his recent piece about his ex-gay friend, Michael Glatze. He is also the author of “America Anonymous: Eight Addicts in Search of a Life.”

headline: Chait on the Democrats, Frum on the Republicans
text: In addition to Frank Rich’s piece on the parallels between Barack Obama and J.F.K., whose premise I disputed rather vigorously in yesterday’s column, New York Magazine’s politics issue included provocative pieces by Jonathan Chait (on why Democrats are perpetually dissatisfied with their presidents) and David Frum (on why Republicans have lurched into extremism and folly). I agree with many of the points that both authors make, but I think that both pieces indulge in a kind of partisan bias in reverse: Instead of giving their own side too much credit, they make their own side’s vices seem somewhat more distinctive than they really are. For instance, here is Chait contrasting Democratic infighting with Republican loyalty:

headline: CUNY Prepares for More Student Protests
text: As City University of New York trustees prepare to vote Monday afternoon on a series of tuition increases over the next few years, the school system is bracing for a possible repeat of the conflict that marred last week’s hearing on the increases.

headline: TimesCast | November 28, 2011
text: Egypt votes in a historic parliamentary election; Congolese voters encounter problems at the ballots; and the first anniversary of "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark."

headline: The Rakoff Rejection
text: Jed S. Rakoff, a judge for the Federal District Court for the Southern District of Manhattan, has rejected the proposed $285 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Citigroup related to the sale of mortgage securities.

headline: An Interview With George Kateb
text: George Kateb is a Professor Emeritus in the political science department at Princeton University.

headline: Validus Abandons Transatlantic Bid
text: The long fight for Transatlantic Holdings appears to be finally over.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: The Acorn division of Totes-Isotoner, Lewiston, Me., which sells footwear, selected Kelliher Samets Volk, Burlington, Vt., as its agency. Billings were not disclosed for the assignment, which had been handled by local design companies.

headline: Lana Peters, Stalin’s Daughter, Dies at 85
text: Her three successive names were signposts on a twisted, bewildering road that took her from Stalin’s Kremlin, where she was the “little princess,” to the West in a celebrated defection, then back to the Soviet Union in a puzzling homecoming, and finally to decades of obscurity, wandering and poverty.

headline: In New Ads, Some (Drinkers) Like It Hot
text: Remember the commercials that proclaimed Reese’s Peanut Butter Cups offered “two great tastes that taste great together”? A campaign for a new variety of a venerable liqueur is serving up a similar idea, with a Cajun twist.

headline: An Interview With George Kateb
text: The philosopher on a good life in a damaged world.

headline: Prosecutor Who Can’t Avoid Trouble
text: There is probably no more sobering measure of the changing landscape of on-screen entertainment than the downward trajectory of Scott Turow’s legal thrillers.

headline: For the Jets, a Victory That Exposed Some Weaknesses
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. – The Jets defended the Bills’ final drive Sunday – the one that stalled at the Jets’ 24, after three straight incompletions – with zone coverage. Or, as Darrelle Revis put it, the “don’t let them in the end zone” strategy.

headline: True Color
text: One of New York City’s hottest hair colorists, Frédéric Fekkai’s Reyad Fritas, can spin straw into gold. ‘‘I see a lot of overprocessed, dry hair out there,’’ he says. Not on his glossy girls, bien sur. ‘‘We get their hair into amazing condition and give them color that sparkles.’’

headline: Really? The Claim: Coffee Can Prevent Some Medications From Working
text: THE FACTS

headline: Rebels Resume a Crackdown on Somali Aid
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The Shabab militant group, which has already blocked many aid agencies from reaching starving people in Somalia’s famine zones, ordered 16 more aid agencies to shut down on Monday. Heavily armed Shabab fighters then raided the offices of several aid groups, looted equipment and accused the aid workers of being spies.

headline: Youssou N’Dour to Put Music on Hold and Turn to Politics
text: With his country gearing up for a hotly contested presidential election early next year the Senegalese singer and songwriter Youssou N’Dour, one of the biggest stars of the “world music” genre, is putting his career on hold to plunge into the political fray. It’s not clear in what capacity — as a candidate for public office himself, or just lending his prestige and support to someone already in the running — or for how long, but he made the announcement over the weekend and set a date to stop performing.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 28
text: A view of the day in sports included flag waving at cricket matches, a volleyball spike, and perhaps a cue shot at the world snooker championships that began in India.

headline: Drumbeat of World War II, Tweet by Tweet
text: So you thought Twitter, the popular social media site, was only good for what’s happening now? Minute-by-minute updates on your friends, celebrities and latest news? No more. While you can still keep tabs on what happened 20 seconds ago, some feeds offer a chance to brush up on military history.

headline: The decline of violence, a medical adventure story and a hunt for the cure for AIDS.
text: The decline of violence, a medical adventure story and a hunt for the cure for AIDS.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 73
text: Perhaps slower to act after all that turkey, city officials allowed Monday morning eviction deadlines to pass with little change for Occupy protests in Los Angeles and Philadelphia. The Los Angeles police said they were focused on clearing streets for the morning commute and arrested four protesters for blocking traffic. In Philadelphia, protesters who held an eviction party Sunday night were still waiting for things to change early Monday afternoon. Nine people were arrested in Augusta, Maine, for demonstrating at the governor’s mansion after their encampment was closed. [New York Times, Portland Press-Herald]

headline: File Under: Huh? Norton Hires Actors to ‘Stage’ Facebook Status Updates
text: Another advertiser is joining in a popular trend, producing and sponsoring live content that can be watched online.

headline: Flavorful and Sustainable Fish
text: If you’re concerned about which fish are environmentally safe to eat, you can’t do better than consulting the Web sites of the Monterey Bay Aquarium or the Environmental Defense Fund for their handy pocket guides for buying seafood (or choosing it in a restaurant). I printed one and put it in my wallet this week, and cooked fish for dinner every night. My son loves seafood, so he didn’t object.

headline: Google Pulls the Plug on a Renewable Energy Effort
text: The company dropped an effort to make steam to generate electricity using  a giant field of computer-controlled solar mirrors that will focus the sun’s light on a black-painted absorber.

headline: Hallmark Hall of Fame Has Rough Start on ABC
text: After proving to be a stable presence on broadcast television for more than 60 years, the Hallmark Hall of Fame is off to a rough start in its new home at ABC. This feel-good film franchise was dropped by CBS in May, after a 16-year partnership, only to be picked up in July by ABC.

headline: New Hope of a Cure for H.I.V.
text: Medical researchers are again in pursuit of a goal they had all but abandoned: curing AIDS.

headline: Capitals Turn to Hunter to Spur Underperforming Stars
text: The Washington Capitals know there is a problem, and now hope their former star and team captain Dale Hunter is the solution.

headline: A Closer Look at Teeth May Mean More Fillings
text: Until 2010, Amelia Nuwer, 22, visited the same dentist every year in Biloxi, Miss., her hometown. And every year she came back with a clean bill of dental health: no fillings necessary.

headline: Election Monitoring Crowd-Sourced in Egypt
text: Although some prominent Internet activists decided to boycott Monday’s elections in Egypt to protest continued military rule, many well-known bloggers spent the day working as self-appointed election monitors. Using the same social media tools that helped them to force Hosni Mubarak from office, the bloggers posted images of long lines at polling places and passed on reports of apparent violations of the electoral code.

headline: It Could Be Old Age, or It Could Be Low B12
text: Ilsa Katz was 85 when her daughter, Vivian Atkins, first noticed that her mother was becoming increasingly confused.

headline: Pakistan: Children With Pneumonia Fare Better With Home Treatment, Study Finds
text: Letting “lady health workers” in rural northern Pakistan treat children with severe pneumonia in their homes worked better than the established practice of telling parents to take them to a hospital, a new study has found.

headline: TimesCast | Bridging Cairo’s Divisions
text: November 28, 2011 - Along July 26th Street are Cairo's toiling and privileged, its Islamists and less pious, and on election day, Egypt's divides were bridged, if only for a moment.

headline: Doctor and Patient, Bound by Mutual Dependency
text: A doctor is sitting at his desk, waiting for the last patient of the day. The patient is very late. The doctor has called his phone: no answer.

headline: Mission Not Accomplished
text: Matt Yglesias and Kevin Drum say the right thing about revelations that big banks got very easy terms during the financial crisis: the real scandal isn’t so much that those banks got rescued as that the rest of the population didn’t.

headline: Federer Wins on Court but Not at Polls (Not That He Was Interested)
text: Roger Federer’s triumph over Jo-Wilfried Tsonga at the Barclay’s ATP World Tour Final on Sunday was an exclamation point on a season-ending, 17-match win streak that has reinvigorated his career at a time when some were beginning to question his ability to beat the world’s top players.

headline: A Setback for Electric Cars
text: DETROIT — Even as they pour money into developing a range of electric vehicles, automakers have acknowledged that widespread sales of battery-powered models are years away.

headline: Risks: Partial Hysterectomies Affect Menopause
text: Younger women who have hysterectomies that preserve the ovaries almost double their risk of early menopause, a new study has found.

headline: Are Dentists Overtreating Your Teeth?
text: Have you had a rash of fillings after years of healthy teeth? The culprit may be “microcavities,” and not every dentist thinks they need to be treated, reports today’s Science Times.

headline: Childbirth: Benefits Seen in Clamping the Cord Later
text: Waiting three minutes or longer before clamping a newborn’s umbilical cord reduces the prevalence of iron deficiency at four months, a large trial has found.

headline: Romney Supporters Take to the Phone Lines
text: 3:15 p.m. | Updated  Call it the Mitt Blitz.

headline: Supreme Court TV? Nice Idea, but Still Not Likely
text: WASHINGTON — A couple of weeks ago, the Supreme Court agreed to hear a constitutional challenge to President Obama’s health care law. The case is a once-in-a-generation blockbuster, and the court underscored its importance by scheduling five and a half hours of oral arguments, the most in any case since 1966.

headline: Mercury Creeps Upward, Ignoring That It’s Nov. 28
text: So you believed the forecasters who said the temperature on Monday would soar to the upper 60s and beat the late-November record. You thought about wearing a T-shirt and shorts to the 5:30 p.m. holiday tree lighting at 63rd Street and Broadway. You fantasized about tropical temperatures the rest of the week.

headline: Widening Hunt for Details of MF Global’s Collapse
text: Jon S. Corzine, MF Global’s former chief executive, is expected to testify in Congress next month about the firm’s collapse, having received requests to appear before the Senate Agriculture Committee on Dec. 13 and a House Financial Services subcommittee two days later. Questions continue to swirl around missing customer money totaling $1 billion or more that might have been used to shore up the firm’s own trading position, and there are multiple investigations of its operations.

headline: Patterns: Less Salt Isn’t Always Better for the Heart
text: For years, experts have believed that lowering sodium consumption reduces the risk of heart disease. Now a large new study suggests that it may not be so simple.

headline: In the Context of No Context
text: During my recent blogging hiatus, Will Wilkinson penned a withering post criticizing a recent convert to Christianity who had suggested that atheism can’t supply “meaning” in human life. Arguing that questions of meaning are logically independent of questions about metaphysics, he wrote:

headline: Hope Glimmers in Long Lines at Polls in Cairo
text: CAIRO — Tethering Cairo’s toiling and privileged, its Islamists and less pious, its worldly and street-smart, July 26th Street was named for the era of a long-ago revolution. Another one played out Monday along this rollicking thoroughfare, where Egypt’s divides were bridged, for a moment, by the simplest of ideas: a chance at self-determination.

headline: Beauty Product Picks for 2011
text: Among the year’s many samples, several beauty products rise above the rest.

headline: Ask Peg Tyre: The Tricky Matter of Turnover
text: Answering questions from readers on how to find a good school, Peg Tyre, journalist and author, deals with the tricky matter of teacher turnover and what to look for in a principal.

headline: For Gifts, a Crop of the Creams
text: AS the Beauty Spots columnist, I receive an overwhelming number of samples. Although many items end up in shopping bags under my desk or donated to charity, I make an earnest attempt to try as many eye creams, lip glosses and nail polishes as possible. Life is tough, I know.

headline: Are Fairy Tales Really for Children?
text: Would you buy your children a beautiful new volume of classic fairy tales this season? And having bought it, would you read it to them?

headline: As Kicker Goes, So Go the Chargers
text: Nick Novak had to relieve himself. So Novak, the San Diego Chargers’ kicker, took a knee in Sunday’s game against the Denver Broncos and did his business — with TV viewers watching from behind.

headline: A Bacterial Platoon With Fungi Engineers
text: Bacteria and fungi — microbiology’s classic enemies — constantly fight over the rhizosphere, the enriched underground environment created by nutrients leaching from the roots of plants into the surrounding soil.

headline: Hard Reality of Nostalgia, Laid Bare
text: Baby Jane Dexter’s message is loud and clear: This is how it is. And for all the pain and misery involved, it’s not unbearable. In her new cabaret show, “Still Bad, Still Blue,” at the Metropolitan Room, Ms. Dexter, a gentle mama lion, accompanied on piano by her longtime musical director, Ross Patterson, resurrects, with additions and subtractions, her successful 1996 act, “Big, Bad and Blue.”

headline: The AT&T and T-Mobile Pullback: The Web Reacts
text: Over Thanksgiving, AT&T and T-Mobile USA said they would withdraw their application with the Federal Communications Commission to join their cellphone operations. How did tech-watchers react? Well, the companies may be saying they still plan to deal with the Justice Department and pursue a merger, but many observers are saying that a deal is unlikely.

headline: Israeli Leader Visits Jordan to Discuss Palestinian Issue
text: JERUSALEM — King Abdullah II of Jordan played host on Monday to Shimon Peres, the president of Israel, in an effort to make progress on the stubborn Palestinian question at a time of regional diplomatic uncertainty and fragmentation.

headline: Steamed Cod or Sea Bass Salad With Red Peppers, Cilantro and Mint
text: This refreshing combination has Middle Eastern overtones, though in the Middle East the fish would probably be fried or poached. Serve it as a first course or as a light main dish. Pacific sea bass or Pacific cod are the most environmentally friendly types of fish to use here.

headline: Albacore Steaks With Simmered Fennel
text: Sea bass is the fish I always associate with fennel, as the combination is a classic in Provence. But cross the border into Italy and you’ll find tuna cooked with this anise-flavored vegetable.

headline: Kansas Governor Apologizes to Tweeting Teenager
text: Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas issued a public apology today to a high school student who was disciplined for posting a disparaging Twitter message about him while she was attending a youth program at the state Capitol.

headline: A Few Stops on the Way to the Gotham Awards
text: The statuette season begins in earnest tonight, at the Gotham Awards, which honors independent cinema in its own kooky way: “It’s where all these weird New Yorkers are just handing out these weird awards, and crack semi-lame jokes and have fun,” as our pal James Schamus, head of Focus Features, put it last year.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, Syria, Congo and Cambodia.

headline: Tony Kushner Wins $100,000 Award for ‘Creative Citizenship’
text: The playwright Tony Kushner has been named the recipient of a $100,000 award honoring artists and others for “socially responsible work” and challenges to authority, like Mr. Kushner’s fight with City University of New York trustees last spring over an honorary degree that they temporarily withheld from him.

headline: Woman Claims an Affair With Herman Cain
text: An Atlanta businesswoman came forward in an interview broadcast Monday to say she had a 13-year affair with Herman Cain, the latest in a string of women to make allegations of improper conduct by the presidential candidate.

headline: Leading One of New York’s Smallest High Schools
text: What is it like to run one of the city’s smallest public high schools? SchoolBook profiles Julie Conason, principal of Humanities Preparatory Academy in Chelsea, home to 192 students, a high graduation rate and an unusual discipline policy that entails sending misbehaving students before a “fairness committee” that metes out alternatives to suspension, like writing letters of apology or community service. Read more on SchoolBook »

headline: Saluting a Serial Seducer and His Steamy Tell-All
text: PARIS — Giacomo Girolamo Casanova was a gambler, swindler, diplomat, lawyer, soldier, alchemist, violinist, traveler, pleasure seeker and serial seducer.

headline: The Life Report: B. Clewly Johnson
text: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

headline: Different Strokes With a Baby on Board
text: When bottlenose dolphins swim — at a cruising speed around six miles an hour or a sprinting speed about twice that fast — they are constantly fighting against the water’s drag, which only gets worse as they swim harder.

headline: On Subway Walls, the Saga of ‘Phillip’ and ‘Erin’
text: For the right subject matter, even harried commuters will take the time to peruse a stranger’s old photos. Or something that purports to be them.

headline: Thanksgiving Week Broadway Box Office Stuffed with Good News
text: Broadway box offices enjoyed a hearty Thanksgiving last week, with 34 musicals and plays grossing a total of $28.1 million, an increase of 6 percent from the comparable holiday week last November when 39 shows were running. Earning more money from fewer shows is in part the result of a so-called dynamic pricing strategy among Broadway theater owners and producers to sell more premium price tickets for high-demand performances, including during holiday season.

headline: Skills in Advanced Angling, From Another Age
text: Hidden in the coral terraces that line the eastern shores of East Timor are troves of artifacts and skeletal remains that tell a story of coastal activity going back tens of thousands of years — to the time when humans first settled nearby Australia.

headline: Exploring New Frontiers in Salad
text: IT all started with a raw kale salad I sampled at a restaurant several years ago, showered in bread crumbs and anchovy-garlic dressing. A salad of raw Brussels sprouts with pecorino and walnuts came next, followed by a raw beet slaw with orange.

headline: The Certainty of Memory Has Its Day in Court
text: Witness testimony has been the gold standard of the criminal justice system, revered in courtrooms and crime dramas as the evidence that clinches a case.

headline: The Life Report: Neil Richard Parnes
text: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

headline: Last Notes From a Man of Letters
text: In accepting the National Book Critics Circle Award in Criticism for his 1983 collection, “Hugging the Shore,” John Updike modestly described himself as “a freelance writer who writes on occasion about books, bringing to the task a rusty liberal-arts education, an average citizen’s spotty knowledge of contemporary issues and a fiction writer’s childish willingness to immerse himself in make-believe.” His decision to begin writing book reviews, he said, was probably prompted “by a dim sense that the humanities and arts need repeated injections of amateurism.”

headline: Police Release Quarterly Report on School Arrests
text: Complying with a new city law, the New York Police Department released a quarterly report on school arrests and summonses, which showed that nearly half of the 63 students who were arrested were younger than 16. The report also showed that the police issued 182 summonses, and that the students arrested were more likely to be black and male.

headline: Why I Signed: Principals' Objections to the New Evaluation System
text: Principals across New York State who object to the new state system to evaluate teachers and principals based on student testing have begun circulating a petition against it. A few of the 650 principals who have signed give their reasons.

headline: ‘Beginners’ on the Awards Circuit
text: Here is Part 2 of the Bagger’s new and possibly continuing series of films that may not get enough awards attention this season. (Suggestions welcome, commenters!)

headline: Italian Bond Dispute Illustrates Obstacles to  Triggering C.D.S.
text: The publisher of the Italian yellow pages directories, Seat Pagine Gialle, has missed a payment on its bonds and announced a tentative agreement to cancel the bonds and issue shares in the company instead. But that agreement may collapse because of a disagreement over how much stock will be issued.

headline: Will the Lights Stay On in Texas and New England?
text: Texas and New England may soon run short of the generating capacity they need to reliably meet peak loads, largely because old plants will be retired rather than retrofitted to meet new pollution rules, the North American Electric Reliability Corporation reported on Monday.

headline: A Venerable Birding Club, at an Epicenter of All Things Feathered
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — The Nuttall Ornithological Club, the nation’s oldest birding group, was having a meeting, and Ron Lockwood, its president, was calling things to order.

headline: Behind Rakoff’s Rejection of Citigroup Settlement
text: As President Ronald Reagan famously said, “There you go again.” Judge Jed S. Rakoff of Federal District Court in Manhattan followed through on Monday with his threats by rejecting another settlement by the Securities and Exchange Commission. This time, he turned down the S.E.C.’s accord with Citigroup over the bank’s sale of mortgage-backed securities that cost investors almost $700 million in losses while the bank garnered profit of about $160 million.

headline: Crowning Moment
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Unfurling Hallelujahs at Full Throttle
text: The Christmas shopping season began as soon as the Thanksgiving dishes were cleared away, so it seems fitting that the parade of “Messiah” performances that fill New York concert halls and churches during the holiday season began early too. And even in a city where that vividly pictorial Handel classic is interpreted in a rich variety of styles, this year’s first major entry was a daring challenge to the current orthodoxy, which places the highest value on readings by period-instrument ensembles and chamber choirs.

headline: Design Space Becomes Installation Setting for Merce Cunningham Dancers
text: The design firm Harrison Atelier is making a habit of dabbling in dance. Last year it was credited as a co-creator of “Anchises,” a sophisticated work about aging choreographed by the former Merce Cunningham dancer Jonah Bokaer. Now the firm has brought in the current Cunningham dancer Silas Riener to choreograph “Pharmacophore: Architectural Placebo,” an installation at Storefront for Art and Architecture in Little Italy.

headline: A Guide to Balanchine, Ardent Yet Unflinching
text: Three years ago the dance critic Nancy Goldner brought out her “Balanchine Variations,” a paperback guide to 20 ballets by the choreographer George Balanchine (22 if you count the three parts of “Jewels” as individual ballets). Pocket-friendly, modest, undictatorial, with a bright but quiet voice, it touches on multiple aspects of ballet (music, drama, ballet classicism, spatial architecture and more), engaging readers in a manner so unassuming that they are effortlessly involved in critical thought by way of friendly conversation.

headline: How Do Eminent Physicists Tackle the Higgs Boson? With Chocolate
text: In 2005, at a festive midsummer night’s banquet at Uppsala Castle in Sweden, I chose a seat across the table from two of the world’s leading experts on particle physics: the theorist Frank Wilczek, the previous year’s winner of the Nobel Prize in Physics, and Janet Conrad, a leading experimentalist.

But you will take them from a man who regularly gets out in front of an excellent band and six high-grade gospel singers, takes his position behind the central microphone and reveals that he has a very ordinary voice.

headline: Democrats Take Aim at Romney in New Ad
text: The Democratic National Committee on Monday escalated its effort to define Mitt Romney, seeking the Republican nomination for president in 2012, as a flip-flopper with a new ad in five battleground states. Called “Trapped,” it is styled as a parody of a sci-fi movie trailer for “the story of two men trapped in one body.”

headline: Metro-North Reopens Port Jervis Line
text: Three months after Tropical Storm Irene dismantled 14 miles of the Port Jervis train line, turning parts of the tracks traversing Orange and Rockland Counties into mangled piles of debris, Metro-North Railroad officials restored service on Monday, one month ahead of schedule.

headline: Searching for Virtue, After a Weighty Feast
text: AFTER so many days of feasting, it was time for something light, fat-free and, dare I say, cleansing. But something flavorful, too, it goes without saying. A good day for fish, I thought, planning a meal in my head.

headline: 3 Asset Managers Win $254 Million Powerball Lottery
text: 8:46 p.m. | Updated

headline: Living in a 76-Story Work of Art, and a Symbol of Rebirth
text: Frederico Farina, a creative director for fashion brands, recalls waking up every morning last summer in his 21st-floor apartment in Brooklyn Heights and gazing across the river at the new Frank Gehry-designed apartment tower in Lower Manhattan. Its rippled stainless-steel facade reflected the sun, making it shine like a beacon.

headline: It’s Called ‘Airplane Mode’ for a Reason
text: A Disruptions column about the use of electronics gadgets on planes seems to have touched a nerve with readers. Here are some responses to readers’ questions and comments debating why the Federal Aviation Administration’s rules should be kept in place, or re-evaluated in an era of more e-readers.

headline: China: Ads Banned in Middle of TV Dramas
text: Officials announced Monday that the government would impose a ban on advertisements in the middle of television dramas starting Jan. 1. The agency imposing the ban, the State Administration of Radio, Film and Television, said on its Web site that ads would only be able to appear at the start and end of an episode, which generally run 45 minutes. Analysts say the new regulation would result in lower ad revenues for television networks since many companies want to place their ads in the middle of a program. The new policy is the latest in a series of moves by the agency to tighten restrictions on television. In October, it announced limits on entertainment shows broadcast nationwide during primetime hours.

headline: France Will Withdraw 200 Soldiers from Afghanistan
text: France announced Monday that it would withdraw another 200 soldiers from Afghanistan by the end of the year, after transferring command of two districts to the Afghan Army. The reduction is part of the “Afghanization” of the war, which is supposed to be complete by the end of 2014. Another 200 soldiers returned to France in October. France now has about 3,800 troops in Afghanistan. That number will fall to 3,600 by the end of the year, according to Col. Thierry Burkhard, the French military spokesman. To date, 76 French soldiers have died in Afghanistan. The Socialist presidential candidate, François Hollande, has promised to pull all French troops out of Afghanistan by early 2013, not by the end of 2014, the date agreed on by all NATO allies.

headline: N.B.A. Teams to Be Paired for Two Exhibition Games
text: It could be another week before the N.B.A. ratifies its new labor deal and releases a 66-game schedule for the revived 2011-12 season. In the meantime, the league is constructing a hurried preseason schedule.

headline: City Abandons Rezoning Plans for Village and Chelsea
text: UPDATED | City officials have dropped their plans to rezone crowded public elementary schools in Greenwich Village and Chelsea after a parent council voted down their most recent plan. Instead, officials will focus on zoning in Lower Manhattan, and they plan to present a third version of a zoning plan for the new Peck Slip School.

headline: Turkey: Premier in Good Health After Surgery
text: Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan was in good health after laparoscopic surgery on his digestive system, his office said Monday. Mr. Erdogan, 57, had the operation on Saturday and was recovering at Marmara University Hospital in Istanbul, a government official said, adding that he expected the prime minister to be discharged Tuesday. Mr. Erdogan was elected prime minister in June for a third consecutive term.

headline: Britain Braces for Large Strike
text: Britain is gearing up for its largest strike in more than 30 years, with as many as two million teachers, health-care workers, local government employees and border agents expected to walk off the job on Wednesday to protest a government plan that would require them to work longer and contribute more to their pensions. Some 90 percent of the country’s schools are expected to close, local services will be severely curtailed, non-essential medical procedures face possible cancellation, and international passengers arriving at Heathrow Airport have been warned to expect delays of up to 12 hours in immigration halls. At least one airline, Etihad Airways, has already canceled flights; others are urging passengers not arrive on Wednesday and offering to let them change their reservations free of charge.

headline: Violet the Hawk Has Worsening Leg Problems
text: We write with bad news about Violet, the red-tailed hawk whose child-rearing and leg problems were chronicled on City Room in the spring.

headline: For Giants’ Defense, Getting to Brees Is Imperative
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ defensive game plan rarely wavers from week to week. It starts with rushing the passer. The rest trickles down from there.

headline: At Top Colleges, Anti-Wall St. Fervor Complicates Recruiting
text: 9:40 a.m. | Updated NEW HAVEN — College students seeking jobs on Wall Street have always had hurdles to overcome — grueling applications, endless rounds of interviews and fierce competition for the relatively few available spots at top firms.

headline: Times Photographer Complains of Israeli Soldiers’ ‘Cruelty’ at Border Crossing
text: Updated | 10:39 p.m. Israel’s Defense Ministry apologized on Monday for forcing a pregnant New York Times photographer to remove her clothes and submit to a physical search after she had already passed through an X-ray machine three times at a checkpoint in Gaza last month.

headline: In Bleak Cairo, a Call for Optimism
text: Cairo

headline: Capitals Hire Hunter to Replace Boudreau
text: Dale Hunter, one of four Capitals players whose jersey (No. 32) hangs from the rafters of Verizon Center, was named to coach the team Monday, replacing the fired Bruce Boudreau. Hunter has spent the past 11 seasons as the coach of the London Knights in the Ontario Hockey League, reaching 400 victories faster than any coach in league history. Since starting the season 7-0, Washington has lost six of its last eight games.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Drones for Everyone, and Bitcoin’s Decline
text: Interesting things that Bits reporters and editors found on the Web. More here.

headline: App Smart Extra: Guide to Roadside Amenities
text: In an earlier App Smart column, I tested out a few apps that help you track your car’s performance, and maybe remove some of the pain of driving in the meantime.

headline: Iran: 50 Suspects Indicted in Bank Fraud Case
text: The chief prosecutor investigating a $2.6 billion bank embezzlement scandal said that more than 50 suspects had been indicted and that 40 companies had been found to harbor unreported debts and irregularities in connection with the fraud, the biggest in the history of the Islamic republic. The prosecutor, Gholam Hossein Mohseni Ejei, also said 106 potential suspects had been interrogated since he was assigned to the case more than two months ago, the semiofficial Mehr News Agency reported.

headline: Should Legislation Protect  the Obese?
text: Should it be illegal for businesses to discriminate against unhealthy and heavily overweight applicants?

headline: Motorola’s Droid Razr Still Has It
text: The new Droid Razr has a lot to live up to. The original Razr was a flip-phone marvel of sleek design. It became the best-selling phone in the United States until the iPhone knocked it from its perch. The new Razr, while lacking the wow factor of the original, is still a credible heir to the name.

headline: U.S. Opposes New Trial in Arms-Dealing Case
text: A juror’s post-trial statements in which she said she had seen a movie inspired by the life of the man she voted to convict, Viktor Bout, should not be enough to warrant a new trial, federal prosecutors say.

headline: Q&A: Pinning Photos on a Map
text: Q. A friend sent a photo he says he shot with his phone. I see from the JPG’s “properties” latitude and longitude are listed. Is there an easy way to determine the physical location from these data?

headline: Woman Claims Affair With Cain, and He Denies It
text: An Atlanta woman came forward in an interview broadcast Monday night with details about what she called a 13-year affair with Herman Cain, the Republican presidential contender whose campaign was already struggling to overcome damage from accusations of sexual harassment.

headline: Trainer’s Success Is Built on Patience
text: Bill Mott has had a very good month — the kind that he patiently spent a year working toward. It is a month that should earn him his third Eclipse Award as the nation’s outstanding horse trainer.

headline: Disaster Go-Bags of the Famous

headline: Time to Run. What Is in Their Bag?
text: IN a year that delivered Hurricane Irene and one of the most powerful earthquakes to hit the East Coast, the term “go-bag” — which grew common after 9/11 and is defined by the New York City Office of Emergency Management as “a collection of items you can use in the event of an evacuation” — has become as much a part of the city’s parlance as MetroCard and Gray’s Papaya.

headline: Dodgers Owner’s Feud Is Now With Fox
text: The animosity that once enlivened Frank McCourt’s desperate battle against Major League Baseball to hold on to his ownership of the Los Angeles Dodgers is now fueling his feud with Fox Sports.

Fine was fired by the university after another accuser came forward and Coach Jim Boeheim quickly retracted his previous unconditional support of Fine.

text: Gary Speed, the coach of the national soccer team of Wales and a steady and skilled player in the top divisions of English soccer for more than 20 years, was found dead in his home early Sunday in the village of Huntington, England. He was 42.

text: The six-year contract agreed to by Coach Meyer and the university includes $4 million in annual compensation.

headline: The Jets’ Secondary Leaves Itself Open to Criticism
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets could have arrived at team headquarters Monday mourning an opportunity missed. They could have deconstructed how Stevie Johnson managed to find such a wide seam in their coverage, catching the game-winning touchdown pass that resuscitated Buffalo’s playoff hopes and stomped all over the Jets’.

headline: Militants Turn to Death Squads in Afghanistan
text: SABARI, Afghanistan — As targeted killings have risen sharply across Afghanistan, American and Afghan officials believe that many are the work of counterintelligence units of the Haqqani militant network and Al Qaeda, charged with killing suspected informants and terrorizing the populace on both sides of the Afghanistan-Pakistan border.

headline: Week 12 Live: Giants-Saints Win Probability
text: The Fifth Down provided live updates and analysis during the Giants-Saints game in New Orleans on Monday night, while tracking the probability of a win throughout the game. A quick review for those unfamiliar with the metric from Advanced NFL Stats: Win probability measures just that — the probability that each team will win the game at any moment.

headline: Pepper Spray in Santa’s Bag?
text: BLACK FRIDAY. I’m not shopping but I am in a mall — the Atlantic Center in Brooklyn, home of the Department of Motor Vehicles, a pedestrian bridge away from the second floor of Target. Having surfaced from the underworld of the Atlantic-Pacific subway station, my 19-year-old son, Walker, and I have taken two flights of stairs and an escalator to emerge on the wrong side of the mall. By the time we arrive at the D.M.V.’s doors and survey the tangled queues of wild-eyed applicants, we’ve struggled through a tide of consumers washing frantically in and out of stores, dragged down by purchases but still moving briskly. What would be worse, I find myself wondering, to join the frenzy of holiday shopping, or to at last confront the appointment with destiny Walker and I have conspired to avoid for years?

headline: Justices to Decide on Fairness in Drug Sentences
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to resolve a question that has vexed the lower federal courts since Congress enacted a law to narrow the gap between sentences meted out for offenses involving two kinds of cocaine.

headline: Shooting Suspect Is Called Fit for Trial
text: An Idaho man charged with trying to assassinate President Obama by firing a semiautomatic rifle at the White House on Nov. 11 was found competent to stand trial by a psychologist who evaluated him, according to court papers filed on Monday by prosecutors in Washington.

headline: For New Coach at Ohio State, It’s First Down and $4 Million
text: Ohio State University hired Urban Meyer as its football coach Monday, giving him one of the richest contracts ever in college sports — the latest indication that the big business of college football is undeterred by the nation’s broader economic woes or by concern about the prominence of sports on campus.

headline: Keep the Clean Water Act Strong
text: San Francisco

headline: Western Union’s Singing Telegram Makes a Modern Comeback
text: THE singing telegram, once a popular way to share birthday greetings and other congratulatory messages, is returning with a twist that reflects how such sharing now often takes place digitally.

headline: Looking at Dogs and Cars
text: Often when I’m out and about I’m looking at cars, and when I’m not looking at cars, I’m looking at dogs. Recently I realized that these apparently different activities are linked by the emotions provoked by the two objects of my gaze.
