headline: Horse Racing Draws a Line at Licensing Chechen Leader
text: Thoroughbred racing has always attracted a mix of royalty and rogues. Blue bloods like the Whitneys and the Vanderbilts have long been owners. So, too, have mischief-makers like the mobster Arnold Rothstein, who won the 1921 Travers at Saratoga with a racehorse named Sporting Blood.

headline: AT&T’s 11th-Hour Plan to Save Its Deal With T-Mobile
text: About an hour after AT&T announced its $39 billion acquisition of T-Mobile in March on a Sunday afternoon, I got a call at home. It was Randall L. Stephenson, AT&T’s chairman and chief executive. Mr. Stephenson, an affable man with a wry sense of humor, knew he would face a battle persuading regulators — and maybe even me — that the deal should be approved.

headline: Photoshopped or Not? A Tool to Tell
text: The photographs of celebrities and models in fashion advertisements and magazines are routinely buffed with a helping of digital polish. The retouching can be slight — colors brightened, a stray hair put in place, a pimple healed. Or it can be drastic — shedding 10 or 20 pounds, adding a few inches in height and erasing all wrinkles and blemishes, done using Adobe’s Photoshop software, the photo retoucher’s magic wand.

headline: Mourning a Cultural Hub Disguised as a Used Bookstore
text: METUCHEN, N.J. — Even admirers concede it was always a stretch to imagine a combination literary bookstore, avant garde cultural center and family-friendly guerrilla street theater emporium here on Main Street. So Alex Dawson’s seven-year run at the Raconteur, which will come to an end on Jan. 31, was about seven years longer than anyone should have expected.

headline: A Fixture on the Bench, and in the Community
text: Jim Boeheim will forever be the defining face of basketball at Syracuse University. He shepherded the men’s program from a regional power to a national one, winning an N.C.A.A. title in 2003 and earning a spot in the Basketball Hall of Fame.

headline: Crisis in Europe Tightens Credit Across the Globe
text: Europe’s worsening sovereign debt crisis has spread beyond its banks and the spillover now threatens businesses on the Continent and around the world.

headline: The Accented Activist, the Blue Woman and One Curious Year in Court
text: Some things that are perhaps worth knowing about Vesselin Dittrich are that he is 64, a freelance translator of Bulgarian, divorced and a resident of Hoboken, N.J. He is also deeply concerned about injustice. And he was sitting on a PATH train in the Hoboken station on Aug. 9, 2010, at 5 in the evening, staring at a young woman because she seemed to be all blue.

headline: A Court, Not Votes, Sustains a Political Machine in Queens
text: Pity the poor Queens Democratic machine; so many of its loyal sons have taken head-first tumbles of late.

headline: Obama Meets Leaders of the European Union
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama met with top European Union leaders as the euro zone sovereign debt crisis entered a perilous new phase, with increasing worries about the sustainability of the 17-country monetary union and borrowing costs climbing to new peaks.

headline: At Airports, a Bigger Push to Sell Electronics
text: Sales of electronics and their gear in airports have gone from little more than an afterthought a few years ago to a rapidly growing presence.

headline: The Life Reports II
text: A few weeks ago, I asked people over 70 to send me “Life Reports” — essays about their own lives and what they’d done poorly and well. They make for fascinating and addictive reading, and I’ve tried to extract a few general life lessons:

headline: Carry On a Christmas Pie, Not a Merry Snow Globe
text: MY daughter, who was always a resourceful child, showed up for the Thanksgiving visit with her husband, our three small grandchildren and a homemade apple pie.

headline: Barney Frank, a Top Liberal, Won’t Seek Re-election
text: NEWTON, Mass. — Simply put, Barney Frank has had enough.

headline: Nicaragua’s President Rules Airwaves to Control Image
text: MANAGUA, Nicaragua — The election this month in which President Daniel Ortega won a third term and a supermajority in Congress may have been marred by irregularities — the European Union’s electoral mission called the vote tally “opaque and arbitrary,” and observers were blocked from monitoring some polls — but on most TV news channels, things looked different.

headline: Amid Protests by Students and Others, CUNY Trustees Vote to Raise Tuition
text: With a raucous protest outside summoning all of the volume, but not the violence, of a similar clash last week, City University trustees approved on Monday a series of $300 annual tuition increases that will extend through 2015.

headline: Exiting a Middle Seat With Gymnastics
text: IN general, I don’t mind flying. But if some clever person invented teleportation like that in Star Trek, that would relieve a lot of the hassle of business travel.

headline: Money Found in Britain May Belong to MF Global
text: About $200 million in customer money that vanished from MF Global is believed to have surfaced at JPMorgan Chase in Britain, according to people briefed on the matter. The discovery could be the most significant breakthrough in a monthlong hunt for the missing funds.

headline: Woman Gave Councilman Part of Her Pay, She Testifies
text: A woman who had a romantic relationship with City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook testified on Monday that in instances in which she was hired as a consultant based on Mr. Seabrook’s recommendation, she gave him part of the money she received from her employers.

headline: Capitals and Hurricanes Change Coaches, With Different Expectations
text: For two N.H.L. coaches, it was Black Monday.

headline: Germany Cuts Off Its Nose
text: “Lords of Finance,” Liaquat Ahamed’s magisterial 2009 history of the events that led first to the Great Depression and then to the Second World War, is, necessarily, a book about policy mistakes. Central bankers and Treasury secretaries, presidents and prime ministers: all of them are locked into their own economic and political orthodoxies. Each is certain that his is the only sensible course of action. Crippled by their blinders, they consistently make economic choices that appear to us, nearly a century later, to be insane but to them seemed completely sensible.

headline: Telemarketer Abuse Statute Confounds Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — “This is the strangest statute I have ever seen,” Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. said near the end of a Supreme Court argument on Monday.

headline: Myanmar: A Welcome From China
text: Vice President Xi Jinping of China welcomed the leader of Myanmar’s military on Monday in a ceremony at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing and called for closer military ties between the countries, in what appeared to be a response to the visit by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton to Myanmar later this week.

headline: As Public Sector Sheds Jobs, Blacks Are Hit Hardest
text: Don Buckley lost his job driving a Chicago Transit Authority bus almost two years ago and has been looking for work ever since, even as other municipal bus drivers around the country are being laid off.

headline: 2 Celebrities Point Fingers at Murdoch in Inquiry
text: LONDON — For weeks, the spotlight in inquiries into the practices of Britain’s rambunctious tabloids has been on James Murdoch, the 38-year-old scion of the family-run media empire operated by the News Corporation, and the extent of his knowledge of the wrongdoing at The News of the World, the newspaper under Mr. Murdoch’s authority that was shut down this summer.

headline: A Not-So-Straight Story
text: It’s funny the way close observation can change your perception of things. Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle says something like this about observing quantum particles [1]; maybe borderology needs its own uncertainty principle. Consider: What is the longest straight-line international boundary? Why, that has to be the American-Canadian border between Lake of the Woods (Minnesota/Manitoba) and Boundary Bay (Washington State/British Columbia), which runs for 1,260 miles along the 49th parallel north. Right?

headline: Putting Others Ahead, and Then Falling Behind
text: There is a certain type of woman who is good at taking care of everyone but herself.

headline: Panel Urges Sharp Change for Hospitals in Brooklyn
text: The New York State health commissioner should be given sweeping new powers to replace the executives and board members of private hospitals, a group appointed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo recommended Monday in a report on how to restructure Brooklyn’s failing hospitals and health system.

headline: What Happened on the Border?
text: It’s not clear what led to NATO strikes on two Pakistani border posts this weekend, but there can be no dispute that the loss of lives is tragic. At least 24 Pakistani troops were killed. We regret those deaths, as we do those of all American, NATO and Afghan troops and Pakistani and Afghan civilians killed by extremists.

headline: Tuesday: Run to Las Vegas
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I know times are tough for everyone, so it really shouldn’t surprise me when cries for help start to get embedded in crossword puzzles.

headline: Senate Democrats Propose Extending Payroll Tax Cut
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats introduced legislation Monday to extend and expand an expiring payroll tax cut, setting the stage for a showdown with Republicans who are almost certain to reject the Democrats’ proposal for paying for the cut.

headline: The S.E.C.’s Enabling
text: Judge Jed Rakoff is furious. He should be. We all should be. On Monday, the Federal District Court judge rightly rejected a plan by the Securities and Exchange Commission to settle a securities fraud case against Citigroup, saying that the $285 million deal was “neither fair, nor reasonable, nor adequate, nor in the public interest.”

headline: Boudreau Is Fired, Replaced by Hunter, a Former Capital
text: WASHINGTON — The Capitals took a page from their own record book Monday in an effort to regain their winning ways.

headline: With Crosby in Form, Rangers Face Tough Task
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — It has taken only a week for Sidney Crosby to re-establish his credentials as hockey’s best player. Consider his numbers since returning Nov. 21 from a 320-day absence: in four games, he has two goals and seven assists and is plus 7.

headline: City Council Plans Suit Over Homeless Policy
text: Christine C. Quinn, the speaker of the City Council, announced plans Monday to sue the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg over a new policy that imposes stricter requirements on homeless people seeking shelter.

headline: Reporting Abuse
text: Prosecutors have a long way to go before they unravel the sexual abuse scandals that have engulfed the athletic departments at Pennsylvania State University and Syracuse University. What is clear from both cases is that college administrators need to contact off-campus law enforcement authorities immediately when they receive allegations of criminal conduct. It should not take prolonged inquiries or complex new standards for universities to take this common-sense step.

headline: Missing Girl’s Mother Freed, but Still a Suspect
text: PHOENIX — The mother of a missing 5-year-old girl from Glendale, Ariz., who was arrested last week on suspicion of child abuse, was released from jail on Monday morning after prosecutors failed to file formal charges in the case, the authorities said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Victory for Grizzly Bears
text: Thanks to a federal appellate court ruling last week, grizzly bears in the Rocky Mountains will continue to enjoy protection as an endangered species. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that the Fish and Wildlife Service had not only acted prematurely when it removed the bear from the endangered species list in 2007 but had ignored clearly documented threats to the animal’s food supply — in effect putting politics ahead of science.

headline: And the Gothams Winners Are …

headline: Obituary: Gary Speed, 42, Welsh National Soccer Coach
text: The Times obituary for Gary Speed, the former Wales soccer coach who died Sunday in an apparent suicide, has been posted online. Speed, who played for Leeds, Everton, Newcastle United, Bolton and Sheffield United before moving into management, was the first player to make 500 appearances in the Premier League. He was 42.

text: The Oregon State Board of Higher Education voted Monday afternoon to terminate the contract of the University of Oregon president, Richard W. Lariviere.

text: Michael Hastings, a British playwright whose best-known work, “Tom and Viv,” about the first marriage of T. S. Eliot, created a cultural brouhaha over the appropriateness of fictionalizing the lives of real people, died on Nov. 19, at his home in London. He was 74.

headline: Brees and Saints Have Their Way Against Giants

Coughlin has never been shy about showing his emotions, particularly when the Giants are not playing well, and it seems as if he has several variations he uses when he wants to indicate “disappointed.”

headline: Giants Replay: Week 12
text: Images from the Giants’ 49-24 loss to the Saints in New Orleans on Nov. 28.

headline: Why Are Primaries Hard to Predict?
text: Presidential elections are predictable. At the national level, economic conditions — measures like the change in per-capita income in the year or so preceding the election — usually do a good job predicting the popular vote. At the state level, you can usually predict the outcome given the vote last time, after adjusting for the economy and the home states and regions of the candidates. At the level of individual voters, preferences are largely predictable from political ideology, degree of partisanship, and, again, recent economic conditions.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
text: Opposition against the central government’s decision to allow 51 percent foreign direct investment in multi-brand retail is mounting, prompting Prime Minister Manmohan Singh called for a rare all-party meeting to help reach a consensus (Business Standard). Commerce and Industry Minister Anand Sharma said on Monday that retail foreign direct investment would be allowed only if foreign companies source 30 percent of their products from India’s micro, small and medium enterprises, known as MSMEs. Analysts argue that diluting the policy in this manner “could effectively make foreign investment in retail less attractive,” Mint reports.

headline: How to Succeed in Business? By Reading, India Says
text: It was a different kind of shopping trip for Pallavi Rao, 24, a trendy human-resources consultant who normally picks up things like sunglasses, bags and short jackets.  After work last week, she browsed among dozens of stalls at Bangalore’s annual book fair and carefully selected a handful of titles on management and leadership.

headline: A War Crimes Court and a Travesty of Justice
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — On the fourth floor of a nondescript pale-blue government building in Old Dhaka, clerks are stapling together copies of depositions from witnesses to the crimes committed during Bangladesh’s 1971 war of secession from Pakistan — a conflict that may have killed up to three million people, according to the Bangladeshi government. Above them on the wall is a map showing the 11 sectors of what was then called East Pakistan.

text: On Nov. 29, 1947, the United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution calling for Palestine to be partitioned between Arabs and Jews, allowing for the formation of the Jewish state of Israel.

headline: Is Microsoft Running Out of Time for Tablets?

headline: British Inquiry Is Told Hacking Is Worthy Tool

He confessed to lurking in unmarked vans outside people’s houses, stealing confidential documents, rifling through celebrity garbage cans and pretending that he was not a journalist pursuing a story but “Brad the teenage rent boy,” propositioning a priest.

headline: A World of Change on the Lower East Side
text: Harvey Wang was a young photographer when he moved into a fifth-floor Chinatown walk-up in 1979. It was an easy bike ride from the East Village clubs where he took pictures of strobe-lit dance floors and bohemian debauchery — and besides, rent was only $140 a month.

headline: Is Too Much Meaningless Cricket Killing the Sport?
text: In 2014, Brazil will host the football World Cup for the first time in 64 years. Now, imagine that Brazil wins the tournament, sending the Brazilians into raptures. Six months later, the Brazilian Football Federation invites the English football team to play five games across the country. Brazil wins all of them by a comfortable margin, dominating the English team. Yet, the stadiums are half empty and attendance is lowest at the Maracanã stadium in Rio de Janeiro. Even the TV ratings are down, far lower than forecasted.

headline: What Are You Good At?

What are your talents and skills? What products or services might you be able to provide, either free of charge, or for a fee?

headline: Paris ‘Nap Bar’ Provides Respite for Worn-Out Visitors
text: Sore feet, aching limbs and the midafternoon slump are all enemies of the ambitious tourist. Now, visitors to Paris can turn those unpleasantries into sweet dreams with a new “bar” devoted to naps. Located in the heart of the city, the Zen Bar à Sieste (29 Passage Choiseul; www.barasieste.com), the Zen Nap Bar, offers a dark and peaceful spot for a moment of rest.

I’ve never seen a driver use one unprompted or even consult a conventional street atlas.

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 29
text: The Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain, whose campaign had already been stung by accusations of sexual harassment, was confronted with allegations on Monday that he carried on a 13-year affair with an Atlanta businesswoman. Because the story broke while Mr. Cain was live on CNN’s “The Situation Room,” he responded to the allegations by the woman, Ginger White, before they had actually aired on the Fox affiliate in Atlanta, WAGA-TV. According to The Huffington Post, the allegations “didn’t come up during Cain’s first segment with anchor Wolf Blitzer. That’s because Blitzer didn’t know about them either when the two men sat down.” During that first segment of three, CNN producers began to see posts to Twitter that mentioned the coming WAGA story. “While seated during a commercial break, Blitzer then asked Cain about the Atlanta report and the candidate acknowledged that his campaign had been contacted about it and would be willing to discuss it on air,” Michael Calderone of The Huffington Post reported. [Huffington Post]

headline: Wade Phillips’s Defensive Intervention in Houston
text: Wade Phillips has performed one of the great coaching turnarounds in N.F.L. history. Each of the past few seasons, Gary Kubiak’s Texans have been on the verge of making the playoffs but have been undone by inept defenses. Houston joined the league as an expansion team in 2002, and its defense has never been very good, struggling in various measures of efficiency. But the bottom fell out on the Texans in 2010, when they had one of the league’s worst defensive seasons. Consider that last season:

headline: Barron’s Heroes, Felder’s Ambitions and Other Bits of Politics
text: Take a few days off, and you never know what you’ll miss in this city. So for the benefit of those of you who had better things to do during the Thanksgiving break, here’s a roundup of some political developments. They make up in eye-catching potential for what they may lack in cosmic value.

headline: The ECB’s Reverse FDR
text: Ryan Avent joins the chorus of those suggesting that the European Central Bank’s decision last spring to start raising rates — a decision that seemed crazy then, and looks even crazier now — was the point at which everything started to fall apart.

headline: Big City Book Club: ‘Breakfast at Tiffany’s’
text: Norman Mailer famously called Truman Capote the most perfect writer of his generation, saying of “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” that he would not change two words. The 1961 film that came out three years after the novel’s publication of course changed many words, siphoning off the book’s abiding spirit of melancholy. When I encountered it for the first time, years ago, just out of college, I felt a race of fury over the liberties and licenses Hollywood had taken in its rendering. Holly’s profession is hardly glossed over in the novel, and her neighbor, the book’s unnamed narrator, does not and cannot provide her with a happy ending. I’m interested in hearing from all of you, but especially from those who have just read the book for the first time, presumably after some familiarity with the iconic film.

headline: Counting the Underwater Homeowners
text: Analysts have been celebrating various pieces of good economic news, including an uptick in consumer spending. But the housing hangover is still raging.

headline: Wide Response to Educational Plight of Mexican Immigrants
text: An article in The New York Times about low rates of educational achievement among Mexican immigrants in New York City drew a large and varied response, ranging from despair to xenophobia to calls for action. It even inspired a video.

headline: More Testing Time for Third to Eighth Graders?
text: Is the state proposing to radically expand the reading tests it gives students from grades 3 to 8, growing them to almost three hours over two days? The Daily News reports that such a plan has been floated to school leaders and district superintendents throughout the state.

text: As part of that long-term project, I’ve been looking at the long-term debt history of the United States, using both the Fed’s flow of funds data (which start in 1952) and the earlier, not quite comparable, data from Millennial Historical Statistics. headline: Double, Triple and Quadruple Toil: Alan Cumming Will Star in One-Man ‘Macbeth’
text: They don’t call it the Scottish play for nothing: when a new National Theater of Scotland production of “Macbeth” comes to the Lincoln Center Festival in the summer it will have only one Scotsman composing its entire cast, thus lowering the risk if anyone says its title out loud. Alan Cumming, the “Good Wife” and “Cabaret” star (not to mention the voice of another great Scot, Gutsy Smurf), will perform every single role in the Shakespeare tragedy, including the regicidal schemer of its title and his devious, spot-obsessed wife (though we’re especially intrigued to see what he does with the three witches). The production, to be directed by John Tiffany and Andy Goldberg, will originate in June at the Tramway in Glasgow, and then be presented at the Lincoln Center Festival in New York from July 5 through July 14.

headline: As Water Levels Drop, Texas Drought Reveals Secrets of the Deep
text: MARTINS MILL, Tex. — For more than three years, the lake on Jack Mewbourn’s ranch here held a secret at its murky bottom: A 1999 Chevrolet Monte Carlo. His grandson was the first one to notice the top of the car peeking out of the water. It wasn’t luck, or even fate. It was drought.

headline: Storming of British Embassy in Tehran Broadcast Live on State Television
text: Last Updated | 3:32 p.m. Iranian state television showed live images of student protesters breaking into the British Embassy in Tehran on Tuesday and hurling rocks and Molotov cocktails, my colleagues Alan Cowell and Rick Gladstone report.

headline: Surprise Winners and Choice Quotes
text: Well, so much for predictions. The Gotham Awards, the first stop on the celebrity prize circuit, offered a slew of surprise winners on Monday night, and even a tie for its top category, best feature. That honor went to “Beginners” and “The Tree of Life.”

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Bloomberg Businessweek: Supermarket store brands (like those primordial cans marked “beans” or “beets”) were once mocked as cheesy copycat products, but recession-cautious shoppers have emboldened Safeway and Kroger to step up the quality of — and the marketing for — their own private labels. Via San Francisco Chronicle. — Glenn Collins

headline: Jason Moran Is Named Kennedy Center’s Jazz Adviser
text: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts said on Tuesday that the pianist and composer Jason Moran has been appointed its new artistic adviser for jazz. Mr. Moran, 36, is the second person to hold that post, which had been vacant since the death last year of Billy Taylor, the venerable pianist and educator who began advising the Kennedy Center in 1994.

headline: Edible Selby | Danish Modern
text: The father of modern-day foraging, René Redzepi, is not short on accolades. His Copenhagen restaurant, Noma, has earned best restaurant in the world in San Pellegrino’s foodie poll two years in a row, his abstract dishes comparisons to the paintings of Cy Twombly. Behind the chef’s famously free-form approach is a highly studious investigation into the culinary possibilities of foraged ingredients. The El Bulli and French Laundry veteran has set up a nonprofit called the Nordic Food Lab on a nearby houseboat to “create cornerstones for a new kind of cuisine,” he says. The research lab, led by Lars Williams, a former Noma chef and an alum of New York’s WD-50, has been experimenting with fermentation and umami for seven months, for instance. “It’s a bridge between science and the cooking world, but not for the sake of science,” Redzepi says. “For the sake of deliciousness.” Go to interactive feature >>

headline: Its Growth Slowing, Britain Extends Austerity Measures
text: On the eve of a huge strike by public sector workers to protest austerity measures, the British government said Tuesday that it was falling behind with its deficit reduction plan and that the measures would drag on for two more years.

headline: AMR Filing Is 2nd-Largest by a U.S. Airline
text: While the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, is the last of the legacy airline companies in the United States to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, it’s not the biggest filing. In 2002 UAL, the parent of United Airlines, filed with $25.2 billion in assets, slightly more than AMR at $24.7 billion.

headline: Christmas Pends: Remember the ‘Tree Man’
text: The scent of turkey and yams has barely faded only to be quickly replaced by a piney reminder of the coming Christmas holiday. Noble firs once again line the sidewalks as we recall “Tree Man,” last December’s City Room series that followed Nikola Ivkovic, a Christmas tree vendor, through his selling season.

headline: The Buyer’s Remorse Primary
text: One of the features of this year’s Republican nomination calendar is an unusually large gap separating the first few voting states from the larger block of states that vote in March. The gap resulted because Florida, Iowa, Nevada, New Hampshire and South Carolina moved up their voting dates by roughly a month from their original schedule while most of the others remained in place.

headline: Trying to Save W.P.S.: A Player’s View
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — “When W.U.S.A. folded, one of the worst things I continued to hear was that it was too bad they [the general public] didn’t know more about it.” When I read that in an e-mail from a fellow W.P.S. player, I was moved to do my part.

headline: Leading Off: Meyer’s About-Face
text: Today we are reeling with the shocking development that Urban Meyer has been introduced as Ohio State’s football coach. The sporting public is gobsmacked that Meyer would change course like this, taking over college football’s latest version of the Titanic only a year after tearfully walking away from Florida to embrace the family life he had neglected for so long. We were so convinced Meyer would gently fade from the scene in favor of enjoying his lovely wife and daughters, except when he was talking to us on ESPN every week.

headline: Rabbit, Run: ‘Harvey,’ With Jim Parsons, Sets Broadway Opening Date
text: The Jimmy Stewart vehicle “Harvey” – and the Emmy Award winner Jim Parsons (“The Big Bang Theory”) – are coming back to Broadway this spring. Roundabout Theater Company confirmed plans on Tuesday to mount the first Broadway revival of “Harvey” since 1970, when Stewart reprised his performance as Elwood P. Dowd from the 1950 film (as well as from the 1940s Broadway production.)

headline: Patton Oswalt Steals the Scene at the Gotham Awards
text: There’s a scene-stealer at every Gotham Awards – last year it was Bill Murray. (“His shadow is a better actor than 70 percent of the people in this room,” Mr. Murray said, introducing the career honoree Robert Duvall.) This year the undisputed star of the night was Patton Oswalt, who plays a crippled, sensitive sad sack opposite Charlize Theron in “Young Adult,” the dark comedy written by Diablo Cody and directed by Jason Reitman. Mr. Oswalt introduced Ms. Theron for her career tribute award with a mostly improvised routine.

headline: Nostalgia Trip With an Old Friend
text: Among traditional gamers — those who were playing before the likes of Wii Sports, Guitar Hero, Angry Birds and World of Warcraft returned interactive entertainment to the masses — there is no more hallowed franchise than The Legend of Zelda from Nintendo. If you grew up playing consoles in the late 1980s and the ’90s, Zelda probably provided some of your touchstone gaming experiences.

headline: Biden in Iraq to Prepare for Postwar Relations
text: BAGHDAD — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived here on Tuesday for a visit meant to inaugurate a new relationship between the United States and Iraq, just weeks before the last American troops are scheduled to leave the country.

headline: Qatar, a Greenhouse Gas Titan, to Host U.N. Climate Meeting
text: The Persian Gulf nation of Qatar has been selected as the site of the United Nations climate change meeting next year, edging out South Korea. The announcement came as this year’s meeting opened in Durban, South Africa, with delegates from 194 nations facing growing concern about rising global temperatures and more frequent climate-related catastrophes.

headline: Q&A: It’s the Season To Earn, and Spend, Points
text: BRIAN KELLY started planning his father’s work trips — and managing his travel awards — when he was still a kid. At 13, he had collected enough points to book a family vacation in the Cayman Islands. Now Mr. Kelly’s blog, thepointsguy.com, helps frustrated travelers who don’t know how to make the most of their awards. With so much gift-giving and family visiting, Mr. Kelly said, the holidays are the season for racking up travel points. Below are his five tips for giving — and getting.

headline: For Contractors, How Quick Is Obama’s QuickPay?
text: In September, The Agenda reported about the Obama administration’s QuickPay program, an effort to reduce payment time for small-business invoices from 30 to 15 days. Earlier this month, a reader, Paul Kakert of Davenport, Ia., wrote to express his skepticism.”Sure, it sounds good. Paid within 15 days,” he commented. “But within 15 days of when?” He went on:

headline: A Dash of Drama in the Pizza World
text: A heady perfume of cheese, tomatoes and crispy coal-fired crust wafts onto the sidewalk of Old Fulton Street, intoxicating enough to cause tourists to snap pictures and queue in stomach-growling anticipation.

headline: Raikkonen Returns to Formula One
text: After a couple of years away from the series in a failed attempt at rally racing, Kimi Raikkonen, the 2007 world champion at Ferrari, will return to race in Formula One next season.

headline: Raikkonen Returns to Formula One
text: After a couple of years away from the series in a failed attempt at rally racing, Kimi Raikkonen, the 2007 world champion at Ferrari, will return to race in Formula One next season.

headline: Les Waters Named New Artistic Director at Actors Theater of Louisville
text: 4:30 p.m. | Updated Les Waters, an Obie-award winning director known for his work with Sarah Ruhl and other emerging playwrights, will become the new artistic director of the Actors Theater of Louisville on Jan. 9, officials at the Kentucky theater said on Tuesday. Mr. Waters, 59, has been the associate director of Berkeley Repertory Theater in California since 2003.

headline: CUNY Board Approves Tuition Increases
text: Richard Pérez-Peña reported in Tuesday’s Times that tuition at the City University of New York will rise by 31 percent over the next five years after a vote by CUNY trustees on Monday. He wrote:

headline: Profile in Style | Francesca Bonato
text: Francesca Bonato’s accessories line, Hacienda Montaecristo, was born of necessity. When she and her husband, the model Nicolas Malleville, opened their hotel, Coqui Coqui, in Tulum, Mexico, 10 years ago, “Calvin Klein didn’t sell linens here,” she says. So the couple made their own, working with local weavers for everything from towels to uniforms. Along the way, she fell in love with the traditional shawl called the rebozo, which she and her partner, Jacopo Janniello Ravagnan, use for their bags, sandles and jewelry. “We’re inspired by the synchronicity of the colonial and local traditions,” she says, “by the romanticism of Mexico.” See more >>

headline: In Protest Over NATO Strike, Pakistan Will Skip Afghan Conference
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan announced Tuesday that it would not attend an important international conference on Afghanistan’s security and development that is scheduled to begin in less than a week in protest over the weekend strikes that killed two dozen Pakistani soldiers.

headline: For Blake, a Focus on Fund-Raising
text: James Blake did not have to rely on a big serve or the speediness of his quick feet Monday night. Instead, Blake, the  American tennis star, needed a steady handshake, a broad smile and the ability to work a room full of family, friends and guests.

headline: Gingrich Aims to Turn Immigration Issue on Foes
text: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C. — Newt Gingrich sought to turn the fractious issue of illegal immigration from an Achilles’ heel of his campaign into a spear aimed at opponents. He attacked both the Obama administration for failing to control the Mexican border, then pivoted in an interview to warn his Republican rivals Mitt Romney and Michele Bachmann that they would pay a price for distorting his position.

headline: A Palm Beach Story, Millions Not Required
text: I sized up the 14th fairway overlooking the sea in Palm Beach, Fla., long a winter escape for millionaires, and pondered two questions:

headline: ‘Living Dead’ Fans Digging Up Funds to Keep Chapel from Going Under
text: They’re coming to save you: though the reanimated corpses from George A. Romero’s 1968 horror classic “Night of the Living Dead” are long since buried (and hopefully deceased this time), one original building remains from the shooting of that film, and its fans are fighting to preserve it. The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported that in September, the Evans City Cemetery Association gave Gary Streiner one year to raise $50,000 to repair a run-down chapel in that Pennsylvania town — a building that “Living Dead” aficionados may remember from the graveyard where Barbra is teased by her brother, Johnny, “They’re coming to get you.” (No spoilers, but let’s just say Johnny comes to regret that taunt.)

headline: Mathew Cerletty: ‘Susan’ at Algus Greenspon
text: Algus Greenspon

headline: Empire State Building on Track to Be Part of I.P.O.
text: 8:36 p.m. | Updated

headline: TimesCast | November 29, 2011
text: Protesters ransack the British Embassy in Tehran; and American Airlines' parent company files for Chapter 11.

headline: Clinton’s Visit to Myanmar Raises Hopes and Concerns
text: BUSAN, South Korea — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton’s trip to Myanmar this week is raising hopes for greater freedom in the isolated country, but also concerns that the Obama administration is rushing to reward the leaders of one of the world’s most repressive countries.

headline: Jackson’s Doctor Is Sentenced to Four Years
text: LOS ANGELES — Dr. Conrad Murray, the physician convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the 2009 death of Michael Jackson, was sentenced to four years, the maximum he was facing, though how many days he will actually spend behind bars remains unclear. The sentencing comes three weeks after a jury found Dr. Murray guilty.

headline: The Politicization of the Solicitor General
text: It is customary in Washington to handle allegations of wrongdoing by accusing the other side of the same, often in a purely optical attempt to establish parity. With the health care reform case soon to come before the Supreme Court, calls for Justice Clarence Thomas to recuse himself have been met by calls for Justice Elena Kagan to recuse herself.

headline: The Poorest and Richest Counties
text: The county with the lowest poverty rate in America last year was Falls Church, Va. — actually an independent city — where about 3 percent of residents live in poverty, according to a new data release from the Census Bureau. The highest poverty rate was in Ziebach County, S.D., where about half of residents are below the poverty line.

headline: Wings’ Eaves Pays the Price for Blocking Shot
text: If you’re ordering a smoothie today, consider drinking it in honor of Detroit Red Wings forward Patrick Eaves. Milkshakes, pureed and liquefied foods, smoothies and energy drinks will be Eaves’ diet for the near future, after a gruesome accident during Saturday’s 4-1 win over Nashville left him with a broken jaw.

headline: Look of the Moment | Stella Tennant
text: The Look: Black on Black on Black. Varying textures of noir –– reflective, matte and furry –– are cut with a sharp, plunging V and gold accessories.

headline: More Parents Skip Childhood Vaccines
text: Health officials have struggled for years to reassure parents that childhood vaccinations are safe, but the number of parents who skip the shots continues to grow, according to a new analysis by The Associated Press.

headline: Judge Says Islamic Center Can Stay, but Owes Rent
text: Consolidated Edison cannot evict the developer of a controversial Islamic community center in Lower Manhattan, though the tenant does owe at least hundreds of thousands of dollars in back rent, according to a Manhattan judge.

headline: Official Calls for Urgency on College Costs
text: As Occupy movement protests helped push spiraling college costs into the national spotlight, Education Secretary Arne Duncan urged higher-education officials Tuesday to “think more creatively — and with much greater urgency” about ways to contain costs and reduce student debt.

headline: For Maybach, a Long Slouch Before the Fall
text: On July 2, 2002, two luxury barges idled in New York Harbor. One, the Queen Elizabeth 2, had just completed a transatlantic crossing from Southampton, England. The other, the first Maybach 62 sedan ever produced, had stowed away for the voyage in a glass box on the ship’s sun deck. The box was eventually lifted, gingerly, by a cargo helicopter and set down on a nearby pier, from which the V-12-powered car departed for a news conference on Wall Street.

headline: Q&A: Installing Software on Linux
text: Q.

headline: Another Tethering App Bites the Dust
text: Apple has removed from its App Store a tethering app that granted customers the ability to share an iPhone’s Internet connection with a computer after paying a one-time fee.

headline: Worker Transit Benefits Scheduled to Shrink
text: If you qualify for pretax transit benefits, you’ll probably see the perk shrink starting in January.

headline: At C. Wonder, Something Feels Familiar
text: THE designer Tory Burch might not be the gayest divorcée in town, but she is certainly one of the most doggedly productive. Her distinctive crest, two facing T’s that resemble a medieval cross, bedecks ballet flats from Manhasset to Myanmar; her signature caftans billow above thousands of tummies; the vice president’s wife carries one of her handbags. The golden-haired Ms. Burch, mother of three and stepmother to three more, has also dated Lance Armstrong, and, though she has resisted the term “socialite” (heck, who wouldn’t?), is often photographed at parties wearing a chunky statement necklace and an enigmatic grin.

headline: ‘Beginners’ and ‘Take Shelter’ Pick Up Spirit Nominations
text: “Beginners” continues its indie roll, earning nominations for best feature, best screenplay and best director at the Film Independent Spirit Awards, the West Coast answer to the Gothams. Another Bagger favorite, “Take Shelter,” picked up nominations in those three categories, alongside the likely Oscar contenders “The Descendants” and “The Artist”; Michael Shannon, the star of “Take Shelter,” also earned a nod for best male lead.

headline: A Tutoring Company Learns a Lesson
text: In my last post, Alexandra Mayzler pondered the best way to train the tutors she hires to work for her company, Thinking Caps Tutoring. She had devised a manual but feared she wasn’t presenting the information it contained in a compelling or memorable way.

headline: Barry Llewellyn, a Founder of the Heptones, Dies at 63
text: Barry Llewellyn, a founding member of the popular Jamaican harmony trio the Heptones, died on Nov. 23 in St. Andrew, Jamaica. He was 63 and lived in Brooklyn.

headline: F.T.C. Settles Privacy Issue at Facebook
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Accusing Facebook of engaging in “unfair and deceptive” practices, the federal government on Tuesday announced a broad settlement that requires the company to respect the privacy wishes of its users and subjects it to regular privacy audits for the next 20 years.

headline: Indoor Maps for Android Users
text: Today, Google announced that its Google Maps Android app would feature indoor mapping data for several airports, stores and shopping malls in the United States and Japan. Here’s the press release announcing the new feature.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 74
text: Occupy Wall Street protesters may have cheered Judge Jed S. Rakoff’s ruling Monday against the Securities and Exchange Commission’s proposed settlement with Citigroup, but a friend of his says, “Don’t confuse Judge Rakoff with some member of the Occupy Wall Street movement,” citing his career defending investment banks and corporations as a litigator. [DealBook, BusinessWeek]

headline: Are Your Children at Risk From Vaccine Exemptions?
text: Vaccine refusal rates are going up. The Associated Press reports a rise in the number of parents in many states who either don’t vaccinate their children or who limit vaccinations. In eight states, including Washington and Colorado, more than 1 in 20 kindergartners attending public school haven’t had all of the shots that are “required” for school attendance, with many choosing to skip shots for philosophical reasons.

headline: Basketball’s Misguided Fixation With Starting
text: A place in the starting lineup is one of the N.B.A.’s most overrated currencies. In actuality it indicates nothing, other than that a given team prefers to have a particular player on the floor to complete a specific lineup. Sometimes the starting five consists of the top five players on the roster, but more often it is a group that has been configured to manage strength and weakness, balance starters and reserves, and create a meaningful product out of a roster of moving parts.

headline: Sony Music Executive to Rejoin Bertelsmann
text: 3:37 p.m. | Updated

headline: Even With Reruns, CBS Is No. 1
text: Even with CBS showing a full slate of repeats the other broadcast networks could not compete on Monday night as CBS ranked first in total viewership and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic segment, according to Nielsen. New episodes of “Terra Nova” and “House” on Fox made only slight gains compared to last week against the weakened competition, with 7.2 million total viewers and 7.3 million respectively. ABC’s presentation of “How the Grinch Stole Christmas” drew 7.7 million viewers.

headline: Brother, Can You Spare a Line?
text: This past summer I drove across the country interviewing people who had lost their jobs since 2007 — since the housing market disintegrated, since Lehman Brothers evaporated, since layoffs subsumed the work force. I asked for details about the climactic phone call, the conference room, the look of the sky out the window, the security escort, the drive home: all the particulars of the experience.

headline: Support for Tea Party Drops Even in Strongholds, Survey Finds
text: 11:11 p.m. | Updated  The full report of this article is available here.

headline: Google and Apple Are Both Winners in Mobile Race, Report Says
text: It is not very often that you get two winners and two losers in the same competition. Yet according to a new report to be issued Wednesday by Nielsen, the market research firm, Google and Apple are both winning in the mobile smartphone race.

headline: A Worrisome Snag in the E.C.B’s Bond-Purchasing
text: An effort by the European Central Bank to intervene in government bond markets hit a technical shortfall Tuesday, raising new questions about how long the central bank can avoid taking bigger steps to address the euro region’s debt crisis.

headline: 2nd Bribe Case for Lawmaker Just Acquitted
text: Even to those accustomed to the sins of New York politicians, the latest trials and tribulations of Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr. may have hit a new low.

headline: New York Film Critics Circle Go With ‘The Artist’
text: All day long the New York Film Critics Circle has been posting the results of its much-earlier-than-usual year-end voting on Twitter, a slow drip of news somewhere between live-tweeting World War II and those moments when Doogie Howser would sit typing pensively on his blue computer screen (Carrie in “Sex and the City” or Jenna in “Awkward” for later generations).

headline: A Call for Lower College Costs
text: In an article posted on The Times’s Web site, our colleague Tamar Lewin writes that Education Secretary Arne Duncan on Tuesday “pushed higher education officials to ‘think more creatively — and with much greater urgency — about how to contain the spiraling costs of college and reduce the burden of student debt on our nation’s students.’ ”

headline: The Pace of Reform Accelerates in Myanmar
text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton is scheduled to arrive in the country on Wednesday as a show of support for its transformation to a nascent democracy.

headline: From Spring to Winter: Explaining the Egypt Elections
text: Overview | What is happening in Egypt in the aftermath of revolution? How does the situation in Egypt compare with other nations that have experienced uprisings in the Arab World? In this lesson, students get updated on Egypt and then develop a series of current events talks for their community on what has happened to the Arab Spring as it turns into Arab Winter.

headline: For AMR’s Now-Former Chief, a Long Career Felled by Chapter 11
text: Throughout his eight-year tenure as the AMR Corporation‘s chief executive, Gerard J. Arpey had consistently emphasized one strategic point: He would not put the airline into bankruptcy.

headline: Choosing Between the Rich and Everyone Else
text: Republicans have been railing against the latest Democratic plan to extend the payroll tax cut, and it’s pretty clear why. Of all the contortions they’ve been forced to make by their refusal to raise taxes on the rich, this is the most painful. It is the one that will affect average Americans the most directly, and will starkly illustrate the advantage Republicans prefer giving to the rich over everyone else.

headline: Opening the Doors of Dior
text: SAINT LAURENT, Chanel, Dior: the names of the most famous Paris houses sort of dance off the tongue. Their histories defeat the idea that younger generations might be bored with old things. And a stream of books and films helps to assure that they won’t be.

text: The move by Herman Cain comes a day after an Atlanta woman named Ginger White gave details of what she said was a 13-year affair with him.

headline: How Does the American Airlines Bankruptcy Affect You?
text: American Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday, is among the last of the major carriers to do so, raising predictable questions for customers about how the changes will affect them. Based on what can be gleaned from the bankruptcies of other airlines over the past few years, the general answer is that at least for the short term, the experience of flying with American will remain largely the same, though changes are likely down the road.

headline: Notes From a Young American in Congo: The Election
text: “There is no government in Congo,” Maman Marie Nzoli, director of the local non-profit organization COPERMA, said over a year ago.“[Joseph] Kabila’s government is a government that doesn’t exist.”

headline: Apps for Autistic Children
text: The iPad has been hailed by many as a life-changing device for children on the autism spectrum or with other special needs, helping them to communicate or develop fine motor skills. But the market is so flooded with apps for special-needs kids that it can be overwhelming to find good ones. Our friends at the Gadgetwise blog have offered a roundup of Web sites that review these apps (and don’t take referral fees from the manufacturers). Read more at Gadgetwise.

headline: Come Together
text: On Sunday night, the fashion collective Three as Four opened its highly anticipated exhibition “Insalaam Inshalom” at the Beit Ha’Ir Center for Urban Culture in Tel Aviv, bringing to fruition a project over two years in the making. Covering the walls of the four-story building in fabric printed with their spring collection’s central motifs, which are made of a mix of Muslim and Jewish symbols, the designers Gabi Asfour, Adi Gil and Ange Donhauser invited 10 artists to show works that relate to the project’s central notion: that Judaism and Islam can live side by side. “We’ve accumulated the energy of artists and performers who are like-minded,” Asfour said. “We tried to balance things from all sides, though it’s always difficult.”

headline: A Pastry From Brittany Making Waves Stateside
text: Who could pass up something billed as “the fattiest pastry in all of Europe”? That’s how the kouign-amann, a specialty of Brittany in France, was described to me when I visited the region this summer.

headline: inSALAAm inSHALLOm

headline: Yanks’ Calm Is Sign of No Pressing Needs
text: Pay attention to the Yankees this time of year, and you remember certain myths of past off-seasons. Bubba Crosby was once the answer in center field, not a free agent named Johnny Damon. Alex Rodriguez would be shunned if he opted out of his contract. Mark Teixeira was too expensive to pursue. Rafael Soriano was not worth the sacrifice of a first-round draft pick.

text: The AMR Corporation is in bankruptcy court for its first day of Chapter 11 hearings. The parent company of American Airlines, it is seeking approval for a flurry of customary motions that will keep its lights on as it seeks to cut costs in bankruptcy protection.

headline: At Diamond Foods, Accounting Weighs on Pringles Deal
text: It appears that not even Diamond Foods knows what the future holds for its proposed acquisition of Procter & Gamble’s Pringles brand of chips. Behind the uncertainty of Diamond’s deal are competing narratives of a company that is either the victim of an attack by short-sellers or otherwise responsible for its own troubles.

headline: Design Competition for an AIDS Memorial Begins
text: The coalition behind the plan to create an AIDS memorial in St. Vincent’s Triangle Park is kicking off an international design competition and has selected a panel of judges. At the helm will be Michael Arad, the designer of the poignant and provocative 9/11 memorial in the footprint of the former World Trade Center.

headline: The ‘Revkin’ Collection in the Climate E-mail Release

Here’s the search result for my name.

headline: Americans Used to Be Much More Anti-Tax
text: In addition to his Economix post, Bruce Bartlett also has a Tax Notes column today looking at public support for raising taxes (instead of or in addition to cutting spending)  to narrow federal deficits. He found dozens of surveys conducted over the last year showing that most Americans believe that taxes should be part of any deficit reduction package.

text: In another co-location conflict, parents at The Talented and Gifted School for Young Scholars in East Harlem, a kindergarten to 8th grade school, are upset about plans by the city to expand one of the schools with which they share their building into a high school. With seats in gifted and talented programs so limited, they say, the city should be allowing their school to grow.

headline: Reviewing Fatty ’Cue
text: Last month, after reviewing Rouge et Blanc, the French-Vietnamese restaurant in SoHo, I speculated here at Diner’s Journal on the status of fusion cuisine. While many of the restaurants that gave fusion a bad reputation have thankfully passed on, the notion of blending the techniques and ingredients of multiple cultures pervades restaurants today.

headline: A Roadhouse With a World View
text: CONSIDER butter. It’s exalted, whether in the copious amounts that flavor and enrich classic French haute cuisine, in the supremely pure examples reverently served at Per Se, or even in the farmer-labeled bars peddled at the shop on the corner.

headline: Music Is Love, and Love Is Music
text: For Frank Ocean, love is in many ways music itself. In his elegant, savvy, slightly crooked postsoul, he shifts sneakily between the two topics, singing about love as a byproduct of music and using the subject of music to dig deep about love.

headline: Turkey Increases Pressure on Syria Over Oppression
text: ISTANBUL — Turkish officials continued Tuesday to step up pressure on Syria, saying they would consider having their military cross the border to impose a safety zone if the Assad government failed to stop killing citizens demanding democratic change.

headline: Creatures Big and Small, Remaking a 16th-Century Legend
text: Before there was Rocky Horror, before there was Frankenstein’s monster, before even the sorcerer’s apprentice’s broom, there was Golem: the original man-made being gone awry.

headline: The Top of the World, Then Prison in Siberia
text: Soviet Communism may have toppled, but in high places in the Kremlin the old authoritarian mind-set still prevails. Enemies of the power elite can be arrested, tried on trumped-up charges and imprisoned in a system as labyrinthine and secretive as it was during the Soviet era. At least that is the perspective on Russian political power games expressed in “Khodorkovsky,” the German filmmaker Cyril Tuschi’s sympathetic documentary portrait of the persecuted Russian oligarch Mikhail Khodorkovsky, who ran afoul of the former Russian president Vladimir V. Putin, who is now prime minister.

headline: RIM Reacts to Bring-Your-Own Devices Policies
