headline: Rewriting History (Second Revision)
text: Most journalists — and regular people, too — dream of knowing what the world’s most influential figures are saying, thinking and plotting in their most private moments. And that’s why we have Hollywood.

headline: States Receive Health Care Grants
text: Hoping to alleviate concerns of states, the Obama administration on Tuesday said it would award nearly $220 million in new federal grants to states to set up exchanges where uninsured Americans may eventually be able to buy medical coverage as part of the federal health care law.

headline: Egyptians Turn Out for a Second Day of Voting
text: Polls opened for a second day of voting on Tuesday in the first parliamentary elections since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: 24-Hour Arty People | T’s Art Basel Miami ‘to Do’ List
text: The artist Rirkrit Tiravanija’s beach towel for Art Production Fund’s Works on Whatever editions pretty much sums it up. Art Basel Miami Beach, now in its 10th year, kicked off today, and if you plan to take it all in — and see some art — you are going to be busy indeed. T’s impartial to-do list, below, even allows for some quality beach time, so don’t forget to throw in that towel.

headline: Punch Lines for the Right and the Left
text: If all of America’s registered Republicans were struck by an ideology-specific bird flu, and 50 among them had to be placed in a secure bunker to repopulate the species entirely, P. J. O’Rourke would hold a place on many people’s list, mine included.

headline: A Warm-Hued Beginning for Quartet’s New Violinist
text: The Juilliard String Quartet’s first violin chair was once its rock of stability: Robert Mann held it from the group’s founding in 1946 through 1997 and saw the players in every other position change at least once.

headline: Now a Word (and a Dance) by a Sponsor
text: Advertising a pharmaceutical product must be a tricky business; there’s so much cognitive dissonance involved. Think of the television commercials that show images implying happy outcomes, while a voice simultaneously lists at length everything that could go wrong. Or take the home page of a Web site promoting the anti-H.I.V. drug Reyataz: a column of side-effect warnings fights for space with photos of a woman stretching and leaping, perfectly toned, the picture of health. Underneath her is one more disclaimer: “not a patient dramatization.”

headline: Cyber Monday Shopping Surpasses Expectations
text: The final numbers for holiday gift shopping on Cyber Monday are rolling in, and online sales beat early expectations, making Monday the biggest online shopping day on record.

headline: TimesCast | Protesters Storm Embassy
text: Protesters ransacked the British Embassy in Tehran.

headline: Supporters Buy Ad Urging Palin to Run
text: Sarah Palin supporters just won’t give up.

headline: Iraq War Presidential Drop In
text: BAGHDAD – As the Times’ Mark Landler reports, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived in Baghdad Tuesday night for an unannounced visit to mark the twilight of the United States’ military’s presence in Iraq with ceremonies thanking American and Iraqi troops for their work and sacrifices, and meetings with Iraqi leaders on the road ahead for the two countries.

headline: Older Music Refracted Through a Modernist Prism
text: There were only two relatively short contemporary works in the remarkable recital performed by the tenor Ian Bostridge and the composer and pianist Thomas Adès on Monday night at Carnegie Hall. Yet this was inspired programming: strategic choices, in the context they set up, teased out the modernist resonances in older music, even a cycle as familiar as Schumann’s “Dichterliebe.”

headline: Footnote
text: Richard Fleeshman and Caissie Levy, above with Mr. Fleeshman, who are playing the lead characters Sam and Molly in the London production of “Ghost: The Musical,” will reprise their performances in the Broadway staging this spring, the producers said on Tuesday. The show is scheduled to begin preview performances at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater on March 15 and open on April 23.

headline: U.S. to Take Over Orchestra’s Pensions
text: A federal bankruptcy judge has agreed to let the federal government take over the Philadelphia Orchestra’s pension plans, saying the orchestra was unlikely to survive if it tried to keep running them itself. The two pension plans, one for musicians and the other for staff members, cover about 200 people. Some musicians are likely to have their pensions reduced after the takeover. Although the government’s Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation insures defined-benefit pensions, its insurance is limited. In the past symphony orchestras competed for and retained top talent by promising generous pensions, so musicians with many years in the Philadelphia Orchestra probably have earned benefits above the insurance limit. The orchestra, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April, had asked for the government’s help with its pensions, saying that it could not raise money if donors thought their dollars might end up in a troubled pension fund. The pension funds are set up in a way that makes the orchestra bear all the investment risk. When the orchestra emerges from bankruptcy its musicians and staff members will have retirement plans under which they bear the investment risk.

headline: Raising a Teenager? What’s Not to Hate?
text: “Parenting” is one of those words, like “veggie,” that worm their way into common parlance on the back of infectious social preoccupations. We are a nation obsessed with how to raise children and how to eat, perhaps because we’ve become so bad at both.

headline: Images Show Devastation at Iran Base After Blast
text: The large, deadly explosion at an Iran military base in Iran on Nov. 12, which Iranian authorities have called an accident that set back research work there by a few days, appears to have been far more devastating than their description suggested, according to an analysis of newly released commercial satellite images of the blast site.

headline: A New Shot at Mortgage Relief
text: Like millions of other homeowners, William D. Compton would like to refinance his mortgage so that he pays less each month for his three-bedroom house in Gulf Breeze, Fla. With the savings, he figures he could afford a few extra movies and restaurant dinners or he could buy a new stove and brakes for his car, purchases he has postponed because finances are so tight.

headline: In Whirlwind of an Election in Congo, Votes May Become Victims, Too
text: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — A volatile combination of suspicion, shootings, political clashes and voting breakdowns continued in Congo on Tuesday, the second day of nationwide elections, with some areas still casting ballots, others counting votes and initial results showing a big victory for the opposition here in the capital.

headline: When the Chefs Come Home
text: IN the food world, chefs are the 1 percent, and the rest of us are the 99 percent. At this time every year, we dream of catching crumbs from their tables: shiny new cookbooks, stuffed with recipes so brilliantly simplified as to lift us up to their level.

headline: Slotted Spoon at MoMA Stores
text: Good design results in an everyday utensil that can go from kitchen to dinner table without raising its pinky and that even deserves gift-wrapping for a cook. This sleek, shiny stainless-steel slotted spoon with an extra deep bowl can lift pieces of meat, chunks of fish and mussels in their shells from a casserole or serving dish. It can also dredge up macerated fruit from a bowl of wintry glogg and transport it neatly into punch cups. A ladle will take care of the liquid.

headline: Tea Time for All Ages (Fairy Dust Optional)
text: WHEN my mom and I used to come into the city at Christmastime to see “The Nutcracker” or the holiday windows at Saks Fifth Avenue, chances are we would end up at tea. Formal tea at one of the hotels — the Plaza or the Palace — was its own rabbit hole, an upholstered salon filled with elegant women who left lipstick prints on the rims of their cups and murmured their secrets along the banquette to the flourishes of live harp music.

headline: A Zeal for Democracy in Ghana
text: In the fleet-footed, engagingly volatile documentary “An African Election,” the director Jarreth Merz hurls himself into the thick of a political contest defined by high hopes and even higher anxieties.

headline: Council Resolution Calls for Support of Occupy Wall Street
text: Three City Council members introduced a resolution Tuesday that would formalize support for Occupy Wall Street and its message condemning economic inequality.

headline: Once Again, Paulson Regrets the Error
text: In his third-quarter letter to investors, John A. Paulson, the billionaire founder of Paulson & Company, apologized yet again for his hedge fund’s disastrous slide this year.

headline: Clip: ‘Khodorkovsky’
text: A scene from the documentary "Khodorkovsky," directed by Cyril Tuschi.

headline: Pecan, a Cafe, Opens on the Upper West Side
text: A bright, modern, uptown branch of Pecan, a cafe whose TriBeCa parent has a homier personality, has joined a spate of new restaurants and food shops that have opened or soon will open on the Upper West Side. Coffee and breakfast items start things rolling, followed by sandwiches, salads and soups, including several vegetarian choices, like a roasted sweet potato sandwich and a black lentil salad. Delivery is not available yet, but for now takeout is a fine option. Wine and beer are also coming. And if you opt to drink your well-made coffee at one of the long white tables, a barista (like Ricardo Palma, above, who is also a cook) will serve it in china.

headline: Among Great Wines, Plenty of Choice
text: I HAVE never been one of those people who feel they live in the wrong era. I am eternally grateful, for example, to draw breath in the age of anesthesia. But I have occasionally lamented that I was born just a few years too late.

headline: A Hard Cider From an Heirloom Apple
text: Many cider makers will tell you it takes several kinds of apples for a well-balanced drink. But the Oregon producer Original Sin, where Gidon Coll has been making blended ciders, has an outstanding new one made from a single heirloom varietal, the Newtown Pippin. This hard cider, pressed from an apple with historic roots in the New York region, has a Champagne delicacy and refreshing acidity that make it a fine aperitif or mealtime quaff. In a different style, the rosy Cherry Tree Hard Cider, Mr. Coll used a mixture of apples blended with tart cherries, creating a mellow drink that can handle charcuterie or dessert.

headline: Reviewing Café de la Esquina at Wythe Diner
text: La Esquina opened in SoHo in 2005 with an unlisted phone number and an attitude. Frank Bruni described it as “Studio 54 with chipotle instead of cocaine.” Six years later, it has spawned a sequel, of sorts, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn: Café de la Esquina at Wythe Diner, the subject of one of this week’s Dining Briefs.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Reggae for When the Lights Were Low
text: Lover’s rock — homegrown British reggae of the late 1970s to ’80s — earned its name when the lights were turned low. Songs like Janet Kay’s “Silly Games” and Louisa Mark’s “Caught You in a Lie” were the soundtrack for slow, intimate dancing, “scrubbing,” that was all about bodies rubbing against bodies in the dark.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Gingerbread Dwellings

headline: One Love: The Rastafarian Origin Story
text: Riffing on an unlikely nexus of black radicalism and white college students, the satirical newspaper The Onion once ran an item headlined “Bob Marley Rises From Grave to Free Frat Boys From Bonds of Oppression.”

headline: As Tasty Morsels, Pig Wings Take Flight
text: St. Cloud, Minn.

headline: To Keep Paul, the Hornets Could Let Him Help Build the Team
text: The tentative agreement between the N.B.A.’s players and owners doesn’t contain any particularly shocking elements; most of the new rules are natural compromises between the two sides, with the players finally getting some of the system considerations they had previously deemed to be paramount.

headline: Tenants Trying Again to Buy Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village
text: For the second time in six years, the tenants at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village are seeking to buy the financially troubled complexes, which have served as a leafy refuge for generations of middle-class families in high-priced Manhattan.

headline: With Romney, a Time for the Press and a Time for the People
text: TAMPA, FLA. — Mitt Romney came to Tampa to talk about trade policy, but the press wanted to talk about — anything but trade policy.

headline: The Year’s Notable Cookbooks
text: It’s hard to do justice to all the great cookbooks published this year, but here are some of the Dining staff’s favorites:

headline: The Politics of Economics: Feedback
text: So many readers agreed with the thesis of my last column – economics has been corrupted by the same virus that has hit the rest of our national discourse – that my contrarian, live-to-argue side almost wanted to take it all back. But, no. Fortunately, enough people found things to disagree with that we need not suffocate in a big kumbaya hug. Let me respond to a few of the more popular complaints.

headline: Bloggingheads: Debating Colonoscopies
text: John Horgan, left, of Scientific American and George Johnson of The Cancer Chronicles debate the value of cancer screening.

headline: Reviewing Chuko
text: Ramen is a complicated business, requiring endless minute adjustments of stock and seasoning, along with a certain reckless imagination. At Chuko, a ramen shop that opened in August in Prospect Heights (and the subject of one of this week’s Dining Briefs), the chefs and owners, Jamison Blankenship, David Koon and James Sato, make a valiant effort to achieve the fathomless broths, suffused with umami, found in Japan.

headline: Diamond Foods Makes Odd Moves
text: Things aren’t getting any better for the snack food maker Diamond Foods. A month ago, it delayed its $2.4 billion plan to buy Pringles from Procter & Gamble in order to look into accounting concerns. Now, the company is burying news about the inquiry and increasing payments to a couple of directors who are walnut growers. These and other inconsistencies don’t seem to augur well for the investigation, or its deal with Procter & Gamble.

headline: Treating People With Schizophrenia
text: To the Editor:

headline: Support for Iranian Group
text: To the Editor:

headline: Changes for the Jaguars, From the Very Top Down
text: The Jacksonville Jaguars’ owner, Wayne Weaver, woke up Tuesday with a long to-do list.

headline: Food Aid Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: Toyota and Subaru Preview Their Rear-Wheel-Drive Coupes
text: Leading up to their formal debuts at the Tokyo auto show, two long-gestating rear-wheel-drive coupes co-developed by Toyota and Subaru have been previewed in production form.

headline: Chile Indicts Ex-U.S. Officer in 1973 Killings
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — A Chilean judge indicted a former United States Navy officer on Tuesday in the killings of two United States citizens shortly after a 1973 military coup here.

headline: U.S. Settles Suit Over Anthrax Attacks
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government has agreed to pay $2.5 million to the widow and children of the first person killed in the anthrax letter attacks of 2001, settling a lawsuit claiming that the Army did not adequately secure its supply of the deadly pathogen.

headline: Vonns’ Divorce Will Also End a Skiing Partnership
text: Virtually inseparable on the ski racing circuit since 2005 and married four years ago during a snowy, idyllic ceremony at the base of a Utah mountain, Lindsey and Thomas Vonn each filed for divorce last week, ending a partnership widely celebrated in the wake of Olympic success and multiple World Cup titles.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Which Way on Taxes?
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Interview With Carolina Herrera
text: Jessica Michault of The International Herald Tribune talks to the designer about the “Twilight” wedding dress, her relationship with Renée Zellweger, and working with family.

headline: The Future of China
text: To the Editor:

headline: Facebook May Be Forced to Go Public Amid Market Gloom
text: Facebook is in a corner.

headline: How to Free Congress’s Mind
text: WHEN it comes to changing the toxic partisan gridlock in Washington, the Beatles got it just about right: “You tell me it’s the institution/Well, you know/You’d better free your mind instead.”

headline: Galleon Chief’s Lawyers Seek to Delay Prison Term
text: Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund manager convicted of insider trading, is set to report next week to a federal penitentiary in Ayer, Mass., to serve an 11-year sentence.

headline: ‘American Pie’ Still Homemade, but With a New Twist
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — To step into the Tin & Lint bar here is to be surrounded by stories. Carved into the wooden walls, booths and benches are 30 years of names, dates and declared loves: Mike was here; Don loves Joanna 4EVER; Amy and Jennifer, 1989.

headline: Lines Grow Long for Free School Meals, Thanks to Economy
text: Millions of American schoolchildren are receiving free or low-cost meals for the first time as their parents, many once solidly middle class, have lost jobs or homes during the economic crisis, qualifying their families for the decades-old safety-net program.

headline: Judge Says Suit to Void Marriage Act May Proceed
text: Harshly criticizing Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo for the tactics he used to win approval of same-sex marriage, a state judge has ruled that a lawsuit challenging the enactment of New York’s Marriage Equality Act can proceed.

headline: Pushing Latin American Banks to Lend
text: MEXICO CITY — As economic turmoil whiplashes banks in Europe and poses new threats to American financial institutions, the view from Latin America is very different. Well off the radar screen of the global economic crisis, Latin America’s banks have proven their sturdiness, emerging relatively unscathed from the collapse.

headline: In Interview, Romney Sets Stage for Gingrich Rivalry
text: So, what does Mitt Romney really think of Newt Gingrich?

headline: Recalling Days on the Run With Abducted Children
text: The week before they abducted their eight children from a foster care center in Queens, Nephra and Shanel Payne stocked up at Costco on supplies and dry goods, like graham crackers, diapers and infant formula for Nefertiti, their 11-month-old daughter. They stashed family photos and important documents in a storage facility and crammed a basketball and a football — essential for traveling with a Little League team’s worth of boys — into their car.

headline: Apple’s Siri Stumbles Over an Abortion Question
text: Nov. 30, 8:28 p.m. | Updated  See Apple’s response to this issue.

headline: Muzzling the Rainbow Nation
text: Johannesburg

headline: Cain Speaks on Foreign Policy, Avoiding Accusations
text: HILLSDALE, Mich. — Seemingly unbowed by the escalating scandal about his sexual conduct, Herman Cain addressed a crowd of several hundred in a college gymnasium here Tuesday night, but he made no mention of the allegations against him, instead focusing on vague and optimistic foreign policy ideals.

headline: Cleveland Turns Uptown Into New Downtown
text: CLEVELAND — Since 1950, when its population peaked at 914,808, Cleveland has steadily shed residents and jobs. In 2010, just 396,815 people lived within the city limits, almost 81,000 fewer than a decade before, and about the same number of people who lived in Cleveland in 1900.

headline: Facing Generic Lipitor Rivals, Pfizer Battles to Protect Its Cash Cow
text: For the last year, Pfizer has been laying the groundwork to combat the looming competition against Lipitor, forging deals with insurers, pharmacy benefit managers and patients to meet or beat the price of its generic replacements.

headline: What Would Gandhi Do?
text: New Delhi

headline: Understating Greece’s Problems
text: Ratings agencies missed the economic problems in Europe.

headline: Giving Where It Works
text: At Fixes, we often argue that good ideas are plentiful — but ways to keep them going are hard to find. That’s why we pay a lot of attention to sustainability, especially financial sustainability.  Life is always precarious for programs that depend on government financing or charitable donations, particularly so today. So we choose many of the programs we highlight because they have found a creative new way to sustain good work, often through combining social and for-profit missions.

headline: Details Emerge on MF Global’s Last-Ditch Effort to Fill Shortfall
text: After MF Global discovered a nearly $1 billion shortfall in customer money in the early hours of Oct. 31, the brokerage firm lined up a last-ditch — but ultimately unsuccessful — effort to fill the hole, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Making Local Food Real
text: You might think it would be difficult to find a cheerful and optimistic farmer the year a hurricane wiped out most of the crop, but I did so in Burlington, Vt., the day after Thanksgiving. I was visiting the Intervale Center, a nonprofit that manages a 350-plus-acre flood plain not far from downtown.

headline: Obama Is Facing a Replay of ’08 Hurdles in ‘Hillary Country,’ Pa.
text: SCRANTON, Pa. — It was trivia night at Kildare’s bar here, and among the teams competing was a group of history teachers from Scranton High School. They easily won the round that tested their knowledge of American presidents, including that the last one with facial hair was William Howard Taft.

headline: For 92nd St. Y, a Break From Wall St. Worry
text: Clients of John A. Paulson, the billionaire hedge fund manager, have had a brutal year, absorbing losses of as much as 50 percent.

headline: Valentine Is Chosen to Manage Red Sox
text: For more than a century, the rivalry between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox has been the stuff of legend, filled with large personalities and fiery competitors. Now add to that caldron Bobby Valentine, one of the more colorful and controversial figures in recent New York baseball history.

headline: Gingrich Gave Push to Clients, Not Just Ideas
text: Newt Gingrich is adamant that he is not a lobbyist, but rather a visionary who traffics in ideas, not influence. But in the eight years since he started his health care consultancy, he has made millions of dollars while helping companies promote their services and gain access to state and federal officials.

headline: F.C.C. Report Details Merger Shortcomings
text: The Federal Communications Commission said it had allowed AT&T to withdraw an application to buy T-Mobile USA. Separately on Tuesday, the agency released a report that officials said outlined the $39 billion deal’s shortcomings.

headline: College Athletes Move Concussions Into the Courtroom
text: The punt soared through the night air, arriving just before the tackler crashed into Derek Owens. No penalty flag was thrown, and Owens maintained one would not have been justified. It was football, the sport he still loves, despite his concussions.

headline: Morocco: Islamist Named Premier
text: King Mohammed VI of Morocco appointed as prime minister on Tuesday the head of the moderate Islamist party that on Friday won the country’s first elections under a new constitution, the royal palace said. The king chose Abdellilah Benkirane, the general secretary of the Justice and Development Party, to form a coalition government. The new Constitution, drafted by the king in response to calls for more democracy inspired by the Arab Spring, still reserves important powers for the king, including over military and religious matters.

headline: No Money for a Living Wage? But Fat Abounds
text: Everyone knows what marbled steak looks like, with the streaks of fat running through the red meat, right in front of your eyes. The marbled public works project is harder to recognize, but it most certainly exists.

headline: Tahrir's Candidate
text: Zyad Elelaimy first emerged in January as a main voice of the youthful revolutionaries in Tahrir Square. Now he is running for a Parliament seat as a candidate in Egypt's strongest liberal party.

headline: In Congress, Role Reversal Over Federal Payroll Tax Cut
text: WASHINGTON — In a sharp role reversal, Democrats and Republicans have become divided over whether to extend a federal payroll tax cut enjoyed by working Americans this year, with Democrats leading the charge for the tax break and many Republicans demanding that the cut be paid for if it is extended at all.

headline: Giants Have Little Time to Fix What Ails Them
text: The day after the Giants lost to the Philadelphia Eagles last week, there was palpable anger from the players, a genuine frustration over an opportunity lost. The Eagles, for all their preseason hype, have proven eminently beatable and the Giants did not hide their rage over letting a victory slip away.

headline: The Arab Awakening and Israel
text: Israel is facing the biggest erosion of its strategic environment since its founding. It is alienated from its longtime ally Turkey. Its archenemy Iran is suspected of developing a nuclear bomb. The two strongest states on its border — Syria and Egypt — are being convulsed by revolutions. The two weakest states on its border — Gaza and Lebanon — are controlled by Hamas and Hezbollah.

headline: Lottery Numbers
For S.E.C., Court Ruling on Penalties Ties a Hand
text: WASHINGTON — When a Wall Street firm trades billions of dollars of securities a day and sometimes showers seven-figure bonuses on top executives, regulators are hard-pressed to fashion a penalty that really hurts.

headline: Cain, Support Eroding, Weighs Dropping Bid
text: WASHINGTON — The leading conservative voices who have come to Herman Cain’s defense began backing away on Tuesday as he acknowledged that he was reassessing his Republican presidential bid, uncertain that he could withstand a report of an extramarital affair after accusations of sexual harassment and stumbling foreign policy responses.

headline: Mexico: Accuser of Police Is Killed
text: Prosecutors said Tuesday that their primary line of investigation in the killing of an activist who had criticized the police was the possibility that he had ties to organized crime. The activist, Nepomuceno Moreno, had accused police officers of kidnapping his 18-year-old son last year. He was shot to death on Monday in the northern state of Sonora. Members of the group that had served as a platform for Mr. Moreno, the Movement for Peace with Justice and Dignity, said state and federal authorities did not protect him when he requested it; the authorities said they had not received any requests for protection. Mr. Moreno’s son is still missing.

headline: So Near the Garden but Still Miles Away
text: Chris Paul mentioned moving boxes, Carmelo Anthony and New York — magic phrases that, with a little clever splicing, would leave Knicks fans all aflutter.

headline: Y.M.C.A. Adopting Health Policies for Youth
text: WASHINGTON — The Y.M.C.A., one of the nation’s largest child-care providers, intends to announce Wednesday that it is adopting new “healthy living standards,” including offering fruits, vegetables and water at snack time, increasing the amount of exercise and limiting video games and television for youngsters in its programs.

headline: Too Much Holiday Food? This Campaign’s for You
text: PEPTO-BISMOL, the brand of stomach remedies, traditionally has highlighted the symptoms it relieves, with commercials in the 1970s featuring pained-looking actors whose torsos expanded as if reflected in funhouse mirrors, and the promise that the pink product “coats, soothes, relieves.”

headline: Beyond ‘Glory’
text: Mention black soldiers in the Civil War today, and most people will immediately think of the 1989 film “Glory,” in which relatively enlightened Union officers train and then lead an all-black infantry regiment into battle. Part of the film’s power comes from the way that it gives the impression that employing black Americans as soldiers was a radically new idea.

headline: Single Spark Sets Off a Long Year of Debt
text: In July 2009, Jose Antonio Ithier woke up coughing and struggling to breathe. Plumes of black smoke were choking his lungs.

headline: In Chapter 11, a Bid to Cut Costs at American Airlines
text: After resisting for a decade, the parent company of American Airlines announced Tuesday that it would now follow a strategy that the rest of the industry chose long ago: filing for bankruptcy protection so it can shed debt, cut labor costs and find a way back to profitability.

headline: My Man Newt
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Ratings Firms Misread Signs of Greek Woes
text: In a stern pronouncement, Moody’s Investors Service this week warned of rising prospects for multiple defaults by countries in the euro zone and credit rating downgrades of nations across Europe if leaders should fail to resolve the spreading debt crisis.

headline: Don DeVito, Producer of Bob Dylan Albums, Dies at 72
text: Don DeVito, a longtime Columbia Records executive who produced albums for Bob Dylan and others, died on Friday in New York. He was 72.

headline: National Report Praises School-Choice System for New York City Students
text: New York has the most effective school-choice system of any of the nation’s largest school districts, allowing students and parents the most freedom and providing them with the most relevant information on educational performance, according to a new Brookings Institution report scheduled for publication online Wednesday.

headline: Germany’s Denial, Europe’s Disaster
text: Each day Europe inches closer to a full economic meltdown, but Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is still blocking what is needed: a real bailout of Europe’s weakest economies by their richer neighbors or the European Central Bank.

headline: An Intolerable Burden of Proof
text: The Supreme Court ruled in 2002 that it is unconstitutional to execute mentally retarded criminals, finding that the death penalty cannot be justified for these offenders because they are morally less culpable.

headline: Lockout Is to Be Partly Lifted
text: For the first time in 153 days, N.B.A. players will be allowed back in N.B.A. gyms when the league partly lifts the lockout on Thursday. The league sent a memo to all 30 teams on Tuesday informing them of the move.

headline: U.S. Motives in Myanmar Are on China’s Radar
text: BEIJING — When Myanmar’s military leader, Gen. Min Aung Hlaing, arrived here on Monday in a crisp tan uniform and a matching cap, he got a welcome from the very highest levels of the Chinese government.

headline: Some Thoughts for the Shopping Season
text: The big banks canceled plans for new debit card fees after their customers rebelled and members of Congress objected. But if Americans think their debit card problems are over, they’re wrong.

headline: Wednesday: Things Understood by Few
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I consider Wordplay to be an ongoing cocktail party of sorts, where everyone can come to discuss the puzzle, the words contained therein, and anything — within reason — that those words might evoke. It both humbles and inspires me to watch how you all check in with each other, help each other through the solving process, encourage newcomers, amuse us with stories, and even look out for one another on a personal level. Wordplay is a very special place, and I am happy to be a part of it.

headline: China: Dissident’s Wife Questioned
text: Lu Qing, the wife of the dissident artist Ai Weiwei, was questioned by the Beijing police for more than three hours on Tuesday afternoon, said an assistant who was with her. The officers asked Ms. Lu about her company, Beijing Fake Cultural Development Ltd.; personal details; and a housing project the company designed in Inner Mongolia several years ago. On a police form, Ms. Lu was listed as a suspect rather than a witness, the assistant said. She was told not to leave Beijing. Mr. Ai, a frequent critic of the Communist Party, was detained for 81 days this year and faces charges of tax evasion.

headline: When Apartment Rents Climb, Landlords Can Say ‘The Computer Did It’
text: The lease renewal notices that landlords send out annually have contained little good news for renters in recent years: Rents are up and vacancies down around the country. And having resigned themselves to paying more, renters may wonder whether the new number on their lease was plucked out of thin air.

headline: Group Predicts 28% Gain in Carmaking Jobs by 2015
text: DETROIT — Employment in the auto industry will return to prerecession levels by 2015, with carmakers and their suppliers adding about 167,000 jobs by then, according to estimates by an auto industry research firm.

headline: Suffolk’s Mean Streets
text: The police in Suffolk County, Long Island, are seeking a court injunction this week that would prohibit alleged gang members from hanging out with one another in a designated “safety zone” — in this case, the commercial center of Wyandanch, a predominantly black and Hispanic hamlet beset by poverty and crime.

headline: Key Witness Inconsistent During Trial of Official
text: One of the main government witnesses in the corruption trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook testified on Tuesday that she had consulted a doctor about her diminishing memory, then offered contradictory accounts on several important points in the case.

headline: Where Should That Lottery Check Go?
text: The three  investment managers who hit the Powerball jackpot may not need the money. What should they do with it?

headline: Support for Boeheim Is Followed by Win for Syracuse
text: SYRACUSE — Standing and flashing an occasional smile, Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim faced the television lights and the pointed questions.

headline: The Huntsman Handicap
text: “I don’t claim to be the perfect candidate,” Newt Gingrich told a South Carolina radio station last week, as he settled into his role as the latest not-Romney in the Republican race. “I just claim to be a lot more conservative than Mitt Romney and a lot more electable than anybody else.”

headline: Ups and Downs of the Cain Candidacy
text: Herman Cain has been losing his standing in the polls since claims of sexual harassment surfaced last month.

headline: Patrice O’Neal, Boisterous Comedian, Dies at 41
text: Patrice O’Neal, a stand-up comedian who boisterously took on controversial topics like race, AIDS and his own struggle with diabetes, died on Tuesday. He was 41 and lived in New Jersey.

headline: Rates of Increase in Subsidized Lunches
text: The proportion of fourth graders eligible for the federal government’s school meals program has increased nationwide since 2007.

headline: Democratic Voters Waver in Scranton
text: President Obama faces a replay of ‘08 hurdles in ‘Hillary Country,’ Pa.

headline: Qatar’s Capital Glitters Like a World City, but Few Feel at Home
text: DOHA, Qatar — Along a skyline that feels as ambitious as it is ephemeral, there is a building named for its design — the Tornado. The renowned architect I. M. Pei built a museum here in a quest for the essence of Islamic architecture. Another tower, built by another famous architect, is sheathed in an exoskeleton and suggests a Saracen helmet.

headline: Matthew P. Sapolin, Who Led Bloomberg’s Office for Disabled, Dies at 41
text: Matthew P. Sapolin, the Bloomberg administration’s disabilities commissioner, died of cancer on Tuesday. He was 41.

headline: Perry Gains Endorsement From an Arizona Sheriff Tough on Immigration
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Rick Perry is polling at only the single digits in New Hampshire, and the question on this Tuesday was: Can a hard-nosed Arizona sheriff who was sued by the Justice Department and is known for aggressive pursuit of illegal immigrants — and for making inmates wear pink underwear — help him gain traction six weeks before the primary?

headline: Rangers Hold Off Crosby and Penguins
text: All eyes were on Sidney Crosby at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, but the players to watch were Marian Gaborik and Brad Richards as the Rangers took a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins in a clash between clubs with the N.H.L.’s best percentage records.

headline: Highly Skilled May Wait Less for Visas
text: In a rare show of bipartisan comity on the angrily contested issue of immigration, the House of Representatives on Tuesday passed a bill that tweaks the visa system to allow more highly skilled immigrants from India and China to become legal permanent residents.

headline: Ex-President of Ivory Coast to Face Court in the Hague
text: PARIS — The former president of Ivory Coast, who took his country almost to the brink of civil war after losing an election last year, was unexpectedly handed over into international custody on Tuesday and was flown overnight to the Netherlands, where the prosecutor at the International Criminal Court in The Hague has accused him of crimes against humanity, Ivorian government officials said.

headline: Support for Tea Party Falls in Strongholds, Polls Show
text: Support for the Tea Party — and with it, the Republican Party — has fallen sharply even in places considered Tea Party strongholds, according to an analysis of new polls.

headline: Short Week and Tough Questions for Giants
text: During a typical week, the Giants begin practice on Wednesday around noon, after going through morning meetings where that week’s game plan is introduced by the coaches.

headline: Andrew M. Kramer, Leading Labor Lawyer, Dies at 67
text: Andrew M. Kramer, a lawyer who handled dozens of labor disputes for major corporations and helped old-line manufacturers figure out how to cope with crushing health care costs for retirees, died on Nov. 21 at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 67.

headline: Senate Approves Requiring Military Custody in Terror Cases
text: WASHINGTON — Defying the Obama administration’s threat of a veto, the Senate on Tuesday voted to increase the role of the military in imprisoning suspected members of Al Qaeda and its allies — including people arrested inside the United States.

headline: For Red Sox, Life Just Got Very Interesting
text: Nobody knows if Bobby Valentine, the new manager of the Boston Red Sox, will guide his team out of its third-place malaise. We might not know until the very end of the regular season. But the journey to get there will be fascinating.

headline: Massachusetts: Effort to Close Reactor Is Denied
text: A licensing panel at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has turned down the state’s effort to block renewal of the operating license of a reactor because of the Fukushima Daichi accident in Japan. The reactor, Pilgrim, resembles the reactors at Fukushima and is on the coast, at Plymouth, but in July the commission received a report from a task force that concluded that the Fukushima accident did not indicate any imminent risk to public health and safety from American reactors. Several states have tried unsuccessfully to block license extensions for reactors within their borders. Vermont could not stop re-licensing of a similar reactor, Vermont Yankee, owned by the same company as Pilgrim, Entergy, but the state is still trying to close it by denying a state permit.

headline: Path Tries Again With a Wider Network
text: Path, a photo mobile social network, began with great promise late last year.

headline: Private Dollars Revive a Solar Panel Plan for Military Housing
text: An ambitious project by a California company to install solar panels for more than 100,000 military housing units has been revived with private financing after it failed to receive a loan guarantee from the federal government.

headline: How Exercise Benefits the Brain
text: To learn more about how exercise affects the brain, scientists in Ireland recently asked a group of sedentary male college students to take part in a memory test followed by strenuous exercise.

headline: Word of the Day | hazardous
text: hazardous •\ˈha-zər-dəs\ • adjective

headline: NYT Front Page for 11/30/2011

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
text: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, whose government has frequently been criticized for paralysis on policy, has pledged not to reverse the decision to allow foreign direct investment in retail, which could see big-box stores like Walmart, Tesco and Carrefour set up shop in India (Economic Times).   “I am confident that foreign direct investment in retail will help to bring modern technology in the farm sector, less wastage and more jobs,” Mr. Singh said Wednesday.

headline: Massachusetts: State Takes Over Lawrence Schools
text: The state board of education voted Tuesday to take over the Lawrence Public School system, an embattled district where fewer than half of students graduate from high school in four years. It is the first district to be taken into receivership after a 2010 law empowered the state board of education to take such action on “chronically underperforming” schools. Mayor William Lantigua requested the state take the action, which comes as the district’s former superintendent prepares to face trial for fraud and embezzlement, and Mr. Lantigua himself navigates a series of recall efforts.

headline: The Adidas Samba Tees Off; and Soccer Shoes With a Chip
text: I have a confession to make: I’ve been an Adidas-head ever since my dad dug deep into his pocket and forked over $75 (at least that’s what I think it was) to buy me a pair of Tokyo track spikes when I was in high school about 100 years ago. They were the lightest, the coolest, the bluest shoes on an old cinder track. Did they make me faster? Not likely. But man, they sure looked good.

headline: Corrections: November 30
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Long Wait For Green Cards Could Soon End
text: The United States House of Representatives on Tuesday passed a bill that will allow more highly-skilled immigrants from India and China to become legal permanent residents in the United States, Julia Preston reports.

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 30, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Britons Strike Over Extended Austerity Measures
text: LONDON — Hundreds of thousands of public employees walked off their jobs in schools, hospitals, airports, courtrooms, libraries, museums and government offices on Wednesday, as British workers became the latest in Europe to demonstrate mass fury at government austerity measures.

headline: As Britain Closes Embassies, Iran’s Isolation Could Complicate Nuclear Issue
text: LONDON — With Britain’s decision to close its vandalized embassy in Tehran on Wednesday and expel all Iranian diplomats from London, Iran appears to have moved a major step closer to international pariah status. That isolation could complicate efforts by Western governments to halt what they have identified as Iran’s covert efforts to acquire nuclear weapons, according to diplomats and others who monitor Iranian affairs.

headline: Life in Limbo for Chin Refugees
text: Thirty-year-old Biathleng fled Myanmar’s Chin State for Delhi in June, with three children and a teenage wife. “I have an appointment for my refugee card,” he says carefully, when asked about his new life.

headline: Ex-President of Ivory Coast Arrives in the Hague to Face Charges
text: PARIS — The former president of Ivory Coast, who took his country to the brink of civil war after losing an election last year, was unexpectedly handed over into international custody and flown overnight to the Netherlands. In a statement on Wednesday after he arrived in the Hague, the International Criminal Court said Laurent Gbagbo “allegedly bears individual criminal responsibility” for four crimes against humanity: murder, rape, persecution and inhuman acts.

headline: North Korea Reports Progress on New Reactor
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea reported brisk progress in building a new nuclear reactor and producing enriched uranium on Wednesday. Although the statement appeared to invite international inspectors to verify that the facilities are for peaceful purposes, it was the latest sign that North Korea is pressing ahead with its nuclear program.

headline: Nov. 30, 1995 | President Clinton Visits Northern Ireland to Support Peace Process
text: On Nov. 30, 1995, President Bill Clinton became the first United States chief executive to visit Northern Ireland, touring the cities of Belfast and Derry to show support for the peace process.The New York Times reported, “The president has been more deeply involved than any of his predecessors in the intractable problems of this island, an involvement that caused him to cast aside the fears of other presidents that a trip here might fray relations with the British.”

headline: Building a Better Mitt Romney-Bot
text: “Your story about dust regulation captures my interest,” Mitt Romney said to the farmer, sounding as if he actually meant it. It was a late October afternoon in Treynor, Iowa, the setting for one of those campaign meta-events at which a presidential candidate enjoys a casual moment with real people that is in fact carefully staged and dutifully broadcast by multitudes of local and national reporters hovering a few feet away. In this instance, Romney was participating in a round-table discussion with a dozen local businessmen — his kind of folks — and exhibiting his teacher’s-pet flair for spewing out entrepreneurial minutiae.

headline: Turkey Moves to Intensify Sanctions Against Syria
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey took steps on Wednesday to freeze the Syrian government’s financial assets, impose a travel ban on senior Syrian officials and cut off transactions with the country’s central bank, sharply escalating international pressure on Damascus in response to its continuing violence against civilians.

headline: Why Not Rahul for U.P. Chief Minister?
text: If Uttar Pradesh were an independent country, it would be the world’s fifth most populous nation, just behind Indonesia and ahead of Brazil, a nation with 35 times U.P.’s land mass.

headline: Clash Between NATO and Pakistani Forces Defused
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A cross-border incident involving NATO and Pakistani forces was quickly defused early on Wednesday with no loss of life, according to Brig. Gen. Carsten Jacobson, the spokesman for the American-led international coalition here.

headline: Greeted Quietly, Clinton Arrives in Myanmar
text: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived here on Wednesday to measure the depth of the political and economic opening that the country’s autocratic, military-dominated government has unexpectedly begun.

headline: British Inquiry Is Told Hacking Is Worthy Tool

He confessed to lurking in unmarked vans outside people’s houses, stealing confidential documents, rifling through celebrity garbage cans and pretending that he was not a journalist pursuing a story but “Brad the teenage rent boy,” propositioning a priest.

headline: ‘Occupy’ Protesters Evicted in Two Cities
text: LOS ANGELES — The steel-mesh fence went up around the perimeter of City Hall Park here early Wednesday morning. Behind it, fields of dirt and brown grass were covered with the detritus of what had been one of the largest Occupy encampments in the country: tarps, tents, discarded bottles, coolers, protest signs, a torn-up dollar bill, a California driver’s license and a beat-up acoustic guitar.

headline: Bankers, Too, Cast a Safety Net

headline: Where You Can Give It Away, in Berlin
text: Last summer, Andreas Richter, a 28-year-old computer programmer who lives in Berlin, wanted to get rid of some stuff: clothes, DVDs, a set of drinking glasses. He didn’t want to throw out the items — still perfectly useful — but he also didn’t want to have to schedule pickups or use DHL for a couple of T-shirts. So instead, he got out his power tools and built a telephone-booth-sized structure that he called “Givebox” on his street in Mitte (Steinstrasse 37b). Since then, the project has taken on a more interactive aspect and has expanded to other locations and even other cities.

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Nov. 30
text: DealBook explains some of the thinking behind the report that Facebook (no relation) may be planning an initial public offering in the spring to raise $10 billion, with a company valuation of $100 billion. In short, Steven M. Davidoff, the Deal Professor, writes, Facebook “just has too many shareholders.” When a United States company has 500 or more shareholders of record it must soon begin filing reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including audited financial information. Facebook is likely to reach 500 in April 2012, he writes, and most companies conclude that “if they are going to be subject to much of the regulation that comes with being public, they might as well just go ahead with an I.P.O. and get the full benefits of being public.”

headline: On Our Radar: Mining Dispute in Peru
text: A  corporation halts work at the $4.8 billion Minas Conga gold operation in Peru after protests against mining that left at least 17 wounded. Farmers worry that the vast mining operation will exhaust water resources. [Bloomberg Businessweek]

headline: Inflation Fears Easing, China’s Central Bank Turns to Lifting Growth
text: HONG KONG — China’s central bank, in a surprise move on Wednesday, shifted its economic focus from fighting inflation to stimulating growth by freeing the nation’s commercial banks to lend more money.

headline: Crowding Concerns Raised Over Cobble Hill Charter School

headline: This Faust Builds Atom Bombs (He Still Sings)
text: It is best to put aside any knowledge you may have of Goethe when attending a performance of Gounod’s “Faust.” There is beautiful music — stirring ensembles and a few gotcha arias — in Gounod’s score. But this melodramatic opera is anything but philosophical.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Tips on Earning and Spending Points
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

text: “In Holland, we don’t know anything about the Iraqi people,” said the Dutch photographer Marieke van der Velden. “When we hear Iraqis are killed … if they have no face, then we feel no hurt.”

headline: Another ‘Special’ Day, Another Retail Dollar
text: It has become increasingly clear that the country’s best hope to climb out of its economic doldrums may be to keep coming up with snappy sales gimmicks attached to specific days of the week. That’s what now passes for a recovery plan. New York, with its many retailers, hardly stands apart from the trend.

headline: Daily Report: F.T.C. Settles With Facebook on Privacy Policies
text: The federal government on Tuesday accused Facebook of engaging in “unfair and deceptive” practices and announced a broad settlement that requires the company to respect the privacy wishes of its users and subjects it to regular privacy audits for the next 20 years, reports Somini Sengupta in the New York Times.

headline: 6 Central Banks Act to Buy Time in Europe Crisis
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve and other major central banks moved on Wednesday to help foreign banks more easily borrow and lend money, seeking to forestall a breakdown of global financial markets and giving Europe more time to wrestle with its debts. The latest round of interventions by central banks, including the expansion of an existing Fed program that lets foreign banks borrow dollars at a low interest rate, reflects growing concerns that Europe’s financial problems are hampering growth.

headline: Questions Of Confidence
text: Some readers have asked why, given my scornful discussions of the “confidence fairy” story about fiscal austerity (will that be my lasting contribution to economic discourse?), I’m willing to take seriously the idea that ECB rate hikes had a huge impact via expectations.

headline: New York Rated Tops in Nation for School Choice
text: A report by the Brookings Institution rates New York No. 1 in the nation when it comes to school choice, finding that it provided the most freedom to students and parents and the most relevant information on educational performance.

headline: That’s a (Re)Wrap
text: During the holidays there are essentially two types of people: those that relish in receiving and those who find greater joy in giving. The subjects of today’s story fall primarily in the latter category. They’re the people who make presents their most presentable by swapping traditional wrapping paper for more unconventional, economical and environmentally mindful materials. “Anything is better than a giant roll of unrecycleable metallic Santas,” says the Bodkin designer Eviana Hartman, who paints brown paper with pastel watercolors and uses once-trashed treasures, like sheets of architectural blueprint, when making the perfect parcel. But it isn’t all arts and crafts. “A really easy option is to give gifts in colorful, reusable tote bags, like Baggu,” Hartman says.

headline: Good Boy! Good Supporting Actor!
text: Here is an Oscar campaign the Bagger can support thoroughly, even without the ministrations of highly paid consultants, glossy ads or red carpet hijinks (although we would take a funny YouTube reel). The fine folks over at Movieline have started an awards push for Uggie, the exquisitely emotive pup in “The Artist.”

headline: Christmas, Plain and Fancy
text: If you drive through the typical suburban tract in December, the houses seem grouped in two categories: There are the homes vigorously festooned in blinking multicolor, with life-size Santas and 3-D nativity scenes rendered in glowing plastic. And there are the others, their tended lawns unmarred by seasonal gnomes and Rudolph paraphernalia, with perhaps a single tree draped in tasteful white lights.

headline: HBO Says Time is Right for Ricky Gervais’s ‘Life’s Too Short’
text: When Ricky Gervais completes his third go-round in January as host of the Golden Globe Awards (and the monthlong non-apology tour that will surely follow), he won’t immediately go into hiding: he’ll be back on HBO the next month with his new comedy series, “Life’s Too Short,” which will make its debut on Feb. 19, the cable channel said.

headline: Iraq Would Accept U.S. Soldiers as Trainers
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s prime minister signaled Wednesday that he was open to the eventual return of American troops as trainers, underscoring the reality that the United States is likely to be involved in this country’s security even after the last soldiers depart in the coming weeks.

headline: The 10 Best Books of 2011
text: Choosing our 10 Best Books of the Year was not an arbitrary process, but neither was it a scientific one. How could it be, when the editors here, like all readers, respond subjectively to any work of fiction or nonfiction? The one guideline for the 10 was that they had to have been reviewed in our pages sometime in the past 12 months.

headline: The 10 Best Books of 2011
text: In 2004, the Book Review, which had previously offered a selection of the year’s Notable Books and Best Books, began limiting the number of Notables to 100 and the Best Books to 10. Choosing 100 is hard enough. Whittling that number to 10 is even harder, though the process is always interesting. And as is so often the case with lists, the numbers contain subsets that are interesting in themselves, suggesting coincidences, trends and patterns within.

headline: Olivier’s Twist
text: Since Olivier Theyskens exudes an edgy romanticism with his poetic long hair, he has always seemed like a Belgian goth. At the end of the last century, when he was a 21-year-old prodigy, he made clothes with a hint of darkness and dressed Madonna in a long frock coat for the 1998 Academy Awards.

headline: Time Warner Picks New Head for Time Inc. Magazine Unit
text: 7:34 a.m. | Updated As Time Warner searched for a top executive to run its sprawling magazine unit, it did not look just outside the company. It looked outside the publishing industry.

headline: In Praise of Grover Norquist
text: I debated the Americans for Tax Reform impresario at the American Enterprise Institute last night (I’ll link to the transcript whenever it becomes available), and since I spent the evening arguing that his Taxpayer Protection Pledge has failed to actually protect taxpayers I thought I’d say something nice about him this space. Like any good activist, Norquist is a monomaniac about his issue: Everything in American politics revolves around taxes, all good things flow from tax cuts, no deal that increases taxes can ever benefit America, etc. etc. As I said at AEI, I think this view is mistaken, and that focusing obsessively on tax rates has proven to be an insufficient and even counterproductive strategy for actually limiting the size and scope of government. (Steven Hayward elaborates a bit on this argument in his recent essay on conservatism’s intellectual blind spots.) And worse, because taxpayers are liable for tomorrow’s debts as well as today’s tax rates, even the pledge’s present success at keeping rates relatively low may look like a pyrrhic victory in the long run.

headline: The Kindle Fire: Clunky but Content-Rich
text: As gadget reviewers have pointed out, the newly released Amazon Kindle Fire is clunky and slow — in keeping with Amazon’s sense of style. But it seems it is being purchased in droves by consumers and is poised to become the second-most-popular tablet in the United States, after Apple’s iPad.

headline: Banks Act, Stocks Surge and Skeptics See a Pattern
text: A move announced by central bankers on Wednesday to contain the European debt crisis resulted in euphoria in global stock markets, but it also prompted skeptics to wonder: will this time be different?

headline: Oscar Controversy, in Many Languages
text: Many of the 63 films submitted in the competition for the 2012 Academy Award for best foreign-language film have not yet even begun a commercial run in an American theater, and some never will. But since its introduction in 1947, the category of best foreign-language film is one that has always been marked by controversy, intrigue and speculation, and this year’s contest is already proving to be no exception.

headline: For Small Fishermen, a Fairness Issue
text: In an article in Monday’s paper about an experiment off the central California coast, I mentioned a program introduced by the Pacific Fisheries Management Council to combat overfishing. Known as catch share, the program allocates quotas of overfished species to various vessels.

text: I’m trying to teach my 13-year-old son, Nathaniel, to be polite. In a Facebook and Evite world, this is no easy thing.

headline: For Coaches, It’s Hiring (and Firing) Season
text: As Jack Del Rio can now unhappily confirm, we are well into the heart of coach-firing season. It’s a curious time of year, when most people are festively preparing for the holidays or the playoffs or bashing the Bowl Championship Series like a piñata, coaches are entering their real estate agents into speed dial and packing up the family photos.

headline: Fracking Forum Moves to New York City
text: Hearings on the controversial natural gas drilling process known as hydraulic fracturing move today to New York City, a locus of opposition to the state’s plans to approve the practice.

headline: Now Playing | Madewell’s ‘Choose Your Own Adventure’ Video
text: Tea or coffee? Geek chic or glam adventurer? Sparkle or confetti? These are just some of the choices you get to make when playing Madewell’s fun new fashion adventure video. Choose tea with the model Dree Hemingway and watch her swap a yarny sweater and glasses for a.) a white shirt and coral pencil skirt, or b.) denim shirt, sequined skirt and trapper hat. Opt for coffee with the stylist Marina Muñoz and help her dance her way out of pajamas into either a.) a strapless dress and peony-purple sweater, or b.) minty pants, plaid shirt and boyfriend blazer. You have five seconds to pick accessories, dress code and party decorations from there. “What makes the video so amazing is that you control it,” says Madewell’s head of design, Kin Ying Lee. “You choose every direction the video takes — from what pieces she wears to which party she goes to — the options are endless. It’s completely addicting.” Featuring user-directed technology developed by the interactive multimedia company Interlude, and directed by Nagi Sakai with music written and performed by Katie Herzig, the video makes its world premiere here on The Moment. Press play to play!

headline: The Other New Zealand Muppet Movie Connection
text: As awesome as are the Muppets, there is a hilariously offensive film which is the muppet’s exact reverse, and, coincidentally, also linked to the New Zealand/Peter Jackson/Muppet connection that Adam Sternbergh wrote about for the magazine. As I began researching his article, I was reminded of the most fantastically warped Muppet-style movie ever made: “Meet the Feebles,” Peter Jackson’s second full-length feature — a film that surely must lurk somewhere in the mind of every New Zealander about the age of Bret McKenzie.

headline: When Flavor Meets Virtue
text: Feeling a little like a cleanse, or perhaps just something a tad less heavy after all that holiday fare? Me too. Still, we all want something good for dinner, and I never really want to sacrifice flavor for virtue.This week’s City Kitchen features an easy fish dish with sesame and ginger, designed with both health and pleasure in mind. Sesame, often used in nearly every cuisine, is considered quite healthful. It is rich in antioxidants, vitamins and minerals. Ginger, too, can make this claim, as well as other countless health-giving qualities. Thankfully, they taste good too, providing lots of flavor, especially for light, low-fat dishes. It’s win-win.

headline: American Won’t Be the Last Airline Bankruptcy

headline: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers

Use the comment field below to ask your questions, and the answers will appear on The Fifth Down on Friday.

headline: Should Owners Have to Bet the House?
text: An article we’ve just published focuses on how common it is for small-business owners to tap their home equity to start, expand and maintain their businesses.

headline: Other Voices: Life on Planet 3.0
text: Michael Tobis, a climate scientist and software engineer long at the University of Texas Institute for Geophysics, describes himself as a “sustainability nerd, neo-Texan, Internet addict.”

headline: Why Gingrich May Be the Last Anti-Romney Standing
text: It’s natural to look at the latest Republican polls, five weeks from the Iowa caucuses, and marvel at the weirdness of it all. In a party well stocked with successful governors and ambitious senators, how can it be that the guy leading the field at this late date is Newt Gingrich? Could the last man standing against Mitt Romney really turn out to be a washed-up politician who has never been elected to anything outside a single Congressional district, and who managed to pull off the most calamitous campaign rollout since New Coke?

headline: A Brooke Astor Auction Planned by Sotheby’s
text: For decades Brooke Astor was a tireless supporter of a variety of causes and institutions including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Pierpont Morgan Library (now the Morgan Library & Museum), the Animal Medical Center of New York and the New York Public Library. So before she died in 2007, at 105, she selected a number of charitable organizations to benefit from her estate.

headline: A Contract to Stop Driving
text: The continuing battles over car keys — including how long older drivers can safely operate automobiles, under what conditions, when it’s time to stop and who gets to decide — have come up many times here. It’s one of the toughest issues families confront.

headline: Airlines Cut Back, Hotels Step In
text: YOU don’t have to fly first-class to get V.I.P. treatment at the airport — if you stay at the right hotel. As more and more guests show up harried after airline delays, baggage issues and other travel hassles, hotels are stepping in with new services designed to make the airport experience less stressful. From wardrobe storage to airport concierges, here’s a rundown of some of the options being offered.

headline: Vain Glorious | Tenoverten’s New Nail Polish
text: Nadine Ferber and Adair Ilyinsky, the co-owners of Tenoverten, the stylish TriBeCa nail salon, were inspired by client feedback when concocting the formula for their new polish collection, and since their client list is filled with fashion-world heavies who know their Peridot from their Bordeaux, the partners couldn’t have asked for a better focus group. “People love certain aspects of different polishes,” Ferber says, pointing out that some of her customers choose Essie because it lasts the longest, while others rave about Chanel’s color choices. “It became about how to meld the best of everything into one product,” Ilyinsky says. After months of research in the field, the duo nailed their first six shades, which are named after streets in downtown Manhattan. A bright blue polish called “Commerce” was inspired by the West Village street where Ferber’s clothing boutique, Mick Margo, is located. “Church” is a burnt red alternative to Wicked (a popular Essie shade), and Reade, a metallic charcoal, was named for the salon’s home base. With its five-free formula (no formaldehyde resin, camphor, formaldehyde, toluene or dibutyl phthalate) and easy-to-hold brush (the salon’s technicians work from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m., so a little attention to ergonomic detail was in order), this new polish deserves a big hand.

headline: Palestinians to Receive Payments, Israel Says
text: JERUSALEM — Israel agreed on Wednesday to transfer to the Palestinian Authority about $100 million in tax and customs payments that it has withheld for four weeks in protest over the Palestinians’ membership efforts at the United Nations and pursuit of power-sharing with Hamas.

headline: The Not-Romneys
text: David Brooks: Gail, which was your favorite not-Romney boomlet? Did you like the Bachmann Spring, the Cain Supernova, the Trump Tornado or the Gingrich Comet?

headline: In Gingrich’s Words, Promoting His Clients
text: The St. Petersburg Times has tracked down audio from the “health transformation summit’’ at the Florida State Capitol that Newt Gingrich and his for-profit Center for Health Transformation held in 2006, and which The New York Times wrote about today. At the event he promoted some of his private clients – paying members of the center — to state lawmakers.

headline: Why Miami Shouldn’t Abandon Mike Miller
text: The pressure for a team like the Miami Heat to improve is never-ending, as dominance will only bring calls for more dominance, and victories will be met with demands for more victories. It’s only natural, after all, that much would be expected of a team with such potential. But those expectations fly in the face of one important fact: the avenues of improvement for Miami are closing off rather quickly.

text: 10:54 p.m. | Updated  The full report of this article is available here.

headline: Changes in the Lunch Line for Some Schools
text: As more students across the country are signing up for free or reduced lunches because of the ailing economy, in New York City, principals are trying to collect lunch money from those students who are not eligible for free lunch, but whose meals were being picked up by the city in past years. Here is how it is affecting students at Edward R. Murrow High School, as reported by the The Murrow Network, the student newspaper.

headline: Commuters, Your Despair Is Restored
text: It might take the Metropolitan Transportation Authority months to fix a broken escalator, but mess with the World’s Most Depressing Subway Poem and the agency will spring to action in a jiffy.

headline: From Bathroom Basic to Fashion Accessory
text: A few years ago, a heart-shaped USB flash drive that was covered in black Swarovski crystals was atop my holiday wish list. The drive was only one gigabyte (I need at least four), but who cared? The appeal was turning something mundane like a memory device into a fashion accessory.

headline: Political Standoff Escalates in South Ossetia Over Vote

headline: Mitt Romney Talks About Himself, Not Obama, in New Ad
text: Mitt Romney’s campaign released its second television ad on Wednesday, a spot that is notable for having what the former Massachusetts governor’s last ad did not: a positive message.

headline: Scandal at Finmeccanica Revives Questions in Italy
text: ROME — For weeks now, the influential chairman of Finmeccanica, the state-backed Italian military equipment group, has been resisting calls to resign, even as the company sinks ever deeper into a widening kickbacks scandal and posts disappointing returns.

headline: President Obama: Veto the Defense Authorization Act
text: When President Obama came into office in 2009 he promised to shut down the Guantanamo Bay detention camp and end the extra-judicial system that his predecessor had created to imprison terrorist suspects without trial, often without even filing charges. He has broken that promise.

headline: As Economy Lags, Cuomo Reconsiders Tax Stance
text: Faced with a worsening financial climate, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Wednesday that he was contemplating whether to propose changes to the state tax code, and he did not rule out the possibility that he would seek to raise taxes on wealthy New Yorkers.

text: November 30, 2011 - While Secretary of State Clinton assesses Myanmar's steps toward democracy, our reporter takes to the streets of the country where most foreign journalists have been barred.

headline: Artifacts | The Activist Inside Us
text: The first World AIDS Day, in 1989, was called “A Day Without Art.” Museums and galleries closed or hung black streamers in place of significant artworks, or hosted memorials for the thousands whom the H.I.V. virus had already killed. Initiated by Visual AIDS, a support group, what was to be a national day of mourning actually signaled the start of the ‘90s culture wars.

headline: Congressman Presses California on Fuel-Economy Standards
text: Suspecting that California regulators may be exerting unlawful influence over the agencies that determine federal fuel-economy standards, Representative Darrell Issa has begun an inquiry into the practices of the California Air Resources Board, or CARB, the agency charged with setting pollution standards for the state.

headline: The Failed Potential of the Progress Reports
text: When the city first began issuing progress reports, they had the potential to spur innovation and the sharing of best practices that would improve all schools. Instead, a principal writes, they have sparked competition and confusion. And they are fundamentally flawed.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 75
text: Protesters gathered in Madison Square Park to meet arriving delegates from the aerospace and defense industries to a conference hosted in part by Credit Suisse bank. A rally to protest “war profiteers” is planned for 4:30 p.m. in the park. [NBC New York]

headline: Soviets Invade Finland, in Real Time
text: RealTimeWWII, the World War II Twitter feed we profiled this week that has attracted some 155,000 followers, began on Aug. 31 with Adolf Hitler’s 1939 invasion of Poland, in violation of Germany’s non-aggression pact with the Soviet Union. Now, it’s the Soviets’ turn to show what-for. After days of rumblings, the Red Army has invaded Finland.

headline: Playwright Criticizes Casting in Hartford for ‘The ____________ With the Hat’
text: 6:03 p.m. | Updated In a rare attack by a playwright on a professional production of his own work, Stephen Adly Guirgis took to Facebook on Wednesday to assail the casting of two white actors as the Puerto Rican lead characters in the Hartford regional production of his play “The ____________ With the Hat,” which was a Tony Award nominee for best play. The Hispanic Organization of Latin Actors has also complained to the theater, TheaterWorks, noting that the production had casting calls in New York City, a training ground for many Hispanic actors.

By comparison, Pandora is more “lean back”: you just press play and let it go.

headline: No Greater Role Than His Own

Outside, in the wide hallway, a line of languid models waited by an agency next door. One was changing from flats to hellishly high heels. Many stared into space.

headline: Newt Again, and Again
text: I first wrote about Newt Gingrich in this cover piece for the magazine back in 2009, just after President Obama took office. There are few more confounding figures you can write about in politics and perhaps none who elicit such strong responses from our readers. Here’s my latest column over on the Caucus blog, about why it is that Gingrich (everyone calls him Newt, really) has managed to outlast his better-equipped rivals.

headline: On Lens: An Intimate Portrait of Baghdad Today
text: Our colleagues over at the Lens blog have a great post today on a side of Baghdad that you don’t normally see: its personal side, shown through sometimes quiet, sometimes playful, sometimes somber pictures of the normal lives of everyday Iraqis. Marieke van der Velden, a Dutch photographer, collected the images as part of “Baghdad Today,” a project that she undertook in August of this year. Michael Kamber writes: “Ms. van der Velden’s recent photographs of daily life — not death — in Baghdad make you feel…“Baghdad Today,” forms one of the most intimate portraits of Iraqi life to emerge since the 2003 American invasion.

headline: 2 Governors Asking U.S. to Ease Rules on Marijuana to Allow for Its Medical Use
text: The governors of Washington and Rhode Island petitioned the federal government on Wednesday to reclassify marijuana as a drug with accepted medical uses, saying the change is needed so states like theirs, which have decriminalized marijuana for medical purposes, can regulate the safe distribution of the drug without risking federal prosecution.

headline: Secret Santa in the Senate
text: Let’s leave aside those questions of naughty and nice. Scores of senators this year are feeling festive, and plan to exchange gifts, Secret Santa style, across party lines.

headline: Notes From the Underground | A Place to Bury Strangers
text: A wall of sound does not even begin to describe the effect on the ears when the New York band A Place to Bury Strangers performs. From the pulsing floor, through your toes, and up your spinal column, everything in your body starts to tremble. By the time you remember to stuff some tissues your ears, your mind is already reeling from the cocktail of endless guitar rumble, thundering drums and hysterical visuals. If you are into this kind of experience, which I happen to be, A Place to Bury Strangers, fronted by Oliver Ackerman and backed by Dion Lunadon and Gavin Haag on bass and drums respectively, is a must-see. More than just a shock to the system, the trio’s music is completely solid.

headline: The Life Report: Wayne McWilliams
text: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

headline: Crunching the Numbers: Exploring the Math of the Debt Crisis
text: Overview | What consequences do countries face by being in debt? What obstacles do they face trying to get out? In this lesson, students investigate the mathematics of being in debt by exploring and analyzing debt-crisis data. Through collecting and crunching economic information, calculating debt-repayment, and exploring the concept of financial risk, students apply quantitative skills that will help them better understand the crisis of being in debt, abroad or at home.

headline: A Thermostat That’s Clever, Not Clunky

headline: Alaska, Texas and the Wide Sky Between
text: Photo lovers within driving distance of Buffalo, will be well rewarded by a visit to the Albright-Knox Art Gallery this fall to catch Victoria Sambunaris’s solo exhibition, “Taxonomy of a Landscape.” Sambunaris is a New York-based photographer who has been trekking across the U.S. for a decade. More than 30 images from her travels make up her first show to appear in a major U.S. museum. The examples above hardly do justice to their scope and exquisite detail. Which is why you should see the huge prints — some measure as large as 55-by-77 inches — in person.

headline: Reindeer, Crime and Underwear Pay for CBS
text: The 1-2-3 scheduling punch of “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer,” “NCIS” and the “Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show,” while perplexing, proved to be a knockout for CBS on Tuesday night as the network finished No. 1 in total viewership and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. “Rudolph” at 8 p.m. brought in 12.7 million viewers while a repeat of “NCIS” at 9 p.m. drew 13.4 million. At 10 the “Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show” enjoyed its highest 18-to-49 rating ever, up 35 percent compared to last year and its largest total audience since 2002, at 10.3 million viewers.

headline: Undaunted by a Great Canvas, Filling It With Spectacle

He’s the man who helped synchronize 16,000 performers in the Bird’s Nest stadium in Beijing for the opening ceremonies of the 2008 Olympics. And on Tuesday he took full advantage of the hall’s expanse with a mere 32 dancers. Scale is not his problem.

headline: On Belonging to Western Civilization
text: A day when America’s Federal Reserve has apparently decided to play John J. Pershing to the latest European crisis seems like as good a time as any to talk about that old warhorse, Western civilization — and particularly the debates kicked up by “Civilization: The West and the Rest,” Niall Ferguson’s latest tome. Though perhaps “debates” is too high-minded a word, since the most prominent argument has featured Pankaj Mishra accusing Ferguson (in a vituperous London Review of Books review) of being a neo-imperialist, “white’s man burden”-toting Euro-chauvinist, followed by Ferguson threatening to sue Mishra for libel. But I did think this comment from Brad DeLong raised some interesting issues. He’s objecting to the idea, raised by Ferguson’s book and emphasized by Donald Kagan’s Times review, that European colonialists did good as well as evil, and that the Western imperialist project has to be credited with positive legacies as well as with grave crimes. Here’s Delong’s retort:
